personal_statement:
Tuesday mornings were the highlight of my week at the UCLA AIDS Institute. With a cup of coffee in one hand and my notebook in the other, I was always ready to absorb the discussions that clinicians and scientists held on the advancements of novel therapies for HIV/AIDS during our weekly institute-wide seminars. As clinicians debated the merits of treatments such as HAART and CAR-T, they drew from their experiences in treating patients and their concern for them. Working towards a career in medicine but new to translational research, I found myself reflecting on what it meant to bridge the gap between science and medicine and felt my aspirations for becoming a physician fully crystallize.
 
I was initially drawn to studying HIV because I had seen firsthand how destructive a virus could be. When I was a pre-teen, my dad fell acutely ill from his hepatitis B (HBV) infection, which was endemic to his native country of South Korea. I will always remember how my mom choked back her emotions to explain to me why Appa was in the hospital. Having met someone who had lost her dad to HBV just a year prior, I instinctively braced for the worst and felt my youthful light-heartedness dissipate as I trudged into a premature adulthood. It hurt to learn that if the HBV vaccine had been developed earlier, it might have prevented my dad’s infection. My dad’s doctors were eventually able to control the virus and prescribed a drug that had newly been approved for HBV. Unfortunately, the pill caused harsh side effects in my dad and it would be years until a more tolerable alternative became available. From watching my dad become a fraction of the person he had been before his illness, I learned how critical the prevention of an illness was and how existing treatments had their drawbacks and limits.
 
I entered UCLA determined to learn about the preventative care that could be so pivotal to a person’s life. First as a member, eventually as club president, I volunteered in a community outreach club and served at local health fairs throughout Los Angeles. I joined health professionals to care for patients, many of whom had limited access to medical attention beyond these fairs, and measured blood pressures, explained what to expect during a mammogram and comforted anxious patients as they had their blood drawn. While talking to patients, I often found myself using the same reassuring voice and approachable body language I saw in the physicians working alongside me. At one event, I met a woman and her daughter at the flu vaccine booth and we communicated through a mix of broken English and Spanish. As I explained why annual flu vaccines were beneficial for both her and the community, I noticed that despite nodding along, she was turning away. Recognizing parallels in our immigrant backgrounds and how multigenerational households are more common in these demographics, I asked if they happened to live with any grandparents to which they answered “yes”. Because the elderly are more susceptible to serious illness from the flu, it was safer if everyone in a household were immunized. Instantly, the vaccine that the woman seemed ambivalent towards became her imperative. A potentially lifesaving vaccine was readily available to this family, but if it were not for my cultural sensitivity and respectful persuasion, it might as well not have existed. I decided then that as a physician, one of my highest responsibilities would be to treat patients with an understanding of their backgrounds and unique circumstances.
 
At the fairs, I also met patients who had fallen through the imperfect safety net of preventive health and who, like my dad, were inflicted with the slow burn of an incurable or chronic condition. Even with treatment, some of these conditions could progressively worsen. At the time, I had come to accept this as an unfortunate fact. It was when, at the Institute, I met the physicians who tackled HIV/AIDS at both the bench and bedside that I saw how I would be able to help change this notion. As a physician, I would directly treat patients while simultaneously advancing treatments through research to broaden the possibilities of care for those left with few options. 
 
Today, I conduct translational research at UCLA where I discover and validate novel cancer treatments with the same passion as when I first felt the thrill of being at the frontiers of medicine. The cancer cells I examine under the microscope daily are my domain, and each incremental discovery I make builds a case for the capabilities of modern medicine. I am driven by the clarity with which I can envision myself comforting patients and their families as I combat their cancer cells with an arsenal of clinical knowledge. While my journey towards a medical education has been a long and nontraditional one, the additional courses I took and excelled at through UCLA Extension and the diverse clinical and research experiences I gained have enriched my perspective and equipped me with the skillsets that I will need in my chosen field. As I take the next step towards my medical career, memories of my own family’s experiences and the stories of the patients I’ve had the privilege of meeting over the years keep me committed to my path forward with unwavering conviction.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: My previous trip to Tokyo had been a success, but I felt uneasy when I arrived to Kyushu- an island of Japan, and noticed that the street signs were solely in Japanese. Whereas Tokyo was accessible in various international languages including English, in Kyushu I was not able to make either heads or tails of the street signs in front of me. Supremely lost, I relied on the kindness of strangers and communicated through hand gestures and Google Translate to find and reach my destinations. During my humbling adventure, after which I decided to learn more about any region before traveling there, I learned to approach people in an entirely new environment with whom I did not share a common language. This taught me to let go of all assumptions and to remain mindful of how diverse our lived experiences and world views often could be. As a physician, I will treat my patients with utmost respect and treat them as unique individuals who will have been shaped by their different life experiences.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
I grew up feeling fortunate to have lived in a community as multicultural and welcoming as that of Los Angeles (LA). Ready to give back while at UCLA, I co-founded the Mentoring and Health Education Program (MHEP). _x000D_
_x000D_
MHEP, a weekly program that connected UCLA mentors with kids K-12 from the LA area, focused on pairing students with mentors with whom they could relate to. We encouraged group discussions on topics such as practicing effective communication and gave students a healthy outlet to discuss the nuances of coming from different cultures and family dynamics. Additionally, we empowered our students to make healthy life choices such as by teaching them about the importance of eating fiber and starting each class with a group meditation. By utilizing my familiarity with the local community and providing members with the resources that I knew would benefit them, I positively impacted my LA community. _x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact: I was not largely affected by the pandemic. During most of 2020 however, I was not able to work in the lab and therefore do not have as many publications as I had hoped for.

Hrdshp_Comments: My Mexican mother and my Puerto Rican father were the only members of their respective families to move to the United States. As first-generation immigrants, my parents grew a family with barely any social or financial capital. My family relied upon food stamps to survive despite my parents working constantly. As a parentified child, I spent most of my time cooking, cleaning, and raising my siblings. When I was old enough to work, I had a job to help the family instead of focusing on school or social life. When my parents were home, there was often conflict resulting in verbal and physical abuse. My father was especially emotionally elusive and financially impulsive, contributing to our financial demise. When I left for college, my mom struggled to manage the household unaided, and I would return home on weekends to help, disregarding my needs. Introspecting my childhood, I can emphasize how it has shaped me into the resilient, caring, and creative problem solver I am. These experiences allowed me to develop expansive empathy. I comprehend how it feels to be mistreated, and I aspire for the opportunity to make my future patients feel protected and heard in their most vulnerable moments.
personal_statement:
During the 2006 FIFA World Cup, my family observed Leo slowly stop yelling “GOLAZO!”. Subsequently, he started jumping and flapping when he was happy or excited. Leo’s developmental regression and repetitive behaviors at two years old were the first warning signs. Since the closest developmental pediatrician had a two-year waiting list, we searched for another who was two hours away but only had a 6-month waiting list. The longer the waitlist to see a developmental pediatrician – the more time Leo would go without preventative therapies. When Leo finally received his diagnosis of Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD), I could see my father distancing himself as I witnessed how my mother solely carried the burden of having a child with additional needs. During the emotional whirlwind, my parents faced the tribulation of navigating the American healthcare system as Spanish speakers. I could sense my parents’ struggle due to their lack of social support and financial resources. I wanted to lift my parents’ burden while providing agency for my younger brother, who was eight years old and non-verbal. I was determined to find a way to help my younger brother, Leonardo, communicate. Over my two semesters of American Sign Language (ASL), I was able to teach Leo many simple signs such as “please,” “thank you,” “more,” “help,” and “I love you .” To our amazement, ASL bridged the gap in verbal communication. By the end of the year, Leo would not stop asking, “More Cheerios, please!”. This experience, coupled with years of learning how to care for Leo’s unique needs, drives my passion for pursuing a career as a developmental pediatrician. 

When pursuing a career in medicine, I seek to amplify access to healthcare for underserved, minority communities. My parents needed a professional who spoke Spanish, comprehended their culturally-informed perspectives on ASD, and could effectively communicate medical knowledge using a culturally humble approach. Nevertheless, their difficulties stem from systemic inequity that demands a global overhaul across the healthcare system. I contributed to this significant issue by practicing Medical English with Cuban doctors who recently immigrated to the United States. I spent two hours a week for a year building an English medical-specific vocabulary with them as they studied to pass the Step1 exam. Despite their credentials, it disheartened me that language was a high barrier for them to practice in this country where there are Spanish-speaking communities. Moving forward into medical school, I strive to use my Spanish speaking skills and Latinx identity to traverse language and cultural gaps between the medical system and minorities. 

As a queer, non-binary Latinx, I value understanding intersectionality and individuals through their multiple identities. Every Wednesday afternoon, I spent time with 12-year-old Areli – a young Latinx with a single working mother, a recent diagnosis of ASD, and a fierce mistrust towards doctors. Areli can speak English, but with me, she chose to talk in Spanish out of comfort. We worked through math homework, chatted about her crushes, and explored the Mutter Museum. On the brink of puberty, Areli often asked me questions about her changing body, menstruation, sex, gender, and even her attraction toward other girls. Areli showed me how language, cultural humility, and vulnerability could serve us when trying to bridge the most distrustful gaps. In building rapport with Areli, I developed a relationship that allowed me to offer her a new perspective on how seeking medical advice can be safe.

Finally, my passion for medicine comes from a desire to improve the accessibility of research for underserved minority populations. The barriers for minorities in research became more evident as I made my way through posters and presentations at the International Society for Autism Research (INSAR) Annual Meeting in 2018 and 2019. During the conferences, I would my time perusing the demographics of others’ experiments, where I frequently found myself disappointed in the lack of diversity in research. However, as a Clinical Research Assistant at the Center for Autism Research (CAR), I have been able to make an impact on ASD research perceptions in the Latinx community. Telemundo 62 reached out to CAR looking for a Spanish speaker to present our research for their Enfoque segment. I was the only person at my workplace who spoke Spanish. Though apprehensive, I knew this would be an opportunity to make ASD and research a more approachable topic for the Latinx community. 

A career in medicine would allow me to help others, use critical problem-solving, and do what I do best—connect with those who are often misunderstood and neglected. The compassion I gained while raising Leo compelled me to seek experiences that have given me the confidence to become a physician. Mentoring Areli, tutoring Cuban doctors, and working at CAR have reinforced my commitment to becoming a bilingual developmental pediatrician. I intend to plunge headfirst into the medical field, lead by example, and show others how to deliver culturally sensitive care. Ultimately, I hope not just to become a doctor but an advocate and change-maker working towards a more equitable medical system.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As a queer Latinx, I am no stranger to how identities lead to stereotypes and discrimination. As an undergraduate student at F&M, I minored in Women, Gender, and Sexuality Studies. I learned the roots of discrimination and oppression during those classes. Having an academic framework allows me to internalize no longer the racist, sexist, homophobic actions of others. I learned even more from commiserating with others that had similar experiences. My education and experiences compel me to advocate for those that do not have the platform to help themselves. I appreciate how Rush Medical shares the value of using its resources to provide widespread care to the niches of society. I am especially interested in the Rush Community Service Initiatives Program, which serves low-income and displaced populations, to the Correctional Health Initiative. I cannot wait to use my cultural humility to get involved in helping the diverse community on the West Side of Chicago.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I want to harness my language abilities, empathy, and interpersonal skills to heal the wounds medical racism has left on people of color. While working at the Center for Autism Research, Telemundo 62  approached me with an opportunity to demonstrate our research for a segment called "Enfoque: Trastornos del espectro autista." This opportunity perfectly reflected the kind of work I wanted to do. I want to use my Spanish and cultural competency to bridge the gap between the medical field and underserved communities. I am interested in beginning my medical education in Chicago because knowing I can serve primarily people publicly insured, people of color, immigrants, and low-income makes me excited. I look forward to continuing to hone my language abilities at SOAR meetings, Medical Spanish elective, or volunteering at the Mexican Consulate Health Organization. I am especially keen on the study abroad options via the RISE program in Villa Verde, Dominican Republic.
7_-_COVID_Impact: When the COVID-19 pandemic began, I was concerned for the health of my parents and my younger brother because they all have preexisting conditions. As a family, we had many conversations about planning what would happen if our parents passed away, mainly because my younger brother has high-needs autism and cannot live independently. In August 2020, I moved to California to get a fresh start and apply to post-baccalaureate programs. I recognize that the COVID 19 Pandemic was and continues to be detrimental to many people and communities. Furthermore, the hardships I faced during the pandemic do not compare to the heartbreak many endured. The pandemic further highlighted the inequities and gaps in medicine. These gaps compelled me to pursue medicine to use my Spanish and cultural competency to help bridge the divide.

Hrdshp_Comments: I was born and raised in northern Chicago, an area experiencing a massive Latinx population boom at the time. Both of my parents were Mexican immigrants who moved to the U.S. in pursuit of a better life. My father never graduated high school and had to work overtime to keep us afloat. Spanish is my first language. I had to learn English with little to no help from my parents since they could not speak it. Thus, in grade school I became the main translator for my family. Navigating online resources was hard because I didn't have internet in my house until high school. It was hard to find Hispanic mentors who worked in medicine. To the point of people telling me “Mexicans don’t become doctors here”. I have worked full time while going to college full time. This and the anxiety about paying back a six digit value in student loans contributed to the downward trend in my grades my final two years. Every experience has been a lesson. By overcoming the challenges I faced, I learned that my failures are not indicative of who I am. I have developed the strength and tenacity needed to overcome problems with limited resources. But I have also learned the power of compassion and how to reach out to others. I'm grateful for what I learned throughout my journey, for it has contributed to my unique perspective on life.
personal_statement:
Going to see a doctor was an ordeal for my family. We were on Medicaid and there were a select few clinics who accepted this insurance. My mother could not afford a babysitter, so when one of us needed to go to the doctor all three children went to the doctor. My mother would hold onto my brother with one hand, hold me with the other, and carry the baby in a baby carrier strapped to her chest. My mother spoke very little English, so many things were lost in translation with the pediatricians. I tried to help with the English that I learned in primary school but there is only so much a child can do. The situation was complicated by my older brother’s autism diagnosis. We were already struggling with communication issues, and now there was a nonverbal child with a Spanish speaking mother in a mainly English speaking world just trying to get help for him. But one day my mother met a pediatrician who would unknowingly start me on my path to medicine, Dr. JoAnn Ruiz. She was the first pediatrician that I met who spoke Spanish. As I watched her treat my autistic brother, her soft and quiet interactions with him settled something within me. Dr. Ruiz did more than treat our physical ailments, she provided hope and guidance. Reflecting upon this as I grew older, I realized that I wanted to dedicate my life to pursuing a career as a physician. 
Throughout my college years I noticed there were very few Latinx mentors who worked in medicine. It made navigating pre-med difficult. My situation, that many other first generation Latinx youth experience, made me become self-reliant. That unfortunately made it hard for me to understand when it was time to ask for help, how to ask for help, and how to not feel undeserving of help. I felt as if I was falling behind. As I continued gathering clinical experience I was given the opportunity to shadow a physician. Dr. Jacqueline Olivo was the first Latina physician I ever worked with throughout all of my clinical and volunteering activities. She was not surprised. As Dr. Olivo began to mentor me, she stressed the need to understand oneself and why they wanted to be a doctor. Through reflection I realized that there was more than treating a patient in a clinic setting. A physician is also a mentor and advocate. I saw the need in the Latinx community for more Spanish speaking doctors who identify as Latinx. Anyone can learn Spanish, but that is completely different to understanding the struggles that Latinx people go through when it comes to their health. Dr. Olivo would also go on to introduce me to the most inspiring organization I have ever been part of: The Medical Organization for Latino Advancement.
During MOLA’s 2019 symposium I was overcome with emotion when I saw a room full of Latinx students and professionals. Dr. Pilar Ortega, the president of MOLA, spoke about how lack of representation affects both our health and aspirations. It makes us believe that there is no space for us in a field predominantly populated by people who don’t look like us, or sound like us. But we belong just as much as anyone else. When I had the opportunity to volunteer for them during the COVID pandemic, I saw their message in practice. We wrote letters to advocate towards allowing International Medical graduates to practice medicine during the COVID crisis, we had multiple events to promote masking and vaccination in the Latinx community, I organized virtual interviews with Latinx health professionals so they could discuss how the pandemic was affecting the Latinx community and how history and disparities was affecting that change.
I decided to go back to school to study Public Health, because I wanted to learn how our current health system operated. Everything from where you live, what food is available to you, safety, culture, and how much income you earn greatly affects your health. Through my studies I began to make connections to my experiences and how they have affected me in ways that were out of my control. I heard so many stories about the deterioration of physician/ patient relationships because some doctors just didn’t understand the culture or language of their patients, even when the doctor had good intentions. Or how peoples’ symptoms or concerns were brushed aside because of their race or gender. But I know there are doctors out there trying to make a difference. I saw it with my pediatrician and each of the doctors involved in MOLA. 
I appreciate every challenge that I faced because it allowed me to become the person that I am today. While my interest in medicine was birthed by witnessing how impactful a physician can be to a patient and their family, I was also motivated through understanding the disparities faced by Latinx patients. I want patients to see themselves reflected in their doctors. Through each experience my understanding of a physician’s role in society has evolved. A physician treats but also uses their platform to advocate for better healthcare and advocate for the betterment of disadvantaged communities. I believe my medical education would help me achieve that dream.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I grew up in a largely Hispanic neighborhood in Chicago. But when I was in middle school, my parents decided to move out to the south suburbs. I was shaken by the experience. The school had 2 other Latinos and neither were in my specific class. It was hard trying to connect with people who you had little in common with. But there was a girl there named Meriem, she was Arabic. We began to talk about our home lives, parents, siblings, foods and noticed we were quite different. But even though there were differences, we noticed similarities as well. Rice was an important staple in our dishes. Our parents pushed us to be academically successful, and that religion played an important part in our lives. It showed me that no matter how different someone is, they can have similar dreams and fears as me. Listening to them and putting myself in their shoes is both a novel and well-worn experience. Something so small as meeting a new friend can help you grow so much as a person.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I had the opportunity to intern for MOLA during the first year of the COVID-19 pandemic. Around this time there was a lot of misinformation and fear regarding the virus. Latinx were some of the hardest hit by the pandemic and I wanted to do something about it. At first it was word of mouth and sharing resources on my social media accounts. Even though I was nervous, I decided to get vaccinated as soon as it was made available for healthcare workers in December of 2020. I believed this could provide confidence to friends, family and other Latinx who were nervous about the vaccine. I had many reach out to me to assure them that it was safe. As I shared my experience with other MOLA members we decided we needed to reach out to the community. I, along with committee members and co-chairs, decided to organize a virtual event that discussed COVID-19 misinformation and why vaccinating was important. More importantly we had segments spoken in Spanish, so we could reach as many as possible.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I had been working on two research projects during the Fall of 2019 and Spring of 2020. The projects included a systematic review regarding peer support and chronic kidney disease, and the development of a phone application for chronic kidney disease patients. On March 12, 2020 I was finishing up a power point presentation because we were going to be presenting our CKD phone app project during the Ruth K Palmer Research Symposium that Friday. When the shut down happened we could no longer safely recruit patients and the project was put on hold. The COVID-19 virus halted a lot of in-person extracurricular activities that I was slated to participate in. Such as LUPHA's tabling event where we would provide information as to why it's so important to fill out the 2020 census. MOLA's annual symposium had to become a virtual event. The pandemic pushed us to become creative and resourceful to reach out to the community. So a lot of events became virtual.

personal_statement:
I have stood in more graves than I care to admit. And as the fall season gave way to the cold of winter, I found myself in yet another empty grave. As I waited for the deceased’s body to reach me, I heard the chanting of a prayer from the crowd above, and the nearby idling of a bulldozer. The aluminum ladder, my method of entry and sole means of exit was removed, and a body was gently lowered from above on a plastic board. Steadying myself, I quietly worked to slide the body off the board. I then positioned Auntie Jameela’s head towards Mecca and used my hands to move dirt into the crevices around her body. My work done, I signaled above and the ladder was lowered. I took one last look around and climbed upwards. Sweating and covered in dirt, I inhaled a deep breath of fresh air. 

Three weeks prior, Auntie Jameela was alive and awaiting my visit to her nursing home. She was a member of my congregation whose cancer had, until recently, been in remission, but who was now terminal. As an Imam, or faith leader in the Muslim community, I considered my task simple: to visit her and provide reassurance. During the walk to her room, I felt confident: after all, how was this any different from leading prayers or teaching classes at the mosque? But as I entered her room, I sensed something was different. When I took my place in the chair at the foot of her bed, she motioned for me to move closer. When I did, she looked into my eyes and said, “I don’t want to die.” I felt my confidence evaporate. As I held her hand and caught sight of the prayer beads on her blanket, I could feel the fear in the room. I also realized that I would need a new approach. After a few moments of silence, I gathered the courage to speak and offered to recite a chapter from the Quran on healing. The tension in the room dissipated, and, over the next hour, Auntie Jameela shared fond memories of her grandchildren and her youth spent overseas. When the conversation inevitably reached a moment of regret or sorrow, I gave her space to feel her emotions and to grieve. As I lay in my bed that evening, I felt as though my visit had improved Auntie Jameela’s mood and given her some measure of peace. 

Inevitably, my time with Auntie Jameela and countless others- before and after their deaths- has caused me to reflect on my own life and mortality. My work as an Imam had made me adept at providing comfort and reassurance to individuals who were sick and dying. Yet I still felt a yearning to provide something tangible that would alleviate their suffering. In volunteering at Kaiser Permanente, I witnessed physicians treating patients with interventions that lead to something tangible: reduction in pain, and sometimes, even a cure. These experiences nurtured my desire to better understand the role of a physician. At Children’s Hospital Los Angeles (CHLA), I not only met Dr. De Filippo, a urologist, but was also exposed to the significant emotional investment and time demands required of physicians. Time and again, I observed Dr. De Filippo reschedule personal obligations in order to attend to his patients. In particular, as I was getting ready to leave one evening, I got a text from Dr. De Filippo: a family had arrived upstairs without an appointment. Their toddler was having surgery the following week, and they were concerned about the operation. As I joined Dr. De Filippo, I was surprised to find that rather than tiredness or frustration, he appeared energized. His patience in answering questions and explaining the treatment plan to patients and their loved ones underscored to me that medicine was a calling. Even as I found my community work as an Imam fulfilling, I recognized that clinical work gave me the tangible results I was seeking as patients became healthier. This helped me to confirm that medicine was my passion.

Although I enjoyed studying Public Health, I found health policy lacked the personal interactions that I craved. I soon began creating such opportunities outside of my mosque as an Interfaith leader. In this role, I facilitated dialogue between Muslims and members of other faith communities. In one meeting in a local church, what was supposed to be friendly dialogue between a Christian and a Muslim became heated. As I worked to defuse the situation, I reminded them about shared values and beliefs: love of God’s creations; justice and tolerance; and the value of service to others. I shared how lessons I had learned from both the Bible and the Quran had taught me not to fear, but to help the homeless, the sick, and the disabled. Moreover, my faith guided my interactions at CHLA: through prayer, reflection, and consultation, I learned to understand and limit my own biases as I cared for patients.   

My interest in medicine stems from my desire to care for others. This began in my local mosque as well as in the churches and temples of my community. As I brought different groups together to build bridges and foster dialogue, and as I comforted the ill, I knew that I wanted to alleviate suffering and provide more than hope to those whom I was serving. My time in graves continually reminds me that while I cannot stop death, I can work on both the temporal and spiritual levels to improve the lives of my patients as a physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: My social justice experiences have underscored to me the importance of humility and optimism when helping others. Initially as a college student, however, I was exposed to the opposite attitude: too often humility was seen as a weakness by colleagues, or as the opposite of confidence. In volunteering with the American Red Cross (ARC), however, I had a paradigm shift: as I toured sites around the Greater Long Beach area and engaged with diverse stakeholders- K-8 students; parents; community leaders; the elderly; and others- I realized that traditional (paternalistic) approaches would only exacerbate existing health inequities. Instead, I found that by becoming an inclusive, shared decision maker, I could effect greater positive change. In modeling this behavior, I discovered that clients began to engage with me more. They also requested additional materials and signed up for CPR classes. I look forward to sharing my insights and experience on creating inclusive teams with RMC.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: In mid-2020, the outlook for a COVID-19 vaccine was uncertain. On a personal level, I worried for my own health and my elderly parents. During this time period, my mosque was deeply affected: as parishioners became ill and passed away, there was a great deal of emotional and spiritual loss within our community. In spite of this, I placed my fears aside and put my trust in God‚Äôs hands. I served my mosque by delivering groceries to elderly parishioners; comforting the ill and their families; and performing the last prayers, washings, and burials for the deceased. My goal with each individual was to give her/him a decent interment. And, furthermore, to support their families by providing a prayerful sendoff. As I worked to support my community, my listening and empathy skills grew. I also became increasingly resourceful and patient as funds and personnel stretched thin. My time comforting the families of the deceased taught me when to speak, and when to give others room to grieve.

Hrdshp_Comments:
Growing up, I was fortunate to have a home or never have to think where my next meal was going to come from. Though I knew finances were a concern in our household, my parents were able to provide me with the necessities. It became apparent how fragile our finances were in the inability to afford extras. Interest in participating in any extracurricular was usually met with the concern of how to pay for it. During my junior year of high school, I started working to have spending money for myself. Though this took away from my studies, I was still able to gain a college acceptance.
When I started at San Diego State, money continued to be the main factor in my decision-making. I stayed with a relative for the first year of college instead of living in the dorms to save money. While I was able to save money by not staying in the dorms, I instead had a 45-minute commute each way to school, which took away time from studying. Also, while at San Diego State, I had to work to support myself. I worked 30 hours a week on average and lived on a tight budget. Working a shift the night before an exam was not unusual. The demands of providing for myself and being a full-time student often clashed with each other. Since returning to school in a better possession financially, I’ve been able to be a better student.
Inst_Action_Desc: In my freshman year, Spring 2006, I was placed on academic probation due to poor grades. I lacked the maturity to make the adjustments necessary to succeed in college. Though I was able to be removed from academic probation after Fall 2006, I found myself on academic probation again in Spring 2007. During Summer 2007, I took classes at San Diego CC; during that time, my grandpa became sick, and I spent time back home without completing my courses, putting me on academic probation. Days before the start of Fall 2007, my grandpa passed away after battling cancer. Attempting to cope with his loss and maintain satisfactory academic performance was too much for me, and I was academically dismissed from San Diego State after the Fall 2007 semester. I attempted to continue my education at the local community college in Spring 2008 but made no changes to my academic habits or attempts to heal from my grief. I was academically dismissed from San Diego CC. In reflection, I should have taken a leave of absence from academics to cope with my loss, but a leave would have likely just delayed the inevitable as I had failed to change my study habits. When I returned to school, I had improved time management and study habits.
personal_statement:
The sound of rifle fire and mortars filled the air and was as dense as the smoke that limited my visibility. The freezing mud chilled my bones as I crawled under the barbed wire towards the cries for help. When I finally reached the Marine, I found a mangled mess of flesh and bone where his left knee should be. As blood squirted from his leg, I slid a tourniquet over his left thigh as high as possible, then cinched the tourniquet until the bleeding stopped. Noticing no other severe injuries, I relentlessly dragged him towards cover. Upon reaching safety, I completed my assessment to treat any other injuries. Unfortunately, all I could do was provide covering fire and continue monitoring the casualty until the evacuation arrived. The instructor then slapped me on the helmet, letting me know I passed, reset the dummy for the following individual, and return to the starting point.
I had initially gone to college to pursue a career in engineering. To continue financing my college education, I decided to join the Navy in hopes of doing their nuclear engineering program. After being medically disqualified for being color blind, my focus changed to joining the Navy regardless of position. Now here I was, learning how to be a hospital corpsman. Not even a year later, I was about to explore a career I had not planned for.
At my first duty station, I was assigned to work in a Family Practice clinic. There I met “Paul,” a retired veteran, merchant marine, and diabetic. Paul’s jolly smile was the first thing I immediately noticed when we met. Looking over his lab results, I noticed his blood sugar levels were elevated. He dejectedly admitted that he was not the best at taking his medication or monitoring what he ate. As I asked Paul more about his lifestyle, he explained that he spent months at a time out to sea as a sailor and worked long hours. Meals were prepared for the whole crew; since most of the crew was Filipino, rice was present at every meal. Smiling, I told him I understood as rice and tortillas were also present for me during every meal while growing up. I recommended limiting the rice at each meal to reduce his carb intake and try walking around the ship for exercise. Paul returned a few months later for a follow-up, and his face was noticeably slimmer. When he stepped on the scale, I congratulated him on the weight he had lost. Chuckling, Paul proudly showed me the belt he was wearing. He proclaimed that he no longer needed to use the makeshift holes he made and could use the predrilled holes of the belt. Paul excitedly told me that he had more energy and could feel a change. Working with Paul to understand his lifestyle and how incremental changes that fit his habits could cause transformative changes had me start considering a career in medicine.
Front desk lunch coverage was usually a time to relax and catch up on any unfinished work from the morning, but today was different. I recognized “Lilly” at the window immediately, her usually bubbly personality was replaced by a pale stare, and I immediately knew something was wrong. As I spoke with Lilly, the counter supported more and more of her as her legs became unsteady underneath her. I rushed Lilly to an exam room and sought out Dr. Barr, our only Family Practice provider that would monitor her pregnant patients until it was time for them to give birth at the base hospital. As Dr. Barr searched for the fetal heartbeat, I could feel a collective sigh of relief as the familiar whooshing sound was heard. Satisfied with Lilly’s state, Dr. Barr asked me to start an IV and to stay with her until she felt better. As we sat and shared details about our lives, I learned that her husband was away conducting military drills and would not be back for a couple of weeks. Although she was used to being alone, this new chapter of being pregnant and alone scared her. Assuring Lilly that we would be here for her, I could sense relief when she would eventually share the name for her future daughter, “Ivory.” Although I found joy in providing comfort to Lilly, I felt the need to reassure her with the knowledge that only a physician could provide that she and her baby would be ok.
My experiences have shaped the kind of physician I envision myself to be. By working with my patients, I aim to understand their personal and social lives and help guide them to make health decisions that fit within their lifestyles. While teaching and educating my patients, I want to be an example for the next generation of healthcare professionals and contribute to their education. Lastly, working with underserved populations is not enough. I seek to increase the representation in medicine by mentoring students on their path to medical school. Mentoring students as early as high school to ensure that they are prepared for success in their undergraduate education and can become successful medical school applicants who become practicing physicians. Through my efforts, I hope to increase the diversity and inclusion of medicine.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
I was fortunate to have grown up in a diverse city. When I joined the Navy, I was exposed to even more diverse groups of people. Growing up in California and being Mexican, I had always been surrounded by my culture. When I got stationed in Hawaii, where there‚Äôs a mixture of cultures present, the Native Hawaiians with large influences from Pacific-Island and Asian cultures mixed in, the security of having my identity always present was gone. I was fortunate enough to work with local individuals who were welcoming and exposed me to the various cultures present._x000D_
My experience of being in an unfamiliar cultural environment helped me experience what being an ‚Äúoutsider‚Äù felt like. Being able to build a community where I felt comfortable and safe stemmed from the fact that other people were willing to teach me and expose me to their culture while also learning about mine. For me being inclusive means building a community where cultural experiences can be shared, and everyone feels valued.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: While working in a local high school in support of Improve Your Tomorrow‚Äôs mission to increase the number of young men of color to attend and graduate from college, I saw how the lack of basic necessities could disrupt a student‚Äôs education. During one of my mentoring sessions with Joseph, I asked about his grade in biology and why he had some missing assignments. He confided in me that he couldn‚Äôt afford the poster board to complete the project and was also facing food insecurity. To assist him, I let him know IYT had a fund for such occasions and gave him a list of local food banks in the area. I wish I could say Joseph was the only student I worked with who faced such challenges, but many of the students faced struggles outside of the classroom. The barriers many students faced made it understandable why school was not always a priority in their lives. Yet, despite the adversity they faced, many just wanted an opportunity to succeed.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
During the 2020-2021 academic year, I planned to return to school to continue my path to medical school. I had taken two years off to be a stay-at-home parent and to support my spouse‚Äôs career. Due to classes being online, my family and I did not move from our mid-size city to the major metropolitan area where the school was located. I looked forward to the shadowing, extracurricular, and research activities that would be available. Unfortunately, like many students, the activities were canceled for the 20-21 academic year. _x000D_
Where my situation differs from my classmates was the unique challenge of being a father and having a wife who works in healthcare. The plan for when I returned to school was for our 2-year-old daughter to attend daycare while I was in school. However, finding reliable and safe daycare was difficult, especially since my wife works with a vulnerable population. Despite these challenges, I feel like I did well in the program.

Hrdshp_Comments:
I’m a first-generation, undocumented Latina from Mexico, raised by a single mother with a sixth-grade education. While in elementary and high school I did not have academic or financial support, though we would have likely qualified for SNAP, WIC, and Pell grants if not for my status.

Being one of a few students of color I was unable to find encouragement for higher education from staff at my high school. Ineligible for federal financial aid, I enrolled in community college then transferred to the University of Washington with scholarships. I was facing housing and food insecurities, without strong cultural capital. Once Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) was enacted, I worked 40+ hours a week while enrolled full-time in upper division STEM courses. Consequently, I withdrew from courses I was not prepared to take.

I was in college when I met a Latinx physician; it was transformational seeing him lead a medical team as it was previously difficult to stay motivated without seeing representation. This invigorated me to ask for help, and self-advocate, and was subsequently able to pursue an accelerated MPH at Columbia. I prioritized school and strengthened my academic skills by active learning. With discipline, I thrived in my advanced science classes while studying for the MCAT and working.
Inst_Action_Desc:
In the spring of 2014, I was placed on departmental academic probation. I was taking 2-5 science classes like biochemistry, microbiology, organic chemistry, and labs. I wanted to take the same classes as my peers, ignoring my lack of a solid academic foundation and socioeconomic hardships. 
 
I was hungry and couch surfing, while also taking time to go to my mother’s appointments 3 hours away by bus. I would often become emotionally overwhelmed with family, financial, and immigration worries and was unable to focus on class. We were severely in debt as my mother went through her cancer treatments and once I gained the right to legal employment in 2013, I became the head of household.  I feared DACA immigration policy would end, and I would be unable to continue to support my family. 
 
From 2014 until my graduation in 2017, I was not placed on departmental academic probation again. I found mentors, worked less so I could attend office hours, and joined study groups; I learned I enjoy teaching others. These experiences taught me to have good communication with family members to support my mother, good time management to balance school, work, and studying, as well as the humility to ask for help when necessary to move ahead. I can appreciate the hardships I experienced because of the resilience developed.
personal_statement:
The newest FDA-approved chemotherapy was my mother’s last hope, and we were crushed when her oncologist said the risks outweighed the benefits. I knew from my time as a cancer information specialist that clinical trials might be an option, but given my mother’s undocumented status, I was unsure if she would qualify. My mother's oncologist has always made her feel heard, safe, and well cared for; she trusted him with her life, and yet she hesitated to let him know. As a volunteer interpreter at free clinics and health fairs, I have observed the same uncertainty weigh heavily on undocumented families' decision to seek healthcare even when physicians have created a positive, trusting environment. Factors beyond the healthcare setting affect the care patients seek, and this continues to motivate me to become a physician confronting disparities. As a caregiver and undocumented individual, I have discovered a passion for medicine and a desire to advocate for underserved communities.
 
I volunteer as an interpreter at health fairs knowing that undocumented immigrants, like my family, often fear pursuing medical services that may lead to financial burden and deportation. While volunteering, I met a woman who was unsure which services she should prioritize. She confided that she had been waiting since the previous night, as buses did not run early enough for her to line up, and I understood the extraordinary lengths many patients go through to receive even limited care. She chose mental health counseling and shared it was a service she long had been thinking about, but her diabetes management had taken precedence due to limited time off work. I felt like an intruder in such a personal conversation, and the patient also wished for a provider who spoke Spanish so she would not have to divulge her feelings to a third party. I realized it was not enough for me to empty drains, care for surgical wounds, and interpret. I want to be the person capable of offering hope by gaining the knowledge, critical thinking ability, and skills to treat patients holistically to create a comfortable environment and improve outcomes. 
 
To understand systemic inequities in health I explored health disparities in research which exposed me to themes of medical mistrust. As a research coordinator for the Comparing Outcomes of Drugs and Appendectomy (CODA) study, I observed how some participants of color were distrustful of the trial. I was once paged to randomize a Spanish-speaking patient, unsure about participating. I understood her hesitation given the historical trauma minoritized communities have suffered through research, and subsequent deep-rooted distrust in healthcare. I answered her and her family’s rapid-fire questions, tailoring my answers to meet their health literacy needs. In the end, she consented to randomization. She felt empowered to help future patients like her. It was incredible to work with the physicians who were taking care of patients in the clinic and taking care of the community through patient-reported outcomes research. Like them, I hope to build trust, educate, and humbly amplify the voices of vulnerable communities to implement equitable solutions in medicine.
 
The opportunities to work as a cancer information hotline operator and research coordinator, could not have happened without the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) policy. I was granted a work permit in 2013, and I was finally able to legally work to significantly help my family and find stability for myself. As an undocumented transfer student at the University of Washington in 2012, a traditional pre-medical experience became even more challenging as I balanced schoolwork while navigating housing instability, food insecurity, and caring for my mother. I struggled with confiding in advisers and pursuing opportunities for fear that my status would be discovered. I learned how to operate within the higher-education system while using codes to safely ask about resources for undocumented students. My love for science mitigated my fears and galvanized me to forge my own path to explore and learn about medicine. Encouraged by my mother who only had a sixth-grade education, I became the first in my family to earn a Bachelor of Science degree and later a Master in Public Health degree.
 
My journey working within and advocating for diverse populations has solidified my intent to provide quality compassionate care for underserved communities as a physician. My collective experiences have provided me with empathy and resilience to establish the foundation for a career in medicine. I am undocumented and unafraid, and I understand my role as a bilingual, first-generation, Latina physician-activist in the making. I want future physicians to join me in understanding social justice as a medical issue and the importance of emphasizing social determinants of health in medicine to improve care. Using my platform as a physician to improve health equity is a responsibility and a privilege, but what calls me the most to medicine is the trusting partnerships with individual patients. I look forward to the day I lead a medical team to treat patients, respect their lived experiences, elucidate barriers to healthcare access, and advocate for health justice.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
As a smoking cessation counselor for the National Cancer Institute Contact Center, I counseled clients who felt they had tried everything to quit. I do not have family or friends who smoke, so it was challenging to understand the anxiety and desperation they felt. However, my training in motivational interviewing skills, coupled with my empathetic nature, allowed me to forge a connection with my clients._x000D_
_x000D_
Many clients expressed their frustration with themselves. But they were facing incredible odds given the addictive nature of nicotine, coupled with poverty, unemployment, racism, discrimination, and domestic violence. I learned that successful health interventions should take these social factors that result in health disparities into consideration. This experience inspired me to improve health outcomes as a future physician by motivating patients, providing health information, and addressing non-medical needs with a team of social workers and patient navigators for all patients.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
I recognized the crisis my own family was experiencing was similarly affecting thousands in Washington State - we were ineligible for the CARES act relief and unemployment benefits due to our immigration status. At the Washington Immigrant Solidarity Network Hotline (WAISN),  I answered calls from community members facing eviction, workplace safety concerns, and food instability. One caller had lost his brother to the COVID-19 virus but was so worried about making rent payments that he did not even have time to grieve. _x000D_
_x000D_
Amid these calls, I noticed the Spanish-speaking community was receiving delayed information regarding masking, symptoms, and vaccines. I was able to start a conversation with WAISN leadership to prepare for COVID-19 vaccinations. We now have a regularly updated list of vaccination sites across Washington State and a Washington Department of Health-approved script to reassure callers that regardless of their immigration status, they can receive the vaccine at no cost._x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact:
I refrained from shadowing and volunteering in person; I had to keep my family safe. Instead of shadowing in person, I interviewed physicians over Zoom. It was inspiring to meet physicians who were all unified in the fight against the COVID-19 virus. The health fairs I usually volunteer with were canceled, so I volunteered with WAISN._x000D_
 _x000D_
There, I gained insight into how other undocumented individuals in Washington were fairing during the pandemic. Many sought resources to bury their loved ones, escape domestic abuse, or find legal advice for renters.  _x000D_
I enrolled in an accelerated Master in Public Health degree program at Mailman. I was disappointed it would be online but grateful for the opportunity to continue working part-time. Due to the pandemic, I was unable to pursue internships or conduct research during my program that would serve my community. _x000D_
 _x000D_
I have turned the challenges of these last two years into new opportunities and have grown tremendously from these experiences.

Hrdshp_Comments: After my father was diagnosed with renal failure and placed on disability, my mother became the sole financial earner for our family. She worked long days at the salon while I helped take care of my three younger brothers. Our family heavily relied on government assistance for food and housing, and without it, would not have had access to the basic amenities and peace of mind they afforded. With Vietnamese as our primary home language, I initially struggled in school but fortunately through the help of ESL classes, became proficient enough to translate for my parents when they needed. With their support and student financial aid, I was the first member of my family able to attend college. During my undergraduate studies I frequently returned home to assist my parents with moving after we were evicted. I had a difficult time managing my responsibilities at home and school which affected my study habits. Despite these circumstances, I was grateful to have a chance at a future my parents did not have but wanted for their children. I became stronger and more resilient by working to better manage my time while fulfilling my obligations. Furthermore, I sought out academic and emotional support from friends and mentors during this period and grew to understand that it is acceptable to ask for help.
personal_statement:
I felt helpless as my father's health deteriorated and my parents, Vietnamese immigrants with limited English skills and exposure to American healthcare, struggled to understand and treat his condition. They would often look to me for clarity as I tried to translate and relay their concerns to his physician. Over time, I saw my father transform from a man who avoided the doctor's to one who diligently watched his diet and stuck to treatment. Initially, I attributed his recovery to countless medicines and dialysis, but later realized it was possible through the connection between him and his physician. I saw firsthand how powerful a patient-physician relationship could be and was inspired by their compassion in working with my stubborn father to follow in their footsteps.

As the first in my family fortunate to attend college, it took time before I learned to balance home and school through my post-baccalaureate program. Mentors like Dr. Jey, who despite caring for patients day in and day out in the emergency department (ED), also devotes time creating a national mentorship program helping students like me achieve their goals in medicine. Through working with him, I expanded my definition of a physician as a healer and educator of patients in understanding their diseases, but also an advisor who harnesses their gratitude to give back. Motivated to offer some of the guidance I had wished for at that stage of my life and have been lucky to come across since, I organized a Pre-medical Youth Conference for high school students in disadvantaged areas aspiring to be clinicians. 

Appreciation of the resources available to me led me to volunteer with the Project Vietnam Foundation to provide basic medical services to the rural communities of the Hai Duong province in northern Vietnam. One bác (uncle) suffering from headaches was found to have significantly elevated blood pressure. We rushed him back to a physician who swiftly ordered medicine to lower his blood pressure and improve his headache. I learned a blood pressure reading was more than a mere set of numbers and timely intervention could mean the difference between health and more serious complications. Back at home, I had the privilege to educate uninsured Vietnamese patients at a student-run clinic on the basics of blood pressure control and risks of unmanaged hypertension. Aside from a shared common language, there was an element of trust that enabled me to introduce complete strangers to preventative health measures. Connecting with our community reinforces my goals to become a relatable physician who educates patients towards better understanding and control of their health. 

My ability to connect with patients was challenged when I met Debbie, an elderly resident reliant on 24-hour care at the nursing home due to speech and motor impairment. During one of our initial reading sessions, she became visibly shaken and tearful. I felt inadequate as I spent an eternity trying to figure out the issue. The tension gradually resolved from her face as we wheeled across the grounds at her direction until she finally revealed she was afraid of getting kicked out of the facility. I paused at a thought so incredible but kept in mind this was her reality as I cautiously reassured her she was in the right place. Over six years, Debbie grew comfortable confiding in me and I was able to pick up that a furrowed brow and distracted stare signaled pain or anxiety to come. I learned effective patient care can involve communication that transcends words. Although you might not be able to fully understand what patients feel, you can offer comfort in their time of need. My time with Debbie taught me the importance of patience and paying attention in building trust to be able to offer this comfort. 

Working as a medical scribe with physicians who take the time to understand the underlying reason a patient comes to the ED broadened my awareness of community health needs. Specifically, many patients do not have access to primary care services. While others remind me of my dad before his recovery and demonstrate poor compliance and understanding of their conditions. It became apparent many patients who rely on the ED experienced a gap in their healthcare that could have been bridged through continued medical care, a growing need I recognized and am committed to provide in the future as a physician. 

Being a scribe trainer reinforced the idea that everyone learns differently. One student better understands how to compose progress notes through worksheets while another by acting out scenarios. Seeing them both grow and grasp concepts as I tailor my teaching style has been rewarding and reflects how I intend to adapt to teach my patients in the future. 

My appreciation for medicine stems from the lasting impact it has had on my family and has grown over the years after seeing the effects of health education and primary care on others. In my mind, the core of quality patient care is achieved through trust and communication between patient and physician, and improved health outcomes start at the foundational level. I hope to one day be able to give back to our community as a primary care physician who connects patients to the comprehensive patient care they need.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Before I started scribing in the ER, I had limited contact with the unhoused community but grew increasingly aware of the stigmatization this marginalized group carried. Homeless patients frequently visit the ER for non-medical resources like shelter placement and are often dismissed as less deserving of medical attention, which I learned to be a dangerous bias after judging a patient based on their appearance and assuming they did not have a true medical emergency. I was humbled as I thought back to my childhood when my family relied on government assistance for shelter and peace of mind that others are not so fortunate to have. Stereotypes will continue to persist in society but medical establishments should remain a sanctuary for all patients, regardless of their socioeconomic status or background. As a future physician, I will be more mindful to prevent the overwhelming collective opinion from shadowing my own and diminish pre-existing biases while serving diverse communities.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I opened the door to find my neighbor Roosevelt standing grinning from ear to ear. ‚ÄúBoth my doctors said they were so proud of me and how long I‚Äôve come!‚Äù I have known Roosevelt for about five years during which he would often come seeking dietary advice and help reviewing lab results. As an African-American man with a strong family history of kidney disease, Roosevelt grew more conscious of his health with age. Given my father had dealt with renal failure, I shared with Roosevelt the dietary restrictions I knew of such as substituting his favored orange juice with options that contained less potassium and were easier on the kidneys. He was often surprised by the impact of small changes on his health but was always engaged and excited to try. Additionally, I urged a more active lifestyle and was happy to eventually see him on his daily walks while on my way home. I was honored he wanted to share the news his efforts were paying off and even more glad I could help him along the way.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I was initially planning to take the MCAT at the beginning of 2020 however my exam was pushed back multiple times due to COVID-19. This made preparing a study schedule and planning for practice tests around my work obligations especially difficult as I could not afford to use up my resources before having an official testing date. In the end, I decided to save my materials and instead take additional virtual classes on immunology and human diseases, which were particularly interesting in light of the pandemic.

personal_statement:
I was quietly seated in an ill-lit cafeteria when an older man parked his wheelchair next to me. I recognized Chris from the addiction support group I ran the prior week at Boston Healthcare for the Homeless Program (BHCHP). While we exchanged pleasantries, I noticed he had lost his left foot.

“My diabetes medication isn’t working. They are amputating the other one,” he said somberly. That night, one question kept repeating in my mind: could Chris’s situation have been prevented? Although I was familiar with socioeconomic determinants of health, this was the first time I made a personal connection with a homeless individual.

While I volunteered at BHCHP Chris and I established a friendship; I learned about his upbringing, his favorite sports teams, and his substance use disorder. I told him about my spinal disorder and growing up in a household with addiction. As I got to know Chris, I began to grasp how lack of access to adequate housing, transportation, and a litany of other worries compounded Chris’s health issues making it nearly impossible to manage his diabetes. Although I could not treat Chris medically, I wanted to help him in some way, but at first, I wasn’t sure how.

A common topic for us was footcare. Both Chris and I had lost significant sensation in our feet, Chris’s due to diabetic neuropathy and me due to a spinal condition. Having a disease that is poorly managed or incurable is overwhelming and difficult to accept, however, I found comfort in sharing my fears with Chris and learning how he coped with his amputation.

Chris and I also spoke about my older brother’s addiction: he has been in and out of treatment for opioid use since I was in high school. His slow decline into an angry, resentful, and often violent person was impossibly hard to watch and comprehend. Growing up in a household with constant arguing, the ever-present fear that he may overdose, and his complete lack of remorse for his actions caused our family intense emotional strain.

Meeting patients BHCHP like Chris with substance use disorders similar to my brother’s helped me understand the intersectionality of psychological, physiological, and societal components that contribute to illness. Listening to patients’ recovery journeys sparked agency and hope in me; learning how I could make a difference in the lives of patients further fueled my fire to continue to support others and helped me accept my brother’s illness. I realized that to accept someone with an illness as consuming as addiction is to relinquish any expectation of reciprocation of support or even mutual respect.

Whether it was because he was transferred to another hospital or back in a shelter, eventually Chris stopped coming to support groups. Saddened by Chris’s departure I realized with each patient I interacted there was a common denominator—lack of resources. Even if Chris had access to sufficient care, the lack of social support contributed to the progression of his diabetes. Although I was angered by the unfairness of the patients’ circumstances, I was more upset that I had lost contact with patients with whom I had close established connections.

I found myself coping by immersing myself in scientific inquiry: by understanding the mechanistic basis of disease I felt hopeful that someday I could prevent negative outcomes. In retrospect, it was a way I could hold onto the friendships I made with patients. By researching diabetic treatments and mechanisms and the impact of homelessness on health, I still felt connected to Chris. Furthermore, our past conversations about my own illness prompted me to read literature on how developmental genetic modification possibly contributed to my spinal disorder and how physicians could use this information to pursue treatment.

Throughout my time at BHCHP, I have come to understand how I could help the patients as a volunteer. Listening and adapting to patients’ needs, promoting acceptance, and directing patients to resources helped me connect with patients. Ultimately, I noticed this trust allowed me to have a greater impact as a volunteer. Further, I found hope in reading scientific and public health journals because I saw how research could elucidate possible solutions to issues I witnessed at BHCHP. The intersectionality of health, social issues, genetics, and addiction absorbed me because I was piecing together a life story.

The combination of scientific investigation with the opportunity to establish meaningful connections while giving back to my community draws me to medicine.  Although I have always been interested in biological mechanisms for disease, it has been the experiences with my brother and patients like Chris that solidified my pursuit of a career in medicine. Working with patients like Chris I realized my passion for medicine is rooted in my desire to deepen my understanding of the interplay between the physiological, social, and scientific contributions to medicine and how these aspects affect patient care. Furthermore, watching my brother struggle, I find that feeling understood and accepted are crucial to creating the safe space necessary for effective care and healing. My time at BHCHP, various research laboratories, and clinical work have affirmed my passion for medicine.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Volunteering at Boston healthcare for the Homeless, I interacted with patients of various ages, gender identities, races and ethnicities, and different backgrounds than myself. Through this experience, I connected with patients on a personal level and learned about their upbringings, how they became homeless and how they felt stigmatized for their situation.  From this exposure, I changed my perspective and understanding about how socioeconomic status, intergenerational capital and institutional barriers effect physical and mental health. I also learned that it is the personal connection and desire to improve a patient‚Äôs life that draws me to medicine. Volunteering with this patient population I realized that I genuinely enjoy establishing connections with people from different backgrounds from myself, understanding different perspectives and learning from other people‚Äôs experiences.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As a volunteer at Boston Healthcare for the Homeless (BHCHP), I worked with populations at risk for opioid usage and HIV. In my role I lead addiction support groups and organized events in which health providers presented on various educational topics. For example, I hosted a staff nurse who presented on HIV prevention measures explaining its their benefits and uses. Another project I worked on was planning and hosting events to raise awareness about the impact of and how to prevent stigmatization of homeless individuals. Lastly, I collaborated with physicians and social workers on a grant for funding for patients suffering from substance use disorder to transition to sober living facility after they left the hospital rather than back to a shelter or living on the street. Organizing and participating in these projects I tried to educate, support and advocate for patients at BHCHP.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
During the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic I was in the second year of my master‚Äôs program. Although I struggled at first with online classes I was able to figure out the best learning strategy for myself. Additionally, hoping to get more research experience, I started working in the Wainford lab at Boston University in January of 2021, however, I was unable to continue due to capacity restrictions._x000D_
_x000D_
Personally, during this time I was diagnoses with a form of colitis. This experience was stressful because appointments were not as abundant so my diagnosis and treatment were delayed compared to pre-pandemic times. This experience was during the months leading up to and during the time I took my MCAT exam for the first time. The pain and stress of my condition hindered my ability to prepare and perform as well as I had hoped to on my exam. However this year, I retook my exam and received a higher score once I was able to manage my colitis.

Hrdshp_Comments: I spent my early childhood growing up in East Los Angeles, an urban community plagued by poverty and gang violence. My parents immigrated to the US from Mexico and worked long hours in manufacturing factories to support our family. My parents feared for our safety in the community we lived in and made the difficult decision to move us to the rural city of Santa Maria while my father stayed behind in LA to work. Though the transition from an urban to a rural city alleviated our anxieties about constant threats to our safety, it also presented an unexpected set of challenges. I found that my rural, underfunded high school lacked the resources to adequately prepare students for the rigors of college. As a result, I paved my own way through high school, independently seeking out experiences to enrich my education. Moreover, healthcare was far more inaccessible in Santa Maria than in East LA, further exacerbating the health disparities I observed in my community.  In hindsight, these hardships made me stronger in the face of adversity and taught me the importance of resilience. As a physician, I hope to draw on my background to serve and connect with patients from communities like my own.
personal_statement:
When I remember my childhood in East Los Angeles, I can almost smell the pollutant-filled air that often exacerbated my asthma. I remember walking into Emergency Rooms feeling breathless and afraid, only to be met by kind physicians who treated me so I could breathe comfortably again. The hospital became a refuge for me, both from my asthma and from the violence in my neighborhood. While children often feared going to the doctor, I valued the moments I spent there, as they were a momentary escape from the outside world.

One night, when I was eight years old, we awoke to the noise of stray bullets shattering our living room windows. It was then that my mother relocated my four siblings and me to the rural city of Santa Maria, CA. We moved in with my uncle, who worked in the fields as a fruit picker. He always stressed the importance of education to us kids, often saying, “The fruit of my labor is providing the opportunity for you all to pursue something greater than working in the fields.” My family’s unwavering support drove me to focus on academics and become the first person in my family to attend college.

While completing my undergraduate degree at UC Berkeley, my uncle passed away after a battle with colon cancer. Like many Latino men in my community, he was apprehensive about attending doctor’s appointments due to the social stigma and language barrier. Because of this, he had never received a colonoscopy prior to the day he was diagnosed with metastatic colon cancer. As I interpreted for my uncle when his doctor broke this news, I remember my frustration with my community’s lack of health literacy, the scarcity of preventative public health measures tailored to them, and my own lack of knowledge about his disease. When I reflect on my uncle’s passing, I sometimes wonder if he would have been more likely to seek care if he had a Spanish-speaking physician. This frustration ignited my passion to pursue medicine and bring this knowledge back to my community. However, during this time, I also suffered from kidney stones, and the debilitating pain impeded my academic performance for many months. As a first-generation student, I failed to realize the breadth of resources available to me during this challenging time. In retrospect, I learned a valuable lesson in asking for help, prioritizing my health, and drawing on the support of my mentors.

Upon graduating, I sought to deepen my understanding of the molecular mechanisms of disease by pursuing a master’s degree in Stem Cell Biology. Under Dr. Eric Huang at UCSF, I identified and characterized a unique architecture in the developing brain that underlies the expansion of neurons during development. I became fluent in the vocabulary of neuroblasts and germinal zones, but could not share my excitement for this work with my family. I found myself caught between two worlds: that of biomedical research and that of my community in Santa Maria. Often serving as a bridge between these worlds for my family during doctor’s appointments, I became interested in making science and medicine more accessible to patients from backgrounds like my own.

To this end, I became a Spanish medical interpreter for various free clinics and outreach programs in my community. I currently serve as the Clinic Director for the International Health Collective, a non-profit organization that provides basic healthcare in Tijuana, Mexico. We work with members in the community to provide holistic and culturally sensitive care. On one memorable afternoon in Tijuana, an elderly woman presented with acid reflux. She was hesitant when describing her symptoms and often responded in one-word answers. Noticing her reluctance to engage, I sought to calm her by making a personal connection. When I shared that my parents are also from Mexico, her affect completely changed. As we connected over shared experiences, she elaborated on her symptoms and confided in me that she was having painful discomfort while urinating. With this information, her physician could more appropriately diagnose and treat her resulting in relief of her symptoms. I saw how, when the patient was able to relate to her care team and speak her native language, she was able to advocate for herself. Through years of working with patients from diverse backgrounds, I have learned that each patient’s relationship with medicine is a product of the culture they were raised in and their personal experiences with healthcare workers. It is a privilege to gain a patient's trust, educate them about their health conditions, and empower them to advocate for their health.

I envision myself becoming a physician who provides accessible healthcare to underserved patients and improves health outcomes in these communities. Healthcare is a right that should not be dictated by socioeconomic status or the color of one’s skin. It is through my upbringing and experiences that I have garnered the resilience to pursue medicine, the empathy to be of service to vulnerable patients, and the motivation to treat each person with the humanity they deserve. Today, the hospital no longer serves as an escape from the outside world; instead, it is the place where I see myself making the most meaningful impact on my community.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Living in the Bay Area, I learned about social determinants of health and observed the impact of food deserts on health disparities. Inaccessibility to nutritious foods like fresh produce contributes to chronic health conditions such as hypertension and diabetes. As a volunteer for Oakland Youth Aspire (OYA), I sought to reduce these barriers by distributing fresh produce to families living in food deserts.
