In these neighborhoods, I built community gardens and led classes for youth about diet and nutrition. These experiences taught me the importance of listening to communities to understand their individual needs. As a Latina, I valued the opportunity to learn about the barriers unique to other marginalized communities and how I might better serve as an ally. As a physician, I hope to serve as an advocate for these communities by working with groups like OYA to improve accessibility to health resources, increase health literacy and help families understand the importance of nutrition.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I am a Clinic Director for the International Health Collective, a non-profit that travels across the US-Mexico border each month to provide healthcare to a rural, impoverished community in Tijuana. We aim to build trust with community members by maintaining a consistent clinic schedule, treating all patients with respect, and ensuring care plans are feasible for patients. Moreover, I have pioneered a Spanish interpreter program to widen the scope of our clinic and increase accessibility to care. As a first-generation Mexican-American, I value the opportunity to provide accessible, culturally competent care to underserved communities like my own. I am excited to get involved with similar outreach programs at Rush, such as RU Caring, and draw on my experiences in this space to pioneer novel ways of increasing health literacy and access to healthcare in underserved communities.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Though I was deeply emotionally affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, I had the privilege of maintaining stable housing, access to resources, and employment. The effects of the COVID-19 pandemic exacerbated health disparities in marginalized communities and called me to dedicate my time to Clinic by the Bay, a free clinic that serves a diverse patient population in San Francisco. As layoffs increased, I helped patients apply to CalFresh, a food security program, to address the increased food insecurity that patients faced. Further, recognizing the difficulty of scheduling vaccine appointments for people who lack access to a computer, I helped patients schedule their appointments and answered questions regarding the safety of the COVID-19 vaccine. By playing various roles to serve our patients during this challenging time, I gained insight into the societal factors that are deeply intertwined with patients‚Äô medical needs.

personal_statement:
As the sun rose on the expansive desert of my native Torreon, my uncle Mario received a call informing him his daughter’s fever, for the fourth day, was unremitting. He told his wife they could not afford to take Mariam to the doctor again. Two hundred pesos, ten dollars, precluded Mario from having his daughter medically evaluated. I saw anguish and desperation in his frowned eyes. I felt sick and powerless. As we rode the rest of the way to my grade school in silence, I kept asking myself how a medical system could value wealth over life. Mariam recovered fully, but that experience planted a seed within me that grew my aspirations and decisions for the next two decades.

I immigrated with my brother to this country at the age of thirteen amidst a security crisis in Mexico in which my family and I had received over twenty-three death threats. A subconscious remainder of this crisis drove me to attempt cultural assimilation by decentering my heritage. This insidious yoke led me to believe in an ethnocentric narrative that valued homogeneity, uniformity, and repetition. Working with an advanced cancer patient, Perla, helped me to better embrace my heritage. 

Perla emigrated from Latin America to Boston to seek better medical care. Before her admission into Health Care for the Homeless, Perla was sent from doctor to doctor throughout the city. Initially, we continued the indications from her last physician: a clinical-trial treatment for her cancer, metformin for her diabetes, and risperidone for schizophrenia. We noticed a worsening tremor and a marked absence of schizophrenic symptoms throughout her time with us. I studied her chart intensely, curious about her high dose of antipsychotic medication for over a decade. I found the note about her original diagnosis: shortly after immigrating, Perla’s mom passed away. Perla confided in her physician that she could “feel” her mother’s presence, and the physician diagnosed her with schizophrenia. Over a decade of notes, I found no further information about her diagnosed condition. I brought this to her clinician’s attention. Her neurologist, alongside a psychiatrist, ran tests concluding Perla was misdiagnosed and her medication had induced parkinsonism.  

My heritage and my roots allow me to provide unique perspectives that could benefit patients. If an understanding of Latin American culture’s deep religiosity had informed Perla’s original diagnosis, her expression of grief would have been considered non-pathogenic. Cultural heterogeneity, diversity, and variation, I have learned, are vital to providing high-quality, patient-centered care. Working with Perla, I visualized the networks of vulnerability to which she belonged: networks which, in part, I understood. I feel morally compelled to use my heritage and the educational opportunities this country has given me to dedicate my life to the service of others.

As I’ve acquired knowledge, my ability to serve others has increased. From the start of university, I knew I wanted to be involved in a lab where I could contribute to creating such knowledge. Fortunately, I found a biophysics lab where I obtained unrivaled mentorship. I was first tasked with a simple job: keeping the cells alive. While doing so was interesting, I wanted to contribute in a way that advanced the research. For that, I would first have to acquire more knowledge. 

For a year, I spent my time between classes, in the evenings, and on weekends at the lab, where I carried out literature searches, integrating what I learned with lab experiments. One morning, my studies proved useful when, under the microscope, I discovered a problem with our model: it lacked epithelial cells, and instead, connective cells had taken over. It was homogenous rather than heterogeneous. I urged the team to halt ongoing experiments; this timely realization avoided the inevitable retraction of our publications. My supervisor proceeded to confidently invite me to co-author a publication, lead a group of undergraduate students, and co-lead my projects.

My journey at university, however, was not always smooth. I had a difficult transition during my first year, and I can vividly recall telling myself that I should consider an alternate field. I overcame but did not want other students to believe they should quit because of a difficult adjustment period, so I became a mentor for first-year students. Most face similar, complex adjustment processes: through conversations with students, I helped isolate the causes behind their lack of success. Time and time again, their grades improved along with their confidence to remain in premed, which to me underscores the importance of guidance in decision-making. 

My experience with my cousin Mariam inspired me to become a physician. My trajectory toward medicine, however, has been a process of self-reflection and constant exploration. It has allowed me to evaluate my values and identity, all while having the privilege of helping someone else. Perhaps that is the beauty and allure of medicine: in the process of helping others, in attempting to understand the essence of humanity, one better understands oneself and grows. Medicine allows physicians to be advocates, teachers, and healers, all of which I hope to be for my patients.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Immigration requires the abandoning of that which is familiar for the unknown. At age thirteen, I had to leave Mexico due to an increasingly volatile security situation. My grandfather was previously kidnapped, my family received death threats, and a stray bullet tragically killed my aunt. This was the nightmare most Mexicans lived under at that time. _x000D_
 _x000D_
Arriving in the United States bound for Oregon, though I was alone with my brother, I felt privileged to have the opportunity to build my life here: in a diverse and safer society where I could grow. After high school in Oregon, I moved to Massachusetts to attend university, and finally, this year, I am living in Florida with my spouse._x000D_
 _x000D_
As I attended different states, I was exposed to the multiculturalism and diversity, racial, ethnic, and cultural, existing throughout the United States. I learned that cultural humility is the cornerstone of respectful relationships through which we advocate, teach, and heal.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
As I pursued an education in the United States, I learned that poverty among certain communities is not accidental. In some instances, decades of racist legislation have created a complex web of causality that systemically harms communities and robs them of their health. To lift and heal communities, therefore, it is necessary to advocate for change; it is necessary to provide a voice; it is necessary to work on the frontline and help heal._x000D_
 _x000D_
Medicine, to me, extends beyond a physician‚Äôs awe-inspiring responsibility of physically caring for a patient. Medicine bestows the responsibility of helping effect social change._x000D_
_x000D_
Working with Perla, to whom I refer in my personal statement, I realized the intersectional vulnerabilities that coalesce to create networks with the power of causing harm. I take pride in having been able to help resolve Perla‚Äôs mistreatment, but it was distressing that it occurred. This experience reinforced the importance of cultural humility.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
Like many others, I lost someone close to me due to COVID-19. Raquel lived in my hometown in Torreon, Mexico. I urged her to seek medical advice, even if over the phone. Two days went by before she passed. I later realized that urging an individual to seek medical advice is a bogus entreaty if the area lacks medical personnel. Raquel had no one to seek out. Lack of medical insurance, lack of funds, and a lack of physicians isolated her from help._x000D_
_x000D_
The mission of Boston Health Care for the Homeless is ‚Äúto ensure unconditionally equitable and dignified access to the highest quality health care‚Ä¶‚Äù While despondent after my loss, I also felt resolved to contribute to my community and ensure that equitable and high-quality care can be accessed by anyone, regardless of socioeconomic condition. My loss motivated me to dedicate my time working at BHCHP, and it reinforced my desire to continue my medical career, as I aspire to provide the highest-quality medical care to whoever may need it.

Hrdshp_Comments: I was four years old when I came to the United States from Guyana, a developing country in South America. I lived with six family members in a one-bedroom apartment. I was ten years old when one morning before school there was an unfamiliar knock at the door. When my mom opened door, the environment changed. Three law enforcement agents entered, and I saw the fear in my mother’s-tired eyes. Both of my parents were arrested, it took more than a week for my sister to find my mom at the airport about to be deported. Much later we found our father at a holding facility in New Jersey. After several years of being considered undocumented, I encountered the many difficulties that come with such as status. Not qualifying for financial aid, the constant fear of deportation, coupled with working at times three part time jobs while going to college full time were all experiences and challenges I live with. It is a better situation now as a DACA student however, these challenges are still present. The experiences of my life have helped inform me of the inequities and inequalities in our society. They have made me more sensitive to the plight of others from various backgrounds and lower socioeconomic status. Despite the adversities, I remained steadfast to peruse my desire to become a culturally competent physician.
Under_School: City University of New York Hunter College
personal_statement:
As a volunteer on the Nine East floor of Mount Sinai Hospital in Harlem, many of the patients have Crohn’s disease, which like my older brother’s medical conditions, to date are incurable. One day, while making rounds, I walked into a patient’s room and asked if she needed anything. She requested a newspaper and some water. I brought it to her and we began talking. We soon realized that we both have Caribbean roots. She passionately shared her story about growing up there and migrating to the United States as a single mother. She spoke of her painful, swollen legs, which caused her hospitalization. The mood changed once the doctor walked in and sat down; the patient squeezed my hand and insisted that I stay by her side. The doctor explained her medical diagnosis which was cancer. After discussing the next steps in her treatment, the doctor left the room. The patient and I sat in utter silence for several minutes. She then began to share her thoughts. I was awestruck as she encouraged me to follow my academic goals and pursue a career in medicine. Despite receiving a life changing diagnosis a short while ago, this patient found solace in sharing words of support. I had just met her, yet we formed a connection. I wanted to do everything I could to help her emotionally process her diagnosis. Encountering patients at their most vulnerable points in life solidified my desire to join the medical profession as a physician, I want to be an advocate for my patients as a compassionate and knowledgeable physician. 
My first exposure to healthcare was the responsibility I had caring for my older brother. He was born with severe autism and epilepsy and does not speak. However, over time, I became aware of his many non-verbal cues. I am able to recognize his physiological gestures, such as a tilt in his head position which indicates he is going to have a seizure and I make sure he is in a safe position to prevent any injuries. I recall an evening in our hot, humid one-bedroom apartment; I heard a loud thud from the kitchen. I found my brother on the floor and my mom turning him on his side to ensure his safety. He was having multiple seizures and there was a brief moment of recovery however, he continued to seize. This episode was a new symptom that we never experienced; the decision was made to take him to the hospital. As we drove to the hospital, I held him as he seized in the back seat.  His seizures continued as I wheeled him into the reception area. This was the first time I felt helpless because there was nothing more I could have done to help him. I assisted my mom, and three other nurses help control his movement to insert an intravenous line into his arm. There he was given the medication Ativan and he was soon sedated. I fell asleep to the beeping cardiac rhythms of a patient next to us. This medical emergency occurs yearly. Caring for my brother, accompanying him to doctors’ visits and being his healthcare advocate, provided the initial spark for me to consider a career in medicine. The firsthand experience in my brother's life triggered my desire to improve health and healing for others. I learned the true meaning of patience and compassion, and the profound effect that healthcare can have on improving a person’s quality of life. 
I was inspired to contribute to the medical community when I took my first biology course in the Fall of college in 2015. One way in which I accomplished this was through a nonclinical research experience. While working in that administrative setting, many patients at the outpatient office were anxious about their kidney function; sensing their concerns I would have cordial conversations with them to make them feel comfortable. I remembered the patient I saw in Mount Sinai Hospital and the impact of having someone to speak to during a time of need. During the conversations with these patients, it became evident that there were other areas to explore that could put the patient more at ease. In conversation with Dr. Jia Ng, we embarked upon such a project. Since then, I have a firmer grasp on the intricacies of the research, the project is still ongoing. I hope to take this newfound love for research with me into my medical career, where I can cultivate my passion for evidence-based medicine, to benefit my patients, as well as the medical community at large.
My qualities of compassion, perseverance, and diligence will inform my journey into becoming a caring and culturally competent physician. I am very thankful for helpful mentors, teachers, and, most of all, for my older brother. He is a special gift to my family, and we care for him. Helping him is my guiding motivation and inspiration for wanting to make a difference in the lives of others.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Many inquiries were revealed during an open discussion about the office transition to electronic forms. My coworkers were apprehensive regarding electronic documents as they expressed concerns about possible repercussions. A secretary mentioned a HIPPA security risk because the tablets could be lost if not diligently monitored. I felt that tablets were secure by reducing the likelihood of misinformation from paper legibility issues. Despite having different perspectives, we collaborated to advance our main objective, patients' well-being. We coordinated a hybrid solution to give patients a choice of using paper or electronic forms. Through this experience, I learned to listen to the diverse perspectives of others and cultivate new approaches to conflict. As a future physician, I anticipate moments when I disagree with my colleagues; however, it is vital to remain open and value different perspectives to develop professionally and improve the healthcare I will provide to my patients.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I had the privilege of working as a mentor at Van Guard High School through the Liberty Partnership Program. A large percentage of students are minorities who are from economically disadvantaged backgrounds. One student expressed her passion for math; however, she was frustrated at the lack of access to resources for higher-level courses such as calculus. Coming from a low-income background, I understood her agitation and the relevant social issues. I empathized with her discomfort and remained truthful. Despite the many obstacles that may arise, her goal of getting a higher education is a marathon, not a sprint. I encouraged her to remain resilient and spoke to her about college. It was inspiring to hear her enthusiasm about her future career aspirations to explore the engineering field. As a mentor, I had the privilege of impacting and guiding an eager group of students while gaining new perspectives and skill sets that I hope to contribute to Rush Medical College.
7_-_COVID_Impact: During the pandemic's peak in late March and early April of 2020, I tested positive for COVID and had symptoms for over a month while experiencing new health issues. I canceled my MCAT retake exam and postponed my application to medical school to focus on my health. Once I recovered, I resumed my position as a medical practice associate at Columbia University Medical Center. Due to the strict COVID guidelines, patients were not allowed to have guests accompany them in the waiting room during their procedures. This is a point in time when I saw healthcare workers' compassion and empathy placed at the forefront because we became the support and assurance for the patient during an emotional moment in their lives. Essential workers had to remain resilient and adhere to the ethical obligations to care for patients needing medical treatment amid a global emergency. This experience fortified my desire to become a physician working on the frontline during future public health emergencies.

personal_statement:
“Did I do something wrong?” I thought to myself while pacing around the empty halls. As a volunteer in the pediatric unit, I had become accustomed to patients being delighted to have my company. So, when Annie threw a lunch tray at my face while screaming “GET OUT!” I found myself at a loss. Her glare conveyed such a striking mixture of anger and pain that I sought to understand her. Several weeks of board games and puzzles later, she confided to me that she had received her repeat PET scan results. I could not imagine the daily difficulties she faced as she reflected on the strain her systemic illness put on her and her family. It was heartbreaking to hear her contemplate if her condition caused her parent’s divorce or the peers in school who made fun of her disfigurations. Knowing the struggles she faced and sensing my role as a confidante in her life, I dedicated part of my shifts to visit her.
I truly felt fortunate to be able to comfort her with my presence and privileged to be privy to her vulnerabilities, but an internal frustration arose as I came to realize my limitations. I could not even understand a simple Web MD summary of her disease, much less make a tangible impact on her medical conditions. This realization sparked my interest for a career in medicine and I knew this was a path I needed to explore more deeply. 
To better understand the role of a physician in a healthcare team, I worked as a medical scribe in several inpatient and outpatient settings. I particularly enjoyed the North Point Wellness Center - a holistic medical, dental, and mental health center tailored to serve minority and often uninsured patients. The sensitivity and ingenuity the family physicians demonstrated while building learning environments with patients of various backgrounds resonated with me deeply. The physicians would address various levels of medical knowledge using easily understandable terms and explain various practical solutions based on the patient’s preferences and available resources.
 One shift, a physician’s assistant asked the physician I was working with to help develop a health care plan for a medically complex, primarily Korean-speaking patient. Unfortunately, the patient did not regularly see a healthcare provider, resulting in poorly managed chronic diseases. Upon entering the patient’s room, I could tell she was uncomfortable as she was squirming in her chair and gazing at the floor. There was no interpreter immediately available as it was a hectic day in the clinic. Hoping to put her at ease, I cheerfully chimed the proper greeting for elders in Korean and offered to interpret informally until one did arrive.
Despite a language barrier and the pressure of a full clinical schedule, the physician remained relaxed and sat down at eye level with the patient. While holding their hand, she expressed her worries about the patient’s current trajectory. She then declared,” But I like patients like you. Because there is so much chance for improvement.” She balanced explaining the harsh realities of the patient’s diseases while remaining optimistic and inspiring, presenting several lifestyle and medical interventions to improve outcomes.
Throughout that year, I saw that patient several more times. She appeared progressively more vibrant and healthy, which was supported by the clinical findings. She attributed these changes to that first encounter where she finally understood the problems she faced. Because of this physician’s deliberate communication, the patient realized the importance of following up on her chronic diseases, and her trajectory improved. Observing and interpreting for both parties made me realize building rapport with patients was deeper than simply understanding what is said. This rewarding experience piqued my desire to become a physician who empowers his patients with the knowledge to change the course of their health. Furthermore, I learned the importance of educating patients in an accessible manner, tailored to their unique needs, communication styles, and preferences.
During my gap years, I have been working as an anesthesia technician in the OR. There, I have continued fueling my curiosity towards the science of medicine. What factors determine what type of anesthesia the patient will receive? What muscle/nerve tissues are currently visualized on the ultrasound? My questions were perpetual, and it was rewarding to apply my knowledge. Sometimes the anesthesiologists would answer my questions and other times I would read the available medical textbooks. I could use this knowledge to reassure patients when they had misunderstandings about a procedure within my scope. Over time, I was able to piece together patient factors and predict which surgical cases would require my services. There was always something new to learn if I sought it out.
As a physician, I hope to continue learning and use the knowledge to empower my patients. Having been on the periphery of the physician-patient relationship for years, I look forward to the day where I develop connections with my own patients. The trust bestowed upon me by patients during my medical experiences and the use of medical knowledge to improve patient’s lives serve as an impetus for why I am pursuing the profession.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
In my junior year, a friend confided to me about her living situation with her partner. It was jarring to hear her recount the abuse, and even more heartbreaking that she thought no one would believe her. The next several months helped me begin to understand how hostile and biased the world can be against women._x000D_
Her attempts to break the lease were met with ‚Äúwe need more proof than just anecdotes,‚Äù which made finding a new apartment difficult: especially with limited finances. I was sure that pressing charges was the next step, so I contacted legal offices. When she found out, she became very upset. I learned that women who experience domestic abuse more often keep it to themselves for fear of public backlash, and taking this to court would likely involve a lengthy legal battle that would bear no fruit._x000D_
I now know that there is much to learn about the world that others live in, because it is not the same as mine. I am ready to keep an open mind so that I may do that._x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As a part of our research, my team and I created community cooking classes for the Hmong community in Minneapolis. The goal was to empower recent immigrants to continue cooking their traditional dishes with affordable ingredients they had access to in Minnesota. We hoped to counteract the impact adopting a western diet had on the microbiome and metabolic diseases. But as the number of people expanded, so did our scope. I proposed coordinating with a diabetes educator to make our recipes diabetically conscious. Participants shared their own recipes and favorite ethnic grocery stores. Seeing the general excitement and approval from students, especially the elderly members was very rewarding. Members organized carpools and bought food items in bulk to distribute amongst the class so that those without transportation were able to get groceries. Most of all, I felt fulfilled seeing our efforts helping enable this community access to nutritious food.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
‚ÄúCode blue. COVID rooms.‚Äù I rushed down the hall with the crash cart. In a cramped room, the team frantically bustled around the patient. Several hours later, despite our best efforts, a time of death was called. I looked at the MD in charge. The sweat inside her PPE could not completely disguise her tears. The 4th patient we lost that weekend. My own eyes began to moisten. But this wasn‚Äôt the time for that- my work phone was ringing again._x000D_
In contrast, the pandemic‚Äôs effects on my personal life might seem trivial. My dad was forced to move to Korea for work. No confidante to share my daily joys or struggles with. Home has become just as silent and eerie as the hospital rooms I worked in. This made me more mindful of the patient experience. Considering how difficult isolation is while healthy, I can only imagine how difficult it is while ill._x000D_
Medicine is a sacrifice. My pandemic experiences have only solidified this. But they have also solidified my desire to be a part of the solution.

personal_statement:
I sat down, sweat dripping onto the rickety plastic chair, and directed a woman wearing a straw hat to sit on a shaded wooden bench across from me. I felt as frayed as the tarp above me as I began to speak. Here, behind the backdoor of a plywood-tented clinic, I asked her to share the place, time, and brief description of her last experience with sexual or gender-based violence. I explained that I only needed to know the last time; not the first time and not every time. I told her that she only needs to share with me what she is comfortable with. That this would put her on a list for the women-only section of the camp and connect her to other resources. I made it clear that I am not a doctor. My role was to listen and collect information. I could not provide the help she needed. She stood suddenly and vomited over the fence, her straw hat falling off her head onto her back. She wiped her mouth with the back of her hand, sat down, and started speaking. I listened and wrote: forced prostitution, Turkey, three days ago. How do you fit this into a two-line box? 
 
Each time, I made sure to sit facing the women, and that I do not sit between them and the way out. I made sure to bring a bottle of water. If asked, I would hold their hand. I made sure to meet their eyes. I filled out the boxes. I made no false promises. I let them know what I can do and what I cannot. I’ve done these interviews in six languages; the one word everyone knows: “Doctor.” I found myself wanting to respond to the call of  “Doctor, doctor”. Instead, I had to shake my head and tell people there were no doctors that day. 

At fifteen years old my only association with doctors was the one standing between me and my life plan: a college cross-country skiing scholarship and the Olympics. I had trained year-round since I was nine, driven to pursue that dream. An injury taught me the fragility of my body and how entirely my health determined my path. I spent frustrating years in and out of arm braces, supporting my teammates who achieved our Olympic dreams. Five years later, a doctor who understood the impact of my injury promised the level of function I needed. I struggled to balance the demands of rigorous college courses and the work to heal both my mind and body. With the aid of a team of dedicated health professionals and six appointments a week, I healed. My experience with injury as a teenager fortunate to have access to healthcare was in contrast to what I saw working in refugee camps.

When I lost skiing I lost my team, part of my identity. I found a new team when I volunteered with humanitarian aid organizations in the Moria Refugee Camp in Greece. This team was focused on and dedicated to being in service to others. The complex social, legal, and health issues presented in the field of humanitarian aid are fascinating. I was overwhelmed by the amount of need and the lack of resources. I saw doctors from around the globe spend their vacation working in a clinic stocked with not much more than Tylenol. “Doctors are needed,” as my friend put it simply, “because we need to be alive to make a new life.” They made patients feel seen, heard and cared for despite limited resources. When I asked refugees the one thing they wished the world understood, “that we all wish to go home” was the resounding response. For millions of refugees, home is a place they can never return to, that I alone cannot give them. However, I could return to my home, Alaska, and support the Alaska Native people in their fight to stay in their ancestral lands. 

I have the privilege to come from a home so well cared for by its people, that it is mistakenly called wilderness. I work in the Alaska Tribal Health System, which serves to keep Alaska Native people healthy and in their homes. I found unexpected parallels between the Greek refugee camp and rural Alaska in the complex legal, social, and cultural issues facing these populations: poor sanitation, overcrowded homes, and limited access to healthcare. Today I work alongside physicians who spend their time learning about the people they serve and seeking to enhance their cultural competency with the aim of providing the diverse care that Alaska Native people deserve. What struck me about the Alaska Native people was the fierce determination to stay in their homes and the incredible sense of community. I want to be a doctor who strives to understand the historical and cultural backgrounds of my patients, meeting people where they are with what they need as individuals and as a whole. 

The woman with the straw hat came back the next day saying that since talking to me yesterday she cannot close her eyes for fear of reliving her experience. “Please, I want the doctor,” but I could not be the doctor she needed that day. While I could not fully help in that situation and cannot give someone a home, I can help support a person to stay healthy, enabling them to keep or build their life. I strive to understand the larger social, cultural, and legal systems that impact individuals' lives and their health. I desire to be the doctor I needed when I was injured, the doctor needed across the globe, and the doctor my home needs working for its people.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
One experience which helped me realize how colonization and systemic issues such as racism and intergenerational trauma impact an individual‚Äôs life was the Alaska Blanket Exercise (ABE), a participatory exercise on historical trauma that fosters respect and reconciliation. Participants hear descriptions of historical events, including genocide and cultural oppression, as land is figuratively stolen from under our feet and devastation brought by colonizers through war, disease, and substances. _x000D_
_x000D_
In the talking circle that follows, indigenous and non-indigenous share our experiences and visceral reactions, learning, and healing. This training and others like it have made me realize the importance of increasing my own knowledge and cultural humility and has provided a framework to look at data sets and see beyond the ‚Äúsocial determinants'' to roots in the colonist practices which formed them. Three years later, I support the ABE, helping the program reach those around the state.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
I worked in Moria refugee camp with asylee seekers of various backgrounds, including places where it is illegal to be gay. Instead of having to hide being queer, I realized it served to connect me with those I was working with. While there were many differences between us, I found parts which I identified which I realized one of my first days working as coordinator of a women's health clinic while completing a triage form for a Congolese woman. I got to the question asking what type of birth control she used. Without missing a beat, she grinned and replied, ‚Äúwomen,‚Äù and I, understanding what she meant, grinned as well. Hoping in that small moment, I could convey that she was understood, seen, and accepted for who she was. _x000D_
_x000D_
On the surface, this is an experience in which I was working with those unlike myself. However, I found that I could utilize my lived experience as a queer woman to find commonality which allowed me to connect with and serve this population._x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact:
I moved to Alaska just before the pandemic to support my Aunt with a stage IV cancer diagnosis, limited to supporting from six feet away. I was stuck across the country as my family in Vermont contracted COVID early in the pandemic and sustained financial stresses. I lost several family members who died alone, the all too common tragedy of the pandemic. _x000D_
_x000D_
I was able to find employment as a Research Assistant; however, many projects were halted during the pandemic, which continues to affect distributing and publishing. Despite volunteer opportunities closing, I was able to join the local volunteer fire department, experiencing how COVID impacted our community from the front lines. Bringing patients to the ER provided unique access to a hospital setting as shadowing opportunities closed. _x000D_
 _x000D_
COVID stalled and changed my trajectory into the healthcare field, but through the hardships, I found unique and rich experiences that strengthened my desire to attend medical school.

Hrdshp_Comments: Coming from a rural town, finding a career outside of the coal mines was unheard of, and the idea of pursuing a professional degree was almost sacrilegious. In my hometown, poverty was no stranger and affordable housing was often unavailable, making my family move 3 times in just as many years. My father took a job as a truck driver, working 14-hour days and hauling cargo across the United States. My mother picked up shifts at our local gas station at night, after my sister and I had gone to bed, to provide another source of income. Despite their hard work, my family could not afford basic amenities like electricity, qualifying us for government assistance like CAP and food stamps. The school district that we could afford to stay in was under funded and did not supply opportunities to explore my growing passion of medicine. My circumstances did not discourage me from following my passions. Instead, I found other opportunities that would allow me to provide care and nurture a career in medicine. When life got tough, I continued to maintain a positive outlook and remained resilient in the face of adversity. I have learned to use my experiences to empathize and aid those who are facing similar struggles.
personal_statement:
“Uncle, I love you”. These words came as a surprise to me, especially since I was only 16 and not even an uncle yet. This phrase sounded even more shocking coming from my 55-year-old camper, who I was currently bathing after having spilled a bowl of chili on himself at dinner time. Coming into Camp PARC, I realized what I was signing up for, but I had no idea what to expect. I was excited to take a volunteer counselor position for three adult campers who had intellectual and developmental disabilities. I had been looking forward to this week and was excited to make friends with people in my community who are often overlooked. As the week progressed, I realized that providing emotional support when they missed their parents or giving hugs after singing their favorite songs were the reasons why many of the campers came back each year. They didn’t come back for the finger painting or bingo; they came back to see their friends whom they didn’t converse with outside of the camp session. Through my time at camp, I recognized the importance of relationships and how they will impact me as a future physician. As I pursue a career in medicine, this experience has made me recognize the uniqueness in each of my future patients, as well as the importance of developing a trusting relationship, like I was able to do with my campers. From my experiences volunteering and being a traveling personal care aid in my rural community, I have come to learn that taking care of people involves more than just understanding each person’s diagnosis; it is about listening, empathizing, and encouraging them to freely share information, concerns, and actively engage in their own care. Throughout my time as an aide, I found that people need compassionate and sensitive caretakers who are willing to listen to their patients’ difficulties that may not always be solved by a prescription. I hope to be a physician who appreciates the differences between each patient and can form a trusting patient-provider connection for everyone with whom I provide my care.
	My time throughout my rural hometown has made me recognize that a disparity in healthcare is present in my community. I have learned that there is a dire need for education on the need for good hygiene, the importance of food availability, and the promotion of self-care throughout my town. Although there are services that can benefit the people I took care of, many patients that I cared for did not understand how to complete the forms or even how to communicate that they needed help. Being from a rural, underserved community, disparities are often prevalent in people who are isolated geographically and economically. I, like most of the patients I took care of, live over 45 minutes from the nearest hospital, making a medical appointment unfeasible and a financial burden that many cannot afford. Through my research at my university, I learned that health disparities are present across the world. In a remote village in Tanzania, citizens face dangerous levels of fluoride in their drinking water, causing health burdens, like fluorosis. I am researching a cost-effective and functional way to remove fluoride using clay that is found in the village, potentially alleviating the symptoms of fluorosis for the benefit of the community. Through these experiences, I have recognized the impact of water quality on health and have developed a passion for family medicine and providing healthcare to rural, underserved populations like my hometown, as well as the village of Olkakola, Tanzania.
My decision to pursue family medicine was further solidified when I shadowed Dr. Lowden, a local family practice physician, on a “normal day in the office”. I saw the wide range of cases he attended to, as well as the lasting relationships he had formed with his patients. When witnessing his caseload, I saw that medicine is not always linear. In fact, many patients had comorbidities, like diabetes and high blood pressure. I learned that treatments were often interconnected and knowledge from many areas of medicine are required to create the best plan of care for each patient. As a work-study student at a hospital in Pittsburgh, I have helped physicians improve their work by identifying current literature that is relevant to their patients’ diagnoses. Exploring medicine through my time with Dr. Lowden piqued my interest in family medicine as he was often the first physician patients would see when they were developing symptoms of a new affliction. His willingness to listen to patients and create a comprehensive evaluation to understand the patient’s ailments confirmed that family medicine is my passion. Through my time with Dr. Lowden, I realized that the relationship between provider and patient is different and unique than what I have experienced. I witnessed patients being totally vulnerable to their provider, baring secretes they would never divulge to anyone else, experiencing a relationship that I have never seen before. I hope to one day implement the same techniques that Dr. Lowden used, like active listening and reassuring the patient, to create a welcoming environment for anyone in my care. I want to help and care for people in the unique way only a provider can, using education, research, and experience.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Recently, I was granted the opportunity to perform research in Belize where I performed water quality testing in remote villages that only spoke Mayan and relied on the native flora for their medicines. Being there for a month, I was able to immerse myself in the cultural and medical practices that were commonplace in the country, witnessing various roots being made into tea for upset stomachs. In my previous travels to other countries, I was able to develop an understanding of diverse customs, but my experience in Belize allowed me to witness the influence of medicine on a diverse population. My time exploring the village shaped the way how I will approach medicine, developing my cultural competence in providing care for diverse groups. My research experience shaped the way how I will perform medicine by recognizing the value that each patient may have on their culture‚Äôs natural remedies for ailments and how I, as a physician, can help bridge the gap with modern treatments.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: In my community I started an after-school program for elementary students whose parents were facing struggles like addiction and suicide. As a high school student, I volunteered at my local elementary school and was informed of the devastating situations that many kids were facing in my community. So, I, with the help of my advisor, created an afterschool program where we provided a meal, help with homework, and companionship to younger students. I recruited 15 high school students to help provide this mentorship to elementary students who would deeply benefit from interactions with someone in the high school. By ensuring young students could receive this positive attention, I believe that I have helped my community by creating a safe haven for children who are experiencing unfathomable hardships. This opportunity created a lasting impression on my future and has inspired me to pursue primary care in a community where I may be able to provide this same service.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The pandemic and the impact it made on my family‚Äôs health has greatly influenced the way in which I want to perform medicine. While my sister‚Äôs health was rapidly declining, I saw the lack of readily accessible healthcare in my rural community. The lack of representation in medicine in rural areas had always been an important issue for me, but by experiencing the physician shortage and how it impacted my family, I became focused on the importance of primary care, and specifically, family medicine. Seeing the value that physicians placed in their patients and performing care for members in their community during the pandemic was monumental. I was inspired by the overarching dedication to service by healthcare workers and I realized that being able to contribute to medicine by providing care to rural communities will allow me to ensure that in the event of another healthcare crisis, I can be on the forefront and aid people in need, like my sister.

personal_statement:
The more you ride, the more you fall. Some falls leave you with only dust on your back to show for it, others have you icing that back for a few days, but either way, you’re back on that horse as soon as you can be. I was fortunate that I avoided any major tumbles for my first six years with horses, but once I began to compete at the collegiate level, I gained a new appreciation for my helmet. My healthcare journey followed a similar trajectory. 

A physician father and physical therapist mother made early exposure inevitable; it took me until fifth grade to realize that placing IV’s wasn’t a “dad skill” like mowing the lawn or manning the grill. My mother still has the picture of thirteen-year-old me with my cow heart: gloves tied on at the wrists, braces bared in a rare grin. That delight was just as intense for me at twenty-one, while watching procedures on living human hearts—and all UTHSCSA wanted from me in return was a few pages of writing. After that summer, I was flying as high as I’d ever been, and wanted nothing more than to get the second half of my undergraduate education over with so I could get back to the “real world” of medicine.

Congratulating yourself for a jump is a great way to miss the next one—shortly after San Antonio, I fell. It had been a decade in the making, and there were plenty of warnings: I had the constitution of a Victorian orphan all through grade school and high school, with eleven broken bones to my name by age seventeen. Every specialist offered a different guess, from lupus to celiac disease. By the time I went away to college, my issues had resolved seemingly of their own accord, but we were never able to nail down why the sound of pencils gave me migraines or why I hadn’t ever hit my growth spurt despite every hormone panel coming back normal. 

So of course, I got sick. Weeks became months, and lethargy became borderline narcolepsy. If I wasn’t at work or in class, I was sleeping. I forgot to eat. I dropped a pen once, leaned down to retrieve it, and woke up the next day. A wiser student might have put school on hold, or at least asked for help. I blame stubbornness as much as the feverishness for that particular oversight: I couldn’t stop. I had to finish my last two years, hurry up and get my degree. Plenty of students were exhausted in college—I was fine. 

I reached the end of my denial phase halfway through senior year, and pushed through my final semester so I could hurry up and rest. I set my career aspirations aside and fell into the familiar routine of blood tests and sleep studies and consults, and thanks to several doctors and two very dedicated parents, I began to improve. This was true in more ways than one. I’d always hated talking to people, so when I was healthy enough to work, I made that my full-time job. Door-to-door salesmen are paid on commission, so my paycheck was directly tied to my performance. 

I found a job in the equestrian world, next, training horses to teach and riders to jump, and spent my extra hours at an assisted living home nearby, exploring a very different side of patient care. I still remember the look on one woman’s face after a flippant, “Da svidanya” at the end of a day; Maria was thrilled to converse in her mother tongue, despite the clumsiness of her partner. Tending to her and the others in her hall was excellent practice for helping my maternal grandparents when their health worsened in 2019. 

When COVID forced the world into a gap year, I was restless for more than one reason, and had plenty of time to think about why. I had graduated three years ago, and had no plan now beyond, “work”. Medicine loomed, rather than beckoned; I couldn’t possibly be a doctor, after stepping away for so long. But I still felt an itch, a craving for the pace and the rigor and the puzzles. My work as a STEM and test-prep tutor during lockdown both rekindled that spark and bolstered my confidence: I was twenty-five, not fifty. So shortly after I went back to my equestrian job, I made arrangements to leave it. 

Midway through my first month as an anesthesia tech, I was struck by a sense of having found my place. I have had days where everything went right, and days with two crashes in a row. I have learned to take pride in the small things, like neat cables or five-second art lines, and grown adept at fixing problems before they arise. That last is a recurring theme for me, in each of my very different workplaces, and likely the result of co-parenting several of my siblings. I am a restless tech, lost without a machine to fix or a case to start. 

But monitoring techs don’t fix people; we just measure them. And I want more. Even after sacrificing vacations, losing patients hours after laughing at their jokes, and working twenty-four hours, straight, I want to be a physician. I want to troubleshoot people, not touchscreens. I want it the same way I have always wanted to point my horse at a line of jumps. Never mind the blisters and bruises and broken toes; I get to fly.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: If I had to pick one experience, the most profound for me was my nine months of door-to-door sales. My job took me all over the greater Troy area (in MI), and the neighborhoods ranged from quite affluent to the projects. But whether the house had a gate I had to unlock or a front porch that was falling apart, what lay on the other side of the door was a person. I was surprised by how relatable many of my customers were; I could have a conversation with any one of those folks, about their kids or their favorite team or the schoolwork they were struggling to complete online. I once had a twenty-minute conversation with a Venezuelan man about Spanish League Football (‚Äúsoccer‚Äù). The bottom line was, everyone had something they loved to talk about, something that made them open up. It‚Äôs just a matter of finding it.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I have a soft spot for the elderly thanks to my closeness with my maternal grandparents, which I owe in large part to the months I spent caring for them while working full-time. They were getting into their late seventies and lived just over half an hour away from the rest of us, which was becoming less feasible as time went on. My aunts and uncles all wanted them to move closer, as my grandmother‚Äôs health was deteriorating at an alarming rate (anxiety, paranoia, insomnia). My grandpa was overwhelmed, so myself, one of my uncles, and my sister rotated on a caretaking schedule from February to June. We cooked dinner, helped with meds and bedtime routines, and woke up early to fix breakfast and get them ready for their day before starting our own. After a hospitalization and a few family meetings, we finally moved them to a fixer-upper that we all pitched in to fix (I did the wallpaper and a lot of the painting), where they were able to live two peaceful years close to their grandkids.
7_-_COVID_Impact: COVID nudged  me back toward medicine by a) providing me ample time for self-reflection as to what I wanted for myself and b) providing a vastly expanded market for my little tutoring business (it wasn‚Äôt so little in the year 2020)! Once I started teaching science‚Äîand re-learning a lot in the process‚ÄîI realized how much I missed it. One thing led to another, and by the time the pandemic ended I‚Äôd sent off applications to several labs and hospitals both in-state and out. I ended up moving back home to Milwaukee to be able to work in an OR, and the rest is history.

Inst_Action_Desc: In the 2nd semester of the academic year 2014-2015, my assigned Organic Chemistry (CHEZ I)  lab partner and I were accused of working together on a pre-lab assignment which was supposed to be worked on individually. These pre-lab reports were to be completed prior to the day we performed that specific lab experiment. For one of these pre-lab reports, my lab partner was confused on what needed to be done so I decided to explain the instructions to him and give him a summary of what was expected. Although we worked on it individually, we ended up having almost similar calculations and as a result, we were accused of working on the report together. I took responsibility for my actions and got a grade of zero on that assignment. I realize now that I should not have given him that summary. This taught me that it is important to assess the type of assistance required in any given situation before jumping in to help. Since this incident, I have not had any other violations and I have gone on to continue serving and helping people while also adhering to the policies put in place for my roles as a volunteer, medical assistant and medical technologist. Moving forward, I plan to continue growing, helping and assisting those in need while also following protocol.
personal_statement:
For the first ten years of my life, I lived in Bamenda, Cameroon, one of two English-speaking cities in an otherwise exclusively French speaking nation. I was about the age of eight when one evening, my brothers noticed I was sweating a lot and I felt warmer than usual. My parents rushed me to the nearest hospital where they were told I would need blood work done. Although my dad tried distracting me from seeing my blood being drawn, I remember looking over, seeing my blood and screaming. In that moment, a man, whom I later knew as Dr. Mukete, walked in and joined my parents in trying to calm me down. I don’t remember exactly what he said but as he spoke, I noticed he had a French accent and he was very accommodating.

The language barrier caused other economic and social divides to form in all areas of life, especially in healthcare. As a result, back then, rarely did physicians transfer from the higher paying, French-speaking areas of the country to the English-speaking cities. It was also very unlikely for a French-speaking physician to be friendly with an English-speaking patient or family. However, throughout my stay at the hospital, Dr. Mukete made efforts to comfort, relate, and inform my family and I of my progress and status. He would speak with us and make us laugh when he came to my bedside to check up on me. This effort made me feel like I could trust him. One afternoon after he finished speaking with my dad, I worked up the courage to ask him if he was from the French part of the country. I eventually came to find out he was French but had completed his college and medical school education in the English part of Cameroon. In an effort to bridge the divide within the nation, he decided to move to Bamenda for work.

At the time, Dr. Mukete’s drive and venture didn’t mean much to me and I often wondered how hard it must have been for him to learn English and leave his family behind. However, years later as an immigrant in the United States, my family and I relied on community events organized by people trying to bridge the gap. These events allowed us to network when we were seeking employment, obtain free health screenings when we didn’t have health insurance and get to know people in the community. These events opened up many opportunities for my family and I. Inspired by them, I started volunteering with organizations like the Minority Association for Prehealth Students (MAPS) while attending VCU, Christ Chapel Outreach and Convoy of Hope to provide food, clothing and basic medical exams for people in homeless shelters and low-income neighborhoods. Volunteering with these organizations caused me to realize that availability of resources such as good schools, grocery stores, good healthcare centers, libraries etc. are somewhat based on the economic standard of that community. This was the kind of divide Dr. Mukete was trying to bridge in Cameroon’s healthcare and his commitment showed me that no matter how small one’s effort is, it can have a significant impact at not just the individual level but that of a whole community. As a result, I decided to become a vessel of hope, awareness and representation as needed in medicine.

Throughout my journey, I have had several highs and lows. My weaknesses to work on and strengths to build on were made evident but through it all, my passion for medicine was solidified. So, while building better study habits in the G-squared advanced biomedical science program, I also learned how to better prioritize and manage my time. These skills helped me become a better student and a more confident test taker, which served me well when I took the MCAT. Additionally, becoming a part of the healthcare team as a medical technologist and medical assistant was very beneficial to me; working both in the lab performing tests and, on the floor, triaging patients, taking vitals, histories and assisting the physicians in minor procedures. I am able to witness the different processes physicians use to diagnose and treat patients. I also see the impact a physician can have on a patient based on their approach to the patient’s complaints and symptoms and how they advocate for them. Having a better understanding of the limitations in healthcare in addition to the overall knowledge I have acquired so far have helped me mature into a better and stronger individual. Although there is still a lot for me to learn, my experiences have allowed me to know what to expect and have prepared me to take on any challenges in medical school and beyond.

Nineteen years ago, Dr. Mukete showed me that being a physician goes beyond just seeing patients, making diagnosis and treating symptoms. It is being able to be a representation and a resource to people including underrepresented minorities. Additionally, it is about educating people with facts about health care and the benefits of taking care of one’s health for the betterment of the community as a whole. Being a physician is providing the best possible care to both the patient who can afford it and those who can’t. Finally, being a physician, I know long term would put me in a position to help take care of my family financially. I don’t know where Dr. Mukete is today but I am grateful to have been seen by him that night I fell sick.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I currently work as a clinical medical assistant at George Mason University (GMU) Student Health Services. GMU has a very diverse student population including international students. As a clinical medical assistant, I have to be able to interact with these students in a way that not only makes feel helped and cared for but also be respectful of their different cultures and background. I have come to understand that just because something may be normal for me doesn't always mean others are comfortable with it and I believe when providing treatment to patients, that needs to be taken into consideration. In addition, we see many of these international students at the clinic and language barrier can sometimes be an issue. This helped me become more patient and understanding since they might not always get the full idea of what is going on during the visit. As a result, I make sure the student's questions are answered to the best of my ability and that their complaints are addressed.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I believe that societal and structural determinants of health are just as vital as the physiological aspect. Good healthcare policies gives way for better treatment and healthier patients. Furthermore, healthy patients make healthy communities. It was this understanding that fueled my passion for health equity and as a result, I joined the Anti-Racism and Inclusive Excellence (ARIE) Health Equity Committee at GMU. In this committee, we develop ways to help everyone know their implicit biases towards people from different ethnicities, had some diversity training geared more towards learning to treat all patients with the same care and concern, surveyed students seen in the clinic to make sure they were properly taken care of and looked into other ways in which we could better serve the student population. It has been noticed that patients feel safe coming to be seen at the clinic because they feel heard, are respected and their specific complaints are addressed.
7_-_COVID_Impact: As a full time medical technologist at Reston Hospital Center, I was required to only work 40 hours a week with no overtime. Every hour I worked as overtime had to be approved by the laboratory manager. However, all of this changed in the spring of 2020. Like most hospitals, we had limited resources with increased demand for care. As a result, we worked over 40 hours a week and tested twice or triple what we would normally test during a regular flu season. My coworkers and I quickly became each other‚Äôs support system as we spent a lot more time together. Moreover, staying with a parent who was considered high-risk, I had to quarantine at hotels several times due to exposures at work. Working under such conditions allowed me to not only see but also experience some of the undesirable parts of medicine. This provided me with more insight and understanding about the career I am trying to get into and helped me be better prepared for it.

Hrdshp_Comments:
Due to domestic discord and the cultural implications of divorce and separation, my family and I moved over 20 times throughout my childhood. My mother singly raised my 3 siblings and I, pursuing nursing to help take care of us. When situated, she worked many hours, leaving me the eldest child as a “back-up parent”.

The instability, and some medical emergencies that paused my mother’s ability to work, resulted in instances of homelessness, and use of safety net programs such as food stamps and unemployment assistance. I was on free/reduced lunch throughout grade school, and often missed or repeated units previously taught due to moving in the middle of a school year. Starting college at 15, I came of working age and used these funds to augment my aid to pay for groceries, sending extra money home. In light of my limited time, I enjoyed palliative care research as it was both an academic challenge and method of meeting financial needs.

My upbringing highlighted the importance of independence, being self-directed and resilient. I am grateful for these tools as they allow me to tackle the difficulty of becoming a physician and push through adversity. I want to be a physician in spite of my father’s occupation, and hope to lean on my life experiences to better support and advocate for others.
personal_statement:
As a child, I moved more than 20 times, living in over 15 cities and 2 countries. Family dysfunction and my mother’s job as a traveling nurse fed into the constant relocation. In one move, I fell asleep in our packed minivan leaving the desert bordertown of El Paso and woke up in the urban city of Newark. Through it all, I had to learn unfamiliar cityscapes, adjust to new schools, master vernaculars, and develop often fleeting friendships. With this ordeal of instability came the gifts of adaptability and empathy. Faced with the frequent change, I learned to navigate various cultures and connect with diverse people. Always the new kid, I sought to understand and include others, making sure they felt the openness that I received. I came to value relationships, short-lived though they could be, and the cultivation of relationships forms the foundation of my goal to be a physician.

In college, I was my mother’s caretaker post-hysterectomy. This was scheduled after yet another hospitalization for a transfusion due to fibroids. In the surgical waiting room as her companion, I thought back to my first time accompanying her. I was 7 years old and had gotten out of school early. What I thought was an errand-run turned into a visit for a mammogram where I learned that my grandmother had passed from breast cancer. Though explaining as best as she could, my mother did not quell my many questions. Confused by what had happened with her family, I asked why she had to go into the scary machine, while frantically trying to grasp the breast diagrams posted in the room. Then as a young adult sitting alone in the waiting room, I was reminded of that feeling of helplessness, with the matured understanding that her healing would be complicated by stress and financial strain. Duty and obligation became tenets of my upbringing as I watched my mother sacrifice her health to support our family.

Nothing attracts college students like free food, and as no exception, I found myself at a Pre-medical Organization for Minority Students (POMS) meeting, looking for pizza and information. This turned into a significant stop along my journey as three years later, after serving in a variety of roles to fulfill our mission of empowering minority pre-health students, I was elected president. One goal as president included linking with local high schools to extend our pipeline to medicine, utilizing the access to underrepresented minority students afforded by my urban campus. When "Aaron" approached me at an event, peppering me with college application process questions, I never expected the impact my informal mentorship would have. Months later, with his college acceptance in hand, Aaron contacted me, thanking me for my help in navigating the process. With POMS, I was able to help reduce barriers to education, with representation being a vital first step in diversifying the face of medicine.

While kindling my interest in medicine, I found that working in palliative care research taxed my capacity to care for those living with life-limiting illnesses because I was frequently left feeling helpless. One student with cystic fibrosis had a packed schedule requiring airway clearance treatments, reminders to eat, and clinic visits–all on top of going to class. Here I came as an assistant, adding on that we regularly complete questionnaires. Despite how sobering our conversations could be, I looked forward to interacting with these patients and wanted more. With a stop in the real world, I transitioned into oncology as a coordinator. Fully integrated into the clinic, I was humbled with the access to patients’ lived experiences. One day I met “Martha”, a gardener who developed metastatic breast cancer. Under the bright lights of the small clinic room I listened to her story. She had been in remission for several years, and recent back pain led to the discovery of a recurrence. Martha’s goals were to see her daughter give birth in a few months and to play with her son’s toddlers. She valued treatment, with maintaining quality of life as a predominating goal. In our next conversation 6 months later, she expressed her accomplishments, crediting her physician and care team. Although my interactions with metastatic populations seldom ended happily, they signaled that I aspired to play a more direct role in care administration, to educate and learn with patients, maybe adding hope.

My interactions with patients have helped me to appreciate the trust they place in physicians, allowing access to their intimate moments. Through exposure, I have developed, now cherished soft skills, particularly in establishing relationships. How physicians act upon their training and knowledge, as well as the medical field’s need for adaptability bolster my view of medicine and treatment as a holistic pursuit. I desire to help those of underrepresented backgrounds enter medicine, as I do not want to be one of few but one of many. My mother's healthcare interactions helped me to learn about access to care and utilization. I also came to recognize the impact of support and advocacy. Medicine for me lies at the crux of my passions and those qualities have propelled me along my journey toward medicine, leveraging my passions in pursuit of service.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: After college, I remained in town for another year working with my research team. In that year, I became increasingly involved in the community. The topic of one community meeting I attended was that another high-occupancy housing was to be torn down - a reliable option for those needing to affordably live close to downtown. The community was vocally worried, as there was now a pattern. With the different tech companies adding headquarters to the city, and the expansions of existing entities - long time residents were being priced out. They discussed strategies, race, gentrification, both the historical context and recent widespread examples like Washington, D.C. I had been in Pittsburgh for years and it was the first time I truly engaged in this manner. As an out of state student, one can isolate the city as the setting for my school, but there is life and blood running throughout. I was able to think about my diversity, actively listen and empathize with those who were different.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I was a volunteer tutor with For Love of Children (FLOC) working with under-resourced students. I saw many values were critical to my interactions with the students. One student did not want to be there, and that showed in his attitude. Though they warmed up in their own ways, I imagine that consistency and attentiveness helped. It was not my place to force a child to learn, but to be present for them to help facilitate their progress. Towards the end of the year with my regular student, as news of the pandemic was rising, she recalled that I worked in a hospital (I was a research coordinator), and asked questions about how people got sick and how the virus worked. Of course, I did not want to speak out of turn without express permission or what I was trained to do, but it was heartwarming that she felt comfortable enough to ask and trusted me with her questions. I was honored to be able to offer a calming voice of hope, though there was a great deal of uncertainty at the time.
7_-_COVID_Impact: While I was still a coordinator, our primary disruptions included partial furloughs, a hybrid work environment as we had patients receiving critical cancer treatment, and helping our medical oncology clinic screen patients for COVID-19. In one breast tumor board meeting, the medical oncology, radiation oncology and breast surgery teams received guidelines to cancel or postpone non-essential procedures, such as lumpectomies and mastectomies. They met to see which patients could be medically managed indefinitely. The physicians submitted a great deal of exemption requests because they knew their patients could only reasonably tolerate a moderate delay. The advocacy was admirable to observe, and allowed me to mature my outlook of medicine to broaden the extent of teamwork, and responsibility required. In addition, For Love of Children was interrupted, as they did not yet have the support to move everyone online. When programming resumed, I was in Cleveland beginning my master‚Äôs program.

Hrdshp_Comments:
My parents divorced at a young age. My mom and I depended on food stamps while she made minimum wage.
 
I did not learn to read in elementary school until the third grade. Because of my school district’s budget cuts, vision screening was not offered at the time. It was not until I was in the fifth grade I got my first pair of glasses.
 
In high school, my mom opened a restaurant after getting laid off due to the recession. Profits were minimal, so I refused pay as long as she could not pay herself. Instead, I picked up a second job as a sales associate.
 
While scholarships and loans covered most of my college tuition, I still worked to make ends meet. Unfortunately, it all took a toll on my academic performance, and I ended up with grades that did not reflect my capabilities.
 
My mom’s ailing health also impacted my ability to focus on school and my long-term goals. Less than two weeks before my MCAT exam in 2017 and 2018, my mom was hospitalized. Though these events were distressing, I took the exams, scoring much lower than my practice tests.

In 2019, my mom was diagnosed with metastatic cholangiocarcinoma. I assumed the role of her primary caregiver and could not take courses for my post-baccalaureate during this time.

These experiences have helped me develop resilience in the face of adversity.
personal_statement:
From a young age, the words “autoimmune hepatitis,” “cirrhosis,” and “ulcerative colitis” were part of my vocabulary. For most of my childhood, it was just my mother and me. I accompanied her to all her monthly doctor visits and ensured she took her medications. Despite following the doctors’ recommendations, she was frequently hospitalized for various medical and surgical emergencies. This took a significant toll on her mental health. The fear of bad news sometimes stopped her from seeking vital care, a concept I could not understand at the time. I felt helpless.

In 2017, after over a decade of severe ulcerative colitis, my mother’s doctor found over two dozen precancerous lesions in her colon. He recommended a preventive total colectomy. Due to her end-stage liver disease, she needed a new liver, but a potential diagnosis of colon cancer eliminated any possibility of receiving a transplant. Overwhelmed with the prospect of another major surgery, my mother immediately refused the colectomy and shut down further discussions. When we returned home, I wanted to understand her decision. She wanted to live as long as possible but feared uncontrollable bowel movements, potential leaks, and modifications in her life associated with an ostomy bag. I realized she needed people who could help her work through her concerns. I connected her with support groups, ostomy nurses, and mental health providers to address these concerns. She began to believe she could still live a healthy and happy life. She ultimately agreed to surgery and received the support needed to adapt to her life with an ostomy.

My journey with my mother planted the first seed for a career in medicine. I want to help others with similar circumstances align their treatment with their goals and values. During my experiences as a medical scribe in the emergency department and an internal medicine clinic, I enjoyed the critical thinking required to balance scientific concepts while addressing patients’ needs. While working with a primary care physician, I was inspired by how physicians develop therapeutic alliances with patients through their personal connections and longitudinally following their health. Like them, I also wanted to support patients and their families during their most vulnerable times.

During my time as an anesthesia technician, I observed a difficult decision made during a family conference for a critically ill patient in the intensive care unit. The physician presented the family with options for either a complicated heart valve replacement or comfort-focused care and explained the slim odds of surviving surgery. They had to decide on her behalf as she lacked decision-making capacity. I had a similar experience with my mother toward the end of her life when she, too, was presented with two options: comfort-focused care or surgery to place biliary drains. The chance of successfully placing drains was less than 1%, and the risk of infection was extremely high. It was a painful decision, but we ultimately pursued hospice since the procedure would not improve her prognosis and furthermore, did not align with her goals of care.

With tears streaming down their eyes, the family made the tough decision to pursue the complicated surgery despite the low odds. My knee-jerk reaction was thinking how this was not the right decision. However, as I watched the physician navigate the difficult conversation, tease out cultural intricacies, and ultimately respect the family’s decision, I realized this most aligned with the patient’s beliefs. In this moment, I recognized how vital a physician’s role is in understanding patients’ wishes in all care, especially when involving complex decisions. This inspired me to continue growing and expanding my cultural awareness to be the best advocate for my patients. I know there will be times when I may disagree with patients’ decisions, but my role will be to help them make their own decisions, not decide for them.

I wish to communicate openly with patients and understand their needs so I can empower them to make medical decisions that align with their health beliefs and values. Since becoming a crisis text line counselor, I have learned that the best communication lies in active, empathetic listening. To effectively de-escalate someone’s crisis or collaboratively problem-solve, I must first understand their perspective.

I previously thought the best physicians were those with the most scientific knowledge and advanced technical skills. While those qualities are still important, my personal family and work experiences have shown me that these qualities must be combined with deep compassion and empathy for patients’ emotional and physical needs. Watching the healthcare professionals I admire connect with and guide their patients through difficult times has solidified my passion and drive to become a physician who is knowledgeable yet humble, empathetic, and aware. I will carry these lessons and perspectives with me as I work towards becoming a physician who emphasizes patient-centered care with shared decision-making to best advocate for my patients’ needs.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I traveled to Panama on a medical mission to provide free healthcare to their indigenous population.
