It was a life-changing experience that helped me expand my cultural humility. I struggled to communicate with the locals when I did not have access to interpreters. However, over time, I became more comfortable with non-verbal communication and realized I could still have meaningful interactions despite the language and cultural barrier. I learned that delivering competent care and effectively communicating with patients from different backgrounds requires an understanding achieved through experience. Because of my experiences with people from various backgrounds, I will prioritize effective communication across all communities and strive to provide culturally competent care to my patients as a physician.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
During the 2009 recession, my mother lost her job and health insurance. She could not afford treatments for her ulcerative colitis. Years of flare-ups ravaged her colon and led to a total colectomy, which could have been prevented with adequate healthcare access. Witnessing complex social and economic barriers preventing patients like my mother from accessing essential life-saving medical care gave me perspective and fueled my ambition to work with and advocate for uninsured and underserved populations._x000D_
_x000D_
I aim to be a part of the progress to tackle the barriers these patients face. In early 2020, I volunteered with Be the Match‚Äôs event to promote diversity in the bone marrow registry during Black History Month. And as a crisis counselor, I have gained insight into others‚Äô mental health needs and learned how to effectively communicate with those in crisis. I am confident my experiences give me a unique perspective that will only help me connect and build trust with my future patients.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
COVID-19 had a profound effect on my life. As both of my grandparents lived in a senior living facility, my family and I feared they were at high risk of contracting COVID-19. Unfortunately, our worst fears came true, and both passed within a week of each other due to COVID-19 in April 2020. This was especially hard, as none of us could be by their side at the hospital._x000D_
_x000D_
As it was for everyone, the pandemic was an isolating time. The lockdown occurred five months after my mother's death. I was unable to pursue group grief counseling. Additionally, due to my employment as a frontline healthcare worker, I had to isolate myself from my family. There were also many months I worked overtime because of outbreaks among hospital staff and being constantly understaffed._x000D_
_x000D_
While the pandemic was one of the most challenging years I have faced, I am thankful for the growth that has come out of it. These challenges have built a resilience that I will be able to draw upon during medical school.

personal_statement:
catalyst (n): a substance that enables a reaction to proceed at a faster rate or under different conditions than otherwise possible

	From a young age, I knew I would pursue a career in a STEM field. I asked for a microscope for my sixth birthday, solved math problems at the dinner table for fun, and saved my chemistry homework for the end of the night as a “reward.” I realized my interests might lend themselves well to medicine during my freshman year of high school, when I dissected a fetal pig in my biology class. What had once been a chore of a class turned into an exciting exploration of the animal’s body: I marveled at the yielding of the tissue under the scalpel’s gentle pressure, the expansive network of red and blue blood vessels, the precise organization of the interconnected organs. I eventually realized there was a way to “do something like this” professionally. I decided to become a doctor.
	I spent my adolescence preparing for a career in medicine, completing all my college’s pre-medical courses and shadowing physicians. My first major clinical experience—volunteering as a medical scribe at a rural clinic—highlighted the profound impact that physicians can have on their patients’ lives. I watched first-hand as the providers’ care plans, gradually but unquestionably, helped their patients recover from severe chronic illnesses. My time at the clinic reinforced my desire to enter the medical field and led me to scribe in an emergency department after graduating from college. Jumping from primary care to the world of emergency medicine was certainly an adjustment, as every shift brought something different: minor concerns like bone fractures, life-threatening diagnoses like strokes, “sneaky” conditions like heart attacks masquerading as acid reflux. Rather than shying away from the fast-paced, unpredictable environment, I reveled in the new challenge and truly thrived. I was sure I wanted to go to medical school.

	What shifted my “want” to a “need” was my brother.
	My parents first described my brother as being born with “a broken heart;” at the ripe age of two and a half, I couldn’t say “transposition of the great vessels,” let alone understand what it meant. I knew he had surgery a few days after his birth, saw a cardiologist regularly, and had scans every few years—but he was an otherwise healthy kid. His last cardiac MRI was set for the spring of 2019, and we assumed this would be the end of his specialized medical care. However, the MRI yielded an unexpected finding: a large mass behind his heart. He spent the next few days getting poked, prodded, and scanned before finally being diagnosed with Stage IIIB Hodgkin lymphoma.
	My brother had cancer.
	Once my brother started chemotherapy, my shifts in the emergency department took on a whole new meaning. I had the most medical knowledge of anyone in my family and often translated jargon into layman’s terms for my parents; even with my years of clinical experience, however, I was little help when it came to hematology and oncology. Every day in the emergency department, I tried to learn something that would help me better understand my brother’s case. The doctors spent time teaching me after each shift, explaining the meanings of different lab values, physical exam findings, and even some radiological images. Perhaps more importantly, they showed me how to speak to people in immensely stressful situations. After watching the doctors interact with both patients and their loved ones, I adjusted my tone, vocabulary, and comportment when talking to my own family. Although balancing my full-time job and my brother’s care was immensely stressful, this period of my life cemented my decision to pursue a career in medicine.
	
	Six months of chemotherapy and three years later, my brother is officially in remission. I have spent the years since his treatment strengthening my skills so that I can be the best physician possible. Following some time away from clinical settings to study for the MCAT and protect my family from unnecessary COVID-19 exposure, I began working as a Medical Assistant at a dermatology office. I reveled in the opportunity to combine my scribing skills with direct patient care. I conducted patient intake interviews on my own, drawing from my previous clinical experience to ask the right questions. After years of observing doctors “do” medicine, I finally had the opportunity to assist with numerous biopsies—and I loved every moment of every procedure. From dermatology, I shifted my focus back to academia and pursued a Special Master’s in Physiology (SMP) at Georgetown University. This program allowed me to experience the academic rigor of the first year of medical school, reinforcing some of the concepts I had learned in college and introducing me to more complex physiological topics. Most importantly, my success in the SMP Program reinforced my belief that I am ready for medical school.
	Without my brother, I still would have wanted to become a doctor. His journey, however, was a catalyst for my decision to enter the medical field; now, I cannot think of anything more rewarding than pursuing a career in medicine. I believe I have proven that, given the opportunity, I am prepared to succeed in medical school and the medical field.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: My family‚Äôs experience and cultural diversity has greatly shaped my views on multiculturalism. My grandfather, uncle, and aunt immigrated to the United States from India, Nicaragua, and Somalia, respectively. By growing up in such a diverse family, I learned at a young age that our cultural differences are what make each of us unique and interesting. My family members‚Äô life journeys have made me significantly more empathetic towards all immigrants, regardless of their country of origin or legal status. Moreover, my mixed-race, multicultural family taught me to appreciate and respect people who look, speak, and act differently than I do. As I grew older, I learned that many American families are not as diverse; most of my high school classmates grew up in culturally homogenous households, and some of my college friends grew up in all but segregated communities. I now realize how lucky I am to have grown up surrounded by such rich, varied cultures.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: While I was Chief Scribe in the Virginia Hospital Center Emergency Department, the hospital changed its scribing program from individual scribes for physicians to a shared scribe model, where one or two scribes assisted all the providers. My fellow scribes and I were disappointed, as the new role offered us less clinical exposure. To ensure the shared scribe model would be as satisfying as one-to-one scribing, I surveyed the scribes and providers to identify potential tasks for shared scribes. I then explained how I envisioned the shared scribe model to the Department Chair: a mix of paging specialists, reviewing charts, preparing discharge instructions, and documenting patient encounters if time allowed. As a result of our meeting, the Department Chair developed a better understanding of the scribes‚Äô frustrations; from then on, he worked closely with me to improve the shared scribe model. Through our collaboration, we developed a successful scribing program that is still in use today.
7_-_COVID_Impact: From late July 2020 until August 2021, I worked full-time as a Medical Assistant (MA) at Georgetown Dermatology, a private practice in Washington, DC. As an MA, I grew comfortable working under pandemic conditions. Today, I hardly notice when I wear a surgical mask, as I had become accustomed to wearing an N-95 for eight or more hours per day. I better understand the risks associated with working in healthcare during a global pandemic and the policies and practices meant to ensure the safety of patients and front-line workers. Perhaps most importantly, I gained tremendous respect for the physicians who worked tirelessly and selflessly to treat their patients through the pandemic. Even though they were risking COVID exposure, the doctors in my office always quieted their patients‚Äô fears of the virus while providing care. I remain impressed by the grace, patience, and compassion that Georgetown Dermatology‚Äôs physicians showed with every patient interaction.

personal_statement:
The treatment that I received after being diagnosed with a blood disorder (immune thrombocytopenic purpura) at 15 years old inspired me to pursue medicine. The interventions that I received helped and eventually cured my condition, but it was the caring and attentive manner of my physician that impacted me the most and gave me the motivation to actively pursue the study of medicine to impact other people’s lives as a physician.
Over the last several years, I have gained a wide variety of clinical experiences and patient interaction that enhanced and solidified my interest in pursuing medicine. During my undergraduate studies, I had the privilege of shadowing in The Johns Hopkins University Pediatric Operating Room. There I observed a wide-variety of cases and gained an appreciation for the teamwork required among health care providers before, during, and after the operations. For example, I saw that significant meticulous care and expert knowledge was applied in multi-physician operations such as interventions for scoliosis and saw the large positive impact that medicine can have in a relatively short amount of time. Not only was I exposed to the surgeries themselves, but also to how the physicians worked with and collaborated with others during their surgeries. It was very rewarding to see the patients recover and respond well to treatment in the recovery room as well. I implemented these principles of collaboration and attention to detail as a medical scribe in various medical clinics and specialties at the University of Miami. 
In addition, I had the privilege of shadowing Dr. Dileep Yavagal, who has become a mentor of mine in many ways. In his neuro-interventional suite I expanded my knowledge of neurology and experienced first-hand how neurologic interventions are perfomed for strokes and other vascular conditions. I was able to see how Dr. Yavagal intervened and improved the health of patients with technological advancements that were discovered to save people’s lives. This helped motivate my desire to not only practice medicine but perform research, as I have seen how research impacts and changes medicine to improve patient care. Experiencing Dr. Yavagal’s successful interventions for carotid disease and aneurysms, for instance, further inspired me, and reminded me of the great potential I have to one day help improve other people’s health as a physician. 
I also observed and engaged with patients in Dr. Hoover’s family practice clinic, where I helped to familiarize them with the clinic and developed a professional, compassionate rapport with them so that they were comfortable receiving care. I plan to serve people from all walks of life as a physician and this experience allowed me to grow and mature. I also observed as Dr. Hoover treated generations of a family and saw her caring bed-side manner when there was a passing or loss in a family. I plan to implement the same caring bed-side manner when I am working with patients. 
As a survivor of domestic abuse, I am also moved to help others that have gone through a similar devastating experience. I decided to volunteer in a woman’s shelter in my hometown that helps the underserved: Lotus House. During my two-and-a-half-year tenure as a weekly volunteer at Lotus House, I saw the positive impact I made in the lives of the children and mothers. I volunteered during the weekly children arts and crafts activity nights and with other women’s shelter activities throughout the year. I learned how to effectively discuss and teach various activities to the children, which is a skill that will translate to my future work as a pediatric physician. I could see the impact I was making on these children through their smiles and excitement. I look forward to making positive patient improvement and having similar positive interactions as a physician. I also taught children in Brain Fairs at the Miami Science Museum where I educated children of all ages about nerve impulse transmission. These interactions with children helped to supplement my clinical experience and solidified my aspirations of pursuing pediatric medicine. I plan to continue volunteering and serving not only the underserved in my hometown but on a larger national and eventually global scale as a physician.
Despite difficulties, I have not given up on difficult paths. My passion for medicine has driven me to persist through difficulties and seek applicable experiences on my road to medical school. I have seen how medicine has improved my own life further reinforcing my desire to serve others directly along with advancing science and medicine on a global scale through research as a physician-scientist.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: While volunteering at Lotus House, a local women‚Äôs shelter in my community, I served people of diverse backgrounds different from my own, which allowed me to enhance my ability to understand those unlike myself. I taught and engaged with children and mothers from a wide variety of backgrounds, most notably African American and Hispanic. I connected and worked with all the children, and engaged with them in a loving, compassionate manner as I taught them the arts and crafts activity of the day. I also displayed patient and understanding if a tantrum, or the like, occurred. The children respected me and they worked well together despite their differences. I enjoyed seeing the children grow and mature week after week and became more comfortable teaching them the arts and crafts activity of the day. As time passed, I became more confident with working and engaging with the children of all backgrounds, and I plan to do the same in the future as a pediatric physician.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: While volunteering at West Kendall Baptist Hospital in Miami, FL, I noticed that there was a patient who did not have any visitors. On the weekend, I got flowers and went to visit with the older gentleman for a few minutes. He was very moved, and I was glad to have made a positive difference in someone‚Äôs life. On a larger scale, I had the opportunity to impact the community at Lotus House, a women‚Äôs shelter in my community of Miami, FL. Once a week, I taught the children the arts and crafts activity of the day. In the time that I had with the children I was satisfied that I was able to assist in giving them a nurturing, safe environment to learn and explore. Seeing the children run to me to greet me or smile and welcome me week after week was very rewarding. This experience helped to solidify my aspirations of pursuing pediatric medicine. I plan to implement the same compassionate manner at the bedside with my future patients.

Hrdshp_Comments: My family falls into the category of economically disadvantaged. After a stroke she had in 2004, my mom lost her job as the director of nursing and required unemployment for one year. My siblings and I needed jobs to pay for their phone bills, vehicles, car insurance, school trips, etc. We had reduced lunches at school. I started working at the age of 14 as a paperboy, then at McDonald's once I turned 16, the required age to begin in New York. During college, my mother tried to create a dog breeding business along with her day job to afford to send my siblings and me to college. We still require additional financing from my uncle and grandparents to pay for school. I had also spent a lot of time working rather than studying in college, and during the summer, I held jobs close to home because I couldn't afford to live where I could find an opportunity to shadow. There was no public transport in my hometown, and the closest hospital was over 10 miles away.
personal_statement:
From an early age, I knew that healthcare workers had to be dedicated to their patients as well as team members of a larger healthcare system. My mother, a director of nursing, brought home stories of her time as an ER nurse and times she had to discipline employees for failing to follow protocol, putting patients in danger. As I grew older and listened it was clear that she dedicated herself to the patients she cared for and the staff members that she managed. Similarly, I depended on my mom. If I needed to go to the doctor, she helped me. If I was saving up to go on a trip, I anticipated that she would help me out if I didn't have enough money for gas. This dependent relationship is so normal it goes unrecognized until it's gone. In 2016, she suddenly passed away. She was both the breadwinner and the only good relationship I had with a parent; I was forced every second to recognize her absence in almost every aspect of my life. Her caregiving skills allowed her to excel both in medicine and as a parent. 
My mom died in the middle of my college career, leaving me alone and no longer with a safety net. After finishing my degree, I was broke. A family friend sold me a 2002 Saturn for $200, whose muffler would soon fall off, to start a job in Arlington as a medical assistant at a dermatologist. I had borrowed more money to pay for the first month's rent plus the security deposit, and luckily my soon-to-be roommate agreed to the cheapest apartment. I even had to buy the most affordable mattress off Facebook marketplace, strap it to my car, and carefully drive down the highway for 30 minutes for something to sleep on. After working for a bit, I worked myself up to a slightly better-paying job. Since my car was impounded soon after I was hired, I was fortunate that I could commute via public transportation. This independence forced me to be disciplined, sacrifice, and improvise when dealing with limited options. I stopped wasting money such as going out to eat, developed healthy workout habits, and followed through on commitments that I made to both others and myself. If I wanted to pursue medical school, I needed to excel at my job and study for the MCAT. My solitude and work environment matured me by instilling better time management and prioritization of my pursuit in medicine. It is these qualities that lead to my success at my job and in graduate school. 
After finding some stability, I've no longer become reliant but someone to depend on. I picked up a job as a tutor for extra income not realizing how important it would be. I first noticed how far I had come in my relationship with a student that I tutored. The inherent dynamic between the tutor and the student is that they expect you to be knowledgeable and make little to no mistakes. This was the innate aspect of my relationship with Jake. Beyond this expectation, we learned about each other's idiosyncrasies, hobbies, and even favorite music, which made the teaching process feel more natural and ultimately helped him learn more than if we were strictly business. Jake started a ritual of playing each of our favorite songs before we began our sessions. I believe that these little exchanges established trust beyond the built-in confidence that a tutee has for their tutor. We didn't exclusively discuss his homework problems but also his habits and study schedules that worked around his hobbies. This relationship allowed for a better understanding if he was having a rough week and how it affected his schoolwork. And when he scored well, we celebrated together.  
Soon after came another win, as my bosses promoted me to a clinical manager role. It became even more clear that others had appreciated my personal growth and trusted me with the responsibility associated with the position. In this new role, I recognized how much patients count on health care workers flawlessly completing their jobs. A patient's biopsy was missing after a passive medical assistant ignored protocol. After a few calls between myself, the patient, and the doctor, getting the patient to come back to the office and confide their health at our practice again was a challenge. I spent countless hours focusing on other tasks to enhance the quality of patient care we provided. Among other protocols, I reinvented our procedure to recount biopsies to avoid another incident. I created a comprehensive training protocol after a medical assistant incorrectly administered local anesthesia to a patient. I wasn't just responsible for myself; My coworkers, bosses, providers at my practice, and patients required that I be meticulous, disciplined, and adaptable.  
Relationships often come with fundamental expectations that can often be taken for granted. It is further shaped by how people live up to these expectations. It is the acknowledgment of these struggles that creates a unique relationship between medical staff and patients. Patients unreservedly leave themselves and their health in our hands, and it is the medical staff's responsibility to work tirelessly to justify that faith. Not every career has such a bond; I am grateful that my path is built on that concept. My life experience will be integral to my execution of that responsibility.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Although I am personally not part of a marginalized community, I have watched discrimination occur and stand up to any exclusionary behaviors. Growing up in a rural, low-income area, I learned about people when I went to college. One of the most formative parts of my undergraduate was joining the debate team. During the debate, you were assigned a position on a prompt that can range from world conflicts to social justice. The best part was that success required you to argue a position you may not personally hold. This allowed me to step outside the view I grew up with and have a critical lens of the belief system I once knew. It inspired me to join other student groups because I wanted to learn from people from different backgrounds. As a biologics coordinator, I often had to fight for patients against insurance companies to cover medications. I understood how a patient's condition affected their life and how their financial situation impeded their ability to get these medications.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Another formative experience in my undergrad was spearheading a project to make the campus more accessible to people with disabilities. In addition to my love medicine, my passion is helping others and fighting for a larger cause. Growing up, my grandmother was wheelchair-bound due to her multiple sclerosis. I remember the difficulties we went through in restaurants and other spaces for her to even be ther. I had the chance to help people with disabilities on a larger scale during my Student Government work. It was rewarding to interact with students and faculty and hear about how their disabilities shaped their campus experience and their idea to improve our campus. We conducted a tour of the campus to document which spaces need renovation to be wheelchair friendly, beyond ADA guidelines and updated the accessibility map to include all doors that are wheelchair accessible and inclines that were considered too steep to be added to the map.

Hrdshp_Comments:
I grew up in a multigenerational household where my mother worked as a house cleaner to support my disabled brother and me. I am also a child of divorce. I found myself working from eight years old to help my father stay afloat while simultaneously assisting to care for my brother, splitting time between both households. Both my father's and brother's physical disabilities put a ton of strain on our family economically. We did not have much monetary means but at a young age that didn't bother me. I always qualified for free lunch programs, but so did many of my close personal friends. Yet as I grew older and moved through the public school system in the bay area, I became more and more aware of the stark socioeconomic gradients that were present. 

I am the first person in my family to attend a four-year college institution. As such I have covered a great distance academically. Early on I struggled with learning how to ask for help, which stems from a high degree of responsibility placed on my shoulders from a young age. As a first-generation college student, I seek to succeed not only for myself but for my family and community. Thankfully I qualified under the FAFSA for the Pell grant and California grant which, in addition to taking student loans, afforded me the opportunity to pursue my education.
personal_statement:
It was in a student-run clinic in San Francisco where I came to understand that there exists a need for doctors who look like, speak like, and come from a similar background as I do. Engaging with Spanish-speaking only recent arrivals from Mexico and Central America, many of whom shared stories of homelessness, human trafficking, and the pursuit for better opportunities. I was made a student to their struggles, informing my perspectives of what community medicine can and ought to be. I knew I belonged in medicine as the hours would bleed away effortlessly as I carried out my work: Spanish translation, taking vital signs, and advocating the needs of patients alongside medical students and preceptors. In the twenty-five months I spent as a member of clínica, I found a sense of purpose, challenge, and agency in the service to my community. It is this aspiration to lead a fulfilling and uplifting life that pushes me forward in the pursuit of primary care medicine. 
 
My wealth of unorthodox and difficult family experiences have enhanced my ability to connect with a wide variety of underserved populations. I grew up in my grandparents’ home in Santa Clara in a multi-generational working-class Mexican-American household. I was raised in a collective effort by my mother, grandmother, disabled father, and others. I worked in the family business throughout my childhood, waking up at 3:30 AM to go set up and sell at local flea markets with my father, arriving back home again well past dark. Growing up in such an environment I developed a firm work ethic, family values, and a strong sense of racial identity. I am a child of alcoholics, a child of divorce, and the son of a Navy veteran grappling with PTSD and homelessness. From these lived experiences I gain understanding and compassion for the daily struggles and trauma which often go unnoticed. While such themes as substance abuse, illness, and trauma have informed my understanding of empathy and care indirectly, my struggles growing up have taught me resilience.  
 
The youngest of four brothers, for the first seventeen years of my life I witnessed my older brother's battle with Psoriatic Arthritis and substance abuse. I internalized his struggles and they, above all else, have led me to Medicine. I had to watch the police take my brother away from me in handcuffs, and I witnessed him try to put the pieces of his life back together again. Every time he would take a step forward, the progression of his disease would push him two steps back. My brother struggles to walk most days, his pain is constant, and depression his companion. Late at night, I would hear my brother’s labored dry heaving in the bathroom on the other side of the wall. The sound of exhausted retching and blood mixed with his tears broke my heart. The most honest answer I can give as to why I want to be a physician is that somewhere rooted in the shadow of my childhood is a deep desire to fix my brother so that he too could lead a normal life one day. I now know this ideal to be unrealistic, of “fixing” my brother to be lacking in nuance and impossible per se. But the spirit of it remains the same: Striving to meet others where they are, to relieve suffering, and promote wellness.
 
Young men from my community, the neighborhood where I come from, don’t leave. Many don’t pursue higher education, and end up cemented in place, or worse. I left directly from high school to a four-year undergraduate institution before I was ready. In those days the opportunity to move away, to live in a new city and open a new chapter in my life, was my only way to escape my situation. My brother was severely verbally and emotionally abusive throughout my childhood. I have in the past akin the environment at home to that of a battlefield. Harsh and ugly words pouring out like chlorine gas, smashing plates-slamming doors like hand grenades. I moved to San Francisco for college. Free of the abuse in my home environment I came to better know myself and thrive. Educationally I have covered a great distance, having made mistakes along the way. I felt I was playing catch up to many of my peers early in my college career as I struggled to adjust to university workloads and learning how to study. The path that I chose when looked at in conjunction with  the growing pains associated with years of emotional and verbal abuse was not easy, but it carried me to this point, and that has made all the difference.   
 
University exposed me to an education rooted in Ethnic Studies. Developing a unique understanding of its paradigms and application in relation to intersectionality and social stratification of underserved communities both in the United States and globally. Through my undergraduate institution, I moved to Spain at the age of nineteen, and discovered an unbounded passion for travel, intercultural communication, and connection. My years abroad in both Spain and Mexico have made me a lifelong learner. I look forward to bringing this diversity of experience into the medical field.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I grew up along the intersection of my older brother‚Äôs substance abuse, my father‚Äôs untreated PTSD, and my mom‚Äôs sobriety. I saw my father lose everything, living out of an old 02‚Äô Dodge van in front of a grocery store. My brother was taken away from me in handcuffs in elementary school. I grew up bi-racial, pulled between questions of self-identity and values, fighting off stereotypes transposed upon me by society at large. The intersectionality in my identity and my lived experiences have given me insight into the struggles of many different communities sharing these insights would benefit many of my peers in this year‚Äôs class. The depth and breadth of experiences I have lived are my teachers, my greatest strength. The things I have walked through with my family have taught me more than any college class ever did. I hope to share this with my classmates and the communities I work in, I hope they may take the good and leave the rest. I have lived in Mexico and Spain for a year each.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: My experience working in a safety net clinic serving Spanish-speaking only, recent arrivals from Mexico and Central America alongside preceptors, medical students, and undergraduate volunteers showed me firsthand the transformative power of community-first collaborative medicine. It reinforced my commitment to creating more equitable access to healthcare for migrant populations, Spanish-speaking only communities, unhoused, and other underserved populations. As volunteers at Clin√≠ca Mart√≠n-Bar√≥, our work directly benefitted the community by providing access to a free community food bank, free clothing and winter coat closet, free mental health services, free prescription drug access, and free basic health care services. Furthermore, our clin√≠ca created a safe space for patients to come together and organize community initiatives, and share resources. I believe that sustainable and impactful health promotion can be created in working with community partners and empowering the patient.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The COVID pandemic interrupted the research work I was doing at Stanford University. My favorite aspect of my role as a research assistant at Stanford was administering neurocognitive assessments to elderly populations. With the onset of the pandemic, all of our in-person work with elderly populations was suspended. We also saw a complete removal of the hands-on polysomnography projects with youth. I transitioned to working exclusively from home during my final seven months as an active lab member, which provided me with an opportunity to work on a review paper on sleep medicine. Due to the pandemic, my only option to complete the Organic Chemistry II Laboratory requirement was online. I completed my course through the University California Berkeley extension program with much success. Volunteering in many traditional ways was shut down due to the pandemic. I was able to secure a virtual shadowing opportunity, following a group of LMFT therapists for nine months.

personal_statement:
I started writing when I was 12 after watching the movie Amelie. It was an enlightening film which explored the themes of transformation and bettering people’s lives. Like Amelie, I too wanted to create happiness in all those who surround me. The following year, I suffered my first setback when I witnessed my grandfather’s battle with cancer. Fueled by the emotions that followed, I wrote a scathing satire of my misconception that physicians were all powerful beings. As I matured, I used writing as a conduit to further understand illness, injury, and recovery. I wrote a poem about the fleeting yet precious nature of life after I protected my brother from a firearm. I wrote a script about a pirate with a peg-leg modeled after Pirates of the Caribbean after I suffered a ligament tear in soccer followed by a happy alternative ending to the Butterfly Effect after hearing about a classmate’s rebound from depression. Writing allowed me to materialize my evolving understanding of medicine and gave me the strength to move past both the physical trauma of my injury and the emotional trauma of losing my grandfather. 
As my writing matured, I began to approach life with a broader perspective and a newfound desire to serve. In college, I was accompanying a patient as part of the No One Dies Alone initiative. His demeanor was peppery as if scolding a child and his jokes, while well-intentioned, were laced with racial slurs and cut deep. Yet the crackle in his voice and the tears in his eyes betrayed his feelings of fear, regret, and sadness upon being informed that his family could not arrive in time. As I sat silently through the night, I watched the physicians and nurses in their constant efforts to reduce his discomfort and ease his passing. At the end of my shift, his eyes reflected a tranquil acceptance of his condition and he smiled with a warm gratitude as he gazed at each of us in turn. Touched by the immeasurable difference that we had made, I reconciled my childhood misconception of doctors to realize their true identity as guardians and leaders dedicated to helping others.
Being in the presence of patients and witnessing their struggles showed me the tremendous feats that physicians could  accomplish while also painfully reminding me of the limits of medicine. The weight of that patient’s passing strengthened my resolve to bring medicine to new heights by becoming a physician leader. I redoubled my efforts in academics and in extracurriculars with the goal of pioneering discovery rather than following the trodden path. I decided to major in Electrical Engineering with the hope of combining technology and medicine to formulate creative solutions to tomorrow’s challenges. My experiences abroad shaped me into a holistic student and taught me that medical advancement is closely linked with scientific research. Exposure to a diverse array of research projects has helped me develop a multi-disciplinary approach to problem solving while also providing a  gateway to explore innovation through novel fields like tissue engineering and robotic prosthesis.
As I continue my medical education, I hope to adopt a comprehensive approach to patient care. As the treatments for illness and injury continue to evolve, the tasks and responsibilities of physicians will change alongside them. But regardless of how technologically advanced our treatments become, I believe that medicine cannot exist without empathy. Critically, working at a community health clinic and serving as part of Food Recovery Heroes showed me the unique obstacles that disadvantaged populations face. While I wish to mediate the marriage of health and technology I will do so without sacrificing humanity and compassion in our increasingly data-driven world. Above all, I look forward to continued practice during my medical training and onwards to ensure that the patient and the person below them can achieve trust and understanding through the sacred patient-physician relationship.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Working at Access Community Health provided a glimpse into the inner workings of Federally Qualified Health Clinics (FQHCs) and their essential role in healthy communities. 80% of our patients are on Medicare and over 40% identify as homeless. I was in charge of calling patients to schedule them for appointments. Through conversing with my coworker who was a DACA recipient originally from Mexico, I was able to learn a bit of Spanish. I utilized this powerful tool to communicate and connect with Spanish-speaking patients when an interpreter was not available. Through sharing our experiences, I learned of the obstacles many Hispanic patients had faced in their journey to the US. I was humbled by their integrity and kindness. As a result, I gained understanding of the trials and tribulations of undocumented immigrants especially in regards to their language, healthcare and employment barriers.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As a resident assistant, I connected with a freshman who told me of his difficulty with acceptance as an African-American at a predominantly white college and of his perceived alienation from the floor due to his different background. I was taken by surprise as this resident had run for Student Government and had participated in multiple campus and building programs. I realized that the barriers to inclusion are often complex and hidden beneath the surface. When I dug deeper, he confided that the primary cause for his difficulty in socializing was his low self-esteem which stemmed from his strained relationship with his mother. Throughout our conversation, I recognized his bravery and kindness. I told him that our struggles make us unique and that everyone on the floor saw him as a friend. I encouraged his desire to reconcile his goals with his mother‚Äôs expectations which resulted in his inclusion within the floor and his embrace of his identity.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The COVID era proved to be the most emotionally, mentally and physically challenging time of my life thus far. My family was hit extremely hard and various friends and acquaintances cut ties with me due to my race. I developed insomnia from working the graveyard shift at lab and the graduate student who had been assigned as my mentor dismissed my project as futile and even went so far as to tell me to look for another job. After my failure to be accepted to medical school in 2020, my parents recommended that I change my career. Collectively, these events greatly demoralized me and I reached a low where I needed to reassess my goal of becoming a physician. However, I stayed true and believed in myself even when the world did not believe in me. By persevering through adversity, I cemented my commitment to medicine and rekindled the burning passion which first set me upon this path.

personal_statement:
Trying to mask the quiver in her voice, "Mira" probed me with questions about her eight-year-old daughter's newly diagnosed psoriasis. Our conversation touched me; my mother had experienced the same sense of helplessness when, at the same age, I was diagnosed with lichens sclerosus atrophicus, a rare skin condition. Like Mira, my mother was wrought with anxiety, with the words "no cure" glaring at her as she searched for information about my alien-sounding disease online. My mother tried to shield her concerns from me, but for the first time in my life, I knew she had no solution.

Our anxiety began to subside six months later when we met Dr. Frieden at UCSF. She was approachable and used superhero analogies to explain how my immune cells were causing my disease instead of protecting me. Still, I felt shaken— betrayed by my own body. To ease my distress, Dr. Frieden encouraged my mother to plan fun activities after my visits. As my treatment took effect, memories of ice cream at Ghirardelli Square overshadowed those of the hospital.

Fifteen years later, as a Patient Navigator at the National Psoriasis Foundation, I shared this approach with Mira. With resources and support, I watched her transform from a fearful parent into an empowered advocate for her daughter's health. The desire to share knowledge and build resilience in others is central to my pursuit of becoming a physician. I fulfill this goal on a small scale now, but only as a physician can I fully achieve it by guiding my patients' treatment journey from start to finish.

I first became seriously interested in medicine when I met an endocrinologist at a high school biology conference. I was moved by her role in helping a young diabetic athlete overcome his fear of hypoglycemia through participation in a clinical trial, investigating a new insulin pump. Until then, I had assumed that research was limited to poring over microscopes. Seeing that advancements in medicine could be used as a tool to build patient resilience motivated me to accept a position as an ENT Clinical Research Assistant in college.

On my first day in this role, I met Dr. Javer as he rushed into the ENT ward's cramped lunchroom, still in his scrubs after a 16-hour day. I was captivated by his enthusiasm as he gathered our diverse team of fellows, surgeons, and medical students. Over the next few years, we garnered academic recognition for our research on novel sinus disease treatments. But when I interviewed patients to assess their understanding of these same treatments, their blank expressions prompted me to re-evaluate the success of our research. Feeling a responsibility to ensure our studies reached our patients, I designed a pamphlet that summarized our findings in layman's terms. Dr. Javer shared my excitement as patients began referencing the pamphlet and asking more informed questions. This initiative instilled in me a passion for science communication and informed the type of physician I want to be—a bridge between cutting-edge research and the patients in my exam room.

This passion and my early interest in clinical trials led me to join Dr. Blauvelt in conducting dermatology clinical trials. I was proud to play a role in educating patients and building resilience by connecting them to front-line treatments. It seemed like our clinic reached the most underserved patients as we combated barriers posed by cost and poor health literacy. My belief was challenged when I met "Mo," an elderly Black patient who detailed a lifetime of eczema diagnoses. When Dr. Blauvelt diagnosed him with psoriasis instead, he furiously shook his head in disbelief. "That explains why my treatments failed," he remarked. To my dismay, I quickly realized that his experience was commonplace. I often encountered previously misdiagnosed patients and learned that medical knowledge of how diseases impact skin of color remains scarce.

These interactions left me determined to educate myself on this issue. I combed through medical textbooks for more information, but my research fell short, as I only found a handful of images featuring patients with skin of color. It was clear that this was a systemic issue, requiring widespread patient and physician education. A few months later, my commitment to addressing this issue led me to my current role at the National Psoriasis Foundation, where I have created and shared resources on psoriasis in skin of color. As a physician, I look forward to furthering my efforts by influencing change at the highest level. I will strive to bring awareness to the impacts of the social determinants of health beyond financial and educational barriers.

I aspire to be a physician who will form meaningful, long-term relationships with my patients and play a vital role in guiding their unique treatment journeys. My experiences as a patient, researcher, and navigator have reinforced my drive to support others in making informed health choices, which can only be achieved to the fullest as a physician. Furthermore, interacting with diverse patients, like Mo, has instilled in me the importance of breaking down barriers that prevent access to care. As a physician, I will proudly uphold my duty to act on these lessons, pushing the boundaries of current approaches to health care.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
I am a first-generation Indian-American-Canadian, who was born in San Francisco, spent her middle school years in Delhi, immigrated to Vancouver, BC at age 12, and now lives in Portland. Adapting to new cultures at a young age taught me the value of building connections with people of all backgrounds. As a new fourth-grade student in Delhi, I recall making friends by sharing my traditions like trick-or-treating on Halloween. In return, my classmates taught me Hindi at lunchtime as we scarfed down PBJs and paranthas. _x000D_
_x000D_
These early experiences cultivated a lifelong commitment to diversity and inclusion. In college, I hosted celebrations such as Pride and Eid, where students connected through shared experiences. Recently, my advocacy for the needs of BIPOC patients led to a collaboration with Dr. Tiffany Mayo to create resources on psoriasis symptoms in black patients. I hope to share my experiences with peers at RMC to promote inclusivity in our student body and patient population.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
While working as a Clinical Trials Research Assistant, I met with "Alma," a Spanish-only speaking patient with severe vitiligo who was an excellent candidate for an active study. Unfortunately, since she required a translator to review the informed consent form, she could not enroll in the trial. When I approached my colleagues to request a translator, I was initially met with resistance as they shared that trial sponsors rarely agreed to pay for this service. Disappointed by this information, I urged Alma to return with an English-speaking caregiver. Fortunately, she did; and enrolled in the trial a few days later. However, most minority patients are not as lucky. _x000D_
 _x000D_
To prevent future discrimination against Spanish-speaking patients, I took on the responsibility of working with trial sponsors to ensure our clinic received Spanish translations of all informed consent forms. I also pioneered a relationship with a non-profit organization that offers free, on-demand, translation services.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
In March 2020, I was laid off from my Dermatology Clinical Trials Research Assistant position due to pandemic-related budget cuts. My plans to increase my clinic‚Äôs recruitment of racially diverse patients and create patient education resources quickly halted. Additionally, my commitments to volunteer at OHSU‚Äôs outpatient unit and shadow OB/GYN, Dr. Christina Djabiras were canceled indefinitely._x000D_
_x000D_
Despite these setbacks, working as a Patient Navigator during the pandemic prepared me to help patients make informed health decisions and address disparities in healthcare in medical school and beyond. I shared up-to-date information with psoriatic disease patients concerned about the safety of vaccines and the risk of psoriasis flares after COVID-19 infection. I also assisted patients with scheduling vaccine appointments to combat disparities in vaccine registration caused by poor access to digital resources. Lastly, I was a support system for patients facing isolation during the pandemic.

Hrdshp_Comments: I was born in Lebanon and later moved to Glendale, CA, fleeing war and uncertain economic conditions. Knowing very little English, it was very tough to both assimilate into a new culture and learn a new language at the same time. After arriving to the US, our family lived in a studio guest house in the back of my uncle's house. We were able to move out into a small apartment, but it required continued financial assistance from my uncle and my dad working two jobs 7 days a week, delivering pizza and the odd photography job. The financial stress put an increased strain on my parents' marriage, sometimes resulting in violence. I served as a second caretaker for my younger sister, and I would take her on bike rides every time my parents fought to shield her from those experiences. Eventually, my parents got divorced and my mom started working longer hours as a dental hygienist, which required me to take my sister to school, cook for us, and babysit her after school. Growing up in a single family household was very tough financially. My father is still struggling and is on food stamps. He is working as a pizza deliveryman with COVID having devastated his photography business. Furthermore, since I am the first person in my family to attend college, I had no guidance on SAT preparation and college admissions.
personal_statement:
Heroes come in all shapes and sizes. When I was 7, a small, stubborn Toyota saved my life. On one of our trips to the local Lebanese bakery in Beirut, my grandpa parked the car in front of the bakery. In a flash, we heard an explosion so loud that it smashed the windows of our car, the shrapnel making Swiss cheese out of our Toyota. The car shielded us, we were dazed and confused, but alive.

We were rushed to the local hospital, which was swamped with critically wounded patients. My grandfather lost a chunk of his calf, and I remember the horrific chaos and feeling utterly hopeless. But like angels dressed in white, I witnessed valiant doctors zooming from one patient to another. To my childhood eyes, they were heroes wearing white capes. In the midst of utter despair, there was reason to hope. I knew right then, that’s what I wanted to be, a physician.

As conditions worsened in Lebanon, my father relocated us to Glendale, CA in a small apartment. We became refugees with poor English skills and nothing to our name. When my parents divorced, I took on the additional responsibility of taking care of my younger sister. Through my experiences in Lebanon and in Los Angeles, I was thrust into adulthood at an early age. While my childhood was challenging, the hardships and extra responsibility made me a creative problem solver and determined change-maker.

I carried this attitude to college where I started a new fraternity focused on diversity and community service. While I fulfilled my goal of creating a unique community, I also took on the added responsibility of managing finances and human resources while adjusting to the rigorous academic environment at University of Michigan. Our fraternity was very involved in philanthropy, working with organizations such as NAMI and Autism Alliance. I am proud that something that I created has done so much good and continues to do so.

At the same time, my family was struggling financially. So I turned my lifetime hobby of DJing into a job and worked almost every weekend to make some money. It was challenging to balance academics with extracurriculars and my work; however, I thrived with the added workload. Covid made my senior year more difficult, and I was forced to scale back my philanthropic efforts, as well my DJing. After graduation, I worked full time as well as some weekends and most holidays at my family's jewelry business. Through it all, what has kept me going is a realization that life becomes meaningful when it is used to help others; that the character and values are strengthened through overcoming hardships. So when opportunities to contribute dried up at home, I decided to volunteer internationally.

While volunteering at Wigmore Orthopedic Clinic in Armenia, I have come across countless patients who are living in abject poverty. Over the last six months, we have taken regular trips to the rural villages and provided free care to orphaned children who are suffering from physical disabilities. This was the only medical intervention these kids ever experienced. Working with an underserved community and providing care to a population that cannot advocate for themselves, I felt like I was making a significant difference. Moreover, in the pediatric population, early intervention can make a large impact in their health outcomes later on in life. I am very passionate about helping kids neglected by society; I want to provide compassion and hope to ease their suffering the same way I experienced as a child.

Simultaneously, I have been working with Frontline Therapists in Armenia, an organization dedicated to helping war veterans. I was immediately drawn to it for two reasons: most of these soldiers were from villages with no mental health resources; and secondly, I understood that trauma can leave profound marks on one’s soul. All too often, I saw the “thousand-mile stare”: young soldiers, in the space of a few months, experiencing a lifetime of grief, violence and misery. While war has devastated Armenia, I see a similar tragedy in the US. Volunteering at a shelter in inner city LA, I see homeless who trudge through the food lines with the same exhausted, blank looks. Like war refugees, they live in tents in the streets, surrounded by used syringes instead of mines. I met an 18-yr old male who told me about his cocaine habit, “I don’t use it because I’m addicted, I use it to stay awake so I don’t get raped.” The homeless live in extreme conditions and suffer from PTSD that comes from unspeakable trauma. Having worked with these underserved populations firsthand, I am very motivated to help them. I want to make a large impact as a physician and provide care to those on the fringes of society.

I believe a hero is anyone intent on making this world a better place. I know all too well the devastations of war including the displacement it causes and the childhood trauma. Through witnessing these horrors, the tragedy of homelessness and experiencing hardships, I have seen despair. Yet, I am filled with hope and optimism. I have also seen the myriad of ways in which one can ease someone’s suffering. That’s what those physicians were to me after that bombing. I want to one day be able to put on my white cape and continue to fight for those in need.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I started my sophomore year at a new high school where I was the only Arab student. It was not long before I was ostracized for being different. ‚ÄúTowel head,‚Äù my swim teammates would say while wrapping towels above their foreheads. I wanted to belong, but it was difficult to ignore their racist remarks. At first, I didn‚Äôt know how to deal with the bullying and I was considering switching schools. Then I realized that they were bullying me because they didn‚Äôt know anything about me or my culture. So, I invited some teammates over for dinner, where my mom cooked a traditional Lebanese feast. They agreed and this was the beginning of a cultural bridge that would continue to be built for years to come. I carried this attitude into college where I minored in Judaic Studies, eager to expand my cultural competence. Every individual has unique experiences and perspectives and I feel that in order to cultivate a cooperative environment, acknowledgement of these differences is crucial.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: In my time volunteering in Armenia, I felt I made a difference working with Frontline Therapists. Mental health is a taboo topic in Armenia and, as a result, mental health services are scarce in the country. This reality was apparent when I started helping the young soldiers in our art therapy sessions. Given the cultural stance on mental health and the strict adherence to traditional gender roles in Armenia, these young men were reluctant to participate in any form of therapy, noting that it‚Äôs ‚Äúfor the weak.‚Äù Despite the language barrier, I was able to connect with them and show them that engaging in therapy is a positive thing and nothing to be ashamed of. I am proud that I helped so many soldiers in their journey to improving their mental health, as well as increasing the awareness and access to mental health resources in the most underserved areas in the country. I also learned the importance of providing medical education in keeping a population healthy.
7_-_COVID_Impact: When the Covid-19 pandemic started during my senior year of undergrad, my family‚Äôs jewelry business was devastated. I spent a year working 60-70 hour weeks while studying for the MCAT. Philanthropic opportunities were scarce during this time so I looked for creative ways to continue serving communities in need, which led me to Armenia. For six months, I worked with children at a pediatric orthopedic clinic and counseled veterans at a mental health non-profit focused on soldiers with PTSD. These experiences have not only made me more culturally sensitive, but have also humbled me. The resilience of the patients I encountered and their struggles through poverty and disease is what inspires me to be a socially accountable physician. In the past two years, my personal growth through these experiences has made me a much more informed and motivated medical school applicant.

personal_statement:
“Adam! Adam!” The sound of retching came from the other side of the house. Bursting through the bedroom door, I see my mother holding my grandmother in the fetal position on the bed. My grandmother was vomiting blood onto a towel. The look of terror on my mother’s face, combined with the image of the red blood on the light green towel, is something I will never forget. Time seemed to stop as I relayed information to EMS while attending to my grandmother. Once EMS arrived, the next moments flew by in a blur. My grandmother was loaded onto a bright yellow backboard, taken out the front door, and loaded into the ambulance. Lights flashed and sirens screeched as they rushed to the hospital. That was Christmas morning, 2015. 

Over the next few weeks, I did my best to interpret the medical jargon, but there was nothing more that I could do. The physicians and nurses were unequivocally focused on my family and our concerns. It was as if nothing else in the world was as important as my family. I hung to their every word. Ultimately, my grandmother passed that following February and what stuck with me were the conversations I had in that ICU room. I was shaken to my core and subsequently began to reflect on many of my decisions in life. A career in chemical engineering was supposed to be my way of making a difference in the world, but something was missing. What role could I play so that other people might find refuge during the storms of their lives like I did with those nurses and physicians?

The summer following my grandmother’s passing was the same summer I spent volunteering in the Bahamas. I had hoped to have a mental reset from the past couple of years of tribulations, but it became so much more. One of the most important responsibilities in my position was the constant monitoring of the health and safety of the visiting volunteers. During orientations and days at the job sites, I often used the phrase, “7 hours.” It was a simple reminder and a word of caution denoting the time necessary for an emergency medical evacuation to the nearest major hospital in the states. One day during a roofing project, I heard a crash from behind me. I turned to see that “Emily” had fallen and put her leg through a soft spot in the roof. We locked eyes, and I saw the fear she was trying to contain. All that came to mind was “7 hours.” Sitting down next to her, we began to breathe together slowly. Her face began to soften. Another volunteer and I freed Emily’s leg and were able to lower her down the ladder. Gathering the chaperones, I informed them that Emily did not seem to have any serious injuries, but the next several hours would be crucial. We agreed to let her rest and closely monitor her progress. Luckily, Emily could gingerly walk the following day and eventually flew home without complications. It was thrilling to get the news that she had safely landed back home. There was something that spoke to me at that moment. This brief practice of healthcare was incredible. Maybe this was what I was missing.

The next summer, I was renting kayaks at a nature center when I heard the park’s UTV barreling in my direction. Park ranger “Ben” informed me that a boy had wrecked on one of the trails and needed help. When we reached the wreck, “Aaron” was crying on the ground and holding his arm. His friend, “Tyler,” was frantically pacing the trail next to him. Through the tears, Aaron informed me of a loud pop during the crash, followed by a lot of pain in his right arm. I had heard that pop and felt that pain. I had broken my arm in the same place when I was Aaron’s age. The fear I had felt was the same fear that Aaron was feeling. My heart was racing. The only thing I could think to do was to tell the story of my broken arm. When I finished my story, Aaron had stopped crying, and everyone else had calmed down too. We loaded the boys and their bikes into the UTV and headed back down the trail. Tyler’s mom was anxiously waiting for us in the parking lot and was relieved to hear that everyone was relatively alright. As their black SUV disappeared behind the trees, I remembered the ER physician who cared for me. Would the same physician see Aaron? As I reminisced on my experience, I realized I wanted to do this every day. I wanted to become the physician that would see the next Aaron with his broken arm, the next Emily with her sprained ankle, and the next grandmother with the scared family.  

We all experience storms in our lives. Sometimes we get a little damaged. Sometimes we get a little lost, but that is when the lighthouses break through the clouds to guide us back to land. The physicians in my grandmother’s ICU were my lighthouses, and I had the incredible opportunity to be a lighthouse for Emily and Aaron. Now when I see patients in the hospital and the clinic experiencing their own storms, I can be their guide as a small lighthouse in their day. These moments are what truly inspire me to continue down the path of becoming the physician that I want to be in the future. Ultimately, I hope to use all the knowledge, expertise, and technology available to me as a physician to build my lighthouse and others as tall and bright as possible to guide many more lost boats back home, no matter how rough the seas may be.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: During my master‚Äôs program, I lived with a former coworker who was also in the master‚Äôs program. ‚ÄúAden‚Äù and I had been rock climbing a few times and living together seemed like a logical decision. When the unrest in Yemen had reached a peak in early 2020, I had the opportunity to sit down with Aden and his father. We discussed the politics of the war in Yemen and how Aden‚Äôs father moved his family out of Yemen to the U.S. shortly after Aden was born. During that conversation, I learned a great deal about Aden‚Äôs family and their culture. Aden‚Äôs tendencies that annoyed me were just cultural differences that we eventually embraced. Because of this conversation and many others with Aden, I am now more aware of my own biases toward people I do not yet know. Aden and I grew very close that year, and his friendship is still incredibly important to me today. His perspective is so different than my own, and I love being able to have such open conversations with him whenever we can catch up.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: During the stages of my transition from volunteer to volunteer coordinator, I was tasked with developing the relationship between our clinic and a newly opened dental school. The community of East Knoxville has been in desperate need of a center for oral care for quite some time, and our clinic could be a pivotal location. Renovations began and the details were discussed at length. When the volunteers put out the word, our number of daily patients grew by almost 30% in a few weeks. Patients could now see a medical physician and a dentist for free on the same day. I can still see ‚ÄúMs. Jones‚Äôs‚Äù face after her first evaluation. She looked at me with the biggest smile and said, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm getting new teeth!‚Äù Ms. Jones will receive her new dentures in a couple of months. Her oral infections will be cleaned out, and she will be able to eat pain-free. All the hard work had been worth it, not just for Ms. Jones but for all of East Knoxville.
7_-_COVID_Impact: When the pandemic began, my final months of graduate classes shifted online. I had to drastically change my study habits. I appreciated the new flexibility in my study schedule, and I realized just how impactful my group study sessions were to my academic performance. I also developed new coping strategies to deal with the stresses of intense academic studying. Running, cycling, and street photography to name a few. Upon completing my master‚Äôs program, the world was still shut down which made for the perfect MCAT studying environment. However, I decided to postpone my most recent application cycle to recover from my previous application cycle. This allowed me to deal with some family financial issues and gain more clinical experience during a monumental time in human history. Seeing the pandemic from inside the hospital as a nursing assistant was quite incredible. I am now only more motivated to become the physician that my local and global communities need.

Hrdshp_Comments: not sure if applicable, my ethnic background is a disadvantaged status as well as my living conditions growing up
personal_statement:
Some people never get the opportunity to pursue what they are passionate about. I have experienced living in a country that doesn’t give much access to opportunity. I think about this a lot. About how fortunate I am to be in a position where exploring my passions is a possibility. Having emigrated from the Dominican Republic, my childhood was untraditional. I lived in a predominately rural environment where farm steading was very common. Coming to the United Sates was not an easy journey for me, or my family. Looking back at the financial and cultural hardships my parents faced, I am fortunate to have been raised in this environment. Being foreign-born also comes with its share of advantages, for example the necessity to seize opportunity. A drive that is synonymous with “The American Dream.” As such, I never felt I was at a disadvantage. More so, I benefited from having to work harder to reach the goals I set for myself. I learned how to be persistent. I learned tenacity. However unconventional my childhood was, I am grateful for it. It has been a large inspirator for me and a great point of reference in my journey of becoming a physician. 

I have faced many obstacles in my journey. However, one obstacle gave me more trouble than all others. I fell into depression during my undergrad studies. I was met with an opponent I believed to be insurmountable, and my academics suffered for it. My savior came in an unfamiliar form. A small organization called Medical Missions Abroad. I had the opportunity of starting an organization that provided basic medical attention, food, and housing to disadvantaged areas all over the world. Somewhere along the way I had forgotten why I wanted to pursue a career in medicine. My time in this organization refueled my inspirations and while practicing overseas I realized, for the first time in a long time, I was happy. Perhaps the onset of my depression was fear in realizing I may not be able to do what I love most, or rather not be able to realize the intentions I had cultivated for so long. However, a journey is not a journey without hardships and as Bob Ross would say, “we don’t make mistakes, just happy little accidents.” This was my happy little accident. In retrospect, I am thankful this happened to me. I learned much from this experience. I learned about failure, but more importantly, I learned that my desire to become a physician would not be undone so easily.

My journey does not end at or after medical school. My journey’s goal is one of self-fulfillment and medical school is just a means to obtain my true motivator, happiness. To me a physician is an artist, a conductor, a master that guides his own symphony. A calling for which I have a romantic devotion. I had this moment of fulfillment the first time I observed a Neuro-Oncologist perform a tumor resection. Dr. Komotar, Director of Surgical Neuro-Oncology and Fellowship Program. It was a 5-hour long procedure where the patient remained awake. My gaze did not shift, nor did the smile that seemed to be permanently glued on my face. Experiences like that tend to leave lasting impressions. I occasionally reflect on the events I saw that day and I make comparisons with art and music, two other things I’m equally passionate about. I liken it to that of an orchestra with all the individuals representing musical instruments working in tandem to generate one beautiful product. This is why I want to be a physician. I want to be passionate about my craft. I want to excel. I want to continuously challenge myself. Being a physician means more to me than just a job. For me it is an opportunity to exercise my passions and to actualize that dream I cultivated as a child long ago. I am going to be a physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: To preface, I was not born in the United States. I emigrated from the Dominican Republic at a young age. The term immigrant is often interpreted in a negative way. I argue, being an immigrant gives me a perspective that most people do not have. Adjusting to this country was difficult for my family and I. Culture is at the center of all homes, but what happens when you remove someone‚Äôs culture and place them in an entirely new setting? This is an insight as to what it means to be an immigrant. I consider myself bi-cultured. I identify with the culture of the United States and with that of my birthplace. Having this internal dichotomy gives me an upper hand when it comes to cultural sensitivity. I am not confined by one culture, so in a sense I am aware there are cultural differences and I always do my utmost to show my respect. The lesson to be learned here is that everyone has a unique background, if we can respect that, understanding each other shouldn‚Äôt be so difficult.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: During my undergrad I had the opportunity of working with an organization called Medical Missions Abroad. As the name suggests, this organization is a student run, student lead, mission trip service that provides food, shelter, clothing, and basic medical attention to communities all over the globe. My work focused primarily on underserved communities in Colombia. I oversaw large groups of students to these rural, underserved communities. The students and I saw, first-hand, how poor living conditions affect the psycho-social determinants of health. In fact, a large part of the individuals we helped were Venezuelan refugees that crossed borders to Colombia.  Although our actions could not make as big an impact as one would hope, I like to believe our work meant something to the individuals living in those communities. The most rewarding aspect of this experience was being able to see the smile on people‚Äôs faces and receiving gratification for our hard work.

Hrdshp_Comments: I believe I should be considered an educationally disadvantaged applicant since my secondary education did not have the resources to fully prepare me for college-leveled courses. In regards to the learning environment, many of my STEM courses like Biology and Chemistry did not have rigorous curriculums and there were no labs. More specifically, getting an A in classes that were supposed to be challenging such as AP Biology and AP Physics required only attendance, and it did not matter how poorly you did on exams. This reflected in my grades for my introductory courses and I felt like I was behind everyone else. For instance, I remember my first time in Biology lab where I had to use parafilm on an agar plate. Since it was my first time dealing with laboratory items, I asked my group mates what parafilm was and how to use it. One of my classmates was condescending towards me and asked, "How do you not know what parafilm is? Haven't you ever done a lab before?" I had always thought in the back of my head that my peers were ahead of me in the classroom, but this moment truly showed me that my intuition was right. Although I was able to adjust later on, it was definitely hard to keep up with the rigor of college-leveled science courses at the start, and I attribute that to my lacking secondary education.
personal_statement:
Sunday mass was a tradition in the family, where my proud Catholic parents preached that the whole point of going to church was to devote time to God and strengthen our relationship with Him. As I grew older, I questioned if attending weekly mass alone was enough to nurture my spirituality. Despite the plethora of teachings I acquired from the church, one idea stood out to me the most: service. According to Catholicism, to serve God is to carry out one's moral responsibility of meeting the needs of others. Thus, I chose to practice my faith by grounding my connection to religion through action, not just presence. One way I implemented this principle was through church retreats, where I once volunteered at the Los Angeles Regional Food Bank with fellow retreatants to package food for underserved populations. This was an enriching experience because I was able to connect and learn from individuals from all walks of life, while ensuring that those in need of food obtain the fuel they deserve. Looking back on that sense of fulfillment, I decided to pursue a career that would allow me to work in a diverse environment and give back to the community.

Making the decision to serve others for a living felt natural, but figuring out the exact way to do so was the challenging part. It was not until eighth grade when I discovered the impact of service through medicine as a patient. At the time, I had a large chalazion bulging underneath my left eyelid that persisted for 6 months. While it was not physically painful, I suffered mentally. Under constant scrutiny and criticism by my peers and even some teachers, my self-esteem began to crumble. Moreover, the lack of knowledge on my affliction made it even more terrifying. Luckily, this changed when I saw a dermatologist.

The doctor educated me on all I needed to know about chalazions and exhibited her prowess in skin anatomy. Until this moment, I had only known science in theory through the context of molecules and chemical reactions. However, hearing the physician go into detail on the anatomy and physiology of my condition triggered my fascination with the human body. It felt extraordinary to encounter biology in a clinical setting where theory was applied practically—knowledge was no longer confined to textbooks—it had the power to actually change a life. Moreover, my dermatologist also demonstrated a great deal of compassion by listening to my story, and it was comforting to know that she saw me as a human being with feelings, not just another medical chart. After my surgery, she guided me in understanding preventative measures so that this ordeal would not repeat again. Through her, I healed both physically and emotionally as I became an active participant in my own health. The impact she made in my life as my physician was unforgettable, and I realized that I wanted to serve others the same way she served me. Ironically, my chalazion that I hated became something to be grateful for: the catalyst in my drive towards medicine.

Following this event, I aimed for opportunities that would grant me a deeper view on the close-knit interaction between science and medicine, and how this interaction influences positive patient outcomes. My experience as an ophthalmic technician was extremely significant because it solidified my desire in becoming a doctor. By testing visual acuity, conducting fundus photography, and performing scans, I worked alongside ophthalmologists to supply the tools needed to monitor the progression of glaucoma. Through my work, I became inspired when I felt how rewarding it was to apply what I learned in school and change people's lives for the better. I vividly remember the long, tiring nights I spent on a glaucoma case study report in a Pharmacology course where I learned about its pathophysiology.
