This made it a lot more comfortable for me to not only practice diagnostic analysis as a technician, but also act as an educator to patients who were curious about their eyes at the biological level. One patient that comes to mind is Hilary, an 18 year old who had recently been diagnosed with glaucoma. By being afflicted with the disease at such a young age, it was no surprise that something as simple as an OCT scan would make her anxious. As a technician, it was my duty to alleviate her worries by providing thorough explanations on the purpose of the tests we conduct, and how they are vital in monitoring her condition. Without my knowledge of the disease that I acquired from school, I would not have been able to properly educate her on glaucoma and its relationship with the OCT, and she likely would have remained nervous for future visits. Thus, it was extremely gratifying to see that my words induced a change in her attitude as she started to become more confident due to an improved patient care experience. In this way, I have come full circle during my time as an ophthalmic technician: I used my education to help patients become active participants in their own health, just like how my dermatologist did for me.

Ultimately, those in need often find solace through faith or science. However, I have found mine at the intersection of these crossroads, where I choose to feed my spirituality by serving others through the lens of medicine.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As a volunteer at the Filipino American Mental Health Resource Center, I aided in the effort to destigmatize mental health in the community of the Inland Empire. I participated in workshops that focused on various mental health disorders and even created my own event that educated the audience on anxiety. Despite the fact that the resource center's target population was the Filipino community, we welcomed every individual from any background that needed assistance. Having said that, I realized that mental health conditions are a one-size-fits all: they affect anyone regardless of age, race, gender, and socioeconomic status. By interacting with individuals that come from differing backgrounds, I discovered that various factors such as socioeconomical, cultural, societal, and gender norms play a big part in the development of these conditions. Consequently, I gained a more comprehensive understanding of those unlike me, and it felt natural communicating with a diverse group of people.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: At UCR, I was a member of the Nutrition Committee at a club called Mini Medical School. During my time there, I collaborated with other students to educate the community on nutrition and leading healthier lifestyles. At school and health fairs, I conducted presentations and engaged in conversations with individuals on how they can take better care of their wellbeing. Not only did we teach the audience how to read nutrition labels, but we also offered brochures detailing cheap, easy, and nutritious recipes that people could use. I recall speaking with one individual who was struggling with being overweight, and as someone who used to be overweight herself, it was easy for me to empathize with them. By listening to their story and providing support, I instilled confidence in them as their attitude towards nutrition improved. It felt rewarding to assist others as they became active participants in their own health because I knew I was making a meaningful impact in their lives.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I was still in the middle of spring semester during the first year of my post-baccalaureate program when the pandemic hit, and initially it was a lot harder to excel in my academics because of the online format. The lack of presence in a classroom where I could directly interact with my peers and professors made it harder for me to understand the material. To adapt, I experimented with new ways of learning and discovered new methods of studying I would not have tried if not for virtual learning. Moreover, COVID-19 also affected me in a professional aspect. I chose to not engage in clinical opportunities during my first two semesters at SFSU until I became acclimated to my new program. Thus during spring semester, I needed to gain more clinical experience to enhance my application. Unfortunately, opportunities were scarce and it took me nearly ten months to find a job starting the spring of 2020. Thankfully, I stumbled upon an ophthalmic technician position and started in January 2021.

personal_statement:
As an only child growing up on the Yang-Ming Mountain in Taipei, Taiwan, I felt most comfortable when surrounded by trees with the companionship of my wildlife friends. I enjoyed discovering new barbet nests, catching crabs in streams, and smelling the fresh scent of wet earth mixed with the unique sulfuric odor of the nearby hot springs. As I grew older, I began caring for some of my animal friends - from baby squirrels who fell from their nests to a falcon who injured its wings - I nurtured the animals back to health and released them home. My connection to these animals initially left me dreaming of becoming a veterinarian; however, my plan shifted when I took an EMT course out of curiosity before my sophomore year in college.

I fell in love with human medicine during a shadowing EMT shift, when I followed two paramedics escorting a lady, “Jane”, from a beachside restaurant to the ER. She was pale and clammy, curled up on a bench, moaning loudly due to sudden intense abdominal pain. As I watched the paramedics transfer her onto the stretcher and into the ambulance, I felt a surge of helplessness that I could not do anything to alleviate her pain. The ten-minute ambulance ride felt like an eternity. I tried my best to attend to Jane, gently patting away her cold sweat and covering her with blankets. I encouraged her with words and held tightly to her hand, hoping to somehow transfer some of my energy to her. Finally, we arrived at the ER and got her the medical care she needed. Right before I left her bedside, I felt a light squeeze on my hand and turned to see Jane giving me a small grin. She mouthed a quiet, “thank you”, and through her eyes, I saw her pain gradually fading away. It was this humanistic side of medicine that drew me toward the field - that I was able to sympathize and connect with people in a way that I cannot do with my animal friends.

My passion and understanding for human medicine continued to grow as I began working as a full-time clinical research coordinator. As a coordinator for large kidney transplant clinical trials, I print my patients’ lab reports and mark abnormal values with yellow highlighter weekly for principal investigators to assess. Oftentimes, I notice and feel excited for my patients with less and less highlights on their lab reports as they progress deeper into our studies. Each change in the lab reports signifies the power of medicine and science, which translate directly into our patients’ everyday lives. During the clinic, “Richard”, an older gentleman, shared how ecstatic he was that he was finally off dialysis after transplant and could travel out of state to visit his family. “Estrella”, a young energetic mom, shared that she was finally able to take her kids to Disneyland and did not have to worry about taking mountains of pills daily thanks to our alternative study infusions. With the combination of medical care and clinical trials, our patients were relieved from their chronic pain and regained their quality of life. I learned that medicine is not only about fixing what went wrong, but also about making our patients feel human again. Knowing our study team was able to make positive changes in our patients’ lives, I feel the same joy and fulfillment as the times when I released my animal friends back into nature each time I wave a patient goodbye from completing their last research visit.

Outside of my work hours, I continue to learn about human medicine. On a Saturday night, “Alex”, my youngest patient who had just come into the clinic for his infusion, suddenly texted me stating he was experiencing high blood pressure and was very anxious about what to do. I immediately contacted Dr. S, and she responded right away that she would reach out to him. A few minutes later, she updated me that she had instructed Alex to take some Metoprolol and comforted him that he was not in danger. Hearing Dr. S’s words of reassurance, I let out a sigh of relief and thought about the stress, or even fear, that Alex must have gone through. It was at this moment that I again experienced the uniqueness of human medicine, that doctors not only provide medical support, but just as importantly, serve as patients’ emotional anchors. Alex did not have a medical emergency that night, but the comfort he received from Dr. S healed his mind and heart. As a third party who often experiences small but sure interactions like the one between Alex and Dr. S, I was also healed repeatedly and reaffirmed in my decision to pursue human medicine.

Reflecting on my experiences, I am certain human medicine is my vocation. As an EMT, after taking patients like Jane to the ER, I was left wondering about their conditions and yearned to be a part of the team continuing to provide them care. As a clinical research coordinator, I was blessed to accompany patients like Alex on their recovery journeys; however, I am also driven to work harder to be able to provide them first-hand care and support like Dr. S. Back on the Yang-Ming mountain, my love for my childhood friends led me to care for them when they most needed it. Now with more experience, I am eager to use this same passion to care for the patients I have built such close relationships with over the years.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Growing up, I was never a concertgoer or a party person. Therefore, when I obtained my EMT certification, I volunteered with RockMed to expand my worldview. Through the organization, I staffed concerts, festivals, and sports game venues around the San Francisco Bay Area. Here, I met people from various backgrounds and learned about lifestyles that greatly deviated from my own. From interacting with patients from all age groups, around the country, and of all socioeconomic backgrounds, I strengthened my belief that healthcare access is a human right instead of a privilege. I also realized that equitable healthcare requires more than compassion. It requires tangible action to let patients understand that they always deserve the best quality care regardless of their background. Therefore, when patients refuse our care due to financial or legal concerns, I would always ease their concerns and proudly inform them that RockMed provides free, non-judgmental care.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As a clinical research coordinator, I work closely with study patients in scheduling their clinical trial appointments. Since our hospital is one of Northern California's largest kidney transplant centers, many patients travel far from their homes to receive care. One of my patients, ‚ÄúJake,‚Äù had to drive a 3-hour round trip monthly for his 30-minute research visits, and I noticed Jake looking more tired each time I met him. After learning he worked three part-time jobs, I advocated for his well-being to the principal investigator. Instead of having Jake come in for research monthly, I pushed for establishing home visit services. For visits he had to complete in our hospital, I asked for additional car mileage reimbursements to balance the inflated gas prices. With more personalized care and financial support, Jake expressed great satisfaction in participating in our study; this motivated me to continue looking out for other patients in the same way I supported Jake through his journey.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I am fortunate that the COVID-19 pandemic did not disrupt my work or financial situation.

personal_statement:
My ambition to become a doctor is rooted in delivering dependable care to families. My goals are to increase access to quality medical care for all communities, regardless of socioeconomic status. The gravity of astute diagnosis and procedural intervention was revealed to me when my baby brother was diagnosed with congenital hydrocephalus by a brilliant pediatric neurologist when others could not explain his symptoms. My family’s platinum insurance gave us access to her compassionate, expert care as she rushed my brother into surgery to save his life. Since witnessing her lifesaving and proficient intervention on my brother, I have been inspired to pursue a similar path to be able to perform such procedures. The connections I have made with providers and patients have solidified my determination to advocate for healthcare rights. I dream of channeling my passions toward opening a reproductive health clinic, dedicated to supporting the health of all families through quality care and education.

The community health field and its commitment to promoting equitable healthcare access motivate me to become a doctor. After graduating from college, I joined Chicago’s National Health Corps to serve a federally-qualified health center (FQHC) to engage with my community while acquainting myself with the daily responsibilities of a healthcare professional. Working in health education for public schools and as a Medicaid insurance navigator connected me with the healthcare disparities I only knew through the classroom. I bore witness to patients who, without FQHCs, would be denied preventative healthcare and unable to pursue medical treatment because of social or financial constraints. As I bonded with immigrant patients afraid to apply for health insurance for fear of being deported and high school students without consistent access to a primary care provider, I grew a profound responsibility to dismantle healthcare inequalities. When school clinics closed at the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, I created educational video content for my students about preventive health practices while screening patients’ social determinants of health to provide them with supportive resources. In my current position as a pediatric scribe, I am learning how private practice can aid in facilitating equitable care as I work with the leading physician to produce affordable treatment plans based on a patient’s insurance status. I aspire to one day form my own clinic committed to giving affordable reproductive healthcare because I believe prioritizing reproductive health can foundationally uplift disadvantaged populations for generations.

I continued the path towards my goal by obtaining an M.S. in medical physiology with a 4.0 GPA because I enjoy the pursuit of new medical knowledge and how treatment plans are developed based on various diagnoses. By directing my enthusiasm for learning toward discovery, I have initiated a research project with my graduate school’s hematology department to investigate West African natural medicines for sickle cell anemia. From this opportunity, I have been able to critically engage with complex concepts to form a comprehensive research model, solidifying my interest to conduct clinical research alongside my education. I am confident my fascination with medical science will drive my success in medical school.

My passion for medicine began with my little brother and evolved into a movement to advance healthcare equity. Healthcare is a human right I plan to protect, especially for communities with low access to quality, compassionate medical care. The COVID-19 pandemic has exposed societal gaps in health education and increased governance impacting reproductive healthcare access has worsened healthcare disparities, promoting distrust in the medical field. My vision for the future is to prioritize individualized care and education for each patient, no matter their background. I want to engage with communities through proficient medical care, as well as increase exposure to trusted medical professionals outside of the clinic by using advancing social media platforms and hosting neighborhood town halls to answer general healthcare inquiries. As an African-American woman from the southside of Chicago, I want to become a doctor to help patients find the treatment they need to protect their well-being and inspire young minorities to add their voices to the health field. Medicine needs providers that reflect the communities they serve and are willing to use their expertise to remove healthcare inequities plaguing patient populations. I choose to become a physician because I know the medical field can elevate families, communities, and our social well-being. I welcome the challenges to come and am excited for the opportunity to work with brilliant physicians to make a better future.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
My grandfather‚Äôs colon cancer diagnosis exposed our conflicting perspectives about western medicine. My grandpa refuses traditional cancer treatments and proceeds with naturopathic methods through nutrition because he distrusts the medical field. My bias toward medication and surgery left me unable to accept his approach as an effective plan to save his life. Consequently, our relationship became strained as I could not give my grandpa the unconditional support he has always given me. _x000D_
_x000D_
I have learned that providing support means meeting someone where they are without judgment. When I opened my mind to understanding my grandfather‚Äôs convictions, he opened up to me about the nutritional research he‚Äôs done and the reactions he‚Äôs received from oncologists surprised by the effectiveness of his approach. As a physician, I will give care to patients with different views than my own and it is my responsibility to ensure bias does not detract from the quality of support they receive from me.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
While serving as a health educator, I was the nutrition counselor for one student, Diego, who changed my perspective on how I can impact communities. Diego sought to lose 15 pounds ahead of his wrestling season and informed me that his previous approaches were to starve himself. When I educated him about the benefits of eating consistent, nutritious meals throughout the day, he opened up to me about his family‚Äôs food insecurities._x000D_
_x000D_
This admission inspired me to create a resource list of food pantries near his home, food stamp application guidelines, and low-cost, healthy recipes he could share with his family. This taught Diego feasible nutrition methods to meet his goals while indirectly improving the nutrition of his family and friends with similar limitations. From this experience, I learned that providing one person with quality healthcare has enough impact to benefit the health outcomes of entire communities.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
My family is lucky to have not suffered severe infections or loss due to COVID-19. However, the pandemic shifted my attention toward the need for greater social justice work in medicine. This crisis exposed us all to the extensive healthcare disparities that exist as barriers to care for low-income, minority patients. These populations have disproportionately high rates of chronic disease, leading to more severe or fatal coronavirus infections. This trend then furthers mounting distrust toward the medical field. _x000D_
_x000D_
The COVID-19 pandemic has taught me that becoming a doctor means more than taking history, performing an exam, and prescribing treatment. I want to be a part of the next generation of physicians who are committed to advocating for patient rights and upholding equitable care. I am inspired to expose patients to different treatments within their means while adding my voice to conversations centered around intertwining social justice with healthcare.

personal_statement:
My very first call as an EMT brought me to the scene of a car accident that had taken place early on a Saturday morning. The squad and I were eating breakfast when sirens echoed throughout the station. I remember seeing how the atmosphere instantly changed as everyone rushed to their respective vehicles, already knowing the tasks for which they were responsible. We arrived on scene to a patient sitting in the car holding their face with a star-shaped crack on the windshield. We opened the door and assessed her as we carefully prepared to relocate her to a stretcher while stabilizing her head and neck. It was this event that made me realize the unique cross-section that takes place within the world of medicine. Medical knowledge, empathy, urgency, communication, and the human element seemed to converge in the back of an ambulance. Looking back on this day and my experiences since then, I feel gratitude for my decision to change my career path and explore additional avenues of interest that helped me grow internally and change my perspective about myself, finding what it is I love.

When I think about the lessons learned during this journey, two of the most important ones in my experience are choosing your own path and not letting a single characteristic define you. Although there are circumstances outside of your control, many obstacles to the goals you want to reach, standing by your decisions and being multifaceted allow you to not only learn the most about yourself, but also connect with many aspects of life you would otherwise not have. 

For many years up until my first fall semester at NKU, I had only seen myself as a soccer player. I had been playing my entire life up to this point but began to wonder if this path was something I truly desired. I loved the sport and had been afforded great memories of it through the years. However, I had to truly ask myself who I honestly was and what were the things that genuinely defined me. During that first semester, I experienced hardships dealing with a coach who was verbally and physically abusive towards other players and myself on a regular basis. Having my major outlet feel like the root of my stress, while also being the primary means of affording college, led to a sense of feeling trapped and a profound sense of dissonance. The effect of this experience had manifested itself in parts of my personal life, grades, and relationships. However, it also served as the initial catalyst to begin redefining myself.

As time passed and after transferring to another school, I truly began to take the needed steps to find myself and heal after my experiences. However, it was not until the end of my junior year that I truly decided on what path to choose. I knew from where I stood the road would be long and difficult. However, I still began with minor changes in my philosophy surrounding academics and work ethic. The change in results was not instantaneous, but over many years allowed me to completely overhaul what I was capable of and what I could accomplish. 

After graduating from college, I began working for the military, with my main goal being a slow transition to the medical field. This slow transition involved several steps: 1) saving enough money to get my EMT license and 2) registering for post-baccalaureate advanced biology classes. Additionally, it was during this time that I had learned the most about my limits, as going back to school full-time while working full time during the pandemic was genuinely challenging. However, there are two sides to every coin, and the pandemic, while challenging, did offer an opportunity to attend multiple schools while managing my daily workflow. I am incredibly grateful for this experience, as this was my last step before entering the medical workforce. 

This path has opened avenues within me that I never knew existed. Interacting with so many people from different occupations pushes me to find the place in the community that is most in line with my experiences. Everything has a connection, experiences of different people allow us to further relate to each other, and medical school is the next step in allowing the experience of myself and others to influence people both inside and outside of medical settings. I have viewed each step of this process as a means to an end. I feel that becoming a physician will allow me the tools and perspective to not only further grow as a person, but also to impact people in a way that goes beyond what I may know clinically. I understand that the road is long, challenging, and demanding. However, I also have realized that deciding for myself what is most important to me and walking a path that both acknowledges the many facets and what I have gone through can still bring me joy that I can spread to others.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
One experience that has truly helped to open and change my worldview is Crisis Text Line. When going through the training phase, the principal points discussed are bias and perspective. We must be cautious of these aspects of our behaviors, as serving others requires you to leave them behind.   _x000D_
_x000D_
As a counselor, you quickly learn that your viewpoint is limited. You never truly know the obstacles a person faces, or what experiences may be influencing their decisions. Additionally, you may encounter persons you surmise are the antithesis of your own beliefs. Even still, you must understand that this is merely a lens you must remove. I view this as critically important, as this teaches you multiple ways of understanding views outside your own. Furthermore, removing your lens leads to expressing genuine empathy. Over my time serving, I have realized that this point of empathy is the start of helping people through crisis.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
When working as a nursing assistant, there are times when we are tasked with observing patients with suicidal ideation. On one particular night shift, we admitted a man experiencing this following an attempted overdose. I have always been open to listening to patients I care for, as I often enjoy learning about their backgrounds. However, I seemed to have profoundly impacted the man I cared for this particular night. It started with normal conversation and introductions, but as time passed, we began to talk deeply about music, home life, traveling, his time in the military, and much more.   _x000D_
_x000D_
The conversation lasted for many hours, and felt incredibly open and honest. I learned that he was a very thoughtful, kind, and resilient man, and as time passed, he became warmer and more cheerful. By the night's end, he shook my hand, thanked me for how kind I was to his story and situation, and even wrote a letter expressing how this connection changed his outlook.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
The covid pandemic created a peculiar environment given my situation. At this point in time, I understood applying to medical school would require returning to undergraduate courses. However, the courses I needed to take were not always offered locally. Furthermore, having a full-time job did not permit flexibility in my schedule required to attend physical classes.   _x000D_
_x000D_
However, many institutions converted learning to an online format as the pandemic peaked. This ended up being critical for me, as my place of work also made this change. This permitted me to be more effective with my time, as my physical presence was no longer required. This allowed completion of both work and school to become possible. By compressing my work tasks to be done as early as possible, I could attend the zoom lectures and tests later in the day. Additionally, remote learning enabled me to attend schools at a distance, allowing me to find classes I needed for applying.

Hrdshp_Comments: Throughout my childhood, both of my parents faced serious drug addictions, and neither held a steady job. My mom is emotionally unstable and was imprisoned, while my dad still lives in his mother’s garage. There was no money for healthcare or food, so I worked nights and weekends to support my family. I became a parent to my little sister and made sure she had clean clothes, dinner on the table, homework finished, and a ride to school. After years of physical and emotional abuse, we were removed by Child Protective Services. Growing up in a chaotic household, I struggled to get support with my classwork and never discussed basic topics for standardized exams. Despite this, school was my safe zone. In high school, a mentor helped me apply to university. My mom dropped out of college after one term, and my dad never finished high school, so I had little guidance in applying. Seeking a new beginning, I gained admission to UC Santa Cruz with full-ride scholarships, while working up to three part-time jobs. Last year, I was selected for the UC Riverside School of Medicine post-bac, entirely on scholarship, though I still worked and cared full-time for my teenage sister. It is through these trials that I learned the resilience it takes to complete my education and realize my dream to become a physician.
personal_statement:
The spring I was thirteen, I rode my bike for miles on busy city streets to Planned Parenthood. I scheduled the appointment on my own because in my family, if something was wrong, you either toughed it out, or if it was an emergency, you went to the ER. Forced to grow up fast, through emotional and physical abuse, visiting clinics with my parents by my side wasn’t an option. Without insurance, I had no other way to access healthcare. Sitting on the waxy paper, feet dangling from the exam table, I told the doctor my concerns. For once in my life, I felt heard and seen by someone who listened and cared about me. That was when I knew I wanted to become a doctor, to make others feel as safe and heard as I did in that moment. 

During my last year of college, I had that opportunity as a medical scribe. Although the county hospital was an hour away from home, I sought work there to serve a diverse population. There were mental health patients, trauma victims, uninsured fieldworkers, and prison inmates seeking care in an overwhelmed ER. As their first point of contact, I recorded their medical histories. Some patients were in crisis mode while others were too ill to talk. Often, I was the only one in the room who spoke Spanish. I knew what it was like to be confused and afraid in unfamiliar surroundings. Growing up with parents who battled addiction, I’d spent most of my childhood managing difficult situations. I learned to read the energy of a room from an early age, which prepared me for a lifelong career of working in unpredictable environments. 

Exhausted from working overnight, I was jolted awake by the loudspeakers in the windowless and bone-chilling cold of the emergency room announcing a code blue. A young woman had been found alone and unresponsive at the door of the ambulance bay. She was mottled gray and blue across her pale skin, foaming from her lips, with track marks lining her arms. Hands covered her body as the paramedics pushed the gurney. Despite endless cycles of CPR, there was nothing left to do. As difficult as this was, I listened intently to the doctors calling out physical findings to record every detail. For the first time, I felt the heaviness of losing a patient. Although I know I can’t save everyone that I will care for as a provider, I still hope for the opportunity to try.

Two years later, listening skills helped me connect with others in a vastly different environment. As a Peace Corps volunteer in Peru, one way I helped people was by completely immersing myself in their culture and beliefs. Just days after I’d arrived, I awoke to the sound of tears and panic in my host mother’s voice - her mother, Abuelita, had died of a heart attack. She asked me to join her to cleanse Abuelita’s spirit using the traditional Peruvian holistic medicine of the Sierras. Slowly we picked up the large green hierba santa leaves, soaking in water next to the bed, to sweep them over her cold rigid body. Though I had seen death previously, at that moment, I needed to listen with my heart and mind to understand how to connect to my host family in an entirely new way.

Every encounter as a health volunteer in the Peace Corps was an opportunity to learn and to establish the confianza (trust) that people in the community needed to feel before I could step in to help. Under the blistering sun, Dr. Don Roberto, Nurse Maria, and I walked along uneven dirt roads to meet our first patients of the day. In a two-room adobe home without running water or electricity and surrounded by a yard with a handful of chickens and cuys (guinea pigs), I spoke with a young pregnant mother and her six-year-old daughter. Because I was the only foreigner in the village, none of the topics were easy to discuss: Family planning in a Catholic country. Nutrition in the face of poverty. Hygiene with no access to clean water or sewer lines. Only by listening empathetically to her concerns could I begin to bridge that gap in health education. I heard her sigh of relief and sensed that she felt the way I did at my first encounter with that caring doctor who deeply impacted my life and career path. Standing in this family’s home, I realized how much an environment could impact a patient’s access to healthcare, and ultimately, their own health.

From urban hospitals to rural villages, these diverse experiences have rooted me again and again in my journey to become the compassionate doctor I aspire to be. Growing up in an unstable household, I know the feeling of being uninsured, lost and afraid in a bewildering medical environment. I know how it feels to be vulnerable in a place where no one speaks my native language. As a result, I can now relate to the medically-underserved patients I will serve as a bilingual, Spanish-speaking primary care doctor. By constantly learning the differences among customs, cultures, and languages, I hope not just to care for my patients, but to care about them as individuals. If I truly understand them and their stories, we can work together for better health outcomes even in difficult and uncertain circumstances. I can’t always meet families in their homes as I did in Peru, but I can help them navigate our complex healthcare system by listening, caring, and connecting - one patient at a time.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Coming from American suburbia, I found myself in a rural village in Peru for my Peace Corps service. Serving a community vastly different from my own, there were values and traditions I had to understand before I was effective as a health volunteer. With hospitals more than an hour away, and no money to pay for medical treatments, families used natural remedies to sustain their well-being. In Peru, food is medicine, and ‚ÄúPachamama‚Äù, Mother Earth, heals the community. During home health visits, I learned how to collaborate with families to create patient-centered care plans based on local resources. This level of communication taught me the importance of developing trust with patients. As a doctor, I will connect with people from diverse cultures, who speak different languages, and with backgrounds different from my own. Much like the emphasis on community-based medicine in Peru, I hope to recreate these inclusive healthcare practices in my own clinical practice at Rush Medical College.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: At Santa Cruz AIDS Project (SCAP) I worked directly with at-risk populations through field outreach, educational presentations, and community health projects. On outreach missions, I lead Naloxone trainings while handing out hygiene and safer sex packets in unhoused communities. Monthly, I facilitated educational presentations in rehabilitation centers where I identified knowledge gaps and connected attendees with resources to make safer decisions in high-risk activities. To promote sexual health education, I lead a condom dispenser project and distributed more than 20,000 condoms. By connecting with many vulnerable populations, I gained insight into how stigma and shame around HIV/AIDs, sexual health, and drug use resulted in misinformation and discrimination. These experiences taught me how to make meaningful impact within a population through community-based interventions while advocating for underserved populations in a non-judgmental environment.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
I was forced to evacuate and leave behind my host family, my village, and my project in Peru where I was serving as a Peace Corps volunteer in March, 2020. Without a home or a job to return to, I secured housing and assumed full-time guardianship of my younger sister. We moved four times in 3 months until we found permanent housing. Meanwhile, I found a full-time job as a COVID-19 test site technician while I applied for programs to continue my medical school preparation._x000D_
_x000D_
In July, 2020 I was accepted into UC Riverside‚Äôs Post-Baccalaureate Program. Classes were fully online so I attended virtual office hours and facilitated Zoom study sessions with my cohort weekly. For the first time in my academic career, I obtained a 4.0 GPA. Though the pandemic forced me to face some of the hardest years of my life, I was proud of myself for this academic achievement. I am confident that my resiliency through the pandemic has prepared me to pursue my dream of becoming a doctor at Rush University.

Hrdshp_Comments:
Having been raised by a single mother of four, economic hardship was our greatest adversary. Our family required government assistance programs such as WIC and SNAP benefits to help with food. Although we had assistance, coming from a low-income household often required everyone to work to help pay bills or school fees. Personally, I view these adversities as character-building experiences, but they also bring about academic difficulties. I had to split my focus between working to pay for my college tuition and my studies. I strongly believe I would have attained a higher GPA if I were solely focused on my education. Similarly, due to financial struggles, purchasing preparatory courses for standardized tests or private tutors was not an option. 

From a different perspective, having an immigrant father that spoke mainly Spanish and a mother who only attained her GED, I was considered a first-generation Latino student. While given this title is a great achievement, navigating these unfamiliar waters as a premed student was challenging and often lonely. Though I had to pave my own path, I thankfully established my own social support system. Grateful to my peers, professors, and employers that have provided me with guidance, I was not alone when overcoming these obstacles.
personal_statement:
After coming inside the house having spent several hours in the relentless summer heat changing my car’s brakes, a typical Sunday turned into one of the most surreal moments of my life. A 500-pound water heater fell on my brother resulting in a deep 7-inch-long laceration to his forearm that severed a tendon. As most would expect, my little brother gripped the wound as blood started dripping profusely and began to run out of the house saying “we need to head to the hospital now.” Scared, my mother began to cry and yell “he could lose his hand” which naturally ensued chaos for everyone in the house. Amongst this commotion, disregarding my own hysteria, I found myself administering first aid by using a clean towel to apply pressure to his wound. With my hand squeezing his muscle back into his arm while raising it above his head, I encouraged my chaotic family to quiet down and grab a lawn chair so I can elevate his feet. Handing off the applying pressure responsibility to his girlfriend, I then took off my shirt and used it as a tourniquet to slow the blood flow to his arm. Grateful for my sister always being on her phone, the ambulance was already on its way and I sat there holding my brother's arm while comforting him. 

Reminiscing about myself sitting in the doctor's office as a child, I remember listening to my mom describe when Dr. Devas saved my sister's life when she had a seizure and stopped breathing. It was the first time I realized physicians do more than routine check-ups. All I could think about is how this person with a stethoscope on my chest was able to handle that situation. When my little brother confided in me after his surgery about how grateful he was to have me there for his accident, I realized I had been developing those same courageous, knowledgeable, and leadership attributes I had idolized in Dr. Devas throughout my premed journey. 

As important as it may be to handle an emergent situation, it is just as vital to be able to display that empathetic perspective that is fundamental to holistic medicine. As a caretaker for my grandpa during his end stage of Parkinson’s Disease, I witnessed firsthand the difficulty of seeing a loved one slowly perish with each new day. However, there is a bit of beauty in every situation. Fortunately for my case, I was able to spend every day with my grandpa for the last few years of his life. Spending time with and caring for him was when I first began to learn about medicine and understand how life-threatening conditions affect people. As one of his caretakers, I reflected on many aspects pertaining to his healthcare plan. As I organized his medications, I would contemplate if prescribing L-Dopa is the best treatment available for this condition. And if there are better treatments, is it a matter of money? After witnessing the impact this condition had on my family, I questioned how a person can help those affected, including family, cope with a disease so devastating. Intrigued by the medicine and curiosity that surrounded my grandpa’s condition, I was motivated to obtain more education and clinical experience which has ultimately strengthened my resolve for becoming a physician. 

After my grandfather passed away and I graduated high school, I had the opportunity to work for several employers that provided a better glimpse into medicine. Working in these professions, I discovered that I sincerely have a passion for caring for patients and not just an interest in learning medicine. My most influential experience was working as a CNA in a dementia unit. Similar to caring for my grandpa, I helped people with dementia-related conditions live a more comfortable life. Although the title of a CNA implies several job responsibilities such as charting daily intake or walking patients, my idea of providing care embodies aspects that were not a part of the job description. I would often work another eight hours after my first shift because of a call-off, just to ensure the residents were not being neglected due to low staffing. Other times I would come in for a few hours on my day off because Trudy was combative, didn't realize where she was and refused to come out of her room for anyone besides her husband. I never did say I was her husband, but she never once refused to have a cup of coffee with me. 

I wholeheartedly believe the world is in need of physicians who not only understand the medical concepts but also the situation, and embody the attributes to properly handle them. As displayed in my brother’s accident, having a first responder skill set to deal with an emergency will most certainly benefit a physician during their career. But just as vital, a physician needs to be able to display an empathetic and caring hand in those situations that seem almost impossible to provide tangible help. Through my clinical, personal, and educational experiences, I have come to understand that the path toward becoming a physician is everything but straight and requires true grit. That being said, having the opportunity to hone these attributes throughout my experiences and possibly develop them through medical training is the essence of what I believe would make me an excellent physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: One experience that has improved my understanding of individuals who come from different backgrounds would be working alongside graduate students at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. Ranked 5th out of 1,000 for overall most popular U.S. universities for international students, many of my friends that I have made during my employment come from another country. With the amount of time that I have spent learning about their culture, I have also learned about the struggles they encounter in America. Amongst these struggles, the most common concern is how to comprehend the intricacies of the U.S. healthcare system. Listening to the negative interactions that they have experienced has displayed the importance of alleviating obstacles, such as the complexities of healthcare coverage, so that we may strive to improve health equity for all people regardless of their background.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Leaving rural Illinois to attend college in the Chicagoland area taught me there were differences in health disparities between urban and rural communities. Despite these differences, I have noticed that both of these communities struggle with outreach and educating people about healthcare-related resources. I was fortunate enough to have firsthand experience with outreach when I volunteered as a Pandemic Health Navigator. In this position, I helped patients that were quarantined understand the funded resources that could be provided to them, such as assistance with food and medicine. I found this experience to be very fulfilling because I helped many people in my community who were struggling in various aspects as a result of the pandemic. Although my time as a volunteer has allowed me to contribute to the pandemic, this experience helped illustrate the importance of outreach and education as necessary steps toward meeting the healthcare needs of our communities.
7_-_COVID_Impact: When the COVID-19 pandemic started I was forced to graduate a few months early with no commencement ceremony. After graduating, my job offer to work as a research technician at Loyola University was retracted and I spent the next  3-4 months unemployed in Chicago using my entire savings to pay for living expenses. In addition, I had planned to retake my MCAT before the application cycle for 2020 started, but all exams were canceled for several months. Given my circumstance, I decided it would be in my best interest to take some time to stabilize my life and potentially strengthen my application. This process started with my relocating to central Illinois, which allowed me to gain new research, volunteer, and personal experiences. Although my path taken toward applying for medical school is untraditional and filled with many challenges, I am fairly grateful for these adversities; it is a beautiful testament to the grit I possess and the resolve I have to become a physician.

Hrdshp_Comments: Eleven years ago, I moved from India to obtain a master's degree in the United States. Moving to a new country was very exciting but also very terrifying. Integrating into a new culture came with its own difficulties, including learning English as a second language and experiencing homesickness. I would walk home in embarrassment after asking the waiter to prepare my food to be taken as a "parcel" and for them to never understand. I later learned the correct word for my request was "to-go." Since then, I have put in conscious efforts to learn the colloquial verbiage by interacting with native English speakers. Additionally, I faced financial and living insecurities due to my lack of a credit history. Paid clinical positions were not allowed because of the absence of a work permit, and this held me back from gaining long-term clinical experience. To gain relevant experience, I started volunteering in research labs and hospitals. Although I was financially disadvantaged through volunteering, I gained valuable experience, great friends, and mentorship. Through my interactions with peers and mentors, I was exposed to several glimpses of a career in medicine. These have helped me immensely in training myself mentally and physically to face more enormous challenges and overcome them successfully.
personal_statement:
Amidst the screaming cries of "Rena," a four-month-old girl, I struggled to collect her demographic details from her parents, Bangladesh immigrants who did not speak English. The family had come to Satya Sai Institute of Higher Medical Sciences (SSIHMS), Bangalore, India, seeking medical care. This hospital provided free medical care to people of low-income status. Despite the commotion, Dr. Gupta entered and easily connected with the parents through gestures, reassuring tones, and interpretation service. He examined Rena, ordered tests, and ensured the family had a better picture of the course of treatment. This episode has stuck with me for the past twenty years because Rena's parents put all their trust in Dr. Gupta, a stranger from a different country speaking a foreign language. As a fourteen-year-old kid working as a 'Sevadal' (volunteer), I realized that medicine is a profession that overcomes all superficial barriers and facilitates two human beings to help each other in vulnerable times.
At the end of my high school education, I was at the crossroads of choosing a major for college. I strongly considered medicine, but I held myself back and steered away from this dream with a self-imposed doubt of not being able to shoulder the immense responsibility of patients' health and, more so, their lives. Nevertheless, I completed the four-year engineering program with distinction, accomplished to get admitted into the University of Maryland, College Park, for my master's degree, and finally secured a full-time job as a mobile communication Engineer. Having cleared my student loans, I was happy that the job gave me financial security. Yet, although the work was important, I still felt incomplete.
I knew I had to take the leap when my friend told me about an opportunity at Wilmer Eye Institute, Johns Hopkins. With little to no knowledge of Biology, I learned to dissect the eyes and pancreas of mice on day one. As a retina surgeon, my PI encouraged me to go beyond mice studies and understand human physiology. I invested a lot of time learning and gradually realized my heart was always in medicine. While I realized I was at a disadvantage concerning my age, background, and immigration status, I was still determined to make it work this time as I explored various available options.
I shadowed Dr. Tanner, an OB/GYN, to further explore my interest in medicine during a hysterectomy procedure. I not only witnessed Dr. Tanner's expert robotic surgery skills on the 'da Vinci' but also his compassion when he had to deliver sad news to his patients. One encounter that impacted me was when he had to relay to "Sam" that further exploration showed a mass on her ovaries. While Dr. Tanner explained the findings, I held her hand and realized what it felt like to be vulnerable. I kept my eyes on hers and softly smiled as I attempted to comfort her. Dr. Tanner consoled Sam and answered all her questions empathetically yet assertively. He explained every treatment option available to her and empowered her to make an educated decision on her next steps. This experience humbled me as I realized an expert skillset is not enough to deliver quality care. The human connection and compassion physicians offer their patients are necessary to uplift them and help them cope with their circumstances. Someday, I hope to experience the honor of earning my patients' trust and healing them of their ailments.
To gain more clinical experience, I started working as a clinical research coordinator (CRC) on Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS). As a CRC, I was trained on various techniques, including measuring Slow Vital Capacity (SVC). SVC scores depended on multiple factors; I scored low while training, as I grew up in a tropical country with substantial air pollution. "Sarah," one of our new patients, had trouble using the machine as she had bulbar onset of ALS. Looking at her score drop, Sarah did not want to continue the analysis and requested to leave. She said an online forum mentioned a poor prognosis for low SVC results. I shared my SVC experience with her and explained that the scores depend on various factors. Dr. Berry, the study's lead investigator, shared the perils of diagnosing oneself based on partial information found in online forums. All of this gave her some solace, and she decided to stay for further diagnosis. This was an enriching experience as I felt I did my part to improve Sarah's quality of life by empowering her to continue in the research program. As a physician, I hope to help alleviate the added stress of misinformation from online forums.
Stripped down to a hospital gown and in pain, often without a known cause, patients inevitably look to their doctors for guidance when making life-altering decisions. The desire to fulfill this unwritten contract has fueled me through the long days and nights working full-time and completing prerequisites for medical school over the last five years. This drive - to develop myself to serve my patients better - will give me the determination to overcome the challenges presented by medical school and residency. Each morning I wake up resolved to become a reliable, competent doctor worthy of the utmost trust, capable of changing the lives of patients who seek healthcare every day.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Living in Baltimore and East Harlem has opened my eyes to many social disparities. I was in the ER recently due to a vasovagal response. Fortunately, my family is insured. I was shifted to the nearest hospital within ten minutes of placing the 911 call. While I was rushed into the ER, there were several patients, primarily underserved, outside the hospital, waiting to be treated. On another occasion, I saw a man lying on the sidewalk near my home, unresponsive but awake. I waited for a few minutes and called for an ambulance. I was surprised when it took twenty minutes for them to arrive. Having given the benefit of the doubt, I started explaining the situation. They brought the man to consciousness, gave him fluids, and left. I realized that, unlike me, this was the level of treatment he could expect, as he did not have insurance. These experiences have taught me that the underserved are less likely to receive even the most basic medical care, which most of us take for granted.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Volunteering at New York Common Pantry, Manhattan involves distributing meal packages to the socioeconomically disadvantaged population of East Harlem. The ‚ÄòSmiths‚Äô are a regular family I have known fondly. One Sunday, I was talking to them about their daughter‚Äôs exams when Mrs. Smith mentioned that she didn‚Äôt score well on them. She said they had to move to the Bronx as the rent had increased astronomically. Because of the move, their daughter could not prepare well. Their whole life was uprooted, and now they had to look for schools and healthcare providers and form relationship in a new community. In the hope of reducing their stress, I contacted our Bronx-based pantry and enrolled the Smiths there. Like them, most of their friends and family were displaced into other burrows of New York City. Gentrification results in the expulsion of residents, a decline in neighborhood diversity, and a decrease in small businesses. It is one of the significant catalysts leading to homelessness.
7_-_COVID_Impact: "Your MCAT has been canceled.", "We have no openings right now.", "Your Greencard application is on hold." These were some emails I received when COVID-19 hit. After rescheduling the MCAT twice, I decided to try later. Although all my volunteering activities were canceled, I was lucky to receive a work permit. This allowed me to apply to paid positions. But there was a hiring freeze. I made peace with it and decided to work on my greencard application. However, all greencard applications were on hold due to a staff shortage. This came as quite a shock for my family. It meant our stay in the US would soon end, and I would have to give up on medical school. It was all the more challenging to stay positive. That's when a friend suggested that I sign up for Zooniverse, where one can virtually authenticate the accuracy and reliability of animal research data. Although this was not what I had planned for, it gave me a sense of purpose and let me contribute to something larger than myself.

personal_statement:
This personal statement of mine opens with a very impersonal statement that opens a great novel. “It was the best of times, it was the worst of times”. Dickens was writing of the French Revolution. In the case of Iranian politics it was the Green Revolution in 2009.

In 8th grade, in 2009, I decided to use the extra hour on my final exam to write an anti-government poem for a sympathetic literature teacher. Riskily, she posted my poem on a website. Even though it was anonymous, my parents were alarmed – people who wrote such things sometimes disappeared. Moreover, I sometimes skipped school to join the protests and to paint pro-democracy paintings. On June 17th 2009 one of the college students was shot by police.

In 6th grade at the age of ten, I had decided that I’d be the one to find a cure for AIDS. (I had been reading many biographies of scientists.) The only way to set about doing this was to become one of the 120 accepted out of 50,000 applicants to the National Organization for Development of Extraordinary Talents (NODET). In Iran, every school is limited to the government-controlled curriculum. Except for NODET. They were known for offering a strong, independent education to help modernize Iran, teaching critical thinking while trying to stay within the confines of government regulations. Even so, sometimes they would slip.

One of my teachers mentioned in passing that Iran reported inaccurate incidence rates for AIDS; the government was denying the facts about prostitution, drug use and homosexuality. Working with fellow students, I dug into publicly available data-sets of socioeconomic data to identify high-risk groups. The data-sets clarified many correlations otherwise obstructed by the government. For months, I sent daily emails to MAHAK hospital, a non-profit and non-governmental organization to help children who had cancer. The daily e-mails persuaded them to let me contribute to their epidemiological research department despite my not having a high-school diploma. (Iran was decades away from electronic health records.) It fell to me to call families and ask about their child’s post-operative health. Sometimes I had to ask about a child who had recently died.

It was at this time, while my concern with community health was growing, that my parents talked everyday about moving to America. When I was fifteen, we got on a plane.

The Iranian government was denying treatment and preventative care to its people to escape criticism of its policies. Such shortcomings were not unique to Iran, they were common even in the USA. I explored different strategies including artificial intelligence and Blockchain. Without knowing how the results were implemented at the patient level, it felt abstract.

The work at Epic, the well-known, often loathed electronic health record company, started with talking to providers and understanding their workflows. At a company meeting, I learned we could use our dynamic cloud data to predict outcomes. I wanted to support physicians conducting real-world data analysis.

Learning to do this meant gaining the skills and the knowledge to make sense of clinical observations, mine and other people’s, and of population-based correlations. This, while providing clarity and comfort, knowledge and understanding, for patients. I’m one of many immigrants who, in making a new beginning in a country where they did not at first speak the language, are being brought to realize their own hopes and ambitions.

While working with patients in Boston, I saw them cope with the realization that their Parkinson’s symptoms were going to worsen despite receiving every medical and surgical treatment possible. When they would panic, the neurologists with whom I worked transformed from diagnostic specialists to comforting comrades. They listened, calmed, asked patients about their goals, and soberly explained what to expect as their disease worsened. I came to realize the neurologist's ability to care came less from reading about the nervous system than from directly tending to many patients throughout the natural course of disease. Acknowledging the opportunities I’ve had till now - from conducting academic research to working in corporate healthcare - I have good reason to believe that a career that will offer the most intellectual stimulation and emotional satisfaction will be that of a physician.

A physician’s role should perhaps not be siloed to individual patient interactions. There is a larger setting that should be considered. This sentiment is best put to words not by me but by Dickens in a poverty-stricken London setting. A crossing-sweeper in London has died. “Dead! Dead, your Majesty. Dead, my lords and gentlemen. Dead, Right Reverends and Wrong Reverends of every order. Dead, men and women, born with Heavenly compassion in your hearts. And dying thus around us every day.”  Heavenly compassion, as Dickens knew in his campaigning, needs practical compassion in this life. And there is even such a thing as intelligent self-interest. For, as with the COVID pandemic, a death in sickness that was preventable is often infectious and contagious, and “shall work its retribution, through every order of society, up to the proudest of the proud, and to the highest of the high”.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
During my free time in Ghana, I took boxing lessons from Dominque, a local Accra boxer._x000D_
_x000D_
At first it was challenging for us to communicate. I spoke American English while he spoke Pidgin English but we found ways to understand each other. I asked him how many siblings he had. He told me several had died before the age of 5 of diarrheal illness. I had studied child mortality rates in global health classes but meeting Dominique made it tangible. _x000D_
 _x000D_
I couldn‚Äôt imagine being in their shoes and though I‚Äôm embarrassed to admit, maybe I judged Dominique, as the only literate member of his family, for spending so much time in church instead of finding ways to provide more for them. He finally invited me to visit his family. Living and breaking coconuts with them for a day made me understand their reality a bit more. _x000D_
_x000D_
Serving God was their source of comfort. They had learned to appreciate little moments more than I had. Then they played music and taught me the Adowa dance.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
I worked with a network of safety net hospitals in rural Texas for one of my Epic projects. To help alleviate problems affecting low-income patients in this hospital network, we decided to use capabilities offered by having an electronic health records system to convey a more holistic view of the patient‚Äôs health journey. _x000D_
_x000D_
By giving providers a dedicated workspace to document various psychosocial and economic challenges facing each patient, they could better tailor each patient‚Äôs discharge plan to suit the patient‚Äôs needs. For instance, to assist patients with unstable housing or food insecurity, I met with public health experts to define metrics that were most important for designing unique care plans for each patient and optimally utilizing local social services. _x000D_
_x000D_
Through this work, I was able to help providers soften the effects of structural inequalities on patients._x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact:
In January of 2021, my mom became severely ill with COVID while traveling to Iran. She wasn‚Äôt able to return when expected, and I became my 11-year-old brother‚Äôs primary caretaker. Though I was worried about her survival, I had to be strong for my brother and be his Math, English, History, and PE teacher. I was simultaneously working full-time at ThermoFisher to help researchers develop vaccines._x000D_
My role as an implementation specialist brought me into hospitals where I first appreciated the impact of COVID not just on patients, but also providers. Everyday, I saw providers‚Äô physical and emotional limits pushed as COVID surged. Working in the ICU at Arrowhead Medical Center, I also saw nurses uplifting each other through small gestures like posting sticky notes in staff bathrooms reminding them of their value and consoling families that couldn‚Äôt see their loved ones. Witnessing these acts of courage and compassion only strengthened my desire to become a physician.

Hrdshp_Comments:
As a single immigrant parent, there were few things my mother would not do for us. Often working ten-to-twelve-hour days cleaning houses yet scared to ask for more than what equated to less than minimum wage, many of my mother’s responses were a consequence of the wounds that persisted years after domestic violence and abuse at the hands of my father. Where adult supervision was scarce, my development was nurtured by my older sister and the transient mentors that came into my life. When my brother spiraled into his meth addiction, I remember being afraid I would follow in his footsteps.

But my mother raised us to be brave and to have the audacity to do everything with love. It was these lessons that sustained me when I struggled to keep up with my peers as a first-generation college student and sometimes to even afford to feed myself. The housing insecurity I later faced only brought back the doubt and fear that had characterized much of my childhood.  

Yet, it was these challenges that forced me to be vulnerable and transparent with those around me. It fostered a greater sense of adaptability in my person and gave me purpose. A deeper perspective and connection to my cause of advocating for and helping empower the underserved.
personal_statement:
As warm tears trail down my cheeks, I hug my mother as tightly as I can. Border patrol agents proceed to brush me aside and handcuff her. As the afternoon dusk of the Arizonan desert turns to night, we are driven to a detention center. At seven years old, I remember wondering where my sister and I would call home as I stammered in prayer.

During my mother’s absence, my definition of family became broad, as my sister and I looked to the support and kindness of friends and strangers alike to get by. My community included many who had come to the U.S. with the hope of finding a better future but who faced a distinct reality in trying to survive—a reality that consisted of seeing friends and family more scared of a hospital bill than the chronic pain they suffered, and of translating for family members in an emergency room at 3 a.m. when no one else could. This fueled my desire to be a physician. I wanted to understand what caused my best friend’s cancer. I wanted all to view a hospital as a sanctuary rather than as a last resort. But most importantly I wanted to provide empathy and understanding when it was most necessary. I left home to become the Doctor my community needed.

It was again seeing people around me struggle to be heard or to be seen that first drew me to the student-run clinic, the Suitcase Clinic, as an undergraduate student at the University of California, Berkeley. At times I felt that the hygiene supplies and clothing donations that I offered our clients as Health Education coordinator fell short of the reality many patients faced dealing with homelessness as soon as they walked out of clinic doors. But over the years, I realized that every story I heard, and every friendship I formed with those who came to clinic represented a tie to my community. A deeper understanding and connection that compelled me to make the extra time to help a client after clinic closed or go beyond my expected role to find a resource for patients. It was an effort to ensure that patients knew that if nothing else was consistent, clinic could be a dependable source of hope.

As a Family Services Specialist for the University of California, San Diego, I carried the lessons from my community work forward to support families on what was often their worst day following the passing of a loved one. For some, that meant helping facilitate the process of organ donation to help their loved one give the gift of life, while for others it meant overcoming every hurdle to make sure families could say goodbye to their loved one in person at the height of the COVID-19 pandemic. At times working in 24 to 48-hour shifts, I quickly learned that part of being an advocate within healthcare meant going beyond one’s comfort zone to help those in times of crisis begin to heal. It was treating a patient and their family as a whole and being willing to meet families in their grief and anger. Despite differences in culture or language, it was my desire to understand and the humility to know I did not have all the answers that allowed me to connect with families, and where words failed, have my actions reflect my commitment to patients and families alike.  

Time and again, I desired to see in medicine a physician that reflected my community.  Part of my struggle to become a doctor stemmed from a desire to be represented and to belong. That sense of belonging did not come until I had the privilege to be a part of the underrepresented student pathway program, the UCSF Kaiser Permanente Undergraduate Research Internship (URI). Here, for the first time, leadership embodied vulnerability, and the son of a housekeeper could believe he had something to offer medicine. Research came to represent an avenue through which I could bridge my love of learning with my commitment to service. I came to see the discovery and mentorship inherent to research as an avenue to assume leadership and disseminate knowledge to communities that would otherwise not have access. I knew I wanted to someday continue research as a physician so that I might serve as a bridge between my roots and academic medicine, and thereby promote the health of vulnerable communities and the empowerment of diverse scholars. I continued to work toward this goal by returning to the University of California, San Francisco, as an instructor for the URI Leadership Curriculum and as a clinical research coordinator for the Pediatric Surgery Division. Through these experiences of learning and teaching, finding a renewed purpose in working alongside future leaders in healthcare.

I am a culmination of my experiences as the son of immigrants and as a healthcare advocate. I have seen the importance of staying connected to the spaces and people who have helped raise me. I know that part of the fight to respect the autonomy of patients and make healthcare a human right will require advocacy both in and outside of clinic. I adamantly believe those I have had the privilege to grow alongside in my journey toward medicine will be instrumental in seeing the realization of this purpose.  My commitment to someday work as a physician for all, but especially the vulnerable and underserved, emanates from knowing that it has often been these people whom I have called family.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As I sit down with Harvey inside of clinic and begin to bandage his hand, he tells me about the dog that attacked him on the street. Despite my insistence for him to see one of our providers in the clinic, he is reluctant and continues sharing. Unfortunately, his story is not unique. Many who came to the Suitcase Clinic and were unhoused often shared the neglect and violence that came with their day to day. Something I knew little about. But on those days when I came into clinic ready to learn from patients, I was able to earn their trust. As I walked with Harvey to see one of our providers after some convincing, I realized that for many who routinely encountered discrimination in society at large for being unhoused, it might not be enough to be a physician. I had to be someone that they could trust, someone who they had seen week after week in their community. Who I was as a person came before who I was as a physician in meeting a patient's needs.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: The fight to address the systemic and structural barriers that compromise the health of our communities is larger than any one individual. But the strength and solidarity I found in pathway programs like the UCSF/Kaiser Permanente Undergraduate Research Internship (URI) demonstrated to me that making a difference started with empowering others. By returning to URI as an instructor and helping elucidate the hidden curriculum behind medicine while mentoring students, my impact was seen in the cohorts of other underrepresented first-generation students that continued their journey into medicine with a renewed sense of direction and hope. By working with this community, students walked away with the support and resources needed to assume leadership roles in service organizations and enter medical school. Gradually I knew that each contribution I made contributed toward my dream of having medicine better reflect the diversity of the communities it seeks to serve.
7_-_COVID_Impact: At the height of the COVID-19 pandemic, my uncle passed away due to COVID and my sister was admitted to the hospital after developing a pulmonary embolism. My bout with the disease alongside many family members caused me to consider whether medicine was a ‚Äúrealistic prospect‚Äù after months of being unemployed alongside my mother and seeing our financial resources dwindle. This in turn led me to delay some of the steps needed to move forward with improving my application and applying to Medical School. However, against the advice of even some of my family members, I began taking post-baccalaureate coursework at UCSD Extension and volunteering at St. Leo‚Äôs Free Medical Clinic while seeking work. At that point in my journey, I felt I could lose everything. Yet, I chose to focus on the eagerness and love I could only derive from pursuing higher education and working in my community in the hopes of someday entering medical school.

Hrdshp_Comments:
My parents, who immigrated from Mexico and El Salvador, saw education as the key to success, but getting into college was not the final step in reaching my aspirations. As a first-generation college student, I lacked mentorship in navigating higher education and was lost in accessing the resources needed to succeed at this level. Initially, I managed to keep up with the newfound rigor of my courses while juggling work to support myself. But as time passed, I began to struggle and didn’t know where to turn for help. Raised in a Latino household, where mental health was never acknowledged, this struggle felt like a reflection of my ineptitude as I lived in denial of any issue.
It was not until the end of my junior year that I came to terms with the reality that I needed help and was diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder. With therapy, I overcame my depressive episode and learned coping techniques for my anxiety. As a result, I succeeded in the rigor of my academics, the pressure of being a new high school teacher, and the complexity of graduate school research. My experience also informed my teaching as I supported students struggling with their mental health. Through my challenges, I am grateful to have gained invaluable emotional growth and the confidence to handle any stressors ahead of me.
personal_statement:
My family talks about their horrifying accidents and near-death experiences in a nonchalant manner. My father is no exception. Scars run down his legs because scalding oil spilled onto him as a child, severely burning through layers of skin. Since the nearest hospital was two hours away, my grandmother, a self-sufficient mother of 13, took it upon herself to treat his injury by applying melted tire to the wound to kill off any infection. The carefree nature with which my father relayed this contrasted sharply with my horror at hearing a remedy that seemed worse than the injury.
To this day, my Abuelita trusts herself more than any doctor - using VaporRub to treat a swollen ankle or instructing my dad to sleep with onions in his socks when he has the flu. I understood why my grandmother had to use drastic remedies after visiting Mexico and traveling to my dad’s secluded childhood home. The dark, dirt-floored kitchen where he was born hardly seemed like a safe place to go into labor. The disparities in access to health care and my grandmother’s earnest attempts to heal first inspired my curiosity for medicine and desire to help those in underprivileged communities. However, my family’s contradicting attitude of deference and distrust for physicians created a confounding perception of medicine and our healthcare system.
My great-grandmother, Tité, listened intently, nodding as her physician explained her condition. At the end of the explanation, she turned to my grandmother, “Que dice?” Tité sat behind a wall of confusion, unable to understand a word of the prognosis. When her physician was hesitant to perform a life-saving surgery because of Tité’s age, my family’s demeanor quickly turned to skepticism as they whispered doubts about the physician’s rationale. I was perplexed by this sudden shift to distrust, but it was not an unusual reaction for my family. Their experiences unveiled my naivete of idealizing our healthcare system as infallible and echoed a trend of medical distrust felt by minorities. These realizations inspired the hope that, as a physician, I could be a part of shaping the necessary change in our healthcare system.
Seeking to address inequities in education, I joined Teach For America, where I first experienced the weight of responsibility for someone else’s future. After a long day of conferences, our team of ninth-grade teachers was excited to meet with our last family, but the room quickly sobered as we saw the concerned look on Elisa’s face. “I’m doing my best to take care of my grandson,” she said defeatedly, “but I don’t know what else to do.” My chest felt heavy hearing her sincere hopes for his future, but as we made a plan to support him, this weight gave way to purpose.
Every time I walked into my classroom and met 32 pairs of eyes beaming expectantly, I felt the onus to ensure my students’ academic success and address their individual needs. Unfortunately, I found that the latter was not always within my ability. I could not change their home life or quell the frustration of schooling as a new English learner. Rather than be defeated, I used this as motivation to do what I could - providing individual tutoring or a safe space to talk during office hours. Their excitement to learn and increased confidence highlighted the direct impact these actions could make, and I relished my responsibility to my students despite how daunting it initially seemed. However, seeing students fall behind due to chronic health issues or worries for their families' health during the pandemic made it clear that education could not always come first.
Drawn back to medicine, I began shadowing at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, where I met Dr. Alice Chung, who embodied the ideal physician I once naively imagined. I listened intently as she patiently guided me through the steps and rationale behind a sentinel node biopsy and lumpectomy - my eyes transfixed on her steady hands, etching through layers of fat to free the tumor.
