Elated with my newfound grasp of these procedures, I left inspired by the warm learning environment Dr. Chung created and energized by the prospect of carrying my role as an educator into medicine. On my next shift in the clinic, the patient from the OR sat in a pink gown - her ecstatic smile was contagious as she heard about the procedure’s success. Her relief exuded everything I hoped to provide for my patients: the triumph of their fight, the serenity of better health, and the anticipation for their future.
While Abuelita’s home remedies inspired my initial interest in medicine, my community’s distrustful attitude toward our healthcare system transformed it into a drive. The lack of representation in medicine made my goal of becoming a physician seem distant, but it motivates me to push forward in hopes of serving as a mentor for students with backgrounds like my own. While I hope my background creates a comforting space in healthcare for members of my community, it will also inform my practice as I work to improve the position of underserved communities within our healthcare system. Though my care as a physician will look drastically different than my Abuelita’s, I will carry her same passion to each patient I encounter, hopefully, equipped with more than onions and melted tires.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
As a teacher, I saw differences in my students‚Äô motivations and learning styles. I quickly realized that it would take much more than simply implementing lesson plans for all my students to find success. I created individualized assignments for my students with disabilities using sentence frames with word banks and bilingual assignments for my English learners, leading to a shift in my students‚Äô confidence. While accommodations were originally unfamiliar to me as a new teacher, it became clear how essential they were for my students‚Äô learning. _x000D_
_x000D_
By acknowledging my students' differences and adapting my curriculum to meet their needs, I created a classroom where everyone could find success. I‚Äôve learned through my students that without embracing diversity, we risk isolating groups and limiting their capacity for growth. As not all systems equitably support the diversity of our population, we must take steps to learn about the inequity that impacts marginalized groups within our society.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: In Teach For America, I had the opportunity to work in an underprivileged area where I discovered the most important aspects of being an educator were patience and the flexibility to meet students where they were. One student, David, deflected any serious conversations about his mother‚Äôs absence but stood on tables or walked around during class to cope. I used these moments to talk about what he needed rather than penalize his behavior, building a relationship based on communication. When David moved away, he emailed me, ‚ÄúNo matter what I did the day before, thank you for acting as if nothing happened the next day.‚Äù I was surprised at the impact that seemingly small actions could make, as it felt like a given to reset each day. As a physician, I hope to care for my patients with the same patience and flexibility to create comfort in uncertain times.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
While teaching at a school with a predominantly Latino population, I saw how my students and their families were disproportionately affected by the pandemic. My students struggled with academics as concerns about the health of their families overwhelmed them. The pandemic was just one example of disparate health outcomes marginalized communities face, but the issue is far more pervasive. These observations pushed me to be a physician that can help improve conditions for communities like mine._x000D_
_x000D_
While looking forward to volunteering in a hospital again after transitioning from being a full-time teacher to a student again, I found it challenging to find volunteer positions, let alone anywhere I could directly assist patients. Thankfully, I found the Pre-Health Volunteer Program through Cedars-Sinai, which allowed me to shadow two physicians for a quarter last fall. As I continue volunteering at Cedars-Sinai, I also hope to find other physicians open to shadowing despite the pandemic.

personal_statement:
“Ok Navin, let’s try reading through this list next!” I was twelve-years old when I watched my once jovial Uncle Navin, with surgical staples holding his skull together, struggling along with the help of a hospital rehabilitation therapist to verbalize first-grade level words. My uncle had already defied the odds by overcoming cancer, but this did not stop his battle with alcoholism and Bipolar I disorder from manifesting into a life-threatening skull injury that left him disabled for months. He miraculously recovered and returned to living independently, so my family was devastated from his sudden death years later from a completely unexpected cause: a heart attack. I struggled to come to terms with his loss because in my heart I knew his death was due to more than some uncontrollable physiological etiology. I understood my uncle’s death as the culmination of enduring a lifetime of various factors that deteriorated his health ranging from growing up in a culture that did not recognize mental illness as a disease, unhealthy lifestyle choices, and financial barriers that prevented consistent access to healthcare. My memories of my uncle and everything he endured left a deep impression on my understanding of the complexity of health and spurred my desire to pursue medicine to counter the health disparities he faced. 

During my time in college, I was compelled to pursue majors in Anthropology and Psychology and develop outside of the classroom in order to learn about medicine from a holistic, biopsychosocial perspective. I reveled in mentoring a small group of middle school girls in Oakland and helping them develop into leaders for their underserved community. My mentees divulged that many of their peers worried about their next meal, and I was proud to see them transform interventions we brainstormed together into school projects ranging from hosting food drives to making educational posters. My mentees motivated me to become a physician who could not only heal patients, but could also provide the guidance needed to confront major health crises propagated by cycles of intergenerational socioeconomic inequality. As a university health worker, I also offered health-related advising and directed my peers to take advantage of accessible hospital resources. I saw first-hand how breaking down knowledge barriers could alleviate health disparities by trickling down to affect peoples’ health at the level of preventative care. Though I was not always able to address all my peers’ unique health concerns, I discovered showing compassion as a non-judgmental, approachable equal was another crucial aspect of providing care. 

I further deepened my understanding of medicine through working as a surgical assistant at an oral and maxillofacial surgery practice and witnessing the immense responsibilities of a doctor. As I handed instruments and monitored vitals during these high-pressure surgeries, I watched in awe as the surgeon deftly performed his procedures while soothing his patients. It was here that I had the revelation that the beauty of medicine is in its paradox: it is as much an art in responding to the patient’s emotional distress as it is a science in treating their physiological needs. I later jumped at the opportunity to work as a clinical research coordinator for the Stanford Pediatric Oncology Department having experienced the importance of clinical research in providing my dad, a CML patient, with a life-saving targeted therapy drug. I observed oncologists working together with families to make hard decisions concerning the best interest of the patient, how long to pursue treatment options versus prioritizing quality of life, and avenues for making chronic care more accessible. I realized the discipline of medicine appears deceptively black and white when in reality it requires navigating through a sea of grey. I often think of little ten-year old Tim, who had multiply relapsed anaplastic astrocytoma, who came to Stanford to enroll on a phase I trial utilizing electric fields emitted by transducer arrays attached to the scalp to halt mitosis in cancer cells. Though he was clinically improving on trial for a year, his interval MRIs served as a dismal reminder that his disease was still progressing. Despite the terminal nature of his cancer, Tim exuded life whenever his neuro-oncologist or I talked to him about Star Wars or engaged him light-saber battle while pretending to be Darth Vader. His giggles lit up his parents’ eyes, and his mom constantly expressed how grateful they for these valuable moments of joy with their son. It was clear to me that even when a cure is out of grasp that a physician could still be a pillar of solace for their patient. As I move forward on my journey to become a doctor, I envision a future where I can bring a radiant smile to the face of a suffering patient like my Uncle Navin or Tim.

My experiences have shown me many avenues for enhancing the lives of others whether it be through performing a life-altering surgery, serving disadvantaged communities, educating the masses about public health crises, or researching to further innovations in cancer treatments. As long as I am equipped with the armor of medicine, the sky is the limit in terms of how I can care for humanity.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I have always appreciated being able to live and work in environments where I am constantly being stimulated by different cultures, religions, and perspectives. I had one experience when volunteering the hospital where a nurse asked if I could bring a heated blanket to an elderly Chinese woman in pre-op. I could sense how nervous the patient was when I approached her, and I also realized she did not speak English. I did my best to make her feel comfortable, and after I noticed that she had a picture of a dog on her phone screen we bonded through sharing photos of our dogs. When I discharged her after her procedure, the sweet lady shook my hand and had her son thank me for making her feel comfortable when she was feeling scared. Her son told me that she previously avoided going to the hospital because of her inhibitions with the cultural barrier. In the future, I will continue to find ways to connect with patients from diverse backgrounds in ways that will transcend cultural barriers
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Even more so through working at Stanford during this COVID-19 pandemic, I have seen the socioeconomic barriers that our patients experience with healthcare access, as many of them live in areas of California that lack health clinics that can provide the specialized care they need. It is hard seeing families struggle to make ends meet to bring their children all the way to Stanford from all over California to receive care, and being exposed to this reality really opened my eyes to the scarcity of physicians. I have been working with the Stanford IRB and the sponsor for my clinical trials to gain approval for my study patients to get the standard of care aspects of their therapy at clinics closer to home. Seeing the challenges presented to our healthcare system during this COVID-19 pandemic and impacting our medically underserved communities has further solidified my desire to pursue medicine to work on finding ways to expand healthcare accessibility for patients of all backgrounds.

Hrdshp_Comments: As a child, my five person family solely relied on my father’s income and federal assisted programs like WIC. Additionally, besides needing to provide for our nuclear family, my immigrant parents provided monthly financial support to relatives living in both Mexico and Él Salvador. In the eighth grade, I began cutting neighbors’ yards and as soon as I turned fifteen, I got a job as a soccer referee, a position I held for the majority of high school. Despite the role money and my parent’s limited educational experience played in my life, I made sure to prioritize participating in educational opportunities that I believed would help me be successful, such as joining the International Baccalaureate program and playing the violin for seven years. I excelled in school academically and socially in spite of the mistakes I originally made; in hindsight, due to not having a traditional support system that most of my classmates seemed to have. Throughout college, I held paying jobs, on top of my other extra curricular activities. Although, at first it was overwhelming and my grades reflected this at USC, I overcame these hardships which is shown through the exponential improvement in my academic performance. Overall, these experiences allowed me to strengthen skills that will help me excel in medical school.
personal_statement:
“Are you ready for the first case?” asks Dr. James, one of the attending doctors of the Pediatric unit at Duke University’s hospital. As I stood outside the room, one of the three residents said, “Our patient is a 3 year old boy who needs a radical nephrectomy due to a rare Wilms Tumor.” I walk into the room and see four adults surrounding a small boy hooked up to several IVs, all talking loudly in Spanish. They turned to face us and the room went silent. “Hola, me llamo Hector”, happily said the boy. Dr. James grinned and started explaining the diagnosis and case to the family, using a lot of scientific terminology. I scanned the room and saw the family members’ faces go blank.

            “¿Usted qué piensa?” asked Hector’s mom. I glanced to my sides at the medical staff to see how they would respond. After a long pause, I realized that she was asking for my thoughts. I felt my hands get clammy and the blood rush to my face. All I could think about was that I was only 19 years old and this was my first time stepping into the shoes of a physician, rather than being in the familiar role of a patient. Three days prior, I arrived at Duke University to start the Summer Biomedical Sciences Institute, a pre-health program for underrepresented minorities. “What was I doing here?”, I asked myself.  I did not know anything about pediatric renal tumors and I thought I could not give her the answers she was looking for. 

          “¿Hola muchacho, usted qué piensa?” Hector's mother asked me again intently, with more pressure. I wanted to say “No sé”, until I observed the desperate expressions on the family members’ faces. I looked at Hector’s mom and all I could see in her face was my own mother’s. She contorted her face in the same anxious and distressed way my mom did every time we went to the doctor’s office growing up. Even if it was a simple, routine checkup, my mom was always on edge because she had a general distrust of doctors and struggled to understand their recommendations, due to her language barrier. I remembered how every time we went to the clinic, I would always need to reassure my mother that she should trust the doctor. I realized, looking at Hector’s mother, that although I was not equipped to give advice on her son’s medical condition, I could still offer her reassurance and comfort. 

          “Están en las mejores manos.” As soon as those simple words came out of my mouth, I saw her tense shoulders relax, as she sighed with relief. I walked out of the room feeling proud, as the attending said, “Great job. You calmed her down more than we could.” That night, I ran through Duke’s campus back to my dorm, feeling a sense of satisfaction and joy that I will remember eternally. This was the first moment in which I felt confident about my decision to pursue a career as a physician. As I progress in my pursuit of medicine, I never forget the power of comforting words and how they can make a big difference in a patient’s experience. Even now, in my current role as a surgical assistant at a dermatology clinic, I prioritize minute details that will make the patient feel supported and heard. For example, since the majority of our patients are elderly, I will often give them an extra pillow to support their knees when they sit in the exam chair, or walk them back to their car, despite a busy schedule with back-to-back surgeries. I know my actions are much appreciated, as multiple patients have expressed their gratitude over these small gestures. 

	  While I felt like I truly understood how important it is to approach patients with empathy, I wanted to feel more prepared the next time a patient asked me for my medical opinion. In order to expand my scientific knowledge, I joined a renal research program at the Mayo Clinic under Dr. Joseph Grande. The lab focused on the role inflammation has on the development of chronic renal disease. While sifting through research, I learned that Latinx and African American communities experience the highest percentages of end stage renal disease. Immediately, I thought of my aunts and uncles who suffered from a variety of kidney problems, some even requiring dialysis. I recall connecting the dots between my experiences with my mom, families like Hector’s, and this new research I was conducting. I want my place in medicine to involve helping underserved communities that reflect my background and roots. 

          Although I have grown, and am no longer the nervous 19 year old who once stood in Hector’s room, I know that I still have a long journey ahead. I will continue to be faced with questions to which I will not know the answer. While I will feel challenged and discouraged at times during medical school, I know that I can always ground myself in my motivation to help the communities from which I come from. I will continue to build a solid foundation of medical knowledge, while never forgetting to treat my patients with empathy and warmth. As long as I stay true to myself and my values, I know I will succeed in my dream of becoming a physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: At the dermatology clinic I worked at in Wellesley, Massachusetts, the majority of the patients were elderly white people, usually over the age of 70. At first, I wasn‚Äôt sure how to connect with the patients, as I grew up in a Spanish-speaking community in Texas. Now, I was finding myself talking to people who had fought in World War II and had lived in majority white spaces their entire lives. Over time, I learned to ask questions about topics that were relevant to them, such as golf and classical music. Towards the end of my first year working at the clinic, I realized I had established strong relationships with a number of patients. One of the biggest lessons I learned is that even if I have nothing in common with the patient, I could make them feel more comfortable by asking questions about them and their lives. As I continue to move forward in medicine and interact with patients who have a different background than me, I am confident I will find a way to connect with them.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: During high school, I had a small business of cutting lawns for people in my neighborhood. There was one neighbor who I would help out a little bit more than the others, Holly, a 70-year-old widow who lived alone. In addition to cutting her lawn, I would clean out the gutters on her roof, remove weeds from her garden, and move heavy furniture around her house. She would make snacks and I would sit and talk to her about her children, old jobs, and her mother. Even after I moved away for college, I always saw Holly when I came back for the holidays and helped fix things around the house. My favorite part about visiting Holly was seeing how happy and excited she was to have someone to talk to. I knew these small gestures meant a lot to Holly. My visits broke up her monotonous days and made her feel heard. As I move forward in my career and personal life, I will never forget how small acts of kindness can make a difference in someone else's life.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Right before the pandemic, I joined a research lab at the Children's Hospital of Los Angeles. After working in the lab for a few months, I realized I had a good opportunity to build upon my prior research experience and work with an increased level of autonomy. Once the pandemic occurred, all work in the lab stopped and I was unable to progress further in the research. Due to COVID-19, I lost the chance to enhance my research skills and potentially get published. The pandemic also gave me perspective on living in the present moment. Originally, I was going to apply to medical school a year ago, but since COVID-19 caused me to spend the entirety of my senior year in my childhood bedroom, I realized that I should maximize each day and not wait for the future to experience the world. In a few weeks, I will be starting a months-long backpacking trip across South America where I will not only explore the continent, but also volunteer at rural medical clinics.

personal_statement: The first time I put on my SCUBA gear and dove into the deep blue sea was unforgettable. My heart pounded in my ears, but everything went quiet as soon as I reached the bottom of the reef wall. Thousands of colorful fish surrounded me, and I could have watched them for hours. I was 16 at the time and had dreams of being a Marine Biologist. I grew up in rural Missouri but was in love with the idea of playing in the ocean for my job. I thrived in the first year of my Marine Biology program and wasn't ready to return home for the summer. I was hesitant because it was finally time to empty my late father's storage unit. Nestled between dusty tackle boxes and faded Western novels, I came across his diploma from nursing school. His stories about the elderly and newborn patients he loved caring for flooded my mind. Flipping through his old notebooks, I yearned to hear more about his nursing days and ask what it was like to care for patients at opposite ends of life's spectrum. Sitting in my oceanography class the following year, my peers gushed about their dreams of jellyfish genome research and advocacy for manatees. Similar aspirations weren't there for me. I struggled to find meaning through work in marine science. As I was considering other career paths, a family friend suggested I shadow a doctor at the local hospital. I had never considered a career in medicine for myself but remembered my dad's enthusiasm for healthcare. The next week, I drove across town on a chilly night and stepped foot in the ER. One patient I saw had come by EMS in respiratory distress. The doctor entered the room while nurses and respiratory therapists bustled around the patient. A woman was on the stretcher, doubled over, eyes wide and gasping for air. With a calm demeanor, the physician assessed her and quickly ordered treatments. Before long, the patient was at ease and chatting with the medical team. This was exactly the kind of direct impact that was missing in my pursuit of marine biology. After that night, I found myself googling "roles of a doctor" or "how to become a doctor." I felt I was on the right track, moving away from marine biology and toward a future in healthcare, but I needed more experiences with patients to be sure. I sought out a job as a Medical Assistant in my last semester. From sick visits to chronic disease follow-ups, I loved the variety of encounters. One afternoon, I was restocking the table paper when a coworker alerted me that the next patient had arrived. Collecting his vitals, I asked about the reason for his appointment that day. I saw the hollowness in his eyes with tears streaming down his cheeks as he told me that his thoughts were too much for him to handle on his own anymore. After his appointment, I watched as the physician walked his patient to the door, still offering quiet words of support. Meaningful relationships are central to who I am, and I was humbled by the trust present in this encounter. To have interactions with patients built on this level of trust would be a rewarding privilege. In an effort to expand my experiences in healthcare, I worked two jobs during my gap years. Recalling my excitement from shadowing, I returned to the ER as a scribe. Being exposed to endless specialties, I imagined myself in the Cardiologist's shoes, rushing a patient to the cath lab. Or as a Surgeon, sitting with an anxious patient before her first surgery. In all scenarios, I saw myself as a physician, treating a patient in their time of great need. While the ER was exciting, my time in AmeriCorp allowed me to incorporate my passion for community service and address healthcare inequality. On my first day, my supervisor whisked me around the city as we visited free clinics: one in a homeless shelter, one at the Vietnamese community center, and another at the crisis nursery. I observed how an acute illness or untreated chronic condition could unravel a person's life, especially in an underserved community. "Ann" came to the clinic multiple times per month. Between her debilitating migraines and a car crash that broke her pelvis, Ann could never seem to catch a break. Because of her health problems, she bounced between jobs. I assisted Ann where I could, by helping in her job search and accompanying her to food banks, but her health was the one thing I couldn't affect. It was also the obstacle I wanted to help with most, because I could see how deeply intertwined her health was with the rest of her life. Finding my dad's old nursing school books in that muggy storage unit planted a seed that I didn't know I needed at the time. It started me down a path away from an unfulfilling career and toward becoming a physician. My earliest patient encounters affirmed my desire to pursue a career in which I could form lasting and impactful relationships with others. In recent years, I've deepened my understanding of healthcare by exposing myself to areas of healthcare that are often overlooked. I want to be a physician so I can more powerfully advocate for underserved patients like Ann, who I've been fortunate to serve in my limited capacity thus far. If given the opportunity, I look forward to having a direct impact on people by treating the most central aspect of a person's life: their health.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: When I was 16 years old, I packed two large suitcases and moved nearly 5,000 miles from home. I was selected to participate in a year-long program called the International Fellowship Classes. I left my small Missouri hometown behind to live and study with a diverse group of high school students from around the world. Coming from a homogenous class in my hometown high school, I was certainly nervous at first. I wondered if I would be able to relate to my new peers, especially with language barriers, but I can honestly say that leaving home and embarking on this year abroad was the best decision I could have made. At an age when my thoughts and views were especially malleable, I learned valuable life lessons by interacting with students who were different from me in so many ways. One of the most memorable lessons I learned through this experience is to always be mindful of opportunities to form a personal connection with someone.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As a Community Health Worker, one of my main responsibilities is reaching and supporting marginalized groups in the community that I serve. My role allows me to meet and work with people from many different backgrounds and with very different life experiences than myself. The community that I serve in south St. Louis has a large Bosnian population. Many of these families face the same challenges to accessing healthcare as other south St. Louis residents but with the added obstacle of a language barrier. In an effort to eliminate this additional barrier, I‚Äôve advocated for quality and linguistically appropriate care in the form of screening forms and health education in Bosnian. I‚Äôve also connected with a local pharmacy owned by a Bosnian woman and established a partnership with her to further serve the Bosnian community. Through this experience, I‚Äôve learned the importance of uplifting others‚Äô voices and offering support as we navigate and eliminate barriers together.

personal_statement:
On a crisp fall night, I responded to a paramedic intercept request for a burn victim across county lines. Unable to gain more information by radio, I didn't know I had two patients – or the severity of their burns – until arriving on scene to a bloodcurdling scream that pierced the night sky. I found the first of two young women burned to disfigurement and was stunned to see EMT's pouring bottles of cool water over her violently shivering body – a direct contrast to our training of keeping severe burns dry to prevent hypothermia. However, she screamed the moment the pouring stopped and begged for it continue. The crew asked me what to do and, forced to choose between prolonging her suffering or putting her into shock, I froze in the face of this lose-lose decision and focused my response elsewhere, ignoring the pouring as it continued.

Perhaps I prioritized her comfort despite knowing hypothermia, not pain, endangered her life. However, we all collaborated before I briefly stepped away to balance two patients at once – an event reminiscent of ER shifts when I’d see one doctor manage multiple critical patients by delegating teams. Successful care required a physician equally skilled as both a communicator and a clinician. The leader sets the tone in high-stakes settings where chaos cannot reign. I aim to become that leader.

My road to medical school, though lengthy, proves linear. Growing up with a medical helicopter pilot and an ER/flight nurse meant trips to the hospital as kids for a handoff between parents who worked overlapping shifts. On busy nights I’d witness the ER’s commotion in awe, later spending years as a trauma “patient” for physicians at MCW’s ATLS course. Such early exposure to both medicine and education drew me to both careers as I became an English teacher by day and an EMT by night. My patient care interest prevailed and I went straight to graduate school, researching public health, clinical simulation, and how handoff communication impacts patient outcomes. 

My inherent drive to serve and love of patient care run deep; however, I’ve grown constrained by the limitations of EMS despite reaching the highest level of prehospital training. I feel incomplete leaving patients at hospitals with lingering questions that I long to answer, and I crave the knowledge base to search out solutions. Everything clicked when my full-time position in an urban hospital provided a front-row seat into the work of a physician.  Once I witnessed doctors balancing the roles of skilled clinician, effective leader, and real-time educator, my own career paths collided into one profession before my eyes and ignited the drive to become a doctor. My calling became instantly clear and I've worked toward it ever since. 

When I had to withdraw from school in fall 2018 to make ends meet, I focused on teaching myself MCAT subjects while balancing full and part-time jobs – the only feasible option. This employment shift in my journey proved a blessing when I led training for the second-largest ambulance service in Wisconsin. This experience also revealed my own ignorance once I ran 911 calls in Milwaukee. Early on, I judged a patient whose children slept on a bare mattress on the floor. I subsequently responded to countless barren apartments where piles of clothing served as beds. Months later, my perception shifted when I saw another bare mattress and thought “At least they have a bed." I realize that physicians must exercise self-awareness and reflection to actively avoid bias as leaders; that experience reminds me I’m still learning. 

Years of experience taught me how patient care ownership extends beyond clinical skill and problem-solving; it requires the humility to seek help answering what we ourselves cannot, and the perseverance to lead an entire team through a perpetually strained healthcare system. Over time, I’ve embraced the satisfaction and pressure of steering the clinical ship. As an educator at my core, I’m also committed to building the future of medicine with generations of ethical, kind physicians by teaching them to approach patients as people we serve, not problems we fix. 

I recognized the healing impact of kindness and compassion in my care of “Kelsey,” the second burn patient from the night noted above. Once the helicopter arrived for her critically-injured cousin, I focused solely on Kelsey, who calmly conversed throughout our 35-minute transport despite her own serious burns. She shared her goals, fears, and even plans to start physical therapy school the following summer. Sensing her resilience, I encouraged her for the grueling road ahead with my belief that she'd undoubtedly emerge from this even stronger. Kelsey later thanked me for our conversation in an email, saying the night was “a blur” yet she remembered our talk, writing "I was able to talk to you about so much because I felt comfortable enough." That next July, I saw Kelsey by chance at a library as she started PT school. She leapt to greet me with a hug, unhindered by the protective compression garments encasing her arms and legs, and shared her new goal: treating burn patients. Words can't express the joy of seeing a former patient happy and healing; as a future physician, I'm elated to know she won't be the last.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: While living in the city of Chicago, a miscommunication led to a terrifying encounter with police in which I was mistaken for an intruder in my own home. This humbling experience completely reshaped my skewed perception towards forceful police encounters with civilians. While in my home, officers ‚Äì with guns in hand ‚Äì opened my front door and ordered me to raise my hands, which I did. As a first responder, I've strongly supported police and believed everyone should "just comply" to prevent problems - until that moment. Despite their commands to step outside, I froze where I stood, confused and genuinely fearing I‚Äôd be shot with one wrong move. I was then briefly detained until the confusion was resolved; one very kind officer apologized, but another scolded me for not complying. I now understand how fear and panic, not just aggression or defiance, might influence behavior with police. I‚Äôm also perceptive of everyone‚Äôs communication and actions when viewing recorded police interactions.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As an BLS/CPR Instructor of 10+ years, I've directly and strategically led CPR education initiatives to provide instruction and certification in areas where such opportunities previously did not exist or were not economically viable. In Milwaukee, I appeared on Telemundo/CBS TV with the AHA as we - in Spanish - demonstrated/advocated for CPR in the Latino community, after which I subsequently instructed Spanish-language CPR classes for a schools, businesses, and licensed health care facility in the region. As the ‚ÄúCommunity Liaison‚Äù at the only hospital in Racine, I successfully gained CPR instructor status for hospital-employed athletic trainers when Wisconsin mandated CPR/First Aid certification for public school coaches. In turn, our athletic trainers provided free CPR classes for coaches at all eight schools in the region, saving school districts this massive, sudden expense while proudly fulfilling our hospital‚Äôs service-oriented mission.
7_-_COVID_Impact: COVID-19 directly delayed my application by two years, as I registered in October 2019 to take the MCAT in March of 2020 and apply that spring. My workload at Paratech surged in early 2020 between Milwaukee 911 calls and contracted COVID transports; I also oversaw and authored decontamination policies. By summer of 2020, COVID‚Äôs impact on Paratech forced me to quickly find a new job which shifted my focus away from applications as I postponed my MCAT again. As the demands of my new full-time teaching role overlapped with my September MCAT prep, I planned for my next attempt. I also stepped up at my second/part-time job to cover COVID shortages, averaging 22 hours per week in 2021 as colleagues retired or resigned when loved ones succumbed to COVID-19, while others were directly stricken with the virus itself. With the combined workload and global shutdowns, I deferred my application one last year to build savings, spend time with loved ones, and briefly travel before medical school.

Hrdshp_Comments: My path to be a prospective medical school applicant has been atypical compared to my peers due to my identity as a minority disabled queer female from an underserved community/county. My mother came from Mexico to the United States with no high school diploma, barely any knowledge of the English language, and barely any finances to be able to survive in an apartment with 5 other individuals in San Bernardino county. Throughout my life, I had to learn Spanish to assist my mother in various social situations. In addition to this, schools in San Bernardino country have been notoriously underserved and underfunded. Many advanced placement courses and extracurricular activities, that many of my fellow college peers were able to participate in, were unavailable in my area. My high school at the time had no college advisors and the counselors of my high school could not assist me with applying to colleges outside of the Southern California region. Even the ability to afford tutors was a struggle as our family finances were primarily used to cover debts and help fund a sustainable living wage for my extended family in Mexico. Additionally, I am a disabled female who has faced issues including PTSD from my childhood and family abuse. My upbringing might have had several disadvantages, but I have thrived from it.
personal_statement:
Junior year, undergraduate thanksgiving break. For most, those words invoke memories of roasting and carving turkey with extended family or Friendsgiving with roommates. To me, it reminds me of shouting out of a car for my mom in Spanish down the streets of Fullerton, 40 miles away from my hometown. My mom’s mental illness seemed to mimic Murphy’s law: anything that can go wrong, will go wrong. On top of that, all mentions of mental illness and caring for mental health were immediately met with shushes, as such conversations are seen as taboo among immigrant Mexican parents. These factors culminated in how on thanksgiving night, I found myself searching for my mom, wondering if I should withdraw from Berkeley and temporarily abandon my physician dreams to take care of my family. Yet, my tumultuous upbringing secured my desire to become a doctor and gave rise to all of the strongest qualities I embody today.
	
	I was never unfamiliar with hospitals growing up. I was diagnosed with alopecia areata at age five and then diagnosed with chronic idiopathic urticaria at age fifteen. Additionally, I would accompany my mom to her own physician appointments, to support and translate for her when necessary. I was in and out of emergency rooms and physician offices for my autoimmune diseases and helping my mom navigate the medical system for her declining mental health. Over time, I became familiar with the settings and feelings that lingered in a medical environment. What initially was the fear of developing a worse condition became the comfort of knowing that even in the worst condition, my primary physician would work endlessly to help me survive and thrive in my state of health. The dedication that physicians had to surpass all medical improbabilities became a strong source of inspiration for me. Through this inspiration, beginning at age 15, I decided to volunteer in my community hospitals and further solidify my desire to become a doctor. As I began volunteering and interning at local hospitals, I started to view hospitals and the medical field in a new, yet familiar, perspective than I did as a patient. I realized, through both volunteering and in doctor appointments with my mom, that there was a severe lack of Spanish speaking medical personnel. Moreover, I observed how undocumented immigrants faced a plethora of barriers when it came to getting the care they desperately needed. The lack of Spanish speaking physicians and challenging barriers for non-American citizens led to my mom feeling helpless, and eventually led to the worsening of her mental health as she felt discouraged to advocate for herself with her broken English. She became exhausted with her doctors asking my dad and I questions on her behalf, rather than making an attempt to talk to her directly. This saddened me greatly as I knew her doctors were trying their best to alleviate the strain of her conditions, but that there was an overall health disparity for non-English speaking patients. As a bilingual volunteer, I began to readily offer my services to translate and provide a more comfortable environment for patients and physicians alike as I understood first-hand how frustrating a language barrier can be. Moreover, I eventually started a Refugee Clinic at San Francisco General Hospital as I recognized, from personal experiences, the constant dilemma of going to hospitals as an undocumented individual and the struggle to find a hospital that would be willing provide care. Assisting in hospitals not only strengthened my passion to become a doctor, but I realized the set of skills I had that were valuable to the medical community.

	When in late 2018, my mom’s mental illness took a turn for the worst, I had a decision to make: continue my undergraduate career 400 miles away or temporarily leave it behind to care of her. I ruminated my choices, as I knew my mom needed an advocate and translator. On the other hand, I had put in endless hours of effort in becoming a pre-med student. As a consequence of the choice I had to make, I spent restless nights worrying and my grades quickly declined. After a few unpleasant months, I made a final decision to finish my education and attempt to support my family from a distance. It was not easy helping file police reports and keep my mom stable hundreds of miles away, but I could not give up on my “American Dream” so easily. As a first generation Mexican-American, I understood the privilege that came with studying in the United States and the desire that immigrant parents hold for their children to become successful academics. Furthermore, I knew that if I continued working towards my aspiration, I could become a physician that advocates for patients just like my mom and alleviate the health disparity immigrants face daily. Even though the choice was distressing, I knew I needed to follow through on the dream I worked perpetually to flourish into a reality.

	My road to realizing my dream of becoming a physician has been arduous, yet I have embraced the challenge. Overcoming all of these challenges has made me more driven to become the physician I know I can be. As my family always reminds me, Mexicans are innovators, creatives, and above all we never give up. After all it is “Mexi-can” not “Mexi-can’t”.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Volunteering as a medical staff member at concerts all around the Bay Area has allowed me to work with an array of diverse individuals. I worked with colleagues and patients who widened my horizon to many different backgrounds and viewpoints. I learned to be more culturally competent all while doing the best I could to protect and aid the patients I served. Moreover, working with a diverse team at every event helped me comprehend the different ways one could help their patient and the best ways to respond to patients' concerns. I began including follow up questions outside of the typical A&O times 4 questions that we were required to ask. This allowed me to understand what further actions an individual patient might prefer, what precautionary measures we might have to take due to cultural or religious restrictions, and helped myself and my team understand the individual as a whole rather than just another emergency call.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: In 2017, I began interning as a health advocate at San Francisco General Hospital. I would work first-hand with patients to assist them with external needs: housing security, legal documentation, and government relief services. At this time in San Francisco, there was a high influx of immigrants due to fears over increasing border control and refugees due to ensuing wars. Latino physicians and myself noticed there were several immigrant patients who needed resources to establish their life in the US. As a child of a Latino immigrant, I understood firsthand how obstacles related to assimilating to a new culture could negatively impact one‚Äôs health. I used health advocacy research to understand what services the Latino San Francisco population desperately needed and helped establish a Refugee clinic in the pediatric department to address those needs. As our patients‚Äô achieved better health and a more comfortable lifestyle, I recognized how impactful our assistance was.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I first applied to medical schools in 2019. The pandemic hit halfway through my last semester and towards the end of the medical school cycle. As I was finishing my last courses virtually, I was working as an essential worker. As pandemic fears grew, I became lost on what I could do. Any last minute medical school interviews were canceled and I was unsure as to what my next step should be. With the uncertainty of the pandemic on my mind, I decided I wanted to help in the fight against COVID. In July 2020, I began working as a formulation technician where I synthesized oligos for research on the novel virus. I regained my footing and my purpose. In 2021, I decided to continue work on COVID by helping create a PCR detection assay for COVID and other respiratory viruses. I gained a new appreciation for research and became more resilient over time. I learned that no matter what comes my way, I will find any path I can to serve patients and the medical field.

Hrdshp_Comments: Based on my economic and social needs, I received a need-based scholarship that covered all of my costs to attend the University of Pennsylvania for all four years. I am the first person in my family to attend college, as I result I identify as a first-generation low-income student. While we always qualified for state and federal assistance programs, my mother chose not to apply to most due to previous encounters with the system as an immigrant. Prior to receiving adequate health insurance from school and my current job, we were Medicaid beneficiaries which often prevented us from accessing the care we needed.
personal_statement:
We always got our clothes from Macy’s. Expensive as they were and the amount of debt we drowned in as a result, none of it mattered to my mother. She’d tell us, “jan ou vini se jan an yo resevwa ou,” - the way you come is the way people will receive you. It was very important that we did not “look” like our circumstances. She believed what we wore provided us with an armor that shielded us from stereotypes of incompetency and miseducation, including that which stemmed from healthcare professionals. As I reflect on my experiences with the healthcare system, I wonder if my mother’s proverb held any weight and if things could have turned out differently had we remained true to ourselves.

The first time my brother complained of stomach pains, his primary care physician told us it was due to gas. She criticized our intake of Haitian food, deeming it too salty, too spicy, and too oily. And so, in an effort to resolve his pains, we deprived ourselves from the cuisines that tied us to our culture and roots. We abandoned our identity in the interests of Westernized health, sacrificed preservation to avoid hospitalization, and ironically, gave up soup joumou - our freedom soup. Unbeknownst to me, this was my first interaction in learning how individual behavior affected health. Getting sick was no longer solely due to microscopic forces that I could not understand but instead, a consequence of what we could and could not afford to eat. Although it was more expensive to reduce our intake of processed foods, we were determined to alleviate his pain by changing our lifestyle. We believed we solved the mystery of his pain, until we found ourselves in the doctor’s office once again.

The second time my brother complained of stomach pains, his primary care physician told us it was due to a stomach virus. Similar to the last visit, I noticed there were no laboratory or physical exams done. She minimized his pain and suggested we re-evaluate the spaces where we came together. Without care or concern, she patronized the large public schools we attended and the one-bedroom apartment that four of us shared. At the age of nine, obscured in this encounter was my first experience with physician bias. I realized that because my brother was a dark-skinned, athletic male, racial and structural inequalities prevented this physician from recognizing his pain. His thick skin, which could not be veiled under his Calvin Klein’s, rendered him emotionally inept. And while he might have worn his pain well, he was stripped of a favorable patient outcome.

The third time my brother complained of stomach pains, we went to the emergency room. On May 31st, 2009, dressed in our Sunday’s best, my eight-year-old brother was diagnosed with Stage 4 Neuroblastoma cancer. That day, when the attending physician palpated my brother’s abdomen under his freshly ironed button up, he was not concerned about our attempts to make a good impression; his only concern was to provide equitable care. From the age of ten to nineteen, my life was filled with hospital visits, chemotherapy trips, stem cell transplants, CAT scans, MIBG scans, and translating medical jargon into our native language for our mother. While at that time I could not fully understand the role of equity in a healthcare setting, my experiences from that moment solidified my understanding as to what it is. It is the brand new backpacks and back-to-school supplies we received every year put together by social workers from Friends of Karen when my mother quit her job to support my brother and I full-time. It is the transportation services we received to travel two hours to the Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia every week in pursuit of better care. It is the grocery store gift cards and rent assistance we received from The Valerie Fund at Newark Beth Israel Medical Center when we struggled to make ends meet. As physicians identified our personal needs as part of their clinical care, used culturally appropriate language to break down complex test results, and worked with us to determine the best treatment plans, we became better equipped to deal with the circumstances we attempted to hide. Through these experiences, I learned that an impactful physician is one who is biomedically trained to provide the best care but socially trained to recognize its barriers. My desire to become a physician who advocates for my community to mitigate healthcare disparities was solidified through my interactions with physicians dedicated to our care.

Even in the face of death, my mother held firm to her beliefs: Jan ou vini se jan an yo resevwa ou, but this time with a slight modification. In the best suit our credit limit allowed, my brother rests in the most polished, blue casket. Laid alongside him are his thickly framed glasses, his overworn blue knit hat, and his favorite black, over-the-ear Beats headphones that played his favorite rap music day in and day out. Reflecting on my mother’s words, it is clear why she dressed him this way. Although there was a desire to present him in a more assimilated manner, there is integrity to being yourself. As a result, I strive to become a physician who maintains her integrity and serves as a first line of defense for those who feel the need to hide behind a shield.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
In order to get the care they need, patients present themselves in their most vulnerable, authentic form. Yet, Black women such as myself are constantly chained to the expectation that our afros and kinks should be stowed away. Through individuals criticizing my hair and going as far as changing my texture, I realized the importance of authenticity within medicine and understanding those unlike myself._x000D_
_x000D_
My experiences have shown me the way I wear my hair does not make me a better person. The way I wear my hair does not make me a better friend, and the way I wear my hair does not determine my integrity. And while I may change my hairstyle again in two weeks, my values of empathy, compassion, and self-awareness will always remain the same. As Rush Medical College is committed to training students who can connect with diverse populations, I am confident that when my patients see me, they will see themselves. We are not our hair. We are not our skin. We are the souls that live within.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Since graduating from Penn, I have worked full time as a clinical research assistant with health equity researcher, Dr. Candace Feldman at Brigham and Women‚Äôs Hospital and Harvard Medical School. I currently manage seven projects aimed to mitigate disparities within rheumatology, all of which have helped me gain greater insight as to how social determinants of health manifest in different ways and how to measure them. For example, our Photovoice project has allowed us to empower our participants with a camera, providing them with the ability to control their narrative and share unique elements of the interplay of their environment and health that are not routinely available to healthcare providers or researchers. Through this project and others, I have been granted the unique opportunity to use research as an advocacy tool through papers, abstracts, and presentations to problem solve and share solutions within communities and beyond.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
The color from my face disappeared when I first received the notice for the immediate evacuation of students from campus. I felt betrayed by my university as it was the one place that guaranteed me financial, housing and food stability. After advocating for myself, I soon found myself in an advocacy role for others._x000D_
During the onset of the pandemic, I was forced to forgo my front desk job at the adjacent dorm Additionally, I no longer had the opportunity to shadow various physicians within the University of Pennsylvania Health System in fear of later infecting other students on campus and the older adults in my home. Despite these challenges, I was able to virtually participate in the Penn Program for Public Service to support West Philadelphia students and worked to create tangible solutio_x000D_
While the pandemic delayed many of my endeavors, I have learned (and still continue to learn) the importance of empathy and advocacy, which I hope to carry as I begin my career of serving others.

personal_statement:
Trails of ants circulate in and out of a small mound of dirt wedged between two glass panes. I watch them intently through the inquisitive eyes of a nine-year-old, fascinated by the way they invade the ground, metastasize through the soil, and establish long colonies in every direction. This distinct memory, one of nostalgia, coincides with the phrase, “ant farm”. However, this came to mean something different when my grandmother used these two words to describe her mammogram results.

Upon hearing those words over the phone, I envisioned a network of ants multiplying and migrating down several tunnels. Coupled with my experiences in oncology, I knew this sounded like ductal carcinoma. When she asked me what an ant farm meant, I could not bring myself to deliver my illustrations. All I could tell her was to wait to see how the biopsy went.

The day the biopsy results were shared, the oncologist routinely stated the cells were malignant. He nonchalantly outlined the required surgery and chemoradiation schedule. As I turned and saw her blank stare, I knew he lost her after the first sentence. This immediate disconnect with her physician eventually cascaded into a growing mistrust in science and heightened anxiety. Little did I know, my grandmother would choose me to be an integral part of her journey. Our Sunday breakfasts meant for catching up on life soon turned into Q&A sessions on the lymphatic system and why of all people did she get cancer.

No matter how many doctors she spoke to before her surgery, she always came back to me with her unanswered questions. Even with a mere biology degree, my grandmother held my opinion in the highest esteem and looked to me for clarity and compassion. My medical knowledge, limited to fundamental biology and ENT experience, could only carry me so far. Nothing had prepared me for questions on invasive breast cancer, anatomy, or the immune system. With my expertise limiting my ability to help, I felt incapable of really being there for my best friend. Nonetheless, she still looked to me for support during the scariest time of her life.

When surgery day came, she was struck with fear. Wishing I could have taken her pain, the words of my mentor came to mind: “Medicine is 90% reassurance”. I then realized the art of this profession rested upon knowledge and emotional support, the two pillars of reassurance. Without one, patient care would be sacrificed. While the oncologists were treating the cancer, they seemingly neglected to treat the person. So, with a hug never meant to be let go and a bad joke, her tears subsided. As her journey was underway, mine was just beginning.

With this thirst for knowledge, I oriented my courses at the University of Pennsylvania accordingly. I excelled in the lessons of cancer biology, anatomy, and immunology, allowing me to restore a sense of confidence in medicine in my grandmother. As the semesters progressed, our Sunday breakfasts became more substantive and therapeutic. Expressions of fear turned to understanding and her cries were now in relief and appreciation.

Seeing my grandmother receive her last chemotherapy dose with a smile that did not fade, I noticed the beautiful potential medicine holds in our lives. Only one year of advanced biology classes equipped me with the capability to affect change in a person’s life. Marking a pivotal moment in my life, a notion of rising to the challenge overcame me and inspired me to dive deeper into this frontier of knowledge.

Joining the efforts of a lab at Boston Children’s Hospital were my first steps on this path. Conducting notable immunological research that will one day hopefully lead to an effective vaccine for millions not only advanced my critical thinking, but introduced me to the unexplored lands of medicine. I then began authoring my own research study on an unprecedented case of lymphoma, published in January 2022. Months of dense literature reviews, consults with a multitude of medical specialists, and many late nights spent writing brought me to the forefront of research on this topic. Lastly, in line with my dedication to volunteering and working towards something greater than myself, I ran the Boston Marathon this past spring while raising $11,000 for the kids at BCH. From coupling these accomplishments over the past year, I now grasp the tremendous work necessary to balance knowledge and emotional support.

Despite all my clinical experience, providing this support for my grandmother through the medium of medicine has truly shown me what it means and takes to become a physician. It is an unrelenting commitment to a purpose. It is pushing your legs to their limits everyday so one kid can watch in awe as you run 26 miles and be inspired to push past their own limits. Above all else, it is a multidisciplinary approach that integrates expertise, trust, and compassion. This challenging journey has since given a new meaning to the phrase, ant farm. Now, this phrase embodies the strength of a collective effort working towards one common goal. A unified connective network of knowledge and support, all serving the patient. With passion and purpose, it would be an honor to contribute to this cohesive ecosystem for patients to come.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As an ENT medical scribe, an immigrant family came to the practice for their son. Functioning as the Spanish translator, this family recounted to me their humble beginnings working on a farm in Guatemala, with their son by their side as they needed the extra hands to help make ends meet. Being in this dangerous environment resulted in their son injuring his ear, which required an unknown surgery at a local veterinary hospital. Our audiologist detected a rare form of hearing loss caused by displacement of the middle ear bones, which the doctor suspected was a consequence of this prior surgery. Recognizing their financial status, without hesitation the physician offered to perform a reconstructive surgery pro bono. Being the middleman in this encounter opened my eyes to the financial hardships and scarce access to quality healthcare these third world countries face. My mentor‚Äôs actions elucidated the impact physicians can make in our world, motivating me to follow in his footsteps.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I have never been one to sit by and watch the suffering of our marginalized communities due to social inequities. Seeing how lower class children are disproportionately affected in their health and well-being sparked me to start ASL Sports. Everyday, these children, whether cognitively or physically impaired, are weighed down in their aspirations by society‚Äôs systemic neglect and lack of support for them. Thus, each clinic I made it my responsibility to aid in the effort of improving the lives of these children. My sports clinics did not simply teach them how to throw a ball, but also instilled the idea that disability does not mean inability. From my countless clinics, fundraisers, and support, I have since become an advocate for the hearing loss community, strengthening its voice and public awareness over my years. In medical school and into my career as a physician, I intend on continuing to address these social determinants of healthcare in our community in any way possible.
7_-_COVID_Impact: When the WHO announced the pandemic, the ENT practice I scribed for went virtual. I began aiding in the practice‚Äôs transition to telehealth and wrote newsletters for our patients discussing COVID-19. However, every uptick in cases was still adding fuel to my fire to serve and help. I hence decided it was time to improve my education so I can better make my dream of medicine a reality, starting with UPenn‚Äôs rigorous post-baccalaureate program. After converting my dining room into a classroom, I abandoned my studying habits from undergrad and focused on group learning and frequent meetings with my professors to review the past week‚Äôs material. These effective strategies towards studying translated into my successful performance in these advanced classes and later my MCAT. COVID-19 has propelled me further down this path that I have chosen. I have always had a love and passion for healthcare and COVID-19 has only made me more eager to answer the call for people in need.

Hrdshp_Comments: Being a first-generation college student from a low-income background and with an unstable home life created additional barriers to applying to medical school. Nevertheless, I developed strong interpersonal skills and emotional intelligence by navigating my father’s substance abuse disorder, which led to multiple arrests and domestic violence, and my mother’s bipolar disorder. I contributed to my family income once I started high school out of necessity, and juggled work and school even while studying abroad in college. My freshman year of college, while working full-time, I commuted two hours total every day to avoid the additional costs of living in a dormitory. Upon achieving an average undergraduate GPA, I reflected on what I did wrong and adjusted my study habits while completing a master’s degree. I have gained a lot from the hurdles I faced, including resourcefulness with free, online learning materials, open-mindedness and empathy for different walks of life, and resilience to major and minor setbacks. I intend to use my perspective to make medical school and the medical field a more inclusive space for those who grew up in similar situations and are not well represented in the field.
personal_statement:
As the Red Wings took their last slapshot in the game my family was watching, the night turned upside down. Suddenly stiffening in my mom’s arms, my infant brother was rushed to the ER while having a seizure and immediately life-flighted to another hospital. I was only ten years-old, but the time I spent in the hospital with my brother listening to the doctors give updates sparked my interest in medicine. I noted the contrast between the excellent care my brother was receiving to the lack of health care available to many in my low-income family. My budding interest in medicine became inseparable from how it is inaccessible to some. I have since sought opportunities to explore medicine and learn how I can bridge gaps in my community where inequalities exist. These experiences have affirmed that being a physician who provides compassionate, patient-centered care to underserved populations is where my passion lies.

I did not grow up in a rich family. We relied on government assistance and at times had our electricity shut off. Through hard work and a caring support network of teachers, I navigated entering college and acquiring student loans. Working full-time and commuting to save housing costs placed challenges on my undergraduate education; however, these experiences were formative in shaping my worldview and determination to make a difference.

I studied abroad in Freiburg, Germany during the 2015 European migrant crisis, an opportunity made possible by obtaining additional student loans and working while in Germany. During this time, I volunteered at an elementary school to assist children with refugee status in learning German. My first day in the classroom, I sat next to “Sara”, a six-year-old who wanted to attend school but feared being away from her mother. I asked Sara about her butterfly shirt, and although neither of us understood each other, by pointing at her shirt we were able to figure out that butterfly is Schmetterling in German and farasha in Arabic. I started to draw my own butterfly and Sara quickly joined me as we spent the day drawing various objects and teaching each other how to say them in our respective languages. I worked with Sara for a couple more weeks before she moved to a different school, and in that time, she was able to learn basic German. While I will never be able to understand the experiences Sara had before going to Germany, our time together taught me how important it is to meet people where they are. I learned that fundamental to helping someone in any capacity is prioritizing trust and emotional wellbeing.

I returned to Michigan and pursued a master’s degree in physiology to gain a stronger foundation in basic science. I began volunteering in an ICU in Detroit, and one evening, as I helped a nurse adjust her patient in bed, I immediately noticed the yellow undertone of the patient’s skin. The nurse later informed me that the patient, “Ann”, had liver failure due to drug abuse. It became routine that I would help turn Ann, and although she could not speak through the ventilator, I looked forward to interacting with her and seeing her face light up. By the third week she recognized me when I entered her room and gave a slight nod. Moments later, she coded. Doctors ran to her side as I felt my heart racing. I knew her situation was critical, but I was saddened to hear when she passed, and shocked to learn she was only a few years older than me. I repeatedly thought about what could have prevented this outcome and the obstacles she must have faced. I could not help but feel that her challenges were like those of my family as my father struggled with substance abuse my entire life, which resulted in multiple arrests, DUIs, and domestic violence. I empathized with how difficult it must have been for Ann to seek help. I admired the devotion her care team had for her and the respect they showed for her autonomy because they understood that it was her right to make her own choices regarding her substance abuse, and nevertheless did everything in their power to prolong her life. In this moment I witnessed a tremendous display of what medicine means to me—unconditionally providing for those in need.

Losing my father to the effects of substance abuse months before watching Ann do the same plagued me with the thought of knowing how preventable both deaths were. I know first-hand the impact highly trained, deeply compassionate physicians can have on families that do not have immediate access to quality healthcare. The path to applying to medical school to become one of these compassionate physicians has not been easy. I was not accepted during the 2019 application cycle, but I have persisted; I have since completed a master’s degree in physiology with a 4.0 GPA, obtained direct patient care experience as a phlebotomist, and gained invaluable research experience. Research has granted me a greater comprehension of mechanisms of disease and medical research. Through mentorship with physicians in my lab, I have gained a better understanding of what a physician does and what impact they can make. I want to honor life by using my love for science and people to promote health, especially in those without the power to advocate for themselves.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
As a waitress in an Irish pub in Germany, I worked alongside individuals from many different cultures, including those who grew up in war-stricken Bosnia, left Spain and Romania due to economic hardship, and others who moved to Germany for a less restrictive government. Hearing their stories and not being afraid to ask questions in a respectful manner taught me about their traditions and worldview. For example, I learned about what it was like being in high school at the end of the civil war in Bosnia and about the workplace norms in Spain._x000D_
_x000D_
I am now more open-minded and recognize how important controlling my reaction is when validating someone‚Äôs experience. I heard how detrimental negative stereotypes about a culture can be on someone‚Äôs mental health and value actively respecting one‚Äôs culture and protecting their right to practice it. I learned to be curious about other cultures, ask questions, get familiar with popular phrases in someone‚Äôs language, and be more adaptable._x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As a teaching assistant in Germany, I often worked with a Syrian refugee, M, who invited me to meet her family. I spent the afternoon with them as her mother kindly gave me food to try while she prepared iftar. I taught them important German words and played tag with M. I saw how M marveled at her mother‚Äôs hijab, telling me she could not wait to wear one and look just as beautiful. I noted how important religion was for her as it marked milestones along her journey growing up‚Äîit was something that remained unchanged and part of her identity. M was old enough to notice that her culture stood out in Germany and was often too shy to talk to the older German students. As I got to know M better, she became more outgoing with me and her personality shined. The more time I spent with her, the more I saw her also open up to the German kids in her school. Similar to religion providing comfort, I served as a safe person and source of stability, helping M integrate into her new school.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
Had the pandemic not cancelled volunteer and employment opportunities, I would have re-applied to medical school following an unsuccessful attempt in 2019 without mature reflection. As a result of Michigan‚Äôs shutdown, I enrolled in the M.S. Program in Physiology at the University of Michigan._x000D_
_x000D_
Immediately upon beginning the program I realized how much of a sacrifice medical school is‚Äîhow much work, time, and resources go into learning the science behind medicine. During my second semester, I started volunteering in an ICU where I felt what it was like to see vulnerable patients on such a large scale. I saw the impact of COVID spikes through the almost permanent lines on doctors‚Äô faces from the masks and the toll it took on patients to not see loved ones as I answered the phone and told family members they were not allowed to visit. Due to the pandemic, I now appreciate what I will be giving up attending medical school and the mental and physical toll a medical career can take.

Hrdshp_Comments: I was born, raised, and currently reside in South Los Angeles, an underserved community where only 5% of residents have a college education. I had to overcome a significant lack of social, educational, and safety resources in this neighborhood, including lower quality schooling in my elementary/middle school years, inadequate career mentorship, and lack of safe spaces for studying or enrichment. As the first person in my family to receive a college degree in the sciences or pursue an advanced degree, I am navigating the process of becoming a physician entirely on my own and with virtually no interaction with Latino physicians who have similar social, cultural, or educational backgrounds as me. The absence of these support networks often made me question if people like me were capable of becoming leaders in medicine. I have experienced firsthand the lack of Latino representation among physicians, biomedical researchers, and other healthcare professionals, and this has motivated me to push forward with my education and be that Latino doctor who is so desperately needed as a clinician, academic, and mentor. I hope to one day inspire the next generation of physicians who have persisted despite having faced similar social and cultural biases, so that they too may become the first physicians in their families.
personal_statement:
My first exposure to medicine is also one of my earliest flashbulb memories. My parents are hosting a small family gathering to celebrate my newborn brother’s baptism. It’s unusually gloomy and windy for a spring afternoon in Los Angeles, but this is no deterrent to a carefree six year old and his play. As the adults sip away at my grandmother’s freshly made cinnamon tea, I decide to climb our rickety swing set to impress my aunt with my monkey bar skills. I learned shortly thereafter that the Capri-Sun juice on my hands and the metal bars would not mix well. Despite the concert of mothers shouting for me to get down before I hurt myself, I climb the set, only to immediately slip and fall 6 feet into the dirt. After landing fist-first, I look down to see a bone protruding from the newly acquired 90 degree angle in my left forearm. This was the first time I had truly felt pain. Next thing I remember, a woman’s gentle voice, which I later learned belonged to that of my “doctor,” put a mask on my face and told me to blow out the magic bubblegum flavored dust. As I struggled to recall what had gotten me in this predicament, everything seemed to fade away. The amazing scent, her kind voice, and warm hand at my shoulder put me at ease as she counted down from ten. In that moment, she was at the center of my world. At a time when I was highly vulnerable, frightened, and in pain, my doctor made me feel safe. While I couldn’t have understood it at the time, this experience was one of the first instances in my life that piqued my interest in medicine and led me onto the path of becoming a healer. In becoming a physician, I hope to one day also be entrusted with the privilege of providing that same sense of comfort to patients who place their faith in me when they are most vulnerable. I believe that my intellectual curiosity and passion for community-centered care would help me achieve this goal and improve the lives of others. 
When I decided to volunteer at California Hospital, my increased exposure to physicians, patients, and the intricacies of a hospital setting further solidified my calling for the profession. Once in the ER, I met a man named Diego, who had a long, deep gash in his right leg. I could see the intense worry and pain in his teary eyes as he tapped endlessly with his non-injured foot. “I need to get better now,” he said in Spanish. “I can’t drive my daughter to school with my leg like this, and I probably won’t be able to work for the rest of the week.” He was dressed in navy coveralls, the type my father would often wear when we would do mechanic work on his car. The look in his eyes revealed to me a man whose livelihood and obligations to his family were at risk. Amidst the rushed frenzy of the ER, I reached for his hand, told him that I was with him, and that the doctors would provide him with the care he needed to return to his family. After wheeling him to an available bed and wishing him a speedy recovery, he wished me God's grace, gripping my hand tightly with both of his. He let out a sigh of relief as the ER Physician entered the room. 
I want to become a doctor so I can partake in more of these moments with patients. Diego serves as a reminder that a large factor in a patient’s wellness and healing has to do with whether they feel like someone genuinely cares about their suffering. Also, my experiences with him and other patients from my local community have inspired me to one day incorporate my fluency in Spanish and cultural awareness as a minority to connect more personally with my patients, address systemic healthcare issues, and provide higher quality care to the medically underserved. Yes, a physician needs to know how to examine the body and which drugs to prescribe, but the effects of non-medical factors such as compassion, mutual understanding, and cultural competence are often underestimated in the healing process. I pledge to adopt these values in my care. More specifically, I am called to do more for this man than just offer my words of support and encouragement. I want to not only be the one responsible for treating his injury, but also the one tasked with improving the methodologies that affect his care.
For this reason, I have dedicated my studies wholeheartedly to the sciences. As an undergraduate, I never missed an opportunity to learn more about interesting topics, ranging from Astronomy to Anatomy and Physiology. The irresistible allure of scientific discovery drew me towards biomedical research, a field that has blessed me with opportunities a young Latino from South Los Angeles could only ever dream of. Throughout my journey in medicine, I hope to build upon my interests in immunology, regenerative medicine, and cell biology to help develop cures for diseases. I firmly believe that my pursuits in academic medicine and research have enabled me to hone the critical analysis and innovative thinking required to excel in medical education and synthesize a vast array of information to improve a patient’s quality of life.
