In combining my passions for research and community-centered care, I hope to one day become a physician that is well-versed in meeting the needs of a diverse patient population and bringing quality healthcare to those who need it the most.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: At California Hospital, roughly half of the patients are Black. Connecting with these patients at the bedside made me realize that while we may not share a similar ethnic or cultural background, we share a community that affects the health of all of us. Black patients in my community of South Los Angeles have faced similar challenges as my fellow Latinos with regards to socioeconomic barriers, cultural biases in patient care, and a lack of providers who share their background. As an aspiring minority physician who was raised in an underserved area, I believe I can connect more closely with patients from underrepresented groups and understand the social determinants of health that disproportionately affect them in communities like my own. I am called to help mitigate disparities for patients from all backgrounds by communicating in their preferred language, understanding cultural differences in certain health attitudes, and doing my part to help minimize barriers to healthcare access.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Not one surgeon I rounded with for the Physician Mentor Program identified as Latino or had a working proficiency in Spanish. After a few weeks, I began to notice that the care team spent significantly less time in rooms with Spanish-speaking patients. Less time spent with the patient, coupled with difficulties in communication, can lead to them not understanding their treatment, not knowing what questions to ask, or how to properly prevent disease recurrence. Since I was often the only Spanish speaker in the group, I never missed an opportunity to hear their stories and make them feel like someone was listening to them. The appreciation and gratitude I received in return showed me that I was capable of making an impact on a patient‚Äôs wellness and inspired me to be the one directly involved in their care. I plan to become a bilingual physician that can help meet the needs of my fellow Latino community and minimize systemic inequalities that limit their access to quality healthcare.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Firstly, I am blessed to have not lost anyone close to COVID-19. My ‚Äúlosses‚Äù truly are minuscule in comparison. Despite this, the pandemic did significantly alter my status as an applicant. In April 2020, my MCAT was canceled due to COVID-19. I fully committed to take it in April so that my score was available for a timely submission of my primaries in June of that cycle. With no MCAT score or clarity regarding exam security during this rapidly shifting global event, I had no other option but to postpone my application and pursue full time work opportunities, since I was now solely responsible for supporting myself and paying my own living expenses. Thankfully, I was able to secure a wonderful position conducting research at UC Davis Health and take my MCAT shortly after that yearlong appointment. After years of postponing due to factors brought forth by the pandemic, such as MCAT delays, financial constraints, and employment, I am finally prepared to apply for medical school.

personal_statement:
M has been battling neurodegenerative Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH-ND) for 9 years. In clinic, she mentioned failing a chemistry quiz even though she exhaustively studied for it the night before and day of. She handed her notes to Dr. McClain and me- they were incredibly detailed. The material clearly made sense to her, but M blanked come quiz time. Memory function and concentration can be significantly impacted in LCH-ND patients. I saw in her face the turbulence of frustration, pain, and fatigue attached to this disease. Trying to imagine a teenager having to bear almost a decade’s worth of such experiences was heart-wrenching. Wanting to help yet unable to, I stood lips pursed in the corner as tears fell from M’s eyes. 

M is part of a study I’m currently heading trying to understand how combination chemo/BRAF inhibitor (BRAFi) therapy impacts disease presentation in LCH-ND patients. She was in complete remission 6 years ago after initial chemotherapy treatment, but relapsed in 2018. Adding the BRAFi to her regimen was a game-changer. The drug significantly decreased M’s blood cell BRAF mutation levels and the size of her maxillofacial lesions. Her ataxia score from earlier that day was the lowest it’s been in years. And, her scalp rash has nearly healed. Despite her current strife, she is faring substantially better now compared to even six months ago. 

I am following 14 other LCH-ND patients for this study. Watching scientists in my lab and physicians like Dr. McClain utilize clinical and research data to further probe the complexity of this affliction has affirmed my own desires to become a doctor. The striking vulnerability of this profession draws me in the most. Lesser studied diseases like LCH-ND compel both patient and physician to confront mortality. Though decades of experience may go into a clinical decision, nothing is absolute. Every prescription has a negation. Every choice is a frontier. The limitations of science and self are acknowledged daily. This uncertainty brings an immediacy to the moment: an immediacy of kinship and purpose for the individual’s betterment. Admittedly, I was not aware of such a dimension to compassion until relatively recently- and three years prior, I certainly did not think I would want to chase after it for years to come.

The spring of junior year, I remember my lab notebook fitfully bouncing on my left knee as three bioinformatics dot plots finished loading on Dr. Spinler’s computer screen. Quiet at first, she gradually became more animated as she deciphered the graphs. Gut microbiome population shifts were small, yet significant enough to be deemed diet induced. More testing was required but dietary microRNAs could therapeutically impact mouse gut microbiota! Walking out of lab that day, I was initially on cloud nine. Oh, the excitement! My mind raced with thoughts of diet’s medicinal utility: could microRNA biofortification of food crops be used to shape a healthier tomorrow? Inspired by agricultural giants like Norman Borlaug in high school, I’ve for years dreamt of advancing agronomy for mankind’s benefit. And there I finally was- perched on the brink of scientific discovery, with experimental findings that could help humanity clutched to my chest. This moment was supposed to be the first day of the rest of my life.

It wasn’t, however. And present day, I’m starting to understand why. Currently at Houston Methodist’s neuro ICU, I help patient care assistants check vitals, transport, and tend to admits. L is a bed bound 82 year-old lady who suffered a fall-related brain hemorrhage some time back. And every week without fail, when I go in to adjust her bed wedge, she grabs my right wrist with a vice grip. Her knuckles turn white and her hand shakes until she can’t hold on anymore. I was taken aback at first, but soon realized L was trying to tell me something. She was trying to tell me that she hasn’t given up. She was going to fight- fight her way out of the bed and onto her own two feet. That’s what I was missing in agronomy. The impersonal nature of science leaves little room for connection. That’s why, despite experiencing a momentous scientific breakthrough in lab that day, I still felt a lingering sense of unfulfillment. This pursuit did not connect me to people as I thought it would. True connection is one molded by compassion and empathy towards a human. My agronomic endeavors brought me closer to humankind, but medicine can bring me closer to the individual. Using science to initiate sweeping social change is noble, but not the way for me to find personal significance. To me, the individual is significant. Furthering M’s impetus to study despite her handicap is significant. Preserving L’s will to live is significant. Having found this beacon of meaning for myself, I hope my medical training further guides me to be an upstanding physician: persistent in his care towards humanity, one person at a time.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
In kindergarten, I remember prancing around our living room while watching TV and stepping on a pencil. The sharp point lodged itself through my right mid-foot. I immediately fell to the ground, wailing in a cloud of pain and confusion. My mom didn‚Äôt know what to do. Her English was limited at the time and we didn‚Äôt have health insurance. She ended up going door-to-door in our apartment complex, pleading for help. Thankfully, our neighbor‚Äôs daughter Sofia was an ICU nurse, who was able to quickly patch me up._x000D_
_x000D_
I did not live under such uncertainty for an extended period of time; though I cannot fully grasp what these people may endure, I can choose to empathize and serve. I currently strive towards increasing information accessibility in medicine. Since college, I‚Äôve been fascinated with our relationship to food. Through my gut microbiome research, producing my food documentary Convenience, and volunteering for the Houston Food Bank, I work to practice compassion towards those in need.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
Mentoring underserved students with Rice EMPOWER, I came to recognize the value of information. Adult role models gave me some guidance in my academic and extracurricular interests- a privilege that many of my mentees didn‚Äôt have. Their intellectual curiosity was often sidelined by survival in turbulent home environments. But that didn‚Äôt mean it couldn‚Äôt be kindled. Helping steer these kids towards career goals and higher education, I saw them roused with hope for a better tomorrow._x000D_
_x000D_
Formative experiences like these helped me reflect on how I wish to serve my community in the future. I‚Äôve come to recognize that information drives perspective, action, and acceptance. With information comes the ability to ponder consequences and make decisions appropriate to circumstance. As clinicians, being sensitive to the adversities of marginalized individuals and evolving our actions accordingly can significantly improve their health outcomes.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
I learned some significant lessons from COVID-19. Thankfully, through its height and subsequent peaks, my parents and I were able to properly quarantine and sustain ourselves. I was still in college when the pandemic hit, and was able to smoothly transition to remote class work/research. As with the rest of the country, in-person volunteering/clinical opportunities were put on hold for some months; however, I was able to redirect my curiosity for nutrition education and outreach into production work for my food documentary Convenience._x000D_
_x000D_
One slight inconvenience was the pandemic pushing my graduation date to December 2020. I was taking Calculus 2 online Spring 2020 and couldn‚Äôt manage the class with my full course load at Rice + research publication deadlines + COVID hitting. I finished all my credits except for the math course by May 2020.

personal_statement:
While my friends spent the night of the seventh-grade dance tearing up the dance floor to Lady Gaga and Katy Perry, I was trying to keep my friend alive. Adrenaline pulsed through my veins as I received a text from my friend “Allen” that stated, “I want to die.” I texted back in confusion, unable to understand why he felt that way. My confusion quickly grew into terror as he started sharing plans to end his life, and every “ding” of my phone was accompanied by a fear of that text message being the last I would receive from him. Running to my mom in tears, I realized she also did not know how to help Allen, and my heart raced as I spent the night desperately attempting to offer him the smallest ounce of hope so he would abort his plans. As the sun rose, relief fell over me knowing he survived the night. Although terrifying, I found joy in helping Allen through this crisis; however, I knew my help was only temporary. Unsure how to offer him long-term support, I turned to the internet to try to understand Allen’s feelings. I found myself intrigued by mental health and the brain as a physical organ. I started seeing my life being dedicated to being someone others can confide in when they are surrounded by darkness and from here, my eyes turned towards a career in medicine.

To further explore the field of medicine, I began volunteering as a COVID-19 screener in the oncology department. The biggest challenge I faced as a screener was at the peak of the COVID-19 pandemic. One morning, a woman named “Lynn” approached my table with her husband “Joe.” Lynn was here for an appointment, and I recited my list of screening questions to her. After taking her temperature, I turned to Joe and asked if he would be willing to wait in his car because we only allowed patients into the hospital to reduce the spread of coronavirus. He looked into my eyes and replied sharply, “If my wife is getting bad news, I want to be there with her.” Lynn looked at me with sad eyes, and it broke my heart explaining to her husband that he could not accompany her to the appointment due to the hospital’s protocol. Although we were able to find a compromise by letting him be on the phone during her visit, I longed to offer them more support. I wished I could be in that room with Lynn, holding her hand as she received news on how her cancer was progressing. Seeing both the physical and emotional toll cancer had on these patients only solidified my desire to help those in both physical and emotional crises. With a career in medicine, I would be able to support patients like Lynn in a more significant way, whether it be through healing them from an injury or helping them emotionally cope with a disease and being someone to lean on during difficult times. 

Being interested in the mind and body, I conducted psychiatric clinical research after college. My favorite part about this job was conducting structured clinical interviews with inpatients. I remember one patient, “Tim,” who had been experiencing depression and was admitted to the inpatient unit right before starting college. I interviewed him shortly after he left the hospital, and he revealed that he had been depressed for two years leading up to this hospitalization, causing a drastic decrease in the quality of his schoolwork and the recent loss of his job. With the stress of starting college in a few weeks and his friends and partner recently moving away, the lack of a close support system led him to a suicide attempt. After being started on an antidepressant, his mood greatly improved, and he had not felt depressed since leaving the hospital. It was incredible to see that a physical drug had drastically changed his illness for the better. With this improvement, he reported that he was excited to start college the following semester after taking some time to focus on himself. I loved speaking with Tim for several hours and learning about the numerous challenges he has faced. I want to continue to make deep connections with patients, learning about their stories and how their illnesses impact them. Although his illness delayed his start of college, medicine was able to return Tim to his baseline, putting him back on the path of furthering his education. For people like Tim, the hospital holds the last glimmer of hope that things can improve. Working with inpatients has further revealed a passion for working with people in acute distress. I want to have the skills and knowledge to help reunite people with the things their illness took away, helping them heal and return to a life of normalcy. 

My experiences have shown me that medicine is more than making diagnoses and providing treatment. Throughout my life’s journey, I have found a passion for helping people in crisis. As a physician, I look forward to helping people heal, hearing my patients’ stories, and connecting with them on a deeper level. I want to give my patients a voice and empower them to live life to the fullest. I am excited to work on fixing problems and understand the humans underneath them-- listening to the hardships my patients have faced and celebrating the victories they experience.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: When I started conducting clinical interviews as a psychiatric research assistant, there was one group of disorders that I was uncomfortable with: substance abuse. Having lost a loved one to a drunk driver, I came into this job believing many stereotypes of this population. I did not understand why someone would let themselves become addicted to a substance. As I began interviewing this population, my viewpoint quickly changed. I remember "Zack," who described a history of childhood physical abuse, ultimately leading to opiate addiction in his 20s. He had been in and out of rehab for several years, trying to get clean but struggling greatly. Hearing stories like Zack's has helped me understand the mindset of addiction and the pain this population experiences. These illnesses impact every aspect of their lives, including their daily functioning and relationships. I quickly learned to view a person as a whole, not as a diagnosis.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Cornell's peer mental health counseling training program questioned how we could transfer our program to an online format due to the COVID pandemic. Being in-person helped create a group identity and allowed students to bond before and after class, building trust with each other. Our biggest concern was: how do we create an environment where students can build rapport with one another through a computer screen? A team of myself and four other trainers met weekly over the summer to brainstorm how to overcome this transition in the fall 2020 semester. We piled into a zoom call, clicking random buttons until we mastered various features. We created new skill exercises utilizing breakout rooms and the whiteboard feature. We ultimately had a successful transition. The majority of our 90 students we onto the next level of training. I am thankful that we could still create an environment that allowed students to be vulnerable to one another and learn skills they could use to help their peers.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I had originally planned to volunteer at Cayuga Medical Center starting in March 2020; however, my start date was delayed to September due to COVID. I was also originally going to volunteer in the Emergency Department; however, I was switched to a COVID screening position in the oncology department. In my peer mental health counseling experience, we switched to only conducting counseling sessions over the phone and ultimately decided to suspend the service starting in November 2020, cutting my counseling experience shorter than expected. My time conducting research at Cornell and being on the Cornell Concert Commission were also suspended in March 2020 at the start of the pandemic. Although many of my activities were canceled altogether, I am thankful I was still able to participate in many things I enjoyed, even if in a strictly online format.

Hrdshp_Comments: I believe I would be considered disadvantaged due to Las Vegas being medically underserved for the majority of my childhood. Growing up, the closest hospital was 20 minutes away. My dad also received unemployment benefits for a period. Lastly, I received free lunch from kindergarten to my senior year of high school from the National School Lunch Program.
personal_statement:
“¿ Mija que dice el médico?”, (honey, what is the doctor saying?) is a question I heard throughout my childhood. As a first-generation child of immigrants, it was bestowed upon me to serve as a translator, interpreter, and historian for my Spanish-speaking parents, aunts, and uncles. Being merely 8- years old, the nature of these conversations was often out of my grasp. I struggled with how to communicate a family history of leukemia, diabetes, and extensive heart disease when these were alien-like words to me. However, as the years passed, I communicated the excessive thirst, frequent urination, weight gain, dizziness, and headaches that eventually led to my mother being diagnosed with diabetes and hypertension. I later understood how important it was to accurately communicate a patient's symptoms. The alien-like words I was exposed to as a kid piqued my interest in medicine. 

This interest and desire to become a physician were further cultivated by my own healthcare experiences. Serving as a scribe for an oncology & hematology clinic exposed me to a side of medicine I hadn't yet seen. I learned what the whole process of diagnosing entailed. Extensive medical history, family history, pertinent negatives, and seemingly unrelated symptoms are pieced together, like a puzzle to form a cohesive diagnosis. Once, I was present in the room when a patient was told they had cancer; this was a humbling experience. I recall being upset earlier that day that there was traffic and my favorite coffee was out of stock. At that moment, all my trivial problems vanished. I was struck with feelings of empathy and awe as I observed the patient say “I will beat this'' as tears stained her face. I want to be a doctor to deliver these difficult conversations with compassion and develop their treatment plan.

As a scribe, I also served as an interpreter for the many Spanish-speaking patients in the clinic who mirrored my family. It was hard not to see my parents and grandparents, who bore overwhelmingly similar socioeconomic circumstances. My encounter with a 60-year-old woman who had just been diagnosed with mesothelioma was a full-circle moment. I was able to aid some of her confusion and fear by being a source of familiarity. Relaying to her the extent of her cancer, available treatment options, imaging, and the urgency in which these had to occur was a challenging task, one where I had to find the strength to convey this without worry or fear in my voice. This further motivated me to become a physician to help bridge the cultural and language gap that exists locally and nationally. 

In contrast, my earliest experiences in healthcare were in the realm of pediatric cardiology, where the gravity of situations is often expertly masked with fun and the promise of a gift from the treasure chest at the end. Having congenital aortic stenosis, my earliest memories have always been in Dr. Mayman’s office. He always made me feel safe and took the time to explain my condition in a manner I could actually grasp as a kid. He diminished the fears I later had concerning my heart and future health. Dr. Mayman further impacted my future health by being a source of encouragement and support in my struggle with childhood obesity. He never shamed me as other adults in my life had, but made healthy eating and exercise seem fun. This nurtured a dedication and determination to lose weight in order to be the healthiest version of myself as I could be. In him, I saw a mentor and someone whose empathy, compassion, and understanding I hope to emulate one day as a physician. I aspire to become a physician to impact and support another child's health, much like Dr. Mayman did mine. 

At the time I didn't know it, but the theme of heart health would come to be a repeating arc in my life. Heart health, or rather the lack of it, would come to be the demise of three of my grandparents. At the age of 12, I experienced the death of my grandfather. I couldn't understand how the man who always protected me could succumb to illness so suddenly. At that moment, I learned death doesn't discriminate and can happen no matter how loved a man was. I felt so helpless, like a passive bystander who could only watch as her grandfather collapsed on the floor. My maternal and paternal grandmothers' subsequent deaths 10 and 13 years later bore a similar arc of lack of access to specialty care in a rural community. The closest cardiologist was 3 hours away and trying to schedule one visit, let alone multiple regular visits, was timely, costly, and often unattainable. While I know nothing can stop death, I can't help but wonder if access to regular specialty care might have extended their life span even if only a couple of years. 

These experiences molded my desire to increase healthcare access to rural communities that so deeply need it. I hope to one day add to the growing community of physicians who are already working to remedy this inequality nationally and internationally. I want to become a physician to help bridge the cultural and language gap evident in our community. My experiences as an oncology scribe, translator, and interpreter will aid me in my journey to become a well-rounded and empathetic physician; I will no longer be just a passive bystander.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Growing up, my whole family was devoutly Catholic- weekly outings to church and pilgrimage trips to Mexico surrounded my childhood. This was true for 12 years of my life. At this age, my aunt announced she had converted to the faith of Jehovah's Witnesses (JW) which shocked everyone. I did not know what JW believed and had trouble understanding how my aunt could ‚Äúabandon‚Äù our family. As time passed, however, I understood she was not abandoning us just because she was transitioning to a new religion. Instead of dissecting the reasons for her decision, I accepted her choice because she is my aunt and I love her. I‚Äôll admit when I learned she would not accept blood transfusions because they are against her beliefs, I was shocked. I couldn‚Äôt understand how she could deny something the doctor, who had her best interest in mind, recommended. Eventually, I realized while her beliefs are not mine, I respect them. My aunt brought a diversity of beliefs into our religiously homogeneous family.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I have volunteered with disadvantaged populations through the Operation School Bell program by helping facilitate a back-to-school shopping experience for kids. They choose school supplies and clothes. My first time volunteering at this event was inspiring; I couldn't have predicted the joy the kids expressed. I also have volunteered at the Las Vegas Rescue Mission, which provides meals and shelter. I helped prepare the dining hall, clean the dishes, and serve the food. I got a holistic view of what helping this underserved population entailed. It was unlike anything I had ever seen. I learned just because you are an adult doesn't mean you cannot face significant struggles that can result in being left without a home or health coverage. I learned never to judge someone's situation and to treat everyone with kindness and respect. The empathy and compassion I developed for these underserved populations is something I will continue to reflect on in my pursuit of a medical education.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The pandemic was a turning point in my academic career. In this uncertain time, when everything in the world shut down, my classes moved online. Having never taken online courses, it was a big change for me. Ultimately, I adjusted to this online format and thrived in my last semester of college. I found I enjoyed online classes as they had recorded lectures I could refer to at my leisure. Apart from completely switching my learning dynamic, the pandemic canceled the shadowing and research opportunities I had lined up. However, the pandemic motivated me to pursue an avenue of volunteering I hadn't ever thought of- hospice. The elderly population was one of the most affected by the pandemic. I chose hospice volunteering to provide the needed support that was lacking. People were cautious about leaving their homes, and as a result, the number of volunteers dwindled. Ultimately, the pandemic was overwhelming, but I gained the love of hospice volunteering.

personal_statement:
After securing the final bolt of the new centrifuge rotor, I watch as thousands of specimens travel down the green, felt conveyor belts on the two 100-foot-long automation tracks at Northwestern Medicine's Central DuPage Hospital. As the samples divert to the pre-analytical modules and analyzers, I can't help but think of the doctors and patients who depend on these machines. I currently work for Beckman Coulter, a company that sells diagnostic analyzers to clinical labs. My official title is "Field Service Engineer," but in truth, I am a repairman. I maintain massive automation tracks in large hospital systems across the Chicagoland area. These tracks process up to 1,450 samples per hour, taking over all the steps in sample processing, including centrifugation, aliquoting, sampling, and storage of the specimens. Any track downtime significantly impedes physicians' care decisions for patients. I joined Beckman Coulter to combine my engineering background and passion for technical problem solving with the ability to have broad impacts on patient care. Supporting healthcare infrastructure is not glamorous, but it's satisfying to know that my work helps thousands of patients receive the treatment they need.

Part of the satisfaction of my work comes from knowing that infrastructure like the automation tracks allows doctors more time with their patients. As a Medical Scribe for Dr. Fotso, I witnessed the large impact that a little extra time has on patient care. Dr. Fotso runs a Family Medicine practice in a fast-paced outpatient clinic. Being trilingual, she has built a large patient population, specifically in Hispanic communities in Chicago's western suburbs. As a scribe, I aided Dr. Fotso by recording procedures, diagnoses, treatment plans, prescriptions, and follow-up information, often listening to conversations in Spanish and transcribing them in English. Early on in my role, I learned to predict the treatment plans for common conditions for her patient population: increased metformin doses for diabetic patients with consistently elevated A1cs and decreased lisinopril doses for hypertensive patients after weight loss and diet change. But there were often more complex cases where the technical solution was unclear. I struggled to imagine how Dr. Fotso would handle a patient suffering from severe depression following her sister's suicide or a patient with terminal liver cancer who confided in us that she couldn't bring herself to tell her loved ones that she was dying. In these moments, Dr. Fotso always took extra time to simply sit and listen, even with a packed schedule. I saw how this patience and grace had built a foundation for trusting relationships with her patients, allowing them to be vulnerable and share their feelings of fear and uncertainty. For me, it was a lesson that it's often the humanistic, not the scientific, side of medicine that has the most impact. It showed me that great caregiving requires a commitment to understanding the entire patient.

While working as a Medical Scribe, I also volunteered as a Sexual Assault Victim Advocate, where I began practicing the caregiving techniques I saw Dr. Fotso use with her patients. In my role, I traveled to emergency rooms throughout DuPage County to counsel survivors, offer them resources, and educate them on different legal and medical options after these traumatic incidents. With 99% of all sexual assault perpetrators being male, I was mindful that my presence could be a barrier to the healing process and that earning survivors' trust was paramount. Over time, I learned to tune my body language and stay soft-spoken to communicate to survivors that they were in a safe space. Helping survivors work through their feelings of fear, anxiety, pain, confusion, and guilt was challenging. I came to see that no two survivors' healing plans were the same. Some needed to pursue legal action to find peace and healing, while others simply needed a confidant to externalize their experience. Working as an advocate showed me that effective caregiving requires a tremendous amount of self-awareness and adaptability on the part of the provider. Patients deserve personalized treatment plans, and physicians must uncover each patient's unique needs to guide them in the right direction.

Through these experiences, I've seen that practicing medicine is not all that different from the operation of the automation tracks that I work on. Similar to how the centrifuge separates a specimen's different layers before routing to the necessary analyzer, a physician must separate and understand all components of a patient before guiding them through one of the many clinical pathways toward healing. A physician must use their technical knowledge to physically treat a patient; however, it is those humanistic skills – interpersonal warmth, patience, and a willingness to listen – that allow doctors to understand each patient's perspective. As an engineer, the technical side came more naturally to me. But over time, I learned the humanistic side and realized it is the driving force in my path toward becoming a physician. As a future Family Medicine doctor, I look forward to merging these two facets of medicine to guide patients with individualized care plans.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
When Roberto, a Spanish-speaking patient of Dr. Fotso‚Äôs, came in for a hospital follow-up visit, he explained how thirsty he‚Äôd been feeling. Reviewing his chart, I saw that he was prescribed two medications for his newly diagnosed diabetes. During the encounter, we found that he wasn‚Äôt taking either medication, and his blood glucose level was over 500mg/dL. Before probing for the root cause, I assumed he wasn‚Äôt taking the initiative in his health; however, I discovered that he misunderstood his treatment plan through the interpreter._x000D_
_x000D_
In retrospect, as a native English speaker, I realized I‚Äôd taken my healthcare accessibility for granted and assumed Roberto had the same knowledge of diabetes. This experience taught me to refrain from prematurely faulting patients and instead, strive to understand and help them overcome the limitations they face in their care. In doing so, we can work toward providing education and resources to vulnerable populations to help close our nation‚Äôs care gap.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As a Sexual Assault Victim Advocate, I helped survivors overcome their horrific, life-changing experiences. I worked to create a trusting, non-judgmental space for survivors to share their experiences and emotions to help lead them down the best path to healing. I calmed one hysterical survivor by facilitating breathing exercises, offering a hand to hold, and reiterating that nothing that happened to her was her fault. After establishing trust and validating her emotions, she confided in me that her uncle was her perpetrator, and she was scared to pursue legal action even though she knew it was best for her emotional healing. After hours of discussion, I assured the survivor that she wasn‚Äôt alone in her journey. By supporting this survivor and connecting her with various legal and counseling resources, I helped her uncover what was best for her overall well-being, and she courageously opted to pursue legal action and perform a medical evidence kit to begin her healing process.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Upon graduating, I planned on gaining more clinical experience during my gap years. Due to COVID-19, I struggled to find available clinical opportunities. Although limited, I still felt a call to action to help the struggling healthcare infrastructure in any way I could. Four months into the pandemic, I got the opportunity to contribute as a full-time Medical Scribe for Dr. Fotso and volunteer as a Sexual Assault Victim Advocate. As a scribe, I helped Dr. Fotso with her administrative duties, thus enabling her to catch up on an appointment backlog by scheduling more patients each day in an already underserved Hispanic community. As a Sexual Assault Victim Advocate, I helped provide care and healing to survivors of trauma who otherwise might have fallen through the cracks. Although the pandemic limited the available opportunities, I worked hard to find clinical experiences that allowed me to help provide care to members of my community while also making me a more well-rounded caregiver.

personal_statement:
When I was two years old, I showed signs of pituitary cancer. I was referred to Children's Hospital in Los Angeles for a barrage of tests. There I met my childhood hero, Dr. Kaufman. She made me feel safe in a scary place. As my endocrinologist, she ruled out cancer and diagnosed me with precocious puberty. From then on, I received monthly injections from my pediatrician and visited Children’s Hospital multiple times a year. It was the compassionate care that Dr. Kaufman provided that originally inspired me to become a physician. I want to provide a sense of safety for patients like she did for me. Working as an EMT in the field and alongside physicians in the hospital for almost a decade has caused my initial curiosity in medicine to bloom into a lifelong passion.

I worked so diligently in school to become a doctor that I earned a scholarship to a prestigious private high school. Unfortunately, after transferring there in 11th grade, I found that homophobia was commonplace. At a time when I was coming to terms with being gay, it was hard to be in a school that codified their opposition to LGBTQIA+ rights in their policies. I ended up dropping out, but I was undeterred from my goal of becoming a physician. I went to community college to finish my high school diploma and start my pre-med coursework. I was also able to get into UC Berkeley for Molecular and Cell Biology and complete a hands-on hospital internship which confirmed my desire to become a doctor.  

The first code blue that I witnessed during my internship was a transformative experience. A man in his twenties came into the ER with chest pain. An EKG revealed that it was a STEMI and within minutes he went into cardiac arrest. I’ll never forget the rapid, tactical response of the hospital code team as the patient’s eyes rolled back into his head. They placed the pads on his chest and restored a pulse with a single shock. When the man started talking again, it felt like I had witnessed a miracle. Seeing the ER nurses and physicians save his life has been a major influence on my pursuit of medicine and my deep interest in emergency care. 
My fascination with the ER motivated me to become an EMT. I have had so many meaningful patient care experiences as an EMT, such as my first serious trauma call at the retirement community. At four in the morning, an elderly man tripped and fell on a glass table. I found him on the floor in a pile of shattered glass bleeding profusely from his head and complaining of neck pain. Being the only EMT on shift, I simultaneously held his c-spine stable and put pressure on his head wound. I told him the fire department was on the way and that I would be here for him until they arrived. I saw his overturned walker and made a joke about him needing to take some driving lessons which put him at ease. I loved providing care in the field as an EMT, but I wanted to do more.

When the pandemic hit, I pivoted to the hospital environment to work more closely with physicians and help address dire staffing shortages. As a patient transporter in radiology, I made an effort to read imaging reports and assist with interventional radiology procedures. This gave me a deep appreciation for the work that radiologists do in both diagnosis and treatment. I remember seeing my first CT-guided biopsy of a liver mass—I helped the radiologist, Dr. Acquarelli, collect the sample and hand it off to a pathologist who determined it was benign. The fact that they could diagnose a condition by simply looking at a scan or a slide amazed me. This is an ability I hope to possess one day. 

After years in the healthcare field, I secured my ideal pre-med job as an ER EMT. The ER doctors I work with are inspiring. Whenever we have a critical patient, a calm settles over the room when the doctor walks in. We recently had a patient in SVT with a heart rate of 210. She was terrified. I repeated EKGs and set up for a cardioversion while asking the patient about her family to distract her. Dr. Moya, the ER doctor, walked in and put her hand on the patient’s shoulder. She explained the effects of adenosine in a calm and soothing manner. The nurse administered the medication at the doctor’s order while I performed a Valsalva maneuver by lifting the patient’s legs in the air. Her pulse rapidly shot down to 80. I want to provide definitive care like Dr. Moya that can pull patients out of scary situations.

Providing patient care alongside inspirational physicians like Dr. Moya and Dr. Acquarelli has continuously reaffirmed my desire to become a doctor. The seed planted by Dr. Kaufman has been watered by the many kind physicians I have met along my journey. As I reflect on my path to medicine, I am reminded of a quote that I pass by every day at Cedars-Sinai: “The bridge between doctor and patient sustains both.” Throughout my life, the doctors and patients that I interacted with have kept me both grounded and motivated to move forward. The more I have learned about medicine and applied it to practice, the more fulfilled I have become. I would love to bring my knowledge of patient care to the next level in medical school. I know that charting a course to restore and maintain the health of people as a physician is my true calling.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I have worked with a variety of diverse populations. I grew up in a suburb, so I wasn‚Äôt really exposed to those less fortunate than me that often. In my first EMT job, I transported unhoused psych patients who were detained by the police during a crisis. We would wait for hours at psychiatric facilities. The conditions and care they were subject to was abhorrent. I learned that our mental health system needs improvement. It creates an unending feedback loop.  They get released after 72 hours and come back weeks or days later to the same facility.  I also worked directly with inmates at LA‚Äôs largest jail. In listening to their stories I often found out they had been suffering from a condition for weeks before they were provided care. I learned that I want to make conditions better for underserved communities. We need more funding for safety net programs and to address the social determinants of health. We must fight gentrification and urban decay, and improve healthcare access._x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
We need more LGBTIA+ physicians, especially with the increase in people identifying as transgender and non-binary. Just recently I had a transgender patient who came into the ER for suicidal ideation. She was misgendered and misnamed multiple times by staff. I was able to advocate for her by offering to be her sitter. I informed all staff of her preferred pronouns and name. We need to change how the healthcare system treats LGBTQIA+ people._x000D_
 I am the first person in my family to be openly gay. This was hard to come to terms with since I live in a conservative community where casual homophobia was common. Coming out was difficult, but I paved the way for my cousin to come out too. I‚Äôm passionate about impacting the queer community in a positive way. Queer people are much more likely to be unhoused, have mental health issues, and commit suicide. I hope that I can introduce policies to deal with these problems and increase healthcare access for all underserved communities. _x000D_
_x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact: When the pandemic hit I had just begun a new research position studying inflammatory bowel disease. I was also working as an event EMT on the side at LA‚Äôs largest stadiums. All events ended during the pandemic, so we were hired on by the CDC pandemic response team at LAX where I screened travelers for COVID symptoms. I was also able to review newly published research on IBD and COVID-19 at home until our lab re-opened fully at my research job. After my CDC job ended, I wanted to keep up my clinical skills and help the sick during the pandemic. I took the first hospital job I could find as a transporter. I was able to minimize suffering under catastrophic conditions. With this experience, I was able to get a position as an Emergency Room Assistant a year later where I now provide care and assist physicians with procedures. These positions provided me with so much physician and patient interaction, and further confirmed my desire to become a physician.

personal_statement:
The alarm clock hits 5 AM. I never used to think of myself as a morning person, but the prospect of going to work at Dermcare has me excited to start the day. I spring out of bed. Yes, I will take that cup of coffee, thank you. My racing heart is not caffeine-induced; my excitement for another day operating as Chief Medical Assistant has my heart pumping.

Assisting physicians during surgical procedures and office visits in the dermatology clinic synthesized my passion for hands-on clinical work and finding novel solutions that materially impact lives. After several months, I was offered a leadership role and worked even harder. Leading the team gave me immense accomplishment and pride, heightening my enthusiasm for providing patients with the highest standard of care. I looked for solutions to make the office more efficient while never sacrificing the care a patient would receive. I gradually became adept at collaborating with my fellow staff, finding room for improvement, and accepting responsibility for the actions of those on my team.

One regular patient still stands out: Leo (alias). Leo is deaf, and the first time we met, his anxiety had understandably got the better of him. I had to take special care to ensure he understood the procedure he was about to undergo. I assisted during his first Mohs surgery to remove a squamous cell carcinoma from his nose. The clinic was fast-paced, but I always endeavored to elucidate the nature of the procedure at length for the patient's comfort. As Leo read my lips, I could feel his tension dissipate. The mere explanation of each step and subtle movement of my lips brought him closer to comfort and healing. While this job provided me with a strong foundation for a future in healthcare through clinical skills, it was just as critical to continue to practice soft skills. I understand how important it is to be able to comfort someone, to patiently listen, communicate clearly, and emphatically advocate for my patients' needs. Talking to Leo pre-op was a seminal experience because I learned two things: First, I had developed an effective and compassionate bedside manner, sufficient to calm down even challenging patients, and second, I felt called to continue this work for the rest of my life. I want to continue studying via medical school because I want to be able to educate, advise and comfort using the knowledge I have learned.

Clinical experiences with patients like Leo illustrated to me the need for innovative medical solutions and my desire to apply them hands-on. My background in research was driven by a desire to solve the structural challenges faced by the human body. This hope propelled me to jump at the challenge of working at the Infant Vision lab at Boston Children's Hospital. I researched Retinopathy of Prematurity, a curable form of blindness if treated early. I created a novel predictive model that could assess the children's future eyesight up to 20 years post-diagnosis, enabling us to predict their future visual acuity. I love creating these models, and moreover, I want to implement them hands-on, seeing how my work directly affects people's lives. I have consistently positioned myself at the cutting edge in the hopes of pushing the field's boundaries. At the Harvard Medical School's Kreiman lab, I worked on creating a customizable head-mounted display for blind people that provides audio guidance to describe their surroundings using artificial intelligence and helps them navigate the world independently. While running experiments on blind participants, I heard firsthand from them how most present-day technology does not work for differently-abled people. This calcified my determination that medicine must seek scientific means to tailor treatment to the individual and make these tools accessible and more affordable for patients.

At Neuro-Electronic Research Flanders in Belgium, I taught paralyzed mice how to walk again and investigated the mechanisms of circuit assembly behind their locomotion to potentially apply our findings to people with spinal cord injuries. The opportunity to investigate promising research that can transform patients' lives was edifying and intellectually stimulating.

Presently, I have been re-hired as a Pharma-Collaboration Associate at Benevolent AI, a London-based drug discovery company seeking new therapies for undertreated diseases. My end goal has always been clinical medicine, yet I believe this role will help me to formulate and implement cutting-edge solutions in the field.

The spirit of reform and equality is core to my desire to work in this field. I have lived abroad before and seen alternative models of care, from the UK's NHS to Japan's SHIS, which inspire me to work toward reforming American healthcare. 

I am resolved to contribute to the lives of my patients by creating and applying avant-garde solutions to medical problems. I am ready to dedicate my life to this mission. I have proven my capacity for leadership, excellence in care, and innovative methods. Medical school will teach me the necessary skills to make my vision a reality to provide compassionate care, implement cutting-edge innovations and help impact people's lives for the better.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
I lived on a rough street for many years in college. It was a street people avoided at night because of a large tent encampment and a hub of gun violence._x000D_
One day, I left my apartment early in the dark morning, tripping over a person lying on my front door. A man was sleeping on my stairs. _x000D_
‚ÄúAre you all right?‚Äù_x000D_
‚ÄúI‚Äôm okay.‚Äù_x000D_
I was heading out to get coffee and offered to buy him a cup. Returning with caffeine, I asked if I could sit with him. After exchanging names, I asked if he felt comfortable sharing how he ended up on my front door. His story was unexceptional but tragic. By no fault of his own, he had lost everything. A man, down on his luck, with no safety net. His story could easily have been my story. Or my parent‚Äôs. Or anyone in America. Before I left, I gave him a blanket and my new unisex hiking boots. My neighbors living in tents now had a name, and their stories had a face. The empathy I gained will last me a lifetime and will inform my decisions as a physician and activist
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I had a patient with late-stage Alzheimers at Dermcare. I was the medical assistant during his melanoma excision. He suddenly became aggravated in the middle of his surgery and accused us of scamming him. He tried to stand up and came close to breaking the sterile field. This was a huge issue; he could give himself an infection. I reassured him and calmed him down. I saw his anger came from a place of fear. The explanation of the procedure soothed him, so I talked through the rest of the surgery. Afterward, we sat together until his family returned. I saw how medicine is deeply personal because people are at their most vulnerable. My presence made him feel more comfortable by lessening his fear and keeping him safe from touching the incision. A seemingly small act of compassion and understanding can have the biggest impact. As medical professionals, often the most important part is not the physical care we provide but the emotional support we give patients. _x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact: When Covid began, I lived in an apartment with six other students. Their adherence to Covid restrictions varied, prompting me to return to living with my parents until it was safer to return to campus. Unfortunately, my parent's rural home lacked wifi for most of each day. When it was functional, it could only handle one device. Moreover, my mother and younger brother were also attending virtual classes. Consequently, it was challenging to attend class regularly. I strove to participate despite these barriers by being flexible and finding creative solutions. However, it still affected my academics. I had to take two courses as pass/fail despite personally calling the utility company repeatedly for months.

Hrdshp_Comments: In 1987, my family braved the difficult journey of immigrating to America to provide their children with a better life. My parents worked tirelessly and sacrificed a higher education to provide the means to pursue our dreams. Thus, I did not have the luxury of having my own room or bed, as I shared with my father. My father handled his grief poorly when my grandmother and aunt perished in that catastrophic plane crash. He became an abusive alcoholic. Ultimately, he left our family without a word about his whereabouts. As a result, my mother could no longer afford the mortgage, leading to the foreclosure of our apartment. We were homeless but found refuge with my grandparents in a crowded house with six residents. Therefore, I slept on the floor with a mat so my sister and mother could sleep on the couches. Despite the circumstances, I was grateful to have a roof over my head, food on my plate, and surrounded by people I loved. I expressed my gratitude to my grandparents by helping them with chores and caregiving, such as medication and transportation to doctor appointments. Spanning multiple generations, I became the first in my family to attend college with the help of FAFSA and many private loans that included the cost of living, knowing that I would be solely responsible for repaying the total amount.
personal_statement:
My body subconsciously reacted to each step as we crossed the jet bridge. My heart rate elevated; sweat beads raced down my body; my knees began to wobble. Twelve hours prior, we had received a life-altering phone call. My grandmother and aunt were on board Air India Flight 812 when it crashed upon landing. Amidst the ensuing chaos, we booked the next available flight for the funeral. When the plane approached the runway, I began hyperventilating, and the knot in my stomach tightened. I was initially perplexed by this feeling, but in hindsight, I realized I had a panic attack. My mother sensed my inner turmoil and held my hand, which eased my anxiety. That day, I learned that challenges could arrive suddenly and that tribulations do not have to be confronted alone.

While I could not tell her, my fascination with medicine stemmed from my time with my grandmother. She was diabetic and had a walking impairment. As a result, we formed a partnership; to compensate for her immobility, I became her insulin courier and observed each injection. Galvanized by the prospect of a cure, I joined a research lab in college to investigate the induction of hepatic insulin secretion. I was ecstatic to apply my classroom knowledge to a cause close to my heart. With each pipette, I imagined a future where daily injections would become obsolete, preventing others from becoming insulin-dependent. While the lab work satisfied my craving for problem-solving, I considered research too impersonal. 

I coveted personal relationships like the one I had with my grandmother, which can only be achieved through patient-physician partnerships. Therefore, I joined Adapted Fitness, an organization aiming to encourage exercise for people with physical disabilities. This club was the catalyst for my companionship with H, a lady with muscular dystrophy and a positive attitude similar to my grandmother’s. H’s goal was to enhance her ability to stand and walk. Thus, I curated an exercise regimen suitable for her goals and household with limited equipment. I taught her how to perform step-ups on a staircase to strengthen her legs and utilize her couch headrest for assisted squats to build her core stability. Moreover, her mental fortitude seemed to surpass her physical limitations, enabling her to persevere through adversity. H compelled me to change my definition of health. As a former athlete, I defined my wellness by tangibles such as speed and strength. However, H’s wellness was not limited to such measurements. She taught me how my perception of an individual can evolve and how patients can enrich my life. Due to our lengthy companionship, I observed a striking improvement in her independence, which affirmed my ambition to become a physician. I cherished improving the mobility and self-sufficiency of someone like my grandmother. 

Observing H, I saw that her care was not limited to physical therapy. It encompassed multiple disciplines and modalities of healing. I was drawn to participate in a healthcare setting that implemented interdisciplinary treatment. Therefore, I became an ophthalmic technician at a retina clinic. One memorable patient, T, was an elderly man who had a tractional retinal detachment caused by diabetic retinopathy. I conducted the fluorescein angiogram that elected T for surgery. I simplified the steps of the procedure, giving T the confidence to proceed with the surgery. After T’s PCP faxed us his clearance, we scheduled him for surgery. Finally, at his post-operative examination, I read the notes sent by the surgery technician and removed his bandage. T’s gratitude for my role in saving his vision invigorated me, and I was proud that my collaboration with like-minded individuals culminated in T’s recovery.

While striving for the best outcome for another patient, S, I formed an unexpected connection due to her resemblance to my past. S had symptoms of a typical retinal detachment and feared losing her vision. Moreover, S had an aversion to eye care exacerbated by an anxiety disorder, making it challenging to administer eye drops and obtain intraocular pressure. I called upon my past trauma to soothe her fears. I reached out my hands for her to embrace. Her distress, on the other hand, was only marginally alleviated. I needed to modify my approach, so I guided her through a breathing exercise. Consequently, her anxiety subsided, and I performed the necessary tasks for the vision examination. This encounter left me with an indescribable feeling of fulfillment. I valued that I could share this moment of vulnerability with another person. This closeness reminded me of my relationship with my grandmother; it cemented my aspiration to be a physician.

My life experiences repeatedly tested my resilience, but each time it strengthened my compassion and emotional intelligence. As a physician, I will utilize these strengths to implement holistic, patient-centered care that integrates mental wellness and personalized treatments to preserve a patient’s autonomy. Furthermore, only medical school will allow me to collaborate with others who share my passion for medicine. Ultimately, I aspire to provide people with the greatest quality of life, commemorating my time with my grandmother and reviving the bond I treasured so dearly.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As a phlebotomist at a plasma center, our donor demographic was mainly underprivileged people. One donor was an African American man, C, who tried to make you laugh whenever possible. C had notoriously tricky veins. The first time I stuck C, his encouragement gave me the confidence to perform a flawless venipuncture. He donated twice a week and requested me each time because we formed a bond and he trusted my skills. He was never upset when I failed, despite losing significant income. With each donation, I learned more from him, such as life in a group home. When I told C about my recent financial struggles, he advised me to apply for food stamps, which helped me greatly. I learned that being vulnerable with others enables you to grow, even if they differ substantially. Then, one shift, a coworker told me that C had died from a heart attack. That was a difficult day because I valued our time together and never expressed gratitude for his uplifting jokes and helpful advice.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
_x000D_
A person I worked with as a patient advocate encompassed the challenges brought by COVID. J was diagnosed with triple-negative breast cancer that had metastasized to her brain. She had been taking Xtandi, an expensive medication. I suggested ‚Äúcopays.org,‚Äù and I assisted with her application. Her difficulty paying for necessary treatment exemplified the rising cost of medication exacerbated by COVID, which plagues future inclusive health care._x000D_
_x000D_
I helped her gain admission to a clinical trial, but COVID forced a delay. ‚ÄúI am scared,‚Äù J expressed. She feared that COVID would directly reduce her remaining time or postpone her vital treatment. Therefore, I found a support group that could help J manage these feelings. I assisted J with finding a webcam, but it was difficult due to the demand for webcams and supply chain issues from COVID. I discovered how telehealth could reduce accessibility barriers in health care and connect impactful support groups over vast distances._x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact:
COVID has created some extra barriers for me. During my spring semester of 2019, my Patient Advocacy certificate program switched to remote only and a pass/fail grading system. My original goal for this program was to improve my GPA with these courses while gaining experience as a patient advocate. I decided to take two upper-level science courses during the fall to compensate, but I only did well in one of the courses. I found that my microbiology course was poorly suited for remote learning and limited office hours. _x000D_
Unfortunately, I could no longer afford the increased cost of living in Madison with my wage as a phlebotomist. I was fortunate enough to qualify for SNAP, which eased my financial struggles and provided me with a healthier diet. However, I decided to move back home to Des Plaines. Moreover, the inflation caused by COVID strained my ability to apply to schools promptly because it was difficult to appropriately allocate my wages between rent, groceries, and applications.

Major_Long_Desc: Molecular and Cell Biology, Immunology; Economics
personal_statement:
“My dad committed suicide last night.”
 
I felt my heart sink as I listened to my college roommate weeping. A year prior, I lost a friend to suicide. Just as I felt guilty pondering whether there was more I could have done for my late friend, I noticed my roommate harboring similar feelings toward her late father. Over time, she began to express suicidal tendencies herself. While we each shared our own unique experiences grieving, I understood how important my support was for her. I was grateful to be there for her, listening to her and sharing my coping techniques. I validated her feelings and shared my vulnerability with her to confirm a mutual understanding that vulnerability is healthy. Although overwhelming at times, together we worked to address and express her pain and reestablish her sense of self-worth. Her first smile and chuckle, weeks later, will forever stay with me.
 
My experience with my roommate fueled my desire to search for opportunities in which I could have a positive impact on others. After much exploring, I decided to volunteer as an elementary school mentor. My mentee was reserved and struggled with making friends. Over the course of our first few meetings, I noticed he rarely smiled. During recess, I noticed my mentee avoided other kids, often isolating himself to an empty area of the playground. I sensed his anxiety and I opened up to him by explaining how we shared similar experiences when I was younger, in hopes of establishing trust. I shared what helped me feel more comfortable in my own shoes and make friends when I was his age. With time, he became more comfortable with me and those around him. I watched as he gradually befriended other kids in his grade. On the last day of my mentorship program, my mentee handed me a picture he drew. I unfolded the drawing to uncover the image of a smiling boy holding hands with a girl. I pointed to the boy in the picture and asked my mentee, “Who is that?” Beaming with joy and displaying a smile larger than life itself, my mentee said, “Me and that’s you!” I was overjoyed at the difference I could make through something as simple as mentoring. I still keep the drawing with me as a reminder that the impact of empathy bears no age limit.
 
Upon completing my undergraduate degree, I knew I possessed a passion for science. However, I needed to see first-hand how understanding the complexities of the human body could be directly applied to improve lives. Thus, I took on the role of a medical scribe in an outpatient rheumatology office. Following a long day of seeing patients, we would finish the day by catching up on patient phone calls and prescription requests while the rest of the staff went home. On nights I felt particularly burnt out and exhausted, I thought back to my experiences with my mentee, my roommate, and my late friend.
 
My drive to persevere was further cemented when following up a year later with a patient confined to a wheelchair. While charting the HPI, I noticed the patient’s voice began to quiver as he explained how his deteriorating health had caused unhappiness and a decline in his will to live. I glanced up from my computer to see several tears leave his eyes. As he continued his story, I struggled to fight back tears. I remember the doctor asking the patient what he wanted most, to which the teary-eyed patient responded, “I just want to walk again.” While handing him tissues, we briefly locked eyes. In those few seconds, his blue eyes became oceans filled with pain and sadness that I felt in my core. I wanted nothing more than to help restore his happiness. As I returned to my computer to finish charting, a small glimmer of happiness came over me and offset some of the sadness I felt. Why? There was no place I’d rather be than helping the patient.
 
I often reflect on the potential experiences of my late friend and roommate’s late father; their cries for help were regularly overlooked. The sadness of my roommate’s trembling voice as she spoke the words “committed suicide” still echoes through my ears. Helping my roommate through her grief taught me how to endure hardships and remain optimistic in the face of adversity. My experiences have shown me that suicidal thoughts and tendencies can frequently be associated with chronic illnesses and have become increasingly prevalent in today’s society. Much like I guided my mentee and roommate, I want to guide my patients to improve their health and wellbeing. Being a physician is more than possessing a body of knowledge enabling one to prescribe a drug to treat a medical condition. Scribing has helped me realize that being a physician requires the ability to blend knowledge and empathy and this is where I believe I can make a substantial societal impact. While scribing has emphasized my desire to pursue medicine, my experiences with my roommate and mentee have taught me how to integrate common knowledge with empathy. I yearn for the opportunity to integrate medical knowledge with empathy to treat patients, ensuring my patients’ cries for help are no longer neglected.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Growing up as an East African, Pakistani Muslim female in a predominantly White community, I was made out to be the ‚Äúother‚Äù that did not belong. I struggled with a great deal of harassment and felt the need to hide my culture in order to fit in. Gradually, I learned to appreciate my culture rather than hide it._x000D_
 _x000D_
After graduating, I became a mentor for immigrant Afghan students. I feared that these students would feel pressures similar to the pressures I felt. I wanted to ensure that these students embraced their cultures as they entered into a country which was foreign to them. Working with my students has provided me with an amazing opportunity to learn more about their culture as well as develop a deep appreciation for their experiences. I have learned how to be an advocate for my students which has taught me the importance of trust, patience and persistence. I will never forget the feeling of being able to connect with my students, share our cultures and understand their concerns.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: My brother attended a work event one night and hadn‚Äôt returned the following morning. His phone was located in an impound lot along with the remains of his car. He had been taken to UCLA Medical Center. Following his accident, I struggled with stress, fear and guilt and I hoped to create a resource for others. I formed a wellness group to help address fear and pain through communication, yoga and breathing techniques. Eventually, I worked to further expand my group and began including mindfulness practices. I focused on helping others be more present in the now as well as increase their ability to regulate emotions and decrease stress. I intended to help others become more fully engaged in life. It was rewarding to watch the development of personal growth for those in the group. It became apparent to me that I had impacted this small community when group members expressed gratitude towards me for creating a resource enabling others to cope with negative emotions and stress.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I have lost a few family members to COVID-19 and these past few years have taught me how to process grief. The onset of the pandemic cultivated within me an immense desire to relieve the apprehension of others in my community. Religious gatherings were restricted and our mosque closed to prevent spread of the virus. The closure of our mosque was difficult for many members of our community especially the elderly who found safety and comfort in daily religious gatherings. This led me to volunteer with COVID-19 testing at my local mosque. It amazed me that members of my community recognized me behind my PPE. Although our interactions were brief, I could tell it made a difference by the glimmer of hope present in their eyes. I was grateful to be able to provide members of my mosque with some comfort during a time of great uncertainty. This experience was extremely gratifying and taught me the importance of being present and playing an active role, if possible, in times of difficulty.

personal_statement:
The cool touch of the operating table made it all very real. Scanning the room, I felt my nerves escalate as the medical team prepared me for surgery. After battling with drug-induced lupus throughout my junior year of high school, I was blindsided by the new diagnosis of an ovarian cystadenoma which was growing at an alarming rate. However, my OB/GYN was always nearby to ease my trepidation. 

Within minutes of speaking with her, I was comforted by her confidence to perform this surgery laparoscopically. Though technically more elaborate, this procedure aimed to preserve instead of remove my ovary, as I was previously informed. And after seven hours in the operating room, that was exactly what happened; the huge mass was removed, and the ovary remained intact.

Fortunately, within a short time since diagnosis, I was treated. Yet, despite the promptness, I reflect on that experience with serenity, undoubtedly due to the surgeon's professionalism and attentiveness. As I headed to college soon after, I credited this experience with steering my interests toward accessible health care and women's health. 

During my early college years, the opportunity to become a birthing doula presented itself, and I began exploring how I could play a part in the OB/GYN field. From learning about induction using Pitocin to observing C-sections, I approached each labor and delivery shift as though it was an immersive lecture with a new topic. While closely observing the nurses and doctors, I simultaneously comforted the mothers by positioning them in poses that promoted dilation, providing words of affirmation, and encouraging teamwork among the family.

The labor and delivery unit housed a variety of childbirth complications. Despite the unpredictable nature of these cases, they were counteracted by the efficiency and professionalism of the medical team, a group I was privileged to work with. As I immersed myself into their environment, I had to adapt to their experienced pace; I learned to appreciate and understand their fervor in caring for patients. However, I was unsure of my own impact amid the intense experience that is parturition, and I questioned whether my efforts to help the women were futile.

During an early morning shift, I attended to a woman who spent hours contracting with minimal progress. Surrounded by the soon-to-be grandparents, she had little energy left and a look of defeat. I reassured her that she was capable, and since she did not have the epidural, I guided her through positions to alleviate her discomfort. By implementing movement, she quickly took to pushing and soon delivered her child. As I headed out after saying congratulations, the newly dubbed grandmother expressed her gratitude and declared, "Your good nature and warmth helped my daughter tremendously today." As we embraced, I smiled at the healthy baby coddled in the new mother's arms. This experience left me with a refreshed perspective and a solidified career goal.

It was at that moment that I was reminded of the gratitude that my mother received from her patients, even during casual run-ins at church or the grocery store. She modeled compassionate patient care through her routine early morning hospital visits and lengthy patient calls in order to mitigate their worries. Having had the opportunity to meet with many of her Hem/Onc patients after receiving chemotherapy, I was proud to hear about my mother's positive role in their lives. And as I started to make similar connections of my own, I gradually understood my purpose to care for, empathize with, and treat those in need.

I was able to explore this purpose further when I conducted a research project on women's reproductive health in Puerto Rico. This class project gave me the opportunity to speak with local Puerto Rican women suffering from the lack of accessible health care, especially due to the damages caused by Hurricane Maria. I was touched by the obstacles they overcame: one woman even delivered a child during the hurricane without any phone connection, electricity, or medical care. Aware of the magnitude of the nation's public health problems, our group, in collaboration with Senator Vargas Vidot, fundraised to alleviate the challenges of the Puerto Rican people, including the women deprived of adequate medical attention. By implementing needed health initiatives at both community and nation-wide levels for Puerto Rico, I have developed an overwhelming appreciation for accessible health care. 

Many factors, starting from childhood, have influenced my decision to become a physician. Throughout my journey of self-discovery in the healthcare field, I have come to understand that my affinity in the medical field lies with prioritizing the patient. In an ever-growing field that is medicine, I appreciate the challenges that stimulate my mind, but my patient interactions, especially from the labor and delivery unit, stand out most. An emotional and compassionate connection transcends all other forms of communication, and similar to how my surgeon cared for me, I am determined to pursue that quality of care throughout my medical career that emphasizes and prioritizes the importance of the patient's well-being.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I had the opportunity to go to Puerto Rico to research about women‚Äôs reproductive health and talk with organizations about their relief efforts after Hurricane Maria. The community suffered major blows after the natural disaster, and I was able to hear about the goals of these organizations and how they strove to provide accessible health care and education to the Puerto Rican community. While there, we met with an organization which focused on emergency preparation for the community, and another which helped to reintroduce incarcerated people into society. Among meeting these various motivated groups of Puerto Rico, I connected with the locals and witnessed first-hand the importance of health equity, especially for those who were stripped of accessible health care. This trip helped refine my cultural competence, exposed me to a new and diverse community, and emphasized the importance of social justice in providing the Puerto Rican locals with the opportunity to lead a better life.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I volunteered as a doula at the labor and delivery unit of the NYU Langone Hospital Long Island. This was one of my first positions in a real health care setting where I interacted with new patients and their families. This was also the first time I worked with a team of nurses and physicians. I assisted in natural births as well as C-sections. I was trained by the Long Island Doula Workshop and volunteered over 100 hours helping women during parturition by providing both physical and emotional support. Most of the time, the women and even their families have expressed gratitude at the attention given to the woman during labor. Some have compared previous labor experiences and have truly emphasized appreciation to my continuous assistance. Although it may be a subtle detail during the event of parturition, I am grateful to have positively impacted their experience and to have alleviated any discomfort they had on the unit. I aspire to care for my future patients in the same manner.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Starting in March of 2020, it was challenging to find a study location for school and for the MCAT. I found the transition difficult because there was not an obvious division between home life and student life. Since I was used to using local libraries as places to study and complete my school work, their limited hours affected my initial progress on my medical school applications. After some time and experimentation, I grew an affinity for working on my application in nature, whether it was in my backyard, parks, or beaches. Galvanized to find more areas in the outdoors, I explored more of Long Island and exposed myself to new study locations, from Queens to the Hamptons. As I began traveling around, I was able to create a balanced work-life relationship once again and genuinely enjoyed working on my application.

personal_statement:
I staggered with a whiff of the most atrocious smell I had ever experienced. As we entered the classroom, the teacher announced the activity to the gaggle of squirmy first graders around her: squid dissection. Most of the girls shrieked in horror. I shrieked in excitement. As the carcass was peeled apart in front of us, revealing three hearts and an ink sac, a curiosity was sparked in me that led to a passion in science and medicine that still grips me today. 
My fascination with anatomy developed into an interest in medicine in high school. I shadowed at the Montreal Heart Institute where I observed surgeries, attended rounds, and met with researchers. I was inspired by the inventiveness of geneticists unearthing data from failed drug studies in search of new possible targets.
