It was clear that medical breakthroughs require deep understanding of physiology, but also imagination, and I started to apply myself in more creative ways. For example, in high school I developed the concept for a device involving spider silk and tension-triggered spring-loaded pistons to prevent sports-related overextension injuries. 
Studying evolutionary anthropology at the University of Michigan, I began to see humans as people, not just as organisms for study. Previously, I had considered a disease like obesity to be the direct result of poor lifestyle choices. Through this new lens, I learned that while individual behavior does play a role in health, external influences like structural racism, lack of environmental protections, and socioeconomics present immense barriers which must be considered when developing healthcare strategies. Following this interest, I conducted my Honors Program thesis research on the role of the environment on genetics and phenotype in climate-adapted populations. I am eager to learn more about cultural, evolutionary, and environmental determinants of health and how to use this knowledge to help others. 
Following graduation, to continue work in genomics and medicine, I joined a biotech company where I learned how collaboration, flexibility, and compassion are key to healthcare research and delivery. While I was helping manage a large gene-based cardiac drug trial, the COVID-19 pandemic began to tear through our vulnerable patient population and study centers around the world. We had to act quickly and flexibly in the chaos to ensure our study was not significantly impacted while prioritizing the safety of our subjects. I was moved by the compassion and commitment the physicians showed to their patients, sometimes traveling great distances to hand deliver study drug. I was drawn to this compassionate side of medicine.
In parallel, I discovered what gives me utmost joy in life: giving to others. In 2017, I joined charitable organizations like the Rotary Club of Ann Arbor, where I could be of service in my community in an immediately tangible way. Welcomed as the youngest of more than 300 members, I was intimidated by this group of community leaders many years my senior. However, as I immersed myself with enthusiasm, I found it was a perfect environment for growth and development. By taking on roles to strengthen weak areas of the club, I became a committed volunteer and leader. As I served as a mentor for at-risk high school seniors, I saw many of my fellow mentors having trouble connecting with their students. I taught the mentors how to better relate to their mentees, helping bring new enthusiasm and students to the program. Within 2 years I was elected Director and Board member and featured in Rotary International’s magazine. In this role, I have helped the club grow, improving its processes and presence in the community. Giving in this way started me on a search for a career with similar impact.
	In 2019, I suffered a trimalleolar fracture which required two surgeries to repair, and the pieces of my story abruptly came together. Through interacting intimately with medicine in this time, one path that could bring my passions, skills, and interests together became evident: medicine. To ensure this was the right decision, I began volunteering at the Veterans Affairs Ann Arbor Healthcare System, primarily in the surgical department. I saw some of the challenges veterans face – PTSD, depression, poverty, and homelessness – and how care teams address disease in conjunction with these challenges. When a patient arrived for a possible thyroid cancer diagnosis, the clamor in the waiting room triggered his PTSD. I found him a quiet room to wait instead and stayed with him. It was gratifying to see some of his anxiety melt away as we chatted and laughed together. 
Though providing this emotional support was important, I was unable to give the relief that excising his tumor would. I am eager to train to become a physician capable of relieving physical ailments while caring for patients as dynamic individuals. Each day I am involved in the healthcare field, my commitment to further my education and my ability to positively impact others by pursuing a career as a physician has strengthened. What began as a mere fascination with what’s hidden beneath the skin has developed into curiosity, creativity, compassion, and commitment, which I am confident will allow me to develop into an excellent physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: For years I have had an interest in the Arab world. I have taken opportunities to learn more by visiting Arab-focused museums, art exhibits, and events, as well as by consuming media showcasing Arab perspectives. Most impactfully, I attended Friday prayers at a Mosque with a Muslim friend. I was excited but nervous to experience this vital piece of the Islamic faith. I was given a hijab to cover my hair, one often used by children, with a pre-cut opening for the face. I entered the basement of the Mosque with the other women, as the sexes were separated, and became acutely aware that I was the "other." However, I was immediately welcomed by those around me ‚Äì my interest in their culture overjoyed them ‚Äì and I was humbled as I fumbled through the motions of prayers. Being vulnerable, stepping out of my comfort zone, and experiencing a culture different from my own increased my understanding of those who have different identities and values than me and improved my ability to empathize.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I served as a mentor for disadvantaged high school students for several years through the STRIVE program. This program offers students one-on-one support and scholarships to community college upon successful completion. In my second year as a mentor, I was matched with Catera. She had transferred schools several times after struggling socially and missing class frequently to help care for family members and work a part-time job. When she entered the STRIVE program, she had a grade point average of 1.5. She knew attending college would help improve her life, but she did not know how to get there. Throughout the year, I worked with Catera to help her develop better studying habits to improve her grades, fill out her college applications, and even open a bank savings account. I was incredibly proud at the end of the year when she received a 4.0 and was awarded the highest scholarship amount. Since then, Catera has taken college classes and is on her way to a better life.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
The COVID-19 pandemic has introduced challenges that have reduced my ability to gain clinical exposure before applying to medical school. It was only in July 2021 that I decided to pursue a career in medicine, having graduated from college over four years prior. That summer, I began conversing with physicians from nearby hospitals and clinics. Though these discussions were valuable, my requests to shadow were turned down due to safety protocols implemented at their institutions._x000D_
The Veterans Affairs Ann Arbor Healthcare System, the location of my long-term volunteer post within the surgical department, paused in-person volunteering for four months due to the Omicron variant surge. This caused my clinical exposure and volunteering time to be reduced._x000D_
In addition, the clinical research job I had held since May 2016 was eliminated at the end of Dec 2021 due to budgeting issues at the company caused by the COVID-19 pandemic.

personal_statement:
At the age of ten, my summer nights were spent with my brother binge-watching Lord of the Rings. One night our movie marathon was interrupted by a streak of alternating red and blue lights that had pierced through the window. While the siege of Helms Deep was ongoing, my mother was experiencing another manic episode – this time in my front yard for the entire neighborhood to see. Growing up with a mother who suffered from alcohol dependence and prolonged depression, I had become accustomed to these events. The officers explained to me that if I could not calm her down they would be forced to detain her. So, I confronted her in the street with the hopes that I could talk her down– but my efforts were futile. While the images of tail lights rounding the corner offered some immediate relief that the night was over, this sensation quickly subsided with feelings of powerlessness.
Several days passed before my mother returned to our battered living room. As soon as she walked in, she gave me a gripping hug and began to thank me. She revealed how my repeated attempts to console her over the years afforded her the reassurance she needed to carry on. Though I felt undeserving of her gratitude, I was just happy to have my mother back. But beyond this, I was left empowered in my ability to connect with others and be a source of comfort.
After years of looking after my mother, I became interested in medicine and began scribing for an emergency department. One night, a soft-spoken man with tattered clothes was brought in. He was apprehended after wandering aimlessly in traffic and escorted by EMS for medical evaluation. Though the man appeared to be in good spirits with no medical complaints, the self-induced cuts along his arms told a different story. I had seen this same mask growing up. 
“Is everything alright man?”
With a deep exhale, he detailed how he became homeless after being laid off. Despite having family in the area, he was abandoned because of his schizophrenia. The cruelty of his situation had suddenly dawned on me. If he had suffered from a more socially acceptable illness would his family have still abandoned him? If I had not been there for my mom where would she be? With the weight of this truth off his chest, I could see a look of appreciation in his eyes. This simple gesture of listening meant more to him than I could have imagined. My upbringing laid the foundation for what I could not fully comprehend until this moment. Care is not limited to a medical intervention but also requires a human connection. This visit helped me codify what I wanted most out of my career – the opportunity to use my training and experience to serve others in their most dire straits.
With these lessons, I began volunteering as a literacy mentor for students from low socioeconomic backgrounds and home-lives similar to my own. One of the students I worked with was a fourth-grade Hispanic boy named “Jose” whom I was told had a learning disability. The teacher cautioned me that due to his limitations I should not expect much improvement. Knowing the power of labels and the stigma associated with them, I was motivated to support him in any way I could. After only a few visits, I discovered that though Jose struggled reading English, he excelled in Spanish and was far from disabled. From a boy reluctant to even speak with me, Jose was now bringing his own books for us to read. By the end of the summer, he had progressed an entire grade level above where he started. To see a child be dismissed based on a label, just as the man from the ED was, showed me the value of advocating for the voiceless. These small efforts to individualize care were ultimately the most meaningful aspects of their experience.
Reflecting on my past experiences I consider myself fortunate. Fortunate because being raised by a mother with mental health issues taught me that care is holistic and extends beyond medical intervention. Fortune to have lent an ear to a man struggling with his own mental crisis. Fortunate to have positively impacted a youth population that reminded me so much of myself. Together these lived experiences culminate into a creed I strive to live by: to treat each patient as family, to offer the support needed to share their experiences, and to advocate for the powerless in a system that often fails to do so
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Most days, I take a virtual passport and practice Spanish with people from around the world through language exchange apps. Through this, I have made a friend named Sadaf. She is a student from Iran with aspirations to study abroad. She also happens to be proficient in Farsi, English, and Spanish. _x000D_
I had built this preconceived notion that Iran, and moreover, the Middle East, was the antithesis of western culture. News outlets and politicians would have you believe that our lifestyles are incompatible. But the reality is far from stereotypes or headlines. By getting to know Sadaf and her culture, I discovered that there is far more that unites us than divides us. I began to understand that people's differences stemmed from the environment they were brought up in. I learned that by focusing on our shared humanity, you can open a window into an entirely new culture. In a nation where we are taught to be fearful of strangers, I aspire to approach diversity with an open mind and arms.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Every week I volunteered at various elementary schools around the Fresno School District to help students with their math and reading. While my house was a brief 20 minutes away, the drive to South Fresno underscored a tale of two cities. From the windowless classrooms to the playground devoid of a playset, it was clear that these students faced an uphill battle. The pandemic left many students on an academic hiatus. This had drastic downstream effects on the students‚Äô academic and emotional development. I sought to address this issue by engaging with students in a way that left them excited to learn. Whether it was illustrating a passage or turning a few paragraphs into a time trial, I knew that developing their interest in learning would be vital. The payoff was at the end of the year when I was able to see the marked improvement in their standardized testing. But beyond improving their scores, I believe I was able to guide these students to be their own advocates for success.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The COVID-19 pandemic has barred my ability to volunteer in a healthcare setting. All hospitals and clinics in my area have suspended their volunteer programs preventing me from taking part in this vital step of patient care. As it stands, these COVID policies are still in place with no mention of when they will resume regular volunteer operations.

Major_Long_Desc: Natural and Applied Sciences; International Relations
personal_statement:
The cold hospital floor against my back didn’t keep me up that night. Growing up in a house that served as a sanctuary for many Cuban refugees, I was used to giving up my bed to family members and friends that would stay with us for months at a time. Instead, it was the subtle moans of pain that came from the other side of the hung-up bed sheet separating my grandmother's bed from that of Rosa’s, a middle-aged patient. Diabetes was what her sister explained to me as we scoured the different floors, eventually bringing back a chair from the waiting room for her to spend the night. I had just learned about Diabetes in my college Physiology course and that night I was too absorbed in scientific literature to sleep, devouring information on how lifestyle and dietary changes could offer a potential treatment. 

While I later went on to publish a study on calorie intake and the risk of insulin resistance, through research I have realized my passion for actively searching for solutions and trying to comprehend a situation. I think back to my time as a research diver with the Diversity Project in Moorea. While en route to Gump station, our base for the summer, I saw a man holding a sign that read: “Fresh Fish, NO Ciguatera.” Over conversations with locals, I learned how parts of the island are avoided due to encounters with fish that cause ciguatera poisoning. I thought back to the patches of algae that would find their way into my scuba gear and wondered how this alga could serve as a contributor to instances of ciguatera. My group and I began fieldwork, ultimately learning how the algae expansion may potentially increase the rates of this fish poisoning. 

In my approach, I tried to emulate a physician I had observed while volunteering at Nicklaus Children's Hospital. Simon, a young boy I was tasked to play with presented with severe asthma. He was too tired to play and so I sat beside him watching King Kong as the physician spoke with his parents. In conjunction with treating his symptoms, the physician pried deeper and through conversation, it was reasoned that the mold in the household could be an active contributor. After following the treatment plan, a few weeks later I saw Simon again. This time the room was filled with laughter as we launched plastic monkeys into the air. I was amazed by the impact that this doctor had on Simon's life. While the solution was not directly apparent, through communication and collaborative reasoning the physician was able to reach it. My journey into the world of research has instilled in me a desire to learn about natural processes, starting with that which lies beneath our own skin. While I further explore this scientific curiosity at the NIH, I hope to see my work on the CRISPR-Cas9 system contribute to improving treatment plans for patients like Simon, as our studies in Moorea may help the community in preventing ciguatera. 

While research offers a means to expand my knowledge, working directly with patients provides satisfaction that remains unfulfilled with sole benchwork. I remember the early stages of quarantine vividly and from what was on TV, I thought all people had the privilege of living in the comfort of their homes. That’s when I received an email from my team, the Dade County Relief Response group, that emphasized how the homeless population in Miami was in need of our help. Immediately plans were put into place and as a team, we ventured out towards the greater Miami area to administer resources and COVID tests. In comparison to the rest of Miami, here it didn't look like we were in the middle of a pandemic. Here there were no comforting shelters, no germ-x at every turn, and certainly no masks. A population left to fend for themselves. As I handed out hand sanitizer bottles, I couldn’t help but reflect on the harsh reality of the disparities in health care. I thought back to my time at the hospital and how the presence of a chair could have helped Rosa and her family feel more comfortable. During my first shift, I interacted with individuals like Gloria, who was afraid of the nasal swab test. While our team physician, Dr. Armen, performed COVID tests on others, I slowly gained Gloria's trust. As we sang along in Spanish to her favorite artist Celia Cruz I acknowledged her fears and thoughtfully explained the test until Gloria confidently received her COVID test, later smiling at her negative result. It’s in these moments with individuals like Gloria that I have seen the importance of understanding and catering to a patient's individual needs. These situations further fuel my desire for genuine human connection and to address the needs of those underrepresented in medicine. 

As I continue to live through diverse experiences, what I have come to understand is that while I was excited by the knowledge behind Diabetes that night in the hospital, it’s the potential of seeing the application of that knowledge help a boy play again and laugh as he launches monkeys into the air that draws me to the field of medicine. I hope to combine my passion for science, problem-solving, and human connection in following the next steps to be able to regularly improve patient and family lives as a physician. I reaffirm this interest everyday in my current roles.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Growing up in Miami, I was accustomed to having friends from diverse backgrounds. While I always felt comfortable with diversity, my move to Maryland has shown me that I was not accustomed to the lack of it. My new friends all assumed that I was Mexican. I was asked a few times if I speak Mexican, and have heard phrases such as how Shakira, Pitbull, and Enrique Iglesias are all great Mexican artists. After learning more about my friend's upbringing, I understood that they have not had the same experiences as me and that I am the first Cuban American that they have come across. In response, I encourage open conversations where I teach them about Cuban culture, and I am equally interested in learning more about their experiences. As I see my friends today excited by Cuban culture, I‚Äôve realized how by encouraging an atmosphere of mutual respect and by trying to understand another person's perspective I have the chance to learn from others and also share my experiences with them.  _x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation: While working as a soccer referee in the city of Miami, I noticed considerable differences in field conditions depending on the area in which the school was located. I thought about how minority groups have less access to quality resources, education, and opportunities. I decided to help those that are not granted equal opportunities and began to serve as a volunteer tutor for children in my neighborhood whose parents were undocumented. I especially remember Maria. Maria‚Äôs parents did not understand English and they could not afford tutors which tend to come at a high price, in turn, she was struggling in school. I would help Maria by reviewing her homework, teaching her concepts, and helping her navigate a computer. My time with Maria helped to lessen the impact of obstacles to her education that are particular to children from minority groups and low socioeconomic backgrounds. With this awareness in mind, I hope to continue breaking down these barriers moving forward in my career. _x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact: Studies have shown that certain populations have been disproportionately affected by COVID. I was made aware of this discrepancy while volunteering with the homeless population in Miami over quarantine. While providing resources, I noted how for this population access to masks and other preventable measures was limited. While helping Dr. Commodore with her research I also learned how the pandemic highlighted issues such as the link between air pollution exposure and health disparities. Because of the pandemic, I am more aware of existing health disparities and I am committed to helping improve this situation. I also worked as a clinical research coordinator for a COVID study. In this role, I noted the struggles that patients and families are facing while managing the side effects of the virus. By engaging with patients and families during these difficult times I have recognized the importance of providing empathetic care which I hope to continue to do as a physician.

personal_statement:
My passion for medicine stems from growing up in a Latino and autism community that lacked access to high-quality healthcare. Several issues complicate care for these communities, including physician distrust, language barriers, and lack of experience with people on the Autism spectrum. Language barriers hurt the quality of care and can have potentially dire consequences. An example that embodies this is when my grandfather moved from Mexico to the United States, bringing only his dreams, clothes, and foot sores from inadequate access to healthcare. Initially, he refused medical help as he worried he would not receive appropriate aid due to his inability to speak or understand English. By the time he agreed to go to the hospital, his sores had developed into gangrene, which required surgical intervention. During his stay at the hospital post-surgery, he struggled to get basic help because of the lack of available interpreters and miscommunications due to his dialect's subtleties. As a child, I recalled when my grandfather explained his time at the understaffed hospital, where even asking for water or a blanket was a daily challenge. This event was my first exposure to the feeling of powerlessness many Latinos face within the U.S. healthcare system. It motivated me to build trust between Latinos and physicians to better healthcare access and outcomes. 
In addition, the gap in high-quality care that many individuals with autism face due to lack of experience was highlighted by my brother's experience. He was taken to the Emergency Department because he complained of stomach pain. The team handling his care had limited prior experience with autism, and thus my brother’s disability was overlooked. My brother was not able to communicate vital information about additional symptoms. His illness was dismissed as stomach flu, and he was sent home. Weeks later, his condition worsened, and he returned to the E.D., where his stomach pain was diagnosed as pneumonia. After his diagnosis, my brother’s condition severely progressed to the point where he was admitted to the ICU for multiple weeks and placed on a ventilator due to his lung function deteriorating. On my visits to him while in the ICU, I asked the nurses if they had experience with people on the spectrum, and the overwhelming answer was no. Thankfully, my brother eventually made a full recovery. To this day, this event continues to haunt my family as this harrowing experience made me realize that not fully understanding underserved groups can be a considerable detriment to adequate care and its lasting effects. As a result, my parents still hesitate to bring my brother to the hospital for fear of similar experiences. This is not how healthcare should be thought of, and this inspired me to become a doctor that treats the patient holistically and provides patient-centered care to those with disabilities.
After being discharged from the hospital, getting my brother the services needed to catch up with his missed class time was extremely difficult, so my parents tasked me with facilitating his growth. I can recall times when he became easily frustrated with tasks, so I developed a reward system to improve his patience. After each homework assignment, I would let him play with toy cars for a set amount of time. If he had good behavior at school for the month, I bought a “Hot Wheels” set of his choice. Teachers would call to comment on his improvements from the practices I did with him. The joy these calls brought me fuels my desire to become a caring and compassionate physician and seek out current physicians that embody this.
I was fortunate enough to witness the incredible power of a compassionate physician when I interned at the Darrow Stem Cell Institute. Dr. Darrow performs stem cell procedures at the clinic to treat musculoskeletal disorders. Patients are often initially skeptical, as treatment is done with minimal anesthetic and with the patient awake. I witnessed him go above and beyond with a patient who initially declined treatment due to his phobia of needles. Dr. Darrow answered all questions and discussed at great length about the patient’s military history to gain his trust. The patient proceeded and benefited greatly from the procedure. The humanity he never fails to show his patients has instilled in me the type of care my brother and grandfather deserved during their stay at the hospital. In this experience, I learned that medicine is more than just a set of skills, it is fundamentally about the relationship between people. 
My experiences growing up in a predominantly Latino community and seeing family members receive subpar healthcare has made me aspire to become a physician- to give back to the communities I grew up in, and to address healthcare disparities. I have learned to treat patients honestly, I must foster a close relationship with them. I have the desire, along with the determination, to promote health care equity within the underserved minority and autism communities. I will make the most of every opportunity given to me and be a valued addition to your medical school.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Growing up in a predominantly Hispanic area, my worldview was expanded once I entered undergraduate. As I met my current girlfriend's Filipino family, I had the opportunity to learn about the country's history and how that contributes to their health. Hypertension and hyperlipidemia are common issues in the Filipino community due to their traditional high-sodium and high-fat dishes._x000D_
_x000D_
As a medical scribe, we had a patient of Filipino descent struggling with controlling their hyperlipidemia without using medications. I talked with the doctor about certain dishes to include in their discharge instructions to make their treatment plan easier to follow, which led to more favorable outcomes._x000D_
_x000D_
With this background, I would like to share my experiences with my peers and improve my overall understanding to close the gap in healthcare access. The culmination of these experiences has taught me to be mindful of cultural differences, especially in medicine.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Fitness is an integral part of my life, particularly for my physical and mental health. Because my brother is autistic, I know firsthand how difficult it is for those with disabilities to interact socially in sports or perform independent performing activities. Therefore, I joined Strive, which helps autistic adults transition into independent living. However, Strive did not teach the importance of diet and exercise. I incorporated small activities for my students, such as stretching to improve posture, basketball games to teach social skills, and taught fundamental nutrition at Vons to improve their diet. When our program was informed of the student activity improvement, I was gratified by providing my students with tools to augment their lifestyles. As a physician, I will focus on treating the patient rather than the symptoms in medicine. I have seen that every person is different and sometimes requires treatment plans tailored to them.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I was recently recovering from COVID during my first MCAT exam. Although I tested negative, I still felt the effects of the illness. On exam day, I trusted my practice exam scores, but during the exam, I felt too ill to perform to the best of my abilities. This led to my subpar score and required me to retake the MCAT.

Hrdshp_Comments:
I was born and raised in Ethiopia, a country underserved in the medical sector. In addition to the medical sector, educational programs that aim to help people become aware of preventative diseases still have a long way to go before fulfilling their goals. The inadequate medical and education sector has given way to the death of many people. Although this is the case, the country is moving forward to better focus its attention on these sectors and I believe that I can help by giving part of my time providing service as a physician. Having been raised in a middle-class family, I have seen the result of both the devastation caused by lack of medical attention and the promising result from the assistance of healthcare providers. I should be considered a disadvantaged applicant for having the experience of being in a country with inadequate amounts of healthcare providers
and facilities.
personal_statement:
Several vital moments played a role in my decision to apply to medical school. Deep down, I have always wanted to help people the best I can. While in high school, I chose to volunteer weekends at my local children's home, tutoring English, math, and science for kids ages 11-13. I shared knowledge and any bit of advice I had with the exceptional children under my wing. I was, in return, humbled by the impact that I left on them and that they left on me. In high school, I chose to pursue science because I found biology and chemistry intriguing. My love for the sciences and urge to help the communities around me fueled my enthusiasm to venture into the medical field. From high school science courses to premedical coursework in college, I maintained my drive for the medical field by satisfying my growing curiosity about the human body.
A little background about myself: I was born and raised in Ethiopia and moved to the United States when I was 18 years old. Although Ethiopia is one of the fastest developing countries in Africa, it is among the many medically underserved nations globally. Most medical facilities are in the capital, with only a few in the rural towns where most of the population resides. The inadequate medical care and resources result in much unnecessary suffering and in severe cases, death. I observed both private and government-funded medical facilities: the insufficient contribution of the country's income to the health sector and the difference in the quality of care found in these two types of facilities fueled my interest in pursuing the medical field. I hope to one day help decrease the gap in access and quality of health care in Ethiopia through the collaboration of local and US hospitals. 
In college, I ventured outside of my comfort zone by partaking in extracurricular activities and taking classes beyond the sciences. My first and second years were challenging due to my financial status and having multiple jobs on campus. However, I utilized various resources on campus and learned that it is okay to ask for help. In doing so, my family and professors gave me valuable insight into managing my time better. I found that balance between my academic, extracurricular, and work commitments. Being a part of the African Student Association as vice-president showed me the qualities a good leader should have. From open communication and delegation between people of different backgrounds to planning events, I learned that teamwork and motivation were necessary for a productive team. 
As an ER volunteer for two years, I developed in-depth interpersonal communication skills by observing and practicing patient-physician interactions. After volunteering, I shadowed physicians with various specialties (cardiology and obstetrics-gynecology) in the ER and ICU. Learning about each one and gaining direct patient contact experience by assisting physicians increased my fascination and desire to make my own contribution to the field. As a student and colleague of numerous talented people, I knew that I was a step closer to becoming the doctor I wanted to be in the future. I want to be a compassionate and hardworking physician that provides maximal care to patients. I always want to keep learning from my future professors, peers, and fellow medical researchers to be the best practitioner I can be.
Attending a liberal arts college helped me develop a more open-minded perspective. By engaging in various academic pursuits, I gained a profound respect for and understanding of the human body. Upon graduating, I wanted to gain more hands-on experience in the medical field and become a better prospective medical student. During the pandemic, healthcare workers' hard work and dedication inspired me to keep contributing in ways that could help my community. I worked as an ABA behavioral therapist for children with autism. Being dependable and adaptable were critical skills I learned and put to work in my day-to-day responsibilities. I was patient and understanding and gave it my all, cooperatively working with my colleagues to devise and implement daily plans for each child. I enjoyed every day and worked towards my individual growth and towards being there for the people I worked with. 
Soon after, I joined the army, became a medic, and got my EMT license. Enlisting was a big commitment, and going through basic training was both physically and mentally demanding. Resilience and attention to detail were crucial skills I honed through this process. I was tested beyond what I thought was my limit and questioned myself when things got tough. What kept me going was thinking about why I joined the army and what the future holds for me. My primary motivation was my goal of becoming a doctor and learning how to work in a stressful environment while keeping my emotions in check. Learning to assess, treat patients, and follow up with documentation in different medical scenarios was exhilarating. I firmly grasped the ethical obligation we have to ourselves, our peers, and our patients. I am grateful for succeeding and gaining some invaluable lessons that I will take to medical school. My struggles and accomplishments have contributed to my personal and educational growth, making it possible for me to stay determined.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I work as an EMT at Smiley's Family Medicine Clinic at UMPhysicians. Sometimes I come across Ethiopian patients with whom I share a similar background because I grew up in Ethiopia. However, most of the time, I tend to a diverse patient population. In all cases, I start by introducing myself and asking about the patient's day to make them comfortable. Some patients are more anxious about their visit than others. For instance, I had a patient who was angry about what was going on in her life, her medical problems, and the healthcare team. Although I tried the same approach to talking to her, it did not seem to work, so I listened to her vent and asked what she wanted us to do to help. I learned that the best way to deal with emotional patients is by lending an open ear and expressing sympathy toward their issues while maintaining professionality. I continue to understand the family medicine practice and grow my skills within the medical field as I learn about various cultures.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Since graduating from Augustana College, I have gained more hands-on experience in the medical field while fulfilling my desire to serve my community. As an aspiring pediatrician, I moved on to work as an ABA behavioral therapist for kids with autism in the Somali community. My team members and I worked closely to devise and implement an individualized treatment plan for each child. During every session, we aimed to advance the potential of each child in mastering communication, social, and independent living skills. In addition, we organized group-based activities so the children could progress their teamwork skills. In time, I witnessed the children achieve numerous goals, and I was honored to be part of their development. Early childhood education helps them better transition to school and maintain their health._x000D_

Hrdshp_Comments:
I am Latinx woman of Mexican descent and a first generation college graduate. My parents immigrated to the United States as teenagers and still speak primarily Spanish. My father acquired citizenship through a work amnesty granted by the US Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986. My mother became a citizen through a marriage based petition in 2005.  Growing up, my parents worked in cleaning, maintenance and construction jobs so the household income was near or below the poverty line for extended periods of time. They worked paycheck to paycheck and took advantage of food stamps, school and hospital based financial assistance programs.

At the age of 11, I was accepted to Prep for Prep 9  - a "leadership development program that offers promising students of color access to a private school education based in New York City" https://www.prepforprep.org. I gained access to critical resources and mentorship. I also qualified for programs due to my socioeconomic background such as William's College's "Summer Science Program," Tri-Institutional MD-PhD "Gateways to the Laboratory" program and presented at the Annual Biomedical Research Conference for Minoritized Scientists.
personal_statement:
Occupational mishaps were the norm in my childhood home. My father would recount the misadventures of his bruises, cuts, and falls at the dinner table, always with a smile. One day in June, we got a desperate call: “Marco had an accident, his right hand - it’s bad this time.” At the hospital, I could barely recognize him. There was no twinkle in his eye, no attempt to weave a captivating story and ease our worry. An escalating discussion ping-ponged between my parents, the Spanish interpreters, and the medical team but I could only make out snippets: Nerve damage. We need to put him under. He’s diabetic. Easier to amputate. 

He shook his head firmly: “No.” 

A quick amputation would save him from a life of chronic pain, but he didn't see it that way. With that calloused hand, my father built sturdy homes, strummed his steel-string guitar, and pushed us too high on the swings. After much deliberation, the medical team strategized a more conservative surgery to restore as much function as possible. Following my father’s post-operative care, accompanying him to physical therapy and follow up appointments taught me how complicated bodies are, even at rest, and how they adapt ingeniously after trauma.  I will never forget that only with the support of his medical team, my father beat the odds.  Patient centered care means integrating a patient's values into the treatment plan and sometimes providing alternative solutions. 

Freshman year, in psychology class, I learned the term “phantom limb syndrome.” There was a brief case study on veteran amputees for our neuroscience unit. My mind flashed back to restless nights, my father’s grimacing face as he endured alternating hot and ice baths. Understanding the plasticity of the nervous system after trauma inspired a broader love of the life sciences. Learning the healing our bodies are capable of on a molecular level gave me hope that one day my father will live pain free. This curiosity lead me to pursue a neuroscience thesis project starting sophomore into my senior year. 

On one hand, my genetic rescue experiments on Drosophila were stepwise, elegant, and measurable contributions to our scientific body of knowledge – they had the potential to shed light on dopamine’s role in human movement. On the other hand, I needed to bring the rigor of research back to my community where the variables are not always so controlled.  

After college, I dove head first into the world of public health, of immigration justice and community based participatory research. Connecting the dots through immigrant justice health work has given me a more holistic understanding of medicine and it has been critical to my desire to be a physician. I learned that chronic disease, overwhelming medical bills, ER visits and a paralyzing distrust in the medical system are widespread symptoms of the health inequity experienced by low-income uninsured communities. 

As a community health coordinator, I helped to navigate Spanish speaking immigrants to accessible health care services. One day, I met a gentleman who had been released from the hospital earlier that week. He shared: “They said I have diabetes. I have to check my sugar every day but I don’t know how.” He had no support system and lived paycheck to paycheck. The wrinkled pamphlet they provided was in English. His diagnosis, although common, was life changing. Even taking a simple glucose test felt out of his control. 
I twisted and disassembled the lancing device: “Mi papá también tiene diabetes.” After years of taking my father’s glucose, it was muscle memory for me. I loaded the lancet, adjusting the knobs so that it would pierce his calloused fingertips and I explained: “It’s just like a drill with different levels, with practice - you can do this.” We pinpointed a safety net hospital and thought of questions he could ask during a follow up appointment. I assured him there were parts of his disease that could be controlled but I knew as a society, we could have intervened earlier. 

What if medical professionals were trained to anticipate the gaps and not exacerbate them? 

The "promotora" community health worker model recognizes that the wellbeing of individuals and their communities are inextricably linked. It puts into practice empathy, persistence, and troubleshooting as challenges arise. Embodying this approach in my nonprofit and research experiences has been a critical steppingstone in my decision to pursue medicine. I worked to formalize my skills in medical interpreting. Now, I recruit Spanish-speaking patients, women and other underrepresented minorities for cardiology clinical trials in NYU and Bellevue Hospital. The growing network of multilingual health providers and research projects excite me because we are building a future where everyone has access to exemplary care.

I want to practice medicine with a resilience that defies borders. I hope to learn more, contribute to global health initiatives of and be worthy of the trust patients give us. I will push others to advocate for our patients even when it seems impossible like my father's medical team. When physicians are attuned to the needs of the community, there is no limit to the care we can provide.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: At the age of 11, I was accepted to Prep 9 - a leadership program for promising students of color in New York City. After fourteen months of preparation, I attended Deerfield Academy, an independent boarding school and later, Williams College in rural Massachusetts. The whiplash of attending well-resourced institutions as a low-income student of color taught me to be resilient in the face of adversity and also to genuinely listen in order to effectively collaborate with people vastly different from myself. I came back to Brooklyn excited to build people power through health access and activism. My clinical research experiences working with diverse patients also instilled a deep respect for ethics and for all people regardless of background. At Rush, I will collaborate and prove myself worthy of being a community physician. I will also use my academic privilege to promote health access in Chicago and to protect our most vulnerable patients while improving upon the standard of care.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: During the early months of the coronavirus pandemic, I was involved in activism to secure economic relief for immigrant families in Brooklyn.  I drafted a proposal to secure $10,000 from the Brooklyn Community Foundation. At first I was excited but then, I realized we would have to distribute the funds. How were we supposed to determine who needed them the most when so many had lost their loved ones, jobs and homes? We created a google docs survey, a system to safely distribute $200 gift cards to 50 high-need families and even hand-wrote encouraging notes. Despite our efforts, it was not enough money and we received backlash on social media due to the lack of transparency. The situation was challenging but navigating it with a resilient team taught me the importance of taking baby steps in the face of demoralizing systemic injustice. Afterwards, we partnered with the Mayor's Office of Immigrant Affairs to provide relief to families who were excluded in the first round of distributions.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Conducting public health work during the pandemic taught me resilience, resourcefulness and the power that communities hold to overcome trauma. I was visiting family in Mexico when the first case of coronavirus was detected in NYC. The initial fear of being delayed at the airport due to travel restrictions was no match for the months of uncertainty that followed. At the time, I was involved in health disparities research and also working part-time as a community health coordinator. The pandemic exacerbated inequities for populations that already experienced higher comorbidities, poverty and barriers to care. I helped coordinate outreach, navigational services to funeral homes, economic relief grants, face masks, coronavirus tests and later vaccines. Balancing these responsibilities was intense; however, I learned what it means to be a front-line health worker. I‚Äôm pursuing a medical career to mitigate the disparities that made coronavirus so lethal to vulnerable communities globally.

Hrdshp_Comments: Growing up, my parents spent long hours working from the Inland Empire to LA for their small businesses on $10-15,000 income. We were supported by kind neighbors who looked after my brother and I, and summers with my grandma provided a secure childhood space. Due to their self-employment, we did not have funds for health insurance, and I have not had dental care. I am grateful for my school’s lunch program, which I applied for. I helped our small business, and my parents supported me with all they had, encouraging values of curiosity, hard work, and giving to others. Thus, I only noticed any lack of experiences or resources, such as travel, camps, or enrichment opportunities upon entering college. While I took advanced courses in high school, my high school peers and I were not prepared for the academic rigors of college, and we all struggled to pass introductory STEM courses. As our business struggled and we faced greater financial insecurity, I helped my family with food stamps. As first in my family to pursue healthcare, I learned how to seek and advocate for resources, guidance, and opportunities to help me overcome challenges, and I eventually achieved a 3.8 in my post-bacc program while balancing 350+ hours of additional programs, obtained a job, bought a car, and help support my family.
personal_statement:
I peeked through the backseat window of Mom’s van, as she made a detour in Downtown LA selling plants. Windows were glimpses into communities I fantasized for, but with a different turn today, I witnessed lines of tents, aching individuals, and wanted nothing more than to help. At 8 years old, my curiosity lingered on Skid Row. Clutching my biology textbook, fantasies turned into hopeful dreams to be a doctor.
Despite my dreams, I hardly went to see a doctor; uninsured, healthcare was a luxury. It was not until college that I appreciated medicine’s responsibility and explored my interests—helping live births and laughing with a baby’s first words after neurosurgery. The resilience of a child’s brain facilitating her life ahead was inspiring. I strived for more than glimpses into patient room windows, but to be a part of their journey.
Yet windows were never only a peek out to the world, but a peek into our home. As I appreciated medicine in its tangible moments, health began to personally feel further away.
For us, an hour of sleep meant one less hour of income, as I navigated food stamps at home. Asking my dad about hypertension medication, he’d reply, “No time, we’re just trying to make it day by day.” Eventually, he was in the ED for uncontrolled hypertension. These times amplified our place in the healthcare system and how social determinants shaped the health of families. From our lived experiences, I reflect on realities patients face and want to advocate realistic ways to manage health, when sometimes the priority is keeping a roof over our heads.
Recalling confusion and difficulty accessing care and cultural stigma barring us to seek help, I became director for a grassroots student group organizing free health fairs for under-resourced Asian American and Pacific Islander families, which provided culturally humble health resources we would’ve benefitted from. I learned how adequate primary care could prevent or manage chronic conditions of hypertension or diabetes, but how difficult it was to access due to larger systemic inequities and barriers, and I aim to further address realities of under-resourced AAPI families often overlooked.
To explore tackling health inequities in under-resourced communities beyond my own, I worked in South LA. As ED scribe, I witnessed further detrimental but preventable effects of inadequate primary care for chronic conditions, how environment affected health outcomes, and how ED was primary care. As care navigator, we connected patients to primary care and resources. In community-partnered research, the community directed the research. We developed a parent-peer intervention for minority families with children diagnosed with Autism, combating cultural and language barriers to navigate the special needs system and advocate for services. From this, I aim to partner with families in care, have continuous dialogue with cultural humility, stay grounded in my community, and empower patients with tools to manage their own health.
But in 2020, I suddenly moved out of urban LA to subrural Menifee. Helping care for my grandma’s end stages of Alzheimer’s reminded me how the science and fragility of medicine remained at the forefront, as we confronted her last days.
We’d change her diet based on stools and run oxygen tanks when she seized. Despite working in the ED, I didn’t know why oxygen helped or why she seized—were they TIAs or glucose? I desperately wanted to understand these mechanisms to better care for her.
Soon my aunt and I contemplated intubation and hospice care. Decisions are never black and white, as we grappled with quantity vs. quality of life for my loved one who raised me, and I aspire to support others in these decisions.  Moments highlighted how conditions never affect one person but all loved ones, how care was 24/7, and the many questions families have because they care.
While my grandma has since passed, I now treasure the privilege to coordinate novel gene therapies for infants with rare, neurodegenerative conditions. Their diagnostic odysseys alongside our experiences with providers motivate me to always listen first to families. While I appreciate relaying over family’s health questions, I strive to one day answer them.
Medicine allows peeks into others’ windows of vulnerability through a biological lens, in a sacred space often closed to others, but where real strength, connection, and change can begin as well.  I strive to be on the other side of windows I’ve passed, sit with patients as they gather strength amid uncertainty, and develop the expertise to guide families’ diagnoses through the lens of their experiences.
Though my reasons for medicine have taken many forms over time, every new experience has propelled my convictions.  It is hard to forget the uncertainty of our next dollar or grandma’s last day; like many patients I have met, my intersectional experiences drive my desire to further serve and uplift voices of vulnerable populations often under-resourced, overlooked, and marginalized by our complex healthcare system. From this, I aim to be a physician practicing community-partnered research, to work at the forefront of innovative programs and treatments for those most vulnerable, and compassionately advocate for just healthcare system.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Designing for a community Autism conference, I was invited to design for community conferences to address cancer disparities, working alongside community stakeholders, non-profit directors, and academic faculty members, participating in knowledge exchanges and developing community-partnered programs for the Black and Latino communities of South LA. _x000D_
_x000D_
During monthly meetings at Healthy African American Families non-profit, I had the privilege to be the only student, Asian, and member under the age of 30 at the table. I listened and learned about community experiences unlike my own, substance use research challenges, community health implications, and more._x000D_
_x000D_
I learned the vibrance of cultures different from my own, overlaps yet differences in challenges amongst minority communities, the importance of actively listening first to authentically engage with others, centering their voices, cultural humility, cross-cultural conversations, and understanding my own positions and privileges._x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
In college, a board member had not upheld responsibilities, which frustrated some peers. However previously, this person excelled and provided high quality work._x000D_
_x000D_
One day, I received a phone call from them asking to talk, as their significant other told them that if they were away, to reach out to me. Surprised by this phone call, I met them in their dorm. With overfilled trash cans and leftover meals on tables, I entered the room as they wiped away their tears and made space. We talked about a variety of things - their depression, experiences, and guilt for not meeting responsibilities. I reassured their efforts, validated their emotions, celebrated small wins, and offered support and plan together. Without disclosing, I encouraged others to provide this person grace, especially given their track record. Eventually, they were back with high quality work, stayed on board for their achievements, and went on to medical school. Years later, they told me this conversation saved their life.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
Due to COVID-19, I suddenly moved out of urban LA to live with relatives in a far, sub-rural city of Menifee in a medically underserved area of CA at the end of post-bacc. Since I did not have a license, it was a challenge continuing previous involvements in LA‚Äì Care Navigation, babysitting, and a transitional home for women and children. I mainly continued remote volunteering with research and classes, but the internet was intermittent, and my parents were evicted from their office the same time as my original September MCAT. _x000D_
_x000D_
Throughout this time, I helped care for my grandmother in her end stages of Alzheimer‚Äôs, as we navigated COVID-19 Visitor Policy restrictions. IHSS cut our stipends as her condition declined, and I pursued a full-time job to obtain a license, a car, help support my family, and save up money for medical applications, and I worked full-time for another year to continue to save money, alongside preparing for my MCAT and applications.

personal_statement:
Beads of sweat collected on my forehead as my teenage arms shakily carried my bike down the stairs of my apartment building. I rode past my local library, convinced that the “CLOSED FOR THE SUMMER” sign on the front door mocked my 4-mile commute to Barnes & Noble. Until her hospitalization, I simply thought Crohn’s disease meant my mom got stomach aches and we had to keep a roll of toilet paper handy everywhere we went. Seeing her body curled on the hospital bed left me both frustrated and confused – how could stomach aches suddenly cause such a strong woman to be so frail? Dissatisfied with my ignorance, I biked to Barnes & Noble to seek answers. As a single parent, my mom juggled multiple jobs, leaving her with little time to learn about her illness. As an immigrant, she avoided asking questions about her health, fearing that more time spent in a clinic would leave her vulnerable to deportation. At 13 years old, understanding Crohn’s disease was the only way I felt I could sincerely support my mom through her diagnosis.

When I returned from Barnes & Noble, I sat at my mom’s bedside eager to share the new notes I took that day. Texts such as, "Crohn’s and Ulcerative Colitis – The Complete Practical Guide", helped me explain how her symptoms were manifestations of different organs inflamed by Crohn’s disease. My drawing of the digestive system guided me as I gently felt her abdomen, estimating the location of each organ. To my delight, she began referencing my notes during medical appointments, helping her to develop a dialogue with her physician to better understand her health and make informed health decisions. Seeing how my ability to understand and communicate medical science expanded my mom’s health literacy gave me the confidence to advocate for the well-being of my community. My summer at Barnes & Noble was a microcosm of my greater purpose in pursuing medicine.

Without my familial exposure, I likely would not have taken the initiative to learn about Crohn’s disease nor known how to support my mom. Witnessing how my actions helped her take ownership of her health made me wonder how others in underserved communities navigated their chronic illnesses. I joined Dr. Giselle Petzinger’s lab as an undergraduate research assistant where I helped to promote physical activity among Spanish-speaking Hispanic women with neurological disorders. I recall speaking with a participant, “Lupe,” who stopped her evening walks in her neighborhood park due to safety concerns. Lupe drove to pick up her granddaughter from school and I suggested she try walking instead. During a follow-up conversation, she shared that not only had she incorporated walking into her daily life but that her mental well-being improved as well. The satisfaction I felt helping Lupe overcome a health-related barrier provided a similar sense of gratification to my experiences supporting my mom. However, in this instance, I played a direct role in Lupe's health by finding a solution to meet her physical activity goals. Through these experiences, my mission became clear: to collaborate with and empower individuals from underserved communities to take an active role in their health. My medical education will grant me the platform to fulfill my mission, while my personal and research experiences with health disparities will inform the care I provide.

Interested in expanding my patient interaction skills beyond the lab, I began volunteering at the emergency department where I met “Ana,” a Salvadoran woman with a severe lupus flare-up. I felt helpless covering her in a warm blanket as she was still deeply uncomfortable. I remembered a similar frustration of not being able to cure my mom during her Crohn’s flare-ups; however, this did not deter me from doing everything else in my power to put her at ease. I stayed with Ana until the attending physician arrived, trying to bring her solace. She complimented me on how long my hair was and joked about the hair she had lost since being diagnosed with lupus. “Mira, somos iguales” (Look, we’re the same) I said as I showed her a picture of my shaven head in high school when I donated my hair to Locks of Love. Her eyes widened with disbelief. I told her that if I could pull off the look, so could she. Ana laughed – while her visible relief helped curb some of my helplessness, I wanted my impact to go beyond just a human connection. I want to provide compassionate care while also being equipped with medical knowledge to heal patients like Ana. As a physician, I would be uniquely positioned to accomplish both.

I did not anticipate that my passion for medicine would be birthed that summer several years ago. The knowledge I discovered and shared with my mom eventually drew me to a field that would challenge me to take initiative in learning and critical thinking. My eagerness to not only learn but also listen to others unveiled my dedication to providing equitable healthcare for all. Throughout medical school and beyond, I hope to nurture the skills that have blossomed in me ever since I was a young girl spending my summer at Barnes & Noble.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Amber-colored leaves waved in the Hudson Valley breeze of my home for the next four years. I left my family at 14 years old for boarding school where I learned and grew with students from across the globe._x000D_
_x000D_
When collaborating with my peers, I saw how offering insight from our unique backgrounds enhanced our projects' outcomes. I hope to work with a medical team that reflects the diversity of our patients, as I believe this will be vital for optimal care._x000D_
_x000D_
As I connected with my peers, I learned to view situations from various perspectives. As a physician, I will seek to understand my patients‚Äô attitudes and make health recommendations cognizant of their background._x000D_
_x000D_
Even as our different cultures shaped our identities, I realized respect, dependability, and empathy were pivotal in establishing and maintaining lifelong bonds with my peers. I‚Äôm eager to create the same warm and inclusive environment I experienced in boarding school when serving the diverse patient population of Chicago.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
During my gap year, I was excited to merge my research and clinical volunteer experience to support a study examining the social needs of our emergency department (ED) patients._x000D_
_x000D_
While volunteering, I met ‚ÄúJC,‚Äù a patient experiencing homelessness. Like the eye of a hurricane, dead skin encircled an infected wound from stepping on broken glass with his bare foot. JC was treated for his infection, but I wondered how homelessness would endanger his health again._x000D_
_x000D_
As part of the research team, it has been fulfilling and illuminating to work with disadvantaged patients like JC and offer community resources to serve their needs beyond the walls of the ED. Understanding how health disparities can arise when these basic social needs are unmet drives me to be a physician who provides holistic care informed by the social determinants of health. I believe Rush‚Äôs Health Equity and Social Justice Leadership Program will equip me with the necessary skills to fulfill my purpose.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
In the summer of 2021, I coordinated a virtual exercise program for geriatric patients and interviewed them for a study about their experience with the classes. Before the program, many patients were sedentary and isolated. It brought me joy to speak with patients like ‚ÄúJT,‚Äù who showed me her growing bicep muscles she called her ‚Äúguns,‚Äù and ‚ÄúEd,‚Äù who found purpose in life again after forming a community with his fellow participants._x000D_
_x000D_
Working with a vulnerable community during the pandemic gave me further insight into factors outside the clinic that impact health outcomes. Barriers to equitable care often exist because these factors are largely unacknowledged in the context of health. As a medical student, my insights from this project better prepare me to approach patient health from a holistic position. I hope to build upon these skills through the Rush Community Service Initiatives Program, where I will seek to provide comprehensive care to underserved communities throughout Chicago.

personal_statement:
Hospitals have always symbolized hope. Behind their walls patients who are ill receive treatment by physicians who deeply care for their health and who are advocating for them even when they cannot for themselves. Being able to embody these tenets has always aligned with my values, however, due to my family’s circumstances, my desire to walk this path was overshadowed. We were Mexican immigrants who had no grasp of the English language, yet doctor’s offices were a place of refuge. There is where I realized that medicine is an art that goes beyond diagnoses and procedures, it encapsulates treatment through uplifting others. It translates scientific knowledge into compassionate and culturally competent care. It treats others so that they can achieve wellness through happier and healthier lives. This is what being a physician represents to me and why today, I want to become a doctor.

I vividly remember when my grandmother was diagnosed with diabetes. She complained of feeling tired, frequently urinating, and having a thirst she couldn’t quench. No one in my immediate family was in healthcare, thus it was difficult for us to understand what was happening to her. Soon after the onset of her symptoms, she was diagnosed with diabetes. After that I accompanied her to many doctor's visits, where I would gaze at the person in the white coat and wonder what it took to be like them—a natural-born gifted to heal, teach and put a mind at ease. I saw how loving and patient her doctors were with her despite her inability to speak English. And in these moments I came to know that medicine would allow me to connect with people further by bridging a language gap so many patients face.

Her latest doctor’s visit was in the ER after an episode of delirium. I was reminded of my time in the ED where we saw many patients who suffered from urosepsis. Often these patients also presented with delirium, and I realized there may be a connection to my grandmother’s condition. After a series of questions at the bedside, she admitted recent discomfort while using the restroom. I helped interpret her concerns along with this crucial piece of information, and it was at this point I knew she would be okay. Seeing the relief on my family's faces as the ER physician assured them she would recover emphasized the significance of earning someone's trust to care for their loved ones. Days later, she was discharged from the hospital after completing her IV antibiotics. Here I experienced firsthand the value of the family-physician relationship and the impact it can have on the course of treatment.

My interactions with medical staff would continue. One night I began to vomit blood, and my mother rushed me to the ER, where she tried to string sentences together in the best English that she could to communicate with the staff. Then and there it was not only my illness that weighed me down, but also seeing my teary-eyed mother struggle to talk with the staff, all while the possibility of her living her worst nightmare lingered in her mind. Today I think about all the questions she couldn't articulate and the anxiety behind each one, and I've vowed to one day be the kind of physician that addresses all his patients' concerns.

My friend's brother was diagnosed with kidney failure at eighteen. He had been vomiting for weeks until one day he felt so sick he walked himself to the hospital, where he would then start dialysis. I was shocked that such a disease could bring down a young person, a person like me. Learning about his brother helped me realize that medicine is not only for the older or chronically ill but also for the seemingly young and healthy. This experience shed light on utilizing medicine as a means to help people from all walks of life and to bring others back to wellness so that they can live their lives to the fullest potential, regardless of how much of their lives are left in front of them.

"Eva" had missed her connecting flight, and the next one wouldn't depart until the morning. She was alone and without any money to buy food or pay for a hotel. She also mentioned she had diabetes. I knew I wouldn't leave her without food to get her through the night, so I found a nearly closing cafe where I bought her a cold turkey sandwich and an apple. I handed her the food, hoping it'd be enough to prevent her from becoming hypoglycemic. I wished her the best on her journey and left the airport teary-eyed. I was dismayed I was unable to help her more, further, I was disheartened that she suffered from an illness that is worsened by a lack of access to proper food and care. This reminded me of the underserved who often fall through the cracks, and how healthcare can fail to reach them. But I also realized that as a physician I could be in a unique position to help intervene by acting as a source of information and support for those at risk.

My journey through healthcare has taught me that being a physician also entails being an advocate, a teacher, a counselor, a coach, and very often, simply a listener because a healer wholeheartedly uplifts the human spirit. I attribute my sensibilities to these experiences as they have kept me grounded and have served as a reminder of what practicing medicine means to me: restoring hope.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
My time volunteering has allowed me to work with people, for people, from all walks of life via various venues. From serving hot meals to next-door neighbors or refugees to assisting families in getting comfortable while waiting for a loved one who is undergoing a life-changing procedure, every individual interaction has been a unique opportunity to connect with someone unlike myself. As new arrivals in the U.S., my family and I cherished these kinds of interactions because they signified visibility despite differences and an understanding of who we were at our very core, simply human._x000D_
_x000D_
Today, these experiences have underscored that we are all the same at the most fundamental level; we all share similar hopes and dreams: hopes to live a healthy life with shelter and food at the table, hopes of well-being for those we love and care about so dearly, and dreams of being happy. By working with people with diverse stories, I have learned that we all stand upon more common ground than not.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
My internship at the Lawndale Christian Health Center (LCHC) on Chicago's west side was a unique opportunity to impact the neighboring communities. At LCHC, I found that my impact on the patients we met took the form of providing health education. When seeing patients at the LCHC, I naturally gravitated toward the educational components of our visits because, to me, education is one of those gifts that keeps on giving, regardless of the form it might take. But health education, I believe, is integral to the betterment of any community, especially the underserved communities of our country. _x000D_
_x000D_
Health education transcends large distances, land and sea, borders, state lines, and generational gaps, to name a few, allowing everyone to reap the benefits so that they too can live healthy and happy lives. It saves lives, which is why I believe it is crucially important. It's also why providing health education is at the top of my interests as a Rush Medical College hopeful and future physician.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The COVID-19 pandemic was the catalyst that did not allow me to continue as a medical scribe for the time planned. When the first cases of COVID-19 were detected in Illinois, I was working as an emergency department scribe at a small community hospital. Initially, I had planned to be there full-time for at least a year to acquire a comprehensive understanding of life as an emergency medicine physician. After the year, I planned to work weekend shifts only while working a full-time research job on the weekdays. But to add insult to injury, the emergency department staffing agency at the time was closing out its contract, and the contract with the new company would not take effect until that August. Still, the outgoing staffing company ended the scribe program much earlier due to the pandemic and low patient volumes. Although I eventually transferred to a new emergency department, I would later find it difficult to juggle my weekday job with the new schedule at the new hospital.

personal_statement:
“Please, please don’t give up on my son!” cries our fourteen year-old asthma attack patient’s mother, as she bangs on the emergency room door. The room fills with a tense silence during my ten-second pulse check that feels just short of an eternity. I am exhausted, sweat-soaked gown now clinging to my forearms after several long minutes of CPR, yet in the moment I still wish to do more: to console his mother, to explain why I stopped the chest compressions, and to ensure the boy’s healthy recovery. Our young patient’s pulse returns. The room breathes a collective sigh of relief. Three years of providing emergency medical aid to people on the worst days of their lives has presented me with many tough moments like this. Despite the heaviness and stress, I am honored and grateful to have a place in them. Being a positive force for others has always been a core goal of mine– a cornerstone of why I pursue the path of a physician.
On top of my passion for helping others, I specifically enjoyed helping underserved communities during my time at The Suitcase Clinic. I had the unique opportunity to provide free public health services to the local unhoused community of Berkeley, California as just an undergraduate student. Over time, I grew into the role of Housing & Employment Officer, in which I talked with the community members to understand their circumstances and match their needs to available resources, such as warm meals and shelter provisions. This work exposed me to the fundamental problems associated with the stigmatization of homelessness and the lack of medical and general support services for low-income populations. Serving the unhoused community not only gave me a deep sense of fulfillment, but also presented me with a stark awareness of my own privilege. Now fitted with a yearning for a greater understanding of the medical healthcare system, I transitioned into urban medicine.
I earned my EMT license during my final semester of university, enabling me to continue to help those within my community while also allowing me to explore patient care and confirm that I wanted to practice medicine. It was a harrowing transition from providing housing services out of the local church to providing medical care in the back of an ambulance and inside of patients’ homes. Through the lens of my EMT license, I now saw the multifaceted burdens that disproportionately plagued impoverished communities, such as asthma and COPD exacerbations, uncontrolled diabetes, and missed appointments due to financial constraints. Yet, just as I had with my housing work, I could expand my knowledge and improve myself to provide the care that this patient population needed and deserved. I voraciously sought courses at my local medical educator and uncovered a personal fascination with both the science behind my care and how the intersection of my patients’ history and medications resulted in their medical emergencies. Exploring this blooming interest drove me towards extra opportunities for learning in classrooms, shadowing in operating rooms, and working in challenging patient-care environments. I transitioned from providing prehospital care to 911-response, to a high-volume emergency room setting at the San Francisco General Hospital. Eventually I developed the medical knowledge and experience to reinforce my passion and to position me to make a difference in hundreds of patients’ lives.
This was the case when an unconscious young man arrived at our hospital with a failing heart and no clear cause. His condition was difficult to manage, with six short-lasting resuscitations within the first hour. My team fixated on hypoxia as the root cause due to low trending oxygen saturation, but from previous experiences and my assessment of the case, I believed there might be more to the story. I immediately repositioned the probe and warmed the site with a hot pack, which increased blood flow and achieved an accurate reading near one hundred percent. While the patient initially improved, their palpable pressure soon declined so I stressed the need for epinephrine. I swiftly alerted our attending physician who supported my suggestion. Following that medication administration and continued treatment, the patient stabilized and later recovered with zero neurological deficits. I felt immensely fulfilled in that moment; my medical knowledge, medical experiences, and personal empathy enabled someone else to live another day.
After university and my involvement with The Suitcase Clinic, I continued to pursue opportunities to become a more learned medical provider while maintaining my dedication to working with underserved communities. I believe that medical school will help me develop the knowledge and skills which I can use to help uplift these communities in the future. My experiences both inside and outside of the emergency room have helped me build the emotional resilience needed for this career path, while also giving me a taste of what it feels like to take part in a miracle. Some days I take part in the saving of a life, and others I witness the ending of one. I will carry all of these experiences with me as zeal, compassion, and composure while I go along my journey to flower into the best provider and person I can be.
