1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As a volunteer with The Suitcase Clinic, a student-led organization that helped the unhoused community of Berkeley, California, I worked with people from vastly different backgrounds from my own and saw firsthand the impact of poor social determinants of health. To understand our clients‚Äô needs, I would listen to their stories and ensure that they felt heard, respected, and welcome in our clinic space. Through them, I learned how systemic barriers kept generations in cycles of poverty and how for many of them, the growing stress from insecure housing, financial burden, and poor health education contributed to their chronic health problems. While I could not treat our clients‚Äô medical concerns as an undergraduate volunteer, I was able to secure them places to stay, resolving one root cause of their health problems. Being able to address the social determinants of a community‚Äôs health was deeply fulfilling and motivated me to work with historically disadvantaged communities as an EMT.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: In April 2020, Rock Medicine partnered with the newly erected COVID-19 Field Care Clinic and I took the opportunity to serve the under-resourced neighborhood of Bayview, San Francisco. I quickly became a familiar face around the clinic as a consistent volunteer, so I could pinpoint the challenges that we struggled with. I proactively redesigned our testing and treatment sites to reduce the likelihood of patient exposure and documented volunteer responsibilities as our staff grew. I also helped actualize our medical director‚Äôs ideas, such as architecting a curbside treatment area for immunocompromised patients. Despite my title as a volunteer EMT, I filled out the gaps where I felt leadership was needed and helped turn our scrappy clinic into a powerhouse for improving the health of this neighborhood. My experience improving care accessibility and care quality for this community helped shape my desire to become a physician devoted to uplifting community health.
7_-_COVID_Impact: In Spring 2020, alongside my work at Eagle Ambulance and volunteering at the COVID-19 Field Care Clinic, I worked towards a phlebotomy certification that would help me transition into a clinical EMT position within an emergency room (ER). Unfortunately, the pandemic changed my plans; my hospital externship was delayed and my housemate moved out due to my high exposure risk. Faced with rent I could no longer afford, I moved into my mother‚Äôs house and took a temporary position closer to home as a 911-response EMT at Falck while I finished my externship and earned my phlebotomy license. After two months of providing high acuity patient care, I transitioned into my current position at San Francisco General Hospital‚Äôs ER. While I regret only having the opportunity to work at Eagle and Falck for two months each, I learned to adapt to the unforeseen and, in doing so, gained valuable clinical experience and a greater understanding of the physician‚Äôs role in acute care.

personal_statement:
My rundown 2008 Toyota minivan Sulley has taught me many life lessons on the route to medical school. 

When I was nine years old singing in Sulley and dreaming of the future, I never imagined that my unconventional interests would lead me to medical school. My road map to medicine consisted of an engineering degree, minors in music and Southeast Asian studies, and the blood of at least 300 fruit flies dissected in Shanghai in the name of science. Combined with my experience as a chaplain and biophysics research assistant, some may question how medicine interests me at all. Medicine is the missing link in each field I explored. I enjoyed the teamwork and problem-solving of engineering but craved a real connection with the patients I was designing for. I loved caring for people’s emotional needs as a chaplain but missed engaging with science. Human health is influenced by more than just chemical reactions; culture, disposition, and systemic factors all influence an individual’s health. My eclectic educational route equips me to provide an interdisciplinary approach to medicine.

I rolled into my junior year in a not-so-new set of wheels and quickly learned that some of my best problem-solving would happen in my minivan. After spending hours fruitlessly brainstorming, my senior design team hopped in Sulley for a break and some bubble tea. Interestingly, drinking bubble tea in Sulley reminded me of bonding over boba with migrant farm workers I met while shadowing doctors in Southeast Asia. Many of them suffered from chronic knee pain; and few affordable, effective, and flexible solutions existed. As we considered possible treatments, the makeshift recording studio I built in my van led me to consider therapeutic ultrasound. My experience building microphones in music class guided me as I designed the ultrasound circuit in the knee brace. My design project acted as an important pitstop by showing me how my wide range of expertise fueled innovation. Each person has a complex background; I want to combine my strong scientific foundation and personal creativity to address the healthcare needs of each individual.

Practicing medicine allows me to guide people through adversity. After graduating, I served as a chaplain through the organization Cru to counsel Cornell students during the pandemic. Little did I know that the pandemic would hinder my ability to be on campus, and counseling would occur while driving Sulley. Because I drove a soccer-mom minivan, many students would ask for a ride to the airport or grocery store. Eventually, my free Uber service morphed into a moving chaplaincy. People who didn’t have a destination but needed someone to talk to would hop in the van. Some days, I spent five hours driving aimlessly listening to my passenger’s story. By the end of our miniature road trip, people would express their gratitude and renewed hope. I discovered how my simple ability to drive and listen provided a safe place to be vulnerable. I want to use my unique skills to care for others through an intimate part of life: health.

Many of those minivan conversations were difficult. When I picked up Mannayah from her dorm, I didn’t expect to sit in a parking lot for two hours mourning her friend’s suicide with her. It reminded me of my junior spring semester when I drove home after my cousin’s funeral wondering how I was going to move on from her suicide. Around that time, I battled unexplained health issues, and loss seemed to define my life. As I struggled to believe I was more than my sickness, my physicians relentlessly fought for answers and reaffirmed my inherent dignity. The experience encouraged me to be a physician so I can protect quality of life because we are not defined by what we’ve lost. My cousin’s death is one of six in my family in the past six years. So along with being a patient, I’ve been the support system—one of the many wringing their hands in the hospice and nervously calling the ICU. When I shadowed Dr. Duncan, a surgical oncologist, a desperate family traveled across the country for his surgical expertise. He not only provided physical care but was a source of strength for the patient’s family. One of the biggest reasons I want to be a doctor is to prevent loss and suffering for both patients and their support systems.

Contrary to Rascal Flatts’ hit song, life was not a highway for me after college. Life has been driving through downtown Baltimore catching every red light and inching towards my next destination: medical school. After Sulley was towed on my second day of work, I knew that Baltimore's city, culture, and parallel parking would be very different from my suburban childhood. Trauma research—my penultimate stop—combines scientific inquiry with my desire to walk with patients, yet I feel frustrated that I can’t treat their injuries or provide answers to their health concerns. I want to truly practice and apply medicine. When I drive to work, I sometimes think of how I want my career in medicine to be like my minivan—an embodiment of scientific theory used for diverse applications, a safe space to be heard and supported, and a vehicle of change creatively used to serve people from all walks of life.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: In January 2019, I joined the executive board of Community Faith Partners, a service-oriented organization. After the murder of George Floyd, we created an online seminar series, where BIPOC people could share their stories and educate on racial injustice. Their experiences made me aware of the long-lasting consequences of injustice and inequality. After seeing a change in our small community, I pursued my current position to better understand injustice in the medical field. Born to a nurse in the suburbs of Indiana, I didn‚Äôt face obstacles to health care like my patients, who are primarily from low-income areas in Baltimore. Because our patients expressed difficulty receiving care and information on their brain injuries, I started a quarterly newsletter with research and guidance on recovery. I am beginning to explore patient advocacy from a research perspective, and as a medical student, I want to learn how to educate patients on policies and health risks relevant to their community.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Each Saturday, after volunteering at Second Wind, I would drive back to Cornell‚Äôs beautiful campus on the next hill over. With each mile, I‚Äôd feel more disconnected from the community I served. The men and families living in the houses I helped to build were strangers to me, until I made efforts to eat, hang out, and do life with them in my later years of college. Installing insulation and painting walls was worthwhile, yet playing board games and celebrating Thanksgiving was equally important. As a junior, I coordinated Care Day, a service event with multiple work sites across Tompkins County. With the help of families from Second Wind, we laid hay, cooked meals, and cleaned homes for other people living in Tompkins County. Community service took a new meaning for me and the community of Second Wind: we were equipping our community to serve our community. Care Day continues to occur biannually with the volunteer force growing yearly.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The COVID-19 pandemic began midway through my senior year of college. I received the Sterry Career Research Award during the summer of 2019, which would have culminated in a poster and presentation at the Engineering Learning Initiatives Undergraduate Research Poster Session in April 2020. Unfortunately, the event was canceled, and I was unable to present my work, ‚ÄúDevelopment of a new optical tool for studying chromatin conformation and gene regulation." Additionally, during the summer and fall of 2020, I planned to volunteer at Cayuga Medical Center, which I had previously done in 2017. Because the hospital restricted visitors to protect patients, I volunteered at a community kitchen, Loaves & Fishes, and continued to serve as secretary of Community Faith Partners.

Under_School: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
personal_statement:
My earliest memory is of zigzagging between kiosks, boarding a plane, and clicking my seatbelt in place—ready for take-off. The commotion of the airport and the idea of flying across the world gave me a sense of connectedness, a feeling in which I found comfort, even as I left my own home in North Carolina to fly to China to visit my uncle. It was no secret that my uncle was my favorite. Growing up, I was always the loud, talkative one in the family. My uncle, who never missed a beat in making our family laugh, mirrored my very essence in the form of a 44-year-old Chinese man. It was through my time with him at his most vulnerable that I first became in tune with my passion for serving others and put me on the path to medicine. 

At the start of my freshman year, my uncle was diagnosed with stage 3 liver cancer. Regardless of how busy I was, I made sure to FaceTime him several times a week. During those calls, I would tell him stories about school or work, pausing to listen to his dreadful jokes. Over time, I sensed my uncle’s energy dissipating. As I heard less of his own wit, I infused more of mine, doing my best to make him laugh. I felt so much joy and fulfillment from seeing his smile and by reciprocating the lifelong kindness he had shown me until the very end. As I coped with the loss of my uncle, I reflected on the many oncologists and nurses that were unwavering throughout his treatment; how they eased his pain through a balance of expertise, compassion, and the staunch commitment to his daily care. These physicians treated medicine as a means to not only treat a patient’s illness, but also champion an experience of mutual support and trust at a time when the patients needed it most. I know this meant the world to my uncle, and from then on, I set out to find a career that would enable me to reciprocate their strength, insight, dedication, and resilience.

I knew there were many paths that would enable me to have a similar impact on people’s lives. While studying at UNC, I was exposed to the ceaseless demand and variability within medicine during my time with Timmy Global Health (TGH). Through TGH’s international healthcare programs, I traveled to 11 rural towns in Ecuador to assist physicians and nurses in local clinics. Alongside the lead attending, Dr. S, I saw over 20 patients per day from sunrise to sundown. I quickly learned that all I had been taught in public policy classes about healthcare equity and clean water access was but a small element of the reality. No matter the case, Dr. S took the time to understand her patients, alleviating them of their concerns by internalizing their questions and providing thoughtful answers. Time and time again, I saw her actively listen to mothers with sick children, sons with ill fathers, and siblings with no one but each other. Her thoughtfulness was heroic to me and left me to wonder what drives her to return to Ecuador every year. I came to realize that Dr. S was passionate about global health, not just global medicine. Dr. S worked with her patients to educate them on diet, clean water and more, not just to solve the case but to improve their long-term health outcomes. My experiences in Ecuador taught me that medicine is not just about diagnosing the patient; it is also about empowering the patient with the knowledge necessary to improve their health long after they’ve been discharged. This illuminated the importance of academic medicine and led me to the field of clinical research.

As a Clinical Research Coordinator at Massachusetts General Hospital (MGH), I began to cultivate the same passion that I witnessed in so many physicians and experienced firsthand how research is the driving force behind the advanced level of medicine I wanted to provide. In particular, one patient I worked with faced a difficult journey and the daunting prognosis of colorectal cancer with metastasis to the liver. Dr. W made clear to me that the majority of his patients have a short lifespan depending on the stage of diagnosis, so because of the nature of his specialty all he can do is his best. His research focuses on improving dosimetry and response following treatment, and it is particularly exciting to be a part of research that will have a direct impact on not just this one patient, but also on the improved clinical protocols used by other healthcare professionals.

Since my uncle’s death, I’ve looked to medicine as the path to find fulfillment in my career, accumulating many lessons along the way. My time with my uncle taught me how to find strength in times of loss; volunteering with TGH taught me how to take a holistic view of a patient’s life; working at MGH has made clear the role that clinical research plays in elevating the quality of health care. This strength, insight, and dedication is supported by a fierce resilience developed through my own personal experiences. Now, I am eager to integrate these lessons and dedicate myself to the craft of providing outstanding patient care. Although flying still gives me the same sense of connectedness that I felt as a child, I’ve realized that the sense of fulfillment upon landing to see my uncle will only come with a career in medicine as an adult.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As a volunteer, I traveled with clinical teams to underserved communities in Ecuador to provide medical care. On one particular clinic visit, I had the opportunity to chat with a young eight year old girl who was brought in for a fever and cough. We spent the visit connecting on her interest in reading, drawing, and our shared bond of having a younger brother. What my experience with this young girl made clear to me is how people are more similar than they are different, no matter where I go. While from different countries and life circumstances, we shared strong common bonds of mutual experiences. While medical expertise is a must, I believe it will be my ability to connect with patients‚Äô experience and life perspective that can help enable better health outcomes. Above all, a physician must be able to empathize with their patient‚Äôs emotions and understand their perceptions, and be able to use those help empower them.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: At Boston Medical Center (BMC), an institution that is similarly an anchor within its community, I helped facilitate the process of cardiac non-stress testing by preparing each bed and escorting each patient. One patient I assisted was apprehensive as it was her first time at BMC. To provide some support, I checked up on her frequently and brought extra pillows for her comfort. When the test was completed, she smiled and whispered ‚Äúthank you‚Äù. A simple gesture, but it made me proud. I realized how valuable the ‚Äúlittle things‚Äù are and that bringing something as simple as a pillow or just being there are small things that have a huge impact on a patient. I also recognized how parts of the patient experience contribute to the healing process. I find these little interactions motivating and energizing, reminders of the passion and interest that initially launched me into the path of medicine.
7_-_COVID_Impact: During the pandemic, I was redeployed to double-shifts assisting mask distribution for Massachusetts General Hospital. I am thankful for this opportunity to be a part of a team that indirectly helped patients receive care during these challenging times. I saw what being a healthcare professional meant - collaboration, support, and dedication is what comprises the community that is the healthcare system. Having the opportunity to interact with patients and providers during my pandemic assignments also revealed to me the inequality in healthcare. I learned that many communities near Boston had limited access to COVID testing compared to others. Moreover, many patients suffered delays in seeking needed care, especially among the underserved population. As a prospective medical student, I intend to help address medical access and equity by participating in programs or student organizations that focus on vulnerable patient groups, such as Heart to Soles and the Community Health Clinic.

personal_statement:
My motivation for medical school has been influenced by my family’s personal experiences and health. My first cousin has TAR syndrome, a congenital birth defect. My mom and I both have autoimmune diseases - she has alopecia and I have celiac. My dad has spent much of his adult life battling an alcohol addiction. Following a car accident, my grandfather lived the rest of his life in chronic pain and with a failing heart. 

As a young adult, I deeply appreciate how each family member has influenced me and my motivation for medicine. All have faced at various times intense social stigma. My grandfather - Opa as we call him - had to quit work in the prime of his life for an invisible injury. My cousin’s very obvious physical disability has led people to assume more about what he cannot do than what he can. My dad’s journey to recovery proves he is so much more than his addiction, and my mom staring down age-old definitions of beauty is honest and brave.

All of us have had excellent healthcare providers and good insurance benefits. I acknowledge that not everyone has the same access to medical care. As much as it was the compassion and skill of individual doctors, it was also the community resources, financial stability, and absence of systemic biases that gave me the chance to have the family that I do.

I am my Opa’s grandchild, and I know the weight of that statement because of the years I was given with him. He passed away in January, just shy of 24 years since a complicated open heart surgery, which coincidentally took place on my first birthday. My Opa’s wisdom, love and example of resilience in the face of chronic pain helped us all. Had he not recovered after his car accident, or heart surgery, how might that have changed how the rest of us faced our own struggles? When I think about ‘why medicine’, my family is always close to my mind. Everyone deserves to be seen as more than their diagnosis. It’s not the status or prestige that draws me towards being a doctor; it’s the chance to heal. 

This is not my first time applying to medical school; in fact, it is my third. Throughout my previous cycles I felt a lot of self-imposed pressure, and when the rejections came, they hit hard. In those tough times I found that I had a depth of resilience to draw on - a product of the resilience I have seen emulated in my family my entire life. I finally stopped trying to force some idealized plan.

Over the past three years I’ve affirmed that I have the attributes, talents and motivation to be a strong medical student and doctor. I spent three years as an undergraduate in a neurosurgery research lab. I mastered surgical procedures and built skills needed to approach longitudinal objectives. I loved being a valued member of a team all working towards a common goal. Collaboration, community and a shared love of learning are things I want to foster and experience in my medical career.

After graduation, I worked as an assistant for the emergency department, which provided an unvarnished view into the successes and difficulties that doctors face. One of the most impactful parts of this job was witnessing support and collaboration play out across medical and academic settings. I experienced it myself, especially when the Vice Chair of Education mentored me in support of my goal to go to medical school. I also got to work with her and two other women to form the UW Group on Women in Medicine and Science, a forum for women doctors and scientists to collaborate, find peer mentors, and share lessons with each other. Success doesn’t happen in a vacuum, and being a doctor includes accepting help from others in order to give the best to your patients. 

These experiences prepared me for my current role as a research coordinator in the ER. I engage with patients who are scared, uncertain, uncomfortable, and often in pain – and find ways to connect with them while conducting valuable research. Working directly with patients has honed my skills, especially building rapport and increasing my comfort with uncertainty. The connection that I get to make with a wide variety of patients – from ten-month olds in an asthma study to octogenarians taking part in pneumonia research – has reinforced that keeping the humanistic aspect of medicine center of mind is critical. This role has also exposed me to the inequities that different communities face and the way that exacerbates the health and treatment of individuals. Through these various perspectives – research, medical education, administration, and patient care – I’ll be entering medical school with an unfiltered view of the way the medical world operates, how I can use my skills to impact and change that world for the better, and a strong confirmation that this is where I want to be. 

The core tenets that guide my life – strength, family, and resilience – will help me to excel in medicine, a field I have repeatedly chosen to pursue, despite the difficulties I know lie ahead. I’ve put in the work to ensure that I know why I want to be here, and what I am getting into. I’ve had the chances to bow out and move on, but I have proven to myself that I have what it takes to be a compassionate, dedicated, curious, informed, and empathetic doctor.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: While in the ER I was recruiting for a substance misuse screening tool study. After talking to one patient, he asked: ‚ÄúAre you asking everyone, or just us Black folks?‚Äù I had not recognized how this interaction must have seemed to him. I knew the wide eligibility pool, while he saw a white woman asking sensitive questions to a member of a population historically stigmatized for drug use. This interaction spurred me to start a conversation amongst my team and create a more equitable and informed framework factoring in the implications of research and whose narrative it strengthens. This has included working with study teams to change the ‚Äòpitch‚Äô of studies to be more clear and patient centered, as well as learning to assess potential barriers and biases that we carry or may be perceived by patients, particularly around the studies in our portfolio that focus on more stigmatized medical diagnoses or societal issues.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: During my time as the president of the mountaineering club I notably changed the culture of inclusion, specifically related to women holding leadership roles. When I first joined, I was one of only two women who held active leadership roles in a club of over 100 people. As president I had the ability to enact long-lasting change in a manner that I had not been able to through individual mentorship. I applied for university grants on behalf of the club to subsidize leader training, fought for and gained increased funding, and expanded the pipeline of programs for new and veteran leaders. I ran a women‚Äôs film festival and used the profits to create a club scholarship fund for women in leadership training. In the years since graduating I have stayed on as a community member and continually see the lasting impact that my efforts have had. Now, there is about an even number of women and nonbinary folks in leadership positions as compared to men.
7_-_COVID_Impact: During the pandemic, I continued working in the medical field, first in a hybrid model and then onsite in the emergency room. Both models required creativity and resilience, and accelerated my professional development in ways I could not have expected. While on the medical education team, I supported students through virtual learning, remote residency interviews, and canceled clerkships. Working in the ER, I saw how typical barriers to care were exacerbated. The isolation of the pandemic led some people to delay care, while others ended up in the ER for chronic conditions that they were unable to manage on their own. This changed the type and severity of care needed, and required a holistic understanding of our patients‚Äô situations when interacting with them. Through the pandemic, I have developed creative solutions, greater empathy, and improved patient skills that will benefit me as I pursue my medical career.

personal_statement:
One of the most meaningful values I grew up with is the idea of community service and "repairing the world." An opportunity to offer support to underserved youth in my local community arose, which allowed me to work with children and adolescents at the Minneapolis American Indian Center. This experience enabled me to understand how even the smallest of interventions can have a profound influence on the trajectory of human health.

While volunteering, I discovered the power of building relationships quickly and its capacity to impact impressionable youth positively. One day, I was walking by a student's laptop when something caught my eye. I looked over and my heart dropped when I saw the search bar read "guns for sale." My mind jumped to all of the different potential outcomes of this search and I felt an overwhelming sense of fear. However, instead of shutting the child's laptop and following up immediately with a lecture about the dangers of guns, I decided calmly to sit down next to the child and have a conversation to get more information about the situation. After a brief discussion, I learned that the child did not feel safe walking alone to school from home and felt the need to find a means of protection. We assessed alternative transportation methods and how to identify and obtain available school resources. We also discussed the potential consequences of taking different actions and weighed the benefits and costs of different scenarios together. By the end of our conversation, the student came to the conclusion that a gun is not the best method for protection and stopped researching guns. I notified the program head about what had happened, and while they expressed concern, they were appreciative regarding the way I handled the situation.

This encounter did not occur in a medical setting, but it did involve a conversation that reflected some of the core values and strengths that I will bring to my work as a future physician. My open-minded attitude, natural curiosity, and interpersonal skills were essential to finding the most effective solution. Creating and maintaining trust in my relationship with this child is something I will continue to do with patients. The process of identifying issues early on and creating a follow-up plan draws me toward becoming a physician.

During the past couple of years, my experience providing care to patients at an academic medical center has solidified my desire to become a physician. When assigned to a patient who recently developed auditory hallucinations that presented in the form of hearing people's voices in a hidradenitis suppurativa-specific visit, I approached the situation with compassion and took a nonjudgmental stance. The patient was originally resistant to seeking psychiatric help. However, by the end of our 15-minute clinical history conversation, I earned a measure of their trust that enabled them to seek psychiatric help. In a different clinic I served as a clinical artificial intelligence photographer and data interpreter. One hair loss patient I worked with suffered from terminal illness and major depression. When the patient entered the photography room, there were no traces of hope or happiness on their face. In that moment, I wanted to do anything in my power to lessen their burden, even if for just a short period of time. While taking photographs, I asked them to tell me about things they enjoyed. Gradually, they became animated and smiled as they told me about their favorite show on Animal Planet. Even though their face returned to its original expression when the attending and resident rejoined us, the knowledge that I had brought happiness to the patient during our time together reaffirmed my decision to pursue a life in the field of medicine. Rejoicing in the small effects that I have already had on people's lives in the clinical setting brings me hope that I can have a wider impact as a future physician. This hope makes me more dedicated and determined to succeed in medical school. My will to "repair the world" is strong; when difficult situations arise, I want to be there for those around me and find the best solutions to meet individual needs. 

Repairing the world requires filling in the gaps. There are gaps and tears in the fabric of medicine in the United States today, and underserved populations are some of the first to feel the rip of the seams. I am one person with one needle who wants to engage in the work of mending and hope to do so in the field of medicine.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: In college, I volunteered at a local elementary school where I mentored my first-grade buddy. My buddy was polite, funny, and smart, however, he received regular punishment where he was unable to go outside for recess. The group of students with this punishment was disproportionately Black. I inquired further, and the gym teacher told me that there would be no opportunities for re-evaluation in the near future. I advocated for my buddy and asked for a sooner re-evaluation date, and when all else failed, offered to accompany him to recess. They agreed. This situation taught me about how difficult it is for young Black students to succeed when their peers, teachers, and school system are not supporting them. As a medical student and future physician, I will consider the impact of systemic racism on Black patients' overall health and wellbeing. Furthermore, I will make compassion, respect, and a willingness to engage in regular self-assessment a priority.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: For the past year, I have had the privilege of volunteering at the Minneapolis American Indian Center‚Äôs (MAIC) Golden Eagle after-school program. Golden Eagles provides a safe space for Native Americans and other underserved children and adolescents. I enjoy building relationships with these children and offering them additional support. When a boy in our program opened up to me about how he was teaching himself to play the piano, was upset that his keyboard had stopped working, and was unable to afford a new one, I made it my mission to find him a replacement so he could continue to pursue his passion. In addition, this past July, I partnered with GAP Inc. and Old Navy to coordinate the donation of hundreds of new clothing items to Haven Housing, a local women and children‚Äôs shelter, and the MAIC. I believe that supporting my local community in these ways has better prepared me to care for underserved populations and my community as a medical student and future physician.
7_-_COVID_Impact: While I was originally planning on applying to medical school with one gap year, my plans changed due to the need for me to care for my grandmother during the early pandemic. Unfortunately, this situation prompted the cancellation and deferral of my scheduled MCAT. However, these unexpected changes turned out to be blessings in disguise because they led to an incredibly rewarding clinical research experience that allowed me to discover my passion for research and patient care. As a clinical research fellow, I helped provide direct patient care when patients started to come back to in-person clinics. During this time, medical students had not yet integrated into the clinical setting and I had to learn quickly how to scribe and take patient histories remotely and in-person. I believe that my transition into the healthcare field during this particularly turbulent time has increased my ability to adapt and be resilient in the face of obstacles within the field of medicine.

personal_statement:
“Alex, dale agua a tu Tata, tiene sed.” (Alex, give your Tata some water, he’s thirsty.)
“Cómo Nana? No veo un vaso.” (How Nana? I don’t see a cup.)
“Con la esponja.” (With the sponge.)
 
I was 15 years old when I heard the word “hospice” for the first time. I discovered this meant my Tata (grandfather) would never hold a cup or drink on his own again. That day he laid before me, deflated, unable to speak, sit up, or move his head. He was not the man I knew, whose arms I would run into when he came home, who patched up drywall when I roller-skated inside the house, and played guitar for his family. A shadow of the man I knew and loved now lay before me. More than anything, I wanted to press the damp sponge gently on the leathery lips of the man who raised me. I wanted to do anything that could bring him the tiniest bit of relief. But I couldn’t. I was scared. I always wanted to be a doctor, but after seeing the rock of our family die before my eyes, I wasn’t sure. I needed to uncover if there was more to medicine.
 
Moving forward, I never wanted fear to outweigh my desire to help someone ever again. I vowed to conquer the experiences that scared me. One such experience found me early in my undergraduate career. I applied for a program called Data+ where I worked on a project called “Social Determinants of Health” (SDOH) that included ten, 40-hour weeks of pure, grueling bliss. As my team worked tirelessly to develop an interactive map of resources connected to SDOH in Cabarrus County, North Carolina, my world expanded. I not only learned an entirely new coding language, but I also realized that the world was not what I thought. Before Data+, I never knew that a zip code was so closely related to a community’s average lifespan. How could it be that within a county, the concentration of vape shops and convenience stores compared to Starbucks’ locations and yoga studios correlated to race, education, income, and health outcomes? What started out as a hesitant step outside my comfort zone, turned into a passion.
 
I delved further into this world when I was accepted into an interdisciplinary research program called Bass Connections on a project team called “SALUD: Scholar Academy for Latinxs United for Diversity”. Its purpose is to expand Latinx representation in STEM and healthcare careers through a curriculum designed for local Latinx high schoolers. Through this program, I explored health through the lens of my community, while helping others do the same. During one session, we watched a video about an undocumented Salvadoran woman living in Durham who struggled to pay for insulin. One of my students' eyes lit up, “That’s my tía (aunt).” What ensued was a rich conversation within my small group about what it meant to need medical care in the United States as a Latinx patient. The discussion transitioned to solutions regarding how to ensure that everyone’s “tías” get the care they need and deserve.
 
The interplay of these two experiences enhanced my interest in SDOH while allowing me to explore how data analysis is used to enact change. At El Futuro, a local Latinx mental health community center, we watched a documentary called “Resilience” centered on Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACEs). A physician in the documentary created a community center through her practice and researches the effects of ACEs, while integrating data and medicine to improve health outcomes in the lives of children who have experienced a high number of ACEs. I watched in awe as I saw my dreams lived out before me and realized what a privilege/honor it is to be a physician: to be a pillar of the community, to have the ability to conduct life-changing research, to have the authority to implement it, and most importantly, to use this to improve the quality of life for patients.
 
Around the same time, I enrolled in a course called Death and Dying that involved service-learning. When selecting a site, I chose to volunteer at the Hock Family Pavilion, a hospice facility. I recognized the time had come for me to confront my fears regarding hospice care. Through my experiences, I met many families who reminded me of my own and I sat by the beds of many families' Tatas. As I did, I couldn’t help but picture my own Tata, although now I was finally able to find the healing and closure I wasn’t ready to face at 15 years old. My understanding and perception of hospice shifted; it was no longer a time when people give up and die. Rather, it was where people find comfort and peace in their final moments.
 
Death no longer looms over me as a fearsome, ever-present enemy. My goal as a person and future physician is no longer to beat Death. My focus has shifted to the living. I strive to do what I can now, and I hope to provide culturally competent care to improve the quality of life of those around me. Some days that might be data analysis, other days it could be participating as a speaker in a program like SALUD, or even sitting at the bedside of a dying patient offering words of comfort. Being a physician will require overcoming many obstacles and fears, but I will embrace these challenges. If there’s anything my experiences have taught me, it’s that every scary moment is an opportunity for growth.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: When I volunteered at a nursing and rehabilitation facility, I interacted with a resident who I'll call James. James is a permanent resident and generally pretty soft-spoken. The first time I met him, we asked each other what it was like growing up since he's lived his whole life in North Carolina and I grew up in Arizona. I left that day looking forward to continuing to build our friendship. When I returned the next week, James had forgotten who I was and our previous conversation. Once more, James recounted the beauty of the rolling hills and North Carolina skies, and it was just as vivid as the first time. Understanding that James would likely not remember me the next time we visited, I created a plan so that we could engage in other activities if he didn't feel like talking. To my surprise, it worked. We watched sports on the iPad or read the Bible. Spending time with James showed me how to form a different kind of connection brought about through creativity.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: One of the motivations behind all that I do is the notion of giving back what I've gained. Two of my extracurricular experiences emphasize this value, my time as part of the SALUD program, and becoming a LEAPS facilitator for the Death and Dying course. I joined SALUD to provide an example for Latinx high schoolers interested in STEM or healthcare and help them in their journey. I discussed the realities of college and pursuing STEM as an underrepresented minority. In the end, I helped my students apply to summer programs and colleges. I'd like to think my guidance has played a small role in their lives. On the other hand, I became a facilitator for Death and Dying to assist my peers. Having gone through the heavy topics and service-learning placements changed me and how I view the world. If even a single student gained something from hearing my own experiences or through the small group discussions I ran, then I consider the world changed.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Due to COVID-19, I could not continue some of my in-person clinical volunteering activities at the Durham Nursing and Rehabilitation Center and the Hock Family Pavilion. Due to personal living situations, I did not pursue clinical experiences until a vaccine was available. After moving cities, delta and omicron variants have limited new opportunities. To continue engaging, I have taken advantage of online resources such as virtual shadowing to gain further exposure to different specialties. At home, I‚Äôve had multiple family members die, the closest being my godfather who is one of my inspirations for becoming a physician as he was the director of the local hospital in Mexico where my family is from. The circumstances brought on by the pandemic are challenging but have taught me to treasure moments with family more than before and has shown me what I would be missing without clinical care as a part of my life, reaffirming my desire to get back to it.

Hrdshp_Comments: I grew up in a suburb of Bello, Colombia. I lived a happy childhood and was fortunate to have good health. In 2012, my mom and I moved to the United States, looking for better educational opportunities. We enjoyed financial stability, though it only lasted a few years. My mom got laid off from her job and simultaneously divorced my ex-stepfather. We lived in the living room of my aunt’s already crowded apartment until my mom and I could rent a small apartment. Both of us sacrificed our sleep and health to afford it. My mom worked as much overtime as she could, and I worked between 20 and 30 hours per week during my junior and senior years of high school. Through college, I lived with financial distress and doubted that I would belong in the medical field due to my background. In addition, only 0.6% of my community has achieved a professional degree, ranking my city as the least educated in my state. Nevertheless, I think of all the hardship my mom and I have gone through. I turn the unfavorable odds into motivation to one day be a role model for other Hispanics looking to contribute their background and skills to the medical field.
personal_statement:
Frequent fainting spells, severe headaches, and droopy eyes: suddenly, these warning signs had become regular occurrences in the life of Dayana, my significant other. We met with Dr. Dob, a neurosurgeon. We felt chills running through our bodies as Dr. Dob gave the devastating news: a brain tumor. To have the best chance at recovery, we decided to proceed with surgical removal. Seconds felt like hours during the surgery as I sat in the hospital’s lobby desperately waiting. Eventually, Dr. Dob called us with the good news: The procedure was successful. The hospital’s Neurology Department became our temporary home for a few weeks while she recovered her strength, speech, and sight. Physicians checked on her every day, diligently arranged the plan for her recovery, and prepared us for our roles in it. Even on days when Dayana was at her weakest, Dr. Dob always appeared optimistic while still realistic. He lifted our spirits and always let us know that Dayana was recovering as expected despite the occasional trying moments. Eventually, Dayana made a full recovery, and her life progressively returned to normal. This event in 2017 motivated me to explore medicine, hoping to be as capable as Dr. Dob, who, through his knowledge and positive demeanor, saved Dayana’s life and made this challenging period easier to overcome. 

Combining my interest in medicine with my Hispanic heritage, I became a Spanish medical interpreter at the Rhode Island Free Clinic (RIFC). One day, I interpreted for “Maria,” a middle-aged woman with diabetes who had an abnormally high blood sugar level. Quietly shaking her head, her eyes focused on the floor, Maria seemed hesitant to follow Dr. Larkin’s advice to present to the emergency department. As soon as Dr. Larkins left the room, Maria leaned toward me and began expressing her deep concern about the financial cost of the emergency department. I nodded in understanding and told her that we would do our best to resolve her worries; she agreed. I shared Maria’s worries with Dr. Larkins, and we spent the next half hour along with the free clinic coordinators ensuring that Maria would receive the necessary financial aid. Later that week, I learned that Maria went to the emergency department, and her blood sugar was now under control. Maria’s experience was typical at the RIFC, where non-English speaking patients often felt more at ease confiding their troubles and concerns to others who speak their native language. Through my experiences with patients such as Maria, I realize that it is essential for patients to be culturally represented by their provider, as an interpreter may not always be available. I wish to become a physician so that through our shared language and culture, I can be a representation and make patients like Maria feel more comfortable and confident to share their concerns, allowing her to receive the best care possible.

After interpreting for three years, I then pursued a more active role in the care of patients as an Ophthalmic Assistant. One day, I saw “Jane,” an older woman experiencing blurred vision. As she sat in the examination room holding the occluder during her eye exam, she squinted, blinked, changed her posture, grumbled, and continuously requested first dimmer and then brighter lights. Her vision had been almost 20/20 a few months earlier; now, the “E” indicating 20/400 visual acuity on the well-lit screen proved a challenge for her. The testing screen revealed bleeding in the macula of both eyes, which gravely compromised her vision; the treatment required monthly injections. Jane’s tears engulfed her eyes as she confessed that her relatives had gone blind from eye disease. I pulled a chair over to sit before her, remained calm, and listened while placing a gentle, comforting hand on her back. I thoroughly addressed her concerns, pointing to the 3D anatomical poster on the wall to show her the source of the bleeding and where the doctor would insert the needle. I explained the positive outcomes we had had with other patients with the same condition and the possible risks. Jane sat back, took a deep breath, and expressed her intention to stick to her treatment diligently. It became clear that kindness and empathy were powerful instruments for Jane’s treatment. However, I strive to have a more active role in the care of my patients. In training to become a physician, I aspire to obtain the practical medical knowledge that, along with the comfort of understanding, will best help my future patients heal.

Dayana’s surgery sparked my interest in medicine, which I then developed through my own experiences in healthcare. My goal is to serve, educate, advocate for, and represent the Hispanic community as a physician, striving to provide each patient with the care they deserve regardless of their socioeconomic background. Seeing patients at their most vulnerable times also compelled me to become a doctor, and I aspire to provide kindness, guidance, and medical care that will improve the quality of life of those patients. I wish to be the best I can be for underrepresented patients like Maria and vulnerable patients like Jane; this keeps me eager and motivated to become a doctor.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Studying in Barcelona, I met and shared time with individuals from all over the world. During one of our activities, we were in a competition where we had to develop ‚Äúan interesting story about the day in the life of a ten-year-old boy.‚Äù Our team members had diverse upbringings as we all came from different countries, and in fact, from different continents! Our differences enhanced our team as we all contributed unique stories that we had lived when we were younger. Activities such as this one taught me to appreciate and value diverse views and ways of accomplishing goals.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: "Steph" was a Haitian student who came to the United States at 15. I met Steph when she was in 10th grade. She told me that although her English proficiency was on par with 10th-grade students, her high school insisted on placing her in ESL classes because she had a "thick" accent. Being in ESL prevented her from taking Honors or AP courses, which put her at a disadvantage for college admission. At the time, I was a senior in high school and had been through a similar situation in the past; I took it upon myself to help her. I went with Steph to our guidance counselor and spoke about the situation. I explained my story ,and how transitioning from ESL to traditional courses improved my pronunciation and speaking confidence. I also encouraged Steph to emphasize that she needed help with accent reduction but that language wise, she was on par with her peers. Our counselor agreed and advocated for Steph to be placed in conventional classes, where the school would monitor her performance.
7_-_COVID_Impact: In August of 2020, I resumed volunteering at the Rhode Island Free Clinic and took the opportunity to volunteer as a COVID-19 phone assistant. Here, I experienced the frustration of many patients who could not get tested at a convenient location and time or did not qualify to get tested at our clinic. Likewise, many patients struggled to get an appointment when the vaccine became available. This position made me aware that patients may have the best intentions to improve or maintain good health, but getting the proper treatment may be more difficult for them than anticipated. Hence, it taught me to be vigilant when ensuring my patients have the resources to obtain the treatment they need.

Hrdshp_Comments: My parents and I are undocumented immigrants from Oaxaca, Mexico. Prior to the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) executive action, I grew up without employment authorization and protection from deportation. During my childhood, my parents did not speak English fluently, lacked a higher education, and had to work multiple jobs to make ends meet. I attended a high school where many of my peers did not pursue college. Despite these barriers, I excelled in my AP coursework, extracurricular activities, and was the my family to go to college. The uncertainty associated with my legal status makes it difficult to plan my educational goals beyond two years. I continue to remain ineligible for most federal and state financial aid. My parents do not have a basic understanding of higher education such as career preparation, emotional support, and expenses. I worked during my undergraduate years while also being unprepared academically and emotionally. I struggled in my grades but was able to improve my coursework through mentorship, time management, and seeking guidance. With these improvements, I was the first in my family to obtain an undergraduate and graduate degree. The challenges I overcame and mentorship I have received have shaped me to become the resilient and capable individual that I am today.
personal_statement:
“Help!—Is there a doctor around here?” I looked up from my clipboard and was met with the concerned face of a man scrambling for assistance. I was a high school volunteer at a Flying Doctors Health Fair that day which took place on the same campus as a 5K charity run. I asked the man what was going on and he explained that a child had collapsed on the track. We left the sign-in booth and made our way to a classroom where the boy and his parents were located. As soon as I walked in, I saw the boy wheezing with his face flushed and wet with sweat. My chest tightened and my heart began to race as I heard him struggling to breathe. However, I maintained my composure as I introduced myself to the family. I immediately asked the boy to sit on a student desk and rest his head on his forearms while I left to grab one of the volunteer physicians.

I ran to the medical booth and found Dr. Raul Ruiz, an emergency room physician giving physical examinations. Dr. Ruiz listened patiently as I explained the situation and reassured me that everything was going to be okay. I escorted him to the classroom where I had left the family and he began to ask the parents questions about the boy's medical history. The parents revealed that he had asthma and had forgotten his inhaler at home. Dr. Ruiz then instructed me to get a nurse from the medical booth who had an emergency kit and to call for an ambulance in case the asthma worsened. As I ran back to the medical booth, I prayed for the boy’s health and hoped that the paramedics were only a precaution. Ultimately, the nurse and Dr. Ruiz were both able to find an inhaler and stabilize the boy while the ambulance arrived.

Although this was a brief experience, I was inspired by Dr. Ruiz’s calm leadership and quick thinking. Prior to this, most of my interactions with physicians occurred during my mother’s routine visits where I acted as a translator. These interactions typically left me feeling frustrated and questioning why immigrants, like my parents, often had a difficult time finding a Spanish-speaking physician. However, working with Dr. Ruiz left me feeling empowered, supported, and reassured that the boy and his family were getting the attention they deserved. I began to imagine how my parents' health would improve if they were able to have Spanish-speaking physicians who understood their language, culture, and could appreciate the struggles they faced as undocumented immigrants. Envisioning this type of care for my parents is what fuels my goal to make healthcare more accessible, affordable, and culturally competent.

As a caseworker for the Mobile Clinic Project at UCLA, I was able to get a glimpse of the type of care I want to provide as a physician. During clinic hours, I worked with volunteer physicians and medical students in providing holistic care for medically underserved populations. A client I had worked with was chronically homeless for several years and suffered from severe depression. Through our interactions, I learned that his inability to find stable housing prevented him from getting treatment for his mental health illness. Though he did not have a safety net, I was there to listen to his life story and create a safe and non-judgmental environment. Experiences like these challenged me to get out of my comfort zone and interact with individuals who have complex needs. Over time, I was able to build strong working relationships with clients and found joy in hearing their life updates.

I heard everything as a caseworker. I heard achievements such as clients finally being admitted into a shelter or clients finally feeling a sense of optimism and joy. However, I also heard setbacks such as clients having their personal belongings stolen or relapsing into substance abuse. My experience as a caseworker allowed me to understand the importance of establishing a human connection in a clinical setting. I learned that every human deserves to have their humanity acknowledged and have their personal stories heard. This was an unforgettable experience where I learned how to practice compassion and clinical skills at an equal level. As a physician, I envision treating my patients with the same compassion and empathy that the clinic fostered.

As an undocumented immigrant, my journey to medical school has not been easy. There have been times when I was discouraged from applying to internships, job opportunities, or scholarships based on my immigrant status. However, my immigrant status is also my greatest source of inspiration. Through my storytelling and student activism, I have learned how to become a leader and build coalitions for immigration reform advocacy. I was also the first in my family to graduate from college and obtain my Master of Public Health from an Ivy League institution. Throughout my entire trajectory, I have used my story and immigration status as my North Star in breaking down barriers for other undocumented students. As a future physician, I am committed to providing culturally competent healthcare and being an advocate for health equity among all populations. I am more than confident that my medical training will continue to foster these values and allow me to be a healthcare leader for social change.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As a caseworker, I worked on improving health outcomes among housing-insecure populations. Before this opportunity, I viewed homelessness as an issue related to income and mental health. However, I worked with chronically homeless individuals that had diverse backgrounds such as former police officers, recovered drug addicts, and aspiring artists. The life stories I heard from clients encouraged me to challenge my perspective of homelessness and reflect beyond my scope of understanding. I learned that homelessness is a complex social issue that stems from discrimination as well as social and racial inequities. I also learned that listening to a patient‚Äôs life history can reveal a lot more about their illnesses than simply checking off a symptom checklist. As a physician, I aim to be there for my future patients when they have a setback and help them heal in a manner that occurs with empathy. I hope to continue working with people from different backgrounds in Chicago‚Äôs west side.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As a project specialist at USC, I surveyed Tribal health facilities to gain a better understanding of the gaps in opioid use disorder (OUD) services currently affecting California Tribal communities. I collaborated with a community advisory board in recruiting Tribal health leaders for key informant interviews and developing the methods of dissemination for our project. Through the interviews, we learned that Tribal facilities often combine various sources of funding in a patchwork-like method to sustain their current treatment programs and recovery services. This was particularly evident for facilities that had a focus on traditional medicine as many of these services are ineligible for reimbursement through major health care funding sources. With these findings, we submitted a policy report to the California Department of Health Care Services to advocate for health policies that reimburse traditional healing methods and show that OUD services are fragmented in Tribal communities.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I was laid off from my job during the early months of the pandemic which caused me a great amount of financial and mental distress. On top of losing my source of income, I was also taking post-baccalaureate classes to improve my science GPA for my future medical school applications. I felt suffocated during this time by the mounting responsibility of finding new employment and balancing my coursework. The pandemic also affected my post-baccalaureate coursework since my classes switched from being in-person to a virtual format. I required a learning environment where I can ask questions in person and build relationships with my peers. With a virtual format, I was unable to connect with my class more traditionally. Lastly, the COVID-19 pandemic affected my MCAT preparation since my test date was canceled due to the winter surge of COVID-19. Although I had more time to study, I could not sustain my mental energy to continue preparing for the exam while also working full-time.

personal_statement:
I downloaded the Wikipedia app for the first time when I was 11. Ever since, I’ve read about unmeetable people, mysterious histories, and many articles reminding readers that their contents–whether published in a textbook or within that very entry–remain “poorly understood.” I knew I’d want a part in sharing and expanding that understanding.

I was elected editor-in-chief of my college newspaper, ‘The Heights,’ my junior year. While spending up to 30 hours or more each week managing the paper left me with everything from fewer hours to study to inevitably waking up roommates at 3 a.m. after finalizing each week’s issue, I knew I was contributing to that same goal. Indeed, journalists are not so different from physicians: each seeks to inform others by making intangible, abstract, or detail-laden truths accessible and understandable.

I spent much of sophomore year writing an investigation into how a simple mistake by my college’s IT department left thousands of confidential details about students and staff accessible to nearly anyone at the university. This led my coauthor and I to be quietly threatened with disciplinary action (none ever materialized) as the university did not want us to publish our report. But the right of thousands of students to know about and understand this oversight was far more important. My coauthor and I were the only students who knew all the details, so we had to explain what happened in a way that was clear and accessible to our readers, regardless of whether they were computer scientists or art historians.

Working as a medical scribe for a pediatric neurologist required similar precision–certainly, it was more than an exercise in stenography and typing 80 words per minute (though the importance of the latter should not be understated). I learned when to record every detail–a child’s bedtime down to the quarter hour for sleep training, medication titrations for controlling evening seizures, summer camp plans–and when to listen in silence, as when a mother told us, in a whisper, about abuse inflicted by school assistants on her daughter with Rett Syndrome. Without overstating my otherwise quiet, observant presence buried behind a bulky Workstation on Wheels in the corner of an eight-by-ten exam room, I was always present—listening in and paying attention.

Often, the most important detail I recorded was just that an eight-year-old boy with Angelman Syndrome–a rare genetic syndrome that often leads to pediatric epilepsies–slept, uninterrupted, for eight hours the previous night. “Just,” of course, understates the myriad of interventions that led to such success, the signs of which exhausted parents wore on their faces as they walked into clinic. Parents of children with lissencephaly or yet-to-be-named mitochondrial diseases had in their child’s health records the unthinkable weight of hospice and visiting nurses' notes, sometimes filed just hours before their clinic appointment.

What helped ground me while scrolling through these records and preparing clinic notes is a concept called radical hope. Claimed by everyone from parents to theologians to historians, radical hope can be defined as hope that is available to all people, at all times. Availability on its own, however, is not enough. Such hope must be made accessible.

In clinic, patients and families were always met where they were regarding their understanding of their child’s disease, therapies, and treatments. The clinic’s NP developed a method for navigating the pre-authorization procedure for children with epilepsies resistant to first, second, and third-line treatments. The clinic’s dietician walked parents through why a ketogenic diet was, at times, as effective as antiepileptic medications. The neurologist asked as earnestly about the health of his patient’s parents and their access to care as he did when discussing their children’s care. No suggestion or change went unexplained.

My role as a physician will always lie in bridging the gap between the availability of information and care and a patient’s actual access to these resources. My knowledge of a prognosis or treatment may be only as beneficial as a patient’s own understanding of it, so it will always be my responsibility to ensure patients have real, working understandings of their conditions.

A favorite story of the late Fr. Michael Himes, himself a favorite and storied priest at Boston College, is one from the eighteenth-century biography of the writer Samuel Johnson. In one scene, Johnson and his biographer charter a short boat ride across the river Thames while discussing whether it is beneficial for everyone to be “classically educated” in the liberal arts–even those whose lives traditionally do not require such knowledge. Johnson turns to the uneducated teenager sailing the boat and asks what he would give to know about Orpheus and the Argonauts, the great, mythical sailors who searched for the Golden Fleece. To gain such knowledge, the boy replies, “I would give what I have.” Johnson, impressed with the boy's response, tips him double, and concludes that in fact, it is one’s nature to give everything to learn.

I’d have tipped him too. But I’d have sat with him and helped him search for the Argonauts on Wikipedia first.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
At Boston College, I became particularly interested in working with populations that have been systematically excluded from and underserved by their communities. As a volunteer at Boston Health Care for the Homeless Program (BHCHP), service began with allowing myself to be vulnerable to the needs and experiences of those I served. Indeed, the lives of those with whom I worked were considerably different than my own, and my goal was not to simply search for parallels between our lived experiences. _x000D_
_x000D_
Instead, choosing to consider their lives complexly became essential to how I volunteered and will be central to how I will support patients as a physician. Part of my role at BHCHP involved administering patient care surveys to patients waiting in clinic. While my role was limited to helping record responses, I spoke with patients to better understand the intricate challenges they faced in accessing high quality care, and how BHCHP could work to respond. _x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
I administered patient care surveys to those receiving regular medical care at the BHCHP clinic. The survey was written in a tone that assumed respondents were unhoused. While this was often true, when I reached the ‚Äúcomments‚Äù section with one patient, he told me that, in fact, he was not homeless. He had just recently been able to transition to a supportive housing program, and he wanted me to make note of this to provide some additional context to his other responses, and that the survey should be changed._x000D_
_x000D_
This was not something I could solve; there was no manager to whom I could bring this patient‚Äôs concern. But I made myself available to hear him, to respond carefully, and to always encourage patients to share with me as much as they were comfortable (which, sometimes, was nothing). As it was made clear to me, along with clinicians and other staff members, we were often among the only ones willing to listen to anything many of these patients wished to share.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
Until March of 2020, I was working part-time as a medical scribe at Massachusetts General Hospital. Unsurprisingly, the office soon transitioned to telemedicine visits, and my position was put on hold ‚Äúindefinitely.‚Äù_x000D_
_x000D_
Students were soon sent home from my undergraduate institution. I requested a waiver from Boston College to remain on campus, hoping that some office visits might continue in person, and that I might be able to continue scribing. Many scribes in the Emergency Department there were also college students forced to leave their campus housing, but they were not granted any waivers to stay. I chose to retrain as an emergency medicine scribe and began working in the ED by April rather than return home. Though scribes play a small role in a patient‚Äôs ED visit, I knew it was still worthwhile for me to apply my skills, even if it only meant that an attending physician could leave a few minutes early, or that patients could look at their doctor instead of a screen during a visit.

personal_statement:
For the majority of my life, I have comfortably resided in the suburbs of North Georgia in a community with a school system recognized for its many accolades, a diversity of places of worship, and a variety of health care facilities. It is no surprise that news articles have regarded our community as one of the best places to live in the nation. My experience, however, differed drastically from that of my cousin Martinez, who was born with cerebral palsy, adopted by our grandmother, and raised in the southside of Chicago. I grew to learn more about him and his experiences when he and grandma moved into our home for a period of time after struggling financially. I saw how multiple surgeries and his living conditions had affected his life and can only imagine how powerless he has felt, however despite the obstacles he has faced he has always been ambitious and remained a positive outlook on life. 

In having witnessed my cousin navigate his life as a disabled minority living off the limited income of a single guardian, I am aware that there are complex socioeconomic factors that contribute to disparities in healthcare. I recognize my privilege in my upbringing and I understand how many others, like Martinez, do not have a say in their environment or physiological condition. Inspired by what I had witnessed and driven by my interest to research, watch informative videos, and read articles outside of my academic studies, I investigated other disparities in our healthcare system. I was stunned at the limited distribution of healthcare providers throughout my state and shocked at the high maternal mortality rates in our minority and underserved communities.

Because of this knowledge, during the pandemic, I sought opportunities that would connect me more to my local underserved community and volunteered for the Good Samaritan COVID-19 helpline which assisted my community with information about the virus and with testing and vaccination appointments. I listened intently to how the pandemic was impacting my community, how families struggled maintaining jobs, and how worried they were for the health of their loved ones. Although I initially thought my job was simple I recognize my guidance and reassurance may have had a huge impact on these families navigating the world in uncertain times. 

Interested in expanding my clinical experience, I gained a position as a medical scribe in the emergency department. I was initially overwhelmed with my job as it was a step out of my comfort zone: the environment was new, there was a constant babble of alarms chirping, phones ringing, overhead announcements, and a lot of unfamiliar terminology. As I gradually grew accustomed to the conditions, I began learning more about my community's struggles. For instance, although I had spent most of my life living in north Georgia I had not anticipated seeing how prevalent drug addiction and homelessness were. 

I also learned a great deal about the demands of an ED physician. Paired with Dr.Halligan, I observed her approach a patient and ask, “¿Dónde está tu dolor?” the patient began motioning toward their abdomen and explaining their symptoms in Spanish. She examined the patient, gently reassured them, and discussed the plan all in proficient Spanish. I had difficulty understanding the conversation and began to reflect on how equally alienated and confused patients might feel being surrounded by an unfamiliar language. I was impressed by Dr.Halligan’s dedication to eliminating the language barrier and was inspired to start an introductory Spanish course. 

In another encounter, a man with a history of CHF presented to the ED complaining of chest pain. Upon questioning, he expressed that he had stopped taking his medications for the past few months because he no longer had insurance and was now relying on special water marketed as a panacea. The patient was adamant that his intake of electrolyte-infused water had improved his condition over the last few months despite his current pain. I couldn’t believe what I was hearing as I quietly jotted down notes in the corner of the room. I found his situation to be tragic as he, pressured by economic hardship, felt the need to look for alternatives to his medications. Unfortunately, he would be one of many patients who were unable to continue taking their medications due to limited expenses or lack of insurance. This experience illustrated to me how damaging disparities can be and has reminded me that when it comes to treatment plans physicians can only advise patients and inform them of their options, while the power to make decisions is left to the patient. 

Through my experiences, I have witnessed the direct consequences of socioeconomic disparities on our patients’ health and I have gathered that much like the cycle of poverty, health disparities are, too, cyclical in nature. I recognize that many people are struggling due to circumstances that they themselves cannot directly control. I believe as a physician it is important to recognize the barriers patients have in accessing resources and attempt to stop the damning cycle. I hope that I can one day use my compassionate understanding of disparities to provide quality healthcare to communities in need.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Growing up as an African American in the suburbs of North Georgia, I‚Äôm accustomed to constantly being surrounded by people with different religions, ethnicities, cultures, languages, and viewpoints. Collaborating and working alongside classmates with drastically different backgrounds has in some ways broadened my world view.  My understanding of global history and desire to study Japanese has also encouraged me to consider others‚Äô perspectives. In addition, my experience as an ED scribe has enhanced my ability to understand other individuals particularly those struggling with mental health and drug abuse. I recognize that traumatic experiences can bring about these difficulties and I witnessed how these issues impact the family and community. I believe that being open to diverse perspectives improves patient care as it assists with being able to make educated decisions, collaborating with peers, and connecting with diverse patient populations.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: During my time volunteering for the Good Samaritan COVID-19 helpline I assisted the local Atlanta community in receiving free appointments for testing and vaccinations. I remember listening to how the pandemic was impacting a mother who, while juggling multiple responsibilities, was trying to get her kids back in school after being exposed to another sick child. I listened closely and comforted her as I scheduled appointments for the entire family. I believe that my effort impacted not only her, but also the many other families in the community.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I began to understand the severity of COVID-19 and the upcoming pandemic when my coach called a meeting to announce the cancellation of ACC athletic events for the remainder of the spring of 2020. I promptly packed home and finished my classes online. I had applied for many summer undergraduate research experience programs, but sadly received letters about their cancellation. I spent that summer in quarantine with my family focusing on running and reflecting on recent events. Upon my return to school both academic and athletics had changed dramatically. Throughout the school year in preparation for the summer I planned to shadow local physicians and volunteer at a local hospital however when I emailed and called to apply they said their programs were still postponed. I then began reaching out to local clinics who told me they were not currently accepting any shadowing or volunteering. I was devastated but was able to volunteer at a Vet Clinic and Good Samaritan.

personal_statement:
My parents rarely went to the doctor and always ascribed to the “best not to know” policy with healthcare. After losing two grandparents to lung cancer and my grandmother being diagnosed with a brain tumor, the word healthcare was riddled with anxiety and intimidation for our family. Staying out of the “know” was the best way for my parents to avoid the heartbreak and uneasiness healthcare has given them in the past. Knowing this, I was ready to accompany my parents to the doctor when abnormal symptoms arose. When the physician told my mother that she has diabetes, and my father has prostate cancer, shock and dismay followed. Feeling scared, vulnerable, and powerless were just some of the flooding of emotions I remember. Will this change their quality of life? Is this manageable? What is the next step? Questions came pouring out as the physician listened quietly. When we finished, she confidently responded to each inquiry. She was empathetic, passionate, knowledgeable, and in the end, optimism replaced our worries. 
Our family’s policy of staying in the dark was obsolete that day. A single conversation with our physician allowed us to move past despair and hopelessness, which sparked an internal drive in me to comprehend healthcare, console the vulnerable, and offer guidance during uncertainty. To dedicate my life to these new goals, I faced a significant decision; leave the architecture program I was currently enrolled in, for a new frontier in medicine. I knew being a doctor encompassed more than science classes and incorporated many of the skills I already possess and paralleled with architecture; empathy, communication, problem-solving, and teamwork. My experiences in the Las Vegas General ED were pivotal in my decision to pursue healthcare and refine my skills for medical school.
