Keeping up with the bustle of the Las Vegas General ED is challenging, especially when you are hauling a computer on wheels into the blistering summer heat of an ambulance bay. Despite the unpleasantries, I felt excited each shift as a medical scribe because there was an opportunity to learn a new aspect of medicine that led me closer to fully understanding the entire picture of healthcare. On one shift, the physician and I ran over to see an 18-year-old girl sobbing with her family. After addressing the medical emergency and explaining that their daughter needs evaluation for a heart condition, they flooded us with questions. “I don’t understand how this could happen?” her mother cried, “She is a soccer player and has a scholarship. Will she ever play again?” At that moment, I saw in them my own family and our shared pursuit of clarity. I studied how the physician expertly navigated concerns, and my time studying these interactions as a scribe was instrumental in solidifying my decision to go to medical school. 
One morning I awoke with a text from my manager, and the message was terrifying. A mass shooting on the Las Vegas strip occurred the night before, and we needed more coverage to help with the influx of patients. Saddened and shocked, I quickly rushed over early to meet with my assigned physician. Throughout the day we made sure to sit fully with each patient, assessing not only their physical injuries but also their mental state. “Life altering events are remembered vividly,” the physician explained to me, “they will remember our interactions today for the rest of their lives.” Towards the end of our shift, we both realized we could do better to make all types of interactions like this, even the diagnoses we have seen dozens of times. The reason to seek any medical help is a life altering event for a patient, and our goal was to guide a patient through their distress with empathy and compassion, just like my primary physician did for my family. I was able to see first-hand how trust was developed, how to fully connect with a patient, and how to individualize an interaction and provide guidance when a patient is under distress. These types of interactions are what inspired my drive for medical school, and I focused on using this communicative style as a model for every future interaction, learning how I can be the type of physician that moves others past despair and hopelessness. 
When I was an architecture student, I wanted to construct green buildings, bridges, and perhaps even hospitals. Accompanying my parents on that fateful appointment years ago offered a different blueprint for my life, one that I am thrilled to be adding to. In the end, I am excited that what enticed me about architecture; goal setting, collaboration, and being detail-centered are also abundant in medicine. I was fortunate to refine these skills while developing new ones specific to healthcare, such as patient-centered care, effective communication, and becoming comfortable providing care in ambiguous situations. Changing paths allowed me to write a new philosophy for my family and I; one where “being in the know” is life-affirming and caring, a mantra that embodies my “why?”. It’s the drive that fuels me toward my goal every day.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As a Court Appointed Special Advocate for foster children, I represent abused and neglected children in court to advocate for their best interest in overall wellness. After an intensive training, I was assigned a girl who has been in foster care for over one year. During the time I developed a relationship with her, I grew to understand multiple viewpoints which I have never been exposed to before. I learned to understand trauma responses and underlying issues causing distrust, which allowed me to develop a relationship based off understanding and empathy. I observed how cultural ideals fostered development and I saw issues facing multiple levels of socioeconomic backgrounds. I also learned how nutrition and health are pivotal in a child‚Äôs progress. These experiences gave me first-hand knowledge about issues faced by marginalized communities and ways to help address inequalities by utilizing resources and developing connections based off empathy.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As a volunteer for the American Society for Microbiology, I coordinated activities with after school programs and low-income schools for science experiments. On one occasion, we went to an elementary school to do a four-week science fair challenge. As I approached my group, I was met with boredom and ‚Äúisn‚Äôt science just plants and animals?‚Äù. To show that science is more, I took them to research a wide range of topics. I watched as their eyes lit up as we stumbled on robotics and other topics. For the next four weeks I was met with excitement about the next new discovery. Afterwards, I was told stories from teachers and parents about how our projects increased ‚Äúwhy‚Äù inquiries in the classroom and at home. This experience informed my future goals of science education in medicine. Allowing science to be understood creates a friendly environment to ask questions, which in turn can translate into acting for your own health by asking about and understanding preventative measures.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The week I defended my thesis for my Master‚Äôs Degree in Biology, Las Vegas shut down due to COVID-19. I was in a unique position to use my microbiology laboratory background to help the community fight against this novel virus. I volunteered to make COVID-19 testing kits by distributing sterile viral transport media into hundreds of test tubes. I also responded to an emergency declaration to help the University Medical Center process a massive influx of COVID-19 tests from around the valley. I worked with a biotech company focusing on a novel quick COVID-19 testing method to keep businesses open safely and reduce public health risks. These transformative experiences allowed me to refine my critical thinking and laboratory skills to help the community during one of the most difficult times. I developed resilience and the ability to further understand healthcare in terms of public health, preparing me to have a background for future challenges in medicine.

personal_statement:
“…suffocating.” I listened as Esther, a mom of two and lung transplant candidate, described a process we all take for granted: breathing. My design team had gotten to know Esther for her love of the outdoors, her devotion to her family and her experience living with interstitial lung disease. We met through a project in collaboration with Michigan Medicine to design an improved oxygen tank transport device for delivering high-flow oxygen to patients with end-stage lung disease during medically-required walks. Daily exercise requires an IV pole, monitor, and high-flow nasal cannula attached to a 130 pound, H-sized oxygen tank and humidifier, along with two to three assisting staff members. By Esther’s account, walking amidst a parade of equipment made her feel unstable. She described walks as logistically exhausting for her and medical staff. This was the problem we were here to address.

Our goal was to design an optimized transport system that consolidated all the necessary equipment onto a single cart that could be operated by one staff member. Esther had unknowingly become a valuable team member for her unique perspective. To better understand the limitations of the old system, I asked the respiratory technician if I could try it out myself. He placed a nasal cannula around my head and tied an IV line to my wrist. Just as Esther described, I used a wheelchair as a walker. The technician turned on the humidifier and started the flow of oxygen, following closely behind me pushing the oxygen tank cart, while a nurse shimmied the IV pole alongside us. Mid-walk the humidifier battery died. Cold, dry oxygen burned the inside of my nostrils, making it hard to breathe. Humidifier is non-optional – noted. Then as I bent down to pick up some dragging tubing, the wheelchair rolled away, jeopardizing my balance. I experienced the same challenges and feelings of unease that Esther had described and observed new issues I felt we could address. It became clear that the current transport system, which was intended to build patients’ strength, was limiting their mobility.

It was Esther’s personal account of using the old transport system that seeded my emotional connection to this project. Getting to know her as a once-active parent and wife expanded my focus beyond how to safely deliver medical care to creating a product that supported her morale and independence. Effective health care goes beyond the technical. As standards of care continuously evolve, I look forward to being a physician that uses imagination and a clear understanding of my patients’ unspoken needs to deliver outcomes with true value.

I now work as a research coordinator in a pediatric intensive care unit, where I enroll children into clinical studies and process their samples for experimental use. Our research focuses on the role of T cells in acute upper respiratory virus infections in children. My past experiences with pediatric patients have hugely shaped my clinical interests and aspiration to be a physician. Pediatric medicine offers the opportunity to build strong, long-term connections with young patients and their families that can impact the trajectory of a child’s lifelong health. Participating in pediatric research has deepened my understanding of the clinical considerations unique to young patients, yet the intensive care environment has challenged me to adapt how I connect with patients and their families. The relationships I previously built on laughter and shared experiences as a hospital volunteer are no longer feasible. Many of the patients I work with cannot speak for themselves. Their parents are scared.

“High risk of death” were the words I read on the chart of a six year old with no past medical history, now on life support as the result of the flu. As I approached his parents, their faces showed the anguish of the last five days, but the mother’s grasp on her son’s hand told of the six years prior. Such instances of unpredictably severe respiratory infection are the impetus behind our research, but it is especially difficult to approach these families about research participation. In these cases, I earn a family’s trust through patience, deference and transparency. By thoroughly explaining the goals of our research, speaking in the family’s preferred language and dedicating time to their questions, I help them independently make a decision for their child that they know will be respected. Even in devastating circumstances, the majority of families chose to participate, motivated by the opportunity to benefit children hospitalized in the future. These interactions have led me to see patients and families as true collaborators in research and not merely as peripheral contributors.

The strong connections I formed with patients and their families have continued to inspire my ambition to study medicine. I have witnessed how effective clinical care and meaningful innovation rely on eliciting patients’ trust and understanding their experiences. Research and new medical technologies are driving advancements in medical care and demand physicians that will challenge convention to improve their patients’ outcomes. I am confident that as a physician I will bridge patients’ narratives with clinical insight to deliver inventive care.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Walking down the busy hallways of the Audubon Pediatric Clinic, you will notice that all the staff are fluent in both English and Spanish. For the clinic‚Äôs predominantly low-income, Spanish-speaking patients, this means communicating without limitations at all stages of their visit._x000D_
_x000D_
Attaining Spanish fluency has been a longtime goal of mine, but currently my moderate proficiency is not reliable enough for the patient care environment. My job collecting blood samples for research would not be possible without the bilingual nurses, medical assistants, phlebotomists and translators who have all helped me communicate with patients and their families. The staff taught me colloquial Spanish phrases to offer comfort, educated me on prevailing values among patient families and prepared me to actively engage patient families in their child‚Äôs care. I saw firsthand how language concordance allows patients to dictate their own care, and equips physicians to provide better informed care.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
My first time meeting Henry, he eagerly told me about his favorite activities: riding his bike and playing soccer. Other than a congenital limb defect affecting his right hand, he was a typical, active six-year-old boy, and our team had the exciting honor of designing him a custom neuroprosthetic device at no cost to his family. This initiative was driven by the principle that, when equitably distributed, medical technology has the potential to mitigate the effects of social health determinants._x000D_
_x000D_
Getting to know Henry helped us build a device that accommodated his physical deficiencies, but also his hobbies and preferences. After months of work, he was elated to receive a prosthetic that was clearly designed with him in mind. I look forward to future opportunities to build trusted relationships with patients and use their perspectives to produce impactful solutions that confront social inequities.
7_-_COVID_Impact: As a 2020 college graduate, the pandemic resulted in an abruptly premature end to my positions as a clinical research assistant and hospital volunteer. Soon after, the full-time job in clinical research I had lined up for after graduation was unexpectedly dissolved due to an indefinite hiring freeze. Instead, during this time, I volunteered as a tutor and collaborated on an initiative to address COVID-19 medical equipment needs in rural, resource-limited communities across Ghana. In early July of this year, I caught COVID-19 and I am currently experiencing persistent long-haul breathing difficulties and chronic fatigue.

personal_statement:
"Paging Medic 32: We need you en route to a possible motor vehicle accident. Number of patients unknown." I went into emergency response mode: Lights, sirens, directions. My partner pulled up the directions and instructed me to turn the ambulance around. We were driving on a country road at night, so finding a place to turn around was difficult. When a driveway appeared, I slowed to turn. Suddenly, our ambulance was thrust into a 360-degree spin. During the brief, violent crash, my head hit the driver window, and my grip tightened on the steering wheel to regain control. When the ambulance stopped spinning, my partner and I watched the dually truck that just rear-ended us crash into an electrical pole. Though concussed (as I later found out), my first response was to render aid to passengers in the other vehicle by getting them safely out of the fiery truck. I braced one of the patient's broken legs and applied burn bandages to his forearms. Both patients were stabilized and left for the hospital in another ambulance. As the dust settled from the accident, my call to be a physician was solidified. My call is to help people through the most challenging moments of their lives.

A cardiac fellow, Dr. Arain, helped me through the most challenging moment of my life. My father had complications after an orthopedic surgery, which resulted in two pulmonary embolisms (PE). One cardiac fellow recommended an immediate Ekosonic Endovascular System, a new procedure using ultrasound waves to dissolve PEs for patients in severe respiratory distress. The operation was risky, so we investigated second opinions. During this time, Dr. Arain took over the shift and reviewed my father's case. He believed the PEs were of concern, but the procedure would be too risky since my father was not in respiratory distress and his vital signs were stable. Dr. Arain used Evidence-Based Medicine (EBM) to present a different plan allowing my father's system to dissolve the PEs naturally. Within a few weeks, my father's health improved. I cannot speak to the result had my father undergone the procedure, but I can speak to Dr. Arain, an advocate for my father's well-being. Thankful and inspired to have witnessed this fellow's expertise and responsibility to my father, I recognized the importance of patient advocacy and EBM.

My interaction with Dr. Arain left me curious about the causes of cardiovascular diseases. Eager to investigate my new questions, I joined a research lab that examines the individual roles of junctional proteins (JP) in cardiomyocytes. Each JP contributes to the heart's function, and cardiovascular diseases can arise when mutations occur. By linking cardiovascular disease to specific mutations, we can better understand how to treat the source of disease instead of the symptoms. This research is important to me because it will be incorporated into future treatment plans for patients suffering from cardiovascular diseases. Moving forward in my medical path, I plan to continue with research and implement EBM in my future treatment practices.

Outside of research, shadowing provided the opportunity to see patient advocacy in action. One physician, Dr. Buzzard, examined an eight-year-old boy in the emergency room with a leg rash. Upon examination, he diagnosed the child with cellulitis and noticed other physical factors indicating the rash might be due to neglect. The parents were on their phones, constantly arguing and vaguely answering the doctor's questions. After noticing the parent's demeanor, Dr. Buzzard decided to sit down with them. He carefully chose words that led them to focus on their son's treatment. Dr. Buzzard went above and beyond to be an advocate for this little boy. My goal is to bring these same meaningful conversations into people's lives.

The Biomedical Masters Program allowed me to be an advocate for patients, as I witnessed with Dr. Buzzard. As a Physician Task Facilitator in the emergency room, one of my roles was to ensure patients were comfortable and supported during wait times. One patient, 'Ren,' alerted the department of his discomfort by screeching at the top of his lungs. I tried to calm him, but he was too intoxicated. Due to his disruptive behavior, Ren was sedated twice over two hours and woke up louder each time. Hearing the discomfort in his voice, I listened carefully, thinking it could be a clue. That's when I heard the screeching was him incoherently yelling, "pee!" Ren needed to go to the bathroom. I told the medical resident my interpretation of his screeching, and the resident ordered a foley catheter. Two and a half liters of urine drained from him in forty minutes. Afterward, Ren became calm and quickly fell asleep. Fueled by my interactions with Dr. Arain and Dr. Buzzard, I was able to listen to Ren and become his advocate in his time of discomfort.

In the ambulance accident, my first instinct was to help others who were injured. My aptitude to help them and others, such as Ren, deepens my confidence in becoming a physician. These experiences as a first responder and an advocate for patients have strengthened my commitment to medicine. My goal is to continue to grow in knowledge and expertise by attending medical school as I continue answering my call to be a physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
After joining the Panhellenic community, 'Liz' and I discussed the recruitment process. "I didn't get a choice in my chapter,‚Äù she frustratingly explained. Liz believed she was dismissed from other chapters because she was Jewish. "Being Jewish is a part of me, but not my whole story." Listening to her perspective, I realized the practice of being judged by a filter inhibited Panhellenic from empowering women. _x000D_
_x000D_
Wanting to face this challenge, I met with the President to create and lead a new position; Director of Diversity and Inclusion. The position facilitated conversations about microaggressions and passive exclusion, which resulted in changes._x000D_
_x000D_
My interaction with Liz helped me appreciate different cultural groups and remove unconscious filters placed on someone before getting to know them. Now, my relationships can start on a more open platform to foster dependability. I will bring these skills to Rush Medical College when interacting with future patients and fellow students.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: According to the US Census Bureau, 17.3% of individuals living in Chicago live below the poverty line. While working as an EMT-B in Grimes County, I saw poverty's direct impact on individuals' health. 'Tom' was a 36-year-old male who had been stabbed in the stomach. He needed transport to a hospital to treat the uncontrollable bleeding wound. "I cannot afford that," Tom looked at me. "I have a baby, and I have no money." I explained CHI St. Joseph's affordable plans, but he refused transport. These moments drive me toward becoming a physician to help individuals struggling with receiving proper medical care due to financial disparities. As a medical student at Rush, I would work towards providing affordable healthcare to underrepresented populations through volunteering at the Rush Community Service Initiatives Program Clinic at Chicago Church and the Community Health Clinic. These programs resonate with me as they bring relief to patients below the poverty line.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
Breaking News: ‚ÄúFirst Responders dwindling due to COVID-19 Infections.‚Äù I began to wonder who was helping when the first responders became overworked. That is when an idea formed to utilize my EMT-Basic license to help relieve the burden._x000D_
_x000D_
However, I knew that in order to do so, I would have to leave my family since my mother is immunocompromised. I faced a difficult decision: leave home to help others or stay to take care of my mother. That is when my mother reminded me of what the Nobel Prize winner Aung Kyi said. ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre feeling helpless, help someone.‚Äù So, I did._x000D_
_x000D_
Choosing to serve allowed me to experience direct patient contact. As an EMT-B, I had the opportunity to address and soothe patients' fears about the ongoing pandemic by educating them on the CDC-recommended protocols at the time. My experience in emergency medicine during COVID-19 furthered my commitment to medicine, and I hope to continue improving my skills by attending Rush Medical College.

personal_statement:
At a familiar hospital in an even more familiar city, my eight-year-old mind saw the practice of healing in a brand-new way. My father and I were visiting my uncle in the suburbs of Chicago, and while we waited for him to return home from work, our plans for the afternoon suddenly changed. Getting out of the car, my father accidentally slammed the door on his finger, cutting the skin open and exposing the bone. Immediately, we got back in the car and rushed to the hospital. Despite my dad screaming in pain, I was surprisingly calm in the midst of all the chaos and blood. The first thing I did was call my uncle, who was a practicing orthopedic surgeon. Before long, we were at the hospital, and my uncle was standing at the entrance waiting for us. With grit and haste, he stopped the bleeding, closed the wound, and ultimately saved my dad’s finger. At this moment, I knew that medicine was a potential path for my future, allowing me to care for others the same way my uncle did for my dad. Unbeknownst to me, this memory would later foster a deep passion for medicine.

As time passed, many of my interests in life changed, but my fascination with medicine was constant. Eager to learn more about the field, I started my first shadowing experience in my senior year of high school. One day in the orthopedic surgery department of a nearby hospital, a new patient who I will call Steven came in to receive cortisone injections for his arthritis. When my mentor asked about his eating and social habits, a look of despair filled Steven’s eyes. I listened as he explained how his closest grocery store was miles away, and as a result, he frequently ate fast food. As I aspire to be a physician whose approach to healing is multifaceted, Steven’s visit further showed me that health is affected by more than just pills and procedures. It is heavily influenced by circumstances that take place outside of the doctor’s office.

Having a grandmother who also has arthritis and experiences food insecurity, I empathized with Steven. My grandma would often stress as she had to travel farther and spend more money than she wanted to on groceries. In Steven’s case, living in a food desert contributed to his weight gain and worsening joint pain. The next time I saw Steven, I gave him the same information I had given my grandmother on local farmers’ markets and government services that would broaden his access to affordable nutrition. This experience strengthened my desire to one day heal patients through medicine while addressing the social determinants of health that affect their daily lives. Over the next four years, I made the most of my shadowing experiences in orthopedics and cardiology, while still working to improve my community through organizing blood drives and taking an active role in my church’s food pantry. These pivotal years enhanced my passion for medicine and zeal for addressing disproportionate barriers to living a healthy life.

In addition to the obstacles that patients face outside the walls of medicine, their experience at the doctor’s office matters too. Patients are at a disadvantage when they do not receive compassionate, culturally sensitive care. While physicians of any identity can provide this care, mounting evidence suggests that health outcomes can be improved when physicians and their patients have similar lived experiences. As an African American male, I can attest to the importance of being able to relate to my doctor. While my friends would often recount instances of feeling unheard or misunderstood, I always felt safe and cared for. I was fortunate enough to have a thoughtful and attentive, black pediatrician who became my role model and the epitome of how I want to treat my future patients.

I met even more amazing doctors when I joined the I Am Abel Foundation, an organization dedicated to helping underrepresented students become physicians. At the new member gala, I saw more black and brown doctors than ever before. This experience was so much more profound than it seems; every physician there wanted to help pre-med students like myself achieve our goals. Often hearing the phrase “You can’t be what you can’t see”, that night I was truly able to see what I aspire to become. Striving to pay forward the support my physician mentors gave me, I began serving as a mock interviewer for college and scholarship interviews. My desire to support and encourage my peers can be summed up in the words of I Am Abel’s founder, Dr. Conway, “ …Always leave a wedge in the door so that others may follow.” I see every stage that I pass on my way to becoming a physician as a new opportunity to assist someone else to walk through that same door. Visualizing a future with more diversity in medicine, I will continue to motivate my peers as we work towards becoming the physicians our communities need.

Unwavering in my pursuit of becoming a physician, I aspire to instill change in my community, combat the social and cultural barriers that impact my future patients’ health, and smoothen the path to medicine so future generations of doctors can better reflect the diverse population they will serve.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Being a preacher‚Äôs kid and attending catholic school, I did not meet many people with a different religion from my own until I was in college. In addition to having the opportunity to interact with people from unique, diverse backgrounds, I witnessed how aspects of one‚Äôs identity are interwoven with other areas of their daily life. One experience that stands out in my mind occurred during my senior year when I was shadowing. I saw a patient around the same age as me who needed heart surgery and could not accept blood transfusions for religious reasons. My mentor asked if the patient could explain more about her beliefs, and as I listened, I gained insight into the religion and values of someone unlike myself. I also witnessed how these factors influence patient care. Specifically, I saw how cultural sensitivity and a desire to understand others are tenets of patient-centered care that help make people feel heard and safe at an often difficult and vulnerable time.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: During my first year of college, I assisted in planning and holding peaceful protests on campus following several disturbing incidents. That year, a student wore blackface as part of their Halloween costume, and hateful notes signed by the KKK were found etched into walls, toilet seats, and more. More common was when students from certain backgrounds unknowingly said or did something hurtful towards their peers of minority backgrounds. Often these students touched others' hair without permission because they had never seen "something like that before." Through these experiences, I learned how to put my anger aside in the moment and instead help those around me understand how their actions were offensive and why a lack of exposure is no longer an appropriate justification for their actions. The result of the protests, meeting with the university's administration, and using our collective voice to address our concerns changed the atmosphere on campus for the better.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Since I started shadowing my senior year of high school, in addition to everything I learned, those experiences served as snapshots of my future career if I work hard. When these experiences ceased due to COVID-19, I looked inward to rediscover the reasons I wanted to become a physician in the first place. These reasons include addressing social determinants of health, working to create more equitable and accessible healthcare, and paying forward all the support and encouragement I have been given. One positive aspect concerning my classes was that my professors provided many more office hours to accommodate students living in different time zones. While I was still able to attend classes, I took advantage of the extra help and learned how to best prioritize my time. I made significant progress in this regard during my last three semesters of college. As a result, my academic performance improved, and I ultimately graduated with honors in the spring of 2021.

personal_statement:
It was the summer of 2018 when I became the first college graduate of my family and received a generous job offer in China, though I was still reluctant to commit to a career in finance. Although my interest in science continued to grow during my resistance training career, I suppressed that interest to not put additional financial burden on my parents. To provide me with the best education, my mom moved across the globe with the sole purpose to care for me. She endured all the hardship that came with being a first-generation immigrant, and practically raised me as a single mother. Everything changed when she was diagnosed with stage I cervical cancer soon after my graduation. Her battle against cancer solidified my decision to become a physician, which transformed my curiosity in science into a tangible desire to make a difference.
My mom’s battle with cancer showed me the direct consequences of misinformation and poor communication. The initial prognosis was great, given her early diagnosis. Unfortunately, that hope disappeared when she opted for alternative medicine due to some online "health gurus" she followed. Upon realizing that her chance of survival diminished with every second, I began frantically trying to convince her to seek professional medical treatment. No matter how pleadingly I begged her in tears, or how many systematic reviews I sent her in despair, she was determined to continue down her path. By the time she realized her remedies were failing, the tumor had metastasized. The pain of witnessing one of the strongest women I know tortured to skin and bones, the remorse of implementing such a confrontational approach, and the will to put my multilingual communicative skills to meaningful use in this diverse society, so susceptible to misinformation, all propelled me towards a career in medicine in hopes that similar incidents could be prevented.
To my family, this career change may have seemed like an emotional decision, though my interest in science and medicine stems from my early childhood memories. My grandma had a booklet with dozens of scientific experiments suitable for kids and would find the required materials to help me conduct them. I vividly remember the experiment of Pasteurization in which we poured milk into two glass containers, brought one of them to a boil, sealed them and left them in the balcony. When I opened them 2 days later, “Yuck”, the pungent smell coming out of the container with spoiled milk served as my first introduction to control group and treatment group. I deeply appreciated the scientific method especially after I began resistance training and had many questions unanswered. What kinds of adaptation do different training stimuli yield? Is pre-training carbohydrate intake really ergogenic? I was mesmerized by how nuanced a topic can be and the logical process of deriving practical recommendations. I would get so excited when a new paper presented findings that went against the consensus, and I had great fun looking into the contributing factors of such discrepancy. Operating based on evidence led to my success in resistance training and has been very intellectual stimulating. As a physician, I look forward to continuing to satisfy my curiosity and vow to never be complacent in this lifelong learning journey.
An opportunity to make a difference emerged during my coaching career when I found out Alex, who had just started resistance training with me after being diagnosed with prediabetes, was vaccine hesitant. Alex was Peruvian with Chinese ancestry. As a Chinese who grew up in South America with many loved ones affected by diabetes, I looked at Alex as the younger brother I never had and mentored him in and outside the gym. My first intuition was to send him all the research showing the safety and effectiveness of the vaccines, like I did with my mom. However, with the importance of patient-centered communication in mind, I took a different approach. I sat down with him and acknowledged the validity of his concerns, which made him more accepting of the subsequent information presented. I then compared the relative risk of certain side effects associated with the vaccines to that of contracting the virus. Citing information from reliable sources, I offered basic education on the Central Dogma and debunked some common myths around the vaccine. Alex received his first dose of the vaccine a week after our conversation. For the first time since mom’s passing, I felt noticeable relief, as I realized that while mistakes in the past cannot be undone, one can still learn from those mistakes. As a physician, I will continue to be introspective of my mistakes, while maintaining my pursuit to better the lives of my patients.
The past three years have been arduous but fulfilling. Although I still have to make a conscious effort to reconcile my mom’s early passing, I have learned to channel that remorse to foster permanent discipline, rather than temporary motivation. I will exonerate myself by becoming a doctor who can make a difference, who not only treats patients, but also serves a reliable source of evidence-based information in his community, who fights against medical misinformation, and rebuilds the trust in our healthcare system, one patient at a time.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I grew up in a Chinese household and spent the major portion of my childhood in Argentina. I never knew how unique my experience was until I moved to the U.S in 2010. On the first day of my high school ESL class, we had to share where we came from, and I didn‚Äôt know what to say. Eating steamed buns for breakfast and empanadas for dinner at home was a normal occurrence. Initially, I hated this identity confusion since no one I met shared identities that intersected like my own. But in college, as I began introducing authentic Chinese food to my Latinx friends and teaching my Chinese friends basic conversations in Spanish, I learned to appreciate how my experience can contribute to the essential building of cross-community connection at a time of heightened racial injustice. I look forward to continuing bridging two of the largest ethnic communities as I advance in my medical education.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Growing up in a low income household, I witnessed how most of my relatives developed type II DM as result of unhealthy lifestyles. My observation of metabolic disorders disproportionally affecting low-socioeconomic status households was further reenforced during my time working in clinic. My interest in the role of lifestyle modulations continued to grow during my fitness journey as I learned about the myriad benefits of exercise beyond increasing insulin sensitivity, ranging from protection against cardiovascular diseases, fractures to psychiatric disorders. As a fitness coach, it has been rewarding to offer free coaching services to young trainees who are motivated to improve their health but lack the financial means to hire a personal trainer.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I was grieving the death of my mom alone when the pandemic stifled my hope of reuniting with the rest of my family that I learned to cherish even more. Additionally, I was temporarily laid off by the clinic due to reduced patient flow. This overarching sense of powerlessness did not begin to subside until I was called back to work. Most of our patients were seniors who needed routine injections to maintain vision. The nature of working in a small clinic allowed me to get to know many of them on a personal level. I learned that many lived alone and looked forward to coming back to the clinic despite the discomfort of receiving an injection because this visit might be their only social interaction in a month. In the process of assisting my doctor in providing care during the pandemic, I received continuous support from patients as they learned about my aspirations. This symbiotic relationship formed during the pandemic added to my understanding of the patient-provider relationship.

personal_statement:
In my first week of high school, I walked into a class with a dead body sprawled across the floor. “This is your first case,” the teacher said, assigning me to be a medical investigator. Right off the bat, I was curious about what had happened to the mannequin on the ground. With the goal of determining the cause of death, I consulted with a forensic pathologist who helped me better understand the biological signs that could explain this victim's death - a clear overdose.

My forensics course was one of many that made up a unique healthcare-oriented high school curriculum - the PLTW Biomedical Science program. Each year of the program highlighted a different facet of the biomedical field as a means of understanding medicine not just as clinical science but also as part of a greater institution. During my first year, I took courses that allowed me to play several roles, including that of a physician, a geneticist, a member of an emergency response team and a member of a research and development team. Through each of these various roles, I began to develop an appreciation for how these individuals face real-world challenges. In my second year, we were tasked with building Resh, my group's anatomical skeleton model. Using clay, we pieced together each organ and, in the process, learned about the anatomy and physiology of each organ system. By giving Resh life, I gained an understanding of how the systems worked together to keep the body healthy, from the ground up. After understanding how a healthy body operates, the focus of my third year switched to learning what happens when things go wrong. In doing so, I learned how physicians not only address disease but also aim to prevent disease in the first place. By the conclusion of the curriculum, I was left inspired by what I had learned and by my newfound understanding of the role physicians play in keeping individuals healthy.

Having been fascinated by the gross pathology I learned in high school, I focused my college education on the microscopic by majoring in Cell and Molecular Biology. I became fascinated with how our cells adapted to environmental stressors through intracellular and intercellular signaling. There was something extremely humbling in knowing that small downstream signaling events could lead to great effects on a macroscopic level. With this knowledge, I sought to contribute to the field by participating in research focused on the carcinogenic potential of saccharin, an artificial sweetener. Through my research, I gained a greater appreciation for the way in which our environment can impact our health. Additionally, by taking part in the research process, I learned how research drives many of the evidence-based medical-decision makings that doctors partake in.

Throughout my studies, I was surrounded by like-minded individuals who all loved science; however, I realized that physicians have to interact with individuals from all walks of life. As such, I took it upon myself to learn how to navigate this social challenge through my role as a college resident assistant. While many of the residents had different backgrounds, interests and career paths compared to mine, by building rapport with them, we exchanged trust that allowed for more open communication and disclosure. This ultimately allowed me to develop my self-reflection and interpersonal skills. Altogether, this experience made it clear that physicians should be not only competent in the clinical sciences but also cognizant of the lived human experience, always remembering to treat the patient as an individual first.

With a foundation of medical science and interpersonal communication developed across non-clinical experiences, I sought to find clinical experiences that would firsthand better inform my understanding of the field of medicine. While my first gap year was limited to virtual clinical shadowing and other virtual opportunities as a result of COVID-19, I was fortunate to obtain a role as an emergency department medical scribe during my second year. Over the several months working side by side with various physicians, I became enlightened on their duties and responsibilities beyond patient interaction and care, including administrative tasks, documentation of patient visits and follow-ups, and keeping up with pertinent news, policies, procedures and more. Furthermore, apart from improving my communication skills, I enhanced my medical knowledge through assisted interpretation of lab and diagnostic results, adapted to individual needs to optimize efficiency and workflow, and promoted proactive follow-up in a fast-paced and high-stress environment to reduce patient stay times. This experience has tied up the loose ends of my previous experiences, confirming my desire to become a physician.

What started as an appreciation of anatomy and physiology has developed into an appreciation of and a desire to become a physician. Through my experiences, I have learned that medicine is a dynamic and interdisciplinary field. As such, it requires a passion for life-long learning in the pursuit of helping our fellow human beings. As I continue my journey in medicine, I will always remember that at the heart of medicine is not only a love of the sciences but also a passion to serve others.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: While I was born in Saudi Arabia, I was raised in Florida for most of my life. Then, add in my Syrian mom and my Cuban dad and you can imagine the clash of cultures between both my family and the environments in which I was raised. While young, I remember being exposed to the same culture and Arabic language in Saudi Arabia. However, when I moved to Florida, I was exposed to a diverse melting pot of cultures and identities. Surrounded by people of different backgrounds, beliefs and paths of life, I learned about and appreciated the presence of diversity and its importance in enriching culture, inspiring creativity, and promoting understanding of differences. I was also viewed as ‚Äúdifferent.‚Äù Even so, I learned to connect with those around me, uplift their individual cultures and values, and embrace my mixed background, strengths I hope to contribute to my future peers, patients and communities.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As a college resident assistant, I learned about the unique struggles people face based on their backgrounds and identities, which taught me the importance of advocating for diversity and inclusion. One way of doing so was by raising awareness of implicit bias. I first learned about the concept of implicit bias during my training as a resident assistant. Initially, it just felt like another segment of training. However, as I engaged with my residents, I realized just how many preconceived notions I had in response to their majors, backgrounds and affiliations. Henceforth, I pushed myself to learn more about other forms of bias and their effects to share this information with my residents so that they could also identify and address their own biases. In doing so, I helped my residents and our community create a more open-minded, inclusive space. In my future career as a physician, I aim to continue combating barriers to diversity and inclusion by continuing to educate myself and others.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Upon earning my bachelor‚Äôs degree in May 2020, I intended to start in-person clinical experiences. However, many of them were halted with the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite this, I took the initiative to find alternatives, which led to engaging in various forms of medical media, such as virtual clinical shadowing, podcasts, blogs and articles, which have been very insightful and taught me a lot about the field of medicine and its different facets. Furthermore, despite it becoming difficult to find a position as a medical scribe, I was able to eventually find an open position at Homestead Hospital in August 2021. As an emergency department medical scribe, I obtained invaluable firsthand experience working alongside a team of physicians and other hospital staff to take care of a diverse patient population. Through this experience, I have grown as a person and gained exposure to the medical field which has only reinforced my motivation to become a physician.

Under_School: Wesleyan University - Entered Fall 2000 or Later
personal_statement:
In the backseat of the SUV, my older brother trembled continuously mumbling incoherent sentences. His hands tightly gripping mine and my mother’s as my father weaved in-and-out of the lanes, speeding down I-95. It was that night during the winter of my senior year of high school that I was introduced to medicine. 

Once we got to the hospital, we entered the evaluation room hand-in-hand and were met by an attending psychiatrist. In a calm demeanor, she asked us questions, looking for behavioral signs and subtle clues that were not even on my family’s mind. Even with only an initial interaction, she had found some answers. She made the abnormal seem normal. For weeks, my brother made comments about a radio chip inserted in his head, his own attempt to make sense of the current circumstance. While my family had not understood the meaning of the radio chip, the psychiatrist quickly recognized it as a possible first-episode of psychosis. From that day in the evaluation center, I knew I wanted to be a physician, treating illness in a holistic approach. I wanted to support people like my brother by reducing the stigma associated with certain diagnoses, similarly to how this psychiatrist viewed his behavioral symptoms in terms of any other medical condition.

Two and a half years after my family’s experience in the evaluation center, I returned to that same hospital, spending my summer as a mental health worker, primarily on a unit for female patients with diagnoses ranging from depression to schizophrenia. As a mental health worker, I participated in morning rounds with the healthcare team, listening to the physician present each patient’s case. For that summer I kept a journal of the medications I had heard during rounds, listing their class and contraindications. On my first solo shift after training, I was told I would be one-on-one with a potentially aggressive patient. When I entered the room, she was calm, staring at the wall. She quickly opened up to me, discussing how she had mainly been stable since her bipolar diagnosis. However, due to an eviction notice and other situational factors, she no longer felt in control. I thought about how sudden homelessness would impact anyone and how magnified those effects would be for someone with a disorder causing chemical brain changes. After my experience as a mental health worker, I wanted to learn more about the interaction between medical conditions and situational factors.

After my initial exposure to medicine, I looked to gain more clinical experience, volunteering at my local hospital and obtaining my EMT license. While working on an ambulance for my EMT training, I encountered a patient around my age suffering from rapid blood loss after sustaining a laceration to his foot. When the situation was more under control, the lead EMT asked me to obtain a set of vitals, an important step in obtaining the license. Based on the patient’s blood pressure and heart rate, phrases I have learned came to mind like “hypotension” and “shock”. I wanted to share the data with the lead EMT, but before I could do so, I looked at the patient’s terrified eyes. This was the information not in the textbook. From my prior experience, I knew that while obtaining an accurate set of vitals was necessary, I needed to make the patient feel safe and comfortable. Kneeling down, my eyes met the patient’s and I reassured him that he was receiving excellent care and we would arrive at the hospital shortly.

Over the past year I have worked as an emergency department medical scribe at my local hospital, observing as each physician interacts with patients while keeping their poise during the COVID-19 pandemic. The experience has enabled me to keep mental notes of the diverse range of approaches to patient interactions that I would like to use as a future physician. After the physician and NP or PA see each patient, they discuss the differential, included as part of the documentation. In the collaborative environment of the emergency department, the providers discuss the most likely diagnosis vs. other possible diagnoses. On many occasions after labs and imaging have resulted, the most likely diagnosis is not what the results showed. Watching the steps to diagnosis, I realized the importance of investigating all possibilities and how systems in the body can affect other systems. In this aspect, I think back to that time in the evaluation room, watching as the psychiatrist took into account each symptom and how the brain impacts other systems throughout the body. While psychiatry and emergency medicine encompass different scopes of practice, the goal and the steps to reach that goal involve similar guides.

After watching my brother’s journey to his diagnosis, I knew I wanted to be a physician. The person I had looked up to my entire life had suddenly lost a sense of reality. From there, each patient I have met through volunteer work, research, and clinical experience has reinforced my desire to pursue a medical education. With a medical education, I hope to learn more about the body’s systems and how they interact while also providing support to patients as they struggle to find answers about their illnesses.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Having worked with patients with schizophrenia as a mental health worker and through research at outpatient clinics, I have learned about the unfair stigmatization of people suffering from mental illness. Through many interactions with psychiatric patients, I have been able to learn how society judges people and through no fault of their own, these judgments negatively impact the lives of patients with mental illnesses. _x000D_
_x000D_
While shadowing a psychiatrist in a public clinic in NYC, I met a patient who had spent much of his adult life in and out of prison. The patient‚Äôs arrests paralleled the onset of psychotic episodes. He was unable to afford proper care for his schizophrenia due to chronic unemployment, but when he was stable, he could not even imagine committing any crime. I thought to myself that not only was it unfair that medical care can be unaffordable, but how this particular patient and others like him experienced a vicious cycle of prison stays due to chemical imbalances.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: During the pandemic I began volunteering for the online tutoring company UPchieve. Living with members of my family that are educators, I learned the impact online learning had on the educational gap. I did my own research and learned how the achievement gap only increased in low-income households due to lack of technological resources and having parents that were essential workers. Using my skills from my prior tutoring experience, I signed up to volunteer with UPchieve, tutoring algebra and chemistry. In this role, I have been able to help students who otherwise would not be able to afford private tutoring services. In order to help students build their confidence, we walk through problems step by step until they feel comfortable with course concepts. Through the step by step process, each student is able to take an active role in their learning as a way to combat the educational gap.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Before the onset of the pandemic I was in the process of obtaining IRB approval at Hartford Hospital for my master‚Äôs research project involving the incidental self-reference effect in schizophrenia. However, after the pandemic began and non-essential personnel were no longer allowed in the hospital, I had to edit my research protocol to include remote, virtual participant sessions for the IRB. The process of changing my protocol required me to work on my study for an additional semester, complete additional training, and reduce the number of participants. However, I was thankful I could still perform my own research study and obtain meaningful results for my thesis. According to my advisor my results are highly publishable and the research lab has since continued to conduct research for my project.

Under_School: The Ohio State University Main Campus
personal_statement:
It was a normal Wednesday evening. I was commuting to the hospital to begin a 12-hour shift when I received a call. My Mom was in tears. She explained that my Uncle was resuscitated three separate times earlier that day and had passed. I was shocked. Walking into work, I knew tonight was going to be a struggle. Later that night, as I was recalling the memories I had shared with my Uncle, I read the words “Room 304: CODE BLUE” on the call light monitor at the nurses’ station. Shivers immediately ran down my spine. Within seconds the floor went from calmness to chaos. After calling the code in, I promptly helped push the code cart into the room. The patient’s family members were all frozen in the hallway. I looked up at the wife of the patient and she glanced back at me with eyes full of fear.

I entered the room and saw the man lying there lifeless on the bed. I performed two sets of compressions before the rapid response team arrived. After seeing that they no longer needed my help, my attention then turned to the family. They were still standing outside the room completely broken down, desperate to hear that their loved one was brought back to life. I consoled them. As if they were my own Aunt and Cousins who had experienced a similar trauma that day. I took them to a seating area away from the commotion. I felt obligated to sit with them in an effort to bring them comfort. The patient was brought back after 15 minutes. After, I contemplated what I had just witnessed. I realized I had a true passion for easing the burden of patients and their loved ones as they go through their most vulnerable times. Throughout my life, I have observed many providers care for me and my loved ones as we’ve gone through our toughest times. This, along with my past experiences has motivated me to do the same and pursue medicine.

I was born to two Egyptian, Coptic Christian parents who had just immigrated to the United States in search of a better life. Our faith was instrumental in the way my parents raised me. From an early age, I viewed serving the needy and loving your neighbor as fundamental values. Looking back, the values that were instilled in me as a child are at the core of why I want to be a doctor. Through the church, I started to realize how intrinsically rewarding giving back to the community can be. As I continued my path to medicine, I explored many opportunities that allowed me to serve others.

During my freshman year of college, I embarked on a trip that combined two things I loved: traveling and serving others. I traveled to Peru on a medical mission trip to help set up clinics in impoverished communities. My job for the first part of the day was to check patients in. A man named Javier stood out to me; he complained to us that he has had persistent pain behind his ear and was eager, but scared to have a doctor examine it. I walked with Javier to the examination table. I watched as the doctor was able to make an instant connection with Javier. He examined his ear then pulled a quarter-sized block of ear wax out of his ear. It was a spectacle better than any magic trick I’ve ever seen. These doctors continued to completely change patients’ lives one by one. I was hooked. From that day on I was certain that I wanted to become a physician. The physicians displayed the same desire to alleviate the patients’ burden as I did while working in the hospital. Yet, through their training and education, they were able to accomplish this feat by answering every question and putting each patient’s mind to ease.

When I got back to the States, I quickly explored every opportunity related to medicine. I fulfilled my intellectual curiosity by attending many seminars and enrolling in several electives. I became educated on topics ranging from racial health disparities to innovative cancer therapies. However, the combination of a large course load, many extracurriculars, and a job made me quickly realize that I was stretching myself too thin. Although it was a challenge juggling all my responsibilities, the long days and nights I experienced allowed me to reevaluate and reaffirm how badly I wanted to pursue this field.

Observing physicians interact with their patients always put in perspective what I was studying for. As I stood in the corner shadowing a Neuro-Oncologist, I felt a deep connection with the patients and their families. Their words were hopeful, but I could tell they were anxious about the future. Three of my grandparents passed from cancer so I understood the suffering a family has to endure while watching their loved one’s condition deteriorate.

Standing in that room I felt a similar sense of helplessness as I felt sitting with the patient’s family in the hospital. My passion for medicine is how I resolve my intellectual curiosity along with my desire to do more. At the core of a physician’s work, is the devotion to do good and improve the quality of the patient’s life. With each of these experiences, I find that the values of a physician and the values that I hold close to me are identical. I aspire to gain the expertise as a physician to one day have the privilege of treating someone’s loved one without the feeling of helplessness. I truly can’t think of a better way to spend the rest of my life.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
While in undergrad, I decided to go on a volunteer trip to serve in a homeless shelter in Atlanta‚Äôs bluff, one of the most dangerous neighborhoods in the country. I had the privilege of serving children in an after school program, working with employees on projects around the shelter, and serving meals to residents. The meaningful connections I made throughout that week with individuals of a totally different walk of life from me taught me that I can always express love and kindness no matter what difficulties I am going through._x000D_
_x000D_
After that experience, I decided to consistently serve at a local food pantry. Volunteering at the Vineyard Food Pantry allowed me to give back to the community and stay grounded. The visitors that came were always smiling even through their struggles. I learned from them that I could find joy in life‚Äôs simplest of pleasures. As a physician I would really love the opportunity to work in the community and help those that are less fortunate._x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
In college, I had the opportunity to serve on the Morrill Scholars Program Advisory where I was the link between Ohio State‚Äôs administration and the scholars that have exemplified diversity and inclusion. Through this role I was given the responsibility of planning events for over 1500 students to engage in the community. I decided the best way to do this was to hold a community service involvement fair. We invited representatives from over 50 organizations in the Columbus and gave students the opportunity to make connections and create relationships that could last years._x000D_
_x000D_
Although indirect, I believe this was one of the biggest impacts I had on the community. Sometimes there is a divide with the university and the surrounding community. I was able to come up with a way to connect both together. This event has now become an annual occurrence and thousands of Ohio State students have benefitted by getting involved in the community. _x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact:
In March of 2020, I embarked on a study abroad trip to Europe. Little did I know that when I would return nothing would be the same. While in quarantine, I received word from my priest that many of the elderly in our church community were afraid to go in public so I arranged a service through Coptic Club where students would pick up groceries for our elderly community members._x000D_
_x000D_
In August I moved to Florida to complete a master‚Äôs degree in medical sciences. When we started, the plan was to have online classes for two weeks and then transition to in-person classes. Unfortunately, that transition never happened and I completed my degree entirely online. With the lack of in-person interaction with professors and peers, it was difficult to build meaningful relationships, especially at a new school, city, and state. Overall, this pandemic has provided many barriers but has shown that flexibility, creativity, and resilience are key when faced with unprecedented challenges.

personal_statement:
I made my way to Walter Reed Military Medical Center on a cold, rainy morning to volunteer. My excitement was palpable as I entered the Military Advanced Training Center (MATC), which is their physical and occupational therapy section. MATC is technologically stunning, with rooms of giant hydraulic platforms and sensor arrays. It is amazing how precise prosthetics need to be; each patient has different specifications which need to be tailored for. Observing these amputees training hard with their prosthetics is inspiring and moving, like watching miracles happen, as patients can be wheeled in one day, and walk in on another. At MATC I met Mark Marsico, an occupational therapist here. We are collaborating to use electromyography sensors to make a videogame controller for our amputees. This is particularly important because certain occupational therapy tools use specialized videogames. It is very exciting to collaborate with Mark on my prototype and will be even more so to see the faces of the soldiers as they use it. Meanwhile, even the day-to-day tasks are fulfilling. They give the simple joy of connecting to the stories of each patient.  It is a humbling and motivating experience to encounter the patients and the accomplished physicians who treat them. Volunteering here has moved me by reminding me of the impact that a career in medicine has to offer, and to not take my blessings for granted. 

The love of helping people and of technology is why I chose engineering as my pre-med path. Information technology is transforming medicine from big labs to family clinic, profoundly affecting everyone, and the trend is accelerating. This realization inspired my coursework and research. I earned my M.S., with a thesis on machine learning applications in neurology. Dr. Daniel Hier, my M.S. co-Advisor, is an inspiration to me, as a neurologist working with computer engineers to tackle what he calls the “thorny problems”. His exemplary career, as a clinician, educator, and researcher, encourages me to seek collaborative projects and a deeper understanding of both the medicine and data science disciplines. 

After earning my M.S., I returned to the National Institutes of Health for a postbac opportunity to use my machine learning skills for interdisciplinary collaboration.  I enjoyed my internship, so elected to continue my work with Dr. Marc Ghany, a hepatologist. We just submitted our first of what will be several papers on machine learning in hepatology. My clinical work with him involves quality of life surveys to patients on the clinical protocol, among other tasks. This gives me perspective into the lives of these patients, and I have grown in compassion, connection, and understanding as a result. Dr. Ghany is also an inspiration, through his breadth of clinical experience interacting with the hundreds of patients in his cohort. He has a deep sense of each patient, as well as the communities that these patients come from, which I tremendously admire and will continue to emulate. It is an honor and an obligation to continue this tradition. I continue to look for exciting opportunities to expand my clinical experiences, so I accepted the invitation to collaborate this December with Dr. Mason Cobb and Victoria Healthcare Systems in Vietnam, which treats 10,000 patients per month. This visit will expose me to the complexities of how an entire system supports the front-end mission of physicians and caregivers to provide the highest standard of care and respect for patients and their families. He also will arrange for me to help at government clinics, to see how dedicated professionals strive to do their best with even greater patient loads. 

I have always sought to improve the outlook of others around me, with my enthusiasm, scientific fascination, compassion, outgoing personality, and sense of humor all helping accomplish the job. As an undergraduate, I was passionate about the peer tutoring program, working for it all four years, developing improvements, and eventually becoming its student leader. For educators, it’s all about the students. For physicians, it’s all about the patients. This makes all the sacrifices worthwhile. While I understand that the journey to becoming a physician is demanding and will continually require ever-increasing effort, I am willing and determined to do what it takes. No matter where I end up, medical school can unite my desire to care for patients with my technological background to be well-equipped for future advances in health care. I also want to grow to know, love, and care for a community of people: perhaps soldiers like I do now at Walter Reed, or in a more rural setting like my hometown in Rolla, Missouri. It’s difficult for me to pick just one field, since I see the overlap between disciplines everywhere, and applications are potentially boundless. My goal is to advance medical practice by uniting a deep understanding of treatment with a broad range of engineering and scientific knowledge, appropriate for deploying technological advances for patients’ benefit. There are so many opportunities to use engineering advances to improve patient outcomes!
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: For many rural students, the multiculturalism in college is transformational. Although I have had friends from different cultures since childhood, college still opened new horizons. For example, I was treasurer of the Missouri S&T Fencing club. It has a very diverse set of members, with diversity in heritage and LGBTQ representation. I worked closely on budgets with our officer corps. The experience gave me an opportunity to hear and understand the perspectives of my fellow officers. Although Missouri S&T‚Äôs student population is diverse and accepting, the small, rural town it is in can feel isolating by its lack of diversity. Hearing their stories left me with a new perspective on my hometown and gave me insight into the importance of diversity. It is a great feeling to make a personal connection with someone and help them achieve more than they had thought possible. This is only possible with respect. It is the cornerstone of helping anybody, especially where teaching is concerned.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: At the start of the Fall 2019 semester, I was promoted to associate-head of Missouri S&T‚Äôs tutoring organization, consisting of 50 tutors. During this period, I was instrumental in switching the tutoring organization into an online-only format so that we could continue to function despite the COVID lockdowns. As things reopened, and I became head, I was able to improve the organization, making policy and infrastructure changes, which helps share the workload. We hired a superb associate head and I obtained permission to create another position, the communication officer, to monitor our email and social media, and update our weekly schedule on our official website. We met bi-weekly to discuss new initiatives and bounce ideas off each other for improving the organization, and we began more initiatives than any other previous administration. As a result, we reached more students and hired more tutors than ever before, greatly increasing our positive impact on our campus community.
7_-_COVID_Impact: COVID  prevented volunteering in a medical setting, as many places were not seeking volunteers. I am grateful that in the past year, I have had some more clinical experience through my assistance of the clinical protocol at the NIH and through my assistance at Walter Reed medical center. I am about to begin additional volunteering through Capital Caring, a hospice and pediatric organization located in Washington, DC, to gain additional breadth in my clinical experiences. These activities are helping me offset opportunities previously lost due to COVID-19. Even as recently as this Spring, COVID continued to disrupt my volunteer opportunities. I applied and was accepted to the aforementioned preceptorship in Vietnam, and had planned to go in March. I was very eager to help and learn. Then the U.S. State Department put Vietnam on a do-not-travel list, and Vietnam imposed a several-week quarantine. These required deferring the visit to December.

personal_statement:
The alarm goes off at 3:00 am. My eyes are heavy as I drag myself out of bed and put on my scrubs. Once I arrive at the dialysis clinic, I hurry to prep my machines before my patients arrive.

By 9:00 am, I’ve replaced a machine and cleaned blood off the floor. As I prepare Mr. Brown’s access, he scolds me for being lazy and slow. I can feel tears beginning to form, but I pause, take a breath, and focus on completing my tasks. Part of me questions why I choose to endure the stress, but then I remember I’m not the one suffering from a chronic disease. I don’t have to sit in a chair hooked up to a machine, for four hours a day, three times a week, getting pricked with needles and being told to restrict my diet. Holding Mr. Brown’s arm, I pick my target and carefully insert the needle under the skin. He flinches, makes a face, then lets out a sigh of relief. I am reminded that while dialysis is necessary for his survival, it can be a significant burden. As a physician, I want to comfort patients in the midst of their pain while being in charge of their medical care.

As the sounds of dialysis machines echo through the clinic, I wonder how Mr. Brown reached this point. I have learned some pathophysiology of kidney failure, and after completing a Masters in Nutrition I know that health is multidimensional. While volunteering at a community clinic, I saw patients whose ability to care for themselves was limited by time, money, and location. Unable to follow the recommendations of their provider, patients often felt lost. As Mr. Brown pulls out his standard breakfast, a sausage McMuffin, I sense a similar pattern. By reviewing his chart, I learn that his kidneys failed as a result of type 2 diabetes—now he depends on a machine to survive. Feeling this tension, I imagine myself as his doctor, going back in time, and maybe I could have prevented a lifetime of discomfort for Mr. Brown. On the other hand, maybe I would be powerless to change anything. At the very least, I want the chance to prevent this result for other people in similar circumstances. Even though I can’t change the outcome of Mr. Brown’s disease, I am grateful to provide the care that allows him to live another day. After his treatment is finished, Mr. Brown packs up his belongings and I wave him goodbye, knowing he’ll be back soon.

While dialysis does not cure, it was a curative experience that sparked my passion for medicine. I volunteered in rural Kenya with a team of surgeons from around the world. There I met a young Kenyan woman about my age. Her eyes were bloodshot, and on her neck was a goiter the size of a baseball. Her pain was not just physical, but deeply personal—she was expelled from school and ostracized by her community because they believed she was cursed. With nowhere to go, she reached out to our team. As I wheeled her into the operating room, I felt her squeeze my hand, so naturally I squeezed back. For a moment, I was no longer a stranger from across the world, but simply a human supporting a fellow human during a time of uncertainty. After the mass was removed, she repeated, “asante, asante”—“thank you, thank you”—relieved that her sense of belonging could be restored. Not only did this surgery change her life, but it also changed mine. In that moment, I realized the profound impact I could make as a physician.

When Mr. Brown returns to the clinic, the monotonous beeping continues. Across the room, I watch someone hurl into a red hazardous waste bag. I am reminded that medicine is not always glamorous or profound. As I grab a 15 gauge needle, the nurse tells me the doctor increased the needle size. I’m nervous about how Mr. Brown will respond; after working with him for months, I know he gets anxious prior to cannulation. Before he sits in the chair, I carefully lay out his blankets and turn on his favorite channel. As I inform him of this change, I remind him of our routine—deep breath, count to three, and make an ugly face. I finish my speech and prepare for the worst. His eyes widen. His voice is hesitant, but to my surprise, he replies by saying, “I trust you, Jordan.” A few days later, he walks in as if a weight was lifted off his chest. He was still sick, yet this small change helped to lighten the load. Even though the possibility of life-change drew me into medicine, it is the small wins that keep me here.

In the midst of the highs, the lows, and everything in between, I know a career in medicine will not always be enjoyable or even fulfilling. However, I was raised to value the life of every human being. We all experience pain and suffering. When comforting a vulnerable patient it helps me to remember the times I’ve felt scared, lonely, and powerless. At the end of the day, the same patient who calls me lazy and slow is someone’s father, sibling, and friend. The chance I have of easing someone’s burden is more than enough motivation for me to get up at 3:00 am, put on my scrubs, and get to work.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: While serving in Kenya, there was a patient who arrived at our clinic with elephantiasis. As I guided him to the exam room, I could see significant swelling in his right leg which was constricted by the fabric of his jeans. This seemed very uncomfortable for him and I wondered why he chose to wear long pants instead of shorts. As his physician explained the dangers of restricting circulation, I remembered that Kenyan culture emphasizes modesty. Instead of asking this patient to wear shorts, his physician suggested he wear loose fitting trousers until he could travel to a clinic with better resources. While I was disappointed in the outcome of this case, I was reminded of how culture influences behavior. As a physician, I must be aware of the values and customs in my patient population. This experience not only improved my cultural awareness but it also encouraged me to be a provider that seeks to understand people from different backgrounds.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As a volunteer at People‚Äôs Community Clinic, I educated patients on healthy diet and lifestyle behaviors. I remember one patient attended our class in hopes of improving her diet to help manage her diabetes. In addition, I learned that she came from a Hispanic family and grew up cooking meals that were associated with Mexican culture. She knew these traditional meals were bad for her blood sugar, however, she felt lost when it came to preparing healthier options. With this perspective, I showed her how to make healthier versions of the foods she loved. By choosing whole wheat tortillas, prioritizing beans over rice, and limiting foods with added sugar, I helped improve her diet while still honoring her culture. In the end, I believe this approach was less intimidating and allowed for more sustainable change. As a physician, I want to collaborate with my patients and invite them to participate in their plan of care. This way, I can help them achieve better health.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
At the start of the pandemic, my classes moved online and my volunteer opportunities were suspended. In the meantime, I anxiously wondered how this would affect my dream of becoming a physician. _x000D_
 _x000D_
Despite these worries, I looked for opportunities to help. I volunteered in virtual nutrition classes at People‚Äôs Community Clinic where I learned to appreciate telehealth technology and educate patients on diet and lifestyle. In addition, I worked part-time at Whole Foods Market while pursuing my graduate studies. I served my community by providing floral arrangements during some of life's most difficult moments. When one woman shared that her grandmother passed away due to COVID-19, I comforted her by helping her pick flowers that honored her grandmother._x000D_
 _x000D_
