Looking back, I can see that growth is often greater when life doesn‚Äôt go as planned. Ultimately, I am grateful for my experiences and the people I‚Äôve met because they are part of my journey to becoming a physician.

personal_statement:
As the rumble of the timpani roll intensified, I focused on the beats and struck the first chords of Grieg’s Piano Concerto in A Minor. I tuned my ears to the orchestra’s melody, staying in rhythm and matching the colors of the string and woodwind sections. Throughout the 13-minute piece, I told the story of a hero defending his land against an imposing army. Growing up, playing the piano was my favorite hobby. I looked forward to learning new challenging pieces and telling stories through my performances. Upon constructing each “story” and learning each piece, I learned that there is always room for improvement, whether by articulating a trill more or adjusting the tempo of a melody. Yet, what I appreciate most about my journey with the piano is how I can apply the motto of continual improvement to my daily routine.
This passion for improvement guided me as I ventured a few thousand miles away for college to explore my interest in healthcare originating from my time as a hospital volunteer in high school. As I learned about Asian and Pacific Islander health through volunteering with Asian Pacific Health Corps, I grew particularly interested in preventative care and health equity. At our free health fairs, I translated for Cantonese- and Mandarin-speaking patients. One was a fifty-four year-old woman who lacked health insurance and had not seen a physician in many years. From our mammography to bone density station, she sought to utilize every health service. After checking her cholesterol levels, she spoke with Dr. Lin at the Physician Consultation station. “Your cholesterol levels are abnormal,” I translated and continued to convey the doctor’s concern for her risk of developing cardiovascular disease. Surprised by her results and worried that this could lead to a downward spiral in her health, she asked what to do. We consoled her by recommending lifestyle changes, such as dietary changes and increased exercise, and statin medications to help lower her cholesterol. With multiple options available, she could decide what she felt most comfortable doing to improve her health. The physician placed his hand on her shoulder and told her that everything was going to be alright. Despite the language barrier between them, the woman felt hope. “Thank you,” she repeated in Cantonese as she bowed her head at us. Observing Dr. Lin’s interactions with service recipients like that woman, I was amazed at the positive impacts his abilities in assessing their health, diagnosing their concerns, and counseling had on them. Translating for him taught me that bettering one’s health involves not only forming a personalized treatment plan, but also offering prophylactic measures that can avoid exacerbating conditions. I aspire to be like Dr. Lin and provide quality care, especially for under-resourced individuals.
Upon graduating from UCLA, I began scribing at urgent care clinics to encounter a wider array of medical conditions and learn more about providers’ medical decision making strategies. Working with ER providers, I completed their charts, allowing them to focus on seeing patients and improving their healthcare experiences. Challenging myself to grow as a leader and wanting to better more patients’ healthcare experiences, I am also establishing a scribe program for outpatient clinics at Children’s Hospital Los Angeles. Working with attendings in different specialties has been an exciting preview of medical school, and I have learned about new medical conditions in different areas of medicine and basic management. Upon seeing patients such as ones who sustained open fractures, I have even been able to learn more about the continuity of care for patients who are referred to specialists. In departments such as orthopedic surgery, attendings have struggled to balance completing notes and seeing patients on time. Weaving in the scribe’s role, I have helped attendings focus more of their time on patients by taking down the details of their histories. With the attendings spending less time taking notes at the computer and more time with their patients, parents have even had more satisfaction with their child’s care.
Throughout my undergraduate career and gap years, I have learned that medicine aligns with my own values of seeking improvement and desire to solve patients’ health concerns. From specific trills to the underlying rhythm, there are different parts to a piano piece that I can personalize and refine. Likewise, a physician’s role is to continually improve their patient’s health through lifestyle modifications, prescriptions, counseling, and education. Inspired by my experiences, I want to play a direct role in caring for patients while participating in community outreach to tackle health inequities and increase access to care. Just as I have fine-tuned my trills on the piano, I long to develop my knowledge and skills for a lifelong career of healing where I can listen to others’ needs and walk with them on their journey to better health.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: The teenage girl sat on the examination table with her arms crossed as she saw me and the physician walk in. She had previously undergone a gender affirmation procedure, and she was upset that her recent progress notes still addressed her by her former name and male pronouns. I apologized for the oversight and although it was the first follow-up note I created for her, I completely corrected her chart. My encounter with the transgender girl taught me that being addressed by a former name can be similar to being called an insulting nickname. It can make you feel invalidated and even dismiss the person you are. In medicine, it can even cause one to lose trust in their providers. As a future physician, I long to promote an inclusive environment for others and serve as an ally even for those I may not identify with. Ultimately, I plan to advocate for their needs and hope to improve the healthcare experience where everyone can feel respected and safe regardless of their background.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Working with Asian Pacific Health Corps (APHC) to host free health fairs for underserved Asian and Pacific Islander communities in Los Angeles allowed me to combat these populations‚Äô health disparities. I offered Cantonese and Mandarin translational services, and promoted preventive health by educating patients about topics like healthy diets and diabetes to increase health literacy. I also compiled and distributed lists of local low-cost specialty clinics, so patients knew how to access resources to follow up on their chronic conditions. These experiences taught me how communication and fiscal gaps prevented these individuals from relaying their needs or even accessing care. It was fulfilling to help community members better understand their health and the importance of preventive screenings, and I want to apply my experiences with APHC to overcome similar barriers to care that burden vulnerable communities on Chicago‚Äôs West Side, such as unsheltered and uninsured ethnic minorities.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I had difficulty finding employment after graduating during the onset of the pandemic since I did not receive responses from employers or was informed of delays in hiring. Due to restrictions, I could not continue conducting research and all club events were canceled. Despite these shortcomings, the opportunity to volunteer on the frontlines at a testing site showed me how the pandemic has exacerbated health disparities, such as how a lack of understanding of the virus led to lifestyle habits that unknowingly worsened minority health outcomes. Moreover, working as an urgent care scribe showed me how misinformation can impact one‚Äôs health, such as developing antibiotic resistance due to believing that antibiotics can treat viral infections. I strive to build on my prior experiences to increase health literacy and dispel misinformation to improve population health even during public health crises.

Hrdshp_Comments:
Although I am proud of my accomplishments, I would like to explain obstacles that directly impacted my academic progress. At a young age, my family was exiled by the Sudanese government after my father spoke out against injustices, resulting in us being homeless. Years of stress decimated my father’s health, resulting in multiple heart attacks and numerous medical complications, further causing a significant loss of income. To have some semblance of financial stability, we applied for asylum in the U.S.

As a first-generation, low-income student, I was initially clueless about studying for college-level classes. For example, when I was a high school sophomore, I was offered the opportunity to take AP classes that would allow me to get a head start on earning college credit. Unfortunately, I was unaware that these classes would impact my college GPA, and at this point, I had yet to establish study habits that would set me up for success. However, I have made much progress since then and have maintained a competitive GPA throughout my undergraduate career while balancing several responsibilities, such as working multiple jobs to pay tuition and support my family. I chose to view obstacles, however, as growth opportunities; in retrospect, these experiences will help me succeed in medical school and beyond.
personal_statement:
I was the only one my dad trusted to touch the blue medicine box - not even my mom, who was so gentle with everything she held, handled this sacrosanct object. Each day after dinner and hours of watching Al Jazeera Sudan News, I carried this box along with notes I took at his doctor’s appointments, reading them as he patiently sat on the living room couch. “Take two a day with food and make sure you take it with water and not chai, alright baba?” I read to my dad as he gazed at me, amused by my almost perfect English pronunciations. My father drank his Sudanese tea so religiously that the doctor often encouraged me to occasionally remind him to drink water. 

From a young age, I made many such recommendations from the doctor to my father following several open-heart surgeries. I found serious joy and purpose in gaining my dad’s trust to guide him with medical decision making. As the most fluent English speaker in an immigrant Sudanese household of ten, I took on the responsibility of escorting my father to every appointment. Like many immigrants in the U.S., my dad dreaded speaking English in public out of fear that others would judge his accent or assume he was incapable of understanding.Witnessing the effects of these barriers in my father’s experiences with the healthcare system helped me truly understand the importance of cultural humility in medicine - these moments shaped my desire to serve, advocate, and empower immigrant communities to be active stakeholders in their health outcomes.

Through my experiences as a clinical research associate at Washington University, I recognized that my family is not alone in their struggle to access equitable healthcare. I saw the concrete ways in which the socioeconomic background of the patients that I met determined healthcare outcomes as much as their genetic predispositions did. As a Black woman, it was heart-wrenching to witness firsthand how healthcare barriers disproportionately affect people of color, reflecting centuries of institutionalized racism in America directly impacting patients to this day. One woman confided in me that she was suffering from domestic abuse from her partner yet simply did not have the finances to escape and live independently. She made clear that she never felt comfortable reaching out for help out of fear of retaliation. Yet, when I pressed her to call the local crisis nursery, she put her faith in my advice for one simple reason: I reminded her of one of her closest childhood friends. I was happy that I was able to gain her trust through sharing a similar narrative of the Black Female experience. The demographics amongst medical professionals need to reflect society’s diverse population to lend unique perspectives and build trust amongst communities, particularly those of color. Trust saves lives.

I had similarly meaningful experiences during my time recruiting in the WashU COH3 OBGYN clinic, which primarily served young Medicaid recipient mothers. Having been raised in a low-income household myself allowed me to easily understand and connect with my patients. The relationships I built while working in research not only helped me connect vulnerable mothers to resources such as the crisis nursery, but allowed me to bridge the gap of understanding between communities of color and medicine. Using my fluent Arabic skills, I communicated with refugee mothers from various African and Middle Eastern countries– some who for the first time were receiving prenatal care– to simplify medical terminology and emphasize the importance of adhering to their medical team’s plan. This minor exchange of knowledge and compassion resulted in improved outcomes for our mothers who often expressed gratitude for their ability to access the clinic.

These experiences reinforced the importance of cultural sensitivity and solidified my passion for medicine, allowing me to recognize that I want to serve through a lens of understanding. Through familial and clinical exposure, I discovered that medicine is not solely about understanding the science behind treatments but also about human dignity and establishing genuine relationships, based on trust, by recognizing and respecting each other’s differences. When a patient's holistic needs are met in an unjudged way, they are more likely to feel comfortable and trust their physician, leading to improved health outcomes. I am motivated to provide this type of culturally sensitive care with respect to the patient's core values, beliefs, and experiences. I want them to entrust me with their blue box, as my dad trusted me to assume the role of his caregiver. In retrospect, I feel humbled that my dad trusted me with something as important as his health - I eagerly await the day when, as a physician, I’ll be entrusted with the same honor to establish the same connection with my patients.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Throughout my life, I lived in communities lacking resources people often take for granted, such as in war-torn Sudan, where scarcity permeated every aspect of life from healthcare to education. Even after gaining refugee status to move to the US, my family‚Äôs struggles were never entirely mitigated. In retrospect, I now recognize that we were directly impacted by the consequences of poverty, where our socioeconomic status determined the extent to which we could pursue a dignified life. Although these experiences were harrowing, they fundamentally fueled my desire to serve others as a culturally competent physician-advocate, especially for those facing various forms of discrimination and insecurity.  My upbringing across several countries introduced me to various backgrounds and cultures, which taught  me to always keep an open mind. These experiences formed my identity and, I believe, can provide unique perspectives to discussions regarding diversity and advocacy with my classmates.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: The alarming maternal mortality rate for Black women is an issue that galvanizes me to ensure equitable access to medicine. They face the highest pregnancy-related deaths and complications compared to all racial groups, independent of socioeconomic status. In my clinical experiences, I often encountered Black mothers who shared their fears regarding delivering due to previous negative birthing experiences they heard about or experienced themselves. I listened and empathized with the moms and through various tough conversations I helped empower them to advocate for their needs. They would often express gratitude for the support they received. As a Black woman and future physician, this disparity is profoundly alarming and drives me to help close racial and gender gaps that should not exist in modern medicine. I look forward to the prospect of serving the diverse Chicago west side neighborhoods to address health disparities existing for Black and all underserved and disadvantaged groups.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The abrupt transition to remote-learning forced me back into my parents‚Äô crowded home and lack of a study space and stable internet access made focusing an arduous task. I keenly felt the loss of being on campus, which provided an optimal learning environment. Altogether, these factors severely impacted my ability to study for classes and prepare for the MCAT. I also started working 3-4 jobs to pay tuition and support my family. Although unplanned, I ultimately decided to take gap years to submit the best application possible by studying for the MCAT and gaining additional clinical experiences. Although this time was strenuous, I realized the pandemic only highlighted and exacerbated pre-existing health and socioeconomic disparities for communities of color. By experiencing these disparities first-hand, I know it is crucial for physicians to advocate for solutions to structural inequities so that everyone can achieve better health outcomes independently of their socioeconomic status.

personal_statement:
I know I’ve jokingly told my students that I would traverse the seas to help them if needed, but I never imagined it to become a reality during my last quarter at UCLA, teaching a biology section from across the world in Seoul, mid-pandemic. Given the time zone, I found myself propped up in front of a Zoom call at 3AM, rubbing my bleary eyes with one hand and downing a mug of coffee with the other.
But that didn’t matter then. Nothing took precedence over caring for my grandmother, who suffered from a stroke the previous summer. The situation was too reminiscent of my grandfather’s passing when I was ten. Unfamiliar with death, I remember spending hours at the hospital mortuary as my mother accepted condolences. Seeing her trembling, withholding tears as visitors laid snow-white chrysanthemums by the casket, was enough to make me understand how difficult goodbyes could be. It was then, with the naïve notion that I could always prevent early deaths as a doctor, that my 10-year-old-self resolved to study medicine.
It wasn’t until years later at UCLA, however, that my academic interest in the human body truly blossomed. Bolstered by brilliant physiology professors, I found myself endlessly fascinated with the human body. Yet, I wasn’t content with physiological knowledge alone; I wanted to apply my education clinically to serve my community.
This led me to seek out volunteer experiences in preventive health, one of which was providing EKGs to patients like Kyle at heart screenings. Despite the technician’s explanation that the process was painless, the child’s stoic expression and rigid posture told me he was unconvinced. So, while his mother filled out forms, I took the opportunity to show him the EKG leads were painless, repeatedly attaching and detaching the electrodes on my forearm in a slapstick comedic fashion. Still unconvinced, I then handed one over to him so he could verify it himself. Success. After fiddling with it for a bit, Kyle slowly brightened up, which told me I had alleviated his doubts.
Not long after, I noticed another patient fidgeting and glancing elsewhere instead of completing her health questionnaire. Seeing as she was anxious, I peeked at her chart and found that her surname was "Park”. Recognizing this as possibly a Korean surname, I asked if she needed help with translations. Upon confirming, her relief was immediately apparent from her smile; her English-proficient son had stepped away to take a call, leaving her to fill out the form alone. Reassured that I would help translate, she completed the form and proceeded to take her EKG.
Even if I didn’t interpret the EKGs myself, I felt truly fortunate and elated to have played a role in detecting signs of heart disease, especially after hearing that two of the patients we screened that day had EKGs indicating atrial fibrillation. Although I don’t know if Kyle or Ms. Park were included in the two, I found these experiences to highlight the value of human interactions in medicine. Something as simple as acting on nonverbal cues can move patients to place their faith in me, enabling me to convey my compassion and commitment to my community.
Unfortunately, these exchanges were cut short by the pandemic. With in-person interactions out of the picture, I redirected my efforts to serve my community another way: teaching.
Globally, students struggled to navigate their coursework over Zoom, which was especially apparent in my section when I first relocated to Seoul to care for my grandmother. It only took five minutes to gauge that my students didn’t understand membrane transport despite an impending midterm. Suspecting this was due to the dense language of textbooks, I transformed the endless paragraphs into digestible flowcharts, which, judging from their responses, seemed to help. For those still lost, I reassured them that they only didn’t understand “yet”. I always emphasized the “yet” to foster a growth mindset, and that I would help them get there even if it was 3AM from across the globe. As a student myself, I knew how difficult Zoom classes could be, so I committed to teaching in the hopes of not only helping students understand the material, but also building up their confidence.
Needless to say, I was thrilled when my students made progress, knowing I had contributed to their growth. This joy I felt from teaching only solidified my conviction to become a physician, as doctors are essentially teachers. I realized I could repackage the complex science of the human body into feasible steps my patients can take to recover. And, for patients that feel hopeless in the face of their illness or injury, I hope to nurture growth mindsets to spur progressive thoughts that can greatly influence their path to recovery.
What started as an innocent goal to prevent all goodbyes matured into a desire to pursue a career in which I can accompany patients in their journey to improve their health. As a physician, I hope to leverage my experiences to deliver comfortable care to my patients, ultimately striving to prolong their time with their loved ones. From easing my patients’ anxiety to instilling hope in their recovery, I aspire to empower my patients to take control of their health through heart-to-heart interactions and medical practices.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
I don‚Äôt know what I was expecting my grandmother to say when my mom sliced her finger with a knife, but it definitely wasn‚Äôt ‚ÄúBRING THE SOJU!‚Äù._x000D_
Turns out it was a Korean folk remedy to pour drinking alcohol over wounds. Evidently this was questionable, but at 9 years old, I didn‚Äôt dare challenge my grandmother. In Korean filial piety, talking back to elders would equate to a cardinal sin._x000D_
As I grew, however, I learned to use this upbringing to interact with people different from myself, especially at work. For example, to eliminate misinformation in low-income communities, I pulled from my experiences to first respect their beliefs, then kindly inform them their understanding was actually inaccurate, and finish with explaining the proper care for their concern. This allowed me to correct the patients without provoking them._x000D_
Given Chicago‚Äôs diverse population, I hope to leverage my experiences to navigate patients‚Äô diverse beliefs, ultimately empowering them to lead healthy lifestyles.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
While working with local Asian communities in free health fairs to promote healthy cardiovascular lifestyles, I realized that a huge contributing factor to misinformation was language barriers. As important as it was to get blood pressure and body mass index readings, the efforts would be in vain if the patient didn‚Äôt understand what the results signified._x000D_
That‚Äôs why I primarily volunteered as a translator on- and off-site. During health fairs, I would help providers translate lifestyle recommendations and deliver educational presentations in the community‚Äôs native language on varying health topics. Outside of health fairs, I would draft and translate informational pamphlets for patients to take home for future reference. I felt fulfilled in contributing to health literacy by making accurate information accessible to non-English-speaking patients, and I hope to continue supporting their control over their health in the future as a physician.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
I knew from my second year onwards that I wanted to take a gap year to gain clinical experiences while applying to medical school. However, when COVID hit, I found myself barred from both my academics and extracurricular activities. My community organizations had their health screenings canceled, and I couldn‚Äôt go into my research lab. With no reason to pay for exorbitant LA rent, I moved back home._x000D_
Since I didn‚Äôt dare risk spreading COVID to my hypertensive parents, going out for clinical opportunities wasn‚Äôt an option. Moving out again wasn‚Äôt feasible either as I couldn‚Äôt afford rent and didn‚Äôt want to burden my parents whose business was already struggling. As if financial concerns weren‚Äôt enough, my grandmother collapsed from a stroke, requiring me to relocate to Seoul to care for her. Given the loss of opportunities and future uncertainties, I decided to take one more gap year than intended.

personal_statement:
As I looked up at the ceiling tiles, I surrendered my pointer finger to the lancet and watched my pediatrician draw my blood into the test strip. As the device counted down, I remember feeling helpless as I sensed tension building in the room. I was nervous and scared, holding back tears as I watched my worried mom observe every moment. Leading up to this moment, I had been feeling sick, but I did not register its severity as a nine-year-old. When the doctor informed me of my new health status, a person with Type I diabetes, I struggled to understand what this meant and how it would impact my future. Although my doctor said I was lucky that my disease was manageable, any sense of luck eluded me as they explained my new responsibilities. I remember feeling overwhelmed and helpless as I tried to understand, retain, and execute the complex instructions that would keep me alive. 

Though I did not know it then, my visits with my endocrinologist planted the seed that eventually grew into my unwavering desire to become a doctor. My appointments with her were much different from my other doctor experiences because I felt like I was in an environment where I could learn from and talk openly about my mistakes without judgment. I appreciated that I was included in conversations regarding changes to my basal insulin levels and carbohydrate rations and loved feeling like an active participant in my diabetes journey. As my diabetes care skills improved, I started visiting with my endocrinologist less frequently. During gaps between visits, I began to look forward to my appointments with her because of how she made me feel when I was there. My younger self understood that doctors were knowledgeable, kind, and caring. But, as I matured around my medical condition, I appreciated the more significant impact a doctor can have on someone's life. This realization fueled my passion for becoming a doctor because I want to provide quality care for someone like my endocrinologist did for me. 

My dad constantly reinforced the importance of managing my disease, which required maintaining a close relationship with an endocrinologist. As my best friend, he never wanted me to feel apprehensive about seeking medical care. Once I entered high school, my dad's concern for me became apparent as he opened up about his personal health journey. In our few discussions about this sensitive topic, he explained that his physical condition was considered morbidly obese by medical standards. I felt that this assessment was an unforgiving definition of my dad. When he explained how he thought there was a barrier between him and his doctor because of his physical condition, I sensed a sadness in his voice. I also remembered feeling surprised that he had such a different relationship with his doctor compared to the one I had with my endocrinologist. 

Tragically, my dad suddenly passed away at age 55 from undiagnosed colon cancer. His death was likely due to him not abiding by routine medical screenings because of the barriers he felt. I was a senior in high school, and our conversations about his doctor experiences were still fresh in my mind. As I sat beside him in his hospital bed, watching his lips turn the slightest shade of blue and his heart rate decrease, I remember feeling many emotions. I felt scared, helpless, and uncertain about what the future held. As more time passed, the fear was replaced with feelings of devastation and then anger. I constantly questioned the circumstances surrounding his death. Nobody deserves to feel how he did about seeking medical care. The loss of my dad further ignited my interest in becoming a doctor because families should not lose a loved one in a similar way to how I lost my dad. My desire to limit patient apprehension in seeking medical care has been a constant driver in my journey to becoming a doctor. 

Motivated by my life experiences, I decided to immerse myself in clinical care. While in college, I volunteered at a local hospital on the pediatric floor. During one of my shifts, the nurses assigned me to help them care for a baby who had just undergone surgery and was challenging to console. While holding her, I sensed that she was scared. I cradled her, and within minutes, her body relaxed, and she began to sleep. As she calmed down, I felt myself do the same as we bonded. I remembered the interactions with my endocrinologist when I was scared as I cared for the baby. As I connected with her, my aspiration to become a doctor strengthened. I felt hindered by my inability to provide care beyond simply holding her, despite my desire to limit her stress and uneasiness. I aspired to have a doctor's knowledge and expertise to provide the highest quality care for the baby. 

The culmination of my life events has clarified my unwavering desire to practice medicine. I aspire to become a person with the knowledge and training needed to guide patients in their care and treat others' ailments. As a doctor, I will work tirelessly to effectively manage a nine-year-old's stress around her medical conditions, reduce a dad's apprehension about seeking care, and console a baby in need.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
During my undergraduate college career, I worked in Dr. John Cronan's laboratory, where many international students from China were employed. As a result, my daily interactions and work partnership with one member, Yuan, set up a fertile learning environment about Chinese culture and norms. Because English was not her first language, it was often challenging to communicate with her effectively. In our work-related conversations, I learned to add non-verbal communication, such as hand gestures and facial expressions, to exchange information. _x000D_
 _x000D_
Based on this, I have learned that what makes people human goes across all cultures and ethnicities. I recognize that dealing with others is not letting the language barrier impact how well communication happens. As a Medical Assistant, I handle patients every day who come from different backgrounds than my own, and I work hard to display empathy and kindness towards them. What I have learned will influence me when I provide care as a physician.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Due to my performance in the Master of Science in Medical Physiology program, I was selected to become a Peer Educator for Post-baccalaureate Admission Program (PAP) scholars at the University of Illinois at Chicago College of Medicine (UIC COM). PAP scholars are students who are underrepresented in medicine (URM) and complete a year-long program in anatomy, physiology, and biochemistry before entering medical or dental school. During their Summer Prematriculation Program (SPP) session in 2022, I had the opportunity to support their efforts in studying high-yield concepts in anatomy and related clinical cases. My commitment assisted them in gaining the knowledge and self-confidence required for success upon entering medical or dental school. As a result of tutoring my students, I had the opportunity to impact the communities where many of these future doctors will practice. I look forward to continuing these efforts during the 2022-2023 academic year.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
As a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, I could not start my shadowing experience after graduating from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. While I was looking forward to furthering this part of my application, the safety of the patient and doctor was most important. The hospital and medical practice restrictions meant that only the doctor and their patient could be in the examination room. Luckily, many regulations have been lifted due to the COVID-19 vaccine. Therefore, I am currently in the process of gaining shadowing hours and feel fortunate at the opportunity. _x000D_
 _x000D_
An additional change for me was related to my employment. I planned to return to my summer internship lab to complete further research at UIC with Dr. Herbert Engelhard after my undergraduate school career. The cancellation of research funding ended my plans to continue research opportunities.

personal_statement:
While surveying a small church in the heat of the afternoon, my thoughts are accompanied by cries in Spanish, Creole, and English, creating a symphony of frustration and pain. As a medical volunteer in the rural Dominican Republic, I am overwhelmed by the absolute burden of infectious disease in the community. Many Haitian immigrants within the country lack proper healthcare due to ethnic prejudice and insufficient infrastructure. As I assist with triage, I feel their depression and intuit their fear. I pause momentarily to regain my composure and begin to contemplate what a mentor once told me. "Look for life," he said. And so, within the sea of patients surrounding me, I find laughter and love. I feel unity and hope, and through their anguish...I gather my strength.
  
   Working as a medical research volunteer, I saw the effects of social determinants on marginalized communities. I gained insight as I witnessed families navigating through barriers set to minimize or eliminate their access to healthcare. One young Haitian mother from a rural community of Baraguana brought her children to me, who were malnourished and suffering from a parasitic infection. Disheveled and feeling defeated, this mother was all too familiar with rejection due to her socioeconomic status. My heart broke as she described, with pleading eyes and a broken voice, her children's preventable illness, calling it a "death sentence." As I continued my assessment and time passed, I watched as her anxiety dissipated and the color returned to her face. She informed me that this was the first time that she and her children had been treated with compassion. Within medicine, compassionate care is the hallmark of implementing a holistic approach to healthcare. The role of empathy is multifaceted and serves as a bridge to address inadequacies in patient care. 

   Breaking down the intricacies of medicine and public health for patients allowed me to connect on a deeper level with the community. Understanding their experiences with healthcare through their stories taught me the importance of viewing people as more than their illness. Listening to the woman's story about her physical and social struggles exemplified the importance of an empathetic approach to care. I saw the joy my mentor had told me to look for in the community. The close relationships within Baraguana were critical to bridging the gap in health care access and provided a sense of community for individuals invisible to society. Practicing medicine goes beyond simply making a diagnosis or prescribing a medication. It involves forming a human connection as a form of empowerment. 

   Growing up in a rural community of 6,000 people, I am all too familiar with the stigma surrounding those socioeconomically disadvantaged. Not only is healthcare restricted or unavailable to those living in poverty, but the cycle of negligence in some communities results in homelessness, addiction, malnutrition, and crime. My early exposure to the silent, invisible unfortunate inspired me to become involved. As a Community Development Intern for United Way, I partnered with local doctors to develop Medicaid and public health outreach programs. Our team hosted fairs to provide education and resources to individuals struggling with housing and food insecurity. Through a direct connection to physicians, low-income families could voice their struggles within the community obtaining care. Approaching healthcare through this lens revealed to me the importance of patient-centered medicine and an avenue for doctors to assist in rebuilding a sense of agency within marginalized populations. It is essential for physicians to protect and serve their community by addressing social factors that influence health. 
   
   My work at the molecular epidemiology lab (WHO Collaborating Center for Onchocerciasis Diagnostics) has inspired me to continue to pursue the ability to utilize clinical research to address social determinants of health, including but not limited to combating outbreaks in endemic regions. Collaborating with international researchers, I developed cost-effective, efficient, and portable assays for communities. Inaccurate testing models have proven devastating, leading to diagnostic errors and increased disease prevalence. Overall, working with the WHO allowed me to translate research beyond the lab and directly to the patients' bedsides. Approaching research from a human perspective in data provides an avenue for greater research efficacy and insight into health advocacy. 

As a physician, my passion is to focus on my patients holistically, centering on health equity, quality of life, and patient independence. Looking back at the journey that drew me to medicine, I am confident that my experiences have shaped my desire and ability to provide vulnerable populations with public health resources to improve their quality of life. Practicing medicine goes beyond simply making a diagnosis or prescribing a medication. In the future, I hope to apply the lessons that have shaped me to utilize research and patient care to connect and educate patients to provide an integrated and empathetic approach to care.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As a frontline healthcare worker performing research in the Dominican Republic, my mentor taught me to look for life in communities. Working in clinics allowed me to observe healthcare discrimination firsthand. Serving as a Clinic Coordinator, I led healthcare workers in rural communities, providing marginalized populations with primary care services. Conducting clinics in rural communities, I worked with Haitian immigrants lacking equitable access to care. Through this, I witnessed many patients disheveled and defeated due to years of neglect. Understanding their experiences with healthcare through their stories taught me the importance of viewing people as more than their diagnosis and seeing life in every patient. Community health's role in disrupting cycles of neglect in healthcare revealed that physicians could do more than treat patients' ailments. I hope to use these lessons to advocate, educate, and empower communities. _x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Studying the effect of infrastructure on waterborne diseases allowed me to witness health disparity research directly informing health intervention. I connected with communities to design solutions that mitigate health inequities, broadening my understanding of what it means to be a caregiver. In doing so, I collaborated directly with communities to analyze waterborne disease burdens in rural immigrant communities. Along with this, I facilitated focus groups with communities and developed educational programs to increase health literacy. Working alongside community leaders provided insight and helped me become a community member. I created educational curricula and health services reflective of the community's needs. This project determined the overarching disease burden within rural communities and identified the causes of the outbreak. Going forward, this research has provided a foundation to implement sustainable WASH  projects to reduce disease burden and increase health agency._x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact:
When USF closed due to COVID-19, I felt hopeless as the pandemic consumed much of my momentum and hard work. Previously, I was chosen as a finalist for a community health research internship with Johns Hopkins. Concurrently, my family experienced financial difficulties during the pandemic, pushing me to pursue opportunities closer to home that would allow me to support my parents. _x000D_
 During this time, I worked as a Residential Assistant with first-generation students developing curriculum and social events for students to connect.  By creating educational and professional development curricula for my students, I utilized my connections with the community to create professional development lectures for students and create a community during the pandemic. _x000D_
In addition, I was approached to assist in Florida's Covid Taskforce, tracing outbreak cases and conducting COVID research. I coordinated research activities and local partnerships, providing additional education and health services.

Hrdshp_Comments: "You have to go to school" is my dad's signature phrase that he repeats in his broken English to remind me of the importance of pursuing education. He would say this when my thin arms would grow tired of mopping nail salon floors on school nights in middle school or when my wheelbarrow full of cement bags would slip from my sweaty palms during high school summers. Different arduous tasks equipped me with the adaptability and resilience that I would also pour into my efforts to pursue education. Unfortunately, I struggled to transition from natively speaking Spanish to speaking English during my developmental years. In an already under-resourced school system, I was placed in ESL (English as a second language) classes. I had to catch up to my peers who performed under the state average. I felt like I was catching up even through college, where most students came from well-resourced schools and were better equipped to handle academia's collegiate pressures. However, I seldom felt my upbringing was a disadvantage. My struggles nurtured the humility and work ethic I used to overcome the educational and financial obstacles I faced through my academic journey. Thanks to my parents and upbringing, I never felt like my barriers were insurmountable and instead felt like they were opportunities to learn and adapt.
personal_statement:
As the son of agricultural workers in the Central Valley of California, I left for the University of California, Davis as a first-generation college student without a clear vision of who I might become. The sciences had always fascinated me and my older brother, Alex. Although Alex was headed to medical school and towards a career in medicine, I remained uncertain.  

My relationship with healthcare was complicated. Growing up in an agricultural community of Latinx immigrants, I witnessed the stress my parents endured with health-related issues. I'll never forget the day my mother decided to use the pharmacy's drive-thru window. Unable to communicate in English to the pharmacist's satisfaction, even with the help of Alex's interpretation from the passenger seat, he humiliated my mother's inability to speak English in front of us. Alex sat with his fists balled, tears rolled down my mom's cheeks, and I felt wounded and angry with a painful knot filling the back of my throat. I was only seven but dreaded these interactions that belittled our dignity. My parents had no choice but to endure such challenges in seeking healthcare. Limited insurance meant limited access to scheduled appointments, and an urgent visit required lining up at the community clinic early in the morning, giving only a possible chance to be seen. If we were lucky to get through the doors, my siblings and I were expected to interpret words and phrases that seemed equally confusing and foreign in English and Spanish. My experiences withered my dignity and left a subtle bitterness toward healthcare; It ultimately pushed me away from dreaming of a career in medicine. 

Despite these early experiences, my relationship with medicine changed on Veteran's Day weekend in 2016. I was a college freshman and home for the holiday - the same weekend my epileptic uncle stayed with us. I'd known since childhood how to recognize and respond to his mild seizures. I was never prepared for the severity of the episode that ensued. His face became blank, and his body vigorously jerked, grunting infant-like murmurs. I felt immensely helpless as I sat beside his unconscious body. Standing next to his bed in the ICU was my first experience with hospital medicine. I was stunned to witness the choreography of caring and competence of Dr.S. I deeply felt the power of a physician to protect human dignity and support the patient and the family when death seemed acutely possible. By the time my uncle was discharged, I had developed an overwhelming sense of gratitude towards Dr.S and a newfound respect for the transformative power of medicine.

With my newfound encouragement in medicine, Alex encouraged me to join Clinica Tepati, a non-profit health organization serving underserved Latinx communities in Sacramento. Not long after joining, I prepared an intake sheet for a concerned mother, "Rosa," whose son, "Julio," had cerebral palsy and severe epilepsy. I couldn't help but feel a wave of emotion wash over me. Old memories flooded my mind as I recorded Julio's blood pressure. I could see in them the hardships my family, especially my mother and uncle, had faced. But it wasn't until she shared that Tepati was the only clinic willing to help them due to their immigrant status that I realized my past experiences served as a scaffold for the help I could provide. My background, language, and story allowed Rosa to be seen and heard in a way my family rarely was. By interpreting her problems in their truest form, the medical student and attending physician I worked with responded with sincere compassion. At Clinica Tepati, I found a unique opportunity to offer the connection and understanding I believe all patients deserve. For the first time, I envisioned the larger effect I might have as a physician.

As I continued to explore a medical career, I was encouraged to explore scientific research through an undergraduate project in the Beal lab. My independent project related to a gene-editing protein called ADAR1, and I found the work fascinating and essential. I considered applying to MD-Ph.D. programs and excitingly joined Dr. Chan at UCSF as a research technician after college. This work has exposed me to CRISPR gene editing and its use to model patient-derived genetic mutations in mouse models to dissect the biology of underlying rare inherited diseases of the immune system. Aside from her extensive research mentorship, Dr. Chan has been an invaluable sounding board for my career ambitions. As an MD-Ph.D. herself, she's helped me understand where my passions lie and how I might navigate a career in medicine to feed my passions. Ultimately, I have realized my passion is for the human connection clinical medicine offers and the opportunity it affords to shape my community. 

Now, with clarity of purpose, I look back at my early experiences with healthcare as my greatest asset. I believe more than ever that the role of a physician must extend beyond simply treating an illness and must, instead, treat the human. This means taking on the responsibility to fight for health equity within a system where the underserved and marginalized are left to fall through the cracks. It's a responsibility I walk toward as I embark on a career in medicine.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
As a Behavioral Technician(BT), I worked with kids diagnosed with Autism Spectrum Disorder(ASD). I had yet to learn how to compassionately interact without triggering their specific ASD sensitivities._x000D_
_x000D_
On my first day, my enthusiastic "hello!" made nearby children wince. I quickly learned a few kids had Hyperacusis, an increased sensitivity to sound commonly diagnosed with Autism. I would continue to learn and refine my interactions when I first met "Nate." He sheltered himself away and despised social interaction. Sometimes just a simple high five resulted in a painful kick to my shin. However, I soon picked up on his appreciation for a lively imagination. I enthusiastically voiced over his favorite Avenger figurines, facilitating meaningful communication and a genuine friendship._x000D_
_x000D_
In many ways being a BT provided a comprehensive understanding of the ASD community as well as a lens to understand someone's strengths and sensitivities if I want to deliver meaningful help. _x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
Growing up, I witnessed the trepidation that seized my parents' faces when exorbitant medical bills threatened our financial situation. I often encountered the health disparities Latinx immigrants suffer, which motivated me to alleviate the hardships my community endured at Clinica Tepati (CT)._x000D_
_x000D_
CT is a student-run clinic that provides free medical services to the underserved Latinx population in Sacramento. As co-head of the pharmacy committee, I guided a team of 15 members to ensure our uninsured patients received their medical supplies and prescribed medications free of cost through pharmaceutical companies' Patient Assistance Programs (PAPs). I utilized my Spanish and the humility of my background to advocate for our patients as we submitted dense PAP applications. If PAPs fell short, we offered reimbursements for any drugs listed on our extensive list of approved refunds. I used my leadership experience to ensure our patients never felt alone when seeking medical treatment._x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact:
I was impacted by the student housing crisis prompted by COVID-19. My roommate and I decreased the rent price and waived several fees and utilities to attract new renters in Davis at the expense of the savings I worked hard to accumulate through my tutoring position. The finances I put aside were originally intended to help me dedicate time to applying to medical school, but I've since been forced to work while applying._x000D_
_x000D_
Although it's a challenging journey applying while working, I've strengthened my ability to manage my time between my work and my interests. I took advantage of every open opportunity to dedicate to my app while still completing full-day experiments at UCSF. I used early mornings before work, lunch breaks during work, and late nights after work to dedicate my efforts toward the MCAT, primary and secondary applications. Through this journey, I've developed confidence in my time management and resiliency, which will help me through my medical school journey.

Hrdshp_Comments: I am a first-generation Mexican-American who was raised on the lower end of the socioeconomic scale. My parents have always accepted aid from the government in the form of WIC and public health insurance. The high school I attended had high student/teacher ratios and low test scores, which resulted in less than half of students pursuing a higher education. I was also one of many who qualified for free lunch and had ACT and IB test fees waived. After my parents claimed bankruptcy in 2010 and had a car accident in 2012 that left them without income for 3 months, I was not surprised when the FSA expected $0 family contribution. I gladly accepted Pell Grants and several merit and need based scholarships to fund my undergraduate education. Despite various detrimental experiences, I continue advocating for underrepresented communities. In college, I used my role as resident assistant to engage with students on topics such as privilege, structural racism, gender identity, sexual orientation, and intersectionality. Ultimately, the struggles I have gone through will make me a better physician when building rapport with patients and mentees while diversifying the image of a doctor.
personal_statement:
My upbringing is shared by many Americans: I was raised by immigrants on the lower end of the socioeconomic scale who would have been proud if I graduated high school alone. Fortunately, my parent’s never-ending support of my constant engagement in extracurriculars eventually resulted in several scholarships to fund my undergraduate education. After graduating college as a first-generation, female, Hispanic student, I began to believe that with perseverance I could accomplish my goals. Now that I am the proud mother to a toddler, I have more reason to become a physician with the unique paradigm of being a parent. I am confident and excited in my decision to attend medical school and pursue a career as an academic physician scientist, diversifying the image of a physician while pulling others up through mentorship and contributing to the evolving medical field through basic science research.

I remember being in awe during my first exposure to the medical field where I was not seen as a patient or Spanish interpreter for family. While shadowing pediatric cardiologists at Children’s Hospital Colorado, I watched as they developed treatment plans for the most complex patients. I was fascinated by their medical knowledge and capability to improve others’ lives and captivated by their abilities to consider every detail of a patient’s history to develop the best plan for them. It was through programs aimed at increasing diversity in the medical field that I received these experiences, and I also realized becoming a physician provides ample opportunities to mentor future medical professionals as I had been mentored.

Most recently, I have spent time volunteering in a level 1 trauma center emergency department at the University of Colorado Hospital. I have enjoyed interacting with everyone in the department, from the patients and visitors, to the EMT’s, nurses, and physicians who are constantly working to improve everyone’s conditions. It impressed me how seamlessly the medical teams work together and watching the physicians determine complicated pathophysiology in seconds every time they walk into a new room inspires me to fulfill that leadership role. I observe physicians as they think critically about each patient they are treating; considering their histories, the missing information, and what additional resources they need to determine etiologies of their patient’s symptoms. I am even more inspired when I visit with patients; the comfort I can bring them by offering snacks, a warm blanket, or a conversation in either English or Spanish gives me the chance to build rapport quickly with patients I may never see again. Still, my motivations and curiosities extend beyond the clinical role of a physician.

I was first introduced to bench research as an undergraduate working in an infectious disease laboratory where I completed a research thesis based on my findings. There, I became excited about basic science and how it can inform and inspire clinical therapies. Learning the physiology of tuberculosis allowed me to think critically about the history of therapies and how we can improve treatments at the bedside. I gained leadership skills by teaching lab techniques and overseeing other undergraduate students working in the laboratory. I quickly learned how rewarding mentoring can be through the interactions with trainees. These experiences ignited my passion for research as a form of extending the current boundaries of knowledge while inspiring others to carry on the torch after I graduated.

As a result of my drive and experience, I earned a position in Dr. Steve Abman’s Pediatric Heart and Lung Center where I currently work with Dr. Erica Mandell. I have continued pursuing my passion in research, contributing to several manuscripts including a first author manuscript based on my novel work. I have also been responsible for designing, optimizing and conducting novel experimental rodent and cell culture models. After expanding my repertoire on basic research techniques, I shared this knowledge with several trainees in the lab, ranging from high school volunteers, medical students, residents, graduate students and post-graduate fellows. My experiences in presenting at conferences have helped develop my skill with scientific presentation while showing me how other physician scientists are contributing to the field of neonatology. Our lab collaborates with various departments both on campus and nationally. This multidisciplinary approach allows me to appreciate the unique contributions that enhance the overall understanding of the physiology of lung development. These experiences have helped me realize science and medicine are two sides of the same coin and I look forward to a career where I can do both as an academic physician scientist.

Having reflected on these experiences, I feel confident in my decision to attend medical school and pursue a career as an academic physician scientist. I will understand the struggle my patients or mentees will be going through as mothers, children of immigrants, or people living on less in the US. Moreover, I understand the value of having experiences as a clinician and a researcher. Ultimately, I want to push the field forward by becoming an academic physician scientist.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Since volunteering at the University of Colorado Hospital, I have been exposed to the need for diverse and multilingual medical providers who reflect patient populations. The immediate relief and trust I experience when I interact with Hispanic patients makes me feel like they know I am supporting their efforts in healing. As a child of immigrants, I understand the responsibility that comes with learning a new language and culture. When interacting with patients different from myself, I am open to hearing their stories; everyone has their own struggles and experiences. I believe it‚Äôs important to consider each patient individually; combining their history, context, and current evidence to treat them using precision medicine. These experiences have made me certain in my aspirations to become an academic physician scientist, where I will be an advocate for both patients and medicine to decrease mistrust in medicine and improve health disparities among vulnerable patient populations.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Growing up in Aurora, CO, I have always been exposed to diversity. My high school alone comprised of students representing over 90 countries. This foundation in recognizing and celebrating differences encouraged me to apply for a Resident Assistant (RA) position when I entered college. My first year as an RA, I was tasked with providing resources to a floor of international graduate students. Although initially intimidated, I earned each student‚Äôs respect by providing a welcoming and supportive environment. I was also grateful for my multilingual skills. I encouraged them to consider their privileges in our society and recognize institutional racism. By the end of that year, students were regularly inviting me to hot pots, sharing their stories and asking me for resources when they were struggling. These experiences have instilled a sense of openness and understanding when I interact with people; skills that will be advantageous as an academic physician scientist.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
I was seven months pregnant when notified I had to quarantine due to the COVID-19 pandemic. I was grateful for my past experience working in an infectious disease laboratory with tuberculosis, where I had been trained on working in a BSL-3 level environment._x000D_
_x000D_
Once maternity leave was over, I returned to the Pediatric Heart and Lung Center where I work as a research assistant. The founder, Dr. Steven Abman, is a knowledgeable pediatric pulmonologist. Just before quarantine, I was developing a newborn rat model for Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) with Dr. Erica Mandell, a neonatologist. When discussing with our collaborators, I learned of the many opinions regarding which ventilator and settings are used in the clinical setting, especially with COVID-19. I found that the questions raised during these discussions were also applicable to our CPAP model. This work exemplified bench-to-bedside research, and I hope to engender similar experiences as an academic physician scientist.

Inst_Action_Desc:
Two incidents in college showed my immaturity, and I have learned a lot from them.

One night in freshman fall, I started drinking after failing a math midterm. I wanted to forget my frustration and sadness after working so hard, yet coming up short. I had many mixed drinks, and after vomiting for a few hours, an RA called 911. Although the EMTs determined that I did not need to go to the hospital, this incident was irresponsible, and it will not happen again.

Before college, I had little experience with alcohol and did not understand responsible drinking. Since then, I have learned to count drinks and not have drinks made with unknown amounts of alcohol. More importantly, I realized that alcohol is an inappropriate response to a life setback.

During my summer after sophomore year, I lent a friend my student ID so he could use the gym. My friend was stopped at the front desk and not allowed in. I met with an administrator, who said another incident like this could result in losing my gym access. I realized how significant my action was; if everyone shared their ID cards, safety would be jeopardized.

These instances show that I did not appreciate my privileged position as a college student. I need to act responsibly and think of others.
personal_statement:
Silence, then soft crying. This was the reaction of a young mother, "Nancy," after I told her that her infant son tested positive for COVID-19. I tried to comfort her, but when I realized she needed more than what I could provide, I told Nancy to call her son's pediatrician and that I would call back later. 

During the pandemic, I was a contact tracer. I called patients like Nancy to inform them of their test results, educate them on self-isolation, and gather close contacts. My favorite part of these calls was comforting patients, listening to their concerns, and answering questions. However, often there were questions only a doctor could answer, and I wished I could do more for these patients.

Wishing I could do more for someone was my initial motivation for medicine. As a child, I would see the drop of blood my grandfather Marvin had to prick from his finger to test his blood sugar; if it was too high, we worried about diabetes complications. My grandmother Nadine would then counsel him on his diet, just as she did for patients as a nurse. I wanted to treat Marvin's diabetes, and I understood that without insulin, my grandfather may not have been there to raise me.

Because of this, I always wanted to work in healthcare, for providing medical care to someone in need is inherently good. After learning to code, I wanted to contribute to medicine as an engineer; for example, by writing an algorithm to help doctors diagnose cancer. In college, though, I realized engineering is not the role I wanted: most engineering takes years to make a difference in someone's life, and I also like working with people. As I pondered my future, several memories came to me one night. I thought of my fascination with dissecting a pig heart in high school, the comfort I felt when a medical student stitched a cut on my face, and my long-held desire to treat my grandfather's diabetes. I wondered if I should become a doctor.

I began shadowing in an emergency department to answer this question. Each shift, I saw the staff touch lives in a way that is only possible in medicine. I witnessed, for example, an orthopedist use his fingers to guide the fractured tibia of a patient, "Jose," back into place. Out of all the staff, only a doctor could do this closed reduction, and without this procedure, Jose's leg would never have healed. There was no way I could achieve this through code. I realized that I am drawn to the human aspect of medicine; what I am searching for would not be found in coding but at the patient's bedside. I should be a doctor, not an engineer, I concluded.

After college, I needed time to heal from an anxiety disorder that I developed during the pandemic. I also wanted to make healthcare more accessible through telemedicine. I spent months at a startup, Comet Healthcare, building a website where new mothers could access physical therapy for conditions like incontinence. Despite my efforts, we did not achieve our goals, and I left because I did not have the skills that Comet needed. Working at Comet, though, made me experience first-hand a lesson I learned in college. As an engineer, I can make a difference on a large scale. However, this comes at the cost of seeing a difference in one person's life. Thus, engineering is not as meaningful to me as working with patients. 

This lesson was particularly true in the case of "John," a man who called a suicide hotline I was volunteering at. John began the call by stating he was considering going to a sporting goods store and buying a shotgun to end his life. In our hour-long call, I learned about his alcoholism, divorce, and job loss. I put myself in his shoes, tried to understand his pain, and validated his feelings. At the call's end, John said I talked him "off the ledge." This call was meaningful to me because I made a clear impact on John's life; hearing that John no longer felt suicidal made me feel like my life had a purpose. Conversations like these have reaffirmed my decision to enter medicine, for providing compassion is more rewarding to me than writing code.

Many professions require compassion — therapy, social work, clergy. However, only a doctor has the privilege of listening to people while also being able to perform interventions like closed reductions. Additionally, I want to become a doctor because their training makes them the best person to treat diseases like diabetes. In my time off from school, I recovered from my generalized anxiety disorder. I feel ready to care for patients and now understand what they go through.

As a physician, in addition to seeing patients, I want to build an innovative healthcare company. Although I have engineering and startup experience, having a doctor's training will allow me to better understand and solve problems in medicine. My background will also provide valuable insights when artificial intelligence is used in medicine. For example, when an AI program detects a breast lesion, I will be able to explain what this means to a concerned patient. 

Regardless of the advances in AI, no one wants to hear a diagnosis from a computer. Thus, there will always need to be someone there with the patient. I hope to be that person with the patient; I want to be the doctor patients like Nancy can call.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
My brother and I have taken different paths in life. I went to college and now work a white-collar job; he worked minimum-wage jobs after high school. We also differ in interests, lifestyles, and political beliefs. _x000D_
_x000D_
We discussed his future one night. Our family wanted him to further his education; although he had a job, it was not lucrative. I suggested finding another job. He became irate; he was proud of his work. He shouted, then went to his room crying. Later, we reconciled. I knew my brother struggled in school, but I could not imagine the difficulties he described to me, particularly with reading. Thus, he had no interest in school. He also described his job preferences. _x000D_
_x000D_
I learned so much about him and also realized my mistake. I had projected my values and interests onto my brother when I should not have. I wanted the best for him and thought my path was ‚Äúbetter,‚Äù though this was not for my brother. We are on a different path in life, which is okay. _x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
During the summer of 2020, like across the country, there were social justice protests in my hometown. I joined one but wanted to implement real change, so two former classmates and I created a form that asked about experiences with racism and distributed it in our community. We wanted to start an open dialogue so that all members of the community, especially people of color, could feel safe. _x000D_
_x000D_
We received over 30 responses, with some in Spanish and some anonymous. Several mentioned hearing racist remarks in school, grocery stores, and at their jobs. Others said they believed the police racially profiled Hispanics and described their negative interactions with the police. We then presented the responses to the city council and chief of police. We ended our presentation with recommendations to improve public relations with the police, such as community listening sessions. Our presentation was one of the first steps the city took to improve racial justice._x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact:
At the start of the pandemic, I moved back home with my grandparents and brother. During this, I reconnected with my brother and spent time together for the first time in years._x000D_
_x000D_
Although I reconnected with my brother, I was profoundly lonely; I needed more socialization than Zoom breakout rooms. During one quarter, because of this isolation, I suffered waves of anxiety that forced me to lie in bed, unable to do anything. I finished the term, but I needed help. I was diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder and took an SSRI for a few months. Because of this, I decided to take time off from school after college. However, the pandemic reaffirmed my decision to enter medicine, as I wished I could treat patients. Although my shadowing at a hospital had stopped, I started EMT training.

Hrdshp_Comments: As the first in my family to attend college, I would not have been able to graduate without loans, financial aid, and multiple jobs. With parents who struggled to afford my educational and living expenses, I first began working in high school and continued to do so when I moved away. My low budget compromised my living conditions, where I rented a cheap living room in La Jolla for the majority of my time at UCSD, and then subleased a room from a family with a toddler. Both environments made living affordable, but were not conducive to studying. This motivated me to study on the campus until last shuttle bus operated or later, leaving me to walk home in the late evening. Not having my own car also left me reliant on public transportation to attend volunteer opportunities, including shifts at a hospital nearly 30 miles away. I realized how my circumstances affected my academic performance and took the opportunity to attend a post-baccalaureate program, through more loans and a partial scholarship. I decided to invest in my studies as a full-time student and was able to excel academically. Upon my successful graduation, I continue to work multiple jobs in order to afford the cost of living, alleviate some of my debt, and save toward medical school.
personal_statement:
From an early age, I perceived health to be a commodity that my family could not afford. Both my grandmother and mother had diabetes and I grew to fear what would become of my own health, thinking I was next in line as I watched them prick their fingers for blood every morning. Every time I visited my pediatrician, she validated my concerns: I was obese and pre-diabetic. I began to despise these visits because they always ended with the same seemingly impractical treatment plan – a healthier diet and exercise. 
Despite my pediatrician’s recommendations, it was challenging to prioritize health in our household. My parents spent most of their time working in order to make ends meet, often sacrificing health and nutrition for convenience and affordability. Given our limited resources, they focused on putting food on the table and a roof over our heads. As such, our health was only an afterthought and I continuously struggled to make healthier lifestyle changes. My doctor’s orders felt out of reach. 
As a first-generation college student at UC San Diego (UCSD), I gained a deeper understanding of the barriers to care and community health. I learned about the social determinants of health through my coursework and saw firsthand how factors such as environment and economic stability impacted members of a community. I was able to envision what it means to make health more accessible when I began volunteering at various community health clinics both locally and abroad. In 2019, I traveled with UCSD’s Global Medical Training to provide free health assessments and medical treatment to rural communities in the Dominican Republic. There, I learned that a dirty riverbank was the community’s main source of water for bathing, cooking, and cleaning. I began to see the correlation between their environment and the high prevalence of female patients who arrived with vaginal infections, among other medical concerns. I worked closely with a local physician from Haiti, and observed how he not only prescribed medication to treat the infection, but also carefully educated his patients about boiling water in order to prevent recurrence. I realized how imperative this was for a community who had limited access to care and became inspired by the level of resourcefulness and empathy it took to be a physician that provides care in under-resourced settings.
I had the opportunity to further understand the impact of social determinants of health during my time as an undergraduate research assistant at the iSTRIVE research lab and studied intersectional risk factors experienced by youth in the U.S.-Mexico border region. In focus groups, I listened to adolescents share how the cost and location of services prevented them from receiving proper sexual and reproductive healthcare. As I became aware of the detrimental health outcomes that disproportionately affected this population due to these barriers, I began to see the value of the research I did. The voices of the youth and other community members were vital to understanding the need for resources in their community. As a physician, I see an opportunity to empower similar voices by providing accessible care and resources to address the health inequities they face.
My experiences have opened my eyes to the inherent responsibility in the work of a physician to bridge the gap between social determinants and health itself. As I interacted with various communities, I realized that each patient has a story, making each gap unique. Some patients arrive with all of the details, and others require probing and inquiry – almost like a puzzle, where each detail acts as a piece that contributes to the overarching picture of health. I am intrigued by how a single question, whether it be regarding a patient’s living conditions or insurance coverage, acts as a piece needed to understand their ability to maintain their health outside the clinic. With every patient interaction, I became increasingly motivated to become a physician that dedicates my work toward solving the complexities in every puzzle of a patient’s story, and allowing them to inform how I will provide compassionate care. 
The health disparities I witnessed throughout the communities I have worked with, as well as my own, have also made me realize the importance of physicians who are committed to making health equitable for patients of all backgrounds. My desire to pursue a career in medicine has grown as I worked alongside various physicians, community leaders, and volunteers who share a common goal of promoting health equity among underserved communities. The need for curiosity, resourcefulness, and compassion with every patient interaction has all contributed to the type of physician I want to become. Moreover, I aspire to be the physician I needed when I was a young girl struggling to manage my own health amidst the greater socioeconomic issues at hand. Health should not be viewed as a commodity and as a physician, I want to make care and resources accessible in ways that eliminate this perception for patients in need.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
As a hospital intern, I have been berated and swung at. One patient, in particular, used the strongest, most profane language as I assisted him. Perhaps he preferred to be cared for by an intern of a similar race or a nurse instead, I thought. However, while serving him dinner, I had the opportunity to learn more about his past, and while he became emotional, it was irrational to justify his comments with any other reason besides the pain he felt. _x000D_
_x000D_
This experience reminded me to look beyond the externalities and empathize with a patient's circumstances. Whether working with patients suffering from mental disorders or other ailments, I understood my role was to provide a safe sense of comfort throughout their pain and recovery._x000D_
_x000D_
I have grown to approach each interaction holistically and support every patient with a high level of compassion, like the physicians I have worked with. This is a perspective I hope to contribute to the diverse and inclusive culture at Rush Medical College.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
As a research assistant, I worked to increase vaccination rates for marginalized communities in San Diego. Within my role, I learned of the common myths and misconceptions surrounding COVID-19 vaccines to address them using education. _x000D_
_x000D_
Knowing my best friend was an uninsured Latinx adult who remained vaccine-hesitant, I eagerly shared my knowledge with her. While she feared COVID-19 vaccine myths and misconceptions, I provided facts and resources for every one of her concerns. After endless conversations, she finally decided to become vaccinated at one of our free community pop-up clinics._x000D_
_x000D_
After seeing how misinformation influenced the health of a loved one, I recognized education as a privilege that allows some communities greater access to health care over others. As a medical student and future physician, I remain committed to using this privilege to empower patients toward more informed health decisions and improving the health of underserved communities, one patient at a time.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
It was challenging to adapt when my courses transitioned online in December 2019. At the time, I rented a room from a family in a small apartment with a toddler. Out of precaution for him and the rest of the family, I took a 3-month leave from my hospital internship. _x000D_
_x000D_
