Upon moving, I continued volunteering at the hospital while studying online and maintaining three jobs, two of which were research assistant positions, and the other was babysitting. Once I graduated with my bachelor's degree in December 2020, I continued working until my post-baccalaureate program started in June 2021. _x000D_
_x000D_
During the post-baccalaureate program, I contracted COVID-19. It challenged my ability to study, and after this realization, I decided to postpone my MCAT exam date from early March to late April. While I finally got an in-person graduation ceremony through my program in June 2021, COVID-19 still limited my experience, especially in being able to interact with my colleagues in person over the year.

personal_statement:
My brother, Bryan, is a super happy kid. He is the person who inspired me to become an advocate and a doctor. Bryan is an expressive and clever boy who always laughed at the sounds of our voices. As the oldest, first-generation daughter of a Vietnamese immigrant family, I was eager to protect him, teach him, and guide him. My mom wanted five kids; her body could only withstand two. When my brother and I were both prematurely born, it seemed like the world had already given us a rough start. I was underweight and had mild episodes of GERD reflux. Bryan was born via emergency C-section and struggled with respiratory failure and eye defects. After receiving life-saving amounts of oxygen, his eyes deteriorated and he was robbed of his vision.

Bryan introduced me to the difficult yet intriguing aspects of medicine as soon as he came home. Of course, the new responsibility of managing his daily medications and setting up his nebulizer was complex. But, it was crossing my parent’s traditional and cultural barriers in getting him the proper accommodations that was even more frustrating. 

The round peg forced to fit into the square hole eventually breaks. Upon learning that my brother will be blind, my dad quickly dismissed the idea of using a walking stick or learning braille. My mom, understandably, wanted him to stay close to home and was resistant to enrolling him in schools for the blind. As Vietnamese immigrants who recently assimilated into Western American culture; they only wanted their kids to fit in. They wanted the best for my brother but were afraid of being stigmatized. They had a deep cultural shame associated with a son who is disabled. 

I advocated for him. For the first few years, Bryan grew up with very little accommodations for his conditions. Instead of independently walking with a walking stick, my parents wanted teachers and friends to guide him. Instead of learning and reading braille, they decided that talking and listening to radio podcasts was enough. As he matured, he was frustrated by the difficulties of the generalized treatment he received. So, I began advocating for him. Despite my parent’s resistance, I advocated for our school to emphasize teaching him braille and how to use a walking stick. I volunteered at my local talking book library and brought home audiobooks and braille books. After years of research, persuasion, and emotionally-charged family discussions, my parents were finally okay with my brother attending a residential school specifically for blind children. Now finishing up his first semester at the school, he is receiving accommodations tailored to his specific needs, becoming more independent, healthier, and even happier. Not only did Bryan give me early exposure to interesting pharmaceuticals and medical interventions, but he also provided me with an introduction to the cultural battles surrounding medicine.

The discourse revolving around unique individuals, their personal situations, and culture is not exclusive to my family. I spend my Tuesday nights as a volunteer clinic manager for a free primary care clinic. Our core mission is to provide inclusive care to uninsured individuals. Other days, I work as a medical scribe and assistant for an orthopedic surgery clinic. From a skier with an ACL injury that will hinder them from pursuing an olympian career, to an uninsured Venezuelan mother with severe postpartum depression planning to kill her newborn child, I have met and encountered many events of tragedy. Fortunately, medicine has  allowed these individuals to have a second chance. The patient with an ACL rupture had extensive reconstructive surgery and is recovering well. The Venezuelan mother was given life-altering, no-cost pharmaceuticals with therapy and is now happily raising her son. 

I am pursuing medicine because I am aware of the incredibly broad reach that medicine may have. The service work I have participated in, the clinical environments I have witnessed, and my personal familial experiences have all solidified my aspirations and shaped me into someone who truly desires to continue with this career path. Additionally, when I have the privilege of practicing medicine, I will make it my personal goal to continue on the legacy of free, low-cost clinics.

Western-influenced medicine and innovations tend to favor a general, one-size fits all template. The round peg forced to fit into the square hole eventually breaks, and so I believe we should instead, smooth out the rigid edges of the square hole to allow the round peg to seamlessly fit. Medicine should be adjusted in a way that advocates for the individual’s personal circumstances and is tailored for an individual’s specific needs, cultural traditions, and socioeconomic barriers. We should always be cognizant of these differences because our patients deserve our empathy and understanding as a means to a better life. As a physician, I will advocate for these individuals, as I did with my brother, and be the change I wish to see in modern-day life and medicine.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: From tutoring at-risk youth to treating wealthy stockbrokers, I have met and empathized with many people. My most insightful experience was when I was a math tutor for a girl named Kelly. We met every Friday morning to discuss the principles of adding and subtracting numbers. It was through Kelly that I learned about her Latina family. While eating with her family at dinner, I learned that her parents were against the new Covid vaccine. As immigrants, they had a minor language barrier and only obtained their information from certain media outlets. These were flooded with a conglomerative of true and false information but have mostly dissuaded them from getting vaccinated. Even though I disagreed with them, I validated their feelings and respected their decision to abstain from the vaccine. Reflecting on this situation, I remembered that people have a right to their bodily autonomy, and we should always remain open-minded to learn from their perspectives and opinions.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I currently volunteer as a clinic manager for a nonprofit, student-led free clinic that focuses on delivering healthcare to low-income populations. From untreated diabetes to manic psychiatric cases, I guided patients through the difficulties of societal and healthcare barriers. I remember a time when an HIV/AIDS positive man presented to the clinic. He described his year-long difficulties obtaining proper treatments with very little money and no medical insurance. Within 30 minutes of checking into the clinic, we provided him with a pharmaceutical course that saved his life. I have always felt the need to emphasize accessibility to healthcare, especially for underserved or low-income patients. My experiences at this free clinic were what shaped my desire for health equity and what jump-started my passion for free clinics. As a medical student in Chicago, I will continue the legacy of free clinics for the underserved population and am excited to learn more about RCSIP‚Äôs clinics.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I saw that the pandemic changed many people, some temporarily and others in the permanent loss of loved ones. During the pandemic, I became sick and had my MCAT rescheduled multiple times. However, in the peak of Covid, I stayed home as a student, but continued to see my mom and other frontline healthcare workers risk their lives. COVID-19 taught me that working in healthcare and any essential personnel job takes intense resiliency, strength, and bravery, which motivates me to continue my pursuit of medicine. I witnessed the various ways our government responded to a global pandemic, how science can literally save our lives by synthesizing a new vaccine, and lastly, I learned how to raise a pandemic puppy. At this point, I can confidently say that I am ready to begin my exciting journey into medicine.

personal_statement:
Medicine became a significant part of my life at age eight. I was born to immigrant parents who distrusted the medical system and relied on naturopathic remedies and alternative medicines to cure most ailments. However, these modalities did not stand a chance against my congenital heart defect. I remember sensing my parents’ apprehension and fear when my pediatrician and cardiologist pushed for me to undergo open heart surgery. Fortunately, the operation was a success. As I gradually healed, my shortness of breath dissipated, my energy levels rebounded, and the dark circles from beneath my eyes vanished. I was fascinated by the “magic” behind the medicine; the seed for my passion to pursue a career in this field was planted.

Over the years, my perception of medicine evolved and shifted with exposure to different experiences. I saw medicine as an ever-present force which brought comfort to many of my loved ones. It served as a glimmer of hope when my grandmother emigrated from Poland to receive chemotherapy for her aggressive breast cancer. It became a guardian when it rescued my father twice after he suffered a heart attack and underwent double bypass surgery. At the same time, I observed medicine’s limitations, especially when it proved futile in saving my dear friend and laboratory director from a fatal arrhythmia.

Through these experiences – both the good and the bad – it became clear to me that medicine’s grounding in science and technology is often key in saving lives. I wanted to master the creative, problem-solving mindset that is so essential in this field. When I joined the Paller lab at Northwestern, I was given the opportunity to address real world medical problems through innovative technologies. My research addressed an unmet clinical need for wound healing therapeutics among the diabetic patient population. Although frustrating at times, I found my research immensely rewarding. I knew my hours of creating 3D human skin cultures and prototyping stratified skin models with embedded nerves could potentially help someone, even if not until sometime in the future. Ultimately, I found that I value translational research and its potential for providing a better and healthier future, but I find assisting others in the present more fulfilling.

My volunteer work in college demonstrated the nature of medicine through a human lens. One night, I was on call when my coordinator notified me that one of our patients, as he was nearing his final hours, was in need of a compassionate companion. I quickly made my way to St. Mary’s Hospital where I found the terminally ill patient entirely alone. Beside him lay a book of blessings by John O’Donohue. I quietly read to him, hoping to offer some comfort. As I watched his chest rise and fall, I noticed his respirations gradually becoming shallower. I took his hand and held it with a strength and warmth that contrasted his frail condition. Although a stranger, I felt spiritually connected to him as I prayed the rosary at his bedside until he took his last breath. In that room, I participated in a holistic approach to healing that serves the body, mind and spirit with equal measure. Volunteering ultimately fueled my desire to provide care to patients in a more humanistic way. 

My clinical experience as a medical assistant has allowed me to see the effects of modern science while in a real primary care clinic – blending my respect for and knowledge of science with my love of interacting with patients. At the clinic, I noticed that many diabetic patients had not undergone screening for diabetic retinopathy, a disease that causes vision loss. Utilizing the knowledge gained while conducting diabetic neuropathy research, I piloted the use of a retinal imaging tool which has helped many patients with their eye health. 

Among these patients, one was particularly memorable. Sitting on the exam table before me, she had a dejected look and solemnly expressed her concerns. As I scanned her ophthalmology report, a key detail stood out: further loss of vision is very high. I acknowledged her struggles and despair, which helped ease her anxiety. After her doctor and I discovered that she was lacking an awareness and understanding of diabetes, reliable transportation, and financial stability, we worked to address these obstacles. We validated her concerns and offered an individualized care plan, resulting in immense relief and gratitude. This encounter was memorable because I saw firsthand how medicine’s commitment to the entirety of the human experience can ultimately save someone from life-threatening circumstances.

My volunteer, research and clinical experiences have validated my decision to pursue a career in medicine that is rooted both in science and compassionate care. I have no doubt that I am up to the challenge of medical training, so that I can someday become a physician committed to providing care that involves understanding the people behind the symptoms. I know I will have achieved my greatest professional goal if I become a physician that my eight-year-old self would have been proud to call “her doctor”.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As a free clinic volunteer and medical assistant, I care for a diverse patient population daily. Among all the patient encounters I have had, a memory of caring for an elderly Hispanic woman with limited English proficiency and lack of adherence to her medications stands out to me. While actively listening to her concerns, I realized that ethnocultural differences and lack of understanding contributed to her fear and apprehension. Without being able to easily communicate, I sought out creative ways to offer tactful, compassionate care through using teach-back methods and being mindful of my body language and tone of voice. I learned the importance of identifying patients‚Äô unique health challenges and ensuring that each patient has a basic understanding of their health and options. My experiences have allowed me to better care for all patients, as I now appreciate how their beliefs and value systems impact their ability to participate in their medical care.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As a medical assistant, I have seen first hand how the pandemic has affected routine healthcare provision, especially for our diabetic patients. Moreover, I noticed that diabetes-related care measures were not being met, especially diabetic foot and eye exams. While diabetic foot exams can be performed in the clinic, many patients did not follow up with their ophthalmologists to undergo retinal imaging screening. Utilizing the diabetes knowledge base I acquired during my research fellowship at Northwestern, I worked with my clinical director to roll out a diabetic vision screening initiative using Retinavue. This handheld retinal camera enables remote ophthalmologists to diagnose diabetic retinopathy in patients with diabetes during their routine primary care office visits. During the pandemic, I was able to address an unmet clinical need through implementing this tool, delivering real-time insights at the point of care and making diabetic eye care more accessible to our patients.
7_-_COVID_Impact: In March of 2020, I continued my courses virtually, conducted discussions virtually while assistant teaching, and stopped my extracurricular obligations. I encountered challenges with my MCAT exam because it was rescheduled multiple times until late summer. The pandemic also has impacted my perspective on public health as it has shed light and exacerbated pre-existing health disparities. This knowledge furthered my desire to close the gap by taking on a clinical facing role as a medical assistant. In this role, I help ensure that our patients have a basic understanding of their health and help facilitate access to resources based on patient needs. I have also supported medical providers through multiple COVID-19 outbreaks while helping keep our staff healthy and safe. During the pandemic, I learned the balancing act of leading patient testing and treatment while addressing the needs of the regular stream of non-COVID patients.

Hrdshp_Comments:
Living in a rural, small town in East Tennessee, we were medically underserved and underrepresented both by geography and ethnicity. My family also endured socio-economic hardships coming from a low-income, Mexican immigrant family of seven. They were limited in the work they could do and had little to no government assistance due to our immigration status. In all, the thought of obtaining a college education and becoming a physician seemed unattainable, conflated with the fact that I did not have deportation protection until DACA issued in 2012.

Not wanting to be defined by circumstances, I focused on academics as a way out. I became a 1st-generation high school graduate and went to college as a 1st-generation student on scholarship. As a 1st-generation student, I was not prepared for all the challenges of college which caused a drop in my grades, a C/D+ in both organic chemistries. Learning from my mistakes, I changed my studying tactics leading me to have a solid upward trend in my junior and especially in senior year when I got A’s in both retakes and graduated “cum laude” with a biochemistry degree.

However, as a 1st-generation college graduate who can only apply to schools who accept his DACA status, I understand that I might be fundamentally disadvantaged when applying to medical schools.
personal_statement:
Experiencing excruciating abdominal pain, I was rushed to the ER in the dead of night. I had appendicitis and needed emergency surgery. I was terrified going from extreme pain to suddenly being told I needed to have surgery; it made 12-year-old me feel very overwhelmed. I am from a Mexican immigrant family whose parents primarily speak Spanish with some working English. Thankfully, “Dr. Stiles” went above and beyond to alleviate our worries. He took his time to interpret for my parents, explain things calmly to me, and reassured us throughout my stay. Seeing how well he treated me and my parents during a very vulnerable time, I decided I wanted to go into medicine. I want to be just like the doctor that treated a scared child and his terrified Spanish-speaking parents so well. I want to be that source of comfort and care for my community especially in rural, low-income, and Spanish-speaking areas where there are not a lot of people of color, people like my family and I, as physicians.

I was just a 19-year-old when my family had to go through our most harrowing night. My twin, Rene, and I were sleeping in our room like normal when I was awakened to the sound of strained gasping. What I saw will forever stay with me. Rene was violently convulsing, struggling to breathe, and had a glazed appearance. He was having a seizure. I yelled for my parents, waking my siblings in the process. Not knowing what to do, my parents went to his side and tried to comfort him as best they could. My sister was crying hysterically, and my little brother was frozen with fear. With everyone letting their emotions get the best of them, I knew I had to be one to get us through this together. I told them to hold Rene on his side to allow him to breathe better, keep soothing him, and for my sister to call EMS. EMS came a few moments later, and I gave my report to them as they assessed and took Rene away. Once at the hospital, we saw that Rene was feeling better albeit with some sluggishness. Throughout this night, I felt so ill-prepared to help. Knowing how it feels to be a patient and family member in a medical crisis, I want to go into medicine so that I am prepared to help other patients and their families.

My clinical experiences have cemented my drive to be a doctor. As an undergraduate neuroscience intern, I give cognitive exams. I remember being told about a patient, “Jane”, who has severe anxiety and was feeling very uncomfortable being at the clinic. Knowing this, I tried my best to make her feel comfortable throughout the exam, so I listened, encouraged, and gave her ample time to answer. Jane scored fantastically in the end and was rightfully proud of her accomplishment. She just needed a little encouragement. As a nurse technician on an oncology floor, I got to know my patients from working multiple night shifts. I had a very kind, elderly patient, “Tom”, who was on the floor due to bouts of neutropenia. He and his wife, “Maggie”, rarely asked for anything as he was mostly independent during his stay. However, one night I was called to his room. Opening his door, I saw that he was profusely sweating and trembling uncontrollably. Maggie said that he was having one of his “bad nights” where he would overheat giving him the “shakes.” In a hushed, shaky voice, he said that a cup of ice water and something cold to hold to his head was all he needed. I said that I’d be right back with the items. After closing their door, I hurried to get ice water and an ice pack returning a few moments later. Checking in later that night, Tom was cooled and doing much better, and Maggie was at ease. Seeing them in a better state, I was relieved I was able to make their night better. Both experiences showed me that medicine is a service industry where you treat people and not only illnesses. I want to pursue medicine to provide patients with the best service possible to leave them doing better than when they came to me.

Volunteering at a free clinic has allowed me to be the change and representation that I want for my community. Because of my Mexican heritage, I can linguistically and culturally relate to Spanish-speaking patients. I remember translating for a distraught mother, “Maria”. Her toddler, “Manny”, had a painfully infected ear. I was able to confer Manny’s symptoms to the physician and pharmacist so that they could get her the needed antibiotics. I also talked about superheroes with Manny as we waited for the medicine to keep his mind off things. At the end of the visit, Maria was relieved to have the medication needed to treat Manny's ear, and Manny was ready to watch a superhero movie. I was ecstatic I could be of service to them. As an immigrant, I want to give back to my community, and these interactions have shown me that I can do just that. In all, I plan to use my translating skills and my cultural background as an immigrant to reach a wider community in medicine.

Undoubtedly, all my experiences have prepared and led me to medicine. I hope to be able to implement changes in medicine for the better of everyone involved, and I plan to serve my community by using my cultural competencies, interpersonal skills, and clinical experiences to provide quality care to the most vulnerable and underserved populations in medicine.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: While not an official member, I sometimes partook in activities for my college‚Äôs PRIDE club. The club promotes equality and tolerance about LGBTQ+, women‚Äôs, and social issues. While I am a straight cis man, I want nothing but the best for all members of the LGTBQ+ community. I also know the hardships that the LGTBQ+ and women face for recognition. As a pre-med, I met many amazing female peers during my college years. Their stories of people telling them not to pursue science or medicine was disheartening. It was not because they were not equipped for the job. It was because they were women going into a male-dominated field. I could only relate to a Mexican immigrant's point of knowing how it feels to be seen as different and not entirely accepted into a larger community. My experience with these great individuals shows that I still need to learn more to be a better advocate and ally for change.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
At the free clinic where I volunteer, I was able to help a patient get the care he truly needed. He organically only came to get pain medication for his back. While translating for him, he also told me that he was having problems with depression due to the loss of his father and the possibility that he had herpes from a past sexual encounter. Because he felt comfortable with me as a fellow BIPOC/Latino, we could also give him medication for depression and his STD and point him toward the health department, which could further help him._x000D_
_x000D_
Also, I was recently able to get one of our economically disadvantaged nurse practitioners in contact with a patient assistance program to give her free medication for her type 2 diabetes. She is a retired healthcare worker who takes time out of her day to volunteer. I knew I had to help her, and the medical director trusted me to find a solution. She deserves all the help possible because she is such a great person who provides so much.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I originally intended to apply in the 2020 cycle, but I quickly realized that I would not be able to effectively apply with all the stress that the pandemic was causing in my academic and personal life. Therefore, I focused on my academics and crafting my senior thesis based on cancer research I had done at the University of Michigan. Seeing that the pandemic was still limiting my ability to gain shadowing and clinical experiences, I decided to wait to apply in the 2022 cycle and not in the 2021 cycle. I then spent the year gaining fantastic clinical and shadowing experiences and being mentored by excellent physicians along the way. The pandemic challenged me as an individual, and I knew I had to rise to the challenge to mature and learn from it. My persistence in the face of the pandemic kept me on my path to medical school and made me a more holistic applicant. I am better equipped for medical school because the pandemic allowed me to grow as an individual.

Inst_Action_Desc: I previously lost financial aid at College of Lake County for falling behind satisfactory academic progress at the beginning of my academic career. I subsequently appealed this decision and began receiving financial aid once more during a probationary period. This occurred in fall of 2016 while I was working full time as a firefighter/paramedic and attempting to pursue school full time. The time commitment was too much for me during that period, and I dropped 16 credit hours in the fall 2016 semester in order to focus on work. Beyond this, I did not have the same drive and interest in pursuing my education as I have had for the past three years.
personal_statement:
If you would have told sixteen-year-old me that someday my dream would be to become a physician, I would have called you crazy. Sixteen-year-old me was a self-proclaimed rockstar, dragging out one-hundred pounds of music gear into dark clubs to play for eight people. I was fueled by the feeling of being on stage – the adrenaline, the lights, and the noise. I considered music my dream, not medicine, much less the academic rigors involved with becoming a doctor. 

However, before I graduated high school, with my parents' voices reverberating in my ears, I realized that I would need a more realistic career to pursue while I waited for music to propel me to stardom. As hesitant as I was to fathom the possibility that I would never become the rockstar of my dreams, I obliged. This more realistic career option was working as a firefighter. The pace of firefighters responding to emergencies seemed to match the pace I enjoyed so much on stage. The job could be loud, energetic, bright, and exciting, much like the feeling of strumming away and singing until my voice was fried in a dingy club. Surprisingly, it was just what I needed to kickstart my interest in becoming a physician.

As a child, I was curious about the medical profession. The sights and sounds of an ambulance passing would stop me in my tracks. I could not keep myself from watching it fly by, with busy paramedics in the back working to save someone’s life. With this child still somewhere in my psyche, I enrolled in an EMT class after graduating high school. As my EMT course began, I realized that I could not only enjoy learning but excel at it. My EMT license led to my job with the fire department, which led to my paramedic license. Before I knew it, I was a full-fledged firefighter/paramedic, entering a career I could have continued to work in until retirement, but I craved a deeper learning. I spent a semester pursuing pre-med prerequisites full time, but with my job at the fire department, I found little success. My clinical rotations in the hospital were fascinating, yet I felt I was missing a level of depth. With each patient I transported to the hospital, I wondered more about their journey after we dropped them off. I eventually began instructing EMS courses as adjunct faculty, where I started to realize that my love for learning about medicine meshed with my love for teaching it. I wanted to continue this learning in medical school, so I left the fire service to focus on my newfound dream full time. 

My interest in academics developed organically, through an urge to learn more. Although I had once not been interested in school, once I solely focused on my education, my pre-med classes began to leave me entrenched in curiosity and wonder; I have not yet escaped this feeling. A lecture on sickle cell anemia in my genetics course left me more capable of understanding what patients with the condition go through, and how they ended up with it, for instance. I am constantly attempting to connect topics taught in my lectures with experiences that I have had in the hospital. As I continue taking classes in the sciences, I am drawn closer to medicine as I realize that continuous learning is a passion for me, and a necessity in the profession. Physicians must stay current on the newest, evidence-based practices, to provide the best care for their patients. Knowing this, I look forward to learning new things every single day as a medical student, and someday as a physician. 

At this point, I feel at-home in my academic journey. Prior to solely pursuing education, I was unaware of how much working as a team with classmates mirrored my experience of working together with the members of various bands. Just as a mutual working relationship with my bandmates would increase the quality of music, so does the team atmosphere in the classroom. Much of my enjoyment in college has revolved around working with classmates who have similar goals to mine, in order to learn the most we can.

I also experience this team dynamic in my current work in the emergency department. As an ED tech, I have learned how all members of a healthcare team work together. We all perform vital tasks to provide the best patient care. Physicians would not be able to deliver proper care without the collaboration of nurses and various support staff, such as myself. The healthcare workers I admire understand this concept through and through. They realize that we are all in this together, and job title is not as important as being a vital member of the ED team. I have thrived as a team member, and plan to incorporate this valuable practice into my career in medicine.

Starting with my journey in EMS and continuing into the hospital setting, I have direction and valuable learned lessons that ignite my interest in a career as a physician. I am capable and motivated to succeed in medicine at the highest level. Over the last ten years I have grown from someone with little interest in academics – someone whose rockstar backup plan was to work as a firefighter – to someone with an entirely different set of priorities. Playing music is still very important to me, but it is no longer my dream – practicing as a physician is my dream – and one which I am ready to pursue to my fullest potential.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As someone who grew up in and around the city of Chicago, I have spent my whole life observing this city's immense diversity. Although I have not worked in healthcare in the city, I have witnessed the healthcare inequities of individuals without medical access in my suburban emergency department. Over the past two years I have watched many patients struggle to navigate the complex healthcare system, often presenting to the emergency department with seemingly benign concerns because they feel they have nowhere else to turn. These patients are often under or uninsured, with little access to quality healthcare. The best physicians with whom I have worked have shown me that with effective patient education and providing necessary resources, we can do a substantial amount of good for these patients. I have observed the ways the best practitioners provide for those who are under or uninsured, and I plan to emulate these practices in my role as a physician in the future.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: My involvement in the Future Health Professionals Club at Northeastern Illinois University has allowed me to give back to the Chicago community surrounding the NEIU campus. In the fall of 2021, our group assembled care packages for Chicago's homeless population. Subsequently, we dispersed these care packages, including some in the vicinity of Rush University on Chicago's west side. We have continually endeavored to support those in need by organizing and conducting blood drives, educating kids on oral health, and volunteering at local food banks to pack food. My experience as vice president of this organization has equipped me with the required leadership skills necessary to continue serving Chicago community members while in medical school. With this, I am excited and prepared to collaborate with other students at Rush Medical College to provide community service to Chicago residents through the Rush Community Service Initiatives Program.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
During the COVID-19 pandemic, I began working in the emergency department. Working at this time was significantly challenging, as we saw great numbers of critically ill COVID-19 patients. The pandemic challenged everyone who worked in healthcare. Upon the release of COVID-19 vaccines, we struggled taking care of very sick patients as others displayed hesitancy toward a vaccine that we felt would save lives._x000D_
_x000D_
Despite this, I observed clinicians taking additional time to inform patients about the vaccine. This opened my eyes to a new duty of physicians as educators, who must remain current not only on disease processes and treatment strategies, but also on the most recent vaccines. The pandemic has highlighted for me the importance of a physician's role as an educator in fostering an inclusive healthcare environment. The thought of assuming this position and educating others on the most cutting-edge, scientific technologies motivates me to continue the pursuit of a career as a physician.

Hrdshp_Comments:
One warm, summer evening, it was the end of the month and my mom told us all to get in the car. Of course, my three siblings and I obliged. She drove us to Vons and told us we each have $7 to spend on whatever we want. She had just gotten our weekly groceries, and our EBT card was resetting the next morning. I felt like a king, wandering Vons for 20 minutes with $7 to spend however I liked. My final choice was to get Whoppers and M&Ms.

Moving from my Title I high school to UCLA was definitely a culture shock. I didn’t realize that other public schools had speakers that worked or TVs from this century. I never realized I was disadvantaged till I met everyone else.
I grew up with my single mother, but unfortunately she usually wasn’t home as she worked two to three jobs at a time, always on a hustle. I had my three older siblings to take care of me. That’s likely why my siblings and I have gotten so close. It’s also probably because we all shared a bedroom, until my oldest sister was 22 years old, I was 15.

We were fortunate enough to receive the aforementioned government aid. This dramatically helped ends meet, particularly the Food Stamps and Medicaid. We also received rent-assistance from the state. I don’t know where we would be without it.
personal_statement:
At sixteen years old, I shed my first tear since beginning puberty. While watching a news broadcast on the civil war in Syria, I saw boys my age, speaking my language, practicing my religion, being dealt calamitous fates. Desperate to help, I looked into the corresponding physician’s organization Médecins Sans Frontières to figure out how to help. Their website had two options, monetary donations or volunteering as a clinician. With no money, nor any clinical qualifications, I felt devastated. It was at that moment I began pursuing a career in medicine.

My experiences form the tapestry that is my path towards becoming a physician. Early in my journey, I met Daniel* while volunteering for a health fair in Los Angeles under the UMMA Clinic, a free clinic for the underserved. Daniel was an on-shift security guard whose first stop was the free food table. After he joked that his two bagels would taste better with a Coca-Cola, I encouraged him to receive a health evaluation at a nearby station. Daniel said “Nothing’s broken if you don’t know about it.” Our laughs were immediately followed by a shared look, we both recognized the danger in a statement like that. After a brief conversation about soccer, with a segue into healthy lifestyles and preventative care, he was willing to have his finger pricked. Ten minutes later he informed me his readings looked good, thankfully. It was a happy ending to a pleasant afternoon chat.

Not all my experiences with medicine have left me feeling as accomplished. Two weeks after being hired at my lab, I was tasked with euthanizing 28 mice in a single evening. It was one thing to stain glass slides of mouse brains, another to watch the light leave their eyes as I injected the pentobarbital. The irony was deafening, on a mission to save lives, here I was sacrificing dozens. Despite following humane euthanasia protocol, I came home that night feeling void.
What brought me back into the lab on Monday was an email my principal investigator, Dr. Cole, shared with me years ago as an undergraduate volunteer. The husband and caretaker of a clinical trial subject reached out to Dr. Cole and explained how our lab’s Alzheimer’s treatment has dramatically improved their quality of life. He explained how every morning and evening when dressing his wife, she would vehemently resist for up to thirty minutes. After our treatment, she’s still sick with poor memory, but now she allows the wardrobe change. The additional hour per day he spends with her means the world to him. Hallmarks of progress like those are what reaffirm my passion towards medicine. Knowing that it's possible to make a real change.

Each project I’ve had the privilege to participate in has its own stories with unique characters, differing objectives, and special memories. Nowhere else do you find stories like you do in medicine. They’re often sad. My story isn’t as grim: a single-parent household, struggling with poverty being a first-generation college graduate. I thank God that my uninsured family had health conditions limited only to my flat feet, which still managed to get me through three marathons. Life has been difficult, but surmountable.

What seems insurmountable is the news program that led to my first tear, a video of a charred Syrian child hobbling across a street of rubble. Or more recently, a Ukrainian family who just lost their home. I hear the stories from my parents who came to America as refugees, and I know by one stroke of luck, I’m here, safe in my Los Angeles home, and despite sharing a room with my three siblings we don’t have bombs flying over our heads.

Then I turn my gaze away from the TV and down our apartment corridor and see our family friends, the Rabadis, and their severely intellectually disabled son, their middle child, David* sprinting through the hall equipped with his vibrant red helmet. Knowing that no matter how pure and lovable David is, his fate is all but written.
That’s why I aspire towards a career in medicine. That’s why I’ve put hours into volunteering at clinics, attending health fairs, doing research, and studying. It’s why reading Dr. Paul Kalanithi's When Breathe Becomes Air and thinking “he did everything right and still died before getting his dream job” only reaffirmed my passion for medicine. Because it’s not fair that the best we can do is give that husband and caretaker one extra hour with his wife; or that those Syrian children have to experience half a dozen surgeries; or that the Rabadis will never have “normal” lives. Because the world is not fair and we need more stories with happy endings like Daniel's.

The people behind each of these stories are what inspire me to become a physician. There’s a name, a spouse, a parent, a child, a life behind each one. I don’t want them to be characters in a narrative or statistics on a factsheet, they’re more than that. I want to remedy the fact that some people don’t get the chance at a life they deserve. I’m uncertain whether I’ll save orphans in Syria or expand upon the frontier of medicine and cure Alzheimer’s, but I’m optimistic. I’m optimistic that we can save someone from becoming another sad story.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
At six years old, my family briefly relocated from Los Angeles to the Indonesian island of Banda Aceh. We were neighbors with the local people, we shared meals, we visited their homes, we were friends. To many people, my family and I were the first fair-skinned foreigners they had met. Although we spoke different languages, ate different foods, and looked differently, we bonded. I learned that other cultures aren‚Äôt weird, they can only be different._x000D_
_x000D_
Early in my life I was introduced to an entirely different life, and I believe it shaped my worldview permanently to allow me to respect unique cultures. During my time abroad, I witnessed the absolute havoc caused by the 2004 Tsunami, which spurred my interest in supporting underserved communities._x000D_
_x000D_
Solidarity is a verb, and combating social inequities entails action. That means using our resources to support less privileged communities, boycotting products from the Xinjiang province, and speaking up for those in need.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
An experience that truly embodies many of my values, is the UMMA Clinic‚Äìa clinic for the underserved in South Los Angeles._x000D_
_x000D_
South LA, in particular, faces inequality in the realm of healthcare, including having only 11 pediatricians per 100,000 children. It's also a notorious food desert. Millions of residents in our country‚Äôs largest cities are struggling to stay healthy, and that‚Äôs not a personal issue; it‚Äôs a health crisis._x000D_
_x000D_
At clinic, our tasks included clinical volunteering, community health fairs, and biweekly food fairs. _x000D_
_x000D_
The most special element to contributing to the UMMA Clinic was speaking with patients and getting to know the people we helped treat. Volunteering as Clinical Site Director at the UMMA Clinic felt meaningful because I knew that a few years ago, the family in the waiting room could have been my own. I saw firsthand how the statistics manifest into their daily life. It was exceptionally rewarding to know that our efforts were helping those who needed it most.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
In March 2020, I earned a clinical research volunteer position in cardiovascular medicine at UCLA Santa Monica Hospital, which was soon canceled due to the pandemic. I was also furloughed from my job of 3 years at UCLA Recreation because of the global shutdown. In Winter 2021, I was working with a Peace Corps recruiter to prepare my application, but Peace Corps assignments were postponed._x000D_
_x000D_
My family took quarantine extremely seriously, as my mom is still uninsured. Since then, I lost my grandfather and uncle. They didn‚Äôt fall victim to COVID, but nonetheless, the world is now two good men smaller._x000D_
_x000D_
Reflecting upon the pandemic has highlighted the finite time we have together, making me eager to commit my life to an impactful career in medicine._x000D_
_x000D_
From losing opportunities during quarantine to losing family soon after, the fragility of the world has never been more clear. As an aspiring physician, I strive to combat that fragility, and to make the world more stable for our loved ones.

Hrdshp_Comments: I grew up in a single parent household as the oldest of two kids. We lived in public housing projects in New York City. My mom worked hard to support us, but there wasn't a lot of money to go around.  Furthermore, the closest hospitals to me were all a notable bus ride or 30 minute walk away. There wasn't much, if any, in the way of mental health resources nearby. At UChicago, I ended up receiving large amounts of financial aid on the school and federal level. This included Pell Grants. During college, I qualified for food stamps in the State of Illinois.
personal_statement:
Few people would say that visiting their grandmother in the hospital after surgery was a crucial or positive moment in their early childhood.  Apparently, that was in the cards for me as I entered the doors of Montefiore Hospital in September 2003. When I got to the room for my grandma Anna as she recovered from a double knee replacement, my four-year-old mind was amazed. She stood before me in the middle of a large mess of medical gadgets. My eyes raced, from monitors and machines to the clear fluid travelling into Anna via an amazing contraption that I later learned was an IV. After poring over all the equipment, I found “them”. The two even columns of surgical stitches new to Anna’s knees were hard to ignore. Their sudden, strange, and surviving appearance to this day has lasted with me. My memory of Anna’s mobility before the surgery is minor, but she kept up with me as I’ve grown up. 
While it took me another 15 years to begin getting clinical experience, my grasp of critical physician skills was shaped by two principles. I grew to value both giving back and doing more to restore health to the community. The latter shows in how my grandmother was helped by her surgeons. Since I had orthopedic surgeries of my own as a teen, I feel an added drive to contribute more. Being a doctor like those who improved both my life and Anna’s is how the former principle can be achieved. The job’s not easy, and I needed further understanding and time to know that it’s what I wanted to do with my life.  Over the past three or four years, the knowledge that “MD is for me”, was gained firsthand.  
I was fortunate enough to do cancer research during college, through the Center for Global Health (CGH). I was very excited to travel to Nigeria for the first time. However, I found myself in tough situations as I got used to the chaos of the ER. My research required the doctors I visited throughout the country to do a survey that took 30 minutes. This was a hard sell, with far more people to see than providers available. Surveys required multiple visits to complete, a problem only enhanced when shadowing. Critical cases came often to the ER, cutting time short as the doctor rushed to save lives. A lingering memory is the doctors showing me, with pride, the patients they were beginning to work on. They noted my reaction to metastasized cancers and partial amputations like a test I needed to pass. Shadowing and acing said tests was a huge driving factor behind my persistence in getting the surveys done, even in 100-degree weather. The bigger factor, though, was seeing my privilege and the opportunity afforded to me. While these people looked like me, Nigeria’s healthcare system paled in comparison to what I’d seen in America. Seeing these healthcare disparities up close provided new motivation for me to come home, achieve my dream, and give back. Doing so would help me be a global citizen, the goal of CGH. I don’t know if I’ll ever be back in Nigeria but doing good somewhere on Earth is enough for me. 
After graduating college, I began working as a medical assistant at Case Integrative Health. This gave me great experience working with patients, removing their IV lines, giving injections, and performing microcurrent neurofeedback. The last two years saw many visits where my heart wept for the chronic disease struggle our patients faced daily. Watching Dr. Kelley and her care and insight, I learned the ways that Lyme disease can wreak havoc on the body. With this knowledge handy, I was sad to hear so many people tell me that other doctors merely waved them away. Some even questioned the existence of Lyme altogether. These conversations have inspired me to do more to improve and restore the care of my patients, current and future. This principle is even more crucial for those coming in with more disputed ailments. Seeing a Morgellons’ patient bring in the fibers that she said crawled out her skin shocked me. Yet, hearing that she had been subject to mental health tests and police searches for seeking treatment almost brought me to tears. This stigma is the exact opposite of the care I wish to provide. I joined Dr. Kelley in assuring the woman that her experiences were valid.  This visit, among others, proved I must prioritize the patient’s voice and concerns and see them as person first, patient second. Bringing that approach with me moving forward should prove useful in restoring the health of those I see. 
Across the globe, my experience with research, patients, and physicians have bolstered my desire to join the medical field. These opportunities, occurring during and after attending UChicago, have helped me show critical physician skills and set goals for myself. One goal of mine is to wholeheartedly give back to communities that I serve. Seeing people not taken seriously and not getting the best care possible has instilled a strong sense of compassion in me. I strive to be a patient’s biggest advocate and supporter. My ultimate goal is to rejuvenate my patients and restore their lives. This happens both through physical healing of their body and emotional and mental support. With new experiences due with each person I treat, I know that being a doctor will keep me motivated and provide a constant sense of fulfillment.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: My outlook on the world was permanently altered after my research trip to Nigeria in 2019. Being able to observe doctors trying to provide the best care possible despite the numerous factors working against them was quite inspirational. The hospitals I was able to shadow at were frequently overwhelmed by the number of patients to serve, and finances were an issue from the facilities lacking equipment and beds to the patients being unable to afford treatments or medications. Something that I continue to take from this experience looking back is how happy the average Nigerian I met was. They weren't lamenting what they lacked in resources, but were more grateful for what they did have as a result. This outlook is one I strive for daily. I learned that I am a global citizen from this experience, and so I've made it a goal to be able to help people both within and outside the communities I'm in. One person can make a bigger difference than they think, so that's my plan for my career ahead.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I'm very grateful to my current job for exploring the field of microcurrent neurofeedback and allowing me to administer this therapy to our patients. With over 500 sessions under my belt, I've been able to observe people's progress as I alter the protocol to their needs. Typically, the procedure will help with concentration, fatigue, and headaches. One patient that's seen a notable impact from the procedure had her first appointment following a concussion suffered in a motor vehicle accident. The accident left her unable to concentrate on tasks for an extended period of time and exacerbated her pre-existing headache condition. After 20+ sessions with her, she reports being able to concentrate for longer the day following the procedure, and less headaches as well. The patient comes in with her son, as both are patients at our clinic, and she thanks me frequently for the assist I provide in her being able to take care of him. I hope to have a similar impact on more patients in my career.

personal_statement:
I am fortunate to have had a father who was a physician. Throughout my childhood, I frequently tagged along during clinical hours and was enamored by the aura of an operating room. As I got older, I admired how he treated his patients and could connect with each one of them. One of our favorite nightly routines was to go to the gym together. During these personal hours he still found time to answer a call from a patient or help someone with a medical question. As I reflected on these experiences, I realized I wanted to purse medicine not only because I wanted to be like my father but also because I fell in love with the idea of interacting with patients and positively impacting their lives. 
 
After years of shadowing my father’s work and seeing the various patient populations in his practice, I recognized how lucky I was to have access to excellent healthcare. However, I also learned about the significant healthcare disparities that exist in our country and around the world. I sought out first-hand experience to gain a deeper understanding of these issues. 

At the age of sixteen, I began volunteering for Medical Students in Action, an organization that provides primary and subspecialty care through medical mission trips to the Dominican Republic. During these trips, I saw physicians and medical students work together in tough scenarios with limited tools to reach a common goal. Witnessing such teamwork taught me that collaboration on all levels is essential for exceptional patient care. Most importantly, I saw each physician treat their patients like family, regardless of language or cultural barriers. Growing up as a person who prioritizes family, these were defining moments. I want to be the doctor for families that I expect other doctors to be for mine. These profound experiences solidified that I want to dedicate the rest of my life to serving others.

During my first semester in college, I got a call that my father was diagnosed with glioblastoma brain cancer. After witnessing countless patient encounters with my father throughout my life, we suddenly were on the other side of the looking glass. A million questions raced through my mind: “What are his surgical options? Is chemotherapy or radiation useful? What can we do to maximize his chances of beating this?” For a disease where outcomes are characterized in months rather than years, I suddenly understood how valuable every minute was. 

One year later, my father passed away. Although fighting glioblastoma was the hardest thing my father and family would experience, there was a lot to reflect on and learn from. Even in the darkest times, he showed resilience and an unwavering pursuit to be better, despite the circumstance. Every time I step in the library, volunteer, or attend class, I remind myself that I’m progressing one step closer to helping someone like my father and potentially changing the forecast for a family like mine. 

Throughout my father’s journey, I joined my mother in many of his appointments – from transfusion sessions to interpreting MRIs. I was a thoughtful listener and thorough in my research to help my family where I could as the cancer changed rapidly. I quickly realized that there were still many unanswered questions regarding the treatment of glioblastoma. My curiosity and the absence of an absolute solution drove me to dive deeper into glioblastoma research and ongoing clinical trials. I arrived at the understanding that improving patient outcomes and solving unfinished puzzles of complex diseases starts with quality research.

My interest in research led me to join Dr. Elizabeth Hammock and Dr. Michael Orsmbee in their respective labs, where I learned how to conduct research from the bottom up. Their labs focused on the influence of oxytocin production on mammalian development and the impact of different exercise and nutrition modalities on an individual’s health. I gained valuable lab skills while sectioning mice brains for protein staining and genotyping, and I developed a deeper understanding of the metabolic effects of exercise while data on patients undergoing VO2 max tests. I concluded that research is the epitome of being curious, pursuing a goal, and solving a problem – an exciting process resulting in advancements towards solutions for complex puzzles. 

As I go forward, I will continue to take initiative in my community to improve the lives of others through volunteer outreach, academic studies, and research endeavors. I will never forget the feeling of sitting in a quiet hospital room with my father, waiting for the doctor to come in and steer us in the next direction along the course of the disease. Despite the rigorous path ahead, I am confident that my work ethic and passion will allow me to overcome any challenge. These experiences form the foundation upon which I will work towards my ultimate goal of becoming a physician scientist, leading the forefront of academic medicine. It is now more than ever that I want to be part of the solution.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Going on medical mission trips to the Dominican Republic gave me a greater understanding of the cultural differences that exist and how they contribute to the grossly apparent healthcare disparities in some rural communities. I learned how prior knowledge of norms and practices in the community you are serving helps create a more effective treatment plan to combat ailments and injury. Understanding the religious beliefs of locals made communication from the physicians about the importance of taking certain medications of utmost importance. By being cognizant of local practices, physicians gained the trust and comfort of their Dominican patients. I believe that one of the most important aspects of medicine is being culturally knowledgeable and understanding of a patient's background and ideology. I plan on using the knowledge I have accrued from these medical mission trips in my future patient interactions and the communities I serve.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Through conversations with classmates my freshman year of high school, I immediately took notice of their difficulty fitting in or feeling like they belonged in one of the largest schools in the nation. A close friend of mine completed suicide not too far into my first semester, driving me to found the HOPE Sunshine Club. Its membership was inclusive of anyone's ideology and cultural/gender identity, resulting in working directly alongside the LGBTQ+ community. My goal was to create a safe space for all students who wanted to be heard. Student membership quickly grew to over 75 students within its first year. Thereafter, the FISP organization and I implemented HOPE into over 48 other schools throughout the course of three years. I soon received handwritten letters from parents mentioning the impact that the club had on their child's outlook and overall well-being. Students openly told me that the HOPE Sunshine Club saved their life. This is one of my proudest achievements.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The COVID-19 pandemic shook America amid my second semester in college. Despite the indefinite limitations on my academic and professional goals, I read research studies published by faculty at FSU and emailed those who I took a particular interest in, relaying my willingness to assist in their lab when an opportunity presented itself. Understandably, no lab on campus was able to accept students due to the COVID-19 violations during the pandemic. For this reason, my ability to get involved in laboratory research was delayed until later in college.

personal_statement:
It had been years since I had a surgical procedure done. I nervously wondered if this procedure would be quick and smooth. Walking in with a welcoming appearance and calm demeanor, my nurse anesthesiologist got started on my blood draw and IV insertion. I was very anxious. However, she made me feel less embarrassed and safe at that moment. Upon waking up, my surgeon was reassuring and put my mind at ease. The care of this medical team was beyond what I could have expected that day. They ensured I was okay and listened to my concerns. A traumatic surgical experience morphed into an event that deepened my dedication to pursuing a career in medicine. It reminded me why I started: to use my unique experiences to be a relatable, encouraging physician. What I felt during that visit is the empathy and compassion I hope to share with those I touch in my medical career. That moment along with others has molded and deepened my desire to become a physician. 
Medicine is where I want to contribute my experiences to provide care to an integral part of human existence. I want to give the most compassionate care possible to my future patients by being an active listener and always having my patient’s best interests at the forefront of my mind. My training as a certified nursing assistant has deepened my understanding of the importance of treating patients with dignity and respect. I also have become better at learning about patients quickly to better serve their needs. I desire to be a physician that promotes comfort and open communication. Ensuring that I am entering every situation with an open mind has helped me develop the skills needed to achieve this goal. The times that I have interacted with patients let me have a personal part in their care. I remember a patient recovering from a gunshot wound at a hospital where I volunteered. She called the nurses’ desk multiple times to connect with a counseling service offered through the hospital. I could tell she was in a lot of pain and confusion, while she asked for information about the counseling services. On this day, the call phone had a poor connection, so I walked to her room. She was very sweet and soft-spoken yet looked so lonely in that frigid room. Although I could not give her an immediate answer, I knew that she needed her urgent pleas to fall on attentive ears. Interacting with her and reassuring her that the help she needed would soon arrive in the form of a call from her nurse added fuel to my desire of becoming a physician. 
Developing and maintaining relationships with my patients is essential to being the physician I envision. Providing care to an elderly patient at a rehabilitation center imparted wisdom regarding how hard it can be for patients to deal with ailments preventing them from caring for themselves in all capacities. I was a companion, but I also helped with her activities of daily living. I relished this position because I developed a meaningful relationship with her and other residents and learned about their personal experiences. I often shared food and stories with my client and her next-door neighbor, learning how to fulfill my caretaker duties while still being personable. Their experiences were invaluable because they allowed me to deepen our relationship and improve me as a healthcare provider. The residents shared personal details with me that showed how important it is to be there to listen to patients and learn from them. It was more than a job to me; I was helping my client in a journey to regain mobility and independence, a priceless role to hold in someone’s life. I remember assisting her with leg workouts. Seeing her determination to get better made me truly appreciate her spirit of positivity amid her daily struggles. There were tough days. She often became discouraged, but I was there to encourage her. I reminded her of the progress she had and of her family. The physical and occupational therapy, like making bread pudding, also uplifted her. That does not come close to all the prizes we would win at weekly bingo, though. The residents at this facility showed me what enjoying life was about and the importance of being open-minded. 
As I continue my journey in medicine, I want to carry my experiences into my career. I will continue to be inspired and motivated by the interactions I have with patients. The many lessons learned from the health professionals and patients who have crossed paths with me remind me that learning is universal. I have been given opportunities to share my compassion, watch patients grow, and, most importantly, listen to them. I look forward to more opportunities to play a role in someone’s journey in health.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Working as a registered line technician put me in contact with patients and families from various backgrounds. Although my primary goal was to ensure I was provided quality applied behavioral analysis therapy, I needed to understand my clients and aid them in getting the most out of our interactions. I remember a new client we had.  He was very young and neither he nor his family spoke much English. He came every day visibly upset. However, we learned he found comfort in watching shows like Splash and Bubbles. I also made sure to speak to him in simple phrases. My coworkers and I did our best to be welcoming and reassuring. Working with him made me take the time to put myself in his shoes. I was reminded that comfort is very important and that adjusting to uncomfortable situations can be challenging. I learned to lead with empathy and not make assumptions about what I thought he and his family were going through. I became more open-minded and understanding through this experience.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: During my college career, I volunteered for two semesters at the school's Vincent‚Äôs Vault Food Pantry. I served students and faculty who were economically disadvantaged. We provided them with fresh fruits and vegetables, nonperishable items, and hygiene products. I also sought the services of the pantry. I understood what it felt like to feel vulnerable and to have to lean on another person for help with necessities. I have always wanted to give back to underserved and underrepresented communities which inspired me to pursue this profession. Because of this experience, I will bring a caring, nonjudgmental attitude into every patient encounter and strive to improve the care being administered in whatever way I can as a student. I want to attend an institution that empowers its students to enact change in the communities they reside in.
7_-_COVID_Impact: When the pandemic first hit, I was completing my sophomore year of college. I was sent home in mid-March to complete the rest of our semester online. I completed most of my junior year of college online as well. This altered how I would have traditionally taken several of my science prerequisites. I was still able to excel in my classes, though. I had issues obtaining any clinical experience during the summer of 2020. However, I  participated in a research opportunity in summer of 2021. I completed a research fellowship at the University of Rochester School of Medicine and Dentistry. My research addressed the availability of tailored cessation materials for LGBTQ+ nicotine users. I conducted interviews and audited quit lines and quit sites in the United States and Canada. The culmination of my work was a poster presented at the end of the program. I am currently seeking shadowing opportunities. I will be working as a certified nursing assistant.

personal_statement:
One, two, three, four, five, squeeze. I repeated these words to myself as I delivered breaths to a barely breathing, unconscious woman. My first emergency call as an EMT was stressful, demanding, and transformative; this call, and all of the following calls, have cemented my passion for a career as a medical doctor.

My EMT crew had received a dispatch for a “person in respiratory distress.” As I rushed to the ambulance, the possible causes raced through my mind: Asthma? COPD? Anaphylaxis? When we arrived on scene, I was shocked. She was a young mother. I checked her pulse and felt nothing. 

This was my first encounter with a patient in critical condition. The Charge EMT, Ali, was training me that day. She quickly instructed a firefighter to initiate compressions while I prepared to administer oxygen to the patient. I looked down on the young woman lying before me. Her face was a pale blue. It seemed like nothing in my EMT course prepared me for a moment like this. I calmed myself and focused on the essentials: airway, breathing, and circulation. Ali applied the defibrillator pads to the young woman’s chest and – after one shock – her pulse came back. As I continued to deliver breaths, Ali made sure I held a proper seal and told me to count out loud.

I was inspired by Ali’s remarkable ability to multitask. She was able to provide lifesaving care while teaching a novice EMT. She changed my life that day. From that point on, I would dedicate myself to being prepared for any situation that came my way. I spent the next two years undergoing extensive training, attending EMS conferences, and working countless shifts. Each call was unique, requiring me – under pressure – to think critically about what treatments would be most effective in the moment. As I became a more skilled EMT, my passion for medicine grew. 

Initially, my interest in medicine was motivated by a fascination with understanding disease and how to effectively treat it. I was intrigued by the complexity of biological processes and how a seemingly small change in an amino acid or a malfunctioning enzyme could have major ramifications on someone’s health. This academic, clinical interest expanded over time into a real-world desire to alleviate suffering by providing personalized, effective care to patients in their most desperate moments.

And the calls kept coming. One day, my crew received a dispatch for a 50-year-old intoxicated female. We rushed to the woman’s home. Clearly inebriated and with tears in her eyes, the frazzled woman was initially unable to understand my questions. I instinctively reached out my hand to comfort her. The woman firmly grasped my hand, shook her head, and took a deep breath. Still holding my hand, she told me about her son who had recently passed away. She blamed herself for not noticing that her baby boy was sick and lamented her subsequent alcohol abuse. She was struggling to get through the hardest loss in her life.

Any emergency department would have the IV fluids this woman needed. But not every hospital would have the psychiatric services this woman required. By taking the time to understand my patient, I realized that she should be transported to a hospital that provided specialized psychiatric care. Her immediate physical problem was solvable. I recognized that the underlying issue called for a longer-term solution. Patients like this woman have encouraged me to spend every day learning so that I can look beyond the obvious and view treatment in a more holistic and sustainable way.

Fast forward to today: I’ve gone beyond my work as an EMT in my recent positions in health care. I worked as a medical scribe in the emergency room of a major hospital in New York – immediately after graduation, immediately at the onset of Covid. A trial by fire. I also assisted a primary care physician when his office was inundated with patients at the peak of the pandemic. Shadowing him, discussing treatment options, and interacting with patients one-on-one expanded my knowledge of day-to-day patient care within today’s health-care system. All of these experiences – including my current position as a medical assistant at Jefferson Headache Center – have strengthened my desire to aid patients in building confidence and finding strength as they advance through recovery. 

Despite all the suffering I witnessed during the pandemic, it reinforced what I knew about myself from the start: I am meant to be in health care. I want the larger role of direct patient diagnosis, treatment, and care. I want to keep the individual person in front me at the forefront of decision-making to ensure the best outcome. I know a career in medicine means a lifetime of continuous learning and I am committed to that. I have only just gotten started. 

When I look back on the first call that inspired me to sharpen my skills as an EMT, on the grieving mother who used alcohol to numb her pain, and on every patient interaction since, I realize that they all set me on the path to become a physician. I witnessed the color come back into the cheeks of a young mother and brought comfort to a woman who’d lost her son – even when it meant simply holding her hand. I am ready to do more.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
I recently volunteered at Prevention Point, a Philadelphia-based nonprofit public health organization. It was my first time interacting with people with substance use disorders.Each person I encountered had a story. I listened attentively as the women explained their struggles. I encouraged the women to come back to Prevention Point to get preventative medical care, to exchange needles, and to seek refuge, even for just a few hours.The women thanked me for my kindness and for making simple gestures like asking their names. It was a humbling experience that served as a reminder that most addicts and homeless people are not treated like humans. I recognized their humanity and acknowledged their value as individuals, and I could sense that it meant a lot to them._x000D_
_x000D_
Being the "other" in situations will improve my ability to communicate with individuals from all walks of life, giving me the cultural and social foundation I need to succeed in my academic, professional, and personal endeavors.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Over the past few years, I learned that a patient-centered approach to health care allows for informed inquiry and respectful interactions‚Äîand I am committed to providing this kind of culturally sensitive care. As an EMT, I responded to a student having a panic attack. She wanted help, but she explained that her parents do not believe in mental health issues, preventing her from seeking care. Typically, I would transport a patient with her complaints to our local psychiatric center. However, her predicament was unique, and I felt like my hands were tied. Following this call, I familiarized myself with the health and counseling services offered at Fordham, so I could relay accurate and timely referrals to my patients. A career in medicine requires lifelong learning, and by participating in calls like this one, I realized that it is my duty as a physician to learn about issues that might not affect me, so that I can provide realistic treatment plans to those affected.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
It was my final semester of college. The world shut down and my daily responsibilities dissipated. The devastation of COVID-19 made me aware of the vast disparity in access to health care that hit close to home, my home, The Bronx._x000D_
_x000D_
It was during this time that I began working in two vastly different clinical settings: an emergency room and a primary care office.¬†The juxtaposition of health outcomes between patients with and without primary care doctors was glaring. Patients lacking primary care doctors were on their own, so they flooded ERs‚Äîsometimes with non-emergent issues, sometimes when it was too late._x000D_
_x000D_
The pandemic impressed upon me the need to think strategically about the patients in front of me: yes, take care of their immediate needs, but more importantly, understand the circumstances that have contributed to their health outcomes. I was able to pause and reflect on my responsibilities as an aspiring doctor, ultimately sparking my interest in primary care and public health.

personal_statement:
“My name is Nick. Remember, grandma?” I asked as I helped her from the car. She stared at me blankly. Her inability to recognize the face of her only grandson made my heart ache, causing me to fearfully anticipate her diagnosis from our long-time primary care physician. “It seems to be dementia, potentially Alzheimer’s disease,” he confirmed. I sat silently, failing to appreciate what that meant, apart from what I had seen on television. Our doctor noticed my concern, pulled out a blank sheet of paper, and started drawing a diagram, showing me the condition in my grandmother’s brain. At first, I was intimidated and unsure I could understand, but as he kept going, I found myself more engaged. For the next 45 minutes, we discussed the diagnosis, different treatments, and resources for moving forward. I entered his office that day feeling overwhelmed and nervous, and I left feeling empowered and hopeful. 

This epiphany remained with me during my job stocking shelves at Target. On my break, I watched an episode of 60 Minutes, where a segment detailing an experimental treatment for glioblastoma caught my attention. My interaction with my grandmother’s doctor left me drawn to the interviews with physicians and researchers explaining how their treatment could alleviate a devastating brain tumor. Conversations with patients and family members offered a heartbreaking peek into the uncertainty of living with or caring for someone with a potentially untreatable illness. The commonalities between the program and my grandmother’s appointment struck me. That day fostered my conviction to become the person who communicates the complex physiological processes responsible for disease to intimidated patients and loved ones afraid of the unknown by joining the world of medicine.

Before deciding to explore medicine at the age of twenty-five, I spent my early twenties waffling about my path. I bounced in and out of school, tried to follow my father’s footsteps in construction, and thought maybe retail was where I should be, yet nothing ever stuck. Moving forward, I chose to major in biology at my local junior college, feeling optimistic about the journey ahead.

My newfound passion for science and medicine led to an entirely different educational experience, and later I developed a love for research. I showed up each day at the Cellular and Molecular Brain Research Laboratory excited to continue uncovering the novel molecular mechanisms responsible for Alzheimer’s disease. After being drawn to the laboratory because of my grandmother’s struggles, I quickly took to reading new scientific literature and heading my own project that I eventually presented at the 49th annual Society for Neuroscience Conference. Throughout the process, I found value in learning how to break down complex scientific details into a digestible, cohesive story my audience can follow, just as my grandmother’s physician so eagerly and succinctly did for me. These moments further inspired my drive to attend medical school and become a physician who understands, utilizes, and effectively translates scientific evidence to treat and empower my patients.
