During my last year of undergrad, the world shut down. COVID-19 spread to my hometown in Las Vegas, causing fear and panic in the community. While working late in the lab, I received an email asking for help at University Medical Center. “…The new lab has a processing capacity of 10,000 tests, but there is a bottleneck with lab technicians that is hampering progress in fighting COVID-19. We are looking for experienced laboratory personnel...” Before I finished reading, I knew this was a way I could be of service. I immediately applied and was rushed into a high-volume medical laboratory. My family's pleas rang in my ears as I stepped into the secured virus extraction area. “You’re going to be exposed! It might not be safe!” Even with the risks, I was enthusiastic about working 12-hour shifts and staying overtime to get patient results out. I called trauma, surgery, admitting floors, pediatric emergency etc., to help inform providers' decision-making. Working behind the scenes provided insight into the vast interprofessional team dedicated to patient care and increased my motivation to attend medical school.

Watching my grandmother lose her independence to an unseen force will remain with me forever. Because of her physician I will always associate the white coat he wore with security. My hope is to emulate the thoughtful practitioner who guided my grandmother and family through her devastating illness, demystifying details I now comprehend and therefore no longer fear. Through my experiences, I have gained the ability to convey intricate scientific information, while developing a compassionate and caring hand to illuminate the darkest paths during life’s most vulnerable moments.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: While working in retail I saw the significant stress facing economically disadvantaged members of my community. Although we all have the same twenty-four hours, the clock moves at a quicker pace when you lack transportation. Having your own means of transportation means you can readily estimate your commute. My colleagues who relied on alternative modes of transportation were met with unreliable treks causing their work life to bleed into every facet of their lives at home. I also saw how limited access to healthcare and low wages force agonizing decisions. I witnessed coworkers faced with health scares struggle to establish much needed care. There also came choices between losing pay or attending critical appointments. Simple decisions to prioritize one‚Äôs health turned into fraught situations of uncertainty. From this experience, I empathize with the unseen struggles facing many of my neighbors and the importance of resources to assist disadvantaged members of our communities.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: When I was first assigned to my foster child as a Court Appointed Special Advocate, I identified two problems I wished to solve. First, knowing he lacked stable role models, I wished to serve as source of stability. Second, he had not attended school in over a year. His team and I needed to get him help to reintegrate back into school. I accomplished my first task by meeting with him regularly and actively engaging in his interests. We played football at the park and spent weekends at the movies. We became close friends, and when he was in need, I was the first person his foster mom dialed. To help him successfully transition back to school, his team and I enrolled him into mock school days to reacclimate back to regular attendance. We also sought ABA therapy to improve his interactions with peers. If he ever needed help, I offered a steady hand to grasp. His hard work paid off as he successfully reintegrated back into life as a middle schooler, making friends and doing homework.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I shadowed three physicians of different disciplines gaining insights into the roles, expectations, and qualities of each physician I followed. These experiences were not easy to come by. During the pandemic, and even with the easing of restrictions since, local medical offices have not been open to unaffiliated visitors. When I spoke to physicians, they expressed concern over the time they had to commit to student shadowing due to increased workloads and time limits set by office administrators. The physicians who were able to accommodate me were incredibly generous with their time. They welcomed me into their office, provided opportunities to answer my questions, and gave detailed breakdowns of their interactions with patients. As documented elsewhere in my application I have significant healthcare/clinical experience as a member of the COVID-19 Laboratory at University Medical Center of Southern Nevada. I hope my time there will be considered when reviewing my clinical experience.

personal_statement:
A schizophrenic mom and an abusive dad deemed unfit to parent and had their children taken away- that was the thesis of many Division of Child Protection and Permanency cases on my desk. The tragedies were heart-wrenching and intense, but I loved working for a forensic and general psychiatrist and appreciate the biopsychosocial aspects involved in pathology and healthcare. Though I initially began shadowing during free time between classes, I was soon offered an internship; the physician took me through every step of her profession and eventually entrusted me with handling the rest as office manager. 

I recall coming across a patient's chart, Mr. S, who had a large outstanding balance. I noticed that he was listed as self-pay while he had in-network insurance. After hours of phone calls and testing claims in the office, I ultimately managed to reduce his balance to less than half, saving him hundreds of dollars. Mr. S cried when given this news; he could not believe that a stranger had gone the extra mile for him and how much of a burden was now relieved. Even though I was not directly treating patients, I made a positive impact in my role and never took that lightly.

Remarkably by chance, I had the opportunity to experience the “aftermath” of a case and was able to be involved in a different way. For few months during my time as office manager, I also babysat Mrs. Z's foster children. They were three out of seven children of a schizophrenic mom and abusive dad whose parental rights were revoked. Mrs. Z. often complained that they were cold, ungrateful, aggressive children who "didn’t even care when their cat died of cancer”. However, the day after the cat’s passing, the middle child came home shouting for his cat; I watched his eyes gradually dim as he realized that his pet was truly gone. He asked me why cats don’t have cemeteries and what happens to them in the afterlife. Through keen observation, I saw their soft hearts work in little ways, such as when the oldest asked me for money for candy from a vending machine, which she used to buy me a treat as a "thank you” for taking them out that day. 

Though, at first, the kids would  immediately retreat to their rooms after school, I took the time to visit their rooms to greet and hug them. Over time, they came to anticipate these gestures. Mrs. Z. was astounded when all three began to initiate hugs when it was time for me to leave. As I gave them space to share at their own pace, I realized that just because they hadn’t cried didn’t mean that they were ambivalent towards their cat’s passing; just because they did not explicitly say ‘thank you’, didn’t mean that they were ungrateful for the lunch outing. They had been formed based on their life experiences and expressed things differently, in a way that required more observance. The effects of paying attention to people,  allowing them to share on their own terms, and understanding that they may present or express things in a unique way are critical pillars to medicine. For successful treatment, patients need to feel validated by their providers, be part of the decision-making, and have trust in their physician and the progression in their health.

These experiences throughout the years reinforced my desire to pursue medicine, though I struggled through my time as an undergraduate student. Recognizing the need to improve, I tackled my weaknesses, excelled in my studies, and earned a masters in biomedical sciences. I took and retook the MCAT. Currently, I am a medical assistant for over a dozen physicians that specialize in orthopedic surgery, sports medicine, pain management, and podiatry. I enjoy interacting with patients, working with the various doctors, and even studying the physical exam tests, diagnoses and procedures I encounter on the job. Each day, I implement the skills that I have cultivated throughout all of my past activities, especially my dedication to the patients' best interests and listening to the unique story of each individual.

Towards the end of 2021, my younger brother received treatment for his wrist after a tennis injury by one of the orthopedic surgeons in the practice, Dr. Goldberger. I had discreetly approached the billing department prior, asking them to give me the bill instead of my parents, for my family does not have health insurance. When Dr. Goldberger caught wind of this, he ensured that my brother’s treatment be regarded as professional courtesy, free of charge. He showed me the impact of physicians truly caring about their patients and patients’ families.

The interactions and experiences I have had and continue to have foster my goals and desire to pursue medicine. They have illuminated the benefit of giving others the chance to express themselves and hear their stories, while observing what lies beneath the surface. I work hard to be like Dr. Goldberger, as I have witnessed patients that he treated periodically for different injuries and ailments over the years vocalize their complete trust in him.  Rather than be a financial burden, I will continue harnessing traits to serve as a resource for patients to achieve the best version of themselves. I am prepared for the next step, not just to achieve, but to excel in my pursuits.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Earlier this year, as a newly employed medical assistant (MA) in a practice with pre-dominantly Jewish doctors and patients, I encountered a Hasidic Jewish patient, ‚ÄúMrs. B‚Äù, who hesitated upon seeing me when I called her name from the waiting room. Then, simultaneously, we noticed that we were both wearing lavender head covers and laughed. Now, she and I effortlessly catch up at each office visit, as she loves to show me family photos. _x000D_
_x000D_
Further, I have served as the bridge between my primarily Arabic-speaking parents and the communities I grew up in. I am a non-traditional applicant with years of successes and failures, dedicated to a lifetime in medicine, and dedicated to being the bridge between patients and medical knowledge._x000D_
_x000D_
My role of teaching and advocacy will also extend to the Rush and Chicago community. I look forward to embracing differences, discovering similarities and growing in perspective through interactions with fellow students and colleagues.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: One New Year‚Äôs Day, a friend and I were walking behind an elderly couple with their grandson on our way out of the movie theater. Suddenly, the older woman fell forward on the concrete; her glasses shattered, leaving her face cut and bloody. Instantly, I ran to her and¬†supported her head on my lap as I instructed my friend to call the police. I tore a piece of fabric from my hijab and used it to apply pressure. I asked the woman questions to assess if she was oriented in order to discern whether she tripped or if there was an underlying medical reason for her fall. I assured the husband and grandson, and asked them about the movie they watched to distract from the overwhelming commotion. I continued care until first responders transported her to the hospital.¬† The experience reinforced my faith that I was on the right path to become a physician and inspired me to continue learning so that I am even more prepared for potential, similar emergencies in the future.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
Months into my position as office manager at Jersey Forensic Consulting (JFC), COVID ensured. I led the transition to remote overnight, preventing disruption in patient care. The pandemic halted activities, including monthly soup kitchens. The shutdown enabled me to focus on the MCAT and work and forced me to evaluate medical school candidacy, while leading me to the decision to go back to school to prove that I overcame the weaknesses that caused my undergraduate academic performance to fluctuate._x000D_
¬†_x000D_
Despite my dad's hospitalization with COVID, complicated by pre-existing issues, I excelled in the Masters program. In the last 2 weeks before my first MCAT, COVID struck both of my grandparents in Egypt. Heartbroken, my practice exam scores dropped, as did the real score. I am grateful that everyone‚Äôs health was restored.Later, I became a medical assistant but only left JFC once my successor was ready to be office manager. Additionally, I retook the MCAT in June of 2022.

personal_statement:
We were in overtime, and the stakes couldn’t have been higher. Whoever scored next would win the game. The ball was in our half, and I was covering in our defensive shape. As soon as we won possession of the ball, I set off. As the midfielder, I was the balance between offense and defense. It was my responsibility to drop back and push forward. It was my duty to cover the entire field. That day, I made myself open for a pass down the sideline, took a quick scan, and played in the pass for the game-winning strike. The next thing I knew, our bench cleared, and I was wrestled to the ground by my teammates.
Playing in the midfield goes far beyond soccer for me. I not only play in the middle; I live in the middle—at an intersection—and from that space, I embrace the different worlds that surround me. By appearance, I am an Arab. By voice, I am an American. By culture, I am an American, a Palestinian, an Arab, and an Israeli. My being is the direct product of multiple cultures and one world.
Medicine also represents an intersection—of sciences, academic disciplines, methodologies, treatment modalities, and cultures. Physicians strive to understand every patient who walks through their doors. They provide a level of service that not only meets professional needs but also recognizes cultural differences. Physicians touch the lives of people from all over the world and must be prepared to give the specific treatments those patients need.
This hit home in a new way during a week of celebrations in my family. My sister Amani was getting married, and all my family, scattered across the world, came to Alaska to attend. My other sister, Nashwa, and her husband, Taher, were among the family flying in from Israel. On the third day of festivities, Taher woke up with an extremely rapid heartrate, and we rushed him to the hospital. The emergency department only allowed one visitor, so I stayed in the car. Taher was otherwise healthy and only 35, making it unusual that he was having these symptoms. As I sat and waited, Nashwa sent me photos of his EKG readings. I had seen EKGs before but only knew basic rhythms and the characteristics of p-waves, QRS complexes, and t-waves. I tried to analyze his rhythm, so I could give Nashwa some comfort, and although I wasn’t sure of Taher’s diagnosis, I could immediately tell his results weren’t normal.
Taher was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation (a-fib), and this experience inspired me to become a cardiac medical assistant (MA) as a step on my journey to medical school. As a cardiac MA, I provide Holter monitor studies, report critical EKGs, collect pacemaker transmissions, and communicate with nurses, schedulers, technicians, and providers. I have also learned from our patients and begun to understand how much more there is to treating a patient than medicine. Some patients need translators, for instance, while others have never used advanced technology or are uncomfortable putting on monitors.
One such patient was terrified of her Holter monitor she had just received. “I have no idea why I’m even getting this and don’t want it to be affecting my heart,” she said, in a faltering voice. “My heart recently felt like it was going to beat of my chest because it was going so fast. I don’t want this to speed it up faster.”
I was initially confused by her fear, since the monitor was harmless, and unsure what to say. Then I placed myself in her position— as someone who knew something was wrong and was vulnerable and reliant on others for answers, like my sister and Taher had been in the ER. I explained to the patient that the device would not give off an electrical impulse but would only read her heart rhythm. I shared with her how my brother in-law used a monitor, like the one she had, to further analyze his a-fib. She relaxed and decided to wear the monitor.
Shadowing physicians, and volunteering at Ronald McDonald House Charities, have also exposed me not only to the problem-solving aspect of medicine but also to the personal connection needed to treat each patient’s unique needs. Dr. Mamikunian, an otolaryngologist, and Dr. Zumbro, and ophthalmologist, introduced me to their specialties and surgeries, including tonsillectomies and LASIK, respectively. More importantly, they showed me how to communicate medical knowledge within the medical community and with patients of different cultural and economic backgrounds. Physicians are professional and empathetic to each person’s needs, and they build relationships with patients that extend through post-op visits and beyond.
My goal in pursuing a career in medicine is to use my multicultural background and life experiences to connect with all patients and treat them to the best of my ability. Physicians are problem-solvers, responsive, there to listen, and able to tailor their healing methods to each patient’s needs; something that fits who I am and something that I haven’t found in any other profession. As a physician, I am confident that I would enjoy the problem-solving aspect of medicine, and that my background would enable me to empathize with my patients in order to provide them with the utmost care.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: During my junior year, I visited impoverished South African townships for a soccer mission. Azoma, was one of the soccer attendees I was coaching, and when we first met, it was difficult to communicate. Azoma was reserved and hesitant in his answers when I asked him what his hobbies were. These types of questions felt uncomfortable because of our distinct upbringings. However, after a couple of days of soccer camp our bond grew stronger, and it felt like I knew Azoma for years. Even though we looked and grew up differently, we found common ground when we kicked a ball together. Soccer was our muse and our discussions regarding soccer opened the door to other topics as each day passed. Working together and sharing meaningful experiences was a way for people in South Africa to connect with others in their communities, and Azoma taught me this. People like Azoma inspired me to look for common ground between myself and others who represent different cultures, languages, and identities.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I volunteer as a soccer coach for the 90+ Project. 90+ offers soccer training and equipment to under-resourced urban youth and has become a medium for me to connect with diverse populations. While coaching, I began to further understand what it meant to be from an underserved community: individuals do not physically have the resources to reach their fullest intellectual, economic, or health potential. As a coach, I prioritize understanding these differences and adapt my communication and service. I believe soccer can be used as a tool to make a positive impact in my players‚Äô daily lives and in their social and structural determinants of health. Thus, while I coach, I strive to use soccer to promote a spirit of community, develop character, and enable anyone to reach their fullest intellectual and athletic potential ‚Äì regardless of their economic or cultural background.
7_-_COVID_Impact: My initial plans for the summers of 2019 and 2020, prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, were to first join a research internship and then become a medical scribe. The "staying at home" mandates and the restricted job market provided few positions for my plans. I also prepared myself to only take one gap year, where I would be working throughout the 2021-2022 application cycle, but my focus on trying to fit in my other opportunities forced me to have to take at least two gap years. Finally, in the summer of 2021, I was able to secure a research position on a novel drug treatment for Huntington's Disease. After my summer research, I became a cardiac medical assistant. The pandemic has challenged me emotionally and mentally, allowing me to be more adaptive and prudent. My delayed experiences have become blessings in disguise, because I was able to solidify my medical interest and take the time to bolster my personal, professional, and life experiences before applying to medical school.

Hrdshp_Comments: Growing up undocumented affected almost every aspect of my life. From not being able to attend school field trips and not participating in any extracurricular activities throughout childhood and adolescence to living in constant fear of exposure and deportation. My father, who was the primary source of income, worked sporadically, and we were always on the free lunch program at school. Living without health insurance meant that most of our ailments were treated with home remedies, and my immediate and extended family avoided encounters with hospitals due to the potential cost and threats. Because my parents had limited education, they were not able to help my siblings and me much with school work or processes such as applying to college. Once I got to college, I struggled to find a community and connect to campus since my peers did not share the difficulties I faced. I commuted and stayed home as often as possible, resulting in me not experiencing a typical college experience. Aside from the challenges of living undocumented in America, I was fortunate to have a loving and supportive family that always encouraged me to improve academically. Drawing from my experience, I want to create better opportunities, resources and safe environments through culturally appropriate care for disadvantaged populations.
personal_statement:
My tío knows everything about any subject. Once he comes across information he thinks is true, he can’t be convinced otherwise. While this is mostly humorous in our family, his stubbornness is less entertaining when it comes to his health. Like many men in Mexican culture, he avoids seeking healthcare, not out of fear, but because he is, of course, too macho to be persuaded to change his ways. Not to mention he sticks to habits like drinking 6 cans of soda a day and eating high cholesterol and high sugar foods. While it is easy for me to become frustrated at his continuous detrimental habits, I can’t help but feel sad that I haven’t found a way to encourage him to change his lifestyle to improve his health. I have encountered patients who, like my tío, have not learned to be conscientious enough to improve their health and not get carried away by myths. It was during a health psychology class that I began to tie together the instances of my life when I saw the health of those close to me suffer due to a lack of education and self-awareness. Volunteering in health and mental health workshops in my community helped me see the power misinformation can hold and how it can perpetuate dangerous habits and lifestyles. I want to be a physician who serves communities like my own and who can collaborate with men like my tio and women who shy away from seeking the help they desperately need due to the many social determinants of health. I hope to bring my perspective to this field and return to my community to work to shift the narrative around medicine.
My mom once told me about her friend whose oral cancer was discovered after an oral surgery. Rumors spread among my family and friends that going to the dentist gives them cancer, causing them to stop going to the dentist altogether. Even though I knew this was not true, I wasn’t able to speak confidently on the topic because I lacked the knowledge and experience. I consulted with my physiology professor, who was an M.D., and he taught me the language to explain that the trip to the dentist could not have caused the cancer. Equipped with the scientific and culturally appropriate explanation, I was able to spread accurate information with more credibility by using the same method that perpetuated the rumor in the first place: word of mouth. With the knowledge and experience I’ll gain in medical school, I will work to prevent the spread of misinformation by using public health strategies to help people in underserved regions make good choices about their health. As a member of the community I can begin to rebuild trust in healthcare through community health efforts and working individually with patients and families in marginalized populations.
Having grown up hearing and living by the teachings of my church, I learned to treat people with differing beliefs with a high degree of respect. This shapes the way that I approach others in all settings, but especially in medicine. While working the front desk of a clinic I had a patient who came in wearing a face mask that said “against my will,” making it clear that she did not agree with wearing a mask. Part of my job was to enforce safety guidelines during the pandemic, but I tried to always behave professionally and with sensitivity to everyone's beliefs. Even if they had an opinion I did not agree with I saw no need to argue, I listened attentively and sometimes even learned something new. It was and will continue to be important to me for patients to know that I respect their opinions. Even if they have differing opinions I never want to be dismissive since ultimately they are the ones in control of their health decisions. I want to be humble and attentive to what my patients have to say to build up that trust that leads them to better health outcomes without disrespecting or imposing my beliefs on them.
Being undocumented, I have become aware of the countless barriers to access in healthcare and education. It starts with something as minimal as asking for a social security number on check-in forms to providers being insensitive to the specific legal, financial and cultural situation of the patient when treating them. These small instances can lead the patient to refrain from being open with the provider, resulting in a delay of their care. I have heard many family members and friends say they didn’t speak openly to their doctors because the doctor simply didn’t understand them. I was very impacted on an occasion when I attended a graduation ceremony and the class speaker mentioned in her speech “My legal status does not determine my character.” I have always had lingering feelings of unworthiness for the style of life I have here in the United States and often refrain from letting others know my legal status because of an unconscious fear that they’d make up their minds about me without actually knowing me. I have since applied what the class speaker said that day to my life as I hope to apply it to my medical practice: I want to create a safe space for those like me where they will not have to worry that their livelihood is in danger for sharing with their doctor and where they can speak to their provider knowing they will be listened and attended to with the proper dignity and respect.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Up until high school I had mostly been surrounded by people who shared my culture, whether it be at my home, school or church. Even though UCSD was only 30 minutes away from home, there was a drastic change in the people I interacted with and my perspective on the world changed as well. I was caught off guard by the puzzled looks when I shared my experiences or customs and even more so by the differences between my perspectives and those of my peers. I found myself wanting to learn more and expose myself to more outlooks on life. Attending university gave me many valuable experiences and opportunities, but one of the most important to me is the realization that by learning from others and listening to their points of view is how we can grow and create environments that foster individuality, collaboration and a high degree of respect for one another. I want to build on this more by serving Chicago‚Äôs diverse communities and learning from them how to provide equitable and excellent care.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: When I tutored for a free community program I saw the effects of educational disparities on the well-being and academic performance of the kids. As a tutor I was involved in working to improve the program and was later given the opportunity to be the program coordinator. I constantly looked for ways to motivate the tutors, encourage our students and obtain better resources. I was moved by the improvement in the students I tutored and their excitement in seeing it themselves. Too often in Latino culture there is a belief that some people just aren‚Äôt cut out for school and I sometimes heard the kids express these sentiments about themselves. By consistently telling them that they were capable and providing the extra help they needed I was thrilled to see them begin to believe in themselves and achieve the goals that initially seemed too far. I want to keep being involved in uplifting disadvantaged individuals and using my knowledge and experience to serve them in any way possible.
7_-_COVID_Impact: At the start of the pandemic all my volunteer opportunities ceased. I was fortunate that my job in a primary care clinic did not close, but the constant changes in protocol and safety concerns made it difficult to do our jobs. In 2020 three of my uncles passed away and the pandemic made healing difficult with impacted funeral homes and long wait times. After this I had to adjust to online learning in my post bacc program with the added pressure of a full course load of upper division science classes. It was difficult to not be able to bond with my classmates as we would have in person. While the pandemic created stressful environments for me, I acknowledge the immense loss and difficulty that others experienced as a result of it and I am grateful for the opportunity to continue pursuing my goals.

Hrdshp_Comments: Growing up without a dad, I taught myself many lessons about being a good man. My mom did what she could to maintain a stable household but battled unemployment, hypothyroidism, and many other challenges. I largely supported myself financially since I started babysitting at 14 and, at times, have had to raise my mom alongside myself. Without public assistance and generous individuals, I do not know where we would be. A different landlord would have evicted us years ago, and the woman I babysat for did not need to buy me my laptop for college. Without a Pell Grant and Bright Futures Scholarship, I would have stayed home and attended community college. When my grandfather died of cancer in June 2018, he left my grandmother in financial ruin with immense debts to the IRS. I spent huge amounts of time after his death preparing her for the end of the national CDC eviction moratorium on August 26th, 2021. His death offered my mom the freedom to pursue her first passionate work and start her climb out of a mountain of debt. Attending school in Miami was my blank slate, but without a car I was isolated to campus and unable to pursue regular clinical opportunities. I navigated college and medical applications alone as a first-generation student with the resources offered by the Fee Assistance Program.
personal_statement:
Twenty-four years ago, my mom was a pregnant teen all on her own. Despite every reason to pursue abortion and with nobody by her side, she selflessly chose to give up so much of her life to raise me. She always gave enough love for two parents and made the most of what little we had. The challenges we faced due to her lack of college education taught me to take nothing for granted and appreciate the opportunities that education provides. Though I cannot repay that sacrifice or return her to the prime of her life, I vowed not to let her efforts go in vain and to tread a path in which I could positively impact those who need it most.
We dealt with unstable access to affordable healthcare, which at times has been a major obstacle for us both. When I was 12, my mom and stepdad divorced, leaving me with incomplete dental care that would worsen over the years. The troubled teeth in my mouth served as a constant, aching reminder of the realities of life without affordable healthcare.  Knowing I am among the minority living in one of the most prosperous nations on Earth, it bewildered me to imagine how debilitating illnesses must be for those without access to healthcare. Seeing the humanitarian efforts of Doctors Without Borders/MSF and other aid workers on Reddit rooted a desire to learn more about the world and leave an impact where it is needed most.
Years later, while studying abroad at the University of Hull, I attended a presentation with MSF nurse Andy Dennis. He described the miraculous recoveries he witnessed patients make and the tremendous victories that would not have been possible without their efforts. What impacted me most, however, is the story of one young girl who, despite all the best judgment calls made, eventually succumbed to Ebola. The image of her makeshift palm frond cross will forever resonate with me. I felt fortunate to be made aware of the horrifying realities countless others face. He showed me the stunning disparity in health and medical conditions worldwide and the massive impacts possible for a relatively low cost. Reflecting on life's fragility, I understood that failing to pursue a career in healthcare could realistically translate to lives lost. With tears in my eyes, I shook Mr. Dennis’ hand and thanked him for giving me absolute faith in the path I planned to pursue. He inspired me to bring this platform home, and I began hard at work founding the Friends of MSF at FIU. It is a student organization I hoped would inspire my peers and raise awareness surrounding public health crises and humanitarian efforts.
After graduation, I was eager for more exposure to medicine and the day-to-day hum of the real world. Scribing full-time in a breast cancer clinic has awarded me both. Walking through the oncology floor is a humbling experience that instills gratitude for life into me every day. The hope and resilience demonstrated by patients in the most challenging moments of their lives is incredibly inspiring. Attending goals of care conferences for terminal cancer patients offered me an appreciation for just how much patients and their families look to physicians for support and guidance. I was touched by how the doctors provided comfort and relief by focusing on the positives of pursuing a peaceful passing in which the patient’s loved ones could accompany them. Without their physicians’ concerted efforts, the patient’s family would have been much more likely to "Full Code" the patient, pursuing unreasonable lifesaving efforts that would only bring more pain. This experience brought me back to the loss of my grandpa to terminal lung cancer and the lengths my family pursued to keep him from hospice. I am sure that only as a physician will I be in the strongest position to fight for patients and their families, even if that fight means advocating for a peaceful passing.
Long train rides offered me ample time to reflect on my motivations. I have found that efforts made toward improving patients' lives are always worthwhile. Scribing has embedded doubts that any other career will keep me as satisfied and motivated as advocating for patients as a physician. Though my passion for preventative medicine will never leave me, I appreciate with equal importance the extra six months awarded to a terminal cancer patient. I am eager to discover the new perspective and lessons offered by each specialty and facet of medicine. Patients need someone to fight for them. Medicine allows me to advocate for patients, empower them to make substantial changes in their life, and learn from them. The variety of patient encounters often leaves me grappling with my mortality. I feel constant reminders of the sanctity of life and the importance of cherishing each moment and experience. I am left dumbfounded when I try to perceive the magnitude of suffering prevented for patients and their loved ones over a physician’s career. That is a monumental impact that I would be proud to leave.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I was raised by my single mom and grew up around my sisters, grandmother, and their pink appliances. I have been frequently labeled as a "feminine" man for not conforming to many gender norms men are often expected to. Female friends compliment my ability to pick up on subtle cues of discomfort. Without strong male models, I largely taught myself how to be a strong man through literature, rap music, video games, and Reddit forums. These sources exposed me to perspectives and realities very different from my own. As a minority in my predominantly Black high school and Hispanic college, I experienced different cultural values and connected with people unlike myself. I gained awareness of my own privilege and found the confidence to face uncomfortable conversations. Engaging with a mutual sense of humanity has helped me be vulnerable with new people, create more intimate relationships, and achieve deeper insight into the experiences of the people around me.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
Through my work with the Friends of MSF I exposed my FIU peers to the extent of preventable deaths worldwide, which only cemented my own strong desire to pursue a global health pathway. The COVID pandemic became a focal point of conversations, illuminating how unprepared the world is for infectious diseases, particularly in developing countries. We emphasized that public health decisions should never be politicized and that more discussions surrounding social determinants of health and health policy reform are necessary. Most of all, efforts should be made through evidence-based, patient-centered policies and through community-guided efforts facilitated by physicians. _x000D_
I also mobilized the Friends of MSF at FIU in various fundraising, advocacy, and volunteering efforts. I organized trips to visit detained immigrants at the local ICE Detention Center in order to provide a dose of humanity to people who may have not seen a loved one for months or years.
7_-_COVID_Impact: COVID prevented the FoMSF at FIU from ever having an official in-person meeting. Despite immense efforts, we eventually had to make do with a virtual environment. Also, all 6 of my roommates began occupying our 4 bedroom house at all times. We were constantly subject to everyone‚Äôs habits and messes. Staying on top of chores and conflict resolution was very important. Tension rose in confinement, especially with our varying levels of concern for COVID. Volunteering and shadowing opportunities also became limited, affecting my ability to serve the community and limiting FoMSF at FIU's ability to engage members sharing these intentions. My mother and grandmother faced limited employment opportunities during this time and relied on me even more than usual for monetary and physical support. Specifically, my grandmother's eviction was delayed by the COVID eviction moratorium. This helped her stay home longer, but also meant I had to return home for long periods to help her move.

personal_statement:
“I’m open!” yelled my cousin, Mateen, as he ran towards the makeshift goal demarcated by mismatching flip flops. I kicked the soccer ball as hard as I could, and dust collected around me. As Mateen climbed the neighbor’s fence to retrieve the ball, he fell and gashed his leg against metal protruding from the fence. I sat by his side as my brother ran to get help. My family and I were visiting my aunt in Mafinabad, a small Iranian village. The nearest doctor was miles away in the city, so my aunt tended to his wound at home. The next morning, Mateen was running a high fever and had to be driven to the hospital by another relative. Over the years, I was reminded of the hardships Mateen and his family faced living far from medical centers in Iran, which often led to delayed treatment. Recognizing the negative impact being medically underserved can have on an individual’s health, I started seeking opportunities that allowed me to learn more about medicine and what a physician’s role can be in addressing these issues for their patients.
Inspired to one day address the common barriers patients face in accessing medical care, I decided to explore medicine as an ED scribe at BWMC. My perspectives continued to be challenged as I witnessed patients sitting in overcrowded waiting rooms for several hours before being seen by a provider. Often, those same patients were treated for chronic diseases that had worsened due to a lack of preventative care or proper insurance coverage. I remember preparing diabetes education materials for “Ms. Jay,” a young woman with a history of uncontrolled diabetes who visited the hospital twice in one month. She was uninsured, unable to afford her medication, and worried about the effect that inadequate access to care would have on her health. As a single mother of two, she found herself struggling to raise her daughters while looking for work. I felt frustrated by her situation, knowing that the challenges she endured involved more than just the cost of care. She required a different social, physical, and economic environment to reach her full health potential. Experiencing the healthcare system from the perspective of patients like Ms. Jay encouraged me to consider how public health advocacy could be integrated into effective healthcare. The reality of what I witnessed as a scribe is that the role of a physician often extends beyond medical care to this critical intersection between public health and medicine. To further build upon my understanding of social determinants of health and bolster my ability to serve as an informed patient advocate, I pursued a Master of Health Science at Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health.
During my graduate studies, I continued to immerse myself in the complex and interrelated socioeconomic, racial, and ethnic factors that influence community and population health while volunteering at a food pantry in Southeast Baltimore. Through this experience, I refined my awareness of how a lack of access to affordable healthy foods and organized transportation can contribute to poor health outcomes. While food giveaways offered a temporary solution to the problem, the underlying causes of food insecurity remained to be addressed by meaningful systems- and policy-level changes. In viewing medicine through a public health lens, I fostered a profound desire to diagnose health problems, determine their root causes, and implement effective interventions. As a physician, I will use my platform to address the health consequences of outdated policies and programs, minimize adverse health effects, and maximize health benefits for all patients.
Part of what drew me to medicine was the opportunity to form interpersonal connections to make a difference not only medically, but by evoking trust and confidence through cultivating relationships. As a medical assistant at the Maryland Pediatric Group, I was able to take my responsibilities further and build deeper connections with patients. I remember meeting “Mia,” an 11-year-old patient due for her vaccines. To help ease her worries, I shared how I overcame similar fears and explained how vaccines train the immune system to recognize and fight “the bad guys.” I was overjoyed when she discovered the shots hurt less than she anticipated and hopped off the exam table for a hug. Moments like this reinforced the importance of listening to the needs of each patient. Looking toward the future, I want my patients to feel that they can confide in me and trust that I have their best interests in mind while being present in their most vulnerable moments.
My clinical, service-learning, and educational experiences strengthened my resolve to become a physician by showing me the impact of healthcare at an individual and community level. Through seeing medicine across a broad spectrum, I understand that patients like Mateen face significant barriers to healthcare. As a doctor, I will play an active role in advancing patient health and reducing health disparities through advocacy and community engagement, particularly among marginalized and underserved groups. I am continually motivated to become a physician as I will have the opportunity to make critical decisions, empower patients, and be directly involved in their care.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: During my public health studies in India, I met with Dr. Malagi, the Chair of Ayurvedic Medicine at Kasturba Medical College in Udupi. This was my first time learning about Ayurveda, an alternative form of medicine that originated in India several centuries ago. While used as a complementary therapy at times in the U.S., Ayurveda is the standard of care in many parts of India. Prior to this site visit, I had broadly associated medicine with Western medicine. This experience emphasized the importance of understanding that not everyone views medicine and disease in the same way. I came to appreciate that as a future physician, I may have patients with diverse views of disease pathology, and who may not be in agreement with many conventional treatment options. It is essential that I continue to remain open-minded and respect my patients, and seek to fully understand their preferences, needs, and values. Providing equitable care means ensuring care is culturally sensitive and responsive.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Through service-learning, I have partnered with different community leaders committed to creating a positive impact in their communities. During one of my service-learning projects in Baltimore, I met an elderly gentleman who had previously experienced homelessness and could not access job opportunities and healthcare due to a lack of permanent housing. He explained why the economic landscape of Baltimore contributes to higher rates of homelessness and how he plans to raise awareness about its challenges. After hearing his story, I became even more motivated to seek additional opportunities to support his mission. As a graduate student, I volunteered at a food pantry in Baltimore and organized weekly food giveaways for people experiencing homelessness and food insecurity. Staying engaged in community outreach has enabled me to better understand various external factors that impact people‚Äôs lives significantly. I have also learned the importance of nurturing community relationships.
7_-_COVID_Impact: In March 2020, my final quarter as a graduate student moved online, which required adapting to remote learning. I continued to volunteer with Thread and the Alzheimer's Association, while also focusing on my MCAT since my original test date was canceled in response to COVID-19. Instead of holding in-person tutoring sessions at Magellan, I met with students virtually in order to help them set and attain their learning goals. I learned to implement creative strategies to increase student engagement and retention in online courses. I made it a goal to ensure that each student felt heard and understood while adjusting to their new routine. Prior to the start of the pandemic, my current position as a data analyst at Microsoft was in-person; however, it is now fully remote. I found greater purpose in my work as a result of the pandemic, considering the implications of automated clinical note curation. Furthermore, one of my shadowing opportunities in 2021 was halted due to COVID-19.

Major_Long_Desc: Neuroscience (concentration in Neurobiology); Liberal Arts (self-designed focus on addiction)
personal_statement:
"Waaa! Waaa!" Oh no! How do I console this crying toddler? It was 5 P.M.: snack time in Daya Dan, an orphanage for underserved children with physical disabilities, mental disabilities, or both, located in Kolkata, India, run by Mother Teresa's Missionaries of Charity. Mayu, a two-year-old, refused to let me feed him milk. In my teenage ignorance, I initially thought that reasoning with Mayu would calm him down. I explained to him in Bengali that drinking milk would keep him strong. Unsurprisingly, Mayu kept on sobbing. Since reasoning with Mayu didn't work out too well, I decided to simply soothe him. I patted his smooth head and exclaimed, "Shaat, shaat" (this is a Bengali phrase to calm babies). After I had jostled his wobbly cheeks, he stopped crying for a few seconds, so I thought I would finally be able to feed him. I was wrong. Mayu burst into tears and bawled uncontrollably. Nothing seemed to work. I couldn't bear to see him cry. He had no one to call to his own. As I grieved about Mayu's dire situation, I laid my head down on Mayu's arm as he sobbed from his highchair. Surprisingly, Mayu stopped crying, took the milk bottle from my hands, and started drinking. He drank the milk and patted me on the head just like I had patted his head a few minutes back. What a turn of events! I sensed that he understood that I was crestfallen, and thus he patted my head to make me feel better. I witnessed how empathy can lead to a positive outcome. Had I not put myself in Mayu's shoes, Mayu probably would not have connected with me and maybe would not have taken his milk. At Daya Dan, besides feeding children, I washed their clothes, transported them, and helped exercise them. My experience at the orphanage was significant for me as I found providing compassionate care to people with physical or mental disabilities to be very fulfilling.
 
Volunteering at Daya Dan during the summer before my senior year in high school inspired me to pursue a career where I would care for people suffering from ailments that are handicapping or preventing them from achieving the quality of life they desire. During my last semester of high school, I learned of a shadowing opportunity that would take place in the summer following graduation. I had not shadowed a physician before, so I was curious to see whether the duties of physicians matched what I wanted to do in my career. Following a sports medicine physician and an orthopedic surgeon gave me a close-up view of how physicians' care improves patients' conditions. I observed the restored functionality in patients during their surgical follow-up appointments. Seeing physicians' high impact as leaders of healthcare teams on enhancing the well-being of patients struck a chord with me. I realized there's nothing quite like the sense of fulfillment that results from leading a team that works together to heal patients.
 
With a strengthened resolve to care for those with disabling conditions, I entered college with the motivation of addressing an issue that's causing widespread disability in my community: substance use disorders. The opioid epidemic, in particular, has devasted the lives of numerous individuals and their families throughout the nation, especially in Ohio. Determined to address this issue among students at the University of Cincinnati and surrounding underserved communities, I helped lead multiple substance abuse prevention and harm reduction organizations. Upon graduating from college, I continued to address substance use disorders in southwest Ohio by serving in substance abuse prevention and treatment organizations.

A particularly memorable experience I've had while promoting substance abuse prevention techniques was at a church in Lower Price Hill, a diverse underserved neighborhood in Cincinnati ravaged by the opioid epidemic. I helped organize a "Family Fun Night" event to bring the children and adults of the community together to learn about safe prescription medicine practices. We first connected with people at the event by learning about their daily lives and having pizza with them. Afterward, we presented cards with colorful illustrations of various medication practices and actively engaged everyone present there by asking questions and leading discussions. As a result, we educated the participants, especially children, in an appealing manner. Upon witnessing the children's enthusiastic participation, the church manager gratefully explained that we were role models in a community where substance abuse among adults was rampant. It struck me how teaching concepts in a simple manner can have a beneficial impact. This revelation further inspired me to become a physician— a healer who connects with and guides patients and cooperates with them to facilitate their healing.

Inspired by my transformative experience at Daya Dan, I have continued to engage in experiences that have strengthened my desire to heal those with disabling ailments. These experiences and my rigorous academic pursuits have given me a strong motivation and foundation to persevere through medical training. As an aspiring physician, I hope to provide compassionate care to my potential patients and help alleviate their suffering from their illnesses and disabilities.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As an Addiction Navigator, I helped patients who had substance use disorders or were at risk of developing them. A specific patient I interacted with came to the hospital due to extended constipation. Upon screening him, I discovered that he was addicted to pain medications from his previous surgery. Initially, I was afraid I would not be able to connect with him since I am a young person from a relatively well-off suburb, whereas the patient was an older person from an underserved Appalachian county. I, however, did not let our differences hinder my care for him. I empathetically explained to him that I understood the hassle and stigma of treating addiction but that preventing his addiction from spiraling out of control was imperative. As a result, I successfully convinced him to seek treatment at an addiction treatment center. From this experience, I learned that having empathy toward others in distress can substantially help them, even if their backgrounds differ from mine.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I hope to contribute to Rush‚Äôs commitment to improving the societal and structural determinants of health in Chicago‚Äôs west side neighborhoods with my interest in encouraging individuals to appreciate each other's diverse backgrounds and thought processes. When I was the Diversity Council Chairman of my residence hall complex in college, I impacted the complex‚Äôs community by planning events that cultivated inclusivity among residents. One such memorable event was "The Culture Cookout," where residents immersed themselves in appreciating different cultures by learning about different customs and tasting various cultural foods.  Inspired by this experience, as a potential medical student, I hope to build bridges between the diverse students of Rush Medical College. Appreciating each other's varied experiences will, in turn, help us understand Chicago‚Äôs west side neighborhoods better and thus inspire us to serve compassionately as healers and advocates of equity in these neighborhoods.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
I have been fortunate not to be severely affected by the COVID-19 pandemic._x000D_
_x000D_
Professionally, I declined an offer to be a Resident Advisor at a university residence hall during the 2020-2021 academic year out of concern for my family's health and my health. I was also accepted into the competitive Office of Graduate Education Summer Undergraduate Research Fellowship program at the University of Cincinnati College of Medicine during the summer of 2020, but the program was virtualized._x000D_
_x000D_
Upon seeing people's lives in turmoil during the pandemic, I volunteered to help those in need. For example, I scribed for community-based COVID-19 vaccine clinics during my time with the Mercy Serves AmeriCorps program. As an aspiring physician, I hope to draw upon my experience serving the underserved during the pandemic to connect with my future patients and help them navigate the barriers that may prevent them from receiving the care they need.

personal_statement:
When asked to imagine a doctor saving the life of a patient, few people will picture a primary care doctor scolding a weary, disheveled man too young to have experienced a mid-life crisis. But after the fifth time ‘Rodney’ returned to our exam room at LifeLong Medical Care to have his right leg wound debrided and dressed, it became clear that was exactly what Dr. E was doing. Rodney had already lost his left leg to a combination of uncontrolled diabetes and osteomyelitis. Depression and apathy stemming from Rodney’s first amputation and sustained status as houseless had eroded his motivation to practice self-care. Now, his medical non-adherence resulted in our fear that his remaining leg would follow the same trajectory. As a scribe, I initially felt impotent sitting behind my desk, desperate to know enough about medicine and wound care to help the man ten feet in front of me. However, my tenure at LifeLong taught me that there is more to treating patients than the practical application of medical knowledge. 

When I took introductory Organic Chemistry, I first learned the extent to which every physical process can be broken down into increasingly smaller components. After peeking behind the curtain of the building blocks of life, I realized my desire to understand biological systems at the smallest level. I was no longer satisfied with simplified or abridged explanations. Three weeks into the course, I filed a petition to change my major from biology to biochemistry. Later in college, when I discovered Bioethics Debate Club, I realized my need to know the underlying ‘why’ behind everything extended beyond physiology to the thoughts and behaviors of people. I learned to see things through someone else’s lens and uncover the values, biases, and motivations that are often the source of conflict and misunderstanding. 

I saw the value of this insight into the human psyche as Dr. E patiently worked with Rodney to understand his history of non-adherence. Hoping to emulate Dr. E’s attentiveness, I began keeping a journal of patients’ notable life changes to better engage them next visit. I yearned to surmount my preconception that scribes should be inconspicuous shadows and felt a small triumph whenever I was able to distract a nervous patient by coaxing a story out of them. This juxtaposition of the human and academic sides of medicine solidified my goal to combine this newfound avenue of healing with my desire to be at the forefront of the medical field.

Making volunteer calls at Sanctuary Hospice also let me work within my limitations to help people. ‘Rose’, the granddaughter and now live-in caregiver of one of our patients suffering from dementia, had for the past two months appreciated my weekly respite calls as disruptions to the monotony of pandemic-induced isolation. One afternoon, however, when she returned my initial greeting in an uncharacteristically distant voice, I knew something was wrong. She abruptly broke into tears and took a few tries to start her next sentence. She confided in me that she had been sexually assaulted, then lapsed into a panic attack. When Rose told me that she had been unable to share her trauma with anyone besides me, her essentially anonymous weekly confidant, I was struck by the gravity of my position and the potential impact of my next words. I was terrified of saying the wrong thing, but I knew I had to push past my hesitation in order to provide the kind of help Rose needed in that moment. Doing this gave me a glimpse into the similar duty of doctors to prioritize a patient’s needs despite any personal trepidation.

I began by walking her through grounding techniques. Over the next hour, our conversation evolved to her anxiety about finding post-graduate work as an artist, then to the curiosity about musicians sounding better on a recording than in concert. Later that day, I resumed studying physiology but found my thoughts returning to our earlier conversation. While I felt a sense of pride after helping Rose find even a momentary respite from her trauma, I struggled to cope with my inability to alleviate the suffering that would surely dominate her immediate future. This was my first lesson in accepting my limitations while resolving not to let this deter me from providing any kind of aid to my fullest capability. 

Growing up, I sustained a genuine if unrefined aspiration to become a doctor. It was not until scribing at LifeLong Medical Care that my enduring love of medicine crystalized into a passion. My time here has elucidated a drive to work for patients like those in East Oakland, where I can return some degree of equity to the lives of those often overlooked by our healthcare system. Rodney eventually got his infection under control and kept his leg. Though it was impossible to ignore his remaining myriad of social and medical issues, I learned to take satisfaction in the small victories, owed that day to Dr. E’s determination to heal rather than fix. After the umpteenth patient exclaimed to her some variation of “I’m so lucky I found a doctor like you,” I realized that is what I want above all else. I want to be a doctor that patients feel lucky to have found.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Scribing at a Community Health Center illuminated how my privileges shaped my preconceptions about the role of a patient. I expected every patient to comply with their doctor‚Äôs instructions because I had been raised to do so. Instead, I saw patients not completing their labs and imaging and not tending to their infected wounds. Talking with patients and learning about their lives over many visits uncovered that a lack of financial resources or an inadequate social support system were most often responsible for any medical non-adherence. Single parents in a chaotic household cannot simply stop walking on their wounded leg because a doctor says it is necessary. It is almost impossible to prioritize one‚Äôs blood sugar when one doesn‚Äôt have stable housing or guaranteed meals. I learned to be conscious of the ways in which someone‚Äôs situation and background can limit their choices. Practicing medicine with empathy requires meeting people where they are and adapting your care to their needs.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
Making respite calls to isolated hospice patients and their caregivers while volunteering during pandemic-induced lockdown addressed a critical factor of social health: people need other people that care about them. Many people‚Äôs social support systems were crippled by the effects of COVID-19, especially those who were unfamiliar with contemporary methods of virtual communication. My conversations every week let Sanctuary‚Äôs Hospices‚Äô patients vent, receive compassion from someone who cared, and feel connected to the rest of society._x000D_
_x000D_
Teaching 1st-grade Hispanic students how to read in an underfunded elementary school made me confront the marginalization faced by children in families without social capital. Watching my three students progress over the year underscored the uphill battle of social integration. I believe that providing one-on-one support with Fatima, Katy, and Manny let me have a small impact on the inequity in our education system.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Like many others, I mourned the cancelation of my various plans for exciting extracurriculars and athletic competitions following the pandemic-related closures during my last year of college. My final collegiate national climbing competition, my national Bioethics Bowl in Boston for which I had been preparing for months, and my graduation trip to rock climb in South Africa, all gone. While I spent my fair share of time lamenting lost experiences, I am thankful to have had a stable household to which I returned in March of 2020. I was fortunate to secure various opportunities to serve my community, gain hands-on clinical experience, and reaffirm my passion for medicine.

Hrdshp_Comments:
Since the time my family and I immigrated to the United States, we have been on Medicaid. As a family of four, our yearly income averaged around 18,000 dollars. I am also a first-generation college student, who received Pell Grants throughout my undergraduate career. My mother is a housewife, so the only source of income is from my father, who began his career in the United States as a taxi driver. 

Given our poor financial situation, we often struggled to pay off the rent. Some days, we would need to request financial assistance from our friends and relatives. On other days, my parents had to attend court hearings to avoid eviction. 

During my middle school and high school years, I often struggled to obtain basic school supplies like calculators and notebooks. I would also opt-out of class trips that would require payment.

But surprisingly, I did not see my family's financial struggles as a deterrent to how I approached education. I was a witness to how steadfast my parents were in their commitment to giving me and my brother a proper education. Much of my father’s conscientious character and my mother’s persistence have rubbed off on me. And I utilized these characteristics to persevere through my early educational years, no matter the circumstances.
personal_statement:
“The ultrasound of your liver shows that it is in the early stages of cirrhosis. If you do not make amendments to your diet, your liver will cease to function.” My patient nods her head up and down, pretending to understand the physician’s words. 

I translate his warning into Bengali. But despite her being the one diagnosed, I was the one who felt the world crashing down. 

Although she received such a life-changing diagnosis, “Ann” still refused to follow my dietary recommendations. As her personal caregiver, I felt inadequate. If I am unable to better the life of a single patient, how can I possibly hope to become a physician and manage hundreds of unique patients at once?    

For the first week following the diagnosis, I felt waves of anxiety as I thought about Ann’s deteriorating condition. Naturally, it would have been easy to blame her. After all, I had tried to convince her and was willing to do anything to make her condition better. But she remained non-compliant. It was tempting to go down that line of thought. But I couldn’t label Ann as the “lazy” patient. 

The more I thought about it, the more I realized that I truly was the inadequate one in this aide-patient relationship. But not in the way I initially thought. I was not inadequate in my persistence to better her health. I was inadequate in my approach. The reason why Ann refused to follow my guidelines was that it had no identity. It was a generic plan, crafted for the average patient with late-stage liver damage. It was not a plan crafted for Ann, the elderly lady who loves to consume her traditional Bengali dishes. After a month into my role as her caregiver, I realized that her food preferences were something she had been accustomed to her entire life. Having spent decades eating the same dishes, it would naturally be difficult to suddenly stop. Especially when the advice is coming from someone she barely knew.  

In my new approach, I recommended there be subtle substitutions to her diet. For instance, changing the type of oil used to olive oil. And later on, changing the white rice to brown rice. To my surprise, Ann was much more accepting of this idea. And although the diet was not exactly what I would have preferred, it was something much healthier. 

In the end, what helped Ann was not nutrition science, but someone who understood her and her needs. The power of connecting with patients and using that to give the best possible care was extremely attractive to me. And I wanted to understand how this would manifest in a more formal clinical setting. At the time, my best option was to work as a medical scribe for Dr. Moise. He is a geriatrician who helps run a small clinic in an underserved area of Brooklyn. 

One of my most memorable moments as a scribe was regarding a patient with deteriorating sensory nerves in his hand. During one visit, when the patient began talking, I noticed no new concerns. The exact complaints had been documented the previous week. So there I sat, dumbfounded, while mindlessly typing whatever the patient was saying. But to my surprise, Dr. Moise was unshaken and explained that the patient would not lose the ability to move his hand, but he may lose his sensation in that area. It’s an explanation I heard before, but Dr. Moise did not seem bothered repeating it for the second time.  

After the visit, he disclosed to me that the patient had dementia. And he had been coming to see Dr. Moise for the past few months, multiple times, about the same issue. The patient had no close family members to look after his condition, hence the repeated visits. He then continued to tell me stories about the patient, the initial visit, and his circumstances. I was blown away by the details he conveyed to me. Even as a scribe, I wanted to achieve a similar level of understanding.

So the next time a patient told me their story, I did not dare take them lightly. Each story has major clinical utility by providing a small gateway into someone’s life. And to be a better scribe it was essential for me to utilize those stories during patient visits. Doing so, I was able to view the patient in their entirety and not mindlessly type words, but transcribe with intent. 

The connection that I’ve personally built with Ann, although significant, is but a fraction of what Dr. Moise has been able to accomplish over decades of his practice. How can one person have such a thorough understanding of so many people? This is what leaves me in awe, and pulls me to medicine. I, too, wish to cultivate a community that entrusts its lives in me. And I hope to answer that trust by making every clinical decision an individualized decision, which considers the patient’s unique pathological state as well as the story of how they arrived at that state. As a physician, I do not want to just understand medicine; I want to understand people.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
When I completed 4th grade, my parents abruptly decided to leave the U.S. and return to Bangladesh. _x000D_
_x000D_
I transferred to ‚ÄúScholastica,‚Äù an English-medium school where Bangla was ubiquitous. Despite being able to speak Bangla, it was not something I was accustomed to regularly doing. Another major shift in this new environment was the formalities that students were expected to follow. Every morning, we had to sing the national anthem in a school courtyard in a highly regimented manner._x000D_
_x000D_
Just as I was getting used to the Bengali lifestyle, my parents decided to return to the United States permanently. Upon my return, I knew I had brought with me a more refined work ethic, a greater understanding of the Bengali language, and a newfound appreciation of Bengali culture._x000D_
_x000D_
I am bound to meet people whose views/habits may be different, strange, or unfamiliar. My ability to successfully engage with such diverse individuals will undoubtedly take me far in my future career as a physician.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
Working as a medical scribe, I have encountered uncommon scenarios that were challenging to navigate. In one such case, I worked with a patient who presented for an initial visit and was requesting refills for his medication. _x000D_
_x000D_
The issue was that all his medications were previously managed by his correctional facility, where he spent the past 26 years. As such, he could not recall his medication's exact names and dosages. _x000D_
_x000D_
I worked with the clinic's social worker and contacted the correctional facility in an attempt to obtain the medication list. Eventually, we were redirected to the facility's pharmacy. After much discussion, it turned out that it would be impossible to get medication information through a phone due to HIPPA. Per the facility's request, the social worker and I helped prepare a letter to the correctional facility to obtain a medication list for the patient. The patient recovered the information within two weeks, and his medications were sent.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Aside from having to abruptly end many of my ongoing activities/experiences for 2020, COVID-19 has not significantly affected my life. I am very fortunate to have a supportive family who has helped me adjust to the pandemic. Moreover, once the pandemic was brought under control, I was able to resume work during the 2021-2022 year.

Under_School: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
personal_statement:
As I entered the nursing home for the first time, all I could hear were shrieks emanating from down the hall. It was only 7:00AM, and my first call of the day as an Emergency Medical Technician (EMT).  I approached the nurses’ station and was told to “follow the screaming”. I was dismayed by this response, but I was more appalled by the condition in which I eventually found my patient. I entered the room and found him draped over the side of the bed, with a necrotic left foot and a grubby and soiled bandage that had all but fallen off.  He was screaming in agony over the pain in his left foot, and I immediately rushed over to reposition his body in order to alleviate some of his pain. I then approached the nurses’ station to ask if they could give him some pain medication before the transport, since he was clearly in distress. The nurse responded with “He’s leaving, so it is not my problem”. I was dumbfounded by the response, but kept my head clear as I knew the patient needed my complete focus on his situation. When transferring the patient to the gurney, my partner and I took extra precautions to ensure the patient’s foot was properly accommodated. After arriving at the hospital, we met our patient's son and I felt obligated to explain the condition in which his father was found. I informed him about patient rights, and, as a mandated reporter, highly suggested he find a better facility for his father to stay in. Unfortunately, this trend of subpar healthcare is frequent among the underserved areas of Los Angeles, and witnessing the effects has had a profound impact on how I hope to better my community as a physician. As an EMT, I can only do so much, but if I were a full-fledged physician, I would be able to make a real difference in the lives of those I treat.
A significant part of being an EMT is patient advocacy, as many patients are incapable of advocating for themselves, and can end up getting lost within the healthcare system. Therefore, I have been fortunate to be able to continue nurturing my passion for medicine through serving my community as an EMT. During my time in the field, I have cared for patients of varying acuity. For example, I learned that premature babies require medical air in addition to oxygen and that COVID positive patients generally need additional oxygen as they often de-stat during transport. However, my experiences in the field have also revealed a larger threat to the health of my community; inequality. I have seen how someone’s neighborhood, income, or race can have a greater impact on their health than their pathology. Being an EMT has given me the opportunity to provide patients from all across Los Angeles equal care and attention. Inequality can complicate medicine and the objective role of healthcare providers, and I strive to be a part of the solution, now, and hopefully, as a physician. 
While assisting the Los Angeles Fire Department, many of my patients initially refused transport due to fear or mistrust of the healthcare system. While on scene for a man with a suspected stroke, the patient wanted to deny transport as he feared receiving any diagnosis at the hospital. The man spoke broken English and clearly could be better communicated with if spoken to in Spanish, his native tongue. As the firefighters and my partner only spoke English, it was up to me to interpret. I explained to him, in Spanish, why it was important that he be transported, and why it was urgent that he go, since the medication given for a stroke only works within a short time frame. As an EMT, I strive for all my patients to obtain the care they are entitled to, and that begins with ameliorating medical mistrust. Having a mother who immigrated to Los Angeles from Mexico, and being Latina myself, I can understand the disconnect many patients have with their physician or other medical providers, due to the lack of Latino representation within the healthcare system. I have had countless patients thank me and say how much more comfortable they are, purely because I am speaking their native language. I explained to my patient that I understood his fears, but he required necessary medical attention. Thankfully, he agreed to go to the hospital. Having these significant conversations with my patients has shown me the importance of being transparent, yet firm, all the while incorporating a warm approach in order to keep the patient at ease. I hope to be able to put these skills to good use as a future physician. 
Being able to go to medical school will enable me to succeed in becoming the healthcare professional I have always wanted to be. If given the opportunity to be a physician, I aim to work with underserved communities and minority populations, as I have seen first-hand how affected these groups are by the lack of adequate healthcare available to them. I will strive to make my patients feel seen, heard, and understood, and I vow to provide them with equitable medical treatment and compassion. I have had the opportunity to work in underserved sections of the broader community in which I grew up, and being able to make these modest, but major contributions has reaffirmed my desire to become a physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Growing up, I played club basketball, which required traveling every week to attend games all over the county, allowing me to meet and engage with people who had different lived experiences than me. As I explored my extended community, I became more aware of the various social inequities in my hometown of Los Angeles. Over the last two years, I have served these same communities as an EMT and connected with a diverse patient population. I have seen how limited access to adequate food and housing puts patients at elevated risk for anxiety, heart conditions, stroke, and diabetes. In addition, I witnessed the increased morbidity and mortality throughout the pandemic among the underserved and homeless populations. These experiences have inspired me to work with underserved communities as a physician and address social determinants of health in my future practice._x000D_
