2_-_Challenging_Situation: While working on the ambulance, I arrived on the scene at my patient‚Äôs home and, during my assessment, realized she only spoke Spanish. I immediately switched languages and re-explained everything I had said up to that point. While en route to the hospital, she reached for my hand and thanked me for speaking in her native language. She explained that her healthcare providers rarely can communicate directly with her and that my ability to do so alleviated much of the anxiety she usually feels during these transports. Throughout my last two years serving in Los Angeles, I have had similar experiences with many of my patients. Underrepresentation in the medical field can create barriers among minority populations, and as a first-generation Mexican-American, I aim to alleviate these barriers. As a physician, I strive to use my voice to advocate for the Latinx community and work to provide patients with culturally and linguistically appropriate care.
7_-_COVID_Impact: In January of 2021, I planned to retake the MCAT. However, my exam was canceled six days before testing due to COVID19 stay-at-home orders. Once I could secure a new exam date, I had only a few weeks to re-prepare. To my disappointment, I received the same score on my first attempt. However, I knew I could perform better, so I decided to try again. Unfortunately, despite my wishes for the final attempt to go smoothly, the month before my exam, I had a severe car accident and tested positive for COVID19. The trauma and pain from the accident, paired with COVID19-induced malaise, made it extremely difficult to focus on my studies, but I was determined to stay on track. Though it was a demanding process, I was able to persevere and am proud to have improved my MCAT score. My MCAT experience was less than ideal, but it showed me the worth of staying committed to a goal in the face of adversity, and I vow to remember this lesson as a future medical student and physician.

personal_statement:
If there was one specific aspect I could change about myself, it was my body. I was overweight throughout my early childhood and late adolescence. I felt insecure, disgusted, and hopeless. I was consistently reminded by family, my healthcare provider, and friends of how “fat” and “ugly” I looked. This took a toll on my mental health. I would look at my peers and think, “How can I get skinny like them?” I did not care about having a fantastic physique; I just wanted to feel accepted by my peers. However, I knew being skinny was the only way to be considered. In my eyes, I was nothing. Overall, my confidence was at a record low. I will never forget how my doctor would look at me because it was a combination of anger and concern. In retrospect, I understand why my doctor was frustrated with me because I would not follow her plan. I would only put effort a week before my appointment. 

I was 19 years old when I decided to improve my life. One day, when I looked in the mirror, I realized I was extremely unhappy with my physique. So, I took the initiative to make a drastic change.  I pursued a degree in Biology, so I incorporated the knowledge I obtained to understand how muscles develop fully. I researched and found articles on gaining muscular size and maintaining good heart health. 

Fast forward four years, I am still weightlifting and cycling while still finding ways to improve. I can genuinely say that exercising has been my most outstanding choice. I feel confident, strong, and healthy. My discipline and dedication translated into other parts of my life, such as school, volunteering, and work. I felt compelled to be resourceful, especially for those around me. My father is a disabled veteran diagnosed with various health complications. As his homecare aide, I monitored his health status and taught him how to incorporate and maintain healthy habits. I prepared his meal plans, logged his blood measurements, and walked with him every morning for 3 miles. I noticed his mental and physical health was improving due to the minor adjustments we made together. I was determined to help my father improve his health. I also helped my grandmother start implementing more physical activity in her life because I saw how much it positively changed my father's emotional and mental well-being.

As for myself, I know how it feels to be unable to control one’s eating patterns or understand the benefits of exercise. In addition, I was afraid to visit my healthcare provider because I did not want to be judged by my appearance. Today, I am more aware that people sometimes do not have an effective plan to stay committed because I noticed the healthcare system could lack quality care, weight bias, and stigmas. As a result, I am willing to deliver quality care to my future patients.

My weight loss journey set the path for my willingness to pursue medicine. From the interaction with my doctor to my healthy eating habits, I realized I wanted to help others and bring a more inclusive mindset regarding obesity. Pursuing a medical career would allow me to carry a unique approach to losing weight. I want to provide a holistic approach to improving the lives of my future patients. In addition, I have noticed that people trying to lose weight tend to obsess over results, focus on quick fixes, and deviate from sustainability and health. Essentially, my goal as a healthcare provider is to concentrate on the mental aspects of losing weight because a person’s perspective can impact the execution of the plan. Based on my own experience, I was able to follow the protocol by shifting my attention to internal motives and less on external rewards.

Through my shadowing experience, I was able to shadow an internist named Dr. Uchida. Her days consisted of outpatient clinic, teaching, mentoring, and advising. Her patients tend to be older and have more health complications. Usually, her patients had diabetes or were overweight. I was fascinated by how she was inquisitive and compassionate with her patients. As a result, I desire to learn more about her approach to patient-centered care. I observed and listened to Dr. Uchida focus on screening for diseases and conditions for which obesity is a risk factor. She encouraged her patients to start implementing healthy habits into their daily routines. Her practice reflects my sense of medicine as patient-focused and dependent on a trusted and comprehensive approach.

As I apply to medical school, the one commonality that binds every critical event in my life is how each reflects the importance of patient-focused and compassionate physicians. My goal is to fight against the health risk of obesity with the tenacity and determination that comes from personal experiences. As I look forward to my future as a doctor, I will never forget my roots and always remember the days I wanted to give up on my weight loss journey. I am thrilled to contribute to the future of medicine through my vulnerability, empathy, and honesty. My contribution will allow me to learn about my patients and build a relationship upon trust.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: My job has allowed me to understand people from different backgrounds. The people I work with taught me to be sensitive, understanding, and patient because everyone is different. My ability to put myself in another person's shoes has helped me find ways to work in a harmonious environment. Initially, my goal was to complete my job and go home. However, I realize the power of working in a collaborative environment and listening to your coworker's viewpoints. In addition, broadening my worldview has allowed me to have better communication skills and build strong interpersonal relationships.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Fitness has played a major part in my life because I have developed essential skills, such as discipline, persistence, and consistency. Therefore, these skill sets have transcended my job, academics, and personal life. I have been a strong advocate for implementing healthy habits in my life, such as among my coworkers, family, and neighbors. One of my coworkers struggled with her weight and asked me for advice. We both sat down and discussed ways how she could minimize cravings and be more active. Currently, she is doing very well because she was able to take the initiative and ask for help. On the weekends, we would go for runs, and her stamina has also steadily increased. Her improvements have made me realize that I can influence and impact a person in a positive direction. Therefore, moments like these I cherish dearly because small and consistent efforts will pay off.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The COVID-19 pandemic did not affect my personal life because, thankfully, my family was not affected by the gruesome virus. However, my professional and educational life was significantly impacted by the pandemic. My plan was not to take any gap years, but once I graduated with my Bachelor's, I decided to work as a Medical Lab Scientist for a COVID-19 testing lab. Genuinely, working in a COVID -19 lab allowed me to be part of the stop spreading of the virus. My job allowed me to act by the highest integrity, resilience, teamwork, and compassion standards. In the Winter and Spring of 2020, my university allowed the students to convert to Pass/Fail grades. However, I was determined to keep the original grading system, and I was able to maintain a high GPA. In addition, I was fortunate to find a physician to let me shadow, which helped me understand the importance of quality care between patient and physician.

personal_statement:
As I stood next to the patient, lying on the operating table, I felt a rush of adrenaline, certain my life would never be the same. As I watched the cardiologist place a stent in the patient's carotid artery, I was astonished at the possibility of giving someone a new life in less than one hour. From that moment, I have continued to ponder the miracle I witnessed, a routine procedure which intimately impacts the lives of people, every day. As a high school student, this experience ignited my desire for a career in medicine.
College increased my fervor for the medical field. As I began taking my first genetics class sophomore year, I simultaneously started volunteering with Best Buddies, a program partnering mentally handicapped students with peers from the general student body. Learning about chromosomal abnormalities in class, I came to understand the real-world implications of these biological intricacies. I felt an intensified calling for a career in medicine as my interest in genetics increased and my relationships with these extraordinary students magnified. I realized how a career in medicine would unite my passion for service and love for learning.
The following semester, I studied abroad in Santiago, immersed in Chilean culture. I utilized my nine years of Spanish education to develop meaningful personal relationships over the next three months. I was convicted by the stories the Chileans shared about how their inadequate medical care led to lost limbs from gangrene or childhood abuse due to parents with undiagnosed mental illness. These experiences served to intensify my zeal for a career devoted to medical advancement. This desire led me to Guatemala, where I helped provide dental services and taught public health to indigenous populations. The gratitude expressed by these isolated communities reminded me once more how a career in medicine presents unique opportunities to serve.
Outside of the classroom, I sought to strengthen my personal characteristics that would further prepare me for a career in medicine. I refined my leadership skills by serving as a Lipscomb Presidential Ambassador, a student government officer, and a Lipscomb admissions tour guide. I experienced the joy of dedicated servant leadership volunteering two summers as a Lipscomb University freshman orientation leader.
Seeking to expand my understanding of the variety of careers in the medical field, I began to volunteer at Vanderbilt Hospital. I was selected to volunteer in Vanderbilt’s Level 1 trauma center, which introduced me to high quality trauma care and exemplary patient management. The patient and provider interactions I witnessed exemplified the importance of intentional physician leadership as well as a compassionate bedside manner.
The enjoyment I experienced volunteering at Vanderbilt led me to apply for, and be awarded, an opportunity to pursue research at Vanderbilt Medical Center. Unfortunately, due to unexpected consequences of the Covid-19 pandemic, this unique opportunity was canceled. Refusing to allow the unexpected circumstances brought forth by the pandemic to interfere with my interest in clinical research, I sought alternative avenues of engagement. I secured a position in my genetics professor’s lab, where I investigated the role of neprilysin in triple negative breast cancer. As part of a research team, I gained an appreciation for clinical research. Nurturing cell cultures, analyzing proteins and coordinating with other labs throughout Nashville, my regard for the various treatments available to patients today intensified as I grasped the “behind the scenes” work necessary to produce safe and effective management plans. 
After graduating college, I have strengthened my understanding of healthcare teams, by working as a medical scribe. My understanding of the medical field’s complexity has expanded as I assist in a multitude of ways that extend beyond the transcription of medical charts. Helping medical assistants collect vitals and uploading new information to patient profiles has matured my understanding of each employee’s vital role and shown me the interconnected nature of the clinic's daily operations. As I assist the provider by relaying patient information or new instructions to various team members, I have witnessed how a physician’s duties transcend the exam room, to entail responsibilities including communicating with pharmaceutical companies, submitting insurance requests, and hiring new employees. Discovering how doctors look out for patients not only in the exam room but also as advocates within leadership and administrative roles has solidified my decision to pursue a career in medicine. 
From the onset of college to my current position as a medical scribe, my determination to pursue a career in medicine has only intensified. I am convicted by the endless ways a career in medicine would provide opportunities to enhance the lives of others daily. Through experiences like cleaning crash carts in the ER, providing healthcare to the underserved, and serving as a leader on my college campus, I have prepared for the demands of medical training. I am energized by the thought of a career characterized by limitless learning, and daily opportunities to improve the lives of others.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Studying abroad in Chile, I developed a heightened empathy for people experiencing cultural changes as I adapted to an unfamiliar environment. While in a rural Chilean town, I connected with a local family after their toddler wandered over to my table at a coffee shop. Using my Spanish fluency, we bonded over a mutual passion for climbing, and I was invited to join their climbing trip the next day. I appreciated how our mutual climbing interest brought us together, creating a desire to learn more about the lives of one another. Our cultural differences seemed less like obstacles, but rather a unique benefit of our igniting friendship. After spending the next day on the mountain, I was honored when I was invited to the family‚Äôs home for a traditional dinner, unique to their small community. This friendship demonstrated how relationships with people from diverse backgrounds enables deeper interpersonal understanding and offers deeply enriching experiences.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I have actively pursued creative avenues to support my Dallas community. Volunteering at my local church, I provide childcare during church services, assisting with preschool aged children who only speak Spanish. Working with these young children each week, I find great enjoyment providing reassuring consistency when children are dropped off by their families. Supporting the financial needs of my community, I helped organize a school supplies drive, providing over 900 backpacks for elementary students, and 1400 school supplies kits for grades K-12. Translating for families as they came to pick up their school supplies, I felt a sense of fulfillment seeing the joy on the children‚Äôs faces as they chose their new backpacks or received their school supplies. Working closely with patients from a medically underserved area of Dallas, I connect with Spanish speaking patients as I translate and help alleviate some of the cultural alienation they may be experiencing due to language barriers.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
A disappointing impact of COVID-19 was the cancellation of my research at Vanderbilt Hospital. After a rigorous selection process, I had been excited to begin their immersive clinical research and patient care program. Refusing to be deterred, I reached out to my genetics professor, and joined her triple negative breast cancer research project. Working in the lab strengthened my determination during challenging situations and broadened my understanding of the importance of clinical research. _x000D_
When my grandmother suffered a severe heart attack, I experienced how COVID-19 regulations prevented family members from visiting a loved one in the hospital. As my family struggled to get medical updates, I learned the critical need for informative, compassionate communication, and heightened my sensitivity to the emotional distress patients‚Äô families experience. Recognizing the need for strong partnerships with patients and their families will help me build effective patient coalitions.

Hrdshp_Comments:
I came from  a developing country, Ethiopia. I am living by myself here in America; I do not have any source of financial support from my family members.. Along with my education, I work fulltime/part time to cover my daily expenses. I believe I am the most disadvantaged applicant, because I came from a really poor family even in my home country Ethiopia.
My parents live in a very low standard in the rural region. They do not have any reliable source of income.
Fee_Assistance_Program: Y - Invalid for Application Submission information
personal_statement:
Personal Statement

It has been a huge privilege to follow my childhood dreams although they may have initially seemed unachievable due to many reasons. I was born and grew up in a rural part of Ethiopia, where the living conditions are very challenging. Since there were no secondary schools and colleges in the area, I moved to Addis Ababa to pursue my education. I obtained my first Bachelor degree in Pharmacy from Addis Ababa University. During my academic career, I had a chance to get involved in direct interaction with patients and my community during numerous volunteer activities. I have also brought a new positive atmosphere to my birthplace through educating and inspiring the youth, creating a safer community, and improving health conditions by providing lessons for proper nutrition and improved healthcare service. While doing these acts of service, I began to dream of one day becoming a physician, which I knew would allow me to participate in and contribute to the improvement of healthcare especially those in underserved areas like my community.
 
My interest to join medical school was elevated when I was a fourth-year student at Addis Ababa University. By that time, I was excited to apply to an accelerated medical program designed by the Ethiopian government to train pharmacists and nurses as physicians to overcome a country wide shortage of medical doctors. Unfortunately, my mother became ill, and I was not able to attend. Moreover, my parents wanted me to finish school as quickly as possible so that I could support my family financially after graduation. Because of this, I chose to begin working as a pharmacist immediately upon graduation. Despite growing my career in pharmacy, my interest and motivation in studying medicine did not go away. 
After I moved to the United States, I reflected and recalibrated on my goals and motivation to follow my dream. I focused again on the pursuit of my dream to become a physician, which my application demonstrates in taking immediate action to pursue this career pathway. As evidence for these immediate actions, I have completed a second bachelor’s of science in biology from George Mason University. In addition, I have also completed the premedical graduate-level program at Virginia Commonwealth University to enhance my qualifications for admission into medical school.

In tandem with significant efforts to expand my studies and prepare for the academic rigor of medical school, I have also grown professionally in the fast-paced, high acuity environment of an intensive care unit (ICU) through working as clinical technician in Inova Alexandria Hospital. I have always been fascinated by the way a care team can tailor a specific treatment plan for each patient. Most importantly, I enjoyed listening to and understanding how healthcare professionals discuss the condition of a patient based on their scientific knowledge of the physiological systems of human beings. I always want to have that level of knowledge so that I could use it as a base for improving the health of my patients. Moreover, I have seen and admired the multidisciplinary nature of the practice of medicine, and being a part of this team has been a blessing.

Although working in the ICU was challenging in itself, the first six months of 2020 have been particularly difficult to manage because of the COVID-19 pandemic. Our unit and hospital had a surplus of patients that were critically ill and more unstable than even our high acuity unit has ever seen. It was difficult to follow the regular routine and do all the patient care activities due to so many changes in the procedures for treating COVID-19 patients. I worked night shifts while attending school full time. During the surge of the pandemic, there was a shortage of both staff and PPE, so I worked extra shifts even with my tight schedule to support my team and patients. It was a great honor to be a part of a team that ensured all patients received the care needed even during times of a crisis.

I believe that medicine is the most challenging and rewarding career in existence. I am also convinced that the challenges I will face are nothing compared to the rewards I will get back for helping to make a patient well again. I always want to challenge myself and increase my knowledge, so that I can become a competent professional. I cannot think of any other career outside of healthcare that I would rather be a part of or be more committed to. It is difficult for me to answer the question of why I selected the field of healthcare because for me it is like asking why you need water or air to live!

Healthcare helps to sustain and improve life around the world, and medicine is the central part of this service. Inevitably, I will face many challenges while pursuing my career in medicine, but I believe it will strengthen my character and make me an even better physician. Thanks to the opportunities here in the U.S., I am certain in my vocation to be a physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: My experience in the topics of diversity is not small, I have great deal of experience in working with a very diversified team. As a start, I will share my experience about respect for others. I believe that acknowledging other‚Äôs culture, race, gender, social background, etc. is the mainstream to enjoy diversity. I will try to focus on developing creating awareness in the topic of unity and diversity. Our journey to become a physician starts from here, because eventually in one way or another we will end up with treating a patient from different background from us. So, no matter what race or culture that patient is, we will be responsible for giving service to the patient. In my opinion, we do not even have to go this far when it comes to diversity. If we love and care one another, we will forget the act of discrimination and stigmatization in the first place. Everyone should thrive to build this mind set and act accordingly.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: My previous clinical experiences show my commitments to improve the quality of life of my community. I have started working as a volunteer since I was a high school student at Mother Teresa health centers in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. In addition, I have served as a pharmacist for five years at community pharmacy in Ethiopia that serves low-income people. Throughout my life I am inclined to focus on community-centered medicine and improving the health and quality of life of any community. I will achieve and strengthen the positive attributes of a great physician through my RMC experience. After I graduate, I want to advocate for improvements in healthcare systems and community health particularly in underserved communities. When I say serving, it is not just helping them the way they are getting the service right now. I want to go further when it comes to community centered service and direct patient care.  I want to make changes. One of the areas may be focusing on prevention strategies.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
I was working full time at Inova Alexandria Hospital and going full time school during the early stages of the COVID-19 pandemic. By that time, the shifts were so tough that I couldn‚Äôt get back to normal after I finished my shifts. I took the situation both as a learning process and an opportunity to see such brand-new problem. _x000D_
Second, the lock down had a great negative impact particularly during my preparation for the MCAT Test. I usually prefer to study at the library because I do not have convenient place at home. All the libraries and all cafes were closed, so I tried to study at home even though it was not my preference. In my first attempt, I was working fulltime, going full time school, and studying for the MCAT. Since my scores were low, I have decided to aggressively work on my education career. My decision was to quit my job and apply for post baccalaureate program to strengthen my application and improve my science background knowledge.

Hrdshp_Comments: I don’t remember a time that my family was financially comfortable. Although they tried to hide it by making sure my siblings and I had everything we needed, it was quite obvious to me growing up. We were on Food Stamps and Medicaid up until 4 years ago. We were renting and had to move every 2 to 3 years. The longest I was ever enrolled in a school was at Drexel. My parents did buy a home when I was 7 years old.  However, 3 years later, they ran into more financial troubles which resulted in them filing for bankruptcy. After 2 years of owning a home, they returned to renting. About 5 years ago, my dad left his job at a gas station and bean working as a telemetry technician. The pay raise was much needed but it also led to an increase in our spending since we no longer qualified for government assistant. So even though our paychecks were larger, we were spending just as much if not more due to additional expenses. With the help of family, my parents were able to buy their home 2 years ago. Although we still live paycheck to paycheck, we are no longer classified as being disadvantaged due to low income. To me, not much has changed. There are still some days that I worry about how my parents will pay their bills. But I must say that the stability of having our own home makes it up for it a little bit.
personal_statement:
Some physicians have this big moment of realization before pursuing medicine, however, that was not the case for me. I always knew I wanted a career in medicine, even if I didn’t fully understand what it meant. Growing up, my curiosity in science, teaching, and community service began to take shape when I was in middle school. I was participating in community clean-ups and mentoring programs, while striving to get into the upper-level biology courses. Realizing that I could combine these passions in the field of medicine, I pursued opportunities that would pave the way while allowing me to gain a deeper understanding of medicine. With each one of these experiences, particularly my time as a Biospecimen Collection Assistant and Patient Care Assistant, my knowledge of the field grew, as did my desire and motivation to become a physician. 

For my first co-op at Drexel University, my primary responsibility as a Biospecimen Collection Assistant was identifying individuals about to receive spinal anesthesia and explaining Penn’s BioBank to them in hopes they would donate their cerebral spinal fluid for future research studies. The patients I interacted with were primarily minority patients from underserved communities in Philadelphia. When speaking with them, I often found them to be confused and scared by terminology such as “cerebral spinal fluid” which led them to decline participation. These individuals were already terrified because they were undergoing serious procedures such as hip replacements, and there I was adding another layer of uncertainty to their experience. Overtime, through observing the interactions between physicians and patients, I began to add more lay words and spend more time explaining the entirety of the process to patients. With this slight change in my manors, I was able to build a stronger foundation with my patients which led to an increase in rates of consent. Even though I was responsible for gaining patient consent for a research study, this population of patients may feel the same hesitance when presented with treatments and diagnoses that are unfamiliar to them. This experience broadened my perspective and showed me that the underserved population requires additional guidance in the medical field in order to receive proper treatment.

After graduating with my undergraduate degree, I began working as a Patient Care Assistant. As my current position, it continues to exemplify my passion for medicine and caring for patients. Although I was interacting with patients during my co-op, this time I am providing direct patient care. I take vital signs, do bloodwork and EKGs, help with hygiene care, and everything in between. Every patient, although presenting with COVID, has a different background and treatment plan. The connections with patients and physicians are much more concrete as I see the same people for days and sometimes weeks at a time. The length of their stay gives me the ability to truly learn about each individual patient. The motivation to do this has always been present, but was enhanced greatly after my experience with Mr. A. 

I walked into Mr. A’s room and immediately noticed the layer of sweat building up on his body and the empty, yet still panicked, look in his eyes. Just the night before he had been telling me about his time in Vietnam as I watched him walk to the bathroom, but now it took three of us to change his soiled sheets while he lay there unable to move. Not long after, his rapid decline led us to transfer him to the ICU. On the way to the ICU, the physician was finally able to get in touch with his family and they made the difficult decision to change his status to comfort care. The unexpected nature of his death shocked his family and healthcare team. During his decline, I examined every bit of his chart and walked around with a multitude of questions to determine what went wrong. What was the reasoning behind every treatment the physicians had given him? Why didn’t they seem to work? Why he did he go from a healthy man to dead within two days? The physicians and nurses tried their best to answer my questions, but some were unanswerable. Although not all my questions were answered, my desire to pursue their answers strengthened and I began the habit of researching diseases and comorbidities of my patients and their treatments to make myself more knowledgeable in their care. 

When first deciding to go into medicine, I thought that my role would involve assessing a multitude of symptoms and solving the puzzle to properly diagnose a patient. I know now that it was a naïve way to think. Working in a hospital has taught me that the role of the physician extends beyond simply diagnosing, and that this career requires the ability to be flexible and cater your behavior to your patient’s needs. It also requires physicians to be able to guide their patients through difficult decisions using knowledge accumulated through previous learning and experience. Physicians are lifelong learners of science and lifelong teachers for their patients. As a physician, I can use my desire to be both while having a positive impact on a patient’s life.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
At Beat the Streets, I mentored Philadelphia high school wrestlers ‚Äì a group of primarily Black and Hispanic males. While spending time with the children, I learned more about their lives. We explored differences and similarities in our religions. Not only did I learn about the differences between our cultures, but I also heard countless stories about things that no child should have to face. Even though they faced so much negativity in the world, they saw Beat the Streets as a safe haven. They came to the center to increase their chances of a receiving an education. _x000D_
_x000D_
The children left a lasting impact on the way I would like to practice medicine in the future. As a physician, it is important to be mindful of cultural differences within different populations. Being aware of these differences will allow physicians to treat a whole-person specific to their needs. I hope to take everything those children have taught me and continue to make a safe haven for my patients.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
As a Patient Care Assistant, I interact with numerous patients during each shift. Some are only in the hospital for observation for one or two nights, however, we have some patients who are admitted for weeks at a time. Caring for these patients makes me feel as though I have left a positive impact on them, and therefore the community. _x000D_
_x000D_
There is no better feeling than when a patients eyes light up when giving a someone who hasn‚Äôt brushed their hair in two days a comb or successfully getting bloodwork done on an individual who is a hard stick. That is when all the losses one faces in healthcare diminish momentarily because you feel like you did something good by making a patient feel more comfortable and cared for. Indirectly, caring for these patients also impacts the community. Each and every one of my patients is an active member of the community prior to their admission and caring for them allows them to return to the community and continue on with their role.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Right before finals week of my junior year, the entire city shut down. My last co-op was postponed and my job in the city was closed. Every one of my shadowing and volunteering opportunities that I had lined up were cancelled. After the end of my co-op, I shortly moved back to Philadelphia. My time in Philadelphia from September 2020 to December 2020 was not easy. Classes were online and my volunteering activities were cancelled or online. My retail job had opened with minimized staffing; I was not making enough to pay rent. I decided to break my lease to move home. Many times I had one of my parents walk into my room during an exam or had a sibling ask me a question while I was presenting material. All unexpected situations that would not have been present in a physical classroom. I tried my hardest to ensure my grades did not suffer. I began working as a part-time Patient Care Assistant, but I was working more than full-time hours, limiting my availability for other opportunities.

personal_statement:
BP: 66/44. HR: 16 bpm. Grace’s vitals hovered weakly at this level. Then, her heart stopped. The doctor in the ER called for asynchronous CPR. I turned to the paramedic in charge of my ride-along for permission—and some sort of reassurance—then suddenly found myself standing on a stool beside the patient. The respiratory therapist gave his orders: “Deep compressions at a quick pace.” Instinctively, my hands assumed the CPR position and began pushing. With two other nurses, we performed two cycles of asynchronous CPR. After twelve minutes, the physician halted the rotation and ceased all treatment; Grace’s sister requested to stop all life saving measures. A time of death was called. 
This was not my first encounter with death. I had the privilege of spending time with my great-grandmother; every Sunday, she would take my brother and I to the market and share tteok—rice cakes—and regale us with stories of her childhood in rural Korea. But during one of our last visits, I saw her labored breaths and agonized expression. Even at age six, I knew something was wrong, but felt powerless; in that moment, I wanted to become someone I thought would be able to help her—a doctor.

My experience with Grace reminded me of my great-grandmother and why I originally wanted to become a physician. I also realized there was more to learn. I shadowed ER physicians and surgeons who imparted the importance of adapting to situations and providing personalized care. Additionally, wanting to have a more tangible understanding of how doctors could also advance the field of medicine via research and following my interest in neuroscience, I found an opportunity to gain firsthand insight at CHLA. Segmenting pediatric brain scans at diagnosis, after surgery, and during recovery, all highlighted the healing process and the profound impact medicine is capable of. 
Eventually, my curiosity extended beyond the lab—I wished to experience patient interaction and the human element of medicine. Emergency medicine piqued my interest and after obtaining my EMT certification, I chose to work at an ambulance company focused on assisting the underserved communities of Los Angeles. Call after call, the somber realities of the American healthcare system began to reveal themselves, especially in the most vulnerable communities. Hours-long wait times for available beds and physicians along with ineffective interactions caused by economic, cultural, linguistic, and social barriers were calls I encountered too often. However I viewed these calls as opportunities to not only exercise and build my understanding of medicine, but also extend care and compassion to the community. The long waits were shortened by engaging in conversations with patients and as our interactions became friendlier, they became more comfortable discussing their concerns—medical and personal—which I did my best to address. 
From these conversations in the ambulance, hospital hallways, and psychiatric facilities, I learned nearly a third of my patients were homeless and/or suffering from addiction. Thus during the pandemic, I started as a coordinator at a women’s homeless shelter and a healthcare technician at a rehabilitation facility to further explore the issues plaguing these communities. In both settings I formed connections with the residents, learning their stories of survival and encouraging their recovery. 
It wasn’t uncommon for residents to act aggressively and I quickly had to learn to  de-escalate situations and introduce healthier coping mechanisms. I realized the hostility was typically a defense mechanism developed by patients as a result of their pasts. Together with the clinical team, we focused on helping the clients overcome their trauma rather than simply treating the symptoms.
A portion of my twelve hour shifts was spent besides clients, simply listening to their fascinating or heart-wrenching stories. Recounting their histories not only helped the clients start deconstructing their trauma, but also built rapport between us. Much like my EMT patients, clients often began feeling comfortable enough to discuss more private, meaningful concerns—accelerating their recovery. Through active listening, I was able to befriend the facility’s clients; hearing former clients express that they’ve finally “broken generations of addiction” and “can live a life my kids would be proud of” is an experience more fulfilling than I can put in words.
During my great-grandmother’s final days, I thought a doctor would be able to help by bringing back her health. For years, I believed doctors treated a patient. Now, I’ve realized the physician’s potential extends beyond the individual and continues to benefit the greater community as well. From breaking cycles of trauma and addiction, to combating illnesses, to researching better treatments, a physician’s care and insight can influence society for the better. Many patient interactions helped me see that medicine is more than just treating the signs and symptoms and requires acknowledging each patient holistically. While my clinical experiences have yielded me my own special philosophy and set of skills, I believe medical school is the avenue towards enhancing my knowledge so that I too, may help communities thrive in the future.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
I‚Äôve worked with diverse patient populations from various underserved communities - the homeless, formerly incarcerated, abused, and victims of trafficking - in Los Angeles and from a number of Southern states, providing medical care and offering social resources. _x000D_
_x000D_
At South Coast, our clients vary in every sense of the word: racially, religiously, socially, financially, etc. I perform weekly ‚Äúcheck-ins‚Äù where I assess a client‚Äôs health and build rapport with the clients. During these conversations, I strive to create an emotional connection - discussing their history, goals, passions, and stories. By understanding and incorporating each client‚Äôs personal story, I‚Äôm more capable of creating a higher quality treatment plan.  _x000D_
_x000D_
Through these sessions, I‚Äôve been able to befriend and work with former white supremacists, gang members, prisoners, drug dealers, and victims of violence. I realized beyond any noticeable differences, we‚Äôre all just people trying to live a safe and stable life.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
During the pandemic, Los Angeles County implemented Project Roomkey - an emergency shelter initiative - to provide housing for vulnerable populations, like the homeless, in vacant hotels. As the site coordinator, I worked with nurses, service workers, and guards to ensure a comfortable, safe environment for our residents. _x000D_
 _x000D_
Each shift, I made an effort to get to know each client better and with each interaction, I began to see how health disparities - like the lack of access to healthcare, higher rates of untreated medical conditions, etc - negatively affected underserved communities. I also realized the importance of community outreach programs - by offering medical and social resources for the underserved, I saw the positive impact and change these programs could create._x000D_
 _x000D_
We connected clients with social services, paving a way for permanent housing and employment, and provided medical services. By the end of the program, we helped a number of our clients better their situation.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
Academically, as with most students, classes were switched to an online format which posed an initial hindrance, but I was able to quickly adjust to the change. _x000D_
 _x000D_
In regards to employment, I was actually able to find unique opportunities due to COVID-19. The first was my Project Roomkey Site Coordinator position with the Downtown Women‚Äôs Center. Through the program, I was able to work closely with the homeless population in Los Angeles. The Clinical Affairs Coordinator position was later available due to the extra assistance needed to develop a COVID-19 diagnostic assay purposed to differentiate between the common flu and COVID. These opportunities were special experiences that helped shape my perspective of the healthcare industry and medical field and available with the pandemic.

personal_statement:
The summer after my fifth birthday, I practically started a 9-to-5 job that consisted of jumping and flipping under the beating sun on my newest obsession, a trampoline. Friends and family were constantly talking about how the springs in my feet contained enough energy to fuel a busy city. My earliest memories are full of self-made experiments aiming to resolve the curiosity I had about my physical abilities and limits. Once I had a trampoline, these experiments often ended in a pulled muscle, broken bone, or lecture from my mom. However, each attempt led to more questions than answers, so I would inevitably be back on my trampoline planning and executing my next experiment and the cycle would repeat. By the end of the summer, my mother had no choice but to enroll me in gymnastics classes so I could explore my curiosities in a safer way. Immediately, I became devoted to the sport and dreamed of becoming a college gymnast, like my coach Kellie. Injuries are present and inevitable in most sports, so it came to no surprise when the occasional strained muscle or fractured bone would slow or stop the progress of my training. However, through this, I unexpectedly uncovered a deep and persistent curiosity about the human body, its abilities, and the mechanisms it employs.

By the age of 12, I had an early release from school to practice gymnastics 25 hours each week. I considered my coach and teammates to be my closest friends and, like most kids that play a sport, was convinced of my future as an Olympic gold medalist. I dedicated countless hours to perfect a skill that would give my balance beam routine the highest base score to be competed by any Utah gymnast prior to going elite, the back salto dismount. But one week before competition day, I made one wrong move which resulted in a painfully life changing fracture in my lower back. I will never forget when my doctor calmly advised me to quit the sport to prevent permanent back pain. My young mind quite literally thought the world was ending. Little did I know, my world was changing all around me and holding onto this support system, my team, would be vital for my mental health. 

I continued attending practice, as injured members of the team always did, but often asked myself what I was doing since rejoining my team wasn’t a long term possibility. Later that summer, my mother explained the financial trouble we were in and let me know she was selling our house and using the money to move to Hawaii, and I would be moving in with my father and step-mother. A week later, I found out my step-mother was pregnant. A month later, my mom boarded her flight with my two dogs and I wouldn't see them for another year. Now, at 13, I had an abundance of emotions with no clue what to do with them. Relying on my team and coach was all I could think to do until the new year hit with the devastating news that our coach, my lifelong role model, Kellie, had died over the break due to an undiagnosed heart condition.

Just as I was starting to feel optimistic about my new normal and recovery from my injury, mourning the unexpected death of my 27-year-old role model left me feeling helpless and hopeless. The hardships I had experienced up to this point were often overcome with the assistance of Kellie’s optimism and wise words of advice. Without her comfort, I was left feeling scared and lonely. Only after she was gone did I fully appreciate how influential she had been in my life. The support provided by my teammates and the hours I spent with my new therapist allowed me to cope with and ultimately overcome these challenges. I emerged from these hardships and adversities as a happier and stronger version of myself. I promised to not only carry, but implement the values Kellie had taught me for the rest of my life. 

My experiences working through and recovering from hardships in life have encouraged my scientific curiosities and amplified my determination to continually advance my emotional and intellectual capacities. As much as these various hardships and people have taught me, they have also allowed me to offer a helping hand. These experiences are what constantly drive me to enhance my competency to become an active member of society. The opportunity to be an influential part of someone’s journey to a long healthy life makes this dream of mine so rewarding. While exploring my fascination with the human body and strengthening my compassion and empathy through each experience, I strive to grow by continually implementing my passion into medical school and then within the workplace. The springs in my feet contain enough energy to fuel my desire to use my passion to help others and be an impactful member of society.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As a Hispanic woman who grew up in a predominantly caucasian community, I admittedly had insecurities about my heritage and culture. As my school classes grew larger and more diverse I learned to appreciate the uniqueness of the individual and continue to expose myself to the diverse cultures that surround me. While on the road to medical school, I have been encouraged by the engagement the program at Rush Medical College has with surrounding communities and want to be a part of the culture you promote. I have watched family members avoid preventative care due to a language barrier with their doctors and want to learn from a program that works toward dismantling disparities in healthcare. I will contribute to the communities you serve because I have always had a personal drive to encourage and embrace other cultures and will always aim to lift others while being able to learn from their experiences.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Medicine is altruistic in theory but the way it‚Äôs practiced is what shapes medicine into what it is today and what it can become. In a world of change, medicine has proven to be resilient. The healthcare system that has been utilized for years has developed systemic inequalities and the initiative academic institutions have taken to make changes is so encouraging. At the age of 15, my mom began to experience rapid weight loss just as we were selling the childhood home we could no longer afford. I started a GoFundMe fundraiser in hopes to raise enough to schedule a doctor's appointment for her, and was pleasantly surprised by the support my family received from our community. This experience has encouraged me to apply to programs like Rush Medical College, that prioritize communal involvement and equitable, compassionate, patient-centered care. I want to join your team and the fight to dismantle health inequalities and encourage diversity in healthcare._x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact: The pandemic introduced our world to a new way of living that has made significant impacts, both negative and positive. The unprecedented levels of mental health issues, economic consequences, and the social and health factors that determine these outcomes, help to underscore the disparate impacts the virus has made. As a result of these consequences, there has been a surge in mental health resources, movements for equality, and a commitment from the healthcare industry to diminish existing disparities. Personally, the past couple years have reintroduced my struggles with depression and anxiety, which I thought were behind me. However, because of the interests I have discovered, self-love I have developed, and strengths I have gained, I wouldn‚Äôt have had it any other way.

personal_statement:
Chest tight. Lungs whistling and rattling with each breath. My mother rushed me to the emergency department (ED) in the middle of the night. I was handed a breathing chamber that had a mist forming inside. I cycled through some breaths of the mist, and, within minutes, a wave of relief spread throughout my body; I could finally breathe. I often visited the ED or my pediatrician, Dr. O, when I experienced an asthma flare-up. Appointments with Dr. O felt like I was visiting my auntie: the endearing and compassionate tone of her voice, the exchange of Tagalog between her and my mother. Dr. O's management of my care sparked my interest in a career in medicine.

My ambition of joining the field of medicine matured when I began working as a physical therapy aide. With a background in physiology, I was excited to address musculoskeletal dysfunction. I soon realized a major gap in my knowledge: the human aspect of caring for patients in a clinic. My job in Mr. B's case was to guide him through prescribed knee exercises during his pre-surgical and post-surgical therapy sessions. Mr. B shared that he was determined to walk without a limp. Mr. B, his physical therapist, and I made a therapeutic goal that Mr. B would bend his knee more each time he got onto the stationary bike.

Mr. B's recovery was more convoluted than I had expected. There were occasional setbacks during his rehabilitation that brought him to tears. I could not understand what he was enduring, but I knew I had to comfort him, just like Dr. O comforted me whenever I was ill. I handed him a towel to wipe his eyes and reminded him how far he had progressed since starting therapy. After a few months, Mr. B exclaimed, "Justin! Come look at this!" He was able to bend his knee to complete a full rotation on the stationary bike. At that moment, I felt gratitude for being able to accompany Mr. B on his journey. His rehabilitation underscored that the people I am working with are more than a dysfunction or case study. Mr. B reminded me of the human aspect that cannot be forgotten in medicine.

Volunteering in a bustling ED showed me the diversity of patient presentations and further enticed me to enter the medical field. During a shift in the ED, the doors burst open, and paramedics brought in a patient while they were performing cardiopulmonary resuscitation. With my adrenaline pumping, I gathered supplies and became part of the life-saving efforts. I was humbled to contribute in any way and was in awe of the code team working diligently for the welfare of this patient. My eagerness turned to sorrow when the patient was pronounced dead.

This patient's death was not the result I expected. I was so fixated on the positive outcomes and the praise the care team receives for saving a life that I had forgotten about the unfortunate side of medicine. I know this experience paints a realistic picture of what I should expect as a physician. But rather than be deterred, I am inspired by the compassionate and selfless individuals who worked together to try to revive this patient.

My understanding of how medicine extends beyond the clinic further developed as I volunteered with a clean syringe exchange program. The program provides harm reduction materials and other supplies for people experiencing substance use disorder and homelessness. I engaged with a client who wanted access to emergency opioid overdose treatments and sterile needles. He expressed he was not ready to break his habit, but wanted education about medication-assisted treatment. I sensed his reluctance to speak with me, so I made sure to give him my undivided attention. I provided the education and resources available to him and acknowledged his effort in pursuing these services. He thanked me for this information and appreciated how I did not treat him how others do, like "street scum."

Speaking with this client helped me understand the power of creating a safe environment to facilitate conversations about receiving care. The client felt safe to be vulnerable and empowered to ask for support. Because I did not judge this patient, he felt validated and heard. He might not be at a place in his journey to quit, but the care this program provides equips him with the resource should he become ready to take the next step. This opportunity helped me recognize that everyone has their own background that we need to be mindful and respectful of. It is important to meet people wherever they are in life and to remind them that we will be there to support them on their path.

Physicians function in a unique space where science and humanism intersect. My interaction with Dr. O and interest in life sciences drew me to a career as a physician, but work and volunteer opportunities helped me refine my passion. My experiences demonstrated that managing a patient's care is complex and will not always yield positive outcomes. I learned to be mindful of other people's backgrounds and not be quick to judge. I realized my true motivations for becoming a doctor are to provide compassionate care, facilitate human connection, and empower others through medicine. I am excited to cultivate my passions as I progress through medical school, into a long and worthwhile career.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Interacting with the members of a syringe exchange program has taught me to embrace diversity and use people-first language. Participants of the program are people who are experiencing housing insecurity, substance use disorders, or are engaged in sex work. Society has taught us to associate drug use and sex work negatively, which makes these participants vulnerable and shamed for their activities. The program reminded me how to extend compassion, especially to the people that society rejects. Participants are not defined by their practices and deserve the same respect we give others. Using negative labels such as drug abusers validates the stigma and pushes people away. The staff come from diverse backgrounds and create a welcoming atmosphere to facilitate a community partnership. Through this partnership, we empower and improve the participants' health. The program inspires me to unlearn the stigma and be conscious of my word choice, so that people I converse with feel included.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
Volunteering with San Diego Refugee Tutoring challenged me to build enthusiasm in students who were not engaged in sessions. The program sends kids home when they are not participating, which is detrimental since many of the kids are behind academically. My student, M, came to sessions for social interactions and was dismissed often. While working with M, I discovered his academic struggles fueled his frustration. He was placed in seventh grade, despite his academic ability being below that level._x000D_
Being mindful of M‚Äôs negative association with school, I sought to develop rapport to build his enthusiasm. I began our sessions with our handshake and a general check-in on how he was doing in school. I learned about his various interests, such as soccer, wrestling, and music. To keep M engaged, I integrated his interests into math problems and selected reading material he actually enjoyed. My bond with M blossomed into a friendship, making it easier for him to attend tutoring regularly.

personal_statement:
My Friday mornings often began at 7 a.m. in an industrial-size kitchen where I cut copious amounts of fruit, assembled chicken salad sandwiches, and baked peach cobbler. As a volunteer at MANNA, a Philadelphia-based hunger relief initiative, I prepared medically tailored meals for those with chronic illnesses who were unable to afford a healthy diet. Reflecting upon my service work along with my academic and extracurricular experiences, I have learned that compassionate treatment arises at the intersection of medical assessment and socioeconomic awareness. This perspective has led me to pursue a career in medicine because I will have the privilege of developing therapeutic regimens that extend beyond the clinical setting and take into account social and economic factors that are imperative to well-rounded medical care.

One particular patron I worked with at MANNA dropped by frequently to express his gratitude and ask for recipes to recreate at home. Over time, I learned that he was diagnosed with chronic kidney disease and had recently started receiving dialysis. Although he had access to healthcare through Pennsylvania’s Medical Assistance (MA) program, he could not financially sustain the complex dietary requirements that were part of his physician’s proposed treatment plan. After a few months of receiving nutritional counseling in addition to meals that were low in sodium and phosphorus, he showed improvement in his bloodwork and was living an overall healthier life. Being part of this patron’s journey, I gained insight into the complex relationship that exists between one’s well-being and various determinants of health. This experience has driven my objective to attend medical school where I will have the opportunity to broaden my understanding of the effects of food insecurity on health outcomes and build the necessary clinical reasoning skills to make a larger impact on a patient’s health.

An important component of medicine is the ability to integrate theory and experiment in order to address complex issues in healthcare that impede the provision of quality health care. Through my academic research and coursework, I was able to explore this concept and develop related skills. As a research assistant, I pursued a passion for molecular biology sparked by Cellular, Molecular, and Developmental Biology II, a course taught by my research advisor. By formulating a hypothesis based on specific intracellular protein rearrangements, a topic introduced in this course, I designed successful experiments which helped to explain certain overarching processes that occur in cancer metastasis. While I gained an appreciation for the pathology of disease through my research project, I realized that medicine encompasses more than clinical treatment and that one’s health is influenced by a wide array of factors. Later in my undergraduate career, I expanded my knowledge of the detrimental effects of lower socioeconomic status on health during the core elective course: Interprofessional Healthcare in Underserved Communities. Combined with my experiences at MANNA, I utilized literature presented in class on health disparities to develop strategies to combat and prevent food deserts and, subsequently, encourage healthier lifestyles in underserved populations.

Inspired by my service with MANNA and wanting to explore my interest in the field of medicine, I began to volunteer on the labor and delivery floor at Penn Medicine (HUP) where I assisted physicians and nurses in providing medical care to a predominantly marginalized, urban patient population. During one of my volunteer shifts, I worked with a mother whose newborn was placed in the NICU due to postpartum complications. Like many other new parents I encountered, she was uncertain of her ability to foster a strong foundation for her child due to the social pressures and financial strain she faced in her daily life. As I checked in with her throughout the afternoon, I comforted her by empathizing and listening to her concern for her child’s welfare. I also found that despite not being able to ensure an ideal environment to raise newborn infants, many physicians supported new families emotionally and gave them information on social resource centers and ample supplies in hopes of making a difference. 

My volunteer and academic experiences have led me to recognize the importance of being empathetic towards each patient’s unique circumstances when providing treatment since health extends beyond the hospital. I have also learned that with every effort to fully rehabilitate the patient, there should be an equal emphasis placed on providing comfort along the way; each step to restoring a patient's health is an opportunity to provide support and solace. Attending medical school will provide me with invaluable opportunities to realize my goals and empower me with the crucial skills necessary to practice clinical medicine and ameliorate access to quality healthcare for underserved communities.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
The summer of my sophomore year, I traveled to the city of Visakhapatnam in southeastern India to visit my ancestral home. Upon arrival, I helped my ammamma (grandmother) prepare a variety of homemade sweets for the religious festival of Vinayaka Chavithi to distribute amongst family members. Accompanying my ammamma as she visited relatives, however, I quickly felt out of place. While others chatted about upcoming social events or local political elections, I could neither add to discussions nor articulate myself well enough to engage in conversations. _x000D_
_x000D_
To better connect with my extended family, I worked to improve my oral Telugu with impromptu lessons from my ammamma. As I gained confidence in my communication skills, I developed a better appreciation for my cultural heritage. Speaking to my relatives about their lifestyles and values and sharing my own, I recognized the importance of actively working to understand the diverse sociocultural experiences of others.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: An initiative I have led as a pharmacy technician focuses on improving hypertension medication adherence in high-risk patient populations. A particular patient I spoke with was concerned with his inability to consistently pick up his blood pressure medication. After assuring the patient that I would work with him to address the issue, I described different approaches to improving his adherence including mail services and new prescription requests. By supplying medication guides and requesting a pharmacist to clarify the patient‚Äôs questions, I helped provide the patient with the necessary information to make a well-informed decision. Based on the patient‚Äôs choice, I contacted his physician for a ninety-day supply prescription change to accommodate the patient‚Äôs situation. Understanding that others may be facing similar circumstances, I advocated for supplying all high-risk patients with complimentary pill boxes and informational handouts on the importance of medication adherence.

personal_statement:
On one of the first mornings of preschool, I remember seeing a girl sitting on the playground curb, crying. I knew right away that she needed help, and I went over to sit next to her. I asked if she wanted to see what I’d brought from home, and as I pulled  my favorite stuffed cat out of my backpack, her tears stopped. I have always had an intrinsic drive to help  others, which has grown into my motivation to pursue  medicine. If we recognize and care that something is amiss and take some small action to fix it, we have an opportunity to make the world a better place. I saw this proved as I grew up: helping a friend who failed a Latin test drill words until she laughingly said she could hear them in her sleep, or helping a quiet coworker plan how to meet an exuberant officemate halfway. If one can naturally take a small action on a playground, that could be cultivated into an ability to make change on a greater scale. From my experiences, I know I want to use the skills I’ve cultivated to make change as a physician.

Over my ten years in libraries, I worked with patrons daily to understand their spoken or unspoken needs. While I received satisfaction from this, it didn’t feel like an endpoint for my abilities. One day a firefighter fundraiser accidentally  recruited me into volunteering and as an EMT I discovered a new purpose for my library skills and innate drive to help others: they were a natural complement to hands-on patient care. If the human body’s needs could be identified, it was fixable . EMS added a new dimension: recognizing and correcting the “need” happened on multiple levels at once. I had a frightened patient with an arm fracture at a softball game on an ominously cloudy day: we had to earn his trust before he’d let us examine and splint his arm. He gave a relieved sigh as the analgesics began to work, and we loaded him into the ambulance just as the rain started. I found pride in being part of this team, able to walk into an unpredictable situation and bring solutions. As we left the hospital after transferring our patient, I turned  to my paramedic and asked what came next and what the physician would do for the patient. I loved being an EMT, and always wanted to know more. This was the spark to leave librarianship and become a full-time firefighter/EMT : I wanted to explore medicine more fully.

A year later, my paramedic work partner urged me to consider becoming a paramedic; I jumped at the chance to take greater responsibility in my patients’ care. In the classroom it felt like I was on the right track rising to the challenge; we had a joke that we could do any of our skills in any situation and I once demonstrated a skill station upside down. At the same time, I found myself asking my instructors, some of them physicians, about differences with in-hospital applications: the answers I received brought on more questions, and I realized paramedic might be a step, not the endpoint: I loved medicine and being a paramedic but kept wondering what I might be able to do as a physician.

One afternoon my crew was dispatched for a bicyclist vs automobile accident. We arrived on scene to find the bystander kneeling by our bicyclist patient was our command physician. He reviewed our charts and trained us, but this was the first time I’d seen him in field. He stood off to the side to give room for my crew to work, but as command gave us orders on the spot rather than us needing to radio for them. He then rode with us to the hospital, and in the trauma bay he gave the turnover report himself. I listened, rapt: this was the report I had been striving to give each time I arrived at the hospital. I understood at that moment that while I loved the excitement and challenge of being a paramedic, being a physician would bring the knowledge and resolution in patient encounters for which I was searching.

As I realized this, I questioned if I would be able to give up the adrenaline of paramedic life. To explore a side of medicine I hadn’t been exposed to, I worked as a medical assistant in a primary care clinic, meeting the same patients repeatedly. In the clinic, I assisted with a Lifestyle Medicine course, where participants were coached on small changes to help address chronic medical concerns. I remember walking back into the room of a patient I’d seen several times, both of us smiling as I told him that his A1c was now in the target range. I saw that I had a similar joy to the physician I worked with in building these meaningful relationships with patients. She was the facilitator that helped patients achieve their long-term successes: while different from the excitement of being a paramedic, this was what I wanted to bring to people.

In EMS I discovered a focus for the desire to help others that I’d had all my life. As I brought patients into the ER and shadowed in hospitals and clinics, I learned more and more the impact physicians make  on their patients’ lives. I have seen that there are many small things that can be done to improve the world on a daily basis, and found fulfilment in serving those around me as I’ve developed my medical skills. I seek to further my education and experiences in medicine to better accomplish this: I would love to create change in the world as a physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
My education in other countries taught me not to expect to share a fluent language with others. I learned to find respectful ways to communicate and that even without a common language, there was much that I could understand and share with the people I met._x000D_
_x000D_
In 6th-grade math class, we quickly learned that the quiet Korean girl in our group refused to speak aloud ‚Äì but she was by far the best math student. We communicated in our group almost entirely in numbers: we would push one set of problems to the center of the desk and write out the work, continuing to go around the table until we all understood._x000D_
_x000D_
Supporting one another as we embrace our differences allows us to benefit from one another's strengths. I remember feeling fortunate that I was with a supportive workgroup and that we had welcomed a communication method that met all of our needs. This experience has made me a more efficient communicator and someone who can rally others to meet this need.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
When I joined Malvern Fire Company, I was one of the few new volunteers: most had been part of the company since their teens. As someone in their mid-20s with much focus on my new hobby, I spent my first years working hard on my fire education and becoming the best firefighter I could be._x000D_
_x000D_
Something interesting happened as I did this that I did not recognize immediately. As I continued to study and improve my skills through second-level courses, I found that other firefighters that had been with the company for a long time were suddenly enrolling in second-level classes too. Though not my intention, I realized that my colleagues, not wanting to be left behind, were stepping up to continue to explore and improve their skills._x000D_
_x000D_
I unintentionally became a role model for my more seasoned colleagues. Though this is several years later, I recognize the impact I made and try to continue to provide a good example: I encourage others around me to pursue their goals and positively pursue my own.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
I returned to the US from overseas in March 2020 as states went into lockdown, and rather than move in with my high-risk parents, I moved cross-country to live with my partner. That October, he left on another overseas contract, and I was in a new city by myself._x000D_
_x000D_
I faced the same challenges as other students: volunteering/shadowing opportunities were limited, and I did not pursue health-related work until after my partner left for his contract. But I also had the same opportunities: I thought critically about healthy ways to spend my time, and online shadowing exposed me to specialties I had not considered._x000D_
_x000D_
My biggest takeaway from the pandemic was a greater awareness of the access challenges for the homebound. I was aware when doing home book delivery through Atwater Library in Montreal in 2012 that my job was to address an access issue. However, I didn‚Äôt grasp the range of implications until the pandemic, when I faced isolation myself.

Under_School: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
Major_Long_Desc: Human Nutrition, Food, and Exercise Science
personal_statement:
In the medical field, it can easily be forgotten what it is like to be on the receiving end of medical advice. This is something I was reminded of after an incredibly despairing experience - when I broke my pinky toe. Surprisingly, the most painful part of the experience was not the broken bone, but instead, the emotional suffering that the injury imposed on me. Once I was put on crutches, I immediately felt that I had lost my independence, a trait that I deem highly about myself because it reinforces my ability to be self-sufficient. Undoubtedly, my injury prevented me from accomplishing normal activities, such as walking or taking a shower with both legs inside the bathtub. However, I was stunned when I could not perform actions that are secondhand nature for most individuals, such as getting dressed. While I was extremely flattered by the selfless nature of others by helping me accomplish these meager acts, I wanted to prove, primarily to myself, that I could still function normally despite my disability. Sadly, I quickly learned this fantasy was not feasible. Being disabled made me feel as though I was a mere spectacle due to the immense amount of unwanted attention I received. Typically, I always manage to find a positive aspect in any predicament, but this incident tested my buoyant nature; although, I will admit that crutching around a 2,500-acre campus is a great abdominal workout! Ultimately, I was repeatedly questioning the purpose of this accident. However, as time passed, I began seeing the artistry of this experience because it allowed me to gain a deeper understanding of how patients feel when they are admitted into medical care. The thoughts and feelings of a patient can be watered down and lost amongst the colossal world of medicine because while patients want to be cared for, they do not want to feel on display. Breaking a minuscule bone allowed me to understand the profound impact physicians have when feeling helpless and vulnerable because by physicians exuding empathy and respect, they aid in the ability to regain autonomy, an incredibly valuable quality that can easily be overlooked. 

While I have experienced physical trauma, I have also been on the side of adversity that led to comprehending how emotional agony affects daily functioning. At the end of my first year at Virginia Tech, I experienced the death of my best friend and former swimming teammate. This was my first confrontation with the gruesome topic of death and, therefore, I was bewildered about how to properly handle it. Consequently, the addition of this hardship on top of challenging coursework led me to struggle to succeed in classes. However, as time continued, I learned how to masterfully balance health and academics. As my health flourished, I developed exceptional study habits such as attending office hours, studying daily, and proactively reading forthcoming lectures. These habits enabled me to improve my GPA and thrive as a scholar. Therefore, regardless of any challenge I face, I am confident that I will persevere by implementing an optimistic mindset to focus on the purpose behind each adversity and progress towards accomplishing my goals. 

Although my desire to pursue medicine developed within academic settings, my commitment to becoming a humane and exceptional physician was ignited while shadowing a primary care physician. On my first day, an elderly male patient stumbled into his appointment complaining of excruciating back pain. I saw how the physician meticulously examined his entire body while actively listening to his complaints. Eventually, the physician came to the conclusion that the root of the issue stemmed from their feet. As a young student, I was incredibly enthralled by this finding because I would not have suspected that the cause of back pain could be from the opposite end of the body. This moment perfectly encapsulates the importance of a physician’s role in medicine because it seamlessly integrates a physician’s desire to heal with the art of problem-solving. While I am fascinated with the science behind medicine, the humanistic and investigative side of medicine continuously motivates me to become an influential leader within the medical field. Through my experiences, I have realized that I have the desire and skills to bring trust, empathy, and an inquisitive mindset to medical care as a physician. 

I am a unique individual who enjoys concrete facts yet also believes in abstract ideas such as astrology and karma, but one of my strongest beliefs is that everything happens for a reason. My “everythings” have allowed me to grow into an independent and optimistic person who has learned how to cope with loss, failure, and becoming perseverant. Learning how to maintain hope, losing a friend at a young age, and utilizing a restorative mindset to assist others have all augmented my ability to think analytically and become resilient in the face of adversity.
