I am determined to bring my growing enthusiasm and knowledge to medical school and evolve as an influential individual within the medical community. At the end of the day, medicine is the closest thing to a miracle, and I understand how imperative it is to be the difference between life and death.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: While mentoring underserved students of eastern Richmond, VA, I came to understand that having humility is not a sign of weakness. As I learned about parents losing custody due to drug abuse, six-year-olds wrestling with homelessness, and young students grieving siblings who were subjected to gun violence, I saw that, while I could escape tragedy by turning off news media, that is not an option for these children. This made me recognize and critically analyze how my upbringing selectively limited my understanding of others‚Äô cultural and socioeconomic issues. By boldly evaluating how my sheltered background may have impacted my comprehension of these topics, I have been motivated by a persistent desire to learn more about the challenges that marginalized communities face. I am passionate about cultivating an inclusive environment within medicine by embracing all dimensions of the human condition and advocating for equity.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I recall a patient coming in for her annual check-up. When I asked if she had any concerns to ask the doctor about, she hesitated. She motioned to a small brown spot on her shoulder, but she didn‚Äôt want to make a big deal out of it. I reassured her that even if it turned out to be nothing, it‚Äôs best to have the doctor inspect it. When the physician looked at the area, he took a biopsy, and referred the patient to a dermatologist. The results came back as squamous cell carcinoma, one of the deadliest forms of skin cancer. When I called the patient with the results, she profusely thanked me for my advocacy. My impact on this patient‚Äôs life showed me that medicine encompasses more than an understanding of tangible entities such as the science of diseases and treatments. Instead, it requires empathy, dedication, and curiosity. These are skills I have developed through my experiences and aim to continue augmenting at Rush College of Medicine.
7_-_COVID_Impact: While preparing to take the MCAT (already a stressful challenge), I was simultaneously facing isolation and hearing alarming stories about COVID-19-related illness and death. I felt mentally, physically, and emotionally exhausted when I took the MCAT for the first time. As a natural extrovert who enjoys studying in bustling coffee shops, I grew increasingly frustrated having to study and relax in one stagnant setting. Due to this, I greatly underperformed on my first MCAT try. However, as the pandemic progressed, I gradually learned how to adapt my learning habits to successfully tackle the exam. Although the onset of the pandemic was a frustrating and alarming time for everyone, it taught me how to alter myself and prosper in the face of adverse and unprecedented events. I am confident that I am exceedingly well-prepared to manage unexpected challenges that may arise within medical school.

personal_statement:
The passion I have for medicine and the fulfillment I feel when I am able to help people, although probably not unique among medical school applicants, are completely genuine. I know this because any chance I get to be even remotely involved in healthcare, my motivation and passion are unlike anything that I have ever seen in myself.

Volunteering at Banner Gateway’s emergency department was my first exposure to working in healthcare. At that point I had only shadowed before, and I was never fully responsible for any aspect of patient care. I knew the shifts in a busy emergency department were going to be difficult, but I was not prepared for just how intense they actually were. By the end of my first day, I was exhausted. My feet hurt from constantly moving all day and after I got home, I immediately went to lay on the floor because I wanted to be cooled off. My mind and body were completely drained and yet, my heart was so full. I felt so accomplished with how my first day went. 

Virtually all I did was room patients, answer their call lights, and clean their rooms. There was a moment that I got to see a glimpse of treatment for a critical patient but even then, from where I was standing, I only saw a crowd of people huddled around the bed in the treatment room. But that swarm of healthcare providers working in lifesaving, ordered chaos is an image that still stays with me to this day. 

I started thinking about why I was so elated about handing out warm blankets or only staring at a group of healthcare workers from a distance. I came up with two reasons and they are the same as the reasons why I want to become a doctor: my passion for medicine and my desire to help others. 

I chose to be a pre-med major going into my undergraduate degree because of my interest in medicine. Learning biology and chemistry my freshman and sophomore year was intriguing. However, sitting in lecture halls only allowed me to begin considering a medical career. It was not until I directly saw the application of these subjects in a healthcare setting, that my passion truly grew. Volunteering in the ED, I finally saw how my education was directly related to patient care. I got to ask about the labs and medications being ordered, and I was so elated when my physiology knowledge allowed me to grasp what was happening. There were finally real EKGs that weren’t just practice problems from my homework. I saw how reading them led to actual diagnoses for patients. Most interesting to me was getting to hear doctors’ thoughts during treatment. Whether it was treating a simple ankle sprain or saving a patient’s life, I was so fascinated at how they decided what needed to be done. I went into this opportunity knowing that I enjoyed medicine, but I was surprised by just how much fervor I had for this field.

My desire to good for the world is also the result of my want to attend medical school. This is not necessarily in some grand way though; I do not claim to be some kind of martyr. But I am content if I can just make one person’s day even slightly better. This mindset that has been a theme throughout my entire life. When I was in elementary school, there was a heart disease fundraiser called Jump Rope for Hearts. My teacher explained that donating would help research diseases and help a lot of people who are sick. After I got home, I immediately went for my Buzz Lightyear piggy bank. I had spent a few years saving up that money and as a second grader, that was basically half of my life. However, I was not the least bit sad to donate all my savings. I knew that it was going to a good cause and that I was contributing to the care of others. As I got older, I started volunteering at my mom’s Vietnamese center. I was able to teach Vietnamese and spread the culture in an underrepresented area. Helping second-generation Vietnamese children, like myself, get in touch with their heritage grew my aspiration to serve the community even further. 

This is why even doing menial tasks while volunteering in the emergency department only inspired me to complete my goals more so than ever before. Knowing that my actions could ease their pain, even a little bit, was a life-changing experience. As a young adult, I am still discovering who I am. My values, personality, and demeanor have changed a lot over the years. Recognizing this, I am often hesitant to say things that are extreme or absolute because I might not believe in them anymore as I mature. But the two exceptions to that are my passion for medicine and my desire to help people. These values have stayed with me since childhood, and I will continue to foster their growth in every way that I can through my education and career. I believe that as a doctor, I will have the opportunity to improve the well-being of patients and pursue the life-long process of medical education. I have an insatiable passion for both these values, and that is why I want to go to medical school.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
As an Asian person growing up in a predominantly white area, I was an outsider. The model minority stereotypes I heard from my classmates were dehumanizing. I hesitated to participate in class because I knew I would be ridiculed for answering questions correctly. I believed I had to ignore this ‚Äúdark humor‚Äù to be accepted. But trying to fit in meant I was never able to express myself fully. I was just the Asian guy who wasn‚Äôt offended, the scapegoat for white kids to point to after telling a racist joke._x000D_
_x000D_
My childhood has shown me the unfair treatment people experience when not part of the status quo. In medicine, Latinos, Black people, women, and LGBT people have inequitable care due to biases, socioeconomic disparity, and political attacks. A massive failure of our institutions is giving unfit healthcare to the social minority. As a medical student and future doctor, I will work to make sure none of my colleagues or patients ever feel like they are outsiders due to their differences.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: One way I have impacted my community is by reducing food insecurity. I volunteer for Meals on Wheels through the Gilbert Senior Center. We deliver lunches to people who are elderly, disabled, living in poor conditions or all of the above. I have gotten to know the people on my delivery route well. It gives me gratification to provide them with a meal they can always depend on. I also provided residents in my county with information about COVID while I was a Maricopa case investigator. I collected epidemiological data for the department of health and directed people to resources for food and shelter. These experiences have further incentivized me to pursue medicine because I know that as a doctor, I will be able to help people in ways that align with my passion for healthcare.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I initially did not seek in-person clinical experience or volunteering when COVID began. I was concerned for my family‚Äôs health and mostly stayed home until I was vaccinated. Along with this, I chose to focus my thesis because of the issues that also arose due to COVID. As a result, I lost out on almost a year of valuable experiences. But, I still tried to do as much as I could. I participated in remote public health initiatives like the COVID case investigator for Maricopa County. And now, I have taken this gap year to work in the emergency department and volunteer at Meals on Wheels.

personal_statement:
I have found the most success as a trout fisherman on the Slagle Creek, a stream that snakes its way from Harrietta to the Manistee River in northern Michigan. Every year on the last Saturday in April, my dad and I are here for the opening day of trout season. In the previous 12 years, I can count on one hand how many times I have successfully tempted a fish to run away with my lure. This never seems to be a problem for my father- he always out-catches me. As I grew older, catching fish became less important. Going fishing meant spending time with my dad, who instilled in me his love for the outdoors. When he was diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease, I understood that the future of our active lifestyles was uncertain. I knew I wanted to be a physician before my father was diagnosed as I had spent dozens of hours volunteering in my small-town hospital's emergency room, helping in little ways to care for patients. In the years that followed his diagnosis, my decision to go to medical school became ever more solidified. It was humbling to see the effects of serious illness when it struck someone I loved. Journeying with my family through Parkinson’s disease set my expectations of what it means to practice medicine well. Empathetic, patient-centered approaches to care define physicians who made meaningful impacts on our family. I pursue medicine to take that same approach with others. 

Early on, I learned that Parkinson’s is a complex disease. In the confusion of symptoms and treatment options my family found itself were physicians who took the time to teach us about what was going on. Explaining the pathology illuminates my understanding of the disease, bringing me a sense of peace. I appreciated being drawn a diagram about where Dr. Air was going to place the probes during my dad’s deep brain stimulation surgery. This commitment to teaching brought a sense of empowerment to our family. We learn, ask questions, and come to an understanding of the disease, allowing us to make well-informed decisions. I pursued chemistry education research and teaching opportunities in college to get a grasp of what effective teaching looks like. I applied the constructive teaching and learning strategies shown by my research to my classroom as a graduate student instructor so that students may better understand complex chemical phenomena. I consider the various effective ways to teach chemistry and apply the best techniques based on the needs of the individual student, allowing space for questions and independent inquiry. In doing so, I prepare myself to emulate the example of my father’s physicians in my own practice of medicine.

Accompanying my father on his journey with Parkinson’s taught me to value the empowerment stemming from a caregiver-patient partnership. My dad’s doctors seek to understand him as a human being- someone with aspirations and fears. These relationships were impactful in my role as the family member. In my job as a patient companion in the hospital, I see how valuable these relationships are to me in my role as a caregiver. Taking the time to get to know my patients takes our relationship to a deeper place. I learned that taking the time to form a genuine connection with my patient allows me to understand the life experiences they bring with them to the hospital. I learn their needs and goals, which augments my ability to provide them with personalized care. During one conversation with a patient, I learned that she loved apple juice but could not drink it because it caused her to aspirate. I knew we had a thickening agent at the nurses 'station, so after gaining consent from her nurse, I was able to prepare some thickened apple juice for her, which brought a smile to her face. Cultivating relationships with a new patient every shift is my favorite part of my job. I leave each night wanting to continue to work with patients as a physician, where I can be a stronger advocate for their needs.

My parents brought me up in the Catholic Church. Although I have left behind copious Church teachings, I retain a sense of personal responsibility to accompany those facing hardship, particularly poor and marginalized communities. I thank the Jesuits for this aspect of my life. It was because of the Jesuits that I became so involved with marginalized groups in my own community. In their faces, I saw my dad, who has access to the resources he needs to manage his Parkinson’s disease and nurture a fruitful life. To those for whom healthcare injustice is a reality, I desire to use my privilege as a physician to be an ally for them and with them, working to cultivate a sense of hope and assuring them that they need not face challenges alone. This is the altruism that was shown to my family in our time of need. I feel compelled to return that to someone else. 

My family found hope in the warmth and benevolence of physicians who took the time to empathize with us and the unique circumstances we brought to the clinic. Their patient-centered approach means that my dad can continue to catch more fish than me on the Slagle Creek. I am pursuing medicine to provide the same personalized approach to medicine that I know makes a difference in the lives of those affected by illness.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: ‚ÄúSo, where are you from?‚Äù This was the most popular question at the ice cream social during move-in day my first year at the University of Michigan. In keeping with tradition as a native Michigan resident, I held up my right hand and pointed to a small wrinkle just above my wrist. ‚ÄúAdrian,‚Äù I replied, ‚Äúfarm country.‚Äù My hometown is rural, surrounded by corn and soybean fields or the occasional dairy farm. Growing up in a small town means I am no stranger to rural culture and the challenges rural communities face. That dish of ice cream on move-in day marked the beginning of a new learning opportunity: attending college in a big city. The city and university brought me to worldviews and backgrounds considerably different from my rural upbringing, giving me an appreciation for how others see the world. As a result of living in both rural and urban areas, I feel comfortable interacting with people from both communities and can contribute to conversations about rural and urban life.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: During one of my shifts as a patient companion, I helped to care for an eight-year-old boy awaiting placement in a pediatric mental health facility. He was in foster care, and his patient companion was the only person in the room to engage with him. I empathized with how tricky the situation was for him and tried to find things for us to do to keep him engaged. My mind turned to sports upon seeing his plastic ball. I thoroughly sanitized his bedside commode and turned it into a basketball hoop. We practiced shooting and had a ‚Äútrick shot‚Äù competition. After that, I took a fitted sheet used on the stretchers and finagled it into a makeshift soccer net, and we played soccer. I did similar activities with him over the next several days until he was discharged. I believe that my willingness to engage his mind and body helped ease some of his frustrations about having to stay in the hospital and improved some of the emotional difficulties of his social situation with foster care.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The COVID-19 pandemic did not significantly impact my preparation for medical school.

personal_statement:
Raised by my grandfather, I grew up hearing stories of his defection from North Korea to South Korea just prior to war erupting over the peninsula. In his efforts to avoid living under an authoritarian regime, he guided his family through rocky mountains and turbulent rivers to reach safety. He shared with me his hopes for future generations to help people improve their lives — contrasting from the destructive oppression he narrowly escaped. Hence, when I was born as his first grandson, he chose my Korean name to be “Min-Gi,” roughly translating to “a foundation for the people.” After working in impoverished areas like Victorville, California, a medically underserved city, I have discovered how I can live up to my name’s meaning. My family's history and experiences within the hospices and hospitals of San Bernardino County, California sparked my resolve to serve and empower marginalized communities through medicine.

My first patient assigned to me as a hospice volunteer was “Mary,” a 71-year-old woman with pancreatic cancer, liver metastases, and only three months to live. Entering her home, I was surprised to see that Mary and her family lived in their landlord’s garage, with Mary herself only occupying one small corner. Bedridden, she could only interact with her daughter, granddaughter, and medical staff. I provided her with companionship during such a difficult time, discussing her memories of the San Diego docks during her 20s and reminiscing over nostalgic memories with her to detract her thoughts from her diagnoses. Getting to know Mary for three months, I contemplated the escalation of medical conditions. It became apparent that having an illness was not only a result of diseased tissue but also a culmination of biopsychosocial challenges: deteriorating mental health from stress, lack of social support, and insecure living conditions. My newly discovered cognizance of these pervasive entities instilled my passion for serving vulnerable individuals, and I became eager to provide such care as a physician.

While working as an emergency room (ER) scribe, I was intrigued by the myriad of societal issues subsuming the physician-patient relationship in communities with limited access to healthcare and housing services. During one shift, a 12-year-old named “Aiden” experiencing homelessness came into the ER due to auditory hallucinations and methamphetamine abuse, with psychiatric evaluations suggesting a history of psychosis. Hoping to ensure his comfort while nurses were understaffed, I brought him blankets and food as he anxiously awaited an update. I then saw how my physician kneeled next to him, using simple vocabulary to gently explain the rehabilitation and psychiatric treatment he needed, the patient’s face softening as he chose to trust us. I shared notes with the physician on Aiden’s condition and lab results. The doctor called any facilities he could, determined to find Aiden a psychiatric facility more advanced than the local ones. With Aiden’s successful transfer, I was reminded not only of the empathy a physician must have for patients but also their role in patient advocacy. I became inspired by the opportunity to create lasting impacts for patients undergoing difficult circumstances and earn their trust for the maximization of their care.

While ER doctors work with patients in the short term, I also yearned to understand how a physician creates a long-term, individualized care plan for underserved patients. This led to me serving as a scribe in a private clinic, where I assumed more responsibility by talking to patients over the phone about their medical needs. One morning, I talked to “Deborah,” a 45-year-old woman with colorectal cancer and several comorbidities. Hearing her sobbing, I listened carefully as she talked about her cancer treatments being “in limbo” since she could not reach her last doctor, being from an area with low physician-to-patient ratios. Recognizing this as a precedent issue, I assured her I would bring the doctor’s attention to her case. Despite a busy schedule, the doctor and I went through each concern she presented. For two weeks, I called pharmacies to ensure her medications went through and contacted the oncologist’s office to ensure they received the medical records necessary for her appointment. Successfully obtaining specialized care for Deborah resonated with me as I aspire to use my medical knowledge to critically consider appropriate treatments and center care on relationships with the patient.

Having served on the periphery of the physician-patient relationship for several years and currently gaining more intimate patient experiences as a family medicine scribe, I eagerly anticipate a future in which I am caring for my own patients. Through patients like Mary, Aiden, and Deborah, I know there are individuals without adequate healthcare with unique needs and circumstances. My goal is to be an empathetic, holistic doctor who proactively engages patients while being mindful of their environments. My desire to uphold the meaning of the name given to me by my grandfather holds true, as I heal, educate, advocate, and create a foundation for patients to further build their lives upon.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I participated in the Multicultural Institute Program (MSI), a program for first-year students from various cultural and socioeconomic backgrounds to engage in discussions on social justice. Our lectures focused on the experiences of youth as they constructed their identities within their communities and created a foundation for discussions about oppression students faced. I gained a broader perspective on societal discrimination and realized the importance of providing a safe space for people to share their vulnerabilities. After graduating, I observed how societal challenges impact medicine. As an ER scribe, I met patients afraid their diagnoses would be stigmatized due to their identity, giving me a better understanding of why patients withhold care. I fostered a desire to advocate for all people, allowing them to pursue their interests, uninhibited by illness. I want to encourage discussions on societal injustices and stimulate dialogue to enact change within the medical field.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: My experience tutoring elementary students for the Asian American Tutorial Project has been instrumental in understanding the significance of encouraging those I serve like with ‚ÄúJill‚Äù During a session, she tearfully told me she dreamed of being a scientist but was discouraged due to her struggles with her life science classes. Understanding her frustration, I worked with Jill on science passages not only to help her become more comfortable with the concepts, like cellular organelles and photosynthesis, but also encourage her to continue pursuing her ambitions of becoming a scientist. I remember how Jill became ecstatic when I told her the progress she made was evidence that she could become a scientist. Seeing her grades and hope improve, I learned the importance of motivating individuals to pursue their goals. I want to carry the same lessons as a physician by invigorating my patients to not be discouraged by setbacks and push through obstacles to reach their health goals.
7_-_COVID_Impact: When the COVID-19 pandemic began, I was disappointed that my volunteering experiences were halted. As a result, I felt useless when moving back home. These feelings were exacerbated when my grandmother was diagnosed with COVID-19 after suffering a stroke in a nursing home. Unfortunately, my grandmother passed away later that month and my grief lasted for months. When she was later moved to the ICU, I worried even more about her condition. Amidst my grief, I thought about other families that had lost loved ones due to the virus‚Äô impact on vulnerable communities. Determined to contribute to care for such communities, I began scribing for ER physicians as they cared for underserved patients. I am proud of the impact I had in assisting physicians with their charts, easing their workload, and allowing them to efficiently see more patients. The struggles I witnessed others face with COVID in the ER truly put my own problems into perspective and reaffirmed my interest in medicine.

personal_statement:
I was the kid that always wanted to be a doctor. While I did not understand the difficult decisions, years of school and training, heartbreak, and responsibility that comes with wearing a white coat, I did understand that it represented empathy, conscientiousness, and knowledge. Throughout college, I followed a traditional pre-medicine path where I shadowed and took prerequisite courses. While these experiences reaffirmed my goal to become a physician, I was still searching for a deeper reason to fully commit to the profession.

June 27, 2020, the height of the Covid-19 pandemic, the day before I took the MCAT for the first time, and also the day my life changed forever. My mother had been experiencing shooting pain in her abdomen before she scheduled a colonoscopy. She came home with a procedure report that contained a bleak diagnosis: stage IV colon cancer. I spent the remainder of that night sitting in my room feeling hopeless. The next morning, I took the MCAT, and instead of focusing on the test in front of me, I could not stop thinking about my mother’s health. Thoughts like, “How long until mom isn’t in my life anymore?,” and “Do I need to delay my senior year of college to help the family?,” occupied my thoughts. Thus, it was no surprise that my score was less than ideal.

My mother spent months undergoing chemotherapy. In the seventh month, I woke up to multiple missed calls from my father. I sat on the edge of my bed for half an hour before making the six-hour drive home. When I arrived, she was already in a coma. The next week consisted of driving family members to the hospital and spending a few hours each night in the ICU to relieve my father of his duties. On the third day, a stranger approached me. He knew my name and asked how my senior year was going. As the conversation continued, he asked about my siblings and it became apparent that he was my mother’s doctor. Dr. Kocs’ eyes filled with tears as he extended his condolences, but the moment we walked out of the elevator and through the ICU doors, he became a different person. Dr. Kocs’ effortless empathy quickly became a focused review of the information on my mother’s chart. After a moment, he looked up at my father and I and gently delivered the bad news. “Her liver is shut down, and her kidneys are not far behind.” Amidst my family’s devastation, it was comforting to see that Dr. Kocs was not only an oncology expert but also an empathetic person. The pandemic robbed me of my ability to be by my mother’s side during her time in the hospital, but I was relieved that Dr. Kocs cared for her as a patient and a mother with a life beyond the hospital doors. 

After my mom passed, I decided to give back by working as a medical assistant and scribe at a gastroenterology clinic, as well as learn more about the disease that took my mother’s life. When I interviewed with Dr. Chua, he explained that dozens of patients called his practice every month asking to be seen for a procedure because local hospitals had over a month-long wait before they could be seen. I could not help but reflect on the parallels to my mother's situation. Seeing how he cared about treating his patients regardless of the strain it put on him reminded me of my interaction with Dr. Kocs. When working during clinical rounds, I saw Dr. Chua genuinely celebrate his patients that successfully lost the recommended twenty pounds or made the advised lifestyle change. Seeing how these small connections visibly change patients’ attitudes, and ultimately their health, has reinforced my decision to pursue medicine. 

While bedside manner is a complex variable to operationalize, my experiences with my mother’s care and time spent working as a scribe have shown me that bedside manner clearly affects patient outcomes. A 2014 literature review by John Kelley, et al., assessed the effect of patient-clinician relationships on healthcare outcomes by looking at factors such as adherence to treatment and patient satisfaction.* While this study could not quantify the strength of these relationships, there was a link between prioritization of holistic patient care and the quality of treatment. My mom had an incurable disease and the only course of action was to find treatments that could extend her life while maintaining her quality of living. In situations like this, patients spend hours in the hospital every week. Physicians that are willing to spend extra time to get to know the person they are treating make an impactful difference. This is what I aspire to be, a physician that goes beyond the standard treatment of disease and takes a few extra moments to ensure that every patient feels cared for and heard. Looking back on the past two years, I am humbled and grateful for the experiences that have led me to where I am today because I can now confidently say I have found my deeper meaning for pursuing a career in medicine. 

*https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0094207
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
My roommate while at Rush was Ismaili. I did not think anything of it when we first moved in, but throughout the year, we talked about why he fasts for Ramadan, his native language of Gujarati, and his upbringing. I was most interested in the purpose of the religious acts he chose to participate in. _x000D_
_x000D_
Even though my roommate and I had led very different lives, our bond grew when we talked about our differences. During the Fall, we spent Sundays watching football together and telling college stories, but I never felt like I knew him until I learned about his culture and religion. This was a large part of his life, and I did not want it to be a topic that was avoided because of my lack of understanding. Once these conversations started, my roommate wanted to teach me how to make the foods he grew up eating and introduce me to the community he grew up in. I saw how powerful it was for me to learn about his culture because it made him feel accepted despite our differences. _x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
In the Fall of 2021, I began working with Dr. Basapur on a research project at the Oakley Square Apartments, just five minutes from Rush. This project focused on gaining insight into how Rush could improve upon its community clinic model. I worked with eight teenage males during this project, and in November, they left us with one request: a teen night program. _x000D_
_x000D_
The first day we met with the teenagers, they questioned us about our intentions. After explaining the purpose of our project, the room fell silent until one of the kids said, ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs college like?‚Äù None of the teens had anyone in their life that talked about or went to college. This moment showed me that regardless of the different lives we had lived, I could use my experiences to help guide and support the teenagers of this community. In January 2022, I worked with Dr. Basapur to create a weekly teen night program at Oakley Square.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
In the Summer of 2020, my mother was diagnosed with stage IV cancer. Amidst the Covid-19 pandemic, she was left attending every appointment alone, with my father working from his car in the hospital parking lot. This left me as the primary caregiver for my four younger brothers for the rest of that summer. When I returned to school for the Fall semester, it quickly became apparent that my parents needed help. My brothers were struggling with the online schooling format, and neither of our parents could be home to help. _x000D_
_x000D_
I was able to clear my work schedule from Friday to Sunday and received permission to attend my Friday lectures remotely. This allowed me to drive six hours home almost every Thursday night to be home with my family. Even though this resulted in another poor semester in the classroom, I did not have an option. I had both of my parents supporting me for the first 21 years of my life, and I wanted to do everything I could to give my younger brothers the same reality.

personal_statement:
I was lucky to have made a plethora of memories with my grandfather as I was growing up. My family would visit India often, and I would spend most of my summer vacations listening to his childhood stories. A common myth told in the Southeast Asian community was that the elders in the family will only be proud of their children if they choose a career in a STEM-related field. That myth became a reality as I started to notice my friends’ STEM futures were all being planned out as early as elementary school. I was 10 when my grandfather asked me what I wanted to do in life. I wholeheartedly believed that I would share the same fate as my friends. I responded by saying, “I guess anything science-related, grandfather. I only want to make you proud.” He chuckled and told me that he’d be proud of me regardless of what career I chose. He would be content as long as it was the path that I would place all my effort in. Never would I have thought that these very few words my grandfather said would be the reason as to why I chose medicine.
 
I was in high school when I had the opportunity to visit my cousins in Texas for spring break. My cousin planned out a thorough spring break plan for us, which somehow included waking up at 6 a.m. every morning to go to work with his neighbor. I argued that I did not want to go, but he insisted that we stick to his plan. The next morning, my cousin opens the door to a woman wearing a white coat and blue scrubs and says, “It’s time to get going guys. Let’s go to the hospital!” My first impression of the operating room was the amount of silence that filled the room, but then everyone’s movement began to have its unique sound. This is the moment when I realized the art behind medicine. Each medical professional seen through the glass of the operating room was a member of the Beethoven-Esque symphony. At the center of it all was Dr. Basi, conducting the whole performance. The anesthesiologist was the lead in her section and performed her first solo. The solo went smoothly and the patient was put under, quicker than minute rice. With a quick signal from Dr. Basi, the OR nurses harmonized and handed the lead surgeon the vital instruments for the upcoming transition. With each precise incision and suture, the surgeon was introducing new instrument duets in the symphony. I observed three of Dr. Basi’s symphonies that day, each one more flawless than the previous. While everyone in the observation room heard silence, I heard beauty behind the glass. All I could think about was how a unit of people could hold a precious life in their hands and give them the future that they deserved. There was no time to ask for an encore, but I vowed to return in order to experience it all over again. This time as a performer.
 
As a step toward that goal, I pursued the opportunity to work as an Emergency Department medical scribe for a few months during undergrad, and this experience changed my life. I was now part of a section in the orchestra, and I could finally display my abilities. I realized that the symphony did not end in the OR and that the real peak occurred post-treatment. There was one instance during my time as a scribe that reinforced my belief that this is where I belong. “Molly” presented to the emergency department with a severe migraine. She looked at Dr. Martinez and noted the troubles she was facing in her personal life, and how her migraine kept worsening. After doing a physical examination, Dr. Martinez told her she is a strong woman and that it’s okay to fall apart sometimes. He gave her words of strength that instantly washed away her teary-filled eyes. Dr. Martinez’s words shed light on what my grandfather told me as a young girl.
 
After my fifth day of floor training, my mentor evaluated me based on my patient reports and pointed out my mistakes. He bluntly told me that I wasn’t ready to work on my own. I locked myself in my car afterward and was shattered. Then I heard my grandfather’s voice in the back of my head. If this was my purpose in life, I knew that it was not going to be an easy one. From that night onwards, I started to practice writing out stronger HPI’s and had my chief scribe give me feedback on them. The next day I had floor training, I showcased well-written patient charts. Many providers mentioned how they had been noticing my improvements and have noted they enjoyed working with me. Hearing their comments was great but nothing compared to knowing that I played a role in changing a patient’s life for the better. I did belong here.
 
My dream of becoming a doctor was not forced upon me. I may not have been born with this dream in mind. My grandfather’s wise words were a catalyst, but the journey of finding my passion in medicine was done all on my own. I want to become the first doctor in my family because I know that it is my true purpose in life. When my dream was challenged by a peer of mine while being a scribe, my dream’s autoimmune system instantly combated the challenge. This is my dream and the feeling from listening to Dr. Martinez’s words, only solidified it. I only hope that I can inspire other young women, just like how my grandfather did. Any dream is attainable if passion goes beyond bounds, and most importantly if it’s your own.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Most of my extended family resides in India, and we visit them every 2-3 years. One instance that I believe enhanced my ability to understand those unlike myself was one summer in India. It was my birthday, and my uncle had insisted that we go to a blind and deaf orphanage to give out candy to all the children. I thought it would not be very comforting, but the moment I walked in, I was greeted with tons of smiles and hugs. Some children were my age, and my soul felt so warm to see those who couldn't see or hear me be so happy. They've never met me before but saw me as a friend giving them a small gift. I realized that these children who don't live the same life as me were still thankful that my uncle and I came to give them something as minuscule as a piece of chocolate. At that moment, I learned that regardless of who I was, I was welcomed because I could provide that belongingness that these children sought. I know I will do the same for my patients as a physician.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Working as a medical assistant made me realize the importance of diversity, equity, inclusion, and belonging in medicine. The number of phone calls I had to make to patients to remind them that their prescription was sent and hearing that they can't pick it up because they cannot afford it truly upset me. Working in medicine is to provide and help the community, but I felt like I was not doing my job after getting off the phone with one of my patients who could not afford to pay for his insulin pens. After talking to the provider, I asked the patient if he would be willing to join a cost-effective medication program. After getting the physician's approval and the patient's permission, I helped this patient get the medication he needed. At this moment, I realized how important it was to listen to the patient. I will contribute my passion for medicine and show my care towards my patients to ensure they are heard.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The COVID-19 pandemic did not impact my application to medical school as much as I thought it would. I did have some shadowing opportunities lined up that I could not follow through with due to the pandemic; however, I was involved in virtual shadowing, where I shadowed physicians, nurse practitioners, and physician assistants virtually. The pandemic has better prepared me for medical school because I also got involved in the Art of Living Foundation, a meditation group. My meditation instructor, a current medical student, stated that she finds meditating helpful because she likes taking 20-25 minutes of her day to focus on calming her mind before spending hours with patients and learning a plethora of information. I decided to share this practice with pre-health students and organized a virtual meditation practice. All in all, I learned to adapt to what was happening during the pandemic and tried to be involved in medicine as much as I could.

personal_statement:
As a child, I’d eagerly anticipate a nightly reading of my favorite Chinese folktale – “The Boy and His Dog”. The dog suffers from severe illnesses and initially shows no signs of improvement. However, the boy never gives up on the dog and ultimately nurses him back to health. Little did I realize, the boy in the story signified my mother, as I was frequently riddled with fevers and severe allergies. As I grew older, I would become more like the boy. 
Since age 4, I was frequently rushed to the ER for severe fevers ranging from allergic reactions to infections. The front desk receptionists knew me and my protocols well. Constantly ill, I watched while the other kids played. Like in the folktale, I knew that with steadfast perseverance, I could get better. I would not give up on myself just like the boy did not give up on his dog. I would run alongside the field to build endurance, practice basketball to improve coordination, and construct castles in the sandbox. One day, I saw another boy playing alone and asked, “Hey, do you want to play?” We played multiple rounds of basketball and he exclaimed, “Wow! I didn’t know you can play that well being sick.” I recruited more kids and we ultimately started our own team. Just like how the boy never gave up on his dog, I never gave up, not on myself or on any other child.
In university, I joined Alpha Phi Omega, a service fraternity. As an active member, I supported pledges with service and interview requirements. A pledge confided in me saying, “I don’t know if this is manageable, classes are rough right now.” I listened carefully and together we devised a plan. “In-between your 2pm and 4pm class, you can fit two interviews. You can interview someone over dinner or through hangouts.” Not only did this pledge succeed, she later led the Pledge Committee. I was later elected Financial Vice President and responsible for all budget decisions. In the past, the fraternity spent most of its budget on the first half of the quarter, with little funds remaining. Several members wanted a catered banquet. During planning meetings, they argued, “We need this to be big so we can get more members,” and ignored others’ concerns. Instead of criticizing or complaining, I proposed an alternative. “How about a potluck? We’d save money and it would be fun to cook together.” They agreed and we collected ingredients, coordinated ovens, and prepared dishes ranging from pastas to whole chickens. The event brought in 60+ new members, which boosted our service hours. We used remaining funds for new tents (the fraternity has previously thought this much-needed purchase wouldn’t be possible) and planned a camping trip for new pledges. Just like in the medical field, creativity, connection, and support are important in all aspects of my life. Whether dancing, volunteering with youth, or welcoming new peers and colleagues to campus, I never give up and I continue to become more like the boy in the story.
As leader of multiple dance teams and youth volunteer groups, I appreciate the importance of ongoing support. New dancers often doubt themselves. Many express fears such as, “I don’t want to embarrass myself” and “I’m not getting it.” A teammate struggled with practice so I took time to help her prepare. I know that healing and support take many forms. We strategized, “Let’s meet after class and head to the gym.” I provided positive reinforcement with critiques like “I love how you hit those angles with your arms but make sure to keep your form tight.” We practiced late, joked, and bonded over our struggles with the wave. Not only did my teammate’s skills improve, her entire outlook changed. She ultimately became better than me in a lot of movements and would later join a top tier competitive dance team. Like in the folktale, the boy needed a supportive environment if he wanted to help his dog. I strive to create such environment for everyone I work with, from beginning dancers to the sick to the youth. 
As a Ronald Reagan Hospital volunteer, I often shared stories, both my own and the folktale. On breaks, I’d play with young patients while they'd wait for appointments. While we’d build towers out of blocks or solve puzzles, we’d talk. I noticed one of the kids isolated from the other toys and I sat next to him and asked, “Do you want to play?” His face lit up. We struggled but didn’t give up when our blocks toppled. When we finished, his face darkened and I asked, “Can I tell you a story?” I told him about “The Boy and His Dog”. I assured him by saying, “I was just like you, but now I’m big and strong! If you continue to believe in yourself, then you can get better too!” As he left, he said “Thank you mister for the story, I’ll try my best!”
Each child tells their own story, and I want to help shape their narrative just like the boy in the folktale. Just as I transitioned from being the dog to the boy, I want to inspire others to make that same transition. Whether providing medical support, friendship, leadership at a time of need, or simply sharing my own story of perseverance, I will never stop working to help as many children as possible. With all the skills and life experiences at my disposal, I will continue to provide the care, given to me as a child, to others as a future physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: During freshman year winter break, I visited my university roommate Gabe in his hometown: Clovis, CA. I volunteered with his high school club at Clovis East High School. I prepared necessities such as toothbrushes, wipes, soaps, and food to be handed out to the underserved population in the local area. A lady approached us and said, ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt see a lot of people like you around here: People who actually care about the community. Barely anyone comes out here and helps us out anymore.‚Äù After, Gabe explained, ‚ÄúMy parents used to ask for donations too, so I try my best to help out even if it‚Äôs only a little in the long run.‚Äù I grew up in a medically represented area, so travelling to Central California where resources were limited changed my perspective. I can now better understand their struggles and properly help them with the resources available. As a future physician, I would focus my efforts on helping the medically underserved populations.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: In undergraduate, I volunteered for Meals on Wheels in which I delivered hot meals to seniors. One day, during our last stop, one of the seniors needed help moving objects as an earthquake had hit the day before. I noticed that she was visibly shaken as her hands trembled while she was resting. Once I finished, she asked me, ‚ÄúDo you think you can stay for a while? It‚Äôs been very lonely and I‚Äôve been scared ever since yesterday.‚Äù I asked the driver to head back without me as I stayed with her. I wanted her to feel safe and secure before her daughter came to spend time with her. Little by little, she began opening up to me. She asked me, ‚ÄúWhat do you want to be when you‚Äôre older?‚Äù and I responded, ‚ÄúA doctor‚Äù. She complimented me by uttering, ‚ÄúWell, you‚Äôre going to be a great doctor. Your constant smiles will lighten any patient up,‚Äù a statement that I still hold dear to this day. As a future physician, I aim to create a comfortable environment for my patients to share their concerns.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
Initially, my Covid-19 concerns stemmed from my mother being immunocompromised. My mother lost her job for a year during the pandemic, which put a strain on my family‚Äôs financial stability. My post baccalaureate program also transitioned to online learning. Office hours were limited and working on group projects became difficult. Additionally, I was going to start a position as a medical assistant at my local clinic, but I was let go due to Covid-19 scares. _x000D_
However, Covid-19 did not discourage me from pursuing other avenues. While my mother did not have a job, my post baccalaureate program hired me as a peer tutor. The online job helped me financially while also enriching my current knowledge. While I did not have a chance to work in my local clinic, I virtually shadowed other physicians through UC Merced‚Äôs virtual shadowing program, where I shadowed various physicians from different backgrounds.

personal_statement:
I remember sitting on the blue office carpet after primary school, surrounded by posters depicting different regions of the human ear. I read books about outer space while waiting for my dad to finish working on his latest projects. He often brought prototypes home to show my siblings and me what he’d been working on. My dad always had this contagious excitement about his work, never hesitating to describe how these little devices could treat someone’s hearing loss. I was fascinated that something so small could make such a significant impact on someone’s life. Years later, my dad asked me to help him with one of his medical device projects. As we worked together to treat patients with tonal tinnitus, I internalized his passion for advancing the field of medicine and making a long-lasting impact. These early experiences led to my own motivation to explore the realm of medicine beyond the medical device industry.

During my senior year of college, I worked as a Learning Assistant (LA) for a Women’s Mental Health psychology course. Students would meet with me individually in an exercise called ‘Teach an LA,’ where they would come prepared to teach me a topic from the class’s curriculum. Most students chose to speak on the history of women’s health, the cortisol stress response, or the menstrual cycle.

One student I met with, Katie, expressed her frustrations with gender-based healthcare disparities discussed in class. She couldn’t believe that many medical conditions, such as heart attacks, are often misdiagnosed in women due to differences in presentation. I felt the same way when I first took this class. I told Katie that learning about the lack of research and understanding of gender differences in medicine provided me with an entirely new perspective on healthcare. This class had a major impact on my work as an EMT and inspired me to learn more about gender differences in various medical conditions. I wanted to understand as much as possible to provide the most effective, personalized patient care. As Katie and I continued to discuss health inequities, she shared that her mother struggled with infertility before Katie was born. Her mother’s chronic health condition was misdiagnosed for years, preventing her from having kids. I felt powerless as I continued to listen. I couldn’t shake this feeling of wanting to do more, to be an advocate, to be in a position to cure her mother and others alike.

After graduating, I started working as a clinical research assistant in a women’s behavioral health laboratory, where my first project was managing a sleep study. During an enrollment appointment, I spoke with Amy, a busy healthcare worker who struggled with getting consistent sleep. Amy told me that she had never been a good sleeper, and it worsened over the years after having “three loud boys,” she joked. As I showed Amy how to use the devices we were testing in the study, she asked me what ‘good sleep’ even means. I enjoyed answering these types of questions so I could ease any stresses a participant had about our study. We ended up speaking at length about the different stages of sleep and the various activities that could affect her sleep quality. With her newfound enthusiasm, Amy and I scheduled her follow-up appointment, and I eagerly awaited what she had to say about her experience.

Amy returned for her final screening session with a beaming smile on her face. “Henry!” she exclaimed, “I haven’t slept this well in years!” She was so eager to share her experience with me. As we discussed her improved sleep quality, she mentioned that using the study devices also helped her husband sleep better. “My husband loves them,” she laughed, “because I stopped waking him up for his loud snoring.” I was thrilled to hear the positive impact that this had on Amy’s sleep. It was motivating to see that our developing treatment dramatically improved not only her quality of life, but her husband’s as well. Working with patients like Amy inspires me to pursue a career as a physician, where I can discover and apply new methods of improving people’s health and well-being.

The curiosity and passion my dad instilled in me has driven me to seek out opportunities to make a significant impact on those around me. I want to be a part of the next generation of physicians that will fight to improve patient outcomes and mend healthcare inequities. The countless stories I have heard from people like Katie and Amy motivate me to think of all the ways I could improve the medical experiences of many. I want to be a physician that continuously strives to enhance my knowledge and understanding of medicine so I can provide personalized, high-quality patient care. The moments I have shared with patients and physicians through research and patient care have motivated me to pursue a career where I can research, develop, and apply new treatments. I want to share my contagious excitement for medicine as I strive to make a long-lasting impact through the many roles a physician fulfills.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
International Day was one of my most memorable experiences growing up in Switzerland. Students and their families would come to school to share their cultural backgrounds with others through ethnic dishes, ancient games, and traditional clothing. Being exposed to diverse cultural backgrounds from a young age instilled a sense of curiosity in me to learn more about others._x000D_
_x000D_
Years later, I began volunteering at a bilingual preschool, where I assisted teachers by bridging language barriers between children. I empathized with the students who felt separated by language, as it was often something I experienced when I was younger. As a volunteer, I emulated the values my teachers instilled in me at ISL by making students feel included amongst the diverse group of kids._x000D_
_x000D_
I hope to grow my commitment to understanding and appreciating diverse perspectives at Rush, where I can become a physician who is a curious learner and embodies an empathetic, person-centered approach to patient care.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
One of the most meaningful experiences I had while pursuing medicine was being a Learning Assistant in the psychology course Women's Mental Health. Many students in the class discussed their firsthand experiences regarding a lack of adequate or empathetic patient care because of their gender or race. Working as an LA exposed me to some of the challenges disadvantaged populations experience in healthcare settings, reinforcing my curiosity and commitment to learning more about others._x000D_
_x000D_
After graduating, I continued learning about recent discoveries in women's health by working in the Women's Behavioral Health & Wellness research group. I want to continue my efforts to mitigate healthcare inequities at Rush by working with the Center for Community Health Equity. Here, I will be able to use a multidisciplinary and community-centered approach to research and patient care. At Rush, I hope to continue discovering and applying novel ways to improve people's health and wellbeing.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Although the COVID-19 pandemic presented many challenges over the past two years, I sought opportunities to reduce some of the adverse effects of the pandemic. I started working as a Research Assistant in the Department of Psychiatry, where my first study was a sleep study for healthcare workers. The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound negative impact on sleep quality amongst healthcare workers. Our goal was to assess the efficacy of a pair of noise-masking earbuds as a non-pharmacological intervention to improve sleep quality. It was a rewarding experience because I had the opportunity to develop an intervention to reduce the consequences of the pandemic while simultaneously witnessing a significant improvement in many healthcare workers‚Äô quality of life. At Rush Medical College, I want to take advantage of the extensive research opportunities to continue developing and applying ways to improve people‚Äôs health and wellbeing.

personal_statement:
As we sat quietly in the room, I mentally repeated everything she told me to say, terrified I would miss something. The room was sterile, and bright and I could tell it bothered my grandfather’s eyes as he was gripping his cane, staring into his lap. On the other hand, my grandmother was used to these visits as long as I was there to help translate. At 9 years of age, I would much rather have been playing with my friends at school but understood my role as one of the only English-speakers in my household. A gentle knock on the door finally broke the silence followed by a head peeking inside. The doctor’s stethoscope was draped over his shoulders, and he looked around the room almost shocked to see so many faces. “Mr. Lule?” He hesitated for a moment, staring at my grandfather who glanced over nervously at me. I explained that they did not speak English, and I was there to translate everything into Spanish. Being sent as a translator for family members was a common occurrence, and having never met a physician who spoke Spanish, I believed it to be the norm. It wasn’t until my adolescence, when we moved to Los Angeles, that I ever met a doctor who I related to on both a linguistic and cultural level. Having a physician who could connect with my family enabled my grandparents to be their own voice at the doctor’s office and I soon noticed their increased trust in the medical system as a result.
It was from these interactions that I began to recognize the value of a diverse physician population and how it can impact patients. To this day, contributing physician diversity continues to serve as a driving force for me with hopes of being able to help families like mine and improve their care. While volunteering in the ER I had the opportunity to see how I can make a difference in this aspect of healthcare. It was amidst the constant beeping of monitors and chatter that I saw a shadow approach from the corner of my eye. His eyes darted about the lobby, and I was reminded of the same puzzled look my grandparents had whenever someone spoke English. He hesitated and asked, “¿Español?”, I nodded and replied yes in Spanish. Adolfo’s confusion melted into a grin as he stepped closer and explained that he was just told by a doctor that he needed surgery but was unsure what it meant and that he felt scared. I listened intently and after clarifying questions about the procedure, I asked what would help him feel more comfortable. Adolfo explained that religion helped him, this was no surprise to me as religion is deeply rooted within the Latino culture. I helped him locate a church in nearby suburbs and even directed him to the hospital’s chapel on the 1st floor. Unbeknownst to him, this interaction had been a highlight of my day. The conversation flowed as if he were a relative or friend and I felt honored to help comfort a patient in need. I realized during these moments that I truly long for a lifetime of forming these important connections and providing comfort to those in their most vulnerable moments.
In the ER, I also had the privilege of witnessing the role of a doctor as an educator, advocate, healthcare leader, and expert of the human body. Luke had come into the ER with complaints of abdomen pain but when asked to put on a face mask, his demeanor quickly changed from calm to irritable. Throughout the COVID19 pandemic, vaccines, virus transmission, and antibodies were common question topics asked by patients. Luke was no different, he was among the many who felt irritated by the virus and referenced social media sites as a rebuttal to masks. He confidently declared that he did not trust physicians or medical treatments, and that he only came into the hospital to put his family member’s minds at ease. It was during Luke’s care that I observed Dr. Aquino sit beside him, her eyes level with his as she calmly explained some science principles and allowed him to guide the conversation to topics that he felt passionate about. As she explained and addressed his specific questions one by one, it became clear that his mind was more at ease. And in a short matter of time his regard for the physician helping him was transformed into respect rather than skepticism. Watching this teaching moment, I began to realize that the role of physician included being a community leader, educator, and an empathetic listener. Although not all interactions with patients go as this one did, I felt confident that the role of a doctor includes weaving both health and humanity into one, a job like no other and the only one I’d want to have. Going forward, I strive to one day be able to teach and educate patients on their health and the science behind it, not only as a community leader but as a physician.
From growing up in rural California translating medical visits for my grandparents to working amongst the Latino population in a big city Emergency Room, I’ve come to recognize the importance of diversity and accessible community education in our healthcare system. Not only have my experiences in medicine guided me to the path of physician, but they’ve made the decision to serve in a Latino community inevitable. In time I aspire to gain a deeper level of medical knowledge, and have a positive and lasting impact on the lives of others.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Without saying a word he handed me a piece of paper with the name, Simon L. written on it. Looking at my list I found him easily and before I‚Äôd even asked for his ID card he placed it on the counter. As it was a particularly hot day I had been asking everyone if they wanted water and did the same with Simon. He stared blankly for a second and proceeded to point to his ear, shaking his head. Realizing he was deaf I began to understand the situation. He was clearly a repeat blood donor who through his own creativity and practice had found a way to effectively communicate his needs without issue. This experience was a reminder to always attempt to find or create accommodations for those who need them as even a small gesture can make the difference in creating a more welcoming environment. Surrounded by a world that isn‚Äôt catered towards individuals with disabilities, it‚Äôs important to be observant of the needs of others so that at least one aspect of their day can be made a little easier.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Even at our first tutor session I could tell that getting Uriel engaged in his homework was going to be a challenge. His hands fidgeted with anything in reach, and it was near impossible to have him sit in a chair for more than a minute. All he wanted to do was talk about his favorite video game, Roblox, and repeatedly asked if he could play and show me. Instead of asking him again and again to sit down and do his work, I proposed that we finish 5 homework assignments after which we could discuss anything he wanted. He loved the idea and sat down to work for the next 50 minutes and proceeded to show me his Roblox character for the remaining 10 minutes. We continued with this cycle each session and before I knew it, his mother shared with me that not only had his  academic improvement skyrocketed but that he now began to look forward to our tutoring sessions. Uriel‚Äôs new excitement to learn was a reminder that the service done for others, no matter how small, can have a lasting impact.
7_-_COVID_Impact: May 9th, 2020, the day my youngest sister was born, was a day of excitement. Yet in the midst of all this joy was the fear of a global pandemic. Fear of contagion and hospitalization spread, and for that reason my parents decided it was best to do everything in our power to protect my baby sister. This meant not going out for anything other than necessities and resulted in me asking for a leave of absence from any in person responsibilities. Being isolated in my own home proved to be challenging as I dealt with familial issues and tried to find ways to help my community. It was during this time that I found out about the ACS advocacy branch as well as a tutoring service called AOC Homework Helpers. I‚Äôm beyond grateful for these opportunities as they allowed me to give back in whatever way I could without sacrificing the health of my family. This goes to say that I learned that I can still have an impact on others even when trapped within the chaos of the world around me.

personal_statement:
During my senior year of high school, my father had to undergo lifesaving triple bypass surgery. While I understood the gravity of the situation, it impacted me more profoundly than I initially imagined. While he was in surgery, I sat glued to my laptop in the waiting room, researching in real time what was happening. By the time my father came out, I was bursting with questions. The medical team was gracious enough to answer them, and my father’s surgeon even offered me the opportunity to shadow him on the same surgery my father had. I could not say “yes” quickly enough.

I watched the surgeon carefully remove a blood vessel from a patient’s leg to build a bypass around the blockage in an artery in his chest. I had never seen a human heart before, and I walked out of the hospital awestruck. That was the first day I truly wanted to become a doctor. I had always been heavily involved in sports and saw a path in sports medicine. It all seemed simple enough; however, in my quest to pursue a career in medicine, I have begun to understand how much more is involved. I have many patients at a nursing home and a woman named Sarah to thank for helping me come to this realization.

I met Sarah during my early days as a clinical audiology technician. I loved working with patients, and I had mastered the technical components of the exam. However, Sarah was a new challenge: She was mentally disabled. Before I even had a chance to speak, her parents told me she would “never be able to follow the instructions.” I assured them that we would be fine, but in my head I was already anxious.

I began by explaining the test to Sarah as I would any patient, but her lack of response and attention told me I would get nowhere like that. I tried speaking more slowly and clearly; that did not work either. I began to think her parents were right: We would never complete the test. 

With frustration mounting and confidence waning, I thought of another time I had struggled, working with patients at Ridgecrest Nursing Home. When I started volunteering there, I expected the fast pace of a hospital; I could not have been more wrong. One Friday, exhausted after a long week, I wanted to just finish my work and get to my weekend. Then my director told me it was the birthday of a resident, Michael, and that we were throwing a party for him. Although exhausted, I smiled and tried to show enthusiasm. I was tasked with telling each resident about the party and walking them there. I thought, “Fifteen minutes and I can go.” I spent the next hour gingerly walking patients down the hall, constantly repeating instructions. By the time I finished, the party had already begun. I collapsed in a chair, mentally exhausted and feeling sorry for the fate of my Friday afternoon. Then a chorus of residents sang “Happy Birthday.” I will never forget the joy on Michael and his friends’ faces. My attitude changed—his joy was the ultimate reward that eclipsed my exhaustion.

A few weeks later, it was Veterans Day, and I was on my way to the nursing home again. Veterans Day has always been special in my family, so I was surprised that nothing more than a simple acknowledgment was planned, especially given how many residents had served. Thinking about the joy of Michael’s party, I decided to make Veterans Day special. I suggested we decorate and hold a special ceremony honoring our veterans. We placed flags throughout the facility and held an impromptu ceremony that brought tears to many eyes, reaffirming what I learned at the party—extra time and effort to help someone is always worth it.

I succeeded not with medical acumen, but with humanity, empathy, and patience. And that is what could also help Sarah. In medicine, following methods and rules are crucial in testing a patient. However, so are changing communication methods when necessary. Instead of continuing to tell Sarah, I decided to show her. I demonstrated how I would place the earphones in her ears, acted out how to raise her hand when a sound was heard, and modeled how she should repeat words she heard. 

She stared at me blankly for a moment, but when she smiled and gave me an emphatic thumbs up, I felt more joy and satisfaction than I could have imagined. The test took double the time it normally takes, but we got the results we needed. Moreover, Sarah’s parents could not believe what I had helped their daughter achieve. From that day forward, I have been more confident interacting with all kinds of patients, and I am always willing to take an extra moment, or several, to help them.

Seeing a human heart for the first time was incredible enough to spark my interest in medicine—and I had not yet even seen the humanity inherent in medicine. Putting myself in the patient’s shoes and listening to their thoughts and desires are just as important as running a test. My time in clinical settings has helped me understand the importance of listening to and treating each patient holistically. My dream is to work as a sports medicine physician, helping get patients healthy and back to living a pain-free life, and I now know it will take both patience and empathy to get there. Thanks to Sarah and the nursing home, I am ready for the challenge.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
I was raised in South Texas by a father who grew up in Mexico and a mother who grew up in Los Angeles. Dad‚Äôs family gives hugs; mom‚Äôs gives handshakes. Dad‚Äôs family thought mom‚Äôs was ‚Äúcold‚Äù and mom‚Äôs family thought dad‚Äôs was ‚Äúover-involved and emotional.‚Äù I spent extensive time volunteering in the local community to further understand how to interact with people from distinct backgrounds. Growing up in a diverse community also impacted the way I viewed the world around me._x000D_
 _x000D_
I learned that most people throughout my life focused on their differences. Even in school, I noticed that people struggled empathizing with other peoples‚Äô perspectives. In my career, I will encourage my coworkers to start from common ground‚Äîwith friends, family, and future patients. If we start with the mantra ‚ÄúWe all want to help,‚Äù we can overcome religious, cultural, or other obstacles. Using this will help me put patients at ease as I strive to become the best doctor I can be.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: During my time at Baylor, one morning I attended a worship service at a local church. The facility looked ancient and the members were weary. After the service, the pastor pulled me aside to talk with him. He told me about the vision he had for the church, and asked me to help remodel the church. I was quick to say yes, and I called a meeting for my fraternity to gather members to help me on this endeavor. We spent months throwing away old equipment, placing new carpet, and painting walls. The time we spent remodeling was tough, but the thankfulness the congregation displayed made it all worth it. Even though I have graduated and left, members from my fraternity still attend the church today and provide help when needed. This experience taught me to seek opportunities to positively impact the lives of people each day. Walking into the service, I did not have any intention of remodeling a church. However, offering my assistance cultivated a friendship with a local community.
7_-_COVID_Impact: COVID caused great change in my life. During my senior year, many of my classes shifted to digital platforms. I had planned on attending medical mission trips to Peru and Kenya. Unfortunately, both were canceled. After moving back to my hometown, I began grocery shopping for my grandparents, doing my best to minimize their exposure to the outside world. When I started working full-time in a clinic, I was required to always wear a mask and to maintain my distance from others when possible. Seeing the number of patients walking into the clinic every day made me recognize the dire need in my community. Moreover, the myriad non-medical needs of others in the community do not stop during a pandemic. I began volunteering at a local homeless shelter, and this allowed me to see how much impact I could have by using my free time to help others in dire need. I made countless memories talking with people I would have never met and learned to be more grateful for the life I live today.

personal_statement:
There is an expression, “use it or lose it.” But my journey to medicine began when I saw the human spirit of “lose it and still use it.” I was at a half marathon talking with a below-the-knee amputee. He told me about a triathlon held in San Diego each October for individuals with physical challenges. Intrigued, I signed up to volunteer, and one early morning at the ocean's edge, I helped a woman place her prosthetic leg on a beach towel and assisted her as she hopped on one leg to join the others to get ready for the swim. I looked around and took in the sight of all the prosthetics on the beach. Each one representing an athlete’s desire to be able to “use it” despite “losing it” and be part of the world of sports. A world I had always been part of, taking my own physical mobility for granted. Volunteering with the challenged athletes opened my eyes to the empowerment they experienced by the act of participating and the health benefits of an active lifestyle.
This is when playing sports no longer centered around my own individual skills, but the rewards of contributing as a teammate and leading as a captain on three varsity sports. In basketball, as point guard, I worked hard to make sure that if I called a play, the girls knew their roles to make the execution of the play successful. In softball, there was the time that I took a line drive to the face, and I pleaded to stay in and continue to cover my responsibility of third base. And during long cross country practice runs, I knew the girls looked to me, and if I slowed down, then they might too. I felt that also setting an example academically for my teammates was important, and I was proud to be awarded student-athlete of the year, class salutatorian and acceptance to UCLA.
Many were surprised that I didn’t play sports in college, but I knew that science classes would be demanding. I did, however, find time to play 13 different intramural sports on over 30 teams. I enjoy encouraging others to lead a healthy lifestyle, which led me to the role of Risk Manager for my sorority, where I organized Risk teams to patrol events for safety issues and assist when needed. One memorable time was when a member had hit her head and was bleeding and disoriented. Despite her objection, I had to call for an ambulance. This experience allowed me to picture myself in the medical field, providing me with the opportunity to have confidence in my natural calm demeanor and quick judgment calls. I further explored my interest in medicine as a Care Extender at Ronald Reagan UCLA Medical Center. It was this hands-on experience in the hospital where I confirmed my desire to work directly in patient care.
Since graduating, to explore and understand healthcare, I began volunteering as a medical assistant intern. I started in the front office, where I learned about insurance and the importance of authorizations and referrals in order for patients to obtain the care they need. I learned how to be quick, resourceful and understanding during phone and in-person interactions to ensure smooth, productive encounters with patients. Working in the back office, I gained a hands-on approach to patient care. I roomed patients, obtained medical history, took vital signs and performed procedures, including EKGs and injections. I also had the opportunity to shadow physicians in multiple specialties, coordinate patient services, and order lab tests and ultrasound procedures. Due to my exceptional performance as an intern, I was hired full-time to work alongside physicians and train new interns. As part of this group, I also attend clinical didactic sessions, where physicians speak on and discuss important current topics in healthcare.
On weekends, I work as an Emergency Department scribe, where I write History of Present Illness and chief complaints, obtain a Review of Systems and regulate the timing of lab and imaging results. This job has allowed me to start thinking more like a physician.
