I have learned why the doctors are ordering specific tests and their thought processes on the differential diagnoses of the patients based on their current symptoms, medical history and results. I have seen their dedication, watching a physician do chest compressions and get a pulse, only to have to repeat this five times and ultimately have a hard conversation with the family. And later, seeing a tear roll down his face as he took a moment and watching his coworkers give him a gentle tap of acknowledgment. I recognized the human side of medicine and the privilege it would be to become a physician and connect with patients as part of a healthcare team.
To prepare for medical school coursework, I have continued to support my academics by tutoring high school and college students in calculus, biology and chemistry. Given my education and multiple exposures and experiences in healthcare, I have confirmed my decision to pursue a career in medicine. I have been very well acquainted with the impact that being a physician will have on my life, because growing up I saw my dad be able to be a physician while also being a husband, a father to me and my brothers, a coach and a teacher. I believe, given my passion to become a committed physician, I have what it takes to endure the challenging years to come.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: At UCLA, I volunteered at a center for adults with memory challenges. Some of the seniors were reluctant to engage in group activities. I found that having one-on-one conversations often made them feel comfortable and open to participating. I recognized the importance of communication, active listening, and not being afraid to engage in deeper conversations. As a medical assistant near a senior living community, I have had more opportunities to work with the geriatric population. There is an older Veteran who comes in once a month. Sometimes he does not even have an appointment and simply comes in with a box of donuts (despite us being a diabetes clinic) and his own mug requesting coffee. I enjoy hearing about his time in the service and his two Yorkies. I feel that this social interaction and connecting with him is an important aspect of his medical care. My respect and admiration for this population has heightened my desire to play an impactful role in people‚Äôs lives.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I believe that I have been impactful in my community by taking on the role of an educator and mentor, facilitating information to promote learning. I was a TA during COVID, and I found that many students struggled when in-person connections were no longer available. It was rewarding to provide one-on-one support to these students. After UCLA, I joined CCPrep as a tutor and observed how high school students lacked the foundations required to progress in their subjects after a year of online learning due to COVID. I devoted time to reviewing material that was missed due to the information gaps that the online format had created. As a medical assistant in an endocrinology office, I have had the opportunity to teach new incoming interns. I also work with pharmaceutical representatives and insurance companies to advocate for the education, prevention, and treatment of diabetes. As a future medical student and physician, I will serve to improve my community through health education.
7_-_COVID_Impact: In March of 2020, UCLA canceled in-person classes and transitioned to online learning. A research project I was working on got shut down, so the PI offered me an alternative opportunity to be their Teaching Assistant. Unfortunately, my volunteer and clinical activities at Ronald Reagan Hospital as a UCLA Care Extender were also put on pause. I am grateful that after UCLA, I was able to find two direct patient care opportunities as a medical assistant and an Emergency Department scribe. While working in these busy settings, I‚Äôve had to stay extra vigilant and take necessary precautions, not only to protect my coworkers and the patients but also to ensure that I did not bring COVID-19 home to my parents. Both of my parents have autoimmune conditions, and it has been a personal challenge to navigate work and social activities during this time.

personal_statement:
Staying inside while the world was crashing to a halt was certainly not how I pictured the summer of 2020 unfolding. Every day posed a new challenge; news stations kept a running death tally and racial divisions were obscenely apparent. I felt helpless in so many ways that I jumped on the first opportunity to fight back, to take a stand, to support those who were vulnerable and needed me. Donning my mask and poster with “Black Lives Matter” written in large black lettering, I took to the streets to march in solidarity with my friends, family, and community. I could feel the pain and hurt coursing through those around me, and I wanted to do my part to ease them. Being a witness to the disparity of my community was heartbreaking and eye-opening. This rally taught me the meaning of empathy and its importance in healing and growth. I realized how medicine can play a role in healing not only physical wounds, but social and emotional ones. The connection between medicine and social justice clicked in a new way and I understood that a career in medicine involves bringing justice to underserved communities.
My excitement for social justice and desire to connect with people prompted me to consider completing a year of volunteer service after college. I chose a program in Los Angeles that aligned with my values and goals and boarded a plane headed west. I was not concerned about the eight strangers I would be living with or assimilating to a big city, but I was scared about how well I would connect with the clients at my placement site. I had no experience working in the mental health field, in social services, or with unhoused or previously incarcerated adults. I was afraid there would be few commonalities to facilitate a connection. My first few months working as a case manager at the Alcott Center for Mental Health were challenging. I struggled with learning new lingo, navigating the unfamiliar field of social services, and feeling that I was not doing enough for my clients. But with each interaction, whether it was taking a client to the DMV to renew an ID, coordinating care with a client’s psychiatrist, or listening to a client share their struggles, I began to understand the impact that compassion has on the most vulnerable. I was finally able to see the connections I had built with clients and the many ways in which I had helped them thrive. I had listened to them, connected them to necessary resources, and provided them with a safe space to address their mental health when nobody else would. I was frustrated that I could not do more for them and missed being able to use my science knowledge within the field.
I began to reflect on why I missed science and what fueled my love of it. My first biochemistry class in college made my passion for science click in a different way than it did previously. I could see how science applied to actual people and I wanted to be a part of the larger scientific community. I started volunteering my time to assist in the Oakley Research Lab and eventually joined the lab in the fall of 2019. Being involved in research was intimidating to say the least. I was working under and alongside well-known investigators and I had very little biochemical knowledge or intuition. My time there fulfilled the need to connect my experiences and knowledge gained in the classroom and teaching labs to a long-term goal regarding a specific protein. I quickly found that lab work is tedious, time-consuming, and prone to mistakes and failures. From these challenges, I learned how to apply my forming biochemical intuition in overcoming stumbling blocks and forging a new path toward success. I was able to form a goal and take steps toward achieving it by creating protein constructs for use in functional experimentation. However, my experience with biochemical research made my passion for working with people, as opposed to petri dishes and proteins, more apparent. I enjoyed knowing my hard work would benefit the field of science, but it lacked the essential connection to people that the field of medicine provides.
My array of service and educational experiences helped eliminate other career options, and it is at the intersection of my passions for research, biochemistry, service, and community interaction that I have come to know medicine. What could’ve easily motivated me to become a social worker or academic researcher, highlighted their shortcomings and how medicine includes aspects of both. What I was looking for in my experiences and what I received were radically different. My initial impulse to serve and assist was motivated by compassion and drive for knowledge, but I gained an understanding of how to bridge the gap between emotion, humanity, and science. I realized that service and learning take many forms, like volunteering at a mental health clinic, researching proteins in the Oakley Lab, and marching against hate. These experiences have given me fresh eyes and newfound confidence that pursuing medicine is the only way that I can impact my community and be fulfilled. I was not expecting to confront my calling to medicine at a Black Lives Matter protest, but it changed my life in a profound way; medicine was no longer just whispering to me, it was calling to me, and I am ready to answer.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I completed a year of post-graduate volunteer service, working full-time as a mental health case manager in Los Angeles. Moving from a small town in Indiana to a big city like LA was a huge change in diversity. As a case manager, I assisted people experiencing houselessness, substance use disorders, mental health struggles, and previous incarceration. Most of my clients were of different religious, cultural, and ethnic backgrounds than myself. Providing resources and emotional support to clients with such diverse backgrounds was challenging and rewarding. I learned how to be more sensitive to these differences and use these differences to understand and connect. I know more about different religious and cultural customs because of my relationships with clients, and I am grateful to have broadened my world view. The most important lesson I learned through my interactions with diverse communities is that we all have the same goals and wishes: to be understood, respected, and loved.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: During my year of volunteer service, I lived with eight other women. We collaborated on expectations for shared food, finances, cars, responsibilities, and living space. Although we were strangers when we moved in together, we became friends throughout the course of the year. With each of my community mates, I fostered unique friendships, some deep and heavy and others fun and light. Each of us experienced challenges throughout the year, and much of our non-profit work was emotionally and physically draining. In my community, I played the role of active listener, unwavering supporter, and comedian. Without my unique traits, the community would have lacked the sensitivity and levity that I provided. I taught each person to value themselves, demand respect, and forgive when mistakes are made. I witnessed these skills bolster confidence in my community mates‚Äô interactions with others and strengthen their self-care routines. My example and guidance impacted the lives of my community.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Before the pandemic, my path to medicine would have been traditional. However, the concurrence of the pandemic and the Black Lives Matter Movement forced me to consider an alternative path to medicine by incorporating my passions for service and justice. The pandemic provided creative ways to gain shadowing experiences, offered a unique perspective on medicine, and allowed me to build confidence engaging in telemedicine. Despite these opportunities, I desired connection beyond a screen. I wanted to practice applying my passions and skills in a clinical setting, and my time as a case manager allowed me to do that. I was able to experience a hybrid clinical environment akin to the current medical atmosphere. The pandemic provided a reflection space that allowed me to consider a year of service. From this, I gained valuable clinical experience, knowledge, and growth. My year of service, and inadvertently the pandemic, solidified my desire to pursue medicine.

personal_statement:
There is a beautiful valley in Colombia, South America, which is the only place on earth where a special species of palm tree towers 60 meters high among the green mountain peaks. Taking in this scene from the open jeep bumping down the dirt road, I imagine what it would be like to live in this breathtaking paradise. It seems like a utopia until I remember that many of the inhabitants of Armenia, Colombia lack many basic human necessities such as sanitation, safe housing and education.  This was my second visit to this part of the world to work for a nonprofit organization called Imagina. This organization was created to provide a safe haven and education for poor kids on the streets of the city, and to keep them from falling into the gang and drug culture. Before the trip, I developed and obtained funding for a summer educational program to offer the children swimming and English lessons.  It turned out to be one of the most memorable and meaningful experiences of my life.  I learned to understand a new perspective of the world through the children and the differences in our ways of life. I learned a lot about myself as well, how much I love connecting with people from other cultures. I also learned how much I enjoy serving people wherever and whenever I can. This experience motivated me to join mission trips to El Salvador and the Philippines, and work in homeless shelters in Baltimore City.  Most importantly I learned that compassion for others enhances one’s ability to do any service-oriented job better and with purpose.  I believe compassion and service must be integrated into the work of a good doctor.
Growing up in a medical family has allowed me to find models of good healthcare workers, and has nurtured my desire to work among such people. My mother, a nurse practitioner, and my father, a transplant surgeon, met through their shared patients with kidney failure. I have witnessed firsthand their dedication, commitment, and enthusiasm to care for the socially disadvantaged in Baltimore.  I’ve also worked with other doctors and nurses with similar values during my volunteer work at the University of Maryland Medical Center. These healthcare workers have inspired me to acquire the knowledge and skill to do such heroic and lifesaving work. However, my biggest role model in my life and career has always been my father. My father has worked in Baltimore as a surgeon for many years and has often discussed his work with me and introduced me to opportunities there. I was able to experience intense emergency medicine through my time volunteering for UMMC Shock Trauma, which enthralled me. This team of fast paced medical experts sparked my excitement for a future in healthcare. However, when the dust settled it was what was behind the scenes that sealed the deal for me. It was watching my father run down to the hospital cafeteria in between cases to get one of his hungry patients a sandwich, drive a couple hours across state lines to attend a longstanding patient’s funeral, or sit listening to an older patient explaining her day’s needlework because no one else came to visit her. He did not just love his work, he loved the people he served.  He loved healing people, and because of that, all the sacrifices he made for other people’s lives gave meaning to his career. Through him I learned that in order to navigate human suffering in the medical field we need the compassion, resilience, perseverance, and grit that we bring with us from a variety of real world experiences.
I believe that one of the greatest strengths in a good doctor is compassion because it gives more significance and power to a doctor’s natural inclination to heal people. Compassion is a willingness to suffer with another, even when you cannot do much to help them.  It is a difficult virtue to practice, but it comes through gaining perspective of another's world and wanting to improve their condition by giving of yourself. I have had a chance to cultivate my own compassion by exposure to service projects, and by observing compassionate people around me. Community service was a foundational part of my upbringing and behind all of it has been the instruction that “to whom much is given, much will be required” (Luke 12:48). I am fully aware of the many privileges and opportunities I have been given, especially the education and experiences that have allowed me to develop a deeper understanding of the world around me. Many of these have exposed me to an abundance of suffering due to poverty and poor health, and shown me how people can be deprived of many things that make life enjoyable. I have allowed those memories to fuel my ambition for joining the medical field in order to integrate myself into a community of people that serves the suffering. The world may never reach the utopia we all strive to achieve, but I hope to fight for a healthier world one patient at a time, using compassion and hard work to alleviate some of the pain of those around me.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
I truly believe that our strength is in our diversity. Many different backgrounds and opinions produce a variety of ideas for solving problems. Starting at a young age, I was involved in_x000D_
exchange programs and mission trips, as well as extensive education in Hispanic culture through my undergraduate Spanish minor degree. This exposure to different people has taught me that each individual life track gives rise to different beliefs, and to understand those perspectives we need an open mind and empathetic heart. I have learned that bias and discrimination are often due to lack of understanding of another party and a need for education and compassion. Making connections with many kinds of people is something I have always liked, and I will bring this accepting, open-minded attitude with me to Rush Medical College. I would like to be part of an educational community where practice of these principles is encouraged.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
For a volunteer trip to Colombia in 2019 my sisters and I raised money and designed lesson plans for a summer camp to teach disadvantaged kids swimming and English. This trip enabled_x000D_
me to build personal relationships with people in rural South America, and who live their lives with none of the material resources that have been given to me. My sisters and I continue to_x000D_
follow the progress of these children, and we regularly send money to support their higher education. My undergraduate major in Public Health Science and my mission work in South_x000D_
America have given me insight into how important it is to have innovative healthcare strategies for underserved areas. These experiences fostered an interest in working with public health_x000D_
programs that look for creative ways to prevent and treat medical conditions in environments with limited resources. I hope to have the chance to join my fellow medical students in the Rush Community Service Initiatives Program outreach clinics.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I feel the need to speak on my undergraduate transcript in General Chemistry II. I withdrew from my first attempt at and then took it pass-fail. I don‚Äôt believe the transcript reflects the effort I put into the course, or the fact that I had a very good grasp of the content when the course was complete. I could point to several issues at the time like the turbulent academic environment brought on by the COVID epidemic, the transition to online classes and tests, and some other personal stressors in my life. However, ultimately I adapted and worked very hard, and developed a great relationship with the course professor, who wrote me a letter of recommendation supporting my application to medical school.

personal_statement:
I stood in the airport at four in the morning, my eyes glazed over, both saddened and exhausted by the previous day. I hadn’t slept yet - the NCAA hadn’t allotted us the time - as just four hours ago my position with University of Michigan softball had ended on a field in Seattle, two thousand miles from home. I looked to my right and saw our head coach, Carol Hutchins, engaged in a discussion over the game-to-flight turnaround time with the NCAA representative, still fighting for her student athletes' rights, the same way she fought to uphold Title IX over forty years ago. Female leaders and advocates for women’s equity on the playing field, much like Carol Hutchins, surrounded me during my sixteen years as an athlete. It is because of their guidance that I too became a leader and grew passionate for female equity. Though I had spent a majority of my life surrounded by strong female leaders, I was ignorant of how much I wanted these skills I had amassed from years as part of the athletic community to transfer into a future career as a physician. When I assumed the most direct role a person can have with a physician, as the patient, I witnessed firsthand the disproportionate amount of urban and underserved women plagued by chronic conditions and instantly felt pulled to serve, empower, and educate them.

My passion for medicine and working with urban, underserved female populations solidified when, in the summer of 2019, I woke up in a body I no longer recognized or felt at home in. I quickly grew accustomed to spending the better part of my time in and out of physician’s offices, fearful yet intrigued by the physiology of the disease that had come to plague my body. While a firm diagnosis is still on the way, I was eventually tentatively diagnosed with an autoimmune disease and my health has been well-controlled for over a year. Through this frightening time, I found solace in the dedication that my physician allotted to me and my care. She often stayed long over the allotted time to address all of my concerns and sketched complex physiological pathways for me to follow after she learned of my desire to become a physician. During the most medically difficult period in my life, my physician showed me compassion and dedication while delivering a patient-specific education to guide me through. In the midst of my first flare, I became inquisitive about both the physiology and the statistics behind autoimmune diseases. I realized that like my Hispanic mother, aunts, and great-grandmother before me, I had developed an autoimmune disease. I was unnerved at the number of Hispanic and other minority women, often in urban areas, who develop and struggle with autoimmune diseases and other chronic conditions. My experiences with my family’s health struggles and my passion for increasing female equity in athletics combined to bring to light a need to empower and provide women with compassionate, patient-centered care and an engaging medical education as a physician. In recognizing the intersection of women’s equity in athletics and healthcare, I sought out clinical experiences that would allow me to interact daily with underserved female populations.

When my feet once again found solid ground, I immediately sought out opportunities to engage directly with female populations and further advocate for patients in their healthcare experience. In the fall of 2022, I began working as a clinical research assistant testing the effects of a novel device on chronic stroke recovery. My favorite participant, “Ela,” was an older minority woman who, like most of our participants, had long run out of insurance-backed physical therapy and now relied on our sessions as her sole form of medical intervention. When Ela first began, I recognized that she was timid, didn’t believe in her capacity for improvement, and did not understand her diagnosis. I spent our sessions explaining how we hoped the device would help Ela and the specifics of her condition that had claimed the use of half of her body. I also listened to Ela and suggested various ways for her to incorporate her arm into everyday use through her favorite activity, cooking. By the end of our time together, Ela had improved greatly, and would often show up to our sessions with new ideas to try and newfound hope for her improvement. Though I loved the time I spent with Ela, I always wished that I had gotten to be there from the beginning, to have a more direct role in her diagnosis and care–as her physician.

My experience as a clinical research assistant confirmed what my experiences in athletics and my own disease had set in motion. From being raised as a leader and advocate for women’s equity on the playing field to experiencing a chronic disease that disproportionately affects women, I know that my passion for educating and advocating for women must combine into a career as a physician in underserved women’s health. Just as my physician dedicated herself to ensuring my well-being, and as head coach Carol Hutchins has fought for the advancement of women in sports, I hope to dedicate myself to my patients through advocating, empowering, and educating them to find their voice in their healthcare experience.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: When my participant was quieter than usual, I chalked it up to fatigue until we discussed his commute. He explained that he almost had an accident on the PACE bus and barely made it to the bathroom due to an abnormal three-hour commute. Many participants share that they cannot eat before commuting due to uncertainty about when they‚Äôll next be able to use a bathroom, are often bypassed by several full buses, and struggle to find ride-share drivers willing to assist them. Working with patients with physical disabilities has taught me about insufficient access to a city that we should all be able to explore freely. After learning of our participants' struggles, I began offering snacks to supplement their apprehension about eating and became more flexible in scheduling appointments. Working with individuals with disabilities has broadened my worldview on the accessibility of urban centers and taught me the importance of communication and accommodation when working with diverse populations.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Educational inequities are an important determinant of health that I have always been drawn to dismantle due to education‚Äôs profound ability to forever change the course of our lives. For the past year, I have tutored two west side students through Tutoring Chicago, and have recently been selected for a leadership position in the organization. When I first started tutoring ‚ÄúMaria,‚Äù she read below her grade level and disliked school because of how behind she felt compared to her friends. By the end of the year, Maria had earned all A‚Äôs & B‚Äôs, improved significantly in academic vocabulary, and began to enjoy attending school again. Volunteering as a tutor and associate board member for Tutoring Chicago has allowed me to impact Chicago students facing economic barriers. Though I hope to accomplish more in improving societal and structural determinants of health as a student at Rush Medical College, I hope to have played a small role in improving educational access for Chicago communities.
7_-_COVID_Impact: When the remainder of the B1G athletics season was canceled in 2020, I temporarily lost my job with the Michigan Softball program. When the loss of my position led to difficulty in supporting myself at school, I moved home to reduce expenses while utilizing savings as needed. I hoped to spend the summer gaining clinical experience and shadowing physicians, but when those experiences became unavailable I had to find ways to adapt my path to medical school. With little possibility of gaining clinical experience, I focused on my schoolwork and sought out clinical and shadowing experiences as they became available. The biggest change was moving away from my physician in the midst of my diagnostic journey. It was sad to place an indefinite pause on my diagnosis, but moving home allotted me time to develop healthy coping strategies. The pandemic also led to my most important volunteering activity, Tutoring Chicago, which has since become a large part of my life and journey to medical school.

personal_statement:
I was fifteen years old when I watched my grandfather be sentenced to federal prison. It was an unexpected decision for a controversial crime. I saw the ugly side of the story and watched my family get torn apart. The experience opened my eyes to the heartbreaking reality of the world in which we live, where injustice is an ever-present threat, and the punishment does not always fit the crime. As an aspiring physician, I have become aware that there is injustice in healthcare as well, and it comes in the form of health disparities afflicting underserved populations. I have committed myself to becoming a doctor who prioritizes awareness of self and others, one who makes equity of care an essential part of the patient experience. 

At the time of my grandfather’s arrest, I was deciding where to go to college and what to do with my life. My parents were pushing me toward law, perhaps due to what my grandfather had been through, but this career was of no interest to me. I did not want to be in a position to judge or punish people for their behavior; rather, I wanted to provide support in challenging times. I knew I wanted to be a doctor because I viewed it as a career where I could explore my scientific interests while providing care for the whole person, irrespective of past actions. Over the past six years, I’ve come to realize how important it is to be patient-centered and how a personalized approach is a critical part of the healthcare process. As a result, I’ve embraced the more significant role of a physician—to be the bridge that connects diverse communities to care in a way that embraces the life story of each individual.

All the experiences I have had throughout my undergraduate years and beyond have prepared me to work with a wide variety of populations with ever-changing needs. In an effort to engage with the Baltimore community, I have spent my free time volunteering. I mentored a fifteen-year-old boy to help him graduate high school. Despite his abilities, he struggled because he did not have time for school due to his family needing the additional income from his job. I also tutored incarcerated women in basic math and science to help them earn their GED. During our sessions, I quickly learned how most of the women I worked with had never completed middle school, yet they were motivated to take the next step in their education by any means possible. These experiences brought to life the disparities that I knew existed but had never witnessed first-hand. Preconceived ideas and misconceptions about patients are dangerous roadblocks to designing informed treatment plans. As a physician, I feel I must acknowledge that the interplay between a patient’s health and socioeconomic situation is as critical as assessing their physical condition.

After graduation, I learned more about instances of compromised patient care. I worked on psychiatric neuroimaging studies as a research coordinator. Many of my participants were poor, uneducated, suffer from mental health disorders or addictions, or demonstrate a combination of these factors. One of my participants, Andre, was homeless and frequently participated in research studies for money. I was warned that he was not trustworthy about his medical history. When I addressed a discrepancy with him in his medical accounts, he confessed that he had lied to ensure his eligibility. Hearing this, I was disappointed that I had allowed biases to influence my judgment of him. As a result, I started to provide more information about alternative options for study participation for Andre as well as future participants. I found that people were more willing to share their medical history and ask questions about procedural details because they felt like they had a part in the decision-making process. This has taught me to approach my participants as equal partners rather than as a superior. It is imperative for me to show them dignity and compassion and share all the information they need to be empowered to make their own health decisions. 

Today, my grandfather is a convict. Everything he has accomplished has now been overshadowed by his classification as a criminal. Just as preconceived notions overshadow how he is viewed and treated, biased opinions can make equitable care impossible. Together, my experiences have shown me the importance of treating the entire person. If a physician misdiagnoses or creates a treatment plan based on assumptions, it can be dangerous and even life-threatening. That patient’s life, as my grandfather’s, would never be the same. I take with me the lessons learned from volunteering with underserved communities and prioritize connecting with my patients on a personal level. I now access my life experience with my grandfather as a significant factor in helping me become a more compassionate and empathetic physician. Although I initially made the effort to disconnect his experience with my chosen career, I now embrace every life experience as one that can make me a better human being and a physician on which my patients can depend.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Growing up in a Mexican-American family, I saw my Guelita struggle to receive proper medical care due to her inability to speak English. Witnessing this gap in care made me aware that social determinants have an impact on the quality of care that people receive. Consequently, I began to value my multifaceted identity and came to trust in the significance of my diversity in medicine. I also made a commitment to respect the identity of others._x000D_
_x000D_
My Guelita‚Äôs experiences taught me that language or culture often limits the patient-doctor relationships and becomes a barrier to care. To provide equitable care, we as physicians must be aware of the impact social determinants can have on health disparities and become active leaders in public health initiatives. My identity, experiences, and future medical training will enable me to advocate for all community members to provide inclusive, equitable care. I hope to bridge the gaps in cultures and communities to give underserved patients a voice.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I mentor a 15-year-old boy named James from a disadvantaged neighborhood in Baltimore as part of Thread, a volunteer program. James struggled in school and would often skip his required after-school tutoring sessions. His teacher alerted Thread that his absences put him at risk of being put on academic probation. However, James worked a job after school and had been picking up extra shifts to help support him and his family. Recognizing this, I mediated a conversation between James and his school to arrange for James to complete his tutoring sessions before school instead of after. More importantly, I helped James better advocate for himself and form communication channels with his teachers. This created an avenue of trust between us that I cherish. I hope to continue to help him in his life journey and help break the cycle of poverty. Even more, I will continue to seek out uncomfortable social situations outside my norm to build self-awareness and understanding of those unlike myself.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
As I packed my bags to go home for Spring break, the last thing I expected was to live with my parents for the next six months. My new life at home was stressful. My father was a clinical pharmacist working on a COVID floor, while my mother was put on indefinite leave without pay. Like the rest of the world, we had to pivot. _x000D_
_x000D_
The pandemic disrupted my life but allowed me time to step back and evaluate my priorities. I recognized that I was not passionate about working in a lab but I enjoyed clinical research. I found a new interest in immunology, which inspired me to get my Masters in Health Science. It also helped me recognize my privilege - my family was healthy, we were not in financial danger, and we had access to essential resources. As a result, I volunteered to check in on patients and continued mentor to my high-school student. I learned to consider each patient's unique needs and listen intently. As a physician, I must take an individualized approach to provide the best care.

personal_statement:
“You gotta try making callaloo...that's the best way to boost iron,” Lydia shared as pregnant women around the room nodded with excitement. We were seated in a circle at Walton Family Health Center in the Bronx where I was leading a discussion about prenatal nutrition. The women smiled with familiarity at Lydia’s suggestion that the traditional Caribbean dish of stewed greens could help prevent anemia during pregnancy. Their shared Afro-Caribbean heritage proved more meaningful, and ultimately helpful, than the generic nutrition suggestions on the handouts in front of us. That summer, while working at a clinic that treated mainly Black and Latinx patients, I began to understand the importance of providing care that is culturally competent and patient-centered. At the health center, I was inspired by the physicians who had dedicated their careers to caring for groups traditionally underserved by the medical system. By providing care that was accessible – culturally, financially, geographically – and compassionate, the physicians were playing a part in addressing the stark health outcome disparities for women of color in the U.S. I hope to follow in the steps of these mentors by providing quality care to historically neglected populations. 
My time at Walton showed me the possibilities and limits of clinical care. I could offer women a prescription for a breast pump or a voucher for transportation to the clinic, but I wasn’t addressing the root of these challenges. So, I joined the Project Respect team at Boston Medical Center, where I am leading a research project examining racial disparities in women’s addiction treatment. As I began conducting interviews with women of color about the obstacles they face to receiving care, I was nervous about my ability to connect with them. Traveling to methadone clinics every morning or fearing they may face legal consequences for their addiction if they seek care, these women face many hardships. I found that by validating their struggles, celebrating their strengths, and most of all, listening without judgment, I could create a confidential and safe space despite our deep differences. I was privileged to have the opportunity to create these intimate one-on-one environments for women to share vulnerable reflections. I want to be a physician so I can continue to receive patients’ stories.
Sometimes, a patient’s medical condition creates new priorities. I witnessed the power of honoring each patient’s unique set of priorities during my time at Entre Familia (EF), a bicultural residential treatment program for mothers with substance use disorders. At EF, I facilitated support groups for expecting or new mothers. However, the residents at EF didn’t have the same concerns as the patients at Walton. Questions about breastfeeding were superseded by questions about their baby’s withdrawal or caring for their mental health while in recovery. By shaping our sessions to reflect these priorities, I found myself forming stronger connections with the residents. Truly caring for an individual requires understanding how their conditions may create nuances in their needs and goals. At both EF and Project Respect, I have learned that patient-centered care starts with creating space for patients to vocalize their stories. Carrying these lessons with me, I am equipped to continue building relationships with individuals from misunderstood and underserved communities, helping them achieve their unique goals and ultimately making my practice a more welcoming space for all.
My relationships with patients sparked my initial interest in medicine. But my research experience showed me the power of physicians as advocates and solidified my decision to pursue medical school. At Project Respect, I worked with Dr. Kelley Saia to publish a case report documenting a patient’s delayed metabolism of illicit fentanyl, the misinterpretation of the presumptive positive urine tests by the child welfare system, and the necessity of clinical advocacy to prevent unjust legal separation of the mom and baby. Physician advocates utilize our report in the drug court system to prevent similar familial injustices from occurring. While individual patient relationships can go a long way toward ending health inequities, the underlying causes of inequitable care lie at the structural and institutional level. The most effective way to create lasting change is through research-informed policy and advocacy. For example, building upon the case report, further studies may lead to reform of the local child welfare system’s policy regarding fentanyl screenings. I am motivated to continue conducting this kind of research, creating lasting impact.
I enjoy learning about and attending to every patient’s unique experience. The journeys of women from the Bronx to Boston, from community health centers to recovery homes have shown me the pressing need for health equity efforts. But my experiences have also given me hope in the ability of medical professionals to respond to this need. I am eager to use my career as a physician to provide equitable, patient-centered clinical care and to transform patient stories into research and policy that reflect the genuine, complex lives of the people I aim to serve.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: It‚Äôs 6:30 on Wednesday morning during my sophomore year at Barnard. I leave my dorm and hop on the M60 bus. Two bus transfers and ninety minutes later, I arrive at Rikers Island Correctional Facility, the city‚Äôs largest jail, to provide in-classroom academic support to their students. Each week, students shared their individual goals. Some were focused on the assignment at hand, others talked of passing the Regents exam so they could get a job once they were out. Centering each session around their unique goals, I connected with my students and uncovered insight into their lives. One student shared that he grew up down the street from Barnard. Another had plans to become a businessman. In order to truly understand their goals, I couldn‚Äôt rely on my own experiences and expectations but had to create space for the students to share theirs. I‚Äôm grateful for the opportunity to connect with the students at Rikers and the chance to engage across the many boundaries that divide us.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Despite the proven benefits for mom and baby, there are disparities in rates of breastfeeding between Black and white communities. As an Americorps volunteer at Boston Medical Center, I collaborated with community leaders to increase access to breastfeeding support in underserved neighborhoods like Dorchester, Roxbury, and Mattapan. Alongside women from the community, I took the course to become a Certified Lactation Counselor. However, instead of providing direct lactation services to patients myself, I created opportunities, like parenting support groups at local libraries, for these women to share breastfeeding knowledge with their peers. Moreover, the lactation trainings I organized served as avenues of professional development for these women, thus increasing economic opportunities. These projects mirror the approach I hope to take as a doctor - to not just treat, but to educate as well - and put knowledge back into the community's hands.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Throughout the pandemic, many of our patients at Project Respect struggled to access life saving resources, like in-person recovery groups or accessible psychiatric care. Social isolation and increased demand for social services made a high risk group even more vulnerable. The circumstances of patients at the clinic spurred me to help those around me meet basic needs so I began volunteering with Cambridge Mutual Aid. There, volunteers created carpools for community members to travel to doctor's appointments or childcare collectives for frontline workers. I was impressed by the impact we had when people came together to care for each other and address the gaps left by systemic inaction. This work highlighted the importance of creative solutions, such as weaving community-level interventions with hospital and outpatient care, in addressing the both pandemic and long standing health inequities. As a physician, I aim to find new, bold ways to shift our healthcare system to work for all.

personal_statement: As a doe-eyed teenager, my life had consisted mainly of following in others’ footsteps, taking in life day-by-day. While I had recently begun taking myself more seriously as a student, I had felt somewhat directionless. I had earned my driver’s license, had nearly a year of work experience under my belt, and took on more challenging courses while preparing for college applications. Shortly before my seventeenth birthday, this relatively bump-free life took an unexpected turn when I woke up on the bathroom floor after stepping out of the shower. Following two separate seizures, I was diagnosed with a right temporal astrocytoma that required resection. Though the surgery was successful, I faced the challenge of trying to get my life back to normal. I couldn’t drive; I was not prepared for my AP exams and SAT; and I lost my first job. Receiving cards, calls, and visits reminded me of how far I’d gotten with the help of others. Still feeling two steps behind, being surrounded by care along the way had motivated me to keep moving forward and work harder to take my future head-on. Prior to my surgery, I recently began attending Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu classes after a friend invited me. Despite not knowing of the sport beforehand, I thought I’d try something new and expand my boundaries. Still recovering from surgery and without much experience, I did my best to pick up technique by observing classes. Once I was medically cleared to participate, I found myself struggling to keep up with other students. Each day I returned and asked our instructor what I was doing wrong, and how I could improve my technique; many nights I would remain after classes ended, working one-on-one with her to break down mistakes I was making, continuing our discussions as we washed the mats together. With years of training, failure, and learning, my sensei gave me the opportunity to begin teaching classes to my peers. Doing so had helped me realize how much I had left to learn while allowing me to pass down what I had learned so far to others. I saw newer students making the same mistakes I had, and I felt their frustrations. I asked each student what I could do to support them and help them learn, and geared my teaching toward that. Being able to guide students and observe their improvement drove me to continue to do the best I could. Entering college, I was excited by all the potential learning opportunities, while overwhelmed by needing to pick just one. While my experience as a patient pushed me in the direction of medicine, I had no knowledge of what being a doctor entailed. Unwilling to leave my questions unanswered, I had searched for experiences that would help develop my understanding of medicine. Following the advice of my pediatrician, I got a job as a medical scribe during my studies. As a scribe, I was able to observe the work of doctors across many specialties. I learned the importance of an open mind in medicine—that the propensity for learning is essential to the success of any physician across all areas of medical practice. Whether documenting endoscopies or orthopedic exams, my growing familiarity sparked more questions to ask the physicians with whom I worked. By seeing the everyday lives of physicians in a clinical setting, I was able to affirm my desire to practice while cementing my understanding of what it takes to be a physician. Now working in a clinical research setting, I am able to interact with patients and get to know them on an individual level. On one occasion, I sat down with a patient as she received her chemotherapy infusion, and we spent over an hour telling each other about our lives. She asked me about why I chose to work with cancer patients, then confided in me about how her faith helped her get through her ovarian cancer. Sometimes she questioned whether or not it was worth continuing. I reassured her that she is helping countless other women by allowing us to attempt an alternate treatment regimen. The reason I told her I wanted to work with cancer patients was that I felt a responsibility to further my understanding of medicine to improve the lives of those I had once been in similar shoes as. Many patients like her naturally ask dozens of questions regarding their treatment, of which I do my best to answer or seek answers from those more knowledgeable. In response, I ask patients that I work with to return the favor by informing me of what I can do to better advocate for them and ensure they receive the care they need. Whether wearing a gi and a colored belt or researching different treatment options for gynecologic cancers, I’ve found that there is always room to learn and improve. Much like the medical professionals who helped me at my lowest point, I want to do my best to gather the knowledge and experience necessary to give back to others in need. By being able to document encounters across different areas of medicine, I’ve only realized how much more I have left to learn. Becoming a BJJ coach and diving into the field that allowed me to continue has further encouraged me to develop the skills necessary to ensure others can take on the experiences their health has failed to afford them. For each and every person, my one goal is to do my part to help them live their lives on their own terms
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Manuel used the little English he had to ask about my family while making sure I was satisfied with my haircut. At the time, I didn't realize that this is just a taste of everyday reality for millions of people across the country. While lacking Spanish dialogue only made it harder for me to understand him at that moment, lacking English serves as a barrier to many aspects of life I've taken for granted. After leaving their home in the Dominican Republic to provide a better life for their children, Manuel and his family accepted me as one of their own when his daughter and I began our relationship. Since then, I've seen firsthand many of the challenges of being a first-generation immigrant in this country. Without speaking English, they need their children's company for appointments, translating important documents, or even ordering takeout. I had decided that I would begin learning Spanish so I can be one fewer person that makes them struggle with the language barrier.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Working with many patients from disadvantaged backgrounds as a research assistant at Women & Infants, I have taken steps to reduce inequities in our patient population. On one occasion, a patient missed her chemotherapy infusion due to being hospitalized while I was on vacation. Upon returning, I reached out to her to reschedule her treatment. She expressed distress due to the lack of compassion and communication she felt from her providers that, as a black woman, impacted her quality of treatment. I reached out to her oncologist to communicate her concerns, and suggested possible solutions to ensure the patient felt more connected to her treatment. Previously, staff have expressed discontent with the patient missing or being late to appointments, to which I explain her difficulty managing treatment due to raising her two sons alone while her husband is away as a missionary. As a physician, I hope to continue learning from patient experience to better advocate for equality in care.
7_-_COVID_Impact: After extending our Spring break by a week, our school soon announced that we would complete the rest of the semester online. As the graph of COVID cases climbed higher each day, my shifts as a scribe were canceled one-by-one as each provider closed its office to in-person encounters. Professors with whom I planned to join their research rescinded their offers, and the organization I planned to volunteer for discontinued all volunteering. As my paychecks shrank each week, I began a new job in a primary care office. As I began my senior year, my job could not accommodate my changed schedule, and I was laid off. Towards the end of my Fall semester, I received the news that my mother was sick. I was not allowed to visit her in the hospital; I soon spoke to her on the phone, hearing her voice for the last time. With COVID now integrated into our everyday lives, I have resolved to catch up on the opportunities I lost at the beginning of the pandemic, and march forward despite its setbacks.

personal_statement:
“At only 4 years old, she would get up from our table at a restaurant, confidently march over to another group, and jump into a conversation. Can you believe it?! So precocious!” Countless times I have heard stories about a young me displaying a fascination with people. This curiosity and love for connecting with others sparked the early development of emotional intelligence – otherwise known as emotional quotient or EQ – defined as the capacity to perceive, understand, and manage your own emotions and those of others. My EQ has enhanced my ability, in both personal and professional settings, to adapt my demeanor and responses to create an atmosphere of empathy and trust.

My earliest memory of putting this into action is in high school. As our minds changed along with our bodies, some people developed complex emotions and altered life outlooks. For two close friends, this led to a deep depression they felt would last forever. I strongly empathized and found it natural to engage with them, talking through what was happening and ways to approach their circumstances. While others were uncomfortable in this situation, I found myself saying the right things to put them at ease and be comfortable confiding in me. Looking back, I realize I was an early active listener, which enhanced my appreciation for the complexities behind human emotions, thereby helping me better individualize my support. I became fascinated with what they were experiencing both psychologically and neurologically. This pushed me to research mental health pathologies and care options, which informed my understanding of the disorders, treatments, and advisable language to guide someone towards helpful resources. After encouraging them to talk to their parents and seek professional support – and for one person, even accompanying them to initiate a conversation with our school counselor – I was delighted to see my friends on the path to better managing their mental health. These experiences and their impacts ignited my interest in pursuing a career in medicine.

The first time I applied my EQ in a healthcare context was while leading a rehabilitation program for the BU Aphasia Lab in the summer between my junior and senior year. Tasked with developing the session plans, I did a deep dive researching current treatments of aphasia by reading numerous leading peer-reviewed articles on prior study outcomes and discussing them with the lead investigators. From there I conceptualized, designed, and implemented a program that used mobile technology, music, and mindfulness to aid daily functioning with aphasia. The class attracted patients with a variety of ages and cognitive abilities, some were nonverbal while others engaged in continuous ramble. As many were unable to adequately express themselves, I looked to other signals, such as behavioral reactions and nuances in facial expressions, to assess if they were bored or frustrated by the tasks. I quickly realized that we needed to adjust the sessions to be more personalizable, so we created levels that would allow each patient to choose a starting point and advance at their own pace. As the weeks went on, I was delighted to see their moods improve, observing that they were not only enjoying the exercises, but also benefiting from them. In the final class they each joyously showed off their favorite new skill. From this experience, I learned that standard treatments may not always fit every patient, and that it is important to pay close attention to both verbal and nonverbal cues to help inform personalized care.

In my post-grad jobs I found my EQ strength more valuable than any other clinical skill. At NYU, when assessing a potential study participant’s PTSD symptoms during a phone screening, I looked for changes in their tone while discussing a sensitive topic, and I reflected their feelings, which helped them become more comfortable sharing vulnerable information. In my current role as a medical assistant, before I draw a patient’s blood, I assess their body language as we start discussing the procedure, which allows me to adjust my approach to create a more supportive atmosphere. 

I have found that many people's negative perceptions of healthcare stem from experiences where they did not feel comfortable enough to fully express themselves, or sensed that the severity of their condition was being minimized, or desired more information to understand the full scope of their situation. Whether it is the perception that a psychiatrist is diminishing someone’s trauma or a gynecologist is normalizing severe menstrual pain, this is a narrative that hinders care across specialties even with the most well-intentioned doctors. I aim to be a physician who uses a holistic approach to understand patients’ physical circumstances, mental health, and overall well-being, and takes into account all this information when making care decisions. By leveraging and sharing my deeply developed emotional intelligence, I believe I could create an atmosphere that instills trust and helps patients feel heard. Ultimately this approach can lead to tangible medical benefits through improved communication and diagnosis, lower stress, and stronger faith in and commitment to treatment plans.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Every spring break in high school, I volunteered with a local church to build houses in Tijuana, Mexico. In just 4 days, a team of 13 students and 2 adults would build a two-room home for a multigenerational family, otherwise without reliable housing. This trip took me and my peers out of our daily lives, and it was formative to see how this community lived and to get to know our local family through conversation and stories. I looked forward to this trip every year and felt proud to work hard to positively impact their lives. On our last building day, we held a ‚Äúkey ceremony‚Äù to hand over their new home, and I will never forget the parents‚Äô thankful look for their family‚Äôs now safer future. These trips helped me learn how to quickly connect with people from different backgrounds, and made me more aware of those lacking basic needs, such as weather-proof shelter, and access to education and healthcare.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: For 2.5 years after graduating from BU, I was a research coordinator for an NYU clinical trial, which served uninsured women suffering with PTSD, often battling symptoms without treatment. To help them receive this much needed free therapy, I assisted in enabling the study to offer transportation at no cost, sick notes for work, and compensation for their time. As their point of contact, I worked closely with each participant throughout the study, from assessing their eligibility, to coordinating and conducting their visits. They would often confide in me about their challenges and how they used the study‚Äôs treatment tools in their daily lives. This close connection gave me insight into how much their symptoms were improving, and I loved seeing the benefits of empowering them to help themselves. Their visible clinical improvement brought me great joy and will further inspires me to offer treatment to those in need in my career as a physician.
7_-_COVID_Impact: When the first COVID-19 lock-down occurred, I was new to being on my own in NYC, far from family and friends, and living with roommates who did not always follow safety guidelines. After only 2 months of working remotely, my position at NYU was deemed ‚Äúessential,‚Äù and quickly I was back in-person full-time, and in close daily contact with coworkers with new and changing PPE protocols. That, plus studying for the MCAT, made this a challenging period. With the world suddenly in an unprecedented state, I was concerned I would not get the clinical research experience I had planned for, and considered leaving my job to quarantine with my family. After seeing frontline hospital workers relentlessly fight this life-threatening virus, I decided to stay and tackle the opportunity to get IRB approval for adjusted COVID-safe procedures and to enable remote visits. Ultimately, I loved contributing to NYC‚Äôs public health efforts, and hope to one day be as brave as those who protected our community.

personal_statement:
As I closed my eyes, my hands hovered over the balance beam, and I imagined all of my butterflies expelling from my fingers. Each time I compete, adrenaline and nerves take over my body. With one wrong move, my ability to compete as a gymnast was cut short. Sitting in cold plastic chairs, my mother and I waited for my X-rays to return. It had been eight months of pain, a dozen doctor's appointments, and many failed attempts to be the athlete I once was. Finally, my physician knocked on the door, came in with a bright smile, and said, "I have an answer." He looked me in the eyes and said, "You have a fracture in your L5 vertebrae." Instantly, a million thoughts ransacked my mind. No matter the diagnosis, a weight was lifted from my shoulders. I finally had an answer. As a fourteen-year-old, what seemed like a lifetime of uncertainty finally had a label. My mom's sweaty hand grabbed mine and tears began streaming down my face. My physician fulfilled a need for an answer, a need for hope, and I want to extend that to my future patients. 

During the COVID-19 pandemic, I decided to immerse myself in the world of medicine. I spent my days at a free clinic in my hometown. During my first week, I sat in on a call for patients with diabetes as they discussed the cheapest treatment options. The call consisted of six patients, one nurse, a translator, and myself, a young Latina. Exposure to significant barriers to care for Hispanic and other underrepresented patients in the medical field has since pushed me to explore how to address these barriers as a Hispanic physician. During my time at The Free Clinics, there were scarce providers with Hispanic backgrounds and numerous encounters requiring online translators. These cultural barriers pushed me to extend my studies into obtaining an EMT-Basic license, basic life support certifications, and taking Spanish courses that enable me to spread compassion and communicate with those less served in my community. 

Through Spanish immersion courses and service-based learning, I have explored ways that the absence of healthcare can affect everyday lives. The echoing laughter of children radiated in the Boys and Girls Club hallway, "Esperanza" approached me hopefully and said, "My parents do not speak English, will you help me?" Two hours of reading and math homework passed, and we began talking about some of her favorite foods and activities. Casually switching between English and basic Spanish, we discussed her life in America versus Guatemala. I asked if her parents ever cooked dinner at home, and she responded, "We don't have the money." I quickly realized from our conversation that she had never been taught nutrition. These unknowns may be translated into harmful effects on her health as she grows up. I want to be the bridge between underserved patients and knowledge of their own health. 

My time spent training for my EMT certification solidified my passion for extending compassion and hope to patients even in the case of no care. Walking through the halls of the emergency department, the intercom announced "pediatric car accident in five minutes." My classmates and I, as prospective EMTs, could only stand outside of the trauma bay and watch. Once the young girl was stable, my nurse came up to our group and said, "I need two females to come in and assist." Without hesitation, I followed her through the packed halls of the ED. We walked into the room full of bloody rags. I calmly approached the seventeen-year-old Hispanic girl, looked into her watery eyes, and introduced myself. Our eyes locked, she reminded me of a younger version of myself, helpless and scared of her outcome. 

I walked to the head of her bed and told her that I would hold her head and try to ease her pain as we changed out the C-Collar. Halfway through the change, she started crying. I asked her if I needed to reposition my hands. She looked at me and shakily said, "I have a daughter at home." For the next five minutes, we talked about her daughter and how she was on the way to pick up ice cream for them when she got into the accident. I had just stood and watched surgeons and residents work on this young lady, and I was getting the opportunity to reassure her in a moment of need. In just five minutes, this girl changed from a set of vitals to a person with a story and medicine gained an emotional meaning. I am motivated by emotional patient connections and unwavering support of patients to become a physician.

Through my personal and clinical experiences, I have learned how physicians can make life-changing impacts on patients. As a patient myself, I experienced days of hopelessness outside of the clinic. I want to provide my patients with the same knowledge, hope, and compassion that I received. I am drawn to becoming a physician, specifically, because I want to be the voice of hope and the bridge between meaningful connections and social change for individual patients, one patient at a time. When I become a physician, I will think of my fourteen-year-old self looking for an answer, of Esperanza who needed to learn how to take care of her body, and of the seventeen-year-old girl scared for her family's future. I will provide my patients with compassion, guidance, and I will make them feel heard.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Once in the facility, I asked a few people to help us slide our 400-pound patient to his bed. After some time, my partner and I decided we would have to move him over on our own. My patient began to tear up. He explained that as an overweight, African American member of the LGBTQIA+ community, he had experienced this treatment before. We assured him and provided him with our best care. Once comfortable in bed, I went and talked to a different member of the staff and made sure that he would be adequately looked after. My partner and I had no scheduled calls, so we stayed for a few minutes to ensure safety and talk with him about his art pieces in the window. This transport showed me that forms of unjust treatment show through in many ways, whether it occurs due to skin color, weight, gender identity, sexual orientation, or a variety of other reasons. Making this patient feel safe and heard was important. This has made me more aware of the support that I will provide to my patients.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: During my junior and senior years, there were two Hispanics on the North Carolina State cheerleading team, including myself. Sometimes we experienced bias taking place in minuscule ways, like taking group pictures. We were often separated in group pictures because we looked too much alike. However, these small actions have a major impact when group pictures are used as the ‚Äúface‚Äù of the program. These environments are often filled with unintentional ostracism. During the pandemic, when many social justice issues were being tackled globally, a group of minorities on my team decided to start a diversity and inclusion committee to educate our teammates. We led discussions and tried to include groups outside of our own in-groups, such as lessons about deaf and homeless community opportunities. Unintentional discrimination can be present in many different ways, so being able to educate my fellow teammates was beneficial in gaining respect and some level of understanding for each other.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
Personally, I went through a lot of battles with spending time with family while at my university. As a student-athlete, I was exposed to around 50 people each practice. While I had more time to spend with family since many things were canceled, I was often scared to go home since much of my family is at high risk. Spending time away from my family during this scary time period was difficult._x000D_
_x000D_
However, COVID-19 opened a lot of doors to explore what I wanted to do. I began volunteering at a free clinic and was able to see the way that COVID-19 affected people of all backgrounds. This showed me that I could make a meaningful impact locally in my community in a time of need. I found a true love for serving the underserved. Working with many people who were at high risk showed me that chronic diseases are much more prevalent in these underserved communities. Working in these communities showed me a side of medicine I had never seen. COVID-19 solidified my desire to apply to medical school.

personal_statement:
I’ve always paid attention to people’s behavior. I am usually the one who notices when someone speaks but isn’t heard. Born and raised in the US as the first child of Nigerian parents, I juggled two cultures. From my summer visits to Nigeria, I saw the remnants of a time during which food on the table was prioritized over empathy. My mother and father were born during the deadly 1960’s Biafra War, which I believe encouraged a lifestyle of “tough love”. This reality about my parents forced me to develop skills early on to navigate the rising tensions in our home. In the heat of arguments between my parents, I would translate their perspectives so they would understand each other, cool down, and resolve the problem. At the time, it felt necessary to play this role because it reduced the temperature in our home, and prevented my younger siblings from crying, and wondering if mom and dad would divorce. 

The skills I developed at home allowed me to recognize my friends’ emotional needs. I’d listen intently and break down the problem in an understandable fashion to them. They’d marvel at my ability to really understand them, but for me, it felt like second nature. Seeing the impact I was having on my friends gave me incredible joy. Unlike at home where applying these skills was a matter of survival, I felt sparks of passion whenever I helped my friends, and I began entertaining the thought that I could help even more people. As Ralph Waldo Emerson said, “A mind, once stretched by a new idea, never returns to its original dimensions.” I often reflect on this quote because now my mind has expanded, I can no longer “unsee” the emotions people experience. I also cannot prevent myself from wanting to help them. So the next question for me was always - what comes next? As much as I wanted to find immediate answers to these questions, I had to pause my future career search because I faced brand new challenges in high school that I had never faced before.

My parents enrolled me in a prestigious boarding school in Massachusetts, a thousand miles away from home, forcing me to exercise independence for the first time in my life. I navigated all the typical and atypical high school experiences alone - from dorm drama to student protests. As the first in my family to go to high school in America, I had no one to guide me in this new environment. At my new school, I struggled with imposter syndrome and I didn’t know how to use my skills to find my place. But after taking time to reflect, I began to notice that the exposure to many cultures and people was teaching me to build connections with those that were different from me. Realizing that I wouldn’t have had the chance to receive this privileged, well-rounded education at home revealed to me the positive side of this experience. 

Motivated, I took all the psychology courses my school offered and asked my teachers to recommend books to read. I then channeled my energy into learning about psychiatry, a more methodical and researched-based approach to understanding people, their motivations, and their mental challenges. At a summer program, I was able to participate in a neurology project studying the effect of SSRIs on memory. I discovered that I was especially passionate about mental health disorders even without knowing exactly which area to focus on.

As I headed off to college, I wanted to find a career that would match my passion. At university, I saw how my friends were put on various medications for diagnosed disorders. The medications improved their quality of life, however, they still confided in me about the very same problems they began medication for. It made me wonder if those medications were indeed addressing the root cause or just suppressing the symptoms. So I researched other forms of treatment such as cognitive behavioral therapy and other psychotherapies. It left me wondering if there was a middle ground between medical and holistic treatments for mental health. During my junior year, when my college professor wrote a comment on an assignment that my thoughts embodied cura personalis - a concern for the care of the personal development of the whole person (mind, body, and spirit) - he validated my motivation to pursue the holistic side to mental health as a physician.

I have had many opportunities and learning experiences that have led me to where I am today. Among these is my current position as an intern shadowing clinical psychiatrists who treat the mental effects of patients struggling with chronic health diseases. I now recognize the relationship between biology and psychology as I watch them bridge the gap between the mind and body. It inspires me and confirms my desire to pursue medicine to ultimately become a psychiatrist. I truly believe this is my calling and I know my medical training will equip me with the tools and knowledge to make a meaningful impact in the lives of my patients.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: In 2017, I helped organize and lead a medical mission to Liberia. Our goal was to deliver temporary healthcare services to the indigenous people in Ganta. My job was to communicate to the locals about their symptoms. While I don‚Äôt speak any of the native languages, I was still able to interpret their English because of my own cultural background. As a Nigerian American, I‚Äôve spent my whole life repeating my parents‚Äô accented English for American ears. This mission gave me a small yet significant glimpse into a world of patients outside of first-world countries. Culturally aware providers strengthen patient-physician trust, increasing the likelihood of patients visiting clinics. This experience reinforced the importance of treating patients across cultures as well as SES. Living in an intersection of multiple identities, from being American to African, has placed me in a position to think critically about diversity and contribute to the multicultural conversation.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Adiza was a bold and brash high schooler who held unpopular opinions. These would get her into trouble because they made people uncomfortable. I felt the same way but was curious about this Boston-raised basketball champion because I wanted to understand her. Surrounded by Caucasians and heterosexuals as a biracial, bisexual young girl, she shrunk herself to fit their standards. She confided in me after I attempted friendship when no one else did. She had been hiding her sexuality for years, living in a culture where it wasn‚Äôt okay to be gay. She told me she felt seen by me because I welcomed her to our dorm. I also asked her questions about where she got her opinions from and how others had treated her. Slowly, she stopped spouting offensive opinions. She allowed herself to be loved, which healed the pain she held in her heart. We are still very close and when we reminisce about high school, she never fails to remind me that seeing through her facade changed her for life.

personal_statement:
Red splotches covered my torso, arms, and legs. They itched and stung. I am twelve years old confused about what is happening to me and overwhelmed by a feeling of dread. My soccer game was quickly forgotten; instead, my parents brought me to the closest hospital. People were talking fast, my mother was distraught, and the waiting room was full of people of different ages—each sicker than the last. After what felt like forever to my adolescent self, I was brought through the double doors to the only vacant bed in a crowded hallway. Surrounded by my parents, the feeling of dread continued to grow. Finally, a physician came over, crouched down to look me in the eye, and said, “Sometimes things can be scary, but we’re going to do everything we can to make you feel better.” Eventually, I was treated, discharged, and allowed to return home with an EpiPen. Although I never learned the physician’s name, his words in the middle of the chaotic emergency department were a defining moment in my journey to medicine. His compassion and communication during this interaction helped me understand the privilege of assisting people when they are most vulnerable. This core memory sparked my passion for medicine and was fueled by my future experiences as an emergency medical technician (EMT).
 
Working as an EMT, my partner and I responded to a pediatric seizure call. We pulled up to the residence to hear, “We’re coming out to the ambulance; it’s a confirmed arrest.” My heart sank as I realized the enormity of the situation. What started as parents concerned for their seizing child quickly escalated to a 10-month-old turning blue and without a pulse. Before my paramedic partner and I were out of the ambulance, we saw a local fireman coming down the stairs with the limp body of the child. My partner and I were spurred into action. Adrenaline pumping, the protocol for a pediatric arrest ran through my head like a mantra—start CPR, attach the pads, and establish the airway. As each step was completed, it felt like ten more took its place. Pulse checks were met with no success. Before long, we’d done all we could in the field. My partner looked at me across the ambulance and said one word: “Drive.” Responding to the nearest hospital, I couldn’t help thinking of the child in the ambulance and the parents left behind at the house. We arrived at the emergency department to be met by a swarm of physicians and other medical staff. All I could think was, "Please, let it be enough," even though I knew it was too late. Not even five minutes later, I lost my first patient.
