As a patient, I was provided a brief insight into the world of medicine; the act of service, selflessness, and dedication are the foundations of medicine that initially drew me to this profession. As a certified EMT, I was brought full circle: from being the child with the medical emergency to the provider treating the child. I originally became an EMT to pursue the principles I witnessed as a child; however, with the loss of my first patient, I began to recognize the realities of medicine. The highs of realizing you made a positive impact are counteracted by the lows of witnessing a patient deteriorate. When the latter occurs, it is heart-wrenching and revealed to me my inner strength. Returning to work the next day after the pediatric arrest, the first patient of the day was difficult. However, as the day progressed, each call was easier than the last. While my heart still hurt over the lost child, I chose to focus on the positive impact I was making on each patient that day. Although not all the calls were as intense as the pediatric cardiac arrest, I treated each patient with the same focus and care. Knowing I eased someone’s pain when they are most vulnerable makes the challenges seem minute. This experience emphasized that medicine is dynamic, but also fallible. Witnessing the hardships of this profession, my resolve to become a physician and persevere past the challenges to facilitate patients with their needs has only strengthened. My current medical knowledge is limited, and I am restricted in the level of care I can perform at this time. By becoming a physician, I can expand this knowledge and have a greater outreach.
 
My experiences–from a child having an allergic reaction to an EMT–have cultivated my drive to become a physician. Each of these experiences has instilled in me the knowledge that medicine is multi-faceted and is the culmination of several domains. Instead of focusing on one aspect of care, medicine is where empathy, compassion, science, and health combine to form a field I am dedicated to pursuing.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: An adolescent patient identified as transsexual and was self-harming to cope with her emotions. She was in tears as she told me that the kids at her school ignored her request to use her new name. All I could think was, ‚Äúshe is not much younger than my little sister and she is already facing adversity.‚Äù Her mother thanked me at the end of our conversation for treating her child ‚Äúlike a person‚Äù because I used her requested pronouns and name. This comment resonated with me. It was a stark reminder that treating others with dignity and respect is not something everyone has the privilege of experiencing. This experience highlighted that no individual is safe from adversity and it enhanced my desire to fight for patients‚Äô rights whether that be women‚Äôs health, LGTBQIA+, mental health, or basic human rights. I learned that a physician‚Äôs role is multifaceted including understanding these issues and committing their lives to assist their patients on a societal level as well as physical.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I oversaw the implementation of a school supply drive for a local elementary school. The area surrounding Syracuse University has high rates of poverty and homelessness; as a result, students attending the city schools are oftentimes without adequate supplies. We gathered supplies and donated them to the elementary school‚Äôs students. While dropping off the supplies, the students‚Äô faces beamed with happiness. The school supplies relieved a financial strain on the parents of the students and excited the students. This is a small fix to the larger issues of poverty and homelessness, but it at least changed the lives of the students receiving the supplies. I strongly believe that everyone has the right to a solid education regardless of their financial background and I will continue to support similar communities during my time in medical school. I appreciate RMC‚Äôs dedication to improving societal and structural determinants of health and hope to contribute to its commitment.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, my clinical experiences were delayed. Hospitals in my area were not accepting new volunteers and clinical courses were suspended. Without access to traditional clinical experiences, I instead utilized my time on volunteer work and providing mental health resources to students on campus. During this time, I also explored virtual shadowing to learn about different specialties that I did not have access to. Once certificate programs began to open, I enrolled to become an emergency medical technician. Since the second year of the pandemic, I have worked full-time as a first responder providing direct patient care to help alleviate the additional strain of COVID-19 on the medical system. As a first responder, I learned the toll a pandemic or crisis can have on the medical system and the population it serves. I am honored to have assisted during this time of need and I will utilize the insights I gained to further assist my future patients.

personal_statement:
When I was thirteen years old, I learned that our family was going to begin caring for foster children. My parents told my siblings and me that we were going to give these children a safe place to live and treat them as members of our family. I remember being filled with emotion during this time. I was angered, thinking about how my own life was going to be affected and how inconvenient it was going to be for me to have random children living in my home. That all changed when I started meeting the kids who showed up at our doorstep. They were coming from places of horrible physical, sexual, and emotional abuse that the average person could not begin to fathom. Whether they were abandoned by their parents or stripped from their arms by the state, these kids were left with nowhere else to turn, arriving at our home with nothing but the clothes on their backs and terrified looks on their faces. It was obvious that they deserved the utmost love and care that our family could provide. I realized how selfish I had been, thinking of my personal problems; these children were losing everything they knew and were urgently being placed into a foster home with complete strangers. While sharing a home with these children, my compassion increased as my eyes were opened to the magnitude of suffering in my own community. This realization inspired me to pursue a profession focused on providing relief from that suffering.
	Throughout high school, my family continued caring for foster children. I found time to balance my academics with helping at home and watching my foster siblings, so that my parents could get a break. For over a year, my family fostered a young boy named Isaiah. He was on the autism spectrum and had suffered from years of neglect and abuse, being shuffled from one foster home to another. While there could be good times with him, there were many difficult times as well. I had to face the frustrations that came with having a foster brother with a myriad of diagnoses and challenging behaviors; however, no matter how many times he was dysregulated and screaming at me or throwing things, I knew that if I stayed calm and comforting, Isaiah’s tantrums would cease, if even temporarily. After seeing him in crisis, there was an overwhelming sense of peace that I felt when I was able to help him regulate and acquire self-control. It was during these interactions that I decided I would strive to bring peace to those suffering during their bleakest times.
	I struggled for a long time trying to decide which professional direction I would take in my life. I considered many different professions with an emphasis on helping others, but my focus was switched to medicine during my first week of college. I met with a Twin Cities emergency department physician, who told me of his daily responsibility to care for patients during the most stressful and traumatic situations of their lives. He told me how he was able to calm these patients and treat them, so that they could move on with their lives or receive further care. Although I had no intentions of becoming a physician before that conversation, my eyes were opened that day to the possibility of serving people through medicine. I changed my major to Biology the next day.
	While progressing through college and my pre-medicine courses, I frequently revisited and grew excited about the prospect of emergency medicine. While I knew there was a long road ahead of me before practicing medicine, I wanted to start helping people as soon as possible. I enrolled in an EMT course to begin developing my skills and gain experience in emergency medicine. After receiving my certificate, I was hired as an Emergency Department Technician at United Hospital in Saint Paul, Minnesota. On only my fourth shift of training, a critical patient came in by ambulance and immediately coded. Acting on the instruction of the physician present, I began chest compressions. It was an overwhelmingly powerful and humbling experience knowing that my hands were all that were keeping this woman alive. As I worked, multitudes of medical personnel rushed into the room, working as a fluid team to keep this woman alive. After what seemed like an eternity, we were able to resuscitate the woman. I vividly remember exiting the room with my preceptor, visibly shaking from what I had just experienced, and I felt an immeasurable sense of purpose. I drove home that night in silence, unable to get the thought of that woman out of my head. 
Since becoming an ED Tech nearly four years ago, I have treated all demographics of patients. From stubbed toes to psychiatric evaluations and gunshot wounds, I have seen and experienced the full breadth of emergency medicine. While the outcome for every patient is not always as positive as the woman from that first week of my orientation, I find great pleasure in being there and caring for my patients when they need me most; it is one of the greatest privileges I have been given in life. I am beyond proud of the work I have done to help those who entrust me with their care, and I look forward to continuing to serve them in my future role as a physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Growing up in a family that has cared for 61 foster children from diverse backgrounds, as well as working with the varied patient population in an emergency department, I have been exposed to an array of different cultures, races, and socioeconomic statuses. Through my interactions with the diverse patient populations that I have served, I have learned how a one-size-fits-all mentality is not always appropriate for a healthcare setting, and accommodations need to be made to ensure all who seek care feel comfortable. _x000D_
_x000D_
I have spent thousands of hours in community with people from a large variety of backgrounds, which has helped teach me the unique beauty and struggles that arise with each of these different cultures. The knowledge I have gained through these personal interactions has helped outfit me to treat every person I encounter in a respectful and considerate way and to help lead them on a path to recovery and growth.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As an Emergency Department Technician at United Hospital in downtown Saint Paul, Minnesota, I have impacted the community by helping save the lives of patients since 2018. An emergency department is a necessary part of any urban area due to a lack of resources available to a large portion of its residents and those of the neighboring communities. I have been on the forefront of helping people gain treatment for their ailments by being a part of a selfless medical team who has dedicated our lives to caring for others. Whether it has been administering treatment to a patient suffering from an asthma attack, cardiac arrest, or mental health crisis, I am ready to do what is necessary to help anybody who comes into my hospital get the care they need to help them down a path of recovery. I have had the honor of assisting the remarkable physicians, nurses, and fellow techs, with whom I get to work, as we all come in every day with the same goal in mind ‚Äì saving people‚Äôs lives.

personal_statement:
The fans overhead were the only thing keeping us cool on an otherwise scorching day. It was Empowerment Day at Camp Kesem, an organization that hosts free summer camps for kids whose parents have cancer. This is the day that campers share their personal stories. These stories were the only thing that mattered at that moment. As I listened to each story, I was moved that this small community created a moment so intimate. Through this, I gained a greater appreciation for deeper connection and understanding, something I will carry as I work with future patients and has since further ignited my passion for medicine. To further explore my pull toward this field, I joined MD Anderson Cancer Center (MDACC) as a research intern.

At MDACC, I investigated how TTI-101, a drug in clinical trials, impacts mutated cancer cells. Due to the nature of the project, I began investigating the captivating intersection of scientific research with clinical medicine. No matter who I found myself conversing with, each interaction cultivated impactful relationships with my peers and mentors. These bonds highlighted the inspiring dedication required to our work and only strengthened my resolve to serve others through medicine. The persistence to overcome challenges is a mindset I have shaped through this experience and something that motivates me in all facets of life. I left MDACC with excitement for the future of medicine and a newfound importance of relationships between the lab and the clinic and how life-changing they can be. As stimulating as this experience was, I could not shake the feeling that my true passion lies in direct patient care.

As a healthcare technician (HCT) on the surgical floor of a hospital, I discovered what I was missing at MDACC. In the hallway, I saw the startled face of “Anne,” the wife of a patient currently in liver failure. Panicked, she asked if she could talk to me privately. Anne shared the worry she had about her husband's prognosis for recovery. She even disclosed her apprehension about asking questions, for fear of not being able to understand the answers. I sat there for a second as I witnessed worry intertwine with the tears in her eyes as she hoped for answers. It was evident that I was in no place to give medical advice or ensure her husband’s well-being; however, I provided what I could, an ear to listen and compassion for her situation. Anne left the room more relaxed as I stayed behind contemplating. I was conflicted, while trying to envision how I would have approached and educated Anne if I had the tools necessary. I was grateful to have given her some peace of mind, but I knew that was only temporary. I could not provide what she wanted most, transparency on the situation. This interaction emphasized that the high demand for physicians often stretches them to their limits. At that moment, I wanted nothing more than to help alleviate that limitation by playing a larger role in my patient's care and relieve Anne’s worry by offering the medical knowledge she desired.

Anne’s encounter was very reminiscent of my experiences at Camp Kesem. Although I have never had a parent diagnosed with cancer, I can only imagine the overwhelming emotions that come about when openly talking about it. I am very fortunate and thankful to have given this special population of children the opportunity to tell their stories for three years. Even though I knew that behind all their laughs, jokes, and smiles, their main worry remained: their parents' health. Regardless, the resiliency exhibited by these campers has inspired my pursuit to be a physician. Reflecting on my experience with Anne and the campers, I am eager to continue cultivating communities as a physician where I can share more of these transformative moments with patients and loved ones alike.

Over the years, I have come to highly value communication and its importance in fostering and growing relationships. Just as I have done through my collaborations at MDACC and interactions with patients and their loved ones as an HCT, I am eager to learn from the experiences and views of fellow medical students and faculty alike on my mission to become a compassionate physician and colleague. Likewise, I am eager to use my experiences in patient care, research, and leadership roles, to form an inclusive and welcoming environment. Such that my future classmates, myself included, can feel comfortable challenging themselves not only in subject matter, but personal development.

My time at MDACC only reinforced the stance that research is indispensable. While I am grateful for everything I have learned while there, the true heart and soul of medicine rests in care. Being able to do that as an HCT is something that has brought me so much joy, yet a desire to do more. Lifelong learning is an important aspect of this vocation, but the devotion physicians show to their patients and community gives me further excitement for a career in medicine. Knowing that a physician's role extends beyond physical healing inspires me. In my view, there is nothing more vulnerable or open than the patient-physician relationship. I am looking forward to the day when I can serve patients with devotion to their stories and be a catalyst in guiding them to remarkable lives.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Throughout college, I enjoyed being a part of ‚ÄúCelebra Floreciente‚Äù, a day of celebration that promotes Mexican cultural heritage and empowerment of the local Latino community. Speaking with individuals from the Floreciente neighborhood, I learned more about their passions, values, and hardships. Some of the individuals I met have insecurities in many aspects of life whether it be economic, educational, or cultural. Despite their challenges, they manage to keep a positive mindset. This is an attitude that I greatly admire and something I try to apply in my daily life. From interactions like these, I have learned to appreciate and value the opportunity to listen and have conversations with those whose experiences differ from mine. I believe that instead of viewing cultures as distinct and incompatible from our own, we should view them as an opportunity for growth and to broaden our knowledge of the world. At the end of the day, I endeavor to be a supporter and advocate for all.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: One of the positions I held during my time with Camp Kesem was outreach coordinator. This organization provides free summer camps for kids whose parents are affected by cancer. Many of the children that I have had the privilege of working with come from complicated and under-resourced backgrounds. Although the camp is free, campers must still bring their own clothes and camping gear. I have realized that certain families do not have the resources to bring the required items to camp. I encouraged my chapter to set aside money fundraised throughout the year so that we could supply those resources for families if need be. As an outreach coordinator, I wanted to ensure that camp necessities were not a barrier for their children to attend camp. I truly believe that anyone who wants to experience Camp Kesem should be able to. No matter my role in the organization, working with these campers has driven me to ensure that each family feels a sense of belonging to the Camp Kesem community.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Like many others during this time, leaving campus to continue classes online at home was a time of transition. While I did lose two jobs that I used to help pay school fees, I used the time that I would normally be at work to gain a better understanding of the material. Personally, my grandfather was placed in a nursing home in May of 2020, leaving my grandmother alone in their house. I spent extra time at their house to help with household maintenance and to give my grandmother some company in a time of isolation. While my original internship opportunity for the summer of 2020 was canceled, I was instead able to connect with Baylor College of Medicine to participate in a virtual summer lecture series from June to August. I am very appreciative of this experience because it not only provided a much-needed opportunity to converse with other students and faculty, but it allowed me a chance to stay involved and further my knowledge about some of the latest news in medicine and research.

personal_statement:
At two years old, I was just beginning to string together coherent sentences, and my physician parents taught me how to pronounce the word “diverticulitis.” Although my young brain could not comprehend what this term meant, I like to think my passion for science and medicine began then. Fast forward to undergrad, I rolled out of bed on a Sunday morning, ready for a routine 7am shift on the ICU floor at the Ronald Reagan UCLA Medical Center. I saw a commotion in a patient room, home to a 35-year-old man who I played cards with just a few days prior. He was stable overnight but deteriorated quickly, forcing surgeons to attempt life-saving measures in the ICU. It was too late; they were unable to save him from a fatal sepsis infection. I asked a nurse what caused this, and she replied with a familiar phrase: “diverticulitis.” In this full circle moment, I knew my career path was in the field of medicine.

From learning medical terms at the dinner table and begging my dad to bring in a human brain for show-and-tell, to now working directly with patients undergoing chemotherapy infusions, I have always been intrigued with the world of healthcare. I love the vast knowledge and challenging concepts medicine provides - yet I realize it is not simply about science. It is about the patients and their loved ones, the providers and their support crew, and the empathy, communication, and teamwork necessary to be part of a healthcare team.

As a UCLA hospital volunteer, I often interacted with patients from a non-medical perspective. I was the link between the distant outside world and the harsh medical one. I sat with sick and struggling patients, listened to their stories, and provided a moment of meaningful humanity during a truly difficult time. I talked for hours with “George,” a friendly older gentleman who had undergone a CABG with complications. He told me about his travels to Europe and his Tuesday golf adventures with friends. One day, George excitedly told me his grandchildren were visiting and asked if I would help him get ready to ensure he did not look “old and sickly.” I helped George look his best, and that brief moment of my time meant the world to him. The connections I built with patients while volunteering showed me to value humanity amidst professionalism. Compassion and empathy are character traits of utmost importance to me; my experiences have taught me to understand others’ personal struggles while providing needed support.

While earning my bachelor’s degree at UCLA, I was a member of the Division I women’s rowing team. Rowing in a boat of eight rowers, led by one coxswain, helped me master the skill of working in sync with others, while simultaneously maintaining technical precision and pushing my body to its absolute limits. In an environment of controlled chaos, with unpredictable outside forces, my teammates and I worked together to reach our goals. We relied on one another, trusting we would remain focused individually while overcoming every hurdle collectively. I faced many challenges as a Division I athlete, but with inordinate personal strength, resilience, and dedication - and an even greater commitment to my team - I thrived in this dichotomy of individual success and sacrifice. My rowing experiences translate directly to working with a healthcare team. Every member is essential and success is dependent on fulfilling individual responsibilities and being supported by the rest of the team. I am confident that when I become a physician, I will flourish and enjoy both the rewards of individual successes and strong collaborative team efforts towards a mutual goal.

While I have put my collegiate athletic career behind me, I remain a strong team player. As a medical scribe at the Stanford Valley Care hematology and oncology clinic, I work closely with physicians, PAs, nurses, and MAs to provide quality patient care. Communication plays an essential role in our team effort. When speaking with patients, I respectfully and caringly discuss medical information with individuals who are often in the midst of a medical crisis. When I draft the written record for each appointment, I observe the physicians moving from room to room, endlessly selfless, kind, and authentic with patients, while also demonstrating punctual and professional habits. I am inspired by the patients’ positive attitudes, despite seemingly insurmountable obstacles. I personally strive each day to provide the best patient care in the face of intellectual pressures. My commitment to my healthcare team and patients is unwavering.

Pursuing a career in medicine presents a challenging opportunity in a profession I find cognitively and personally rewarding. Through my experiences, I established I have the competence, character, confidence, and commitment to embrace this path. Having observed and worked with many admirable individuals within the medical community, I am passionate about continuing to develop my skills of empathy, teamwork, and dedication to healthcare. I strive to challenge myself to learn and grow, while building connections and interweaving humanity with medicine. One day, I hope to challenge my child to pronounce “diverticulitis” at the dinner table, and share my knowledge and experience with a new generation.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: In middle school, I had a foreign languages class in which every three weeks was an introduction to a new language and its culture. I became intrigued with Spanish, deciding it was the language I would learn. Ten years later, I graduated from UCLA with a minor in Spanish, further extending my cultural awareness and fluency. During my undergrad, I was constantly immersed in different cultures, meeting others from diverse backgrounds. One of my professors was an indigenous Kichwa woman from Ecuador; her perspective fostered in me a new appreciation for the importance of cognitive diversity. Furthermore, in my travels to Spain, Portugal, and Mexico, I had the opportunity to converse with native speakers and become more comfortable communicating in my second language. I experienced unique foods, asked questions about the countries‚Äô histories, and learned age-old traditions. Studying another language supports an understanding of the relationship between culture and humankind.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: My time working as a medical scribe has allowed me to apply my love for helping others, experience unique perspectives from a variety of individuals, and give back to the community. It has also shown me the many hurdles that the world of healthcare must overcome. In my clinic, the shift to Telemedicine has exposed inequities, forcing our clinic to address problems with diligence and patience to provide inclusive care to all patients. One of our patients is a gentleman experiencing homelessness, currently living out of his truck, and is without any access to a smartphone or computer. We arranged for him to come into the clinic and I assisted him with logging onto the video visit from an exam room to ensure quality care despite his circumstances. Factors such as affordability, access, and diversity can greatly influence healthcare. Achieving equitable and inclusive medicine will always be of the utmost importance, and I strive to play a role in addressing this persistent issue.
7_-_COVID_Impact: When the COVID-19 pandemic began in March of 2020, like others, I was immediately affected by it. My 100-year-old great aunt tested positive and moved into my family home to be under our care. While serving as a primary caretaker for my aunt, I balanced my academics, tutoring position, training as a DIvision I athlete, and studying for the MCAT, which had been postponed many months. My research I had just begun was canceled and all classes were moved online. Fast forward to today, the COVID-19 pandemic continues to have an effect on my experiences. Working in a hematology and oncology clinic, the virus is still threatening our immunocompromised patients. After the Omicron surge this past winter, the clinic was forced to convert to all Telemedicine visits for many months to minimize exposures. Although Telemedicine is challenging, I have learned to adapt as necessary, finding ways to provide exceptional care to our patients while also ensuring patient health and safety.

personal_statement:
As a child sitting on your grandfather’s lap, you wonder why he is in a blue gown instead of his usual dress pants, or why he has long tubes coming out of his body and can no longer speak to you. You start to panic as he doesn’t respond to your calls. You look around at your parents crying and your sister holding on to your mom’s hand, and the panic takes over. Tears begin and don’t stop as you yell at your grandfather to answer. While your mother cries in the corner, adults in similarly blue outfits sit you down and try to explain what is happening. 
My grandfather was diagnosed with stage 4 lung cancer when I was six. It was the first time I experienced life in a hospital. I did not understand why people were sticking my grandfather with long needles and would try to fight the nurses for hurting him. While my grandfather was still strong, he would tell me these people were helping him, how they were fairies sent to help him get stronger. I remember the doctor went along with the story, saying these fairies were injecting magic into my grandfather to help him feel better. Though I know now that the magic was medication, I am grateful to that physician for allowing me to stay a child for a little longer. It was the first time I had been directly impacted by a physician and six-year-old me wanted to become a fairy like him to help my grandfather.
Through Circle of Friends club in high school, I became close with an autistic boy named Spencer. He experiences brain aneurysm complications, leading to regular stays at the hospital. One day while visiting Spencer at the hospital, his mother pulled me aside and told me he would be going into surgery later that day. She was calm and unworried, confidently saying that she trusted the surgeon with her child’s life. I wondered how someone could entrust their child’s life to another’s hands, reminding me of my grandfather’s fairy metaphor. I realized I wanted to be that person, that doctor who eases the worries of patients and their families, earning their trust. I became excited to explore a career that would allow me to study the science behind that metaphorical magic I learned about as a child.
My passion was confirmed the following year when my grandmother’s health began to decline. Over the years, her physicians prescribed more and more medications. She went from taking daily vitamins and mild pain killers to taking six different prescriptions for ailments we didn’t even know she had. Soon she began to act differently. She could no longer cook or tend to her garden and was barely able to get out of bed. My grandmother kept telling me she was tired constantly and always in pain, saying the only thing that helped was the medication. We realized later that my grandmother was not communicating effectively with her physicians which contributed to her decline. My turning point for medicine was my grandmother’s health decline and death. I wanted to learn more about illness in the elderly population and health decline in general. I started to pursue medicine more concretely as I took classes related to medicine, becoming a certified medical assistant, as well as looking into colleges with good premed programs. 
When I graduated college, my pursuit continued as I looked for research opportunities involved with health longitudinally in a population. I heard of the Dallas Hearts and Minds Study (DHMS) through a friend at UT Southwestern Medical Center where they investigate the causes and implications of heart disease in a population over time. Once I was interviewed and heard about the work I would do with physicians and professors, the engagement with patient medical records to determine cardiac events, as well as interacting directly with a variety of study participants, I knew this was the perfect fit for me. I have learned the process of how to read and request medical records and how to interact on a professional level with physicians as well as patients. I am continuing to learn skills required for the biomedical field - communication skills, survey applications, adjudication processes, reading medical charts, phlebotomy, and more. I apply these skills in real life with DHMS. My involvement has an even greater impact on my life than I could have imagined. I have created relationships with the participants and physicians around me as well as found heart disease and the analysis of medical charts fascinating. 
I am inspired by the health professionals I work with daily, who are intent on building relationships, on being trusted by friends and family. I enjoy every interaction I have with patients and health professionals, learning and understanding research and the medical field. I understand the hardships and the daily challenges of life in medicine, yet I am confident in my abilities and am sure of my purpose. Every experience in my life has confirmed my passion. I want to become the “fairy” I grew up respecting, a doctor that my grandparents would be proud of.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I have been exposed to different cultures, religions, and ethnicities since I was young through my friends and family, developing an appreciation for the diversity I see. Through my exposure, I was aware of the discrimination and biases that exist in society, and when I went to college, I sought courses to help me understand this discrimination. I selected courses focused on subconscious biases, how to identify those biases, and how biases affect society. I then took a course focused on understanding and helping poverty in my college‚Äôs surrounding area. As I learned more, I wanted to continue broadening my knowledge by learning about discrimination in different cultures and religions through a course on genocide. I learned about the lesser-known genocides of the Armenian people, the Bambuti tribe, and more as well as the well-known ones like the Holocaust. Through these courses, I realized how much I don‚Äôt know and how much I will never know because I am not a minority.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Though I worked as a Caregiver for a short time, I had a huge impact on the people I worked with and in the special needs community. When I became a Caregiver for these 4 women with disabilities, I became a part of their daily lives. I was with them for 8-12 hours of the day, communicating and interacting with them. I helped them with their psychological and physical needs as they communicated with me about their emotions, their health, as well as their wants and needs. As I continued to bond with them, I became close with their families as I was involved with their social life as well as their healthcare, speaking to physicians and psychiatrists about their wellbeing. When I returned to college, I understood the impact I had on these women. I received numerous calls from their current caregiver and their family members, saying they were asking for me. It was then that I realized how important I was to these women and how I affected their daily life.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Due to COVID, the students at my college were dismissed from campus and required to return home. When classes switched to online, I realized how difficult it was to take courses meant to be in person, online, at home. After a month, I began to understand the mental strain of staying at home. I am an extrovert, and the inability to go out in big groups and see friends was a difficult change for me as I had to learn to cope with being inside constantly. However, I stayed excited because I had been accepted on a mission trip and a medical internship through my college in the underprivileged areas of South Africa. Sadly, the mission trip was cancelled along with the internship. Additionally, all study abroad plans for 2020 were cancelled as well. I was accepted to a university in South Korea for a semester abroad where I would have experienced a completely different country, culture, and language. I became fearful and overwhelmed as I was unsure what the future held.

personal_statement:
My laptop lit up as I accepted “Max,” someone living with gender dysphoria and on the verge of ending their life, from the crisis counseling queue. As I initiated our active rescue protocol, I realized the tremendous responsibility that lay in my hands. After each message, my stomach churned as I awaited their response; time could not have passed by any slower. I thought of the loneliness Max must have felt without their family’s support, a family who “didn’t believe in depression.” My heart ached to hear the distress they were in, and I wanted to do everything in my power to alleviate their pain. Forming intimate connections with patients like Max, who were in a vulnerable time in their life, fueled my desire to become a physician.
I knew that providing Max with a safe, comforting, and accepting environment would be crucial, so I utilized the skills I developed as a clinical assistant at Suburban Medical and Wellness Center. For example, when answering patients’ questions at the center, I simplified everything into manageable steps, translated medical jargon into understandable terms, and checked for comprehension. I learned that the simplest actions made the most significant differences. To make that same impact on Max’s life, I validated Max’s feelings and asked questions with genuine interest. As I reaffirmed to Max that their presence in this world was valuable, they agreed to consider alternatives to suicide with me. Despite my wholehearted efforts, not all cases had such a happy ending. The sense of loss I felt after an unresponsive active rescue drove me to work even harder and provide more relief. I felt immense fulfillment having the opportunity to help each person live to experience another day and enjoy their life even more.
My work as a crisis counselor paralleled my time volunteering at Blind People’s Association, a school for disabled children, where I observed differences in the treatment of marginalized people and the results of a lack of access to adequate healthcare. I heard how Radha, a girl close to my age, could not meet healthcare and educational needs as her family viewed her as “less valuable.” Her story inspired me to found Care for Precious, a nonprofit organization dedicated to addressing the needs of vulnerable populations. By implementing mentorship programs, distributing goods, and hosting workshops, I learned the importance of staying committed to a cause and listening to others’ perspectives. My time working to combat these health disparities taught me to advocate for those who confided in me and pushed me to explore medicine further.
As I dove deeper to understand medicine through shadowing, I observed the nuances and limitations of a career with such responsibility. It was heartbreaking to see a mother refuse treatment due to an inability to afford it, a newlywed couples’ dreams collapse as one of them was diagnosed with metastatic cancer, and another patient find no relief despite pursuing all available remedies for tinnitus. These limitations showed me how vital clinical discovery and comprehensive education are to improving human health. Staying updated on new findings and their implications will enable me to provide patients with the most effective, evidence-based treatments. By pursuing a career as a physician, I can harness its transformative qualities to increase the quality of life of others. Further exposure pulled me even closer into the realm of medicine: the challenge of diagnosis aligns with my love for problem-solving, and the team-based nature of healthcare speaks to my passion for collaboration.
Reflecting on my experiences, my perspective on the role of a physician has changed from someone who treats disease to someone who heals the body, mind, and spirit. As a patient named “Sally” began crying due to an intense fight with her abusive husband, leaving her stranded on a highway, Dr. Jagasia held her hand, nodded at each pause, and spent the time needed to make her feel safe and comfortable. Her frustration with her lingering symptoms melted away, and her motivation to improve her health increased as we modified the plan to match her circumstances at home. Just like Dr. Jagasia, I worked to treat Max with the utmost respect and understanding by establishing adequate support, providing practical coping skills that were personalized to their interests, and connecting them to more long-term resources. I hope to empower my patients to advocate for their own health while showing empathy when they are the most vulnerable.
Experiencing the genuine connection between a provider and their patient drew me to medicine. Even though many other healthcare professions contribute to leaving a meaningful impact on patients, I find that being a physician is the best fit for me. I want to be involved in the entirety of the treatment plan for patients and advocate for them when they are most vulnerable. I aspire to treat each patient with compassion and empathy while working to bridge gaps in healthcare. I look forward to harnessing the powers of medicine to extend every person’s most valuable resource and enable them to experience life to the fullest. I want to push the boundaries of medicine to make every story end like Max’s.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: A life experience that has humbled my worldview is volunteering as a crisis counselor. Through this experience, I counseled texters and formed intimate connections with people contemplating ending their lives or undergoing self-harm. Working with those experiencing eating disorders, physical/sexual abuse, bereavement, substance use, depression, anxiety, LGBTQ+ discrimination, and other mental health concerns broadened my worldview as I listened to each individual‚Äôs personal stories and challenges. For example, engaging in a sixty-minute conversation with a survivor of rape touched my heart as I admired her resiliency and guided her in processing her thoughts, especially when she felt like she couldn‚Äôt confide in anyone else. I learned how to incorporate complete open-mindedness to connect with people with different backgrounds, value other perspectives to learn and grow from them, and support people empathetically to help them during a vulnerable time.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I have impacted the unhoused community in Illinois through volunteering at C-U at Home Homeless Shelter to provide free otolaryngology care. Furthermore, I organized drives for the homeless through my nonprofit Care for Precious to donate blankets, personal hygiene products, oral health kits, care packages, sanitation supplies, masks, clothing, shoes, non-perishable goods, and other needs for shelters. I partnered with the shelter to refer people to affordable counseling services and provide additional mental health resources, like grounding techniques and coping skills to improve mental health. Through this initiative, I met ‚ÄúMegan,‚Äù to whom I recommended scholarship resources so that she could pursue a business degree. By partnering with local accounting corporations, I raised over $4,500 to support vulnerable communities further. The connections I made with her and others in these shelters motivate me to continue engaging with this community and advocating for them. _x000D_

personal_statement:
I did not always want to be a physician, but a specific experience during my high school cross country practice changed my path. In August 2016, my sister and I went to practice with our team for a five-mile run. While finishing the final mile on the track, I saw my sister lying down on the ground. I was initially impressed, because I thought she had finished the run and was recovering. Then, I noticed our teammates were huddling around her. Clearly disoriented, she kept saying, “I love you” to everyone around. Although my sister is an affectionate person, my coach was concerned and transported her to the local clinic. I was alarmed to see my sister debilitated. However, the way our family doctor consoled her allayed my fears. He has been a reassuring presence from the time I was a child. His capacity to match the emotional tone of the room while consulting is comforting and empowering. As we left the clinic that day, I wanted to serve people as he does; his compassionate practice of medicine was how I realized my own calling.

Service has always been an important part of my life. When I was younger, I volunteered to perform my violin and viola at nursing homes. The residents would perk up joyfully to my music, which brought me back often. This past year, I began volunteering with Promedica Hospice at a memory care nursing home. During my visits, I have learned about the lives of my assigned residents and have grown to love them, which makes it even more challenging to lose them. In December 2021, my assigned resident passed away. She enjoyed hearing stories, had a lovely smile, and charmed everyone. I was able to sit vigil with her before she died. It was a blessing to be able to say goodbye and to know she was with her children when she passed. Though a sad time, it was also beautiful. The staff on the premises honored her by lining the hallways as her body was taken to the funeral home. It was moving to see their respect for her life. The love for her was tangible. Hospice volunteering has taught me about grief, life, death, and love. I enjoy sharing my life and simply being with each resident, though they will likely never remember me.

In my medical shadowing experiences, I witnessed many physicians practice their specialties with a heart of service. During a pediatric rotation at a public hospital that I interned with during my study abroad in Puebla, Mexico, a two-year-old girl arrived at pediatrics with an enlarged liver. The attending pediatrician decided an MRI of her abdomen was needed for examination. She was anesthetized to hold still for the MRI, which was frightening to her and her parents as it could not be guaranteed she would react well to the anesthetic. However, the anesthesiologist and pediatrician comforted the family while the radiologist gave a primary analysis of the scan. It was the first breakthrough in the child’s case. She was transferred to another department the next day for more specialized care. The bedside manner and treatment from her pediatrician, anesthesiologist, and radiologist held the same qualities I saw in my family doctor. All these physicians were caring, understanding, and tactful with their patient and the patient’s family. I aspire to channel the leadership, teamwork, and compassion of these physicians in my own practice because they demonstrated how to use their skills to calm and best serve the patient.
I have been fortunate to receive a number of opportunities for leadership, teamwork, and medical knowledge, all of which are integral to service-oriented medicine. I currently work as a research technician in the Cole Eye Institute of the Cleveland Clinic. It has been a challenging but rewarding experience. I chose the lab to learn about ophthalmology, and now I know more about the eye, age-related macular degeneration (AMD), and diabetic retinopathy. Research is crucial for being able to help patients as new information and knowledge on how to interpret that information can make the difference, in this case, between sight and blindness. Research has also given me better problem solving skills. A few months ago, a coworker with past ophthalmic experience asked for my opinion on marking subretinal material in an image of wet AMD. I gave my opinion but also asked two other leads for theirs. The retinal layers were difficult to differentiate, but we found a solution to accurately quantify the disease burden. Communication and collaboration are the trademark of developing a healthy team dynamic. More recently, I asked the same co-worker for insights on choroidal neovascularization identification for a lab project, and he graciously provided examples. My work has equipped me with research and leadership skills which are essential for physicians working as part of an interdisciplinary team.

Medicine is innately service-oriented as patient care is the top priority. Many virtues and skills, such as humility, communication, and leadership, are necessary to provide the best patient care. The virtues and skills witnessed in my family doctor and the physicians I have shadowed propel me to pursue a career in medicine. Their example and the variety of experiences I have lived further confirm my desire to serve my community as a compassionate physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
I volunteered in the summer of 2019 at Maggie‚Äôs Place in Phoenix, Arizona. Maggie‚Äôs Place serves pregnant women, providing them with housing, education, and career development. Many of the women struggled with past traumas or addictions. My role as summer corps was to organize and retrieve donations. Retrieving donations was akin to shopping for the moms. However, the options were limited to what had been donated._x000D_
_x000D_
One day, I received a request from a mom, but the clothing and baby toys she wanted were unavailable. When I told the mom, she ran to her room, slamming her door. I was stunned. From this experience, I learned how to prioritize the good of another, while seeking to understand why the incident occurred. The circumstances of having a traumatic background and living with a certain lack of autonomy explained the mom‚Äôs reaction. These are valuable lessons that I have found useful in other circumstances and likely will continue to in the future.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I impacted my residential hall through my role as a residential assistant (RA). I was excited to be an RA for the 2020-2021 academic year. However, the role was different from what I expected. Training was much shorter, and there was an emphasis on hall staff enforcing COVID policies, such as mask usage. However, my central goal remained unchanged:  to serve as a support system for the first-year students. My own freshman year was difficult, but I remember my RA being a wonderful resource during that time. Meeting and spending time with residents through our section events was the best part of the year. My residents were a diverse group: students were from Chicago, Tucson, Los Angeles, and even the Northern Mariana Islands. We bonded over Einstein Bagel breakfasts and movie nights. Being able to walk with the students during a uniquely difficult year was a privilege. The pandemic was a struggle in many ways, but building a safe and resilient dorm community was truly rewarding.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The COVID pandemic altered my gap year plans to work at the Sr. Maura Brannick Clinic in South Bend, Indiana. I loved interacting with patients when delivering their prescriptions or taking their medical histories. The clinic provided care to uninsured patients, the majority being Spanish-speaking and Arabic-speaking immigrants. I grew up speaking Spanish with my mother, who is originally from Mexico, and I studied Honors Spanish. My heritage helped me connect with the Spanish-speaking patients, but made it more difficult to have my experience cut short. The clinic allowed me to serve the community in a way that resonated with my love for my family. My brief experience at the clinic inspires me to improve medical care for underserved communities through research and clinical practice. In order to continue in my career goals during the disruption of COVID, I volunteered to assist with my university‚Äôs COVID-19 vaccine drive.

personal_statement:
I have learned so much from the way someone says “hello.” Recruiting for NIH-funded clinical trials using virtual reality (VR) to manage pain, I connect meaningfully with others during difficult periods of their disease course. During a GI cancer trial, I spoke with a woman whose simultaneous inviting and assertive “hello” at the start of our conversation instantly revealed her drive to fight pancreatic cancer. Because of the comradery we developed, she was comfortable telling me that the VR experiences were uninteresting. I was not surprised to hear this; she was in the placebo arm. Following the trial, I visited her during a chemotherapy infusion and provided a headset with the full intervention. She emailed me soon after, sharing how it was making a significant difference in her pain and quality of life. 

Through experiences like this, I realized the symbiosis of researching new treatments and providing them clinically. My journey to medicine is defined by my efforts to bridge the gaps of time and equity that exist between research and clinical care.

At six years old, my grandfather, Dr. Samuel Rahbar (“Papa Samy”), took me to his lab at the City of Hope. Papa Samy answered my many questions about his discovery of Hemoglobin A1c and its role in diabetes, using blood samples from mice and explaining the differences to me. From then on, I was hooked on science. In college, I joined the Carmichael lab to study cell-based treatments for stroke, the malady that took my grandfather years prior. Our work was promising, but I realized the limitations of benchwork as it would be years before this therapy could benefit patients. I pondered how I could provide cutting-edge treatments to people currently in need.

The pandemic helped me answer this question. After losing my grandmother to COVID-19, I felt a responsibility to serve Los Angeles, a viral epicenter at the time. I volunteered to provide free testing and vaccinations to those facing barriers to these services. My favorite moments were those when I spent time with people discussing the test or vaccination, because these personal interactions translated to a healthier, better-informed community. One important role involved escorting patients to restrooms at the Dodger Stadium vaccination center. During this walk a veteran asked me why he was waiting after receiving his vaccine. I explained the vaccine had been rigorously tested but there was still a small chance of an adverse reaction. Though eager to leave, he appreciated our concern amid a chaotic scene in the massive parking lot. Answering a wide variety of questions about the vaccine during my time as a volunteer, I realized challenges in research related to communication and access hinder clinical applications to those who may benefit. 

Eager to overcome such barriers in our healthcare ecosystem after college, I began full time work under my mentor Dr. Brennan Spiegel as a clinical trial recruitment specialist. Speaking with patients about their attitudes and beliefs on using VR to manage their pain, I strive to understand them as people, not just participants. 

In our trial using VR for back pain, one man lived in his car and could not mail back the headset. When he dropped it off, we discussed the aftermath of his divorce and unstable living situation. Though he needed a receptive ear, I was the one humbled by his optimism as he declared that he would get back on his feet. When I realized he was not compensated due to incomplete surveys, I investigated and discovered that he merely forgot to press “submit”. I sent him a gift card and invited him to a focus group to discuss underrepresented populations in research. I learned that people trust me when I demonstrate a meaningful interest in their well-being that extends outside of a clinic visit or trial participation.

These interactions highlight issues of digital health equity and the importance of bringing such interventions to patients. In my Master’s in Health Delivery Science program, I am learning through courses in cost-effectiveness analysis and healthcare finance that access to digital health tools is hindered due to insurance and awareness issues. Though VR is free in our trials, I discuss these ideas with patients as part of the shared decision to use VR in their chronic pain journey. It has been exciting to integrate my master’s program capstone project with my real-life patient experiences. To create a blueprint for delivering research to patients who, for geographic or socioeconomic reasons, are not typically reached by clinical researchers, I am facilitating the integration of primary care clinics into our lab’s VR pain research pipeline. My goal is a novel method for health equity, where primary care, research opportunities, and innovative treatments are accessed under the same roof.

Research is vital to the progression of clinical medicine, but its impact is dependent on how equitably and efficiently its treatments are delivered to patients. I want to practice medicine comprehensively, applying the lessons of compassion and cutting-edge advances I learned from clinical research and my graduate education to those in need. This way, I will be confidently prepared to serve my patients, starting with every “hello”.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
My parents‚Äô refuge in the USA following religious persecution in Iran helps me contextualize service as an aspiring physician. I will provide holistic care to address medical symptoms and social factors impacting my patients. I apply this lesson with innovative clinical strategies under Dr. Brennan Spiegel. _x000D_
_x000D_
KS, a patient with low back pain, withdrew from a virtual reality trial due to a pending eviction. He grieved, ‚ÄúI have to throw out parts of my identity.‚Äù So he would not face this situation alone, I arranged for follow-up by our social work team and ensured he could continue using the headset outside of the trial. I addressed KS‚Äôs priorities to comprehensively care for his different needs._x000D_
_x000D_
When he called to thank me, I learned how impactful support is often through seemingly minute extra steps, as opposed to grandiose gestures. _x000D_
_x000D_
As a first-generation Iranian American at RMC, I will continue taking extra steps with patients to promote their overall health and well-being.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
My grandmother‚Äôs passing from COVID-19 served as a personal call to action, leading me to support equitable health access as a volunteer at testing and vaccination centers. To overcome hurdles in the clinical translation of research, I wanted to continue serving my community while broadening my impact. _x000D_
_x000D_
Through a virtual reality (VR) inpatient service and clinical trials at Cedars-Sinai, I connect with vulnerable patients in my community, rural America, and elsewhere around the country. I discuss with patients VR‚Äôs role in addressing chronic pain and its downstream mental health effects.  _x000D_
_x000D_
Moreover, patients also significantly impact me and my work. The hardships patients face before I reach them highlights VR‚Äôs current role as a last-line treatment. However, I believe its biopsychosocial approach to healing and education can serve preventative health and primary care settings too. I explore this further through the capstone project of my master‚Äôs program in Health Delivery Science.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Two days before my MCAT, my grandmother was hospitalized with COVID-19 and passed soon after. Though not upset when I reviewed my score, I knew I could improve. I took time before re-studying and earned a higher score the second time.

personal_statement:
“I’m going to need you to just translate a few things for the doctor, then I want you to wait in the hallway,” my mother whispered to me in Spanish. I was eight years old when I started to notice her exhaustion and her accumulating doctor visits, changes that I only began to understand after accompanying her to a medical appointment. The rest was a blur. I can faintly recall my mother explaining to me that she would soon be taking some medication that was going to make her feel worse for a while and lose her hair. Little did I know, that was the day my mother was diagnosed with Stage 2 breast cancer. 
The months that followed were nothing but frightening. Surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy sessions – all to treat what seemed to be a harmless bump on her chest. However, as I got older, I gradually began to understand the gravity of her condition and it made me realize that the possibility of losing my mother was real. Thankfully, she has been cancer-free since her operation, but this realization drove me to find ways I could help her in the future. Ever since her diagnosis, I have accompanied my mom to every one of her visits, serving as her interpreter whenever she needed help communicating with her physicians. During these visits, I took it upon myself to ensure I was relaying my mother’s concerns as accurately as possible, allowing her voice to be heard by every physician she visited. Facilitating these interactions on my mother’s path to recovery inspired me to consider a future in which I could care for patients of my own, listen to their concerns, and allow them to feel understood, just as I had done with my mother. 
Throughout the summer after my first year at the University of Virginia, I was able to apply my practical experiences of helping my mother to my role as a Patient Ambassador. As I visited patients throughout the UVA hospital, I would often receive requests that relieved the patient’s physical needs. However, this position also granted me the opportunity to provide a less tangible, yet just as important, form of care: a conversation. Through many patient interactions, I witnessed how effective communication and connection with a medical provider were equally as important as the administration of pharmaceuticals. In addition, my Mexican identity, as well as my fluency in the Spanish language, allowed me to extend care to a more diverse group of patients. 
Walking into “Alex’s” room, one of the Latino patients being treated on the floor, I had the opportunity to dive into a rich dialogue in Spanish about his family, his past, and even his aspirations in life. However, during this conversation, I also learned that his back had been sore from being too scared to ask in English to be repositioned. Instantly, memories of helping my mother through similar situations began to flood my mind.  Just as she and so many other patients have experienced, it seemed the fear and confusion of not being able to communicate proved to exacerbate their current state of physical discomfort. Although Alex's medical needs were met, I was reminded of how miscommunication can often prevent people from feeling taken care of. “¡Gracias!” he exhaled as I helped him up, but instead I found myself feeling grateful for Alex showing me how a shared connection helped patients like himself, as well as my mother, feel more comfortable and ultimately better cared for. 
While a sore back was Alex’s only discomfort, it is difficult to put into perspective how many patients are hesitant to tell the hospital staff crucial information about their symptoms that could potentially save their life. I believe that accessing this information can become more feasible when the fear of being misunderstood is decreased by connecting with the patient linguistically, culturally, and with empathy. The impact that a conversation can have on any individual has motivated me to expand this form of attentive care to every patient I encounter as a medical assistant. Through each patient interaction, I actively attempt to understand each person’s individual experience and recognize when they are not feeling understood. Regardless of one’s background, my aspiration in becoming a physician is to alleviate the feelings of fear, confusion, and isolation from the patient seeking medical treatment. By allowing each patient to freely express their personal health concerns, whether it be their sore back or even a seemingly harmless bump on their chest, I strive to ensure they are provided with the best possible care I can deliver, one conversation at a time.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As a medical assistant, I am responsible for administering allergy shots to many patients daily. One day, a new allergy shot patient came in, and as I explained how the shots worked and how I would administer them, I noticed her discomfort as she was going to have to expose her skin. She wore a hijab with a long sleeve shirt, but I reassured her I would be able to accommodate her based on her comfort level. We eventually figured out how to deliver the allergy shots in a way that respected her beliefs and boundaries. This interaction showed me the importance of respecting differences while providing an equal standard of care. By making healthcare more inclusive and finding new ways to provide care, we have a greater chance of impacting a greater number of people. As I train to become a physician in an increasingly diverse environment, I hope to recognize and respect the beliefs of my patients to deliver the best care I can provide.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Growing up and interpreting for my mom, my desire to help those who struggle to communicate continued as I saw similar challenges faced by other immigrant families I encountered while volunteering in college. However, these experiences have shown me that no matter what language is spoken, anyone can make a person feel more comfortable simply through a willingness to listen. When I encountered individuals that struggled to express themselves in a different language, I used the patience that I had developed from helping my parents communicate as a tool to bridge any communication gap that may prevent these individuals from receiving proper healthcare. I hope to bring and share this perspective with the student body at Rush Medical College as I believe that whether you speak their primary language or not, empathy for the patient‚Äôs experiences will greatly help in effectively communicating and caring for a diverse set of patients.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The unprecedented COVID-19 pandemic has affected almost every person on this Earth to some degree. Consequently, it impacted my ability to pursue certain clinical experiences between the years 2020 and 2021. Due to UVA‚Äôs effort to prevent the spread of this disease, the UVA Health System prevented any in-person volunteering, research, and shadowing for undergraduate students. Because of this, I sought out different virtual opportunities where I could volunteer, research, and shadow safely throughout the pandemic. It was only until the UVA Health System began to open during my 4th year that I was able to continue my in-person volunteering, research, and shadowing experiences.

personal_statement:
For most of my life, I thought I knew what it meant to be strong. I always looked at my mother as the pinnacle of resilience. She would always say “jotto hashi, totto kanna,” a rather cynical Bengali proverb that translates to ‘the more you laugh, the more tears follow.’ She raised me to categorize emotions as weakness, defining strength as stoicism. Strength was never letting yourself truly feel. 

This mentality took a toll on my family. It delayed my sister from obtaining necessary mental health care, despite the signs she exhibited. Seeing my sister struggle prompted me to redefine what I had believed strength to be. A serendipitous telehealth call with a patient, “Sarah,” sparked the start of this journey.

It was during the pandemic, and I was volunteering for the Family Van, a mobile clinic. 
My role as a volunteer shifted from providing preventive health screenings to calling patients and connecting them to the Van’s extensive resources. Sarah was dealing with a myriad of issues ranging from food insecurity to managing rent. She was especially upset about her inability to obtain a registered emotional support animal (ESA).

“My daughter has a disability and is having a hard time coping while in school. I really do think getting her an emotional support animal would help her manage her anxiety better, but my landlord refuses to allow pets.” I was surprised to hear that this was her biggest priority, but realizing how much it meant to her, I worked to connect her with housing justice resources in Boston. After talking through various options, she thanked me, her voice flooded with relief: “If my daughter needs a cat to feel peace, then a cat is what I’ll fight for, honey. God did not put us here on this earth to struggle every day. There’s strength in being vulnerable.”

Hearing Sarah’s persistent efforts to bring her daughter ease, instead of encouraging her to repress her emotions, taught me the importance of finding peace in a world focused on glamourized struggle. Through this, I began to redefine strength as a celebration of human emotion rather than the absence of it. This shift in mindset has been crucial in shaping my desire to pursue medicine. Illness is a point in which people are at their most vulnerable state. As a physician, I will strive to empower my patients to choose effective treatments that also tend to their unique social and emotional needs.  

I have been able to witness many examples in which patient comfort has been a focal point of medical care. My experience of working as a medical scribe has tangibly shown me how to empower patients to find strength in vulnerability. When I look back, one patient stands out to me in particular. She entered the clinic, her face contorted in pain as she clung to her walker. With great difficulty, she propped herself on the examination table and turned to reveal severe deformation left in the wake of a botched gluteal augmentation. 

I observed as “Dr. Jacobs,” immediately took control of the scene, asking about her level of pain and whether she was comfortable disclosing the details of when she received the augmentation. The patient’s eyes welled with tears. “I feel like I did this to myself by seeking out this under the table procedure. I’ve been so afraid of asking anyone for help, but the pain is just unbearable.”

“You deserve to pursue procedures that make you feel confident,” Dr. Jacobs earnestly responded.  “I’m sorry that you received such poor care. As doctors, it is our responsibility to make sure you live not just the healthiest, but the most comfortable life. We will work through this together.”


I paused my notetaking, hoping to create a space that was more sincere and caring. I observed the various steps Dr. Jacobs took to make sure that the patient’s comfort was prioritized. He asked whether she had a support system at home to ensure her ability to rest and recuperate and offered her two different treatments, allowing her to have the final say in which one worked best for her. He made sure to not only tend to her medical needs, but also to her wellbeing as a whole. 

This taught me how vital vulnerability is within the physician-patient relationship. Without opening up about her covert procedure, the patient would have continued to endure chronic pain and suffering. There was strength in seeking advice to ease her discomfort and in trusting others to obtain the necessary care. Additionally, Dr. Jacobs met her halfway, cultivating a space in which her relief was highly regarded within her treatment. Upon reflection, I can truly see how the prospect of forming such meaningful connections has fundamentally shaped my love for medicine.

A physician’s role is to promote healing. Through my experience, I have learned that healing requires an intricate balance of prescribing strong treatment regimens while emphasizing patient comfort. Although society often equates strength with struggle, there is power in advocating for what feels right. As a physician, I hope to center vulnerability within the crux of the physician-patient relationship. I will always remind my patients that whether it is an emotional support animal or the choice between two effective treatment plans, I will advocate for their right to heal with ease.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
As an educator, I work with students attending a variety of different high schools. One week, Jenny, a student from an underresourced school, pulled me aside in tears. She expressed feeling out of place as the only Black student and felt that she did not know enough to be included in the program. At this time, I drew from skills I had learned to help reassure her. I commended her for the leadership skills she demonstrated in class, and reminded her of some correct answers she had given. Later in class, I identified that students often fixated on getting the correct answer the fastest, leaving out those who did not have such strong science backgrounds, and quickly worked to address this. _x000D_
_x000D_
Jenny‚Äôs words taught me to step outside my comfort zone with my educational content and showed me that different people's lived experiences impact how they interact with education. As a physician, I will aim to keep this in mind as I teach patients about the conditions affecting their bodies._x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
Growing up, it was easy to embrace my Bengali-Muslim roots; the two were not mutually exclusive. However, it became significantly more difficult as I started to incorporate queerness as into my identity. It was not safe to be open with my family, and the lack of South-Asian LGBTQ+ representation prevented me from approaching the topic with my friends._x000D_
_x000D_
Coming to terms with my sexuality has been a long process and my experiences have motivated me to advocate for others. I noticed how the Brandeis South-Asian and Muslim Students Associations lacked advocacy for sexual and gender minority students. Thus, during senior year, I organized a panel event to discuss the history of queerness in our communities. Seeing such a safe space created for myself and others was gratifying, and piloting this discussion event has set a precedent to ensure that these important conversations continue to take place. I hope to continue advocating for health equity among underrepresented communities at Rush.

Hrdshp_Comments: I lived in a country with a subpar healthcare system for half my childhood. Facilities often lacked medication, equipment, adequately trained staff, and emergency intervention tools, such as blood transfusions, which led to delays in care and increased preventable deaths. I can easily recall when my brother and I carried our sick mother over five kilometers to a hospital where we had to wait hours to be seen by a physician because of the lack of transportation and poor road conditions. When we moved to America, I had to work to help provide for my family here and back home. I often had to prioritize my family's needs over my own. I could not participate in some extracurriculars because I was a full-time student, worked, and helped take care of my siblings. Faith and hard work have helped my family overcome many obstacles. Now, I want to give back to the communities both here and in The Gambia that have shaped me into the person I am today. I am involved with organizations that aim to improve health outcomes for underserved populations, and I have helped many immigrants navigate life in the U.S. through interpretation and tutoring. I am grateful for my experiences because they have made me resilient.
personal_statement:
Darkness engulfed me as my aunt placed a blindfold over my eyes to take me to an unknown destination. My mother's grip on my arm loosened, and she began to sob uncontrollably as my aunt placed me on her back. I grew more apprehensive and held my aunt tighter with every step. The blindfold was ripped off abruptly as I sat inside a bucket of water and found myself surrounded by the unfamiliar faces of other young girls. My aunt assured me that this procedure was good for me and that it would make me clean. Suddenly, two women held me down while a third performed the procedure. I let out several screams in response to the excruciating pain. Female Genital Mutilation (FGM) is the total or partial removal of external genitalia for non-medical reasons. This experience motivated me to become a global health trained physician who will serve as a bridge between medicine and underserved populations to improve care by establishing trust early on and boosting health literacy in the community.

My nuanced relationship with FGM shaped my relationship with the people around me and the healthcare field. Growing up in my home country of The Gambia, FGM protected me from being bullied by my peers for being a "solima" or a girl who has not undergone FGM. However, it also made me skeptical of physicians. I hid my ailments, such as migraines and stomach aches, from my mother because I knew she would take me to the hospital to see the "Tubab" doctors that practiced western medicine. I felt I could not trust them since they were against FGM, nor could I trust the native healers who performed the procedure. My hesitancy toward medical treatment diminished after I moved to America.

My perception of healthcare shifted when I became my stepmother's primary caregiver. I looked forward to attending her appointments and observing the interaction between my stepmother and her care team. During one of the visits, she was reluctant to undergo an electrocardiogram, but her care team guided her through it with patience and understanding. I became fascinated by the different tests conducted and the physician's holistic approach to medicine as I interpreted information between my stepmother and her physician. Despite countless exams, my stepmother's illness remains undiagnosed. This has further influenced me to become a physician to help find a diagnosis for others with similar symptoms. 

The experience with my stepmother motivated me to get involved in my community by shadowing and volunteering. While shadowing an OB/GYN, I met "Ophelia," a homeless nineteen-year-old patient who grew up in a drug-abused home. She suffered from depression as a side effect of her birth control implant. She was afraid of needles and asked me to hold her hand to comfort her while the physician removed the implant. I saw the hope in Ophelia's eyes and sensed this small gesture was meaningful to her. During the procedure, she opened up to me about her life and her excitement to finally have a physician who looked like her. I found myself opening up to her about my background and culture. Through my interaction with Ophelia, I realized that my experiences as a Black immigrant woman would allow me to better connect to my patients, particularly those from underserved groups. I will establish trust early on with my patients so women feel safe in my presence.

As a Wellness Ambassador for the Foundation for Black Women's Wellness (FFBWW), I advocated for Black women's wellbeing and increased competent care in underserved communities.
