The FFBWW strives to improve health outcomes for Black women in Wisconsin through health and wellness services, advocacy, and the promotion of healthy living. While leading a discussion on wellness for teen girls, I realized there was a lack of knowledge in the Black community about reproductive health. Many of the girls not only misunderstood their menstrual cycles but felt ashamed of them as well. To combat this issue, I provided menstrual education and promoted self-acceptance through confidence-building exercises. It was apparent that the girls enjoyed the sessions and had a newfound confidence in attending school. I learned that as a physician, I could combine my expertise, aspects of my identity, and experiences to serve as a bridge between medicine and my community.  

Through shadowing and volunteering, I found that cultural differences and disparities in access to care are significant barriers. My experiences drive me to continue being an advocate for members of underserved communities and improve the quality of women's health services in these areas. Becoming a physician will give me the expertise and knowledge to educate communities about the psychological and physiological consequences of harmful practices against women globally, like FGM. I will continue educating young women on reproductive health while promoting self-acceptance and wellbeing. Additionally, I would like to work toward increasing culturally competent care in the U.S. by advocating for cultural awareness training for physicians. As a physician, I aim to empower my patients and instill confidence in them as agents of their bodies.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: In 2019, a friend's homophobic stepfather kicked him out after a fight. He couldn't stay with his grandparents because they were unaware he was gay and feared rejection. My friend enjoyed cross-dressing and was vocal about gay rights, so I was unaware he hid his sexuality from his family. I realized I had created a fixed image of him that caused me not to see the internal battles he endured. As a result, I have worked to ensure that I view the people in my life as complex individuals with different layers of depth. Now, I have more profound conversations with my loved ones to gain a deeper understanding of them as individuals. Lastly, I learned to appreciate the impact the adversities people face have on them instead of comparing them to others' challenges. In the future, I will continue learning more about others to ensure that I do not make the same generalizations with the patients I encounter. _x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation: My cousin and I did everything together growing up. Things were great until people started comparing us to each other. Her mother frequently pressured her to lose weight to be like me. My cousin internalized these comments, which gave her low self-esteem. She stopped eating to lose weight, her grades suffered, and she hated herself. I was afraid to confront my aunt about her comments, so I decided to share my insecurities with my cousin instead. I expressed wanting to gain weight but being fearful because people told me that being skinny was ideal. After watching videos online, my cousin and I embarked on a fitness journey together. Our initial goals were to gain and lose weight; however, we soon fell in love with fitness. Soon after, our goals shifted to getting stronger and learning to appreciate our bodies. The gym became an outlet for us to destress and tune out the world. Today, my cousin is in college, has a better relationship with food, and has more confidence in herself._x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact: During COVID, my in-person shadowing, research, and volunteer experiences were canceled. Although I was disappointed about not being able to perform these activities in person, I still managed to receive exposure to different specialties through virtual shadowing. Every Monday, I joined the shadowing platform that The Medical School Headquarters provided to learn from and interact with physicians. Additionally, the nonprofit work that I was involved in moved online, and we were able to impact more people. Our professional development workshop at conNEXTions became more accessible because participants did not have to commute or seek childcare. I connected with our mentees more because I could meet with them virtually to develop their goals and business ideas. Despite the challenges, I'm grateful for the skills and resilience I gained during COVID.

Under_School: Columbia University in the City of New York
personal_statement:
I did not enter college as an aspiring doctor. I did not grow up with doctors around me, nor did I have anyone seriously encouraging me to pursue medicine. Becoming a doctor or lawyer was something I thought other people did, rich people perhaps, but not me—not my family. Theoretically, I always knew it was an option, yet it sounded nearly as far-fetched as when other kids claimed they were going to become astronauts or the President of the United States. Sure, one of those starry-eyed children might have actually wound up exploring the cosmos, but even from a young age, wishing on a star seemed akin to playing the lottery—one-in-a-million at best.

Medicine seemed out of reach to me back then, but art, a subject I thoroughly enjoyed, seemed much more tangible. My godfather Andre was an artist and an early role model of mine. The countless childhood afternoons spent in his studio have since blended together, but I will never forget the day he was commissioned by Nike, which to my 7-year-old-mind was as good as becoming the POTUS. I wanted so badly to be Nike-level good at something. Validated by my admission into an advanced art program, I thought maybe I had gotten a head start on what would be my future, but as much as I enjoyed art and other creative pursuits, I realized I didn’t want to be an artist. Exasperated, I traded Crayolas for calculators and threw myself into schoolwork. By the time I was in high school, I had fallen in love with biology. Understanding living systems came naturally to me, and for the first time in a long time I felt a genuine connection to a subject, a thrill I rode all the way to college.

Faced with a plethora of possibilities, I started pursuing biology generally. While I struggled to nail down a more specific major, I found myself surrounded by fellow students who, when asked what they planned to do at Columbia, would coolly reply, “Pre-med.” I was impressed by the concision and certainty with which they answered, all the while thinking that could never be me. Belonging to the small percentage of publicly educated students at Columbia, I felt I lacked the same educational foundation as most of my peers, but the reality was we were all taking the same classes. The coursework no longer seemed as lofty and esoteric as I made it out to be, and suddenly my thinking shifted: why not me? Excited yet apprehensive, I brought my newfound confidence to my advisor for next steps. However, our meeting left much to be desired, and my prospective changes were met with more discouragement than support. “Unless you’re 100% sure it’s what you want to do, I wouldn’t recommend it,” she said matter-of-factly, not bothering to introduce me to the pre-med timeline or resources for me to explore on my own. In my freshman naivety, I heeded her advice and let the registration period slip by without adding any pre-med classes to my schedule. Seemingly benign, this misguidance would later leave me scrambling to finish my major and Columbia’s core curriculum within 4 years. I knew post-bacc was always an option, but I was determined to chase my dreams on my terms, even if it meant taking on a heavier course load in later semesters.

Although I felt alone in my decision, my switch was met with overwhelming support from friends and family. I built connections with so many other students on the pre-medical track and we all took turns supporting each other through the rigorous classes, but as the intensity increased, those familiar faces began to fade. By junior year, most of my friends found their hearts were not truly committed to medicine and decided to switch paths. Senior year became incredibly lonely, and with the threat of a global pandemic on the horizon, it was tempting to uncommit myself, yet I persevered despite the challenges. Unlike with prior pursuits where my interest waned with exposure, my desire to practice medicine grows stronger each day. Reflecting on my clinical, volunteering, and shadowing experiences, I am thankful for the opportunity the Bakers provided me at Riverside Medical Group where I went from having no exposure to medicine to being able to anticipate diagnoses and treatments. Since then, I have worked in family medicine, gastroenterology, emergency medicine, and presently dermatology. I have shadowed pediatricians and nephrologists. I have tended to the needs of hospital patients and their families, and perhaps most valuable of all, I have provided compassionate patient care in a pandemic during which I myself was terrified.

Health is fundamental to every person, and to be trusted with such an essential and sensitive part of people’s lives is the utmost honor and a tremendous responsibility I have spent years preparing for. I recognize the importance of being a young Black female in a field where I am not traditionally represented—somewhere patients may not be used to seeing someone who looks like them and either understands or is willing to understand their cultural background. Now cognizant of the effect a lack of representation and encouragement had on me, I strive to be both a positive role model and a standout provider. I may not have had a good answer for my advisor freshman year, but I can now confidently say that I am 100% sure this is what I want to do.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
After my parents‚Äô divorce in 2007, my mom, brother, and I relocated to Fort Lee, NJ where nearly half the population is of Asian descent. This was a huge change coming from Teaneck where the extent of my exposure to Asian culture was my family‚Äôs favorite sushi restaurant. Most of my new friends were either first- or second-generation Asian-Americans, and I spent many afterschool afternoons at their homes. Although I was young and nervous about being different, I found their families were actually happy to share their culture with me._x000D_
_x000D_
Experiencing culture shock early on in my life has made me a more tolerant individual and has fostered a general curiosity about others. It will always be important to me that I surround myself with a variety of people and personalities for my own personal growth. Healthcare is unique in that everyone needs it, but everyone needs it differently, and I therefore strive to be adaptable, compassionate, and culturally sensitive in my approach to patient care.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: The creation of Polaris Academy was not only meaningful to me but also to my peers who helped create it and the community it was created for. Many students do not make the most of their early high school years, and we wanted to encourage kids from our town to make goal-oriented decisions and aim higher. While academic achievement was a major objective of our program, personal development was not neglected, and I encouraged my mentees to explore creative pursuits. One of my mentees, Shadae, was honest about her general disinterest in school, but expressed an interest in fashion and photography. We would spend our meetings taking photos for her to practice editing in her downtime and making plans for her future, including adding classes like digital media and advanced painting to her schedule, saving up for a new camera, and creating a portfolio for fashion school. While I cannot take credit, Shadae began her first year at FIT last fall, and I am happy to have been a part of her journey.
7_-_COVID_Impact: After graduating virtually in May 2020, I was employed almost immediately at a local urgent care. The smallest of three locations, we had the least staffing and struggled the most when COVID ramped up. As a frontline worker, I spent long hours in a physically and mentally taxing, high-risk environment, and most of 2020-2021 was almost entirely consumed by the pandemic. Prepping for the MCAT or beginning my application my first year post-grad came second to combatting a global health crisis. When COVID finally became more manageable, I was able to start the process for medical school with fewer distractions. Although I did not begin my application as early as I would have liked, I would not trade my experience for anything less. I will undoubtedly encounter tough challenges in my journey to becoming a doctor, but I am proud of the care I delivered during a universally trying time and feel significantly more resilient as a result.

personal_statement:
Linguistic determinism teaches us that language shapes our perception of the world. To master another language is not simply to interpret; it is to collaborate on common ground, it is to inform and further oneself from ignorance, it is to feel compassion because one can relate. As a female, second-generation, Pakistani-American Muslim, I know that the reality I live in is different from those around me. The languages that have shaped my worldview play a large role in that. I speak the language of the minority, one that is often misrepresented. I hope to use the languages that I speak to create a more equitable health system, thus a higher quality of life for others.

Firstly, I speak the language of culture. As I speak Urdu, English, and Spanish I can break language barriers with individuals whose backgrounds enable them to see the world differently. I had the opportunity to utilize this when I met a refugee family while shadowing at my local hospital. Their native language was Urdu, and I was able to help translate their diagnosis and treatment options. This was a rewarding experience for me as I was able to aid the patient in feeling comfortable while receiving the care they needed. This language allows me to navigate different perspectives and thus provide care with compassion and empathy.

 I speak the language of the female leader. My mother, a female physician herself, showed me the importance of compassion and dedication. I watched and learned how she extended such matriarchal qualities beyond our family and into our community. So, I committed outreach too. As the only female board member of my university’s Muslim Students Association, I brought my voice to the table and worked with a team. As a youth group leader, I inspired others to pursue their passions no matter the limitations they face — just as my mother had modeled for me. Being a strong leader also requires an understanding of the mechanisms of change. As an aspiring physician, I not only aim to heal patients but to also heal the system. This is why I place an importance on the disciplines of science, political science, and health administration. Through my studies of laws and policy, I have learned the systems of healthcare that govern our ability to heal. The study of policy is one of my passions, but through my experiences in healthcare I have realized that I want to have first-hand experiences with patients so that I can advocate for them from the inside; thus, improving their lives both personally and systemically. I aim to utilize my knowledge and experience to blaze a strong path forward for myself and others — one built on understanding, teamwork, and respect; all of which I will bring to my future career as a physician.

I speak the language of the patient. I learned this language by caring for members of my family who were ill, volunteering at community hospitals, and being a patient myself. What really solidified my understanding of this language was realizing that there is only a single entity that truly matters. It is the very thing that gives you life yet also takes it away. It is constant until it is not — your heartbeat. In 2018, I stood above a man with his chest cut open and stared down at his beating heart. I realized this is what my heart beats for. At this moment, as I shadowed an open-heart surgery at a free hospital in Pakistan, I solidified my passion for the human body and my drive to become a physician. This experience highlighted a simple fact of life: our society is only as great as the health of those who compose it. This idea is under attack around the world. In some areas, healthcare is inaccessible; in others, it is not at the caliber at which it ought to be. I recognize the responsibility of the medical provider is to help maximize each patient’s quality of life. This language highlights the importance of patient-provider communication to ensure patients feel comfortable and acknowledged. In this language, healthcare is half science and half trust.

Lastly, I speak the language of science. This is a language I have spent many years learning and admiring, and one which I desire to keep practicing. Early in my undergraduate career, I struggled with this language. I found that I had thrown myself into this field without firm reason. I spent time trying different subjects and approaches until I recognized that success comes through following one’s passion. I realized that my setbacks were leading me back to my love for the language of science. I realigned myself with my appreciation for the sciences through research, academia, and shadowing while incorporating my other passions such as advocacy and law. Rediscovering my drive allowed me to flourish in my last few years of my undergraduate career and further on into my masters education. This prepared me for medical school and solidified my dedication to the language of science. I practiced my perseverance and committed myself to growth and learning. These very principles push me towards achieving excellence in the medical field. If admitted into medical school, I will be granted the opportunity to further my education in the human sciences. Mastering the language of science, both a social and academic one, will allow me to prosper as an aspiring physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As a minority myself, understanding others is a core tenant of who I am. Personally, I have organized interfaith gatherings in my community which foster healthy relationships between those of different beliefs and backgrounds. As a leader of several cultural organizations at my university, I organized educational events regarding overlooked communities. Further, my advocacy has extended beyond problems that plague my own life. As a campus leader, I helped raise money and awareness for the Black Lives Matter and Anti-Asian Hate movements. Understanding and fighting for those who are different from oneself is crucial in creating an innovative and healthy society. I learned that ignorance comes from a lack of knowledge, compassion, and understanding. The responsibility to be welcoming to all extends into life as a medical student and physician. I hope to do this by educating myself and others, standing up for fair policy changes in medicine, and by prioritizing patient rights and health.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: My experiences and identities have taught me how to work with compassion and ultimately use my knowledge and passions to positively impact others. This was exemplified by my time working in a nonprofit hospital in a low-income area of Pakistan. I learned about my own privilege and the responsibilities that come with that. Here, people traveled for days to reach the hospital. They would wait outside in long lines, in hopes of seeing a physician. Regardless of this struggle and lack of access, these people were still grateful. Being part of this hospital, I felt a great sense of purpose and fulfillment. I learned that knowledge is a privilege and using that knowledge for positivity is my responsibility. These realizations inspire me to practice medicine in underserved populations, join initiatives for cost-free medical missions to areas in need, work towards more equitable and extensive policies regarding access to healthcare, and educate myself and others about healthcare disparities.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The COVID-19 pandemic had a profound impact on our world ‚Äì‚Äì I was no exception. The pandemic canceled my travel plans, part of which involved volunteering in Pakistan. However, I used this as an opportunity to help in different ways that resulted from the pandemic. One of these was to virtually tutor children in minority communities, which helped them to adjust and overcome the challenges of virtual learning. Academically, my shift to virtual learning impacted my ability to interact with others, but I learned to utilize virtual spaces to foster a good relationship with my professors and peers. During this time, I was preparing for the MCAT. Due to the pandemic my exam was postponed for four months. This uncertainty and constant change was difficult to study and test through, but I developed strong lifelong study habits to help me succeed under stress. The pandemic was a challenging time but I was able to learn ways to succeed through difficulties and find new ways to give back.

personal_statement:
The knots in my back paralyzed me with millions of needles shooting down my legs, all while the back muscles gave their best effort to separate themselves from their attachments. Laying in the emergency department after a weightlifting injury, I could only grasp the rails of the bed to distract me from my pain. Blitzing through the doors, the emergency medical service team wheeled in a breathless infant on a stretcher. Dr. Smith darted to the infant to administer medical treatment. Hovering over him, each set of chest compressions was followed with the hope of a breath. His shouts for lab orders, imaging, and the next steps of treatment broke through the ear ringing ambulance parked outside. I wanted to jump out of the bed to help in any way, but I could only watch with a breaking heart. Moments passed, and like a miracle, the infant took his first breath back into the world. With a rising chest for each breath, Dr. Smith's relief reflected off the shimmering tears and sweat now pooled on the tile floor under him. I had no idea what had happened, but I was certain I had witnessed the type of care only a physician could offer. Squinting at the blinding ceiling light that towered over me, the longing to be free of pain paled in comparison to the newfound longing to provide life-changing treatment to patients in need.

I wanted to be a person who, when all hope seems lost, can be entrusted with patients in their most vulnerable state. I yearned to experience and understand what it was like to be part of the healthcare team taking care of patients. With a clear goal in mind now steering my decisions, I began working at the hospital as a clinical technician.

The vibrant emerald, green eyes returned their gaze with a contrasting empty expression. One of my patients, Mary, was so old, so fragile, and so silent without words. Giving her a spoonful of dull, orange potatoes, she turned her face away from the food with furrowed eyebrows. Asking if there is anything I can do to make the food more palatable, she finally broke her silence with a single word, "salt." Jumping with excitement and almost tripping on the floor mat, I sprinkled a pinch of salt over her potatoes. She took another bite and I hoped for a smile or a nod of approval, but she pushed the spoon away with a raised eyebrow. The same word came out of her mouth. Looking back at the salt package, both of us read sugar. The radiating smile on her face was bright. Bursting into laughter, her silent character began to crack into a playful friend. I may not have made the most significant impact during her treatment, but the change in her character mirrored her growth during her stay at the hospital. This experience ignites my heart to further my medical training to the greatest level and propels me to continue pursuing my goal of becoming a physician. I hope to bring healing into patients' lives, not just through my interactions with them, but also through the highest level of care.

I later found myself in another clinical setting, this time as a medical scribe. Mike blazed through the doors with the urgency-stricken nurse who rushed him into the clinic in his wheelchair. He stared blankly into the far distance as he was rolled into the exam room. Mike sat in front of the slit lamp, ready for the evaluation. Peering through the lens, the doctor shook his head and confirmed the retinal detachment seen on the imaging. The deafening sound of surgery pierced through the conversation between Mike and the doctor. He shoved the slit lamp away and tore the surgery forms into flying pieces. He did not want surgery and he had limited access to transportation with his required wheelchair. I knelt to eye level and told him my grandmother had lost vision in her right eye and she has been receiving treatment to improve her vision with the other. After accommodating Mike with transportation, he decided to proceed with the surgery and take the first steps to recover his vision. It hurts me to see patients turn away from treatment. Breaking the barriers that prevent patients from receiving optimal healthcare is required for change to happen. Advocating for patients like Mike is necessary and can change the course of both their care and life. I hope to be a physician who advocates for patients to make their health a priority and help them make the best decisions for their health.

Through my experiences, I have been with patients in many different stages of their treatment. Watching the infant in the emergency department, I witnessed the life-changing possibilities that a physician can offer. Feeding Mary, I experienced the difference that can be made with small but sincere actions. Advocating for Mike on a personal level, I realized the value of bridging the gap between needs and healthcare. The vulnerability shown to me by the many patients I have had the honor of serving has solidified my goal of becoming a physician. My encounters with the multitudes of patients are a reminder of the goal I am pursuing. I hope to be a physician who tends to the patient's health in the most trying times of their lives and advocates for their health. I hope to be a physician who is driven to serve those who are limited in their access to healthcare.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: ‚ÄúWe need labs for room 12,‚Äù the nurse told me as she ran by me. Opening the door, I see Max squinting while holding his right leg. I began setting up my supplies for the blood draw on the table, but the weight of the mother‚Äôs glare sank me through the floor. She towered over me with her eyebrows lowered. She declared that her son‚Äôs blood will not be drawn. She told me they were Jehovah‚Äôs Witnesses. Unsure of their beliefs, I asked her many questions as she gradually uncrossed her arms. She allowed me to collect the labs because the blood was only to be used for testing purposes. I drew Max‚Äôs blood and he smiled as he told me that not many times, did he get his blood drawn well the first time without pain. Physicians will be engaged with those of diverse backgrounds, sometimes even coming across those with backgrounds they have not interacted with before. Working with others from different backgrounds requires a willingness to understand their beliefs and a sensitivity to their needs.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Josh returned to the clinic for his monthly medication injection in her left eye. For many years now, he has been receiving these injection treatments to maintain his vision. My first encounter with him was many months ago. He walked slowly, cautious of bumping into another person or furniture. He was told to begin treatment immediately because the risk of losing vision was high. Without insurance and money to pay for treatment, he told me he wanted to defer treatment at the time. Bringing this up to the physician, we had him enrolled into the copay program, which has been helping to alleviate the cost of his medical care. At his latest appointment at the clinic, he read each letter on each line perfectly. Had he not received treatment early, it is possible that he could have lost his vision. My experiences with patients like Josh have led me to believe that it is necessary to serve the medically underserved populations in our community so they can receive the treatment they deserve.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
Luke, a 12-year-old boy I met while distributing care packages, coughed persistently in the cold winter air. I suggested he see a physician. He told me that without medical insurance, his family did not have the financial means to see a physician regularly._x000D_
An inability to start my job after graduating allowed me to invest in my community further. The pandemic altered the course of my volunteer group. We were unable to collect donations and convene as a large group. Unwilling to stop our service, I took the initiative to continue to serve our local community._x000D_
_x000D_
Many people in my community found it difficult to access healthcare without medical insurance. Without insurance, the financial burden of healthcare is a barrier that is hard to overcome. Tearing down barriers to healthcare and providing equitable and inclusive care for all people, especially the medically underserved population, is a goal I desire to work towards.

personal_statement:
“The doctor will see you now,” the nurse said to my family who had been sitting in the waiting room for four hours. My ailing sibling was dehydrated and fatigued, groaning in pain. I scanned the room and saw 100 patients requiring acute medical care, and there was only one medical officer - it was heartbreaking. I learned that the most crucial medical supplies were scarce or even lacking. Later, I lined up at the pharmacy unit to collect drugs after a positive amebic dysentery test, only to be told that there was no metronidazole to treat my sister’s ailment. A medical facility missing a drug to treat a diarrheal infection as common as dysentery speaks to the scarcity and lack in public hospitals in my homeland.   That was perhaps the first time pursuing a career in medicine crossed my mind.  
When I moved to the United States at the age of 15, I experienced firsthand the impact that a properly developed healthcare system has had on our lives and how much underserved communities both here and globally can benefit from it. For many years prior to moving to the United States, I had this left upper quadrant abdominal pain. However, I did not want to be a burden on anyone, so I suffered in silence and took some herbal medicine known as “obosaro” that was known to “heal all ailments.” It was not until the Fall of 2016, beginning of my freshman year in college when I finally told my father I was not feeling well, and he told me that I could go to an urgent care since I was covered under his insurance. I was diagnosed with peptic ulcers that had been caused by Helicobacter Pylori and received treatment immediately. While this was a blessing to have had the opportunity to move to the US, this experience affirmed my desire to become a physician. 
 Soon after, I decided to enroll in pre-medical classes. These classes were engrossing, and given my success with these courses, I became motivated to participate in a research lab where we focused on apolipoprotein a1, a component in HDL and is implicated in cardiovascular and neurodegenerative diseases. I worked with a graduate student to identify C-terminal residues implicated in self-association and lipid binding.   My contribution, albeit small, taught me how to work in a team, with patience, especially when experiments don’t go as anticipated, and improved my critical thinking  through making inquiries, analyzing information and evidence, and arriving at conclusions. 
Although I enjoyed various aspects of research in the lab, my desire for a career in clinical medicine became stronger, and I became a certified nursing assistant (CNA). On my first day as a CNA, I was unsure if I could aid the residents. My doubts were cast aside soon because I realized that the rewards of medicine stem from serving those that needed help whether it was helping a resident find their room or even learning to say a few foreign words to communicate with a resident. Seeing the smiles on their faces through each positive interaction was a reward. 

Ultimately, I knew I needed more direct personal interaction and began working as a medical assistant at Action Urgent Care. I observed here that medicine is diverse, including the patients, the illnesses, and treatments .  I have evaluated two different patients with similar UTI symptoms leave the clinic with different diagnoses and different medications, while some with the same diagnoses respond differently to the same treatments. Similarly, while shadowing Dr. Sikander, I witnessed one patient with hypertension had lower dosages of both lisinopril and amlodipine, while another only had a higher dosage of lisinopril. I learned being a doctor requires attention to detail, especially when getting a patient’s medical history, because it gives a better understanding of the patient. 

As I desired more direct interactions with patients, I decided to complete volunteer work at a free medical camp in Kenya. Most people in this community are barely making it, and our services could not have come at a better time. Through our health screenings, I observed a few common diseases among the children as well as some adults in the community. Others had conditions not so common. For instance, a five-year-old male was diagnosed with cryptorchidism from preliminary examination that needed an urgent ultrasound and surgical correction. His parents told me that they could not afford said services, and so efforts to raise funds for him became underway. These patients exposed me to difficulties in healthcare accessibility and inspired me to practice medicine with the underserved in mind.

My motivation and preparation for a career as a medical doctor started off in an unexpected way but has led me to my research, my volunteer activities, and my work to recognize the responsibilities that lie ahead in medicine. As I reflect on my personal experiences, I have solidified my determination to practice medicine with empathy, compassion, attentiveness, humility, and confidence. I know that medicine will be a challenging career, but that is partly what draws me to it. I believe that to develop my love for science further while allowing my passions to serve my patients will be a rewarding experience.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: At my first job ever, I experienced a shift in demographics, where I found myself to be the only non-Spanish speaker that worked there. I felt out of place and a lot of the time was not included in what was happening at work. I understood that it was most likely not personal but due language and communication barriers. Instead, I began paying attention to what was being said and asked questions in order to learn some vocabulary. Although I don‚Äôt speak Spanish fluently, I can now communicate to some extent. I‚Äôve moved enough through my life to know it can be tough being the only person who is different from others in a group of people, or even being the new person. To this day, similar experiences echo in my daily life and I am glad I took the lessons from this experience with me. I understand that as a physician, I will encounter a varied group of patients and I look forward to using my presence in a diverse workforce to enlighten others who might not have the same experience as mine.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
In Swahili, we have a saying that goes ‚ÄúTenda wema nenda zako,‚Äù meaning do good and move on. Growing up, it was a lesson not only emphasized at home but also at my church. My family had very little growing up, it always amazed me how positive and generous my parents were. Perhaps that provided some inspiration because as I got older, I continually felt drawn to helping others. I started organizing several clothing and shoe drives when I was a teenager, the most recent one being a clothing and shoe drive I helped organize for Shining Star children‚Äôs Home, an orphanage in Kenya. The most rewarding part was seeing the appreciation among the recipients, many of whom had probably never dreamt of receiving that much. I felt uplifted to improve the wellbeing of others. I admit that however small an act of kindness is, the ripple effect can be immeasurable and therefore, in my aspiration as a physician, my desire to serve humanity will be fulfilled. _x000D_
_x000D_

Hrdshp_Comments: I always enjoyed the escape education provided me and dreamed of going away for college but had no direction or references on how to achieve higher education. My mother was a homemaker that immigrated from Mexico. My father was a military man who was gone for most of my young life. As the eldest of three, I helped to raise my brothers when my parents eventually ended their marriage. I lived less than four miles from the San Ysidro Land Port of Entry in a predominantly Spanish-speaking neighborhood. While the blending of Mexican and American culture is a beautiful thing, it comes with its own trials and tribulations. It was impoverished and lacked the infrastructure needed for children to feel safe. And the socioeconomic status of surrounding neighborhoods contributed to poorly performing surrounding educational systems. We did not have a school bus route available so we walked to school in areas saturated with gang life. It felt impossible to concentrate on my studies, let alone excel. At 17 years old, I followed in my father's footsteps and I enlisted in the Navy for 10 years. The mission always came first during my years of service and higher education was not a priority of the uniformed service. It did, however, provide me with the tools to start my journey in higher education.
personal_statement:
When people think of California, the golden coasts, near-perfect weather, and wealthy zip codes come to mind for many. However, some forget the terrible droughts and destructive fires that soon follow. Dry weather invites wildfires to scorch towns and forests, leaving behind ash. Thankfully, with destruction comes regrowth and beauty. The mighty giant sequoias of California are injured by fire but not killed–the trees require fires to accelerate the growth and survival of newer generations. New seedlings cannot grow to be free and stand amongst the greats without it. Nature teaches me about balance. The shifting equilibria in our world and the desire to share these occurrences connect us all.

My father says that challenges can serve as kindling in life; all that is needed is the spark. Becoming a US Navy Diver was the first spark that started my internal fire. Repairing US vessels underwater may be rewarding, but the job is inherently dangerous. On one November day, I was reminded of the dangers.

I was paired with a senior diver, Mike, to replace a 32-ton propeller on an aircraft carrier ship. Into a laborious hour beneath San Diego Bay's frigid and murky water, I heard a chilling cry. A hefty piece of equipment called a chainfall dragged Mike to the ocean bottom. I rushed to assist him in avoiding complications from exceeding the allowed depth and maximum dive time. As I touched the sea floor, visibility went from bad to worse; I had to rely on feel to search for him. Through the turbid water, I felt a hand grab my arm and soon spotted the amber glow of his flashlight; I had found him! Tangled up in chains and mud, Mike was stuck. While reassuring him that we would be okay, I freed him and the chains from the muck, and we quickly ascended from the deep. 

Unfortunately, we required time in a hyperbaric chamber to release built-up nitrogen from our systems to avoid diving-related illnesses. As we entered the chamber with our dive medical physician, "Doc" tended to our well-being with an infectious smile. I realized that comforting people in tricky positions could be just as important as helping them physically, especially when it comes from a friendly face. 

It was my first experience with an emergency in the Navy, and we lived to dive another day. Though jarring, Doc's swift ability to become the solution in a crisis left me enamored. After the incident, I felt an ignited desire to explore a new world of medicine to make similar impacts as Doc did for us. I soon set off to change my naval career to become a Special Operations Medic.

The fire inside me grew as I learned from exceptional physicians, senior medics, and supplemental courses. One such course was a 14-day professional development training designed to prepare me for scenarios that would require me to care for casualties with little resources for hours or days before help arrived. I believed that this course would be worthwhile if a medic could better train for unpredictable misfortunes. But I learned we would practice our new skills on actual patients – livestock. On the one hand, I was against the practice, as I have read opposing arguments citing little to no gain over training on manikins. On the other hand, having heard the benefits from doctors that completed this training, I put trust in the process to learn as much as possible in the days ahead. 

Upon my arrival, an anxious feeling of hesitancy crept up my throat. I took a breath, accessed my surroundings, and found a calm clarity wash over me. In my eyes, these anesthetized animals who deserved dignity and respect were now my patients. I continued studying and practicing prolonged care airway management, wound care, and pain management. The course concluded with a trying 48-hour-long application of the acquired medical knowledge and skills.

We partnered into two-person teams to collaborate on prolonged medical care scenarios presented by the instructors. My partner and I scheduled sleep rotations to monitor our patients, yet neither of us could sleep due to our elevated nerves. Instead, we shared deeply personal stories during lulls of the events. On the last day, relief came as the sun broke over the horizon. It was hard to part with the patients as it was difficult not to imagine them like fallen comrades. I thanked them and said my cathartic goodbyes. Though I initially struggled with the ethics regarding the practice of medicine on animals, I am glad I committed to the process. If a day of catastrophe comes, the skills I learned provided me the confidence that I can help on or off the battlefield.

My diverse and arduous experiences undoubtedly trailblazed a path for me to continue the pursuit of medicine, to forge upon my skills to make holistic and positive impacts. The unavoidable and challenging encounters have taught me to pause before reacting, becoming the solution in the face of adversity. Like a sequoia, progress has made my roots grow profound and my core more resilient, bringing me closer to a devotion that has always been inside me — people. My internal fire continues to drive me toward a better version of myself. I hope to continue raising my branches toward more knowledge and leadership in medicine to give back to my community as a physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
When deployed in the Middle East, I was intrigued by the holiday of Ramadan, in which Muslim people fast from sunrise to sunset. My peers did not readily accept my curiosity as we were in an active war, but I found the culture too fascinating not to learn more about the religious practice. _x000D_
_x000D_
A gentleman who cut hair on the military base was a man named Aasim, and I started to ask him as many questions as possible. Aasim eventually invited me to a dinner in which they broke fast. It was such a simple yet profound experience for me. I had an epiphany; I knew then that people aren't so different. _x000D_
_x000D_
I believe sharing a meal with someone is one of the most basic yet educational pathways to understanding a culture. I realized that I was in the middle east in support of war and felt a bit of humility and guilt. I went on to learn more about the Muslim culture, and from then on, whenever I travel, I try the local food and strike up a conversation to better know the community.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
The most linear example I can think of is when I spent time with Burmese refugees in Mae Sot, Thailand. Although my main focus in Thailand was to attend a tropical medical course, I had the privilege of volunteering medical aid to the Burmese people escaping violence and religious persecution with the "Eyes to Burma" project. _x000D_
_x000D_
My primary duty in the makeshift village in a Thai open-air waste facility was treating the refugees directly under my supervising physician. The interventions would range from tropical diseases to trauma wounds, assisting with baby deliveries, and helping maintain the facility as needed.  _x000D_
_x000D_
The most significant rewards were receiving all the smiles after long swelting days and knowing I was one of the friendly foreign faces making a difference in their community. It was an unforgettable experience and a huge reason I left the military to pursue my dream of becoming a physician.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I would like to address my MCAT performance. I was not an exception to the effects of COVID-19 and experienced personal hurdles. My wife and I lost people from our families during my MCAT preparation. It took more of a mental toll than I realized each time I signed up for the exam. However, my MCAT score does not accurately display my passion or ability in medicine, like my GPA, clinical experiences, or personal experiences. The process has made me more resilient and has only strengthened my love for medicine. I am grateful for those who held our family member‚Äôs hands as they passed and for the global push for vaccination innovation.

personal_statement:
My 4-year-old sister’s screams alerted me that something was wrong; my 11-year-old self rushed into the room to find her with her hand stuck in a moving treadmill. With a phone in one hand and my crying sister on my lap, I called 911 and went to the ER with my grandmother, ready to serve as my grandmother’s translator and my sister’s caretaker.
 
At the ER that day, I carefully wrote down the doctors’ wound care instructions in my pink Hello Kitty notebook. Every day for 2 weeks, I gave my sister medications and fluids, changed her gauze, and watched, intrigued, as her skin healed. Because our parents were away for weeks or months at a time for work, I often found myself taking on caretaking responsibilities for my sister. Some occasions led to amused stares — I was the only 11-year-old stand-in parent at the preschool’s Muffins for Moms brunch — but sometimes the responsibilities were more serious, including taking care of her every time she got hurt.
 

The satisfaction I felt helping my sister heal and the incredible resilience I saw of the human body was what put me on my path to medicine. My sister is extremely accident-prone and many more accidents were yet to unfold. But eventually, I was able to teach her her own care instructions, and transitioned from caretaker to care-teacher. 
 

Throughout college, the experiences that helped me strengthen and confirm my decision to pursue medicine also broadened my conception of care-teaching. In particular, I spent many hours volunteering at a local free clinic which served uninsured and homeless populations in greater Los Angeles. Many of our patients were immigrants and non-English speaking. As part of a three-person team, I took on many responsibilities, including translating for Telugu- and Spanish-speaking patients. My translations weren’t perfect, but I noticed that patients appreciated the effort and felt more comfortable when we met them where they were at. More than once, I found myself translating for someone else’s grandparents the way I had once translated for mine. Seeing recent immigrants struggle as my own grandparents had helped me understand the importance of culturally competent care and health literacy in vulnerable populations. 

 
These issues go hand-in-hand. One clinic patient, “Oscar”, who’d been given a free monitor and asked to track his blood pressure, brought an empty log sheet to his follow-up. He explained that neither he nor his wife could understand the monitor’s instruction booklet. Whenever he tried to take his blood pressure, all of his readings were outside of the possible ranges shown in the manual. In many cases, it would have been easy to mark this up to noncompliance; however, because we took the time to understand the lack of follow through without blame or shame, we were better able to identify and find effective solutions. We sent Oscar home with instructions written at an elementary reading level that included pictures. I also demonstrated properly tightening the cuff so he would know what it should feel like during a home reading. He brought his completed log to his next appointment, providing essential information about his health.
 

As I continued volunteering at the clinic, I felt a pull toward working with patients like Oscar and realized that I want to serve underserved communities and continue to make strides towards providing equitable care. Health disparities exist due to differences in socioeconomic conditions, some of which stem from financial insecurity and others from unequal access to interpretable health information. The height of the COVID-19 pandemic revealed the spaces in which I could play a small role in addressing these disparities in health literacy. I have long been involved in journalism and have noticed many parallels between journalism and medicine: both doctors and journalists provide facts to empower others to make informed choices. However, most health information is written at higher than the national literacy level, which makes health information inaccessible to most people. 
 

With this in mind, I created Bruin Medical Review (BMR; soon to be SimplyMD), an organization that creates engaging health- and science-related content at a middle to high school reading level and hosts health-literacy outreach programming in the greater Los Angeles area. At BMR, I lead a group of over 100 student volunteers whose content reaches readers in 39 countries. I’ve returned to my role as a care-teacher, but now for a broader audience. I hope to make widespread impacts on health literacy by empowering many more people than just my little sister to engage with health and science information, thus creating more positive health outcomes. 
 

While I no longer attend Muffins for Moms or write wound-care instructions in my Hello Kitty notebook, I still desire to be the person who knows what to do in challenging situations and takes action not only as a physician, but also as an advocate for vulnerable populations and a leader in creating health-informed policies and improvements in health literacy. A career in medicine would make me a care-teacher once again, incorporating my passions into a fulfilling career while empowering others to make positive changes in their lives.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: In high school, I participated in a summer homestay program in Germany, with my host mom and two host sisters, Nele and Zoe. I attended school with Nele where most of her classmates only spoke fluent German but could converse in some others. If I wanted to talk to Nele‚Äôs friends, we went through a list of possible languages we had in common and did our best. Some might find this frustrating, but for me, I developed a much deeper appreciation for diversity in culture, language, and life experiences. Since then, my favorite pastime has been learning languages. In high school, I took Spanish and Chinese; in college, Hindi and French. On Duolingo, I am actively learning three languages. I am not yet fluent by any means, but as I continue this interest, I hope to converse directly with patients from different backgrounds, without needing a translator. At Rush, I hope to similarly embrace the diversity in cultures, traditions, and thought processes of my peers and instructors.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Conejo Free Clinic quickly became the single-most influential clinical experience I‚Äôve had. Being a necessary part of a three-person team was not only a large responsibility, it was also the experience that changed my trajectory in medicine. It was striking to me how so many individuals fall through the cracks of healthcare. By working with low-income and uninsured populations at a safety-net organization, I found myself wanting to pursue a path in medicine providing essential care to vulnerable populations. I grew up with immigrant, non-English-speaking grandparents who struggled to communicate with their health providers; my volunteering has been marked not only by clinical exposure, but also by witnessing and participating in advocacy for particularly vulnerable populations like my grandparents. My experience at Conejo Free Clinic solidified my desire to work at the intersection of policy and practice, advocating for health policy and providing excellent clinical care for all.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I remain grateful that none of my direct family members contracted COVID-19, however the pandemic did affect my academic and professional pursuits. The research lab I was to join was shut down, my hospital volunteering was cut short, my study abroad programs were canceled, I was laid off from my job, and my shadowing opportunities were restricted to prevent unnecessary exposure. However, the pandemic gave me a chance to introspect. Free clinics near home needed more volunteers during the pandemic, and when I began volunteering in-person with vulnerable populations, I found that these were the populations I wanted to serve as a physician. I saw misinformation being spread and founded Bruin Medical Review to combat it and encourage engagement with science information. I saw my mom work tirelessly as a physician to support the patients who were able to be treated. COVID-19 changed the environment and activities that I had planned, but it also shaped the trajectory of my path in medicine.

personal_statement:
Language is the single most impactful means by which to stimulate the mind and the heart. It fosters trust, security, and harmony through which we gain the ability to connect to people living parallel lives across the globe. My captivation by neuroscience stems from its link to the mechanics of language and its usage. Yet it was through music, my longtime refuge and pure delight, that I discovered the unique ability for intense focus, precise logic, and astonishing creative expression of the mind. I was adamant to combine and grow my passions in college, which ceremoniously stimulated the expansion of my perspectives far beyond one that is centered on my own self. Further exploring medicine, languages, and music has devoted me to care about the needs of others and to service those needs through a single pursuit: patient care. 

Living in Lebanon from ages 3 to 8 cemented my love for languages, people, and cultures. I developed my reading, writing, and speaking skills in French and Arabic, and soon after moving to the States, in English and Spanish as well. Yet what I most gained from these formative years and the mastery of four languages is the awareness of the diversity of the human experience, which has allowed me to acknowledge the unconscious biases that may dilute our thoughts and actions. During one of my shifts as a language interpreter at the student-run free clinic, Spanish-speaking patient James and his mother were scheduled for a consultation. Throughout our discussion, it became evident that James may have been exhibiting schizophrenic symptoms for many years. In his hometown of Mexico City, James had consulted various physicians but had, up to this point, remained undiagnosed and untreated. Through my cultural studies, I gleaned that unconscious biases surrounding mental health in certain socioeconomic regions of Latin America may have been a root cause for James’ delayed diagnosis and thus treatment. I separately communicated this to the medical team who verified my presumption and referred the patient to more specialized care. My experience taught me that education and collaboration within a medical team is a powerful tool in combating implicit biases and ensuring positive outcomes for patients. 

Working alongside the medical students at the clinic gave me insight into the commitment and diligence required to become a compassionate and competent physician, which I have vigorously taken on as my own aspiration. I further gained insight into the value of physician-patient connections when my family and I were seeking medical care for my father’s spinal stenosis, which had been progressing and was causing him debilitating pain. Having consulted numerous neurosurgery and orthopedic specialists, I was marked by one visit in particular. As I sat in the chair by my father’s side, I watched the physician enter the room and face my father. He began masterfully extracting pertinent details from the HPI as my father - a notoriously taciturn man - recounted his experience with his symptoms and debilitations. Dr. Burke proceeded to educate rather than lecture my father about the various treatment options at his disposal. His demeanor made my family and I feel at ease and trust that my father’s condition was now being managed by considerate and able hands. I vowed to always approach all patient encounters throughout my career in a similar manner.

My patient care endeavors have set a precedent for how I plan to critically and thoughtfully contribute to the medical profession. I also aim to contribute to the advancement of medicine through research. My experience in my neurology lab has impacted the way I think about the mundane conditions of our health and abilities. My research team and I developed and tested nanopatterned microelectrodes that allow direct control of a prosthetic limb while greatly reducing the foreign body reaction. Through every impassioned investigation and meticulous exploration, we arrive one step closer to actualizing a reality where vitality is attainable by all. I am now confident that our innovations in laboratory techniques, our careful observation and applications of biomimetics in a variety of unlikely scenarios, and most of all, our determination for inquiry and adaptability have the potential to thoroughly rectify conditions previously thought to be unconditionally constraining.

By intertwining the objects of my fascination, I have discovered that the complexity and variety of human communication is a paramount constituent of scientific inquiry and healing. There exists an unmistakable likeness between how musicians orchestrate a plethora of elements - from the artistic decision-making and synergy throughout the piece - and how clinicians and surgeons orchestrate their own symphony in the clinic and operating room. Applying myself to music, language, and service, I have gained the adaptability and resilience that I am compelled to embody while caring for patients. What I hear in Edouard Lalo’s “Symphonie Espagnole,” is beauty that I can also see and touch. The intricacy of its harmonized melodies are characterized by a stimulating complexity, one that is mirrored in my lifelong pursuit - a fine art composed of the most harmonious instrument: the human body.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
I spent five years of my childhood in Lebanon, a country with many different faces. To the media, it is a war-stricken country in the midst of ongoing conflict; to historians, an archeological phenomenon; and to sociologists, proof that a myriad of different religions can coexist. My cherished memories of Beirut instilled in me a yearning to discover what my country's history means to me. Through this ongoing introspective discovery, I have gained a deeper understanding of myself and an ability to recognize insecurities in others and address them with empathy and understanding._x000D_
_x000D_
The differences each of us portrays allows for the expression of a diversity of thoughts, ideas, and experiences. In everything that I dedicate myself to, I make decisions that help me attain this mindset. At Rush Medical College, I aspire to apply my willingness to appreciate differences to my interactions with my peers and to my future delivery of care, by listening to others as they tell their story.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I was able to measurably impact several communities across different cities through the Kidney Disease Screening and Awareness Program. Kidney disease is a common and chronic condition which often presents without symptoms. Our goal was to provide accessible testing and education in prevention and care management in medically underserved communities, specifically in bustling cities where many health issues may be neglected. We encouraged patients to take charge of their health; during follow-up, our patients reported changes in their diet, exercise, and lifestyle habits. Overall, we innovated in the way that people receive and seek out healthcare, and in the way they perceive their health - as something tangible to be managed. Through this experience, I have learned skills that I hope to apply in furthering the mission of the Rush Medical College by incorporating education and epidemiology into the strategies for achieving improved health and wellness in the Chicago community.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
The hardships faced by marginalized communities became apparent to me during the COVID-19 outbreak through my role as a Spanish interpreter to patients with limited English proficiency at the University of Michigan Student-Run Free Clinic. As a medical interpreter, I rely heavily on facial expressions and body language to relay messages. In the virtual format, I was challenged to adapt my skills by relying instead on the tones of voice._x000D_
_x000D_
Confronting uncertainty, I evolved my approach by maintaining a therapeutic patient-provider relationship. Even though I volunteered at the clinic since my freshman year, the spread of COVID-19 illuminated a variety of healthcare aspects that I was previously unaware of. The pandemic presented me with certain challenges through which I vowed to use every circumstance to learn about myself and others, to learn from my mistakes, and to use my shortcomings as means to improve. Medicine evolves unexpectedly, but I have learned to embrace ambiguity.

Hrdshp_Comments: Growing up I attended lower income schools that lacked adequate resources and funding needed to prepare their students for the next level of education. Once I began attending higher educational institutions, I needed to take loans out and look for any scholarship available in order to pay for schooling. I received the Pell Grant while in college and am still taking loans out to pay for my schooling. In my hometown, my home is located in a lower socioeconomic location in the city. The areas around me are surrounded by violence and crime and I've grown accustomed to hearing the sirens of police and ambulances going by my house every night. In addition to this, we are also medically underserved. We do have a hospital near, however anytime I've had to get care from this hospital, it has been filled with mistakes. In order to get quality care we need to travel to facilities in Los Angeles, about an hour drive away.
personal_statement:
BEEP! BEEP! BEEP! Our duty phone had just gone off. It was my first call as an EMT. I trained extensively for this but, now that it had arrived, a wave of nervousness came over me. Despite my nervousness I was ready to act and do what needed to be done, which was getting to the patient and giving them the care they needed. Upon arrival, the patient was lying on the floor moaning in agony. I made first contact, immobilizing their cervical spine to prevent further injury. The patient’s head was just 6-inches from a brick wall, so I maneuvered between the patient and the wall to take the spinal precaution properly. In doing this, I could see fear in the patient’s eyes. I told them “Don’t worry, we got you.” With those simple words, relief visibly swept over the patient's face, and a simple smile conveyed the trust they had given me. I continued talking with them as we waited for transport to higher medical care. Despite its brevity, this interaction has taught me about the importance of human connection in medicine. Sometimes, what matters more is showing the patient how much you care rather than how much you know. This is something I strive to keep with me as I venture further into medicine.

Medicine has been a part of my life for as long as I can remember. I was born with a heart condition diagnosed as a “Single-Left Ventricle.” Because of this, I had three open-heart surgeries by the time I was 2 years old. This already difficult experience was amplified by the negative outlooks given to my parents and I. “Don't get too attached to your son, he isn’t going to live long.” “None of these operations matter, he’s going to need a new heart anyway.” “Don’t sign your son up for any sports, he won’t be able to play.” However, I decided that my diagnosis was not going to determine the outlook of my life. With the help of my family and my doctors, I was able to beat the odds and overcome all of these negative prognoses. I did continue living with the same heart, and through hard work, commitment, and dedication, I was able to play baseball up to the collegiate level. My heart condition has taught me how to overcome the hardships of life, regardless of the projections of others. Most importantly, it has also given me perspective on the patient’s side of medicine. I’ve experienced sitting in a hospital for weeks, having strangers enter your room and take blood, run tests and ask you personal questions you feel obligated to answer. I understand the vulnerability and dependency patients feel when they’re sick or hurt, having to rely on others to help them. This perspective allows me to shape my style of care to advocate for my patients and form strong relationships that empower them in their treatment.

Despite my lifelong connection, I did not initially choose to go into medicine. While having some idea of becoming a doctor, being a first-generation college student, lacking resources and connections, led me to limit my career-path options. I initially chose to major in electrical engineering not through my true desires, but through the tainted lens that I viewed myself. As I found myself unsatisfied with my current goals, I met with counselors to speak about my preliminary idea of becoming a doctor. They would ask “are you running away from something or running towards something?” Looking back, I can confidently say that I was running towards something, my dream of becoming a doctor. As I went through this transformation, I chose to switch majors and transfer schools. Almost immediately following my decision I began to feel an inner happiness that changed my entire perspective on my education and life. My study habits changed, and I began receiving higher grades. I began reaching out to organizations around me and got more involved in my community. I began to see my pursuit of becoming a doctor as the potential for me to give to others the same way that I was given to as a child. This idea brings me unexplainable happiness and satisfaction and I use it to bring me strength and drive as I venture through this journey.

It has been four years since I made my decision to pursue becoming a physician and I have not had any regret since. This journey has given me many experiences, opportunities and connections that have made me sure that I have chosen the right path. From volunteering at RotaCare Bay Area free medical clinics connecting financially struggling people to healthcare to volunteering at Golden State Orthopedics and Spine getting patients ready for the intimidating process of surgery and recovery, and even being the first line of defense for my community as an EMT. I’ve been a shoulder to cry on for a patient who hurt their back and could no longer work despite being the only source of income for their family, a source of strength for a patient experiencing a mental health crisis from the hardships of life, a support system for a young boy terrified of the scary saws that are used to take off casts. I cherish all of these experiences, and they have proven to me time and again that becoming a doctor is the right path for me. Medicine is my way of giving back to the community, advocating for people in need, and making true connections. This is a lifelong commitment and that’s exactly what I want from medicine.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Growing up, I lived in an underserved, low income community that surrounded me with an immense amount of diversity. So much so that the high school I attended had a 92% minority enrollment rate, which allowed me to be surrounded by others from different backgrounds. Having this experience so early in life enabled me to understand the importance of making connections with people from different backgrounds, and how learning about a person‚Äôs culture, religion or heritage, can help you to become a more open and well-rounded person. One experience in particular that enhanced my ability to understand those unlike myself was learning about Hawaiian culture. I was completely unaware of such different traditions, especially a place part of the U.S. This experience taught me not to prematurely judge any one‚Äôs background and culture. I have kept these lessons thus far in my life and still make it a point to learn as much as I can about the people around me.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Two of my most impactful experiences that entailed helping my surrounding community would be volunteering at RotaCare Bay Area and Believers in Christ. Both of these experiences allowed me to lend a helping hand to individuals in need. Rotacare was a free medical clinic for the people of San Jose who were unable to afford a hospital visit due to lack of insurance or any other financial barriers. Although I did not directly serve as a medical provider, helping the clinic run in a quick and efficient manner meant more people were receiving much needed care. I took my role very seriously and put forth my best effort to help the patient‚Äôs visiting the clinic. Believers in Christ was a program that fed unhoused people every Sunday. I was able to form many connections and friendships with the people I served, and I found it to be extremely rewarding. I feel that these two experiences are examples of how I made an impact in my community helping people receive healthcare and warm meals.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The COVID-19 pandemic began at the end of my first year at Santa Clara University, just as I was starting to solidify myself in organizations and volunteering opportunities. I lost a year as an active EMT, a clinic I was volunteering at shutdown, I was unable to tutor in person and I could not be a peer educator in person for the incoming first-generation transfer students. Although I was able to contribute to these activities online, it took away many of the personal connections that I strive to make. My research grant was also pushed back a year. This caused me a domino effect of problems. I had initially planned to solely study for the MCAT during the 2021 summer, however my research project was pushed into this summer and I was forced to balance studying with a full-time research project. This impacted my studying greatly and resulted in me having to push back the MCAT, which would continuously cause me problems as I was never able to give my sole focus to studying for the exam.

personal_statement:
I announced myself through "paseo" and saluted the drums; only then would the dance begin. I swung my arms, creating waves with my long white skirt, while the drummer synchronized his rhythm to mine. The annual "Semana de Puerto Rico," a time to celebrate and reflect on the history of our home island, included a lesson on Bomba, our oldest musical genre. In Bomba, the dancer tells the story while the percussionist amplifies and supports, nurturing respect between muse and musician. This bond shapes my vision of the physician I aspire to become: a doctor who listens to and respects each patient's story. In the last few years, three individuals' poignant stories have played a pivotal role in my decision to study medicine and provide healthcare to underserved communities.

My heart raced as I listened to Figueroa's slurred words on the phone. I was back home from college when Figueroa, a security guard whom I have known since I was young, had suffered a stroke. He was referred to a psychiatrist to help him cope with his disability rather than a neurologist to prevent a worsening of his pathology due to the scarcity of physicians accepting "La Reforma," the Puerto Rican term for Medicaid. In order to grant him more appropriate care, my neighbors and I gathered funds for his neurologist appointment — it was not unusual for me to get involved in my community; I often visited a local women's shelter and volunteered at the local public school as a French teacher every Friday after classes. Unfortunately, several days after Figueroa's call, we learned that he had suffered a second stroke that left him partially paralyzed. Although there was immense value in our grassroots organizing, it alone could not prevent Figueroa's second stroke. Growing up, I witnessed how inadequate medical care in Puerto Rico can be, and while studying in Maine and subsequently living in New England, I found that an efficient way to spread awareness of the inequalities faced by Puerto Ricans was to share individual experiences of hardship, such as Figueroa's. When local musicians popularized Bomba, they amplified lost voices and shared the stories of their ancestors: tales of oppression and resilience. To similarly elevate stories of struggle, I co-hosted the Puerto Rico Series on the "All Alone with Something to Say" podcast that reached audiences unfamiliar with the island's plights, and created an online platform to share experiences of injustice with my colleagues, family, and friends.

My desire to help marginalized individuals enduring medical hardships led me to Project Healthcare at the NYU Bellevue Hospital Emergency Department, where I volunteered as a patient advocate at a safety-net hospital in which 80 percent of patients come from medically underserved populations. For five consecutive days, I stood beside Karina, a Hispanic woman suffering from severe abdominal pain. We shared stories in our native tongue, which provided her with comfort and a sense of community. When we were not conversing, she spoke to a phone held up by her physician. The interpreter’s voice at the other end of the line asked her questions and repeated her answers in English, impairing the patient-physician bond. Karina reached for my hand as her doctors huddled outside her curtain, and I yearned to be part of the discussion to ease her pain while also allowing her to share her own story.
 
A couple of weeks after Karina was discharged, I sat beside James, a man roughly my age who reminisced about his childhood in Jamaica and confided in me as he shared his struggles to sustain his mother and sister in a new country. On the fourth day of my shift, I learned he had been sent back to Riker's Island, where he was awaiting his trial. Despite his status as an incarcerated immigrant, I wished to establish the same relationship I had formed with my previous patients, even if some of my colleagues discouraged me from doing so. My encounter with James thus expanded my vision of advocacy and caretaking to encompass marginalized individuals beyond my immediate community.

As a child, I learned that without the dancer there is no Bomba. Years later, I realized that Figueroa, Karina, and James are the dancers who drive the beat of the intimate bond that is the patient-physician relationship. These three experiences have convinced me that medicine is the path I want to pursue in order to alleviate suffering stemming from health inequities and provide proper care to any patient who seeks medical treatment. My career as a physician will only be fulfilled if I can additionally provide medical care in safety-net clinics like Bellevue Hospital. I will treat patients with limited financial resources like Figueroa, patients who overuse emergency services when their medical conditions become exacerbated, such as Karina, and socially stigmatized individuals like James. My goal is to be a physician who amplifies every patient's voice and addresses their health needs with empathy and respect, just as the percussionist elevates the dancer, and just as Bomba empowers my community.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I was born in San Juan, Puerto Rico, my mother's hometown, but spent my first seven years in France where I grew up speaking Spanish and French. My father then moved our family to California to grant us the opportunity to obtain an American education, one he wished he had received growing up in the remote Moroccan countryside. A couple of years later, my family relocated to a suburb of San Juan. A Puerto Rican girl tasked with learning academic Spanish at 11 years old, I felt a unique need to earn my place culturally, and with adequate resources, I was successful within the academic year. However, I promptly noticed that in Puerto Rico, many public school students do not have the opportunity to learn foreign languages. As a result, in middle and high school, I taught French to at-risk teenagers at the local community center every Friday. Since then, I have continuously pursued volunteer work as a form of advocacy and am now eager to support vulnerable communities through medicine.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: At the Bellevue Hospital Emergency Ward, I met a young man named James who spoke endearingly about his sister and mother. He provided for them after his father passed away prior to their immigration to the U.S. He had a hard life but a gracious outlook, sharing his dream of becoming a pilot. When a nurse suggested I stay away from James, as he was awaiting his trial at Rikers Island prison, I respectfully reminded her that he was deemed non-violent by the police officer and that my duty as a patient advocate was to grant him the same treatment I was providing other patients. James later told me he was taken to the ED after a suicide attempt, and that I was the first person to engage in non-medical conversation with him. I wondered how the social isolation and stigmatization could have adversely affected his delicate mental condition. Although briefly, I provided him a space to be vulnerable and granted him companionship, which he acknowledged was lacking in his everyday life in prison.
7_-_COVID_Impact: At the start of the pandemic, I returned home to Puerto Rico to continue my pre-medical studies remotely. I volunteered to make face shields with a 3D printer at my former high school and distributed the equipment to first responders across the island. Later during the lockdown I baked and sold bread, donating the funds to Instituto Santa Ana, a home for young girls who have been victims of abuse.
