In late summer, my grandmother passed away, so we traveled to France to pay our respects. This loss was difficult to process since we were unable to embrace her in her final moments and our mourning process, a time to traditionally reunite with family and friends from France and Morocco, was interrupted. The pandemic has pushed me to find ways to help my community during times of suffering, a skill I will keep developing as a medical student and physician. I have learned that especially during seemingly hopeless times, even a small benevolent act of support can foster healing and recovery.

personal_statement:
There was a tap at the door, and twenty sets of eyes turned to watch the reading specialist as she entered the room. She called my name, and the focus shifted to me. As a fourth-grade student, I felt humiliated to not be able to read. While my classmates devoured Harry Potter, I struggled through Captain Underpants. At home, my mother painstakingly organized fun activities to practice my reading: I played word games for M&M’s and read flashcards in alto and soprano. It took considerable effort, but by sixth grade, I had caught up to my peers and was on my way to becoming an A student. The interventions of those supporting me, as well as my own determination, were key to my success. Ever since then, I have wanted to support others on their own journeys. Through my patient care experiences as an intern at a medical center, emergency medical technician (EMT), and clinical researcher, I have discovered that medicine is a career that would allow me to do this and in which I would thrive.
 
As an intern at Tufts Medical Center, I met “John,” a 15-year-old eczema patient enrolled in a biologic drug clinical trial after 10 years of failed treatments. John’s discomfort and desquamation were so severe that he was homeschooled and wore towels, as they chafed less than shirts. John was worn down by his condition and its impact on his quality of life, which was not helped when little to no improvement was noted weeks into the trial. Through my attempts to make John more comfortable, I discovered that he played Subway Surfers on his phone, which sparked a friendly months-long competition between us. As I watched John open up and grow more optimistic about the clinical trial, I realized that I enjoyed building long-term relationships with patients. With support from me, the clinical team, and his family, John stayed in the trial and was re-randomized; his eczema cleared almost entirely by the following summer. I saw how my relationship and rapport with John contributed to his positive medical outcome, and I saw how gratifying this aspect of being a doctor would be for me. 

My experiences as a Tufts EMT further solidified my desire to build strong relationships with patients and exposed me to the complex problem solving involved in medical encounters. During an EMT shift, I was dispatched to an 18-year-old female who was having an anxiety attack because her cycle was late after having consensual but unprotected intercourse. Her physical assessment indicated no major concerns, but I was troubled when my patient admitted she lacked friends, thought she had an undiagnosed anxiety disorder, and received an abstinence-only sex education. I did not feel comfortable leaving this patient alone with her spiraling anxiety, so I recommended she seek more urgent care. Through this and other patient care encounters, I found that the challenge of gathering information, weighing evidence, and making an appropriate decision motivates me to pursue a career in medicine. I feel satisfaction when solving a patient’s puzzle and contributing to their improved well-being, and this feeling motivates me to be a physician who strives to provide the best care to each unique patient. 

A non-clinical situation where I worked to find solutions to patients’ needs was when conducting research and interning in the Severe Asthma Clinic (SAC) at Boston Children’s Hospital. The SAC aims to improve care coordination by providing patients access to multi-specialty clinical care in a single location and coordinated manner. I participated in the study design and data acquisition of a project that aimed to acquire funding for each patient in the SAC to have private social work appointments scheduled during each clinic visit. I consented study participants, coordinated participants completing a questionnaire assessing anxiety or depression symptoms, and analyzed the data for correlations between reported anxiety or depression symptoms and asthma control indicators. My biggest takeaway from this project was seeing the collaborative nature of research and clinical medicine. It was bolstering to witness the support between providers and reassuring to know that as a physician, I would be able to obtain assistance if a patient’s needs exceeded my area of expertise. As someone who prides herself on being a resource to her team members, I also look forward to the opportunity to share my knowledge with others when they need it. I thrive in collaborative situations and working with the SAC showed me that medicine would be a strong match for me.

I know how challenging it is to struggle, and how life-changing it can be to overcome those struggles. As a doctor, I would look forward to the reward of knowing my efforts have led to the increased well-being of others. Whether it is playing Subway Surfers to build rapport, being perceptive and flexible with a complex patient, or supporting a team working to provide comprehensive healthcare, my passion is individualized patient care. I will be a successful physician because I will identify and treat my patients’ diverse medical, emotional and social needs, while working closely with other providers on the care team. My disposition to go above and beyond for patients is the distinction that will lead to my overall success.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Growing up, my parents valued diversity, so we celebrated Ramadan, Hanukkah, Christmas, Kwanzaa, and Chinese New Year. This upbringing has provided me with a platform to connect with people and made me value diversity. For example, I was a member of a research group comprised of twelve young women of various backgrounds and religions. Sharing my own family‚Äôs traditions, I took the lead in ensuring that everyone felt comfortable talking about their own cultural experiences. Being raised in a primarily white, Christian, middle-class community, it would have been difficult for me to connect with diverse individuals if not for my parents‚Äô traditions. For example, as an EMT, I was better equipped to advise a fasting Muslim woman during Ramadan after she fainted because I recognize the traditions of the holy month and could relate to her experience. As a medical student, I will use my diverse upbringing to connect with my peers and patients, so people feel more comfortable and included.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: In the Severe Asthma Clinic (SAC) at Boston Children‚Äôs Hospital, I conducted research testing the hypothesis that symptoms of anxiety or depression are highly prevalent in pediatric severe asthma patients and negatively affect asthma control. The goal of the project was to provide evidence of the correlation and to petition the hospital for more funding for social work interventions in the SAC. Many of the young patients who participated in the study had such severe conditions that they could not play on youth sports teams. Those same children often noted not being compliant with their medication regimen due to feelings of helplessness and lack of motivation. After completing the research and proving the correlation, it was incredibly gratifying to know that my work impacted the SAC patient community by providing these children with the social work resources they needed to cope with their chronic illness, improving their mental health and hopefully, in turn, their physical health.
7_-_COVID_Impact: With online learning induced by the pandemic, I graduated early and became a medical assistant in January of 2021. Therefore, I experienced the positive and negative ways the pandemic impacted the healthcare system, which in turn contributed to my own career goals. I witnessed significantly more vaccination sites being placed in wealthy suburbs, compared to densely populated marginalized communities in the city. Yet, I also saw the enhancement of telehealth technology. Wheelchair-bound individuals no longer had to leave their homes for appointments, and virtual medical translators were accessible in minutes. The pandemic highlighted the issue of health equity, sparking my interest in exploring the topic further. At Rush Medical College, I would apply for the Health Equity and Social Justice Leadership Program where I would gain the knowledge and skills to advocate for health equity and make care more accessible through technological advancements and equitable resource distribution.

personal_statement:
For my fourteenth birthday, my mother gifted me what she believed to be the latest innovation in kitchen appliances: a hollow cylindrical device that could produce... a vertical omelet. Despite what would be her final attempt to sway me toward the culinary arts, I was hardly inspired. Medical dramas, not cooking shows, had long been the staple of my media diet. My expectations for a career built on well-timed epiphanies and risky interventions were set in place by an episode of House, MD, in which the eponymous physician convinces his team that their patient has a rare form of paralysis called locked-in syndrome. The opening scene ends as Dr. House stares into the patient's near-lifeless eyes and says "Oh, this is going to be fun".
Television's tendency to glamorize every encounter in medicine left me ill-prepared when I finally found myself shadowing a surgeon at Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center as a college freshman. The first case I witnessed that day, the excision of a pilonidal cyst, excited me as a clinically inexperienced student, but humbled the naive teenager in me who had envisioned a day filled with only the most high-stakes operations. Dr. Mancini, the attending physician, allowed me to stand just outside the sterile field throughout the case, eagerly welcoming my questions and quizzing me on anatomy in between explanations of how to properly hold instruments. I had no doubt that he had performed thousands of procedures just like this one, and yet, he seemed to share in the sense of novelty that I felt as a student watching a surgery for the very first time. In showcasing his craft, Dr. Mancini was invigorated by the role of a mentor that could perhaps distinguish a given case from the many technically identical ones he had done in the past. I began to notice that teaching was integral to Dr. Mancini's profession when he handed his needle driver to the resident standing opposite him and watched closely as she sealed the surgical defect with the final sutures. As she took over and finished the case, the distinction between student and colleague became more fluid; in this instance, teaching and learning appeared to be an act of partnership.
My interest in medicine found a new motivation: being a doctor entailed not only treating illness, but also fostering a learning environment where seasoned experts and their juniors could temporarily become equals in order to safely transfer skill and knowledge. I felt less intimidated by the seeming vastness and complexity of a physician's duties, knowing that their mastery comes from this kind of a joint effort where building mutual trust is the cornerstone of collaboration between a teacher and a student.
The camaraderie that was essential to mentorship in medicine was not lost on me when I spent four weeks shadowing a urologist named Dr. Steckel, who treated me as a member of his team by involving me in nearly every patient visit. He emphasized the patient's perspective in the exam room, creating a relaxed atmosphere where unpressured face-to-face interaction prevailed over clinical jargon. A casual, caring demeanor seemed natural to Dr. Steckel as he met each patient at eye level and shared stories about his personal life. Still, I always struggled to describe the concrete elements that formed a trusting bond between a physician and a patient.
When I joined a dermatology clinic as a medical assistant after college, I realized that patients were not always receptive to the compassionate gestures that I emulated from my prior mentors, like sitting down and mirroring their posture. I eventually came to understand that an empathetic approach was not a uniform pattern of actions, but rather an individualized response to a person's emotional needs; a patient would often benefit from having these addressed before their medical concerns. When an elderly woman named Kitty presented with painful blisters all over her body—apparently suffering a recurrence of bullous pemphigoid after years of failed treatments—I found myself trying to model composure and empathy in front of a newly hired assistant in training. As Kitty refused to answer even the most basic of intake questions, her intense scowl signaled a need to unleash frustration, and so I grabbed a stool and listened quietly until she regained calm. Although I was used to what teaching looked like in an academic setting, the task of demonstrating the emotional subtleties of patient communication in the clinic was especially challenging because I could not explain them in words to my trainee. Unlike the tutoring that I had done throughout college, the unwritten curriculum of empathy required learning through observation and experimentation. The notion of lifelong studentship in medicine began to make more sense to me as I played the role of a teacher for a skill in which I had not yet become proficient myself.
My exposure to real clinical situations has opened my eyes to the unexpected duality of the physician as both a healer and an educator. Whereas my initial excitement for medicine stemmed largely from the misguided thrill of managing constant life-or-death scenarios, I now also look forward to the collegiality of the learning and teaching process that is embedded in the physician's career.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
When I joined other undergraduates on a trip to Israel four years ago, I hoped to explore undiscovered parts of my Jewish heritage by immersing myself in the arts, language, and cuisine that honored those roots. Unexpectedly, I also encountered a wholly unfamiliar culture along the way._x000D_
_x000D_
Arriving in the Negev desert, my group was welcomed into a Bedouin village, a semi-permanent home to the land‚Äôs nomadic people. As we settled into an open tent and enjoyed dinner around a table without chairs or utensils, we learned about the Bedouins‚Äô way of life, which was built on relocation and adaptation. Their hospitality and their mastery of the arid environment embodied harmony, and I felt humbled to imagine a life in which not even shelter could be taken for granted. Largely isolated from the innovation-driven world around it, this community taught me a different kind of luxury, in which unity with nature and with each other exemplified a level of fulfillment that technology could not provide.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
As a teenager, I was used to having unpopular opinions at the dinner table. As the first in my family to be born in the United States, I had long perceived that my community, consisting mostly of Soviet immigrants, was resistant to the more progressive ideas on gender and sexuality that I had adopted throughout my upbringing. Coming out as gay forced me to challenge prejudices at home, and taught me the power of open dialogue in changing people‚Äôs minds. _x000D_
_x000D_
I leveraged my roles in community service to underpin difficult conversations with my family. Volunteering as a crisis counselor, an admissions essay coach, and an organizer of Dartmouth‚Äôs Medicine and Justice Scholars program, I came across firsthand accounts of sexual and gender minorities‚Äô journeys to establishing their identities. Sharing their stories with my parents compelled them to become more accepting of those who present differently. In turn, I learned to be a better advocate for groups whose voices are often diminished.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
Prior to the pandemic, I structured my academic plan to include a six-month window after junior year that would be free of classes, allowing me to pursue extracurricular activities full-time. By the Winter term of 2020, I had secured two consecutive internships to take place during my time off, the first one in urology research and the second in clinical work at a burn center in Nepal. When the emerging global health crisis had officially become a pandemic in March 2020, both internships were abruptly canceled._x000D_
_x000D_
I moved back home during this period of uncertainty, living with my parents while enrolling in Dartmouth's online courses for the Spring term. In this time, I started volunteering as a mental health counselor for Crisis Text Line, and completed a remote internship in public health that summer. The inaccessibility of lab spaces on campus rendered a senior thesis project impossible, and I instead chose to complete my major with a culminating course on the neuroscience of obesity.

Hrdshp_Comments: I grew up in the underserved area of East Los Angeles and attended low-performing public schools prior to matriculating to college. My parents had me when they were only sixteen years old, and we had a limited family income. Throughout high school, I was a student with Upward Bound which is a college preparatory program designed for first generation, low-income students. As my parents took non-traditional pathways to higher education, I navigated college mostly independently and without someone’s example to follow. Due to my parents’ limited income, I made an effort to find work-study jobs and paid summer internships that would allow me to pay for my education and personal expenses. The limited educational preparation I received in high school led to me struggling to keep up with the rigorous academic demands I faced in college. While I initially struggled to maintain my grades, I developed better study habits by attending office hours and collaborating with others. As an underrepresented minority in an academic setting, I struggled to relate to the experiences of others in college. The research mentors that I had helped me build my confidence and working as an Upward Bound tutor motivated me to expose more students from disadvantaged backgrounds to STEM and medicine.
Under_School: Columbia University in the City of New York
personal_statement:
“Terminal cancer and in lots of pain” was how the first patient that I would be seeing as a Delirium volunteer was described to me. As I walked with my supervisor to the patient’s room, I felt my worries mount against me. This patient had just recently triggered for delirium, and I was to spend at least 45 minutes helping stimulate her cognitive function through a non-medical intervention. Upon entering her dimly lit hospital room and seeing the patient fast asleep in a sea of blankets, I wondered by what authority was I to be attempting to interact with these patients. As a large motivation for me to enter the medical field was the opportunity to build relationships with patients, I worried about my ability to effectively build these connections. My nervous thoughts were put on pause as my supervisor walked me through the usual steps I was to take upon visiting a patient. I opened the room’s blinds and gently woke the patient to introduce myself and let her know that I’d be spending some time with her. 

With the patient awake, I began to ask the usual questions we ask to get to know patients better. As she told me she grew up in the South and was born in Trinidad, I recognized just how different our experiences were. However, I soon realized how exciting it was to have so much to learn about someone who has lived a life so different from mine. I heard all about how New York was during her youth and the foods she loved to cook. While I had entered her room knowing only of her illness, I now knew more about her as a person and how her illness had affected her life. Through building this connection with her, I began to see my desire to pursue a career in medicine confirmed. As I saw how this once-asleep patient laying in a dimly lit hospital room was now awake and alert, I also recognized how establishing these connections and engaging patients in conversation are vital in improving a patient’s health outcomes. As I continued to meet many more patients for the first time, my worries over this first encounter dissipated. I grew increasingly confident in my ability to modify my approach to an intervention based on a patient’s symptoms. For example, with patients experiencing greater cognitive decline and paranoia, I focused on reorienting them to their environment and building trust. 

While each shift was a learning opportunity, I also had the opportunity to teach patients’ families how they could be involved in the patient’s care. Similar to my own worries when I started volunteering, many families doubted their ability to treat and prevent symptoms of delirium. There were several times when the children of patients expressed doubt over their parent’s ability to engage in the intervention. It was heart-warming to see their faces light up upon hearing their names when I asked the patient to list the names of their children. By modeling how to reorient the patient to their environment, I was able to help family members feel more capable of involving themselves in the patient’s care. The teaching aspect of being a Delirium volunteer was highly rewarding as I got to empower patients and their families to feel a sense of agency in their health. During the instances in which I was able to revisit patients during subsequent shifts, I witnessed firsthand their improvement and the impact that frequent cognitive stimulation has had on their health and the ease of their family members. The experience of facilitating interventions has motivated me to continue working towards being a physician so that I can put into practice the process of making healthcare personalized to a patient and involving family in care. 

Along with patients whose experiences differed from my own, I also met patients who were not so different from myself. As one of the few Spanish-speaking volunteers on the team, I worked closely with Latinx patients. While I shared in my culture with many of them, I also learned about how multifaceted Latinx identity is and how there is always more for me to learn about the communities that I serve. With the rewards of getting to interact with patients, also came instances in which I didn’t feel satisfied with the care that I was able to provide to them. Along with some patients simply not wanting to engage, I saw how many patients, especially Latinx patients, were distrustful of me and other hospital staff because of previous negative experiences with healthcare. Hearing their frustrations over the lack of Spanish-speaking staff and the healthcare system at large echoed the frustrations I’ve heard from my own family members that have been hospitalized. While I ensured these patients that they were in good hands and that I empathized with their perspectives, these experiences have further motivated me to enter the medical field so that I can advocate for underserved communities. 

I’ve come to recognize that as an individual, I will always be just one part of a patient’s healthcare experience. From the social determinants of health to other individuals involved in their care, a patient’s healthcare experience has many aspects to it. I hope to continue learning how to navigate this as a physician. I’m excited for the collaboration and challenges that approaching healthcare with this perspective will bring.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: When I moved to NYC for college, I aimed to get involved in the local community. I began volunteering as a high school health educator and thought that as a Latina, I would easily connect to the largely Black and Latinx student population. However, being of Mexican descent, I realized I had much to learn about the Puerto Rican and Dominican cultures that so many of my students identified with. My students taught me more about their identities through insightful discussions. While I thought our backgrounds would be similar as BIPOC individuals who grew up in urban cities, I realized that it was unfair to assume I understood the needs and culture of this community without first engaging in a dialogue with its members. While I hope to advocate for patient needs as a physician, I will ensure that the needs I address have been community-identified. I hope to draw on my experience in immersing myself in new communities to positively impact the health of a diverse patient population at Rush.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
As a Waiting Room As a Literacy and Learning Environment (WALLE) intern, I helped connect underserved patients in the Washington Heights neighborhood of New York with community resources. We screened patients for social needs such as food and housing insecurity._x000D_
_x000D_
One of my most memorable experiences with WALLE was when while trying to reach a patient, the phone was answered by her daughter. The daughter confided in me that she was struggling to afford the nutritious foods she was told would be best for her mother‚Äôs health. Through WALLE, I was able to log her needs and help connect her with community resources. I am grateful that we had created a partnership between the hospital and community organizations to connect patients with the appropriate resources. This experience motivated me to continue addressing the social determinants of health and to ensure partnerships between clinics and community services exist for other underserved patients.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
After leaving my college campus due to the rise in COVID-19 cases, it was difficult to engage in clinical volunteer opportunities at home as my local hospital had suspended its volunteer program. It was not until I returned to campus that I began volunteering with the Delirium Program at Mount Sinai Hospital. As a volunteer, I enjoyed providing patients with company during a time in which many patients faced increased isolation. I recognized the impact that positive interactions with hospital staff can have on a patient‚Äôs health. _x000D_
_x000D_
While the pandemic delayed my start with the Delirium Program, it brought the opportunity to engage in remote research and gain computational skills. I helped conduct statistical analyses for a now-published paper and used the NEURON software to create computational models of neurons. The ongoing pandemic increased my interest in the role of data science in public health and motivated me to engage in community-based research that can inform policy change.

personal_statement:
When I was younger, hospitals overwhelmed me. While I wanted nothing more than to be at my mom’s side while she was there, I could not help but feel a jolt of anxiety any time the alarms on her machines would sound. I nervously waited for a team of doctors to rush in and fix the problem, only to be reassured that she was not in danger – an IV line was just tangled. After months of watching my mom’s hair fall out and her energy drain, I felt immense relief when she came home after her final surgery for Stage IV appendix cancer. We were lucky she was diagnosed in 2013, just two years after the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania (HUP) began offering HIPEC surgery. We were even luckier to have a team of physicians with the skills to recommend and perform this innovative cancer therapy. As I sat with my mom in her oncologist’s office years later, she tearfully thanked her doctor for giving her the chance to see her daughters graduate from high school. I thought about how a person that I hardly knew had helped save my mom's life, something I would never be able to fully thank her for. While I did not understand all that went into becoming a physician at the time, I admired the competence and compassion of this doctor and hoped to one day be like her. With this goal in mind, I sought out opportunities during college to learn about medicine and patient care.

While I hope my mom will stay away from HUP, I now find myself every week in the same hospital that once overwhelmed me years ago. As a volunteer in the Family Caregiver Center, I encounter people in similar uncertain circumstances that my own family had endured. One caregiver that comes to mind is Sara, whose husband has throat cancer. As I offer her a coffee, Sara tells me the most recent update. Her husband needs a tracheostomy, another challenge he will need to overcome despite already feeling so powerless. While we talk, I begin to understand more about his diagnosis and the emotional toll this disease takes on him and his entire family.

These conversations with Sara motivated me to learn more about the patient experience. I began working on a project piloting a new communication app on iPads for patients with tracheostomies. The anxiety I once felt from the alarms and fast-paced environment turned into excitement as I walked into the first patient’s room. After giving a tutorial of the app, the patient pointed out he was having difficulty holding the iPad I gave him due to the IVs in his hands. As a result of our conversation, I suggested to the study team that we provide cases that are easier for patients to hold. This small change significantly improved our patients’ experiences. One of the most exciting aspects of becoming a physician is to have clinical interactions with my patients and their families, with the intent to understand what is important to them. With this knowledge, I will be able to amplify their voices in clinical research and adapt their care plan based on their individual needs.

As medicine advances, new technologies, like the HIPEC surgery my mom received and the app my team piloted, can be met with apprehension. Incorporating new tools requires that providers establish trust with their patients. As a clinical research coordinator for the Memories2 research study, I observed how the physician leading the study developed this patient-provider trust. I learned how I could do the same in my own role. One patient, Pam, was interested in joining but expressed hesitation when I informed her that the study required virtual visits due to Covid-19. She did not have a computer and had trouble using the internet. A few minutes into our phone call, Pam became emotional, telling me how she struggled the past year not being able to see her grandkids, who would often help her use technology. After speaking with her for a while about her family and the challenges brought by the pandemic, I offered to mail her a study laptop. I asked her to trust me, telling her I would walk through the process step-by-step as many times as she needed until she felt comfortable. She agreed to this plan. After a few of our sessions, Pam gained the confidence to use technology not only to join our study visits but also to video call her grandkids. I learned that despite spending a short time with Pam, gaining her trust allowed me to make a positive impact on other aspects of her life outside of our study. While my time with patients may be limited as a physician, I hope that the tools I provide to them will be far-reaching.

I want to provide an extraordinary level of guidance and hope to people when they need it most, so I am committed to becoming a physician who embraces innovation and builds relationships rooted in compassion. As I have personally witnessed in my experiences in healthcare, physicians are tasked with making personalized and holistic courses of care for their patients built on trust. I plan to be a physician who not only offers my patients what they need but also provides them with the knowledge to become active and informed participants in their own care. In the meantime, I will continue to offer a listening ear to the patients and caregivers I meet each week to help make their time at the hospital a little less overwhelming.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: My undergraduate university emphasized the importance of expanding our worldview beyond our classroom education. From talking with Philadelphians from low-income neighborhoods in my work and volunteering, I better understand the unique challenges that people in urban environments face, such as gun violence and food insecurity. I also took classes that allowed me to interact with people unlike myself. In the course "Prison Reading Project," I was able to talk with individuals who had been in the Philadelphia prison system, and we discussed the lasting effects that incarceration had on their lives. While I may never fully understand the challenges that come with incarceration, I left this course with more compassion and a better understanding of individuals in completely different circumstances than my own. I hope to apply the new ideas and perspectives I gained from the people of Philadelphia to work toward health equity and social justice while at Rush Medical College.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: When the pandemic began, I noticed how cases were skyrocketing in the poorer parts of Philadelphia, followed by increased hospitalizations and deaths. In my job as a clinical coordinator, I talked with many people who were from different areas of Philadelphia, including medically underserved areas. When we began to have more in-person visits, I was required to ask if people had been vaccinated against Covid-19. Rather than just asking the question, I would listen to their concerns about the vaccine or the inability to get tested and share what I learned about the vaccine and the locations that I knew near them that were offering testing and vaccinations. I also volunteered several times with Drexel University‚Äôs vaccine clinics where we helped distribute vaccines to both the Drexel community and residents of West Philadelphia. While I do not have a solution to solve the systemic discrimination in the city, I hoped to provide some Philadelphians the resources to get the care they needed.
7_-_COVID_Impact: In 2019, I began two clinical volunteering positions. I planned to be involved with these programs for a year or more, but both programs ended in March 2020 due to Covid-19. Soon after, my university decided to move to virtual learning, and all my courses were only offered online until my fall term of senior year. I had to adapt to this new learning style and find virtual opportunities to stay involved. I did more non-clinical volunteering through Crisis Text Line and Weekly Smile. In terms of research, I had to abandon the project I was working on in the Russell Lab because it required me to be in person. Once I had some training, I started a new project using online bioinformatics tools. While this felt like a setback at first, I appreciated the chance to learn about bioinformatics and it inspired me to pursue it as a minor. Since I could not shadow in person, I found other ways to learn about medicine by joining virtual shadowing sessions and having phone calls with doctors.

Hrdshp_Comments: Facing increasing religious persecution as well as socioeconomic and geographic disparities in accessing healthcare in Egypt, our family immigrated to America, seeking safety and a better life. My mom has severe asthma, and my dad lived with HCV, so access to adequate healthcare was crucial for our family. When we arrived in California, my family of four lived in a small studio apartment where we all shared one room. My parents worked multiple jobs to gain insurance and provide for our family; I went to school. Attending school in a new country and learning a new language while trying to navigate a starkly different culture often posed many challenges. I could not communicate with my teachers or peers and was constantly teased about my thick accent. As a result, I struggled with my self-confidence and became very quiet. Transitioning into college as a first-generation college student, I struggled with everything from financial aid to my academic course load. Overcoming these challenges, I have developed strength in adversity and have learned to utilize whatever resources are available to me to obtain my goals. In retrospect, my uniqueness as an individual stems from my experiences, and I am incredibly grateful for them.
personal_statement:
I never thought my dad’s lifelong battle with Hepatitis C would be the seed that would blossom into my passion for medicine. Growing up in a country with limited access to medical resources, I watched my dad struggle to obtain the life-sustaining medication he needed to survive. Not receiving adequate treatment meant constant hemorrhaging, debilitating fatigue, and dangerously high fevers that left him crippled and unable to care for our family. Financial hardships and healthcare disparities brought our family from Egypt to the United States.

Moving to the United States brought “Dr. Hart” into our lives. Dr. Hart was my dad’s infectious disease specialist. I often accompanied my dad to Dr. Hart’s office to help interpret his questions and concerns. Because my dad was unable to clearly voice his needs, I felt an obligation to advocate for him and help relay his concerns. Our journey with Dr. Hart included multiple unsuccessful clinical trials and countless interpreted conversations until 2015. After trying the newest HCV treatment, we visited Dr. Hart to review my dad’s newest test results. “Congratulations, Michael, your HCV antibody test results are negative,” Dr. Hart said, smiling. As I looked at my dad to start interpreting, I saw his facial expression transition from fear to unbelievable relief. I quickly realized this statement needed no interpretation. It was a statement my dad had been dreaming of his whole life. Experiencing that moment and seeing that profound change in my dad deeply resonated with me and ignited a fire in my heart for medicine. Dr. Hart played an instrumental role in giving my dad his life back, and reflection on his impact on both my father’s and our family’s lives greatly intensified my resolve to become a physician. Dr. Hart’s patience and dedication showed me the value of continuity of care in medicine, which I aspire to provide to my future patients, just as Dr. Hart did with my dad.

As I transitioned into college, I discovered a passion for mentoring. I was first introduced to mentoring as a Learning Assistant in Dr. K’s biochemistry class. There, I met “John,” a struggling student who approached me after failing his first exam. As we worked together, I actively listened to John express his fear of not being smart enough and failing. Empathizing, I shared how as a student in Dr.K’s class the prior year, I faced the same dilemma and doubts that I could not rise to the challenge of the course, so much so that I almost dropped the course. I revealed how I also had setbacks during the course but sought out resources, grew further motivated, and worked even harder to eventually succeed. By illuminating the similarities in our struggles and recognizing the triumph at the end, I cultivated hope and empowerment in John to strengthen his resolve and work hard through the quarter. My vulnerability towards John helped us establish a bond of trust that aided our endeavor to his success. Like mentoring, the practice of medicine encompasses more than the application of hard sciences; medicine is about people--their feelings, struggles, and concerns. This experience revealed to me the beauty of connecting with humans and meeting them amidst their struggles; something I hope to do as a physician.

As a volunteer at Hoag Memorial Hospital, I sought to build bonds with my patients as I did with John. Of the many connections I made, some have left a lasting impact on my heart and have cemented my decision to pursue a career as a physician. “Amy,” a long-term patient with a terminal lung cancer diagnosis, was being transferred to hospice. During the weeks leading up to her transfer, I actively checked on Amy even though I was always met with silence and a weary look. Regardless, I would refill her water, get her an extra blanket, and tell her to page me if she needed anything else. I hesitantly yet steadily continued this routine, meeting Amy’s silence every time. It was not until the last day before Amy’s transfer that I realized how my small and often hesitant effort had influenced Amy.

As I did my final rounds, I went into Amy’s room to refill her water cup. Handing her the water, I saw her silently looking at me with tears in her eyes. She hoarsely whispered, “Thank you for your kindness.” Joy flooded my heart as I reached for her hand, smiled, and whispered back, “you are very welcome.” While I couldn’t change Amy’s diagnostic outcome, I felt fortunate to have provided Amy comfort and support in her most vulnerable state, even within my limited scope as a volunteer. This experience reaffirmed my conviction to become a physician; to be a reminding presence for patients that they are more than their physical ailments.

My experiences have increased my dedication to medicine and incited an ever-growing desire to care for others. From my dad’s HCV journey to connecting with John and Amy, I have developed a deeper understanding of humanistic care. My commitment to medicine is motivated by the unique opportunity to serve people in their most vulnerable times of life. Becoming a physician will fulfill my life’s best purposes: establishing trusting relationships, practicing clear and open communication, and embodying my dedication to patients’ health as whole individuals.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As a hospital volunteer, I distinctly remember conversing with one of our patients, Mr. G, who shared that he had been chronically homeless due to a work injury resulting in a permanent disability to his right hand. He then explained how recurrent infections frequently admitted him to hospitals and how the stigma surrounding homelessness often affected his treatment. Diversity encompasses more than race and ethnicity; it includes factors such as housing status. Implicit bias surrounding housing status comes in many forms, however, its impact on healthcare is prominent. Being aware of the existence of these biases is the first step towards identifying and abolishing them. Through this interaction, I have become aware of these biases and have begun to address them through listening and gaining a basic understanding of each person‚Äôs journey. Additionally, I learned that even though people may come from different backgrounds‚Äî most seek connection, compassion, and the chance to be heard.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As a seven-year-old Egyptian immigrant attending school, I faced many challenges and often struggled academically. Through years of perseverance and mentorship, I became fluent in English, excelled academically, and helped new Arabic-speaking students. This experience birthed my passion for mentorship and service as well as inspired my involvement in EASE. As a former EASE student, it was important to me to give back to the program that contributed to my success. My aim as an EASE Peer Coach (EPC) was to be a relatable mentor by sharing my experiences and lessons learned throughout my journey. Consistently working to help my students realize their potential in spite of their struggles, I was delighted to learn that three out of the six newly selected EASE Peer Coaches were former students of mine. During our most recent gathering, I had one student, ‚ÄúMeg,‚Äù share with me that I was the reason she wanted to become a leader and give back to EASE as an EPC.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The truth is that human interaction makes me feel replenished. As an extrovert, the pandemic stripped my day of its structure, merged my personal and academic lives, and left me starving for human interaction. This sudden isolation made it difficult to be productive as well as maintain relationships with professors and peers. Adapting, I created systems to separate school and personal activities. To stay connected and active, I set up daily walks with friends, during which we would talk on the phone while exercising. These activities helped structure my day and maintain my social and emotional wellness. Following this routine, I excelled during my last year of college despite the pandemic, and, more importantly, I learned a lot about the various contributing factors of wellness. Experiencing how consequential it can be to care for the elements beyond our physical health has increased my desire to work with underserved communities to help address mental, social, and physical health.

personal_statement:
From late nights in kindergarten when I secretly watched televised cardiothoracic surgeries past my bedtime to my recent endeavors in treating eating disorders, my life has continued to center around my passion, healthcare. The ever-evolving field of medicine has inspired awe in me, and my interest in it has only grown stronger over time. However, the flame of my passion was truly ignited when my childhood best friend, Katie, went into cardiac arrest in the third grade. After seeing her on the ventilator, I realized I wanted to do everything in my power to ease her pain. I read nearly every book in the local library about the human body. I took notes as the nurses changed her IV bags, and I listened to every word the doctors said about her condition. I wanted to heal Katie; I longed to ease her pain. Healthcare wasn’t just interesting anymore; it was a field that motivated me to learn more every day.

As Katie’s condition stabilized, she was released from the hospital. Though she could breathe on her own, she could not walk or talk. Each day after school, I would go to Katie’s house to care for her in any way I could. I massaged the muscles in her appendages, helped her mother change her feeding bag, and kept her company so that she didn’t feel alone. This time was difficult for both Katie and those who loved her, but it was then I learned that I find joy in taking care of others. Caring for Katie gave me a sense of fulfillment that I could not have imagined. After seeing her improve, watching her smile again, and knowing that I had a small part in that process, I felt gratification that I still carry to this day.

Unfortunately, Katie was not the only person close to me who underwent significant maladies. As I was nearing the end of elementary school, my dad began to experience episodes of extreme joint pain and fatigue. Upon meeting with his doctor, his concerns were minimized, and he was told to return home and simply take naproxen when he wasn’t feeling well. The doctors continued to dismiss my father’s condition until a few weeks later when his symptoms became so severe that he was writhing on the floor in pain. He complained of severe chest tightness, so my mother rushed him to the emergency room. As he was experiencing chest pain, his concerns were taken more seriously than before, and he underwent a myriad of testing. After spending several days in the hospital, an attending physician diagnosed my dad with lupus.

At the time, I thought little of the dismissal of my dad’s symptoms and pain because, in my Mexican-American town, it was common to have underdiagnosed or mistreated ailments. Many of my friends' families had also experienced illnesses for which no treatment had been offered. However, in high school, I learned this treatment stemmed from racial biases in healthcare. I was astonished at the subconscious maltreatment that was happening to minority groups across the country, and I could not help but wonder if my dad would have received treatment earlier had he not been Hispanic. It was then I knew that not only did I want to work in healthcare, but I want to be a physician. I want to lead a medical team in fully assessing my patients' concerns regardless of their race, gender, or socioeconomic status and provide them with better treatment than my father experienced.

However, treating physical ailments is not the only element of holistic patient care. I’ve had my fair share of broken bones, and many people I love have experienced extreme physical illnesses. Yet, high-quality patient care encompasses physical health, mental health, and the intersection between the two. In college, I realized my passion lies in providing care for those with mental illnesses. These diseases are often only visible to those who are afflicted by them, and it is frequently hard for people to find accessible psychiatric care. For this reason, I chose to study psychology and subsequently work at a hospital for pediatric patients with eating disorders. Here, I learned that psychiatrists direct a patient’s care by providing diagnoses and a treatment plan to the patient as well as to the patient’s healthcare team. Due to this, I want to become a psychiatrist so that I may focus my professional efforts on providing care and treatment for those affected by mental illness. As a psychiatrist, I hope to provide effective medical interventions for the mental and physical symptoms associated with these disorders. 

For nearly the last seventeen years, I have been filled with relentless curiosity about the dynamic field of healthcare. Attending medical school allows me to combine the pursuit of my deepest interests with the joy I find in patient care. I want to provide unconditional and empathic treatment so that I can assist people in bettering their mental states. As a physician, I can not only save the life of the next Katie but also ensure that every type of pain people feel, across every demographic, is not ignored.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
As a teenager, I began attending a predominantly Black church. Growing up in a largely Mexican-American town, I had little knowledge about the black experience. I joined a Bible study and engaged in conversation with many African-American church members. I heard stories of their upbringings and learned about the traditions of their cultures. During this time, I learned to honor people‚Äôs differences and incorporate their varying perspectives into my life. _x000D_
_x000D_
Years later, I helped build a home for a young, African-American mother. At the building site, she told me about her tragic encounters with racism. Later, she explained how she overcame hardships and advocated for herself. This taught me that although I may never encounter what some demographics must endure, I can respect the difficulties they have faced and serve as an empathetic outlet for others. As a physician, I will acknowledge the disparities in healthcare and work to undo systemic racism in my own practice and beyond.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As the Diversity and Inclusion Chair of Hoof‚Äôn‚ÄôHorn musical theatre, I led the organization in choosing plays for our upcoming season. As I reviewed the suggestions from the general body, I saw musicals of various genres and cast sizes. However, I noticed one fallacy. All of the suggested plays depicted the narratives of white, middle-class Americans. I explained that we needed to select plays with diverse narratives, and I tasked each club member with finding one alternative suggestion that presented a more diverse story, whether it be in terms of race, sexuality, or socioeconomic status. One week later, I heard a myriad of new suggestions, and in effect, we presented a season that included shows such as The Color Purple and In the Heights, musicals that portray black and Latinx narratives respectively. Now, Hoof‚Äôn‚ÄôHorn musical theatre intentionally selects musicals with diverse characters and content so that every member of the audience and cast has a place in the performing arts.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Because of COVID-19, almost all in-person shadowing and clinical experiences were halted. Although since the beginning of the pandemic I have only been able to shadow in person twice, virtual shadowing allowed me to shadow doctors from various locations and unique specialties. In this way, the pandemic forced me to seek more diverse shadowing experiences and allowed me to learn more than would have been necessarily possible if I only shadowed doctors in my location. Similarly, the clinical experiences that remained available during the pandemic were those that were integral to the patient experience, such as hospice volunteering. This allowed me to take advantage of clinical experiences that would most strengthen my understanding of the many facets of the healthcare environment. Consequently, COVID-19 taught me to make the best of unforeseen situations, and it also inspired me to be more open-minded and explore many career paths during medical school.

personal_statement:
June 2005: “Pedal to the medal” – I had heard my dad hoot and holler this phrase countless times on our weekend bike rides, but never at this point on our route. At just six years old, I knew something was off. There was no way my dad was serious. This wasn’t the time for “pedal to the medal,” not as we were approaching the busiest cross street of the Burke Gillman Trail, which served as our weekly turnaround point and a pit stop for a popsicle. This was the first moment when I knew something was different. It was the first of many times when I was the ‘parent.’ But this was not always the case; there was a time when my dad was far more capable.
	September 1986: My dad, an ED physician in Everett, WA, received the incoming trauma no one wants to hear: a 3-year-old boy who was in full cardiac arrest. EC, the toddler who my dad later described as “dead-on-arrival” after being beaten to death by his father, effected not only my dad’s career but also the entire state. As a girl, I remember seeing a documentary disk on my dad’s desk with EC’s name. After inquiring about it, my protective father told me, “He was a very sick little boy that daddy took care of.” With time, and because of the public nature of his death, I learned the horrifying details. I’m confident my dad was always the energetic, hard-working, patient, avid note-taker, and gentle physician as so many described him. But EC challenged my dad. Decades after caring for EC and many others, my dad was diagnosed with Early Onset Alzheimer’s disease. He survived what was both a long and much too short ten years. And, while my dad was dissipating, becoming a mere shell of himself, I was becoming more and more like who he once was. My dad was no longer capable of caring for patients, his children, or even himself. As his disease progressed, I was growing up, learning to care for my terminally ill Daddy.
	The last five years of his life were also the most painful years of mine. For the last year of my dad’s life, I was the only person who was able to coax my father into the shower. At 15 years old, I didn’t want to be the one bathing my own dad after he defecated his adult diaper in the middle of a Starbucks. I was ashamed and I was angry. This type of occurrence dominated my childhood and often left me struggling to reconcile feelings of resentment with grief. The complex sentiments of my childhood shaped me into the observant and resilient individual I am today.
	Caring for my father and being surrounded by the other residents in his assisted living facilities instilled in me the value of compassion. Years later, as an EMT, I prioritized approaching all patients with a universal sense of compassion.
	January 2020: It was an old building and dimly lit. We were there to transport an immobile COPD patient with faulty communication skills, living in a one-bedroom apartment of a hoarder. We found the patient sedentary in a pile of feces with O2 tubing tangled in the mess. I explained we would take him to the hospital and get him more comfortable. He squeezed my gloved hand; that was his way of communicating. As we exited the elevator, the patient became distraught. He sat up and patted the top of his head while locking eyes with me. Being half Jewish, I knew what he needed. I returned with the patient's Yarmulke. His face lit up, and he squeezed my hand once more. I approached this patient with compassion, lacking judgment, mirroring the values my father once embodied when caring for EC. Despite these two patients being separated by more than 30 years, their similarities only brought me closer to my favorite person, despite our time together growing into a more distant memory. To myself and, more importantly, my patient, the significance of my actions extended far beyond a Yarmulke. It was about noticing someone's needs and acting in a manner that made them more comfortable and secure while dealing with so much unknown. My time spent with my dad in his assisted living facility was spent noticing so many things like this. I know how I would want a medical professional to treat my dad, someone who also struggled to verbally communicate at the end of his life, and I use this inkling to act with empathy in my own patient interactions.
	The healthcare system is rapidly evolving, yet it always seems like there’s never enough time. I’ve always hated the concept of time, often wishing I could either speed things up or stop the clock, depending on what was going on in my life. Before my dad got sick, I remember counting ‘sleeps’ at camp until my long-awaited return to the comfort of my parents’ arms. Or, in sixth grade, when my PE class crossed paths with my dad’s day program shuttle every day, I hoped the moments aligned just right so we could share a wave. And today, I sometimes wonder if this time was ever enough. Did I ever really know my dad? Or worse, will so much time pass that one day I’ll forget him? I find solace knowing that in more ways than one, I am him. Years apart, and not enough time together on this earth, but we are the same heart. Time is complex, but the bottom line is everyone deserves more time. More healthy time, more family time, more time to grow – and as a physician, I will try my best to give people more time, no matter the cost.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: This past year I worked as a Research Assistant on Dr. Ringman‚Äôs team at USC. With a longitudinal clinical trial, we studied autosomal dominant dementia mutations. Since one of the mutations originates in Mexico, this gave me a platform to use my Spanish minor and connect with the Hispanic population. I noticed a language barrier between physicians and these patients and a lack of medical translators. This meant that many of our patients often waited until their health deteriorated before seeking care. No one should have limited access to necessary medical care, especially because of language and cultural barriers. I hope that my Spanish-speaking skills and experience working with Hispanic patient populations will help me be the empathetic and culturally-aware physician who assists in breaking down these communication barriers. Medicine must be inclusive, and cultural differences celebrated rather than hindering access to necessary medical care.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
During my work as an EMT, I had many patients in crisis, and I prioritized empathizing with them while maintaining quality care in the short time we spent together. One patient was a young girl with a femur fracture. As soon as I laid eyes on her, I knew she was in immense pain. While my partner requested more morphine before moving her, I approached the patient, noticing she tensed up with each inch I moved closer.¬†_x000D_
_x000D_
The TV was on in her room; I smiled and whispered something to her about the Disney Channel show in the background. When she started to relax, my partner signaled that we were ready to move her. I looked our patient in the eyes and said, "Okay, now this part is going to hurt, but we can count to three, and just remember the sooner the pain starts, the sooner it's over." And after the 45-minute ride, we had to do the whole thing again. I am confident that while our time together was brief, I made a difference in this young patient's experience.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I knew I could handle being a first responder with an autoimmune disease but doing the job during a pandemic brought obstacles that forced me to reflect on the bigger picture. The initial months of the pandemic brought a push-pull of emotions. I worked tirelessly to earn a position at UCLA EMS. Still, I wondered if it was worth the agony of voluntarily putting myself in situations where we did not even understand the full health implications. After meeting with several Field Training Officers, we decided that the position was not the right fit. This was when I decided that I needed to talk to someone. With the closure of one door came a chance to focus on me. I learned it was okay to feel scared as a young woman with an autoimmune disease during a pandemic, and at the same time, it did not negate my desire to be a physician. The opportunity to partake in therapy before attending medical school is something I know will enhance my ability to be a thoughtful and self-aware physician.

personal_statement:
“That can’t be right…” I thought to myself as I rang up the next customer in line. The customer’s bill had come to over $3,000 for one prescription—a single vial of insulin. Instinctively, I double checked the patient’s insurance information but to no avail, the charge was legitimate and had to be collected. I explained to the customer, a father of a young child with diabetes, that the cost was due to a commonly overlooked coverage gap in their insurance plan and waited for his response. As he processed what I had relayed, his eyes began to swell with tears and his head shook in denial. Expecting him to refuse the prescription I began to cancel the transaction, but before I could do so, he replied in a broken voice “Well I guess she has to have it…doesn’t she…”. With that, the father passed me his card and I proceeded to charge him the full amount. I will never forget the emotions expressed by the father that day or my own feelings of guilt during this transaction.
While working as a pharmacy technician for the last four years, I have repeatedly seen insurance and drug companies charge egregious amounts for prescriptions. Many times, I have witnessed the internal conflict that occurs as a patient decides if they can afford their medication or go without care until funds become available. Although such instances are sometimes unavoidable, they can be minimized by the efforts of a physician who is willing to advocate for their patients at every step.
My main motivation in becoming a physician is to serve as the voice for those who are unable to advocate for themselves. I have experienced firsthand what it is like to forgo care due to social repercussions, and I have witnessed others do the same to avoid financial ruin. It is my belief that in these situations a resolute physician is the most powerful advocate a patient can have—possessing the ability to transform the patient’s entire healthcare experience. 
By being involved and taking an interest in the patient’s financial wellbeing, I have seen many physicians negotiate with insurance companies to secure a cheaper alternative or lower price for medications that are vital to the patient’s health. While shadowing Dr. Jason Blomstedt, I saw him work tirelessly to ensure a complex prior authorization was completed appropriately and that the patient was notified when it had been approved, sparing them from worry. Conversely, I have also seen the alarmed look of patients when they are notified that their physician is not willing to investigate cheaper alternatives or other ways to minimize costs. These experiences have shown me just how potent the role of a physician can be as an advocate for their patients, but also how neglect for the patient’s financial status can negatively affect the care they receive. As a physician, I will seek to utilize these experiences to ensure that each patient receives affordable care and that third-party policies have minimal impact on the quality of care given.  
Advocacy is vital for those who do not meet the status quo of society and whose lifestyles differ from the norm, as my own health journey has illustrated. At several points in my life, I have been fearful to request necessary care, in fear of rejection or exposure from those who do not understand my concerns and lifestyle. While I have the knowledge and financial flexibility  to circumvent obstacles that may limit the care I have access to, I know that for many this is not a part of their reality. In these cases, in which the patient feels trapped and without options, a physician who understands their patients’ needs and struggles can have profound effects on the patient’s life. My life has been spared from chronic disease due to the acts of a physician willing to advocate for me when no one else would, and I am fervent to be this same beacon of hope and promise for my future patients. My journey has enlightened me to how inhospitable our healthcare system can be for those who go against the grain and how much effort, time, and money is needed to access the care an individual needs.  I am passionate about increasing representativeness and advocacy for marginalized groups in medicine, and I will forever act as an advocate for others who find themselves in a position where I once found myself.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: While growing up, my parents housed individuals traveling for various reasons across the state. Most of these individuals, traveling for events related to our church, were foreign and often came from impoverished regions or third-world countries. While these individuals were in our home, my family was able to share many meals and conversations with them and often discussed how life differed back home from in the US. Through these conversations I was able to gain insight into how diverse humanity is in terms of values, culture and religion. Further, my own travels across the world have also contributed to my understanding of cultures different from my own and how certain beliefs or values come to be held. These experiences have provided me with a broad and open perspective to interact with others with and are something I am very thankful to have been exposed to.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I was able to improve the community of my hometown through my participation and dedication to the community orchestra Simply Strings. This group provided for my community opportunities to engage with live music and to interact with others in the community. My hometown, McCook Nebraska, has long appreciated the arts but has had limited events open for the public to enjoy. Simply Strings has provided an outlet for the community to gather and allows the community to continue to value and appreciate the arts. As the group has progressed I have been able to see growing interest from the community, evident in our increasing audience size at our annual concert. With this group I have also been able to provide music for several area nursing homes and hospitals for patients.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The COVID 19 pandemic prepared me for medical school by directly showing me the role and critical need of healthcare professionals. During this time, there were several moments in which I was fearful of the future and was not sure what each day would bring. During these time I found comfort in the information and advice being shared by physician and other healthcare professionals. Further, while working in a hospital during this time I was able to see the direct role of physicians in leading the healthcare team in entire units infected with the virus. While these events were hard to watch at some points, it was inspiring to see the level of trust and unity among the care teams, each led by a physician. These experiences solidified my desire to become a physician and provided me with steadfast examples of what it means to be a leader, no matter the situation. The pandemic taught me a lot about myself and my capabilities, but especially showed me how important my own mental health is.

personal_statement:
And have you ever been pregnant before, Isabella?" I inquired. "Yes, I've had three miscarriages and am miscarrying now," she replied. I clenched my jaw, swallowing hard and fighting to keep my facial muscles still as I concealed the pang reverberating in my gut. Working for a private practice fertility clinic on Manhattan's Upper East Side, I was in an atypical consult when I coordinated and scribed a visit for Isabella, who was insured through Medicaid, currently unemployed, while miscarrying.  

Based on the patient's history, several standard genomic labs were indicated as necessary, with significant markers pointing to potentially underlying abnormalities in her chromosomal makeup. Unfortunately, no treatment plans currently offer can address these abnormalities, and as such, getting pregnant in these patients will lead to repeat miscarriages. Logically, this information should be considered necessary to one's well-being and health to prevent the trauma women endure with each miscarriage and to allow for coping with the reality that biological children cannot be an expectation within one's family building plan.

Despite the medical and anatomical evidence that this patient had aneuploid germ cells, Medicaid did not cover the required labs, deeming them unnecessary. As such, to minimize the out-of-pocket cost for the patient, Dr. Hade could only offer limited and generalized advice and little hope for clarity of her situation. Thus, leaving her both medically and emotionally unsupported. Understanding that even the limited care we could provide was far too expensive, I consulted with our practice founder to approve the waiving of her $650.00 New Patient fee. Despite this, waiving the fee would do little to impact the structural inequities that create the actual barriers to care here. The patient never returned nor answered my follow-up calls. I assume that she faces the same infertility predicament today as before she attended her appointment.  

Along with this incident and those I have been a part of, which are hauntingly similar, I have learned this is the dogma and limitation of our current medical systems. Through my Gender and Health minor, I took a course on Reproductive Justice. For my final paper, I researched how our current healthcare system creates disparities for women of color and lower socioeconomic status to impede childbearing autonomy. These women are disproportionately offered Long Acting Reproductive Contraceptives, such as IUDs or Nexplanon, even when their family-building process includes biological children. Additionally, these same populations are disproportionately limited in their access to options for unintentional or unwanted pregnancies. These factors severely limit these women's freedom over their lifestyle and family-building process. My desire to understand health disparities also led to my work in Dr. Kevin Chung’s lab, where I wrote about how people of minority racial, ethnic, rural, low income, and low socioeconomic status are greatly impacted in their ability to seek specialized medical services in plastic surgery and receive culturally competent patient education. Finally, this review demonstrated the need for more research on these disparities and an opportunity to create structures to mitigate these issues. As one who had, at a time, experienced severe financial hardships, notably in 2008 when my parents both were out of work and my father found himself reliant on methamphetamine in coping with these times, I have bared witness to the connections between lack of financial security and health. I have also faced my fair share of confusion or discrimination as a multiracial individual. Many times, I don't wholly belong to one category or another and have been the subject of disparaging comments targeting my Asian heritage. As someone who grew up in the diverse San Francisco Bay Area, I have witnessed and experienced the complex issues surrounding our country's social structures, but I am confident that I will be a culturally competent physician.

My journey to becoming a competent physician, cognizant of and willing to address disparities, has included many rewarding experiences. From my work at Birth Detroit, where we sought to address the disproportionate rates at which Detroit's Black mothers and infants face complications in the birthing process, to gaining hands-on research experience with pediatric patients facing Cystic Fibrosis, I've seen the many facets of medicine which can genuinely change the course of someone's life. As a physician, I hope that when I encounter patients like Isabella, I can do far more than waiving a fee; that knowledge from medical school and residency training, coupled with my exposure to the healthcare system, equip me to make a more significant impact.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: In 2006, my mother quit her job as a mortgage broker. Then, my dad lost his job as the country plummeted into a recession. My parents borrowed money from my uncle to keep me and my brother in school. Matters worsened when my father turned to meth and alcohol as coping mechanisms. I remember that he and his friends were strung out on drugs constantly. One such friend developed schizophrenia and was in and out of the hospital. During this time, I witnessed many disturbing events unfold and found myself compartmentalizing. I wore different identities between my private grade school, gymnastics practice in Oakland, with my friends, and at home. I was hypervigiliant that my homelife didn‚Äôt necessarily always match that of my peers. I have experienced first-hand the effects of societal pressures on mental, physical, and intellectual health to the point of alienation from society. As a physician,  my experience will allow me to understand and empathize with my patients of various backgrounds.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As I became the Lead Study Coordinator at a dermatology clinic, I was surprised to find that even within research, there are still many obstacles to care. One of my studies only accepts patients with an official medical diagnosis of acne or rosacea. However many potential participants had severe, uncontrolled conditions, but were never seen by a provider and had no diagnosis due to a lack of insurance coverage. To dismantle this boundary, I developed a plan with our Practice Manager to provide these patients with a complimentary screening visit. Since then, I‚Äôve enrolled several participants who were previously untreated for their condition due to inability to afford care. In addition, I developed and executed a plan to deliver our clinic‚Äôs surplus soap, lotion, and face wash samples to a local women‚Äôs shelter. Although these actions are still minute, I hope to become a physician who consistently combats boundaries to wellness and healthcare and provides inclusive, quality healthcare.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
The pandemic hit as I embarked on my MCAT preparation, which felt saliently claustrophobic as an individual with ADHD. I was operating unmedicated and unable to work outside my home to avoid distractions, an essential coping mechanism for my own focus. Moving into my shoebox apartment in New York City after graduation proved to be extremely challenging for studying. Adapting to global circumstances challenged me to set boundaries with my roommates, incorporate exercise into my routine, and create a strict schedule._x000D_
 _x000D_
During this time, I was working as a clinical assistant at a fertility clinic. My personal experience with the pandemic shed light on the invisible distress that was weighing on our patients. With this in mind, I made efforts to notice patients‚Äô moods, specifically noting if treatment was unduly impacting their well-being. As a physician, I hope to continue to embrace the values of protecting my patients while ensuring their autonomy and success.

Hrdshp_Comments:
Growing up in a family of Burmese refugees, I struggled to find a sense of identity and belonging. As one of the few Burmese in our neighborhood, my parents hid our culture, traditions, and language, in fear of being discriminated against or judged. Without cultural ties, I questioned my self-worth and longed for a community to call home. 

As the first in my family to enter college, I struggled to navigate my education, lacking resources and mentorship to guide my career. Living in a low-income household further worsened my challenges. At home, my family shared one car, which limited opportunities for work or volunteering. I also worked part-time to financially support my family and pay for food and rent.

Throughout my education and career, my experiences have taught me how to be resilient in times of vulnerability. From lacking cultural belonging to facing socioeconomic challenges, I learned how to navigate hardships and take initiative, actively seeking out opportunities for personal and professional mentorship as a Burmese-American. Most of all, I also discovered my passion to uplift disadvantaged communities like my own, mentoring low-income and first-generation students towards pathways in research and supporting health fairs and free vaccine clinics for immigrant and refugee populations.
personal_statement:
I was four when my grandfather’s fainting spells first started. The sights and sounds I distinctly remember: the dull thud of his head against the restaurant table, the flurry of ambulance sirens, the soft squeeze of my grandmother’s hands as we waited in the emergency room. For my family, who fled as Burmese refugees and hadn’t seen a primary care physician for decades, the ER was the easiest way for us to get the healthcare my grandfather desperately needed. What started off as one trip to the ER quickly spiraled into a multitude of health complications: kidney failure, liver cirrhosis, and colon cancer. As a young child, I struggled to understand why my grandfather’s health deteriorated so quickly, and I became disheartened with my inability to help. Witnessing the healthcare disparities of my family firsthand sparked my interest in medicine: a career where I can uplift vulnerable populations and create equitable access to care for underserved communities like my own.
I still thought of my grandfather while working as a Medical Assistant at an Outpatient Primary Care clinic. There, I encountered “Cherry,” who had refused getting mammograms for the past four years. When asked, she shook her head, expressing doubts about its purpose. Seeing her clenched fists and reservations brought me back to my grandfather, who relied on self-medication and resisted going to the hospital until it was too late. As a Taiwanese immigrant with limited English, Cherry felt overwhelmed with complicated terms discussed throughout her visits. She consistently struggled to receive and understand her medications, which further discouraged her from trusting her physicians. To ease her worries, I started to break down the mammogram process, using a combination of Chinese translations, analogies, and hand gestures to alleviate her fears. Witnessing Cherry’s gradual change and acceptance showed me the importance of holistic, preventative medicine.
