By utilizing cultural competency and inclusion as tools in understanding a patient, I can encourage them to engage in healthy behaviors and seek out routine preventative care. 
As a volunteer for Asian Pacific Health Corps, I continued to extend my experiences beyond an outpatient setting to local communities, coordinating free health fairs in churches and community centers. There, I administered free health screenings and became a translator to bridge communication gaps. “Nate,” who lacked reliable transportation, crossed the street alone in his wheelchair. “Am I able to see a doctor here?” This was a common question asked by many patients I met. “Sal,” who carried his two infant sons, shared his difficulties managing his diabetes due to lack of child care. “Ada'' who spoke limited English did not even know where to begin to enroll in health insurance. My interactions broadened my perspective about the barriers affecting preventative care and its direct adverse impact on the health of communities. Through learning about the diverse range of healthcare experiences and inequities in access, I discovered my passion for community health, further deepening my motivations to bring health interventions directly to communities and connect patients to care they need.
With the onset of COVID-19, I saw healthcare disparities in access magnify while working at Dynasty COVID Vaccine Clinic. As a volunteer helping to provide free vaccinations for immigrant, refugee, and uninsured populations, I saw an array of passports come my way, from Mexico and Brazil to China and Myanmar, each encased with their own experiences and stories. “Sarah,” a 10 year old girl, hid behind her guardian’s back as I examined her Burmese passport: an item I recognized from relatives who escaped from the military coup in Myanmar. Instantly, I thought of my parents’ own experiences–fleeing from daily gunfire and rationing moldy rice to survive, and struggling to rebuild a new life in a foreign country–and I related these hardships to Sarah in front of me, whose eyes remained fixed towards the floor. Extending my hand to Sarah, I sang a Burmese lullaby, one that my mother had often sung to ease my nervousness when I was younger. Her gaze meeting mine, I watched Sarah slowly emerge from her guardian’s shadow. Meeting patients who crossed national borders demonstrated to me how medicine can be mobilized to alleviate social inequities surrounding access to healthcare. As a future physician, I want to expand on and cultivate sanctuaries for displaced communities to receive care no matter where they come from, and bring justice to my grandfather’s memory. 
Medicine is the culmination of my passions for cultural humility, community health, and service. As I move forward in my journey, I am constantly reminded about my grandfather, my parents, and the patients I’ve met, who have shown me firsthand the challenges that immigrant and marginalized populations face when receiving care. Beginning with my childhood memories, my resolve for medicine has grown and deepened with each person and story I’ve encountered. From emergency rooms and primary care visits to mobile clinics and health fairs, I hope to create more accessible healthcare systems, empower patients with holistic preventative care, and in turn, foster community healing.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
‚ÄúHenry‚Äù had untreated microtia and shuddered at the mere thought of being in a doctor‚Äôs office. Due to being undocumented, he feared receiving care.. _x000D_
_x000D_
As a Financial Director for Speak Out for Surgery, a club raising awareness for domestic health inequities, I met other individuals like Henry, while working with low income Latinx and unhoused communities in Los Angeles. Coming from a background of immigrant and refugee parents, I was no stranger to language barriers and inability to afford services. However, exploring challenges of housing insecurity and navigating insurance being undocumented was new to me. _x000D_
_x000D_
With each patient interview, I was constantly humbled, learning about the institutional barriers of care that impact patient wellbeing. From demystifying insurance to finding accessible housing, I found ways to mitigate these barriers. I also recognized the power of community advocacy, using fundraising, caseworker referrals, and health literacy workshops to empower communities.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: With the onset of the COVID-19, I witnessed how disparities in access to healthcare were exacerbated amongst vulnerable populations like my own. Burmese refugees have one of the highest uninsured rates in the country, low health literacy, and the lowest educational attainment rates among Asian subgroups -- disparities I see reflected among my own parents and relatives, who prioritized hard labor over school. However, as a Volunteer at Dynasty COVID Vaccine Clinic, I was able to alleviate language barriers to care by increasing health literacy and creating sanctuaries. Through translating vaccine information and patient intake for hundreds of patients, I helped to mitigate language barriers and distrust in uninsured and underserved populations. Most of all, being able to give back to the immigrant and refugee communities deepened my resolve to continue advocacy for my community.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
COVID-19 impacted my life professionally and personally, from limited healthcare experiences to educational and financial challenges. _x000D_
_x000D_
Due to laboratory restrictions, I halted my in-person research experiments and analyzed data from home. I could not participate or coordinate community health fairs because of social distancing; in addition, since I take care of my immunocompromised grandparents at home, I could not continue my clinical work until COVID-19 vaccinations were available._x000D_
_x000D_
COVID-19 also created financial and educational barriers. My father had recently lost his job, causing financial strain on my medical school applications and emotional stress within my family. Furthermore, I took my MCAT in the summer of 2020 during the peak of COVID, which impacted my performance. From sharing a room and desk with my younger sister to balancing household duties as the oldest sister, it was difficult to focus, but I made the most of the situation.

Inst_Action_Desc: As a freshman electrical engineering major at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, I was academically dismissed after the Spring 2018 semester due to my low semester GPA. During this semester, I struggled immensely with severe endometriosis pain which I was not diagnosed with until after the dismissal. This severe pain often caused me to miss classes and assignment deadlines. More than once, I left an exam knowing that I had failed due to not being able to finish it because the excruciating pain would cause me to black out for short intervals of time. I did not express what I was going through with my professors because I was embarrassed due to the nature of my medical condition, and I assumed that they would dismiss it as “bad cramps” and minimize the severity of it. This was a mistake. I should not have made assumptions about what they would think. I should have had an open and honest conversation with them about what I could have done to make up for the exams I was unable to finish. Because I had always done very well academically, I had never experienced failure and believed that I could still improve my grades even when it was too late in the semester. I now realize that I should have been a better advocate for myself with both my professors and with the university clinic.
personal_statement:
As another wave of excruciating pain came over me, my vision started to fade to black. I fought to keep my focus on the exam in front of me, but the stabbing pain in my lower abdomen was all-consuming. Suddenly, the exam was over, and I was turning in the exam which I had only half completed, knowing that I had failed. This was not the first nor the last time this would happen. The pain caused me to miss classes and assignment deadlines as well. I didn’t know what was happening to my body. Having been a disciplined and hard-working high school student, the feeling of failure was unfamiliar and distressing. I wanted to tell my professors why my grades had suddenly taken a turn for the worst, but I didn’t know how to. In my Mexican culture, “female issues” such as menstruation are rarely talked about, especially not with men. I felt embarrassed to tell my all-male electrical engineering professors that “bad cramps” were preventing me from excelling as I knew I could, and I was worried that I would not be taken seriously by my predominately male classmates if they found out. 
When I returned home at the end of the semester, I met the gynecologist who would change my life. After an initial assessment, he told me that I had endometriosis, which was later confirmed via laparoscopic surgery. I felt an overwhelming sense of relief to have an explanation for what was happening to me and to know that the pain I had endured during the previous semester had been valid. At the same time, I felt disappointed in knowing that my endometriosis had prevented me from reaching my full potential academically. My battle with endometriosis during the previous semester had led to my academic dismissal. I was devastated. This low point in my life opened my eyes to the importance of medicine and how much an illness can affect every aspect of your life. I was lucky to have found a gynecologist that patiently listened to me in a way that no one else had; however, I knew that many women were not as lucky. It felt unsettling to know that although endometriosis affects 10% of women, only a fraction of them are correctly diagnosed while the remainder continue to suffer. The fact that so many women have to deal with the repercussions of living untreated, such as disruption to their professional lives and the potential for infertility, ignited my desire to become a physician so that I can be an advocate for those in similar situations.
Starting over my academic career was a humbling and challenging experience. I knew that my grades from the previous semester would negatively affect my overall GPA no matter how well I did in the future, but I did not let that hold me back from pursuing my goal of becoming a physician. The daily medication I started taking after my surgery allowed me to have a normal, pain-free life again, which led to a transformation in my grades.
During my junior year, I began working as a scribe in the Houston Methodist Hospital Emergency Department (ED). As I became comfortable in the fast-paced environment, I found myself trying to absorb as much as I could from each patient encounter. Over time, I began to anticipate the questions the physicians asked during each evaluation and how the answers assisted in the medical decision making. Every encounter confirmed one thing for me: I wanted to be the one to gather all the information and come up with the best diagnosis and treatment for patients. I never could have imagined that my desire to become a physician was about to be tested by an unprecedented global pandemic. 
COVID-19 reached Houston in March 2020, causing fear and panic to spread amongst my fellow scribes in the ED. One-by-one half of them quit. I knew l was needed now more than ever as a massive influx of patients overwhelmed the nurses and physicians in the ED, so I decided to stay even though I knew I would have to take extraordinary safety measures to protect my family. When the hospital had to cut scribes due to costs, I was chosen to stay and was told it was because of my calm and level-headed nature, which was essential in such a dire situation. I worked day and night shifts, weekdays, and weekends, all while being a full-time student and maintaining my grades. When I would get home at the end of my shifts, sometimes at 4am, I would feel exhausted but with a sense of accomplishment and pride which motivated me through the nightmare that was the peak of the pandemic. The horrific events that I witnessed on the front lines changed me as a person. Although at times the situation felt emotionally unbearable, the heroism and bravery demonstrated by the techs, nurses, and physicians in the ED inspired me to keep going. I hope to one day become a physician as courageous and fearless as those that I met in the ED, running towards danger to care for patients who put their lives in my hands, trusting me to do everything in my power to help them during some of their most vulnerable and frightening times.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Growing up in Houston, which is considered one of the most diverse cities in the country, I have always been surrounded by people from all over the world. From elementary school, some of my closest friends have been from Vietnam, China, India, Mexico, and El Salvador to name a few. Learning in this environment was enriching as we all had to learn to be considerate with people from different backgrounds from a young age. I now recognize this experience as a very important aspect of my growth and development. As an adult, I not only welcome but seek opportunities to continue accumulating this type of exposure, and to contribute with my own perspective as a Hispanic woman. I feel fortunate to have grown up in such a diverse city that has that has given me the ability to be open and accepting towards people from different cultures and backgrounds.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: The patient population at the emergency department (ED) I worked at in the Houston Medical Center consisted mostly of minorities. As a Spanish-speaker, I interpreted for many Hispanic patients in the ED when interpreters where unavailable during night shifts or, especially, during the COVID-19 pandemic. I witnessed first-hand how much of a difference it made for these patients to be able to communicate effectively with their physicians. They were always so grateful that all of their symptoms and concerns had been heard and taken into consideration in their treatment plan and that they understood what their next steps would be. Residents and consulting physicians would often ask me to interpret for them as well because they knew how important it was for them and their patients. Although interpreting was not officially part of my job as a medical scribe, it was one of its most rewarding aspects because I knew how much of a difference it was making for my local Hispanic community.
7_-_COVID_Impact: When the COVID-19 pandemic reached Houston, I was working at an emergency department (ED) as a medical scribe. Working on the front lines of the pandemic was the most challenging situation I have ever experienced. As many scribes in the ED quit, I took on extra shifts despite being a full-time student. I knew this decision would make excelling in my classes more difficult, but I also knew that the doctors in the ED needed as much help as possible. In addition, an internship with CDC Headquarters in Kenya I was selected for was cancelled. My job would have been to assist researchers focused on diseases such as tuberculosis, and HIV/AIDS that directly affect the communities in this area. Lastly, the pandemic affected my ability to obtain volunteer experience with patients. Even in late 2021 I was unable to find a place that was accepting volunteers to work with patients or in underserved communities, so I decided to volunteer at an animal shelter that saves dogs and cats from euthanasia.

Hrdshp_Comments:
Growing up, my hometown was experiencing a lot of violence – I remember the walks to the nearby market, averting eye contact with gangsters on the way, and being afraid that I would be at the wrong place at the wrong time. My parents witnessed how the youth in our area were dropping out of school to join gangs and stressed the importance of education early on. While we lacked school resources at home, our family found ways to get around this obstacle and despite my city’s failing school system, I was fortunate to have teachers see my academic potential and push me to apply to private high schools in nearby affluent cities. With the help of my teachers and my family’s support, I received admissions with a full-ride to a prestigious high school. 

My family bought a home three years before I started high school but unfortunately, we fell victim to the subprime mortgage crisis and our house was foreclosed my Freshman year. Complicating the social transition into a predominantly white, affluent school, my family moved 4 times as we struggled to recover financially. These times were difficult, but going through it and witnessing how my parents handled the situation with grace and a positive attitude had a lasting effect on me – it shaped me into the resilient person that I am today.
personal_statement:
Arriving at Grandpa’s side last summer, I saw anguish on the face of my mother – a woman who with limited elementary education had escaped a cartel-infested Michoacan state before picking fruit and dodging I.C.E. raids in California's Central Valley. She could tell Grandpa was suffering, but didn't know why or what could be done for him. I was in a position to help, thanks in large part to my parents' decision to relocate to the Bay Area. The two-car garage I called home gave me the better life they sought, but their immigration status has carried with it burdens, including sparse and fraught access to healthcare. Our struggles have profoundly impacted my desire to serve individuals in vulnerable situations. What this service would look like, however, wasn’t immediately clear to me.

In high school, my excitement for the academic opportunities that a scholarship presented quickly dissipated. I was one of a handful of minority students in an affluent setting. As I walked around campus on the first day of school, hair slicked back, wearing my favorite basketball jersey, I noticed how everyone looked at me. An upperclassmen spoke to me in a “cholo” accent, getting a couple chuckles from his friends. On another occasion, a classmate spit in my face and called me a “dirty Mexican.” Social survival became my top priority, and it stayed that way through several semesters of college.

That includes my sophomore year at UCSB, when I saw my best friend and roommate consumed by an opioid addiction. Suggesting he seek out therapy only drove a greater wedge between us. I felt helpless. During that time, I was in physical therapy and though I loathed the deep tissue therapy, which left my shoulder looking like it had skidded across asphalt, I saw how my relationship with my providers kept me on track and inspired confidence in a full recovery. These two contrasting experiences made me see what effective treatment looks like and how gruesome lack of care can be. For the first time, I began to consider a career in healthcare. 

As I learned more about medicine through my involvement in clinics and enrollment in post-bacc courses, I started to think about the impact I could have with families like mine. I’ve lived in fear for my family’s health. I understand what it’s like when your uninsured dad develops chest pain or your uninsured mom has painful untreated arthritis. I want to help patients like them. A sobering call from my mom last summer made me realize how critical this endeavor really is.

“Mijo, estoy preocupado por tu Abuelito.” Grandpa was not doing well. He had returned home earlier that week after an ER visit, but the language barrier had left my family confused. I took a look at the discharge paperwork. “The doctors found masses in Grandpa’s lungs, Mom.” I hugged her and my aunt. They told me he wasn’t eating, and I could tell he was fighting back considerable pain. “Let's get him to a hospital tonight,” I said. After rolling him through the double doors of the triage tent, I initiated emergency insurance paperwork, and after a long wait in the ED I heard his name called. I looked him in the eyes, told him that I loved him, and that he was in good hands. Given my clinical work experience and the language barrier, we all knew that navigating the healthcare system would fall to me.

“Your grandpa has metastatic colorectal cancer, and I’m afraid he’s approaching the end of his life,” is the sentence I had to translate for my parents. He was requiring more and more respiratory support, and his doctor needed a DNR decision. My family, clinging onto hope, insisted that we start him on chemo. I told them the doctor thought that further treatment would be futile, that CPR would only prolong his suffering, and it was unlikely he would wake up if intubated. As I did my best to help them understand his reality, I knew hundreds of thousands of families have likely faced similar medical decisions without the information needed to make an informed and compassionate choice.

Our family opted for palliative care. Pandemic policies prohibited visitors, but I explained to the charge nurse how he’d uniquely benefit from having family members around who could understand and comfort him. Fortunately, we were granted an exception. I called his doctor asking for a letter supporting an emergency visa for family members in Mexico and wrote letters to help facilitate their entry through U.S. Customs. 

Two weeks after Grandpa’s passing, I closed my eyes as I sat in the dark, quiet parking garage of the Pearson test center. I thought about his life, my family's sacrifices, and what I had overcome to get to this point. I recognized how my upbringing and difficulties growing up had equipped me to help bridge an enormous cultural divide in medicine. I felt privileged to have been in the position to help my family and am eager to help similar patients and their loved ones navigate their most difficult moments – not just by being a physician advocate for them, but also by  joining others in building pathways towards a career in medicine for the next generation of Latinx students.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I remember my first day at San Francisco Zen Center. While I was excited to help the chef, or "Tenzo," prepare meals, I initially felt intimidated by the cultural differences I encountered. The way people moved about the center seemed to follow a specific set of rituals that I was not privy to. For example, instead of saying a simple ‚Äúhello,‚Äù monks and nuns I passed would come to a complete stop and take a deep bow in my direction. My initial intimidation quickly turned to respect, and I grew to love the sense of community fostered by these monks, nuns, and laypeople. From all parts of the world, they have come together with a common Buddhist aspiration ‚Äì to end the suffering of all sentient beings. I see medicine as an incredible opportunity to continue connecting with people from different backgrounds while contributing to this same aspiration by living a life of service where I treat and build nurturing relationships with patients.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: The lack of educational opportunities and mentorship in my hometown contributed to a significant amount of my childhood classmates getting involved with gangs and dropping out of school. Throughout high school I heard stories of childhood friends who were in and out of the jail system and in 2012, I received the sad news that my former classmate, ‚ÄúAdrian,‚Äù had passed away at the hands of gang violence at the young age of 17. These experiences inspired me to establish a paid summer mentorship program at my research lab for first-generation college students who are underrepresented in medicine. Seeing my mentees‚Äô faces light up when concepts click ‚Äì like when I taught them immunofluorescent staining ‚Äì has been a highlight of my summer. As a future physician, I will continue to empower first-generation college students from underserved communities by implementing similar programs.

personal_statement:
As an eleven year old boy, I took a horseshoe to the forehead. I can distinctly recall the extent of my fear as my legs gave out from under me and I fell to the ground, the pain and blood shocking me into a state of vulnerability I had never experienced. My parents brought me inside and my mom cleaned the wound and started to stitch me up as I squeezed my dad's hand. Even more than the pain of the event, I remember and treasure the comfort of my dad's embrace in that moment. At first, I assumed this unique feeling could only transpire through a parent's relationship with their child. As I continued to mature and look to my parents for guidance, I realized that wasn't the case. I saw them leave for work every day and make a tangible difference in people's lives, just as they did for me in my moment of vulnerability. I admired how my parents, like other medical professionals, extended unwavering support and compassion to their patients each day, and this cultivated my own desire to be a part of that process as well. 
When I was 17, I had the privilege of shadowing a urologist and was able to sit in on operations like prostate surgery. One particularly senior patient struggled with the pain of the procedure, even with the anesthesia. While the surgery progressed, my eyes darted between the procedure monitor and the grimacing patient, feeling his uneasiness and pain. I approached with an outreached hand, which he squeezed firmly for the rest of the procedure. While I wished that I could do more in this situation, I felt as if I had started to fulfill a duty to do what was right for the patient. He later told me he wasn’t sure he’d be able to get through the procedure without my help. This experience started to solidify my conviction to become a physician. I was taken aback by how influential my seemingly minor actions could be on someone, and while I still wanted to do more, I learned that an integral part of healthcare comes from just being present and empathetic with the patient who may be suffering. As a physician, I would simultaneously showcase true, empathetic care, and motivate the healthcare team in our shared primary goal of doing what's best for the patient. While the elderly gentleman squeezed my hand in pain, I remembered squeezing my dad's hand as a child. I was reminded that across generations, backgrounds, and lifestyles, we all feel the same weight of pain and suffering at some point in our lives. That's why it felt so valuable to be there for him like my dad was for me. Despite not knowing each other, the bond in caring for this gentleman was incredibly fulfilling. 
As time went on, I was reminded both of this pain and bond when the roles were reversed and my dad was diagnosed with terminal brain cancer in August of 2020. As an impoverished immigrant from Mexico who had made a living in the Army and then as a PA, my dad had always blazed his own path, solving problem after problem and being my hero and role model throughout my life. So when our family was faced with a problem not even he could solve, it was hard not to constantly feel the immense weight of an impossible climb back up to a normal life. After three craniotomies and adjuvant chemotherapy, he could no longer use his entire left side as well as other higher faculties. My mom and I took it upon ourselves to be his primary caretakers and we witnessed him weaken with each passing day. I did my best to ease his suffering and stayed by his side, helping to feed him, move him, and use the restroom. Near the end, he couldn't speak and could only move his right arm. I sat by his side and he anxiously reached out for my own hand and squeezed with his remaining strength. I could see the sadness and relief in his teary eyes as we embraced. It was clear that just being there for him calmed his anxiety and comforted his pain. The months I spent with my dad, and even those few moments with the elderly man in surgery, left me hopeful to ease the burdens of more people in the future, especially when in a position where I can do more.
I sometimes felt hopeless, knowing that the end course of the disease was inevitable and that there was nothing I could do. However, I also cherished the 16 months I had left with my dad, and while he was originally given roughly 6 months to live, he willingly embraced aggressive treatment in the hopes of spending more time with loved ones. Looking back, I’m glad I could be at his side every day to comfort him during that terrible disease. 
Modern medicine gave my family that cherished extra time, and as a physician, I want to be able to help other families and sons like myself spend as much time with their loved ones as possible. The extra time we had affirmed for me that medicine is not always about curing diseases, but that just being there for someone alone is a powerful form of healing and empathy that makes the process of illness all the more manageable and human. As a physician, I hope to use my experiences to become a more well rounded provider, and show my future patients that I can be there for them in more ways than one.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: My Army training in Kentucky brought together people from all over the country with varying backgrounds and living experiences and prompted us to come together as a team with a shared goal. During that time, I learned about each person's background, aspirations, and struggles. I remember one soldier from South Carolina. He told me about his struggles growing up in a small rural town, away from major education centers and hospitals, and with an expectation that most never receive a higher education. He used the Army to escape his home's impoverished and secluded lifestyle while hoping to one day support his family enough to relocate them someplace with more resources and opportunities. Being from Southern California, I did not fully understand this type of desperation before meeting him. I learned to recognize my privileged position and use my future career as a physician to advocate for patients like his family, who did not have the medical or educational resources to thrive._x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I recall one patient at the clinic, a homeless woman with diabetes. The physician and I spent much-needed extra time attending to her, and we formulated a practical plan for her to get the help she deserved. I also called and made her referral appointments while she was still at the clinic, then talked her through each one to help her better understand as she struggled to read and write. During our conversation, I learned of the intense struggles she went through on a daily basis, and she told me I had helped make it all just a bit easier. Seeing her more hopeful after our aid made me want to have a similar impact on others in her shoes. Patients like her showed me why it is crucial to develop a deeper understanding and connection with the diverse population served to best provide equitable care. In doing so, I could make a tangible improvement in their lives while preparing myself to meet my future patients' unique needs and challenges.
7_-_COVID_Impact: When school shifted to online learning, I was thankful to be at home with my family during the difficult times of the pandemic and my dad's sickness. However, with everyone back at home, it would prove to be a challenge to maintain the same focus and study habits necessary to succeed. Nevertheless, by focusing on finding a balance between spending time with family, my schoolwork, and other responsibilities, I became more efficient with my time and more productive during my work sessions. The time management and coping skills I learned from navigating my dad's illness, my school work, and other responsibilities will carry over to medical school and prepare me to succeed no matter the challenge that life throws my way.

personal_statement:
I did not discover my passion for medicine until I had the opportunity to explore other fields. I started with an interest in business and took a summer internship working at a lending institution in Chicago during the Summer of 2016. Although I learned a lot from this experience, I truly felt like something was missing. The time spent pouring through figures and tables was intriguing, but not fulfilling. I aspired for deeper connections with real people, to help others navigate complex problems, and to use my problem-solving skills in a scientific context. As I advanced through high school and college, I found that my exact interests pointed me to medicine. I realized that I could best accomplish my goals by pursuing a career as a physician because of the plethora of opportunities for creativity and discovery through conducting research, the ability to specialize, and the chance to lead a team of clinicians. Since coming to this realization, I have made a conscious effort to expose myself to experiences that would best prepare me for life as a physician. 

One meaningful experience was my time volunteering in a local emergency department, where I learned that practicing medicine is more than simply prescribing treatment: it involves a combination of proper body language, providing empathy, and overcoming language and health literacy barriers. These components of the doctor-patient relationship are fundamental to building trust and maximizing the quality of care provided by the healthcare team. The specialists I observed in orthopedics, anesthesiology, internal medicine, primary care, and radiology were masters of these principles. Whether dealing with challenging workplace complexities or treating patients suffering from excruciating pain, these physicians truly listened to their patients and understood the value of the role they carried in their care. The empathy, composure, and pursuit of health equity that these physicians exhibited in the clinic are attributes I strive to embody in my practice. As a doctor, I want to use active listening as a powerful healing tool, serve others with equanimity, and understand the perspectives and stories of my patients when formulating treatment plans. 

Serving my community at the Phoenix Allies for Community Health (PACH) Clinic allowed me to shift observation into action as I volunteered with physicians, pharmacists, nurses, and physician assistants in their respective practices. I serve as the PACH COVID-19 Vaccine Center Co-Coordinator, which allows our team to order vaccines, assemble a group of volunteers, log data, and schedule patients every weekend. PACH serves the marginalized Latinx community of Phoenix and reduces barriers to equitable healthcare access. Coordinating these vaccine events with other volunteers gave me the opportunity to expand access to care and improve the public health of my community. Experiences such as volunteering at PACH, the local food bank, mentoring at-risk youth through after-school programs, or assisting the elderly in preparing their homes for the winter allowed me to feel the personal fulfillment that comes with helping those in need and witness the profound impact that my actions could have on the well-being of my community. I hope to continue working with underserved communities, both internationally and domestically, throughout my career to work towards mitigating disparities along socioeconomic, racial, gender, and ethnic lines. As a physician, I want to continue my work with Latinx populations by providing care in both English and Spanish to improve access to care and healthcare comprehension amongst my patients in this community. 

Over the past year, I have been working as a medical assistant and a clinical researcher in a Mohs micrographic surgery and dermatologic oncology practice. This opportunity afforded me significant patient interactions and a chance to gain a broader knowledge of the responsibilities of a physician. It has also led to several peer-reviewed journal publications and an abstract since I began in May 2021. I collaborated on research projects, assisted in surgeries, and took patient histories. My work as a medical assistant has allowed me to serve a diverse patient base by assisting in surgical procedures such as Mohs micrographic and complex reconstructive surgery. My clinical and research activities introduced me to another avenue to help patients on a broader scale and understand disease processes as a physician, motivating me to continue involvement in academia throughout my career. During my career as a physician, I want to continue using my curiosity and application of the scientific method to further discover different pathologies, therapies, and medications to better treat patients. 

The ability to serve others and conduct research have invigorated me to serve a positive role in my community and the world as a medical student and a physician. My initial exploration of other fields, such as my summer in business, sparked my journey to medicine, but my continued experiences in various clinical, research, and volunteer contexts are what truly deepened my desire and sparked my drive to pursue a career in medicine, better informing me of the rewards and challenges of life as a physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Spending time in Iran and with my family has allowed me to see how my upbringing differs from that in the United States. The stories of my family informed me of their experiences during the Islamic Revolution. I deeply value freedom because of my parents' struggles as their liberties were taken away during the revolution. One trip to Iran was during nationwide demonstrations, the Iranian Green Movement, advocating against an election that many believed had been manipulated by the government. During my weeks there, I saw a regime violently suppress peaceful protestors and bystanders, which showed me not to take my freedom for granted. This was the first time I saw regulation on freedoms I have been so used to my entire life, as I grew up as a first-generation Iranian American. As a student at Rush Medical College, I believe my experiences throughout life will allow me to continue learning from my peers and serve a diverse community fairly.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As a volunteer at PACH, I work as a Spanish interpreter to provide COVID-19 vaccines, interpret primary care visits, and record patient histories and vitals. As a physician, I plan to communicate with non-English speakers, and this past year has bolstered my familiarity and understanding of medical Spanish in a clinical setting. Working directly with the Spanish-speaking community in Phoenix as an interpreter and COVID-19 vaccine coordinator at a free clinic impressed upon me the value of working with diverse populations. Directly serving marginalized communities to improve healthcare delivery by reducing language and technological barriers motivates me to continue serving my community as a physician while practicing medicine in Spanish and English. This past year has not only reaffirmed that I understand the life of a physician and am eager to pursue this career, but it has better prepared me to succeed in medical school and make a profound impact on my community as a physician.
7_-_COVID_Impact: During my gap year, I planned to apply to medical school while working as a clinical researcher in Chicago. The opportunity was canceled due to the pandemic. Looking for other opportunities to pursue instead, I found a different clinical position that also allowed me to work with patients as a medical assistant. I completed projects and worked with a team to publish manuscripts about reconstructive surgery in dermatology, conserving lidocaine in a global shortage, ways to prevent sharps injuries, and unique methods to shape cartilage grafts. The pandemic also highlighted the need for medical care for marginalized communities, such as the Spanish-speaking populations in central Phoenix, which I served as a volunteer. I recognize that the pandemic has a lasting impact, and I am fortunate not to have faced hardships during the COVID-19 pandemic. The past year enhanced my clinical knowledge and reinforced my desire to pursue medicine, fight for health equity, and serve others.

personal_statement:
I was the first person she told about the mass she found in her abdomen. What was supposed to be a forgettable follow-up visit for back pain had taken an unexpected turn right in front of me. Continuing with the check-in process, I verified the rest of Mrs. K’s information. I took her blood pressure as I told my usual joke about imagining a relaxing beach with a margarita in hand - no salt, of course. She let out a lighthearted laugh, but the unbridled fear and vulnerability that we shared in that moment continued to weigh us down. Even though she would be crushed by the eventual revelation of metastatic cancer, the magnitude of her trust in me left a profound and unforgettable impression on my heart.

Working as a medical assistant at a family care center has always brought unique emotional and intellectual challenges. My persistent curiosity and pursuit of knowledge had driven me to achieve a master’s degree in kinesiology. However, despite the confidence I mustered up on the complexity of human physiology, every patient brought with them their own unforeseen obstacles. Wincing, I assisted Mrs. P. in slowly removing the bandages she had fixed under her arms and breasts. Attempting to hide the painful, draining lesions, my heart broke as she shared the embarrassment she felt with something as simple as wearing summer clothing, or as personal as intimacy with her partner. With a new diagnosis of hidradenitis suppurativa, she found herself overwhelmed by the cost of treatment and the number of follow up visits that would ensue. Struggling to secure transportation, I connected her with our Uber Health program, but still wished I had more to offer. Whether it was fighting limited access to care, or straining to afford medications, I was coming to the realization of just how complicated healthcare can be.

Instead of straying away from these multifaceted disparities, I became motivated to find alternative ways to create connections through my role as chronic care navigator. I still remember the excitement in Mr. S’s voice when he told me his blood pressure readings were finally within target range. For four weeks we had implemented a routine that fit with his taxing schedule. Between weekly phone calls and visits with our dietitian, he established a new normal. We shared a laugh when he joked that this was the first time he wasn’t nervous for his upcoming three month follow-up visit. Unfortunately, not every interaction has been this fruitful. Ms. B proves to be one of my most challenging patients. After the unexpected death of her sister in February, she has struggled to make ends meet while caring for her own three children and now her two nieces. As our relationship has grown, my initial bias shifted from viewing her as non-compliant and difficult, to persevering and tough loving. Devastated to see her health placed on the back burner, I have worked hard to learn how to effectively communicate with her. While our goals are not yet met, I continue to meet her where she is at and push forward little by little.

My passion for working with under-resourced communities has been incredibly rewarding, but the limitations of my role as a medical assistant and care navigator have become more frustrating. While I cherish the relationships I am able to form and continue to enjoy growing alongside each patient, I struggle with the desire to navigate other aspects of their care. I aspire to be an effective liaison for the patient, where I can help coordinate between other disciplines, balance their prescriptions, and utilize my knowledge to design the most effective strategy for treatment. More than being a provider for this community, I want to be an advocate and leader. Longing to create a space where someone feels secure enough to confide in me their deepest concerns or share the extenuating factors that pose a barrier between them and their health; I will strive and continue to forge relationships built on trust. Because I try to see the entire picture for each patient, I also long to be a part of their parents’, daughters’, brothers’, and grandchildren's lives. In order to be this medical foundation for each patient, I find myself called to become their physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Centered in one of Kansas City‚Äôs most impoverished regions, HFCC has a patient population composed of people who are different from me economically, culturally, racially, and educationally. Serving daily in this community has taught me that, beyond our measurable differences, everyone has a story. By taking the time to sincerely listen, I can better understand and care for the person in front of me._x000D_
_x000D_
Mrs. C presented for a follow-up regarding hypertension. What started out as a simple conversation about salt intake turned into an exchange of recipes. When telling her about the home-grown tomatoes I use for salsa, her face lit up, and she started gushing about her own impressive garden. Living just two blocks away for the last 72 years, she has gradually expanded this garden. Vulnerably sharing her financial hardships, I learned that Mrs C grows enough food to sustain her through the winter. In this moment I was humbly reminded that what is a hobby to me, comes out of necessity for her.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
When invited to step into the role of Chronic Care Manager (CCM) at HFCC, I was elated at the opportunity to commit more time to this patient population and improve access to care. As CCM, I am responsible for assisting patients in navigating chronic diseases, and am also a member of the Quality Care Team where I help to identify/address gaps in care._x000D_
_x000D_
While assessing our clinic‚Äôs preventative measures, I discovered mammography compliance was 3%, and 85% of mammogram orders were incomplete. Upon reaching out to patients, it became evident that cost and education were significant factors. In an effort to mitigate cost, I connected with imaging centers who provide reduced out of pocket pricing and sliding scale fees. Collaborating with providers, I developed handouts educating patients on mammography technique, importance of preventative screenings, and risk factors. I‚Äôve learned that in order to impact a community, you must intentionally communicate to better understand why needs exist.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
Ironically, I am writing this as I recover from variant BA.5. Like many, the COVID-19 pandemic altered the timeline I planned for my application to medical school. Working in healthcare throughout the pandemic posed the greatest challenge to this timeline. Struggling with staffing shortages resulted in extended working hours and limited time off. Because of this, test dates were pushed back, less time was available for shadowing, and hours allotted to working on my application were restricted. _x000D_
_x000D_
However, I should note one silver lining of this virus in my preparation for medical school. While working in healthcare during this time has proven to be a challenge, it has also been a privilege. If it weren‚Äôt for the prolonging of my application, I would not have the experience I do now. My current roles have not only enhanced my insight to the field of medicine, but have deepened my desire to become a physician.

personal_statement:
I was 15 when my grandma told me that the fire sprinklers on the ceiling were moving. In the past, she had sometimes forgotten important events or saw things that were not there, but this time she was so frightened and convinced that it was clear something was wrong. After seeing her doctor, she was diagnosed with Alzheimer’s disease. Blindsided, I scoured the internet. I wanted to understand why it had happened to my grandma and what I could do to help her. Reading that keeping the mind active slowed the disease’s progression, I brought her a math workbook to keep her stimulated. Over time, she started to forget how to cook foods I had grown up eating or wash her clothes, and I began to watch and care for her after school. One day, she forgot my name, and I realized that despite my best efforts and modern medicine, her disease would continue to progress. When she forgot her words, I still listened attentively; when she forgot how to chew, I brought her meal replacement shakes. At the end of her life, she passed peacefully in the morning after a restful night of sleep. Her battle, lasting 8 years, made me understand that there was nothing more valuable to me than trying to alleviate her suffering. She showed me that I could make a true difference in someone’s life. I will never forget the fulfillment I received from caring for her and her story has inspired me to pursue medicine to help others through that same compassionate care.
 
Between caring for my grandmother and transitioning to college, I found teaching piano to be an outlet to share my passions with others. When I started teaching Elsie, she struggled with the treble clef. Despite being an otherwise quick learner, this made her struggle to learn new songs despite reviewing the topic each lesson. Brainstorming ways to better adapt my teaching, I tried many different strategies such as rote memorization and individually labeling the keys and sheet music. Finally, I created a mnemonic called “FACE in SPACE” for her to remember that the notes F, A, C, and E are in the SPACES of the treble clef. She was finally able to overcome the block and make progress towards new pieces. Finding an approach that worked for her allowed me to help her overcome difficulties with other topics as she advanced. By working with her, I have learned to become a more flexible teacher, realizing that all students learn differently. As a scribe, I have seen that teaching is central to medicine. One physician, for example, spent an hour teaching a new patient about her nonischemic cardiomyopathy. She later expressed that she learned new things about her condition that she never knew before despite being diagnosed ten years prior. In medicine, I seek to utilize the skills I have gained as a piano teacher to personalize my care of each patient, taking into consideration their unique backgrounds, and teach patients about the pathology of their diseases and treatment options.

Scribing has also afforded me the opportunity to meet patients such as Trey, a 50-year old man with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. Previously an avid runner, he became unable to walk up a flight of stairs without becoming short of breath. Our team recommended he undergo catheter ablation, and, at his follow-up, he expressed his relief and gratitude that he was now able to return to doing what he loved—running. I saw myself in Trey. When I was 18, I injured my lower back and suddenly could no longer do what I loved – tricking. Though it took months of rehabilitation, I eventually recovered and learned firsthand how freeing it feels to heal from illness. Knowing that I had contributed to his care felt meaningful. Beyond that, I found it fascinating how our understanding of the physiology of the human body and pathophysiology of disease could be used to develop a treatment. I thought about how disorganized signals originating from the pulmonary veins caused his atrial fibrillation. By understanding this mechanism, our team could use cryo energy to freeze Trey’s pulmonary veins, form a durable scar, and thus block these disorganized signals from conducting. Counterintuitively, otherwise healthy heart tissue had to be destroyed to cure the disease. As a scribe, the gratification I have received from seeing how medicine has significantly improved the lives of my patients coupled with my interest in the underlying mechanisms of the human body and disease have further pushed me towards becoming a physician.

In caring for my grandma, I gained an appreciation for the difficulty—yet importance—of compassionately caring for others. In teaching, I have enjoyed working closely with my students and tailoring my lessons to each student. These activities led me to explore opportunities in healthcare such as scribing, and in medicine, I see a field that combines my desire to improve the lives of others and passion for education with my interest in scientific technologies and advancement. Though limited in what I could do to help my grandma, I seek to become a physician to care for others like I did for her and to improve medical knowledge and treatments to help patients live longer and better lives.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I met Rosie, an older Hispanic woman, at the Ballard Food Bank. According to her, I was the first volunteer to ask for and remember her name. After helping her weekly, she opened up to me about some of the struggles she faced as a homeless woman. Eventually, she revealed to me that she had been assaulted twice in three months. She then opened her bag, revealing to me a Taser that she carried to defend herself. Describing how she constantly worried for her safety, I learned more about some of the struggles of what living homeless in Seattle is like and to be more cognizant of the struggles those from different backgrounds may face. I felt proud to have successfully developed our relationship such that she not only trusted me to help her with her meals, but also felt comfortable enough to share her vulnerabilities with me.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
I first started teaching piano to Jason, a shy student with no prior musical experience, in 2017. As we progressed through the curriculum, he began to realize how much effort was needed to succeed in piano. He began to practice more at home, and I noticed how this paid off in the increasing speed that he was completing assignments. I encouraged him to continue his hard work. At his first recital, he was extremely scared of performing. Following this, I helped him gain confidence through mock performances._x000D_
_x000D_
As I reflect, I still remember how he was playing ‚ÄúOld MacDonald‚Äù in 2017. Now, he performed Mozart at his recent recital with poise and confidence. I am amazed to see how far he has come as a pianist and how he has grown into an outgoing, confident young man. Though I have only taught him for five years, I have been his piano teacher for more than half of his life. It is humbling to have been a key figure in his life and to have such an impact on his growth.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Due to my grandmother‚Äôs late-stage Alzheimer‚Äôs and my grandfather‚Äôs frailty, my grandparents required 24/7 monitoring. Unfortunately, it is exceptionally difficult to find Vietnamese caregivers and many of my grandparents‚Äô social workers and caregivers quit due to the COVID-19 pandemic. As a result, my parents, relatives, and I spent more time personally taking care of my grandparents. Not only was this emotionally stressful, but it required a significant time commitment.  I spent the most time taking care of my grandparents in the summer after I graduated in 2020. After I became employed in August 2020, I still went home every weekend to help my parents care for my grandparents which continued until my grandparents passed away in November 2021 and March 2022. The increased time commitment of caring for them due to the pandemic, along with working as a medical scribe, volunteering at the food bank, and teaching piano prevented me from pursuing other experiences that I would have liked.

personal_statement:
It was a hot summer day, used needles were spread throughout the small blue pickup truck. A woman was overdosing in the parking lot outside the urgent care where I worked. I ran inside to grab the Narcan from the pharmacy next door to us, not fully processing what was going on. Once outside, the doctor administered it, while I pumped the Ambu Bag as she slowly stopped breathing. After what seemed like hours, she became conscious, just as the ambulance had arrived. Tammy, whose name I learned shortly after, was not my first patient. However, she was the first to have been so close to death. This interaction is one of many where I have borne witness to the grim realities of the medical field and yet it does not take away from the incredible interactions that keep me pursuing a field I love. 

Just before graduating high school, I was devastated to hear the news of my grandfather’s cancer diagnosis. For the next few months, I watched him undergo treatments at the hospital. I felt powerless in that there was nothing I could do except to be there for him. His diagnosis left me with a yearning to learn more about the pathophysiology of his condition and so I decided to pursue biology. In my classes, I learned about the body’s internal defenses against cancer, however, sometimes this is not enough to stop cancer. A few years later, I was fortunate to be selected to participate in the Summer Research Opportunity Program through the University of Michigan. My focus was to research how therapeutic drugs were designed to aid in the treatment of cancer. I spent hours immersed in articles on the development of therapeutic drugs. It gave me the opportunity to use my knowledge from the classroom and apply it to solve real-world problems. Research allowed me to further my pursuit of knowledge to help people, such as my grandfather.

As the daughter of an immigrant, I would often find myself having to translate for my mother growing up. She would bring me along with her to doctor appointments, where I would try my best to explain her symptoms to her physician. He would listen to me as I did my best to explain everything, and I admired him for his patience and understanding. As I got older, I realized that language barriers prevent people from seeking much-needed medical care. I had witnessed this too many times and wanted to make a change, even if it was on a smaller scale in the grand scheme of things. 

These interactions inspired me to become an English as a Second Language tutor for Washtenaw Literacy during my undergraduate studies. I met once a week with a group of adult learners of different backgrounds. As a tutor, I was responsible for cultivating lesson plans tailored to their learning styles. Zhivko from Bulgaria talked about his excitement to retire from his factory job so he could spend more time with his grandchildren. Dario from Mexico talked about his dreams of working in hotel management. I enjoyed seeing their progress throughout the weeks and learning about their successes. Their stories of perseverance inspired me to continue my own path in medicine. 

My experiences both inside and outside my clinical experience have helped cement my passion for medicine. I want to be a source of trust for my patients, regardless of cultural and language barriers. I want to be there for them in times of celebration and in times of distress, holding their hands through it. This is why I want to be a physician, to make an impact in my community. The satisfaction of helping to alleviate someone’s pain or something as simple as putting a smile on their face makes the journey worthwhile.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Growing up in an immigrant family, I would get weird looks from my peers during lunch when I would bring traditional foods from home. I began to fear roll call, as I would hear my name mispronounced countless times. I felt like an outsider, surrounded by people who were different from me in various ways. My junior year of college, I discovered Washtenaw Literacy and decided to become an English as a second language tutor for them._x000D_
_x000D_
As an ESL tutor, I had the opportunity to interact with people of various cultures and backgrounds. Growing up in a town with little diversity, I welcomed this change as it allowed me to meet people I would not have met otherwise. My learners shared with me about their cultures and traditions, something which I greatly valued. I have learned to appreciate these differences that us unique. My experiences as an ESL tutor have fostered my enthusiasm to learn about other cultures and perspectives, which is something I look forward to in medicine.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: When I worked in urgent care, I often encountered many challenging situations which did not have simple solutions. One day as I registered a new patient, she explained that she did not have medical insurance. I informed her about the option to be seen as a cash patient, meaning she would have to pay out of pocket for her visit. At this urgent care, cash patients were required to pay the office visit the same day as their visit, which often presented a problem for many people. She let me know her situation and that she could not afford the office visit due to financial issues. I did not want to turn her away as I knew people were experiencing financial problems during the pandemic. I met with my manager and explained the patient‚Äôs situation to him. He acknowledged my concerns and we decided to bill the patient for her visit. She was very appreciative of our understanding. I hope to have impacted someone‚Äôs ability to access medical care that day, no matter how simple it may have been.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
I had been working as a medical assistant for a year before the pandemic started. Much fear and misinformation was going around, and I questioned whether I wanted to continue pursuing medicine during a scary time. However, I decided against leaving and continued working, where I would test dozens of patients a day for COVID-19. I heard the fear in their voices when I would call for positive test results, faced with the uncertainty of their diagnosis. _x000D_
My experience was a little different working as a patient care technician in one of the COVID units in the hospital. It was difficult having to witness many patients get worse as time went on. Seeing the improvement in other patients‚Äô conditions often renewed my hope and reminded me of why I wanted to become a physician. Being in these positions as a healthcare worker during a pandemic reaffirmed my decision to continue my path to medical school.

Hrdshp_Comments:
Socioeconomic Disadvantage: I inherited the immigrant experience, being foreign and dark in a predominantly white society, especially as a BIPOC woman in STEM. My mother grew up during the Civil War while my father’s village has no clean drinking water to this day. The family separated to establish a better life for the children. Since the economic toll of education was better buffered in the US, as opposed to the UK, through the provision of financial aid, a decision was made for me to move schools. In this way, I was fortunate enough to afford continuing education at a top tier college - something I once thought impossible. 
Sponsorship for Scholarship: I have been the recipient of need-based assistance in the form of grants and bursaries that funded my secondary and tertiary education. My family income bracket always fell below household thresholds for FAFSA, which found me eligible for null contribution. I also chipped in via work-study stipends as a means to pay rent. Still, there was familial responsibility to be as fiscally independent as possible. After late payments for dormitory and tuition costs led to disenrollment from classes and, on one occasion, being locked out of my room, I had to petition for further funds. With fee waivers, federal loans and free insurance, I could cope.
personal_statement: Face. Arms. Speech. Time. These were the signs of stroke, according to an advert on the telly. Days later, when slurs laced Nana's voice, a young version of me became versed in the cursory mnemonic. With a British stoicism that kept her calm, I put into words what unfolded until an ambulance arrived. While the NHS nursed her regardless of citizenship, my visits consisted of helping in the only way I could: daily doses of laughter. Across the pond, we call it the gift of the gab. Equipped with a bit of banter and flexible repertoire, I tend toward comic relief. Always the protector, concerned with making people feel better, I wanted to be a provider. I would bend over backwards-literally. Mumbling, Nana swore she would be dead had this happened back home. While she did later suffer a stroke in Nigeria, she survived, albeit crippled. I questioned why the outcome was so different. Revelations about epidemiology triggered outrage, then intrigue, in public health. Lack of access to even PSAs leave our natives helpless. My therapeutic curiosity stems from that early perception of health disparity, as its determinants were made devastatingly clear by Nana. Having harnessed my sensitivity to subtleties, such as context clues and body language, to detect time-sensitive symptoms, applied science resonated with me. I wondered how linkage between social and natural science could respond to need. Justice has always been important to me, but its rendition in health is inspirational. So far as biology justified such signals, scientific study gave my nosy mind direction. This led me to the US. I sought to get to the bottom of socioeconomic or environmental telltales to health. Travel introduced overwhelming insularity and insecurity, which were emotions foreign to me. I couldn’t talk my way out of this one. It took time and treatment to mend maladaptive practices. Where was the girl with the gab? That being said, recovery began with reflection. Once I established an equilibrium between being thoughtful and overthinking, introspection was a source of empowerment. In this way, stigma doubled as my strong suit. Mindfulness, perhaps the most underrated social skill, will let me look behind surface markers. Meanwhile, the dismissal of mental health concerns by my tough-love family, who could not legitimize any illness that was not visible, left me to fend for myself. At odds with medical mistrust and supernatural beliefs, psychiatric acceptance is hard to come by in black communities. For many, lack of awareness worsens taboo, which only adds insult to injury. Instead, I see it as a silent epidemic that I must not only manage but leverage in order to validate others. I’m even better suited to attend those in need—not as a distant observer, but as a sapient empath. While 9 out of 10 doctors in Nigeria seek to leave, I am compelled to do the opposite. There, my perspective can humor my passion for patient service. Health equity means all measures of well-being, including mental. Coping taught me that there is no catch-all cure to sickness, or the experience of it. Like comorbidity, I treat intersectionality holistically. I grew interested in how psychology and physiology converge along pathology. Soon enough, resolution gave way to research that employed these very lessons. Work with HIV-positive participants in research that synapsed the specialties of psych-neuro-immunology, whose societal stigma exposed more vulnerability, delays in treatment-seeking and exclusion from interventions, evidenced the need for interdisciplinary study and aired a universal need for affirmation. In aims to better the participant experience, I noted that, sometimes, TLC is the best medicine. Later, I used affective sensibility to curate my approach within another vulnerable population, children, who use expression as outlet. Taking this to heart, I have known an emotional bond to be as vital as a clinical one. Life's lessons were not only formative to my emotional maturity, allowing me to keep my wits about, but also inform the scope and nature of my care practices. It's transformative to my contributions as a classmate, conversationalist and countryman. It was a process, not a position. Throughout the turbulence, I tapped into a socio-scientific sixth sense. As an outlier longing to belong, I found my place and purpose in the pursuit of medicine. From medical advocacy to translational policy, I am conscientious. Like advocates, doctors know their job is done when they no longer need you. I know I can bridge borders, bring perspective and breed compassion (pregnant pause) because I’ve done so before. Beyond the call of duty, I can be support system for minority and marginalized groups. I can use cultural comparison to convey and demystify disease. With the competency to enlighten and an expectancy of endless insight, I can continue to serve as relief for social ills, providing tactful care for the sickly, stigmatized and susceptible. It's often said that jokes are all about delivery; interaction with an audience mirrors communication with patients, and comic timing resembles the ability to counsel while avoiding unease. Having explored new material, I set the stage for medicine. Since, I’ve refined my bedside manner, whether humor or healing.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I set out to fully immerse myself in the American experience through Greek affiliation. Though I thought a group couldn't be more white than my high school in rural Maine, I was wrong. On bid day, I was surprised to see that none of my so-called sisters looked like me, and feared that I would be the token black girl. Even so, I gave it a chance conducive to expose any bias, or at least lead by example. Learning from diversity requires fight not flight. Until we hold ourselves and our organization accountable, there isn't collective effort, let alone change. With this in mind, I opened the floor to peer dialogue about racial slights or fiscal stress. The more I listened, I found we were more similar than I initially gave credit for. In furtherance of intercultural fraternization, such interpersonal narratives complement care. These fireside chats became known as Courageous Conversations, which let us emerge as a dynamic, inclusive and representative class. Above all, I am a team player.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Blood is thicker than water. I learnt this the hard way: in the thick of a dark and deficient delivery room in Nigeria. A fatal postpartum hemorrhage opened my eyes to our maternal-neonatal mortality rate, where the preventable loss felt cruel. Having already labored by the light of my phone, the new mother bled from childbirth. Her husband was told there was no blood and, perhaps worse, no blood bank. The need for blood is universal, but access is not. It offended me as a black woman, immigrant and fellow human-being. Then and there, I embarked on a medical mission-change from within. Demographic disservice moved me to service-learning in New Orleans. Besides transfusions, I'm a clinical resource for cultural competency, racial relativism and mental-health advocacy. Through inter-professional rigor and interpersonal ties, teamwork treats overlooked communal needs or complications. In the same vein, I coordinate efforts overseas, using what I learn for effective, enduring service work.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Lockdown deglobalizes us. Social distancing goes against human nature. No matter which population, the pandemic was telling of this. Due to underlying fear in the HIV/AIDS cohorts, prone to infection, and minimal personnel on-site, work-study hours were cut. In the midst of my research, it changed entirely. To negotiate seemingly dire times, clinical conduct had to be modeled appropriately. Countermeasures consisted of consolidating contacts. I took it upon myself to review safety bylaws, update voluntary consent and envision a new variant of mediation- online. Expecting virtual visits to threaten participation, I emphasized outreach. This couldn't have been farther from the truth. For want of company, otherwise healthy subjects made time for ample, in-person checkups. Others navigated long-term treatment adherence, which I assessed via video. Despite publication plans fading into a prolonged timeline, my hands-on, frontline input on outpatient therapy proved worthwhile beyond measure.

personal_statement:
Staring blankly at the ceiling as the fluorescent lights slowly came into focus I found myself lying motionless in the middle of the ice rink, completely numb to what was happening around me. As I slowly realized what had happened, I felt a stabbing sensation along my inner right thigh. I had torn my adductor longus and ended my hockey career. I was overwhelmed by a feeling of helplessness following the injury, but the medical staff who cared for me during my recovery helped relight the fire inside me. In particular, Sharon, my physical therapist, went above and beyond. She helped me set goals and encouraged me on days I felt like giving up. I would not have made it through my recovery without her. Looking back on the experience, I hope to provide the same determination and compassion to people when they are dealing with medical challenges that can be life-changing. Whether it is people struggling to afford access to healthcare due to financial barriers or patients like myself trying to get back to things they love, I have realized, through clinical exploration, that I can best address both as a physician.

While recovering from my injury, I made lifelong friends who helped comfort and support me. Through these relationships, I had my eyes opened to some of the glaring disparities that exist within healthcare. As I learned more about biomedical engineering during college, I was determined to be involved in increasing access to medical technology. During my senior year, I led a team of my peers in developing a less-expensive alternative to an upright walker for “Mary,” a 93-year-old woman, who could not afford the current device. We decided to design an attachment to current rollator walkers that could transform them safely and inexpensively into an upright walker. When it came time to hand off the device to “Mary,” she lit up with joy as tears started to roll down her face. In that moment, I realized how deep of an impact creating accessible medical technology can have on people who cannot afford the alternative. As a physician, I would want to continue to use the skills I developed during my engineering degree to innovate within healthcare, and help patients like “Mary,” with the goal of addressing disparities within the field.

While writing the provisional patent for our walker, I realized that increasing access to medical technology is only one piece of the puzzle. This became glaringly clear as I watched COVID-19 disproportionately affect marginalized populations. I decided to start the non-profit Your Health Matters, Inc. to help lessen financial barriers to healthcare. Alongside my board of directors, we have directly supported local free clinics in the Boston area through fundraising and by recruiting a team of physicians to provide free virtual consults for patients who cannot make it to a clinic. As a future physician, I want to continue to work with these marginalized communities and help remove the financial burden of seeking healthcare.

Following college, I worked for H-Wave, a medical device company that makes an electrostimulation device aimed at eliminating pain. While at H-Wave, I had the opportunity to work with “Bob,” a patient like myself, who wanted to get back to activities he loved. He suffered from chronic back pain and could no longer play with his three children because the pain had become so debilitating. While fitting him for the device, he confided in me some of the goals he had if the pain subsided. He pulled a picture of his kids out of his wallet and said while on the verge of tears, “If this device helps my pain, I promised him,” pointing at his youngest son, “that I would help him learn how to play baseball.” A wave of overwhelming emotion crashed over me before I smiled and replied, “Let’s try every placement we can to make that a reality.” After an hour or so of working with his physician to find the right placement for the electrodes, we were able to get him the relief he desperately needed. The rest of the work day seemed to fly by as I was almost giddy from the impact I seemed to have on Bob’s life. Over the years, moments like this have helped me realize that I needed to pursue a career that would allow me to help give someone their life back by solving a multidimensional problem that originally seemed impossible. I have realized for me that career is medicine.

Whether it be creating a cheaper medical device to increase access to its technology, trying to address the financial barriers to healthcare, or helping a patient through their most vulnerable moment, I have realized my desire to empower people who feel powerless is central to my goals as a future medical professional. A career as a physician will not only allow me to continue helping underserved populations, but also enhance my capacity to provide them with the medical care they deserve. After completing my masters and overcoming adversity throughout my college education, I feel incredibly humbled and prepared for obstacles I may face during my medical journey, and I am thrilled at the prospect of continuing to innovate and learn along the way. Finally, I strive to one day provide patients with the same superior care I received alongside teams of compassionate physicians and healthcare professionals.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: When I first started college, I struggled heavily with my sexuality so one of my friends suggested that I come to an ALANA Collegiate Association (ACA) event with her. ACA is an organization that is devoted to supporting and advocating for all minorities that is open to anyone who wants to support these communities. While ACA did not have many other LGBTQ+ members, I was able to sympathize with and comfort other members of the organization due to my personal experiences with discrimination due to my sexuality. I made lifelong friends within this organization that helped me slowly come to terms with my sexuality and accept myself for who I truly was as a person. While participating in these events, I also learned a lot about various different cultures and backgrounds which helped me expand my worldview and opened my eyes to some of the disparities that exist in healthcare.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As a homosexual male, I struggled with accepting my sexuality throughout my childhood. During college, I found a sense of community within the ALANA Collegiate Association where I formed lifelong friendships with amazing people from diverse backgrounds. After graduating from RIT, I decided to start the non-profit Your Health Matters, Inc. alongside some of these friends. Since starting the organization, we have raised several thousand dollars to support free clinics in the local D.C. and Boston areas, and we have several donors who have pledged larger donations after our 501c3 status is approved. We also have started to recruit volunteer physicians and residents from different specialties with the hope of launching a virtual free clinic by this coming January. During and after my medical education, I would like to continue to grow my non-profit, with the help of my executive team, to hopefully increase our impact on communities in need.
7_-_COVID_Impact: During the pandemic, I struggled to find in-person volunteering opportunities so I started volunteering as a virtual tutor for Reading Partners. Even though we could not meet in person, this opportunity allowed me to work with children from underserved communities in the Washington, D.C. area and help them catch up to their peers in reading. I also struggled to find shadowing opportunities, but was thankfully able to shadow a neurosurgeon toward the end of 2020. In addition, my original MCAT was delayed by seven months because testing sites were closed.
