As I studied for my first two MCAT exams, I realized I was having issues focusing on tasks for long periods of time. As a result, I scheduled an appointment with a psychiatrist to figure out a potential solution. The psychiatrist diagnosed me with ADHD and prescribed me with medication to help me focus. Afterwards, I began studying for the MCAT again and managed to earn a 521 on the actual exam.

Hrdshp_Comments: I grew up with my mom, stepdad, and three younger siblings. Our parents struggled with opioid addiction, causing us to rely on government assistance programs and live in inadequate conditions. I matured quickly because I had to care for my siblings. Unfortunately, our parents passed away while I was in middle school, but we were cared for by our extended family, mainly our grandparents and great-grandparents. Leaving my hometown and siblings to go to California for school was difficult. I was in a foreign setting, and being overweight with cystic acne diminished my confidence. During this period, I also dealt with recurrent infections since my kidney was removed. I found it challenging to create a community for myself and struggled during my first two years in college, but I persevered. Finally, I met with a dermatologist and urologist to improve my health. Wanting to gain new experiences and cultivate relationships, I began doing yoga and running, making friends along the way. I wouldn’t change these experiences because they helped me gain courage and led me to meet my particular friends, now family. I now better understand life’s hardships and the importance of physical and mental health. I hope to implement my core values of compassion and generosity to serve others facing similar adversities in life.
personal_statement:
I peered out of the car window to admire the lush alfalfa fields, horses, and mossy reservoir I swam in every weekend, for a moment feeling at peace. As my great-grandparents and I passed the farmland, the countryside became barren, and the arduous three-hour journey from Roswell, New Mexico to Lubbock, Texas, began. We frequently drove to Lubbock to see their dermatologist, and the trip always felt like an eternity. Traveling for health care was one of the challenges of living in a rural area. However, our incredible doctors made the trip worth it. Dr. B would hold my grandmother's hand while greeting us, creating a warm environment. I was curious about what she would inject into their skin and the various machines she used. Once Dr. B noticed I was interested, she explained the preventive skin cancer procedures. Although they would leave with many incision marks or occasionally reconstructed ears, she made the complex processes seem effortless and painless, which fascinated me. Afterward, I would put vitamin E oil on my grandpa’s scars so I, too, could be a part of the healing process.

My interest in medicine began with my childhood experiences, and they eventually led me to study biology and public health. However, my path to becoming a physician was firmly established during the Christmas break of my junior year. My grandpa had a stroke and needed significant help due to his limited mobility. Being the main provider for the family, he was uncomfortable when others assisted him, but as I cared for him over my break, I made sure that he felt dignified. I read him a novel where the protagonist was a larger-than-life cowboy, much like him. I also cooked lunch for him and rubbed lotion on his cracked hands. My family and I installed ramps and found ways to make his life easier. Over time, I could feel his spirits lifting. Taking care of my grandpa, I realized I had a direct and positive impact on his energy, emotional state, and physical strength. My dream of assisting others was reinvigorated when his health improved. I wanted to find ways to continue to connect with individuals and assist them in times of suffering to help better their lives.

Later, I had the opportunity to work as a medical scribe for an orthopedic surgeon in my hometown. Most of the patients in the clinic were older and suffering from chronic conditions. I had the pleasure of getting to know them while observing their progress. “Mercedes” shuffled down the hall with a distressed expression. I greeted her in Spanish, which seemed to put her more at ease. I asked about her morning, and she told me she made fresh tortillas for her grandchildren, just like my grandma would do. I told her how lucky they were, and she perked up as we laughed. Over the next five weeks, she received treatments for her shoulders, back, and hip. The procedures pained her, and physical therapy made her occasionally frustrated, but we supported her and encouraged her to persevere. I always checked on her before and after each appointment. After the last procedure, I checked on her to ask for a percentage of hip improvement. She was swaying and did a little salsa dance. She held my hand and happily told me that she was essentially free of pain. I was elated that she overcame years of pain and immobility. Witnessing Mercedes overcome these health obstacles allowed me to experience the passion and joy for helping others heal, much in the same way I did when I helped my grandpa.

Often in the clinic, patients would tense up hearing they needed another procedure or test. “Clay” needed a bone density evaluation but was worried about taking time off work since he had to drive an hour to the city. He asked me where he would have to go for his tests. I explained that everything could be done that day in the clinic. He relaxed with a smile. I was delighted by the structural advancements that Dr. O had implemented, such as the addition of the bone health clinic, which made this possible. This moment motivated me to continue working with dermatologists to explore the usefulness of telehealth for underserved patients without the time or money to visit doctors. Also, many were hopeless about their particular skin condition, as some do not have definitive treatments. The clinical trials for creams and phototherapy proved effective, and I was able to see patients’ confidence and quality of life improve. All of the doctors I worked with created innovative solutions for the obstacles that patients face, which is something I also hope to achieve.

I value every opportunity I have had to make even a small impact on the health outcomes of others through compassionate and dignified care. However, I want to have a greater impact on patients' quality of life as a physician; I continuously see doctors heal patients and enhance healthcare services through innovative means, and this is what I desire to do. Growing up in a rural community instilled my values of compassion and generosity and taught me the importance of good health. I believe one’s environment should be a place of refuge that promotes better health outcomes. I hope to channel these beliefs to become a physician that attentively serves others, ensures quality and accessible care, and strengthens my patients’ community.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: During holiday breaks, I would stay with my best friend, ‚ÄúJasmine,‚Äù and her family. Her mother was in remission, and I would hear her using the juicer every morning to make ‚ÄúJamu,‚Äù an Indonesian health drink. I was taught about other remedies and Kerokan, and we discussed how she felt religion was crucial to her healing. This reminded me of the ‚Äúhealing circle‚Äù my great-grandmother would do when someone was ill. Jasmine‚Äôs family would visit the US often and teach me about Southeast Asian culture, expanding my world views. I had an appetite for new experiences, such as traveling and learning new languages. These experiences helped to define my goal of becoming a physician who tries to incorporate patients‚Äô cultures and traditions into their care, so they can feel safe and understood. I hope to teach my classmates about some Southeast Asian and Hispanic traditions, as well as learn what I can about other cultures to ensure all patients feel comfortable.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I have actively participated in efforts to increase health equity and provide underserved patients in my communities with care. For instance, in my hometown of Roswell, New Mexico, I worked as a Medical Assistant in an Orthopedic and Spine Clinic. I had the privilege of serving under-resourced patients, such as farmers, the elderly, and the Latino community. We promoted bone health evaluations due to the elderly population's vitamin D deficiency. An MRI machine, OR, and physical therapy center were added to the clinic so patients from rural areas did not have to travel to multiple facilities. These were important services implemented to ensure that patients could access care regardless of social, economic, or environmental conditions. I learned that to successfully provide high-quality care, it is essential to build relationships with patients and assess the social determinants of health to understand what is lacking in the healthcare infrastructure.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The pandemic was challenging since my grandfather suffered a stroke, and my siblings had low enthusiasm for school and could not play sports. Even though I was busy with work, graduate courses, being a caregiver, and starting MCAT prep, I created a schedule for my family filled with activities and meal plans. Also, our 80-year-old neighbors had little social interaction, so in the evening, we would stand at the other end of the yard to help feed their cats and chickens. We couldn‚Äôt hear one another well, but it symbolized unity and connectedness. I believe these experiences have better prepared me for medical school since I learned I have strong coping mechanisms for stress as I made time for my physical and mental health to better serve my community and spend quality time with my family. It also shaped my desire to help those in vulnerable positions by listening to their needs and providing social support.

personal_statement:
Wherever he went, my grandfather carried his toolkit, a dusty black bag with a yellow “CAT” logo. 

He was always tinkering at his workbench, trying to improve something, or stopping by friends’ homes to fix cars or furniture. Once, exhausted after a long day shopping in Chinatown, we drove by an elderly man looking sadly under the hood of his Camry in the parking lot. My grandfather pulled over to talk to the man. Thirty minutes later, my grandfather closed the Camry’s hood, the engine roared to life, and the now-beaming old man shook my grandfather’s hand. When Grandpa returned to the car, I asked if he knew the man; he did not. 


“So why did you fix his car?” I asked.

“I had a toolkit, right? So I might as well help.” 

It was more than just his tools — my grandfather’s example and words motivated me to help those in need, regardless of who they were and whether I knew them. 

So I made my own “toolkit,” upgrading my pencil box with extra pencils, scissors, glue, anything. The next week, when one of my classmates didn’t have the worksheet we were asked to print the night before, I handed him the extra I’d printed. His glum expression lifted, and I felt rewarded, knowing that I could help in his time of need. 

As fulfilling as helping others made me feel, I didn’t think about medicine until one day in high school. That night, when my grandmother failed to join us for dinner, my grandfather went to check on her in their basement bedroom. After a moment, we heard a loud howl and hurried downstairs. Grandma lay motionless on the floor, a knife in her hand, a deep, bleeding gash in her stomach. She had a history of mental challenges and had tried to harm herself. While my family rushed in to help, I stood paralyzed, afraid. Grandpa knelt beside her, pressing the wound. When the paramedics arrived, I watched them work quickly, using their equipment to stabilize the bleeding.

Luckily, my grandmother recovered. But the experience changed me. My grandfather, who seemingly could fix anything, could not aid his wife when she most needed it. In life-threatening circumstances, it took more than a commitment to helping others. A toolkit, I understood, was more than physical tools. I wanted to be like those paramedics, with the skills and knowledge to save lives. 

Thus began my journey to becoming a medical professional. In college, I searched for ways to build my medical knowledge. I studied to obtain certifications, eventually taking a course to become an EMT. What I learned made me more confident about responding to medical emergencies, carrying Narcan to music festivals in case anyone overdosed. My desk drawer and backpack held full first-aid kits. When my grandfather cut his finger badly on his workbench, I quickly staunched the bleeding and bandaged the cut. “Good thing you were here,” he said. 

Later, working as an EMT, I was at the heart of the action and had countless opportunities to help those in need. When the 10-month-old we brought to the hospital exhibited a cough consistent with croup, I knew to administer O2. “You probably saved that kid’s life,” the nurse said. I walked out that night feeling a sense of both pride and peace: I knew I’d found the most fulfilling career path for me.  

The next big step on my path came when John, a 55-year-old man, went into cardiac arrest as we drove him in the ambulance. I instinctively grabbed the AED and began CPR. As my EMT team delivered him to the emergency room, the medical team scrambled to their positions. Amidst the chaos, the doctor set a plan and kept everyone calm and focused: “Intubate him…start the line…prepare the LUCAS device.” Despite their best efforts, John didn’t make it. 

Afterward, I sat in the ambulance, sad for John and his family but also because I wanted to do more. I had done all that I could, but there was so much more for me to learn, to know. I thought about the ER physician, who’d acted calmly and confidently amidst the chaos. I realized that being a physician required not just extensive medical expertise, but also the experience-based confidence to make the right decisions in the most stressful situations. I knew I could acquire these attributes only by studying medicine.

My feelings were confirmed months later when I shadowed emergency physician Dr. Hiraoka. Going from room to room, we saw patients with wide-ranging complaints: abdominal pain, nausea, stroke recovery. Despite the variety of problems, Dr. Hiroaka asked smart questions, developing clear recommendations and next steps for each patient. It made clear to me that I wanted to be in his shoes.

My career vision is to solve medical problems on a daily basis, working with a dedicated team committed to saving and improving lives for patients and their families. Becoming an EMT confirmed my strong interest in medicine and provided a starter set of tools. Becoming a physician will equip me with the tools and knowledge I need most.

I’m eager to grow my medical knowledge, communication skills, and confidence, to better care for those in dire need — work inspired years ago by my grandfather, and the trusty toolkit he carried wherever he went.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
In May 2021, I began working as an EMT in Chicago, largely serving underserved patients. _x000D_
_x000D_
Their situations and stories stayed with me. For example, Sam, a 68-year-old COVID patient I drove home from the hospital, had recently been laid off from custodian work and lost her sister to COVID. She said she‚Äôd probably just try to improve her diet to stay healthy, since she lacked insurance and now had no job. Still, Sam was in good spirits, telling me about her brother‚Äôs big sports-bet win, asking me about my life. _x000D_
_x000D_
When we reached Sam‚Äôs house, her family came out smiling, offering me a few crumpled dollars as a tip. I politely declined, telling them to take good care. It was a reminder of how hard those in greatest need are hit by health issues, and why I want to do my best to help. In addition, Sam‚Äôs perseverance in the face of hardship also reminded me of the strength of community, even in the most challenging circumstances.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
In June 2021,  I helped start Ivy Garden Adult Activity Center, a senior community center in Chicago‚Äôs Bridgeport neighborhood, which houses many lower-income Asian Americans._x000D_
_x000D_
Inspired by past experiences working with low-income populations (such as with KDSAP) and helping my grandfather, I envisioned a safe, welcoming space where seniors could socialize. _x000D_
_x000D_
To launch, I led the team to discuss schedules, activities, and space allocation. I personally purchased amenities, created brochures, arranged transportation, and organized events. After talking to area seniors, we realized many lack primary care, so I helped create a partnership with Oak Street Health, bringing physicians in monthly for check-ups and other care. _x000D_
_x000D_
Today the Center serves 40 regular members. I love seeing seniors‚Äîincluding Grandpa‚Äîplaying mahjong, ping-pong, and competing at a riddle game I created, laughing with peers. I‚Äôm proud to have fostered this community that benefits a growing population dear to me.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
When Berkeley went to all-remote instruction in spring 2020, I was thankful to return to a stable home and work toward academic/career goals, ultimately reinforcing my commitment to medicine. _x000D_
_x000D_
Unfortunately, I couldn‚Äôt keep the California-based EMT position I‚Äôd secured, since I would be away from the state for an indefinite period. That same uncertainty made me hold on seeking EMT positions in Chicago immediately. _x000D_
_x000D_
Instead, I volunteered again with Ivy Garden Learning, the tutoring center where I‚Äôd previously worked. There, I held online office hours for elementary-school students and found creative ways to engage them, such as using YouTube videos on the Civil War and asking questions like ‚ÄúWhat would you have done if you lived in the South?‚Äù During that time I also grew my video-editing and kickboxing skills._x000D_
_x000D_
Finally, in May 2021, I began working as an EMT in Chicago, serving many patients daily, including underserved ones. I was glad to do my part while moving toward my vision.

personal_statement:
Ever since childhood, I have been intensely focused on my interests, highly sensitive to my environment, and devoted to fairness. Like many autistics socialized as girls, I grew up as an expert at social camouflage and was not diagnosed until adulthood. Despite my late diagnosis, being autistic has shaped how I relate to others, specifically those with disabilities, and is inextricably linked to why I want to pursue a career as a physician. 

In college, I worked at an after-school center for developmentally disabled youth. I had known I wanted to be a doctor since I was a teenager, but it was my experience at this job that sparked my interest in developmental-behavioral pediatrics (DBP). Through an autistic coworker, disability studies classes, and the online autism community, I learned to view autism through a different lens—traits instead of symptoms, accommodations instead of conformity–that I aspire to bring to the field of DBP. I learned about myself through my students and committed to using my arbitrary position of power to advocate for them when their voices were so often disregarded. For example, when a coworker was speaking disparagingly to a student about her dermatillomania, painting it as non-compliance, I intervened. I took Ava aside, gave her a fidget toy to occupy her hands, and calmly asked if I could help bandage her wounds. With her consent, I was able to care for her. I want to become a pediatrician to work with disabled and other marginalized children in a way that honors their autonomy and affirms their personhood.

I first became interested in working with people experiencing homelessness due to the large overlap between houseless, disabled, and LGBTQ populations. As I delved deeper into the work, my motivations morphed; I saw that all people deserve to have their needs met, not just those with identities that match up with mine. When I think about becoming a doctor, I think about the people I serve in community health care and how it would feel to be able to provide comprehensive medical care for them in a way that is non-stigmatizing and rooted in compassion. I think about Vick, a 70-year-old man who lives in a garage by my old apartment. “Hi mom,” he said one night at the needle exchange, “can I please get a couple bags of 29s, toothpaste, and a sandwich?” A fellow volunteer told me to get him 28 gauge syringes instead. Vick protested, flustered that he wasn’t being heard. I got Vick the 29s. Through moments like this, of listening to and affirming Vick as an expert on his own needs, I have been able to earn his trust over the years. Developing relationships with patients who have been previously mistreated by the healthcare system in order to provide them with care is something that drives me. 

After college, I continued my work with disabled and houseless populations by taking a job as a case manager at Lifelong TRUST Clinic. Recently, I was filling out a form with a patient, copying down his disabilities, when he asked, “what is intellectual disability (ID)?” I used overly academic language in my response. When he left, I immediately researched “how to tell someone with ID about their diagnosis” and reflected on my own experience getting diagnosed with autism, another stigmatized disability. Then, I called him to elaborate, using clearer language and providing examples of tasks someone with ID may need support with. Combining my medical knowledge with sensitivity for my patient affirmed my decision to become a physician and reinforced my belief that I would be able to relate to patients in ways that a non-disabled doctor could not. 

Another affirmation of my desire to become a physician came in the form of a phone call. My patient panickedly told me that she could not reach her boyfriend and that the clinic would not do her abortion without someone else present. I changed out of my work-from-home pajamas to spend four hours in a bleak waiting room. The nurse struggled to find a vein due to her long history of IV drug use and eventually, the procedure was done without pain medication. She came out crying and traumatized but relieved that I was still there. “In an alternate reality, I think I would be a really good mother,” she looked at me as I drove her home. “I think you would, too,” I said. I meant it. I felt fiercely sure of my decision to drop everything and support my patient that day. However, I wished that I could have done more. I wanted to be in the room with Angie, reassuring her, administering pain medicine orally, or even performing the procedure.

I want to go to medical school to combine my passion for the medical sciences with my devotion to equitable patient care. Through working and volunteering in community healthcare, I have gained extensive experience building rapport with some of the most marginalized people. I want to become a physician in order to provide patients with holistic health care that prioritizes their own desires. Whether I end up pursuing DBP or primary care, I believe that my lived experience of disability, pursuit of justice, and unwavering commitment to my passions would be an asset to the medical field. Ultimately, I believe that I would be an attentive and skillful doctor, not in spite of being autistic, but because of it.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
As a freshman, I decorated my dorm room with a statue of Ganesh and Tibetan prayer flags. I grew up in an upper-class, white suburb in which Asian cultural and religious artifacts were used as decoration and associated with a primarily white counterculture. In an attempt to differentiate myself from others, I appropriated clothing, symbols, and art from Asian cultures._x000D_
_x000D_
One day, I was hanging out with my friend Isha and invited her over. She later told our mutual friend that my decorations made her uncomfortable. After our mutual friend brought it up, I read articles on appropriation and considered my own positionality as a white person. I realized that the belongings did not actually have a cultural or spiritual meaning to me, gave them away, and apologized to my friend. Due to my ignorance, I had caused harm. Now, I speak up when I encounter cultural appropriation from my white family and friends. I believe it is important to have these tough conversations in order to invoke change.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As a community health worker, I have extensive experience providing care to people who have been marginalized by the healthcare system and are initially distrustful of me. By consistently showing up, listening, and keeping my promises, I am able to build relationships based on mutual respect. When I first began case management for a patient with end-stage kidney failure and severe depression, he would often answer my calls with ‚Äúwhat do you want?‚Äù and then hang up. I kept calling, going to his doctor‚Äôs appointments, and asking him about his favorite band. The other day, he called to thank me for helping him get an electric scooter and said he was excited to take it to the park. At his next nephrology appointment, he said ‚Äúmaybe‚Äù to dialysis when he had previously been vehemently against it. By listening to my patient‚Äôs priorities and providing consistent follow-through, I was able to show him that I was someone he could rely on, ultimately helping him build enthusiasm for his health.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Due to COVID-related clinic closures, the research project I began coordinating my Junior year (on barriers to accessing services after a developmental-behavioral assessment) was greatly delayed. The developmental-pediatrics department at UCSF Benioff Children‚Äôs Hospital paused new assessments, stalling data collection until March 2022. I planned on completing this research study in the Fall of 2020 and then starting my honors thesis on the effects of disability-neutral language during a developmental-behavioral assessment on parent and child attitudes about disability. Due to COVID, I did not have a reliable research project to do an honors thesis on. I decided to graduate a semester early and used my extra time to study for the MCAT and get more involved with community outreach to support houseless communities who were heavily affected by COVID.

personal_statement:
There was a palpable weariness in the air as the staff on the unit watched Mila inch closer and closer to the end of the hallway for the third time that evening.

At this point, Mila had been an inpatient at Sheppard Pratt, the psychiatric hospital at which I work, for almost a month, yet showed little progress in her treatment. She was triggered so regularly into flashbacks and Dissociative Identity Disorder (DID) episodes that she required constant staff surveillance. Twice earlier that evening she had rolled her wheelchair down the hallway in an attempt to isolate and self-harm as my colleagues and I begged her to talk to us and use the coping skills we had taught her during group therapy instead.

Mila was skeptical of hospitals and doctors, and she invested in her treatment only intermittently. In and out of psychiatric hospitals for most of her life, she was understandably doubtful that her treatments would enable her to live outside of a hospital long term. Stories like Mila’s were common throughout the hospital. One man refused blood work because he thought he would be secretly injected with medicine. Another woman turned down meetings with her treatment team, citing dismissive behavior by clinicians in past hospitalizations.

I have seen firsthand what is at stake when wariness and distrust prevent people from seeking out vital care. I remember the feeling of helplessness as I argued with my grandparents over the phone, trying to convince them to see a doctor after hearing my grandfather slurring his speech on one of our weekly calls. Having lived through decades of volatility in Philippine health systems due to widespread corruption and a diaspora of Philippine-trained healthcare workers, they no longer trusted doctors and ignored the severity of his condition for days before our call. Thousands of miles away, I listened as my grandparents insisted that his symptoms arose from a cold and nothing more. In the end, a combination of emotional and logical appeals finally convinced them to seek medical help for his stroke, but the fear that their distrust of physicians could stop them from getting urgent care in the future continues to weigh on me.

In college, my experience working on a clinical research team investigating barriers that prevent people from getting vital care allowed a scholarly interest to evolve out of this existing concern. Through interviews and surveys, we examined how health literacy levels can affect a patient’s reluctance to seek out or continue treatment for cancer. Patients spoke about how limited communication or incomplete explanations of treatment details made them feel like they lacked agency in making decisions about their care. Dr. McGuire, the principal investigator in this team, taught me how providers can contextualize treatment plans to show how they fit into a patient’s life, turning each visit into a collaborative process. This contextualization was only possible after establishing rapport with her patients – learning about their lives as well as their medical history.

Later, when I started working at Sheppard Pratt Hospital and engaged in regular one-to-one staff talks with patients, I discovered the joy of making those interpersonal connections with patients, learning about their stories through laughter, tears, and everything in between. I held the hands of parents as they told me about their struggles to mend family ties broken by addiction, abuse, or abandonment. I worked with teenage patients to design safety plans after they voiced anxieties about discharge placements and relapses outside of the hospital. 
 
Ultimately, it was those types of conversations that I had with Mila in the past that gave me the tools to help her avoid a third crisis that evening. Stuck in the corner of the hallway, with my hand pressed against the wall to cushion her headbanging as my colleague struggled to slide a helmet over her head, I engaged with her different personalities, a symptom of her DID that emerged during flashbacks. Using my knowledge of her likes and dislikes, I was able to urge Mila to come forward, and together, we talked through a containment strategy that allowed her other personalities to recede, restoring a safe mental environment for her.

Mila’s avoidance of a third crisis that night was only a small, temporary victory in her long-term treatment. Looking back, however, it illuminates a fundamental desire conceived through interactions with my family and strengthened by my experiences: I want to connect with people in order to support them and help them access the resources they need. Patients are often in an unfamiliar, vulnerable position when they seek care. By working to close communication gaps, physicians can serve as guides, helping patients navigate unfamiliar territory and giving them the tools to advocate for themselves. I also aspire to have the necessary scientific expertise to support patients beyond holding their hands in difficult moments – to tangibly help them while putting them at ease. My experiences working with underserved populations have given me insight into the role I hope to play in achieving these ends: to build bonds of trust that create an open dialogue in treatment planning, giving patients power over their own health.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Although many people have preconceptions about psychiatric hospitals from the media, psychiatric in-patients are not at all different from people outside of the hospital. At my job, I talk with patients about their hopes and dreams, which are largely the same as yours or mine. What separates most psychiatric in-patients from people outside is untreated trauma and mental disorders._x000D_
_x000D_
It is not always easy to remember this. I have had to develop a thick skin for insults and threats. Being the recipient of a patient‚Äôs abusive behavior in the unit or discovering that they committed some heinous act by reading their chart, you can start to doubt the hospital‚Äôs capability for rehabilitation. The reality, however, is that these patients are simply people put in some of the toughest moments of their lives by society‚Äôs neglect. Seeing the accumulative effects of these disorders and traumas, I have a better understanding of the immense fortitude needed to overcome them.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
As an Organizer for Tutorial Project, I helped design new cultural competence trainings for tutors. I aimed to minimize bias and teach tutors to meet their tutees where they are academically without imposing their own expectations. I taught tutors to tailor lesson plans to each tutee, which often required teaching foundational content even if the tutee is in a grade level that normally teaches advanced skills._x000D_
_x000D_
Because grades are often conflated with one‚Äôs perceived capacity for success, students are anxious about their grades and their futures. When students think they are ‚Äúbad‚Äù at learning, their internal mental block can turn that statement into a self-fulfilling prophecy._x000D_
	_x000D_
Every session was a chance to tear down that mental block and build an environment where our tutees felt comfortable trying new things, making mistakes, and asking for help. In this way, I tried to shift the way tutees think about learning, making education less daunting and more collaborative and fun.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
The COVID-19 pandemic impacted my journey to medical school in positive and negative ways. Fortunately, I had an office job that could easily move online, allowing me to maintain a source of income. My research project at Johns Hopkins Medicine, however, I was forced to postpone until labs reopened. Academically, I was able to take advantage of the postponement of in-person research and the new virtual modality of my job and classes by taking more classes than I would in a normal semester, allowing me to graduate a semester early._x000D_
_x000D_
The biggest negative effect the pandemic had on me was the implementation of travel restrictions that abruptly blocked me from visiting family in the Philippines. Over the past two years, quarantine requirements that interfered with school and work stopped my family and me from attending the funeral of an aunt that passed away from COVID complications and being there for my two grandfathers, who in 2020 suffered a stroke and a diagnosis of ALS, respectively.

personal_statement:
After a few months of volunteering for hospice during college, I was visiting a patient who trembled uncontrollably while I attempted to calm her in her worst episode of dementia yet. Her scream rattled her living room’s windows and her tremors shook her unstable hospital bed. With the inability to administer any medical treatment as a hospice volunteer, I reassured her that her nurse and physician were on their way. After I spent many minutes offering tranquil words, the 83-year-old-woman started to relax. Once the physician arrived, an IV was started to alleviate her dehydration. Due to her recurring battle with infection, I increased my amount of visits. Medical uncertainty can be eased with a calm voice but ultimately needs an advanced team of physicians—I wish to be an essential part of both.

	My interest in service began when I was 10 years old. At this age, I cherished the time I could spend on the basketball court—however, I yearned to share my hobby with my physically disabled father. This was only a dream until we came across a video of wheelchair basketball. After finding a gym that would allow us to use wheelchairs on their courts, we spread the word and within a few months we had a team. I was focused on playing with my dad; this focus manifested as a drive to start a team. Unbeknownst to me, my narrow ambitions of playing with my father would shift when a boy with Osteogenesis Imperfecta, as well as many military veterans, came to play on the first day. I slowly started to understand the opportunity that was made for many people, like my father, to heal through sport. This small realization ignited my path towards service for people with disabilities which would then later evolve into a passion for medicine.

	After several years of developing this wheelchair basketball team, I found myself packing my car for college to begin my journey towards becoming a physician—a goal that I was excited to learn more about. My understanding of medicine started to take shape upon working in the Waco Center for Youth Rehabilitation Hospital and meeting a 14-year-old boy who recently committed a significant crime. As I approached him for the first time, he was sitting in a shadowed gray room, and he had dark brown scars on his face and arms that he attempted to cover with a Ninja Turtles jacket. He deserved much more than the path he was led down. I sat there listening to him talk about his crime, his past, and his desolate future. I felt powerless; there were not many actions I could take to assist due to the nature of my position. As I talked him through the possibility of a better future, his demeanor started to shift. Our weekly conversations seemed to be a great comfort to him. Yet, I craved the ability to refer him to someone more qualified to treat mental health issues. Simply conversing with someone about their situation can be sufficient; however, in many situations, I wished I had the ability to administer medical assistance. Becoming a physician, for me, means increasing the possible modes of action I can take to help the vulnerable while keeping the mental and emotional health of the patient at the forefront.

       After working with patients throughout college, I started to truly comprehend medicine through a multivariate lens. This desire to understand the comprehensive approach to medicine drew me into conducting suicide research at Baylor University. Extensive studies have been done on the personal factors that lead someone to commit suicide, but I was interested in the factors that people generally had no control over: county-level external factors such as socioeconomics and urbanization. Many factors leading to poor health outcomes are beyond the control of a single person; however, through my previous and future research, I wish to shed more light on the factors affecting the public. Becoming a physician will allow me to consider these issues directly with patients, as well as spread awareness to others in my field.

      Whether it be through hospice care, a sport, a rehabilitation hospital, or research, my desire to assist others will continue to push me in the hardest days of learning and practicing medicine. Working in pediatric medicine or another field of medicine, I aspire to use my experiences to continue leaving a lasting impact on those around me and on my future patients.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Conversations with my father sometimes centered around the plight of children crossing the El Paso and Ciudad Ju√°rez Border. I played with other students that were born a few miles from me but were given a significantly more difficult set of circumstances to grapple with. This early exposure to international diversity showed me the importance of having role models that children can relate to and having circumstances that allow for the same opportunities regardless of someone‚Äôs background. _x000D_
_x000D_
My experiences have inspired me to become an AmeriCorps member in Amarillo at Heal the City Free Clinic. I decided to embark on this mission to assist uninsured patients and reduce the burden of healthcare expenses for many people who are struggling with living paycheck-to-paycheck. This opportunity has allowed me to interact with patients from many different backgrounds. My experiences at Heal the City have furthered my passion for serving in areas with high uninsured populations such as Chicago. _x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
At the University of Washington, hundreds of children across America come to partake in the APEX Summer Camp. One patient was struggling with joining his group and responding to the token economy. However, a small change in his incentives started to reduce his outbursts significantly and decreased his overall aggression. _x000D_
_x000D_
By the end of the camp, he formed a group of what he considered were his first real friends. Although this was a significant step for him, I fully understood the impact of our work when speaking with his parents. Never before had his family successfully gone to any public event. After four weeks of therapy, they were able to attend an airplane show with no outbursts. Furthermore, the patient‚Äôs mother saw a decrease in her depressive symptoms. The impact of working with patients and individuals trickles down further than I had ever anticipated. I hope to treat patients in Chicago in a manner that leads to an even greater impact in their families and their communities.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
After serving on a mission trip in Belize during spring break, we returned to the US and were met with lockdowns. Without being able to visit my hospice patients or tutor in person, I started to work with my organizations to serve virtually._x000D_
_x000D_
The transition to virtual engagement was slow, yet I yearned to make an impact on my suffering community. Due to many restrictions, I reached out to Shopping Angels and started to do contactless grocery deliveries. Furthermore, I became the Texas Branch Coordinator so I could increase my impact on the community without putting my family members in danger. Through virtual tutoring, hospice visits, and coordinated grocery deliveries, I was able to make an impact on my community in a difficult time. _x000D_
_x000D_
Throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, I was reminded of all the possibilities there are to have a positive impact. This pandemic showed me the human ability to enact purposeful change in many circumstances.

personal_statement:
Creamy penne pasta, sautéed onions, garlic, and asparagus, with pan-fried spicy, chicken sausage; that was the first meal I learned to cook at eleven years old, in an attempt to take some of the burden off my mother’s shoulders as we were preparing to move halfway across the country from Illinois to California. At first, when I got the news that we were moving, I thought my life was ruined but over time I understood that my life was not the only one being uprooted; mom and dad were going through the same struggle. I wanted to help in some way to make them feel better, and the only way I knew how was to cook for my mom so she could enjoy a homemade meal without having to cook it herself. That meal sparked one of my greatest passions, cooking, as well as the realization that I loved helping others.
Fast forward a few months and I was adjusting to the huge city of San Jose, CA, a sharp contrast to the 8,000-population farm-town I grew up in. One of the first things I noticed was the large homeless population. This was entirely new to me, and I wanted to help in some way, so I packed food for them. A brown bag with some granola bars, a clementine, a bottle of water, and a few dollars from my piggy bank was what I brought to the homeless man next to the Safeway. I was initially scared since this was a stranger and as an ignorant kid, I thought homeless people were scary. But with my mom watching carefully, I gave the man his care package and nervously told him, “I hope this helps.” After seeing his smile and hearing his words of thanks, I ran off. After a few more encounters and some time, I overcame my preconceived notions about the people I was helping and was grateful to provide any help I could. 
During my teenage years and beyond, I worked with food kitchens to help homeless communities but when I started college, I had to pare back my outreach efforts to focus on school and determine what I wanted to study. I originally applied to college as a political science major but quickly realized that I was more interested in science. Having already studied physics and chemistry in high school, I eagerly delved into biology and realized it would likely be at the forefront of science and technology. My biology courses challenged me, setting the foundation I needed and amazing me with how seemingly random research regarding a single protein could have such an impact on our understanding of life as a whole. Reading research papers for a discussion course excited me to be a part of the force that makes these discoveries, thus leading to a research project in a lab. 
The group and I researched, and hypothetically developed, a detergent pod that would be far more effective at ridding college linens of the surplus of bacteria they house compared to common retail products. As my studies advanced, I learned about health and was fascinated by the different biological systems, how they synergistically function within an individual, and the variability between any two people. While engaging in research was fascinating, I craved the human interactions that I experienced when I was younger. This, along with the desire to improve the lives of others, led me to the revelation that the medical profession would be the best path to make a tangible impact on others. To put the proposition of medicine as a career to the test, I began volunteering at the Avicenna Community Clinic. 
As a free clinic for the under- and uninsured, I interacted with patients who gave me a unique perspective on the healthcare experience as they were often dealing with chronic conditions. It was important to the healthcare team at Avicenna to treat patients as people rather than just a symptom requiring medication. One Sunday a patient with a history of high blood pressure and diabetes came in complaining of fatigue and sluggishness that persisted even after being prescribed medications for his chronic conditions. Concerned that his medications were not working, he wanted to consider changing medication or receiving a higher dose. After a discussion with the patient, the physician recommended that we maintain the current prescription and dosage, but also incorporate exercise into his busy schedule by walking in place while watching tv.  The physician also recommended that he decrease how much bread he ate from three slices to one slice per day. Two months later he returned with such energy and happiness; the physician had not solely relied on medications to treat his symptoms, but considered his lifestyle to come up with the most effective treatment. Working alongside physicians and underserved communities was inspiring, and my dedication to becoming a doctor was cemented.  
The majority of my life I have helped others in need, beginning with snacks bags and food kitchens for the homeless and culminating with aiding the uninsured at Avicenna. My experiences helping others and my love of science and discovery have confirmed my interest in becoming a physician. Once I reach that goal I will make an even more tangible impact on those in need, and strive to provide the best care possible.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
As a biracial individual, I have experienced many levels of discrimination, from being bullied for the color of my skin to regularly being the target of ‚Äúrandom‚Äù security checks. However, one act of prejudice stood out - when a classmate in high school bullied me for my Muslim upbringing. He regularly hit me and insulted my family with the names of Muslim terrorists. These targeted attacks surprised me. I wanted to match his physicality, but I maintained restraint and unsuccessfully tried to explain why his actions were harmful to me and an entire community. _x000D_
_x000D_
These experiences have made me aware of how painful it is to not be respected for my color and culture and have led me to be a more open-minded person. I bring this perspective to my patient care and offer respect and acceptance towards those with unfamiliar backgrounds or customs in order to avoid making people feel unwelcome. For me, I work to educate myself and stay informed on new cultures so that I may be respectful to all._x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation: For the last year, I have been volunteering with Habitat for Humanity on the Rodeo Creek Court Project, building 11 homes for low-income families in the Santa Cruz area; we have completed four thus far. I have been fortunate to contribute to every part of the construction process, from foundation work to installing cabinets. One of my favorite parts of this work is that the future home-owners are required to contribute 500 hours of ‚Äúsweat equity‚Äù in which they work on the houses they will soon live in. This allows me to get to know them on a personal level, hear their stories, and build relationships. I have seen the direct impact this project makes for these families; Luke and his wife lost their house to the wildfires in 2020 and the sense of stability and normalcy they have gained from working on their house and building this new community is invaluable. I am honored to be able to give back to my community and others by building new homes and improving families‚Äô quality of life.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, my time at the Avicenna Community Health Clinic ended prematurely. While in the process of moving onto the intake team, the clinic closed temporarily due to the country-wide shut-downs. Unfortunately, once the clinic reopened for virtual consultations and extremely limited in-person activities, there was no longer a need for new members of the intake team. Though disappointing, this pushed me to pursue clinical experience elsewhere. The strength and courage displayed by the EMS workforce during the pandemic inspired me to dive into emergency medicine as a path for further clinical experience. Working as an EMT during the pandemic has become a significant source of medical knowledge and patient experiences, better preparing me for medical school._x000D_
        	_x000D_
Additionally, the pandemic made it extremely difficult to find shadowing opportunities, especially in the Bay Area, and it is only recently that physicians here are offering opportunities once again.

personal_statement:
Ducking under electrical wires and stepping over piles of sheetrock, I managed to find temporary relief from the boiling Houston heat. Around me, teams of people bustled past, each with a specific task in mind. It was the start of our senior year of high school, and my friends and I found ourselves gutting local houses that had been devastated by Hurricane Harvey. As I stood there catching my breath, I heard someone cry out behind me. Upon turning, I saw my friend Kaitlyn standing still, a wide gash traversing the side of her leg. She had accidentally cut herself on a piece of exposed metal in the cluttered work site. Feeling limited in my capacity to help, I assisted a few of the parents in applying pressure to the wound and drove with them to a nearby emergency room. As I watched the ER doctor access the wound and guide us through his plan of action, I felt the desire to become a physician materialize.         
This would not be the last time I would feel frustrated with my limitations. Throughout most of my undergraduate years, I worked as a resident assistant (RA) for my university’s dormitories. When the Covid-19 pandemic began to affect campus, my responsibilities as an RA expanded to include helping residents quarantine within the dorms. During the chaos of the early stages of the pandemic I watched many students relocate to their two-week quarantine; some with painful body aches, and others only a minor cough. However, beyond bringing them meals and informing them of on-campus resources, there was nothing more I could do. Assuring residents of their new living situation was simple but reassuring them of the nature of their illness was out of my reach.    
        As CDC restrictions began to loosen, I was able to shadow several doctors, one of them an orthopedic surgeon named Dr. Peterson. During one of our days at the clinic, we met a young man who was there with his wife and child. When we entered the room, the man held up his right hand to reveal the bloodied bandages covering the ends of his fingers. He proceeded to tell us about how the injury was the result of an unfortunate lawnmower accident. A clean diagonal cut of the blade had removed the tips of four of his fingers. It was apparent to me that the two were immensely nervous to receive Dr. Peterson’s opinion; and I soon learned why. The man revealed that he was an electrician and relied heavily on his hands. He was distraught at the idea of losing a job he thoroughly enjoyed and being unable to provide for his family. I was amazed by the comforting manner in which Dr. Peterson was able to guide the couple through their treatment options and envious of the level of trust they placed in him. Dr. Peterson would later go on to tell me that this procedure was relatively simple, and yet, I could not stop thinking about the direct and tangible impact it would have on the young man’s life. I realized that there are very few things people value above their physical wellbeing. And so, the ability to use medicine to restore a patient's lifestyle is one that appealed greatly to me. 

      I continued to pursue my goal of becoming a physician by volunteering at the Emergency Room of a hospital near my university. During my time there I was exposed to a diverse population of patients; many of whom were in considerable amounts of pain. On one occasion, I was asked to bring an extra blanket to one of the patients named Mrs. M. Upon entering the room, I encountered Mrs. M crying quietly by herself. When she noticed me entering, she quickly apologized and thanked me for the blanket. Reassuring her that there was no need to apologize, I found myself in a conversation about my time at school. It turned out that I was close in age to her son. Unfortunately, she continued to tell me that he had recently taken his own life following the death of his father in a car accident. As Mrs. M struggled to share her story, I could tell she was also struggling physically. She was in the ER for a suspected GI leak after a recent gastric bypass operation and simply sitting up was a challenge. I imagined what it must be like for her to experience pain in so many areas of her life. But there was nothing I could do to alleviate this pain except sit and listen to her story. And although being able to share these things with me seemed to lift Mrs. M’s spirits, I left that encounter wanting to be able to do more to help her. This feeling reaffirmed my decision to become a physician. A decision that would permit me to learn about the underlying mechanisms afflicting patients like Mrs. M, and hopefully help me alleviate some of their physical pain.   
       Although I have changed a lot during my time as an undergraduate, my experiences with patients and medical professionals have only supported my commitment to become a physician. Interactions such as my talk with Mrs. M, have shown me the value of being a source of calm for patients during stressful times. However, I also realize that I have a desire to do more for these patients. I want to be directly involved with their treatment, from start to finish. And I am confident that the knowledge and skills I will gain during medical school will enable me to address their pain and suffering.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: One of my responsibilities as a resident assistant was to help facilitate a series of programs focusing on different cultures from around the globe. While I am a terrible dancer, my favorite program was an annual event called "Dance Around the World". Here residents and registered student organizations were given the opportunity to educate people about their culture through traditional dances, food, and activities. In the course of only a few hours one could go from learning "Cenderawasih", an Indonesian dance that imitates the birds of paradise, to "stepping", a form of percussive dance in African-American culture. Although it was not quite the same as traveling the globe, this program still offered those who attended, a window into some of the different ways of living that exist. I realized how grateful I am for these differences. I feel that talking to other students at these events heightened my respect for others and prompted me to be curious rather than critical.     _x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation: During the summer of 2020, I worked at a local food pantry. Most of my time was spent processing large quantities of food in the warehouse. Sometimes, I even worked in the kitchen to prepare meals for youth and senior lunch programs. While ultimately I knew I was helping to alleviate some of the stress felt by those facing food insecurity, since I had no face-to-face interactions with members of my community, I felt disconnected from the impact the pantry was making. That was until I was having a conversation with another volunteer and was approached by a lady with two kids. She explained that she had relied heavily on the food pantry to feed her family for several years now. After thanking us for all our hard work, she said she was at the warehouse because she had recently accepted a job that paid very well. Now she wanted to use some of her free time to volunteer at the pantry with her kids. We had helped her to support her family, and now she wanted to do the same for others.
7_-_COVID_Impact: na

Hrdshp_Comments: As Cambodian genocide refugees, my parents had limited economic resources. We relied solely on my mother’s income early on, qualifying us for federal assistance such as food stamps to ensure we had enough to eat. We lived in multi-family households in low income areas to afford rent. I shared one room with 4 others well into high school; growing up with domestic violence in a small space made it difficult for me to focus on academics, so I went to public libraries to do schoolwork. Without access to academic tutors, I often stayed up late to troubleshoot alone and stayed behind at school to work with teachers. After my parents separated, we transitioned to a single-parent household. Moving away for college shortly after was difficult for me, and I struggled as I navigated classes and my mental health with limited support. As I developed better study and self-care habits, I improved my grades and got involved with extracurriculars. I have been working to support myself since graduating college - I worked full-time in a clinic while I paid for my MCAT prep and exam, and am working as I apply to medical school. No matter what I faced, I always knew there was a way to overcome. Having to figure things out alone while facing adversities has made me independent, resilient, and honed my problem-solving skills.
personal_statement:
“Mom, why is Tha’s middle name Winfield?”, I asked as I found my grandpa’s naturalization certificate in his briefcase. “When Tha came to America, he changed his middle name to Winfield to symbolize winning over the Killing Fields.” Sem Winfield Khieu, or “Tha” as I call him, is my earliest inspiration to care for others. When the Khmer Rouge communists seized power in Cambodia in 1975, they persecuted many – especially educated professionals like Tha, who was a physician. Forced to seek refuge in America, he continued his dedication to patient care by helping open a primary care clinic for his new community in my hometown of east San Jose. No matter what he faced, he took care of those around him – just like me.

Growing up as the eldest daughter of Cambodian genocide refugees came with adversity. My childhood was at the mercy of my father’s abuse. Despite the risk of becoming a target, I shielded my mother from his unpredictable attacks. Due to fear of law enforcement, I was taught to never disclose the realities at home. Being unable to use my voice to speak up was as traumatizing as the physical altercations. When my father lunged at me after I retorted I did not need the money I had repeatedly asked for to take my AP exam, I reached my breaking point. Our lives changed days after when I – at sixteen – decided that leaving “home” was safer than staying. I was the catalyst that ended the cycle of violence and fear, as my decision gave my mother the courage to separate from my father and provide the stable home we always wanted. Tha advocated for the voices silenced by the Khmer Rouge by continuing to provide medical care, and I advocated for my mother by overstepping my abusive father. My childhood taught me the importance of having an unhindered voice to communicate, process, and heal. It awakened my determination to educate and to amplify others’ voices, and revealed my grit. My interest in pursuing a career as a physician stems from my desire to use my experiences to advocate for the wellbeing of those whose voices are not heard in our healthcare system and abroad.

During a medical mission trip in the Dominican Republic, a doctor I worked with shared, “The treatment starts as soon as you start speaking.” This sentiment has stuck with me ever since – I saw firsthand how educating patients to boil the water they drink and launder with is treatment just as much as prescribing albendazole for pinworm when preventive measures are not taken. I learned that medical care goes beyond diagnoses and medications, as it is also the empathy needed to connect with others, and the education needed to inform and empower others to make appropriate changes for their lives. I carried this with me into my subsequent clinical experiences. From working in teams during medical mission trips abroad, to observing a surgeon speaking with a post-op nurse to check on his patient, I learned about the dynamic nature of healthcare, and saw how cooperation between unique roles is crucial for improved health outcomes. To solidify my decision to become a physician, I sought out further clinical experience as a medical assistant (MA).

My role as an MA at San Francisco Allergy, Asthma & Immunology has shown me the day-to-day realities of fast-paced ambulatory care, and the multi-faceted role of an effective provider. One patient’s story showed me how important it is not only to have a voice, but also to be heard and advocated for by the right person. Enduring ten months of excruciating, widespread hives, our patient had been repeatedly turned away from care and told to “take more Benadryl,” with no long-term action plan. At her first visit in our clinic, she expressed overwhelming encouragement and relief when our physician told her, “I know what this is. You’re in the right hands now.” I saw how healing it was for her to simply be advocated for. As an MA, I routinely checked in with her before injecting her medication. Our clinic was often extremely busy, but I learned to adapt and did not allow the pressures of the clinic to affect the care I delivered. I prioritized compassion in everything from providing a safe space for her to share, to a cup of cold water on a hot day. I shared in her frustration when her hives were so severe she was embarrassed to leave her house, and I celebrated when they did not recur for weeks. Now, she tells us, “I wouldn’t say that I’m back to normal…I’m better than ever.” Caring for her and many others over the last three years has taught me that so much of medicine is about the doctor-patient relationship: meeting patients where they are, and following through with compassion at the core of treatment.

My life experiences have taught me that having a voice is the single most important catalyst for achieving change, yet not everyone has the privilege of being heard. That is why I am on a mission to become a physician who advocates for the underserved, empowers them to use their voices, and ensures patient autonomy so that people feel in control of their own healing. A medical degree will allow me to pursue my calling, continue my grandpa’s legacy, and establish community-based care in the US and Cambodia to enable the change and healing in communities that I know first-hand is so crucial.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: In 2013, I traveled to Nicaragua with Global Glimpse on a service-learning trip to expand my leadership skills and global perspective. To explore poverty in depth, we visited a landfill where I was shocked to see kids running around in the rubble, and shacks on the outskirts that they called home. To get to know our new friends, we all took a bus down to a clearing for a game of soccer. As we cheered, laughed, and gasped for air, our humanity showed through. No matter what language we spoke, or where we called home, I realized at our core that we were humans all the same. Humans who share basic needs like shelter and water, and who share values like respect. We were as alike as we were different. Before stepping on the bus to drop off our friends, I noticed one of the kids had scraped his knee. I asked a coordinator for bandaids, and was frustrated when I was told I could not help him. That day, I realized my ability to address and act on disparities in our interconnected communities.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: On medical mission trips with Global Medical Training, I helped provide healthcare to medically underserved communities in Peru and the Dominican Republic in free health clinics. Under physician supervision, I helped obtain patient histories, measured vitals like manual blood pressures, and complemented physicians‚Äô acute care plans with education to combat preventable diseases. I learned the importance of primary and preventive care in addressing disparities in healthcare accessibility and outcomes, and came to understand how valuable patient education was, on topics as "simple" as proper hygiene. Our student delegations also donated needed medications, supplements, and supplies to these clinics and communities. For instance, we donated sunglasses in the Dominican Republic to help prevent common issues like pterygium. As education and healthcare are purposeless if they are not accessible, I strive to continue advocating for communities through active outreach and community engagement.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
Due to the pandemic, I was furloughed from my role as a medical assistant in March 2020, and unable to volunteer on another medical mission trip abroad. During this time of unknowns, I studied for the MCAT. When I returned to work in May 2020, I was the sole MA in clinic at the start. My priorities shifted to work and patient care, delaying my MCAT. As my mother has Kartagener syndrome, I feared losing her during this time. It was difficult not being able to see my family, but I do not regret ensuring their safety while I provided care to others. _x000D_
_x000D_
More recently, I became ill from COVID-19 in September 2022 and quarantined for two weeks with notable symptoms including body aches and cough. As I spent much of September recovering, my ability to work on applications was impacted. Now closer to my baseline, I have remained dedicated to completing my applications with an unwavering hope to one day nourish the wellbeing of those in circumstances void of resources and compassion.

Inst_Action_Desc:
During the fall of my junior year of college, I was found to have unlawfully collaborated with other students on weekly assignments in Principles of the Nervous System. Although the violation was unintentional, it occurred because I had a lack of understanding about my learning style. When I had engaged in the course permitted discussions with other students, I wrote the ideas we had discussed in my notes and used the ideas in my notes for my assignment. My reflection after receiving the violation helped me understand that I needed to change the way I completed assignments to avoid any chance of having similar ideas to other students.
	While this experience has taught me much about the way I learn, I have also learned the ability to manage my own pain and help others at the same time. I found that helping others helped me cope with my violation. Further, I became more comfortable asking for help from my professors, family and friends. 
As a whole, I deeply regret my academic integrity violation. Since receiving this violation, I have taken numerous courses that involve weekly assignments with discussion and worked as a chemistry TA in charge of grading quizzes and exams. Equally importantly, I learned how to be empathetic while dealing with personal issues and the ability to ask for help from others.
personal_statement:
Checkmate. Don moves his rook to h8, trapping my black king against the side of the board and ending the game. Don looks up at me, his eyes wide and his face blushing with excitement. Don’s hand trembles as he reaches out to shake my hand. I grab it eagerly, and smile at him. Don is my first student. He has finished his first game.
Don learned chess from a curriculum that I created by researching articles on memory loss and combining my own previous knowledge of chess. He had never played chess in fifty years as a farmer before he came to the Gathering Place, an adult day program for people with memory loss where I was a volunteer for over two years. When I initially approached the director for the opportunity to teach chess to their residents, I was denied on the basis that learning chess would be too difficult for those with memory loss. Yet, with support from scientific journals and a methodical curriculum where I would teach each individual piece on its own, I was given the opportunity to teach their residents. 
As I began to work more closely with Don, he began to show a passion for chess and other mental puzzles. Each week, Don found new puzzles and introduced them to me. He would also help me teach chess to other residents, encouraging his peers when they got frustrated. Though he was not able to remember his previous day, Don was able to find a new passion that helped him stay energized throughout the day. He was more social with the other residents and was more engaged in his daily activities. As a result, teaching Don not only had an impact while we were seated at the chessboard. It seemed to have a meaningful impact on his life. Working with Don helped me understand my motivations to become a physician: I want to help every patient find a passion for their own care. 
The first time I saw my philosophy in practice was when I shadowed Dr. Holmes. Dr. Holmes energized patients to their own self-care. He spent extra time explaining his treatment. After-hours, Dr. Holmes spent time teaching at-home exercises. He challenged each patient with personal motivators. Dr. Holmes would often go out of his way for his own patients by following up with referrals or adjusting his own schedule to meet a patient. But what stuck with me about Dr. Holmes was his ability to devise a treatment plan that was unique for each patient. Though two patients would enter with the same injury, their treatment would be different based on their own interests. I realized that a provider's ability to provide personalized, unique care was what made a patient passionate about their own care. As a result, I watched Dr. Holmes make meaningful change in each patient by using his position as a doctor to provide unique treatment that fit each patient individually. I realized providing unique treatment to make a patient passionate was an ability unique to being a doctor. 
Seeing Dr. Holmes’ ability to provide unique treatment motivated me to find my own way to give unique treatment while advocating for underserved patients. And so I embarked on a two year process that culminated in starting BuddyUp Tennis WashU, a college club that paired with a national organization to provide adaptive tennis clinics to individuals with Down syndrome. I researched BuddyUp Tennis, which teaches tennis basics but uses outside elements such as footballs to make the game more fun and manageable for athletes with Down Syndrome. I brought this organization to St Louis where it is the first BuddyUp chapter to be affiliated with a university. At the end of our first clinic, which involved over twenty five athletes with Down Syndrome, twenty five WashU students and additional members of the St. Louis community, parents of the athletes approached me and described how grateful they were to have our program, how it filled a void in adaptive programming in St Louis and how it motivated their athletes to seek a more active lifestyle. However, since our clinics were only once a week, parents requested more programming to keep their athletes active during the rest of the week. In turn, I started a Connections program, which allowed our students and athletes to stay connected outside the weekly clinics with weekly zoom meetings. These meetings gave the athlete external motivation to stay active outside the clinic. It also allowed for personal connections between our students and athletes. 
Seeing our program impact the community taught me the importance of advocating for underserved populations. It showed me the disparity in opportunity for populations such as athletes with Down syndrome. But it also emphasized that given the opportunity, underserved populations are just as passionate about their own care. On top of that, BuddyUp tennis emphasized the joy and satisfaction I get by making meaningful change in others’ lives. I believe that becoming a doctor will allow me to continue advocating, but more regularly and directly. 
From my time working with Don to starting our BuddyUp clinics, I have developed a strong motivation to become a doctor. I want to use scientific research to develop treatments that enable patients to be passionate for their own care. I want to advocate for underserved populations. I want to make meaningful changes in every patient I treat.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I am from Sheboygan Falls, a rural town of 8000 people, known for being close to the Kohler factory for toilets. So when I walked into Lake Country Academy on my first day of school, I saw no one like me. There was no one there who spoke Telugu, no one who sang carnatic music and no one who was vegetarian. So I had to adjust. I integrated myself into a culture completely different from the one I had at home while keeping the values that my parents instilled in me. I had to understand that my friends had to go to bible classes after school and respect that they could not hang out with me on Sundays. Understanding my friend‚Äôs cultures at a young age has taught me cultural sensitivity, how to be empathetic and helped me develop a willingness to insert myself into novel situations. These traits will promote the diversity of thoughts and experiences in the Rush environment. They will also promote inclusivity by making the environment empathetic and understanding of all backgrounds.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
I walk into a dark room full of video game monitors and posters of anime. My client sits across from the door. He is grinning at me because it is his last day of behavioral therapy before he graduates, the first of my clients to do so. I am so happy for him._x000D_
When I met my client for the first time, I was greeted with angry stares, vicious slaps and disobedience. My first session with him went so poorly I thought I had to quit. Nothing I said calmed him down and I was exasperated. A couple months in, I decided that I was going to have to find a new way to relate to him or I was going to fail. That new way was by talking to him about anime. I knew nothing about anime but before each session I would research anime topics to talk to him about it. Soon, his maladaptive behavior was gone. He began to engage in his therapy by asking me questions about my lessons. He showed major improvement. He taught me the importance of adaptability and relatability, traits I will use as a physician._x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact:
The day was March 12th 2020. WashU sent an email sending everyone home. That meant no tennis nationals, no a cappella, no BuddyUp tennis fundraiser and having to leave my research lab. _x000D_
	After the initial shock of leaving everything behind, I reflected on why I missed my life at school and why it took having to leave school to realize it. I found that I loved every activity I was a part of, but I could not enjoy my schedule because my mind was constantly elsewhere. I realized that I needed to become a more present person to enjoy my schedule and excel in the activities I was a part of._x000D_
	It is August of 2020. I started a fundraiser for a local music group and set up virtual hangouts between WashU students and athletes with Down Syndrome. While I was working on these activities, I found more satisfaction because I stayed focused on the activity at hand without worrying about what was next. As a result, COVID taught me how to stay in the present, a valuable trait for a physician.

personal_statement:
“It’s cancer; his leg needs to be amputated,” explained the doctor as my family listened in horror. One summer during my annual trip to India, my cousin and I were playing tag when he tripped and cut himself. We went to the local clinic, but they were unable to do enough; his wound soon became infected. We were advised to go to a hospital, but the nearest one was over an hour away. We eventually learned he actually had cancer and required amputation. This experience opened my eyes to the disparities in basic healthcare accessibility. In India, my relatives live in extreme rural conditions and I wondered whether sufficient healthcare resources could have prevented his amputation. Returning to America, I learned that the same problem persists in rural areas here and that the lack of advocacy for these populations is a universally pressing yet overlooked issue. I was invigorated to pursue a career in which I could speak out and actively assist these communities. 
 
With this mindset, I joined the social advocacy group CALPIRG in college. As a CALPIRG campaign leader, I encountered a family in Bakersfield living next to a fracking site. Many children in their community had become ill with asthma due to the toxic chemicals released by fracking. The families repeatedly wrote to community leaders to close the sites, only to have their grievances ignored by the oil and gas companies. I recognized that our support could uplift the voices of these families. We gathered petitions and ultimately met with legislators and the Kern county board of supervisors to garner support for our campaign for a buffer zone between fracking sites and sensitive areas. When we hit a campaign roadblock and lost support for the bill, I refocused our campaign to raise awareness and media attention. We wrote letters to editors and held a press conference to place pressure on local legislators to revise the bill and create the much needed buffer zone. My work with CALPIRG showed me how one person can have a major impact by simply rallying others to fight for the same cause.
