While working with CALPIRG allowed me to make a larger social impact as an advocate, it did not satisfy the personal connection I was seeking which I found in my work during the COVID-19 pandemic as a Cub Support tutor.
 
“No! Not math,” whined my student as she shut down and completely stopped responding to my questions. Seeing math problems made her shy and anxious. Once I realized she lacked confidence, I began with simple questions I knew she definitely could answer. Through experimentation, I found that she became most engaged when she could visualize the math. I taught her addition and subtraction using beads and a number line with a jumping bunny. My once anxious student soon excitedly waited for our sessions together. To ensure her continued success, I taught her parents how to help her supplement her school learning, and stressed that this would increase her confidence. Through my tutoring, I realized that I need to advocate for students with different learning styles so their potential does not go unnoticed. Yet teaching and making an impact on only one student’s life at a time was not enough for me – I wanted to be able to do more.
 
During my gap year, I combined my love for advocacy with making personal connections as a medical assistant at an ophthalmology clinic. Due to the pandemic, many older, immunocompromised patients were unable to come into the clinic to get their glaucoma and intraocular pressure checked. This was tragic for one patient as he went blind in one eye; when he finally came in, he was almost blind in his other eye. We immediately referred the patient to the glaucoma specialist, but even after my multiple calls, coordination between the specialist and the patient, and incessant follow up, the patient still had not been scheduled for surgery. Only after my plea for the ophthalmologist to personally contact the specialist was the surgery performed. This frustrating and disheartening process proved worthwhile as the patient has now gained a couple more years of cherished vision with his family. This interaction illuminated the importance of advocating for my patients by using my resources as a medical professional to open doors previously unavailable to patients. Finally, I found my place at the clinic, as I am able to champion the best care for my patients on a daily basis while personally teaching them about their eye health. My time as a medical assistant confirmed my dream to be a doctor because it showed me that I am pursuing a future in which I can constantly follow my passions of advocacy, teaching, and forming bonds with others.  
 
I aim to continue my work with CALPIRG and the ophthalmology clinic by persistently supporting patients both personally and on a larger social scale. As I pursue my goal of becoming a physician, I hope to always advocate for my patients and raise the voices of the commonly forgotten and underprivileged. I find immense fulfillment in knowing that my credibility and connections as a doctor will help me fight effectively for larger issues, creating a positive impact in the lives of individual patients and my community as a whole.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
During the pandemic,  I volunteered as a tutor to help children of low-income families that didn‚Äôt have the resources to properly transition to virtual learning. One of my students was an active eight year old who was bright but had a short attention span. To help her stay interested, I turned the lessons into a personal game for her. I challenged her to do sets of problems as fast as she could and each time she would be more invested because she wanted to beat her own previous record. When my time tutoring ended, I got the chance to advocate for her specific learning needs by demonstrating to her parents exactly what they can do to help her stay attentive in school. _x000D_
_x000D_
Working with this young girl taught me to think from her perspective to come up with teaching methods that accommodate her needs. In the future, I will have to work with people who have different backgrounds than mine and it will be crucial for me to apply this lesson when choosing how to treat them.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As I was growing up, I frequently visited my family in India who lived in rural conditions without access to proper healthcare. I wanted to actively stand up for people living in rural areas, so I joined Hygiene Heroes during college and created nutrition, sexual health, and hygiene curricula for schools in rural India. Since these communities didn‚Äôt have constant access to healthcare, my goal was to educate them on ways to prevent getting sick early on. I also joined a social advocacy group called CALPIRG where I led campaigns fighting to protect the environment. The most notable of all fought to create a buffer zone between fracking sites and sensitive areas such as schools to protect the health of young children from toxic fracking chemicals. Working with CALPIRG gave me the advocacy tools to continue fighting for such communities and to cause change in public health policy and bring better access to healthcare for everyone.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
The pandemic has caused many of my premed volunteer activities, shadowing experiences, and personal milestones like graduation to be virtual. The COVID-19 pandemic hit during my sophomore year before I could get any clinical experience. _x000D_
_x000D_
In addition to this, my MCAT date got postponed twice, however I used this as a chance to better prepare myself for the MCAT and I took it the first chance I got in the beginning of March 2021. I also decided to delay my application by a year and take an extra gap year to ensure I had sufficient clinical and volunteer experience before applying to medical school this cycle. _x000D_
_x000D_
The lack of part time or student clinical positions during the pandemic inspired me to graduate a year early so I could work full time at a healthcare facility as a medical assistant. This gave me the opportunity to help with the shortage of medical professionals during the pandemic while also getting clinical exposure.  It was a time of change, but I learned to quickly adapt.

personal_statement:
It was on January 25th, 2011, a regular Tuesday during winter break, when my family and I were enjoying a visit to the zoo near our home in Alexandria, Egypt. Upon returning home, our relaxing day was interrupted by frantic messages and incoming calls from relatives in the U.S., asking, “Are you all safe?” We didn’t know what they were referring to; the local TV channels, run by the state, provided no information. You may recall footage about ten years ago of groundbreaking protests in the Middle East. Ironically, those of us who were physically there were barred from viewing these images by a corrupt government, refusing to acknowledge the decades of injustice that the country could no longer stay silent against. This was the start of the Arab Spring in Egypt and unknowingly the start of my path to medicine.

As a young adolescent during this tumultuous time, I lived in uncertainty and fear. We avoided leaving our building; however, I would accompany my siblings from one apartment to the next, visiting our neighbors and finding comfort in the stories shared. I would listen to “Karim,” a newly graduated cardiologist who lived two stories below us. Seeing Karim sneak out after the 7 PM curfew to help the wounded protesters expanded my view on what it meant to care for others and brought to light the role of a physician. Notably, it filled me with awe as we would gather in the early afternoon, and he would describe the non-stop care he provided protesters whilst I sat home comforting my younger siblings. I, too, wanted to be directly involved in helping people I knew were in need but also understood that at this time, my place was at home helping take care of my younger siblings.

In the eighteen days it took to overthrow a dictator’s thirty-year regime, I learned the value, obligation, and honor of caring for others at their weakest point. I understood that we could each play this role as my parents did with me, I did with my siblings, and Karim did with the protesters. Through Karim’s stories, I began to see medicine as the career through which I could best directly serve others and satisfy my intellectual curiosity.

Four years after being forced to leave Egypt due to further unrest, I found myself at the start of my college career. Seeing medicine as the intersection between the sciences I enjoyed and the advocacy needed to fight inequalities, I decided to become a scribe to learn more about the role of physicians. Our urgent care center saw patients from diverse backgrounds and was a pivotal resource for immigrant groups. Growing up in a family of immigrants, I understood the anxiety many patients expressed as they entered the clinic for treatment. Many only sought medical attention when absolutely necessary out of fear and lack of access.

One memorable experience was when “Leo” came in with his mother. Leo had hurt himself playing on the swings at school. As I entered the room, I could sense the mother’s distress and anxiety as she avoided eye contact and spoke in an apprehensive tone. I tried to comfort Leo and his mother by speaking about a similar accident of my brother’s that also required stitches and the minimal long-term impact it has had. The physician then communicated with the mother in her native tongue, Spanish, to comfort her amidst concerns over her legal status and self-blame for her son’s injury. Through our conversations, I could see her grow in ease and hope as she was assured that we would do all we could for her son and that her legal status wasn’t in jeopardy by visiting the clinic.

Through such moments, my interest in medicine and patient care grew. I understood the profound relief that medical knowledge, coupled with empathy and care for others, can bring to patients. It was through witnessing hundreds of physician-patient interactions that I was able to see a future for myself as a community physician, providing quality healthcare in a non-judgmental, supportive environment.

My non-clinical college experiences reinforced my vision. Throughout my Jesuit education, I was encouraged to focus on service and advocacy for justice. I began volunteering at my local food bank, where I saw firsthand the effects of the pandemic on those already facing food scarcity. My favorite part of volunteering was saving candy to give to children who were in line with their families. It was reminiscent of helping my mother prepare bags of sweets for our building’s children during the revolution. I reflected on the cohesiveness I experienced in Egypt and how the most difficult of times that test our community are circumvented with brotherhood and solidarity. The non-clinical experiences I am drawn to all connect back to the lessons I learned on the significance of being present for others during times of vulnerability.

I have never forgotten my experiences in Egypt, and they have profoundly shaped both my worldview and how I connect to others. There is power in the human aspect of our shared interactions, especially in times of hardship. My clinical and non-clinical experiences affirmed my career choice and helped prepare me for the challenges of medicine. I see myself as a future physician, continuing to serve my community. I look forward to lifelong growth, service, and patient advocacy.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
I developed a unique perspective on how field workers conduct their work within the environmental science field. I spend most of my time in the field, working in manual labor, mainly climbing smoke stacks for testing. _x000D_
_x000D_
However, among my responsibilities is assessing toxin levels for technicians on site. I noticed some were apprehensive about environmental health. Through this avenue, I formed meaningful connections with many different from myself, worked with diverse teams, and enhanced my communication skills. For example, at a recent project at a concrete plant, I explained the need for monitoring for silica dust and the severe consequences that can arise and impact their respiratory health._x000D_
_x000D_
From my experiences in the field, I learned valuable lessons in communicating and earning people's trust. Fostering meaningful interactions with patients is my goal, and I believe my clinical and non-clinical experiences with diverse populations have well-equipped me for such an endeavor.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
In September 2021, I attended an event at my high school alma mater aimed at sharing alumni experiences with high school juniors. Following the event, many students sought advice about their college applications. The response inspired me to propose starting a mentorship program to the administration._x000D_
_x000D_
My alma mater is significantly under-resourced, with limited faculty to mentor students. I proposed instituting the program to facilitate meaningful relationships between alumni and students, focusing on career options and personal and academic skills. Furthermore, I wanted to utilize my experiences adapting to college in the program. Despite the value of attending a religious school and learning about one's faith, I believed enhancing students' cultural competency was critical._x000D_
_x000D_
I believe the lessons I learned in forming relationships and advocating for change will translate to a career in medicine. As I saw the tangible effects of advocacy, my motivation only grew to become a physician.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
Due to the pandemic, my family and I went through difficult periods financially. My mother lost both her jobs, and my TA position was canceled. I began working for DoorDash for about 30 hours a week in July 2020 and continued until I graduated. The increased hours worked, and the sudden shift from in-person courses affected my ability to prepare thoroughly for the MCAT. _x000D_
_x000D_
Several of my planned activities were also canceled due to the pandemic. I was admitted to the University of Virginia‚Äôs SOM Summer Research Internship Program (SRIP), scheduled for the summer of 2020. I was also due to present my research with Dr. Deborah Luckett at the 2020 Eastern Colleges Science Conference (ECSC). _x000D_
_x000D_
Overall, I believe the pandemic was a moment to show resilience. Despite the unprecedented challenges, I continued to work through this period to support myself and my family and remained committed to my extracurricular activities.

personal_statement:
“It’s hiding,” the doctor says, pointing a finger to his mask. His eyes crinkle in an obvious smile as he greets his patient.

In the background, there is a cacophony: a patient wails in pain, multiple heart monitors beep, radios go off, a nurse shouts so a hard-of-hearing patient can understand her. Our patient has been waiting for 3 hours, and her frustration showed on her face when we walked in. At first, she looks puzzled at his statement.

“My smile. It’s hiding,” he clarifies. 

“Oh,” the patient says, her demeanor shifting as she laughs. “I can see it in your eyes. My smile is hiding, too.” I can feel the room’s atmosphere lighten incrementally. I smile, hoping she can see it in my eyes as well, and introduce myself. It’s going to be a good day.

When I graduated from college, I knew two things: I enjoyed human biology, and I liked helping people. I had thought about being a doctor for a long time, but I didn’t know what it was really like to practice medicine. So, I decided to take 2 gap years, working as a medical scribe to give shape to the abstract ideas in my head about being a physician.

Scribing is unique because it gives a window into doctors’ daily lives, but also makes one a member of the healthcare team. Working side-by-side with an emergency physician for 8 hours a day, I am immersed in the process of diagnosing and decision-making. I’m also gaining a more realistic perspective of the difficulties and rewards of caring for sick patients. Some shifts are exhilarating; I have documented successful resuscitations, life-saving intubations, and STEMIs that were rushed to the cath lab. I’ve experienced the awe of watching color creep back into a patient’s skin when she was stabilized after arriving cyanotic and severely hypoxic. No other feeling can compare to being part of a team that saved someone’s life. I’ve also watched people die, held back tears as a son gently closed his father’s eyelids for the last time.

But perhaps most importantly, I’ve experienced the frustration and disheartenment that comes along with emergency medicine: an overflowing waiting room and a hospital without enough beds, patients who have no insurance and thus no access to primary care, conflicts within the healthcare team, noncompliant patients, and mountains of paperwork. Some shifts left our team drained and exhausted at the end of the night. Yet I always returned, ready for my next shift, knowing that I would continue to enjoy observing the challenges of diagnosing and treating patients. And no matter what specialty I end up in, I now have a more realistic view that my job will include helping patients navigate the complex medical system and educating them about available resources, just as I have watched the attending physicians do in the ER.

Before working as a scribe, I had been a physical therapy aide. Working at an outpatient physical therapy clinic, I developed relationships with some of our regular patients. In particular, I remember a patient with debilitating plantar fasciitis who attended our clinic for management of her chronic pain and difficulty walking. I was able to see her through the treatment process from start to finish. On her first day, I walked her through what to expect from interferential current therapy (IFC), and explained how it would help her with pain management. I saw her trepidation as she eyed the adhesive pads in my hands.

“It won’t hurt,” I was quick to reassure. “It’s just a tingling sensation. And you get to decide how intense you want it to be.” I loved explaining IFC to new patients. Here was a machine that shot electric current through the body, and yet instead of causing pain, it provided pain relief. It was gratifying to see my explanation reassure her.

As I helped her through exercises, I would listen quietly to her sorrow at not being able to walk on the beach anymore. One day, as we discussed her progress, she told me that she realized her healing process was not just physical, but also mental. This was the beginning of my interest in the holistic approach to patient care: viewing the patient as a gestalt, or a whole person, rather than a list of symptoms or a diagnosis.

I am grateful for my experiences, because they’ve allowed me a glimpse into the realities of being a physician, the moments that aren’t portrayed in TV shows. Before working in healthcare, I was a bit of a romantic about medicine. I was a bright-eyed university student sitting in the front row of my anatomy class, ravenously soaking up the names of bones and muscles. I thought that to be a doctor was to have knowledge, that the hardest part of medicine would be deducing a patient’s diagnosis. But I’ve learned through my work experience that scientific knowledge is just part of the foundation. I now understand other factors, such as how socioeconomic barriers prevent many people from having regular access to preventative care. I’ve learned how mind and body are intertwined, and I have come to appreciate that every patient I see is an infinitely complex being with unique circumstances. I can now say realistically that I want to be a doctor. I am determined to devote myself to medicine in all its aspects, including exhilaration, grief, frustration, and satisfaction.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: During my internship with Teen Health Outreach in the Santa Cruz County Department of Public Health, my team taught sexual and reproductive health to students in the rural area of Watsonville, CA. They were at an alternative high school, meaning that the traditional school system had failed them, so they all faced unique barriers to learning on top of living in an area with health disparities. Since I attended high school in a more privileged area, I had to be open-minded in situations I was unfamiliar with, such as students not being able to complete their assignments because they needed to help their families during strawberry harvesting season. I liked the gradual process of building trust and rapport with individual students over several months and identifying how we could create a safer space to improve their learning experience. Above all, my experience showed me that it is essential to be open-minded and adaptable in education.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: During my volunteer work in Nepal, I helped educate middle school and high school girls on feminine hygiene and distributed hygiene products. This enabled these students to continue their education instead of missing 25% of their school year, as was customary during their periods. Working with a local NGO under the supervision of a nurse, we engaged the students with educational materials to destigmatize their natural body processes. It was a small gesture that had the potential to make a long-term difference because we equipped them with tools to educate other women in their community. Our sessions were always awkward at first because most people were not used to talking about periods so openly. But as time went on, I noticed how students became more comfortable as we bonded over universal experiences. My experience inspired me to be an intern with my local public health department when I returned to the U.S., and I want to continue educating and promoting health in my community.

Inst_Action_Desc: I was placed on academic probation after the first semester of my sophomore year of college in 2006. While my first year could hardly be considered a success, my sophomore year was particularly difficult. I was not in a good place mentally and was overwhelmed by academic responsibilities and problems at home. I would officially withdraw spring semester 2007 and give myself time to reflect upon what happened and what I could do to better myself.
personal_statement:
In 2021, I met “Sara” on the patio of a fast-food Mexican restaurant in central San Antonio. A long-term IV drug user, Sara had been living with open wounds on both of her forearms. We were there with San Antonio Street Medicine to treat them. I held her right elbow in my left hand, my right tending to the wound running from wrist to elbow. She winced as I worked, so I spoke to her about growing up in South Texas and she told me what the Texas Hill Country was like in the ‘80s. She said her dog, “Bitita,” refused to sleep on the floor, and I called her a diva, and we laughed as I carefully rubbed on an antibiotic.

She told us that she had missed her last two appointments because she feared being judged by us, but now that she met us, she was grateful for our time. The doctor offered to put her on a weekly rotation, and she gave us the location where she usually slept. I continued dressing the wound and when the tape stuck to my gloves and I couldn’t remove it, we both laughed. We did not force her to endure a lecture or insist she ascribe to some sort of religious affiliation; rather, I sat there with her and her dog and the doctor as the noontime traffic went by beneath the South Texas sun. 

In 2007 I was on the brink of failing out of college — the result of shirking the responsibilities in every aspect of my life. I realized that I had to change, so I did, getting sober, and pivoting slowly to a life of service to others. I spoke in detoxes and at the Salvation Army, checked people into treatment centers, worked at a halfway house, and spent hours sitting with people who had a desire to change. Sometimes these people were friends of mine, but often they were strangers reaching out to anyone willing to lend a hand. These experiences have shaped my perspective and guided my life. But unexpected developments with my family made me realize the importance of a more integrated approach to support and healing.

In April 2017, my younger brother passed away due to an opioid overdose. The community surrounded us and we were met with love and support, but my family still struggled. It wasn't until a psychiatrist got involved that my mother came back to baseline and our family began to heal. The medical community helped us begin the long climb out of the fog. Watching physicians heal my family was transformative, and spurred me to think deeply about my career and consider how I could be most useful to my medically underserved community.

I had already been exploring a career change before my brother's death and was drawn to medicine even then. At the time, this interest was rooted in positive memories of a semester in high school rotating through the hospital, observing patient-doctor interactions. Seeing how physicians helped my family heal not just medically but holistically after my brother passed reaffirmed my desire to pursue a career in medicine. 

A few weeks ago, while I was volunteering as a clinical assistant at Hopelight Medical Clinic, a resident of a youth home came in for a yearly medication management appointment. He was quiet and seemed to have no interest in speaking with me or anyone else. My questions to him were met with short one-word responses.

As I reached for the blood pressure cuff and complimented his cowboy boots, it was as if a light went on. I told him I had a pair back home in Texas and he asked where I was from. He told me he wanted to get involved with the rodeo, and I told him about working on a horse farm in Arizona. He shared his life with me and I shared mine with him, and when I gave my report to the doctor he shook my hand. I enjoy meeting people where they are and doing my best to render aid.

As an MA, I am oftentimes the first person to interact with the patient past the front desk. They may be in pain; they may be scared, but it is my job to work through this so that the physician can provide the highest level of care. I love this; however, I want to do more. I know that as a physician I will not only be involved in the care of patients, but also trained to manage and monitor the health and wellbeing of my community.

I enjoy being placed on the front lines and falling back upon my humanity as I work with people who are seeking treatment. My experiences have made me adept at active listening, collaborative problem solving, and safety planning. I love working closely with patients, and I know that by approaching wellbeing from a physician's point of view, I will be able to treat and heal from a different perspective.

Switching careers is a decision I came to over a period of time that began with me as a sixteen-year-old in medical scrubs and continued through a life committed to service. My time shadowing, volunteering, and working has helped me reaffirm this commitment. I have spent years volunteering in classrooms teaching English to immigrants, offering conversation and a warm cup of coffee to the homeless and transient community, and I have given my time to help people get their life back on track, but I know there is more work to be done. Becoming a physician would be a continuation of this service work but would also allow me to help in a unique way: by attending to individual and communal suffering, through humanistic and scientific approaches.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
‚ÄúRichard, would you mind going and checking in with ‚ÄòJay‚Äô?‚Äù Becky leaned in when she said it, pointing her chin to someone sitting at a table alone, looking exasperated. Jay had recently been released from prison after serving over a decade. He was unsheltered but had recently gotten a job working nights. He was exhausted. I sat at the table next to him and asked him about his accent. He told me about growing up in New York City._x000D_
_x000D_
Sitting with Jay at the Recovery Caf√© gives me an opportunity to share the same space with him and get to know him for who he is. I enjoy bearing witness to another person‚Äôs successes and challenges, and being there for them however they are feeling. _x000D_
_x000D_
People need resources that they can use and apply to their lives so that they can recover, but what I‚Äôve learned by volunteering at the Recovery Caf√© is that it is easier for people to pick up and use these resources when supported by a loving and inclusive community. _x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
‚ÄúHey man, I didn‚Äôt think anyone would be here.‚Äù I was sitting at his kitchen table when he finally woke up. ‚ÄòMike‚Äô, had relapsed, disappearing during his lunch break at work. He resurfaced two days later at 3 a.m., without his car. When I heard he was home, I told the office I was stepping out early and went to visit._x000D_
_x000D_
My seat at his table was hard earned; I had been in his position. In 2007 my life fell apart; I was alcoholic and irresponsible in every aspect of my life. I realized that I had to change, so I did. I got sober and integrated myself into the recovery community, taking on service commitments both anonymous and otherwise._x000D_
_x000D_
I‚Äôve been continuously involved in this community for over 15 years. I do not have the answer to their pain, but I do believe that I am uniquely qualified to hold space and be there for people who are suffering. Mike is one example, and I have celebrated his success every year. Not everyone recovers, but I take pride in being there when they reach out.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
Unable to shadow physicians, I began virtual shadowing. Further, most of my service positions were moved to an online format, which gave me time to seek out additional opportunities. I began volunteering with the Crisis Text Line and eventually with Street Medicine. The vaccine provided a unique opportunity: I was able to be a part of its distribution as a volunteer in my community. Standing in a parking lot working to vaccinate hundreds of people is something that will stick with me forever._x000D_
_x000D_
Last summer I began volunteering at the Recovery Caf√©. The pandemic wasn‚Äôt over, but it was important to ensure that communities that share resources for housing, employment, and mental health were still available._x000D_
_x000D_
Covid-19 tested my leadership skills, commitment to medicine, reliability, and service orientation. The world changed and I was forced to adapt. It was not easy, but I take pride in my dependability and resilience.

personal_statement:
As a pre-med biology major I took art history to fulfill a requirement and admire some famous paintings. I was surprised by how much I enjoyed exploring the detail and historical context of each work of art. I took more art history classes, eventually adding the major, and found that it altered and enhanced my view of medicine. My favorite piece is a ceiling fresco in the Basilica of St. Francis of Assisi. The Franciscan vows – poverty, obedience and chastity – fill three sections of the fresco, and in the fourth St. Francis is seated in heaven. Every richly-hued detail is significant, but also the four sections together create a more powerful message than any of them on their own. This is how I view medicine: requiring knowledge of every detail, but practiced in the greater context of the patient’s life.

I knew I was lucky to be the only non-PhD working in Dr. Ashworth’s cancer genetics lab and was determined to make the most of it. My first task was sequencing cells to confirm whether CRISPR gene-editing had in fact deleted a BRCA2 coding region. I was meticulous at every step, and spent lab meetings googling terms to increase my understanding. I kept track of every research protocol in a notebook and added notes in the margins (like my own Harry Potter potions textbook). Participating in cutting-edge science at the institution where CRISPR originated, for the scientist who discovered BRCA2, felt important, thrilling.

Over four summers I progressed from googling every term during lab meetings, to running projects start to finish and designing my own primers. Figuring out which genetic errors dismantled control of the cell cycle and how to either correct them (eliminating the cancerous error) or damage them further (killing the cancer cells) was an appealing puzzle to solve. I loved the science, but increasingly I found myself drawn to the application of that research, the hope that one day each patient will get a targeted therapy personalized to their tumor.

I wanted to see where my lab work went, the patient side of medicine. As a clinical research coordinator I am where that science rubber meets the proverbial road, I mediate the chaos of clinic for patients on clinical trials. I am a patient’s first call for questions, scheduling requests, or a story about their son’s Halloween costume. Following them through clinic has provided an intimate view of cancer treatment and clinical research and how patients, families and the clinical team work together in search of a cure.

My first patient had recently been diagnosed with colon cancer, and now sat shifting in his seat with a list of questions and fidgeting hands. Dr. Van Loon started, not with cancer, but by learning about the patient's life. When she moved to talk about his particular disease her tone was serious but conversational. He ticked through each of his questions and the shifting and fidgeting stopped. Dr. Van Loon asked about his goals for treatment and what was most important to him. Then she described his treatment options, citing the supporting research and circling back to how each aligned with his priorities and goals. Her encyclopedic knowledge inspired confidence, and she considered every option in the context of his life. At that moment I knew I wanted to be a physician, one like Dr. Van Loon who focuses intently on her patient, sets his mind at ease, and provides that link from despair to hope.

Mia enrolled in my clinical trial and I adored her instantly. Graceful and passionate, I looked forward to hearing about her upcoming art exhibition or granddaughter’s band. Then Mia’s scans showed disease progression. Pain and nausea followed. Dr. Van Loon gently talked through Mia’s remaining treatment options, none of them great; then returned  to earlier conversations about what was important to Mia, what quality of life Mia wanted, and how further treatment was likely inconsistent with those wishes. It was a crushing and humbling reminder that some patients don’t get better, that cutting-edge science often comes up short. When Mia ultimately decided to discontinue treatment and enter hospice, she asked if Dr. Van Loon would still be her doctor. I will never forget the response: “Of course. I’m with you through this whole journey, for all of it.” I learned it’s not about wins and losses, that when cure isn’t possible we measure success by providing comfort, a little more time with family, and help finding peace. I want to show up for my patients, for the whole journey, even when there is nothing left to do but show up.

Working first as a researcher and then in the clinic, I have experienced the science that advances medical treatment and the care of patients who are at the center of it all. I have seen the ‘medical fresco’ - research, clinical care, and compassion - coming together like a 14th century masterpiece, into something more meaningful, something beautiful. And a career in medicine is all I can imagine doing. I want to be the whole picture, to provide patients with the best that medicine has to offer and walk with them for the whole journey, under the entire canopy of options, for all of it.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I didn‚Äôt overcome the distress of my childhood, so much as survived it and found its silver linings. Growing up with a volatile parent, I became adept at reading emotions and diffusing tense interactions. This has been a strength, working with patients facing life-threatening illness. After my father lost his job we wound up living in a friend‚Äôs garage apartment. At my private school no one knew I was on scholarship, let alone that five of us were now sharing 500 square feet. So I don‚Äôt assume to know what others face, I bring an open heart and mind to every room I enter ‚Ä¶ including dorm rooms. As a Sophomore Advisor my role was to support freshmen as they transitioned to college. I attended crisis management training and became suicide-prevention certified, but I didn‚Äôt expect to use those skills, Emory freshmen appeared flawless. I was wrong. Most confided in me things no one would suspect, looking at their shiny exteriors. We all have wounds, but we each scar a little differently.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
Three generations of a Middle-Eastern family, six people in all, were packed into the compact car that stopped at my station. I asked who was getting a vaccine and after a minute of charades to overcome the language barrier, the answer was: all of them! I placed six stickers on the car window, and with laughs and smiles, they edged up to the waiting nurses. Helping at Ethne Health‚Äôs Covid vaccine clinic felt historic and fueled my desire to address health disparities. _x000D_
_x000D_
Through my health and non-health related volunteering, I‚Äôve learned that only when everyone has the opportunity to lead a healthy and productive life, will we attain the potential of our society. John Donne‚Äôs famous ‚Äúno man is an island entire of itself‚Äù rings true in that there are both personal and societal consequences to inequity. My experience with Matriculate, mentoring teens hoping to be the first in their families to attend college, reinforced that the issue is not aptitude or desire, but opportunity and access.
7_-_COVID_Impact: While I experienced many of the universal challenges and losses of COVID-19 - canceled educational and work experiences, family financial challenges, and the serious illness or death of people I knew - none abruptly nor severely negatively impacted my medical school preparation. But the pandemic did afford me an opportunity I would not have had otherwise. Ethne Health is a community health clinic in Clarkson, GA (the most diverse square mile in America), whose patients frequently face language and other barriers to care. Under normal circumstances, there would be no role for a college student to check patients in and help them fill out forms, but these were unprecedented times. From a personal standpoint, it was a deeply moving experience. After a year of fear, sadness, and isolation, seeing people getting vaccinated was exhilarating. It felt historic, and I was proud to play a (very small) part in moving our country beyond the pandemic.

Hrdshp_Comments: In 2002, my family and I immigrated from the Philippines to America due to generational poverty and limited socioeconomic opportunities. I began school in the US as a second grader and was placed in an English as a Second Language class until I advanced to regular classes. To provide for my twin sister and I, my single mother worked as a housekeeper during the day and as a caregiver at night. As a result, we were placed in the custody of close relatives and moved between homes often until I was 11 years old. My mother's solution to this was to move us to an elderly residential home where we worked full-time as caregivers. After school, I helped my mother with providing care for the elderly to lessen her workload. At the age of 16, I became a hairstylist to help pay bills. My decision to pursue higher education was shaped by ongoing financial instability and a lack of guidance. Despite these difficulties, I received the 2013 Top Teen Award for my city and graduated from high school with honors. I decided to attend college two hours away from my family in order to discover more opportunities and myself. In order to support my family and afford college, I worked three jobs. My path to success as a first-generation college student and immigrant was not linear, but I took advantage of all my opportunities.
Inst_Action_Desc: I was placed on academic probation twice during the Fall Quarters of 2014 and 2016 due to poor academic performance. I was a full-time student, worked two part-time jobs, and traveled home weekly to support my family. These responsibilities made it difficult to maintain my grades. On top of these obligations, I also experienced two unexpected losses where a close family member passed away in each of those quarters. It was also in Fall Quarter 2016 that I was diagnosed with ovarian cancer. It was overwhelming to accept my diagnosis at such a young age. Due to my immaturity and lack of emotional coping skills, I didn’t seek mental health care nor allocate the appropriate time to study. Consequently, my grades suffered. Reflecting on this experience, I regret not seeking help from my advisors, peers, and healthcare providers. The grades are a constant reminder of my lack of maturity and the sense of isolation and defeat I felt at the time. From this experience, I realized the importance of community support, coping skills, and emotional hygiene. As a result, I sought help from my mentors, family, and peers, which helped me do well in my post-baccalaureate courses. As I get ready for medical school and beyond, I plan to continue to learn and advocate for mental health and coping skills in challenging times.
personal_statement:
My small legs ached as I sprinted to the nearest drug store for those white pills that relieved my “Lola’s”, or grandmother in Tagalog, painful pressure on her chest. The fear of being too late pounded rhythmically to each of my steps. This was a normal occurrence in my childhood. With no doctors nearby, the only treatments were the pills, prayers, and the crushed herbal salves I massaged onto her limbs. In our rural village in the Philippines, it was a struggle to find care for Lola. Since my single mother worked in another village, Lola cared for my twin sister and me. In turn, we took care of her. She entrusted her dream of moving to America to us, in an effort for us to live a life that offered more than what was offered to her. She was my pillar of strength and compassion. With one suitcase and my Lola’s dream, my family and I started a new chapter. Upon departure, I vowed to return to Lola to give her the care and a better quality of life that she desperately needed.

Longing for familiarity, my family chose an agricultural town in the Central Valley of California. Due to poverty and cultural barriers, we lived in an elderly care facility as full-time caregivers. While my mother worked tirelessly, I was left to the warm, tender care of my adopted grandparents. I had the privilege of meeting people from different walks of life and enjoyed listening to stories about their families, dreams, and even their fears. On quiet days, I entertained them by theatrically re-enacting my day at school. In every interaction, I treated them like my own Lola and constantly yearned to learn more about the physiology of aging so that I could help them more. With Beary, a long-time dementia resident, I patiently listened to her love for figurines and her fears about falling. She always used humor to cope when she described falling as a “one way ticket to the funeral home.” Though I shared her fears silently, I eagerly reminded her that I would be honored to be her “personal cane”. Growing up with the elderly taught me how to comfort others by adapting to their language, beliefs, and past experiences. I learned to connect with people beyond their diagnoses. And I learned how it feels to lose someone twice when Beary slowly forgot me before she passed. I never grew accustomed to death, but I grew to accept and value my role in providing comfort and peace during the time I was by their side. 

Eager to continue this role in college, I joined Hmong Lifting Underserved Barriers Clinic, a student-run free clinic in Sacramento that cared for the underserved. I found my place as a patient advocate and translator for the marginalized like my family. There, I met patients like Sonya, whose pain didn’t need any translation. I saw the sweat that glistened on her forehead; brows that furrowed as she rapidly shifted her anxious gaze from me to the restroom. Her chronic urinary tract infection was intensified by her uncontrolled diabetes. I quickly reminded the clinical staff and urged them to check on her at their next available moment. For the next three years, I scheduled my shifts to match Sonya’s and many other vulnerable patients. I wanted them to be supported and heard throughout their visits. As a result, I was able to celebrate many healthcare milestones, like Sonya’s lowered blood sugar. Volunteering at the clinic taught me more than cultural sensitivity. It taught me how years of systemic inequities can manifest into worse health outcomes for minorities. I learned how heartbreaking it was to hear a patient cry because they had to choose between medications or their next meal. I learned how medical mistrust and unfamiliarity can impact treatment compliance. And I saw firsthand how the simplest gestures could inspire hope in patients to improve their health and their lives. 

Through these experiences, I found my life’s meaning in supporting others to live a healthy and quality life. With Lola, I felt proud to be her personal masseuse, believing with every knead and prayer that she would be healed. For Beary, I was grateful to be her personal cane, privileged to be spending her golden years with her. I felt fulfilled as I held Sonya’s hand during her vulnerable times, her gratitude forever engraved on my heart. By becoming a physician, I know I can make the difference I want for my future patients and ensure they get the best care possible. I lived with many elderly patients who suffered from advanced health conditions and who coped with inadequate medical care. I learned about diseases at the free clinic and how cultural empathy and the right medical care can help marginalized people. Because of this, I will advocate for legislation that expands access to high-quality medical care for all. And when I was diagnosed with ovarian cancer, I realized there was nothing else I would want to commit my life to than being a doctor to help others go through their own health adversities. I will be there to listen and share in their grief and laughter. I will ensure that my patients are validated in their experiences and receive the quality care they need, despite costs and accessibility. Though I was not able to fulfill all these promises for my own Lola, I am at peace knowing that I will keep true to these promises for many others.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: In a corner of our free student-run clinic for the underserved, a Hispanic patient waited for the doctor to see her for her diabetes. A Chinese patient anxiously explained that his ribs hurt to a medical student, while a Mongolian patient paced nervously in line to get checked in. This is what our typical clinic day looked like. Patients of different cultures, languages, and chief complaints come to us because they seek quality, accessible, and culturally sensitive care. In my six years at the clinic, I gained valuable experience in a wide variety of roles. Besides clinical knowledge, I also learned what desperation, abuse, emotional trauma, and fatigue can look like. I learned to meet patients where they are at, in regards to their beliefs. I learned to be patient with those who has never met with a clinician due to their background. Through this, I discovered how much quality care, cultural sensitivity, and respect can accomplish in improving health outcomes for patients.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: To me, the inability to pay for healthcare services means that people do not seek preventative care and wait until later when they are symptomatic to seek the care they needed. Because of this, getting insurance is the most important social issue. It is the first step towards everyone's journey towards their optimal level of health. This is why I became a licensed insurance agent that specializes in health and Medicare insurance. In my free time, I offer free education and resources about how to navigate health insurance. I am an insurance agent because I saw first-hand how my family struggled to get and understand affordable medical treatment. It was the fear of the cost that hindered us from being the healthiest we could be. Moving forward, I will continue educating people, including my patients, about different insurance options tailored to their needs. Insurance is an everchanging terrain, and I hope to make navigating insurances easier for my future patients.
7_-_COVID_Impact: In March 2020, I was in the midst of my informal post-baccalaureate program. It was a struggle to transition from in-person classes to virtual ones. However, I took the opportunity to connect with my peers and professors virtually and we helped each other stay uplifted. Since my volunteer clinic was closed, I founded a philanthropic group called The Givemas Project and continued to provide for the underserved. I wanted to still make a difference despite the unprecedented circumstances. During this time, I also started studying for the MCAT because I was fortunate to receive an MCAT scholarship. But I delayed my test because it was difficult to keep up with all the last-minute cancellations. I also wasn‚Äôt able to visit my family, who lived two hours away. They work as caregivers in an elderly care home, and most of the residents are vulnerable to COVID-19. I signed up for virtual shadowing through online platforms so I could learn more about the clinical world and stay involved in it.

personal_statement:
There are little moments in my life that have had the emotional depth and tenacity to alter my life forever. I do believe my journey to medicine began with one of these moments. At 13 years old, my uncle's suicide left me questioning a lot. My parents and I had always been very open when it came to my mental health and I never felt it was something to be whispered about behind closed doors. When my uncle’s alcoholism and mental state was brought into question, it ensued an eruption of emotions from my grandmother followed by her immediate exit from the room. I was beginning to understand the detrimental effects stigma surrounding mental health had in my family. I noticed the lack in access to mental health resources my cousins living in rural Arkansas had. I wondered why therapy for my cousins, grieving the death of their father, was too expensive or too far away and why counseling through the school did not offer adequate hours for my working aunt. The long-term effects of such unequal access to mental health resources – had costly effects. From school expulsions to arrests, it seems that life for my cousins has been an endless cycle rooted in inequality. This was my first lesson in what I would soon learn to be social determinants of health. 

Shortly thereafter, the pressures of high school guidance counselors and college visits prompted me to seriously consider my future career goals. Being one of the few POC at my high school during polarizing political elections aided in this process. When Obamacare and “socialized medicine” were being debated, I was stunned by the complexity and controversy associated with healthcare in our country and knew it was a sector I wanted to learn more about. I also quickly learned individual biases my peers held towards immigrants like my mother and minorities like myself. When a peer approached me in the hallway and told me to “go back where I came from” I had never felt so helpless and ashamed of who I was. It was a feeling I swore I would never let anyone feel and made me realize I wanted a career where I could be a voice for people who felt they did not belong. 

I entered Northeastern with the hope of one day working in Public Health, uplifting the voices of people falling through our system’s cracks. I chose Health Sciences as a major because it seemed like the perfect mix of science--which I already enjoyed--and public health, my newfound interest. Studying healthcare systems abroad, I learned how differently medicine was provided on a structural level and observed the central role physicians played across every system of health. I learned when conducting public health research, there is only so much a role in public health could allow due to community-level and structural goals of change, but I found fulfillment in working with minority, low-income populations.

My clinical co-op taught me how much I enjoy the intimacy of patient care and interpersonal interaction, something that was missing from my public health experiences. The COVID-19 pandemic could have halted this experience, however, it ended up serving as a defining period of growth and the final deciding factor in my pursuit of a career in medicine. My fellow co-ops all elected to return home, leaving me as the only student co-op in the hospital. The idea of returning home was tempting with my family being over 1400 miles away and the risk of infection given my commute and work, however, I knew it was a decision I could have never made. The hospital was already facing staff shortages and it was a time healthcare workers were needed most. During this time, I was the only person patients would see with some doctors electing virtual appointments and the hospital enforcing a strict, but necessary, no visitor policy. I felt a sense of obligation to assuage patients fears as best I could and help patients who rely on interpreters or family members to attend their visits. Whether it was printing out directions for a patient to get home or color coding patients individual medication lists, I did anything I could to make their days easier to get through. It helped to speak with patients and hear their different stories, but I felt a familiar feeling of helplessness watching patients receive disappointing prognoses alone or listening to patients speak about family members they had lost. The best comfort I could offer was the simplicity of listening and sharing my own similar experiences as a relief. 

I watched as physicians were able to put patients’ worries to ease with their own expertise and experiences. I realized how physicians were put in a position where they not only support patients who are in their most helpless state, but can offer treatment and solutions. This grave responsibility and unspoken duty physicians have to advocate for their patients was what I had been searching for in a profession and what drives my call to pursue medicine. Though I find purpose in medicine, I know I will be a great physician because I have found my passion in people.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I never felt fully accepted by my‚Äô Arkansan family and the political discourse that occurred over the past 8 years only exacerbated our differences. Attending college in Boston but coming ‚Äúhome‚Äù to Arkansas has given me a unique perspective and the space to process my family‚Äô situation in a new light. I‚Äôve realized how vulnerable rural communities are and the effects their abandonment in policy, education and healthcare has had on my family. I realize they, along with many rural communities, reject ideas of ‚Äúprogression‚Äù and technology because of the negative impact manufacturing had on the agricultural industry and farms in their region. I no longer harbor any resentment towards my family, but  instead want to advocate for them and rural communities as a whole in my future medical career. I think we all bring a particular lens to the world and I have learned that being able to understand others' experiences through their own lens is how we foster honest, human connection and change.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: My experience as a DREAM mentor gave me the opportunity to grow alongside my mentee Jojo for four years. I was 19 and Jojo was 11 when we first met. We were both navigating a new school year, I was beginning my sophomore year and Jojo had just started middle school‚Äì it‚Äôs hard to believe I‚Äôve now seen her through her first year of high school. Jojo was the oldest kid in the program and with her previous mentor graduating, she was certain it would be her last year attending DREAM with her baby cousins. From making pancakes in my first apartment to conquering Jojo's fear of ice skating, I made sure our time in DREAM was anything but boring. Talking Jojo through her first breakup and, later on this year, being one of the first people she came out to made me proud of the friendship we have built. We have both grown into people our younger selves would be proud of and we have fostered a relationship that will remain past either of our ‚Äúgraduate‚Äù statuses in DREAM. _x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact: While many saw the COVID-19 pandemic as an obstacle, I saw it as a pivotal learning experience in my journey to medicine. Opting to stay in Boston and work throughout the Spring of 2020, instilled an unwavering feeling of confidence and trust in myself. The responsibilities that come with being a physician can be a heavy burden to bear and individual choices affect the care one provides. I have proven to myself that even in unprecedented times, I‚Äôm willing and able to make the right call- not for myself, but for others. Working full-time with no family or friends a close geographic proximity, was not an easy feat. Like many others, I struggled mentally and emotionally. I was just twenty years old and very scared at the ambiguity of what the future held and when I‚Äôd be able to see my family next. However, beginning my medical career in this chaotic time prepared me for the volatile nature of medicine and honed skills necessary for me to adapt in a constantly changing world.

Under_School: The Ohio State University Main Campus
personal_statement:
“Grrr crsshh PLOP,” roared the ice machine at the Cancer Treatment Center of America, where I was a high school volunteer tasked with delivering ice and water to patients. As I made my way to the next room, I bumped into the oncologist, who notified me that the patient had just received difficult news: Her cancer had metastasized. I entered the room and immediately noticed the patient’s facial expressions were overwhelmingly somber as she grappled with her dismal prognosis. She asked me to sit with her and, to my surprise, reached out for me to hold her hand. As she began to weep, I realized that being a physician required much more than providing patients with a diagnosis and treatment plan. Volunteering in oncology showed me that physicians hold an inherent duty to not only heal the body, but also the human spirit. Working alongside oncologists, I saw how doctors can forge meaningful and trusting relationships that empower them to support and comfort patients facing emotional hardships. I am inspired by physicians’ dedication to constantly adapt and be keenly aware of each patient’s disposition. In turn, I learned how this awareness also allows physicians to assist patients in different facets of their life that cannot be measured by medical devices. This powerful realization shifted my understanding of what it means to heal, motivating me to pursue a career in medicine and to one day support patients in body, mind and soul.

Throughout my clinical experiences, I have seen how physicians can form stronger relationships with their patients when they are able to break through barriers. As an undergraduate student, I volunteered at Riverside Methodist Hospital, where I was eager to learn and use American Sign Language (ASL) to better connect with deaf patients. During one of my shifts, I noticed the nursing staff hastily searching for an interpreter to aid in discharging a deaf patient, Phoebe. I assured the nurses that communication would not be a problem and headed to Phoebe's room. When I introduced myself in ASL, her eyes widened and lit up as she signed back, “I can’t believe you can chat with me!” Conversing with Phoebe illustrated to me how daunting accessing healthcare is for individuals facing various obstacles to their care, such as language barriers, mental disabilities or financial constraints. I came to understand that when physicians and healthcare teams take steps to minimize these hindrances to care, they enhance their ability to truly care for each patients’ individual needs. In cultivating a sincere human connection with Phoebe, my contributions allowed her to feel better supported and ensured she had a positive healthcare experience. Being there for patients like Phoebe taught me to better empathize with patients and how to identify individual circumstances which may impact their ability to receive care and manage medical problems.

After graduating, I moved back home to Illinois, enthused to explore the challenges confronting urban communities and to further grasp how impediments to healthcare affect health outcomes. To this end, I began volunteering with Old Irving Park Community Clinic, which serves the uninsured. When the clinic faced a large patient volume and a shortage of staff, I was quickly trained on how to administer retinal exams, take blood pressures and place leads for EKGs. While taking a patient’s vitals, I was shocked to hear this was the first time he had seen a healthcare provider in six years. He explained that losing his insurance caused an extensive lapse in his medical care, ultimately preventing proper management of his chronic hypertension and diabetes. Assisting the day-to-day operations of the clinic, I saw how physicians can fill the void caused by these systemic factors, such as lack of insurance coverage, that contribute to patients feeling isolated in navigating their medical concerns. Doctors at the clinic taught me the virtue of collaborating with community initiatives to mitigate deficiencies in healthcare access and improving the health of both the individual and community at large. I was moved that this work was capable of changing the health trajectory for many patients, an impact that inspires me to specifically serve and support these populations in my future medical practice.

From ice-water volunteering to serving the uninsured, I have come to appreciate the evolving nature of practicing medicine to best accommodate patients’ unique healthcare situations. My experiences have proven to me the value of constructing strong relationships with patients, the importance of which is only amplified for individuals facing barriers in their care. Throughout my journey to medicine, I have witnessed firsthand the shortcomings of healthcare access for disadvantaged populations. Working alongside healthcare providers and mentors who selflessly address the needs of the community, I am motivated to face this challenge and provide care for those who need it most by joining the next generation of physicians. Moments of vulnerability shared with cancer patients and laughing with deaf patients have prepared me to serve with an open heart and mind. I am impassioned to uphold this ethos in my medical training and practice.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I had the privilege of being accepted to the Global Leadership Initiative (GLI) at Ohio State, an organization of student leaders from domestic and international backgrounds. In GLI, we designed community outreach projects to assist underserved populations in Columbus. Since my project group was composed of students from diverse backgrounds, cultural exchange was important for us to learn to work as a team. Discussing our favorite foods, art and the differences between Asia, Europe and the United States, we came to better understand and appreciate one another. Interacting with students from backgrounds different than my own, I came to realize that our shared values connected us more than our individual differences. GLI helped broaden my worldview and has shown me that genuine collaboration is possible when people from various backgrounds respect their shared experiences. Working with peers from different walks of life has built my confidence in communicating and connecting with others.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Early on in my undergraduate career, I became aware of the large presence of sexual assault and abuse on campus. I joined a student organization, The Unmasked Movement, to bring awareness to the different facets of sexual violence and its increasing prevalence within the lives of my campus community. My work with victims of sexual abuse has opened my eyes to how individuals from different cultures experience and cope with sexual violence and trauma in varying ways. As a result, I have grown in my ability to effectively communicate with individuals facing difficult situations. Seeing how individuals are able to rebuild their confidence and exert greater control over their lives, I have found tremendous fulfillment in supporting others. Having seen the positive outcomes which are possible when disadvantaged individuals are provided with resources that meet their specific needs, I am motivated to continue engaging in social justice work alongside my medical training.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
When my university shifted to online learning at the onset of the pandemic, I moved home and I forfeited the healthcare volunteering positions which were vital to my preparation for medical school. My involvement in clinical research projects was also terminated as the lab halted all in-person activities._x000D_
_x000D_
Living at home in a medically-underserved area, I was eager to help address the needs of those negatively impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. I began volunteering at Old Irving Park Community Clinic (OIPCC) to help support the uninsured populations of Chicago. OIPCC‚Äôs patients harbored distrust in healthcare systems and were hesitant to receive vaccinations against COVID-19. By engaging in patient education, our clinic helped address vaccine misinformation. Despite disruptions in my education plans and extracurricular involvement, I felt proud to contribute to the pandemic response and to learn more about public health measures that increased the health and wellness of my community.

personal_statement:
My mind raced as I eagerly waited in the scrub room, peering through the window to the OR. The room was meticulously organized; tools rested on sterile trays, nearly every surface was engulfed in blue, and the operating table bathed under hanging lights. Once inside, my heartbeat quickened as I looked at the drapes, knowing beneath them lay a patient from my Prosthetics and Orthotics clinical rotation. A transtibial amputation was about to unfold before my eyes. The surgeon called for his scalpel, and the following moments unveiled my purpose: to become a physician. In the OR, I discovered a career that years of my life had been leading me to.

My journey to medicine began on a late summer morning in 2007. My mother and I frantically left our house for the local hospital where my father had been admitted the previous night for chest pain. His condition worsened, and when we arrived at his room, the curtain was drawn, but I could see my father’s feet, stiff at the edge of the bed. Unbeknownst to us, my father’s cancer had returned after years of remission. The tumor in his pericardium stopped his heart. 

My life forever changed at just 13 years old. At an age where a boy looks to his father for direction, mine was taken away in a heartbeat. I yearned to understand how a mass that was so small could affect my family in such a large way. In my free time outside of sports and school, I found myself curled up at my family’s computer, learning about the inner workings of organ systems. I was fascinated by life’s fragility and the human body’s complexity.

After the devastating loss of my father, I began volunteering at City of Hope. I spent my school nights with patients receiving chemotherapy. Sometimes we played cards, while other times, I held their hands and listened to their stories. I saw my father’s reflection in these patients facing the same life-threatening illness. I watched the patients’ care teams quietly and efficiently move around the bulky recliners, adjusting IVs and trying to make each patient feel comfortable despite the heaviness of the room. I contemplated what greater impact I could have in the lives of others when they are most vulnerable.

A few years later, my mother shattered several of her lumbar vertebrae. Her treatment exposed me to the field of Prosthetics and Orthotics (P & O), and I pursued my Master’s in this field, believing that P & O would fulfill my desire to use healthcare as a means to affect the lives of others in a significant way. I thought I had found my calling, but I knew something was missing when I observed that transtibial amputation during my P & O rotation. Witnessing the surgeon cut, cauterize, resect, and sew was an awe-inspiring form of art that left me breathless as the surgeon led the team in their common goal for the patient. In a small way, watching the surgeon work with tools reminded me of precious moments spent with my father, a skilled craftsman who taught me how to use tools to breathe new life into something. This surgery opened my eyes to the breadth of procedural possibilities that are exclusive to a physician. At that moment, I realized what had been missing in my career choice.

I became fixated on medicine and soaked up every exposure to this field presented during my Master’s. On the first day of my cadaver lab elective, I brimmed with anticipation as I held the forceps in my shaking hands, ready to learn more about the structures I saw in surgery. I felt like that 13-year-old boy again, fascinated by the human body, and I daydreamed about a life where I could directly impact these systems as a physician. My curiosity pushed me to ask questions beyond the scope of P & O. I sought answers by attending conferences and symposiums, and reached out to the physicians who participated. After graduation, I shadowed several specialists to gain insight into the daily realities of being a physician. The ability to diagnose patients and use numerous medical modalities was riveting and solidified my choice of medicine. 

Today, I am a clinical assistant and watch our physicians effectively diagnose and treat hundreds of patients. One patient, “Max,” had spent years searching for answers regarding his debilitating back pain. A physician in our office diagnosed his condition and provided treatment for more than a year. Each time we saw Max, he thanked our physician for improving his quality of life. In encounters like this, I am reminded that humanity is one of the most beautiful aspects of medicine; to recognize someone’s suffering and do everything within your power to help them overcome it. While I am proud to support patients as a clinical assistant, I continually aspire to wear and walk in the shoes of a physician, utilizing a wealth of knowledge and expertise to give patients hope. I feel closer than ever to the life I have been dreaming of.

While my journey toward medicine was untraditional, I have confirmed that being a physician is my true calling. As I look toward my future, I believe medicine is the only path for me. I have found not only my passion, but also my purpose.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Working with individuals that have mental and physical disabilities through Outdoors For All is one experience that has broadened my worldview. Throughout my time volunteering with this organization, I have seen how individuals with disabilities are traditionally excluded from everyday activities, including outdoor recreation. It has been rewarding to bond with participants over our love of the outdoors. I relish seeing the joy on participants' faces as we spend the day on the mountain together._x000D_
_x000D_
This experience has given me a greater perspective on my life, helped me better understand the differences of others in my community, and taught me how to address individuals with disabilities without stigma. This experience has also taught me the importance of prioritizing inclusion and embracing the uniqueness of those around us. I want to continue participating in programs supporting this population as a medical student and physician.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Throughout my life, I have had several experiences where I was able to impact communities in need by working to mitigate determinants of health. I traveled to Mexico to help deliver orthotic care to over 100 underserved children with disabilities to increase their activity and participation. During my Master‚Äôs, my classmates and I created adaptive exercise clinics for individuals with physical disabilities to learn workout techniques and increase their activity. Currently, I volunteer with Outdoors For All to help youth with physical and mental disabilities enjoy outdoor sports. I also work with Solid Ground to help provide produce to impoverished communities and those in food deserts. These various experiences have been rewarding and shown me tangible ways I can positively impact the lives of those in my community. I look forward to serving those living in Chicago‚Äôs west side and learning strategies to mitigate the determinants of health for these neighborhoods.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I had a job as a personal trainer in March 2020 and the inability to work for several months significantly impacted the savings I hoped to have for my medical school applications and education. At the time, I was also shadowing several physicians to gain insight into medicine, which I could not do after the pandemic began. My connections with these physicians resulted in me accepting a position as a clinical assistant at a physiatry practice in August 2020. Working in this position has given me a deeper understanding of medicine and reaffirmed my desire to become a physician. While this was a stressful period, it taught me how to be resourceful and patient.

personal_statement:
As I held the patient’s hand during her chemotherapy session, a weak smile broke through her weary face. In spite of all she was facing, her eyes lit up as she shared the events of her son’s baseball game the night before. Of all the lessons from my volunteering in the St. Barnabas Oncology Wing during high school, the way patients' faces brightened when they spoke about their families remains etched in my memory. The experience of working with patients at their most vulnerable time, as well as learning about the etiology and treatment of various forms of cancer, formed an important foundation for me on my path to medicine.
In college, I continued to explore the medical field by working at the Miller Research Lab, which studies neurodegenerative diseases. I assisted in a project centered on reversing harmful tau isoform ratios in astrocytes, a common phenomenon in illnesses like CTE and dementia. The goal of this research was to develop approaches for new therapeutics for these conditions. Being part of a team focused on this cutting-edge research that will directly impact so many individuals held personal significance because of my own concussion and 11-month recovery. Through this work, I grew in my understanding of astrocyte function and its role in maintaining normal brain function, learning how traumatic injuries like concussions can create degenerative protein ratios as well as the hopeful prospects for treatments in the future. As our research successfully yielded a new path for therapeutics, I saw how developing new treatment approaches could change patient protocols and improve medical care. This observation led to my realization that I wanted to spend my career at the forefront of these medical advances, applying them in a clinical setting.
I entered that clinical environment when I joined Total Access Urgent Care (TAUC) as a scribe and technician. In these roles, I have worked with patients of various backgrounds, from underprivileged communities of inner St. Louis to rural towns far west of the city. In one of our downtown clinics, a new patient presented with extreme thirst, confusion, and severe, diffuse abdominal pain. As I palpated for a vein hiding deep in her arm, I asked if she was okay. As our eyes met, she weepingly opened up about her mother’s passing a few weeks prior and how she was drowning in stress and grief. Most relevant to her eventual diagnosis, though, was a fleeting reference to a condition she had not indicated on her intake forms: diabetes. With the IV in place, I asked to smell her breath, testing a theory I formed from that revelation. Struck by the fruity smell of ketones and guided by both the memories of organic chemistry as well as my understanding of diabetes, the picture started to come into focus. I shared this information with Dr. Hayden, hoping the patient’s diabetes and fruity breath would help solve the mystery of her condition. 
I saw the gears churning in Dr. Hayden’s head as she considered the patient’s presentation with this new information before conducting her exam. Scribing this interaction, I was struck by how Dr. Hayden compassionately placed a hand on the patient’s arm, questioning her further to better understand the patient’s medical history and the events preceding the onset of her symptoms. Dr. Hayden, with the lab results in hand, concluded that through a combination of stress and forgetting to take her medications, the patient entered diabetic ketoacidosis. As she shared these findings with the patient, explaining the treatment plan to rehydrate and rebalance her electrolytes with IV fluids, it was evident that Dr. Hayden reached this diagnosis not only through the clinical presentation and lab work but also through the patient’s personal story. Through this experience, I saw firsthand the impact of a physician’s combining of clues from the patient with medical and clinical training to solve problems and provide quality medical care. 
My experiences supporting patients with cancer, participating in cutting-edge research, and serving at various clinics have both reaffirmed my commitment to medicine and provided me with a deeper understanding of the field. As someone who enjoys solving puzzles, I have come to realize that listening to the patient’s story and taking their circumstances into consideration are the framework for quality medical care. Only when the borders are laid out through the patient's history can doctors best deploy advancements in science and complete the full picture of the patient’s condition. My path to medicine has shown me the importance and complexity of a physician's job in drawing on all the tools available, not only science and experience but also compassion and understanding, to achieve an accurate diagnosis and treatment for a patient. This perspective has become the foundation of my commitment to medicine and will continue to shape my path forward.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
By the time we spoke about his depression, my brother had grown increasingly short-tempered and expressed feelings of inadequacy. Whether through game nights or dinners, our family life had become stressful as TJ‚Äôs behavior changed. Speaking openly, TJ shared the challenges in his life and how his outlook on the world always seemed negatively tainted, a viewpoint that was foreign to me.
