In return, I shared how I had sought therapy in high school to empower myself against my anxiety and encouraged TJ to do the same._x000D_
His choice to seek treatment after our talk was a major step for him and our family, demonstrating the impact of supporting someone during personal turmoil. Supporting TJ in his struggles with mental health has shown me that even when I do not completely grasp one‚Äôs point of view, I should always be respectful of their perspective. Being cognizant of these differences and empowering others to advocate for themselves have become the cornerstones of how I view diversity.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Starting my clinical experiences at Total Access Urgent Care (TAUC) in the middle of the pandemic, I gained an understanding of the social problems affecting access to healthcare for many patients. I distinctly recall the fear in one uninsured COVID patient‚Äôs voice as she relayed how she could not afford the medications for her diabetes or hypertension since the closure of her low-income neighborhood clinic, essentially cutting off her lifeline. She could only afford a visit to TAUC due to the CARES Act, which was unsustainable to manage these chronic conditions. Recognizing how the patient was being forced to leverage her financial well-being against her health, I reached out to other community clinics in hopes of securing her access to affordable long-term care. With the referral in hand, the patient left TAUC not only with a better understanding of how to manage her COVID symptoms but also with the means to take back her agency over her health.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
I began my undergraduate career planning to graduate a semester early. After experiencing a full semester of virtual learning and upon being notified that my study abroad program had been canceled, I instead pivoted to take a leave of absence in the spring of my junior year. Seizing the opportunity to enter the healthcare field at a critical juncture, I joined Total Access Urgent Care (TAUC) as a full-time technician and scribe in January 2021. I continued these roles at TAUC throughout my senior year in a part-time capacity, working through both the Delta and Omicron waves, before taking on additional responsibilities after graduating. _x000D_
With many of my volunteer engagements also suspended due to the pandemic, I joined 7 Cups, a crisis text hotline, to support individuals around the country facing especially challenging times. 7 Cups counselor training helped me acquire language and listening tools to support people in crisis through active listening and empathetic responses.

personal_statement:
One, two, three, four, five…counting to thirty never felt so arduous—the feeling of adrenaline surges and the pressure to perform builds. My heart is racing, and my stomach is turning. The trauma room was stale and cold, yet I worked up a sweat. My only priority was to manually keep her heart beating. With every chest compression, she thuds against the bed from the weight of my hands. Her skin becomes bright red from the friction. The nurse across from me analyzes my depth and rate of compressions. She begins to rectify my declining performance. I'm becoming increasingly tired and frustrated with myself, but I maintain my diligent efforts through her instruction. After the final "clear" was exclaimed, the nurse felt a pulse. At this exact moment, I was overwhelmed to witness the impact I could have on another person's life. This relief was temporary as the patient coded again after being transported to the ICU. The physician called the time of death. Walking through those emergency room doors, I never expected to be immediately thrown into such a critical situation during my EMT clinical rotation. I was captivated by the diverse range of emotions, compassion for others, and collaboration with my peers that this field provided. Although this was a routine heart attack for the staff, this experience significantly impacted my career ambitions, becoming the turning point in my dedication to medicine.
My introduction to medicine began as a child with severe asthma and numerous respiratory allergies. I frequently endured extreme exertion on my lungs as my bronchioles constricted. The lack of adequate oxygen would slowly cause me to panic, making me feel as if my life was fleeting. Praying to God, frightened that it may be my last day to spend with my family, we rushed to the hospital for steroids and albuterol treatments. These trips developed into a persistent routine until my asthma became manageable. At such an impressionable young age, physicians became my role models. Although my family deeply cared about my well-being, I saw doctors as my only hope to breathe again. Through their kind-hearted actions, I watched how they could turn my worst days into something tolerable. Being under their care helped me recognize the importance of this relationship and bolstered my desire to provide this for future patients, which ultimately led me to become an EMT.
Next, I found myself posted in an ambulance on the streets of Chicago. My partner and I got a call to transport a patient from the psych unit. The page contained the location, patient identifiers, and permission to use restraints if needed. Arriving at the hospital, nervous about what is to come, we approached the nurse's station. I noticed that security is nearby, but I'm hopeful this was unrelated to the situation. The nurse reiterated potential restraints. As my partner gathers paperwork, I cautiously approached the dimly lit room. The patient was lying in bed, silent upon my entry. The tension escalated until the moment we started conversing. From all the information leading up to this point, I expected him to be a violent, combative patient; however, there was no indication of such. The man I saw had only experienced a rough day. My partner walked in with the stretcher, restraints in hand, and two security guards. Shaking my head, no, we step out of the room. We left without restraints, explaining that I am comfortable being alone with the patient on our trip and do not want to exacerbate the circumstances. He was already there against his will, and I did not want to restrict him further. My partner trusted my plea. In the end, my patient and I had a mutually positive experience. I was confident that showing compassion was more effective than showing unnecessary alarm. Having this autonomy in choices and open communication with my partner, I treated the patient how they presented to me and not how others perceived them.
Wanting to pursue hands-on, procedural-based work, I eventually became a phlebotomist. One early morning, a mother came in with her four-year-old son. He was visibly pale, terrified, and gripping tightly onto his brown, stuffed bear. As they approached, the boy sprinted to the corner with his face towards the wall. After they had a brief bout, she decided to bring him back another day. Recognizing the patient was in an unfamiliar situation, I picked up his stuffed animal from the ground, got down to his level, and explained it to him. I asked if I could glance at his arms with my tourniquet. As he slowly got comfortable with me, I demonstrated what a vein was by having him feel its "bounce." Silently signaling to his mother to have a seat back in my phlebotomy chair, he abruptly followed. Within a minute, the procedure was done, the tests were drawn, and they were both pleased. I recalled the faith I had in my physicians as a kid, who eased the panic of my asthma attacks and wanted to do the same for this boy.
My passion for medicine is uniformly tied to my drive to help and serve others: dedicated to improving each of my patients’ lives. Medical school will give me the necessary knowledge and skills to achieve this goal. The moment I helped save another human being with my medical training solidified my pursuit of becoming a physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: While volunteering at Community Health, a non-profit organization located in West Town, Chicago, I worked closely with the Latinx and Polish communities. This clinic provided care to patients that had limited to no access to healthcare insurance due to their income or documentation status. Although they offered this service, it was severely limited: not offering surgical intervention and relying on volunteer medical students and physicians. On numerous occasions, I had to put myself into the perspective of my patients when it came to concerns about vaccinations. Over time, I could understand why they were reluctant, as many of them were undocumented citizens and mistrusted the government. Many of my attempts to reduce this hesitancy were futile and initially frustrated me. As I was vaccinated, my beliefs shifted from seeing this issue as an obstacle that I needed to rectify to respecting the patient‚Äôs autonomy in their choices and adapting to their concerns.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Becoming an Eagle Scout required a vast amount of community service to obtain: the greatest being a project entirely crafted by myself. This roughly 300-hour time commitment consisted of gathering donations and volunteers to paint curbs bright yellow throughout Schaumburg‚Äôs Public Works Department. Due to the previous lack of visibility at night, injuries and accidents frequently occurred. Although this may seem simple on paper, this project propelled me into a leadership role of over 25 individuals, dictating everyone‚Äôs responsibilities and retaining their focus on the end goal. Once we completed the monumental task at hand, I received periodic updates from the supervisors on the increased visibility. This project was completed seven years ago, but the effects can still be seen today. I am grateful for the opportunity to create such an impactful difference in the safety of my local government employees and for the experience it provided me through leading my peers.
7_-_COVID_Impact: At the start of the pandemic, I lived in the UIC dorms. After classes began to switch from in-person to online, they offered me a partial refund to move out. I decided to move back in with my parents because most in-person activities, such as the gym, research, and classes, were shut down. Now living over 50 miles away from Chicago in a rural community, the abrupt lifestyle change created numerous stressors. While transporting COVID-19 patients as an EMT, I contracted the virus and infected my family in April 2020. With the little public information, my family was terrified. My sister had just had her first baby and would not let us visit her if I continued to work there. With this complication and two-hour commute to the city, I left this employment. Relying strictly on wireless internet connectivity to my house, I could not attend zoom calls or stream lectures. This created complications with research and coursework, but I am eager to pursue these experiences while in medical school.

personal_statement:
I ran for student council president every year from 8th grade to high school graduation and repeatedly lost. Despite the recurrent blows to my morale, I continued to run year after year until, finally, I was elected my senior year. Holding that leadership position was important to me because I knew that I could be the problem solver my peers needed. They asked for non-uniform sweatshirts on Fridays, tampons in the restrooms, and I even remember promising my middle school peers soda at lunch. No matter how trivial the request, I wanted to provide for them. Even then I wanted to be the person that used my skills to benefit others.
This desire followed me to Cornell where I trained on their gymnastics team. There, I experienced a major shift in mindset about my sport. Instead of focusing on my own success, I was driven to help those around me to improve. I supported my teammates through the many challenges that came with being a gymnast; I gave advice about balancing the demands of school and gym, offered guidance regarding overcoming mental blocks, and simply listened when they needed to vent about the pressure of being a collegiate athlete. After being voted captain my senior year, I was eager to bring new ideas to the table, striving to help everyone work together for our collective success. As I watched my teammates reach their goals, I was once again reminded of the satisfaction that comes when helping others.
This same desire to provide leadership and support to others is what drives me to pursue a career in medicine. Being a physician would give me the opportunity to share my knowledge and experience for the benefit of others. During school breaks, I worked as a medical assistant at an OBGYN clinic. My work duties gave me clinical knowledge and showed me firsthand the impact that a doctor can have on people. I appreciated getting to interact personally with the patients, experience how the clinic runs, and see how even a routine gynecological exam can give peace of mind. I witnessed everything from young adults consulting on birth control to the joy of new mothers listening to their baby’s first heartbeat. To practice medicine, combining scientific knowledge with true compassion for others, would be a rare privilege and an honor I hope to experience. 
As an athlete in a physically demanding sport, I relate personally to the patient’s perspective of healthcare. Although gymnastics was tough on my body, sometimes leading to injury, the experience gave me an appreciation for the doctors who treated me. I was treated by doctors who used knowledge and experience to accurately diagnose my problems and recommend an effective plan of care leaving me reassured. Unfortunately, I have seen this special knowledge and experience used for both good and evil, as seen in the case of Dr. Larry Nassar in 2017. Larry Nassar was the USA Gymnastics team doctor for 20 years. Five years ago, he was exposed for sexually abusing gymnasts on the national team. He assaulted at least 265 young girls that came to him for help. This deeply affected me. Gymnastics was my sport. I understood the sense of vulnerability and the call to obedience that this sport demands. The way that this doctor took advantage of these young women disgusted me. I asked myself, “How could someone in a profession that requires compassion and care cause so much destruction and horror?” When this came out, it made me question the practice of medicine. I believed that doctors were fundamentally good, and that those who chose to pursue the profession did so because of their drive to help people. I have come to understand the responsibility that falls on the shoulders of physicians—a responsibility that unfortunately not everyone respects. Reflecting on this made me realize that the only thing I can do is uphold my own beliefs. I can listen patiently, assist responsibly, and care passionately for those in need. 
My mother has been a model in my life for the qualities I will emulate as a future physician. While working as a medical assistant, I have seen my mother at work as an OBGYN. She sees as many as 40 patients per day and she makes an effort to know details from each of their lives. As she listens with compassion to her patients, she gives them a voice and a safe space to open up. She provides support and encouragement as she treats each one with a personal touch. By striving to adopt her curious, caring, and empathetic qualities into my own life today, I am building a strong foundation for my future as a medical professional. 
In many ways, I am pursuing medicine for the same reason I wouldn’t give up as the 8th grader who wanted to be a leader and find ways to help her friends. As a student athlete, I have worked to develop a strong knowledge base aided by my grit and determination. At the same time, I strive to maintain high levels of compassion fueled by my desire to help others and make a difference in their lives. I have seen what a privilege it is to care for others and I know my experiences have prepared me to pursue the most fulfilling career I could imagine, being a physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
When a new genetics specialist joined our team I was excited to get to know him. Alejandro previously lived in Mexico and France, and told me this was his first time in the United States. I toured him around the medical center, explained our public transportation, and recommended some good restaurants that served authentic Mexican cuisine. After two weeks, Alejandro asked me to explain the U.S. tax system. I thought it was out of the blue, but then realized he probably received his first paycheck and had questions about filing it. At this moment I understood how difficult it must be to move to a new country. I explained what I knew about our tax system, and gave him additional resources to help._x000D_
After speaking with Alejandro, I better understood the cultural shock he was experiencing. Becoming more aware of cultural differences people face and how easily they could feel excluded or misunderstood, I feel compelled to make others feel welcomed and accepted regardless of their background.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
‚ÄúI get to choose?‚Äù Josh asks in disbelief as I offer him a Coke or Sprite. Josh is living on the streets of Houston and comes to the Emergency Aid Coalition daily to pick up his sack lunch. Volunteering at the EAC, I pass out lunches and get to know some of the people in my city experiencing homelessness. The lunches are often the same, and the people we serve accept them graciously. However, on this day I not only got to include a cold soda, but I was also able to give people like Josh a choice in what they wanted. Josh‚Äôs surprise to my question made me realize he doesn't usually get this opportunity. _x000D_
While at the EAC I formed relationships with other people in this community and learned specific things they needed or wanted. Wanda loved when I had sunglasses for her from our donation pile, while David appreciated when I included a bag of dog food for his chihuahua. This experience allowed me to impact people in my community and brighten their day in ways specific to each person.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
While the pandemic created tensions at home as everyone‚Äôs opinions on the restrictions differed, I also faced equally challenging issues as the Cornell Gymnastics team captain. Our season was canceled and practices were restricted. Because of this, we lacked the sense of drive that motivated our team for the past three years along with opportunities for team camaraderie and community outreach. To bridge this gap, I planned COVID safe activities like scavenger hunts and sought out outdoor volunteering opportunities. Connecting with the local YMCA, I planned events for us clearing and building up their wilderness trails. While this was nowhere near the amount of service we had done in the past, I was grateful for the chance to give back to my community. _x000D_
While COVID challenges are not unique to me, I know they uniquely shaped me and grew me into a stronger, more adaptable leader. However, the pandemic restrictions made it challenging to find opportunities to serve my community.

personal_statement:
I gazed up and caught her scared, sad eyes.

I looked back down at her mother, our patient, and readjusted my palms toward the center of her chest, while I continued firm and fast compressions. The crying and chaos were tuned out. I was focused. After several rounds of CPR, a pulse was detected, and our team lifted the patient off the kitchen floor and transported her from her secluded desert home to the closest hospital. Although the ambulance sped up, the sirens rang louder, and the prognosis grew dimmer, I held my own steady pace when operating the bag-valve mask. Out of the darkness, two headlights approached, inching ever closer to our rear bumper. We raced through dark, sandy roads, and once in the city, ran red lights and stop signs. Dangerously, the two headlights still followed behind us. I knew exactly who it was.

Moments after arrival at the ER, the elderly woman we treated was pronounced dead. For the first time, I lost a patient. I heard our paramedic reprimanding the patient’s daughter, “Never follow an ambulance so closely!” The daughter cried and ran outside with her young son clinging to her leg. I was in Israel volunteering as an EMT with Magen David Adom, Israel’s national ambulance. I was surrounded by strangers, hospital employees, and patients, who were all conversing in a language in which I had only basic proficiency. I followed my instincts and walked outside to our patient's daughter.

I faced her scared, sad eyes once again.

In Hebrew, I expressed my condolences. She corrected my grammatical errors, and asked me where I was from as she wiped away her tears and smiled. We spoke briefly, and she thanked me for traveling to Israel to volunteer. As we drove to headquarters, my partner told me he appreciated that I made sure our patient’s daughter was okay. He told me we were a good team and said I could work with him anytime. This was particularly meaningful as many paramedics did not have confidence in foreign volunteer technicians. For the remainder of the summer, he and I partnered together for nearly every shift.

Days later, short staffed, I was alone in the back of an ambulance monitoring a woman in labor. Upon noticing her contractions were becoming closer together and longer in duration, I alerted the paramedic who was driving. The ambulance immediately accelerated causing my notepad to fall underneath the stretcher and out of reach. After that, I recorded her contraction times on my glove for our report to the ER doctors. Miles away from the closest hospital, our patient was alone, in pain, and becoming anxious. She regained composure when I led her through breathing exercises. It was a long drive from her village to the closest ER, but we made it safely. Once we arrived, the patient requested that my partner and I stay with her, where we witnessed pure joy and the safe delivery of her child. I expected her family and friends to come rushing into the hospital at any moment, but nobody came. For this patient, no headlights followed the ambulance. 

After much self reflection, my experiences with these two particular patients have given me insight. I have learned that we cannot simply ignore the headlights that follow behind our patients. Our responsibility is both to the patient who lies directly before us as well as to those who may follow closely behind. Further, when there are no headlights that follow, establishing rapport and trust can go a long way.

This insight has helped me in my current position at the Hospital for Special Surgery where I serve as the lead research assistant coordinating a double blind Phase II clinical trial which is under FDA oversight. Here, we are investigating the safety and efficacy of off-label use of abaloparatide (a PTH receptor agonist) in patients undergoing spine fusion operations. Due to COVID-19 there was a strict no visitor policy at HSS. This left many of our participants alone before and after their complex operations. While I meticulously recorded medical histories, drew blood, obtained research documentation, and instructed patients how to self-inject the study drug, I also connected with patients in these moments right before entering the OR and after waking in the PACU. When returning for follow-up visits, many participants expressed their appreciation for my support during these moments.

I have been determined never to lose sight of the patient’s experience, whether I directly or indirectly interact with them. During the pandemic, I investigated how COVID-19 affected vulnerable populations. For this, I was awarded a Tufts Research Grant. My research, conducted with a pediatric radiologist at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, investigated the clinical and imaging experience with COVID-19 in unvaccinated children with cancer. While retrospectively analyzing large bodies of data to uncover pertinent patterns, I never forgot the patients and their families who lived beyond my computer screen. 

I plan to forge a career in medicine as it uniquely combines my passion for science with my natural ability for compassion.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
The clinical trial I coordinate requires preoperative collection of several tubes of blood for diagnostic testing. During a recruitment conversation, a patient explained she was concerned about providing blood. Specifically, she was concerned that any additional preoperative blood loss would increase her risk of needing a blood transfusion, which as a Jehovah‚Äôs Witness, she could not accept. However, she also explained that she was eager to enroll in the trial as it might help her recovery._x000D_
_x000D_
I advocated for our patient by speaking with both her surgeon and my principal investigator about our patient‚Äôs concerns. The blood draw was deemed safe, and I relayed this information to our patient. Ultimately, the patient felt comfortable enrolling and was thankful that I understood her concerns and respected her religious beliefs. I learned firsthand how advocacy, understanding, and connection with patients of all backgrounds are essential pillars in providing the best clinical care.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
Through my work as a research coordinator at Hospital for Special Surgery (HSS), I have experienced how healthcare providers can be catalysts of change for at-risk patients and communities._x000D_
_x000D_
I have been able to help several candidates participate in our clinical trial who otherwise might not have been able to enroll due to their social and/or financial situations. For example, at first, one patient explained to me that she would be unable to participate as she could not afford to take off the extra days from work and pay for transportation for the extra research follow-up visits. I worked with my team to arrange for transportation and scheduled meetings at different times from our usual schedule to accommodate the patient._x000D_
_x000D_
In the future, I would create a practice that considers the obstacles patients face, such as the inability to take off from work, lack of child care during the day, and cost of transportation.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
I had plans to conduct research with Dr. David Kaplan at Tufts University beginning in the summer of 2020 and throughout my senior year. When pandemic restrictions prevented our plans, I immediately searched for opportunities to contribute to our understanding of COVID-19._x000D_
_x000D_
I contacted Dr. Gerald Behr, a pediatric radiologist at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, who I had previously shadowed. We brainstormed over Zoom, and soon thereafter, I applied for and was awarded the Tufts University 2020 COVID-19 Research Response Grant. We focused on the experience of children with cancer diagnoses and COVID-19. This work was recently published in the Journal of Clinical Imaging._x000D_
_x000D_
Additionally, during the pandemic, I continued my service as an EMT with the Tufts University Emergency Medical Service. With each dispatch, I felt the tangible impact of my service and how it directly benefited others in times of severe stress on the healthcare system.

Under_School: The Ohio State University Main Campus
personal_statement:
Over time, different experiences have affirmed my strong desire to become a physician.


As the daughter of a domestic abuse counselor and a primary care physician who serves veterans, I grew up immersed in discussions about physical and mental healthcare issues. At 16, I was intrigued by dinner table conversations about the imploding need for greater access to preventive services and streamlined care for all. Especially motivated to find ways to reverse negative health trends attributed to the adoption of riskier behaviors and a lack of social support, I chose to study public health in college. At 21, the lessons I learned in class about enabling individual growth and building sustainable communities further spurred my passion to work at reducing disparate health outcomes as a physician myself one day. At 23, with direct patient care experience under my belt, my drive to become a doctor has been solidified.


While my upbringing coupled with my innate interests in biology and social sciences ignited my passion to pursue this path early on, many subsequent influences and experiences compel me to push through the long and challenging journey it takes to be a physician.


As an undergraduate eager to get involved, I volunteered with Universal Health Aid: Columbus, a grassroots organization dedicated to improving community health through education and preventive medicine. Elected to the executive board, I helped plan and run our annual health screening. This multi-week event grants medically underserved residents access to a diverse set of health care providers and public health resources free of charge. To me, the most meaningful part was assisting patients at the informational booths. By using simple terminology, hand gestures, and even basic Spanish to communicate effectively, I saw the empowered look on their faces when I linked them to the resources they needed. Because medical information can be ambiguous and difficult to process, I aspire to be a doctor who not only treats disease and illness but also facilitates patients’ efforts to manage their own health and well-being.


Upon graduation, I joined the National Health Corps to complete a public health service year. Assigned to Pittsburgh Mercy Family Health Center, a clinic that serves a large and diverse population, I have endless opportunities to learn from the highly skilled and dedicated team of providers as well as from the frequent and direct patient contact I have myself.


One evening while shadowing, a patient presented with an extremely infected forearm due to IV drug use. I assisted the family medicine doctor drain the abscess while engaging the patient in a discussion about his decision to wait days before seeking help. Visibly distraught, the patient admitted to feeling ashamed about his relapse and fearful of being discharged from his abstinence-based supportive housing. Using harm reduction principles and considering how the patient’s built environment impacted his well-being, the doctor strategized a treatment plan with him, relieved his anxiety, and earned his trust. As a result, this high-risk patient left the clinic healthier and agreed to return for a follow-up appointment. Inspired by this successful model, I too strive to practice holistic and patient-centered care.


As Pittsburgh Mercy is generally hectic, rushing from patient to patient ready to zip through the food insecurity screening is normal for me. One day, however, as I entered exam room 3, the apprehensive look on the young woman’s face stunned me. Seeing how nervous she was, I slowed down a bit and commented on the cute dog pictured on her phone case. She immediately began to feel more comfortable as she told me all about “Rudy.” Soon, intimate details about her unsafe and inadequate housing situation, financial struggles, and difficulty acquiring SNAP benefits came pouring out too. I listened without judgment and tried to maintain eye contact while finishing her intake. Having determined that she lived in a food insecure household, I explained how the health center’s food pantry works and arranged groceries for her to take home. As her initially shy smile grew wider, I saw the immeasurable value of my empathy, compassion, and patience and how they can change one’s entire demeanor. Encounters like this motivate me to provide a safe space for others to speak and to be heard, and to be a doctor who meets patients where they are.


Just as my decision to pursue medicine is catalyzed by a unique combination of influences, the physician I plan to be is the sum of who I am plus my experiences and deeply ingrained commitment to improving public health. Whether at the dinner table, volunteering at health fairs, or assisting patients in examination rooms, I have reaffirmed that becoming a doctor is the best path for me. The medical profession will allow me to deliver comprehensive care to individuals and communities while also working to promote health equity. For me, knowledge without action is not enough, which is “Why” I am confidently dedicating myself to building a career as a physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Since graduating from Ohio State, I have been serving with the National Health Corps (AmeriCorps) at a community health center in the heart of Pittsburgh. In this role, I have extensive interaction with patients who have low income, disabilities, are experiencing homelessness, and/or are severely mentally ill. Serving in this environment has shown me how complex and multifaceted health really is and that many patients have additional unexpressed needs on top of their presenting symptoms. As a result, I have learned to not make assumptions. Instead, I always ask questions to get a better understanding of the barriers people face in accessing care and try to think outside the box when serving patients with financial, transportation, housing, and other concerns. I have also learned that health care must be individualized, broad-minded, and aimed at treating the individuals who struggle to independently navigate the system.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
Throughout college, I volunteered with a student organization called Universal Health Aid: Columbus. As an elected executive board member, I helped organize the annual free health screenings that brought primary care providers, mental health counselors, and local public health organizations to the medically underserved and under-resourced Hilltop neighborhood. As our main goal was to provide holistic care, we also distributed hygiene kits and collaborated with another student organization, Best Food Forward, to provide fresh meals to community members who attended our screenings._x000D_
 _x000D_
While there is still a tremendous amount of work left to be done, our sustained efforts in the Hilltop community increased access to essential health services and education. Additionally, by connecting individuals to the community resources and services they needed to live healthier lives, we ensured that they would continue to be cared for long after our screenings ended.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
When international travel bans prevented me from going to the Israel-Gaza Strip region to complete EMT training and learn about disaster relief efforts for my senior capstone project, I switched gears and found a position with the Ohio Domestic Violence Network (ODVN) instead. _x000D_
_x000D_
During my internship, I quickly grew to understand that domestic violence touches every corner of our society and that COVID-19 has only exacerbated the problems survivors face. As is the case with many competing health crises, vulnerable populations are disproportionately affected. _x000D_
_x000D_
Ultimately, COVID-19 and my time with ODVN furthered my passion to be a doctor. At a time when the need for quality health care is peaking, a career as a physician will allow me to provide care to survivors and vulnerable populations of all kinds on a much deeper level. I look forward to attending medical school with a trauma-informed lens and learning to treat the evolving clinical manifestations of coexisting health issues.

Under_School: California Polytechnic State University-San Luis Obispo
personal_statement:
“Does your pain practice offer stellate ganglion nerve blocks?” a prospective patient queried when I answered the phone. Sounding frustrated and weary, she explained she was hoping for relief from long COVID symptoms. She had exhausted all of her options and a member of her long COVID Facebook support group reported success with this procedure. For over a year, she had been experiencing bitter taste, a muted sense of smell, and heightened anxiety. Today, this burden seemed especially heavy. I reassured her we would do everything we could to help and made her an appointment for the nerve block.  As I listened to the patient share her story on the phone, I felt heartbroken because I could empathize with health struggles that infringe on everyday life.

Beginning my senior year of high school, I struggled with some residual symptoms of Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). During this time, my aspirations to become a physician developed. AP Biology was fascinating; the intricacies of science enthralled me. I believed research-based medicine could truly help people. And yet, all doctors could ambiguously offer me was that EBV sometimes persists for unknown reasons. Similarly to my patient, I was discouraged. Did medicine actually have answers? I needed to reconcile medicine’s limitations with the power physicians wield as creative advocates on the cutting-edge of science. Not only did I need a provider to listen and validate my experiences, I wanted someone who would persevere and partner with me to pursue novel solutions to real conditions. I vowed to become exactly that.

I initially met this patient in person when she returned to our office for her second cervical nerve block. I enthusiastically inquired about the results of her first block, in hopes that she found relief. She excitedly reported how much it alleviated the symptoms that she had been experiencing since contracting COVID. She enjoyed food again and her anxiety and panic had lessened. She was thrilled, and so was I. The doctor discussed how cervical sympathetic nerve blocks usually treat chronic pain related to postherpetic neuralgia, however he was happy to try it. That day, I assisted the doctor in performing a fifteen minute procedure that drastically improved her quality of life.

The cervical nerve blocks helped this patient. Even if it had not been successful, I was committed to being there in support. Working as a medical assistant at a pain specialist this past year has given me many opportunities to interact directly with patients in chronic pain.  I heard countless patients express feelings of exasperation and isolation. The physician I work alongside often mentions a phrase he learned from his mentor: “If you listen to the patient long enough, they’ll tell you their diagnosis.” I would never presume to perfectly understand someone else’s struggle, but my own experiences gifted me a uniquely compassionate perspective.

The importance of improving medicine through research first became tangible to me after my immunology professor Dr. Martinez invited me to work in the COVID testing lab at Cal Poly. I helped develop the saliva-based testing program and transitioned all student testing from nasal swabs to saliva. We later progressed to a paper-based microfluidic analytical device that was more accurate and enabled us to detect positive results faster. We processed 4,000 tests together every day with the shared ownership of keeping our Cal Poly family safe. Medicine does not have all the answers, but my experiences showed me how forward progress positively impacts the health of real people in my community.

With a foundation of empathy for patients and a personal commitment to continuous learning, I realized another element is equally crucial in medicine. As a general biology and chemistry study session leader in college, I explained concepts to students and broke down scientific principles into manageable parcels. If I did not know the answer to something, I would find it. This was my first experience making science accessible and understandable. As I began working as a medical assistant, I realized how this valuable skill alleviates patients' worries. Every day, I observe a physician illustrate the principle of simplifying complicated procedures using models and diagrams. My position as a study session leader equipped students with knowledge and eased fears about exams; the role of a physician interprets scientific complexities and empowers patients to understand their health.

To borrow a compelling idea from one of my favorite memoirs, "Between Two Kingdoms," my goal is to “find resonance in someone’s story without reducing [our] suffering to sameness.” My own health challenges clarified my major strengths. I am there to listen with patience, engage with grace, and help to the best of my ability. As others have done for me, I will listen compassionately with unique insight into the patient experience. I have learned through my mentors in medicine that I will not be able to perfectly fix all my patient’s problems. However, I vow to do my best and see patients as whole individuals. I am responsible for ensuring my patients feel heard, understood, and confident knowing I am committed to partner with them to meaningfully improve their lives.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: In college, I volunteered in the emergency room of a local hospital. Initially an uncomfortable volunteer standing in the corner, I started to carve out moments of connection and engage in conversation. I learned that many patients came to the ER because they had no other option. I recognized an underserved population right in front of me in my own college town. The problems we saw were as diverse as the community we served: a grandparent who fell, an inmate at the local men‚Äôs prison, a person who was uninsured and unhoused. I listened to each story, resisting assumptions to provide compassionate care. The ER is a busy hub where people from every walk of life converge for a few hours to receive medical intervention. Physicians have the unique ability to meet people wherever they are today and partner with them to achieve a healthier future. Every week for three years, I learned how to respect everyone‚Äôs experiences and provide equitable care to all.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Growing up in San Diego, I lived a mere 45 minutes from the US-Mexico border. Twice a year, my family partnered with a local organization in Tijuana to build two-room homes. By providing safe housing, the organization‚Äôs goal was to keep families together and give children better access to education. These moments of giving back to the community right across the border formed my childhood. As my family worked alongside families both similar and different from ours, I developed an acute awareness of my own privileges and instilled my belief that everyone inherently deserves safe housing and basic healthcare. Just as it always felt like a great privilege to build someone else a home, it is a great privilege to train to be a physician. I want to continue developing my medical Spanish skills and become a provider who makes care accessible. Physicians create justice by caring for marginalized populations in ways that are relevant and authentic to their communities.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Like many, I struggled with the isolation of online learning. Working in the COVID-19 testing lab at Cal Poly gave me a small community of people and provided much-needed connection. As we worked together to keep our community safe, I realized that focusing on helping others was the perfect antidote to the challenging loneliness of the pandemic. I had been preparing to apply last cycle, but realized I needed to care for my wellbeing in order to lay the groundwork for a holistic, whole-person approach to caring for my patients in the future. After graduating, I recognized my need to heal and rest and took the summer off to reconnect to others and myself. I processed the gravity of both the many lives we had lost and the time we lost with each other. I remembered one of my core reasons for pursuing medicine: it is about caring for people. Resilience is built in small moments and daily choices to reach outside myself and share both the burdens and joys of life with others.

Major_Long_Desc: Health Sciences - Pre Clinical Allied Health
personal_statement:
"Drugs don't always fix it," my mother told me as I swallowed the small orange pills. I had just completed a four-mile run and was between breaths as I sucked down some much-needed water. I started taking ibuprofen after completing longer runs as an irritating dull ache would arise in my right hip and persist throughout my run and the following days. Today, like clockwork, the pain began after the halfway point, making it hard not to wince as I sat down to stretch. Reminding myself that relief was just 30 minutes away, I heard my mother, a pharmacist for over 20 years, advise me to take the tablets sparingly "if I wanted to keep my kidneys." 

I flashed back to my cross country running days as I read "acute kidney injury" and "adverse effect of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs" in Mrs. T's medical history. She sat on the small padded emergency department (ED) bed with three pillows propping her up, but still visibly uncomfortable, twisting and turning about. As Dr. W walked through the sliding glass door, she resigned herself to the discomfort and lifted her head to greet him, summoning as much enthusiasm as possible. Working as his medical scribe, I trailed in behind him and drew the curtain closed. With tears in her eyes, she explained how she endured the last six days without being dialyzed. My heart ached as she relayed her husband's recent passing, her soulmate and sole source of transportation. In addition to managing her acute discomfort and getting her admitted for dialysis, Dr. W spent significant time talking with Mrs. T about how to get to her future appointments. As Mrs. T was wheeled out of the ED, I noticed tears were still in her eyes as she looked at Dr. W, but this time it was with overflowing gratitude. 

This encounter taught me that having access to healthcare means more than just having a hospital nearby or insurance; having the ability to understand and utilize information can have significant effects in the care patients receive. I want to empower my patients by providing them the essential information they need, just as Dr. W had done for Mrs. T. I reflected on how access to information could have helped prevent this ED visit or her chronic kidney disease. Having grown up with a pharmacist at my side, I now realize that this was a privilege most individuals do not have. Had my mom not warned me about overusing medications, I could have experienced a similar fate.

I continued observing crucial conversations the attendings carried out with their patients, such as Mrs. T, or with family members, regarding a devastating new diagnosis or a loved one’s critical status. Recently, I experienced how it felt to receive upsetting news that clouded my mental state with worries and doubt. After weeks of anxiety-filled scheduling with multiple doctors and diagnostic testing, I was apprehensive of the elusive diagnosis my significant other, Kyle, faced. This would be our answer to why he had sudden left-sided visual changes. As a pilot, he could no longer fly, causing him stress, but mostly frustration, as he expected this would be temporary. After hearing that his eye was physically normal, I became terrified at the prospect of his symptoms having a neurological origin. Passing the time between each appointment, I did my best to stay positive and quell his fears, silently hoping this was an isolated occurrence. My uneasiness grew as he was admitted and given high-dose steroids after additional white matter lesions were discovered. 

I remained on edge after Kyle's discharge until the follow-up appointment a week later. We were placed in a small spotless, white-walled room with two chairs and a hospital bed. I took a seat and stared forever at the door we had just passed through until we heard a knock. Dr. S walked in, his shoulders squared but relaxed, exuding a calm confidence that seemed to spread over the room. I was not prepared when he stated, "Kyle's diagnosis of multiple sclerosis appear[ed] to be more aggressive." Alarm bells went off in my head, but Dr. S continued, "but I have many patients who continue doing well on today's medication." I exhaled the breath I was holding, and with less than 15 words, my trepidation that had built up over two months eased. I appreciated Dr. S's clarity and depth of explanation as he helped us start to understand and cope with this new information. I was awed by his ability to efficiently orchestrate Kyle’s care and develop a meaningful relationship with us in such a brief encounter. 

This emotional journey showed me how easy it was to become frustrated when navigating the healthcare system. From the other side of healthcare, this further enables me to relate more effectively to patients and their family members. I plan to emulate Dr. S's demeanor and continue to build and demonstrate empathy and kindness. Medicine has played a prominent role in shaping who I am today, and I commit myself to a lifetime of learning and meaningful interactions with my future patients and peers. As a caregiver, I hope to continually share with my patients why medication may not always be the answer and, as a patient advocate, ensure they are cared for not only physically but emotionally as well.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I was the teaching assistant when a lecturer made a generalization about Africa. Students expressed concern, but I was confused, my background rarely provoked incendiary comments. To better understand, I spoke with a colleague of African descent. She explained that blanket statements cannot describe the peoples or cultures a continent houses, and these comments perpetuate existing prejudices that may already be in place. I was embarrassed; I believed myself to be open-minded, yet only heard an anecdote, not disparaging remarks. Perhaps more painful, this is not an isolated occurrence; there have likely been past comments I did not recognize and certainly there will be more in the future. Still, it is my obligation to be cognizant of these challenges and suggest solutions. With this experience, I illuminated the vitriolic remarks to my department‚Äôs leadership and shared the new knowledge I acquired. Moving forward, I will continue to educate myself and highlight prejudice to my peers.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I was volunteering at the Illinois COVID Medical Recommendation Hotline when I received a call from a man who was extremely worried about his mother, she was having difficulty breathing. Having multiple comorbidities, he knew she was at increased risk of mortality if she contracted COVID and had spent hours trying to get her tested. Having been told contradicting information, he was very frustrated and tired by the time he was told to contact the hotline. Partway through our conversation, his demeanor shifted from angry to emotionally spent; my heart broke as he began to cry. I shared with him how he could obtain a test from his mother's primary care provider and provided my direct number in case he had any issues. I continued talking until he was emotionally steady and ready to hang up. I received a call from him later that day where he shared that he had located a test and was grateful that I was the volunteer who had answered the phone.
7_-_COVID_Impact: While COVID-19 initially spread throughout the Chicago community, it was hard to imagine the repercussions on academics and daily living. While studying organic chemistry, academics were in constant flux; I was hopeful that schools would reopen before the semester‚Äôs end in order to sit for the remaining exams. Still, COVID-19 propagated rapidly and my hopes of returning to in-person classes dwindled. Although the closures helped maintain good public health, my academic life was derailed. With the complete transition to remote learning, my cohort and I had to complete six exams in the final four weeks of the semester. Personally, I struggled, completing challenging test after test in a short amount of time. During this time, I was also studying to take the MCAT, as I registered to take the exam in early June. Due to the disturbances in my schedule, I was unprepared and had to delay my exam.

personal_statement:
The idea of going into medicine was planted in my subconscious when a kindergarten teacher equated my 5 year old hands assembling a pile of eraser shavings to the steady work of a surgeon. At the time I had no idea what being a surgeon entailed nor the dedication required to enter the medical field, but this seed of possibility grew stronger through the years as my understanding of the profession evolved. Medicine is not just a destination to be reached after many years of education but rather a journey whose continuous challenges I look forward to. As an undergraduate and a medical assistant, I came to appreciate the interplay between the empirical and interpersonal aspects of medicine. A physician does more than simply provide medical care; you must become an educator and an ally to your patients, and this is precisely the aspect of medicine that resonates with me most. 

I learned the importance of patient education during my college sophomore year while I was shadowing a pediatric neurologist. The doctor, who was counseling a mother about the results of her child’s DNA test, spent a large portion of the short 30-minute appointment explaining genetics in a way that was simple and understandable. Though the mother had no knowledge of genetics, the doctor made sure she understood what was happening to her child. Because I’ve spent so many years taking biology classes and learning about genetics, the simple explanation of a nonsynonymous base pair substitution made perfect sense to me. However, knowledge does not always translate to the ability to educate. Even though I understood the underlying genetics, I likely would not have been able to teach it so comprehensively. In fact, I would not have even thought to do so and thus would have left this patient in the dark about a major aspect of their medical care. This is somewhat ironic since a lack of understanding is something I have experienced with my own medical history. Over the past decade, I had many reconstructive dental procedures due to an accident in elementary school and I often found myself confused. Why did one of my teeth become infected and require extraction a full year after the accident? Why did I recently need a crown lengthening and why did this require sutures in place for a month that interfered with talking and eating? These gaps in understanding are avoidable and something I will work to prevent.  

Patient education will be an integral part of my medical journey to help patients be autonomous in their care, and this has so far guided the way I practice as a medical assistant. I work directly with patients before, during, and after their visits with the doctor, and much of the patient education falls into my hands after the doctor has left the visit. I always try to explain not only the “what” and “how” but also the “why” when it comes to medications, aftercare, and other questions that arise. It is not enough to simply tell a patient to put Vaseline on their biopsy site but to also explain that it will help the skin heal better and improve the appearance of the scar because it allows the skin cells to swim and thereby prevent scab formation. When patients understand the “why”, their care compliance improves. I have enjoyed learning various tricks of the trade that I can pass on to patients in order to help them understand their own treatment and increase the likelihood of achieving the best possible outcome.

I have also learned that there is no one-size-fits-all approach to medical care. One afternoon I was in a visit with a patient in her 90's. She had a lesion on her hand that the doctor felt needed to be excised that day, rather than just biopsied. After the visit, I bandaged the excision site, ensured that she understood all her aftercare instructions, and helped her get dressed. I chased down her doctor so that she could sign papers required by her care facility, and I made sure the patient’s driver had been contacted to take her home. I then walked her to the lab downstairs so she could complete her blood work. I helped check her in through the lab’s electronic system as nobody was at the front desk. This level of individual care was only possible because I could delegate some work to other members of my team to cover the slack while I helped this patient. I’ve learned to recognize the needs that individual patients carry and the value of a strong and dynamic team. It is our job to ensure that each patient gets the best start-to-finish care, and in this case it meant taking extra steps to ensure this patient was taken care of even after she left the office. 

My experiences have taught me that being a healthcare provider goes far beyond being a distributor of diagnoses and procedures. We must be allies with our patients to maximize the efficacy of our care. When doctors meet patients’ level of understanding and recognize their individual needs, they can act as guides and educators rather than just a steering force. Working in a medical practice has given me the opportunity to utilize my love of science in a way that educates and heals. Developing my ability to improve the lives of others through care and education is something I greatly anticipate as I progress through my medical career.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Performing in plays has bolstered my ability to empathize and connect with those who differ from me as acting requires putting yourself in the shoes of another person vastly different from yourself. I often play characters of different genders, backgrounds, and philosophies than myself, and a convincing performance necessitates understanding and empathy. One show I performed through the UVA Drama department involved a scene in which I played a character with cerebral palsy. While ideally the role should be portrayed by somebody who actually has cerebral palsy, I did a lot of research to make sure I performed in a way that was authentic and respectful of people with this condition. My acting journey has shaped the ways I interact in my current work as a medical assistant and I find that it is easier for me to connect with and understand my patients. This experience will make me well adapted to the types of diverse relationships I must form as a physician.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: In Virginia, much like in the nation as a whole, structural inequalities have made it such that people of color are more likely to be uninsured or underinsured. Through my work at the Charlottesville Free Clinic, I aim to contribute to correcting some of these structural inequalities in my community. In one instance when I was scribing for an allergist, the patient had dermatological concerns. The doctor did not have a strong background in dermatology and invited me to discuss with him the various treatment options I‚Äôve become familiar with through my MA work and as such we were able to establish a treatment plan together. Though the problem of systemic discrimination is too large and deeply rooted for any one person to correct, the work of organizations like the Free Clinic are making important progress. I am excited that my background allows me to contribute to this effort and I look forward to the ability to make an even greater impact as my medical career continues
7_-_COVID_Impact: Before the pandemic, I was working daily in my research lab, shadowing a pediatric neurologist, volunteering in the children‚Äôs hospital, and rehearsing for a play. I was lucky that the majority of my research could be done remotely, but I was never able to return to shadowing which was disappointing given my interest in the field. Though I could not volunteer in-person, I was still able to contribute to my organization as a program director. As a cast, we adjusted the script to fit an audio production and remotely recorded Shakespeare‚Äôs Twelfth Night as a radio drama. Though COVID did not change my decision to enter a career in medicine, the pandemic put me through challenges that have prepared me for what I will face during my journey. Like many of my peers, I had to work through feelings of fear and hopelessness to successfully complete the hardest year of my education, and I have come to realize how important my work will be and how much impact I can have on public health.

Major_Long_Desc: Psychology; Cognitive Science with Neuroscience Concentration
personal_statement:
English was not my first language. While my parents were away at their 9-5 jobs, my grandparents raised me, teaching me Chinese through stories and nursery rhymes. As a result, I did not realize other languages existed until I began preschool. This language barrier left my classmates as confused and scared of me as I was of them. I felt as though people were constantly talking at me, but I did not understand any of what was going on. Stuck in what seemed like a never-ending game of charades, I would frantically wave and point, while teachers threw out random words, trying to guess if I needed to use the bathroom or was simply throwing a fit. They would often give up and resort to calling my parents, for their limited English, to help translate. Thus, my parents were my voice when I felt as though I did not have my own.

Growing up, I noticed that confusion and dissatisfaction were familiar emotions to my parents as well.  Nobody around them slowed down to explain or to make sure they understood. They often resorted to smiling and nodding through each day, never fully able to grasp what others were saying. My parents lived in a world of distrust and opaqueness—much like I had as a child—wherein there was much noise with little understanding. 

It wasn’t long before I surpassed my parents’ English abilities and took over the role of translator for my family. As a second-generation immigrant, I became a bridge between two worlds. Although it was a challenge holding up lines while I explained ticket prices at amusement parks and asking waiters for their patience while I explained menus in restaurants, I slowly realized this was an opportunity to connect my parents’ thoughts and desires into words. This role taught me to listen, both to the words and the intentions behind them, allowing me to develop a skill for noticing patterns of miscommunication beyond those present in language.

Inspired by my experiences translating for my parents, I trained to become a crisis hotline volunteer to continue advocating for those without a voice. I remember the sharp ringing of the telephone on my very first call in which I was greeted with a shaky “Hello,” full of uncertainty and skepticism. As the caller explained his struggles dealing with depression and OCD all while taking care of his sick mother, I gave him the space to explore his feelings. At first, he simply needed someone to talk to. But as I validated and empathized with his frustrations, he became more comfortable and confided that he felt he could no longer take care of himself. Together, we began exploring different resources from therapy to inpatient hospital services.  By the end of our call, I could sense a shift in his tone. He became more empowered and optimistic as he learned about these opportunities for help. 

I found purpose in helping someone build a path to health and guiding them through their journey. But I found myself wondering what would happen to these callers after hanging up, feeling a sense of unease over their well-being. This sparked my desire to help others through face-to-face interactions and direct patient contact. Joining a volunteer rescue squad as an EMT, I was able to personally treat patients and ensure they received the care they needed. 

One of my most memorable days was when I was dispatched to a motor vehicle accident, where I met “Choe.” I first saw Choe sitting in the driver seat of his wrecked car with a lost expression that I found all too familiar. As I jumped off the ambulance, a group of confused firefighters and medics were quick to inform me he couldn’t speak English. While others around me frantically talked at him, I made my way to him, kneeled to his eye level, and listened. With some patience, I discovered his native tongue was Tibetan, but he spoke some Chinese. Through the comfort of our shared language, I could see the fear dissipate from his eyes. Staying beside him, I quickly directed a firefighter to contact a translator from the hospital, as I explained to Choe what was happening. The more we communicated, the calmer he felt, and the more he trusted me to treat him. It wasn’t just my broken Chinese that made him feel safe, but rather the compassion and effort to truly understand him. I realized that my ability to connect with him was vital in informing him about his physical condition and treatment plan.

Through my experiences with Choe and others like him, I have come to consider communication as a vehicle through which I can break down barriers in medicine. I believe empathetic listening is the heart of medicine and patient care. With each patient I have interacted with, I have had the opportunity to hear their stories and appreciate their fears. I hope to utilize medicine and communication to help patients better understand and take control of their own health. As I continue to enrich my journey through medicine, I want to be a bridge of understanding, making sure others do not have to face the same struggles my parents and I experienced. Through my passion for patient interaction and communication, I envision myself as a doctor that listens to the words and emotions of my patients to guide them towards physical and mental health.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Volunteering in rural Virginia, I have consistently interacted with individuals suffering from untreated chronic health issues. As a healthcare worker, I often found myself wondering how they could allow their conditions to get so bad. However, by listening to these patients‚Äô histories, I realized they didn‚Äôt have much choice in the matter. The more I volunteered, the more I noticed this pattern throughout the community. Patients refused to go to the hospital because they were afraid of the bills. Others lived with undiagnosed mental illnesses as they had no access to mental health services. Witnessing these struggles first-hand has made me more conscious of the problems each patient faces outside of their disease; lack of accessible and affordable health care services perpetuated their conditions. At Rush Medical College, I aim to apply this knowledge and arrive at a better understanding of each patient, treating them in the context of their whole life, beyond their illness alone.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I heard a quiet but persistent knocking coming from outside the rescue station at 2AM. I opened the door to find a man in standing in the cold, anxiously requesting to go to the hospital. Discovering he was homeless, I realized that treating his cough with a transport to the ER was not enough. I informed him of the local homeless shelter I volunteered at and contacted social workers at the hospital, ensuring he received the proper help and resources. At my next shift at the homeless shelter, I was relieved to see him in line getting food, and to hear he had found transitional housing. Throughout my college career, have met several patients like him that needed much more than medical assessments: they needed an advocate. I realized that as a healthcare worker, I had a responsibility to fight for the needs of others, especially those who cannot do so themselves. Through RCSIP clinics, I will advocate for individuals in the underserved Chicago communities, providing accessible healthcare.
7_-_COVID_Impact: March of 2020 felt like a nightmare. One day, I was going home for spring break, and the next, the school had shut down and I was told not to return. The pandemic was escalating, and everything was put to a halt. As an EMT, I saw the effects in the healthcare community immediately. Half of my rescue station consisted of student volunteers, myself included, who were all sent home due to the pandemic. Crews were unable to staff even one full ambulance and remaining volunteers were working additional shifts to fill the gaps. At this crucial juncture of the pandemic, I felt a responsibility to help not only the patients but also the healthcare community as they risked their lives every day. This cumulated in my decision to leave home and live off-campus to resume volunteering. Seeing how healthcare workers came together during this crisis and their commitment to those around them has inspired and strengthened my desire to be a part of that community.

personal_statement:
It was a quiet night. My partner and I talked in the ambulance, parked in our usual spot on our graveyard shift. The radio squawked suddenly: a gas station address for a psychiatric call. As we arrived, we saw our patient, barefoot, sitting surrounded by the police and firemen, drinking water. Mascara ran down her face, and her hands shook with fear. She immediately grabbed my arm and wailed, “Please, don't make me go back, please.” I began asking questions, trying to get some context, but she was in shock and mumbled only gibberish. As my partner reached out to take her vitals, she panicked and became extremely hostile. Having experienced similar situations with my mother, when no words would make her think reasonably, I knew what to do. I took a deep breath, knelt down, and began explaining to her exactly what we were doing in as much detail as I could so she would know we weren’t trying to hurt her. “We just want you to make sure you’re OK,” I said calmly. “Would you let me just check your blood pressure? We're not going to hurt you.”
***

My sister held me tight, her soothing voice telling me it was going to be OK. All I could hear was screaming through the locked closet door. My 6-year-old self could only ponder what was happening. We sat on the floor staring at the door as it rattled with the echoes of the loud, muffled screams. “Give me my children, give me my children, don’t steal them from me!” was all I could hear as my mother hurled herself against the door to my room. Her father, husband, and brother tried to calm her, trying to reassure that we weren’t being taken; no words they said could give her peace of mind. This was the first time I encountered my mother’s manic episode. As children, we experience a lot of firsts, your first steps, your first day of school, but there’s nothing quite like the first time you experience a disorder that can often be ‘invisible’ to the physical realm, but so impactful to everyone it touches. But this experience became a turning point to diving into the world of psychosis, for it was certainly not the last time I’d encounter my mother’s bipolar disorder.

As a child I always had a fascination with the sciences. Participating in the HMS MEDscience Simulation Lab program, I found my love for medicine, the human body, and its various physiological systems. I learned the importance of communication in a clinical setting, as well as other medical history and techniques such as suturing, gallbladder surgery simulations, intubation, and more. As I continued my journey as an undergraduate, I discovered Tufts’ Clinical Psychology major and gained research experience in one of the best psychiatric hospitals in the country: McLean Hospital. Suddenly, the complex world of psychiatric disorders became a lot more clear to me, from their origin to their treatment, and I found something I wanted to be a part of, something that my past experiences had shaped me into pursuing.

That night at the gas station, our patient began to relax after my attempt to calm her, which I quickly used to my advantage and took her vitals. The officers told us she and her husband had gotten into an altercation, and when he hit her, she ran to the closest place she felt safe, the gas station. She insisted she didn’t want to press charges, that she loved him and knew he didn’t mean it – a clear sign of a potentially abusive household. But she did not want to go back to her house that night. I reassured her the hospital would be the best place for her to stay for the night as the police handled things, that she would be surrounded by people trying to help her and keep her safe however they could. I was grateful that night for the tactics I learned from my mother's manic episodes, exuding calm and successfully treating the patient when hostility and fear ruled her emotions. We got the patient the help she needed when she wouldn't listen to reason from any other source. 

The complexity of mental disorders has been clear in my studies. My work in McLean’s Pre-Clinical Behavioral Biology Lab has shown the journey pharmacological treatments go through before reaching clinical trials and later becoming established treatments for disorders. I have learned not only the mechanisms of various abused substances to better understand their receptors of action and the behavioral depressive effects they can cause, but also the effects of new and better potential antidepressant treatments being studied. Although psychological therapies are extremely useful, sometimes medication is the only treatment, since the root cause is a chemical imbalance. As a psychiatrist, my goal would be to combine these approaches to help others as my mother’s psychiatrist helped us and to become a resource for those individuals who are standing where I was 18 years ago. Pursuing psychiatry and its capacity for healing not only illness and disorder but the holistic balance of human health will allow me to transform lives and to bring awareness and treatment to the communities I hold so dear. No longer the scared little boy in the closet, I can turn his fear and pain into a passion for restoring peace and hope to patients and families who once suffered as he did.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Shadowing pediatric neurologist Dr. Alcy Torres was a chance to learn more about the neural and cerebral disorders that can lead to a psychiatric referral and better understand the overlap between these fields. As I had no prior exposure to autism, Dr. Torres took the time to educate me on the relationship between ADHD and autism as well as interaction strategies he uses in treating his autistic patients. He explained that autistic patients tend to have a ‚Äúspecial interest,‚Äù a point of hyperfocus that can be an opening to connect with the patient to elicit more trust but can also restrict treatment if they become oblivious to other questions. He explained the need for balance in interacting with these children so they don‚Äôt get lost in the topic, and he alerted me to how quickly they may become overstimulated, teaching me to take things at a pace comfortable for the patient. Expanding my ability to meet my patients where they are like this broadens my ability to be an effective doctor.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Service through the student-led Tufts Kidney Disease Screening and Awareness Club allowed me to provide free healthcare to communities facing challenges accessing such screenings. As someone familiar with the disparity of healthcare in Mexico, I had been unaware of similar disparities here, since the U.S. is always glorified as having ‚Äúbetter‚Äù opportunities and services. This was really a wake up call, and I have made it a goal as an aspiring psychiatrist to have my own practice providing mental health services to those otherwise unable to access such care due to the cost of services. I used cultural empathy and humility in working with these patients, because they were often nervous or embarrassed to be seeking this type of care ‚Äì a clear systemic crisis, for no one should feel less than worthy of medical care. The help I provided through this club solidified not only my goal to be a physician but also my wish to give back to the communities that have given me so much in my life.
7_-_COVID_Impact: To me, COVID-19 was an exercise in adaptability. While stuck at home, I found creative outlets in gardening, crocheting, dance, and making art, but Tufts' swift, effective response meant the pandemic had no real impact on the quality of my academic experience. Although I took half of the Biochemistry course online, as well as Physics 1 and 2 in the summer before senior year, my professors made online lessons work well. However, my professional opportunities shifted. I had secured an internship in Summer 2020 to assist on an OCD study, but this was paused due to in-person restrictions, and I participated in a student visitorship program involving OCD instead. Studying for the MCAT during the biggest wave of the pandemic also wasn‚Äôt easy. Unsatisfied with my first score, after refocusing my energies on school for my senior year and beginning to work in research, I reattempted the MCAT. Balancing a 40hr work week with studying was hard, but I improved in my post-pandemic attempt.

Hrdshp_Comments: As a low-income family, we utilized government-based resources including food stamps, child support, and homeless shelters. Though we received this help, there were times we went months without electricity and a consistent supply of food, which I managed while attending school growing up. In overcoming these challenges, I built upon my resilience and learned how to use the resources available to me to reach my goals. Furthermore, these experiences have prepared me for supporting me and my family by working two jobs, while completing my undergraduate degree and my medical school applications. Despite these obstacles, I have been privileged in receiving an education at Columbia and am motivated to utilize the resources I have available to me to help other disadvantaged individuals. Equipped with the tools to support my mother and research her mental illness, I have found effective ways to help her through episodes she has had since she was diagnosed in 2014. In order to achieve similar outcomes as a physician one day, I know I must continue going above and beyond for the people I intend to serve.
Under_School: Columbia University in the City of New York
personal_statement:
During my freshman year of high school, I was faced with an obstacle that changed the trajectory of my life. My mother was diagnosed with a chronic mental disorder and for the first time, I felt incapable of helping her. As her symptoms worsened, she began to spend most of her time isolated in her room, eventually losing her job and any source of income. I offered what I could: getting my younger brother and I ready for school, preparing meals, and cleaning the house. Still, as she was the head of the household, I knew this situation was unsustainable. Bills began to accumulate and my studies faltered. Toward the end of that first semester, I sat down with my mom to have a difficult conversation about her condition. We talked for hours, exploring what felt like every possible solution and alternative, including reaching out to extended family members for help.

“Maybe your brother and I should move to Boston and live with your uncle, while you stay in Pittsburgh with your grandmother for school,” my mother suggested. My uncle lived near resources that he could connect my mother with, including a psychiatrist who specialized in her condition. While I realized this would be the best option for my mother’s health and I agreed with her decision, I also felt uncertain. My mother had previously been my pillar of support. The idea of her leaving made my heart drop, even though I knew it was necessary for her to get better.
