Witnessing the effects of this chronic illness showed me not only the consequences health could have on a fragile household, but also the impact that I could have. By being a supportive presence during my mother’s ailment and encouraging her to take steps toward receiving the care she needed, I was able to help. While I was not the physician prescribing her medication, I could still assist her by reassuring her. I dream of becoming a physician who can provide both of these means of support for my patients one day.

With the help of her physician and medication, my mother’s condition improved, demonstrating to me the immense impact the medical field could have on an individual and the type of impact I hoped to create. I began to seek out opportunities to pursue my newfound interest in medicine, and realized I wanted to work directly with patients who were under-resourced to help provide avenues of support. I decided to continue my passion of working with patients by volunteering at the UPMC Children’s Hospital before my junior year of college. One day while doing rounds, I came across a young patient and her mother. The only light in their room was coming from the television, and I quickly realized from their surprise that they were not expecting a volunteer. In an effort to lift the girl’s spirits, I asked if I could talk with her, and discovered we had a shared interest in drawing. She mentioned she wanted to draw while being in the hospital but did not have any materials. After hearing this, I assured her we had art supplies in the hospital and went to retrieve some. I’ll never forget the look of delight on her and her mother’s face when I walked in with a notebook and a pencil kit. I could feel the girl’s excitement as we continued our conversation until the end of my volunteering shift. That was the first time I understood the healing impact I could have on a patient's experience by cultivating an environment of compassion and support.

In my path toward becoming a physician, I know that I will not always have the opportunity to sit down and talk for hours with my patients. However, I do hope that my experiences will help me see beyond the hospital gown. As a clinical research assistant, I witnessed neurologist Dr. Harel accomplish just this when working with a patient who had amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), listening as the patient expressed frustration and hopelessness at the rapid progression of his disease. Dr. Harel chose to make a genuine human connection with the patient through their mutual love of baseball. Suddenly, the energy in the room shifted and it felt as though I was listening to two friends discuss their favorite baseball teams, although eternal rivals, in between discussions of treatment plans. Though the circumstances were quite different, I quickly saw parallels between his ALS patient and the pediatric patients I met while volunteering at UPMC, both of whom had placed their trust in the healthcare team in hopes of navigating their medical situations.

I dream of navigating these situations alongside patients as a physician, offering the comfort I have personally seen change lives. As in the care I saw with my mother and the patients I’ve worked with, I hope to foster a therapeutic alliance by connecting with vulnerable people to enhance their care. Drawing from these experiences, I envision the role of a physician to extend far beyond medicine to encompass leadership, advocacy, and problem-solving, and I am eager to flesh out this vision in my commitment to the journey of lifelong learning as a physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: At the Bronx VA, I worked daily with former veterans whose experiences varied greatly from mine. While it felt daunting at first to work with people much older than me, I learned how to form connections with these patients. Working with study participants, I often found our conversations veered toward the person‚Äôs life, and that patients wanted medical professionals who were empathetic to their experiences and struggles. I saw the importance of being open-minded and non-judgmental to helping people that I saw everyday. This attribute allowed participants to feel comfortable sharing any symptoms that they had with me so I could provide the best treatment for them during a session. Our interactions also showed me the challenges that people with chronic conditions face such as isolation, especially those from vulnerable populations. Similarly, I hope to form connections with Chicago‚Äôs diverse patient population to understand how I can address their needs.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Having studied the determinants of health at the School of Social Work, I wanted to apply my understanding of health disparities to create projects to improve local health outcomes during the pandemic. Through Columbia‚Äôs United Against Inequities in Disease (UAID) chapter, I helped organize a drive to create 160 COVID kits for people in Harlem experiencing homelessness. Witnessing the impact our chapter of 20 students could create underscored for me the importance of collaboration in addressing the needs of others. I‚Äôm eager to see what UAID continues to do and know that as long as our mission of helping the surrounding community stays strong, our impact will be sustained. I hope to create a similar impact on the Chicago community as a student at Rush through its Road Home Program, where I can learn how to practice as a physician who addresses the needs of my patients. I know Rush will provide me with the resources to make tangible change through partnerships and active communication.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
Once Columbia‚Äôs campus closed due to the pandemic, I moved back home to complete classes online. Although transitioning to online courses felt disorienting, I knew I was fortunate as a student to continue my education, even if in a different capacity. _x000D_
_x000D_
My summer plans changed drastically. The biomechanics lab that I planned to work in closed. Thankfully, I could still work remotely at the School of Social Work to help out financially at home and received a summer grant to conduct research on health outcomes during the pandemic through Columbia‚Äôs COVID design challenge. Here, my team and I designed a device to disinfect PPE after 50 minutes of UV exposure. Seeing the device that we could create in only a couple months showed me that it was still possible to create an impact using few resources. Though managing these commitments came with challenges, I‚Äôm thankful I had the opportunity to help my family and work on tackling health inequities that I aspire to confront as a physician.

Inst_Action_Desc:
March 25th, 2021
My friends and I were celebrating around the time of graduation. Concerned about my safety, the RA called the campus police to conduct a wellness check. After talking to my roommate and I, the officer concluded it was safe to return to my room and get some rest. Next day, I felt embarrassed and sorry that other people had to be involved. The incident made me more cognizant of my safety and well-being.
personal_statement:
“Welcome to McDonald’s, how can I help you?” My stepmom leans over my dad sitting in the driver’s seat, “Can I get five large fries, please?” Meanwhile, my three paternal half-brothers and I gaze out of the car window at the New York City sky, consumed by the tall glass buildings and glaring bright lights. Despite only meeting him thirty minutes ago, I accost my youngest half-sibling with questions: “what is that? What about that? And that?” We pull up to the second window, and my stepmom hands each of us a box of fries. At that moment, I had already forgotten the horrific 10-hour flight where I had cried myself to sleep on the shoulder of my oldest half-brother whom, like the other two, I had met a few months before that flight. I moved to Massachusetts from Ghana in 2008, leaving my mom and two maternal half-siblings behind to live with my dad, who was also nearly a stranger to me. It was the hardest thing I have done, and the only justification my dad gave me was that this was the “American Dream.” The idea of limitless potential and opportunities to do or become anything, but as a nine-year-old it did not feel like it.
 
I struggled for the first few years in America as I tried to assimilate to western culture. I fell behind in classes as I tried to understand the intricacies of the English language. I couldn’t find anything I enjoyed learning until I started the human anatomy and physiology unit in my life science class in 7th grade. During those few weeks, I found myself more engaged in my studies than ever before. It was not until my 3rd oldest sibling fell ill to pneumonia and had to be hospitalized for several days that I witnessed and appreciated how resilient the human body can be in its ever-changing environment. Visiting my brother in the hospital, I was overwhelmed with the sight of him lying motionless and lethargic. I observed as the physicians and nurses did their best to bring my brother from near death to his joyful self. I saw my brother garner more energy each day to talk and play with me. It was during that time that I discovered my interest in medicine. I hoped to one day help bring someone else’s brother or sister back home.
 
Fast forward to the summer of 2017, I began the 6-month journey to become a Combat Medic in the Massachusetts Army National Guard. In training, presented with various medical and trauma scenarios, I worked to save the lives of my simulation patients while adapting and improvising with limited to non-existent supplies. I learned to treat sucking chest wounds using plastic packaging and tape to prepare for combat situations where commercial chest seals are not available. I learned a lot from working with simulators but making the transition to real patients was a welcomed challenge. Following a training exercise in the scorching summer heat of Texas, a trainee collapsed to the ground. As other medics worked to pack them with ice sheets, I struggled to establish an IV line on an arm without ideal mannequin veins. After a successful second stick, I unclamped the IV tubing and let the lactated ringers run bolus. Within minutes EMS arrived and the trainee was sent off to a higher echelon of care. As the ambulance sped away, I wished I had the knowledge and skill set to ensure their recovery. I used this experience to fuel my already burning passion to become a physician.
 
My training experience opened many doors and opportunities. My first hospital job as a patient care technician was at Emerson Hospital, a small community hospital in Concord, Massachusetts surrounded by several nursing homes. Spending countless shifts sitting with patients with dementia, I try to emulate the professionalism, candor, and empathy of the physicians and nurses with whom I worked with as I reassure patients they are safe. In room 544 bed 1 in a medical/surgical unit, the wife of a retired Stanford professor and I gently stroke the chest, arms, and legs of her husband to make him aware of our presence. Although he did not close his eyes to rest that night, our hands kept him calm through the night. No matter how distant your consciousness may be, the touch of another human on your body brings you to a present stimulus. I recognized how difficult it can be to care for patients with dementia or altered mental status. Nights like these taught me little lessons that I will bring with me while caring for my patients as a future physician.
 
Since I discovered my interest in medicine at my brother’s hospital bedside, I have worked tirelessly to achieve the “American Dream” I could not envision as a nine-year-old. From the first time I treated a soldier with a severely blistered foot, to the time I cleaned up a dementia patient covered with urine and stool, I’ve met numerous individuals from different walks of life. During people’s trying times, I’ve had the pleasure of making many laugh when they are feeling down, being a calming hand in times of uncertainty, a listening ear, and a shoulder to cry on. The moments I have shared with these individuals during their most vulnerable state, has drawn me further into medicine. As I continue my journey, I hope to draw on these experiences to help me provide exceptional care for my patients.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: ‚ÄúThe only colors you have to worry about are green and red because at the end of the day, we are all in the same green uniform and we all bleed red.‚Äù Drill Sergeant Tucker lectured my platoon several times during the first couple weeks of basic training whenever he noticed racial cliques. To address this issue, our platoon spent a few nights trying to get to know each other. Sitting on the floor in an open bay, we took turns discussing our motivation to join the Army. A few people like myself joined for the educational benefits. Some joined for citizenship, while others joined for family benefits. Some joined to escape their old habits and lifestyles, while others joined to serve their country. By the end of the training cycle, although we had different backgrounds and motivations, we trained and excelled together. I learned to value our collective differences because it was often a strength that complimented our individual weaknesses.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Two years ago, my close friend, Tate, expressed that he felt lost in life and had no idea what to do with himself. During high school, he was a part of the machine tool technology program offered through our school. Post-grad he realized that he had no interest in the field, so he was unsure what to do. He spent the first few years after high school, moving from job to job with zero interest in any of them.  In the Army, I knew several individuals who at some point felt similarly who now have civil service careers. After a few late night conversations with Tate, he expressed that he would see himself as a fire-fighter. I helped him apply to the fire protection and safety program at Bunker Hill Community College. Since then, he has had two successful semesters and has recently completed an EMT course. He is on track to complete the remaining two semesters of the program before he plans to take the civil service exam. It is rewarding to see my friend excel in his newly found passion.   _x000D_

personal_statement:
People want to show others love—all that’s needed is an opportunity. Working at a high school in “Southside” Phoenix, however, this idea is seldom evident. As a gender nonconforming racial minority, I’ve become adept at disregarding whispered indignities about my clothing choices and sideways glares from people that don’t look like me, but nothing can match the brazenly weaponized ignorance of teenagers. Walking the hallways expands one’s vocabulary; there are slurs for every color of the rainbow, doubled for those of us that understand some Spanish. The words disappoint more than they sting.

I had taken a position working with students that required behavioral interventions, naïvely expecting to shepherd every would-be dropout, bathroom smoker, and cafeteria brawler back onto a track of academic and interpersonal success while hopefully improving the school’s culture. A few weeks after starting, my optimistic intentions and I took a stroll through the “M” building and were splintered by the verbal warzone that succinctly demonstrated my impotence at the school level. My beliefs held firm, but I was disturbed by the realization of my inefficacy.
Desperate to provide what respite I could for students, I started a weekly LGBT+ support group. The group’s aim was simple: to provide a safe space for students to escape the hostility they faced in class, at home, or in the community. It wasn’t long after the group began that I was assigned to meet a student that went by “Z”. With their bright green hair and shaved eyebrows, Z had a unique appearance—a valiant gamble for a tenth grader. After we bonded over not fitting expected gender roles, they opened up about their trauma from home, their suicide attempts, and how they felt alienated at school. Having been personally affected by suicide, I wanted to do everything in my power to improve Z’s mental health to avoid tragedy. Not able to address their illness directly, I recommended they join the support group.

After a few weeks of gentle convincing and reminding, Z was finally introduced to the group. When given the floor, Z’s downcast eyes were locked on their black combat boots while they feebly shared their experiences of domestic nonacceptance and internal turmoil. They sorrowfully concluded with “…and I have no friends.” To Z’s bewilderment, this declaration was met with defiance: “That’s not true!” A voice warmly rang. “I’ll be your friend!” For the first time, Z’s eyes lifted, and in them I saw hope. I fought back tears as the movie moment unfolded. All tribulations of ignorance were forgotten. I felt an immense sense of pride in the environment that I had provided. Strangers showed one another love—all it took was an opportunity. After that experience I’ve become sensitive to these instances, where regardless of circumstance or demographic, people can show true compassion.
Hospitals provide the setting for a wealth of these opportunities. As a patient resource tech, I spent most of my time “sitting” with high-risk patients. Not only did this allow me to observe the full interdisciplinary care process, but I also felt like an integral team member, and had the unique position of focusing all my attention on one patient for a full twelve hours. There was the occasional TBI patient that mistook my shoes for a urinal, but overall I did as much as I could to improve patients’ moods, which had ripple effects throughout their stay.

I was most impacted by my first solo sitting assignment: a paranoid schizophrenic around my age named Don. Though unable to hold a conversation, we were able to chat and get to understand one another. In between bouts of fighting demons only visible to him, he told me of his likes and dislikes, his hobbies, why Giannis was his favorite basketball player, and how much he loved his mom. When his mom came to visit, the years of exhaustion were clearly identifiable from her face and tone. I was tortured by a familiar feeling of inefficacy. I could comfort Don and assure him that it wasn’t his fault that he was in the hospital, but I couldn't help quiet the haunting voices or tell his mother why her baby mistook a hospital room for hell. As I left my shift that day, I thanked Don for sharing his story with me and let him know how much I had enjoyed his company. Remembering the sincerity of the smile he gave in return still brings tears. The hopeful look in his eyes was the same that I had seen in Z’s. Don demonstrated that the worse one’s circumstances, the more they blossom when shown kindness. Albeit small, I was glad to have seized the opportunity.

I formed a space where Z could find a friend, but couldn’t treat their depression. I consoled Don when he feared damnation, but couldn’t ameliorate his symptoms. I provided opportunities for these people to be shown love for a moment, but they deserve the power to create opportunities for themselves throughout their own lives. I believe that medicine is the most direct means through which we can restore others’ self-efficacy in this regard. I hope to build a career of spreading the privilege of seeing the same expression Z and Don showed, and above all, I am determined to spend my life creating opportunities by utilizing medicine to reclaim and preserve others’ control over their lives.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: My sensitivity to the homelessness crisis developed as a patient resource technician at St. Joseph‚Äôs Medical Center in downtown Phoenix. Throughout the pandemic, I noticed an increase in ER cases of suicidal ideation requiring a patient sitter. Unfortunately, the majority of my sitter assignments were individuals that lacked stable housing. After connecting with many patients, it became clear that the most vulnerable populations suffered the most severe economic consequences. To make matters worse, many of my patients had additional health conditions that were left untreated. Between a lack of affordable housing, a lack of accessible healthcare, and a rampant lethal virus, it became understandable why our cases of suicidality had increased. The supports in place are overcrowded and underfunded, while seeking help is still stigmatized. I believe that through research and community education it may be possible to lessen the stigma, and increase momentum for forward-thinking legislation.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
I have worked to improve high school dropout rates by overwriting my school‚Äôs discipline practices._x000D_
_x000D_
South Mountain High School‚Äôs graduation rate is 12% below national average due to many pushout factors such as punitive behavioral management policies. I accepted a position that oversaw in-school suspension (ISS), and had the unique opportunity to modernize the program. When I filled the vacancy, ISS became an option that replaced many off-school suspensions. More importantly, I used the classroom to perform behavioral interventions, teach social/emotional learning, tutor all subjects, and provide a cooldown space for students with impulse management issues. _x000D_
_x000D_
Outside the classroom, I‚Äôve pushed to update our practices according to research evidence to include restorative processes and minimize suspension time. I believe my contributions have mitigated dropouts while improving the culture surrounding how students‚Äô behavior is addressed.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
After graduating, I landed the perfect job as a school nutrition manager. My family‚Äôs needs were met, my MCAT study schedule inked out, and my plan felt flawless. _x000D_
_x000D_
Then, in an avalanche of developments, my plan was razed by COVID-19. Schools shut down and I lost my job; luckily, I‚Äôd stayed part-time as an EMT with my previous employer._x000D_
_x000D_
I took a second job at a COVID-19 testing site, and began to spend all my hours either at work or caring for my family. Medical school applications were my top career priority, but the needs of my loved ones were greater. I delayed my MCAT and had no time to study. In addition, physicians weren‚Äôt allowing shadowing due to safety precautions, and in-person volunteering saw the same treatment. The robustness of my application suffered as a result, but I‚Äôm proud to have stood in the face of uncertainty to serve my community as a tester and vaccine administrator. Instead of fearing uncertainty, now I see opportunity for variety and service.

personal_statement:
Is it weird to admit that after breaking bone after bone as a child, I started looking forward to my stays at Boston Children’s Hospital? The grandiose fish tanks. The glittering, cityscape mosaics. The ball machine designed by George Rhoads. These memorable features seemed to welcome me back with each new injury: a wrist shattered on the basketball court; an ankle snapped on the soccer field; a finger bent in the entirely wrong direction, when I refused to fumble on the football field; and an arm fractured by a classmate, who thought the playground offered the perfect venue to practice her new karate moves.
When the physicians arrived, I studied their handling of my swollen joints, turning them over, pressing, and asking, “Does this hurt? What about here?” I squealed in pain. Sometimes I was met with a smile. Sometimes, an apology. I was confused. Did I pass the test? Was this a good thing, or a bad thing, this confirmation of pain? I saw so many physicians, I began recognizing individual personalities reflected in their responses. One doctor, in particular, stood out. I was not greeted by the usual “...so I’ve looked at your X-rays…” Instead, he introduced himself, looked me in the eye, and probed: “How are you feeling?” 
I was stunned. Why was this physician asking how I felt? What about the pain test? I was caught off guard by the question, and within it, an unspoken understanding contrived of simplicity and decency. I felt recognized. Seen. Vulnerable in my injured state, yet cared for and in the presence of someone who understood that I was more than my injury. 
I don’t remember how I answered his question, but I do remember carrying its significance with me to UCLA. While heading to a freshmen orientation event promising “2 for 1 Diddy Riese” cookie dough sandwiches, as I walked along the Westwood sidewalk, instead of chocolate baked goodness, I smelled urine. Then I noticed a seemingly endless row of tents, blistered swollen feet poking through. Ice cream scoopers half-smiled behind cookie dough counters, unsure of whether or not to acknowledge the people camped in makeshift homes. 
Suddenly, I was brought back to my doctor’s visit; my physician had made a choice to recognize me, and I could choose to do the same for these people. I wasn’t yet trained to treat injuries, but I had been shown how to treat a patient. Instead of ignoring the homeless as a symptom of Westwood’s inequity, I wanted to help.
So I joined MEDLIFE, an organization offering medical, social, and legal services to the Los Angeles homeless population. I jumped into the Bruin van and cruised down the 405, arriving at the local McDonalds parking lot to slap together peanut butter and jelly sandwiches. John, a Skid Row resident, greeted me with five simple words: “It smells like ass here.” He wasn’t lying. While I handed out sandwiches, our chat evolved, and in between stories of his son’s escapades, I noticed him jumping from foot to foot. I saw my moment. Glancing at his feet and then back up to his eyes, I asked, “How are you feeling? He looked down and whispered, “Well it feels like I’m walking on fire honestly.” As I directed him to primary care services, I was both grateful and motivated. The opportunity to connect with John and create a safe space where he felt comfortable sharing with me how he felt is something I will never forget. As his feet were being examined, I realized my interaction with John was just the beginning. I knew I was capable of more.
 As I rode back to UCLA, I recalled moments in the hospital when my only understanding of suffering was a broken bone. And the bones hurt, believe me. But I didn’t have to worry about access to medical care, and I didn’t know that others did. I could always count on my mom to get me to the ER, where I received elite medical care, before returning to the comforts of home. A hot, nutritious meal. Relieved siblings signing my casts. A warm, cozy bed to climb into. All integral to healing. Exiting the van, I felt my lens readjust: I now saw medicine seeped in social nuance, and the need to address both social and biological factors to help patients like John.
Today, I reflect on that physician’s acknowledgement of me, as both patient and person, and recognize what I couldn’t as a young kid. That he, one of the doctors I used to think of as an all-knowing entity, was also a person, continuing to grow and learn in his practice, just like me. When I think about pursuing medicine today, I know my views, my goals, and my self-awareness have grown immensely from that first visit to Boston Children’s. Not only have I graduated from backyard ice jumps to park halfpipes, but I’ve found new means of promoting health. I question how to ethically serve people, I look for new ways to recognize social factors and biological differences among individual patients, and I continue to hold close that moment when I was first treated as a patient, not as an injury. I know that my medical philosophy will continually be challenged and amended. And that’s perhaps what excites me most about pursuing a career in medicine.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
After revealing her HIV+ status, the patient addressed the circumstances that had necessitated a visit to the clinic: a swollen belly and nausea. With two children at home and no partner present, the mother explained that she could not support another baby. The problem: South Africa required women to file a request to abort if past the twelve-week mark. I stood in silence, nodding at the patient to put her at ease and watching the physician to see how he would respond to a difficult situation. _x000D_
Finally he spoke, offering her a scrap piece of paper with scribbled digits. ‚ÄúIf you run into any issues, give them this.‚Äù_x000D_
My mind reeled. Is this wrong? Is this ethical? This interaction in Khayelitsha, South Africa, made me realize that the physician‚Äôs job is more than treating a patient‚Äôs physical symptoms; proper health care embodies a balancing act of autonomy and beneficence, of social awareness and attention to psychological health.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
Lining the road to Table Mountain, piles of newspapers warned of the recent escalation in violence: ‚Äú56 killed in Khayelitsha‚Äù, ‚ÄúTourists killed hiking‚Äù. The University of Cape Town canceled outdoor activities and professors advised students to stick in pairs. Fearing for my safety, I questioned if I should forgo my studies in South Africa._x000D_
Then in August, international news publicized the horrific killing of student Uyinene Mrwetyana. The university canceled classes and coordinated a memorial. Local organizers planned a march to protest the senseless violence. I felt out of place, alone, and scared. As both an outsider and a member of the student body, I didn‚Äôt know whether to give the locals space or to grieve alongside them. Torn, I asked Kevin, a Capetonian, for advice._x000D_
‚ÄúNo one would blame you for not going, but if international students participate, it draws attention to how serious this is.‚Äù With Kevin‚Äôs help, I overcame my fears and marched for the right to feel safe.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
The pandemic raised dozens of new problems I didn‚Äôt have answers to. I knew bioethical principles should guide how American society acted; yet, it was not until COVID-19 overwhelmed state hospitals and underscored national health disparities that I understood how the set of ethical guidelines I clung to failed to remedy novel dilemmas. In this way, the pandemic forced me to re-examine my commitment to medicine. _x000D_
_x000D_
I enrolled at Columbia University to pursue a Masters of Science in Bioethics. I familiarized myself with the ethical questions surrounding clinical practice. I learned case-based approaches for ethical dilemmas and applications of biotechnology for real-life scenarios. The resulting devastation, and urgency created by the pandemic motivated me to put my entire being into my studies. Instead of interrupting my application plans, COVID-19 convinced me that I needed to apply‚Ä¶as soon as possible.

personal_statement:
When I heard that my brother, Jacob, was expressing thoughts of suicide, it was extremely shocking. As I learned more, I realized the scale of his unspoken struggles, as Jacob was quietly battling against anxiety, depression, and substance use disorder. This was the start of my pursuit of medicine. Reflecting on how the pervasive stigma of mental health conditions further isolated him and worsened his health, I wanted to help Jacob and others like him.
It was out of this desire that I decided to volunteer for the Crisis Text Line, where texters are often suffering from mental health disorders and reach out in times of crisis. As a counselor, I’ve witnessed the effects that complex backgrounds and identities can have on mental health as well as the inequity in mental healthcare accessibility. I feel privileged to help narrow the equity gap by providing a service that does not turn anyone away. While I am continuously learning how to best support each texter, I have found that approaching the conversation with compassion and without judgment is always the start. I learned that in my future, I want to provide healthcare to communities of people who are historically underserved. As a physician, I will advocate for those facing healthcare injustices, knowing that many patients are struggling with systemic discrimination that is outside their control.
To broaden my experience, I became a certified nursing assistant (CNA) and started working in a nursing home. The geriatric population is notoriously under-supported, and I saw this problem worsen dramatically during the pandemic. With constant understaffing, my first few shifts left me feeling overwhelmed, but I soon learned to manage my time and promote the team environment. I enjoyed maximizing the strengths of the other CNAs and dividing the workload for the essentials, such as getting each resident out of bed, changed, and taken to the bathroom. This required constant communication among CNAs and the floor nurse, and over time our team worked more efficiently. My ability to work in a team was recognized by our CNA coordinator, and I was assigned to train new CNAs on the floor, teaching them the specific care for each resident and how to manage their many responsibilities. I instilled in new trainees the importance of fundamentals like using a gait belt to assist residents and finding a second person when needed. In my future, I will strive to be a strong leader who prioritizes safety and won’t cut corners. I will continue to value all team members and promote communication and collaboration within our team.
Through my work in the nursing home, I witnessed that medicine is moving toward a more wholistic approach that develops care unique to a patient’s needs and priorities. I once accompanied “Jane” to her neurology appointment. Jane had Parkinson’s Disease, and she exhibited severe symptoms of dementia and responded slowly to questions. At first, her neurologist skipped over her when asking questions, looking instead to me for answers. But he quickly learned she just needed extra time and was patient with her after each question. He caught his assumptions of her abilities and adjusted his communication technique. I admired his humility, flexibility, and attention to the subtleties of an individual. Like the neurologist, I demonstrated patience toward the residents, listening to them and designing my care to their individual needs. Some residents needed me to speak or move slower when helping them, while others preferred that I move quickly to let them get back to what they were doing. I enjoyed learning who each resident was and customizing their care. I found deep connections with them, seeing each resident as a unique individual and the shortcomings of a one-size-fits-all approach. I plan to continue this practice in medicine through developing personalized care for each patient.
After caring for the nursing home residents, I wanted to participate in scientific research, so I began working as a research technician at Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center. I have had the opportunity to lead a project to investigate how the histone chaperone SET assists in adenovirus infection, an infection which can be dangerous for elderly patients like Jane. I aim to better understand the intricacies of how this virus interrupts host cell function. From my research experience, I appreciate the long pipeline that connects research with clinical treatments and am excited to create therapies for aggressive disease. As a physician, I will apply my knowledge of disease to guide the care of my patients and continue my own research to develop better treatments.
Through my experiences as a Crisis Counselor and CNA, I have a sense of the qualities needed to succeed as a compassionate physician and collegial part of a medical team. My research experiences have added to my understanding of the science of medicine and helped me better appreciate research as the foundation of new therapies. In my future, I hope to use my voice to build toward equitable medicine, help create better treatments for patients like Jane, and design unique care to the needs of my patients.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I spent a week in Morocco with two friends in 2019. When we first walked around Casablanca, I felt unprepared for the extreme cultural transition. However, my perception changed when we visited the Hassan II Mosque. Our tour guide, a Casablanca local, enlightened us to the importance of the Mosque for the Sunni people. After our tour, we sat outside near a group of women and children playing. Several times, children came over with balls and wanted to play with us. The children laughed with us, and the women smiled at us. I felt grateful to be exactly where I was. As I learned more about the Islamic religion and Moroccan culture, both during our travels and after, I began to appreciate its complexity, tradition, and values. I learned the importance of understanding another culture before forming judgments about it. I minored in history to learn about the history and culture of Islam and continue to grow past my stereotypes and cultural lens to consider other cultures more thoughtfully.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: When I worked at a nursing home during the Covid-19 pandemic, I witnessed the mental harm of social isolation. Patients were unable to visit with families or leave their rooms. I was one of only a few faces they saw each day. While this sometimes felt like a lot of responsibility, I felt privileged to be trusted by them for their care. One patient, ‚ÄúMarcy,‚Äù had severe dementia and rolled down the hall in her wheelchair, talking to herself and staring ahead in a daze. On one rare sunny day in Bellingham, Washington, I rolled Marcy outside into the sun. She didn‚Äôt answer whether she wanted to stay outside or not, so I put sunscreen on her face and went inside. When I checked on her, Marcy had tilted her face upward toward the sun with a slight smile and eyes closed. I was overjoyed that I could provide her with a brief respite from the nursing home hallway. Small moments like these motivate me to continue helping others find wellness and support, particularly as they age.
7_-_COVID_Impact: During the pandemic, I served urban and rural members of my community by performing Covid-19 testing. While not true for all individuals living in rural areas, I found that many of the rural patients I served held different views than myself regarding the Covid-19 pandemic. I valued the opportunity to listen and connect during these interactions and learned that my rural upbringing prepared me for these conversations. I had practice speaking with my parents about the pandemic, opening my mind to their perspective and providing the background science to help them understand mine. While the Covid-19 pandemic has brought substantial hardship, I‚Äôm grateful for the experience of talking with my family and patients about it, because as a physician I will serve patients who have different backgrounds and views from me.

personal_statement:
As I disconnected Millie’s lines from the dialysis machine one morning, she told me that she didn’t want to continue. “I’m done fighting,” she said in an exacerbated tone. I wanted to reassure her, but I wasn’t sure how. All I could do was squeeze her hand and say “I’m here”. Though I had seen medicine cure patients from illness, this hopelessness and lack of energy to continue was something that I could not fix. Two weeks later, Millie died of COVID. As a dialysis tech, I have learned the importance of walking with patients through their healthcare journeys, even if there is no simple resolution. My role was not to fix the problem, but rather to help, to make her feel cared for, and to support her. Similarly, the role of a physician goes far beyond medicine and science. I seek to be a physician who takes the time to get to know my patients and walks with them on their health journey.
        	My commitment to becoming a compassionate physician evolved over many years, with two main driving forces. I have always loved science as it feeds my knowledge, allowing my curiosity to persist. Secondly, I knew I wanted a career that would positively impact society. I fell in love with volunteering in high school, and caring for people in need was a necessity when choosing a career path. Throughout college, I was involved in a service organization, Alpha Phi Omega. I was able to grow that love for volunteering, for giving back to my community in any possible way. The sense of fulfillment this gave me kept me grounded throughout the stressors of college. Upon graduating college, I had taken all of my pre-med classes, researched endlessly about the medical profession, and volunteered for various health organizations. However, I wanted to gain a greater handle on the day to day life of a physician. Thus, I decided to take 2 gap years to further explore by working various jobs. 
          As I reflect on why I want to be a physician, I think about the amazing providers I’ve gotten to work with and learn from. I think about the orthopedic surgeons I currently work with, going the extra mile for every patient. I admire their selflessness, willing to do whatever it takes to provide the best care. I think about the physician willing to pay for an Uber to get her patient to their scheduled treatment. I think about the trauma surgeon, who runs a very hectic clinic, and I admire her always being a team player. One Friday, after the staff had been overwhelmed and overworked, I decided to seek an alternate solution. I suggested switching some clinic placements for a better balance, and it was decided that we would try my idea. The physicians appreciated the efficiency and it ultimately allowed the office to run smoother. The opportunity to apply my problem-solving skills in the context of patient encounters is another aspect that draws me to medicine.
 	My desire to pursue medicine has grown over time and continued to motivate me to move forward. Working directly with patients has allowed me to learn how to use emotional intelligence to determine the best approach—whether the patient needs support, a listening ear, or advice. I have seen admirable physicians work directly with patients throughout their medical journeys, helping to encourage and aid them at every step. The look of relief when a patient’s pain is alleviated, or the grateful smile when they feel that their concerns were listened to and their feelings were validating inspires me each day to continue on this path.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Growing up in a predominantly white, Christian, middle class community, diversity was not something I knew much about. Once I started working, I watched my best friend experience racism in the workplace, and I promised myself to always educate myself on these issues. This was taken to a new level when I studied abroad in Chile. I learned what it was like to be a minority, and experienced prejudice/stereotypes, with the luxury of it not being permanent. I can candidly say this was one of the hardest experiences, and oftentimes found myself in uncomfortable situations. Now, I continually incorporate these experiences into my patient care. I was casting a very frightened 4 year old, recently immigrated from Honduras. While everyone was annoyed at the screaming, I pointed out how scary it must be to be in pain and not understand anything the people around you are saying. My experiences and personal traits push me to work at creating a healthcare system that values diversity and inclusion.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: In college I decided to take a course with a service learning project, Human Genetics. For this project, we worked with the organization Urban Dreams, a nonprofit working for equal opportunity and access to people in the Des Moines community. They provide Des Moines‚Äô inner city with ‚Äúa wide range of human service programs that break down barriers for underserved and underrepresented populations.‚Äù We collaborated with the directors to develop a health survey to help them gather health information on the community they were serving, then went to Urban Dreams throughout the semester to administer the survey. Once we had enough data, we compiled all of the answers and helped to analyze the information we received. This service analysis changed the way they delivered health related services, allowing them to better and more efficiently serve the community. I hope to do projects like this in medical school, using my knowledge for the good of my community.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The COVID-19 pandemic has impacted my preparation for medical school in many different ways. I would have loved to shadow a variety of different specialties to help better understand myself in medicine. Volunteering is also a huge part of my life, and I believe experiencing it in the hospital setting would have been wonderful for myself and my preparation. Furthermore, the pandemic has affected my planning and preparation for the MCAT and applications on a more personal level. Like most people, it affected my mental health and I felt as though my life was on pause. I saw on a personal level how it affected my relationships, as well as the severe impact on my community. I was very lucky to be able to stay in my apartment and keep my job, but working throughout the pandemic was grueling. Listening to physicians, I realized how this has exposed the harsh, and oftentimes dangerous, realities of medicine. Simultaneously, they have inspired me and pushed me to pursue this admirable career.

personal_statement:
From the first second of my life when both my grandmothers traveled from India to cradle me in the hospital to now, family has always been important to me. Regardless of where life was taking us, we would always spend the special occasions together: Diwali, New Years, and the Super Bowl. Spending time with my family is medicinal for me, something I wish everybody could have. I was taught to always be kind and compassionate towards others, whether it was shoveling our neighbor’s driveway during the brutal New England blizzards, smiling at someone who looks sad, or volunteering at food pantries.

Having volunteered at Hope 7 Food Pantry in Troy, NY through my service fraternity in college, I am acutely aware of the effects that food insecurity can have on a family. Food insecurity has peaked during the COVID-19 pandemic, a situation that has been exacerbated by the inability of food pantries to sustain themselves with increased demands. To help, I co-founded a nonprofit, Healthy KITchen, which provides nutritious meal kits to the local Boston community. My days after work are spent constructing meal kits and distributing them at partnering food pantries. As I distributed meals, it became increasingly evident how strong social insecurity is linked to mental and physical health. One night, Hunter, a single father of four, came to the pantry with a look of despair on his face marked with skin lesions that were a result of his liver disease. His son was suffering from Marasmus, a disease caused by severe malnutrition. After hearing this news, I became frustrated that the best I could do in that moment was hand him a meal kit and say, “I’m so sorry to hear that.” Witnessing firsthand the devastating effects that food insecurity and inadequate nutrition can have on family health and more specifically children’s health at the very beginning of life, I wasn’t satisfied with my service; I wanted to treat patients directly.

Eager to better understand the direct role of medical professionals in treating children’s disease, I began shadowing Dr. Paul Lerou, the Division Chief of Neonatology and Newborn Medicine at Massachusetts General Hospital (MGH), on Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) rounds. Parents would occasionally join rounds, many with bags under their eyes, looking like they hadn’t slept in days. One couple, whose baby was suffering from a severe congenital lung disease, was noticeably despondent, as they had been informed that their baby was coughing up blood. The physical and emotional strain that illness had on the family was palpable as their baby was being taken to the operating room. A week after the operation, Dr. Lerou announced that their baby’s condition was improving. The mother breathed a sigh of relief and hugged her husband tightly – it was as if Dr. Lerou’s optimistic words healed the family in seemingly bleak circumstances. The value of being a physician became clear to me and I fell more in love with the role: leadership, service, and compassion.

As my shadowing experience solidified my interest in medicine, I aspired to understand why lung disease was so prevalent in newborns. After graduation, I joined the Pediatric Surgical Research Labs of Drs. Patricia K. Donahoe and Xingbin Ai at MGH, where I was able to integrate clinical and research duties. I have spent two years investigating Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia, a congenital lung disease, using an innovative, non-invasive method of deriving neonatal lung stem cells from tracheal aspirate samples of intubated newborns. This manuscript is currently under review at Science Translational Medicine, where I am a co-first author. As some CDH patients also have known genetic mutations, my other project focuses on characterizing the lung specific role of a CDH associated genetic variant in the ZFHX4 gene. As part of my clinical duties, I recruit patients into the tracheal aspirate collection study and perform consents. A few weeks into the job, I visited the NICU to speak to the parents of a 25-week-old premature baby about our research. I could only imagine the devastation the parents must have felt to see their baby in critical condition with a dozen tubes sticking out of him, stripping away from them the beautiful moments that parents are supposed to share with their child upon birth. Nonetheless, I was impressed by the intricate personal care demonstrated by the medical team for a patient only the size of my forearm. A few months later in the NICU, I ran into the same family who approached me with exuberance. “Look how chubby he is now!” the mother exclaimed, pointing to her baby. It filled me with joy to see the baby’s health improving; the agony of being separated from her baby at birth was finally relieved. The loving look on the mother’s face as she lifted the baby into her arms is what draws me to medicine – the ability to heal not only a person but also their family. 

At an early age, I was taught by my family to always help others and treat everybody with kindness. These lessons encouraged me to pursue numerous scientific and social service projects throughout my life. As a physician, I will strive to serve the community and heal fractured families, so they can have a chance to spend the next special occasion together as one.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Running my nonprofit, Healthy KITchen, has been extremely challenging. After reaping the benefits of eating a high fat and protein diet, I was inspired to provide the food-insecure communities with high quality food during the dire time of the pandemic. As Co-Founder of Healthy KITchen, my role is to manage meal kit distribution, tax paperwork, volunteer activity, corporate partnerships, and market research for new meal ideas. After struggling with finding a balance between food quality and price, we were able to bring our costs down to $2.50 per kit, providing over 1000 meals across my and my partners‚Äô states of Massachusetts, Connecticut, and Wisconsin._x000D_
_x000D_
Converting my frustration over the pandemic into something that has helped my community has been incredibly rewarding. Food insecurity is only one example of the serious flaws in healthcare that exist outside of the hospital. I want to use my power and resources as a physician to fight food insecurity as I proceed in my career.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
I initially pursued a position as a Kumon tutor to pay for my textbook expenses. During the summer of my first year of college, I noticed that ‚ÄúRohit,‚Äù a junior in high school, was struggling with the curriculum. I got to know Rohit as a brilliant kid from an impoverished background. His family relied on food stamps and didn‚Äôt have money to buy new clothes. Rohit was beginning to think he was not meant to go to college, and was considering dropping out of high school entirely._x000D_
_x000D_
Rohit‚Äôs story resonated with me, as I run a nonprofit to help the food insecure. I made it my mission to help him improve in algebra. I set up separate one-on-one meetings to diagnose the pre-algebra competencies he was missing and worked through custom lesson plans with him. Helping Rohit pass Algebra with a B+ is my proudest achievement as a Kumon tutor. Tutoring helped me discover an intense love of mentorship and education, and I want to carry this passion both into my class at Rush and into physicianship.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
I was not prepared for the frustration, anger, and fear in my family when my mother was furloughed from her banking job due to the pandemic. To provide for my parents, I decided to work at Massachusetts General Hospital as a Research Assistant, putting my application to medical school on hold for a couple years._x000D_
_x000D_
We had to learn to process that stress and fear in a way that didn't tear the three of us apart. I challenged myself to re-frame hurtful and angry words from two of the people I love the most. Only by choosing to forgive and helping my parents practice empathy did we make it through this period without destroying our relationships with each other._x000D_
_x000D_
As I helped my family, I invested time into my research project and nonprofit, Healthy KITchen, and sought out shadowing opportunities at MGH. It was enriching to engage with physicians on rounds. I have learned that prenatal psychiatry, palliative medicine, and gerontology are areas of medicine that align with my core passions.

Inst_Action_Desc:
03/24/2018 - Spring first year - Residential Life/In the Presence of Alcohol - warning 
My friends and I got written up for sharing a celebratory drink in our dorm room the day before spring break. I knew that we shouldn't be drinking on campus, and I recognized that I had made a mistake.
 
12/14/2018 - Winter first year - Alc Possession/Consumption - Alc 101 online class, fine
Later in my First Year, I drank too much before an event and got sent home early. I realized that I drank too much. I regretted this and made sure that this wouldn't happen in the future.
 
03/30/2019 - Spring sophomore year - Alc Possession/Consumption - Fine, Individual assessment, warning
My roommates and I were drinking a couple of beers with some of our friends in the dorm room.
I had to meet with a therapist which I went into dreading but left wanting more. This was my first time talking to a mental health professional, and I loved having an unbiased person to talk to about managing stress. 
 
I truly regret that these situations happened. I was underaged, and now my judgment has matured. I have learned my limits and how to manage myself. I have had no other issues since then. I enjoy helping my friends to stay within their limits. I look forward to continuing and furthering a healthy, balanced lifestyle in medical school.
personal_statement:
Medicine has been my whole life. As the son of two Latino primary care doctors, my medical 'education' began early. The honest look into the inspiring and heartbreaking challenges of being a physician combined with my Latino background has shaped the doctor I want to become, one who will speak to patients in their native language and build immediate trust through understanding a shared heritage. My dad was born in Mexico and immigrated to the U.S. when he was three years old. He established and runs the Clinica Latina at the Santa Rosa, CA Kaiser, where he primarily sees Spanish-speaking patients. My mom’s heritage is Mexican and Nicaraguan. She specialized in women's health as an OBGYN. Seeing my parents' impact has given me hope that I, too, can become the third Dr. Garcia, adding to the growing pool of Latin American doctors. I yearn to make the same connections and difference they have made in their communities.
 
The peak experiences of my undergrad years were my trips with Medical Brigades to Ghana and Panama. Working with Dr. Jonah in the temporary one-week Ghanaian clinic was awe-inspiring. He instantly became my hero. I was amazed by his poise in all the surrounding chaos of the crush of people who had perhaps never seen a doctor before. Dr. Jonah had no resources, no fancy equipment, and few medicines, yet he was able to show me how to treat each patient as if they were the only one there - the feeling of giving the patient his undivided attention. So inspiring. It was also my first opportunity to provide direct care to patients, which was energizing and left me craving more. It became clear that nothing else would satisfy me more than to become a doctor. The patients' unique experiences reinforced my belief that healthcare looks different for everyone and should be tailored accordingly for each person. In other words, it's crucial to have a cultural-centered approach when providing health resources.
 
As soon as I completed my Bachelor’s degree, where my minor in Biomedical Ethics was the highlight, I immediately became an EMT to practice medicine. As part of a team, I lead patient assessments and analyze information. Building that rapport and making patients comfortable on what could be the worst day of their lives is highly gratifying. In an emergency, I'm at my best: time is of the essence, direct yet thoughtful communication, quick thinking, assessment, and always learning more.  I love processing tons of information and coming up with an optimal course of care in my role as an EMT. 
 
Being an EMT is gratifying in another way because it calls on me to interact with various populations. Besides the occasional trauma situation, about 99% of the calls in our community are either for homeless cases – specifically addictions and overdoses, uninsured -- or helping the elderly.  I come face to face with ethical dilemmas that continue to reinforce my desire to improve individuals’ health. My past volunteering with unsheltered individuals while at the University of  San Diego helped open my eyes and expand my perspective. In talking with the participants, I realized that non-judgemental conversations help you see the person behind the label, the human being behind the circumstance. Doing one's best not to judge why people are having issues has helped me do my best work every day with an open mind. 
 
A person's mental and physical health are inextricably intertwined. My maternal grandfather passed away from alcoholism when I was 14. He was a Harvard graduate and brilliant Chicano Studies professor who, by the end of his life, was defined by his alcoholism, a sad truth that overshadowed his many accomplishments. His addiction was a formative experience that shaped my outlook on medicine and the physician's role. Many saw his struggle with addiction as a character flaw. This stigma made it difficult to get him the support and treatment he needed. Doctors have an essential role in educating and breaking down stereotypes, supporting patients and their families, and caring for individuals holistically. Beyond this, it's vital to acknowledge that mental health affects everyone of all backgrounds and achievement levels.
 
I love cooking and have many memories of making traditional Latin dishes with my family. Nutritious food was a must in our home. I hope to combine this emphasis with the information I am learning from my Integrative Nutrition certificate to inspire people to make beneficial choices for their health and wellbeing. I'm passionate about food and the social power of bringing people together, and how food can be used as medicine. I hope to get people as excited about food and nutrition as I am.
 
I'm bringing all of myself towards the challenges of providing effective and caring medicine in my future as a doctor. My upbringing, Latino heritage, and life experiences propel me toward a career in medicine, caring for vulnerable communities. People are complex, and their health needs to reflect that. I plan to combine all of the skills and lessons I've learned thus far with continuous learning about the human side of medicine to provide people with the healthcare they deserve.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
While serving pancakes in the community, I talked to one guy who had a string of bad luck, starting with losing his job and his sister getting sick at the same time. He was living out of his car and wanted to do better. It was inspiring to hear him say that this was only a temporary solution as he tried to seek out the services he needed. He was frustrated yet determined to turn his luck around. _x000D_
_x000D_
He gave me great insight into what life on the streets is like and how a few violent/addicted people ruin the image of all homeless people. He said that many homeless women are raped or beaten up by homeless men daily, most of which are unreported to the police and go untreated. It was heartbreaking to hear him express the victims‚Äô helplessness. And tragic to learn that much of the time, they would succumb to their untreated wounds. This sickened me. Better access to health care could prevent this unnecessary outcome. This stuck with me and changed my perspective on the homeless population. _x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
As a contact tracer, I witnessed how the large Latino population in Sonoma County was disproportionately affected by COVID. Despite this, the service announcements offered in Spanish by Public Health were severely lacking. A prime example was the text message we would send when we couldn‚Äôt get ahold of someone. It was all in English, and then at the end of the long paragraph, it said, ‚ÄúEnter 2 for Spanish‚Äù. This was unacceptable. It made Latino patients seem like an afterthought. I imagine this would discourage this population from following up with us, which is unfortunate as they needed the help. I sent an email to my bosses saying either there needs to be a Spanish version or the Spanish option needs to be moved to the top. They responded by creating a Spanish text that we could send, allowing for the inclusion of the often forgotten 26.5% of our population in this county. It felt great to see my solution come to improve access for my fellow Latinos. _x000D_
_x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact:
My research project was cut short, preventing enough data from being gathered to create a topical product. Also, COVID canceled the Scripps trauma internship, where I could shadow ER physicians in a level 1 trauma center. Additionally, I was looking forward to my third Medical Brigade trip, unique in that we would have treated refugees in the camps located in Greece. _x000D_
_x000D_
COVID was not all bad. It brought out the need for contact tracers, so I applied to work as one with my local public health department. Additionally, I participated in virtual tutoring, a marvelous way to connect with youth in a time when we were distanced. I am lucky and thankful that I wasn‚Äôt affected healthwise by COVID. _x000D_
_x000D_
These pandemic years also helped me to have some insights into the need for resilience and dedication to the healthcare field. Doctors and medical staff are celebrated in our communities as heroes, and I believe they are. Despite the challenges, it will be an honor to serve as a future doctor.

Inst_Action_Desc:
Twenty-two years ago, in the spring of 2000, I plagiarized a paragraph of text on an essay. I was running out of time to submit the essay for a class that I had deprioritized in favor of writing my undergraduate thesis. The violation was obvious and in a meeting with the professor and the dean, I received the punishment of a failing grade in the class and a one-year hold on my diploma. This disrupted my post-graduate plans considerably and led to much soul-searching about how I could reach such a low point in my previously unblemished academic life. More than two decades later I can call up these feelings of shame and regret easily.

I believe I emerged from this episode a better student and a more compassionate person. First, I learned to overcome my natural timidity and reach out to my instructors for help when I was struggling in a class. Second, I took responsibility for my terrible decision and lived with the consequences of getting an F in a class and not graduating on time. Third, I learned to forgive myself and move forward, eventually earning three other degrees with zero academic integrity issues. As I look back on this experience with the benefit of time, I believe that finding empathy for myself directly led to my desire to help others.
personal_statement:
One of the hardest conversations I have ever had was with "Ann," a thirty-year-old mother with metastatic cancer. I am a palliative care nurse practitioner embedded in an oncology clinic. It is my job to facilitate tough conversations. Yet the thought of having to tell Ann that she was dying after caring for her for years was devastating. Her oncologist, Dr. V., and I lingered outside the exam room before entering together, knowing what was about to happen. We sat down with Ann and "Jim," her husband, who had been by her side throughout her arduous treatments.

I started by asking Ann how she was doing. She shared her concerns about emerging symptoms and asked what they meant. Why were her legs stubbornly swollen and not responding to diuretics? Why were the whites of her eyes gradually turning yellow? Why was she becoming increasingly fatigued? Dr. V. explained calmly. Then Ann asked us point-blank: how long? The question hung in the air. Dr. V. paused for a moment before slowly saying, "I think a few weeks, maybe a month."

Seconds felt like hours as we sat together in the dense silence of realization. In palliative care we call this "bearing witness," because all one can do in a moment like this is to try to meet the patient where they are, silently acknowledging an unfathomable reality.

The visit ultimately ended the way many of our encounters do in the oncology clinic--with a discussion about Ann's hopes and fears. Dr. V., leading the conversation, masterfully kept the focus on what we could do at that point to relieve Ann's symptoms. After Dr. V. left to attend to other patients, I spent a long time with Ann and Jim, helping them process this difficult prognosis. I explored with them how they could break the news to their young daughters and extended family. Finally, I explained that hospice care could help Ann stay comfortable at home, minimizing the need for repeated trips to the hospital.

Conversations like this stay with me--not only because they are emotionally fraught--but also because they reveal how relational medicine can be. As a nurse I learned how to care for patients at the bedside, an experience I will forever cherish. As a nurse practitioner I learned how to build rapport with patients and support them through some of the most difficult moments in their lives. There was no single moment when I decided to pursue medicine--my interest evolved organically and gradually through caring for patients living with serious illness as well as working alongside patient-centered physicians like Dr. V.

Patients like Ann, who had the audacity to live well in the face of terminal illness, inspire me daily to learn and grow as much as I can in order to help patients make sense of their illness experiences. I now seek a deeper understanding of the "why" behind the pathology I see every day, down to the molecular level, so that I can, in turn, use this knowledge to empower patients to make informed decisions about their health.

Physicians such as Dr. V. inspire me by bringing their humanity to every patient encounter, listening carefully, responding thoughtfully, and acting with resolve. The strength of the patient-physician relationship can be the deciding factor in whether someone skeptical of Western medicine decides to trust their oncologist's expertise and accept a standard of care treatment that has the best chance of prolonging their life. It can also determine whether someone who is desperate to live at all costs can, with enduring guidance from their primary care physician, realistically accept that they are nearing the end of their disease trajectory. In observing my physician mentors' meticulous attention to patient needs and their persistence in fulfilling those needs, I recognize my own aspirations to medicine.

Working with seriously ill patients throughout my nursing career, both in geriatrics and oncology, has crystallized my calling to serve this population. What shape this takes after medical school is yet to be determined. I am most interested in the intersection of primary care and psychiatry, as improving health among the seriously ill requires a multidimensional approach: physical, mental, and social determinants of health must be addressed. As a physician I hope to lead inter-professional health care teams where all of these domains are represented.

Like Dr. V. compassionately breaking bad news to Ann and Jim, I want to be that trusted and expert guide who understands the disease process at the deepest level, walking alongside patients and families, keeping watch over their health, and leading the health care team through whatever challenges arise. I want to listen deeply to patients' priorities through countless conversations so we can decide together how to proceed when times are tough. Above all, I want patients to feel that I have truly cared for and about them. I know the path ahead in medicine will be lengthy and challenging. I also know how painful it is to lose a patient suddenly, as well as the unexpected joy of seeing a patient with metastatic cancer have an excellent response to treatment. In pursuing medicine I choose to lean into the long hours, the tough decisions, the joys of healing, and the sorrows of loss.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Danny was a young Latino man who had lost his dishwashing job during the pandemic and was unable to find work. He was behind on his rent and was worried about becoming homeless. He was spending most of his day staying inside and drinking alcohol, not talking with anyone, withdrawing from friends and family. Suicide had begun to look like his best option for relieving his burdens._x000D_
_x000D_
As a volunteer crisis counselor for 988/Lifeline, I took Danny's call that night. Though I could not solve all of Danny's problems, I could provide empathic emotional support and help him identify ways to stay safe from suicide. I connected him with Alcoholics Anonymous and a free mental health clinic for therapy. Calls like this one bring into sharp relief the disparate ways in which the pandemic has economically and socially crushed a population already vulnerable to economic insecurity and racial injustice. Callers like Danny inspire me to serve the community as much as I can since the needs are so great.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: In my work as an outpatient palliative care provider, I try to address the primary care needs of some of our underinsured patients within the limits of my training. Julio was a 50 year old man with metastatic cancer who presented to clinic with left scrotal pain and dysuria. He had Medicaid insurance, but it only covered oncologic care in our clinic. After work-up revealed chlamydia causing acute epididymitis, we realized that per CDC guidelines, we needed to give Julio an intramuscular injection of ceftriaxone plus oral antibiotics, but his insurance would not cover the injection in our clinic or any of the primary care clinics in our system. I did not want to send Julio to the ED to get a single dose of a cheap, generic antibiotic, so I conferred with my supervising physician. We decided to give the dose ourselves at Julio's visit--and the clinic pharmacy donated the dose (~90 cents). We were glad that Julio did not have to go to the ED for a single shot due to insurance reasons.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
My post-bacc program moved to remote live learning, which made it challenging to engage with professors. However, I adjusted to this change and thrived. It was helpful to be able to replay Zoom lectures later to solidify my learning._x000D_
_x000D_
As a palliative care nurse practitioner I worked throughout the pandemic seeing oncology patients as they came in for chemotherapy infusions. Goals of care conversations took on special urgency. We proactively talked with patients about how aggressively we should treat a severe COVID-19-related illness based on their preferences about using life support. I also had to advise patients that dying in the hospital could mean dying alone due to strict visitation restrictions. Many patients were adamant about not wanting to die in the hospital under these circumstances. To honor these preferences I worked alongside our team to minimize hospitalizations and ensure that patients who wanted it were able to have in-home hospice care at the end of life.

Hrdshp_Comments: I am first-generation American and my parents emigrated from Iran and Poland. They were both fleeing war and poverty and seeking more educational opportunities in the United States. While better educational opportunities were found, my parents were both low-income for a long time. This history impacted my childhood because we experienced housing and food insecurity from the time I was born until about age 4. We relied on food stamps until about the age of 4. Additionally, being part of a diaspora led to a lack of community and meant that I was often left alone as a child and was later responsible for caring for my siblings. This has led to me having less time to contribute to my studies and extracurricular activities, especially in high school and college. I am proud of my family for crossing oceans to give me the opportunity to pursue my dreams and grateful to be so deeply involved in my family’s home life.
personal_statement:
Care has fundamentally shaped my life trajectory. To me, good care takes into account the whole person and their changing needs. It is scientifically sound, and works around institutional barriers in order to tend to a patient in their real-world context. As a volunteer community health care worker at the Berkeley Free Clinic, I have been providing essential preventative care to low-income patients in the East Bay for two years. This fulfilling work has allowed me to provide holistic care to my community while combining my love of biology and community connection. In addition to my clinical work, my family’s personal medical experiences have taught me that health is about more than pathology, and that evidence-based, radically inclusive care is lifesaving. I am grateful for the opportunity to continue to impact others’ lives in the best way I know how—with my hands and heart in the medical field.
Growing up with two physician parents has taught first hand me that being a physician is an intense commitment. As a child I breastfed, played, and grew up in on-call rooms. Some of my strongest childhood memories are of my parents caring for me when I got sick. Their kitchen table discussions—about which antibiotic to prescribe, whether or not I needed an x-ray following a bike crash, or if they needed a third consult with one of their colleagues—not only actively included me (“What do you think, Sahra?”), but also gave me valuable opportunities to ask questions and learn about my health. This was the first place I learned, through their example, that my own thoughts about my health were valued, and that patients deserve to be explicitly involved with their own care and treatment plans.
Helping two of my siblings through health crises of their own reinforced the importance of holistic, patient-centered care in my world. My younger brother was recently treated for epiglottitis and this life threatening infection rocked my family’s world. I’ve never seen my parents so stressed, but the physicians that my dad interacted with at the hospital were calm and kind; they cared for my family when we desperately needed them. Later, when we learned about this infection in EMT school, I was struck by how empowering this knowledge was—without my parents’ quick thinking and the technical know-how of the physicians and nurses in the emergency room, my little brother would have died. Another sibling has faced different struggles related to gender identity and their experiences at school. Watching this sibling’s gender identity be questioned, disparaged, and mocked in school (leaving them afraid to go to kindergarten) has bolstered my belief that all aspects of a patient’s health are important and worthy of attention. In helping them navigate the school system, I have found that the inclusive care and compassion provided by educational professionals has improved my sibling’s lived experience as a genderqueer person and positively impacted their health. Just as technical knowledge of disease saved one brother's life, the inclusive care my other sibling received was also instrumental in shaping their health outcomes. This experience, coupled with my work experience at the Berkeley Free Clinic, has reified my belief that inclusive and equitable care saves lives  
The Berkeley Free Clinic’s philosophy revolves around the idea that health care and health knowledge should be free and accessible to all, and that the homeless, undocumented, low income, and queer communities, as well as communities of color who we serve deserve exceptional care where they feel safe and comfortable. I was recently able to provide this accessible care during a routine tuberculosis screening for a patient. The blood test came up positive, and the patient needed to be connected to a sputum test and physician to determine if she had latent TB. This proved quite challenging because, like many during the pandemic, she was recently laid off, without health insurance, and living in a crowded household. The care plan I crafted for this patient included sliding scale referrals, signing her up for state insurance, and a follow-up timeline. Being able to tangibly help this patient and ensure she wasn’t left behind by a quickly moving, profit-based health care system was fulfilling and gave me hope. The future of health care does not have to be bleak—there are good people who care deeply about the people they help everywhere. After working in the clinic for two years, I am impassioned to continue providing care to underserved populations, and I hope to use my power and autonomy as a physician to give people the best compassionate, evidence-based care possible.
I’ve learned firsthand that interactions with doctors can be life changing. What is likely a small, routine moment for a doctor can be a deeply impactful encounter that a patient remembers forever. This is both the burden and blessing of being a physician—you are always short on time but never on responsibility or impact. Due to my time providing thoughtful, affirming, and scientifically-sound collaborative care at the Berkeley Free Clinic, as well as my personal experiences of caring for my brothers, I believe I would be a positive part of a patient's health journey and an empathetic and informed physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Across age, sexuality, gender, ethnicity, and life experience I‚Äôve been able to effectively build rapport with each and every patient I see to provide more effective and personable STI health information.
