One example of this is when a transgender and polyamorous woman came in for an STI panel. This patient had previously avoided getting screened because visiting the doctor was extremely uncomfortable for her; she was often subject to unnecessary and invasive questioning, misgendering, and awkward fumbling as providers figured out how to deal with a trans person practicing a non-monogamous relationship structure. By making this patient comfortable she was able to ask every question on her mind, have needs outside of the STI panel met, and was enthusiastic about returning for frequent screening. I learned from this encounter that rapport building is a valuable tool for providing patient care across populations.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I have volunteered hundreds of hours to provide healthcare with a team of diverse healthcare professionals in an urban setting, the Bay Area, for the past two years. In my time at the Clinic I have pushed for more comprehensive Mgen and Hepatitis testing, more inclusive language for patient care, and updated HIV care referrals. This persistence in pursuing the best care possible for our patients shows that I prioritize clinical excellence for all. Being a healthcare professional in this particular geographic location has made me especially sensitive to the needs of the unhoused, undocumented, and queer communities of color I interact with every day. These groups have been the primary focus of the advocacy work I do in the East Bay and I plan to continue emphasizing healthcare equity and access in my medical career.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Throughout the pandemic, community need for preventive care increased. When people were unable to see their physicians for regular appointments they still needed PPE supplies, TB tests, and flu shots. I continued to work at the Berkeley Free Clinic during the pandemic and was able to provide these resources. Our tuberculosis (TB) testing shifted entirely to telehealth; I became very comfortable navigating digital appointments and outside lab testing. When I had a patient test positive for TB via a blood test I needed to connect her to a physician for further care. This proved quite challenging because, like many during the pandemic, she was recently laid off, without health insurance, and living in a crowded household. The care plan I crafted for this patient included sliding scale referrals, signing her up for state insurance, and a follow-up timeline. During the pandemic I was still actively serving my community‚Äôs healthcare needs.

personal_statement:
Besides their fun bow-tie shape, farfalle pasta holds a lot of sentimental value to me. The charge nurse during my shift asked if one of the volunteers would assist in serving a patient their meal. Amongst the silent crowd, my hand bolted up and I picked up the meal tray before walking over to the patient’s room. I knocked and entered with a smile as I put the tray down and revealed a display of bow tie pasta. As I sat down and began cutting each pasta piece into two even triangles before serving it to Len, I couldn’t help but comment on the golf channel on the TV while we were chatting. Len’s face immediately lit up as he delved into how much he loved to play before his illness. We quickly bonded over his most memorable hole-in-ones to long drives and risky bunker shots. He was an avid PGA follower and lived for the miles of grassy fairways. I spent the next few days pondering whether Len would ever return to the sport he so dearly loved. I felt for his situation and was happy to have been able to comfort him during a time of physical distress through the game of golf. This was a lasting interaction which first sparked my aspiration of becoming a physician grounded in compassion and shared experiences. 
          My passion for volunteering and interacting with others led me abroad to Ecuador on a medical service trip. Between triaging patients, teaching children how to brush their teeth during my dental rotation, and observing Pap smears, I immersed myself into a variety of healthcare roles. I distinctly remember during my shift at the OB/GYN clinic, our first patient was a middle-aged woman who came in visibly distressed and anxious about her visit. I recalled the stigmas around women’s health within many South American rural communities I researched, such as their spouses often dismissing the importance of these preventative measures. When I led our first patient to the examination room, I greeted her warmly in hopes to ease her nervousness of the novel environment. The OB/GYN carefully talked through treatment regimens and thoughtfully answered her questions before proceeding with her examination. I was relieved at how the patient felt more at ease once she met the physician, who took her time getting to know her patient.  
          I was in awe of the role of the physician after observing how these women were receptive to such life-saving examinations. It truly would not have been possible without the physician’s patience and awareness of cultural barriers, which really made their responsibilities stand out to me. There was no one formula that the physician followed when seeing each patient by the way she prioritized listening to their concerns. The rawness I witnessed in the examination rooms and the role I had in improving the lives of patients were lasting sentiments that made me even more proud to have been a part of this team. I left Ecuador excited and inspired as I knew I wanted to dedicate a lifetime of responsibility towards diagnosing and serving others through healing. 
          Community service has constantly been an important part of my identity and it was through acts of service that I discovered my desire to become a physician. My role as a volunteer in the hospital taught me the importance of interpersonal connections in the physician-patient relationship. Further, working in the mobile clinic taught me about the various roles a physician must take on to provide empathetic and lasting care for their patients. Even now, my observations in the oncology clinic at the National Institutes of Health put a smile on my face under my mask as the physicians naturally intertwine personal conversations with their patients’ scheduled visits. My passion for service, particularly within underrepresented minority groups, has led me to currently serve my local Washington D.C. community as a tutor for low-income elementary school students outside of my day job researching biological differences between races in prostate cancer. 
          I often envision my own future conversations with my patients and am motivated by the thought of serving as their primary advocate for their health. There is no greater act of service that I can see for myself other than the role of a physician, who has the highest responsibility of fighting for a patient’s life. My service-oriented background continues to motivate my desires to comfort and heal others through the power of medicine. I believe that lasting treatment is grounded in prioritizing open dialogue and shared human experiences. The countless interactions with diverse individuals I’ve had along my journey to physician-hood not only leave memorable conversations, but also valuable experiences that I will bring with me as I move forward. It is because of these interpersonal relationships that I feel committed towards diagnosing and treating future patients by serving as a bridge between medicine and individualized care.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: When I volunteered in Ecuador with medical clinics, I recognized how drastically underserved rural populations were as I could see the relief that many of these patients felt to receive long-awaited care by the physicians. I also became aware of the cultural stigmas surrounding preventative care as the physicians empathetically navigated these conversations with their patients. Being immersed in the rural communities of Ecuador strengthened my understanding of the cultural and socioeconomic barriers that are vital for enhancing patient-centered care to eliminate healthcare disparities. I hope to participate in global health initiatives throughout my medical training by continuing community outreach and keeping these issues in active conversation to encourage positive changes. In particular, I look forward to participating in the many clinics that care for underserved populations in the Chicago area to continue educating myself on how to better serve these communities. _x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation: At the beginning of the pandemic, I was inspired to support my local communities through virtual tutoring for students from low-income households as I recognized the challenges of social distancing learning. My love for working with children motivated me to come up with engaging ways to teach my students as I recognized their learning environments were oftentimes distracting and had limited resources. Not only did I get to help each of my students improve academically, but I was excited by how diversifying learning approaches inspired them to enjoy learning rather than fear it. The patience and communication I showed my students is what I intend to draw from as a future physician committed to demystifying medicine within underserved communities. I hope to participate in similar opportunities at Rush Medical College such as the Buddies program and the RCSIP youth advocates program to continue empowering younger generations. _x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact: After graduating, my desire to gain more clinical and research exposure before applying to medical programs led me to a research fellow position at the National Institutes of Health. My research interest in health disparities inspired me to pilot several projects on the genomics of race in prostate cancer which I look forward to progressing until my matriculation in 2023. The pandemic set back my productivity as our laboratory was operating as partially remote for the majority of 2020 and into 2021. Further, the effects of social distancing within the clinical centers limited the number of shadowing hours I was able to achieve as well as opportunities for in-person community outreach. In lieu of this, I have been volunteering as a virtual tutor and also educating my community as a blood donor ambassador for the American Red Cross since 2020. Further, I plan to continue these extracurricular endeavors throughout the next year.

personal_statement:
Truth is, I didn’t always know that medicine was for me.  

Throughout high school I played guitar and saxophone and after graduating, I was recruited into several rock bands and quickly became the primary composer for these groups. Our bands published several albums and were doing quite well financially with royalties and booked venues. But life on the stage ended when our trailer was stolen the night before leaving for a nationwide tour. Under the cover of darkness, all of our instruments and gear were taken. Life had taken a turn for the worst. 
Oh, woe is me!

As if that wasn’t enough of a harbinger, fate chose once again to intervene soon after we had replaced our belongings. 
While laying down a new hit at our favorite music studio, a rooftop maintenance man accidentally dropped a cigarette into the building’s insulation and the entire place ignited. My bandmates and I each scrambled out, coughing and wheezing, as we watched the local firemen spray destructive foam all over our favorite instruments and recording equipment. Our dreams truly went up in smoke that day.

I decided then, that such a lifestyle wasn’t sustainable. I love music, but I felt I needed to do something more meaningful with my time on Earth. I decided to travel abroad, not only to practice and learn more Spanish, but to experience another culture and to perhaps gain some much needed clarity. So a solo ticket to Buenos Aires was bought and I climbed aboard an overnight flight to Argentina.
 
We have a tendency, I suppose, before a vacation to expect smiling faces, cleanliness, rays of sunshine, and a general pleasantness at our destination. Right? 

What I saw after hailing a cab from Ezeiza International Airport left me speechless.

As I peered out the window of my taxi along the route to the hostel, at the sidewalks and byways, I noticed some things I'll never forget. What I saw were not just the homeless collecting scraps of cardboard for recycling, but families garbed in patchwork fabric sitting outside of buildings begging from those entering and leaving. I witnessed genuine “shanty towns”, neighborhoods composed of corrugated roofing panels with dirt floors and wandering stray animals. Barefoot, shirtless children approaching vehicles at the interim between red and green lights with dirty outstretched hands and elderly people ravaged by disease attempting to climb onto over-crowded buses.

I left the airport with a grin of positive expectation, and left my cab with a sunken heart. 
The wind was taken out of my sails.

My interest in medicine was truly cemented after witnessing these conditions in parts of South America. The countries there are beautiful, but they also have levels of poverty we frankly do not see here in the United States. We have our problems, but they are worse elsewhere. There is much greatness in the world but also much darkness swept into its corners.

Seeing the disparity in healthcare between these countries and our own helped me to recognize what an important role that medicine and public health play in a community. It made me appreciate what we have, and made me want to contribute.

Perhaps it is hubris, but my interest in medicine is simply a desire to serve. To pitch in and make a difference. This may sound cliché, but we all need to do something significant with our lives. Over the past year I've endured the untimely death of a very close friend, and watched my grandparents fall victim to dementia and physical disability. I sincerely wish there were more I could do for them or could have done for him.

It was in this spirit that I elected to enroll in an accelerated EMT course and began working for my county's local ambulance service earlier this year. I have since seen some grim things, but also experienced some emotions I have never felt. Regardless of what happens in my life, I am certain I will not forget the pulseless, apneic patient my partner and I managed to bring back. His was the first life I had ever saved, and it only bolstered my interest in healthcare.

Medicine seems like the best place for me to do good in the world, and that sentiment is a heartfelt one.

I know that my pathway to this point is not as traditional as some - I did not jump straight into college with a pre-med track like many of my colleagues.  I like to think, however, that some of my unconventional adventures (music, working, marrying outside the country) will give me a fresh perspective on my medical journey and have allowed me to build up a working discipline that will carry me through medical school, residency, and beyond.

My hope is to rise to the occasion and to the high standards of becoming a physician. I believe that medicine is the noblest profession and I eagerly await my turn to contribute.

Thank you for your consideration.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Nine years ago I met a girl in Argentina. Our backgrounds couldn‚Äôt have been further apart. We grew up with different languages, different customs, holidays, diets, the people there even took ‚Äúsiestas‚Äù! I spent much time in the country and soon became familiar with many of these changes. People are people. My spanish improved, and I grew to know and enjoy her family and their part of the world. She and I eventually became engaged and finally married last year. She moved here and is now learning more about our own culture. There are still a great many things we do differently, but we‚Äôve learned to love the asymmetry. I drink coffee in the morning, she drinks yerba mate with a funny straw out of a dried out gourd. I primarily use the Imperial system, she almost exclusively uses the superior metric system. Our relationship wouldn‚Äôt be the same if we came from similar backgrounds, I wouldn‚Äôt change a thing!
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
RMC's emphasis on supporting and providing for the under-served communities dovetails with what I've come to appreciate through my experiences local and abroad. In my own home state of Florida, there is a disparity in healthcare availability I was not acutely aware of until I began volunteering at a free clinic in a disadvantaged nearby city just this past year. _x000D_
_x000D_
Volunteering here has opened my eyes to some of the public health issues we face in medicine. The patients we see are poor, uninsured, and often have a difficult time navigating our healthcare system. I have a keen interest in serving these segments, and helping facilitate a community-centered education environment, and am curious as to what other roles that doctors can take to help at the population level._x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact:
I feel that I am fortunate. None of my friends or immediate family have died from COVID-19. Although the pandemic has made it difficult to shadow doctors and limited some of my planned research projects, I do not regret this. I know that people are still working hard on the frontline and these efforts take priority._x000D_
_x000D_
As the individuals in society with the knowledge to help the sick and injured, it is the responsibility and duty of providers to serve. This is, in part, a reason I became an emergency medical technician. I wanted to help where others couldn't. I felt a strong obligation. This is also the reason I would like to practice medicine.

personal_statement:
I come from a family embedded within medicine. My parents, siblings, and many aunts and uncles work in healthcare: surgeons, anesthesiologists, and pharmacists. I remember many holiday dinners in which my family would share stories about exciting surgeries, rare medical anomalies, and even heart-warming patient encounters. I would just listen in awe, eyes darting back-and-forth, trying to follow the conversation. Despite all of them specializing in different fields, one thing is consistent: everyone exudes passion for the art of medicine and taking care of others. My father would often tell me that going to work never felt like a job because of how fulfilling it was to leave work making patients happy. Naturally, as a teenager, I gravitated toward experiences focused on medicine. Being a twin brother, one also pursuing medicine, I have learned how important individuality is to me. I feel so fortunate to have a family that casts medicine in a positive light, but it’s important that I discover my own reasons for pursuing it.

One of my first eye-opening experiences was when a base runner slid into my brother’s leg during a baseball game. As soon as his leg started looking more swollen and purple, we took him to the doctor’s office. We were approached by a physician, who, after asking my brother what happened, intervened right away. I know my brother was trying to be tough, but I could see that he was worried (twin telepathy). But with the doctor at the bedside, the concerned look on my brother’s face dissipated. After the culture results came back as S. aureus, he debrided the area, made a small incision, and drained out all of the blood. After I got home, I looked up some of the doctor’s words—S. aureus, necrotic tissue, and hematoma—to understand why he did what he did. I tried to apply what I learned in my biology classes to understand how the hematoma and infection even began.
	
As a high schooler, I was intrigued by this experience. In addition to having a wonderful learning opportunity, I learned that medicine isn’t just an interdisciplinary evidence-based science. My brother had a meaningful interaction with the physician who reassured him, provided him with quality service, and guided him on a road toward recovery. Physicians need empathy and compassion, along with an endless intellectual curiosity to treat their patients. As I realized I aspired to embody these characteristics, what was initially a fleeting interest became a dream.

Fast forward two years, my sister told me that there was an Emergency Medical Technician (EMT) program at our local fire company. I thought it would be the perfect opportunity to build upon my interest in medicine. I found myself immersed in the didactic lessons and fascinated to learn about human anatomy. When I obtained my certification, I took away more than just my certification and a job opportunity: a wealth of medical knowledge I was so eager to continue growing and applying. 

One of my most memorable experiences in EMS occurred at a gymnastics competition. A 15 year-old girl got on a bar, flipped, and landed on the back of her neck, lying in pain. My fellow EMT and I arrived promptly on the scene. As trained, I performed my trauma assessment. I could see that the patient was scared and crying, asking whether she would be paralyzed. I tried to console her like the physician did to my brother. Despite the uncertainty, I told her she would be okay. As we arrived at the hospital, I was relieved to put her in the great hands of the emergency room (ER) doctors. I was filled with satisfaction. I was able to use my knowledge and training to help someone. However, I left the hospital never knowing whether the patient was able to make a full recovery. I wanted to see the X-ray of her C-spine. I wanted to have the knowledge to understand why she felt lethargic and tingly. I left wanting to do more than help the physician; I desired to help heal, to learn.

As I continued my experiences as a health coach and ER technician at the end of college, I gained a newfound appreciation for the importance of service to the community, especially for low-income and homeless populations. I was able to understand their challenges by conversing with them 1:1. I gained a better perspective on why they had trouble maintaining their weight and why some come into the ER every night. Since obtaining the Eagle Scout rank, I hold myself to a standard of finding innovative ways to improve the lives of my surrounding community. I hope that by becoming a physician, I can continue this life-long goal and exude passion for the vulnerable patients I have had extensive exposure to.

As a child, my vision for becoming a doctor was a distant dream. With more life experiences, I was able to gradually relate to why my family loves being physicians so much. My own, unique reasons have become more refined as I have learned the role of empathy, higher-order thinking, and compassion in crafting a successful physician. Given my clinical experiences and curiosity in medicine, I think I can build a long-lasting profession that I am passionate about passing the knowledge I learn to patients.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: My experiences as a weight-loss health coach have broadened my perspective on obesity and allowed me to understand the unique social challenges that many minorities face. ‚ÄúPatty‚Äù was a low-SES black woman who explained to me how hard it was to manage her weight. She worked 6 days a week and had little time to exercise while caring for her family. With my training in nutrition and motivational interviewing, it was my job to provide her advice and positive affirmations. I would try to be considerate of her time and money by suggesting easy and cheap organic foods. I would also find fun ways to teach unhealthy vs healthy foods from a nutrition label. With these strategies, we were able to collectively work through solving her problems. Weight loss is not one-size-fits-all. It‚Äôs important to cater to their needs and be conscious of their background and capabilities. In the end, Patty lost 20 pounds, and it was satisfying to be part of her journey.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Occasionally when I come home during college breaks, I would drive with my dad to my local church to investigate the condition of the six park benches around the playground. The burgundy paint was chipped and the wood was cracked, but the benches were still in great condition for the several years they have been here. I had a personal connection to these benches‚ÄîI built them for my Eagle Scout project. Part of my motivation to build these benches was to express my gratitude for my local church - the home base for my troop meetings. I have formed incredible memories with other scouts and other church members such as holding ceremonies, cooking, and playing dodgeball in the parking lot. Seeing a need for church kids to congregate by the playground, I realized that park benches were just one way to give back. It is warming to know after several years that my work was appreciated by those that helped me and the kids and parents that continue to use them.
7_-_COVID_Impact: In the spring of 2020, my virtual organic chemistry lab consisted of watching YouTube experiments and my professor narrating along the way. I was used to donning my yellow-tinted lab coat, sitting next to my lab partner, and eagerly waiting for the next step in my lab manual. With all of this gone, I took the initiative to find external online resources that were able to supplement the class material. As an active, kinesthetic learner, I looked up simulations of the experiments to get a more immersive experience. While it was not the same as an in-person class, the simulation resource helped me get a better sense of the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù and ‚Äúhow‚Äù compared to the passive learning my professor provided me. I was therefore able to teach my lab group what I learned, spreading the knowledge in ways they said made a lot more sense. COVID-19 taught me to improvise and maximize my learning potential as much as I can even when my learning environment isn‚Äôt optimal.

personal_statement:
My version of “the talk” came when I was twelve years old. My aunt pulled me aside at a family hot pot night to explain in detail how women had little tadpoles in their bodies that would turn into babies, with no mention of the role of the male partner. Growing up, my mother always told me to avoid “cool” fruits and iced drinks because that was what caused vaginal discharge, which was to be avoided because it is considered dirty. My brother and I laughed at how silly they were. It wasn’t until college that I realized that the lack of reproductive health knowledge was anything but laughable. I see the shame they carry about their bodies, the way my mother would snap at me whenever I had a question about my own body with a “wut dut; hm ho gong” [that is impolite; don’t speak of this]. I learned to avoid asking her health-related questions, automatically assuming that I would be met with a cultural myth, false information, or disgust. At university, I realized that my other first-generation American friends had similar experiences with their own mothers, where certain issues with their bodies were taboo. Experiences at home and working with communities very different from mine have taught me to acknowledge and address the stigma and barriers that exist within healthcare. After discovering this prevalent issue, I want to become a physician to deliver culturally sensitive care while creating a safe space for patients to learn about taking preventative measures and long term sustainable plans to improve their health outcomes. 

The Ecuadorian physician I shadowed called in a boy of eight complaining about stomach pain. Seeing the horror on my face after allowing me to hear the rice krispie sounds of the parasites, the doctor casually explained that this was common. Dewormers needed to be prescribed frequently, but the boy didn’t have access to treatment given his location in the rainforest. Dozens of malnourishment and diabetes cases later, I began to notice a pattern in the patients. With the two physicians, a few nurses and the hundreds of patients we saw during those two weeks, I looked around and wondered how this was sustainable. Most of the patients came in with chronic conditions that could not be solved in a single clinic visit. I had the realization that this clinic trip most likely would not have a significant impact without long term care. As exciting as it was to witness dedicated professionals working tirelessly to provide for these patients with conditions I had never seen, the experience triggered a deep, introspective questioning into how I wanted to approach medicine. I realized that patients require consistent care with physicians who can dedicate time to not only treat conditions but also prevent them from arising. I now understand that I want to pursue a career in community medicine where I can build long-term relationships and work on preventative measures to address the chronic diseases facing the community I’m serving. 

Similar to how rural communities in developing countries can be negatively impacted from a lack of health literacy and access, our patients in Oak Park, Sacramento were afflicted with the same conditions due to socio-economic barriers and a historical distrust of medicine. I had a new awareness of parallels reflected in my patients’ lives at Imani Clinic, a free student-run clinic serving the Black community. As a response, I trained to become a Health Educator at Imani to work alongside these community members like “Beth” whose son told me she was at a loss with managing her diabetes. In the beginning, I could tell she was reluctant to listen to my advice on nutrition given that I came from a different background. I patiently explained that I wasn’t going to discourage cultural foods, but simply suggest alternative ingredients, like greek yogurt instead of sour cream, as a first step. Once she saw she could still enjoy fish tacos, I noticed a shift in her body language as she began offering her own ideas. We ended the session with a small list of recipes and a plan to take the stairs to her job instead of taking the elevator for a bit of exercise, showing me the importance of working with the patient by listening to their narratives to achieve sustainable health goals and guide the care I provide. Both abroad and locally, I’ve learned that a key factor of medicine is being mindful of those I will serve and mindful of how my own presence and identity as someone wearing a white coat will affect others, especially in underserved communities. 

During quieter moments, I explained  normal bodily processes to my mother and saw the flash of realization on her face. The same look appeared on a patient’s face after I listened to her concerns. These moments were where I discovered that my strengths lie in individual communication. I take pride in being a safe space for patients to explain their concerns, ask questions, and take control of their health. Seeing how Imani physicians can bring hope to patients who have none has been a great model for the physician I want to become. It brings me great joy being able to help patients who were initially intimidated by the road to recovery become confident in taking charge of their health.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: The diversity of experiences growing up in San Francisco allowed me to take multiple perspectives from a different culture. I felt the fear of western medicine through my immigrant parents‚Äô eyes while I educated my parents about why their childhood foods could make them sick. While serving Black and Latinx communities in Sacramento by leading events, initiating the mental health clinic, and intaking patients, I gained many creative solutions for communicating with English learners that I used with my own family. The experience also gave me the information and confidence to speak with my parents during the height of the BLM protests. Without education on implicit bias or social determinants of health, my parents held onto ignorant views, but we were ultimately able to cultivate a safe environment for discussion. From this experience, I learned to lead with patience and compassion when approaching diverse populations, which I hope to incorporate into my interactions with future patients.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Imani Clinic had targeted services for diabetes management, cardiovascular health, and dermatology among many. I noticed that one was missing and in great need, especially for our patient population battling a lack of health insurance and even homelessness. I started the Imani Mental Health initiative with the Behavioral Health Team in response to signs of depression and anxiety in our patients. Firstly, I made sure to incorporate advice from others who were successful in my position, secure training for our clinic volunteers on how to approach potential patients, and formulate a working protocol for screening and referral to services. After I left the position, I implemented my data science skills from my MPH program to analyze screening data to better understand the prevalence of mental health needs in our population. Hopefully, my work could inform our efforts to provide patient-specific mental health services to our patient population.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I was fortunate that personal challenges of COVID-19 were limited to difficulties in the virtual transition of school. As a TA, I used creative solutions to effectively communicate the material while learning my own course material. The pandemic was most impactful in how it exposed deficiencies in our health care and education systems. Learning for kids on the autism spectrum suffered, as seen through the rows of missing assignments for my clients. Yolo County experienced severe underreporting of STDs since testing is largely done in person. Many Imani patients canceled their appointments because of the bumpy transition to telemedicine. COVID-19 exposed the gaps in these systems, revealing that we must adapt to our changing landscape to ensure that those most vulnerable do not suffer.

Hrdshp_Comments: Will fill in later
personal_statement:
One year after my family arrived in the United States, my dad sustained life-changing medical injuries after his first colonoscopy. In the act of removing a polyp, the physician punctured his colon. After being unable to stand due to severe pain following the colonoscopy, my dad was rushed back to the hospital for an emergency surgery that removed one-third of his colon. Throughout this ordeal, my dad feared voicing his concerns despite his declining medical and emotional state. As an immigrant with only a sixth-grade education, he felt incapable of questioning his physician’s authority. Despite the severity of his injuries  and growing fears, his physician offered no thorough explanation, sincere apology, or words of comfort. For both of my parents, this traumatic experience began a life-long refusal to seek preventative care, until bothersome symptoms escalated to chronic illnesses that required medical interventions. At 7 years old and without the ability to speak English, I felt helpless as I watched my parents -- models  of strength and perseverance in an unfamiliar country -- appear small and defeated in a room surrounded by doctors. I could only offer empty words of comfort from the side of my dad’s hospital bed. As a physician, I will no longer be powerless. Instead, I will actively reclaim a space in healthcare for low-income immigrant families like my own.  

As I grew older, I strove to ensure that my parents were not dismissed like this again. I learned English and quickly became the representative for my entire family. When my dad needed refills on medications or when my mom searched for affordable insurance plans, I was there to communicate on their behalf. However, by speaking for them, my parents were once again stripped of the resilient independence they showed at home. I tried to remedy this by functioning as their interpreter instead. Although it was a slow and imperfect process, I saw my parents come closer to the animated storytellers that confidently expressed their emotions and demanded rightful treatment in Spanish. I am confident that as a bilingual physician, I will bridge the language gap faced by non-English speaking patients that hinders their quality of care. By eliminating the need to interpret at all, I will reaffirm my patients' capacity to actively play a role in their care - ultimately empowering historically disadvantaged individuals.

When I started college, I worked toward this mission by joining HAVEN, a free clinic that predominantly serves Spanish-speaking patients like my parents. In my role as a Patient Services director, I saw that the mistreatment my parents experienced in healthcare spaces was not unique, and in fact plagued many immigrant narratives. However, cultural and linguistic differences were only partially to blame: financial inaccessibility of medical care was particularly devastating among the undocumented population obtaining care at HAVEN. When patients worried more about their crushing medical debt than their critical illness, it reminded me of the months’ worth of paychecks spent on my dad’s emergency surgery. I felt frustrated that after so many years, access to healthcare for families like my own had not changed.  In my position at HAVEN, I could begin to address this by offering financial assistance from the clinic. However, I realized that being an advocate for vulnerable patients, just as I wish my dad’s physicians had, required using my voice inside and outside the clinic. 

In one instance, I interpreted an encounter where the attending physician failed to insert an IUD twice due to a manufacturing error, repeatedly telling the assisting student, “It’s broken!” I translated these remarks, even though the physician reprimanded me for doing so both times.  Witnessing the patient’s confusion about why a simple procedure was causing so much pain and taking so much time, I saw my own dad. I understood the traumatic consequences of weaponizing language to exclude a patient from knowing what was occurring to their own body.  In seeing the parallels between low-income patients and my own parents, I am driven by a personal commitment to health equity: regardless of language, education, or financial capabilities, everyone should have access to high-quality healthcare. As a physician, I will ensure that patients, such as those from my Latinx community, are not denied this right. 

My experiences have shown me that provision of medical care is not enough by itself. Many families, including my own, face socio-economic insecurity that hinders health despite the most rigorous treatments. To actively combat health disparities, these systemic issues must be addressed. Thus, I want to be a physician that also reforms health at the systemic level by using my voice to advocate  for public policy that dismantles structures oppressing communities of color. Through this work and dedication to culturally accessible care, I will ceaselessly empower low-income immigrant patients as we work together to access the highest attainable standard of care. I will make my parents’ experience the exception rather than the norm.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
As a first year college student, I was embarrassed watching my roommates pick out things for our common room at Target that I knew I couldn‚Äôt afford. To my affluent roommates, choosing between paying for decorations or for textbooks was never a worry. _x000D_
At Yale, I continued to be reminded of the wealth and status that surrounded me that I was not privy to understanding. Whereas I initially felt intimidated by this privilege, I eventually pushed myself to engage with my classmates‚Äô complex stories ‚Äî as a First Year Counselor, I listened to students from all socioeconomic backgrounds struggle with imposter syndrome and dream of positively impacting the world. By guiding them through their individual difficulties adjusting to college life, I realized that although I couldn‚Äôt fully empathize with their lived experiences, I could still listen and grow from them. Thus, I learned to navigate these differences while feeling empowered in my own status as a low-income student. _x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
During one of my HAVEN shifts, a Latinx patient refused to get a COVID-19 vaccine. After her medical team conceded and left, she expressed concerns over side effects and fear of exposure of her documentation status. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt get it, but you do,‚Äù she said in Spanish. Understanding her distrust of the healthcare system as a Latina, I spent the rest of the visit reassuring her of the vaccine‚Äôs benefits, confidentiality of her status, and offered translation support scheduling the shot._x000D_
Through these efforts, that patient eventually agreed to get the vaccine. Her medical team then incorporated the same assurances I provided the patient to their future visits. Thus, I was able to use my shared immigrant experiences with medical neglect and state discrimination to rebuild the patient‚Äôs trust towards the life-saving vaccine. Through this practice of culturally competent care, I helped increase vaccine access to this patient and other members of my Latinx community at HAVEN._x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact:
The COVID-19 pandemic affected my family‚Äôs physical and financial well-being. Due to business closures, my mom lost her job. Simultaneously, my dad was forced to work unsafe overtime as a frontline worker where he contracted COVID-19. At 65 years old and unable to recover from lingering side effects, he decided to retire with only Social Security benefits as a safety net. Thus, as I managed academic responsibilities 800 miles away, I also filled out job applications, submitted Medicare paperwork, and took on extra work shifts to cover additional expenses for my dad‚Äôs emergency dental care. Therefore, I had difficulty studying for my MCAT and delayed taking it for various months. _x000D_
Overall, the COVID-19 pandemic redirected my attention towards home, making it difficul to take a challenging workload or pursue more extracurricular activities.

personal_statement:
My parents’ motivation to leave Bulgaria with an infant and $300 was the lack of soy milk. I was born with a lactose intolerance so severe the doctor said I would die without a soy-based formula. My parents found a connection who sold it out of a basement, but the supply was inconsistent. After reading about a child who died of the same disease, my parents decided to use their green card at the ages of 40. Healthcare troubles continued; with a persistent fever and no health insurance, I was rushed to a Boston clinic, where my parents’ fear was calmed by Dr. Leader. As they tried to explain the lack of insurance, Dr. Leader interrupted to say there would be no charge, having intuitively understood our immigrant status. While too young to remember, I spent my bedtimes begging my mom to tell me these stories. Even now, I’ll request a retelling, moved by how much my parents and Dr. Leader did to prevent me from falling through the cracks in healthcare systems.

In high school, we hosted a dinner for Bulgarian students, where I met Ivan, a college student and EMT. His face lit up when talking about patients and the EMS adrenaline rush as I hung on every word. Later, I researched how to become an EMT while still in high school. My parents were frustrated with my interest, worried I would be traumatized, but they were also worried that if something were to happen to them, I might not finish college due to a lack of any other familial or financial support. I took EMT night classes to establish a back-up career, but secretly I hoped to do more, like save a life or help a family.

EMS became my first true love. I even spent my time off-call thinking about patients, like “Jan,” who had suddenly fainted during a funeral. By the time Clay, my paramedic partner, and I arrived, Jan was awake, insisting she was fine. Clay knew something was wrong, and I knew to trust his 20-years-in-EMS gut instinct. So I asked Jan about her manicure and where she got it done, easing us into a conversation. I helped her into the ambulance, where the EKG showed that Jan was having a major STEMI. While panic set into me, I held Jan’s hand, reassuring her. Once we arrived at the hospital, I let out a sigh of relief, thankful that Clay had caught a diagnosis I might have missed. Driving back to the station, I interrogated Clay about how he knew it was cardiac. He gave me the best advice I’ve heard: protocols might be unambiguous, but patients are not. It was like putting on a new pair of glasses—I began to see all the cracks patients could slip through and grew determined to prevent such slips.

In college, I balanced my on-call EMS schedule with computer science classes. I chose my major with the intent of closing healthcare gaps via tech solutions. Medtech was rewarding as a programmer, but I was enticed by the broad scope physicians held. I was coding multiple algorithms for various stroke scales, but I was also bound by a single EMS stroke protocol while physicians had the education and authority to make more nuanced decisions. This feeling, combined with sitting at a computer instead of interacting with patients, left me restless, wanting to do more.

Sitting in Lion Tavern, Tom, a classmate, and I were trading EMS stories, but his were from his Army medic days. He described a cauterizing agent they used in the field that I had only recently read about being added to civilian protocols. The Army seemed likely to provide new challenges, the ability to use my college degree, and the possibility of commissioning as a medical officer. It would also provide financial stability, something still needed years after immigrating, and time to figure out what might come next. After enlisting, there were unfortunately no medical slots. Motivated to serve, I chose a tactical IT position—even hospitals need internet.

The COVID pandemic afforded me a position in the Army’s COVID response team while stationed in South Korea. Working 72 hours a week was tiring, but being adjacent to our unit physicians, like Dr. Ric, was energizing. At each shift change, he answered my eager questions about the rapidly evolving research; even if he wasn’t a Commander, he led from the front. After a slew of night shifts, I picked up the newest patient list for our data analysis, as was routine. This time, I stared at the pieces of paper in my hands, suddenly aware that this was the closest I had been to patients in months. The papers felt heavy. Working to better healthcare systems was not enough for me; I wanted to treat patients too, while leading improvements in healthcare and inspiring others to do the same. In short, I wanted to be a physician.

EMS is still my first love, but now, I can do more. Empowered by the fact that for the first time I know exactly what I want to do with my life, I have retaken classes I once took as a naïve 18-year-old feeling a familial pressure to study science. Every step I take to become a physician is meaningful as it leads me to be able to make the kind of impact Dr. Leader had on my family while contributing to medtech solutions and caring for patients. It’s not just ensuring immigrants feel safe to seek medical care, or even soy milk, but that all patients susceptible to slipping through the cracks receive the care they deserve.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
When we moved to New Hampshire from a diverse Boston, I was the only immigrant student. Although I lacked an accent, I had a foreign name, weird lunches, and secondhand clothes. Not always understanding why I wasn‚Äôt accepted, I went through a phase of difficult assimilation during which I rejected anything Bulgarian. The ongoing reality of proofreading my parents‚Äô English and explaining cultural differences bought me time, however, to proudly grow into my ethnicity. I am grateful every day that I never lost this integral part of who I am._x000D_
 _x000D_
This experience showed me that if you don‚Äôt fit into the mainstream majority, forming an identity and advocating for yourself become daily, unavoidable challenges. That stress can be alleviated by others taking the time to understand, or acknowledging they have misconceptions. Every individual has their own story; my experiences have taught me to remember that the picture I see is one-dimensional and the truth is much more complex.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
As an EMT, I volunteered and worked throughout rural New England, sometimes responding to patients over an hour away. Many patients dialing 911 had chronic illnesses which had reached the point of acute emergency as they lacked the resources to effectively manage their illnesses._x000D_
 _x000D_
Not all underserved populations look the same, but they all face health inequities. Having grown up medically underserved as part of a Bulgarian immigrant family, I became more sensitive to these inequities. In my region, EMS had a shortage of Advanced Life Support (ALS) providers, who could be paramedics or Advanced-EMTs. I felt this shortage as an EMT-Basic, radioing for ALS support for critical patients during understaffed night shifts. While conducting a programming internship at Dartmouth College, I successfully took an Advanced-EMT class and earned my certification as a small step towards closing a gap in healthcare access within my community.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
The pandemic has significantly restricted my ability to volunteer or moonlight in EMS. Despite state shutdowns, the Army continued in-person work. With heavy precautions required to ensure the safety of soldiers, I was unable to work any clinical job while serving._x000D_
_x000D_
Shadowing was also difficult to secure, and I was very fortunate that my Army unit‚Äôs lead physician authorized me to shadow him. While most patients were young men, I was able to observe a medical practice focused on maintaining the fitness of the Army._x000D_
_x000D_
While the negative impacts of the COVID have been endless, the pandemic provided the spark for me to apply to medical school. Assigned to my Army base‚Äôs COVID response unit, I saw how physicians led the response while treating patients. Even though it didn‚Äôt particularly pertain to my position, I learned more about the medical side of the pandemic and the physician role. The more I learned, the more I came to believe that medical school was the path I wanted to take.

Misdemeanor_Desc: During my freshman year of college, I was driving home to see my family for Easter when I was pulled over for speeding. This occurred is Mexico, Missouri on 04/20/2019 in which I exceeded the speed limit by 11-15 miles per hour which is classified as a misdemeanor class C in Missouri. For this offence, the sentence imposed was a fine of $70.50. For my own improvement, I enrolled in a driving safety course and learned about the dangers of speeding and the potential consequences. As I have gotten older, I have realized the impact that one person driving at a higher speed can have on others around them. I now always drive diligently and have not incurred any other violations.
personal_statement:
Silence fell over the room as the ultrasound technician’s smile dropped. Before I knew it, light from the hallway flooded the room as the physician slid the curtain back. The physician directed their attention to my parents and my focus shifted to the dinosaurs and colorful fish adorning the walls, making my 16-year-old self feel out of place. I had overheard the words “blood clots” and the rest of the conversation fell silent to my heart beating in my ears. The physician and their students seemed like shadows at the edge of my ICU bed. I heard the physician ask the residents what indications would be present to move forward with an amputation of my left leg. Working diagnosis: unclear. 

From that day forward, I became fearlessly inquisitive and deeply involved with my physicians and care team. I kept the door open during rounds so I could listen to conversations and plans, seeking the deeper meaning beyond the oversimplifications often presented to me. After an extensive clinical work up I would finally have a tangible term that would explain why deep vein thrombi had ravaged my body. Diagnosis: May Thurner Syndrome. This held deep meaning to me.  I finally had my first cue to explore the vast field of medicine. I dove headfirst into anatomy and physiology, seeking to understand the human form and its anomalies. When it was time for me to apply to college, I knew I wanted to study human physiology. 

Shortly after I launched my academic career, I craved to be a part of the healthcare team.  I distinctly remember one night, working as a pharmacy technician, I was asked to send trauma kits to the Emergency Department. Through the double doors of the Emergency Department trauma bays, I was captivated by the multitude of hospital staff in yellow contact gowns surrounding a confused and fearful patient. The panicked face of the patient contrasted the calm and confident demeanor of the attending physician. The emergency room physician orchestrated the diverse medical team like a master conductor, each specialty taking their solo when the conductor signaled. Diagnosis: hypovolemic shock due to rupture of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Then it clicked for me. A patient, plagued with a vascular condition like I was years ago, laid in front of me. This moment assisted in my realization that I was one step closer to the opportunity of providing care to patients just like me.

I yearned to be closer to physicians and patients, an opportunity that was not present in my time as a pharmacy technician. I pursued a position practicing clinical research within the Emergency Department, where I could be more directly involved in the evolution of treatment and progression of medicine. Peering over more shoulders, working alongside physicians, and interacting with patients daily were highlights of my new position. I was finally able to not only observe, but also participate in the clinical setting by using hands on training.

Despite learning technical skills such as phlebotomy, obtaining vitals, and point of care testing, I still felt as though I was not as involved as I wanted to be. I watched attendings and residents huddle together to practice case studies. They would walk through each case in meticulous detail starting with the physical exam, exploring the pathology, pharmacological options, collaborating with outside specialties, diagnosis, following with patient education. The complexity of each case would increase, requiring the residents to work as a team. I envisioned myself within this team, gaining knowledge, unfolding patient mysteries through the ever-improving tools of modern medicine.

My curiosity led me to a study exploring early sepsis detection in the Emergency Department using infrared technology. New clinical research continues to provide tools to help serve patients faster and more effectively than ever before. Through research, I was not only learning about the process of clinical research, but potentially shaping the way physicians will identify sepsis in their patients. Sepsis may not have been their final diagnosis and may have originated from a multitude of pathologies, but the suspicion of sepsis opens the door for necessary and timely interventions for patients. Ultimately, sepsis taught me that an initial diagnosis can be uncertain and may be discovered over time. This ambiguity calls for early intervention and management through pattern recognition. 

The diagnostic process gives a patient a way to learn about medicine and their own physiology - a gateway to engaging with the healthcare system and promotes shared decision making between physician and patient. It not only paves the way for treatment but gives the patient hope and understanding within medicine. My diagnosis connected me to the field of medicine and allowed me to take part in my care. It served as a catalyst for my passion and instilled me with ceaseless curiosity. It helped me understand what was happening to me. I strive to give this understanding, peace of mind, and hope for resolution for my future patients. Ultimately, I hold the strong belief that my 16-year-old self would be immensely proud of the unlimited potential I wield to further explore medicine and serve others just like me.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: When entering a role as a public servant, being competent, respectful, understanding, and empathetic to the ever-diverse population is crucial. When I was diagnosed with my disability, I entered a community of dissimilar individuals that taught me so much about myself and others. I grew to understand that one‚Äôs potential for growth is not limited by the confines of others and that the key to understanding others is being an active listener. Being an inquisitive and attentive listener to others makes others feel heard. This is crucial for building rapport with those unlike yourself as you show an interest in learning about that individual. When working with people of different abilities, I learned how to support others while being extremely flexible and adaptable. I hope to continue my growth and understanding of others and apply it in my medical education as it will help physicians create stronger bonds with their patients and improve the way physicians work with each other.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: In my leadership position as Program Outreach Coordinator and Instructor within the ‚ÄúSave MO Hearts‚Äù initiative, I provide free hands-only CPR training to anyone in our community during outreach efforts. This initiative has a specific focus on educating women, and children, especially underrepresented minorities. Our goal is to increase the public‚Äôs comfort with performing hands-only CPR and educate our community on how race, age, and access can affect one‚Äôs survival chances in a cardiac arrest. I have had the opportunity to work with all kinds of different organizations and educate my community on the importance of providing CPR even as a bystander. I know this will positively impact my community as it will increase survivorship and increase people‚Äôs comfort with assisting before EMS can arrive. I hope to continue this effort to educate the public and address health disparities that span the nation.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The COVID-19 pandemic impacted my life in a variety of ways. Academically, all of my academic coursework was resumed online only while all of my volunteer, physician shadowing opportunities, and extracurricular activities halted at this time as well. I also lost essential employment, removing me from my living situation and moving me back to the Chicagoland area into my parents‚Äô home. I sought employment within healthcare due to the increased need. I felt that since I had the license to be able to help, that it was my duty and desire to do so. Therefore, I returned to the pharmacy technician position to assist my community. While COVID-19 may have impacted my professional opportunities and hindered me financially, it strengthened my desire to become a physician and became further invested in my community. Ultimately, my experiences with COVID-19 confirmed my aspiration of becoming a physician despite all setbacks.

personal_statement:
What in the world does “idiopathic” mean? I was diagnosed with Idiopathic Adolescent Scoliosis at the age of 13. As my spine curved unrestrictedly, so did my curiosity for the word “idiopathic.” Is IAS genetic? I did not have a family history. I grew interested in uncovering the biological mechanisms of IAS and through reading countless articles, I discovered there were possible environmental causes. Although I was unable to ascertain the cause of my IAS, I had opened doors to a dimension of human health I had never encountered - environmental health. My following experiences as a researcher and environmentalist opened my eyes to the power of preventive medicine, particularly from the perspective of environmental health, and impassioned me to pursue a career in medicine.

As an undergraduate at Cornell, I immersed myself in the intersection between human and environmental health as a field researcher for Jane Goodall’s One Health Initiative in Uganda. One of my tasks consisted of collecting fecal samples from livestock and villagers to obtain data to map paths of disease transmission between organisms. I recall ascending 3000 feet to reach isolated communities and rambling in broken Rukiga to obtain consent. I spent afternoons in the lab, conducting centrifugal fecal flotations with intermittent solar power and water that I fetched from a local stream. Our objective was to implement prophylactic measures to combat a disease outbreak. The zoonotic disease research I conducted helped me understand just how much human health is influenced by a variety of factors, including those environmental.

I will always remember “Enos,” an 11-year-old I met in rural Uganda. Every morning, I observed him herding goats to the local pond. He caught my attention, as he looked too young to be out of school. As our paths crossed one day, I greeted him in Swahili. “Hujambo!” The language barrier motivated me to spend a few hours each day learning new words and phrases in Swahili. Curious, I questioned why he was not attending the local school. He explained when he was nine, his mother had passed away due to complications related to COPD. “It was charcoal cooking,” he said. His mother had worked as a vendor, grilling maize over charcoal fire for decades. Her doctor had advised her to limit her exposure but the damage had already been done. Recognizing the environmental hazards that adversely affected Enos and other villagers motivated me to combat such disparities as a future physician. Perhaps if his mother’s untimely death could have been prevented, I would have known Enos as an 11-year-old student instead of as a goat herder. Upon each subsequent encounter with street vendors, I made it my mission to spread awareness about increasing ventilation. I even harvested and distributed local palm leaves to be used as ventilating fans. My experiences in Uganda taught me invaluable lessons about health inequities and the importance of prevention, but I yearned to learn more.

While working as a scribe at Long Beach Memorial Emergency Department, I met “Fernando,” who arrived at the ED for evaluation of chest pain. He was a construction worker with a history of smoking and pleural mesothelioma due to workplace asbestos exposure. He had been advised to quit smoking after his diagnosis but was never successful. As Fernando prepared for discharge, I asked the physician if a social worker could place a referral for tobacco cessation behavioral counseling. To my anticipation, the referral was placed. Fernando’s case confirmed that the environmental health disparities, as seen in Uganda, are very much present in my own community and made me cognizant of other drivers of health inequity. It was apparent that the amalgamation of social, environmental, and socioeconomic factors can transcend the pathophysiology of diseases, such as cancer. I understood the role of a physician extends beyond diagnosing and clinically treating patients to include addressing external factors at play.

My experiences affirmed the tenuous nature of our relationship with the environment. To achieve health equity as a future physician, I will strive to contextualize environmental burdens within each patient’s course of care. Environmental change is a pervasive, yet silent disease and I believe multidisciplinary efforts are necessary to tackle imminent health challenges. The confluence of human medicine and environmental health presents a unique opportunity for physicians to better understand drivers of health inequities, particularly in underserved communities. By enlisting my experiences, I hope to not only treat, but also prevent illnesses from a holistic perspective and to push a dialogue in which environmental health is inextricable from human health.

With a spinal curve of 55 degrees, partially corrected with a posterior spinal fusion, I have experienced how medical interventions can profoundly change one’s life for the better. I have seen how systemic health inequities, compounded by environmental factors, detrimentally affect health outcomes. Guided by laughs with Enos and a relationship with Fernando, I aspire to unite medical intervention with holistic, empathetic patient care in order to prevent diseases, promote well-being, and achieve health equity.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: While volunteering in Uganda, I observed various obstacles that women face in safeguarding their health. Given polygamy is accepted, many women expressed fear of banishment from their marital homes if they didn‚Äôt bear children. I tried to mask my initial shock when assisting numerous pregnant adolescent girls. However, with research and conversations with local practitioners, I recognized that many of the barriers that women face are due to the socio-cultural realities of the region. My experiences challenged me to not only reevaluate my biases, but also to examine how such biases can influence patients in the US. To work towards achieving health equity, I must acknowledge that I am not immune from implicit biases. I will educate myself on pertinent social issues, participate in discourse, and aspire to create a respectful environment for patients. I want to play an active role in my community to build the cultural competence to treat diverse, patient populations with effective care.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I had the opportunity to conduct a state-funded, community health assessment of an underserved neighborhood in California. We utilized key community based participatory research (CBPR) principles to inform our project design and goals. While working around the initial challenges the COVID-19 pandemic, I virtually interviewed senior residents, performed qualitative analysis of transcripts, and compiled a final report based on feedback. At each step of the research process, we collaborated with key stakeholders to ensure we were accurately capturing their perspective. During a bi-monthly city council meeting, we elevated the resident‚Äôs concerns to the mayor. I recognized that community engagement allows for communities to develop their own research goals and promote culturally relevant research. Furthermore, my experience emphasized the importance of community engagement in addressing the systemic socioeconomic disparities that influence health outcomes in vulnerable populations.
7_-_COVID_Impact: During the first year of the pandemic, I became the primary caregiver for my 88-year-old grandmother, who has a history of dementia. Becoming a caregiver meant limiting my social interactions, delaying my extracurricular and clinical activities, and taking extra precautions to protect my grandma. There were various challenging aspects to becoming a caregiver, such as keeping an eye on her whereabouts throughout the day and night, maintaining my composure during her moments of aggression and agitation, and ensuring she was compliant with her medications. However, it was also an invaluable experience caring for my grandma. On her good days, she taught me how to cook traditional Korean dishes and write Korean-style calligraphy. Although the onset of the pandemic was a difficult time for many individuals around the world, I believe I was given a truly unique opportunity to not only bond with my grandma, but also learn important aspects of caring for vulnerable, older aged individuals.

personal_statement:
As a summer tradition, my family took a trip to Saguaro Lake, which was a great way to escape the blistering heat. We had been out all day and eventually found a spot to relax and eat lunch in a small cove. As we sat and ate, a group of cliff jumpers stood about thirty feet above our heads. My brothers and I begged my dad to join the fun. Initially hesitant, he gave in and allowed us to go, taking comfort in that we were all competitive swimmers and lifeguards. Our longtime family friend, Ruthie, was also visiting for the weekend and decided she wanted to jump.

We all jumped off the cliff into the icy water and swam back to the boat, laughing. The splashes echoing below increased the adrenaline in each jumper waiting to go. It was Ruthie's turn, and everyone cheered her on from the boat, "Three, two, one, go!" Ruthie stepped and propelled herself through the air, hurtling towards the emerald green lake. Complete silence followed the thundering smack. We stood there stunned, waiting for anything. Suddenly, a gasp for air echoed through the cove. Ruthie surfaced, shrieking, "My back!" My lifeguard training immediately kicked in. I dove in and swiftly put her into a spinal stabilizing hold, keeping her airway above water. I began treading water to keep her horizontal in hopes of minimizing further injury. I comforted her as I helped her through the water, ensuring she would be okay. I continued to tread with her while awaiting the rescue boat to assist. The EMS personnel and I boarded her onto the rescue boat before they raced back to the docks, sirens blaring and lights flashing. A helicopter evacuated Ruthie to the nearest hospital, where she received treatment. While visiting her, the attending physician told us she fractured her spine in multiple places. Had it not been for my life-saving actions, there could have been a much more devastating injury. Although this experience was Ruthie's, through this event, I realized I could make an impact in the world. The outcome could have been much worse without my quick thinking and willingness to act. This experience was the first domino in the line pushing me into the field of medicine.

A few years later, I began scribing at the CHOC emergency department while completing my undergraduate degree. At first, I was overwhelmed by the speed and intensity of the job. I had to learn quickly and adapt to the flow of the ER. I dreaded the shifts and felt great anxiety being responsible for over 65 patient charts daily, each with crucial information. Starting this job in the middle of record-high patient numbers at the hospital was a lot to add to my already stressful schedule of schoolwork and swim practices. Still, I knew if I overcame the challenges, the experience would be worth it. After a few months of late nights in the ER, I became more comfortable and grew to love it. The skills of typing up visits quickly, keeping track of a list of patients, and monitoring lab/imaging results became second nature. This allowed me to dive deeper into medicine, asking questions about reasons for specific orders and understanding why certain results can paint a picture of a diagnosis. I would test myself on the differential diagnoses based on histories and exams before the physicians would tell me, which felt like solving puzzles. Scribing brought me to the center of the physician's thought process, which further fueled my passion for medicine. 

One shift that stands out above all began with a code-critical overhead. We waited outside an exam room for a few seconds until a crying mother was pushed in on a gurney, holding her infant in a swaddle. I saw the baby's pale blue skin as the nurses yelled, "No pulse, no breathing!" My heart sank. I knew that a patient arriving with no signs of life had a slim chance of leaving with them. Immersed in the chaos, I still needed to do my job. I remained calm and listened carefully while a brief history was shouted above the noises of IV placement and beginning CPR. Amidst the whirlwind of activity, I watched and recorded timestamps as the physician completed multiple rounds of compressions, pulse checks, and medication pushes. While many of us stood close by, fearing the worst for the baby, hope for survival was fleeting. When I thought the team could do nothing more, the infant started crying. The noise was weak at first but gradually grew to a loud, piercing cry. I never thought I would be so happy to hear screaming, but it meant this child was finally breathing. Joy rushed over me as I thought about the mother being able to go home and hold her baby again. I will never forget waving to the happy baby over the mom's shoulder as they walked out of the ER that day. As I waved, I reflected on the contrast between their arrival and departure. The physician's leadership in saving the child's life greatly inspired me to want to help others in such a way. Although there will be stressful moments, I am eager for the day I can help those in need, just as I witnessed firsthand.

My life's journey has prepared me to succeed in medical school and as a physician. My personal and professional experiences have added to my passion for medicine, which will never leave.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: My collegiate swim program developed a relationship with Ceres Elementary in Whittier, California, during my undergraduate career. We volunteered monthly to help with fitness activities, homework problems, and classroom learning. In this underserved community, many children lacked a supportive family structure and came from violence in the household, so they often had trouble focusing in class and gaining self-confidence. During our time together, we helped them through homework problems with positive reinforcement and provided them with the one-on-one attention that nurtured learning habits. Being granted this opportunity to make an impact in these children‚Äôs lives is something I will cherish forever. This experience taught me that you might never know what is happening in anyone‚Äôs life. I plan to take what I learned from my time with these kids and apply it to my care as a physician, treating everyone with respect and reserving judgment for every patient I encounter.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: While scribing and researching at CHOC Children's emergency department, I played a significant role in projects that aimed to improve the health of residents surrounding the area. The ACEs project is a tool that identifies adverse experiences linked to negative health outcomes later in life. With this, I screened for child neglect, physical abuse, sexual abuse, and emotional abuse. After the screening, I worked with our in-house social workers to assist when needed. The Social Determinants of Health project was another tool I used in the emergency department to screen families for food or housing insecurities. We provided families access to food pantries, food banks, and affordable housing programs. During my work on these projects, several families told me how impactful these programs were in easing the burdens of raising a family. I am eager to continue my education at an institution where I share these values and further improve the health of my surrounding community.
7_-_COVID_Impact: When the COVID-19 pandemic began, I was finishing my last semester of college in 2020 and excited to move on to my next chapter in life. During this last semester, I had difficulty when all my classes transitioned to online. I had previously taken online courses, so I knew I preferred in-person learning in the classroom. This was an unfavorable change for me, but I was able to prosper by working on organizational skills and self-discipline to maintain good grades. I also worked as a scribe in an emergency department, allowing me to see firsthand what many only heard about on the news. Mask shortages, busy nights spent seeing high acuity patients in pop-up overflow tents, and the high tension of the looming pandemic made this period especially stressful. I am grateful for these experiences in the hospital because they have prepared me for the highs and lows of the duties of a physician that have kept me motivated in my preparation for medical school.

personal_statement:
On September 20, 2017, Hurricane Maria hits Puerto Rico. Winds exceed 155 miles per hour and 30 inches of rain fall in eighteen hours. Sitting in my college room, 2000 miles north of Puerto Rico, I wait with my phone on my nightstand. Heartbreaking videos show houses ripped apart and power lines toppled across streets. I think of my grandparents hunkering down in their old house and my young cousins holding their terrified dogs close. Soon after, my father leaves for Puerto Rico, to the home where we had lived, to help our family and bring medical supplies to the community. Given Abuelo’s progressing Alzheimer’s disease and Abuela’s fragile health, I hope that my grandparents might return with my father. However, I know in my heart they will not, and I respect their unwavering love for and loyalty to their island. 

Watching helplessly as the death toll increases, I am keenly aware of how different it is for me to seek healthcare in Massachusetts, than for my family in Puerto Rico. The hurricane exacerbates a growing issue on the island - access to high-quality healthcare - and the destruction causes 70% of hospitals to immediately shut down. That said, I am mindful that my own family’s struggle represents only one among many healthcare disparities. Every day in the U.S., marginalized groups struggle to access high-quality and culturally competent healthcare. After Maria, a deep conviction grows inside of me. Short-term, I will travel to Puerto Rico to assist the rebuilding efforts. Long-term, consistent with my goal of becoming a physician, I will devote my career to improving healthcare equity.

My desire to become a physician took flight in high school when I conducted research investigating the impact of exercise upon the longevity of C. elegans using an electrotactic flow chamber or “worm treadmill.” While presenting at the International Science and Engineering Fair, I was inspired by conversations with fellow students about their work on assistive devices for Alzheimer’s and with NASA researchers about their efforts to decrease astronauts’ muscle degeneration through space exercise. In college, I eagerly reviewed data and wrote countless drafts of presentations to describe the effects of glucose upon fertility in C. elegans. Today, I delight in the opportunity to coordinate all aspects of a clinical research study for patients with testicular cancer at Dana-Farber. Facilitating monthly meetings for oncologists across the globe, I excitedly anticipate the development of new treatment options for the patients that I have come to know. From these experiences, I have developed a deep passion for applying principles of science to help patients live healthy and where possible, disease-free lives.

While research led me to the field of medicine, it is my ongoing experiences with patients that underscore my deep desire to provide culturally competent care. This desire first became clear while working at a large pediatric practice that struggled to recruit Spanish-speaking pediatricians. Frequently asked to translate for patients, I could not help but feel the happiness of families when provided with someone who “spoke their language,” both in words and background. Questions about ear infections often blossomed into conversations about shared heritage. These conversations revealed how important it is to understand and appreciate patients’ cultural beliefs and ideologies when developing patient-provider relationships.      	

Another milestone in my health professions’ journey has been my recent role at Dana-Farber helping to launch a prostate health literacy study.
