Regrettably, for millions, limited health literacy diminishes access to high-quality medical care. Illustrative of this, I can vividly remember offering to walk a patient line-by-line through a dense consent form because there were no other ways for them to take in the information. Seeking to overcome this issue with high-risk prostate cancer patients, I developed pictograms and handouts that display a patient’s treatment timeline and associated side effects. With each educational interview I conduct, I am filled with a hope that these materials may positively impact at least one patient’s cancer journey.  		        	

It has been almost five years since Maria stormed across Puerto Rico, and over two years since the hurricane of COVID-19 began its wrath. Sadly, my worries about my grandparents came true. Abuelo lost his battle with Alzheimer’s shortly after the hurricane, and Abuela succumbed to COVID-19 after 38 days on a ventilator. Although devastating, these losses have only strengthened the commitment that I made in my first-year dormitory room. Since that time, I have continued to engage in research that nurtures my enthusiasm for applying scientific principles to help individuals live the healthiest lives possible. I hope to continue channeling my passion for promoting healthcare equity, having had the opportunity to provide culturally competent care and to develop health literacy interventions. I cannot imagine a more suitable role for me than to become someone who can provide the expertise and the resources needed to help the most challenged among us as they work to overcome the storms that buffet their lives.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: At Dana Farber, I am working on a health literacy project which involves a range of custom handouts and pictograms for high-risk prostate cancer patients. Through this study, I have spoken with patients from a wide range of backgrounds. Some common misconceptions have arisen throughout interviews with patients from all literacy levels; for instance, few know where DNA is found. As most of our patients do not have a science background like I do, I have realized that I may enter these discussions with preconceived notions. For me, a double helix immediately denotes DNA, and the knowledge that cells are the building blocks of all tissue is fundamental. Entire genetic consults have been based off similar assumptions, and these may leave patients feeling lost. Observing this confusion has taught me never to assume that a patient possesses what I believed was ‚Äòbaseline knowledge.‚Äô I have learned to abandon any assumptions, as excellent patient education is the key to providing quality care.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As a Hispanic American, I can share cultural knowledge and traditions with the ever-growing Spanish population in the United States. I first realized the power of a shared background as a camp counselor welcoming a new student, Jav√≠, into our group. I will never forget his sudden burst of excitement when he realized that he was talking to ‚Äúsomeone with an accent in their name like him.‚Äù Our connection allowed him to feel more comfortable in a group of strangers as he shed his previous shy state and grew into an outgoing individual. Learning from this experience, I have used my background with patients at work as it helps to make them feel more comfortable when answering sensitive questions. That said, I acknowledge that I do not share a background with everyone and therefore seek to constantly educate myself on other cultures, traditions, and experiences. In doing so, my goal is to always be culturally humble and welcoming to those of differing backgrounds.
7_-_COVID_Impact: When COVID-19 hit, classes were moved fully online, where they remained for the following year. Due to no prior experience with online classes, I faced a steep learning curve in which collaborating with peers and meeting with professors was a challenge. My summer position within the 2020 Weiss Summer Research Program at Holy Cross was soon cancelled ‚Äì this was an experience I had been looking forward to for over a year. Most importantly, my family was directly affected by COVID-19. My grandmother lost her life to COVID-19 after being exposed in her assisted living facility in Puerto Rico. Not being able to see her or to visit Puerto Rico complicated a really difficult time for my family. However, COVID-19 did provide the opportunity for reflection and growth as I strengthened my abilities to communicate, remain adaptable, and practice resiliency in difficult circumstances. These are skills I have put into practice at Dana-Farber, and ones I will continue to use in medical school.

personal_statement:
As a young child, I held onto a secret hope that one day I would wake up healed.  Each morning when I woke up feeling numb and disoriented due to low blood sugar, I felt severe disappointment settle in the pit of my stomach. My endocrinologist eventually confirmed it during an appointment as I sat on the table, staring at the floor: diabetes was here to stay.  
Years went by, but I still dreaded the searing burn of the needle hitting my skin and the ache after every bolus. My dread compounded when I thought about all the other little things: the way my pump tubing would catch every door knob that I passed, how I wouldn’t be able to sleep on my right side, that I would inevitably wake up that night wrapped up in the tubing, and how all these things would hurt so much. While I grappled with my new normal, my pediatric endocrinologist became one of my greatest encouragements, even going so far as to wear an insulin pump, like me. Since my diagnosis, I had frequently been told to “have a good attitude” and had seen my peers cringe when I drew a needle before each meal, but no one had ever tried to experience what I endured on a daily basis. Seeing Dr. Daniels try to appreciate the frustration that came with a pump’s discomfort brought intense relief and profound comfort from no longer feeling so very isolated and misunderstood. This experience first sparked my interest in medicine, transforming diabetes from the worst thing to happen to me into a gift that could allow me to empathize with and encourage my fellow patients. 
The understanding of healthcare that I’d developed from my own diagnosis was challenged when my grandma was diagnosed with end-stage pancreatic cancer during my junior year of college. I went home to be with her as often as I could, regularly flushing her port-a-cath or injecting her blood thinners. By this time, I had spent over a decade giving myself insulin with similar needles and could do it with my eyes closed, but I always felt hesitant as I plunged the needle into her skin, knowing that it was painful. As I watched my once vibrant, fun-loving, and often mischievous grandmother deteriorate until she lay weak and listless in her dimly lit room, I felt desperate to do something. All I could do was lie next to her and hold her hand.  It was in these quiet moments that I resolved to become a physician. I realized that the hope Dr. Daniels had inspired in me as a child had been reinforced by the careful adjustments he made to my regimen and the practical strategies he taught me so that I could live a fuller life.  Where I stood, I had already begun to develop the ability and insight to emotionally support others as they suffered, but I wanted to have the knowledge and authority of the physician to be able to affect change in a tangible, physical way.
With this goal in mind, I sought to experience more of the physician-patient interaction in a hospital setting and began scribing in an emergency department.  During one encounter, Dr. O’Connell examined Emma, a 12-year-old girl who presented with leg swelling. After feeling her legs and listening to her heart, Dr. O’Connell promptly ordered an EKG and chest X-ray which confirmed her suspicion for heart failure. Impressed as I was by her quick and accurate diagnosis, I was more touched by Dr. O’Connell’s ensuing firm yet gentle discussions with Emma's mother, who wanted to take her child home rather than pursue any interventions. As Emma’s mother listened to detailed explanations of Emma’s current symptoms and the repercussions of deferring treatment, I watched her stubborn expression melt into one of concern, then calm understanding as the doctor reassured her that Emma could be well again. This interaction was one of many to reinforce my understanding that with both health and illness come uncertainty, fear, and vulnerability. A physician can address and alleviate each of these by virtue of their insight into the intricacies of a patient’s condition combined with compassionate application of their knowledge. It is this unique coupling of physical and emotional care that has helped empower me to take charge of my own illness, and motivates me to pursue a career as a physician. 
Living with a chronic illness is like running a marathon without knowing exactly where or when the end is. One of its greatest struggles is knowing that few people around me understand the daily physical, mental, and emotional battles I’m fighting to keep running.  Having experienced this deep loneliness and fear, I want to be a person who imparts comfort and instills hope. Furthermore, like Dr. Daniels, who sat beside me as I grieved my lost freedom while also treating my disease, and Dr. O’Connell, who offered understanding and patience along with science-based reasoning to save a young girl’s life, I aspire to have the medical expertise that will allow me to tangibly impact the people that I serve.  Even now, after 15 years, I hold onto a quiet hope that one day I might be healed. The daily longings and disappointments that I face, though unchanged since my diagnosis, now serve to fuel a deeper desire in me: to heal the sick and encourage those who are suffering.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Nausea, dizziness, numbness, tingling, chills - a wave of confusion washes over me while I try to process what my friends are saying. Seconds pass before I can register the question, and then a few more before I respond. I‚Äôm cognizant that my brain isn‚Äôt functioning at full capacity, but unable to change anything accordingly._x000D_
Hypoglycemic events have been a regular part of my week for 15 years. Not wanting to attract excessive attention, I do my best to mask my discomfort and disorientation. So I‚Äôm thankful that while most will dismiss me, my friends have learned not only to recognize my symptoms, but that they understand my intention isn‚Äôt to ignore them or to be capricious whenever I withdraw from a group. This grace that I receive from my friends is such that I wish to extend to others. I realize that many people have parts of their lives that are uncomfortable or even painful to disclose, and I believe my role is to react with understanding and to offer support should they seek it.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: During my junior year of high school, my aunt passed away after a year-long battle with ovarian cancer. Soon after, my 3 young cousins came to live with us, and because I was homeschooled, I joined my mother in caring for them during the daylight hours. Seeking to minimize any pain we might cause, I agreed with my siblings to refrain from embracing our mom or even calling her ‚ÄúMom‚Äù. When school began in January, I looked for the ways I could help to fill in for my aunt, helping the girls with homework, making the food Olivia wanted for her lunch bag, and holding a despondent Ella while she grieved. I knew that I could never replace my cousins‚Äô mother, but I felt that by identifying the situations where they would feel her loss the most acutely, I would be able to help them the most effectively. Watching my girls learn to smile again and thrive in their respective communities was great reward, and I count it among my greatest joys to have loved them during their greatest need.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
Because of COVID, most of my post-baccalaureate classes were held remotely. Thanks to these online options, I had the flexibility to slowly add on classes or other responsibilities at my own pace. Later in 2020, when hiring freezes were lifted, I was able to work up to 30 or 40 hours a week in the ER while I studied for classes and the MCAT. _x000D_
Being in the hospital throughout COVID taught me many lessons that I believe would not have been as stark in a ‚Äúnormal‚Äù time. I saw the rampant fear that people had when it came to health and wellness, and the high vulnerability patients offered when they chose to seek medical attention. The ER in particular is a place where patients are often at their lowest points, where they come because there is nowhere else to go. Listening to their stories and observing their interactions with providers grew my heart not only for the sick and suffering, but also for the average person who dreads sickness and suffering.

Hrdshp_Comments: I come from a low-income, second-generation immigrant background. When I was six, my dad switched jobs and his new job did not cover family health insurance. In 2012, I helped my parents apply to Covered California, which allowed us to get basic healthcare coverage. However, due to rising premiums and volatile income, we were forced to switched insurance networks almost annually. My parents also actively discouraged us from going to the doctor's unless there was a severe medical emergency because of co-pay costs. Thus, my siblings and I did not experience longitudinal primary care. As a result of these various factors, I did not realize I had a medical issue (severe sleep apnea) until I was in college. In college, I often waited until my roommate slept before going to bed to not disrupt him with my loud snoring. Since my first year, I have also worked multiple student jobs to cover the cost of attendance so my parents can afford to help my two siblings with their college expenses. Due to sleep deprivation, I had trouble focusing in class and spent long hours in office hours to relearn material. I was able to receive a diagnosis and get a CPAP in my junior year after I understood this issue needed medical attention, and since then my academics and health have improved tremendously.
personal_statement:
For as long as I can remember, my family and I have visited different doctors for our check-ups each year. It wasn’t until I was 12 years old and helping my immigrant parents enroll in Covered California that I understood the harsh caveats of the American healthcare system: if you couldn’t afford the insurance premiums, you had no choice in who cared for you. Thus, I learned to expect nothing more from my healthcare than the annual, cursory 15-minute vitals evaluation, conducted by a complete stranger each time. Such disillusionment only intensified when seeing my parents’ healthcare struggles.
One day in 10th grade, my dad came home with his lab results and asked for help Google-ing acronyms such as “A1C,” foreign terms that were never explained to him. That was how we found out he was pre-diabetic. When we called his physician for advice, she told my dad to stop eating carbohydrates like rice if he wanted to avoid developing full-blown diabetes in a few years. Though he did his best to comply, he felt like he was giving up a part of his identity. Watching my father struggle to adapt his lifestyle to his physician’s detached guidance cemented the idea that doctor’s visits were merely a formality rather than genuine opportunities to receive informed care. Thus, while I gravitated towards the biological sciences in college, my conceptualization of healthcare as impersonal and antiseptic made it difficult to see myself as a future physician.
It wasn’t until I started volunteering at HAVEN, a student-run free clinic in New Haven, while at Yale that I realized healthcare did not have to be impersonal and discovered my potential to make meaningful contributions as a healthcare provider and advocate. During my term as Pharmacy Director, I noticed one patient recurringly failed to take his medications. While he was dismissed as irresponsible by his medical team, I thought about my father, whose frustration with his physician’s instructions had led him to ultimately give up on altering his diet. So, I probed the patient as to why he had not been adhering to his treatment. I found out the last time he had gone to pick up his medications at a retail pharmacy, his citizenship status had been questioned, and so he was scared to return. Discovering this – in a way that I wished my father’s physician had considered my father’s background – I picked up the patient’s medications for him and provided clear Spanish instructions for taking them. Recognizing the importance of addressing his concerns, I also clarified the forms of identification necessary and checked in with him periodically to ensure he did not face additional challenges. In doing so, I helped the patient understand that in the future, he could rely on his providers to support him. However, I knew that many in HAVEN’s low-income, largely Latinx patient population were affected by similar systemic challenges. To ease this burden on other patients, I pushed a clinic-wide training to ensure our medical volunteers intimately understood the cultural, social, and political factors that colored our patients’ lives. As a lifelong patient advocate, I will empower my patients by tailoring medical guidance to their personal experiences.
While some situations could be solved with a stronger provider-patient relationship, I also realized that systemic barriers made access to certain life-changing treatments near impossible for many patients. For instance, one patient with Type II diabetes was recommended by attendings to start on SGLT-2 inhibitors, a highly effective treatment. However, without insurance, the medication cost over $600/month, which neither the patient nor the clinic could afford. I knew personally how crushing medical costs could be, since I myself struggled  with costly out-of-pocket expenses associated with sleep apnea treatment. Faced with immense financial burden, many low-income patients were forced to choose between paying for basic necessities (housing and food) and paying for medical treatment; our clinic needed to systematically address this financial barrier to truly provide effective long-term care. Therefore, I spearheaded partnerships with nonprofit organizations and pharmaceutical companies to provide free and subsidized medications to our patients, in hopes that affording treatment would become one less worry in their lives. In finding collaborative solutions to HAVEN’s limited resources, I realized the importance of questioning the status quo and now strive to use my future platform as a physician to open doors to accessible medical care for disadvantaged communities.
Currently, I continue to deepen my understanding of the complex, nuanced interactions between health systems and underserved patient populations. This summer, I am working with Covered California to investigate health outcome disparities among racial and ethnic groups under different health insurance plans. In doing so, we hope to hold insurance providers accountable for key insufficiencies and ultimately create a more equitable standard of healthcare for all. As a physician, I will ceaselessly challenge health institutions to raise the bar on the quality of healthcare provision - so that families like mine can receive the medical attention and informed care they deserve.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
‚ÄúBlack people are so lazy. You‚Äôll never see a Vietnamese person begging for money.‚Äù My mom‚Äôs sentiments, reflective of our largely Vietnamese community, echoed in my head. At the time, I didn‚Äôt have the tools or knowledge to convince her or myself otherwise. _x000D_
At Yale, I sought out a better understanding of race relations. Befriending other Yalies of color, I learned about the unique challenges my Black and Brown friends faced due to racialized, structural violence. This gave me a more critical perspective to consider my implicit biases. I realized that my race and upbringing had sheltered me from the threats of policing, widespread poverty, and educational inaccessibility faced by other minorities._x000D_
Acknowledging these critical differences alongside similarities in struggle with other minorities has helped me build a political consciousness integral to my identity. As a physician, I am committed to advocating for different communities of color through a lifetime of continued solidarity.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
‚ÄúI‚Äôm giving up.‚Äù said one of my Breakthrough pre-algebra students, Ryan, during my office hours. Although my training as a Teaching Fellow had warned me to temper my expectations of my students‚Äô engagement in this virtual setting, I was still shocked to hear Ryan‚Äôs defeat._x000D_
I wasn‚Äôt giving up on him yet. In my office hours, Ryan slowly opened up to me. He explained the issues he juggled off-screen: the stress from his parents being laid off in the pandemic and his grandfather‚Äôs battle with COVID-19. These were struggles that I recognized having grown up in a low-income, immigrant household. Thus, I realized that what Ryan needed most was an advocate._x000D_
From then on, Ryan and I regularly met for 1:1 math tutoring. Ryan slowly gained confidence in his math skills with my constant academic support. Cognizant of his situation, I never pressed him when he submitted homework late or couldn‚Äôt attend class. With compassion and understanding, Ryan blossomed into one of my most engaged students.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
As my mom and dad both had client-facing jobs, our household was in turmoil during the early pandemic. I strenuously juggled filing for unemployment for my immigrant parents, tutoring my siblings as their high school struggled to adapt to remote learning, and completing my college semester remotely in a completely different time zone. _x000D_
When my summer internship at a local community health clinic was canceled, I took to teaching remedial 7th grade math for Breakthrough Silicon Valley as a way to simultaneously grow professionally and care for my community in a difficult time. This opportunity changed my understanding of care ‚Äì supporting my students as an educator through the devastating effects of the pandemic opened my eyes to the interconnectedness of the structural barriers to marginalized communities. With this understanding, I hope to practice holistic service at Rush by intimately engaging in both education and healthcare in underserved communities through initiatives like RCSIP.

personal_statement:
“Cinderella! Cinderella!” I see a 5-year-old girl running at me, unable to control her excitement. An ordinary reaction of any little girl meeting a real-life princess for the first time. Sparkly pink dress, white shoes, and a bald head. Not so ordinary. “Ava” was diagnosed 6 months earlier with Leukemia, having undergone numerous rounds of chemotherapy treatment and procedures. But for the next hour, Ava was able to just be a kid again: dancing, singing, playing games, and even having a princess tea party. Her mother was in tears, saying it had been weeks since she heard her baby girl laugh. Hoping to provide comfort, I embraced her and a soft “thank you” in reply hit me with an intensity of joy I didn’t know possible. Being able to alleviate their pain, even for a moment, is what ignited my interest in medicine. Not only do I want to improve peoples’ lives through compassion, but I seek the knowledge of the fundamental workings of the human body to provide care beyond support.

Working as an in-home caregiver is where I discovered my passion for direct patient care and the value of human interaction. Through this experience I met “Esther”, an 89-year-old woman who I worked with for over a year. When I first met Esther, it appeared that she suffered from loneliness and the grief of her husband’s death. I saw an emptiness in her eyes that indicated she had lost the desire to live and take care of herself. At first, all Esther wanted to do was sleep and watch TV, but with enough time and established trust, I eventually helped her rediscover a sense of purpose and fulfillment. Whether it was talking about her family, going on walks in the garden, or cooking together, my presence seemed to offer a resounding message of encouragement, comfort, and support that she was missing. While the companionship I provided improved her mental state, there were times when my ability to help was limited. Due to her osteoarthritis, Esther often became frustrated at her decreasing mobility and independence. I want to be a doctor because I want to gain the medical knowledge and training to expand the ways in which I can help others. For example, while shadowing Dr. Choles, I learned that reducing sodium intake can help reduce water retention, which lessens the swelling of joints.

To satisfy my curiosity and thirst for knowledge, I joined a research lab for the UW Department of Psychiatry where I became fascinated with the intimate, intersecting relationship between science and patient care. My last year in the lab focused on a study investigating the use of the drug L-DOPA, a precursor to dopamine, on enhancing a process in the brain called fear-extinction learning to help reduce symptoms of PTSD in women. Part of my role was to develop trauma narratives based on participants’ experiences of interpersonal violence to be used during MRI brain scans. At first, it was extremely difficult for me to witness firsthand the abuse and pain these women endured, but then it empowered me. I want to become a doctor for them. For those who have lost their voice, living in a constant state of fear and paranoia. This experience taught me the importance of innovation and comprehensive care on improving the human condition, which I plan to incorporate as a physician.

What really attracts me to medicine is that it is a career not only dedicated to continual learning and problem solving, but also to teaching—a combination of leadership and mentorship. Working as a phlebotomist has required me to obtain adequate knowledge about the circulatory system through trial and error and actively seeking out mentor guidance. This knowledge is essential in my ability to explain the plasmapheresis process and to address and provide reassurance to donors during unexpected adverse events. Being able to describe what is happening inside the body in a way that can be commonly understood has taught me the necessity of effective communication with diverse patients in providing exceptional care. Through shadowing, I have observed how Dr. Choles utilizes her in-depth knowledge of the human body systems to explain causes of symptoms, lab results, disease prevention, diagnostic tests, and treatments. The role of teaching in medicine is undeniable as patient clarity is essential for establishing trust, respect, and dignity, which I hope to instill in my patients to provide better care.

Medicine is a hard science, but it is also a practice of treating people. To be an excellent physician requires more than knowledge and professionalism—it requires compassion, empathy, curiosity, a love for problem solving, and effective communication. This is the physician I aspire to be. A physician who recognizes and respects the humanity and individuality of patients to provide sensitive, comprehensive care. A physician who advocates for patients, seeks out alternative solutions to problems, and utilizes innovation to improve the human condition. I know medicine is for me because it is a holistic discipline that demands all of me and continuously challenges me to be a better person, allowing for the most rewarding patient relationships. In the meantime, I can be found changing lives one needle at a time—dreaming of the day I get to exchange the blue dress for the white coat.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Working as a phlebotomist at a plasma donation center has provided me with the opportunity to interact with many individuals from diverse cultural backgrounds, which has furthered my awareness of my own privilege and bias, and has deepened my understanding of the social determinants of health. For example, a young African American woman shared with me that the reason she donates is because she needs the money to pay for a car repair that she cannot afford since she is a single mother and does not have a full-time job. As a medical scribe, I have also witnessed patients in the ED who are hesitant or worried about receiving care due to lack of health insurance and monetary concerns. Prior to college, I used to believe that illness and health were solely defined by biological and individual factors, but I now understand how cultural, social, and economic factors can disproportionately impact underrepresented populations to influence access to healthcare and the likelihood of disease.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Through my volunteer work with A Moment of Magic, I have served medically vulnerable and underserved children to improve quality of life by inspiring them to be brave, strong, and fearless through fun and engaging social wellness activities. Dressing up as princesses and superheroes gives these children a unique opportunity to interact with the people they look up to most, which is a once-in-a-lifetime experience. Being able to provide imagination and joy to sick children and communities who do not often have similar opportunities is an invaluable gift that I am so honored to have been a part of. One experience I particularly remember is surprising a little girl with Down Syndrome at her birthday party. The smile and amusement on her face when we walked in is a reflection of the impact that we have. The girl‚Äôs mother sent us a message a few days after our visit to tell us that her daughter cannot stop talking about it and brags to everyone she knows about her new magical friends.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, I was unable to continue volunteering at American Family Children‚Äôs hospital, which is still suspended at this time. I have attempted to find other health related volunteer opportunities since, but they have been difficult to come by. To continue gaining medical experience and serving the community, I applied to a CNA program at SSM Health St. Mary‚Äôs Hospital in March of 2020. I got invited to interview, but unfortunately the position was withdrawn afterwards due to the pandemic._x000D_
_x000D_
It was difficult to find medical related jobs that were still going when the pandemic first hit, which was frustrating at times because all I wanted was to be able to help in some way during a much needed time. Nonetheless, I was determined to keep looking, and eventually found a position as an in-home caregiver with Comfort Keepers. I am very thankful for this opportunity to serve such a vulnerable population during a time when they needed it most.

personal_statement:
I was fourteen years old when I first set foot in Children’s Hospital Orange County (CHOC). My mother held my hand as we rushed into the emergency department. To distract myself from the aching abdominal pain, I closed my eyes and imagined myself at my next track meet. My appendicitis diagnosis felt like my biggest hurdle yet. 

At that moment, my only fear was missing track practice. My naturally anxious parents had worries of their own. “Dr. Li” maintained a calm demeanor and adapted to address our individual concerns. “In no time you’ll be able to cross the finish line.” Strangely, this statement brought me instant relief. I was not seen as another patient with appendicitis, but as a young girl who was passionate about running. Dr. Li’s inclination to consider not only my diagnosis but also my personal circumstances served as a source of comfort during a time of pain. Here, I realized the importance of forming human connections in medicine. I grew determined to replicate this feeling of unconditional support for other patients and their families.

Eager to connect with patients, I became a volunteer in the child life department at CHOC. One memorable patient, “Amy,” was hospitalized for leukemia. I was responsible for ensuring that Amy completed her math homework. Unfortunately, she began seeing me as a daunting reminder of her unfinished homework. It became my personal mission to make math enjoyable for Amy by introducing fun methods such as art and games. Day by day, Amy's smile grew as I would come by her room. It was a warming reminder that medicine is not only about treating illnesses but also about building relationships. As I drew parallels between my experience with Dr. Li and with Amy, my desire to become a physician who appreciates the “human” quality of medicine was reaffirmed.  

I learned a similar lesson working with pre-collegiate students as a Campus Representative for my university. One day, I led a tour for students from East LA. As I began to recite my meticulously rehearsed script, I noticed that my group was not engaged. I decided to start an open conversation about college with them and learned that many of these students had never thought of higher education as an option before due to cost or other factors. I then asked them all to share a hobby they had. One student, “Joe,” told me he liked to write stories. I explained to him the opportunity to pursue an english degree through financial aid and scholarships. At the same time, I made sure to acknowledge that while college could be a path he chose, it was not his only option. These special conversations transformed the way I saw patients during my clinical experiences as each patient has a unique story that must be understood. My goal is to clearly educate my patients on all their options with full transparency. I hope to foster an environment of open communication, where I connect with patients through humanity and vulnerability. By doing so, I can empower them to reach their health goals by adapting my medical approaches to their needs. 

Seeking to apply this approach in a medical setting, I began working as a scribe for the endocrinology clinic at CHOC. There, I often worked with patients who did not have sufficient access to healthcare. I remember when “May” first came into the clinic. Her son “Sam” had type 2 diabetes, which had been difficult for her to manage because she worked multiple jobs just to cover the cost of his insulin. After visiting with the doctor, May stood up to leave when I noticed a look of exhaustion on her face. Eager to help, I told her that the hospital had resources that provide access to affordable and healthy food, well-suited for diabetics. She smiled, took the brochure, and told me she was grateful. I felt as though I had not helped her enough; however, this experience influenced my aspiration to become a primary care physician who advocates for policies that improve health equity for underserved populations. 

Recognizing how socioeconomic factors disproportionately affect the health of certain communities, I came to appreciate the value of preventative care. While scribing, I observed how type 2 diabetics can be taken off their medication by managing diet, stress, and exercise. I joined an ED study called Adverse Childhood Experiences to promote access to preventative measures. I surveyed patients to screen for neighborhood-level factors such as food and housing insecurity and connected families with resources. Having witnessed how these simple gestures can improve pediatric health outcomes, I grew inspired to use my future platform as a physician to increase disease prevention. This commitment fuels my desire to pursue the path of medicine. 

These experiences working with different communities remind me of the rush and excitement of race day. They left me with a desire to not only advocate for all patients, but also ensure that their care is as personal as Amy taught me, culturally competent as Joe taught me, and comprehensive as Sam taught me. Now as I embark on my longest race, I recognize my new goal: to cross a different finish line that will allow me the opportunity to connect with every patient and deliver the compassionate and holistic care I once received.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
I worked as a Campus Representative at my university through which I interacted with prospective students and their families from all walks of life. During the first campus tour I gave at UC Irvine, I began by explaining the majors offered. One student, ‚ÄúIan,‚Äù stated that he had never heard of the term ‚Äúmajor‚Äù and that his high school never discussed attending college. I realized that my scripted tour could not be applied to everyone, so I explained every concept I introduced, allowing Ian to feel comfortable asking questions and expressing his fears. _x000D_
 _x000D_
Growing up, my parents reinforced the importance of attaining higher education, so I never considered any other path. Knowing my students, including Ian, came from different backgrounds, I sought ways to empower them and make them comfortable, whether it was to attend college or navigate an alternative career path. At RUSH, I hope to continue to advocate for peers, educators, and patients alike to feel comfortable in every space.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
I am a medical scribe at the Children‚Äôs Hospital of Orange County Emergency Department, which serves a diverse, medically underserved patient population where adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) are common. _x000D_
 _x000D_
‚ÄúEli,‚Äù a six-year-old foster child, had presented for dehydration and weakness. Eli‚Äôs foster mother shared that his biological mother was a substance abuser and had neglected Eli‚Äôs care: he hadn‚Äôt been seen by a pediatrician for some time and his vaccines weren‚Äôt up to date. I offered Eli‚Äôs foster mother pamphlets on nutrition protocols, connected her to a social worker, and relayed the history to the physician. Ultimately, these interactions exposed me to issues I will encounter as a physician and highlighted how I can promote my patients‚Äô well-being. I currently help with ACEs screenings and provide families with self-care and community resources. As a physician, I hope to leverage my platform to implement screenings, education, and care coordination to support my patients.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
After COVID-19, all of my extracurricular activities and research were put on hold. Fortunately, I‚Äôd completed most of the coursework for my major, so I used my free time to take enough courses to graduate a year early and adapted my job hunt for the constraints of COVID.  _x000D_
 _x000D_
As I looked for ways to contribute to healthcare, I first secured a job as a pharmacy technician at CVS and then worked as a medical scribe in a pediatric endocrinology clinic. At the clinic, I saw how increased telemedicine improved access and provided a safer alternative for our immunocompromised patients. Additionally, although my on-campus research opportunities had been on hold, I joined a metabolism lab at Children‚Äôs Hospital of Orange County where I was assigned my own project. Now that health and safety restrictions have been lifted in my area, I also hope to volunteer at a free clinic in Los Angeles this coming fall. COVID has taught me to adapt as a person as well as a future physician.

Major_Long_Desc: Sports Medicine and Exercise Physiology; Psychology
personal_statement:
At this moment, I am writing this essay from a hospital bed, post-op from a prolapse revision surgery, reflecting on the experiences that lead me to this very point in my life. It is a familiar scene around me: my mother is sleeping on a cot in the corner. The medication pumps beep intermittently, and I hear the nurses outside the room. 

Most of my peers began to develop their personal and professional identities at my age, navigating their way through college; however, I was battling a different beast throughout that time. At 16, I was diagnosed with ulcerative colitis. Since my symptoms began, I woke up with unbearable cramps and nausea each morning. Despite these obstacles, my circumstances have only cemented my childhood dream to become a physician and bring forth the impactful perspective as a patient to that of a clinician.

Although my days were filled with doctor’s appointments and medications that weighed on me, I committed to keeping my classes at the forefront of my priorities. I immersed myself in places of solace, whether through volunteering at the local free clinic, playing sports, or expanding my sneaker business. Unfortunately, by the end of my first year of college, all treatment options had been exhausted, and my illness had taken a severe toll on myself and my family. My physician suggested surgery, discussing it extensively with me when I was worried about my physical stability. I will never forget the feeling of looking across the examination table hoping for some good news or even a simple “we will figure this out.” Despite my initial fear of the risks of the surgery, Dr. Abraham assured me that we were on this journey together. On the other side of my five procedures, I found myself a more confident, optimistic student with aspirations to encompass the treatment of illnesses with the actual patient.

With the setbacks of chronic illness and numerous surgeries, I realized how much of a toll they had taken on my mental health. Further research showed that people with lifelong conditions could further spiral into anxiety and depression, which only deteriorates their health. I sought to factor mindfulness into my routine, and I was able to find support in my family. At first, it was a struggle to divulge my worries to my parents, as I was aware of the stigmas surrounding mental health. These stigmas appeared everywhere, but most notably for me was the South Asian idea that depression was a sign of weak faith. I was fortunate to have highly understanding parents, but I knew that many others did not have the same support that I did. This fundamentally became the center of a student-led college course I taught, focusing on stigmas around mental health, and led me to develop a program to help families at my local mosque identify numerous mental health issues. This program aims to provide education and resources such as psychiatrists and therapists with the help of Dr. Asim Shah. As a prospective physician, I find it necessary to advocate for self-care and to learn how to comfort patients in various ways in times of need.

When I healed from my surgeries and was able to return to normalcy, I faced each day with reinvigorated health and a fresh outlook. I returned to volunteering at AsSalam Clinic, where I had the opportunity to assist specialists in providing free health care to immigrant and refugee populations. These communities suffer from low health literacy and inadequate access to care. I recalled how I felt in my appointments, hoping to hear some reassurance that I was not alone. I felt privileged to have the opportunity to show the compassion I longed for as a patient. It was important to remember that these patients were dealing with many hurdles and further reminded me that physicians must also be well-versed in exhibiting compassion to their patients.

My time volunteering revealed the multiple disparities in the healthcare field and made me contemplate how fortunate I was to have abundant access to healthcare. I decided that I wanted to focus on bridging the healthcare discordances present in our healthcare landscape. I intend to care for marginalized patients while working to increase patient education and help pave the way for healthcare equality.

Dealing with ulcerative colitis presented a significant association between my healthcare experience and obligations as a member of society. As a hopeful physician, I aim to integrate what I have encountered to fully understand the interacting factors that affect the ability to provide holistic, patient-centered care. All the while, I hope to tackle barriers experienced by my future patients by establishing mental health interventions and reducing obstacles in access to care. My time as a patient, student, and volunteer has further solidified my desire to become a physician and granted me a unique conglomeration of perspectives in medicine. I look forward to treating future patients with empathy and sympathy to ultimately help them find restored health and peace.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: A prime component of my healthcare experience has been my involvement in the local free clinic, Assalam clinic. There, I was a scribe and took history/vitals, allowing me to interact with a cluster of patients from different backgrounds. We treated primarily underserved and marginalized communities. From them, I learned how difficult healthcare experiences are for uninsured or underinsured and marginalized patients. It is challenging for patients to trust the healthcare system, especially one with high costs for hospital visits, ambulance rides, and daily prescriptions. It can be terrifying for a patient to visit a healthcare facility, and for me, it is crucial to connect with the patients by trying to find something I can relate to or learning about their backgrounds. From my experience, I also learned that as a physician, it is vital to understand the patient's culture and wishes related to their care. I hope to treat patients with empathy and respect in the future.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I remember meeting Saima, a widowed mother who brought her five-year-old son. She trembled in the waiting area, murmuring prayers under her breath. When I asked if she needed any help in Urdu, her native tongue, she burst into tears. I held her hand as I reassured her everything would be okay, and a physician would be available to examine her son soon. I listened to her anxieties about her child's future and helped her enroll in a public healthcare plan. She displayed the utmost gratitude for just hearing about her struggles. Patients like Saima came in often at the free clinic, and I enjoyed being a service to them by also educating patients on preventative healthcare and resources so that they can understand their own conditions and risk factors. I also worked with the executive board to expand our services to three days a week, with additional funding and marketing. This meant that more patients could find appropriate healthcare when they may not have other options. _x000D_

Major_Long_Desc: Biology; Pharmacology and Drug Development; Pharmacology and Drug Development
personal_statement:
“Let me hear your voice” is a phrase I have heard all my life. At first, I thought it was said to encourage my brother to speak. He was diagnosed with Autism when I was seven years old. I did not understand what that diagnosis meant then, only that things were different and my family’s dynamics changed. Therapists started to show up to work with my brother, raising my awareness of the changes happening around me. I often attended my brother’s sessions as they were fun, and we mostly played games to work on skill deficits like turn-taking. Later on, I became a “peer” for other children with Autism when they needed a play partner. I also noticed that my mother became more involved in the community, constantly mentoring families with newly diagnosed children to help them acquire services and support. Words like “struggle” and “advocate” became everyday utterances. I also came to learn the origin of the phrase “Let me hear your voice.” It is the title of a book written by Catherine Maurice that details the life of a mother of two children with Autism. The words spoke to me, and the message was clear: empower the voiceless to have their voices heard.
I carried this message with me throughout high school and into college. 

My undergraduate education was well planned: pharmacology and drug development and a bachelor's in biology. I wanted to follow in my father's footsteps and become a pharmacist, so I started to clerk at his pharmacy. I saw my father constantly advocating for his patients by contacting insurance companies and drug manufacturers and speaking on behalf of his patients to make their voices heard. "Let me hear your voice" echoed in my ears whenever I saw this. Simultaneously, I became curious about the pathophysiology of the ailments I encountered when patients came in. A physician's treatment plan and his choice of medication became a topic of discussion and daily research. My interests were branching out and I was drawn to medicine.

In the Summer of 2019, I began to shadow Dr. Shenouda, a physician at Centro Medico Guadalupano in South Gate, California. His clinic predominantly cared for an underserved Spanish-speaking population. Patients often needed assistance filling out medical history forms and I jumped in to help. I learned about free medical assistance programs offered and began speaking to patients about these options. However, to my astonishment, many patients did not want to sign up, indicating a lack of trust in the system. During visits, some barely asked any questions or requested further explanations. And that is when that phrase jumped in my head; I almost wanted to scream, “LET ME HEAR YOUR VOICE!” Dr. Shenouda saw my confusion but encouraged me to be persistent by continuing to offer help and guiding the patients through their medical care. While engaging these patients was difficult, I saw Dr. Shenouda attempt to connect with all of his patients by speaking in Spanish to ease the language barrier, suggesting further testing, and personally reaching out days later to check-in. It was inspiring to see a physician take the initiative to rebuild their trust in the healthcare system and strengthen physician-patient interactions.

One interaction was particularly memorable. A Hispanic 11-year-old boy came in for a follow-up visit to confirm a diabetes diagnosis. “Vicktor” had severe Autism and limited food preferences. I remembered those days with my brother before he got therapy. After Vicktor left, I felt compelled to speak to Dr. Shenouda about the help he could receive, just as my brother did. I learned that he was offered minimal services by his school, and since the family had limited insurance, they had a hard time finding providers for their son. Dr. Shenouda wrote a referral to a nutritionist and an occupational therapist to work on swallowing pills to help Vicktor take his medication. In the meantime, insulin was necessary to stabilize his blood sugar. I was heartbroken to see the obvious medical inequalities that Vicktor experienced, unlike my brother, and I wondered about all the other patients like him. I hope to emulate Dr. Shenouda’s patient-centered approach to medicine as I continue to advocate on behalf of my patients during my medical career.

While COVID-19 interrupted my other volunteer plans, I kept up with Dr. Shenouda and continued helping with his underserved patient population by transcribing patient charts from his telehealth visits for his other practices. I read about vaccination rates being the lowest amongst the lower socioeconomic groups during that time. Again the “voiceless” were the most affected. The pandemic showcased that medical inequality was more prevalent than ever in our healthcare systems and highlighted a pathway for my career. As I reflected on this, my purpose was cemented. From my experiences with my brother to the populations I have worked with clinically and in volunteer experiences, I have seen first-hand the impact of health disparities and stigmatization. I strive to become a physician who can address the physiological consequences of disease and the more systemic issues within our healthcare system by empowering those whose voices are not heard.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
During my medical mission in Egypt, I witnessed the adverse effects of a lack of care available for patients, which _x000D_
were further exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic. I saw pediatric malnutrition and complications from the mismanagement of chronic diseases in adults. Additionally, shadowing at Centro Medico Guadalupano para La Familia had exposed me to a marginalized, minority community in the US where I attempted to make patients aware of free medical services that they could receive through government organizations. These experiences showed me the extent to which health inequity impacts lives, as well as the difference healthcare workers can have by caring for patients while being cognizant of their social situation. These experiences shifted my perspective of medicine through which I developed a greater understanding of how the socioeconomic factors of patients impact their health. These lessons are ones that I hope to utilize and share through my journey at Rush.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
I hope to serve as a caregiver and advocate for my patients to ensure they receive the care they deserve. I have a brother with autism and was taught early on the need to be his voice when necessary. The world is not always kind or accommodating to those who are different, and I made it my mantra to advocate for and include those who cannot do so. Throughout my school career, I was always a ‚Äúbig buddy‚Äù within the special needs community. I maintained a mentor-tutor relationship with one of the kids I mentored in high school. I helped him academically and continue to help him socially.  As I continue to be part of his life today, I feel content that I am able to contribute a small part to his well being. These interactions have prompted me always to be an advocate for those who may not have the opportunity to stand up for themselves._x000D_
_x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact: Reflecting on the pandemic makes me realize how resilient human nature truly is. Academically, Zoom dominated my life. I had to adapt my learning style from being a hands-on learner to what I saw on a screen. I avoided distractions and managed to excel in all my classes. Structure and routine were vital.  I was scheduled to take the MCAT in June 2021. Unfortunately, all prep courses were canceled and I had to rely on books. I went in feeling unprepared yet still managed to do well. Not all of Covid‚Äôs effects were negative. The time I spent with my family was priceless and strengthened our bond. I also reconnected with my old high school friends. I focused more on my physical and mental wellbeing which were usually neglected in the bustle of life. I became more attuned with myself.

Under_School: Columbia University in the City of New York
personal_statement:
The gunman’s broad silhouette stood out in the doorway, blocking the light in the hallway from entering my room. I pulled the covers up over my head as far as I could, held my breath, and squeezed my eyes shut. This isn't happening. This is not happening… I gasp and bolt upright out of bed, sweat pouring down my face. The nightlight in my quiet room radiates the time on the wall: 2:47 AM. I sprint down the hallway to my parents’ room, where I temporarily feel safer, and attempt to quiet my mind enough to fall asleep again.  

Night terrors like these were my routine for six years: every night was a struggle between my mind and body. It all began following the sudden death of my 65-year-old grandfather when I was seven; grappling with the reality of loss and death at such a young age triggered years of anxiety and sleepless nights. My siblings watched from afar as the troubled middle child was taken to doctor after doctor in an attempt to cure her “disease.” The more I struggled, the more determined I grew to persevere. At age 13, I finally conquered my anxiety and insomnia with the help of my family and a child psychiatrist who has since become my inspiration for a career in medicine.

Overcoming my anxiety, with the help of others, has inspired me to find ways to pay it forward. Growing up in Baltimore, I spent my afternoons teaching dance to children in inner city schools, providing them with an alternative to spending time on the streets. In my senior year of college, I worked as an organic chemistry laboratory teaching assistant, combining my love of science with the opportunity to help students who were struggling through the class. Throughout all four years of college, I was a member of Pizmon, a pluralistic Jewish a capella and outreach group that uses music to lift the souls of those in need. It is in moments like these that I have discovered my passion for serving others.

As a result of the unwavering determination I developed in my battle with anxiety, I am never satisfied with “good enough” and always push myself toward excellence in all pursuits. Having trained in biomedical engineering in college, my drive to engineer change in the world led me to two part time jobs: one in biotechnology commercialization, and the other in teaching. While my role at Johns Hopkins Technology Ventures reinforced my passion for solving scientific problems, my time spent teaching at Roland Park Country School has guided me towards a more personal career with genuine human connection. Beyond simply teaching, I helped many students at Roland Park cope with mental health issues that had been exacerbated by the pandemic, and I have found nothing as fulfilling as helping someone overcome their obstacles. 

Working as a medical assistant at a dermatology practice during the summer of 2020 allowed me to help others in a medical setting. Since the office was severely short-staffed due to COVID-19, my job responsibilities included just about everything: escorting patients to rooms, taking preliminary medical histories, obtaining chief complaints, assisting during full body exams, preparing patients for biopsies, and assisting during surgical and aesthetic procedures. I fell in love with the job, excitedly putting on my scrubs every morning and arriving early to work to jump in. I began noticing abnormal moles before the doctors pointed them out and pulling out the correct ointments without being told which one would be best for treating the situation. The quiet joy that accompanied each time I correctly identified a problem or helped make a patient feel comfortable filled my life with purpose. At the end of each day, my feet hurt from standing and my face burned from the N95 mask and goggles, but I didn’t care; I loved looking in the mirror and seeing the indentations from my PPE, because to me they were a symbol of the good I was contributing to the world. 

In 2021, the summer after graduating from college, I pursued additional opportunities to give back by taking on the role of Health Care Director at Camp Walt Whitman, a sleepaway summer camp in New Hampshire. My role involved minimizing COVID-19 risk for the campers, and it was extremely fulfilling to contribute medically toward restoring a slice of childhood to the many campers who had just endured more than a year of deprivation in the pandemic-affected world. This experience deepened my desire to help others through medicine and helped further develop my love for working with children.

Becoming a physician will allow me to continue to pursue my passion for solving scientific problems, while also enjoying the privilege of healing and genuinely connecting with human beings on a personal level. As I reflect on my life and the mental health obstacles I have overcome, I am determined that others should not have to go through what I did, which is why I am drawn to the field of psychiatry. Through my own battle with anxiety, I can relate to patients firsthand and can help them understand what my child psychiatrist first showed me: that your diagnosis is not a disease, but a part of what makes you human.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
In the summer of 2020, my sorority began to discuss issues of systemic racism in Greek life. Many students of color shared discriminatory experiences that made them feel unsafe and unwanted. The lack of action in response to these revelations left many feeling unheard, causing them to leave the chapter. After reading many educational articles, speaking with close family and friends, and self-reflecting, I withdrew as well. _x000D_
As this occurred in the wake of George Floyd‚Äôs death, I attended a Black Lives Matter rally in my hometown of Baltimore to show my support and solidarity. Throughout these experiences, I grew more aware of the struggles that people of color face on a daily basis, and the negative effect people can have as bystanders. The rally opened my eyes to the importance of unity and working together in building a kinder, safer future. In medicine, I will continue to try and understand the minority perspective, promote diversity, and fight for equality and inclusion for all.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I recently volunteered for a virtual tutoring platform that helps struggling readers from disadvantaged communities. I was paired with a first grader from a school located in my hometown of Baltimore City. Each week, I met with him online to help him practice his reading skills and boost his confidence. While he struggled significantly in the beginning, I quickly found ways to improve his abilities by reading stories about his own interests. At the end of the year, I was invited to visit his school to celebrate his progress. He immediately latched onto me and told me all about his long trek to school every day. It was clear he had a difficult home life. ??The pure joy on his face when I gave him my copy of the book ‚ÄúOh, the Places You‚Äôll Go!‚Äù will forever be ingrained in my memory as one of the more meaningful impacts I have had on another person. I am volunteering for this program again this school year, as I hope to continue to leave a positive impact on the Baltimore community.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The pandemic prompted my summer 2020 employment plans to shift and collapse many times. I was sent home from college as it went virtual for my final three semesters, and I was no longer able to complete my research in the Ghosh Lab, which I had been excited about continuing through graduation. As I scrambled to come up with a meaningful way to spend my summer, my mother and her business partner struggled to find staffing in their medical and cosmetic dermatology practice. They offered me the opportunity to work for them full time as a medical assistant. This experience made me appreciate the medical profession and its importance during a pandemic. After this opportunity, I began and completed my senior year virtually. Taking my classes and being a TA for a lab course virtually led to extreme personal growth in the form of mental toughness and willpower. Remaining focused and determined in utter chaos without in-person gatherings was a challenge that has only made me stronger.

Hrdshp_Comments:
I grew up in a small two-bedroom home shared by my parents, brother, sister, niece, and nephew. Our home was located in the parking lot of my parents' workplace, so in exchange for cheap rent, my parents were expected to be on call 24/7 while only making a combined $45,000/year. 

To save up for college, I was working at a hospital on the weekdays, delivering Indian food on weeknights, and working at my high school’s flea market every Sunday from 6 am to 2 pm. 

While in college, I qualified for the Pell Grant all four years which helped immensely with tuition, but I still struggled to cover food and personal expenses. After developing better study techniques and getting accustomed to the rigorous workload, I was able to cover all of my personal expenses by working three part-time jobs while also maintaining a full-time class schedule and an upward trend in my GPA.

Although these experiences were undoubtedly stressful and sometimes even suffocating, they forced me to refine my time management skills, taught me how to persevere through adversity, and illustrated the importance of delayed gratification.
personal_statement:
I still remember it was three in the morning when I was startled awake by a call from my boss. “Andy? Sorry, I know it’s late, but a patient is getting airlifted to John Muir. Can you cover the case?” I agreed without hesitation and was on my way to my first trauma call. I rushed to the operating room, where I met a 26-year-old man with an unforgettable look of regret. He crashed and flipped onto the side of the road, fractured his neck, and was on his way to becoming a quadriplegic if the surgery did not begin soon. The anesthesiologist intubated the patient, I placed my electrodes, and the surgeon made an incision in the back of his neck. I monitored the patient’s nerve roots and spinal cord while the surgeon delicately stabilized the spine with screws and rods. When the procedure was over, I asked the surgeon if the patient would ever walk again. “It is possible. Thankfully we intervened quickly, or the damage would have been irreversible.” As I drove to my subsequent surgery later that morning, I was still processing what I had just witnessed, making me question why I wanted to become a physician. 

I am the youngest son from a family of Mexican immigrants who moved to California with nothing. Despite lacking a formal education, my parents worked tirelessly to provide for my siblings and me. They ensured we had access to opportunities they never had. Although I was grateful for their sacrifices, I felt like a financial burden watching them perpetually work at such an old age. I was motivated to provide for my family, and at 16, I earned a spot in a paid internship at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center. This opportunity cultivated my interest in the medical field as it exposed me to the various roles within the hospital, and I was fortunate enough to shadow doctors, nurses, and physician assistants. By the end of the program, I knew I wanted to pursue a career in medicine, so I became the first in my family to go to college.

During my junior year at UC Berkeley, I began scribing for a gastroenterologist, Dr. Ezzeddine, who quickly became my mentor. I admired her extensive medical knowledge and dedication to treating every patient. Some of her patients were chronically ill, and Dr. Ezzeddine worked relentlessly to find solutions to aid their constant suffering. She instilled hope and trust within her patients and inspired me to consider becoming a physician. I was unfamiliar with the application process at the time, and my graduation was quickly approaching. With my degree in neurobiology, I searched for a full-time job to stay financially afloat while figuring out the prerequisites for applying to medical school.

Despite graduating during a pandemic, I found a job as a surgical neurophysiologist. This role introduced me to the operating room and has allowed me to work alongside physicians at a dozen different hospitals in the bay area. I monitor patients’ nervous systems during spine and brain surgery and communicate the data directly with the surgeon to minimize neurological damage throughout the case. Meeting with patients before surgery, working in synchrony with the OR staff during surgery, and applying my medical knowledge throughout have been incredibly fulfilling. Even on days when the surgery lasts over 12 hours, it is gratifying to know that my work contributes to the betterment of others. There is no better reward than knowing a patient is doing well after surgery. 

A year had passed since my first trauma case, but it still felt fresh in my mind. Watching someone nearly my age get rushed to surgery due to a severe spinal cord injury was surreal, and I constantly thought about how the young man was doing. I decided to schedule a chat with the neurosurgeon who performed the procedure to ask for a follow-up, which left me in disbelief. After strenuous physical rehabilitation, the patient regained most of his sensory and motor function and can walk and run with only minor difficulties. After our conversation, I walked back to my car with an insuppressible smile. Although the hours in this role may be hectic, and the outcomes can be grim, victories like these push me forward and remind me why I want to become a physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
My fondest childhood memories involve my family's yearly summer road trips to my father and mother's hometowns. Living in Mexico forced me to integrate into a new culture. It allowed me to practice my Spanish and learn about my community's culture and traditions. Overall it helped me become more appreciative of my everyday life after seeing how difficult life can be in Mexico._x000D_
_x000D_
Another experience that has molded my personality is working in the operating room for two years. It can often be a stressful environment, yelling is not an uncommon occurrence, and a lesson I learned early on was not letting people's behavior cloud my judgment of their character. I try and apply this lesson whenever I meet someone new because it helps me understand their actions more deeply. Considering external factors such as their situation, culture, financial situation, etc., makes it easier to empathize with them rather than make an incomplete and unfair assessment of who they are as a person.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
Throughout my career as a surgical neurophysiologist, I have witnessed the devastating consequences of spinal cord injuries, such as paralysis, numbness, and loss of bowel and bladder control. Working in this field made me realize how susceptible we are to life-altering accidents in our everyday lives, and in addition to serving as a daily reminder to be grateful for my health, my job has motivated me to help individuals affected by spinal cord injuries._x000D_
_x000D_
Outside of the OR, I volunteer at my local rock climbing gym. Through a program called ParaCliffHangers, I have become friends with paraplegic climbers in my community, contributed toward new gym equipment through fundraisers, and learned more about their disabilities as we rock climb. Volunteering for ParaCliffHangers has allowed me to develop connections with the community I strive to help.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
My parents have been unemployed due to COVID-19, and the hardest decision I had to make when considering applying to medical school was accepting that I would no longer be able to provide for them. After a year of working full-time, I spoke extensively with my parents regarding my aspirations for becoming a physician. We discussed how long it takes, the possibility of moving across the country, and the financial sacrifices I would have to make. By the end of our conversation, my parents emphasized the importance of pursuing my passion and reassured me that I would always have their support. _x000D_
_x000D_
In preparation for medical school, I have been supporting them with every paycheck, and we are on track to buy a small home in Tijuana just in time before I hopefully begin school.

personal_statement:
From an early age, I remember knowing that my dad, and maybe all doctors, could provide their patients with a second chance. Many afternoons, I recall strangers stopping him and offering a handshake saying, “Dr. Wong, thank you for saving my vision!” After seeing the impact he made on others, I couldn’t help but want to learn more about what he did. The following summer, I asked my dad if I could shadow him at work. Sitting in the corner exam room chair, I was struck by how my dad’s empathy and professionalism cultivated comfort and trust in his patients. With their confidence, my dad empowered his patients to make difficult decisions and take control of their health. Here, it was clear that through their years of training and wealth of knowledge, doctors have the power to give people second chances by educating and inspiring them to make positive changes to their own lives. While I may not have realized it consciously at the time, that summer is when I first decided I wanted to follow in my dad’s footsteps.

Medicine is more than just hard science; that’s a good thing because for me, science always seemed hard. Despite my best efforts, my first two years of college were marred by academic mediocrity caused by an inability to focus. This adversity challenged my resolve to become a doctor. I realized I was at a crossroads and my dreams of becoming a physician would be over if I didn’t figure out how to overcome my attention difficulties. The summer after my sophomore year, I was diagnosed with ADHD and began seeing a doctor who helped me find a sustainable long-term solution to manage my attention challenges. After making a few adjustments to decrease distractions and increase focus, my academic performance improved significantly and I realized this was my second chance. Empowered by my doctor, I reclaimed agency over my attention difficulties and began performing at an ability that matched my effort. 

While hard science is only one component of medicine, it is a crucial piece that constantly challenges, questions, and innovates. In early 2019, I began working in a research lab that used stem cells to study retinal development. Drawing upon my own experiences with chemical imbalances in the brain, I immediately gravitated toward a project focused on neuronal regeneration. Working in research taught me how scientific discovery could be challenging and slow at times. I’ve lost track of the number of late nights spent troubleshooting with my lab mates, followed by early mornings setting up experiments to test our ideas. I’ve been fortunate to work with colleagues who helped me maximize my productivity and arrive at solutions I may never have considered on my own. With the help of a great team, I finished my master’s degree on time amid a global pandemic. My experiences in research further cemented my desire to become a physician and resulted in a tool that has the potential to restore permanently lost ganglion cells in patients with glaucoma. 

To gain a deeper understanding of the clinical side of medicine, I began working as an ophthalmic tech at Rady Children’s Hospital after completing my master’s degree. There, I met 17-year-old Mateo, who came in for an annual eye exam before starting college. As was common practice with teenagers, he was asked to complete the PHQ-9, a questionnaire to evaluate mental health well-being. Upon seeing his results, it became evident that he was experiencing a mental health crisis. When the doctor came to help, her warm kindness gave Mateo a sense of security to confide in her without fear of judgment when he otherwise felt alone in his battle with depression. Her caring approach helped me realize that the practice of medicine takes place in many forms. I already knew the value of compassion in healthcare, but it was here that I realized how doctors could help patients in unexpected ways. While patients are at the heart of medicine, doctors are the heart in medicine. As someone who has experienced and overcome my own internal challenges, I want to become a physician to give patients the ability to reclaim control over their health without fear of stigma.

Through my time serving patients and as a patient myself, I am fortunate to have gained a new perspective on medicine that I will apply myself as a doctor. My vague medical school dreams quickly came into focus when my potential to become a physician was challenged. The adversity I overcame revealed both my resilience and capacity for improvement. While my initial goal of giving patients a second chance never wavered, I now have a fuller understanding of what that objective actually entails. Beginning from an early age, I saw how compassion, trust, and empathy were central to medicine. As my experience grew, I also learned that doctors have a crucial responsibility to serve others as both teachers and patient advocates. I now also understand that a doctor's capacity for service increases when they collaborate with others. The doctors who worked with me to enhance my mental and physical health affected the course of my life for the better. I am thankful to have been given a second chance to fulfill my dreams and will work tirelessly to do the same for my patients.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Working in healthcare taught me that non-English speakers often face compromised quality of care. Here, sensitivity to the specific needs of each patient is paramount. For example, Hila, an Afghan refugee, was a recent immigrant who spoke no English. When communicating with patients like Hila, I utilized an interpreter through which I worked to establish a sense of comfort and trust._x000D_
_x000D_
In the past, I‚Äôve seen patients like Hila wrongly labeled as ‚Äúpoor historians‚Äù due to their limited English. Hila‚Äôs visit required empathy and compassion, but it was clear she appreciated the care I took to ensure the quality of her exam despite the language barrier. While each patient offers a unique challenge, they also bring a particular perspective that, in the future, I will be mindful of with my patients. As a doctor, I may never fully understand each patient‚Äôs lived experiences. However, I can still exercise empathy and compassion with an awareness that diverse patients have diverse needs.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
When I coached the UC San Diego Climbing Team, I helped athletes reach their potential by fortifying their weaknesses and building upon their strengths. During this time, I mentored aspiring athletes who loved climbing but struggled to overcome a fear of heights that kept them from reaching their potential. These student-athletes voiced concern that their apprehension led others to discount them. To empower these climbers to push their mental limits, I taught them how to fall safely and provided opportunities to practice falling in a controlled environment without judgment._x000D_
_x000D_
By giving constructive feedback through an empathetic lens, I helped these climbers push their mental limits to gain self-confidence in all aspects of their life. By viewing climbers as whole individuals, I identified potential deficiencies and partnered with them to come to solutions. At RMC, I hope to serve as a connective tissue that brings people together to overcome their limits and reach their potential.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
The first six months of the pandemic comprised my final months as a graduate student. COVID restrictions forced me to adapt to graduate on time, but in the end, I successfully defended my thesis to a committee of experts._x000D_
_x000D_
After graduating, I hoped to gain clinical experience but delayed my return to in-person activities due to concerns for my family's health. While I used this gap to prepare for the MCAT, I still felt unprepared for medical school when the application cycle opened last year. After careful consideration, I decided to wait one more year to apply._x000D_
_x000D_
Following my original goal, I began working at Rady Children's Hospital. In doing so, I've gained valuable experience that I would've lacked had I applied last year. I enjoy the challenge of providing high-quality care to patients and appreciate the impact I can have on patients. Now more than ever, I am excited to take the next steps in my journey to become a physician and care for the members of my community.

personal_statement:
As someone who diligently woke up every morning to go for walks and willingly ran 5K races, my mom was someone I thought would live past 100. It was not until I was sitting in the doctor’s office one day waiting for my mom’s appointment to hurry and finish that my vision of her was crushed.
