I jerked my head up abruptly when the word “cancer” left the doctor’s mouth; it couldn’t be true. No matter how hard the doctor tried to reassure me that my mom would be okay after a complete nephrectomy, it still did not make any sense to me and left me afraid of what was to come. Though I left the doctor’s office bawling in the car the rest of the ride home, the fear of losing my mom sparked my curiosity in medicine, motivating me towards becoming an empathetic physician who provides care for individuals during their most fearful moments.
I felt powerless being unable to physically do anything to alleviate my mother’s pain as she underwent major surgery. In an attempt to understand how my mother’s sickness came to be my reality, I delved into summer health programs to deepen my medical knowledge and expand on what school taught me. At Stanford’s cardiothoracic surgical internship, I learned the fatal impacts of coronary artery disease and how to treat these individuals by performing a coronary artery bypass graft on a pig’s heart. Cutting through the thick muscle and completing each step of a surgical procedure, I could not help but think about my mom’s surgery. I felt empowered to hopefully someday carry the same responsibility as a surgeon. I aspire to provide my skills and knowledge to instill hope in patients, whose diagnoses may have left them in the same confused and frightened position as it once did for my mom.
My passion to support vulnerable populations was further motivated when I became a crisis text line counselor. My role included supporting individuals across the country during their most difficult moments, guiding them to a calmer headspace, and providing a listening ear so that they would not feel alone. A particular conversation that stuck with me was with “Sara,” a mother who had recently lost her baby. On top of coping with this loss, she also struggled with an abusive partner who blamed her for the miscarriage. Throughout our conversation, Sara constantly apologized for sending long text messages. Despite everything she was enduring, she was afraid of burdening others including me. While I could not begin to imagine the pain she was experiencing, I knew that she should not have to grieve alone. I validated her emotions and continued to remind her of her strengths that brought her up to that point. As a crisis counselor, I have enjoyed providing support for those who have been through tremendous hardship like Sara. I hope to be in a position where I can be there for people who need healing, both physically and emotionally.
Though I gained valuable skills from my experiences in summer programs and memorable encounters from meaningful conversations on the crisis text line platform, I have never felt more confident in my path towards becoming a physician until I began working with patients as a medical scribe. I recall following Dr. F into the clinical room where I met “Jane” for the first time sitting with tear-filled eyes. As the full body skin check began, I noticed scars on Jane’s chest and missing fingers on her hand that were a result of malignant melanoma and metastatic breast cancer. I observed Jane’s eyes full of fear from another impending, unwanted diagnosis that would leave yet another permanent scar on her body. As Dr. F approached, I could not help but notice Jane’s small reflexive flinches. All the trauma endured by her body and mind had left her with so much fear and anxiety. Seeing Jane in tears, I was reminded of my twelve year old self crying uncontrollably during my mom’s diagnosis. I approached and consoled Jane, giving her a tissue to wipe her tears and momentarily relax from the appointment. She released a sigh that may have been of relief as the doctor informed her that no concerns were noted during today’s visit. Jane’s scars and evident fear as well as Dr. F’s consolation and reassurance during the exam showed me how important it was to acknowledge the pain that individuals go through. I hope to comfort patients and alleviate their fear by making efforts to understand what they have been through in their past medical histories and personal lives and treating them in a personal manner accordingly. 
As a daughter, summer surgical intern, crisis counselor, and scribe, I was constantly reminded of the power that sickness holds in its ability to radiate fear and feelings of loneliness for patients, such as Jane and my mom, and their loved ones like me. These fearful emotions have constantly pushed me into wanting to be directly involved in not only counseling and providing treatment for patients but also being there for them emotionally in order to alleviate the stress and pain caused by such fear from sickness. I hope to provide an outlet for fear for every patient that I encounter as a physician and I aspire to be someone who will give their all to support every individual as a medical professional.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: A life experience that broadened my worldview was tutoring Syrian refugee students in English through Paper Airplanes. While teaching English to help these students continue their education, I have learned so much about global affairs and health disparities present in their home countries. I have heard about dangers like bombs destroying their homes and refugee camps being unbearably hot. Sharing meaningful conversations with my students has been so important to me. It has not only shown me how different circumstances are around the world but has also reinforced my passion for practicing medicine globally and helping victims in underserved countries and communities. Students who have acted as first responders to bombings have seen some of the most tragic things, yet they still show up with a smile to our sessions and are ready to learn. Though I may have had the teaching role, I have learned so much about resilience through my students and am inspired to continue to serve them.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: While volunteering at Silverado Hospice, I met many residents whom I was able to share meaningful interactions with. Every Sunday morning, I would visit the facility and spend time with my assigned patients, such as ‚ÄúBlue,‚Äù who was the very first patient that I met. Some days I would spend floating around the facility to speak with other residents like ‚ÄúMary,‚Äù who shared her love for animals and showed me the horses the facility had. Many residents loved sharing their stories and knowledge with me, and I enjoyed listening to them. Speaking with the residents and their visiting family members has helped me realize how important it is for the residents to know that they are cared for during their last few years of life. I believe my presence for many of these residents has provided companionship, and my time at Silverado Hospice has allowed me to create memories I will cherish for the rest of my life.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Before the COVID pandemic, I made plans to shadow physicians abroad during the summer and to work at a summer camp for children with Autism Spectrum Disorder. While finalizing these plans, I was sent back home to finish my education online due to the pandemic. Since I could no longer pursue these opportunities, I focused on taking more courses in the summer, eventually allowing me to graduate a year early. While continuing my education online, I could no longer continue my in-person research and volunteer activities that I had once participated in back at school. Instead, I remotely focused on data input and analyses of patterns in certain eating habits for my lab and sent letters to the residents at the hospice I used to visit before the lockdown. With the pandemic, it also became hard to find physicians to shadow. Luckily, I found great virtual opportunities that presented physicians of all specialties weekly for me to watch and learn.

Inst_Action_Desc: During Winter break of the 2019-2020 school year, the RA staff searched rooms and I received a write-up for one empty spiked seltzer can in my trash can. This can was in fact not mine, but I understand that because it was my trash can it is my responsibility. I only received a warning and did not meet with the Dean.
personal_statement:
Strong women raise strong doctors, and for that, I am very fortunate. My mother grew up in an old-fashioned Spanish family. Her father was the provider and her mother took care of the home. When sent off to college, her mother insisted she find a wealthy man to marry, as she was also destined to be a housewife. Despite these discouraging remarks, she was driven to succeed and eventually became an executive at one of the largest financial companies in the country. She is my idol, influencing the strong, driven woman I am today. Despite her struggles, her successes gave me the chance to pursue an excellent education. This opportunity evolved into shadowing and working for multiple healthcare workers, hence defining my passion for medicine. 
	My mother’s story inspires me to be my best self and pursue an arduous career of my own. I discovered the magic of science as I excelled in classes like Anatomy and Physiology. I also joined a research lab, where I plan to publish my senior thesis on the topic of gecko adhesion as a possible framework for bioinspired synthetic adhesives. After constant self-evaluation of my qualities and interests, I realized that as a physician I would be challenged every day, continue learning throughout my life, and acquire opportunities through meaningful research. These are all aspects I seek in a career. 
	My mother’s strength influences me to be an independent woman that works hard to obtain what I want. In doing so, I earned opportunities in both shadowing and working in healthcare, which further increased my desire to become a physician. In particular, shadowing an orthopedic surgeon inspired me, and I began to envision the idea of myself performing one of the surgeries I observed. Cartilage from a patient’s knee was grown on a dish in a separate facility and, once completed, was transplanted back into that same individual's knee. Standing bedside, I witnessed the perfect combination of research and medicine as the surgeon skillfully remodeled the knee with new technology. I remember how fascinated I was watching the surgeon, who was focused yet relaxed, change a person’s life so seamlessly. The knowledge and ease by which physicians operate using groundbreaking technology is inspiring and powerfully entices me to the medical field.
	Continuing my experiences in shadowing and working for multiple cardiologists, I recognized the value of empathy in medicine. For example, I remember one patient suffering from severe depression due to his chronic condition. I watched the doctor draw upon his personal challenges as an example to encourage the patient to keep battling because there was continued hope. By explaining to him a potential treatment, I saw the helplessness disappear from both the patient and his wife’s faces. The joy and fulfillment I experienced in that room are what I want to give to others and feel for myself every day. Each time I left work or a shadowing experience, I appreciated and enjoyed my day more than expected. I learned qualities of a good doctor one cannot learn from a textbook and now I am recognizing these qualities in myself. 
	Growing up, my mother always took me to charity events and emphasized the importance of giving back to my community. Thus, I joined a club at Villanova called “Best Buddies,” which allows students to build relationships with individuals with disabilities in the local area. In joining, I discovered a new side of myself. I found a new passion for working with disabled individuals. In continuing to build such bonds, I decided that when I am a physician, I will work towards creating an affordable community for people like those individuals I met in Best Buddies. The connection that I was able to make with “my buddies” as a small group leader emphasized the dignity of all people and opened up my heart to the unique needs of my future patients. Similar to the way my mother’s strength encouraged me, I will stand strong while supporting individuals of all differences. 
	Sensitive to all diversities, like my mother, we use our bilingual abilities to bridge gaps in our work. For instance, I found myself translating information for multiple patients in the cardiology office in hopes of bettering their healthcare experience. Specifically, one Spanish-speaking woman from Chile could not return home due to COVID restrictions. I offered to translate her appointment, and the moment I said one word to her in Spanish, I watched her eyes open up and her posture sink in relief. We ensured she understood what she needed before giving me a hug of appreciation when leaving. Having the cultural background that I do, I see firsthand how I will improve a patient’s healthcare experience as a future physician. 
	As a Hispanic woman in STEM, I recognize the opportunities given to me by my mother, making it even more vital for me to achieve what I know I can accomplish. In my annual visits to Puerto Rico, I witness many of my ethnicity who do not have the support and means that I am fortunate to have. My mother’s strengths elevated me to the reality of becoming a physician. Now as a strong woman, my awareness of cultural and physical differences, sensitivity to equity and love for science will shape me into becoming a strong doctor.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I was part of Best Buddies, which focused on building relationships with individuals with disabilities. The time I spent with my buddies increased my awareness and empathy for those different than me. I became more aware of the many different disabilities that exist, increasing my sensitivity towards all people. I learned how to communicate more effectively, both verbally and physically, showing my compassion towards the hardships these individuals face. For example, I was able to comfort and understand the needs of those buddies who were unable to speak. With a grab of my hand, I was able to decipher what they were trying to communicate. Additionally, I was able to develop my communication skills in that I could effectively communicate our rules or expectations in a sensitive way. My overall appreciation for the strength and resilience of my buddies inspires me every day, shifting my focus from disabilities and disadvantages to abilities and advantages.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: The office I work in is located in a town with a large Hispanic population. I am often able to use my skills to translate for my Spanish speaking patients and relate to them in their appointments. I encounter Spanish speaking patients at least once a day, and when I speak with them, I find that their tone changes completely. They become more talkative and seem to feel relief to talk to me directly rather than through a translator. I believe that in being able to communicate directly with the patient as the healthcare worker changes their medical experience because the visit becomes a conversation. The patient is able to explain their story and symptoms, while I respond based off those stories. The patient knows that the healthcare worker is hearing their statements firsthand. Things can often get lost in translation, so being able to communicate with the patient in their first language makes their experience more personal and reassuring.
7_-_COVID_Impact: In 2019, I was offered the chance to shadow surgeons for three weeks in Spain with the Atlantis Fellowship. Unfortunately, when COVID-19 began, this program was postponed, and it continued to be postponed each year. Unfortunately, by the time I was notified that the program was taking place this summer, I had accepted my job with Einstein and was unable to attend. On the other hand, with the start of the pandemic, many offices were seeking staff to keep their offices safe while continuing in-person care. I was fortunate enough to be hired as a medical screener for Cardiology Consultants of Philadelphia, gaining a full-time paid experience in healthcare. This job was beneficial not only because I was able to find employment in a time where it proved to be difficult, but also because it allowed me to gain future opportunities with the same company. Thus, while the pandemic brought many hardships, it also presented me with opportunities I may not have had otherwise.

Hrdshp_Comments: I was born in Germany to parents in the Air Force, and at the age of 3 my parents divorced and my mom gained full custody. After the separation, my mom and I translocated to rural Texas. Since my mom worked minimum wage jobs, we lived with extended family and utilized food stamps and WIC while receiving healthcare through Medicaid. In grade school, my mom and I moved to League City, TX to live with my grandparents to avoid homelessness. Due to the need for money and healthcare, my mother decided to rejoin the military. While my mom was in basic for two months, my sister and I lived with my grandmother. At Fort Benning, GA my mom met my stepfather and we moved to Washington D.C which further disrupted my educational experiences. Due to a lack of resources and an unsafe environment in D.C. public schools, my stepfather took a job with the United States Embassy and we moved to Poland for high school. Because of continuing financial difficulties I worked during high school to offset the cost of extracurricular activities, which took time away from college preparations. Through these experiences, I learned how to be resilient, adaptable, and how to persevere through tough times. Seeing how hard my mom worked instilled in me the value in applying yourself and having a strong work ethic.
personal_statement:
As the first in my family to attend a 4-year college, I struggled with what my future career would be as my goal had always been to make it to college. For my first case as a medical advocate, before my senior year, I drove an hour out of the city to a newly built hospital in the rural outskirts of Georgia. As I entered the room, I was met with a smile and a joke from a young girl wrapped in a blanket. I smiled and made a quick joke back. But I was nervous if I could handle the accompanying responsibilities and properly support the survivors. Thankfully, I quickly learned how to navigate through difficult situations and conversations. I became an active listener and directed interactions to best facilitate patient support. As I took on more cases, I watched the physicians move through the procedures with medical expertise in a supportive, sensitive manner. Over time, I realized that I wanted to be the leader at the bedside providing the medical knowledge and support that comes only with being a physician. 
My past work in sociology has allowed me to understand the person behind the patient and provided me the tools to become a better advocate. After losing two friends to heroin overdoses during my sophomore year, I was desperately searching for answers that sociology was able to provide. I learned how important it was to recognize that a patient is more than an illness and to take into consideration environmental and social contexts when providing treatment. As a research assistant involved in a sociological study, I explored social and health determinants more intricately and began to realize how deeply accessibility is intertwined with the ways in which people seek health. 
My volunteer work as an undergraduate expanded my awareness of this topic and allowed me to gain valuable insight into the healthcare system. I worked with refugees, immigrants, and women in shelters helping them navigate the system by assisting them with enrolling in ACA, Medicaid, and Medicare. As a child recipient of Medicaid, I was able to connect my experiences to those I was helping and engage with them on a deeper level. I saw firsthand the difficulties of figuring out and applying to the system, and how this exacerbated the stress felt by the people that it was designed to help. These experiences allowed me to see the gaps in healthcare, determine things I could do to address those shortcomings, and ultimately furthered my understanding of the ways in which people interact with the medical system. 
To fulfill my interest in health and research, I decided to pursue a job as a clinical research assistant at Joslin Diabetes Center. Here I was in the epicenter of medical research and I wanted to learn all of it. Suddenly I found myself engrossed in the science behind diabetes by wanting to gain a deeper understanding of the pathology, so I started attending grand rounds and began learning the different mechanisms of the disease. I shadowed everyone I could including nurse practitioners, registered dietitians, exercise specialists, and physicians to learn how each role contributed to the patients’ diabetes management.
Through my clinical experiences, I observed the multifaceted impact that compassionate physicians have on their patients. With a financially costly and lifelong disease like diabetes, I saw the ways in which the physicians worked with different income levels and insurance types for their treatment plans. I came to understand how the physician is an integral decision-making part of a team of medical professionals. I admired the problem-solving skills that the physicians portrayed by taking mismatching pieces of information from the entire healthcare team and holistically fitting them together to form a treatment plan that was conducive to the patient’s life. This mirrored my own skills in advocacy and my experience in building support plans with survivors. I saw how those skills could successfully translate to a clinical setting, confirming my decision to become a physician. 
I am continuing my work with vulnerable populations by volunteering at a food pantry and working in healthcare research as a study coordinator for pediatric chronic kidney disease. I am understanding how physicians work with government entities and insurance companies to create innovative and cost-effective treatment tools. By conducting qualitative research with caregivers and patients, we are creating outcome measures to gauge disease progression in patients most at risk. My background in sociology has prepared me for a career in advocacy and community service, while my work in the healthcare field has shown me how research in the social and biological sciences can work together.
Throughout my experiences I have learned that the way I want to make an impact on my community is through becoming a physician. I hope to bring a holistic, research-backed approach to medicine in underserved communities by understanding the multifaceted determinants present in a patient’s life to enhance their treatment plans. My path thus far has instilled in me the determination and drive to bridge the gaps present in healthcare and the willingness to learn, research, and apply new ideas every day while providing a space for innovative patient-centered care.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As a medical advocate, I met a Nigerian woman, who wanted to meet with her spiritual healer before starting any treatment. I was shocked as it is important to receive treatment and preventive medication as soon as possible. However, she was terrified. I sat and listened to her reasoning and realized that this was her way of healing. Her healer met her at the hospital and she left. I felt like I had failed. Afterwards, I connected with her for a check-in. During this call, I came to realize the cultural significance of the healer being someone she trusted and went to for all guidance. I realized the importance of understanding a patient‚Äôs culture and how they choose to seek health. After this experience, the way that I approached advocacy situations changed. I asked questions about the ways in which people sought care previously and I chose to meet them where they were to ensure that they were receiving the best quality of care and that it was respecting all aspects of their beliefs.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As the president of my community living house in college, I established an annual fundraiser that worked in collaboration with two other houses on campus, where we made wellness bags for women and children in a local shelter. Over a two month period, we organized numerous talks from the people who ran the shelters and the women living in the shelters. During these talks, we would fundraise by taking monetary or physical donations such as sanitary products and toys. Next, we held a campus wide event that allowed for people to pack bags for the women and children. Through holding this fundraiser we not only provided necessities, self-care, and fun items for the women and children, but also brought awareness to the shelter and increased the number of people from our campus who volunteered on a weekly basis. This fundraiser and relationship with the shelter has continued on since my graduation.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I began my premedical postbac program in June 2020. The transition from a full time job in Boston, where I had a large support system, to a full time student in a new place was difficult. Classes were hybrid with a portion of the class coming in at different times following precautions, which was necessary but made it difficult to integrate into the community. Additionally, professors held office hours over zoom which led to further difficulty in trying to ask questions. These experiences forced me to explore new and innovative ways to learn and study, which overall helped me become a better student.

personal_statement:
I have fond memories of our small-town residents at the sidelines of a game, soaking up sun outside affordable housing, headed to their car in the store parking lot thanking my father, a physician, for checking on their mother in the critical care unit or securing a sorely-needed specialist referral. I now reflect that these gestures patched holes in the tourist pamphlet version Berkshire County; Hidden behind arts and outdoor recreation, Berkshire County consistently ranks in the lowest percentiles of health outcomes in the Commonwealth, driven by socioeconomic and access challenges, and high rates of comorbidity, opioid use, obesity, and smoking. Shadowing local physicians I witnessed the unending work and dedication required of healthcare providers to navigate understaffing and limited resources endemic to rural medicine. While scribing overnight in the Emergency Department, I overheard a salient quotation from older gentleman in the ED: “I get sick, I come in, I get a little better with you guys. I leave but can’t get off the street to really heal and rest. So, I’m back.” In directly interacting with patients, I sensed, but did not yet grasp, the underlying factors of a cycle of readmissions.

I knew I wanted to pursue a career in medicine when I left for Williams College. While I progressed in my chemistry and biology courses, social sciences laid bare the roles that race, class and environment play in Berkshire County. My focus on social determinants of health and community health then consumed my academic interests. I took classes on how power structures impact care and diagnosis in the United States as well as classes on the cultural underpinnings of death and dying. One of my mentors in the Berkshire is and was a practicing clinician and director of community health. I was struck by the rewarding balance that these two aspects of care generated. 

The opportunity to intern outside of Berkshire County at Brigham and Women's added new dimensions to this balance. There, I  focused on cardiovascular outcomes and maintained a patient registry for lupus patients, which exposed me to new populations and study design. I grasped how similar tools could be applied to assess and drive changes back home. 
My time at Williams had challenged me as an individual, friend, academic and leader. With debt to several incredible peers and professors, I expanded my healthcare knowledge and focused my interests on community health and the social determinants of health. From freshman novice to captain of the Williams rowing team, I led 50 athletes to a tremendous fall season. My peers at Williams drove me to become a more conscientious member of my community, a more selfless leader, and a more developed student. 

Graduating into the pandemic, I was invited back to Brigham and Women’s Hospital by Dr. Karen Costenbader and Dr. Daniel Solomon, both of whom have been very generous mentors. I immersed myself in learning about clinical conditions, primarily rheumatoid arthritis diagnosis and treatment. I drafted research protocols, recruited patients, conducted study visits, analyzed results, and wrote my own manuscript based on the quality improvement project I oversaw.  I am currently managing three studies focused on autoimmune disease including sequelae associated with COVID-19 as well as immunogenicity and disease activity in rheumatoid arthritis patients post-COVID-19 vaccination. I have conducted close to 200 study visits and have been fortunate to be a co-author on seven manuscripts and abstracts. Within these clinical research experiences, I am most energized by the patient interaction. I love hearing about the importance of roll-on sunscreen for lupus patients, or how a participant’s children are navigating virtual kindergarten.  

Endurance cycling emerged during the pandemic as my unexpected passion and source of balance: I love finding time to ride out of Boston to country roads, checking in on what the best sandwich place is with the locals and finding new places to explore. Each of these journeys further strengthen my commitment to community as I spin through myriad snapshots of small-town life. Through directly experiencing the health challenges of rural life, studying the impact of social determinants of health, developing clinical research skills, and joining community efforts to repair health and healthcare, I have built a strong foundation to lean on as a clinician. I want to pursue a speciality like primary care that allows for a dynamic approach to medicine at both the individual patient and macro community level. I aspire to connect these joys, to lead a vote to pave new bike lanes which could begin to address the structural gaps in care, to take Saturday mornings to ride with patients, as physician, engaged community leader, thoughtful clinical researcher, and neighbor.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I reflect often on a moment when I was 14 and washing dishes at a local caf√© that shaped the way I approach any social situation. It was my first summer job and first day of work, and the dishes were piled up as the lunch rush hit. The cook, Ali, a twinkly eyed man from C√¥te d‚ÄôIvoire, came up to me and gave me a big pat on the back. He said, ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs knock these out, then you come join us for lunch.‚Äù We washed the rest and he cooked me a burger. He made me feel like part of the team. I try to emulate Ali as I know how much of a difference it can make. By no means am I perfect, but I always strive to do this in athletics, classes, work, and with friends. At my college graduation, my rowing coach told me that I was elected captain my senior year was because the team believed I could make every member feel important. That moment was particularly sweet, as I knew I had succeeded in making others feel the way I did in that kitchen.That is what I hope to bring to Rush.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I grew up in a medically underserved area of Western Massachusetts. This is an area that is relatively hard to navigate, with little public transportation and relatively sparse social services and resources to aid individuals outside of the hospital. I saw while scribing in the emergency department how hard it is for patients to navigate existing hospital and community resources. I had the opportunity to return to Berkshire Medical and work alongside the director of community engagement at the hospital. As part of this effort, I worked to create a list of free resources and community groups in the Berkshires that could help address different needs and worked with the system to publish this resources list around so providers and other community members could easy contact these resources. Local providers at the hospital still use this resources list and I hope it has been able to address some of the social determinants of health for patients outside of the hospital.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I finished Williams virtually in Spring 2020 in Western Massachusetts. My job at Brigham and Women's was postponed until September and I started work in a hybrid environment in the Fall. I did not meet many of my team members in person until the Spring. I felt very much on my own learning the ropes of being a research assistant. Thankfully, I have had great mentorship and support from my primary investigators during the pandemic and we have navigated many research related challenges like clinic shutdowns and exposure protocols. We have had several successful research studies related to COVID and I have conducted over 200 study visits, learning a little more about each patient's experience in the pandemic and their life in general at each one, but the pandemic has certainly shifted my experience away from a traditional clinical research experience in many ways.

personal_statement:
I grew up in a family that didn’t trust medicine. I was always taught that doctors had ulterior motives, and they were far from the altruistic, caring image they were portrayed to be. My dad would always talk about how big pharma pushed doctors to care more about profits than patients. My mom would doubt every medication prescribed to us. When my grandma passed away, my parents blamed it on her physician’s negligence, rather than her own poor health. 

This mistrust was not borne from nothing. Historical maltreatment, experimentation and neglect all have led to a pervasive distrust of the medical field. Understanding the historical background between my and so many other family’s mistrust in medicine was what first truly drove me to consider a career as a physician. But what first piqued my interest as a child was my Uncle. 

As an E.R. physician, and the only doctor my family knew personally, my Uncle was my first glimpse of the ability doctors have to improve the relationship between medical professionals and those who have been historically harmed by them. My Uncle constantly fielded questions from anxious relatives. He listened, empathized, and explained anxiety-inducing treatment plans or diagnoses in ways that we could understand. Most of all, he encouraged us to be honest with our primary care providers. Even off the clock, my Uncle demonstrated the power physicians have to mend the relationship between mistrustful patients and their healthcare providers. 

In college, I began seriously exploring the medical field and what a career as a physician would be like. My first position was as a patient transporter in an emergency department, where I was able to spend time with patients and families while transporting them throughout the hospital. Once I had a homeless patient, and while taking him to X-ray he spoke to me about his struggles with alcoholism and withdrawal. I remember I could barely hear the words he was saying, his voice was so quiet. He told me how he felt embarrassed to be homeless and panhandling, leaving him dependent on others in order to survive. He said he felt like his kids were ashamed of him, but he finally felt motivated to get better. To even listen and be an ear for someone who needs help feels good. To feel like you’ve made a positive impact on someone’s life and health is fulfilling. 

As a transporter, I learned to adapt to each patient’s needs. But even more, my seat near the nursing station gave me a window to how healthcare professionals speak and act out of view. No matter what a patient had been admitted for, their doctors and nurses would always speak about their condition with compassion and discretion. My uncle’s empathy and drive first gave me hope that the relationship between marginalized groups and their healthcare providers could be improved, but volunteering in a hospital and seeing that same empathy persist fostered that. 

Then, I began working as a nursing unit secretary. In this position, I was able to better see the amount and work and coordination, often across multiple departments, needed to care for a patient. I also experienced some of the frustrating aspects of healthcare. On top of a full unit, we often had to navigate patients who were sun-downing, experiencing withdrawal, or had angry family members, on top of complex medical problems. No matter how tedious it may have seemed, I continued to see doctors take time to de-escalate situations, adjust treatment plans, and solve complex issues. 

Every position in a healthcare team is integral to successful care, but my interest in becoming a physician specifically was driven by their breadth of knowledge, and their ability to manage and direct patient care. 

One of my first times sitting for a patient was for an E.R. admission, transferred to a gynecology oncology floor. She was admitted for rib pain, after being assaulted while walking home. While in the E.R., it was discovered that she had an S.T.I., which she had gotten from a sexual partner she thought she had an exclusive relationship with. She had a history of sexual trauma and abuse, and recently her best friend passed away. She required a sitter because she was experiencing suicidal ideation and experiencing severe panic attacks. 

A hospital admission puts someone in a vulnerable position. In order to access the care they need, a person has to repeatedly divulge personal information. But every physician listened attentively, and though her initial complaint– rib pain– was swallowed up by more serious problems, it was readdressed and assessed before discharge. 

Once more, I was able to witness how meaningful the relationship between a physician and their patient can be. Mental health resources were made available to this patient, and upon discharge she had a plan to ensure both her mental and physical health would be taken care of.   

Though the medical field may have a darker past, things have improved, and they will continue to do so as time goes on. Becoming a physician will allow me to play a direct role in improving the relationship between those who have been historically harmed by the medical field, while also advancing science and contributing to the body of work that we use to treat and care for them.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Growing up as a first-generation American allowed me to be raised in an environment that taught me to be understanding of diverse backgrounds. This was put into practice throughout my life, including when I worked as a patient safety sitter. _x000D_
_x000D_
One patient had been admitted after being assaulted. She had lived her entire life in the city, whereas I grew up in the county. I grew up in a safe home, but she had to deal with abusive family her entire life. She needed a sitter because she had been struggling with suicide ideation. _x000D_
_x000D_
This situation was my first time directly witnessing how difficult it can be to access medical care. This patient had been trying to better manage her mental health, but barriers prevented her from accessing resources. This experience enhanced my ability to understand those unlike myself because I was an ear for a patient who‚Äôd had a completely different upbringing. It taught me that part of being an effective physician is helping patients access needed resources
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Education, and access to high-quality education, has always been important to me. Growing up, I was blessed to attend well-funded schools. The fact that many people in my family and community did not have this same luxury, made me very appreciative of the opportunities I had access to. I understand how much my education has done for me, from a full-scholarship to college, to how prepared I was for my courses, so I‚Äôll always take advantage of opportunities to pass on what I‚Äôve been given. An example of this would be the time I spent as a tutor for a student with a disability during the COVID-19 pandemic. Her school became fully remote, and she had started falling behind. I was offered the opportunity to work with her 1:1 to help keep her on track throughout the rest of the school year. In the time we had together, I was able to work with her, her mom and her teacher to address her weaknesses, and I‚Äôm proud that she was able to finish the year with good grades and more confidence.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
One major disruption I experienced was a difficulty in finding shadowing experiences. I relied on local practices and hospitals, however, most clinical settings understandably disallowed shadowing._x000D_
_x000D_
I adapted by participating in virtual shadowing. Although this was different from traditional shadowing, I was still able to learn about various medical specialties and professions from different backgrounds, and the role they play in quality patient care. Rather than be restricted to providers based in my own state, I was able to gain a better understanding of how state and regional lines impact healthcare. _x000D_
_x000D_
Another major disruption was losing the job that had been my primary source of income, due to pandemic related closures. However, I simultaneously worked in other positions that could transition to be fully remote. I was able to continue to support myself until finding a new job, and still participate in meaningful extracurricular experiences.

personal_statement:
Lab 17! Let’s oxidize methoxybenzyl alcohol to methoxybenzaldehyde with bleach, but there is a problem: how can we get the nonpolar alcohol to react with the polar bleach? That’s where Tetrabutyl-ammonium hydrogen sulfate (TBAS) comes in. While TBAS may be limited to a necessary phase-transfer-catalyst in the organic chemistry lab, in the real world, TBAS are personified as physicians. I have another acronym for TBAS: Toddler Builder Acrobat Servant. Developing the grit of a toddler, the vision of a builder, the work ethic of an acrobat, and the humility of a servant has motivated me to be a catalyst-like physician.

Toddler’s display resilience as they try to walk, often falling and crying, but getting right back up. In Fall 2020, I withdrew from my organic chemistry course because I did not have the learning style needed for success in a rigorous online course. I fell flat on my face and thought I was not cut out to be pre-med. I questioned why I wanted to be a doctor and the answer was straight forward: I want to be like those who I look up to. They are superheroes disguised as human physicians saving families in their communities with unwavering devotion. Motivated, like a toddler determined to walk, I got up. I resolved that success requires an adaptable discipline and put in time to make deeper connections in my learning. As a physician, I will remain flexible and steadfast to overcome challenges.

Builders make infrastructure, like bridges, to connect individuals to this global society. Just like a catalyst, physicians bridge the scientific community and the public. Without this bridge, there would be no societal benefit. As a tutor for underserved K-12 students, I taught subject matters from basic English to Electrochemistry and Calculus. I learned that converting highly sophisticated knowledge into simple, comprehensible lessons is uplifting to the learner and teacher. I practiced this in the clinical setting as I consented pediatric patients and their families into advanced emergency trials to improve patient outcomes. I presented scientific language in a digestible way, giving them the power of understanding. My aim in medicine is to provide top quality health care that improves patient outcomes, comprehension, and comfort through the communication skills I gained through teaching.

Acrobats do many things, of which my favorite is juggling. My greatest attempt and success was in Summer 2021. I received a research internship at Houston Methodist where I studied outcomes following orotracheal intubation in ICU patients with right ventricular dysfunction for 50 hours a week. In addition, I worked as a scribe in the COVID packed ED for minority communities for 24 hours a week. On top of that, the Divine Brain Trust (a place that makes students ideal global citizens by studying the world’s cultures) selected me as their lead mentor to manage 50+ youth with the brand-new online and social distancing format. While being a son, brother, best friend, role-model, etc. I worked diligently and strategically to give my undivided attention to all opportunities I had taken on. During this time, I gained a valuable lesson on teamwork. I was trained in school that I had to do all the work if I wanted the group project to receive an A, but I was wrong. When faced with real challenges, like managing 25 COVID patients at once during the Delta surge or finding ways to engage teens through a small square block on Google Meets, one must collaborate and be open to others’ ideas. With the help of other acrobats, one can juggle many responsibilities whether in patient care or creative projects. By the summer end, I finished collecting the data for the major publication, gained the respect of several ED physicians, and developed such engaging ways to study the world’s histories and philosophies that the group had grown! I am ready to efficiently juggle my growing responsibilities and look forward to working with an interdisciplinary team of healthcare professionals for the united goal of healing.

Serving my community through uplifting youth through knowledge and sports, organizing blood drives, giving hand sanitizers/masks to those in need, coordinating multi-school fundraisers for charities like Ronald McDonald Housing and American Heart Association, distributing the vaccine, etc. has many benefits. One benefit is that it humbles me. For about a year, I voluntarily managed the front desk of a bustling ER. One Friday afternoon, a sobbing mother came running in speaking Spanish while holding an empty chewy vitamins bottle and pointing to her autistic son. I tried to help her but was unsuccessful. The experience taught me that learning languages so I can empathize and deescalate situations is a helpful tool and motivated me to learn Spanish. I am eager to add medical expertise to my toolset to uplift impoverished communities. As a result, I look forward to being humbled and in turn learning ways to improve myself.

I want to be a physician because I want to be The Best At Service (TBAS) and am capable to be a real phase-transfer-catalyst since I have the perseverance of a toddler, the tools of a builder, the daring of an acrobat, and the heart of a servant.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
After 5 shifts, managing a busy nonprofit ED‚Äôs patient influx became like clockwork and my mind engaged in its favorite past time: people watching. I wanted to give these people‚Äôs suffering a compassionate shoulder, but I was afraid my efforts would lead to superficial conversations._x000D_
_x000D_
While learning to make a challenging origami peacock from a YouTube video that night to recharge, I realized how safe I felt. Present day, patients from age 5 to 87, all genders, races, beliefs, etc. have learned origami with me._x000D_
_x000D_
Teaching the Japanese art of paper folding unveiled a level of vulnerability difficult to attain. I dealt with wet origami boats from patients expressing their loneliness due to abandonment. I held sloppy origami frogs made by distracted and unconfident patients sharing their constant battle with poverty and food insecurity. Art really does transcend boundaries._x000D_
_x000D_
Getting to know someone only requires a vision, 15 minutes, square colored paper, fearlessness, and self-motivation.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
Have you ever started a fire? I empower disadvantaged students who don‚Äôt believe in education or themselves. I consistently persevered to start perpetually burning fires for knowledge within our 1.5-hour group "braingym."_x000D_
_x000D_
I went door-to-door, despite prior program rejections and door slams, giving nutrition information with healthy accessible recipes from my cookbook to educate families stuck in a vicious cycle of ignorance/suffering from healthcare disparities._x000D_
_x000D_
As chief youth mentor, I led a team to give hand sanitizers/masks and safety information, socially distantly, to uninformed communities that disproportionately suffer. This spread like wildfire._x000D_
_x000D_
As a physician, my medical expertise, self-sustaining perseverance, and blazing initiative to creatively uplift communities starting with Chicago‚Äôs west side neighborhoods will bring me to achieve my long-term career goal to establish evidence-based models to improve societal/structural determinants of health for leaders everywhere.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
In March 2020 (pre-COVID), I had a prestigious summer research internship lined up and all As in honors courses._x000D_
_x000D_
In May 2020, my internship offer was rescinded. Despite this disappointment, I converted it to motivation and became an online summer undergraduate research training (SMART) program participant at Baylor College of Medicine (BCM). I asked questions about poop pills, neural circuits, and the human genome which led me to write a grant with my honors ethics professor and two geneticists at BCM to bring awareness to race/genetics research and bias-free science inspired by George Floyd._x000D_
_x000D_
Despite my organic chemistry incident in Fall 2020, I came back stronger in Spring 2021. I took 19 credit hours (with organic chemistry), explored cancer health disparities and COVID-19 prevalence, distributed vaccine to the elderly, and attained leadership roles. In the end, I aced every exam/task._x000D_
_x000D_
COVID-19 made me more resourceful and confident to tackle unexpected hurdles at medical school.

Hrdshp_Comments: My family immigrated to the U.S. to end a cycle of poverty. Due to licensure requirements, my father, an accountant, was unable to continue; further, financial hardship forced my mother to withdraw from nursing school in India. As a result, they labored as the maid service at a motel in South Hill, VA. My parents, brother, and I all shared a single motel room and relied on governmental aid for food. I attended schools that lacked the primary resources for fostering a career in higher education. My high school performed below the state average in all subjects and over half the students were on free/reduced lunch. To assist financially, I worked to bring in supplemental income from the age of fifteen. Although balancing academics, extracurriculars, and employment harbored many challenges, it has made me stronger in the face of uncertainty and adversity. Additionally, my family’s immigration status led to avoiding medical care and governmental programs, even in times of crisis. This has only further motivated me to pursue a career in medicine. My experiences have illustrated the significance of advocacy and accessible healthcare for marginalized communities and families experiencing similar obstacles. As a physician, I want to deliver high-quality and equitable healthcare to all patients in the community.
personal_statement:
Sweat was running down my face as I ran frantically from my opponent. I felt a tap on my shoulder, “Tag! You’re it!” Quickly turning around, I attempted to chase my friend across the playground. The next thing I knew, I was lying down in the school infirmary and picked up by my mom to go to my pediatrician’s office. My pediatrician walked in and mumbled a diagnosis unfamiliar to my mom’s broken English. With my naive mind and minimal knowledge of medical terms, I translated and told her that the doctor thinks I may have a condition called asthma and that we needed to see a lung specialist soon. I did not know what that meant, but I was incredibly scared.
 
The following week, I walked to another medical office that reeked of disinfectant. Sensing my fear, Dr. B, a pulmonologist, knelt to my level and explained to me that the 2x2 glass cage was a plethysmograph and it was going to help him see how he can help me breathe better. Consolidating my fears, I followed his instructions to step inside, and I was soon diagnosed with asthma. Dr. B taught me how to use an inhaler and also educated my mom about the disease in Gujarati, the language we in spoke at home. When she informed Dr. B of our financial situation, he handed her a round, purple inhaler and a month’s supply of medicine, all free of cost, as well as affordable options for nebulizer machines. Dr. B revealed to me the capacity medicine has to change people’s lives and the role a physician has in health education, culturally competent care, and advocacy. As the nebulizer found a new residence on my nightstand and my breathing became effortless, I knew then and there that I wanted to have healing magic just like Dr. B. I knew that this is the type of physician I wanted to become.

As I grew older, I noticed that the rest of my family did not have the same access to care and concept of medicine as I did. My mom was laying on the couch next to me when I heard the same wheezing I once heard in my lungs years before. Lecturing my mom on how she should see a doctor brought me to a harsh reality. Due to my family’s immigration status, they could not receive health insurance, and paying out of pocket was not feasible. In 2018, my mother was diagnosed with Rheumatoid Arthritis which had left her lungs scarred. I could not help but think her condition could have been less serious if she had the access to the care she needed earlier. Watching my mother’s health diminish due to lack of access had an unfavorable impression on me. However, watching her health flourish due to her physicians advocating for her to acquire the treatment she needed had an even greater favorable impression on me. Her primary care physician detected the change in her health and referred her to a rheumatologist who was able to give her a definitive answer. From medications to doctor visits, I began to see her health transform before my eyes. She was no longer in so much pain that it was difficult to open a jar. Her physicians were able to give her her life back. This further reiterated my motivation to pursue medicine. I knew I was on the right path.

Upon entering college, I wanted to help families, similar to mine, receive healthcare and also gain a deeper understanding of the medical field. Accordingly, I started volunteering weekly at my university’s free clinic. During one of my volunteer shifts, I met Mr. J who informed me that he was recently laid off, did not have health insurance, was jumping between shelters, and that this was his last hope to get better, so he could start working again. I didn't have the knowledge to know what was medically wrong with him, but it was visibly clear that he was unwell. The following day during my routine follow-up calls, Mr. J answered, and I asked how he was feeling, to which he stated that he was in the hospital. I sat frozen as he continued, “I have colon cancer, the doctor at the clinic told me to go to the ER.” Although I was pleased that Mr. J was able to receive help, I was more so frustrated by my limitations as a volunteer. I wanted to do more than collect vitals and intake, I wanted to directly provide the care he needed. I knew I wanted to help in ways that only a physician can. As a physician, I want to heal patients and address these issues directly by volunteering my time and finding ways for free clinics to receive more funding for preventative resources. I am driven to heal my community and serve them to my highest potential.

My journey to medicine started with my family, but it didn’t stop there. Each step has paved my path to becoming a physician and advocate for those who have fallen through the cracks of the healthcare system. I hope by taking care of my patients I can recognize the public health issues within and work with organizations to form new and effective health policies. My experiences have revealed to me the impact that physicians have in transforming people’s lives with advanced medicine, delivering culturally competent care, and being an advocate. I will not be satisfied with anything less than having full responsibility for their care, so I can do everything in my power to spread a little bit of healing magic to those that need it.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
When I hear the term, immigrant, I‚Ä¶_x000D_
_x000D_
‚Ä¶see my cousin in pain because she could not afford her medications._x000D_
_x000D_
‚Ä¶hear my best friend crying because she can‚Äôt find a facility that will accept her uninsured mother with cancer._x000D_
_x000D_
‚Ä¶smell the smoke of a car crash and my parents begging the paramedics to not take them to the hospital because they feared deportation more than their injuries._x000D_
_x000D_
Physicians endure years of medical training but often fail to help those who need it the most due to systemic barriers and injustices. Having seen the challenges my community faces when seeking healthcare, I will add to the diversity of the Rush class through my perspective on medicine and accessibility to immigrant populations. Further, I will continue increasing access to care for underserved populations through Community Health Clinic._x000D_
_x000D_
I promise as a medical student and physician to be a voice for the voiceless and advocate for the human right of healthcare through dedication to service and health equity.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
While volunteering at my university‚Äôs free clinic, I met a mother who recently sought asylum in the U.S. She feared that her status would invoke deportation if she sought out care but knew her baby needed medical attention. I assured the mother that our clinic does not discriminate based on immigration status. After her visit, I put up signs in English and Spanish to inform patients that they may seek care regardless of their refugee, asylum, or immigration status. The following week we saw an increase in refugee patients. I realized the power that those in medicine have in advocating and increasing access to care for those who typically would not have it._x000D_
_x000D_
Through the free clinic, I have helped the underserved Gainesville community gain access to quality healthcare and met countless individuals, like my family, who all face health inequities. It is these interactions that have fueled my passion to improve the access to healthcare, specifically in Chicago‚Äôs west side neighborhoods._x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact: I joined a research lab in November 2019 because I was interested in learning more about breast cancer research and the upcoming treatment methods due to my family member‚Äôs fight against breast cancer. In January 2020 I began learning lab techniques, but in March, my research was canceled until fall. Due to COVID-19, I did not get to spend as much valuable time gaining research skills to contribute to the evolution of medicine as I would have liked. Additionally, I was hired as an ICU Scribe in February, but  I had to move back home and resign due to the 2.5-hour commute. I also had several shadowing opportunities lined up in specialties ranging from pediatrics to orthopedic surgery, but all were canceled to minimize extra exposure to COVID-19. The pandemic decreased my hours dedicated to research, clinical experiences, and shadowing, but I was able to attain them later through outlets that did not increase the risk of spreading the virus.

personal_statement:
“Ugh, it’s just another Darryl” is a phrase frequently uttered by my fellow coworkers in the emergency transport field. The word “Darryl” is a derogatory term used in the San Diego urban EMS system to describe people of the homeless community, and with it comes a negative bias of poor attitudes and markedly different patient care. Ever since I started work as an EMT, the word has bothered me as I have noticed this negative connotation. Shouldn’t we strive to eliminate negative bias in the medical field in order to provide maximum care? Shouldn’t we treat each and every patient with compassion? The change we yearn to see in society begins with the intention in our attitudes and actions; I intend to lead by example by never using hurtful and derogatory slang. My goal in entering EMS is to prepare myself to be a physician who leads with intention to provide excellent and well rounded care.

The word “intentional” first captured my attention in college and has permeated into my life today. During my time of involvement with Intervarsity Christian Fellowship (IVCF) in college, I learned that intentionality means to pursue something wholeheartedly and with purpose, whether that be a relationship, results for a lab experiment, or comprehensive patient care. As a leader of IVCF, I was faced with many challenges ranging from logistics of weekly club meetings to solving interpersonal disputes between members, and found that leadership requires a combination of intentionality and creativity. For example, when leading a small group geared towards freshmen on campus, I had to be innovative in how to attract interest in the gathering while simultaneously being intentional with the time I invested. Through trial and error I found that classes younger than me responded better to flexibility rather than rigidity of schedule, and found that students were more likely to be consistent if they were consistently followed up with by a leader. When my first small group failed, I had to restructure my plans for the small group and focus on meeting students where they were at, not only providing a community but providing stress relief through weekly art projects. Intentionally leading the students by providing a safe space and creative outlet served both the individual and the community of the club, and taught me how intentionality and creativity intertwine in the care of others. 

After graduating, I became an EMT in the hopes of gaining medical experience. As an EMT, I immersed myself in the culture of San Diego and the lives of our patients; from transporting the wealthiest of folk living in the La Jolla highlands to the people living in poverty just miles away, I began to understand the value of being intentionally compassionate to all patients. I made it a goal to intentionally engage with every patient to the best of my ability. One of our most emotionally taxing patients was a woman whose tendency to complain made it tempting to disregard her; however, with each encounter I was able to form a closer bond with this patient by wholeheartedly listening to her. With trust built between us, she felt comfortable confiding in me that her depression evolved because none of her family remained in her life. Her depression led to alcohol abuse disorder, eventually causing kidney failure, which explained her tri-weekly transport to dialysis treatment. Deciding to remain intentional in my treatment of her, I gave her some prints of my personal artwork to hang in her room, and seeing her face light up when someone finally showed her kindness is a moment I will never forget. This experience taught me that long-term treatment of a patient requires intentionally diving into their story to creatively treat their condition rather than simply evaluating the surface. 

After honing my EMT abilities as a transport medic, I moved on to become a 911 EMT with the city of San Diego. I responded to a myriad of 911 calls ranging from narcotic overdoses, to infantile drownings, to cardiac arrests. The chaos of emergency medicine challenged me to creatively think outside the box, and it solidified how crucial intentionality is for a healthcare provider. While I may not be able to have prolonged conversations with emergent patients, I am still able to offer words of comfort and respect for the patient with an attitude of compassion beyond the physical treatment we provide. My team and I recently had an encounter with a patient having an abdominal aortic aneurysm. While she begged us not to let her die, we held her hands and focused on stabilizing her, encouraging her that we were doing the best care we could. Through our coaching and our teamwork to stabilize her throughout transport, she was able to calm herself down enough to make it to the hospital without incident. Our ability to be compassionate and de-escalate the situation effectively provided patient care, both physically and emotionally. 

Over my year of EMS I meditated over the word “intentional” and how it applies to healthcare and my goals with patient care. Intentionality means meeting all patients where they’re at, listening wholeheartedly, and treating them with compassion. I strive to be the physician who is intentional with her patients and can therefore treat them more effectively.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: A demographic I encounter frequently while working as an EMT in the heart of San Diego are people of foreign cultures. Engaging with such people and witnessing how different cultures have unique values of personal health has given me passion and drive to make healthcare more inclusive. For example, I once transported a woman of middle eastern descent who was in active labor; being part of a religion that values modesty, she and her husband would not consent to my male partner assessing her vaginal region. Watching her husband exercise his control over the situation was difficult for my team and I since our intention was simply to provide optimal care for his wife, however we chose to respect their culture and not infringe on its values. While other cultures are certainly different from mine, it would be unprofessional to treat someone according to the values of my culture only; I can only choose to do as much positive care as each culture allows, showing full respect for my patients.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: While volunteering at a nursing facility in high school, I had grown fond of a hard-headed and ill-mannered elderly patient who lived in loneliness and poor health. As I began to dedicate more time with this patient, they began to confide in me and a friendship was created. The last time I saw this patient, they told me ‚Äúmy wife died of cancer, my children died of cancer, and I‚Äôm dying of cancer. You are my only friend left.‚Äù That week, the patient passed away and I was left with the long-lasting impression of their words. This interaction instilled in me the importance of compassion, for without it, we are simply another care provider biding the time a patient remains in our care. Acting with compassion can make an astronomical difference to the patient, as we rarely understand the entirety of their background and what events in their past shape their present actions. Since that last interaction, I have made the conscious effort to be compassionate to every patient.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The COVID-19 pandemic has both positively and negatively affected my journey to medical school. Along with increased precautions due to the pandemic, all shadowing opportunities I had lined up fell through indefinitely, and still remain difficult to attempt. Positively, however, I was able to find a virtual shadowing program to still interact and engage with physicians. Additionally, due to the pandemic I was able to gain a better understanding of how the healthcare field operates, since the EMS field became markedly more busy with sick patients.

personal_statement:
“He could die in a year, tomorrow, heck, he can even die within the hour!” To family members already in grief, these callous words uttered by the physician with complete disregard for human emotions and psychology were the impetus to a promise I made, a promise that forever changed my outlook on pursuing a medical career.

During my first year at UCI, I witnessed the death of a close family member for the first time. While initially impacting my academics, I came to realize that I must separate the two realms of my life. I must transform this tragedy into a means of growth. The first time my family visited my grandfather after he was put on life support, we were naturally desperate and searching for any glimpse of reassurance from the physician. Instead, he was treated as if he were an object, a case, a mere pawn of one’s profession, rather than my human grandfather. My promise that day was to be more empathetic, to truly understand and care for those in need.

I had never truly understood the importance of patient-physician interaction up until that day. I now know that the way a physician communicates to his or her patients can dictate the attitude, and therefore the actions, of patients striving to improve their health. Since that day, I started to channel all my emotions to form a philosophy of medicine that would be the basis on which I would approach medicine and all my future patients. I began noting aspects from each of my experiences that would help provide the scaffolding to this philosophy. I also pondered the extent and lack of care given to those in underserved communities.

To fulfill my curiosity, I volunteered to be part of a clinical missionary trip to Bolivia, Brazil, and Paraguay. For three weeks, I had the pleasure of working alongside numerous physicians in clinics with predominantly Spanish-speaking patients. I translated patients’ complaints, took their vitals, and directed them to the physician’s office. My initial inclination was to reassure patients that they would get better, thus developing personalized relationships; however, I realized that death, chronic pain, and bleak prognoses are innate and systemic parts of the medical field. Death and disease are realities, but at least I could reassure them they were not alone in the process. As patients communicated their complaints to me, I noticed a commonality. There was a sense of desperation and longing to be noticed and cared for in each patient. For some, it was latent underneath a stoic facade, while for others, it was blatant, but nonetheless, the need for empathy and care is an innate human trait. Regardless of how seemingly mild or unimportant, every complaint needs to be treated with empathy and complete attentiveness; ultimately, it matters not what a physician deems significant as long as it is significant to the patient.

Although my experience as a scribe demonstrated the therapeutic impact of pharmacological agents, I ultimately understood that there is a degree of humanity in each patient that cannot be addressed with medications. A patient named “Linda” came into the office with high blood pressure and was waiting for over two hours. Upon entering the room, it was clear she was distressed and that it carried into her personal life. Dr. Zand was able to transform Linda’s mood by his mere compassionate persona, listening and eventually making her laugh. As she continually came in to see Dr. Zand, I noticed she picked up on his attitude and seemed to adopt it herself. Dr. Zand’s development of a strong relationship with Linda prompted her to be more engaged in her personalized healthcare. I learned that, yes, it is essential to prescribe ace inhibitors and diuretics for hypertension; however, the most effective treatment method is one that addresses both the medical and the human, psychological components.

Volunteering at the UCI Music to Heal Program provided yet another valuable lesson on becoming more empathetic. Utilizing my 11 years of piano training in a medical setting allowed me to view medicine in a creative light. As I played Sonata in G Major by Mozart in a wing of the ICU unit, I witnessed a child slowly come out of his room to watch. Although scared at first, I saw a subtle excitement in his eyes that soon evolved into him dancing. Making certain that I consistently played at that specific wing, I came to know him very well as “David.” I even taught him how to play “Happy Birthday” on the keyboard during one of our many encounters. I felt like I truly made a difference in his well-being; it seemed as if, for a moment, David had forgotten about his ailments.

My clinical exposure, occupation as a scribe, and involvement in the Music to Heal program have substantiated my dream of becoming a physician. This passion for the medical field, my yearning to provide high quality patient-care, and my philosophy of providing holistic care are the primary reasons for my endeavoring to be a physician. I want to be a part of changing the way a patient feels. I want to make a difference. I want to show patients that they are more than just objects, more than just cases, more than just a means of income—that they are humans cared for by other humans.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: When visiting a mental care facility in Paraguay as part of a medical mission trip in South America, each of us had a ‚Äúbuddy‚Äù to spend time with throughout the day. I spent my day with Denis, who was ecstatic to show me around the facility. By the end of the day, I became close to Denis, and he expressed to me how he loved that I actually listened to him. Denis taught me an important lesson that day; being a physician is more than just a career. Rather, it is an opportunity to build lasting connections with your patients, to be there for both physical and emotional support. Yet another crucial encounter occurred when serving a homeless community in Brazil. Hundreds of tents were set up surrounding a miniature church built from bricks and wooden sticks. Despite the lack of basic necessities, the community showed the epitome of kindness towards our group and each other. This taught me that especially when times are difficult, it is essential to remain comforting and compassionate.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
Through my experiences serving marginalized communities such as Skid Row, I have witnessed the lack of the inclusivity of health care due to poor socioeconomic status. As Skid Row is a predominantly Black community, I am given the opportunity to serve my community whilst understanding the needs of certain underserved populations. By preparing and distributing food and care packages while building connections with individuals of this population, I believe I contributed to a larger cause, one that focuses on the well-being of the less fortunate._x000D_
_x000D_
I truly believe that all physicians must truly grasp how such social determinants affect health. Each patient that I see as a physician will be cared for with an understanding of their racial and economic background. Recognizing and seeking to equalize the under-representation of minorities will be one of my primary focuses as a physician.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
COVID-19 especially impacted those who were economically disadvantaged, widening the gap between the rich and the poor. As the homeless population increased dramatically during this time, my primary goal was to venture out to homeless communities such as Skid Row in Los Angeles more frequently. The substantial increase in its population illustrated a novel perspective of the detrimental effects of the inequity of healthcare._x000D_
 _x000D_
COVID-19 was a time of uncertainty, worry, and change. It underlined aspects of our nation that are flawed, especially the minimal attention given to the disadvantaged. Taking initiative and seeking out alternatives during this time was essential. Most importantly, this pandemic taught me how unexpected medicine truly is; there is a plethora of science that is yet to be unfolded. As a physician, I must handle such situations of panic with collectiveness. Lastly, I will ensure that my future patients are all accounted for, regardless of economic background.

personal_statement:
Sitting in my recliner, working on homework late at night, my phone rings out in its shrill tone signaling a call from the hospital. Although still in my first year as a retractor holder, I am used to this from spending multiple nights on call. However, this time is different. The nurse tells me I must assist with an open craniotomy, a sophisticated surgery I had never seen, let alone assisted, in my time as a retractor holder. “Am I even allowed to do that?”, I inquire, “Where is the surgeon’s assistant?” She replies, “This is an emergency, so we have no other choice; she is in bed with the flu.” I am trembling the whole way to the hospital, my brain flooded with thoughts of doubt and the possibility of failure, but also how important it is that I maintain my composure. The time between my arrival and entering the sterile field felt as though it took seconds, and before I knew it, I found myself gazing upon a fellow human in dire need of this operation.
	I felt unprepared to take on such an immense responsibility, and the incident presented itself without warning. Taking on challenges has always been a place I excel, but in the operating room, I found myself being pushed further than I ever had before. This experience with the craniotomy, along with nearly four years of surgical experience, has solidified how much I enjoy stimulating tasks and thrive on conquering obstacles. I found that being presented with novel trials and having to acclimate quickly is something I revel in. Medicine, from what I have observed and experienced, is the ideal environment for such a challenge. Ultimately, when we overcome those tests, the patient’s quality of life can be improved. 
	Healthcare delivers trials to be overcome, and it offers endless opportunities to learn and expand knowledge. As I helped the surgeon operate on the patient’s brain during the late-night craniotomy, I was exposed to anatomy I had never seen. The pumping vessels, various layers of protection around the brain, the sections of the skull, the intricacies of the brain, both seen and unseen, and the complex techniques required to perform the operation all fascinated me. Over time, I have assisted and learned from countless surgeries, including exploratory laparotomies, laparoscopic gastric bypasses, early morning gunshot traumas, breast biopsies, spinal fusions, and various others. Every operation serves simultaneously as an opportunity to treat someone in need and increase my knowledge. In addition to working in surgery, my time shadowing taught me the importance of patient-physician relationships. I am intrigued by how each patient presents a one-of-a-kind personality that a physician must learn to navigate, utilizing the professional relationships with their peers to optimize a relationship with that patient. Something as simple as sitting at the level of the patient or neglecting to wear the white coat can make a world of difference in establishing rapport. That fascinates me. Due to these aspects, I have come to appreciate medicine as a practice. Not merely as a mastery of the human body or treatment, but as an exercise involving learning daily, dedicated to the betterment of others. 
	As we neared the end of the operation, the surgeon and I carefully resealed the patient’s skull, stapled the skin, and added fresh white dressings around the cranium. Enthralled with the intricacies experienced in my last couple of hours, and genuinely relieved as I had accomplished a task I previously believed to be beyond my skill set, I became filled with a unique feeling.
