Goosebumps trickled up each of my limbs, and I was nearly driven to tears. It is difficult to pinpoint exactly what I felt, somewhere between joy and satisfaction. What I do know, is I only feel this way after I have put someone else before myself. When I complete a surgery, or volunteer in local community service projects through my fraternity, I know I have helped improve someone’s quality of life. When I completed my Iron Phi accomplishment, raising money and awareness for ALS research, I knew I was helping to further an entity greater than myself. When I volunteer at Missouri Boy’s State, leading and counseling young men who will one day help build the future of their community, I give younger men tools to use in their upcoming endeavors. The fact that I have been fulfilled by the impact I have helped make on others in these smaller undertakings has pushed me to take on a higher responsibility as a physician, allowing me to play an even more direct role in serving others.
As the surgeon left the room, a quick “great job” functioned as his only recognition of my work that night. To me, though, those two words told me I am capable of being the man in his position. From the drive to the hospital, to the drive home, my confidence in my ability had flipped entirely. Although the operating room would be the last place I encountered the craniotomy patient, it was far from my last instance of caring for others. Despite the many challenges I have faced in surgery, school, and life as a whole, my desire to treat patients as a physician has failed to be extinguished. In fact, my various experiences since I decided to pursue healthcare have confirmed my aspirations as a lifetime calling.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: While counseling at Missouri Boys State, a camper under my supervision expressed feelings of homesickness and explained how he was struggling to find his purpose in the program. I was aware of his identity on the autism spectrum, as well as his residence in a low socioeconomic area, which deeply contrasted with my own community. By asking for advice from a senior counselor, actively listening, and utilizing therapeutic communication, I helped this camper discover his interest in law studies; at the end of the week, he had become one of the most involved and respected members of my group. This encounter illustrated how all humans hold potential and value, reinforcing my desire for making meaningful connections with people. I saw the importance of embracing differing ideologies, characteristics, or personalities as stimulants of societal growth. As a result, I am eager to field concerns from a diverse patient base and effectively work alongside unique colleagues as a physician.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I feel a unique sense of fulfillment that only results from selfless acts, which has motivated me to serve my community in various ways throughout college. One of my favorite projects came from my involvement on the Greek Week Steering Committee during my senior year, which coordinates the service aspects of every Greek organization on campus for a week. While on this committee, I positively impacted the community with multiple endeavors. First, I helped organize, promote, and facilitate a weekend blood drive, producing 300 units of blood for local hospitals. Next, I worked on a ‚ÄúPurple Walk‚Äù, which raises community awareness and education about domestic violence and proper sexual conduct. I then collected money for a ‚ÄúPenny War‚Äù which raised significant funds for local non-profit organizations. Lastly, I worked with my fellow committee members to organize a food/clothing drive, then worked to collect, count, and deliver the donated items to those in need.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The COVID-19 pandemic delayed my initial timeline for attending medical school by halting university research, inhibiting shadowing, and restricting my ability to participate in service projects. Significantly concerned with gaining meaningful experience before committing to medical education, I ultimately opted for a post-graduation application cycle. During this season of setbacks, though, I realized that I struggled with patience. As days went by and I felt stagnant in my endeavors, I reassessed the situation, honing my critical planning skills to recuperate seemingly lost progress. This involved taking advantage of the few opportunities that arose. Additionally, I provided meaningful patient care in the face of a public health crisis and prioritized my endurance. I am now more prepared to adapt to unexpected situations and appreciate delayed gratification. Further, the pandemic motivated me to foster patient trust in the healthcare system, especially through troubling times.

personal_statement:
While driving back from a 12-hour night shift at the hospital as a patient safety sitter, I decided that I am undoubtedly and wholeheartedly committed to becoming a physician. That night I had aided in the treatment of a postoperative young girl, who I’ll name Talia. Talia was born with a deformation to her face that was limiting her quality of life, and she also has autism. I became accustomed to communicating with Talia, who had screws tightened around her jaw, through body language. I became her voice to the physicians and nurses overnight in order to ensure her comfort and health. At about 5 a.m., the female physician and nurse came into the room to tighten the screws around Talia’s jaw. I expressed my thoughts on how Talia’s stuffed animals and sketch pad would best comfort her during an uncomfortable treatment operation. As a team, I comforted Talia with her toys as both the nurse and physician tightened the screws. The operation went as smoothly as possible, and I had never felt so empowered to be standing by two amazing women and a strong, young girl. It brought me great joy that night to have comforted this young girl enough to sleep for the first time in days, be her voice to the team, and collaborate with two amazing females. I realized the dynamic of that night was something that fed my purpose.
During my undergraduate years as a premed, my position at Children’s Healthcare of Atlanta (CHOA) as a patient safety sitter allowed me to best reflect my experience working with patients and staff in a healthcare setting. I was able to work closely on patient cases where the nervous system is altered due to disease, disorders, or trauma like schizophrenia, autism, bipolar disorder, etc. As I completed my studies in related fields of biology, chemistry, and neuroscience, I was actively working with patients who were suffering with deficits in these areas, including Talia. This experience allowed my knowledge and curiosity to prosper as I asked questions like what exact deficits are found within the patient's body and how do the prescribed treatments create a proposed fix for the patient’s case? As a patient safety sitter, I am unable to follow through with each patient’s journey and recovery. I am often asked to leave the room during important consultations. I had no final say in the treatment plan of my patients. These limitations reaffirmed my desire to become a physician because I constantly wished I could do more. I want to be a deciding factor in the patient's treatment, because I have the dedication to interpret the symptoms the patient is facing and find any possible solution for the underlying issue at hand.
My position also exposed me to the role of physician and how this role matches my character. As a physician, I will be able to direct the care around my patient, as I observed the physicians would both inform the nurses on next steps while listening to the nurse's opinion of the case. The initiative physicians take matches my tendency to act as a leader in every formal group situation I have been in, where I both guide my team to stay on track while also respecting their opinions and ideas. Physicians are able to personally watch patients progress and make the final decisions related to their treatments. This direct care fulfills my desire to see each patient to the end of treatment. Also of importance to note, my position as a patient safety sitter has opened my eyes to the impact of every employee within the hospital. Every position has an impact on the patient’s life, no matter how long or short their active care. As a physician, I will never be one to neglect the other caretakers that impacted the patient’s progress.
When COVID-19 hit globally and the world went on lockdown, I did not put a lockdown on my goal of becoming a physician and increasing my knowledge and experience to solidify this commitment. Instead, I took advantage of the extra time at home and reached out on volunteer sites, like Crisis Textline, and hospital jobs, like at CHOA. I knew that at this time these two organizations needed the most help, and I was brave and healthy enough to lend a hand. Simultaneously, I got the chance to experience and reflect on a potential lifestyle of hospital shifts, science courses, research, volunteering, and studying all at once. This would be very similar to the dynamic of a medical school student. I know that my life in medical school would fulfill my passion of learning and practicing medicine, being a helping hand, and collaborating with extraordinary peers and physicians. This particular experience with patients and coworkers at CHOA during a pandemic was challenging, but it solidified my interest in becoming a physician. 
As I continued gaining experiences in the healthcare field through shadowing, volunteering, and my clinical job, I not only learned why I want to be a physician but what kind of physician I am committed to becoming. I intend to become a physician that creates meaningful connections with my patients, dedicates extra time to find an explanation for each patient’s case, encourages patients’ to have a healthier lifestyle, fosters healthy relationships between my staff and team, and exacerbates all options for the health and benefit of my patient and/or team.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
I grew up spending school breaks in Damascus, Syria, until I was no longer able to visit due to the war. The different customs and beliefs created a divide in connection between myself and my family. One of the beliefs I distinguished in Syria was the fear and distrust of healthcare. I observed my grandmother trembling as she entered a clinic to receive a check up. I witnessed family members put off health check ups until their sickness progressed to an unbearable level. Though I questioned this behavior, I learned to respect their feelings and do my best to comfort them. I learned to communicate and connect with my family through conversations about society, healthcare, customs, etc. and form respect and understanding for opinions differing from mine. _x000D_
As a practicing physician, I intend to practice with caution and understanding and further educate others of the significance of background. I aim to represent doctors that can connect and form trust with patients like my grandmother.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As a camp counselor at Lifetime Athletic gym, I observed the unequal treatment towards female camp counselors. A female counselor would make the same exact mistake as a male counselor; however, the female would receive a strict warning and the male would not. After witnessing a situation like this, the female counselor would often not feel comfortable or safe enough to confront the supervisor about the differential treatment, so I took leadership in doing so. I questioned the supervisor whether equity was a value in this organization and that this scenario, along with a few others I had witnessed, does not make female employees feel safe. I further educated my supervisor on the importance of equity within the workplace. After my conversation with the supervisor, he expressed understanding and apologies. For my remaining time on the job, I did not witness further unequal treatment, so I believe I impacted at least my supervisor, if not the camp work environment as well.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
I was a freshman undergraduate when the pandemic caused a global quarantine. My planned opportunities for the summer, like research, shadowing, and volunteering, were put on standby. I saw my dad, a pulmonologist, go to work for countless hours and return home afraid to make contact with my family. I reflected on the cost of being a physician in times like these and how I could help._x000D_
I trained to become a crisis text line counselor, which was in high need due to the plummeting mental health of the American people. I began to shadow on virtual platforms. I began my research project under Dr. Perdue virtually. Finally, I applied for a healthcare job at a local hospital. In doing so, I experienced working through challenging times and aiding overwhelmed nurses with behavioral patients. _x000D_
Although the pandemic caused challenging circumstances for my path to medical school, it exposed me to another side of healthcare. I then learned to help others in ways I had not thought of before.

personal_statement:
My throat went dry as her words vibrated across the phone. Frozen in disbelief, I felt my heart sink to my stomach. "It's cancer." My mother’s words echoed into my ear. After two excruciating weeks, we finally received my mom's breast biopsy results confirming our worst fears. I stood quietly, remembering how just a year prior, my father had survived the complete blockage of an artery morbidly known as the “Widow-maker.” That day, nurses and hospital staff scrambled over my father while the physician directed the entire room. The doctor's swiftness, composure, and certainty in saving my father's life is the type of confidence my mother needed from those around her. Just as I had seen the doctors confront the beast in my father's artery, I found the strength to help my mother take on her own. She faced her illness with grace and courage and now lives cancer-free. My family’s relationship with several doctors over the years inspired my commitment to becoming a physician and treating patients’ illnesses, building connections, and aiding in confronting their beast. 

My love for medicine was cultivated from seeing my parents cured of their suffering, but my interest in healthcare began long before. Goosebumps covered my arms as I walked down the chilly street. Every home seemed indistinguishable from one another. We seldom traveled to my father’s childhood town in the outskirts of Bogota, Colombia, but the times we did struck me deeply. Tall brick buildings were now shuttered homes, and wide paved roads transformed into single dirt pathways. These changes arose a compelling curiosity in me about the inequalities of society.  I was ten years old when my father educated me that access to quality health care was scarce in his town and worsened the deeper you drove into the countryside. I recall children playing soccer on these dirt roads, and it stood out to me that most weren’t wearing shoes.  I struggled to fathom this notion as a child and was left with a feeling of utter helplessness. Growing up, I gathered that these disadvantages are common in Colombia and within my community back home. The trips to my father’s hometown catalyzed my yearning to relieve healthcare disparities in marginalized populations around the world.

Colombia continued to impact me years later. The lively streets full of food and vendors were just as I remembered. Marching towards our makeshift clinic, we digested our surroundings, and the reality of the slums had set in. At the clinic, dozens of families were shuffled into a small daycare room, waiting to be seen. That sobering moment quickly reminded us why we were on this mission. For the first time, my feelings of helplessness dissipated as patients began filtering in. A woman named “Ana” sat in front of me with her arms tightly wrapped around her chest. She gave me a worried stare. “What’s wrong?” I asked her in Spanish. She voiced her concerns about a small lump near her breast. Between tears, she explained her fears of breast cancer. My chest tightened as my mother flashed through my eyes. In hopes of easing her nerves, I told her about my mother’s fight and how strong she remained through it all. A look of hope swept Ana’s face. As our relationship grew, I was relieved she had received the medical care she deserved yet rarely encountered. Ana taught me the importance of human connection. I was eager to return home and eventually make the same connections within my community as a physician.

I opened a window to let the strong Florida rays shine in and uplift the atmosphere. Slurred and emotional words filled the room. Not wanting him to relive his traumatic experience, I listened to "Jon" intently. He was reserved and only told bits of his story. “It’s okay,” I said, reaching for his hand. I shared how crucial it was for the doctor to receive a detailed medical history. He finally revealed that a past stroke and subsequent depression had disabled him from working and now seeks a doctor's evaluation. I came across patients displaced from jobs due to limited resources, and I discovered that most didn’t have health insurance. I felt their lack of healthcare literacy did them a disservice. Like Jon, most struggled to deliver their history, and the best approach was to help them feel comfortable and confide in me. Working closely with patients deepened my desire to become a physician and a pillar of support whenever needed. 

I often think back to my time as a little girl standing in a small Colombian town, disillusioned by the inequalities of the health care system. I would reassure her that there was a way to defy the odds that stood before her innocent eyes. From helping Ana in Colombia to consoling Jon in his difficult times, I found the confidence to continue walking the path of medicine. I hope to be granted the opportunity to practice as a physician in local communities and provide healthcare to those in need. There is courage to be gained when becoming the shoulder to lean on for a loved one suffering an illness and compassion to give when standing by a frightened patient. I seek to take the courage and compassion that have developed over my life’s experiences and become a physician who is a beacon of light for patients during their darkest hours.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: A blank stare peered back at me after introducing myself. ‚ÄúEspa√±ol?‚Äù I asked when it dawned on me that Lia spoke no English. She nodded with relief. Thankful that my parents pushed me to speak our native language growing up, I wrote down her medical history. I was happy to communicate with Lia and contribute to her feeling welcomed at the office. Working as a medical assistant in Miami, I came across patients from all walks of life. Over time, I found myself illuminating friends and family about the towns in Brazil Gigi urged me to visit, or the infamous ‚Äúhead wobble‚Äù Devon mentioned his Indian culture uses to communicate. Communication was just the beginning in gaining respect and trust from the patient. As they found comfort in talking with me, I grasped their concerns better to relay to the physician. Being exposed to the vast array of cultures in Miami not only enriched my mind but granted me insight into patients and their needs by understanding their individual journeys.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As I listened to patients who sought care from our make-shift clinic in rural Colombia, I quickly realized a commonality amongst the population; many were aware of their high blood pressure or glucose levels but lacked the resources to address these concerns. I observed the positive effect a physician can make by providing quality medical care and the necessary resources, like vitamins and medication, to address the community‚Äôs needs. What truly stuck with me was the valiant stories of the families at the clinic. Even in the face of hardship, the community seemed to find happiness and celebrate each moment. I am humbled to have helped bring attention to these areas and hope they felt supported the way I felt inspired by their stories. This mission trip deepened my aspirations to become a physician and provide equal care to communities back home. If accepted to Rush Medical College, I hope to participate in the mission to elevate neighborhoods on the west side of Chicago.
7_-_COVID_Impact: A few weeks prior to the pandemic, I was planning a mission trip, studying for midterms, and excited to begin research. All these endeavors were quickly put aside when my focus shifted to protecting those around me. I was overwhelmed with constant fear for my parents‚Äô safety, and leaving the house for groceries felt like a risk. The pandemic made me realize my decisions can unwillingly affect my loved ones. I watched in awe at the world coming together to help one another. Observing the benevolence and power of community inspired me to turn towards my own for help. I strapped on my mask and knocked on doors where familiar and unfamiliar faces greeted me. It was a pleasant surprise to encounter people willing to gather supplies for at-risk families. Although my goals for the year were postponed, I‚Äôm grateful for the time spent around my family and community. There is value in the unity I created with my community, and hope to do the same with my fellow medical students.

personal_statement:
I breathed in the crisp, early spring air trying to ignore the knot in my belly. Dozens of eyes and several cameras were turned on me. Just a week before, I had received news that half of my immediate family had been shot and killed. It was my turn to speak now at the rally I had organized and call for action. From my years of research and service, I knew how a single narrative could embolden others to ask for help and illuminate gaps in equity. Yet, I never imagined that my own narrative could be used to fight the public health issue of gun violence. 
My first realization of the power of narrative occurred during my college pre-orientation program, Chicago Bound. We completed meaningful service projects at churches and community gardens, yet the experience I remember the most vividly is our trip to a community center. As my cohort and I sat hip-to-hip on the floor, an ex-gang member confided his personal story about becoming entangled in a gang. He was now a mentor, who helped dozens of young men navigate the dangerous process of leaving gangs. Hearing him speak, I was inspired to also one day use my narrative to impact my community, but I did not yet have my platform or my voice.
During my freshman year, I began to fall behind academically. I was struggling with the adjustment to college, and my pre-health advisor suggested that my grades would preclude me from medicine. However, I regained confidence in myself when I began to study psychology. My college was surrounded by neighborhoods with high community violence, and I became curious about how it impacted child development. While completing my honors thesis on the cognitive effects of community violence, I spent hours interviewing adolescents about their harrowing experiences. Many of those with high violence exposure were children of color. Some of them had experienced violent robberies and heard gunshots before they went to bed each night. Due to our shared racial background, they felt they could open up to me without stigma. Without someone involved in the research process that looked like them, they may have never felt comfortable enough to open up. This was my first experience with the importance of representation in a research setting. 
Yet, my passion for medicine was not solidified until I was a research assistant at the Nutrition and Pregnancy Study, a study that explored disparities in birthing outcomes. My participants were pregnant Black women who came into our study weary of the research process. As a Black woman, I understood personally the harsh history of discrimination in research. Participants felt comfortable enough with me to have an open dialogue that strengthened their trust in research, and the medical process and created an extra layer of support during their pregnancy. One participant, Sarah, saw me as an ally and requested that I attend her ob-gyn visits with her. During her visits, I noticed that Sarah became uneasy. Despite their ability to work together and communicate, there was still an element of distance between Sarah and her physician. It was then I realized the parallel between my participants in the community violence study and Sarah. I wanted to be the type of physician they needed- one with strong clinical skills who was also able to serve those that feel disconnected from the healthcare system due to their racial and cultural background.
Yet, my story was still unfolding. Two months before the end of my post-bacc program, I received news that my sister, niece, and nephew were taken away by her husband in a triple murder-suicide. Heartbroken and emboldened, my mother and I organized “Rally 4 Rosey,” a rally that brought together activists, survivors, and loved ones to discuss domestic violence. My relatives asked me to speak as a representative for our family. Although I was frightened, I called for action, using my personal story to address the need for policy and social change. Tied with my passion for medicine, I now knew how to use my story and had a platform to affect change.
I decided to take an extra year before applying to medical school to heal. I chose to spend my extra year working for the American Medical Women’s Association. During my time at AMWA, I joined Gun Violence Solutions. We provided educational programming to trainees and physicians on how to address gun safety with patients and assess firearm risk. It was fascinating to hear the concerns of practicing physicians and to participate in the open dialogue about how medicine can improve to address the needs of patients with high exposure to violence. 
My experiences have taught me the importance of my narrative. Using my voice, I will work to improve educational training in medical settings surrounding counseling patients for firearm risk, as well as advocate for policies that reduce the amount of firearm-related injuries and deaths. Further, I will use my own narrative to connect with future patients who have had exposure to violence and suffer from the health consequences of exposure. Representation in medicine is important, not just cultural and racial representation, but also representation of life experiences. Although my path has been difficult, it has imbued me with my voice and emboldened my passion for medicine.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
During my time on the GlobeMed E-Board, I served with a group of students who were diverse in cultural background and in experiences. Our mission was to form long-term partnerships with grassroots organizations outside of the US, and our partner organization was in Malawi. This required cultural sensitivity and respect for the values and priorities of the Chikwawan community. When strategizing on program implementation, such as the HIV-Awareness program, our chapter had to learn how to advocate awareness for a stigmatized topic in another community._x000D_
Our diverse E-Board included first-generation Chinese immigrants, a native Chicagoan from an under-resourced Latin community, and a child raised in a military family. Due to our different cultural backgrounds, we had conflicting ideas about how to approach forming a relationship with a new community. By first bridging our own cultural barriers, we were better able to collaborate with our partner In Malawi._x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
During the Nutrition and Pregnancy Study, my team and I supported low-income women in Chicago over the course of their pregnancies. _x000D_
 At the beginning of the study, my participants confided in me about their distrust of the research process due to historical incidents of medical racism. As a black woman, I understood their perspective. I validated their unease but also stressed the importance of research that reduced health disparities in the black community. Through open dialogue, I was able to improve their comfort with the research process. _x000D_
During the study, we also connected those with severe depression to community mental health services and those who experienced food insecurity to social workers. _x000D_
Although a good number of our participants experienced pregnancy complications, their rate of pregnancy complications was lower than the general rate for Black women. We hypothesized that this was due to the consistent support that we gave our participants during their pregnancies. _x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact: The pandemic saw an increase in fatalities due to violence. Unfortunately, my family members were included in these fatalities. In 2021, my sister, niece, and nephew were fatally shot during a domestic violence incident. I decided to delay my application cycle by a year to heal and grieve. During this time, I began a remote position at the American Medical Women‚Äôs Association, where I help women in medicine in various stages of their professional journey.

Hrdshp_Comments: As a first generation student growing up in generational poverty and an unstable household, I lacked the exposure and support to pursue medicine. My dad was an emotionally scarred war refugee that projected his trauma through violence, so I learned to become a conflict mediator at a young age. My mom, forced to abandon her education to raise me when she was 17, worked 16 hours a day and was unable to provide guidance. After immigrating to America in 2019, I was further tasked with the role of a translator while having to adjust and learn English. When my dad passed away, the family from his side forced us to leave our home, causing us to become homeless. It was an experience fraught with abuse, yet one that inspired me to take on my dad’s role to take care of my mom and younger sister. Ever since then, we have moved between multiple places while marginally surviving on government assistance. I have always worked multiple jobs while taking classes to pay for rent and to send money to Vietnam for my grandmother’s medical treatment. When I moved to Philadelphia to pursue medicine, I had to seek shelter at the library due to my unsafe living condition. However, the adversities I overcame have taught me to embrace my unique identities and nurtured my ambition to connect the human experience with medicine.
personal_statement:
It all began the night my mom held my dad in her arms, begging him to not give up on himself. That night, my dad impaled himself in the stomach as a desperate call for help after struggling with depression in silence for years. In a panic, my uncle attempted to treat his wound, while my grandmother, traumatized by her past experience witnessing suicide, delayed calling the paramedics. By the time we reached the ER, my dad was pronounced dead. I was devastated and bewildered. In a rushed tone, the physician explained my dad’s cause of death with words littered with medical jargon I could not understand. When he hastily left to attend to other patients, I remained feeling alone, utterly helpless, and unable to find my voice. That night I witnessed firsthand the cultural and linguistic barriers that prevented inclusive care for my family. Since then, I have deeply contemplated the role of a physician in advocacy for patients’ health and pondered the idea of culturally appropriate care. In my last moments with my dad, I promised him that I would strive to uplift the voices of those who are overlooked so that they would not be left in the dark like our family was.

To fulfill my promise, I devoted my undergraduate career to community advocacy. I discovered my passion for community outreach when I joined bridges Multicultural Resource Center at UC Berkeley, where I helped to mobilize resources for organizations serving students from historically disenfranchised backgrounds. By creating inclusive space for cultural engagement and professional support, I facilitated effective cross-cultural discourses and elevated the voices of underrepresented students on campus. During this time, the micro-aggressions reported by students of color accumulated. Their frustration reminded me of the helplessness I experienced being left behind at the ER. It was then that I began to wonder about advocacy in medicine, and this curiosity ignited a spark in me to utilize my experience as a community organizer to tackle inequities in healthcare.
 
My curiosity for advocacy in healthcare led me to pursue the REACH Internship at Asian Health Services (AHS), where I gradually recognized the correlation of patients missing appointments and the declining state of their health. Determined to tackle this issue, I advocated for the implementation of the Companion Care Program (CCP) and consequently served as the Program Coordinator to provide assistance and connect patients for long-term companionship. One of my patients was Mrs. Y., a refugee who confided in me her experience of discrimination that prevented her from seeking diabetes treatment. Her story reminded me of my grandmother, whose fears of the stigma around suicide prevented her from seeking immediate treatment for my dad. As I spent the rest of the year supporting Mrs. Y., I was able to leverage my community advocacy experiences to assist her in navigating the healthcare system. Seeing Mrs. Y.’s health improve as a result of support from CCP affirmed that my passion lies in providing direct care for vulnerable populations. Moving forward, my aim is to be a physician that instills cultural humility and compassion in my practice to make tangible impacts on patients’ wellbeing.
 
I realized that health encompasses more than medical support after my time working at AHS and it brought me back to my outreach trip to Compton High School in second year of college. During this trip, I met J., a student who suffered from multiple physical and mental disorders. He left me a crumbled paper at the end of a school-to-prison pipeline self-reflection exercise that crushed my soul: “All dead. Where to go from here?” I later learned that no one extended their hands to him. Everyone assumed that J.’s situation was ordinary amongst children growing up in Compton, reducing his experience to a statistic and stereotype. Desperate to support him, I worked with J. to undertake medical treatment. Though J. noticed improvement after meeting with the primary care physician, I know that his best health outcomes will only be achieved once the systematic issues that prevented him from seeking treatments are addressed. Looking back, I learned that effective patient-care needs to go beyond providing bandage solutions. I became determined to not just be a physician, but to be one who is aware of the unique needs of my patients inside and outside of clinical settings to promote wellness through preventative care, education, and advocacy.
 
As a clinician, I will strive to cultivate meaningful relationships with my patients to empower them to recognize their own voice, and to break down societal barriers so future generations can dare to dream. Above all, I hope to integrate my passion for community activism with the medical degree to be a primary care physician that serves the most vulnerable populations: the overlooked, resource-denied, and marginalized. The journey that started from a promise to my dad has given me the conviction to engage in the life-long learning process with patient advocacy at the forefront of my efforts. No matter how rigorous the pursuit of these goals may be, I am deeply encouraged by the path that lies ahead and am sincerely devoted to the practice of culturally affirming medicine.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Healthcare disparity stemming from systemic barriers is a devastating issue for Native American communities. I learned of this injustice after meeting Mr. B, a Navajo Nation resident who lost his wife due to the lack of medical support during the pandemic. He believes that the healthcare system does not stand with marginalized populations. His words prompted me to reflect on my privilege. Moreover, I became determined to value the unique needs of marginalized populations and to make an upstream impact to eliminate provider shortage in tribal areas. I am currently working toward this goal as HEAL Initiative Policy Research Specialist. In this role, I draft legislative proposals, organize meetings with congressmen, and build a coalition of academic centers advocating for Indigenous rights. As a physician, I will continue to mobilize for the advancement of the rural/ tribal healthcare workforce, build public health power and advance the right to health through political activism
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Throughout my undergraduate career, I worked as a BUILD Mentor, where I tutored K-12 students of color in Oakland, CA. A student who I mentored was E, who was living in chronic poverty and violence. This is an experience that I am all too familiar with. I wanted to make sure that E. could still enjoy being a kid, so I actively provided emotional support for him in addition to tutoring. We would discuss school, his dream, and how to get to where he wanted to go in life. Now, E. is looking forward to becoming a first-generation college student. By going the extra mile to support E., I broke down the educational barrier and provided him with the foundation to pursue this dream. At the same time, I gained from E. the relentless spirit and an unwavering conviction to not yield to injustices. At Rush Medical College, I strive to share my passion for educational equity with my fellow medical students and connect with Chicago‚Äôs diverse communities in an informed and culturally sensitive way.
7_-_COVID_Impact: COVID-19 has caused my parents and me to lose our jobs. I had also secured a research position, but the pandemic caused all the laboratories to shut down, leaving me unable to start my research. I could not afford my rent and had to relocate back to California. Consequently, I began working multiple jobs to help my parents pay the bills. Having to relocate within a short amount of time and trying to fulfill my obligations was burdensome. However, I continued to work diligently, while serving as my parents' caretaker, and sister's tutor. Additionally, being able to work on the frontline during the pandemic has confirmed my desire to improve patients‚Äô health through medicine and advocacy. Navigating through COVID-19 and serving the community through the pandemic have provided me with a profound foundation for humility and advocacy. At Rush, I am confident that I will be able to thrive above challenges by utilizing the skill sets and awareness that I have gained through this experience.

personal_statement:
As a child, I never thought much about my older brother’s condition; however, my sentiments changed after the introduction of DNA in my 7th grade science class. How could something as simple as an additional chromosome create the condition that perplexed my family so much? Curious to learn more, I started conversations with my mother about what it was like to have a baby with Down Syndrome. She often reacted with silence, and I had to wait patiently for her to be ready to speak. Her demeanor would change as she described her initial denial and feeling of hopelessness. As disabilities were not openly discussed within our Asian culture, the diagnosis was completely foreign to her. Due to my parents’ upbringing, they feared how their families would react. I knew she felt discouraged to have these discussions, but I wished someone told her it was okay to do so earlier. My conversations with my mother about this difficult topic helped break her stigma around disabilities and strengthened the relationship within our household. In many cultures, family bonds are strong, but communicating about stigmatized health topics keeps families from growing and healing.  I want to be a bridge between people and their well-being by addressing stigmatized issues and social determinants of health through compassionate, culturally appropriate medical care.
In order to be a successful facilitator towards patients, I realized that one needs to communicate the science of medicine in a way that is accessible to the public. While scribing at California Eye Surgeons, I met a patient who was inconsistently taking his drops for glaucoma. As Dr. Kaur spoke to him, I realized he had not fully grasped the severity of his condition. She explained how the disease causes irreversible blindness and how early signs are often undetectable to the patient. Most of all, she emphasized how the eyes help us navigate the world, and without his medication, he will eventually lose the ability to drive, read his newspapers, and do the things he loves to do. After Dr. Kaur left the room, I stayed with the patient to ensure he fully understood the treatment plan. I explained how glaucoma was caused by elevated eye pressure and how the medications the physician prescribed for him would help extend his quality of life. He reacted with furrowed eyebrows, finally understanding the reality of his condition. Spending time with Dr. Kaur showed me that the physician must balance treating the pathophysiology of disease with interacting and caring for people. Seeing how many patients have different social and educational backgrounds, I aspire to become the physician that provides relevant patient education and encourages important lifestyle changes while being the facilitator between the science and humanity of medicine.
While my goal in becoming a physician is to serve as a bridge between patients and healthcare, I learned that different language barriers can create hurdles while trying to provide care. When I was volunteering at a COVID-19 vaccination site, I noticed an anxious woman standing at the check-in table with her ID shaking in her hands and her eyes darting around as if looking for someone. When I heard her speak Mandarin, I rushed over to help interpret. Her stress and fear markedly diminished; as she heard me speak her native language, her expression softened, and she let out a sigh of relief. After checking in, I shared her worries about the vaccine with the on-site physician, and I interpreted to the patient that given her medical history, the chance of an adverse reaction was low. I made sure to stay with her throughout her entire process, and she expressed how lost she would have been without anyone being able to help her communicate.  The encounter reminded me of language’s power to build a sense of trust and relief, especially when approaching sensitive topics that patients may be hesitant to discuss. Being able to speak Mandarin fluently and continuing to build upon my Spanish, I hope to reduce some of the barriers that my future patients will face when accessing healthcare with me. 
While I initially became a software engineer due to the lure of job security, I quickly felt unfulfilled from the lack of contact with those who would be affected by my work.  My medical experiences filled what I felt was missing and gave me a newfound passion to address social challenges in healthcare. Becoming a physician allows me to utilize logical thinking and problem solving, aspects of computer science that I enjoyed, to apply the science of medicine to diagnoses and treatments. Along with scientific reasoning, I want to provide culturally appropriate care for various marginalized groups and volunteer for those who may not have the resources. I look forward to becoming a physician who can combine both compassion and logical thinking in assessing cultural discrepancies in healthcare, providing more ease to families like my own.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
During the Black Lives Matter movement in 2020, people brought up issues surrounding the dance scene. While the dance I was involved in was called ‚ÄúUrban Dance‚Äù, it was brought up that ‚ÄúUrban‚Äù was a derogatory term used against Black and Brown communities. As the style stems from street styles originating from Black cultural forms, I felt that I failed as a director of my team for not teaching its rooted origins. I attended speaker events, learning how Black dance forms gave a space of expression for marginalized voices. Through these resources, I helped create policies requiring leaders to teach the importance of its cultural context. _x000D_
_x000D_
I learned how it is important to not only understand, but also to be proactive in learning from different backgrounds. I observed how words carry a lot of weight, and I have become aware of my word choice when speaking to patients. With culturally competent care, I will continue to take actionable steps to provide the best care as a future physician.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
During November 2020, I arrived for my shift at my local food pantry and was shocked at the number of clients lined up. I rushed to load grocery carts, found use of my Mandarin skills to assist clients who could not speak English well, and handed bags of prepared meals for homeless clients. At the end of my shift, I realized I had helped about 50 clients during a pandemic. The impact I felt in what I was doing gave me a vigor and passion to continue helping the underserved._x000D_
_x000D_
Some clients I see currently are the same ones I saw from my first shift, and we have established a relationship that continues on conversations from previous weeks. I save specific foods for clients I remember with food allergies, providing what they need with their food limitations. Volunteering in my community has not only provided healthy food options and hygiene kits to lower income and homeless clients; I also helped provide a mental break from stressors in their lives through having cheerful conversations.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
I was laid off from my full-time software job a month before the pandemic started. The lack of job opportunities put a pause on my job search, and I spent the break thinking about my future career path. I recalled how I struggled to picture myself continuing as an engineer and decided to pursue a career that gave me a stronger purpose. _x000D_
_x000D_
I moved back home to save money and made a part-time income by taking care of my brother with disabilities. It was difficult to find medical opportunities, so I volunteered at a food pantry and a vaccine site. After applying to many job positions, I was hired as a medical assistant and scribe, and because I was turned down by most physicians due to COVID-19 concerns, I utilized online resources to shadow. _x000D_
_x000D_
The pandemic matured me into a better person and put more perspective on how much I wanted to help those who may not share the same resources as me. With growth, I stepped away from engineering and committed to the path of becoming a physician.

personal_statement:
They say, “dog is man’s best friend.” Whether you agree with this cliché, it poses a rather disputed question: What is man’s worst enemy? In my opinion, man’s worst enemy is disease. We’ve seen it all around us these past couple of years, and man had to make a choice: sit on the sidelines or combat its worst enemy. Over the past couple of years, I was able to combat disease, or at least contribute to the effort. From these experiences, I gained a greater passion for science and healing, both of which I plan to utilize for the rest of my career. 
I have always known I wanted to work in the healthcare field, but it wasn't until the COVID-19 pandemic that I knew why. I spent the first few months of the pandemic doing the same as many others: waiting for something to happen. But as someone who always needs to find the solution to a problem, I was itching to help. That opportunity came in the fall of 2020 when my supervisor asked me to run COVID-19 tests. She cautioned me against the opportunity and emphasized my risk of being exposed if I decided to help. However, for months I had been sitting on the sidelines watching others sacrifice their health for others, and I was ready to do the same. 
Weeks into testing, my heart still skipped a beat every time the machine read back positive. For a split second, it seemed like the world stopped, and for someone, it would stop, for the next 14 days at least. I would quietly and calmly walk over to Kristie, our nurse, who delivered the bad news. Then, I would sit back down and keep running the machines, because the pandemic wasn't going anywhere, and hundreds of people were lined up to be tested. There was a disease, and as far as I knew, I was part of the remedy. To me, this was a glimpse of what my future could be like. 
The sense of purpose I gained from running COVID-19 tests quickly plummeted when I was sent home for winter break and could no longer help at school. However, I sought out another opportunity when I applied to volunteer at a local hospital. On the first day of orientation, I was handed a purple lab coat that distinguished volunteers from employees, and whenever I walked to the GI lab for my shift, at least one person told me they were ecstatic to see a purple coat again. That day, I was introduced to a physician who warned me to go home because "1 in 12 people here is carrying the disease." Still, this wasn't enough to turn me away from the once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to work in a hospital during a pandemic. Sitting with patients so they could see a friendly face in recovery, then wheeling them out to their loved ones were moments that I felt certain of my purpose. This was what I wanted to do for the rest of my life: see a disease, find its remedy, and watch healthy patients go back to their families and live their lives. 
As positive as my experience in the hospital was during the winter of 2020, I know that the reality of being in the healthcare field isn't always so: there is not always a cure for every disease. In just one year, the entire world experienced the grief of millions of lives lost to an incurable virus, yet hundreds of other diseases torment our population every day, such as cancer. While I could not specifically cure cancer, during the summer of 2021, I was given the opportunity to conduct research for multi-cancer screening products. This opportunity gave me a new insight into the concept of disease, that there is more than one remedy: treatment and prevention. Ironically enough, not long after my time spent researching and developing cancer screening products, my uncle passed away from colon cancer that could have been prevented if he had just gotten screened. This happened just a few months after I spent my entire summer working to develop a screening product to save lives. However, I plan to use my uncle’s memory as well as my time in research to emphasize the importance of prevention and screening when working in the future to combat disease. 
One of the primary goals of any good physician is to see disease and find its remedy, and if not possible, do everything in their power to try. During the COVID-19 pandemic, I saw the disease and though I did not literally find its remedy, I tried to help in any way possible. I had experiences on both ends of combating disease: prevention and treatment. Just as I did in those situations, I want to dedicate the rest of my life to seeing disease and finding its remedy. Following the theme of prevention versus treatment, I will be spending my gap year earning my Master’s degree in Population Health Sciences, which will allow me to combine preventative measures of community health, as well as treatment in the clinical setting. This experience as well as all the other opportunities I have been given during my college career will allow me to become a well-rounded physician who combines prevention and treatment in the field of medicine. The empathy, selflessness, and dedication to health and medicine I saw from the doctors, nurses, researchers, and epidemiologists during the COVID-19 pandemic are all qualities I strive to possess. With these qualities, I hope to spend my career combating “man’s worst enemy,” and I would love to start that journey by being admitted to your program.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: During my undergraduate years, I minored in Spanish, which gave me many opportunities and insights into different cultures within the United States, specifically in the state of Alabama. One experience that contributed to my readiness for practicing medicine in a multicultural society was when I volunteered as an interpreter for Hispanic patients at a clinic. I interacted with Spanish-speaking patients who utilized the free clinic or the Medicaid office, a demographic that was new to me. I worked under an OBGYN and communicated to patients many milestones: confirmed pregnancy, due date, and sex of the baby. I saw some of the most vulnerable people in healthcare and gained insight into the needs of patients in the US while appreciating relationships with people from different backgrounds than my own. Working with a different demographic helped me see how race and socioeconomic factors affect health, and what work needs to be done to close the healthcare gap.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
_x000D_
Beginning the fall of 2020 when normal operations were suspended, I was asked to help administer COVID-19 tests to students, faculty, and staff. I worked up to twenty hours a week, sometimes 9 hours a day, running SOFIA rapid test machines and helping test hundreds of people. This role was very important in helping slow the spread of COVID-19 on campus. The most important skill I gained from this experience was adaptability because I had to work around my class schedule in order to be an extra set of hands to make sure the Tuscaloosa community stayed healthy. By the time I finished testing community members in the spring of 2021, I helped administer over 1000 tests, and I felt that there had to be at least one person in the community who was a little healthier because of me. Something I learned about myself from this is that I can't sit on the sidelines during times of crisis; I want to be involved in the healing process. I plan to transfer that mindset to becoming a physician._x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact: When COVID-19 hit, I was taking my hardest undergraduate class online, at home, and alone, and I was not handling it well. I sought professional help to cope with my anxiety, which had been growing my whole life, but was magnified during the pandemic. I began going to therapy and starting medication to help with my anxiety, which allowed me to focus better when studying and succeed academically. Since the beginning of the pandemic, I started to see an upward trend in my academic performance as well as professional growth opportunities. Because of the opportunities, I was given to help the community during the pandemic, I became much more passionate about the field of medicine. I spent much of the pandemic contributing to the medical community by working as a COVID-19 test technician and volunteering in various clinical settings, including a hospital GI lab and a free clinic. During the pandemic, I acknowledged my mental health and improved it to allow for more opportunities.

Hrdshp_Comments:
Being a first-generation college student of color at a predominantly white institution sparks plenty of confusion, culture shock, and emotion. I felt as though I had entered college lacking the academic and practical knowledge necessary in order to be successful in higher education. Having been unfamiliar with the rigor and expectations of the college curriculum and having less exposure to the college-going culture resulted in this difficulty in assimilating into the college setting academically and socially. 

Alongside being a first-generation college student, due to my single mother’s limited income, I had to take on three jobs my freshman year.  Initially, I struggled with maintaining my hectic work schedule, classes, and extracurriculars. However, this work helped me pay for living and college expenses i.e., books, tuition, and a meal plan. My course grades were not as high as I wanted them to be and I struggled significantly during my freshman/sophomore year. Given the circumstances, I am still proud of myself for overcoming these social and financial obstacles to achieve the honor of being the first in my immediate family to attend college.
personal_statement:
Clad in black Danner GTX steel-toed boots and bulky orange medical kits, my partner and I sprinted into the “living” room. Empty oxygen tanks, expired prescription bottles, and soiled furniture packed the space intended for social activities. At the end of a long hallway, a grieving woman enveloped a motionless man. After delivering several rounds of chest compressions to the man, I checked his pulse. The paramedic called the time of death. While I comforted the woman, I thought about all the possible scenarios that could have led to this moment. I thought about whether there was anything more my partner and I could have done to save my patient’s life. Though being an EMT in Holyoke, MA is challenging and demanding, I am committed to saving people’s lives and serving my community. 

Emotionally and physically drained, my partner and I returned to base to perpetuate the cycle. I brushed my teeth, made my cot, and rested my head on my pillow. Then, I reflected on my first bad day as an EMT: four patients died, an eighteen-month-old was transported to the ER, a twenty-two-year-old attempted suicide. Flowing down my face were tears that had welled up from deep within. The radio sounded, “medic 1, medic 1, please respond to. . . .” Blinded by my tears, I struggled to slide my feet into my heavy boots as I headed to the truck. The truck—a twenty-by-eight-foot box—was a sanctuary that induced me to take care of my own needs. The truck shielded my humanity from the gravity of the world around me and helped me unpack the emotional and physical trauma I witnessed each time I entered that world. The truck is where my partner and I confided in and comforted each other; where we debriefed about our patient interactions and where we prepped for incoming calls. In essence, the twenty-by-eight-foot box healed me like it was aware that my energy was consumed by those I cared for inside of itself and in the field. My days were long and exhausting, yet I persisted through difficult situations, so I could treat my patients. These difficult situations are what have contributed to my growth as a human being, an EMT, and a future physician.

One difficult situation I experienced in Holyoke was a language barrier in a primarily Spanish-speaking community. This language barrier hindered my ability to provide quality patient care in the field. After coming to this realization, I taught myself basic Spanish words and phrases. To deepen my knowledge of Spanish, I downloaded an easily accessible translation application, Speak and Translate, on my iPhone. Visual communication methods such as hand gestures and facial expressions also helped me bridge this substantial language barrier. I am by no means fluent in Spanish, but it was fulfilling to see the relief on my patient's faces when I ask: “¿Dónde está tu dolor?” I found that adapting to my environment was both advantageous for my patients and myself. Linguistically immersing myself in a community I frequently entered empowered me to better localize the source of my patient's problems and to build rapport with community members. My commitment to serving those in my community became more than just a passion; it became a responsibility. 

To provide compassionate and quality care, I had to recognize what it means to be human. To be human is to be whole. I had to ensure myself that I was someone who possessed feelings, emotions, and a sense of logic and someone who could both connect with and disconnect from patients. Recognizing my own humanity created a space for me to treat patients for who they were and not merely for what they had, thus treating not just their ailing bodies but also their ailing spirits. As time went on, I learned to become comfortable with the unfamiliar and to accept adversity. Every call, every story, and every problem was different. However, the manner in which I relieved their pain, stopped their bleeding, and helped them grieve was similar. Additionally, I learned to appreciate the importance of empathy. Empathy is the characteristic of humanity that resists the entropy and disorder of the world around it. Mediating the bad and fostering the good, empathy strives to deliver compassion all while accepting that the world will need help – I being the one who can help it. Making patients and their loved ones feel cared for, developing strong relationships with community members, and treating them like my own family are how I have and hope to continue to humanize medicine.

The study of medicine is a life-long commitment and one that I am eager to make. To gain the autonomy to diagnose, treat, and heal those who have not been able to heal themselves all while working in a career that is continually evolving and intellectually stimulating. Having said this, my experiences thus far have not deterred me away from pursuing medicine, but they have instilled in me a sense of enthusiasm for what is to come. This past year only confirms this – my passion for medicine regardless of the roadblocks I’ve faced in the process. To help and to heal, but most importantly, to recognize that studying medicine is a privilege and I promise to devote my time to both the study of science and caring for my patients.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Having served as an EMT in Holyoke, with a largely Hispanic population, it was a wake-up call to interact with a community whose first or native language was not English‚Äîa constant I have had in my education and upbringing. Aside from uncovering my own unconscious biases related to equitable care, working with this population enabled me to take tangible steps towards breaking down these barriers through learning universal hand gestures, simple medical phrases in Spanish, and the cultural relevancy and importance of the family unit. These steps provided me with positive experiences and yielded compassion and inclusivity from myself and my peers allowing us to better serve our community. Serving communities during their most vulnerable moments not only sheds light on the value of effective communication, but the value of cultural competence. Holyoke provided insight into different cultures, the adversities these populations may face, and how I, as a provider can be socially accountable.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As someone who grew up in an economically disadvantaged and medically underserved community, I‚Äôve had a passion for addressing the social determinants of health as an individual and prospective medical student. The last two years alone have revealed the significant disparities associated with health inequity and the urgent need for proactive advocacy to address these issues. From serving meals on the weekends and laundry services during the week to orchestrating vaccination clinics during the pandemic and assisting with staffing shortages at shelters on cold winter nights - I have been at the forefront. I not only serve these communities, but I am also a part of these communities - being their voice and addressing their needs as if they were mine.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
What I thought would be a temporary fight against a harmful disease, turned out to be a two-year battle leaving the world in a debilitating condition. My mother, who is immunocompromised, had lost her job as a bank teller at the start of the pandemic. It was up to me, her daughter, to help support her financially. At just twenty-two years old, I was a full-time student, working 60+ hours a week as an EMT. Working as an EMT during the pandemic opened my eyes to the broken healthcare system we had, but more importantly, revealed to me the crucial roles that healthcare providers play in the overall health of the world. _x000D_
_x000D_
Alongside my second semester of my senior year being held completely remote and working 60+ hours a week, many volunteer opportunities were suspended between February 2020-February 2021. Although the COVID-19 pandemic adversely impacted my life in more ways than one, it has inspired me to continue pursuing a career in medicine.

Major_Long_Desc: Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies; Law and Society
personal_statement:
Tom limped into the syringe service program (SSP). The twinge at the edge of his mouth told me his leg hadn’t healed. I poured him a cup of coffee with a heap of sugar and walked him back to the lab. I sat on the floor staring into what can only be described as a hole in Tom’s leg. It had signs of cellulitis with swelling and redness present. I looked up at Tom and once again found myself saying, “I’m not a doctor Tom, but I think it’s time to go see one.” His face sank. He said that he didn’t want to go in, that the last time emergency department providers had been unkind. He gave a heavy sigh and told me that he wasn’t going in yet, it wasn’t bad enough. At that moment I knew I never wanted to hear those words again. I wanted to be the doctor so that Tom wouldn't have to wait for things to get worse before accessing care.
It took me a long time to reach sitting with Tom on the floor of the lab. I first learned about harm reduction in 2012 at HIPS, a harm reduction organization providing syringe services and outreach to people who use drugs and sex workers, in Washington, DC. The tenants drew me in: centering individuals, honoring autonomy and recognizing intersectionality and its inherent complexities. HIPS was in a dingy strip mall basement and there I learned the importance of challenging my normative views of drug use. One particular moment will always stick with me. In small groups we were exploring our personal biases and values around drugs and people who use them. The scenario was this - you’re on outreach and a pregnant woman comes up to the van asking for needles. What do you do? My initial reaction was outright refusal. But reflecting on what we’d just spent hours learning, I took a step back and acknowledged that I didn’t know anything about this person. I didn’t know whether she was picking up needles for someone else, or if the needles were for illicit drugs or diabetes. But most importantly none of that mattered. What mattered was that she was showing up, in the face of potential judgment and scrutiny to get new needles. Harm reduction humbles us. It reminds us that we lack insight into others' lives. Instead of judging or being directive, we acknowledge people have reasons for their behavior, and we work to understand them. Like in medicine, our goal is to work alongside participants, offering education and resources to minimize harm while respecting boundaries.
While working at various SSPs across Massachusetts I learned all I could. I learned how to share the results of a blood draw I’d taken a few days before, informing someone of their new HIV status. I learned how to pack a crack pipe, the best (and worst) ways to de-escalate people and how to reverse an overdose. I also learned how to handle the death of our participants and hold space for a grieving community. To me, not only was my role about providing resources and education but also to learn from people who are experts: people who use drugs.
It wasn’t until I began working at Massachusetts General Hospital that I gained insight into our participants' experiences while admitted. I work as a Clinical Research Coordinator in the Substance Use Disorders Initiative where my role involves chart review and extracting data for research. I am also able to sit in on the Addiction Consult Team’s (ACT) rounds. I hear about ailments and treatment options, and am learning how providers think, make decisions and work together. As a result, I have come to understand the challenges medical professionals have when working with and advocating for people who use drugs in an inpatient setting. As I sit in rounds and read hundreds of charts, I can’t help thinking about the abscesses, osteomyelitis and viral infection that could have been prevented or treated earlier.
I have had the honor of working with many fine colleagues. One mentor, Dr. Fleming, arrived at the Cambridge SSP to be the first on-sight primary care physician. In the beginning she only had clinic for a half a day, once a week. None of the participants knew or trusted her, so Dr. Fleming spent time in the drop-in building rapport. Folks began to trickle in to see her for their medical needs and within weeks there was a waiting list. I had the privilege of shadowing her and seeing firsthand how she worked with our folks. Understanding and kind, she also knew how to be direct when necessary. Dr. Fleming showed how primary care in non-traditional settings can work incredibly well to help address medical concerns faced by people who use drugs. This is the kind of care that I hope to provide to patients, care that is accessible, in spaces where people already feel safe.
I want to be a doctor so that I can work to provide meaningful, patient centered care to people who use drugs; care that prioritizes individual autonomy and the incremental shifts we are all capable of making. I aim to create spaces where the voices of people who use drugs are embraced as experts in how we can improve. And I hope to follow in the footsteps of those compassionate providers who came before me, continuing to expand our understanding of what quality care for people who use drugs looks like. More than anything, I want to look at Tom one day and say, ‘I can help you with that.’
Thank you for your consideration
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Eighteen-year-old me would not have imagined that one day some of the dearest people in my life would be a group of sex workers, people living unhoused and people who use drugs. Today I couldn‚Äôt imagine where I would be without my harm reduction community. Prior to my introduction to harm reduction at HIPS, I led a relatively sheltered life. At HIPS I learned even though I viewed myself as accepting and open minded, I was harboring assumptions and biases. The staff and volunteers helped to unpack those ideas, explore where they came from and question why they persisted. HIPS, and the harm reduction community at large, taught me a new style of self-evaluation and critical thought. I learned that people who use drugs, live unhoused and/or trade sex are the smartest, hardest working and most creative people I have ever met. I also learned the importance of actively listening to understand, of entering a new community with humility and that commonalities can be found between all people.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: When I first arrived in Massachusetts, I attended a hack-a-thon for the ‚Äúopioid crisis.‚Äù It was 2016 and opiate related overdose deaths would hit 2,110 that year. At this event I met a group of people who shared my desire to legalize safe consumption sites. We began meeting every Sunday and named our activism/advocacy group SIFMA Now!. Since 2016 we‚Äôve worked with the state legislature introducing bills that would legalize safe consumption sites, held panel discussions and set up mock safe consumption sites for educational purposes. One of my favorite aspects of this advocacy work is talking with people who may be skeptical of safe consumption sites, listening to their concerns and trying to address them while also honoring their perspective. We have yet to successfully pass legislation, but we have educated hundreds of people about safe consumption sites, built partnerships with municipalities and organizations and hope to see the opening of a safe consumption site in Somerville soon.
7_-_COVID_Impact: When the pandemic hit I was working at a syringe service program and taking classes at Tufts University.  As the pandemic worsened in early 2020, the community drop-in space at the syringe service program was forced to close. Frontline staff worked together to craft an outreach dominant service delivery model focusing on areas we knew our community members spent time. We pre-made safer injecting kits, Narcan kits and food packs and hit the streets by foot, bike and van. As classes shifted online, I continued attending my organic chemistry lecture, office hours and lab but my focus was divided. Taking an exceptional pass in organic chemistry lecture allowed me time to make safety plans at the syringe service program and advocate for resources like personal protective equipment and access to bathrooms/handwashing stations for community members living outside. It wasn‚Äôt an easy decision, but it allowed me the freedom  to serve my community during a time of great need.

personal_statement:
I thought I knew what poverty looked like until I sat there on the uneven dirt floor of the Cano family’s house. The rusty sheet metal encasement resembled a junkyard more than a home. It was the typical Guatemalan house. They all fit on the same mattress even though it bowed and conformed to the ground below. After meeting this family, we knew that something had to be done. Fortunately, we knew an individual that constructed cement houses. He agreed to help us so long as we provided the manual labor for free. It was hard work, but I will never forget the gratitude radiating from their faces as we put the last cement block in place. It was no mansion, but to them it was everything. I felt a huge sense of accomplishment knowing their quality of life had improved.
When working as a Certified Nursing Assistant, I found at times that attending to an individuals’ every need physically and emotionally difficult. This heightened when Covid breached our building. Panic spread quickly through the facility as nearly everyone’s health worsened. One patient in particular that I was close with tested positive, and despite our best efforts with a ventilator, she eventually passed away. It was difficult for me, but even more difficult for her husband who was unable to say goodbye due to the visitor restrictions in place. As he picked up her belongings, I was at a loss of what to say. I hurt for him and his situation. I told him that I was sorry for his loss and that his wife was a wonderful lady. Tears ran down his face as he thanked me for taking care of her.   
My life-long passion for science and problem solving are what led me to initially pursue the field of medicine. I was looking forward to shadowing an oncologist at IMC Hospital to see how the sciences applied to cancer treatment. My excitement quickly shattered when Dr. Low told Tim that the glioblastoma would take his life. Tim muttered, “Are you saying that I will never get to hear the word remission?” I was crushed as I watched his spouse embrace him, and shocked to hear that he did not want to proceed with any form of palliative treatment. Dr. Low taught me that however rare refusal of treatment might be, a patient’s autonomy is one of the most important things to respect. Within any specialty in medicine, the patient’s decision is always the most important.  
My time volunteering as a Spanish interpreter at the Maliheh Free Clinic has been similar yet different from my other clinical experiences. Patients who qualify to be seen at the clinic are seeking the most basic form of healthcare. My job is to translate as best I can what is said in the exam room. Misunderstandings sometimes can happen due to cultural differences, so it is extremely important to have patience while communicating. One individual came to the clinic wanting to discuss her colonoscopy results. Although she firmly stated she had been tested a couple weeks prior, the documentation thereof was nowhere to be found. After a few minutes of confusion and frustration from both the doctor and the patient, I asked permission to clarify with the patient if she knew what a colonoscopy was. It turned out she did not and was unclear about what test had been administered. Although both people were frustrated, the doctor kept his composure throughout the visit. He taught me that patience is a crucial skill to have in all clinical interactions. 
The people that I have had the opportunity to work with have taught me a lot about what sort of a physician I want to be. Whether it be an opportunity to cure a patient’s cancer or consoling a loved one, I want to respect and care for those I interact with. If I find myself in situations requiring hard work or having to exhibit patience, my goal is to alleviate some of the pain and suffering that others experience. I aspire to become a physician because I want to make a difference in the world, and I feel that through my medical knowledge and resources I can do just that.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Growing up playing soccer, I met and competed alongside individuals from many different cultural backgrounds. This opportunity made it natural for me to accept others from all over the world. Amir was a teammate of mine from Afghanistan. Along with his family, they moved here to avoid the terroristic actions inflicted by different organizations. Amir shared with me how difficult it had been to fit in ever since the 9/11 attacks. One frustration he and his family faced was getting through airport security. Nearly each time, they were taken to a separate room to be ‚Äúrandomly checked‚Äù. Unfortunately, injustice towards Afghans is not the only inequality present today._x000D_
Playing soccer helped me to view others as equals. I find it important to look past the differences that separate us and see people for who they are. I hope my experiences in medical school and beyond can continue to enhance my ability to understand more diverse populations and connect with all individuals.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: For a little over a year, I have volunteered as a Spanish Medical Interpreter at the Maliheh Free Clinic in Millcreek, Utah. Most of the patients seen at the clinic are refugees or recent immigrants. Without translators, millions of individuals all over the world would not be able to communicate their healthcare needs. I enjoy translating for patients, and I believe it is just one way that I advocate for the Spanish-speaking population. I minored in Spanish in hopes that it would allow me to be a resource for underserved populations. It may not have changed a community, but I believe I have helped countless people receive the care they need. I am a firm believer that change comes from small changes and influences. I think that my service can help Chicago‚Äôs westside, whether patient‚Äôs speak Spanish or not.
7_-_COVID_Impact: My time as a C.N.A. during the pandemic was difficult. I learned quickly that taking care of patients is not always a happy road to recovery, especially when they have COVID. When I think of the pandemic, I think of people like Ross. He had advanced Parkinson‚Äôs Disease and was unable to say goodbye to his family before he passed away. It was very tough to see him go, but it motivated me to continue my pursuit of medicine. I want to help as many people as possible, regardless of their prognosis. I would also like to continue researching new treatments, cures, and other ways to improve patient‚Äôs lives and to hopefully prevent untimely deaths like my friend Ross.

Hrdshp_Comments:
