I have personally experienced and witnessed the effect the lack of healthcare can have on family and community. I left Nagaland when I was only three, but the family we left behind still faces a lack of primary medical care, primary care physicians, and other basic medical resources. The people there have limited health resources and educational opportunities. As a graduate student, my father, the only one who could legally work, had to juggle part-time jobs to support not only my family but also our immediate family back home—monthly subsistence and funds to seek higher quality medical care in larger cities.
The disparity in healthcare access is apparent even in the U.S. as there are still many in underserved communities who lack access to medical care. My family is an example of those who had a hard time affording basic medical care. As the beneficiary of low-income clinics in the community, we understand what it means to live in fear of getting ill or injured. Such experiences motivated me to pursue studies in the medical field which would prepare me to go out and help those who need healthcare the most. I have the life skills and experiences to listen and communicate with people of difficult cultures and backgrounds and help build the bridge to overcome barriers of the healthcare system.
personal_statement:
I have my mother’s hands. This is something I am proud to say. My mother’s hands have always been a point of pride for her, and for good reason. She has lovely hands with smooth skin and elegant fingers. I remember as a child, I would watch in awe as she delicately painted her nails, smiling at her hands with quiet satisfaction.
It was the night she was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis that I saw her look down at them for the first time with betrayal. These were the hands that carried me into and through life. Hands that I looked to for comfort and guidance. Hands that would now one day grow crooked and knobby like branches on a tree.
I recall huddling close to her as she spoke with the doctor, straining to hear the other side of the conversation through the phone. After she hung up, she cried, and so did I, our hands clasped tightly together. 
The diagnosis initially seemed like a life doomed to be full of aching joints and immobilizing inflammation. Already, she would have bad days on which even walking was a great labor. Already, it was tough to watch her endure the pain of daily life. I did not want to imagine how it might worsen with time. 
It was during this time that I was searching for my first Northeastern co-op, my mother at the back of my mind as I went from interview to interview. It wasn’t until I interviewed for the immuno-oncology group at Morphic Therapeutic that I felt a deep spark of interest. As they explained their research, I realized it was yet another instance of the immune system being led astray. In my mother’s case, the immune cells found an enemy in their own host, while in the case of cancer, the immune cells were being misled by the tumor cells. During my time there, I came to learn about the immune system and gain some insight as to why something that is supposed to protect us could turn around and wreak so much havoc. At the end of the six months, I knew I had barely grazed the surface of what there was to learn and be discovered. However, as much as I loved the research and the promise that each new discovery held, it felt so far removed from the people for which it was intended. I wanted some way to contribute to those who needed help now, and I was able to do so through my second co-op working as a Patient Care Associate at Brigham and Women’s Hospital. 
At Brigham, I was fortunate to have the opportunity to interact with esteemed healthcare professionals of all specializations. I found that I learned just as much from interacting with patients of different backgrounds as I did from the hospital staff. One particular patient sticks with me to this day. She was about my age. I was taking her vitals, just as I had with a hundred others; however this time, there was one problem. She could not stop sobbing, sending her heart rate well into the 100s and her blood pressure even higher. I could sense people growing impatient after the third attempt. I could understand their frustration in wanting to get going with the million standard questions they needed to ask, but I felt for her. She was alone due to COVID-19 restrictions. She was cold in only a hospital gown, scared, and surrounded by strangers. Who wouldn’t want to cry? I remember taking her hand in mine and having her take a few breaths with me while trying to console her as I had seen so many of the nurses had done before and as my mother had done for me when I was younger. 
In a year’s time, after participating in one fateful FMRI research study and the coincidental discovery of a long harbored brain tumor, I found myself in the same position as that patient. Everyone that read my case file gushed about how lucky I was to have accidentally discovered the tumor before it started causing issues. I knew they were right, but it had been one wild ride of a year since the discovery—definitely not the senior year I was hoping for. 
I remember smiling at the irony of the Patient Care Assistant at Dartmouth Hitchcock taking the same vitals and asking the same questions as I had for months. Going into surgery, I should have been nervous, brain surgery is a pretty big deal, but surprisingly I wasn’t. I felt like everything in my life had led to that moment: research in oncology, working in pre-op/PACU, the research study, and getting to know my amazing surgeon over the course of a year. With one final squeeze of my mother’s hand, I went in with faith that everything would be okay.
My experiences have given me not only the scientific and clinical exposure to solidify my passion to pursue a career in medicine, but also the personal experience to empathize with what patients are going through. Medical school would allow me the opportunity to enrich my understanding of the human body and the complex systems throughout it. I strive to look deeper into questions that have yet to be answered. I also hope to bridge the gap between new research and the dissemination of this new knowledge, as well as the treatments that may result from it, to those who would most benefit from it. At the end of the day, I hope to one day offer a steady hand to those who need it and be able to say, with a clear voice and the authority of someone with deep understanding of the human body and its biological processes, “It’s going to be okay."
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
My family immigrated from Nagaland when I was three. I grew up in the US, but there are times when I feel like I do not fit in. The first time we could afford to visit Nagaland was when I was 15. I thought that a missing piece would fall in place among my people. Unfortunately, that was not the case. After years of speaking in English, my Ao language skills were lacking. Not that it made a difference, though. Everyone said they could tell I was American before I even opened my mouth. ‚ÄúIt's in the way you walk,‚Äù they said. _x000D_
It is tough to feel like you do not fit in anywhere. This is why I try to be accepting of others and proudly share my culture with others. The more I met and interacted with people from different backgrounds through my university, volunteering, and clinical experiences, I realized that the beauty of diversity is that we do not need to share the same history in order to relate. We simply need to be accepting of both our similarities and differences alike.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
I served as the co-director of the dance ministry at my church. The program offered free dance lessons every Saturday to children in the community. Most of the children who attended the lessons could not afford to take part in extracurricular activities otherwise. This ministry served a cause that was close to my heart because I had a similar experience growing up. When I moved to New Hampshire, I was excited to hear that my church had this dance program. I enthusiastically joined as a dancer and volunteered to help with outreach events. _x000D_
I became director after a couple years of attending as a dancer. I made sure to continue to provide the dancers with a safe space that was free of judgment. Dance class also served as a fun and engaging way to encourage the children to stay active. I am grateful to have had the opportunity to work with such a fantastic group of people and to provide others with a space to express themselves freely and have fun.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Like most other students, my university had to switch abruptly to remote learning. This occurred during my second and third years of college. I took classes that are crucial for the MCAT such as Biochemistry and Organic Chemistry 2 online. I ended up having to teach myself a lot of material while studying for the MCAT since professors were still figuring out online learning and did end up not covering as much as they usually would under normal circumstances.

personal_statement:
Drive to school, attend crew practice, work at a local store, and complete my homework. My responsibilities were simple and centered on achieving my own educational and personal goals. However, this focus of my daily life shifted significantly during the spring of my junior year of high school.

My mother often complained about bouts of lightheadedness and struggled to get out of bed. She dismissed our concerns, determined to excel at the job sponsoring her immigration visa. After a period of prolonged worsening symptoms and inconclusive tests in 2017, the severity of this situation grew. With my father’s demanding full-time job and older siblings away at college, I unquestionably saw it as my duty to step up. I was determined to assist with my mother’s essential daily tasks and took responsibility for maintaining the needs of our family. I sat with her during waves of fatigue, listening as she described longing to get out of bed and go about her day without growing faint but, ultimately, becoming frustrated at her inability to do so. It was during these moments that I understood my own role in my mother’s recovery. Recovery is not a solo endeavor but rather one in which individuals need both medical and emotional support to heal.

After many futile referrals, Dr. Deshpande, a cardiac electrophysiologist, was quick to acknowledge the validity of her symptoms and assured my mother that he would find an answer. He soon diagnosed her with Dysautonomia and patiently explained the physiology of the disease, why her symptoms were presenting at this stage in her life, and the possible treatment options. He was trying to understand what my mother felt, both physically and emotionally, and convey that understanding to us. While I have always had an interest in medicine, observing Dr. Deshpande’s approach to patient care as I accompanied my mom on these visits was the moment when I concretely understood the fundamental qualities a physician must have.

Inspired by my mother’s diagnosis and my grandfather’s concurrent diagnosis of Alzheimer’s Disease, I chose to study neuroscience at Northwestern. I was eager to understand the scientific perspective behind these conditions. Classroom discussions about both the autonomic nervous system affected in Dysautonomia and the neurodegeneration resulting in Alzheimer’s Disease broadened my awareness of the neurological mechanisms of my family members’ illnesses. My desire for comprehension of these pathologies drove my initial interest in conducting research with the Mesulam Center for Cognitive Neurology and Alzheimer’s Disease. Beyond learning to stain and analyze tissue samples, I found myself seizing every opportunity beyond the bench to learn from the center’s clinicians and ask questions regarding their study participants and how individuals have unique experiences despite receiving the same Alzheimer’s diagnosis. Ultimately, keeping the stories of these patients, whose care depended on this biological research, at the forefront of my mind fuelled my drive to understand these neurobiological pathways and personally contribute to the medical research effort.

Enticed by the ways scientifically defined conditions present beyond either textbook or lab, I began volunteering on a patient floor at Saint Francis Hospital in Evanston to continue serving and supporting individuals receiving medical care. Trusted to independently round on each patient at the beginning of my morning shift, I made it my goal to directly ensure each patient’s needs, ranging from requests for blankets to questions for their medical team, were adequately met. One notable response to a patient’s call light presented me with a middle-aged man sitting up in his bed and struggling to tear open a packet of sugar. Exasperated, he explained how his recent diagnosis with incomplete quadriplegia left him with difficulty grasping objects and, therefore, prevented him from independently preparing his own cup of coffee. As I finished opening the packet and stirred in a splash of milk, I listened as he voiced both his frustration at the sudden loss of independence and greater anxieties about his future. Despite calling upon the skills I had acquired during similar conversations with my mother to put this patient at ease, I recognized the limitations to the support I could provide as a volunteer. I could not cure his paralysis nor could I offer solutions for his post-hospital stay care. I could only momentarily help him feel heard and supported. It is through pursuing a career as a physician that I hope to actively treat medical ailments and provide higher-level care.

While it was my family’s personal interaction with medical care that initially drew me to healthcare, it was my experiences interacting with patients, research clinicians, and doctors that cemented my goal of serving others specifically as a practicing physician. This role will allow me to pursue in-depth knowledge through education and research, and actively apply that knowledge to enhance patient care. Further, beyond my desire to console patients during their treatment, I want to take responsibility for this treatment and their outcomes, and ensure I have done everything in my power to improve patients’ quality of life.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: It is undeniable that rowing significantly lacks racial and socioeconomic diversity. Hoping to confront the long-standing barriers preventing this I worked with North Channel Community Rowing (NCCR) to introduce Evanston and Skokie middle schoolers of diverse backgrounds to the sport by providing free rowing and swimming camps. Beyond teaching technique on the water, I prioritized getting to know the athletes and ensuring that they felt welcome at the boathouse. As they described their excitement to share camp anecdotes with parents and friends and encourage them to also try the sport, I came to understand the importance of racial representation in rowing. Without camps such as NCCR, these athletes may have never been exposed to crew thus depriving many demographics of academic and life opportunities made available through rowing. Creating space for individuals of all populations is therefore essential to producing a sustained change in making opportunities accessible for all.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Despite proper nutrition being a seemingly simple way to manage one‚Äôs health, individuals of marginalized cultural or socioeconomic groups often do not have equitable access to this. To combat this, I worked with Community Health Corps to develop an obesity prevention curriculum for community events organized by Erie Family Health Center. After initially presenting on nutrition labels, balanced meals, and exercise I reexamined if our work considered the backgrounds of those the center serves. As Erie‚Äôs Evanston and Skokie branch particularly assists a predominantly Spanish-speaking community and individuals of lower socioeconomic status, we presented healthier and affordable alternatives to ingredients commonly used in the cultural diets of the center‚Äôs guests and further researched how SNAP benefits could effectively be used locally to support healthier living. I hope to continue with organizations like Erie to create upholding change through increasing access to health information.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Unable to continue volunteering at a memory care facility nor find a physician that would allow shadowing, I volunteered in a dental office where I helped to limit the spread of the virus by sanitizing exam rooms prior to every patient. While I am not interested in a career in dentistry, I was grateful for the opportunity to work directly with patients and healthcare providers in a clinic setting. As I moved back home and observed my pulmonologist father return from treating Covid-19 patients daily in the ICU the gravity of the pandemic became clear. By witnessing the emotional burden of losing patients weigh on my father and observing him remove himself from common rooms out of fear of spreading this unfamiliar illness to our family, I noted the deep compassion and sacrifice he demonstrated as a physician. Despite my grave concern regarding his well-being, I am forever in awe of his dedication to his call to serve through medicine and hope to emulate this as a physician myself.

Hrdshp_Comments: My hometown is medically underserved. I live in a predominantly Hispanic area, with my high school consisting of a roughly 90% Hispanic population. The schools in my hometown, in comparison to the schools in neighboring districts, are underfunded and have less rigorous curriculums because of this. In addition, my family has received government help by the means of food stamps and Medicaid. My father is undocumented and has struggled to keep consistent jobs leaving our family at times to rely on my mother alone to provide for us. In addition, I am a first-generation college student, as both of my parents left school at a young age to help their parents with money. Neither of my parents graduated from college, and their emigration from Mexico often resulted in me and my siblings having to translate for them in situations when we grew older.
personal_statement:
How do we determine who we want to be? Better yet, how do we determine the ‘why’ behind our choice? Growing up, I told my parents, “I want to be a doctor,” to which they responded, “bueno, échale ganas, hijo.” The following week, I wanted to be a dentist. The week after that, a professional baseball player. Their response never changed, regardless of how many times my career choice did. Albeit I was a child with no clue as to the steps it took to achieve these professions, their response was always “échale ganas,” which is colloquial for telling someone to work hard. When they were children, they did not have the luxury of getting to decide what they wanted to become. They abandoned school at a young age to support their parents financially. Ultimately, they decided to leave their home country with aspirations of bettering their own lives and those of their future families. For that very reason, they supported whatever I decided to be.
However, who I was going to be was an obstacle in and of itself. I had little guidance, as neither my parents nor family members attended college. All they were familiar with was manual labor and endless hours. Although this was the case, I had to take the luxury I was granted as an opportunity. 
My first exposure to the world of medicine revolved around my mother’s diagnosis of diabetes. She developed gestational diabetes during her pregnancy with me, which resulted in higher birth weight. I weighed in at nine pounds, 15 ounces; meanwhile, my siblings weighed less than nine pounds when they were born. In 2016, my mom was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes. My curiosity grew, accompanied by my concern. Would my mom be okay? Would she continue to live her life the way she has? I knew little to nothing about the disease at the time, how it manifested, or how it would affect her and our family. Life seemed to proceed normally as weeks went on, and I accompanied her to many of her appointments in hopes that I could learn more and hear good news. However, I began to notice changes in her health. Unfortunately, she started gaining weight and feeling very lethargic. The worst symptom she expressed was profuse pain over the numbness in her feet. Learning about peripheral neuropathy in diabetics overwhelmed me with fear, as I read it could lead to an amputation. 
In the Summer of 2016, my mom began taking medications and altering her lifestyle. My family and I made sure she adhered to her prescriptions, and our diets changed per her needs. Although numbness and pain lingered, I knew she was on the right path. I began driver’s education and had class every day during the Summer. One weekday as I walked to class, I felt a sharp pain in my lower right abdomen. Soon, the pain was amplified by every step. The only way to manage the pain was with short and quick breaths. I Googled what the discomfort could stem from and read that appendicitis is one possibility. Once I was home, I quickly told my mom, “I have appendicitis.” She noticed me in distress and called our doctor. We were seen that same day; however, my doctor could not make recommendations without imaging. He sent me to receive a CAT scan, in which my makeshift diagnosis was confirmed: I had appendicitis. The doctor called Edward Hospital and scheduled an emergency surgery to remove my appendix. 
	Before these experiences, no career grasped my attention for long. I knew I wanted to go to college and make something of myself, but nothing inspired me. Witnessing my mom endure diabetes, the plethora of medications she was prescribed, and the lifestyle changes she implemented piqued my curiosity more than anything else had. Attending her appointments with her and experiencing the patient-physician interactions firsthand provided insight into the medical field. I listened to the doctor’s orders and ensured my mom followed them to a tee. With my own experience being admitted, I gained an alternative perspective as the patient rather than a family member. The doctors who were able to see me that same day prevented worse outcomes and treated me with the utmost care. The ability to have been seen, treated, and sent home within 24 hours was the last push I needed to decide medicine was what I wanted to pursue. 
	Today, my mom’s A1C is in a healthy range, her blood sugar is controlled, and she is living a healthy life. I have had nothing but positive experiences in healthcare and have witnessed how doctors can not only aid physical health but improve an individual’s overall quality of life. After all of the changes in career paths as a child and affirmations from my parents, I finally had a decision set in stone. I credit these two experiences for introducing me to medicine and reinforcing my passion. Although they began negatively, my experiences acquainted me with perspective. I aspire to be like the doctors that cared for my mom and me - showing compassion and commitment to the betterment of patients’ health. Whether it is someone with diabetes, a child with an inflamed appendix, or any other unfortunate circumstance, I want to be able to lend my help and “écharle ganas,” as my parents would tell me.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Coming from a Mexican background, I have the privilege of being immersed in two differing cultures: Illinois and Mexico. While growing up in Aurora, a culturally diverse city, I made friends from other Hispanic and Asian, African, and European cultures. In addition, going to my parents' hometowns in Mexico allowed me to connect with my culture on a deeper level. Much of their healthcare depends on home remedies, which starkly contrasts with the healthcare we rely on here. I have seen family members combat the common cold with teas comprised of lemon, ginger, and many more ingredients. My parents often utilized these methods on my siblings and me growing up. Bringing these experiences back with me and sharing them with my friends, I realized that many cultures outside the states depend on these traditional methods. That connection provided the opportunity to empathize with their culture and recognize the need for modern healthcare in many countries worldwide.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As an older brother, I am responsible for caring for and teaching my younger sisters. I am often the guide they look upon and base their decisions on, so I strive to be the best version of myself. Growing up, my mom worked the second shift at her job, meaning she would be gone all afternoon, and my dad would often come home around 5 PM or later. Their absence meant my brother and I were responsible for caring for our sisters, helping them with their homework, and sometimes, cooking for them. In taking on the caretaker role, I learned responsibility and played a significant role in shaping my sisters. The values my parents instilled in me: compassion, dedication, and hard work, were then passed on to my sisters through me. In doing so, I helped my sister get into college, where she is currently studying sonography and medical imaging. I also continue to tutor my youngest sister as she is entering her eighth-grade year. Their progress makes me proud, and I am excited about their future.
7_-_COVID_Impact: As scary and novel as the pandemic was, it had its silver linings. After being sent home by my college and our classes converting to an online format, I looked for a job. COVID-19 allowed me to work at a pharmacy and vaccinate patients. These experiences with patients highlighted the impact healthcare workers have. I received countless hugs, selfies, and 'thank yous.' Those small gestures connected us during these frightful times, and I sincerely appreciate them. However, being sent home because of the pandemic also ended my volunteering experience at Carle Foundation Hospital. The few months I volunteered enabled me to learn the inner workings of a hospital, gain memorable patient and staff interactions, and improve my skills. Although the time was cut short, I am thankful for being able to have spent the time there.

personal_statement:
“How many Epi-Pens have you already used?” I asked the patient, steadying my shaky voice. Pushing aside the littering of orange and yellow autoinjectors, I oriented myself to the patient, ensuring I would be able to safely examine her. “She’s tachypneic and tachycardic,” I told my teammates.  I initiated the respiratory protocol, opening the side pocket of the equipment bag and reaching for epinephrine. When the patient told me that she had already injected herself with 6 pens of epinephrine, I froze. 

    As my patient’s wide eyes met mine, I learned that my reaction was the most vital aspect of care. All I could do in that moment was be there for my patient, allowing her to trust me as I monitored vital signs and delivered oxygen. As I encouraged her to focus on breathing, I noticed her tight grip on my hand loosening and her breaths starting to match mine. In that moment, calming the patient facilitated her to slow her respiration rate and feel more comfortable. In situations like these, I wanted my patients to feel a sense of control. I realized that this could be achieved through a foundation of trust and mutual understanding.

    Despite the stress of the call, what I remember most vividly is the way my patient looked at me throughout the call. As I first arrived on scene, I saw her pupils dart across the room as she searched for solace amongst the chaos. This fear is understandable, as for many people, medical settings can feel overwhelming and impersonal. It is a provider’s duty to give patients a sense of clarity in the face of uncertainty. As I thought of how I could extend this clarity to my own patient, I remembered my own pediatrician, handing me a pulse oximeter to place on my finger as a child. I felt a sense of comfort as he explained what the numbers meant and my enthralled eyes moved up and down, following the waves displaying my heart rate. I knew that my patient felt powerless among the oxygen tanks and stethoscopes. I wanted to show her how regulating her breathing could make her feel more in control and at ease. 

    I have found that the importance of giving patients control over decisions and actions affecting their health extends to research settings as well. In the Aravamuthan Lab, I work to understand the manifestations of dystonia, a form of underdiagnosed Cerebral Palsy. In the clinic, I saw how the physician’s extensive experience informed their thorough evaluations, but ultimately, a dystonia diagnosis was grounded in the experiences of the patients and their families.

    The patients in the clinic identified certain movements and postures that they perceived as dystonic and were able to work with the physician to confirm which type of Cerebral Palsy they had. The physicians made it clear from the start that parents and families best understood the effects of these abnormal muscle contractions on their children. As a result, they asked detailed questions to understand how they could best address the needs of their patients. At the end of each visit, I witnessed the satisfaction of the parents in their eyes as they first looked at their child and then at each other, letting out a sigh of relief. 

    Inspired by the collaborative nature of care I observed in a research setting, I have aimed to extend the same comfort to patients I interact with in other contexts. During my time serving as a research assistant in the pediatric emergency department, I obtained consent from patients and their families to be enrolled in research studies. For children especially, emergency rooms can be terrifying. Seeing firsthand how patients benefited from involvement in their own diagnostic processes, I wanted to make sure the children were given the same sense of agency while being enrolled in research studies. I noticed that when I first walked into the room, the child would often be looking down at the floor or at a phone. Speaking directly to the child and making sure they understood my role by using understandable terminology shifted the child’s eye line, raising it to meet mine. This assured me that their involvement in the enrollment process made them feel confident and secure.

    In medical school, I hope to become immersed in the collaborative nature of medicine and learn how to address patient needs at a deeper, more complex level.  I want to learn how to use holistically-informed objective knowledge to address patient needs while considering patient identity and specific life circumstances. While training to be a physician, I will not only learn about the pathophysiology of disease, but also how to more fully understand how these illnesses affect patients and their families. My experiences have taught me that research and the practice of medicine are most productive when the goals align with the needs of the patients. Combining my passion for learning about scientific processes and quantitative reasoning with strong interpersonal connections will allow me to empower patients in their medical decisions. I aspire to become a physician because I want to meet patients where they are, in clinical medicine and in research.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: The summer after my freshman year of college, I interned at Nemours Children's Hospital, where I got to assist physicians at a nearby clinic built for Amish families. I quickly saw how all my preconceived notions about the Amish rejecting biomedicine were misconstrued. I saw how parents with no formal education were so well-versed in describing their child‚Äôs complex medical needs. I saw the difficult compromises the families had to make to reconcile their beliefs and values with the medical advice of the doctors. I learned that although the Amish families had different views than patient populations I typically interacted with, they shared the same goal: to give their children the best quality of life possible. When assisting in performing hearing tests for the patients, I encouraged questions and explained every step of the process, establishing a foundation of trust and understanding. This allowed for the patients to feel comfortable in voicing their concerns._x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation: After graduation, I started working at the Cerebral Palsy Clinic at Washington University. While creating a standardized patient intake survey for research purposes, I had extensive conversations with families about what their goals were for each visit. I learned that many families had concerns about a lack of access to physical therapy services and difficulty with transportation to and from appointments. I realized that the survey I was developing could also be used to serve as a tool to connect patients with resources to reduce barriers to therapy access. In the survey, I created a section that allowed families to indicate which therapies they were having trouble accessing and whether they needed assistance enrolling in early intervention programs. These results informed how the clinic social worker prioritized spending time discussing transportation options with families and showed physicians how to contact school programs to advocate for their patients to receive more therapy._x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact: During the pandemic, I volunteered at Almost Home, a shelter in St. Louis, which provides resources to young moms in need. While speaking to the moms, I learned about how inequities in COVID-19 care were exacerbated by the historically oppressive nature of the St. Louis healthcare system. Many of the moms were from North St. Louis, a predominantly black community. This area had a severe shortage of testing sites. Those that contracted COVID had exacerbated symptoms due to underlying conditions that they were not receiving routine care for. Compounding lack of treatment for underlying conditions and unequal access to testing showed me how the effects of the pandemic were especially harmful for communities of color. The moms showed me that it is a physician's duty to advocate for their patients in times of crisis. This perspective will inform my motivations as a physician. I will aim to secure a foundation of trust and equitable access in order to benefit patients and their communities.

Inst_Action_Desc: In May of 2020, we had just started the lockdown, and our coursework had become fully online. During the Physics 1 final, I attempted to access information while taking the exam, which was not permitted. I was caught doing so and reported to the Dean of Students. A few months later, during the fall semester, I had a meeting with the Dean and the instructor of the course, where we discussed my transgressions and what the consequences would be. I was placed on Academic Probation, had a mark of Academic Dishonesty placed on my record, and wrote a two page essay detailing what I had done wrong, the lessons I had learned, and what I would do if I was to be placed in that situation again. This was the biggest mistake I have made in my academic career, and I deeply regret having made it. After going through that process, I have done everything I could to compensate for the mistake, and have grown both academically and personally. I hope to continue to grow as a student and person and to avoid making bad decisions such as academic dishonesty again.
personal_statement:
It was my freshman year of high school, and I was outmatched in the last round of a wrestling match against my strongest opponent. Heaving and sweating, I was ready to give in, and then I remembered my coach’s advice, “if you’re outmatched, you have to think out of the box, catch your opponent with something they’ve never seen before”. I use my opponents' confidence against him, giving him an opening to attack, and use his momentum to flip positions and land on top of him. Upon landing on top of him and keeping him pinned, I heard the referee call my victory, and I ran to my celebrating teammates. Giving an opponent this skilled an opening would have been inadvisable, however because I did something that the opponent would have never predicted, I ultimately succeeded. This was a defining moment in my life because it made me realize that, with the right approach, any problem can be solved, no matter how unpredictable. This perspective would benefit me in college, when I decided to begin working as an ABA therapist with children who were diagnosed with autism. This was one of the most impactful experiences of my life, as I found a passion for healthcare, gained experience in patient care and interaction, and most importantly realized the healthcare disparities in the US, and their effect on people of different socioeconomic backgrounds. These disparities, whether it was due to financial restrictions, a lack of a support system, or lack of education regarding their child’s condition, often directly impacted the child’s progress. After witnessing these problems, I chose to pursue a career that could help prevent and solve them. After observing different health practitioners, I decided that I wanted to pursue medicine because of the problem-solving processes, the dynamic work environment, the effect physicians have on patients and, most importantly, I saw medicine as the most effective path to helping resolve the issues resulting from healthcare disparities. Medicine provides a great opportunity to treat lower-income populations while educating them on preventative measures that can be taken to avoid common health problems.
 
After choosing to pursue medicine, I began assisting in research at Dr. Brian Layden’s lab at UIC, where I learned various scientific processes such as assaying and extraction. I saw the potential of this work to improve our healthcare and experienced the meticulous process of conducting research. Research not only improves the quality and ability of our healthcare, but also can provide affordable and available healthcare options to disadvantaged communities. While working at the lab, I wrote a commentary on the effect of the gut microbiome on the body, and the noninvasive methods such as prebiotics, polyphenols, probiotics, diet adjustment, and the effect of those changes on gestation. I would like to continue healthcare related research both for improving our current processes and to make treatments more available. Combined with the clinical experience I would gain as a physician, I hope to be able to have a very positive impact on the community through the use of research.

In order to gain more experience in the medical field, I began working as a medical assistant at Dr. Altarshan’s clinic. This experience further illustrated the effects of healthcare disparities in the US, largely due to the diverse patient population of the clinic. A common example of this was the process of receiving authorization for the use of an insulin pump or sensor for a diabetic patient from insurance. Wealthier patients with good insurance were usually covered and able to receive these devices, while patients who did not have good insurance would not be able to receive the device. While inadequate healthcare is the most devastating factor to these communities, what is more frustrating is that these patients are often less informed of how to deal with their condition, and have less resources available to make impactful lifestyle changes. These are some of the issues I hope to address as a physician, both by providing more access to healthcare in the community and educating patients on affordable and preventative steps they can take to improve their health.
 
            The issues resulting from inadequate access to healthcare, while prevalent, can be limited and prevented if the right steps are taken. While the current approach to medicine is effective, using unconventional methods can be a more effective way for long term improvement of population health. I plan to contribute towards the improvement of healthcare discrepancies as a physician by providing easier access to healthcare, educating communities, and research into less invasive and more accessible preventative and responsive treatments. While the health issues affecting the disadvantaged are becoming more prevalent, approaching the issue in an unconventional way will have a positive impact and can be the first step to making major improvements on both a large scale and on a personal level.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Growing up I moved around different parts of the US as well as overseas, in the Emirates and in Syria, so I dealt with ever-changing cultures and values early in my life. I attended both private and public schools while in the US, and this gave me a wider perspective from meeting vastly different groups in these schools. My most eye-opening experience, however, was volunteering for IMAN, a non-profit organization on the south side of Chicago. While working with IMAN, I met prostitutes with HIV who would get hired by people looking to receive the disease from them on purpose. The reason for this was because those hiring often did not have access to treatments for other conditions that they had, and by receiving HIV they would be eligible for better healthcare. Even more alarming was how common this was in those communities. This was eye-opening as I witnessed the extremes people have to go through to receive treatment, and have never had to deal with growing up.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: While volunteering for my mosque, we participated in different programs to give back to the community, including soup kitchens, fundraisers, and community events. Through my mosque, I began volunteering for IMAN and gained my first experience of working in programs aimed at making long-term change, as most of the programs at my mosque were relief programs. These programs addressed the lack of hospitals, grocery stores, and clinics in those communities, and a general lack of resources to maintain a healthy lifestyle in the inner city. I experienced the hurdles in trying to provide relief and improvement to these people‚Äôs lives since certain changes could have unintended and detrimental side effects on the community. One example of this is IMAN‚Äôs goal to reform corner stores in the inner city to provide healthier options for residents. However, the corner store owners take a loss by doing so, and the corner store initiative was aimed at incentivizing owners to provide these options.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Before the pandemic, I relied on classroom-style teaching and the teacher‚Äôs ability to learn most subjects. However, the pandemic forced me to learn how to study on my own as a result of asynchronous classes. The pandemic forced me to hold myself more accountable, as well as organize and plan my day to complete my day-to-day responsibilities efficiently. These included academic and work responsibilities, family obligations, the volunteer and research programs that I was involved in, and staying in shape physically and mentally. This later helped me effectively study for the MCAT while working and doing research, and still taking care of family and personal obligations. Although I had significantly less time to study for the MCAT my second time as a result of increased work hours, I was able to improve my MCAT score by six points. The pandemic also gave me space to focus on myself what my strengths were as well as where I can improve as a person.

personal_statement:
“Stage IV Metastatic Cancer.” The hand I am grasping squeezes mine. I stand in a fluorescent clinic room at North Shore Center for Medical Aesthetics, barely breathing as I discuss the news. It is here, in the midst of taking histories and charting visits as a medical assistant, that I grow into my commitment to heal. The patient pulls me in, and I am taken back to a flicker of memory. The memory that first brought me into this room and medicine.

I see my grandfather. I recall a warm smile - him pushing me on a bamboo swing. I see an afternoon of chess, his patience as he teaches me. His calloused but gentle hands as he holds me through heartbreak. What I remember most poignantly are his physicians  – praising his positive attitude and reassuring me that they would provide optimal care for him. Their unwavering acts of encouragement eased my mind about his lung cancer treatment and inspired me to view medicine, not always as a cure, but as a way to offer others hope. My grandfather’s prognosis improved as the chemotherapy and radiation eliminated his tumors and we celebrated.

Our happiness was fleeting, as one night, my grandfather slipped and passed away from a cerebral hemorrhage. His death was so sudden that it was difficult for my family to accept he was truly gone. My aunt most visibly struggled to process her father’s death, as she spiraled into a depression. I offered my support as we processed the grief together. While I could not be at her side because of COVID-19, I kept in touch with her virtually every day. In the hospital, I noticed patients with empty chairs next to them. Although my aunt was fortunate enough to have a strong support system, I realized that not everyone has this privilege. I came to understand that there were people out battling journeys alone, who could use another presence to lean on. They relied on the healthcare professionals alone for strength and comfort. Supporting my aunt through the grieving process and seeing how the medical team provided solace to other patients moved me. I realized it could be my way to serve as emotional support for more people.

As a crisis counselor for the Crisis Text Line, I met Jane – a sexual assault victim who was struggling over the news of her pregnancy. It was against her culture’s beliefs to terminate her pregnancy, but she did not want to live with the constant reminder of her trauma. Together, we saw it was possible to create a plan that aligned with her beliefs and allowed her to be happy. We identified her support system and found activities she could do to find peace, like hiking and meditating. We found long-term support in therapy and a community forum. She agreed to stay safe from suicide until discussing the next steps with her physician. Through helping Jane, I understood the deep connection between mental and physical health. It allowed me to learn what I truly wanted: a lifetime of carrying forward the treasured bonds present in every fold of medicine. I hope to become a physician to heal a person physically, while also being there for them as a companion and guide in their weakest times. No other profession provides this gift – of offering the courage to fight battles, just like my grandfather’s physicians uplifted the spirits of my family.

And so, I strived to gain more insight into the patient-physician relationship by helping underserved populations with the diagnostic side of medicine. As an intake volunteer at Avicenna Community Health Center, I met “Mr. Lopez.” At our first encounter, he arrived pounding his fists. Having just left the previous hospital against medical advice after his COVID-19 diagnosis, he felt as though the doctor there “did not respect him.” Before getting his history, I looked at his chart and saw that he was Spanish-speaking. Even as I tried to slow down my words, he still shook his head in frustration. I saw a gap in communication and understanding. Talking through it with my physician mentor, she immediately saw this too and reached out to a Spanish-speaking physician for follow-up. I admired her compassion for the patient – encased in her leadership skills was humility. She realized that achieving the best outcome for the patient needed evaluation from multiple perspectives, even when that meant another physician would serve Mr. Lopez better. I reflected on the responsibility a physician has for their patient’s treatment plan – to go beyond physical symptoms by exploring lifestyle factors and emotional states. I aspire to do the same as a physician, tailoring treatment to match the patient’s individual needs, which are shaped by a multitude of factors.

With glistening eyes, I snap back into the present moment. I stand in the room, clasping my patient’s hand as they process their melanoma diagnosis. I know they are in pain, but I stand firm. Through witnessing my grandfather’s treatment, supporting individuals in crisis, and helping physicians provide holistic care in underserved areas, I found a love of medicine. I am committed to becoming a compassionate physician to serve both the emotional and physical injuries of patients of diverse backgrounds, like my grandfather, Jane, and Mr. Lopez, and find personalized solutions that will care for the whole person, not just their symptoms.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As an Indian-American, my musical recollections involved learning top Billboard radio songs and Carnatic Classical Music, a form of traditional singing. Therefore, when I began volunteering with children who had a hearing or speaking impairment at the Carle Oral and Auditory School, my blended experiences guided me in teaching music. ‚ÄúMaria‚Äù was a five-year-old, Spanish-speaking girl I worked with. As she started singing ‚ÄúComo La Flor,‚Äù I admired how she proudly shared her music with others. Through music, I was able to connect with her by using her favorite song to explain the concepts: beat, rhythm, and pitch. I not only learned that music is universal as it bridges cultures together, but also that teaching extends beyond just conveying knowledge. Instead, it should be customized to the individual and how they best learn. I hope to continue applying this knowledge by creating personalized music playlists to connect with elderly patients as part of the Musical Minds Project at Rush.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm laying on the bathroom floor, crying uncontrollably and I can‚Äôt stop.‚Äù ‚ÄúAmy,‚Äù a twelve-year-old girl struggling to process the death of her mother, texted me this while I was volunteering for the Crisis Text Line. Although it has been months since her mother‚Äôs death, she told me she still experienced intense feelings of loss. She wanted a friend to share her pain with and I told her I was there for her to do just that. She opened up to me about her favorite memories with her mom and I listened patiently. I know one conversation won‚Äôt end her misery, but it was a step in the right direction. As a medical student at Rush Medical College, I would love to continue providing companionship to children as part of the Buddies program. I‚Äôm excited about the opportunity to spend time socializing with hospitalized children. By emphasizing a strong focus on community service, I am confident that I can further build on my abilities to connect with and provide personalized care to patients.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
After months of extensively planning and fundraising for a Service Learning Trip, I was disappointed to find out that we could no longer travel to Ecuador to provide accessible healthcare to the local community, due to the escalating COVID-19 crisis. Much to my dismay, the pandemic continued and my summer research fellowship was also postponed. Wanting to play an active role during such a critical time, I chose to become a Certified Nursing Assistant and helped residents at a nursing home with their daily activities._x000D_
_x000D_
This allowed me to experience how challenging it can be to provide attentive care, especially when a facility is understaffed amidst a global pandemic. With numerous call lights going off simultaneously, I couldn‚Äôt be there for everyone at once and had to prioritize the most urgent tasks. This taught me to persevere through and bounce back from stressful situations that emerged due to limited time.

personal_statement:
As an undergraduate, I realized medicine is not always straightforward. Prior to that moment, everything I learned about seemed to have an explanation. That changed when I began taking more advanced courses and started asking questions that have yet to be answered. I realized these unanswered questions are the reason physicians continue learning long after medical school. Ever since I was a patient myself, I have been driven to learn more about medicine. My experiences working in the hospital, job shadowing, and engaging in research have demonstrated the potential uncertainty that accompanies medicine. This only reinforced my desire to learn more so someday I could also help people live healthier lives.

Like any patient, when I began feeling sick my senior year of high school, I hoped for a simple explanation and an easy treatment. Unfortunately, it was almost a year before I received a diagnosis that explained why I was feeling ill and required gallbladder surgery. Although my GI doctor felt that my gallbladder was causing my discomfort, the CT scans, an endoscopy, a gastric emptying study, and a HIDA scan did not show strong evidence. While waiting for additional tests, I tried numerous medications and special diets. Meanwhile, the uncertainty of not knowing what was wrong was terrifying. Eventually, another GI specialist concurred with my GI doctor that my gallbladder should be removed.

With this second opinion, we searched for a surgeon willing to remove a gallbladder from someone so young without conclusive test results. I will never forget the surgeon who agreed to remove my gallbladder. He was scheduled to leave for vacation but came in the morning after my graduation to perform the surgery so I would not have to wait any longer. I was thankful for the physicians and the surgeon who were able to provide me a diagnosis and treatment. I knew someday I also wanted to be able to give patients an explanation for their illnesses and alleviate their discomfort.

After reflecting on my experiences, I know that my experience as a patient has helped me become a better nursing assistant. I had the opportunity to meet a diverse patient population and hear their stories, while noticing that numerous patients had experiences mirroring my own. In high school, I was the patient seeking answers but now I was on the care team helping patients through their uncertainty while they waited for their answers. I remember trying to distract anxious patients by taking them for walks while they waited for their results and hoped I could be more involved in their diagnosis and treatment in the future.

My favorite part about working on the cardiac unit was when patients discharged from the hospital because it meant that the patient finally had an explanation for their discomfort and was in the process of being treated. Sadly, as a CNA, once a patient was discharged from the hospital, I never had the opportunity to learn if they fully recovered. Alternatively, my experiences job shadowing gave me the opportunity to witness physicians who were able to offer follow-up treatment for even years after their patient was discharged from the hospital and hear the end of their patients' stories.

While working in the hospital, I also learned that we are not always certain of the cause of a patient's illness and there is not always a known treatment. The opportunity to answer some of these unanswered questions is why I, like many physicians, engage in research and why research is significant to me. Like medicine, research is not always straightforward, and I quickly learned we might not get the answer we expect. While working in the genetic cardiology lab, we hypothesized that by knocking out the SLGT1 gene in the heart by injecting mice with Tamoxifen, we could prevent genetically predisposed mice from developing hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Unfortunately, two of the mice had heart attacks during the echocardiogram and we saw they had cardiomyopathy. This was unexpected because our hypothesis was that disease progression was largely dictated by SLGT1, but there seemed to be another explanation. Even though we did not get the answer we expected, we did discover that knocking out the gene at least slows the disease progression. We are now investigating the mechanism in which SLGT1 in the heart contributes to glycogen buildup in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. This example demonstrates why I enjoy research, because with the results of each experiment, new questions arise. When answered, this has the potential to generate new explanations and make many patients' lives easier.

After gaining an understanding for why physicians continue learning long after medical school, I recognized how these unanswered questions related to my own experience as a patient, how my awareness of the uncertainty of medicine helped me relate to patients, and how the opportunity to continue learning and inquiring is why engaging in research has been significant to me. The uncertainty and quickly evolving information provided by the medical field ensures that each day will be different. I know that each day will present its own questions to be answered, challenges, and opportunities, which is why I am choosing to pursue the journey towards becoming a physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: While working as a nursing assistant on the cardiac, intensive care, and COVID-19 units, I had the opportunity to meet numerous patient populations. I met patients whose lives were challenged by addiction, dementia, financial hardship, and chronic illness. I empathized with all individuals, understanding that each patient has unique challenges that contribute to their health status, no matter what culture they identify with. I recognized the importance of caring for the whole person, including understanding when referrals to community resources were necessary to address a patient‚Äôs access to care and mental wellbeing. Even though I encountered a very different patient population while volunteering at a free mobile clinic than I did at the hospital, the same was true for these patients. My experiences have prepared me for working with diverse populations and I would look forward to joining Rush in striving for health equity in the community.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I had the opportunity to volunteer with incredible organizations aiming to positively impact health in their community when I traveled to Louisville, Kentucky with the Public Health Service Committee. In Louisville, we were able to address disparities in many social determinants of health. For example, we addressed food insecurity by packing backpacks of food for students, planting vegetable seeds, and cooking meals. After taking a determinants of health course, I realized that in Louisville I had also witnessed how disparities in social determinants such as housing and education can negatively impact health literacy and support systems that then negatively impact health outcomes. Once back in Iowa, I began volunteering with the mobile clinic because their mission to provide free healthcare resonated with me after witnessing disparities in access to healthcare in Louisville. Now I aim to positively impact factors that influence health in my own community as well.
7_-_COVID_Impact: During the pandemic, I was able to continue taking courses, perform research in two labs, volunteer with the mobile clinic, and keep both jobs at the hospital. Job shadowing in the clinic was limited, but that just increased my excitement to begin shadowing again last summer. The first fall of the pandemic, I founded the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society as a student organization at the University of Iowa and found it difficult to reach students and organize virtual events. This fall, however, we held our Light the Night event in person, and it made seeing the leukemia survivors interact with each other for the first time since the pandemic even more meaningful. My job as a nursing assistant at my local hospital was the aspect of my life most impacted by COVID-19. When the pandemic began, I volunteered to be floated to the COVID-19 unit as I was young and healthy, and I will always remember how significantly diseases like COVID-19 can also impact a patient's mental and social well-being.

personal_statement:
I was surrounded by the colorful tents, overflowing carts, and vibrant chatter that stereotypically characterizes an encampment. The sun was glaring, and my hands were red from carrying lukewarm water bottles. Yet at that moment, all I could see were his rough bandages. I was doing outreach when my team came across “Jared,” a housing-insecure male who had recently been treated for injuries on his body. I watched the sweat drip down his neck and into his gauze, which had fused into his skin. Unable to shelter from the heat or find transportation to the hospital, his bandages had remained unchanged and his wounds were infected. By the time we arrived, Jared was doubled over in pain. I stood there, water bottle in hand, unable to do anything. Helpless. I knew the outreach I was doing was only temporary—a band-aid solution, but as I sat with him I realized I could do absolutely nothing but hold his hand and wait until our street medicine team arrived. My body itched to do more, but I couldn’t.

As the physicians attended to Jared, I saw the pain in his eyes subside. His grip on my hand loosened and my heart filled with warmth as I watched the doctors do what my water bottle couldn’t. They not only treated his wounds, but asked him about his capacity to care for his wounds, ensured him access to a tent, and taught his neighbors how to change his bandages. That day, it wasn’t the medical expertise of the physicians that gripped me—it was how they displayed patience and respect for Jared’s conditions, using their resources to nurture a space for him to regain agency over his health. Those physicians showed me how building trust and connections through compassion paves the road to better health, and that medicine is about providing care while giving the person autonomy to make decisions about their health. After years of working with the unhoused community, it dawned on me: this is why I want to become a doctor. Homelessness isn’t a housing crisis—it’s a healthcare crisis. And no one is better positioned to address it than the physician, who stands directly at the intersection of human biology and lived experiences. I realized that by practicing medicine in this form, I can truly serve as an advocate. I only hope that one day I embody the values that I saw in Jared's doctors.

Despite this realization, I didn’t always view medicine in this capacity. Growing up, I must have seen a hundred black-and-white angiograms flash across my dad’s computer, continually fascinated by how as the catheter cleared the artery, it became darker, blood gushing through, giving life to the person on the table. The way science and life wove together intrigued me, and I was consumed with trying to understand how one person could impact the life of another in this way. Suffice it to say, it was my dad’s cardinal identity as a doctor that was my catalyst for pursuing medicine. However, as I grew older, I realized that my initial reasons for wanting to pursue medicine weren’t misguided, but simply naive. I didn’t understand the tug that I felt towards it until that day with Jared, and until I started working with underserved and unhoused communities. I came to realize that every relationship and experience that I’ve had case-working only further compelled me to pursue medicine.

In one instance, while volunteering at a clinic for housing-insecure folks, I came across “Mo”. That day I was in charge of foot washing, and as we waited for the water to warm, we struck up a conversation. Before I knew it, we were throwing our heads back, laughing, like we'd known each other forever. As the timer for the water went off, I asked Mo if I could remove her shoes, and suddenly, she went silent. Her gaze shifted to the floor, and she tucked her feet under her. She was in pain, and her feet were swollen, but she was embarrassed. I moved the water and kneeled down, meeting her eyes. My heart broke as she told me why she was hesitant to get her feet checked. She had recently become unhoused and could no longer afford a doctor. We sat there, talking for hours. While no soap suds were formed that day, what formed was a bond built on trust, vulnerability, and respect. After, I got a clinic doctor to check her, and I’ll never forget her smile when she came in the next week, ready to get her feet washed. In those moments, I realized the importance of creating safe spaces and recognizing our common humanity. What happened that day was healing, and it only motivated me further to become a physician. As a doctor, I hope to one day have the honor to nurture these spaces, where individuals trust me to share their stories and vulnerabilities—and heal together.

Through my experiences, I have learned the value of validating an individual’s lived experiences, but I am also realizing that as a student I can do only that. Through medicine, this validation can lead to real, tangible impacts on health. Whether it be facing intense moments like Jared’s, or experiencing heartfelt connections like Mona’s, I have grappled with four years of frustration, anger, and disbelief, as I watched the systems around us erase the rights of these communities. It is this frustration that has pushed me to pursue medicine. As a physician, I can truly stand in solidarity with them.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
While working at a free clinic for uninsured individuals, I came across a woman: ‚ÄúJo‚Äù who confided that as a homeless female, it was impossible for her to receive quality care, leading her to view doctors and hospitals as untrustworthy. In defense, I began explaining how it wasn‚Äôt the doctors, but rather the restrictive policies placed upon them. Upon hearing this, Jo became upset, claiming that I didn‚Äôt understand her._x000D_
_x000D_
What I should‚Äôve done instead was empathize with Jo, recognizing that her experiences and identity led her to view situations differently than I did. In working with homeless communities, I‚Äôve learned that connecting with those unlike myself requires a belief in the dignity of all human beings‚Äì understanding that our unique life stories cause us to rightfully construct different narratives about the world. By recognizing, validating, and respecting these differences, I can better understand others and form valuable relationships built on mutual respect and trust.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Housing over 75 homeless residents, People‚Äôs Park in Berkeley was a vibrant space known for its tight-knit community and decades of advocacy supporting the homeless population. Yet in 2019, UC Berkeley announced plans to redevelop the park‚Äì threatening a space that many called home. Recognizing this, my peers and I organized social media and local campaigns, rallying support from community members and students alike. After months of negotiations, we forced the university to put its plans on hold, pushing it to find alternatives that wouldn‚Äôt jeopardize the unhoused community in the park. And while we hadn‚Äôt solved the broader issue of homelessness, through collective action we‚Äôd successfully advocated for and protected this ‚Äúhome‚Äù. This experience showed that while fighting against institutional entities and addressing systemic barriers can be frustrating and challenging, by finding support in the community around me, I can remain resilient, showing up and fighting for what matters.
7_-_COVID_Impact: During the summer of 2020, I was slated to begin my internship at the Nemea Center for Classical Archaeology. Excavating pieces of pottery might seem boring, but for me, this was an exciting opportunity‚Äì one that would also allow me to earn units towards my degree. Yet, as the pandemic hit, I put these plans on hold. As director of an organization that provided essential services for the unhoused, adapting an in-person service organization during COVID to a remote one took priority, and by forming a coalition of over 20 community partners, we eventually adapted and streamlined much-needed services. In focusing on these goals, however, I ended up shifting my graduation by a semester and changing my plans for medical school, as I was unable to obtain my units. While this delay was unforeseen, caused by the sudden onset of COVID, my decision to focus on my responsibility as a director was a conscious one‚Äì one that I took after weighing my priorities and my commitments.

personal_statement:
On the drive to my first union rally with my mother, she looked at the bitter young boy in the back and explained that anger is of no use without a project to fuel. We spent hours on the streets holding signs chanting mottos that advocated for employers to provide health insurance to workers and their families. Amongst the crowd, I understood what she meant as each union member there was furious to a breaking point though continued to battle for improvement. As I grew up, I began to experience the hardships they spoke of. Whether that was witnessing the rationing of lifesaving chronic medication or outright ignoring comorbidities because they couldn’t afford the price that came with acknowledgment. Healthcare was evidently a privilege that so many, my family included, could not afford. It had become my personal vendetta to ensure that people were going to be of good health. Joining medicine had become my project because I could no longer stand witness to worsening conditions.

Back in 2017, my father had an intracranial aneurysm. The neurosurgeon had stated it was the biggest he had ever seen. They had operated on my father only because the physician had ignored the insurance company’s scheduled date- which was over a week away. In the waiting room with my immediate family, the surgeon told me directly that he was sure the aneurysm would have ruptured had they operated any later. I knew from that moment that I had to continue this example. Choosing the path of becoming a physician was the only choice in my eyes. I wanted and continue to want these responsibilities to ensure that a person's well-being is never disregarded. 

I found opportunities such as tutoring children at underserved community centers and interpreting at Volunteers in Medicine of Southern Nevada. At this clinic, I empathized with the patient’s woes; their drained demeanors and constant visible fiscal concern reminded me of my family. I had begun to rectify the lack of help they had not received. It had been a privilege to remove linguistic barriers, establish continuity and see the positive progression of chronic conditions in patients, especially knowing that their demographic is mostly disadvantaged Spanish-speaking citizens who have not received healthcare for years. Though I had always been concerned with the physical and mental health of others, this exposure showed me how much I enjoy connecting with others while aiding them. It was so enjoyable that I’d illude myself to believe that I was not interpreting for the physician but that I was them, making it difficult to compartmentalize my giddy expression with professionalism. While continuously volunteering, some patients viewed me as one of their providers. They’d attempt to thank me for following their treatment for months; since physicians were rotating residents, I was a consistent face for them. I couldn’t overemphasize how rewarding it had been to see them live a happier and healthier life. Although my volunteer work made a difference, it never felt like a big enough impact was made on my community.

The emergency department showed me a lifetime of knowledge. First, it reaffirmed that the amount of contribution needed to our communities is direly vast. Secondly, it solidified my decision that I must be among the people who will fuel this change. Throughout the past three years of scribing, I have witnessed plenty, from the miracles feasible with modern medicine to the morbidities of debatably ignored demographics. Even before the pandemic, it was apparent that the less fortunate were suffering medically. Heartbreaking to understand why people would avoid seeking emergency care because if they survived this crisis, the financial one to follow would take them. I’d already lost count of the number of deaths I had seen, then the pandemic came and amplified the existing problems. The feeling of impotence was unbearable as I watched people die from the nurse’s station. Each late patient left me questioning why it happened; I’d spend weeks remembering patients, reiterating to myself that it didn’t have to. Those deaths should have been prevented. 

I seek a career in medicine to be able to combat the feeling of hopelessness that I had for months during the pandemic. In less than a decade, I hope to be curing people of diseases. As a physician, I want to remove people from their despondent state and remind them that they are people worth protecting, regardless of their socioeconomic status. Pursuing medicine never seemed obtainable coming from a Mexican household with immigrant parents, but now applying to medical school, I hope to show my underserved community that we all deserve a seat at the table of medicine. When I become a physician, I am going to treat the underserved citizens and not allow the next pandemic to reap on them. I have seen the effects of prophylaxis and know that I can’t wait to apply it to people to a higher degree than I am already attempting to.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I grew up in Las Vegas, one of the most diverse cities in the nation. From my developmental to young adult years, diversity has been my norm. It has made me accustomed to several cultures and appreciate each for its differences. From school to work, there‚Äôd be people from so many different backgrounds, and you could always find some way to relate to the others even if you couldn‚Äôt verbally communicate. A great example would be when I would attend rallies with my mother for the Culinary Union. The melting pot of the crowd was amazing, and to acknowledge that everyone present was advocating for one another was a warm feeling. Understanding and relating to people that vary from me has been a skill my upbringing taught me well. There is something that can always bring people together regardless of how drastic the difference may seem.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
Throughout my years of service as an interpreter at Volunteers in Medicine of Southern Nevada- a clinic that provides free healthcare to underserved communities- I have had the privilege to establish continuity with several patients and watch their positive progression in health. Through my efforts, I have removed language barriers for both parties to get exacerbated comorbidities under control. _x000D_
Additionally, I have been investing in the future generation by tutoring elementary school children for the past three years. Not only does my tutoring relieve some stress from parents who cannot help due to educational, language, and time restrictions, but it helps establish good habits in the children. Throughout my years of tutoring, I have seen kids change their in-classroom classification from troublemakers to straight A students. These lasting effects on their educational career are evident and needed, considering how poorly Nevada consistently ranks in education.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
Noting how the pandemic impacted my life seems wrong because it was not disruptive as it could have been. I maintained my job, completed my undergraduate, and most of all, survived; I am immensely grateful._x000D_
Due to the pandemic, I watched dozens of people fight for gasps of air; while others took their last. Scribing in the emergency room was beyond mentally taxing. Intubations were frequent, but the number of patients coming off of them alive was not. Unsurprisingly my mental and physical health was negatively affected along with my academic performance.  _x000D_
Despite the hardships, I learned much about myself and prepared for the future. It taught me to nourish my support system through challenging times and emphasized the benefits of hobbies to reenergize. It amplified my gratitude and desire to help the underserved. It demonstrated how health disparities would remain without major intervention, which I intend to be a part of. It showed a tragedy we must never allow to reoccur.

personal_statement:
I have an insurmountable feeling of anger rising within me. From the disparity I saw between private and public hospitals in India's southern region, where patients were either in state-of-the-art hospital beds or left lying in the dirt. From the loss of life experienced in my hospice job, where families beg me for more time, and no amount of consoling can change a thing. From unanswered questions at the Minneapolis crisis nursery, when children hold on tightly to me as I cradle them to sleep. I can’t change where someone was born, how they were raised, their genetic conditions, or their income.  I can’t prevent what is inevitable. Yes, there are many things I can’t do, but I will do everything in my power to learn, heal, and understand nonetheless. My family, while none are in the medical field, instilled in me a belief that I should always listen to my heart, and never say “I can’t”. Advanced medical education and training will open the door to my career as a physician, where I will work to answer those unanswered questions and provide the care people deserve.  I have the will, determination, and perseverance to make a difference, and I am ready to get to work.

My time spent abroad studying the diverse healthcare system in India during January of 2020 was a multifaceted exposure to a completely new culture, and there was no rule book on how to approach it.  Seeing these cultural differences led me to a deeper level of understanding and admiration for other cultures. The realization that I have control over my perception of the world, and that my mindset is a powerful tool, has transformed my everyday life. I grew in my appreciation of other cultures and their tolerance and acceptance of diversity. This is very important in the increasingly diverse healthcare environment in the U.S. because health and illness are bound by cultural beliefs and practices. During my time in India, I was confronted with a level of disparity that I had never witnessed before. I walked through a public hospital, where emergency medicine doctors were tasked with seeing over 100 patients a day, where children were lying on the floor in their own excretions, and patients were packed into rooms like soldiers in barracks.   The private hospitals were modernized, clean, quiet, efficient, expensive, yet cold. While the public and private hospitals were not far apart geographically, they appeared to be worlds apart in terms of health care quality and human dignity. I cannot and will not facilitate such egregious disparities. After seeing such upsetting, discouraging sights, I know that there is absolutely no other path for me than that of a physician. 

The road I am choosing is certainly not an easy one, but it is necessary.  It would be a blessing to implement my passion for science, the human body, and the complexities of the mind in such a way that helps humanity.
