One small step in this direction was my experience applying for and receiving a fellowship grant established to promote environmental and social change locally and globally. Along with two other like-minded students from the University of Minnesota, I spent over a year learning from the native people of Kampala, Uganda about how mental health and wellness are practiced in their community. We partnered with a Ugandan business development firm to introduce health and wellness as a module in their new entrepreneurial skills course. Our goal was to educate and equip new entrepreneurs with culturally relevant, actionable strategies on the topic of wellness that would help them understand how building a healthier lifestyle builds a healthier business. In order to ensure the receptiveness of our module, we partnered with professionals in executive coaching and counseling native to Uganda to assist in the live delivery of the module. The feedback from the course participants was very positive: they wanted more. The humanity of seeing people open up about their struggles with mental health on the other side of the world and the gratitude that was expressed for the wellness strategies we provided was incredibly powerful. My takeaway from this experience was how to approach conversations without expectations, search for commonalities, and combine what is familiar with what is new in a palatable way.  These are skills I look forward to building in my career as a physician when interacting with not only patients but colleagues and mentors as well.   

Witnessing disparities in healthcare, both in my local community and abroad, has filled me with a sense of purpose.  I want to take action and continue my studies in science and healthcare towards a higher degree that I can use to one day treat all patients with dignity, regardless of their background. I am still in search of solutions to the problems with the current state of the healthcare system, and I strongly believe I will find some given the opportunity to pursue a career as a physician.  After all, it is not truly the anger that has driven me all this time, but the passion I have for helping others.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I have always considered myself highly respectful of others, but good intentions don‚Äôt always break the barriers between culture, language, and humility.  While abroad in India, I had to retrain my thought processes for how I approached conversations and experiences.  There was no precedent to compare something that was simply on a different plane from what I was used to, and I learned to approach every experience with a completely open mind and absorb as much information as I could about their culture to use as a reference point when comparing new pieces of information. I spent months prior to this experience researching the religious, spiritual, and cultural meaning behind certain topics so as to approach these new situations with true respect.  Through this open mindset, I was able to adapt and appreciate this intricate, diverse blend of cultures, and now have strong tools at my disposal that I can use to find commonalities and gain insight from people of many different backgrounds.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I received a fellowship grant in 2021 along with a team of like-minded individuals, and we had the goal of delivering a live, virtual course module on wellness and stress management education and strategies to female entrepreneurs in Kampala, Uganda.   We spent the better part of a year researching and communicating with experts in the United States on the topics of wellness, mental health, and stress management, along with contacts in Uganda, to hold a progressive discussion with these female entrepreneurs in Kampala.  The live, interactive module detailed how to recognize and define areas of stress, and gave participants actionable strategies and resources to improve their own wellness, which would in turn increase their productivity and capability to handle the demands of their multiple roles in life.  As a result, the strategies we proposed would replace some of the negative coping mechanisms that were commonplace in Uganda, such as binge drinking, and improve health outcomes.

personal_statement:
The semi had the green light. The small car should have yielded but did not, moving too slowly. I shouted out in the split second before the headlights of one met the side of the other. The merged mass tore past the front of my car and came crashing into a ditch. After telling my brother to call 911, I found myself running toward the scene with a seatbelt cutter in one hand and a flashlight waving through the darkness in the other. A vehicle that once comfortably seated five now lay crumbled like an empty milk jug, barely fitting its singular passenger. That passenger, a middle-aged woman, lay on what used to be the roof, breathing heavily but otherwise unmoving.

At this point I had known for years I wanted to pursue medicine, but never before had I felt so desperate to have the proper knowledge for someone else’s sake. A physician could have assessed the physiological damage and improved the outcome. However, I felt helpless at the scene, not wanting to cause further damage by moving her. After telling a police officer what happened, there was nothing more I could do. I never found out what happened to the woman.

My initial interest in medicine came during my freshman year of high school. With a schizophrenic grandpa, it was by chance I was assigned to research the illness for a health class. I became engrossed, my digging far surpassing the necessities of the assignment. I learned of the illness’s ability to pull people toward drug use and alcoholism, the reason I had little relationship with my grandpa when I was young. I learned of antipsychotic medications increasing the chance of diabetes, something I had known him to suffer from for years. Connections were drawn left and right that I was previously oblivious to. Feeling as if the only thing I was missing was a magnifying glass and pipe, my research did not stop there. I drifted into studying other mental illnesses, how they are treated, and most importantly to my future, who treats them. Wanting to educate, diagnose, and prescribe for the sake of the grandpas and all others battling mental illness, I became fixated on psychiatry. Thus, I set my goal to become a physician.

This pursuit brought me to Purdue studying health sciences. When the pandemic hit my sophomore year, I watched as the death count climbed exponentially, many from nursing homes. Knowing many healthcare workers continued working despite risks, I felt inspired to contribute. I passed a nurse aide certification course and took a job at a nursing home near my rural hometown. In the worst of it, over half of the residents were quarantined. Plastic drapes blocked off hallway entrances. Employees wore yellow clothing covers, masks, and face shields, not daring to expose skin. Loved ones were separated, only safe to touch hands across the glass of a window. Residents had no outside support, relying only on my coworkers and me for daily needs. While they were entirely dependent on us, we were entirely dependent on physicians’ treatment instructions. I felt honored to care for the residents during this isolating time, but in my position, there was only so much I could do. Being the one to deliver those instructions was what I truly wanted. 

J was one of my residents that suffered permanent damage to his brain after a stroke. Even in the worst of times, he would smile beneath his white bushy mustache. Although he struggled to verbalize sentences, J was a talented writer. Knowing I would have to stay late charting, I still felt honored reading from his book of life stories to him before bed. I read about his childhood friend who died at a young age and his father whom he embarrassed at a fancy restaurant. All of his stories ended with a reflection upon life and its beauty. The connection I had with J is one I hope to have with many of my future patients.

Once the practice’s COVID restrictions permitted, I had the privilege of shadowing Dr. B, a family physician in rural Indiana. I witnessed him meet with 53 patients, many at their time of desperate need. I stood in a small, white room as a recovering alcoholic broke down, asking for help maintaining sobriety. Another woman going through divorce, seeking help sleeping, unable to get more than four hours a night. I was struck by Dr. B’s ability to wholeheartedly listen. He sat on his sliding stool nodding, asking questions in the pauses, and crafting his solution to the problem at hand. There was genuine gratitude from the patients, one woman cupping her hands around his saying “God bless you”. He brought hope. I strive to provide the same hope to the community I will one day serve.

These opportunities have confirmed my initial decision to become a doctor. I have sought out ways to improve my skills and perspective, to better myself as a future physician while aiding others. But although rewarding, these experiences are building to something bigger. At the end of the day, I am still left wanting to do more. I am still left wanting to take on further responsibility for my patients, to continue to form meaningful relationships but also to heal people and to bring hope. In my mind, there is only one career choice that encompasses all of these roles and it’s the one for me.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: After completing addiction rehab, my uncle lived with us. During this time, I learned a lot about a world I had only seen from the periphery. I saw the difficulty in adapting to an entirely new lifestyle and cutting out friends and family who used drugs. Even at his job as a roofer where I accompanied him one day, I saw his co-workers disappear periodically to use meth. I witnessed him rejecting their offers to join. He and I talked about his daily motivation to stay clean and get his kids back from foster care. As a kid, I had lost contact with family due to their addictions but didn‚Äôt see their day-to-day struggles. Living with my uncle during this time taught me that growing up in an environment with drugs is very difficult to escape. Some, like my mom, do. Many others do not. Previously, I had the belief that all drug abusers were to blame for their predicaments. While each individual can choose to do drugs or not, some people are set up socially and genetically to become addicts.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: During the first wave of the pandemic, I took a CNA certification class and began working at a nursing home. Because of strong restrictions, the residents were unable to have visitors and because so, many suffered from severe loneliness. For some, this brought the anxiety of being alone, for others, depression. I did all I could to bring comfort to the residents at the time, but when I resumed my position in the community service committee of Timmy Global Health the following school year, I wanted to do more for the mental health of local nursing homes. I started what was known as the ‚ÄòSending Love Campaign‚Äô in which Timmy members regularly wrote cards and drew pictures to encourage and uplift local seniors. According to my contacts, the residents loved it. Not only did this bring positivity into the lives of many secluded individuals, it also provided members and myself a fun way to continue serving the community in a COVID-safe manner.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Because of COVID-19, there‚Äôs been a greater need in nursing homes and hospitals. While the pandemic has been a terrible thing, it has provided me with more contribution opportunities. These opportunities have given me first-hand experience in caring for patients and overall helped confirm my career path. Also, I took virus and immunology courses during the pandemic, providing a deeper understanding, and allowing me to discuss options with patients skeptical of the vaccine. The COVID-19 pandemic did delay my ability to shadow physicians, however, and made community service trickier. Also, as someone who thrives on social interaction, I had a difficult time with online classes and didn‚Äôt perform as well those semesters. Fortunately, with my position in the hospital, I still had some exposure to physician care, and I was able to find creative ways to contribute to the community without putting anyone in danger.

Inst_Action_Desc:
In October of my freshman fall semester, I was asked to meet with Student Conduct about an alcohol infraction. My roommate had recently called an RA to my aid one Saturday night because I went out and drank more than I should've. As a first-year new to campus, there was much stress in my world. I was acclimating to intense academic rigor and a heavy athletic training schedule. After receiving my first ever C on a college exam, I went into the weekend with a lot of emotions. I later took responsibility for my actions. Stress is no excuse to drink recklessly. My conduct counselor advised me to explain the situation to my family and behave smarter in the future. Nothing of the sort ever happened again. 

In the spring semester of my senior year, I was asked to meet with Student Conduct about a community standard violation. A few weeks prior, I attended a boxing class with friends. In minding the community standard, we all wore masks and put together a group of 10, which was the maximum number that Duke allowed to gather. However, after the class, the group took a picture to capture the moment. Because the boxing instructor and the receptionist hopped into the photo, our group jumped to 12. The violation was excused, but I held myself accountable and recognize the importance of health guidelines.
personal_statement:
Beneath the fluorescent lights of a consultation room, I stood beside an orthopedic surgeon, wearing my favorite blue button-down and feeling an extreme sense of déjà vu. About a year prior, I had been in a nearly identical room with this surgeon, discussing my torn ACL. Except for this time, the ligament of concern was not my own, and instead of my two parents accompanying us, there was another high school boy and his parents. I discerned in the boy’s face all the same emotions I felt when I was in his position: frustration, pain, and defeat. I wished I could fix his knee at that moment myself because I knew exactly how badly he wanted to compete again. Fortunately, the surgeon was receptive to the young athlete’s emotions, just as he was to mine, and I once again got to witness his stellar approach to treating an injury. I observed how he thoroughly explained all aspects of the recommended surgery and kept the patient’s family at ease by directly responding to any questions asked. At one point, the surgeon asked me to confirm the importance of post-op physical therapy. Excited to contribute, I nervously explained how therapy was integral to my full recovery. That consultation demonstrated to me that treating a patient should not solely entail physiological healing, but should also involve nurturing their sense of confidence in the recovery process. This surgeon, who expertly reconstructed my ACL and so kindly allowed me to shadow him, accomplished this by incorporating empathy into his practice. Witnessing this integrated approach, as both a patient and a student, further inspired me to pursue a career in which I could spend my life holistically improving the lives of others through medicine. 

Shadowing my surgeon also left me with a greater sense of the power of mentorship. I’ve been fortunate to have had several other mentors in my life who’ve similarly motivated me towards positive growth. I developed a successful career in track and field after watching my older sister excel in the sport. I ultimately chose my college major after an introduction by a fantastic professor who charismatically shared his passion for the field. And I’ve grown great pride in my identity as a gay man with the guidance of an older cousin who showed me how to be resilient and follow my dreams unapologetically. So much of my character has been shaped by those who have altruistically shared their knowledge and experiences to guide and empower me. Following the examples of my various mentors, I’ve committed myself to build a life around serving others. 

I was granted the opportunity to put this commitment into practice the summer before my junior year of college. I traveled to Zhuhai, a rural province in China, to create an enriching, immersive linguistic experience for my students. I was intensely motivated to make a difference but quickly learned that this service would challenge me in several ways. I often found myself standing before a sea of energetic middle schoolers, attempting to break through an intimidating cacophony and begin the opening activity of my planned English lesson. I had to learn to adapt to the incredible heat, the pair of boys whose attention I couldn’t keep, and the language barrier that prevented me from communicating with much of the community around me. However, none of these factors kept me from showing up for my students each day. Thinking back to what I learned during my shadowing experience, I pursued a holistic approach to teaching. If I wanted to positively impact the lives and learning experience of my students, I knew I had to put in the effort to better understand them on a personal and cultural level. This meant meeting groups of students during lunch and playing innumerable rounds of requested pickup basketball games after school. Putting my role as their teacher aside allowed me to connect much better with the students. My driving force throughout those rewarding two months, as it always has been and is to this day, was to make a positive impact on the community that would outlive my stay. I expect that these lessons will help me navigate the challenges associated with a career as a physician.

Continuing my interest in mentorship, I currently spend five days a week encouraging high schoolers to go after their goals. I make a special effort to lift up my black and queer students experiencing similar challenges that I was at their age —having a fear of fully expressing one’s identity or feeling like certain paths are not designed for people who look like you, for example. Watching the students I advise receive acceptance to various colleges despite all the challenges in their lives is extremely fulfilling. This reminds me to give credit to my twelfth-grade self who committed to attending college and becoming a doctor because he loved what science revealed to him about the world, he loved learning about how the human body works, and he loved helping people. I am excited to continue my trajectory toward my dreams and develop a foundation of knowledge that will allow me to make a difference in many lives. I aspire to be a physician who not only makes diagnoses and prescribes treatments, but also inspires, empowers, and supports his patients.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
My time participating in a service program in China was challenging, as I was the only black person in most spaces I entered. I often felt uneasy, lonely, and frustrated. My blackness was fetishized, as people shoved cameras in my face, asked about my athletic abilities, and referred to me in terms of my race. I chose to learn from my encounters with prejudice and soon found that many of the actions were not out of malice but out of excitement or curiosity. I was simply a novelty to the community._x000D_
 _x000D_
This experience taught me that I could choose how I perceive situations. That doesn't mean I excused the behavior. However, because I worked to distinguish between mere ignorance and overt racism, I could operate with less strain on my heart and continue to serve my community with both empathy and respect. As a future physician, I'll likely encounter patients who disagree with my sexuality or doubt my abilities as a black man. Though, experiences like this equip me to respond effectively.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Serving for AmeriCorps in Durham this past year allowed me to directly counteract some of the educational disadvantages that many youths in the area face. For example, I assisted students in finding funding for college who otherwise would've had to take out an insurmountable amount of loans or not attend school at all. I also worked with many parents who sought my support because they did not attend college and couldn't guide their children through the process. I felt like I was leveling the playing field and using my privilege as a college graduate to create educational opportunities for a community of students that started out with barriers most of my previous classmates never worried about. This idea of breaking barriers is very much why I am pursuing medicine. I do not only wish to use my practice to extend quality healthcare to the medically underserved, but I'd also like to encourage bright young people who feel the path to medicine was not made for them to follow their dreams.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The pandemic has taught me much about myself and the world around me. COVID-19 has accentuated many of the shortcomings of our administration and current policy. I've directly observed minority communities being disproportionately affected by the pandemic, healthcare workers battling the heavy burden of inadequate covid responses within their communities, and low-income schools persistently attempting to offer quality education with extremely limited resources. Contributing to initiatives dedicated to correcting the injustices of a flawed system in various capacities has been very fulfilling. However, there is a lot I still have to learn about how the world operates and why so many disparities still exist today. I'm confident I'll leave this pandemic a much more informed and determined student, citizen, and professional. While I've effected some change thus far, I aspire to use my medical education to improve healthcare in communities underserved by a system that vows to protect them.

personal_statement:
I sat next to my mom’s hospital bed, holding her hand as the physician confirmed what I already knew when I came home to prescription bottles scattered on the floor. My mom had taken all her pills in a suicide attempt. She was lucky to be alive. As someone who grew up without so much as a broken bone, this is my strongest and most influential encounter with medicine. In the following weeks, the days bled into each other as I balanced school, scheduling appointments, and translating for my mom. However, I clearly remember the moment my mom’s doctor sat down and asked how I was doing. Despite the dark circles under his eyes revealing his own exhaustion, he listened attentively as I shared my favorite stories of my mom. This conversation was the first time I saw her viewed as a mother, a wife, and a human being more than her illness. I walked away from this experience both shocked at how close her life was to ending and awed by the physicians who allowed her to keep writing her story. Having experienced firsthand the impact stories can have on patients and their families, I want to pass on the compassion shown to me in a time of need.

In college, driven by an urge to better understand the role that narratives play in medicine, I began interviewing physicians and patients for the Global Women’s Narrative Project, a non-profit that uses women's stories to promote policy change. One interviewee was "Linda", an uninsured patient whose reluctance to go to the ER led to a wound turning septic. As she showed me the scar on her arm, her frustration was clear. Through trauma-informed interview training, I learned how to remain sensitive and empathetic, and gently reminded her to take breaks. Listening to recounts of system failures and an inability to access affordable medical care has allowed me to reflect on how I can better advocate for low-income patients. Weeks later, I received a card from "Linda", who wrote that recounting her story has been instrumental to her healing. Working with women like her has taught me that system-level changes are needed to ensure that financially disadvantaged patients have access to equitable healthcare. I am indebted to each woman for their vulnerability, as this experience has helped me realize both the healing power of stories and my desire to work with disadvantaged populations.

Moved by this realization, I began incorporating storytelling into clinical practice as a Medical Assistant in Dr. Henry Tsai’s OBGYN clinic. Located in Monterey Park, the mostly working-class Chinese and Hispanic/Latinx patients often bring an unwanted companion to their appointments—anxiety. In addition to their symptoms, these immigrant women are also burdened with worrying if their physician will understand their language and culture. One memorable patient was "Ms. Li", a pregnant woman who experienced bleeding in her final trimester. When I noticed her fingers nervously twirling her hair, I tried to ease her worries in the same way that my mom’s physician did for me, by asking her to share stories. When she realized that I spoke Mandarin, her relief was palpable and she began chattering excitedly about Yin Er Soup, a traditional Chinese dessert for expectant moms. Watching her fingers still, I was filled with satisfaction knowing that I could also practice compassionate care by incorporating stories into medicine. By the end of her visit, I discovered that this petite Asian woman has an enormous belly laugh and is strongly opinionated on baby names (One should never name a baby after a celebrity.) Working with predominantly non-English speaking patients like "Ms. Li" has helped me realize the need for cultural competency and compassionate care that addresses not only the illness but the person behind it. This experience has further solidified my belief that stories can serve as a tool to bridge language and cultural barriers to build meaningful relationships with patients of all backgrounds. To play a small role in "Ms. Li's" care has been a unique privilege. As I watched her walk out the clinic, I realized that medicine alone offers an opportunity to care for the entirety of a person by addressing both their bodily symptoms and their emotional needs.

In many ways, my patients’ love of stories reminds me of my mom. Every year on my birthday, she tells the story of how I got my nickname “DaYu”, meaning downpour in Mandarin. “There was a drought for all of July. When you were born, the skies celebrated with me.” After hearing the same story for 20 years, I often shake my head as she repeats it. My patients finally helped me understand the power of this story—a story of joy and life. In moments of illness and pain, my patients and my mom turn to their stories for strength. They remind themselves that they are mothers, daughters, and human beings who cannot be reduced to their symptoms. My job as a future physician is to listen to these stories to not only connect with my patients but to heal them. I aspire to use each story to tailor treatment plans to a patient’s unique goals in life. My patients and my mom teach me about the healing power that stories can hold, and I know that I will use my future career as a physician to help them write more stories.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Lorena and I are nothing alike. She likes iced tea and hates my ripped jeans. I choose coffee over tea and love my jeans. Most importantly, we have a 60 year age difference. _x000D_
I met Lorena volunteering at her nursing home pre-pandemic, where I quickly realized that we were shockingly similar. Sharing an unhealthy sweet tooth, we exchanged cake recipes. Most importantly, both of us knew what it meant to miss someone. During COVID, Lorena‚Äôs family stopped visiting her. Despite her insistence that it was safer this way, she often looked longingly at a picture of her grandchildren. Similarly, I became isolated from my parents when they quarantined in Beijing. _x000D_
 _x000D_
Lorena and I might never agree on my jeans, but we can agree on the importance of staying connected to our loved ones, which is why I helped set up her Zoom account. Likewise, by emphasizing shared goals with my future patients, I can build meaningful relationships with those that have different cultural beliefs than me.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
When two lines appeared on her pregnancy test, ‚ÄúLina‚Äù excitedly scheduled her first OB appointment. However, at her appointment, the receptionist told her she needed to learn better English. She left without a follow-up appointment, delaying care._x000D_
_x000D_
I heard Lina‚Äôs story when she transferred her care to Dr. Tsai‚Äôs office, where I work as a medical assistant. Although my powers were limited, I could answer her questions in Mandarin, her preferred language, which eased her anxiety. Motivated by this encounter, I also helped to make a bilingual sheet of common medical terms and phrases so that patients can communicate easier with their providers. _x000D_
_x000D_
As a future physician, this experience has taught that healthcare access exists in a complex world of socio-cultural factors. I‚Äôm interested in using stories like ‚ÄúLina‚Äôs‚Äù to improve the experiences immigrant patients have in seeking care. At Rush, I hope to share their stories through Habitus, the health humanities journal._x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact:
In 2021, I was accepted to study abroad on the Health and Society Track at King‚Äôs College London, which allows select students to shadow UK clinicians. Unfortunately, due to COVID, those plans were canceled. While I was disappointed, I instead interviewed physicians about what being labeled as a hero of the pandemic means._x000D_
 _x000D_
One interviewee is a doctor quarantining away from her son, who said the term made her angry. While physicians have been glorified as heroes, many were exhausted and frustrated at the societal inequities that have worsened the pandemic. Infection rates are higher among disadvantaged patients with reduced access to healthcare. These health inequities strain the healthcare system and necessitate the sacrifices of healthcare workers._x000D_
 _x000D_
As a future physician, along with fighting for my patients just as tirelessly as the physicians I interview, I hope to advocate for systemic changes so that physicians, like the one I interviewed, can go home to their families.

personal_statement:
“I’m sittin’ on the dock of the bay . . .” Mr. W’s lilting voice carries from the shower down the hallway of Christ House, a respite care facility for men experiencing homelessness in Washington, DC. Mr. W settled in quickly, and his slicked back hair, memorable voice, and outgoing personality make him stand out. Meeting me in the treatment room following his shower, I proceed to help him with his footcare. He is excited in anticipation of the neck surgery we have scheduled him for, the next day, at a nearby hospital - surgery that will hopefully improve his mobility and quality of life. 
     Christ House is oddly quiet the next day while Mr. W undergoes his surgery. That afternoon, the nurses learn that although surgery went well, he will require a few days at the hospital to recover. It was with surprise, that we received a phone call from a local shelter just one day later, telling us that Mr. W. had been discharged, but instead of making it back to Christ House, he was staying at a tent encampment, and he was in bad shape. I drive to the encampment, longing to hear Mr. W’s cheerful voice and see his slicked back hair, yet that is far from the scene that I come upon. Instead, I barely recognize him: his hair is a cloud above his head, he wears disposable clothes, he is dirty, his voice is scratchy, and he is struggling to move. As we drive back to Christ House, and in the hours and days that follow, I am confused, frustrated, and disheartened. How could Mr. W. have been discharged to the street? Why did this happen? Will he be okay? Did his time unhoused impact his healing? What about others like him who cannot come to Christ House?
     My days at Christ House were rewarding but each day came with its own challenges from barriers related to health insurance, the unpredictable nature of addiction recovery, and the ever-changing demands of the pandemic. Working with an inspired group of healthcare professionals showed me the ways that true passion and caring attention can impact patient well-being. Their indomitable desire to help patients make progress in their lives was inspiring and gave me a deeper appreciation for the healing process. I have witnessed patients make incredible strides going from crutches to walking unaided or having a completely open wound heal to a nearly invisible scar.   
     I have come to better recognize the connection between public health and quality healthcare through my summer research at the New York State Department of Health Wadsworth Center and by interning with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. As I arrived in the Bacteriology Laboratory, the technology and the impressive scientists mesmerized me. In a short time, after settling in, I was directed to work on a project seeking to understand an outbreak of antibiotic resistant bacteria that occurred at a medical facility in the Northeast. Epidemiologists and public health scientists are often referred to as disease detectives and this is indeed the role I assumed. I was given forty-four samples to examine. Although, at first, the samples appeared unrelated, through mass spectroscopy, polymerase chain reaction, and whole genome sequencing, the data became clues that pointed to the possibility of relatedness among the samples. Along with a biostatistician, I utilized this data to create a map to trace the movement of the outbreak through the facility. Organizing my data and presenting my findings to the stakeholders of the facility enabled them to develop policies and procedures to address future infection control. This research created a connection in my mind between the direct treatment of patients and the public health measures that mediate illnesses. A desire to continue learning about public health led me to the CDC where I worked with an education program to provide teachers the opportunity to learn about ways to implement public health into their classroom curriculum. During the height of the pandemic, I worked with public health specialists to develop educational resources on COVID-19. We formulated activities and lessons that were hands-on, question-evoking, and fun. The activities allowed the young students to take on the role of disease detectives and better understand the importance of public health in keeping themselves and their communities safe and healthy.
     My public health research and my volunteer experience at Christ House have shaped my plans for my future career and have confirmed my interest in entering the public health field. While I continue to grapple with the challenging systemic questions I faced when I left the tent encampment with Mr. W., I witnessed how Mr. W., slowly, but surely, got back to his normal self when situated back in a supportive environment. His hair once again was slicked back and his voice once again carried through the hallways. Mr. W was healed in time to perform in the Christ House talent show and as I listened to him sing “watching the tide roll away, ohh . . .”, a smile beamed under my mask. It was the first time I fully understood the saying “it is music to my ears”. I have seen first-hand how patience, resilience, and problem solving in the face of challenge can foster healing and I hope to be a part of that process as a physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As an undergraduate student, I was drawn to a range of opportunities to build relationships with others in communities different from mine. Through experiences working in rural Appalachia, a fishing village in South Caicos, communities for individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities in Jacksonville and Boston, and volunteering in Worcester, New York‚Äôs Capital Region, and Washington, DC, I witnessed the inequities communities face surrounding food insecurity, healthcare access, housing issues, and racial injustice. Connecting with these community members deepened my passion for serving those whose voices are often unheard. Through listening to the stories of those who are different from you, I learned that when you dismantle unconscious biases, you can become more compassionate and understanding of differences. These experiences helped me see how health disparities impact medical care and prepared me to advocate for underserved patient populations.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: My experience at Christ House, a clinic for men experiencing homelessness, showed me the impact that compassionate, holistic healthcare has on healing. Before working at Christ House, I thought that healing started and ended in the treatment room and never really considered the role feeling safe and supported played in the healing process. However, working with this patient population showed me that the healing process involves more than just treating ailments. Many patients arrived at Christ House quiet and guarded. Through sharing stories, being encouraging, and showing respect, I saw the patients became more comfortable and talkative. As I built relationships with this diverse community, I recognized how my presence had a noticeable impact on the patients‚Äô well-being and, in turn, on their healing. Providing a warm and caring environment, lifted their spirits, allowed the patients to focus on their healing, and led to positive health outcomes.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Due to the impact of COVID delays on MCAT scheduling, I had to schedule my test for September in Washington DC. In the span of three months, I graduated from college, moved from Massachusetts home to New York, then to an intentional living community in Washington, DC where I acclimated to a new area, started a new job serving an underserved population, and prepared for the MCAT. The job was rewarding yet draining. I underestimated the impact the work had on my MCAT preparation. As such, my performance on the MCAT is not representative of my potential for success in medical school. I am a conscientious and dedicated student who is excited to learn. In addition to graduating in the top 5 percent in high school, my four-year academic record at Holy Cross demonstrates my consistently strong academic record and is more indicative of my future success. I am academically prepared for the rigorous medical school curriculum, ready to dedicate myself to my medical studies, and excited to continue to serve others.

personal_statement:
Squinting through a face shield, I blinked away sweat from my eyes and collected the names and birthdays of the two adults and four kids in the car. As I began walking away, the woman in the passenger seat called out for me to wait. Her voice on edge, she asked me “is this going to hurt?” I took a deep breath, walked over, and explained the process for her COVID test – “there might be discomfort, but there shouldn’t be pain.” I walked back to registration, labeled the vials for their swabs, and headed back to the car. Channeling my inner soccer coach, we counted loudly together as each family member swabbed their nostrils. I thanked them for coming to get tested, they drove away, and I moved on to the next car. 

I began working at COVID testing sites four days after my virtual MPH graduation, eager to be involved after weeks of reading news about overflowing hospitals and broken supply chains. Managing a mobile COVID testing team in Atlanta fell within my abilities as a seasoned program coordinator and newly minted MPH, but my capacity to provide medical care ended with the receipt of their test results. This experience strengthened a decision I had made during my MPH program to pursue medical school and expand my capacity to provide care.

My path to medicine has not been linear. As a pre-med Theology major, I studied a wide range of topics, from morality and religious ethics to resonance structures and enzyme kinetics. While I had completed my pre-requisites for medical school upon graduation, my experience working with young people in the juvenile justice system led me to work in school-based programming for underserved youth after college. Over my two years working with hundreds of elementary and middle school students, I had time to appreciate the multifaceted nature of each child’s life, and how their physical and socio-emotional health was influenced by these varied factors. To deepen my knowledge of how health could be viewed through an intersectional lens, I pursued my MPH. 

For my MPH thesis project, I worked with urban gardeners to mitigate harm from elevated soil lead (Pb). This experience fueled my desire to become a physician. Over hours of conversation with neighborhood residents, I realized the interdependence of individual clinical intervention and community-level intervention. The health of the community relied at once upon the prevention of exposure and effective diagnosis and treatment for those already exposed. While a physician’s expertise is especially useful for treatment plans, when paired with a trusting relationship, that expertise is also crucial for prevention. As science communicators and practitioners, physicians are positioned to bridge the gap between knowledge and action. As a public health researcher alone, I was unable to offer more insight into the impact of lead on child development or initiate the next steps of a full health evaluation. As a physician with a public health background, I hope to integrate deep knowledge of the human body with a broad understanding of social determinants of health to compose a full picture of each patient. 

While shadowing primary care physicians, I have seen the importance of having the full picture. Unresolved finger pain affected one patient’s ability to work her cleaning job, which in turn affected her diabetes management. Another patient came in for an inhaler refill, but also wanted to discuss his mental health and recent opioid overdose. The intimacy and comprehensive nature of these topics feels similar to the phone surveys that I currently conduct as a Clinical Research Coordinator. With each phone survey, I am offered a window into the life of a young person who is incarcerated. I am humbled by their honesty when I ask deeply personal questions about substance misuse, sexual history, and their mental health. It is in these moments when I again long for a role that would allow me to offer more. While shadowing, I witnessed similar difficult questions and vulnerable answers, but with the added element of a co-created plan to address the identified areas of need. As a physician, I hope to continue these one-on-one interactions with an added layer of biopsychosocial knowledge to facilitate improved health.

As the daughter of two physicians, I grew up a witness to tremendous acts of service and care. I saw the comfort my parents brought to situations of distress, whether they were performing CPR at a wedding or having lengthy phone calls with family friends about a new diagnosis. I am drawn to medicine out of a desire to provide that same comfort and counsel to people about their health. While my childhood environment first sparked my interest, my specific motivations for choosing to become a physician have been shaped by a decade of my own personal discernment working within systems of incarceration, education, health, and the intersections between them all. As a second-generation Chinese Mexican American woman, I have lived at a cultural intersection my whole life. As a physician with experience working across systems, I intend and hope to continue working in an interdisciplinary way. I believe that here at the intersections lies the greatest potential for impact.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: An experience that enhanced my ability to interact with those unlike myself happened during my month-long stay at a language school in Mexico. As a Mexican-American, I felt at home in Mexico. However, all 10 of my classmates at the language school were White Catholic priests from the diocese of Little Rock, Arkansas. In our first week, we established our opposition on nearly every issue from abortion, to gay marriage, to Columbus Day. As time passed, I was able to make a connection with two of the priests, inviting them to play soccer. We eventually found common ground in our belief that religion could serve as a powerful organizing force, as was the case in the Catholic Worker Movement. Nurturing the common ground between us reminded me that there is diversity even among those who check the same demographic box. As I interact with people unlike myself, I am mindful to remember that while cultural context is an important starting point, it does not fully tell you who people are.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I have impacted my community through my food security efforts at the school-based health center. During my first week at the school, several parents asked for food resources during their student‚Äôs appointment. Collaborating with the nurse practitioner and principal I was able to see how our health center could address this need. I reached out to the local food bank and farms and arranged for a weekly pick-up of both pantry goods and fresh produce. I asked the school counselor for advice on which families may benefit, and she provided me with a list of families who had asked about food assistance in the past. In addition to distributing food to these specific families, I also set up free produce stands for all students once a week. I am grateful that the food program has created strong relationships with school staff, students, and families alike. I am looking forward to developing further relationships with families on the West Side through the abundance of opportunities through RCSIP.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
The pandemic influenced my decision to pursue medicine and the work opportunities available to me after MPH graduation. With my background in coordination and public health, I worked as a site manager for a mobile COVID-19 testing site. In my experience, the main barriers to testing were limited mobility and distrust. Witnessing these barriers become more pronounced throughout the pandemic furthered my interest in examining and addressing health disparities._x000D_
_x000D_
The pandemic also illustrated the power of community and connection. I volunteered with the mutual aid project Free99Fridge, which pooled community resources to provide free, quality food at locations across the city. Working with Free99 entrenched the idea that the fulfillment of basic needs such as food, water, shelter, and community are the foundation of all health. These lessons have shaped my mindset as I have prepared my application to medical school.

personal_statement:
Upon seeing my bone for the first time, I had the deepest feeling of panic and dread I can ever remember feeling. I was supposed to be enjoying my birthday at Legoland but found myself being operated on by a surgeon. I woke up with a large cast around my arm as the surgeon calmed my mother, providing her with his private phone number to contact him about my health in the future. Eventually, my pediatrician took out two giant metal rods from my arm and removed my cast. I sat there dumbfounded, moving the arm I thought I would never use again, thinking, “My body healed itself!” As time went on this interest in the human body remained. Upon my arrival at UCSB, I took the opportunity to explore courses that would allow me to learn more about our body’s beauty and flaws. Moreover, through my experiences outside of the classroom, I would come to learn the significance of compassion and leadership, leading me to pursue medical school.

I realized that I could only learn so much about the human body through a textbook and began working as a research assistant for the Pruitt Lab under the supervision of Dr. Blair, which involved studying the impact of cancer drugs on hiPSC-CM’s contractility. It was a surreal experience seeing our inquisition come to life through many hours spent culturing and imaging. During my time imaging, Dr. Blair discussed how he worked as a CNA while considering a career in medicine and how transformative it was for him. 

Following in his footsteps, I took up a job as a caregiver, which I originally saw as an opportunity to learn more about the human body. As I arrived at the retirement community and greeted the nurses, I began to worry that I was not ready to handle the stresses of caring for people in such a critical part of their lives as I saw how hard the medical personnel worked with the families to provide a comfortable life for those staying there. I’ll never forget one resident who was a retired urologist that immediately greeted me on my first day. During our evening walks, we discussed both of our lives and he told me about his arduous, fulfilling career in medicine. As weeks went by, I would come to his home and show him things I learned in my research lab or classes and my positive energy would brighten up his day. It became clear how providing help for something as simple as taking off one’s shoes could have such a positive impact on others. He was always thankful for the help I gave, but as time went by he began to get weaker. One day I came to his home ready to show him a shift in my research results, but I found him bedridden and learned that he had fallen a day earlier. I began to see firsthand how cruel and fast aging can be and the importance of building a relationship with someone over time. Just easing his mood, listening to him, and doing simple tasks would have a large impact on his health. I learned the power a relationship could have on one’s health and the fulfillment I had felt being there for him. I only wish I could have had more of an impact on his health and decided to explore the field of medicine that he informed me much about.

Learning about these fields, I found myself torn between which healthcare career I wanted to pursue. I decided to co-found a pre-health organization with my classmates to engage more with students and learn more about these fields. As the president of an organization, I quickly discovered the workload associated with being in charge of others. Initially, I felt a bit overwhelmed by the responsibilities but learned that listening to others and guiding my team made the work easier. Over time, I began to appreciate having the extra workload and the privileges that come with being the leader of the team as it is an opportunity to create impactful events and help those around me to a greater extent.

Furthering my medical curiosity, I found myself working in the Cottage Hospital ER. Working directly with the doctors, I saw all my experiences connect with the physician's skills. One night, I saw a young boy being hauled in by paramedics for an open fracture wound on his knee from a fall, a similar trauma that I endured many years ago. I saw him cry and understood his panic as he stared at his bleeding leg, but due to the physician's previously developed relationship with the family, they quickly approved of the patient’s images and labs. The surgeon discussed with the hesitant mother to give consent regarding the surgery and lead the healthcare team to get the patient into the OR. A few days later, I saw a healthy young boy in a cast laughing with his family and how grateful the family was for the physician’s work. I realized that the physician demonstrated a deep understanding of the human body, compassion by building relationships with his patients, the exciting discovery process, and leadership within the healthcare team. 

These are some of the most impactful experiences that I underwent over the past few years that I saw come together in the ER through the physician’s daily activities. After a few shifts, I decided that I will become a physician to bring together the experiences I’ve had and apply these lessons, so I can make the same change in one’s life as a surgeon did many years ago to a bewildered kid with a broken arm.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: While volunteering at KCF, I would help families pack up their food and take their items to their cars. During these trips, I would talk to these families and understand what is going on in their lives. One day, a family explained that they had been worried about their daughter‚Äôs fever for several weeks and were grateful for some of our soups. When I asked why they didn‚Äôt take her to urgent care or the family doctor, they explained that ‚Äúthose people don‚Äôt care about us.‚Äù I began to see the mistrust people from low-income families have for physicians. As a scribe, my interactions with patients from underrepresented backgrounds reinforced what I learned while volunteering. Working in the ER, I encountered a Spanish-speaking patient who held her daughter close when the physician arrived, but the interpreter calmed her nerves and gained her trust quickly. I realized the importance of understanding other‚Äôs cultures as it provides insight into the person one is caring for.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Through my student organization, I worked to keep my peers informed on specific health topics and careers. In addition, I offer services for people to find their career paths while tearing down the toxic pre-health stereotypes by creating a host of events through teamwork. One of our more significant events was a lunch-in with local healthcare providers so that students could ask questions or gain experience with these professionals. During this event, one of our members appeared to have difficulty meeting with providers, so I made sure to let him have a direct conversation with a pediatrician. A few days later, he expressed gratitude as he began shadowing the pediatrician at his local clinic, but he found out that he didn‚Äôt want to pursue the pre-med track. Instead, he followed a PA that worked there and decided to pursue that career path. I was proud that I could help at least one person clear up their path and provide people with free resources to further their careers._x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact: During the COVID-19 pandemic, I took all of my prerequisite courses online. Also, I could not begin training at my scribe job until the fall of 2022, even though I was hired early in the summer, limiting my time commitment. The pandemic has limited some of the possible activities I wanted to pursue, specifically clinical volunteering. Many of my prior volunteer commitments, such as Khalsa Care Foundation‚Äôs Hot Meals Initiative, kept me within the program. One of my main goals this past year was to become involved in clinical volunteering to help the underserved community through my passion for medicine. The pandemic forced a local organization named Doctor‚Äôs Without Walls to close its volunteering opportunity to new applicants during this time. This organization allows volunteers to help the local homeless or underserved communities by providing free forms of healthcare at differing locations in the Santa Barbara area.

personal_statement:
“The hardest part about my job isn’t putting people to sleep, it’s making sure they wake up again,” joked my grandfather, a former anesthesiologist for a Veteran’s Affairs Hospital in Florida. When I was young, this comment was over my head, but years after my grandfather’s passing, this is a moment I think back upon fondly. My grandfather faced challenges as a young, Jewish man in the mid-1900s, including poverty and pervasive anti-Semitism. However, by working through school, taking out loans to be the first in his family to attend college, and studying diligently, he was able to gain access to medical school despite so-called “Jewish quotas” of the time. He was aware of the challenges I was facing in my own childhood; as an awkward kid with Tourette’s syndrome, I grew up in a fractured household and bounced between parents. My grandfather offered me valuable advice: “Find what you are truly passionate about, where you can make an impact, and in that you will find happiness.”
Acting on my grandfather’s recommendation, in my teens I played soccer and tennis, learned to code a game in Java, and joined student government. Although these experiences were engaging, I did not feel truly inspired by them. At the advice of my biology teacher, I inquired with my local hospital about volunteering. After a few weeks volunteering in the emergency department, I requested to shadow a physician and was paired with a general surgeon. He was performing an omental patch of the duodenum and the removal of multiple lipomas. I was in awe of the ease with which the surgeon navigated the human body, and with the precision and care he showed in every small movement of his hands. “Even though they are unconscious,” he said of his patients, “I treat them how I would like to be treated in their position. They are entrusting me with their life, and we must give them the care they deserve.” His ability to bring relief and health to so many people was truly inspiring to me. I value the compassion and commitment to others that this surgeon embodies.
 In college, I began to search for others that shared these same values, which is how I met Tommy at our school’s activity fair, when he approached me to return a pen that I left at his booth. Tommy and I struck up a conversation and quickly bonded over a shared love for, among many things, classic sci-fi shows. Later, Tommy attempted to take his own life, and I was devastated when I found out. I did not know at the time that he struggled with depression, and I was in shock, having spoken with him just hours earlier. I felt powerless, not knowing what I could have done to help. As Tommy’s condition improved, I realized I did not want to feel helpless again in a medical emergency. As a result, I volunteered on the Medical-Surgical unit of my local hospital, worked as a first responder at sporting events, and served as the medical staff for a sleep-away summer camp. 
I even earned my EMT certification and volunteered at my local ambulance corps in remote upstate New York. I often think about when I received a 9-1-1 call for Janet, an elderly woman who had a suspected pelvic fracture following a fall. She was frightened, not only from her injuries, but also because of our presence in her home at the height of the COVID-19 pandemic. After I applied a splint and initiated transport, Janet grabbed my hand and said, “I’m scared.” I felt a connection with her, as she was sharing her vulnerability and anxiety with me in that moment, and I wanted to do everything possible to help her get better. While my interventions were important to her outcome, I was saddened that my involvement in Janet’s care ended at the doors of the hospital. I wanted to stick with her, to learn more about her background and history, and to provide more treatment needed for a complete recovery.
I believe that to adequately treat a patient first requires a deep understanding of health and illness. I enrolled in a medical sociology course, which fundamentally changed how I think about sickness as not just as a biological issue, but also as a social one. When a close friend of mine, Jenna, began to have headaches and dizziness and wanted to see a neurologist, I thought about the resources that she had. Did she come from a middle-class family? Did she have a strong support network? Access to a car? Health insurance? Yes. She had the means to travel over an hour to visit a neurologist, as there are few in our rural neighborhood. Others in this small town may not be so fortunate as Jenna, yet they still deserve to have access to care in their community.
As I continue to shadow virtually and observe the interactions between providers and patients, I envision myself as a physician who can use a deep understanding of a patient’s social identity as a framework for effective diagnosis and treatment. Further, I hope to provide these services to those in rural areas, to expand access to affordable, quality care. I am grateful to my grandfather for his advice to “find my passion,” and while I did not know it at the time, I am proud to share in his vision and his drive and pursue a career as a physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I was on a 9-1-1 call as an EMT for a patient with a hand laceration. We arrived to find out that the patient was a Spanish-speaking immigrant. With the use of a translator, I learned that he was scared to call for help because he was undocumented, and afraid that he would be deported. This was a new experience for me. Growing up as a white, male, documented U.S. citizen, I had been raised that I should always call 9-1-1 when I need help and to not fear the police or emergency services. This encounter taught me that when interacting with someone from a different background, it is important to try to consider the situation from their point of view. I also learned to confront my own privilege, as someone who has not had to deal with the fear of deportation like our patient. When dealing with future situations like this as a physician, I will be sensitive to each person‚Äôs unique background and nonjudgmental, while offering guidance and reassurance to provide quality, equitable care.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Learning about how social determinants of health, like race and sex, intersect to determine health outcomes made me aware of just how unequally people of different backgrounds experience healthcare. I believe firmly that a while a physician needs to have a strong grasp on the biological workings of the human body, they also must consider how each patient‚Äôs social factors may be influencing their overall health. During my Immigration and Migration course, I was a part of a research project which examined the access and utilization of reproductive healthcare services by Burman refugees in upstate New York. We found many factors, like sex, immigration status, and educational attainment all were associated with lower utilization of reproductive services. I made an impact on the community by sharing key steps in a poster session with physicians to improve equitable care, such as an awareness of the social determinants of health, and a willingness to engage in cultural competency training.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I was originally accepted to a study program run by the National Institutes of Health (NIH), to take place during the summer and fall of 2020. I was set to be working in the lab of Dr. Carol Thiele, examining mechanisms of pediatric neuroblastoma tumorigenesis. I was disappointed to lose this unique research opportunity when the study program at the NIH was canceled due to the COVID-19 crisis. I am happy to say that I was able to find meaningful work that summer and returned to upstate New York and volunteered as an EMT. When the first round of vaccines became available, I also helped to administer vaccines to students and the local community. Helping provide medical care during a time of great need was a truly rewarding experience which reaffirmed my desire for a career as a physician.

Hrdshp_Comments: With the death of my father, I was raised in a single parent household, which put my family at an economic disadvantage. My family qualified for state aid healthcare (Medicaid). My brother and I received reduced lunch fees in middle/high school. Also, my mom is a small business owner, so COVID had a great financial impact on my family, affecting my ability to pay for college.
personal_statement:
When I was 12, my father had a stroke. The doctors explained that he could not move or speak but could feel everything, and I later learned this torturous condition is defined as locked-in syndrome. During hospital visits, I did my best to look after him. I was determined to live up to my father’s expectation that his children would care for him as he aged, a promise I had made to him years ago. But all I could do was offer him sips of water and patiently interpret his labored communication through the letter board. Remembering a man who was capable of lifting five times his body weight and getting a PhD in his second language, I initially thought he would recover. However, as the subsequent months dragged on, and I watched my father become a prisoner to his deteriorating body, I realized the severity of his condition. From this experience, I learned much about the prolonged, medicalized process we call dying–insurance obstacles, paperwork, hospital visits, the meaning of hospice, the heavy involvement of family. At 13, I was notified my father had become unresponsive; he died soon after, leaving me with an unsaid goodbye. 

Six years later, I was navigating quarantine as COVID cases rose when my grandfather came down with a “cold.” It quickly escalated to a severe case of COVID, and within a week, he was admitted to the hospital with no visitors allowed. Unable to see my grandfather’s decline, I figured he would easily pull through. But he soon requested to come home and be put on hospice. Reminded of the promise I had made to my father years ago, I tried to tend to my grandfather’s needs, offering sips of water and emptying his catheter bag. The morning he became unresponsive, I made sure to be by his side, caring for him in any way possible. The best I came up with was holding his hand, insisting he was not alone. 

The following summer, I worked as a CNA in a nursing home. Like my father and grandfather, many of the patients I cared for were declining or on hospice. While tending to my patients, I often caught myself thinking of these two men and what their deaths taught me: the importance of assisting those under my care to live with dignity in the final stages of their lives. In the nursing home, this form of support often consisted of simply holding their hand, an extra few minutes of conversation, or remembering their favorite treat for a nighttime snack. Working as a CNA, I discovered the need for healthcare professionals to be guides not just toward a healthier life but also in approaching a dignified death.
 
As my experiences brought me new perspectives of medicine, I began to seek further understanding of a physician’s role through shadowing. Due to COVID, I began my shadowing experience virtually, which provided ample scientific information but lacked the patient support I had encountered as a CNA. However, after shadowing OB/GYN physician Dr. Lyndsey Day in person, I observed how a physician can skillfully unite personal connection and medical knowledge. In OB/GYN, miscarriages are not uncommon, and my first patient observation with Dr. Day involved informing a young couple of their loss. As she guided the parents through the next medical steps needed for the mother’s health while also giving essential comfort, I witnessed the priceless role a physician plays in the management of death. This further validated my perspective of a physician as a guiding presence that cannot be emulated virtually. 

Through my experiences with my father, grandfather, and the uncertainty of the pandemic, I have come to discern that physicians act as a bridge between the intricate science of the body and the beautiful complexity of a person. A doctor provides patients with a supportive understanding of how human finitude can be managed with meaning and dignity, which includes caring for the whole patient: familial, spiritual, emotional, social, and physical needs. While the COVID pandemic has exposed the fragility of life, in light of my experiences it has also shown me what gives medicine meaning.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Last fall, I took a cadaver class while also in a Honors course about mortality. I was truly astonished by the makeup of the body. But discussing the dying process in different cultures and professions with my Honors peers, who range from engineering to art majors, I began to see the cadavers not just as educational vessels but also as people with a story who chose to become donors. While during practice stretching, my teammates, knowing I was in the cadaver class, would quiz me about the muscle names, which made me view the body in the context of athletes. As a future physician, I found it compelling to discuss these topics with teammates and future artists, engineers, etc., which has allowed me to connect with others in and out of my major or soccer team in meaningful conversation. Understanding the many perspectives of others, I will bring this ability to connect with fellow classmates at Rush and future patients, whether as a scientist, philosopher, athlete, or student.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As a Division I athlete, there is a lot expected of you from the first day you report as a freshman. During my junior year, Dana, a freshman, was not traveling and breaking team rules. Some upperclassmen were very upset, gossiping about Dana‚Äôs poor decisions and worrying about the punishment the team would receive because of her actions. However, after practice, I pulled her aside and asked if she wanted to stay and do extra sprint work. Giving her tips and encouragement, I could feel her become more comfortable, opening up to me about personal issues she was dealing with. Knowing this, I continued to encourage and support her at practices and when I saw her on campus. Dana earned a traveling spot, playing time, and even a starting position! Soon, Dana was earning conference awards and becoming a top goal scorer on our team. If I had not supported Dana, she may have never felt welcomed, creating a very different season for her and our team.
7_-_COVID_Impact: With COVID precautions, my ability to gain physician shadowing and volunteering experience was greatly affected due to clinics and hospitals being shut off to student observation and volunteering positions. With these obstacles, I sought to supplement through virtual shadowing and becoming certified as a CNA. Additionally, in order for my collegiate soccer team to play and practice, athletes were required to limit any contact with those not in our team ‚Äúbubble,‚Äù not even being allowed to give family who attended games a hug. On top of campus restrictions, I was further limited in my ability to participate in other activities. While this sacrifice was mandatory for athletes, I did my best to stay involved, requiring a lot of zoom. Whether it was zooming with my tutees, research mentor, or professors, I maintained a high level of commitment to my other activities within the campus and athletic COVID restrictions.

personal_statement:
The morning after Thanksgiving of 2016 my father received a phone call that something happened to my mother. She suffered a ruptured brain aneurysm while at work that morning and was taken to the emergency room. She was airlifted to a second hospital for surgery and as I watched the helicopter take her away, I wondered if she would make it through the day.  

Emergency coiling surgery saved her life. She was put into a medically induced coma for three weeks to aid her recovery. I visited her every day and reassured her that I was still working hard on my schoolwork, swimming, and jazz band. The months that my mother was in the hospital were the hardest of my life, but this experience reaffirmed my dedication to a career in medicine. I appreciated the power of modern medicine that saved my mother’s life and experienced the difference a compassionate care team made in the lives of my mother and our family. This experience has taught me about the kind of physician I want to be and the importance of treating the whole patient. 

I have also learned about the kind of physician I want to be from my parents. My father is an emergency room physician, and my mother is a family practice physician. I have seen them deliver culturally and linguistically competent health care to their Latinx and Spanish speaking patients, which has led to my passion for health equity. I explored this passion through volunteer work at several community clinics including the Westminster Free Clinic in Thousand Oaks, California. This clinic serves a predominately Spanish-speaking and uninsured community and I worked there at the start of the COVID-19 pandemic. I wanted to become more involved in the clinic, so I completed their scribe training program. 

Scribing at the Free Clinic allowed me to work with physicians, translators, and other volunteers to provide patient care. I watched many non-English speaking patients struggle to communicate with their physician if a translator was not available and knew that something needed to be done to make language concordant care more available. I described the need for Spanish speaking physicians and more translators at the clinic to my mother and she began to volunteer. I scribed for my mother and saw the difference it made to patients to feel heard and cared for in their preferred language.  I saw how happy and comfortable patients felt and noticed that they were willing to share more information too. Providing linguistically and culturally concordant care created trust between my mother and her patients and seeing this impact firsthand furthered my commitment to becoming a physician that can provide that kind of care in the future. 

My commitment to health equity and diversity is also seen in my involvement in Stanford’s Comunidad for Health Equity (CHE) student group. I have been a member since my freshman year and have been on the leadership board for the past three years. Finding this community has been such a blessing because I have made friends with close backgrounds and similar goals of serving the underserved. CHE has also connected me to pre-medical activities like attending and volunteering at the Stanford University Minority Medical Alliance (SUMMA) conference, exposing me to what life as a medical student is going to be like. 

As a medical student, I would like to continue to be involved in research. At Stanford, I have been a research assistant in the Heller Lab for three years. I studied circadian rhythms and cognition using a Siberian hamster animal model. We used this animal model because it mimics the breakdown of circadian rhythms in humans and allowed us to examine the degeneration or improvement of cognition. For my honors thesis, I tested the effect of donepezil, an Alzheimer’s disease drug, on these arrhythmic hamsters. The goal of this research was to find pharmacotherapies that may improve learning and memory in individuals suffering from mild cognitive impairment due to circadian dysfunction. This work is especially important to me as my family has a history of Alzheimer’s disease and a history of shift work that can affect the circadian system. Pursuing research gave me an appreciation for the work that goes into developing medical therapies and has given me a valuable set of skills. I plan to continue to do research in medical school as it is an important part of advancing our medical knowledge and finding better ways to care for our patients. 

In June of 2022 I will graduate from Stanford University with a Bachelor of Science in Biology, with honors in recognition of my circadian rhythm research. After graduation, I will spend my first month of summer as a coach for Stanford University’s summer swim camp and will continue to volunteer as a medical scribe afterwards. Thank you for your time and consideration.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Volunteering at a free clinic has broadened my own view and enhanced my ability to understand others because I work with a diverse patient population. Our patients are disproportionately affected by high cost of living, access to health care, and burden of disease. One of the patient populations most affected by COVID-19 at my clinic were uninsured, Latinx day laborers and farmer workers. They rely on short term jobs in the farming and food industry and were not able to work from home during any part of the pandemic, putting them at an increased risk of getting the virus. The Latinx community also had disproportionate access to COVID-19 vaccines. Lack of access to time off work and health care meant the Latinx people had some of the lowest vaccine rates even in communities with high Latinx population. The COVID-19 pandemic has made it clear that a lot of work still needs to be done for my Latinx community and I hope to be a part of that positive change as a Latinx physician one day.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I serve my Latinx community as a scribe at the Westminster Free Clinic. I became a scribe here while at home from Stanford during the COVID-19 pandemic because of the increase in patient needs. I work with different doctors every week and they rely on Spanish-speaking high school volunteers to translate. I noticed a disconnect between patient and physician as the physicians would address the translators with questions and answers instead of their patients. I convinced my Spanish speaking, Latina, physician mother to volunteer with me and saw an increase in the quality of patient care. Patients were more comfortable and would request my mother at later visits. I loved witnessing patients receive culturally and linguistically competent care while actively helping them receive this care. I worked at this clinic every week until I was able to go back to school and now that I have graduated, I will continue to work there until I start medical school.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The COVID-19 pandemic impacted my ability to conduct research and complete my honor thesis project. I originally joined the Heller Lab to examine the link between breast cancer, scheduled feeding, and circadian disruptions, but was unable to work in the lab for a year due to the university‚Äôs closure. I pivoted to remote research and helped on other research projects until our lab reopened for in person work. I hit another issue getting lab materials due to supply chain disruptions and ineffective carcinogen batches. I realized that my original project was not feasible and worked with my mentor to create another thesis project. I worked hard to complete experiments with our Siberian hamster model in a short amount of time and was able to present my research at the Achauer Undergraduate Honors Symposium in Biology.

Under_School: Columbia University in the City of New York
personal_statement:
BIO RAD 4. As I read that phrase in my mammography analysis, I had no idea what it meant. As a 21-year-old, with only biology and biochemistry under her belt, I had never learned how to read medical results, let alone mammography ones. Because I always feel the need to understand every bit of information that is thrown at me, I immediately looked it up in the Internet, knowing this could be a big mistake. The first thing I read was “suspicious finding or abnormality. In this instance there is a 20 to 30% chance of cancer.” I gasped. At first, I could not fathom undergoing the pain that I saw my mother, a breast cancer survivor, go through. When my mom saw the look on my face, she immediately understood the fear displayed in my expression. I was terrified. But once I saw her, I understood that if I had the strength to help the person that I love the most confront cancer, I must have the resilience to face it myself. 

My parents and I called every doctor we could think of that would help us understand what these results meant and what steps needed to be taken.
