After days of looking for help, a general surgeon with a specialty in breast cancer told us that because the mass had increased in size, it needed to be taken out. Thankfully, she was able to perform the operation the following week. Before I met her, I researched thoroughly what it meant to have a growing 4 cm fibroadenoma. I prepared myself to use and understand the complicated scientific terminology I thought I needed when speaking to a surgeon. I was pleasantly surprised with Dr. Negrón; she spoke in simple terms and explained everything without the condescending manner I had expected. It was as if we were just two people conversing, without any linger of a power dynamic. I remember thinking: “This is the kind of doctor I want to be–one that speaks with her patients, not at them.”

While in recovery, I recalled my first mammography appointment two years prior. I began getting them each year since I was 19 when I first palpated the fibroadenoma in my right breast. After my first consultation, the nurses told me that I was going to be all right since the mass appeared to be benign. As I walked out to the waiting room, I saw older women looking at me with pity; I can only imagine it was due to my young age. I soon realized that I was more worried for them than for myself. I knew that my diagnosis was negative, but some of the women there were not going to have the same fate. In the car ride home, I kept thinking that there was another 19-year-old girl, somewhere in the world, that was not as fortunate as me in her test results. I promised myself to never forget that 19-year-old girl as I progress in my career as a medical doctor.

This experience pushed me to work harder as a researcher in the Summer Undergraduate Research Fellowship (SURF) later that summer. Even though I worked remotely due to the pandemic, I was still passionate about my help in the battle against cancer. As I compared images that displayed controls and knockdowns about the TP53 proto-oncogene, I knew that my work that summer was the beginning of me putting my grain of sand in this field. I started the program enthusiastic of my work; nevertheless, I underwent several obstacles when collaborating with my peers. When I joined my first meeting, I realized that I was at a disadvantage. Due to COVID-19, I only had the opportunity to perform research for half a semester before beginning SURF, while others might have had years of experience. Moreover, I became aware of my accent when speaking to my peers in English, which caused me to be more nervous and in turn pronounced my Hispanic accent even more. I became self-conscious, began participating less, and dreaded my final presentation. Nevertheless, I kept thinking about that 19-year-old girl that felt the fear of facing a cancer diagnosis. My promise to help her pushed me to overcome the language barrier and do my best when informing about my project. After I finished solidifying the results and prepping the presentation, I practiced every day to get it perfect; I spoke to myself in front of a mirror, and practiced incessantly with my parents and friends until I felt confident. Once I finished, I was proud of my current self, but most importantly, I assured my past, insecure self, that our commitment to help in the fight against cancer was not over. Quite to the contrary, it was just beginning. 

Since then, I have not ceased in my research not only through wet laboratory experiments, but in the clinical field as well. This year, I began working as a Spanish clinical research coordinator at Memorial Sloan Kettering, a place where I can finally use my bilingualism in the pursuit of my passion: helping care for cancer patients. Without these hurdles, I might have never been sure in my choice of pursuing a career in medicine. These experiences have shaped me to be the 22-year-old woman I am today: capable of overcoming the many obstacles that life will undoubtedly throw at me, and more passionate than ever to become the empathetic, caring, professional physician that will be able to help the 19-year-old girl facing a cancer diagnosis.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I recognize that my ethnicity and gender alone contribute to the diversity at Rush Medical College. Yet, it is not merely being a Puerto Rican woman, but growing up with and embracing the values of my culture‚Äîcompassion, inclusiveness, and vivaciousness‚Äîthat I feel define me. It is in sharing these values and in being open to learn from others‚Äô that a truly diverse student body benefits us all. My determination to broaden my understanding of my culture as well as others led me to take music, language and sociology courses and thrive in experiences beyond the premed track. These discussions about poetry, politics, and even dance with students from around the world have taught me the importance of having multiple perspectives for each student to grow. I am sure that as I share these passions with my fellow students at RSM, they will also share their own so that we can continue to enrich each other‚Äôs experience.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: The American Cancer Society says that Hispanics face greater cancer disparities due to ‚Äúdisproportionate poverty, higher percentage uninsured,‚Äù etc. When my mother and other close family members were diagnosed with breast cancer, while testing negative for their BRCA gene, I took it upon myself to do what I could for her and others like her. To start, I joined the Carol Prives Cancer Laboratory to study proto-oncogenic genes like TP53 in the MIA PaCa-2 pancreatic and 468 breast cancer cell line. At Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, I became a Spanish Clinical Research Coordinator to help the Latinx communities in both the IMAGINE and EMPOWER Latinx studies. As I interview them asking how genetic counseling materials could be improved and adapted for their populations and teaching them how to cope with their medical anxieties, I learn ways to better communicate with patients. I look forward to continuing to help underserved communities at Rush Medical College.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Academically, my pandemic semesters were great, but emotionally I missed a proper class discussion, going to the library with classmates, and continuing my lab study. I felt socially stunted, but also my development as a researcher halted completely. I was still an adamant emailer to others to at least mimic an in-person dynamic and set up calls with fellow researches to discuss experimental results. Moreover, I was disappointed that my opportunities for clinical experiences practically disappeared due to the pandemic. Since the IMAGINE and EMPOWER Latinx studies at Memorial Sloan Kettering are hybrid, we rely on the patients‚Äô physicians to approach them, but our referrals come in small amounts. But I have still been able to learn how to approach and interview patients and their caregivers with the warmth, care, and respect that they deserve. Despite the pandemic, I was still able to prepare for medical school.

Hrdshp_Comments:
As the son of undocumented Mexican parents, I witnessed economic inequality between people of color and majority individuals. We experienced living paycheck by paycheck and finding side jobs for extra income. My dad would change from his factory uniform to raggedy clothing so we could scour alleys to sell scrap metal and wooden pallets to make ends meet. Due to my last name, the concept of higher education was never an idea as I was advised to consider trade school as I was unlikely to succeed past high school. My advisor skimmed my transcript for 10 seconds, and I was placed into remedial courses. Even after advocating for myself and testing into honors classes, I was frequently pulled out of class for English as a Second Language matching test to verify I could speak English. I was the only student pulled out as my competence was being questioned all four years. 

I experienced a lack of representation not only in classes but in healthcare, as my experience with Hispanic physicians was nonexistent. My family and I suffered from a language barrier as no physician resonated with my culture. I developed a passion for diversifying our institutions and being a role model for those after me while managing to give back to the community which built me in an effort to be a beacon of progress, not menial labor.
personal_statement:
My voice quivered as I translated the doctor's words into Spanish for my family: "No entiendo porque est aquí, con sus niveles de azúcar, le puede dar un coma diabético. Le recomiendo que se vaya a emergencia lo antes posible." Translation: "I don't understand why you are here with such high sugar levels; I recommend you get to the emergency room as soon as possible." These words simultaneously left my dad speechless and sank my heart. We thought his diagnosis of diabetes was an inevitable death sentence ticking to take my beloved father. After witnessing the fear in my dad's eyes, I knew it was my responsibility to make sure he understood his diagnosis. My dad has always been a mechanically inclined handyman that needed simple terms that I could translate. I googled "blood sugar for dummies" to find explanations I could wrap my head around. For several nights, I stayed up reading article after article about glucose pathways and insulin, wanting to medically understand my dad's condition. The need to understand what made his sugar level so dangerous created my initial spark to pursue medicine. 

I knew that there must be thousands of other patients struggling with English, compounded with a lack of medical comprehension, so in an effort to help people like my father, I volunteered at Old Irving Park Community Clinic, a free clinic for uninsured patients. The vast majority of patients we see are Hispanic, with most being Spanish-speaking only. One day, I met "José," a contractor from Peru. We learned that José had frequently been waking up throughout the night to urinate with persistent thirstiness for several months. He assumed these were just symptoms of getting old and brushed them off. Unfortunately, the blood tests showed that José was suffering from diabetes. However, breaking the bad news was different this time. Before entering the room, the doctor and I discussed how to effectively communicate the difficult news to a patient. He advised me not to beat around the bush but also to convey that everything would be okay and to be ready to provide clarification and reassurance after such a heavy diagnosis. I had to communicate the importance of the statement without frightening him. I was terrified because although it was the doctor's diagnosis, it was coming out of my mouth, and it would be my delivery that the patient would remember. I sat next to José, and with a calm and gentle voice, I emphasized that his diabetes could be managed and that it was far from the death sentence I thought my dad was given. We had a heart-to-heart conversation about how I went through a similar predicament with my father, thinking that his situation was hopeless. I saw my dad in José, and I was transported 10 years in the past. But this time, I knew what to do. We ran through his diet, dissecting his favorite meal (chilaquiles) and finding minor tweaks on how he could control his sugar. We established medication and exercise habits to turn his unhealthy life around. I tried to think of every piece of advice I wish my dad had received and applied it to José. The relationship I built with José continues to be one of the most rewarding interactions at OIPCC, as he returns each month with his blood sugars looking better and him appearing healthier with every visit.

While my interaction with José was incredibly fulfilling, I felt that I wanted to be more than his translator; I wanted to be his physician. I want to take it further and work with patients to best manage their diagnoses and provide implementable solutions for the future. I aspire to be the person researching new and innovative ways to help patients while relating to my patients in the way I knew my dad needed. My dad required more than a physiology lesson; he needed a plan and regimen to follow. Something I learned from my father and José was the needed consistent and accessible guidance for patients after their appointments. This led me to create "Eat this, Not that"  bilingual infographics with universal visual aids and labels to help patients curtail their special diet that enables them to become healthier. Through working with various patients, I learned that while languages are unique, photos can be universal. I began to add visuals of labels and brands that could be applied to any demographic. I knew my initiative was successful when José returned 3 months later with a reduced HbA1C and the same paper I printed for him.

I strive to be the physician that not only provides treatments but also takes the time to sit down and thoroughly understand every patient's unique situation, ensuring that they know that they are being heard and cared for. I want my patients to believe that my support for them does not stop at the end of their visit - that I’ll be there for them when they have late-night calls with concerns or need a simple medication explanation. I aspire to be the most passionate advocate for my patients, where I hope to foster a relationship where they feel comfortable expressing their deepest concerns, regardless of their background and culture. More than anything, I want to replace my patients' worries with hope whenever possible, and convert their once concerned looks into reassured, hopeful smiles.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Working up ‚ÄúJoe‚Äù as the new patient to the clinic, he told me how this was his first appointment in years due to his battle with homelessness and past history of being a felon. Joe shared his intense feelings with me about being stigmatized by the community which opened my eyes to the impact that a community can have on one‚Äôs health. I have witnessed how ex-felons are judged by a mistake and haunted for the rest of their lives. I believe that the job of a doctor is not to judge but to be of service to the patient regardless of their background. I believe that as doctors, we straddle the line between community and patient and must work to progress our community to improve the social aspect of health. I learned that while some communities can be unwelcoming, I can and will be the change by treating each patient with the love and respect they deserve, regardless of their diverse background or past.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Meals on Wheels is a community-based organization where volunteers deliver hot meals and perform wellness checks on a daily basis. I frequently visit Mr. Cook, an 85-year-old individual recovering from a newly repaired hernia. During my first few visits, I started by rearranging his fridge and cleaning up his living room. I could see the gratitude in his eyes but I wanted to do more than tidy up. While cleaning, I noticed he was struggling with mobility and spent most of his time on his recliner. I went home thinking of how we can improve his living space. I had the idea to create a remote stand that helped him organize his remote, store his phone for emergencies, and snacks so he would not have to get up. Mr. Cook‚Äôs face of gratitude made my day as something so minuscule provided so much relief. Every week, I always make sure to leave Mr. Cook at the end of my route because I know he needs extra attention. I hope to make the same impactful relationships with my future patients.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Originally, I was set to shadow multiple physicians in the months leading up to what was the beginning of the pandemic shutdown. My mosquito research was also disrupted as I was to test a yeast encapsulated larvacide that was never sent to me. I transitioned my project towards studying mosquito upkeep and antioxidant SOS defense. While my CHARISMA fellowship transitioned online, I took the opportunity to work on a relevant issue and choose a Vitamin D versus COVID-19 study. While speaking with patients, I learned of a common thread of COVID misinformation, especially around non-English speakers. Through remote recruiting, we worked to dispel common misconceptions and encourage research participation to gather helpful information against COVID. In a time when we were forced to be physically apart, our research helped us get closer to an answer together.

Hrdshp_Comments: I left the United States as a baby and only returned at the age of 9. During that time, I grew up in Japan and Brazil due to my mother's job situating her there. Upon arriving in the United States, I had to achieve fluency in English and assimilate into broader American society. The process of learning English took years, but I did eventually become fluent. This linguistic barrier made me an outsider in American society for years and still sticks with me and my loved ones. The same difficulties eleven-year-old me experienced when attempting to navigate American institutions- from healthcare to education- still stand with me. I often find myself as an outsider in my peer groups or professional environments, as my traditional cultural values are both a ready justification for exclusion or isolation. However, I have come to resonate with these qualities and create a purpose for my life. Although I am an American citizen and have effectively assimilated into American Society, I have effectively lived as an immigrant. I aim to make the process to reach a similar comfortability that I have as an American outsider clear and easy for all. In my professional healthcare life, I aim to use my lived experiences to connect and resonate with immigrant patient populations until the day I am buried six feet under.
personal_statement:
I am seven years old. 

As a sweltering summer enters its twilight days, I spend them as an inpatient at the University of Tokyo Hospital. This isn’t my first time in a hospital- as an immunodeficient kid, doctor’s visits are more routine than trips to the zoo. However, this is different; I’ve never spent more than a week in a hospital, but this time over a month has slipped by. I’m aware that something is seriously wrong, but I can’t even pronounce tuberculosis let alone know the significance of my airborne isolation room. 

Every day, my sister visits me to tell me about her day and what’s going on in the world beyond my window. These stories replace my favorite afterschool cartoons and are a clear distraction from my grave situation. However, even as the possibility of a lobectomy is passed among them, the doctors that visit keep my spirit strong and let me fight on. As the trees in the world beyond my window turn brown, the confidence and care my doctor approaches my treatment with never allows me or my family to give up or relent, even as my condition recovers. 

As the last days of my discharge plan come to an end and the first snow of winter falls, I leave the hospital. For what feels like the first time in my life, I enter the world beyond my window- now lightly powdered by a light snowfall. Even though the beauty of Tokyo in the winter sprawls around me, the awe I felt towards my doctor stands in my mind harder than the scenery around me, leaving a mental impression never wavers. 

I am sixteen years old.

The final bell rings and amongst the mass rush of hundreds of students, my friend Chyou and I walk through the main building of our high school towards the exit. Our typical subjects of discussion include the results of the presidential election, Dr. Strange, and recently- her pregnancy. As we wait out front for our parents to pick us up, she expresses a shaky excitement for her child and her future. At age 16, her child will delay, if not outright cancel, any plans she previously had. It’s been like this ever since she found out, as her parent’s strict values and her health concerns as a teenage mom have drastically changed what she previously imagined as the start of her adult life. 

But, just as our conversation shifts to a less personal subject, my dad’s car arrives and I leave. As I pull away from school, my view of Chyou slowly fades among the sea of cars arriving at the pick-up area and the weekend begins. 

During the first class on Monday, among yawns and general grogginess of AP Econ, the principal calls me and some of my friends to the principal’s office. When we arrive, we are told news that hits us harder than any shot of caffeine could have on that cold November morning.
 
Chyou has passed away. Her family has requested for us to know, but since they do not know English they have chosen to have the school counselor inform us. Over the coming days, I would learn that Chyou had suffered an ectopic pregnancy. She did not seek medical attention and passed away that weekend. Chyou’s parents, as foreigners who did not understand English and had shaky citizenship status, did not seek immediate medical attention for her until it was too late. 

When I knew them, Chyou’s parents had avoided interacting with healthcare, as their inability to speak English made them feel alienated from many American institutions, including medicine. To them, it was easier to rely on their culture’s medicine rather than risk deportation or attempt to cross the linguistic barrier. As outsiders, there was, and always will be, difficulty making that jump into a society they saw as unwelcoming. 

Throughout my entire life, I have lived and breathed the story of a foreigner in the countries and cultures I have walked through. In Japan, I lived as a Brazilian boy in a society that was 99% Asian. In the United States, I lived as an ice-cold chunk amongst the famed American melting pot due to my initial inability to speak English. Even though I have long overcome that barrier and have long been an American citizen, I still understand the hesitancy that Chyou’s family felt. I know the weight that an immigrant can feel when they do try to interact with the institutions of another country. At the same time, I know the impact a doctor who crosses these barriers can have- like those who treated me at the University of Tokyo all those years ago. A doctor who can break these barriers goes beyond their scope of practice, becoming a figure that not only heals the body, but also the divide between people.
 
To me, access to healthcare is a human right. The doctor, and man, I aim to become shares this human right with all by crossing the cultural barriers many immigrants face as outsiders to American institutions. I aim to hold my foreigner emblem loud and proud, using my ability to speak different languages to create a space for as many as I can within healthcare. My life will always be a learning process, as I seek to understand cultures different from my own and integrate my knowledge into my efforts. With every person I bring into healthcare, I hope to prevent someone from meeting Chyou’s fate, and if I’m lucky, inspire others to set on the path towards expanding the spaces I aim to create.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I spent the first nine years of my life in foreign countries. For the first eight, I lived in Hokkaido, Japan, where my Latino heritage stood out like a nail among the almost entirely Japanese community around me. However, even in an environment where I was different from nearly everyone, I still internalized the values of Japanese society and partially assimilated. At the age of eight, I moved to Brazil, where the values I acquired in Japan slammed into an entirely different people and society. Here, I experienced a core aspect of the immigrant experience for the first time- that of being an outsider. These years of my life opened my understanding of the differences between people, particularly their importance and irrelevance. On the one hand, humanity has used cultural differences to justify atrocities out of ethnocentrism. On the other hand, there is strength in blending our cultural differences, as in spaces where all walks of life can coexist, a peerless tomorrow rises.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I believe that healthcare must understand what influences health outside the strict clinical sense. By this, I mean healthcare must understand how culture, tradition, finances, and many other factors cause someone to develop an illness. During my undergraduate years, I worked to establish clinics staffed with people that represented their local community. For example, in Koreatown, I sought out medical professionals of a Korean background or who grew up in Koreatown. However, in East LA, I sought healthcare professionals who understood the Latino experience in this country- especially those who grew up in that area. In doing this, I created teams of medical professionals that could treat patients with the power of shared experience. While our intention was never to stop COVID, we knew we could make people comfortable with the clinics we created. I intend to spend my entire medical career creating spaces where the sociocultural aspects of my community are understood and empowered.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I ask Rush to consider the circumstances behind the only Pass/No Pass courses I have ever had in my undergraduate career. The first is Japan 5, which was put as Pass/No Pass due to my instructor's declining health and passing during the course. The content and structure of the course became increasingly chaotic due to my instructor's unfortunate circumstances. With my personal connection to them, along with the general disorder of the class taken into consideration, I decided to put the class as Pass/No Pass. Furthermore, I put two classes in the winter 2022 semester on Pass/No Pass. This was due to the general uncertainty and confusion surrounding the Omicron variant of COVID-19, which caused UCLA to be virtual for the first half of the quarter and in-person for the second half. When we returned to in-person exams, which was the same week the campus returned to in-person instruction, there was tremendous disorder surrounding all aspects of my class.

Major_Long_Desc: Chemistry with a Concentration in Biochemistry
personal_statement:
Growing up, I was passionate about soccer. Whether playing for my high school team or watching games, I was glued to the sport on and off the field. That attachment ended during a playoff match against our high school rival. My teammate crossed the ball, and I sprinted 30 yards to reach it, only to be brutally slide tackled by the opposing defender. As I landed on my shoulder, I felt a snap, and my shriek reverberated around the stadium. A bit dazed, my teammates assisted me off the pitch. The pain became intolerable when the adrenaline wore off, and I was rushed to urgent care. I could feel the sharp needles in my shoulder as I described what had happened to the physician. I stated I hadn't broken a bone before as he nodded and performed a routine assessment. He predicted a clavicle fracture and ordered x-rays to confirm while confidently dictating the treatment plan. With just a touch the physician had effortlessly handled my crisis. He assuaged my worries about the prognosis while placing me in a sling and ensured a referral to an orthopedic expert. In that instance, the physician comforted me during one of my most vulnerable moments. Impressed by his expertise, the moment sparked my respect and curiosity toward healthcare professionals

After discharge, I consulted with Dr. Olufade, a sports medicine physician. As I entered the clinic, I was reassured to see signed jerseys on the wall and a thank you sign from the success stories he had assisted. While sitting on the examination table, I reminisced over the years I spent playing soccer and wondered whether Dr. Olufade could repeat that same success with me. I asked about his medical journey and how he helps patients bounce back from traumatic sports injuries. He described his battle with an ACL tear, which he uses as motivation to heal others. As he validated my concerns, I was encouraged by the parallels in our stories and realized I could help people too. As I followed up with him throughout high school, his mentorship increased my depth of understanding of the medical field and inspired me to pursue experiences persistently but thoughtfully. Dr. Olufade's determination to provide a sense of hope to others and his excellence in going above and beyond the call were contagious and further kindled my spark to pursue medicine

As I started college, I relied on this spark to further my scientific aptitude. While the academic rigor increased, so did the physical demands. Even though I replaced the hours spent playing soccer with research and pre-med courses, my routine escape from the stress still revolved around my love for the sport. However, as I played a game over the weekend, I missed the ball and kicked the ground instead, resulting in an aching pain in my hip as the weeks went by. Tylenol eased my discomfort while I inched closer to graduation, but as the pandemic began to climax and lockdown ensued, my pain worsened as I limped around my home. The COVID-19 restrictions impacted my access to care; symptoms of sciatica and muscle spasms ate away my physical and mental health as I prepared for medical school applications. Months later, an MRI arthrogram confirmed the torn labrum. As I visited Dr. Olufade, I recognized I had reached rock bottom. Determined to improve, I attended physical therapy over the next few months and did not let my injury deter me from providing support to others during the pandemic. During my recovery, I shadowed Dr. Gavaller, a geriatric physician. On our rounds, I studied the patient-physician interaction when battling chronic comorbidities. Retrospectively, fighting through my discomfort made me more empathetic and allowed me to understand better how to provide comfort to others

One such occasion was during a visit with Ms. R, a 92-year-old patient transferred to our facility after a cerebrovascular accident. She complained of worsening chest pain since her stroke with an inability to sleep. As I reviewed her medical chart, I was shocked. She had a history of a myocardial infarction secondary to coronary artery disease, further exacerbating her chest pain. She was previously prescribed nitroglycerin to manage her symptoms, but surprisingly, it was discontinued before the stroke. With her chronic conditions, pain, and sleeping difficulties, I knew the complexity of Ms. R's clinical intervention. As the physical assessment began, I informed Dr. Gavaller about the discontinued nitroglycerin, and she assured me she would order the prescription. The following day, the shine in Ms. R's eyes was impossible to ignore as she reported a whole night of sleep after dealing with weeks of unrest. For the first time in my life, I truly understood how impactful compassionate care could be. Listening to her concerns and incorporating them with a thorough physical exam and review of her past medical history, I was able to replace Ms. R's discomfort with comfort

What started as a flicker of hope during the dark moments of my journey has since ignited my calling in life. As I evolved along my path, each experience materialized into steps that prepared me to become a physician. I am excited and a touch nervous about this next step in life, but I am confident I will rise to the call. I hope the selection committee considers me favorably.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Due to the geographical distance, I learned to embrace Indian culture overseas. We planned our trip to the Padmanabhan Temple in Kerala during a visit. Before entering, devotees replace foreign clothing with a Dhoti. I instructed my sister to remove her watch when a man shouted, "He is American, not Indian." As we were forced to leave the temple, being discriminated against in my home country left me distraught. _x000D_
_x000D_
However, I am grateful it occurred upon reminiscing on the exchange. As a future medical student, my experience taught me the power of respecting fundamental human rights, such as the freedom of religion and the freedom of speech. I hope to use my experience to ensure that no patient feels the way I did that day. Given the diversity of the class, my journey made me confident that I can be part of a family that has a role in diminishing the inequalities we see as we become physicians that treat a diverse patient population.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
While assisting families at the Northlake Mall Vaccination Clinic in inner-city Atlanta, we talked about our lifestyles during the pandemic. I was shocked to hear stories that described a lack of education and safety regarding the COVID-19 vaccine. The absence of testing kits, clinics, and doctors only further exacerbated the stigmas regarding treatment. The disproportionate percentage of patients that were minorities demonstrated that pre-existing social inequalities tied to race, class, and access to healthcare were becoming increasingly stratified. _x000D_
_x000D_
By incorporating the stories of patients with clinical research, I realized the significance of what I was doing. I learned how urban medicine is directly responsible for ensuring that high-risk communities have strong social provision programs that address inadequate housing and access to healthcare. I am confident Rush University will allow me to work closely with communities to improve access to excellent preventative treatment._x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact:
Eager for an escape during COVID-19, I kicked a soccer ball around my yard, only to injure myself. Tylenol eased my discomfort, but as the pandemic climaxed and lockdown ensued, My pain worsened with the inability to see my primary care physician due to COVID-19 restrictions. Symptoms of sciatica and muscle spasms affected my daily activities while studying for the MCAT for months. Months later, an MRI confirmed I tore my labrum. _x000D_
_x000D_
As I fought to improve my physical and mental health, I continued to build upon my academic readiness by planning to retake the MCAT while volunteering at SummitRidge Behavioral Health Hospital. My experiences fighting through a debilitating injury let me connect with my patients. Battling through my discomfort made me more empathetic and drove me to understand how to provide comfort to others. As a future physician from Rush University, I plan to use these lessons to be a resilient and compassionate provider.

Hrdshp_Comments:
Born to an unprepared couple in a lower income neighborhood in St. Louis, my arrival placed additional strains on them. In an effort to improve living conditions, they took to sprucing up the older house exposing me to the dust of lead-based paint and sending me to the hospital with severe lead poisoning as an infant. My hospitalization was the first major incident that led my grandparents to financially and emotionally support my mother and I. Within the next year they suggested that we move to Nevada with them, allowing my mother escape the abuse of my biological father.  

In this new city, my mother and I were dependent upon the Women, Infant, and Children’s (WIC) program and the aid of my grandparents. Although some aspects of life improved, my well-being as a child was overshadowed by my mother’s vices. Better living conditions and opportunities came later when I was adopted, but did not fully shield me from the drugs and alcohol that were a bigger part of my biological mother’s life. Instead it instilled a sense of self-motivation, determination, and a strong desire to help others. I am grateful for the obstacles I have overcome to get to this point and hope to use the culmination of my experiences to better connect and support patients with diverse backgrounds.
personal_statement:
For as long as I can remember, strangers and acquaintances alike tacked years onto my actual age, often mistaking me for much older. Being raised by a single mother with lifelong substance abuse, and having to take care of her through multiple relapses, I was forced to grow up fast. By the age of seven, I had survived physical abuse and was accustomed to celebrating delayed holidays and birthdays at whichever jail or rehab my mother was in at that given time. Aware of the toxicity and impact this could have on my future, I was internally motivated to avoid becoming a statistic based on my mother’s disease of addiction. To cope with the instability, I sought refuge in my academics and sports, and successfully took control of my own life by entering the courts to obtain better guardianship. Taking charge of my disorderly childhood was the first of many steps in my path towards medicine, which at its core is fueled by a desire to help others in need.
 
As a first-generation college student, I became passionate about community health. I volunteered with outreach programs such as the Sunshine Nevada Organization and the local Community Emergency Response Team, which opened my eyes to the power of preventative health initiatives. These experiences helped guide my decision to pursue my Master’s in Public Health. Excited to explore the intersection between health policy and law, I ultimately found myself gravitating towards clinically-focused projects over the course of my studies. I was fortunate to work with the thoracic surgery department at Massachusetts General Hospital through an initiative that reduced patient wait times and eliminated redundancies in the scheduling process. As one of my first exposures to clinical medicine, I found this work intriguing and sought opportunities to continue engaging with patient care.
 
While drafting a policy brief to implement a clinic-based program focusing on childhood obesity, I came across the work of the Integrated Center for Group Medical Visits (ICGMV). Dedicated to increasing access to primary care with the use of group visits, this non-profit organization provides integrative healthcare to an underserved community and educates other medical professionals to do the same. What started as an informative interview for my project led to me volunteering for the center in any capacity needed at the start of the pandemic. After three months of helping expand the center to offer virtual group visits, scheduling training sessions, and coordinating group sessions for medical school residents, I was offered a long-term position. Since then, I have continued working to grow the organization by expanding partnerships with international organizations and foundations to provide more group programs for the community, as well as regularly engaging with physicians incorporating the group medical visit model into their own practices.
 
Through my role with ICGMV I have been fortunate to meet and work alongside many physicians motivated to reduce health disparities. By stepping into the clinic, I have had the opportunity to observe the role primary care physicians play in patient-centered care. I have observed physicians collaborate with patients to uncover the root cause of symptoms, utilize alternative methods to foster healing, and to empower patients to manage their own health through the support found in group visits. Directly witnessing the importance of the doctor-patient relationship and the power of providing holistic, integrative care in the midst of a pandemic was truly inspiring. These clinical experiences taught me how physicians can cultivate connection and serve as an advocate for their patients' lifelong health and well-being.
 
At the time, I had no idea that my path to medicine began with my early exposure to my mother’s disease of addiction. In the case of my mother’s life, preventative healthcare that incorporated mental health and social services may have made all the difference in her struggles with addiction. Perhaps this could even be provided as a group medical program, similar to the one for fathers with substance use disorder previously held by ICGMV where they collectively wrote a children’s book and received medical services and counseling. Witnessing the impact that physicians can have within their communities has been influential and confirmed my desire to practice medicine. I am deeply committed to spending my career improving the lives of my future patients as a physician in similar ways. I hope to implement my training in public health and organizational experience to work in a preventative health setting in which I can help provide multidisciplinary care to an underserved population.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I have been fortunate to gain exposure to the diversity of care delivery and the disparities between populations. Assisting the Department of Thoracic Surgery at Massachusetts General Hospital and conducting research with Lahey Hospital, highlighted the luxuries of Boston being a global healthcare hub. On the other end of the spectrum, serving as an intern for a pedorthic clinic, a volunteer and employee for ICGMV, as well as shadowing in an underserved community, I gained valuable insight into the patient‚Äôs perspective of health and healthcare. These experiences opened my eyes to community initiatives that could lessen the current barriers to primary care for people residing in diverse settings. Furthermore, by having the opportunity to interact with diverse patients I have become more aware of the barriers to care that low income communities face on a daily basis as well as gain a realistic understanding of what it takes to be a primary care physician in an underserved community.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: In 2020, I began helping the non-profit organization, ICGMV in a number of ways. I have made the most impact by assisting in the implementation of free, group programs for the community members of Lawrence, a city with the highest poverty in Massachusetts. Early programs included adult exercise classes that considered physical limitations and trauma-informed yoga with counseling. In the last year we have received a number of grants to start new programs such as a Nutrition and Functional Medicine program led by a dietitian to help patients learn how their bodies respond to food, an after-school pediatric empowerment program that promotes healthy lifestyles and exercise for community youth, and mental health groups that provide counseling and other health services for free. By helping acquire funding, coordinating  programs, and ensuring patient accessibility, I have had the opportunity to reduce barriers to care and help transform the overall health of the community of Lawrence
7_-_COVID_Impact: I began my post-baccalaureate program in May 2020 and was met with the academic rigor of learning science as a non-traditional student and doing so remotely. Similarly, plans of conducting in-person research with the opportunity to regularly shadow at the hospital were limited due to restrictions. The culmination of the internal pressures to excel academically, maintain my involvement with a non-profit, and uphold my fitness, in addition to the stress of the pandemic, triggered a battle with my own body. After many doctor visits and lab tests, I was diagnosed with an autoimmune disorder and was at the tail end of a three month flare. With the support of my physicians, I have since improved my health both medically and holistically. I am grateful to have experienced these challenges as they have allowed me to gain a greater perspective as a patient, better understand the demands placed on physicians, as well as given me the confidence to continue to face a challenging academic workload.

personal_statement:
On a lazy summer day, Dr. Mama was called into the hospital, and, with no immediate option for childcare, brought me, her 5-year-old, with her. Awaiting her return, I swiveled side to side in her massive office chair when suddenly she emerged to check on me. I beamed and asked what she was doing out there. Readying to leave, she explained, “Sometimes babies are born too early and get sick. I help them so that they can live.” As the door locked behind her, I realized how badly I wanted to be out there with her. I wanted to help the babies live, too. 
For most of my childhood, my parents kept us far from the hospital, which I later learned was their determination not to force their career on their children. However, the silence gnawed at me for years until one day, I asked Mom if she would take me to work with her in the NICU. That day, I experienced a light inside me as Mom moved from one room to the next, checking heartbeats, conferring with nurses, comforting her sleeping patients. Witnessing the personal and practical impact Mom had in the unit was gratifying because I could see the values instilled in me as a child come to life in a professional setting. In that moment, I promised myself that one day I would no longer live vicariously through Mom in her profession as a physician. Instead, I would become one. But first, I would need to explore my own passion for medicine.
Around the same time, I found myself drawn to the realm of psychology after facing the necessity of calling 911 for a friend who overdosed on pills in an attempted suicide. Captivated by the mechanisms underlying a person’s actions and wanting to alleviate the burdens of those in emotional pain, I joined Cornell’s Empathy, Assistance, and Referral Service (EARS) to engage in peer counseling. While counseling “Katie,” I could not ignore the pain in her eyes as she conveyed to me the difficulty she was having being understood in her classes due to her accent. At once, fear ravaged my mind, as I worried that I might struggle to understand her, too. However, somewhere in that anxious spiral, I remembered the wisdom given to me regarding the role of an EARS member: our job is to create an open, empathetic environment where people feel welcome to share themselves. As long as we have done that, we have fulfilled our goal. I took a breath, exhaling the clutter of my mind.
“It sounds like you’re feeling lonely because you want to build connections with your classmates and professors, but you fear they will misunderstand you. Does this sound correct to you?” Sure enough, she confirmed that I had heard her correctly, and we spoke for another hour, her sharing her story with me, and me reflecting it back to her so we could continue to explore her feelings about the situation. I ended my shift taking note of how I felt: fulfilled by the immediate impact I had on Katie’s wellbeing, but troubled knowing there was more to her story. I had helped her, but I had not healed her.
My time in EARS led me to seek out similar opportunities with a more diverse population and the possibility of life-threatening issues. This pursuit is how I found the Crisis Text Line and later, is how I found myself on the other side of a message from “Jamie” telling me that they were about to take all their pills and end their life. After an intense round of texts that almost resulted in my supervisor performing an active rescue, I tried approaching Jamie the same way I had simpler situations: “I’m hearing that you feel there is no way to escape your pain besides taking these pills, and it seems like no one can understand how you feel. It also sounds like you’re really wishing for someone to connect with so you can gain relief. Is that correct?” To my surprise, Jamie immediately softened, and I was able to keep them safe throughout the rest of our conversation. I thought to myself, what a crucial thing it is to feel heard and understood, even, or perhaps especially when one is physically and emotionally very close to death. In feeling what it was like to get someone through what I presume was one of the worst days of their life, so bad that they no longer wanted to be here, I felt inspired to become a physician and provide that same level of support to patients on the worst days of their lives as well.
My counseling experiences have taught me how passionate I am about personal connection within the role of a physician and accessible mental healthcare within medicine as a whole. After working with hundreds experiencing a variety of issues from everyday stress to impending suicide, I appreciated that to alleviate emotional and behavioral issues, I first had to connect with what the individual was experiencing, as they experienced it, before brainstorming any plan of action. I hope to be a physician so I may serve as a leader in my patients’ care by considering all aspects of their personhood, and to me, this process begins with a foundation of mutual trust and understanding. In addition to treating the ailments a patient presents to me, I aspire to connect with my patients in a way that leaves them feeling as though they have truly been seen. This, I believe, is a strength that transcends the boundary of physician and patient, bringing us to our knees in awe of our humanity.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: This year I have returned to work in New Orleans, and a great deal of the patients who enter our vaccination clinic are racial minorities, uninsured or publicly insured, and/or low-income. Many of these patients have not seen a doctor in years, and in these cases, we are their first interaction with healthcare in a long time. While I was fortunate enough to grow up with an attitude of trust towards medical professionals, I recognize that other folks may not have had the same experience. When patients are reluctant to put their bags down or trust us to shred their personal information, I am reminded that it is a privilege to be trusted by patients, and I must work to build a productive relationship with my all of my patients through rapport and empathetic approaches. It is extremely important to me that patients‚Äô time in our clinic is filled with warmth and respect so that they associate health with positivity despite what they might be experiencing in other parts of their lives.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
While learning about barriers to receiving treatment for mental health conditions, I was struck by how many obstacles individuals face in order to obtain adequate care. Issues such as stigma, expenses, and wait times prevent people from receiving the care they deserve. For this reason, I naturally gravitated towards activities in college that could help people having these experiences. _x000D_
_x000D_
One of the reasons I joined Crisis Text Line (CTL) was to help those who needed care but for one reason or another could not find professional help. Throughout my time on the platform, I have engaged with folks who cannot afford care or whose family will not let them seek care. While the nature of the work I do on the platform does not allow me to develop longitudinal relationships with texters, I do what I can in the moment, and I am elated that CTL keeps a directory of resources that I can share with texters, including ways to find affordable professional help such as counseling and support groups.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
Due to my parents working in hospitals and nursing homes, they contracted COVID-19 in early April 2020, leaving them bedridden for weeks. At the time, I felt terrified for my parents with a disease about which we knew very little. Fortunately, my parents eventually recuperated; however, they suffered lasting symptoms from their illness months after the fact. Also during this time, Cornell moved all operations fully online, which continued in some capacity throughout my junior year._x000D_
_x000D_
Additionally, I experienced professional barriers due to the COVID-19 regulations regarding unessential personnel in healthcare settings. My plans to serve as a volunteer at hospitals in Ithaca, NY and New Orleans, LA and to shadow physicians were regrettably canceled in 2020 and 2021. While I am remiss I was unable to actively participate at that time, I appreciate that these regulations were to ensure public safety, and I am savoring my current clinical activities.

personal_statement:
Three weeks into my freshman year, as I was walking to my dorm at night, a man came sprinting towards me.  He was yelling for help.  There was a girl on the ground.  She had been found in the bushes, unconscious and unclothed. I ran to the girl and dropped to my knees.  I told an observer to call our EMS agency, and I did everything I was taught as a lifeguard.  I felt for her pulse, checked her breathing, and asked questions to bystanders. She began to vomit, and I put her on her side. When EMS showed up, I updated them, and they took her to the hospital. As I watched the EMTs work, they executed new techniques that I had never seen before, and I found myself wanting to learn more. As the EMTs were leaving, one of them said “Great quick thinking, you may have saved her life.” I applied to the EMS team that night.  
Since an early age I have been exposed to the medical world through my mother, who is a pediatrician. I had the opportunity to shadow some of her fellow doctors, and I found myself mesmerized by the everyday duties of a doctor. When I got to college, I knew I wanted to pursue a pre-med path, so I sat down with my advisor and set out my entire class schedual for my four years. I have worked throughout high school and college preparing myself for medical school.
During the summer of 2020, I was asked to be the Medical Director at a YMCA camp in Rochester, NY.  The head of that YMCA camp quit on my very first day, and I had to learn to adjust very quickly.  The issues soon surpassed my EMT training. I was sitting on lunch break one day, when one of the teen campers asked if she could sit with me for a while. She chatted about small topics for a while, but I could tell she had something else she wanted to tell me. She eventually opened-up and confided in me that she wanted to kill herself. We continued to talk, and we made a plan.  We spoke with her parents and got her to start talking to a counselor. After the situation calmed down, I realized that EMT training did not teach me how to handle mental health issues. In the future I would like to learn how to handle these hard situations better. The camper was able to continue camp for the rest of the summer, and I was glad to see the big-picture improvements she made with her mental and physical health by August. 
Over the past eight years, I have learned about the medical field, and I have learned about myself. I have shadowed over 15 different types of doctors and increased my knowledge about the different types of medical fields. I observed the doctors I shadowed have good rapport and rapid response with patients, keeping up with emerging science and the big picture. One day I was shadowing a lactation doctor and she began showing a patient a new technique that she said she learned from a recent panel that she attended. Medicine is ever evolving, and it requires continuously learning new material. 
I’ve enjoyed many aspects of my medical journey, and I’ve most enjoyed seeing the positive outcomes of my work.  However, sometimes it can be rare to see the immediate impact of your efforts. For example, while I was working at a YMCA camp, a 6-year-old boy came up to me with a lash on his arm, asking for a band aid. I asked how he hurt himself, as camp had only been open a few minutes, and he replied that it wasn’t his fault. Eventually, he told me that his grandfather has been beating him and he didn’t want to go home. I sat him down with a popsicle and some coloring materials, discussed the situation with YMCA leadership, and went to have the hard talk with Child Protective Services. CPS talked with him that day and got all the information. The boy did go back that night to his family.  From what I learned, the child’s situation improved, but the problem wasn’t completely solved. This opened my eyes to the idea that in the medical field there are many external factors that come into play.  For a long time, I struggled with the idea that I could not completely fix the situation and have learned that I want more training in order to find more ways to help. Throught this experience I learned that health care is a teamwork activity that involves a web of resources available to patients. 
A few weeks after that night my freshman year, while waiting to hear back about my EMT application, I received a “thank you” email from the girl that I had helped. In the next hour, I got my EMS acceptance letter, and I have been working to help my community ever since. Throughout EMS, I have moved up in ranks into an M-1 position where I am the head EMT on all of the calls and work 24-hour shifts. I have enjoyed my time as a leader to the upcoming EMTs.  I have been able to teach them fundamental EMT skills, and they have been able to teach me new tips and tricks. As an EMT, there are many calls that have high stress energy from patients and bystanders that can lead to unsafe environments, so it is crucial to be able to read people and situations. EMS has taught me that I want more clinical experiences to improve my skills. 
I am motivated to build on my medical skills and excited to learn more to help my patients. I believe that all of my training, classes and life experiences have helped me in my journey towards becoming a doctor.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I have had the opportunity to be experience many diverse cultures and environments, such as study abroad, asthma camp for inner-city youth, campus clubs, and a variety of leadership positions.  Asthma camp is a free, 3-day overnight camp where under-privileged Rochester city children were taught how to manage their asthma symptoms while also maintaining healthy, active lifestyles.  As a camp counselor, I began to realize how little the campers knew about their asthma management. After sitting down and talking with them, I realized that they have disproportional access to quality health care. I also found that many of the campers from Rochester city spoke mainly Spanish, which made communication challenging. Throughout the years, I worked on my Spanish so I would be able to communicate and connect with my campers better. I began integrating Spanish in asthma education classes, organizing outdoor activities, educational materials for home, and an end of camp carnival.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I believe that the best way to reach and impact others is by connecting with them personally. I believe that my experiences, and how I use them to relate to others, makes me a unique individual.  When I was in high school, my older cousin, Mike, was walking home and was killed by a drunk driver. Years later, I realized how much this changed me. It allowed me to better empathize and understand patients.  As a camp counselor, I saw a camper who didn‚Äôt speak much English and didn‚Äôt interact closely with others. I ate lunch with him,and started a simple Spanish conversation. He opened up and explained that his grandma was in the hospital, after being struck by a drunk driver. I was able to empathize with him. Being a doctor isn‚Äôt just about medicine.  It is also about how we relate our experiences to one another. In the future, I hope to connect with my patients in this way in order to provide the best care possible.
7_-_COVID_Impact: March 2020 I was abroad in Maastricht Netherlands when I had to suddenly travel home to the US at 3 am. Once I got home, I had to quarantine in my parents' basement and Zoom in to my classes at 2 am because of the time change. Due to the lag in technology, and travel I missed a week of classes. This semester was an extreme challenge in both my studies and mental health. Over the semester I had to learn how to manage my mental health by taking breaks in studying to go for walks, taking time away from screens, and using mindful practices such as yoga. There was additional stress at home because my mother is a pediatrician who had to continue to work throughout the pandemic. Fall 2020, there was an increased need for EMS on campus due to covid, injuries and mental health issues. Many EMS staff were uncomfortable working, so we became an agency of only 6, which meant I was working over 24 hours each week and more of my time and energy went in to helping my community.

personal_statement:
My mother would often tell me the experiences she lived through during her time as a nurse in Mexico. From simple stories, such as taking care of the inebriated, to treating those involved in fatal car crashes or shootings. To me, my mom seemed like she could handle the most extreme sight after having witnessed as much as she has. However, one day, while out at a restaurant with my family, mid-conversation I lose consciousness and fall to the ground. When I came to, just a few minutes later, I would see my mother with tears running down her cheeks. She pulls me in and hugs me asking if I was okay. I could feel her shaking and I told her that I felt fine but she insisted that we head to the hospital. After a few doctor visits, it was concluded that it was a simple episode of vasovagal syncope. However, I never forgot the look my mom had when I woke up. I felt sadness but also anger and frustration towards myself. I could not help but feel responsible for bringing my mother to the point of tears. I began to think about how parents must feel seeing their children in far more critical states than my own. The pain and uncertainty of seeing a loved one in danger eats away at one’s being. As an EMT, I witnessed first-hand what it can be like. I was transporting a 5 month old boy to a Chicago pediatric hospital after the mother had brought him into an acute care center for a seizure. After receiving a report from the nurse, we get the patient ready, and head out on the hour and a half transport. I immediately noticed that the mother was rather anxious, her expression synonymous with my mother’s. I try to provide some reassurance; however, once we get unto the highway she starts hyperventilating, her hands begin to tremble, and she is on the verge of tears. I saw that the five month old was doing fine and turned my attention towards the mother. I tried to talk to her about anything that could take her mind off of the current situation. We talked about her kids, I hoped she could find strength in the love for her children and, thankfully, she was able to calm herself. I felt a greater appreciation for the training I received as an EMT. It gave me the confidence to stay calm in a tense situation and resolve it accordingly. Something that I felt I was unable to do for my mother at the restaurant, now, I am able to do for others.

Many days later, I pick up a military recruit from a VA hospital who was being admitted to a behavioral health facility. When I first met him he did not say a word and kept his head pointed towards the ground. My initial thought was that he was simply exhausted it was around 3 in the morning after all. During transport we started talking about our high school experiences. He told me that he had participated in marching band and that his school had one of the most competitive marching bands in the state. I was taken aback by how much physical training they went through and expressed my amazement at his ability to endure through it all. As we continued talking I noticed that he was feeling a little more comfortable with me, and eventually he talked about the situation in which he found himself in. He told me that he had been sexually assaulted while going through boot camp. He once again turned his gaze towards the ground and a cold silence filled the room. I was not sure of what to say, I don't think there was much I could have said that would have made his world seem less bleak at the time. Yet, I kept talking to him trying to help him in what could possibly be the darkest and loneliest moment of his life. The patient is now faced with unforeseen obstacles through no fault of his own, yet possibly reflecting on his past with regrets. A truly scary and lonely feeling. It is an ugly part of reality; however, one that should not be dealt with alone. Any and all thoughts of what I had going on in my life vanished and only that moment mattered to me. I felt a tremendous sense of responsibility, not simply as an EMT, but as a human being. For him to share something so personal and open up to me, I can only imagine he must have felt something resembling how I felt when I cried to my parents about a school bully as a child. I vividly remember feeling so helpless, vulnerable, and genuinely afraid. However, once my parents took me into their arms and assured me that everything would be alright, that's when I felt truly safe, as well as what I could only describe as love. I realized then what it meant to truly care for others, and how much one simple act of kindness can mean to someone. Many years later, I would be confronted with yet another bully. Only then, it would be my friends that would come to my aid.

Through my friends and family, I was able to come as far as I have, and for them I will strive even further and work towards my goals. Thanks to my medical training and experiences as an EMT, I was able to mature and assist those who found themselves facing adversity. From the mother with an ill child, to the military recruit who lived through something few could truly understand. I wish to continue to help many more like them by going to medical school. As well as to grow, both into someone my family and I can be proud of, and into someone that is a good role model for future generations.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As an EMT, I once transported an older male patient from a facility to a behavioral health hospital. From the time we met, he was very adamant about being uncooperative as well as disrespectful. I wondered why he was being the way that he was towards someone that he's never met. He lashed out at my partner and showed no interest in receiving any sort of help. However, once we arrived at the receiving facility, he seemed to be more cooperative and even engaged in conversation with the security guards working there. I wondered what had changed, at first I thought he was simply intimidated by them, but then he asked one of the guards where he was from. It then hit me that the patient was possibly just defensive against others who did not visibly appear to be able to understand his situation or past experiences. I was ashamed that I had possibly misjudged him. It should be possible to disagree with someone and still respect each other; however, I learned that it is not always so simple.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As an older sibling, I hope that I have made the right decisions in order to set an example for my brother. I once had a conversation with a military recruit and I mentioned that I believed setting high expectations for my brother would hinder his confidence and that I did not wish for him to feel like he was behind. He said that I was mistaken, that my brother would see everything I had done and that those accomplishments themselves would encourage him to reach for new heights. I was able to reflect on what it meant to have certain expectations of others and came to my own conclusion. As fate would have it, some time after that my brother would mention to my mom that he felt as if she had unrealistic expectations of him. I was able to tell him right then and there, that the only reason my parents pushed him was because they knew that he was more than capable of achieving his goals. Of course, I was simply expressing my own feelings on the matter. I will continue to watch as he grows.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I had multiple family members get COVID-19, some of whom were unable to obtain good health care as they lived in underserved communities. Being unable to visit nearby family and to not physically be there for them when they were sick or hurt was a very isolating and saddening feeling. I read of many businesses shutting down because they could not survive the lockdown. I was fortunate enough that around the start of the pandemic I had begun my job as an EMT which allowed me to continue to earn money as well as patient care experience. During the pandemic, it was very difficult for me to obtain volunteering opportunities. I contacted hospitals, searched online, and reached out to fire and police departments hoping to do a ride along; but, none were able to offer an opportunity for a student to participate in. Access to letters of recommendation was also difficult as establishing meaningful relationships with professors was a challenge in an online learning platform.

Hrdshp_Comments: I was born in Iraq seven years before the Iraqi-Freedom war during the rule of the dictator Sadam Hussein who killed several of my family members due to our minority religious affiliation and forced us to leave our hometown. Years after the war, terrorist groups controlled major cities, leading to inhumane conditions for my family, so we fled to the United Nations refugee camps. We were granted a special immigration visa to come to the U.S. after terrorist groups targeted us due to my family's work with the U.S. embassy in Baghdad. Being a refugee meant more than just a title for me; it meant starting a new life and leaving everything behind. In 2016, we arrived in the U.S., and I was 19 years old. At the time, we came with only 1000 dollars to keep us on our feet, so I worked full-time to provide for my family, and I withheld my education temporarily. I was able to build my credit and move my family out of our friend's home, all while saving money to pursue my dream of higher education. Throughout college, I had to support my parents in assimilating to the American culture by teaching them English and helping them apply for jobs. I want my journey to be a reminder of hope for people who faced similar hardships and influence them to pursue higher education.
personal_statement:
“Red or black?”A terrorist asked and stopped me in my tracks. I saw his eyes staring at my brother, Rusul, next to me. I knew these colors represent two religious affiliations, and if I answered incorrectly, the consequences would be fatal. I observed their clothing that accumulated dust, probably while crossing the desert west of Baghdad, through which I recognized their affiliation. I nervously said, “What were the colors?” and he laughed. Luckily, due to our young age, Rusul and I were let go, but as they were preparing to move on, they shot an innocent civilian and left him to die. When Rusul and I took the wounded civilian to the hospital, there was only one physician who was left to assist a growing number of victims. I was frustrated to see victims filling hallways with no chance to be seen, and the physician-to-patient ratio triggered me to take action. I learned how to perform first-aid procedures by reading first-aid and gross anatomy textbooks after teaching myself English, and my frustration turned into motivation to continue learning.  

One night when my cousin and I were shopping in our local market, I could feel the ground under me begin to tremble after a force threw me on my back. In the silence after the explosion, I got up searching for my cousin. I found him slightly injured, so I helped control his bleeding. I heard my neighbor, Morad, in his piercing scream shout, “Get out! They are burning down the city!” Supplies were depleted, and the adrenaline pumped my racing heart to run to the nearest residential area. I knew that responders would take hours to arrive, and I could not bear the idea of letting others bleed while waiting hours for help. So I went door-to-door, asking for any first aid kits people would spare. I returned and applied what I learned to help Morad and others whose injuries I could reasonably manage. Despite my efforts and those of others, some did not make it. Taking away the pain of survivors and increasing their chances to live after experiencing hard circumstances ignited my heart and fueled my desire to pursue medicine.

After leaving Iraq and relocating to California, while I was volunteering at our local hospital, Rusul was brought to the emergency room experiencing an aneurysm. Unfortunately, there was no available neurosurgeon, and he needed to be transferred. By that time, doctors had lost hope. As my parents and our doctors were holding hands, tears filled their eyes when I translated for them what the doctors meant by “Brain dead.”It was shocking to me to realize that even with some of the best technology in the world, living in an underserved community jeopardized Rusul’s chance to survive. I also saw the need to innovate new approaches to treatment that could enhance outcomes and stabilize patients, especially if immediate care is not possible. I knew that training to be a  physician would allow me to explore different treatment approaches and one day determine how best to improve patient outcomes. 

As the COVID-19 pandemic raged on, the City of Hope Cancer Center stopped allowing visitors to accompany patients. I knew the importance of having a support system after my brother’s death, so I was compelled to volunteer and serve as a liaison between patients and their families. "Lily" who only spoke Arabic, once told me that she felt embarrassed to ask for help carrying the spoon and that she could not eat on her own. Every time I helped her eat, she would laugh as I held the spoon, waiting for the hot food to get colder, and she would say, “You didn’t do the chew-chew train.” While it was a very rewarding experience, I wanted to provide Lily with the care that relieves her symptoms and allows her to carry the spoon on her own. After I taught Lily essential words in English to break the language barrier, I saw her positive demeanor change when she knitted hats for everyone. The barrier was broken, and she was more comfortable continuing to seek treatment, showing me that healing the body without healing the soul is incomplete healing. 

It does not matter what side of the globe you are on, facing terrorism or a life-threatening disease; there is always a need for someone who can act quickly and critically to provide treatment while compassionately healing the soul. The aneurysm that took my brother away and the challenges associated with treating such cases highlighted many opportunities for improvement. My interactions at City of Hope taught me the importance of individualizing our health care and breaking the barrier between patients and physicians. I was born during a war, and the first memory of my life is in an underground shelter waiting to get out. I knew that when I got out, I would have to fight. Therefore, I will fight through medicine to lift the spirits of patients after chaos consumes them. I will learn and fight to develop strategies to efficiently treat patients in underserved communities and ensure they will get the chance for quality, holistic care. I will fight for a model of medicine that incorporates social justice and equal access to healthcare. For that, I will become a physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: While volunteering at City of Hope, many of our patients receive treatment for many terminal diseases such as cancer. On one of my shifts, I noticed that the same woman was sitting and praying before her appointment. When I offered her a coffee, she shared with me that she is accustomed to praying with her daughter before she sees her doctor in hopes that she will hear good news about her health progress. Since the pandemic forced many facilities to enforce a strict no-visitors policy, I told her that I would be more than happy to pray with her so she would not be alone. Although I did not share the same religion as her, I saw the importance that spirituality and faith can have on the healing of a person. As a future physician, I hope to provide my support to patients by respecting their faith during challenging times and advocating for their right to practice their spiritual beliefs to provide the best treatment plan possible.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Through working at JDO Mediterranean Inc., I witnessed food insecurity that is faced by individuals in my community. The numbers were shocking, and I realized it was impossible to alleviate the problem without collective efforts, so I advocated for this issue with other local businesses, and I arranged weekly meetings to discuss how to combat food insecurity in our local community. At first, multiple businesses rejected my proposal, so we had to continue alone for some time. When they witnessed our impacts, a few businesses decided to contribute to our efforts. Later on, we started distributing free meals. This experience taught me the impact of working hard to be successful and to learn from my experiences. Through collaboration and advocacy, we can make a larger impact on our community. In being persistent in similar situations, I can learn to overcome barriers I may face and develop solutions to achieve my goals.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Our lab‚Äôs review paper was delayed due to the inability to collect data during the pandemic, so I volunteered at our community hospital. Observing how tirelessly healthcare providers attended to the growing number of patients and treated each one with individualized and compassionate care inspired me to continue my pursuit of medicine. At this time, my brother was rushed to the ER for a brain aneurysm, later losing his life indirectly due to staff shortages and long ambulance arrival times. I rescheduled my MCAT and took a gap year to support my family financially and emotionally throughout our grieving process. Witnessing the toll that healthcare facilities faced and supporting my family, I saw how valuable it is to have support from loved ones during these circumstances. My experiences during the pandemic fueled my desire to continue volunteering and supporting patients and their families in times of need.

personal_statement:
My first exposure to the medical world came abruptly one day as my mom drove me home from school. We were about 3 minutes away from reaching our house when she suddenly began screaming in pain and clenching her stomach. Scared and confused, I asked her what was going on. With her hands tightly clutching onto her stomach, she asked me to steer the car instead. I immediately complied and she switched between the gas and brake pedals as I directed us onward. After miraculously making it home, my family rushed her to the Emergency Room. She squeezed my hand tightly the entire ride there. Once inside the ER, a doctor came in to tell us she had gallstones. After noticing the shock and devastation that formed on our faces, the doctor reassured us that my mom would be okay. I thought to myself, "How can he so calmly and confidently tell us that she will be okay when I just witnessed her in such excruciating pain?". Even though this question remained in my head, the way he comforted us made me feel obliged to trust his words. As he predicted, my mom underwent a successful Cholecystectomy that permanently relieved her of Gallstones. As traumatic an experience as this was, it made me feel good that I was able to be there for my mom in a time when she needed someone most. From making sure we got home safely to giving her a sense of belonging by holding her hand, I felt content about how I handled this situation. The doctor's reassurance and successful procedure made me sincerely appreciate the service physicians provide, which ultimately sparked my interest in the field of medicine.  
 
After this experience, I wanted to learn more about what it means to work in the medical field, so I began volunteering in the same Emergency Department where my mom was diagnosed with gallstones.
