From restocking IV carts to making sure patients had clean blankets and socks, there was always a sense of responsibility that I felt every time I stepped into this environment. The dynamic environment of the ED made me realize the importance of consistent communication and teamwork. Every person had a unique role to fulfill which could not be done without the input and instructions provided from person to person. I felt constantly busy making sure both nurses and physicians had the proper medical supplies to optimally treat the patient, which was only possible by maintaining communication with the medical professionals and my fellow volunteers. Feeling part of the team and being able to make patients feel secure was a great feeling which further stimulated my curiosity in medicine. 

Volunteering in the ED gave me a sense of the workflow that medical professionals have on a day to day basis, however, I was eager to learn more about physician patient interactions. This led me to begin shadowing doctors at both outpatient clinics and hospitals. In addition to attentively listening to the conversations between patients and providers, I was able to gain more and more responsibilities over time, first checking vitals, then scribing, and even seeing patients on my own to collect a thorough review of systems. This allowed me to converse with the patients and learn more about their medical concerns. 

During these patient rounds, I encountered an elderly patient diagnosed with dysthymia. He explained to me how he is a retired surgeon with no one but his caregiver to look after him. He had recently gone on vacation and informed me that he experienced random onsets of depressive symptoms, which made him feel helpless and vulnerable. This being my first encounter with a patient suffering from depression, all I could think of was what I could do to make him feel comfortable and content in my presence. We found a mutual interest in our favorite sports, particularly basketball, which led to a long and memorable conversation. As he was leaving, he shook my hand and said "thank you" with a particular look of appreciation on his face. In that moment, I realized that while I could not directly address his symptoms or give him any advice regarding his mental health, our friendly conversation was something he desperately needed. Clinical experiences like these not only broadened my knowledge in the medical field, but affirmed my goal of becoming a physician who through active listening and compassion is able to make a difference in patient’s lives.

Through the experience with my mom and her gallstones, I learned the importance of having someone support you during your most difficult moments and reassure you that things will be okay. My experience in the ED taught me the significance of teamwork in a medical environment and what its success can do for patient well-being. Through shadowing and scribing, my knowledge of medicine grew exponentially and the power of active listening taught me what it really means to be a provider that can impact their patient through their expertise and communication. Indeed, knowledge of science and medicine is a major component of being a physician, but showing compassion, empathy, and genuine care are just as crucial. People are not just beings who can be defined by a chart or characterized in a report, but rather unique humans with their own circumstances that deserve a provider who makes them feel comfortable.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: My high school hosted special olympics for disadvantaged kids which "Alex", a kid in my gym class was a part of. He was always isolated and watched from the sidelines as we played basketball. Knowing that he would be participating in basketball at special olympics, I approached him and asked him to shoot around with me. Due to his down syndrome, it was difficult for me to communicate with him so I passed him the ball and demonstrated how to shoot. The next day, he came up to me with a big smile on his face making the same shooting motion implying that he wanted to shoot around again. Spending every gym period with Alex made it easier for me to communicate with him overtime, and I noticed his confidence and comfort around me exponentially increased. I started looking forward to gym class because of the positive energy he would bring every day, and I realized that all it took to spark our friendship was a friendly approach between two individuals who didn't let social barriers intervene.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Located in Chicago, Masjid-Al-Fatir is a place of worship which gets minimal donations compared to other mosques in the Chicago area. Due to their lack of funds, it was difficult for them to hire a prayer leader and organize prayers during the month of Ramadan. Due to my experience as a youth leader in my mosque and ability to lead prayer, I was able to reach out to them and volunteer as a prayer leader without payment. Grateful for the opportunity, I advertised Masjid-Al-Fatir at my local mosque to urge people to contribute to donations and volunteer for prayer organization during this month. Overtime, the number of people attending prayers at Masjid-Al-Fatir gradually increased to the point where I was able to lead prayers at this mosque for consecutive Ramadans in a row. I developed a strong bond with the community there and continue to involve myself however I can every Ramadan. My goal is to bring this mindset to RMU and contribute to aiding underserved areas of Chicago.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The pandemic both positively and negatively affected my journey to medical school. Using my part time income to pay for the remainder of my college tuition after FAFSA was difficult following my unemployment due to the pandemic. My only option was to use my dad's unemployment benefits which were primarily used to pay for our household bills. I was also looking to seek research experience following my transfer to UIC which was difficult due to many opportunities being closed due to the ongoing pandemic. Desperately seeking employment, I was inspired by our frontline healthcare workers and the sacrifices they made for their communities during this crisis. I decided that if I was to work it had to include aiding people through this pandemic which is why I started working as a medical assistant/lab technician whose primary job was to work with potential Covid-19 infectious patients. Because of the pandemic, I was able to gain more clinical experience and assist people through this crisis.

personal_statement:
Oftentimes I think back to my Puerto Rican mother's smile as she slowly traced my collarbone with an oil potion made from acacia flowers, hopeful that the ritual would ward off evil energy and sickness. My Spanish father would slice our aloe vera plant to release its cool, sticky sap onto the cuts on my skin after a fall instead of giving me a band-aid. Early memories of my parents cutting their chalky blood pressure pills in half to prolong the prescription are still clear in my mind. As a child, my concept of health and disease was shaped by two non-traditional, anti-science parents. I was not allowed to be vaccinated against HPV or ever finish a full dose of antibiotics. I grew up in a household that was deeply skeptical of modern medicine, and seeing the impact this had on my parents’ lives has made it my mission in life to change that sentiment.
 
At the start of my undergraduate career, I began volunteering at a medical clinic for the underserved to better understand my upbringing and the disparities that were present in the local community. Many clinic patients had stories of abuse that, in addition to their decreased health literacy, left them feeling vulnerable when seeking help. A formative encounter was observing a physician explain high cholesterol to a patient. After finding out that he worked in appliance repair, the physician told him to visualize the condition as if a drain was being clogged. The patient visibly relaxed and smiled, saying “what can I do to unclog it!” The physician laughed and proceeded to talk about the recommendations, building a common framework to achieve their goal together. Watching this relationship form, I admired how he patiently took the time to understand the patient’s perspective. I value the skill of transforming complex medical knowledge into a tool that prioritizes patient success and comprehension to improve adherence. I am devoted to using the investigative nature of medicine alongside education to include patients in the conversation about their health.


After seeing the impact that a physician’s approach has, I became dedicated to providing not only myself and my parents but also my community with evidence-based information to improve their quality of life. When patients confide in me about traumatic experiences, I strive to make them feel heard and dignified. “Jan”, a clinic patient that became very close to me, suffered from domestic violence for years. She cried about her 300-pound body and said that there were no options other than prayer to improve her condition. Each week we worked on breaking down nutritional labels and talked about ways to make better food choices to alleviate her swollen ankles. She was not alone as I told her I previously dealt with overeating during emotional times. From our connection, I noticed she became more open when we spent time together. In the span of several months, she lost weight and developed greater confidence to speak up about her health concerns. I found that empowering others to be their own advocates while making science accessible has become an answer I once sought out when first leaving home. 


During my four years of exploring evidence-based care, I was able to receive my HPV vaccine and have fruitful conversations with my parents about what my experiences in the medical field have yielded. My appreciation for education has led them to make strides in supporting my journey as well as their own. Now, my mother sends me medical articles while my father loves the Institute of Human Anatomy Youtube channel. After working with Jan, I showed my parents the same nutrition techniques. My mother started plating her arroz con gandules in measured portions, which has helped my father lead a more active lifestyle. Through my persistence in sharing the importance of health information, they have found a space to enjoy the art of medicine alongside their non-empirical beliefs. The impact that health education had on my family helps fuel my passion to become a physician who dedicates time for patients to develop a deep understanding of how behavior affects wellbeing. 


I am inspired to be a physician who provides care for patients by working with their perspectives of disease instead of against them. It is crucial to show patients how to conceptualize their health in a way that is relevant to their lives and experiences. When caring for Jan and all the clinic visitors, I see reflections of my mother and father. I started my journey to medicine trying to help my parents learn to trust in science and in the midst of that, I saw my passion in doing the same for others. My mom still delivers the same oil ritual when she sees me, but I now close my eyes and partake with her. I understand that her actions are out of love and compassion. The realization is clear; it is with this same compassion in my heart that I wish to grow with my patients in the future. As I continue to advance my scientific proficiency in a future medical program, I will motivate my patients to be active leaders in their health decisions because the answers I once sought out became personal experiences that inspire me to be a dedicated, humanistic physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As a public health undergraduate, I had the opportunity to participate in a Virtual Exchange Program with medical students from Egypt. While creating our project on disaster preparedness, ‚ÄúMaha‚Äù repeatedly apologized for her English to which I encouraged that her voice was valued in our discussion. Over time she opened up, sending us pictures of her kushari or fish with sayada rice over text. I made efforts to strengthen our connection by learning greetings in Arabic or understanding time zones before suggesting when to meet. This program positively impacted my openness about diverse approaches to problem-solving, crucial in an interdisciplinary medical setting. I actively understand that my future peers and patients will have different perspectives because of their unique lived experiences. I am ready to challenge my ways of thinking and build common ground as a team to achieve a goal. Driven to expand my cultural competency, I will uplift those different from myself at Rush.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As a Cancer Center Intern, my work focused on increasing access to cancer screenings and vaccine uptake in our community. During cervical cancer screening day, I took a phone call with ‚ÄúCarla‚Äù, a single mother with no transportation to receive her pap smear. I spoke to her on the phone in Spanish and reassured her we had organized an Uber to get her the care she deserved. That day I was reached 50 women in the community. As a witness to many families like Carla with lack of access to care, I understand that health is influenced by many factors. Motivated to help others in the same shoes, my team utilized a mobile bus for health check-ups outside neighborhoods. The bus eliminated barriers such as transportation and parking costs. As a future physician, I will address social determinants of health and work with the needs of my patients and greater community to support their goals. I hope to meet patients where they are and equip them with resources to reduce the disparities they face.
7_-_COVID_Impact: During the pandemic, I came home for several months to protect my father who was at high risk due to being in his seventies. The initial feelings of shock were replaced by an active desire to help and use education as a tool to alleviate others‚Äô anxiety from the overwhelming flood of information. As a public health major, I was presented with an opportunity to educate myself about the pandemic through an online course that analyzed the historic, social, medical, and artistic influences of previous pandemics and COVID-19. I used this knowledge to help my close and extended family in Spain and Puerto Rico better grasp the situation. I was able to witness how education played a significant role in reducing stress among individuals who were not familiar with interpreting medical information. These moments further solidified my passion to become a physician that focuses on health education, literacy, and delivering care for patients in a meaningful context.

Under_School: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
personal_statement:
My heart started racing, it was only my second call as a probationary member of the Virginia Tech Rescue Squad and I was scared to see what waited for us. We wound our way into the depths of the dorm, which felt dark, even under the harsh fluorescent lighting. I took a deep breath and turned the corner. I saw two police officers standing on either side of a student, applying pressure to his wrists. He was sitting in a chair with his head slumped over in despair. I know him. “Sam” had been at my house the week before laughing and watching movies with our friends. My stomach sank, I didn’t even know he had depression. As we tended to his injuries Sam mentioned that this should have all been “fixed” by now. He shared that he just started a new medication for depression, but it wasn’t working, and he felt hopeless. On our way to the hospital, the lead clinician explained how these medications can take a while to work and what other resources could help him alongside those medications.
I really admired the way the clinicians on that call took the time to share their knowledge with Sam. The misunderstanding of his own diagnosis and a timeline for treatment could have ended his life. Looking back, Sam and other patients like him, solidified my passion for healthcare and patient advocacy. As I became a team leader, I pushed myself and those around me to focus more heavily on all mental health-related calls from panic attacks to the more extreme. I made sure patients knew they had all of our focus and time so we could build trust and get them the resources or the education they needed.
That night also showed me that there are more important changes that need to be made to help first responders cope with the emotions that come with witnessing trauma. While this is not unique to EMS, I knew I could make meaningful changes in the way my squad handled these calls. I made a commitment to myself to create an atmosphere that encouraged all of us to talk about our feelings with each other or an appropriate resource. My hope is that a culture change would not only help us to better support our patients but the health of our clinicians and the longevity of their careers in the medical field. I made sure my crews were familiar with our local mental health resources for themselves and their patients. We debriefed every call, especially the tough calls, and I made sure they knew they could talk to me if they needed help. My goal was to make sure that every person I trained learned to lean on each other and their resources so we could intervene early for each other and our patients.
As a team leader, I responded to a call for difficulty breathing. I found the patient, “Jen”, sitting on the floor gasping for air. Her fists were balled up and her eyes nervously scanned the ground in a panic. I cleared the room so only myself, the patient, and some equipment remained. I sat on the ground across from the patient and talked her through some breathing techniques to calm her down. After a few minutes, Jen was able to tell me a bit about what happened. She shared how overwhelming her year had been and her concern that asking for help would damage her career prospects. I shared with her my concerns if she choose not to seek treatment, especially after she indicated that her more recent thoughts had started to scare her. Jen agreed to come with us for an evaluation once I reassured her that we could help her and that she was not wasting our time. This is one of the few times I feel like I got the opportunity to help someone in a preventative way and I credit my experiences with patients like Sam for pushing me to train harder for these calls.
At the start of 2021, I decided to leave my lab job to pursue a career in medicine. Going to medical school wasn’t part of my plan, but during my first job out of college working in a lab, I spent many long hours reflecting on my life. I found that most of all, I looked forward to my 14 hours of EMS duty a week, where I got to focus on patient care. The passion I had for research hadn’t changed, however, I craved more integration of my research with patient care. I spent a lot of time thinking about Sam and how much more I could do for him with more experience, education, and training. My decision to go into medicine was exciting and daunting, but once I reflected on how I really wanted to spend my career, I realized that I wanted to focus on developing relationships with patients and creating care plans to improve their lives.
Treating patients and training new clinicians is where I’ve found my niche, and I’ve realized I would like to do more of both. My time in EMS was filled with seeking out training opportunities to better myself and increase my scope of practice, but I still have more to learn. I want to build a career that allows me to empower my patients through education about their health and to share my passion with the generations of clinicians who follow me. More than anything, I want to spend my life doing work that I’m proud of, solving problems I care about. Being a physician would allow me to continue to explore all of the issues I am passionate about now, but with the tools, knowledge, and experience to be able to make a wider, longer-lasting impact on the lives of my patients.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
I come from a non-traditional blended family with siblings and extended family representing multiple races and ethnicities. Even among my siblings, we represent several races and ethnicities, share different combinations of parents, and were raised in vastly different environments and economic circumstances. I grew up in a multi-generational home with parents that were always there to help people in need._x000D_
Surrounded by people who have different beliefs and experiences, I learned the importance of being inclusive and supportive of others; that there are barriers to opportunities that have nothing to do with individual merit or potential; and that by being an advocate and an ally you can change lives. These are the values I live by._x000D_
Having such a positive, richly diverse family experience has sparked in me a love for meeting new people who come from different backgrounds and places. I look forward to continuing to expand my worldview through the lenses of Chicago‚Äôs diverse population.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
When I joined Virginia Tech Rescue Squad there was a mindset surrounding training where the trainee should prove themselves over and over until they are deemed worthy of the role. Additionally, despite our 40-person squad having nearly 70% female membership, only two were cleared as team leads. As I went through my own clearance process to become a team leader, I considered what changes might make our process more inclusive so we could clear more diverse and better team leaders._x000D_
Once it was my turn to step into the role of training the next generation of team leaders I set clear intentions to tailor each person‚Äôs training process to their specific needs. I saw every new member as capable of taking on any role they desired, and my role as the trainer was to help them find the right combination of tools to get there. With time, I taught others to view the training process the same way and our team leaders became a stronger and more diverse group in gender representation and personality.
7_-_COVID_Impact: My volunteer work as an EMT during the Covid pandemic compelled me to work towards applying to medical school, a year after graduation. Because of this, I have fewer recommendation letters and less shadowing experiences than I would like to have at this point. Per the policy at my university, I am no longer eligible for a committee letter due to the amount of time that has passed since I graduated. Additionally, I no longer have relationships with any faculty members from whom I could have requested a letter. I do have letters from people who are intimately familiar with my passions, clinical experiences, and journey in medicine. Finally, while I have completed some in-person shadowing, I was not able to start until May and was only able to shadow one specialty in person. This did not give me the time necessary to establish a strong enough relationship with the physician to get a recommendation letter. I am seeking out more diverse shadowing experiences before entering medical school.

personal_statement:
While brushing “Eve’s” hair and separating it into sections for her favorite braids, I hear a holler down the hall. I assure Eve I will be back and run toward “Ann”. I enter her apartment with a smile and ask if she needs help. She returns my politeness with a soft smile, but I see worry in her eyes. She grabs my hand and asks where her husband is. I say that her daughter will be in this afternoon. She lights up for a moment, but then asks if her husband will be in too. I tell her I am not sure, but point to a picture of him on the wall and ask if that handsome man is hers. The worry fades as she shares about her fifty year marriage. As I fix her pillow, cover her feet with a blanket, and listen to her recall her journey of love, I wonder where I will be when I am 93 years old. I hope I will be as eager to recall my happiness as she is, but as my dad always says, “hope is not a tactic; where you end up is a result of the choices you make and the goals you set.”

As a child, I was fascinated by learning and enjoyed challenging myself. In high school, this manifested into the goal of attending The University of Michigan. After reaching it, I realized that in setting my next goal, I would be making a decision for my future career. My love for science drew me towards the medical field.

Working in Dr. Corfas’ research lab facilitated a real world connection to the textbook science that fascinates me. I took part in the problem solving and discovery that occurs in research. I explored how experiments present real data in need of analysis. Mouse brain dissection, sectioning with a cryostat, immunofluorescent staining, and microscope analysis took precision, interpretation, relearning, adjusting, and complex thought about why results occurred. Research took me outside of the classroom and scratched my knowledge-seeking itch in a new way. I grew through this experience and ultimately realized that science, analysis, and continued discovery is what excites and drives me.
 
Along with my passion for science, I have a desire to care for others. This has manifested itself in an outreach with children including being a family nanny, volunteering at preschools, being a penpal, and helping children in a classroom setting. Encouraging children to find their passion, to express their feelings, and to be curious is a huge joy in my life. Watching Natalie’s cheer routine, helping Priscilla learn the word ‘bioluminescence’, or writing to Janelle about my lab experiments all make a difference in not only the child’s life, but in mine too. Through these experiences, I have realized how understanding another person’s emotions is essential in building trust and creating healthy relationships. Furthermore, my involvement in classroom settings has exercised the passion I have for sharing knowledge and finding ways to explain new information to others.

Knowing that caring for children excited me, I sought to discover if patient care excited me too. To this point, I had only cared for healthy children, but care offered by a medical doctor would be very different. I explored this by becoming a certified nurse aide. Working as a caregiver at a senior living facility revealed that my passion for care was not solely for healthy children. Seeing the difference I could make in not only a resident’s life, but the impact care and kindness can have on a whole family has been life changing. Giving someone a smile and caring touch while explaining what is happening, how I can help, and asking what they need from me is something I am proud to do on a daily basis with my residents. I have supported residents as they decline and join the hospice community with a priority on comfort care. Offering a family reassurance that their loved one is well taken care of when they can’t be with them and explaining what care is given takes a little weight off their shoulders. As a caregiver, I take some burden away, and I will continue to do so as a medical doctor. The patience and resilience I have gained from working with the elderly community has helped me grow as a human being, and the experience has helped me discover that science is not the only part that excites me about a career in the medical field; it is the patients and families that I am able to care for as well.

Becoming a medical doctor will allow me to continue studying science with the promise of continuous learning and the opportunity to show compassion, patience, and kindness. I am excited for a career as a medical doctor bringing my love for scientific application, biological processes, problem solving, learning, and teaching together with my passion for care. When I am 93, I want to look back on my life in awe of how I lived with compassion, curiosity, and discovery. I want to recall a career that allowed me to explore modern science and the wonders of the human body. I want to recall a career that allowed me to take the burdens of countless families. I want to recall the opportunities for teaching the science of the body that amazes me to those in need of a simple explanation. I want to recall that applying to medical school led to the greatest adventure of my life because it opened the door to a career igniting all my passions.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: At my job, I am of the minority race. When Yovan got hired, I knew we would get along. She is funny, straight forward, and hardworking. Soon after we met, we started to bond. Having three children, Yovan can be my mother one second and my gossip buddy the next. One day, I made a joke Yovan thought was hilarious, and she said she enjoyed working with me. I responded saying ‚Äòwhat like you‚Äôre surprised?‚Äô. She answered honestly, saying she thought I was going to be another stuck-up white girl. Part of me was happy I proved her initial thought wrong and the other part sad others had given her that perspective. We have gotten a lot closer since then. We‚Äôve talked about her being a single mother, the struggle of not owning a car, the black lives matter movement, the societal racism she‚Äôs felt.  She has a lot to share with me. My friendship with Yovan has taught me how important listening is. To be heard is important; Yovan and I can hear each other even if our backgrounds are very different.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Last summer, I worked with a girl who became one of my close friends. She struggled with mental health, had a brother with special needs, didn‚Äôt know her father, and had an abusive relationship with her mother. She rode the bus to and from work every day struggling to get by financially and to provide care for her brother. We became close friends after only a few weeks of working together, and after learning a little about her life, I offered her a ride to and from work. We lived only minutes apart, worked the same shift, and I owned a car. After a few weeks of driving her, she told me how much of a difference it was making in her life. She no longer had to spend hours on the bus, could make it home to her brother on time, and had more time to focus on her mental health. The conditions that she was born in, grew up in, and lived in were negatively impacting her health. I was able to make a small difference in my life in order to make a huge difference in hers.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Before COVID-19, I had received my certified nurse‚Äôs aide certification for the state of Michigan in December of 2019. I was interested in entering the world of patient care to get experience and knowledge. With my CNA license in hand, the plan was to apply to nursing homes, assisted living facilities, and long-term care facilities in the summer of 2020. When this time came, COVID-19 was hitting nursing homes and senior living facilities the hardest. With no vaccine in sight and little truly known about the virus, it would have been easier for me to stay home like millions of Americans did; however, I remember being thankful I had received my CNA license because it qualified me to help the vulnerable population. I was able to care for those in need when their families couldn‚Äôt be with them. The pandemic altered my personal journey proving my commitment. There was no hesitation in my application to senior living facilities; I was able to help so I knew that I was going to.

personal_statement:
“Amna, Rameen! Jaldi aao! Come here!” my dad exclaimed, dropping his work bag off at the door and motioning for us to join him on the couch. My dad, his excitement getting the better of him, immediately jumped into a story about an interesting patient he’d encountered at the hospital that day. My sister, never one to be all that interested in his stories, was already grumbling under her breath. Meanwhile, I was impatiently waiting to ask all the questions I had for him. “Wait, Abu, what’s a CAT scan? Are you scanning actual cats at work?” This was a regular routine throughout my childhood. Looking back, I’m not entirely sure what was so fascinating to me about his stories. What I didn’t realize, though, was that by encouraging me to ask my questions he was also instilling in me a sense of curiosity about the world around me and an appreciation for what the field of medicine is capable of. 

Not only did my family help me develop a sense of curiosity from an early age, they also instilled in me an appreciation for diversity and a culturally conscious approach to life. My family is nomadic. Originally from Pakistan, we first moved from city to city in the United States. Eventually, we made our way to the Middle East. After moving to Saudi Arabia, my initial reaction was “Wow, things work differently over here.” On the daily bus ride to school, it was hard not to notice the swarms of migrant laborers working in the scorching desert heat of Riyadh. I began to wonder what life for these individuals looks like and how a country as wealthy as Saudi Arabia still has such large wealth disparities. Upon moving to Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates I decided to join (and eventually lead) human rights advocacy efforts at my high school. We worked hard to organize visitations to the labor camps themselves. This proved extremely difficult, in large part due to the city’s interest in concealing certain human rights violations. The visitations revealed the extent of those violations and the hidden living conditions of the workers; eight workers confined to one room, beds close enough to hear the sound of one another’s heartbeats. A common thread that ran through our conversations with these workers was their lack of access to quality water, sanitary products, and healthcare. Everyone has a right to these necessities and the stress of trying to meet their basic needs was not something they deserved.

Entering college, my goals were twofold. One, I wanted to learn more about medicine and figure out if it was something I wanted to make a career out of. Two, I wanted to continue learning about marginalized groups and the disparities they face. Alongside required courses, I also took courses on incarceration and the history of Muslims in the United States. Subsequently, my interest in social justice reform grew. I joined REDACT, an organization that supports incarcerated Muslims. As I dove into what social justice work looks like, I briefly considered alternative career paths. I was questioning pursuing medicine because I didn’t know if it would allow me the opportunity to continue my involvement in these reform efforts. However, I quickly realized that there is also work to be done in the medical field regarding social justice. Racial disparities in COVID-19 mortality rates, lack of continuity of care during post-incarceration, and general cultural insensitivity in medical treatment are just a few issues that are important to me. I eventually learned to combine my interests in healthcare and inequalities more organically, writing my honors thesis on COVID-19 vaccine equity in incarcerated racial and ethnic minorities. Because I am invested in learning about healthcare inequality in general, as well as my own biases, I hope that I can be in a position to make an impact as a globally raised Pakistani-American Muslim.

While research experience gave me a group-level understanding of what socio-cultural influences on healthcare can look like, a visit to my primary physician gave me a glimpse of what it looks like on an individual level. What I thought was going to be a simple routine visit turned out to bring upsetting news. My physician told me that she suggested, from a medical standpoint, that I abstain from fasting during the approaching Islamic month of Ramadan due to new health concerns. However, fasting is one of the most important aspects of my faith system, and not fasting would impose a great spiritual toll on me. Therefore, through shared decision-making, we concluded that I would fast given that we take other precautionary measures. I respected the due diligence she took to understand what fasting meant for me. Like her, I hope to not only support those of my own identities, but also appreciate the circumstances of other races, ethnicities, religions, etc.

So, why medicine? By going into this career, I hope to continue to learn about ways to advance equity in medicine while practicing socially conscious care to enhance patient outcomes.

These days, it isn’t my dad who is calling my sister and I to tell us about his work day. Instead, it is me who is hijacking the family WhatsApp group to share the latest advances in medicine and social justice reform through medical practice. Oh, how the tables have turned.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
When my family announced that we would be moving to Saudi Arabia from Minnesota at the age of 13, I was nothing but outraged. I pondered why women were obligated to wear abayas‚Äô (loose clothes worn by Muslim women). However, I quickly realized that the adjustments made in Saudi Arabia were no different than the assimilation we unconsciously did while living in the small town of Sartell, Minnesota. _x000D_
_x000D_
Moving abroad, I became more secure with my identity as a Third-Culture Pakistani-American over time. Instead of succumbing to the norms of those around me, I learned how to tolerate and accept others‚Äô differences without compromising my own identity. I was able to have an appreciation for lived experiences different than my own. This was especially important attending international schools in the Middle East. My high school hauled students from every corner of the world. I became more open-minded and understanding as a result of being surrounded by other ‚ÄúThird-Culture Kids.‚Äù
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
Understanding mass incarceration as a threat to marginalized communities is a phenomenon that is important to me. Knowing how faith has the ability to be a pervasive protective health behavior in my own community, I focused my final project in the seminar I took called ‚ÄúMass Incarceration and Public Health‚Äù on the role of religion in incarcerated populations. Given a lack of services for incarcerated Muslims in Minnesota and the high demand for this, I and other community organizers decided to spearhead ‚ÄúREDACT,‚Äù a community organization supporting incarcerated Muslims through re-entry, letter writing, and mutual aid. We have been connecting incarcerated Muslims and their loved ones with the services they seek. _x000D_
_x000D_
Although rewarding, this has been incredibly challenging work. I believe that social justice reform work is a life-long commitment. As a physician, I plan to continue addressing this systemic inequality on a patient and policy level. _x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact:
With bags ready to go in one hand and passport in the other, the United Arab Emirates border shut down on the day of my flight back home. This left me quarantined alone during the pandemic. It was difficult to adjust to this isolating period where social support was important. However, I found solace in taking summer classes, discovering new hobbies, and connecting with others like myself who call home somewhere abroad. I was fortunate to not undergo significant hardships during the pandemic. I can only imagine the loss millions faced due to the pandemic. _x000D_
_x000D_
The pandemic highlighted existing health disparities between US socioeconomic groups. As a result, I became more determined to address these disparities. To broaden the literature, I facilitated studies about the mental health impact in racial and ethnic minority Veterans and COVID-19 vaccine hesitancy in racial and ethnic minority incarcerated individuals. This taught me the need for sustained and time-sensitive health equity work.

Hrdshp_Comments: I grew up in a low-income household where my mom worked multiple jobs to provide for us. When I was 12, I had an emergency appendectomy; we did not have health insurance, so this financial burden led to eventual bankruptcy and a near foreclosure on our home. To avoid this, my mother took up another job cleaning on the weekends and I would go with her to help maximize the number of houses we could do a day. In high school, I had a part time job after school and continued to clean with my mother. Because I balanced it well, I assumed it would be fine in college as well. While in college, I had a full-time job to pay for university and I worked on the weekends with my mother, as well. Initially this was difficult, but manageable; however, in my second year I did not have enough money to pay for tuition and had to sell my car. In turn, this made going back home to clean much more time consuming and my grades definitely suffered as I was not studying enough. Luckily, I found a new job that paid more and became a resident advisor. Together, this provided enough income for me to send money to my mother, rather than going to clean. Although there were long and hard days, I can say that regardless of the circumstances, I have and will continue to work hard to achieve my goals.
personal_statement:
A 52. That was the grade on my first university calculus exam. “I…I failed. There is no way I can get into medical school now”. The tears in my eyes blur the numbers as I try and call my mother. “Well, Zaidmara”, she responds, “should I go pick you up then, bring you home, and you can come and clean with me”. I know she is half serious, so I respond, “No, I am not ready. I can’t give up yet”. It would be a lie to say that things got easier - I was both working and in school full time. I am however determined to persevere and go to medical school; I am willing to work as hard as I need to do so.  
  
Although I have always wanted to become a physician, I have had other interests along the way - I am a French major after all. But I have always looked at these varying skills and interests and thought about their applications to medicine, such as the positive impacts of being multilingual on patient care. The ability to communicate with others has been important throughout my life; I grew up translating for my family. With my grandmother having type II diabetes, it was imperative for me to accompany her to her appointments to translate, so she could care for herself and keep her diabetes under control. Recently, however, she found a Spanish-speaking physician, and I have seen a significant increase in her confidence when she goes to her appointments. As a result of being able to communicate more clearly, it is now easier for her to manage her diabetes, and her health has improved as a result. As someone who is multilingual and aspires to be a physician, seeing the outcome of effective patient communication pushes me to work even harder to achieve my goals in medicine.  
 
During my time working in the emergency department, I witnessed how medicine is not only about diagnosing and treating patients, but also serving as a resource for and teaching patients. After a patient’s results indicated that she was having a miscarriage, the physician asked me to translate for the patient. As it was my first time delivering such emotional news to a patient, I discussed possible reactions with the physician prior to entering the room, but I was not prepared for her response. As I delivered the news to her that she had a miscarriage, “tuviste un aborto espontáneo”, her eyes just remained blank. “Perdón no entendí” (Sorry, I don’t understand). After discussing with her and asking a few questions, I realized she did not fully understand what a miscarriage was. I took the time and clarified for her, emphasizing that it was not her fault. Although she had just been given difficult news, she thanked me for explaining and said that she was comforted now understanding what was happening. In this moment, I realized just how important it is for physicians to take the time and educate patients about their diagnoses because it can provide relief. During my time as a teacher in France, I got a lot of practice in how to explain complex concepts. I often used comparisons and references that they would understand as middle schoolers. It was clear that when I “broke down” the lessons into more digestible parts, they were more receptive to what I had to say.

Communication is essential not only with patients, but with the entire medical team also. During my second training shift as a scribe, an elderly Spanish speaking patient was being wheeled into the trauma bay after a fall. Everyone began to look for someone who spoke Spanish and I whispered to my supervisor that I did. With nobody else in sight, I was given the go ahead and began translating all of the questions the physician was asking. “She says no pain, but she can’t feel anything on her right side.” The patient was immediately taken for a CT and found to be having a stroke. Because she was treated so quickly, she thankfully had a good outcome. In this moment I learned that medicine truly is a team effort, and that each person matters because they bring a set of skills unique to them, even the scribe still in training. 
 
I worked hard in college to manage my time and progressively do better in my science courses but working with patients I learned that there is so much more to medicine than just hard sciences. Patients deserve someone who is willing to work diligently and provide individualized care based on that patient’s needs. I want to be that physician. I want to be able to approach each case and incorporate my strengths into providing personalized care for my patients. As a first-generation student and Latina, I understand that there will be many more obstacles to overcome, and perhaps even more difficult than the ones I have already encountered; but I am eager to continue to work hard to provide that sense of being understood to patients.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As a Latina, growing up in a predominantly white community in Louisiana presented challenges. My culture and language at home was not the same at school, making it difficult to interact with my peers due to lack of similarities. As a result, I have developed the skills necessary to successfully interact with people with whom I share little to no connection. Furthermore, I have also cultivated a desire to learn more about other peoples and cultures in hopes of improving my communication and cultural awareness. During my gap year I chose to work internationally to simultaneously utilize the skills I had learned and gain new valuable competencies. Working in a priority education zone in rural France, I experienced initial culture shock; however, throughout my time there I adapted and had invaluable experiences. Given my combined life and academic experiences, I am uniquely able to empathize and connect with those of similar and drastically different backgrounds and life experiences.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Living and working in the New Orleans community, I am surrounded by people of different cultures and backgrounds. Unfortunately, the majority of healthcare professionals do not reflect this diversity. Working as a scribe, I have seen the effect this can have on patients and how small gestures can make a big difference. While at work, I served as a translator with Spanish and Portuguese speakers. Due to a lack of resources, there were not always translator phones available, leaving me as the only person who could communicate with the patients. I started out simply by translating but realized I could also teach the nurses and physicians common medical Spanish vocabulary for when I was not there. Many were appreciative and even took initiative to learn more independently. This experience and seeing the experiences of the patients significantly improve made me realize how small things can have big consequences, and how having someone who understands you can be everything.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I initially planned to only take one gap year; however, after returning to university in the fall of 2020 I realized that would not be the case. I was a resident advisor in a first-year dorm and because of the pandemic the residents had difficulties adjusting. As a result, I responded to many residents in acute mental health crises at the same time as attempting to study for the MCAT. I realized I was exhausted and emotionally unwell and decided the best way to care for myself would be taking a second gap year. Following that decision, I had a job working for an NGO in Kenya lined up for my first gap year; due to the pandemic and travel restrictions, I was unable to go to Kenya. Instead, I found a job working as a teacher in a priority education zone in rural France. Although my plans have veered in different directions the past few years, I took them in stride, allowing myself to have the unique life experiences and stories I do now.

personal_statement:
When I turned thirteen years old, my grandfather gifted me an Encyclopedia Britannica, a book weighing at least five pounds and containing hundreds of thousands of entries about every imaginable subject. Although it seems like a boring and dry gift for a high-schooler, I was thrilled. As someone who grew up with their nose constantly in a book, I pored over the encyclopedia in between homework assignments and tennis practices. From a young age, I was captivated by unanswered questions about our world. However, one field in particular captured my attention: the human body. Once I started learning about the various processes that keep us alive, from cellular respiration to cardiac contractions, my passion for biology and human physiology grew. As an undergraduate at UC Santa Barbara (UCSB), I aspired to learn about the cellular mechanisms responsible for diseases that I had not only heard of, but that also affected some of my family members. In a class called Human Physiology, I learned how understanding these mechanisms could allow physicians to treat their patients by using pharmacologic treatments to target specific receptors. I realized that by becoming a physician, I could use my passion for learning to diagnose and treat my own patients.
One of the first times I observed the application of scientific knowledge was when I began working as a medical scribe at an Emergency Department (ED), where I saw patients afflicted with the same diseases which I had learned about in my biology classes. One day, an 8-year-old boy with diabetes was brought in by his mother after he vomited multiple times. Through conducting various tests, the physician was able to determine that the patient was experiencing diabetic ketoacidosis. After he had been treated, I went to his room to talk to him and his mother. His mother grabbed my hand and expressed her relief at how much better her son looked compared to just hours prior. I hope that, in my endless pursuit of answering the unresolved questions about human physiology, I will be able to offer a similar respite to my own patients.
In the ED, I observed the humanistic side of medicine in addition to its scientific foundation. I recognized the importance of combining compassion and knowledge in practicing medicine. Our patients came from varied socioeconomic backgrounds and insurance statuses, but what they shared was their need for an empathetic doctor. As a medical scribe, I would often stay behind in patients’ rooms to ask more specific questions for their charts. However, this usually turned into a conversation that taught me about the type of physician I want to be: one who incorporates both a passion for learning and empathy to treat each patient as a whole.
Scribing not only introduced me to the practice of medicine, but it also challenged me to adapt to working in a busy hospital. As I saw how fast-paced the ED could be, I realized that in order to remain a dependable scribe for supervising physicians, I needed to take responsibility for my own familiarity with this novel environment. After my first few shifts, I read articles about common conditions, associated treatments, and other symptoms in order to accurately and informatively write charts for patients with these diseases. For example, I researched terms that would come up with patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD), many of whom required ED visits for issues concerning their hemodialysis. By taking the time to familiarize myself with the typical dialysis regimens of CKD patients, I was able to ask more specific questions that helped my supervising physician make informed clinical decisions.
Hoping to broaden my clinical experience, I joined the Koegel Autism Center at UCSB as a Clinical Research Assistant (RA) as a sophomore. I worked with a team of other RAs and several post-doctoral students to implement a play-based intervention in toddlers with Autism Spectrum Disorder to expand their language capacities. Through bi-weekly sessions, I formed a true connection with the two toddlers I worked with, “M” and “K.” Initially, I was unsure whether I would be able to succeed in my therapy, as I had not previously worked with children in a research capacity. I realized that I needed to ask my team for help, especially when I encountered roadblocks in my progress with M and K. Although it was intimidating, I started to speak up more during our weekly team meetings to share my experiences and ask for advice. I made tweaks to my intervention based on my team members’ perspectives, which proved to be crucial to the toddlers’ language development. Compared to the beginning of my work with M and K, when they were limited to one- or two-word utterances, they were speaking in multi-word sentences and could draw from a wider vocabulary by the end of my time as an RA. Actively initiating discussions in team meetings taught me the value of different viewpoints, which allowed me to become a better clinician for M and K.
While I will always treasure the passages in my worn Encyclopedia Britannica, I found that my passion for learning stretches beyond the pages. I hope to implement my lessons in empathy, adaptability, and communication to become a physician who never stops exploring the unanswered questions in medicine.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: In 2005, my parents, little brother, and I moved over 8,000 miles away from my hometown of Singapore to the San Francisco Bay Area. At the time, I was unaware of the magnitude of our move as I was only five years old. However, as I grow older and work towards my goal of attending medical school, I realize that my immigration and assimilation journey indefinitely shaped my values. My Singaporean accent was an immediate giveaway of my ‚Äúotherness,‚Äù something I wished to conceal. For several years, I was ashamed to be anything other than American-born. I was embarrassed by the color of my skin and my Singaporean pronunciation of certain words. It took several years before I felt proud of my immigrant status, but I will always remember the challenge of getting to that point. Through my medical education at Rush Medical College, I hope to use my experience struggling with my multicultural identity to appreciate and celebrate the diversity of the Chicago community.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: When I helped found the Health & Equity Alliance at UC Santa Barbara, I knew that our mission of spreading awareness of and ameliorating public health issues had to start in our local community. I reached out to PATH, a homeless shelter in Santa Barbara. Along with a few club members, I volunteered at PATH every other weekend to prepare meals for their residents. Although it was a seemingly minor contribution, I formed connections with some of the residents and noticed their appreciation for a simple meal. It was deeply gratifying to make an enjoyable meal for them, but what was more rewarding were the relationships I formed. I talked with the residents about their families, friends, and favorite foods. At the end of our conversations, they expressed their gratitude for having someone to talk to. Spending a few hours of my weekend to bring a smile to the PATH residents‚Äô faces was a lesson in how such a small act of service could have an impact on an entire community.
7_-_COVID_Impact: When the COVID-19 pandemic began, I was a junior in college. My upcoming volunteer commitments at a local homeless shelter and in-person autism research sessions were canceled. However, I still stayed in Santa Barbara to continue working as a part-time medical scribe at the Cottage Hospital Emergency Department. Immediately, I noticed that there were many people who suffered with and even died of COVID-19 but could not afford the care that could have saved their lives. With the suspension of free clinic services in Santa Barbara, the Emergency Department received people lacking shelter or a primary care physician who turned to our department for help. Unfortunately, they were often turned away or had to refuse care because of the cost of treatment. This experience illuminated the inequality of the American healthcare system and inspired me to pursue the expansion of primary care medicine to all patients in need, regardless of their demographics or socioeconomic background.

Inst_Action_Desc: On Sunday, September 4th, 2016, during my first three-day weekend as a first-year undergraduate student, I attended a small gathering in another dorm room. Shortly after I arrived, at around 10:00 pm, the Resident Assistant knocked on the door and explained that the noise level in the room was too loud. He took the student ID information from everyone in the room. I was assigned an excessive noise violation for being in attendance at the gathering. As the first person in my family to attend college out of state, I was excited to mingle and meet new people. However, I realized after this incident that I was also contributing to a disturbance for neighboring students. As the eldest sibling in my family, I understand the importance of leading by example for my younger sister and acknowledging areas of improvement. After receiving the noise violation, I completed community service hours at the LGBTQ+ Resource Center. Through community service, I was able to meet some amazing people at the center as well as at the Women’s Center next door. This experience gave me the opportunity early on in my college career to reflect on how I wanted to move forward in my next four years. As I progressed through my undergraduate years, I met so many people through clubs and classes who remain my close friends to this day.
personal_statement:
The EMTs slowly stepped away from the patient as the Emergency Medicine physician approached the stretcher. As a new scribe, I tried to concentrate on the HPI but my eyes couldn’t leave the man lying on the stretcher in front of me. He arrived under the Baker’s Act, a Florida law allowing individuals who show harmful signs of mental disorders to be admitted for psychological evaluation. The patient was seemingly alone and had no family to contact. As the physician assessed him, the tears welling up in his eyes began to flow down his cheeks. His sobs overpowered his ability to answer any more questions. The physician consoled him, repeating “Everything will be okay,” and “We will take care of you.” As his sobs subsided, I witnessed the influence of the physician’s patience and empathy on the patient. Despite being in a room surrounded by strangers, the patient gained a support system of physicians and nurses who would care for him and provide mental health resources. This moment serves as a reminder for why I am drawn to medicine. I want to support patients in need and be able to offer them proper care and resources. Despite my nonlinear path to medicine, this feeling was the epitome of my pursuit. As a physician, I will be at the forefront of helping those in vulnerable positions.


My interest in medicine began in high school when I had the opportunity to serve as a patient care volunteer at a nearby hospital. I was drawn to the nature of the work, seeing patients wholeheartedly cared for by physicians and nurses. I started college on the pre-medical track but after not meeting my own academic expectations, I was discouraged and decided to explore other fields. I gravitated towards economics because I was fascinated by the intersection of individuals and societies and the rationale behind their decisions. In a healthcare economics course my senior year, I saw economic principles applied to how healthcare professionals and institutions promote positive health outcomes through effective patient care. As I found ways to combine my interests in healthcare and economics, I wanted to see the impact of these theoretical concepts on people’s lives. I revisited my pursuit of medicine and enrolled in a Post-Baccalaureate Pre-medical program. After graduation, I was more confident in my goals and no longer discouraged by minor setbacks.  


The analytical and problem-solving skills I developed in economics classes encouraged me to think strategically and optimize outcomes. I was able to leverage these skills as a research assistant under Dr. Wu Zeng, a physician and health economist. I saw how research in healthcare economics and health policy can guide decision-makers to the efficient delivery of healthcare resources. As a future physician, I value having this background to better understand the barriers faced by under-resourced patients. I experienced the need for this perspective first-hand while working as a health navigator for an Afghan refugee family. On our first call, the two eldest daughters requested a doctor to help their painful menstrual cycles. I was met with an arduous process of finding an OB/GYN physician of a similar Persian background who could speak Farsi and connect with the women culturally as well as accept Medicaid and be accessible by public transit. Though I found one nearly an hour away, I was disheartened by how far the women would have to commute. I was exposed to only a few of the healthcare barriers this family and many others face when seeking accessible and culturally competent healthcare services. As a physician, I want to build on my background in health policy and economics to help bridge the gap between underserved patient populations and their ability to access healthcare resources. 


I noticed parallels between the refugee family and my own Indo-Caribbean family in their abilities to seek out healthcare resources and understand health information. This became especially pronounced during the COVID-19 pandemic. My family immigrated to this country from Guyana and they have a strong history of cardiac disease. Despite their comorbidities, they overlooked the importance of safety precautions and caught the virus with severe symptoms. My mother, a nurse and the only medical professional in our family, became a familiar and trusted confidant. Family members who usually relied on natural remedies or who were afraid to see physicians found a sense of comfort in asking her for medical advice. I admired how she educated them using analogies and basic non-medical terms to avoid confusion. I want to emulate this role as an educator for patients of all ethnic and cultural backgrounds in hopes of increasing health literacy in these communities.   


My experiences have strengthened my resolve to become a physician devoted to helping others in vulnerable positions. I understand, through research and experience, the need for long-term economic and policy solutions in healthcare to assist underserved communities and reduce prevalent health inequities. I aspire to connect patients of all cultural and socioeconomic backgrounds with culturally competent healthcare. I look forward to the meaningful patient encounters and influential changes I will make as a physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
While volunteering in a free clinic, a patient asked me a question in Spanish. I nervously stuttered, ‚ÄúNo hablo Espa√±ol. Voy a hablar a la enferma.‚Äù I quickly brought the nurse over to assist the patient. I admired the way the bilingual nurses and intake staff could easily connect and communicate with our Spanish-speaking patients. I yearned to one day improve my basic Spanish language skills and be able to connect with this patient population. _x000D_
_x000D_
After this interaction, I reflected on the power of human connection in medicine. My time at the clinic highlighted the hindrance of language and cultural barriers that can exist within patient interactions. It motivated me to want to work toward eliminating these barriers as a medical student so I can foster genuine connections with patients. In my medical education, I want to learn how to provide truly equitable and culturally competent care to my future patients.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: My current work as a refugee health navigator has pushed me to acknowledge and learn about the social and economic conditions affecting underserved communities. As a health navigator, I help an Afghan refugee family address their healthcare needs. In my first week working with the family, one of the daughters requested an urgent dentist appointment for her and her mother‚Äôs persistent toothaches. Thankfully, I found a dentist who accepted Medicaid and also spoke Farsi. The daughter expressed her gratitude and appreciation for having a dentist who could not only communicate with her and her mother, but also understand their background and connect with them. After this first appointment, I realized the importance of culturally competent health care to the family and other patients in their position. I continue to locate Persian physicians for the family and work toward improving their access quality healthcare services.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The COVID-19 pandemic brought my senior year of college to a screeching halt. A few weeks following my virtual college graduation, I began a post-baccalaureate pre-medical program. At the time, my mother had ample exposure to COVID-19 in the hospital while working tirelessly as a healthcare provider. Our small home in Queens, New York felt even smaller as my sister and I, both active students, shared the kitchen counter for homework while our mother stayed in one of the two bedrooms. It took me time to adjust to the circumstances and I didn‚Äôt achieve the grades I had hoped for in my first science classes in the program. Through my mother, I witnessed the emotional toll of the COVID-19 pandemic on healthcare providers. The bravery of my mother and all of the healthcare providers during the pandemic was inspiring and I look forward to becoming a part of that community as a future physician.

personal_statement:
Not a single incision was made on the chest of the patient with cardiac arrhythmia lying on the operating table. Yet, as I watched through the plexiglass of the tech room, Dr. M managed to rewire the heart’s electrical signals. Mesmerized by the heart’s real-time beating on the screen, I marveled at the seamless operation. Using their knowledge of cardiac pathophysiology, the team resolved irregular heart rhythms in under an hour.

Early exposure to the medical mysteries that plagued my family had fostered my fascination with the nuances of biology. Watching my mom navigate treatments for her rare Vitiligo from Eastern herbal remedies to aggressive Western UV radiation, and my brother’s weekly injections of a costly drug for an unresolvable immunology issue lead me to wonder how the human body was both so powerful yet fragile in the face of genetic abnormalities. 

Beginning with elementary school science fairs, my very early “research” became an ongoing analytical and creative endeavor to piece together biological concepts in unique ways. Later, my research examined genetic abnormalities in Human Breast Cancer Cells using CRISPR/Cas9 genetic engineering. My idea was to design a small population of genetically engineered cancer cells that could alter signaling pathways, attempting to disrupt communication patterns with other circulating cancer cells to slow tumor progression.**

To continue my work, I began research with a Genetic Medicine Lab at the University of Michigan that had developed clinical drugs to target genetic foundations of cancer cells. What happened there for me was more than just research.

Lacking employee access, I used the public elevators at the Rogel Cancer Center to reach the research floors. The overwhelming size of the building and complicated maps did little to ease the stress of fellow elevator passengers heading to treatments and screenings, so I memorized the floors to provide direction. My brief exchanges with patients taught me how even small talk about the weather and laments about Michigan snow in the middle of spring lightened moods. I learned that cordial engagement was appreciated, and I looked forward to my elevator experiences as they helped me feel better connected to the community I was working within. 

Patient encounters during my internship with Radiation Oncology furthered my interest in the medical field. After partial tongue removal, a lady with oral cancer was referred for radiation therapy. I loved seeing the excitement on her face after I complimented her speech abilities and attributed such success to her optimistic nature and diligence in therapy. Having the capability to wield powerful applications of science as a future physician would allow me to continue cheering on the improvements of patients who have reached significant treatment milestones. 

Unfortunately, I also met individuals who did not respond well to radiation. These cases have inspired my REDcap database designs that are used in clinical studies, such as a novel one I designed for sarcoma patients at Michigan Medicine. Clinical research is something I foresee continuing in medical school as it will enhance my ability to piece together the symptoms of a patient’s case presentation to decide on an effective treatment path.

To combine my vision of being a part of a group that uses science coupled with effective communication to help others, I joined the Neurosurgery Clinical Outcomes Team. As part of a Michigan Medicine initiative that supports the American Spine Registry, I work to talk with and gather healthcare opinions from pre and post operative neurosurgical patients. The patients’ frustration towards strained recovery and limited contact with the primary surgeon mirrored my own frustration with my limited capacity to assist them. Although our conversations were not directly solving issues of opioid addictions and chronic pain, they showed me the importance of simply listening. From the elderly woman who told me about a busy day at her flower shop to the laugh I shared with a man who said he was referred to as a porcupine on the operative table when his ribs were poking out, I helped ensure that these patients knew that their healthcare group was supportive and conscious of their concerns, helping to ease these patients’ mindsets towards their surgical outcomes. Developing rapport with patients has shown me a facet of healthcare that is truly gratifying and how medicine goes beyond the implementation of science by helping through the power of empathy.

Thinking back to that Cardiac Cath Lab, I remembered how Dr. M resolved a serious heart condition all while talking through the operation to ease the patient's nerves exemplifying how I want to adopt both patient care values and a nuanced understanding of biology. As a physician, I will provide emotional support while also exercising my mind to restore the health of the strong spirited patients I meet, helping me to bring back the entertaining personalities that sickness has dampened. I want to be a doctor who empowers patients to not let a diagnosis be the end, but rather the beginning of their journey in uncovering how their body is adaptable to the world in unique and wondrous ways.

** doi.org/10.1007/s11626-021-00566-6, Pg. 543
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
My trip to Machu Picchu was a memorable avenue for cultural exposure. Initial adaptation to the high altitude was more difficult than I anticipated, especially seeing the prevalent use of oxygen masks. When me and one of my younger cousins I was traveling with underwent high altitude sickness, I learned about powerful local remedies, such as the scent of a herbal concoction. I was really given the chance to immerse myself within a unique culture, especially trying to converse with individuals in Cusco, who spoke a unique dialect of Spanish influenced by elements of the indigenous language Quechua. _x000D_
_x000D_
These experiences continue to resonate with me far beyond that trip. I have taken collegiate level classes in Spanish that have advanced my understanding of the language and allowed me to engage in communication on Hispanic society and culture. These classes were conducted only in Spanish, allowing me to better learn a language that many of my future ethnic patients may be comfortable with.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Addiction to pain medication and the opioid epidemic is a prevalent health issue in Chicago. I have dealt with the frustration of many surgical patients with restricted access to pain medications and patients that have been using opioids for years to treat chronic pain. For one patient who was confused and upset for being denied additional pain medication, I took the time to review clinician notes with the patient. The notes had said his past surgical history was a primary reason for restrictions. I carefully listened to his concerns and offered to help schedule an appointment with his nurse practitioner to talk about pain management techniques. These experiences have shown me that there is still much research and education needed on the scientific nature of opioid addiction and for safer alternatives that can be used for pain management. I have also been inspired to provide Naloxone training through my Red Cross Organization at the University of Michigan to prevent opioid overdoses._x000D_

personal_statement:
The patient’s oxygen level plunged and his shallow breaths became desperate gasps. Inhalers and nebulizers failed to treat a worsening asthma attack. Panicked, his parents dialed 911. EMTs arrived in minutes and rushed the little boy into the ambulance. As quickly as they’d come, the howling sirens and flashing red lights faded. My heart raced. Would my little brother survive?

Certain moments embed in our memories while shaping our perspectives, our life’s journey, and our understanding of its meaning. My lifelong rank as the healthy sibling of a chronically ill boy molded my identity, fostered an understanding of my values, and led me to my purpose.

I stood in front of Ms. Laman’s first-grade class with my Fisher-Price medical kit in hand. The case illustrated my dream career to my class: “When I grow up I want to be a doctor because they help sick people, like my little brother.” By elementary school, I already saw Travis stay in the pediatric ICU - twice. Although a first grader, I understood asthma prevented him from living like a normal kid; rather than having fun, he sat in a hospital bed for days or spent hours at the doctor's. Asthma followed him everywhere. A protective big sister, I desired to save him. So, at age six, I set off on my journey toward doctorhood, determined to cure his illness.

I learned his chronic asthma was incurable after witnessing a series of grim hospitalizations. His worst occurred after EMTs loaded him into that ambulance five years ago. A seven-day struggle ensued and I helplessly watched the same, chaotic cycle: He cried, gasping for air. PICU staff fought to get his oxygen levels up. The steroids worsened his symptoms. Doctors found new treatments. As I watched the doctors tackle cumbersome obstacles to save my brother, I realized my trivial toy medical kit lacked the heavy weight of hardship real physicians bore. Childhood innocence could no longer protect me from grasping the harsh realities of healthcare. 

Despite the tiring hurdles, his physicians fought his asthma with tenacity, proving to me a career in medicine can be more rewarding than strenuous. I respected their tireless determination to treat my brother. I admired their ability to admit their errors and problem-solve when they prescribed an unsuccessful treatment. I valued their compassion as they eased my family’s unbearable anxiety. I wanted to impact others like they did me. But did I have the nerve to pursue such a taxing career? Determined to know the answer, I sought opportunities that provided a definitive answer. 

The old man looked white as a ghost. I placed the pulse oximeter on his index finger. It measured an oxygen level of 91. My heart raced as I anxiously recalled the implications of such a low reading. He must have contracted the virus. To my surprise, his test read negative. I remembered certain people, like my little brother Travis, naturally have below-average resting levels. I uneasily reasoned his low oxygen was due to his old age and sent him home. A nervous pit immediately swelled in my gut.‘When Travis fell near 90, Mom called Dr. Smith…if he couldn’t get his oxygen up, he went to the ICU.’ I knew the man needed medical attention, regardless of his negative test. Minutes after he left, I got ahold of the attending physician. “The older patient tested negative for the virus, but his oxygen was lower than normal. I really think he needs to go to the hospital.” She called the patient and advised him to go to the ER, where he was treated. I felt relieved knowing I had left nothing to chance. With every subsequent challenge at the testing site, I grew confident I could endure the harsh realities of medicine. Any doubts I may have harbored about my career choice vanished. I knew exactly what I wanted to do: be a doctor. I quickly sought more challenges to quench my thirst for patient care.

The baby wailed as the ultrasound tech rubbed the transducer along her hip. I tuned out her cries and furiously typed as Dr. Doe dictated her findings to me. “Her left hip is dislocated.” My heart sank. The hip abduction brace failed to treat the baby’s hip dysplasia. Her mother cried hearing her daughter needed an invasive operation to prevent a future of hardship. I was immediately reminded of my Mom. I knew the woman felt helpless, unable to save her child. I kept my eyes on her with a soft gaze in an unspoken pursuit to comfort her. Now I felt even more motivated to become a physician, desiring to provide strength and guidance to individuals enduring hardship.

In these hectic yet familiar moments, my life came full circle. I now bore the responsibility to help ensure the health of human beings and provide reassurance to their loved ones - just as doctors did for my little brother and my family so many times. I found true fulfillment helping those who stood in the shoes I once filled. I sincerely understood the tribulations patients and their families endured and desired to soothe their anxieties and tackle their maladies. Working with patients over the years, I learned I could be what I always wanted - someone who empathizes with, nurtures, and guides people battling tough predicaments. My journey strengthened my first grade dream. Today, I still say: when I grow up, I want to be a doctor.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As a medical scribe at the Children‚Äôs Hospital of Los Angeles, I interact with children from various cultural and socioeconomic backgrounds.
