Every day, I witness the effects of healthcare inequality: patients of lower socioeconomic status struggle to receive prescribed orthopedic bracewear; non-English speaking families wait longer to see the doctor, as they stand by for the clinics‚Äô single interpreter; families from smaller communities commute hours to receive specialized care. I understand multiple aspects of the social experience contribute to a range of inequitable health outcomes. Seeing the effects of systemic health inequality firsthand, I seek to acknowledge and understand the barriers hindering individual access to healthcare, and actively listen to patients directly affected by such inequities. At Rush Medical College, I will work alongside my peers to  advocate for and help cultivate a culture of inclusion and equity among underserved patients to improve healthcare for all.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: With profound confidence, Jessy read the Harry Potter passage aloud for his peers. I watched him in awe: in just six weeks, the shy third grader transformed from an insecure reader to an extraordinary orator. During my sophomore year at UCLA, I coached Jessy and his classmates in the art of dramatic reading, volunteering with a nonprofit that supports underserved students through literary education. Initially, most students showed deficits in their reading comprehension. But, with incredible perseverance and help from our team of tutors, each student showed significant improvement in their reading skills and overall confidence. This experience taught me that empowering students through creative, individualized instruction strengthens their personal and academic development. Tutoring children in underserved school districts, I realized the importance of equitable instruction; everyone has the right to learn skills, such as reading, in an optimal environment, suited for their needs.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I woke up on March 9, 2020 with a nasty cold. I grabbed my laptop to email my nursing volunteer coordinator: ‚ÄúOver the weekend, I developed a chest cold. Given recent concerns of coronavirus, I feel it would be best if I did not come into my shift this evening. Let me know if I can reschedule after spring break.‚Äù Unfortunately, I never rescheduled. When the pandemic hit, the hospital suspended the nursing volunteer program and my healthcare journey came to an abrupt halt. No longer able to care for patients, I worked remotely in different fields to explore other interests. But over time, I grew unsatisfied. So, when asked to work in a COVID lab, I eagerly accepted the challenge. In this fast-paced environment, I conquered obstacles, expanded my clinical knowledge and felt fulfilled working with patients. Though the pandemic initially interrupted my pursuit of medicine, it eventually led me to realize medicine truly was my calling, inspiring me to pursue other clinical positions.

personal_statement:
Growing up, my mother often said, "time waits for no one," leading me to interpret time as impersonal and impartial. Despite this neutral sentiment, my mother overlooked one flaw of time: it had been quick to discriminate against us. My childhood experiences are filled with relatives that succumbed early to heart attacks, strokes, and cancer. In hindsight, their premature deaths could have been prevented with timely interventions. Mental illness and years of addiction compounded the structural barriers to accessing preventative healthcare in my family. In our inner-city Brooklyn neighborhood, our motto is "never ran, never will," a testament to our culture of fighting to survive. Because of the massive violence in Brownsville, we coined our local hospital the "gunshot hospital," only seeking health services there for traumatic injuries. Most, like my family, couldn't afford to travel outside the neighborhood for their healthcare needs. Even those with health insurance never seemed to get the same physician twice, making it difficult to establish a relationship with any medical provider.

The lack of quality and accessible medical professionals is a glaring deficit in my community. In particular, we have a paucity of trusted primary care providers, who are the initial point of contact for health services and education in healthcare. We need providers who understand the reality of living in disadvantaged communities and are invested in patient care informed by social determinants of health. My personal and professional experiences showed me that community-oriented physician advocates willing to provide long-term patient-centered care could have improved my family members’ longevity. I want to be that physician advocate, striving to improve my community's health and winning this race against time on a systemic level.

The desire to advocate for my community's health started early in my life. As a high school student, I observed that my neighborhood had a surplus of liquor stores and a dearth of fresh groceries, making it a “food desert.” My education taught me repeatedly that health and wellness begin with the foods we consume. To overcome this barrier, I started a vegetable garden in my backyard. I shared my knowledge and produce with my neighbors and assisted them with growing foods like peppers and herbs. In the fall, our gardens become plentiful enough for us to collectively donate a vibrant cornucopia of vegetables to the local food pantry. 

This experience of community action affecting health influenced my decision to become a physician. During my undergraduate studies, a class discussion about the preventability of strokes led me to ponder the connection between underserved communities and the unknown benefits of risk factor modifications. Wanting to learn more about stroke prevention and treatment,I was chosen to pursue an internship at the Ayer Neuroscience Institute. Here, I learned about the drug Tissue Plasminogen Activator (tPA), which prevents impairments after a stroke, but only when administered within three hours of stroke onset. This timing is crucial in disadvantaged areas, where there needs to be more education about recognizing stroke symptoms and promptly seeking care. Medical providers that are aware of the social and economic situations that hasten poor health outcomes can give patients a fair shot against time. My goal is to be a primary care physician who can educate community members about preventing debilitating diseases and address barriers such as transportation that may delay care. 

My vision for the impact I can have as a primary care physician has been further solidified in my role as a clinical research assistant at Weill Cornell Medicine. One of my job responsibilities is to recruit subjects for a qualitative research study that aims to elucidate the barriers Black patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease have in managing their cardiovascular comorbidities. In an interview, a subject, Ms. J, shared, "The Tuskegee experiment is fresh in our minds. There's the trust issue, intimidation issue, and lack of knowledge issue. Many things are working against us." Even so, she said the "polite and patient" way I spoke with her validated her existence as a human being and made her hopeful that healthcare is becoming more inclusive. Through this study, I saw that as an academic primary care physician, I could work to improve the health and community of my patients, and I can contribute to generating scientific knowledge that engages patients historically underrepresented in research.  

As I begin my medical training, I look forward to building upon the insights I have gained from my research experience and working towards repairing vulnerable populations' trust in the healthcare system. The reality that underserved communities have generations of early deaths, a simple measure of compromised health, proves the inequitable allocation of precious time and medical interventions. Medicine should be as individual as it is universal, starting with culturally competent primary care physicians who can promote honesty, transparency, and generational health. I will give my all to this mission: guaranteeing a safe space and face to those from marginalized communities like mine.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: On one of my first shifts on a Jewish holiday as a medical assistant for a pediatrician that served a predominately Orthodox Jewish population, a father and his young daughter asked me to turn on the light in a bathroom. I didn‚Äôt understand a very simple request at first because of the language and lack of knowledge barrier. After speaking with my coworker, I learned that this community often could not operate anything electrical during specific holidays. It was apparent that I needed to do more research to have sufficient knowledge of the population I was interacting with daily. After a few weeks, I learned about most holidays and began picking up Yiddish phrases and words with the help of my coworkers. Knowing their religious customs and practices, I anticipated their needs, which helped establish comfort between the community and me. I explored what it meant to provide culturally competent care and its relationship to cultural humility and recognizing one‚Äôs possible biases.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
It was a hot summer day in July 2019, but the air was filled with laughter, balloons, and bubbles. It was "Unity in the Community" Day, and as an event manager, I helped to organize this experience with the event planner company Epiphany Blue. Epiphany Blue specifically creates programs and events for each community and the youth alike. _x000D_
 _x000D_
I provided some ideas about programs that can address my neighborhood's needs. For instance, I commented on our area's lack of affordable and accessible food. Epiphany Blue then brought farmers to the event to provide tips on growing fresh produce and shopping for fresh produce. Our community health center was there to provide health tips from a trustworthy source and familiarize our youth with the center. By creating this space for my neighborhood, I promoted healthy living and harnessed the power of arts and culture to establish familiarity with one another. _x000D_

personal_statement:
Uniforms stained with dirt, grass, and occasional blood comprised a significant portion of the first twenty years of my life. My fascination with the game of baseball began when I was just four years old watching my father coach my older brother’s baseball team in Danville, California. As a batboy, I loved the sound of metal spikes clanking on the pavement, and slowly became a student of the game. In middle school, after moving to Las Vegas, I recall the hectic days of playing on four different teams; switching uniforms to rush across town for the next game was not unusual. Three and a half years at Bishop Gorman HS in Las Vegas and half a year at San Ramon Valley HS in Danville included regular season play, year-round showcases, college development-recruiting camps, and working with professional trainers. Family vacations were often spent attending tournaments around the United States. Over family dinners, when baseball was somehow not the topic of discussion, my parents would talk about their work in the medical field. My father is an Emergency Medicine physician, and my mother an ICU nurse. I recall being keenly aware and attentive to their medical stories and quietly curious when it came to their respect and enjoyment for medicine. On weekends, when I was not at the batting cage, my father invited me to accompany him during portions of his ED shifts. The teamwork and family-like atmosphere of the doctors, nurses, and ancillary staff was captivating and uplifting, and I was intrigued by this medical exposure.

Initially recruited to play baseball at Point Loma Nazarene University, one of the happiest days of my life was when I received a call from the University of Southern California baseball coach in July, one month before starting college. He invited me to play baseball and attend college at USC, one of America's most prestigious and respected college baseball programs over the last 50 years. Playing Division I baseball demanded a significant time commitment and was not always glamorous. As one of the team catchers, I was on call for the pitching staff before, during, and after the hundreds of hours we dedicated to field practice and training. It was a privilege to be a part of something so special, and I loved the players, coaches, and overall team camaraderie. Yet it quickly became apparent that my childhood aspirations of playing professional baseball were not in my future. After numerous meetings with my academic and pre-health advisors, I resolved that as much as I loved the sport that inspired so many years of my life, it was time to make a transition. I will never forget the day I officially decided to hang up my spikes. It was early fall, my fourth year at USC. I walked into the coaches’ office and poured out my heart. There were tears and hugs that day, but my coaches and teammates respected and understood why I decided to step down from the baseball team, sharing their full support.

To catch up on my required pre-med classes, it was necessary to enroll in continuous summer school sessions and pursue an increased upper-level course load. Over the last six semesters at USC and five summer sessions at UNLV and USC, my tenacity and hard work enabled me to achieve a respectable 3.9 GPA. My exposure to clinical medicine was bolstered while working as an undergraduate research assistant with the Pediatric Emergency Care Applied Research Network (PECARN) at the Children’s Hospital Los Angeles Emergency Department. My role was to obtain informed consent from patients and families presenting with head and/or abdominal trauma to evaluate the potential overuse of CT's in pediatric trauma patients. Although these families were often in distress, I looked forward to the exciting new task of interacting with patients and making small compassionate connections. 

After graduating college and training to become a medical scribe, I now rotate through three local Las Vegas hospital ED’s as a key component of our medical team. Supporting and interactively assisting our ED physicians is challenging and exciting as we face multiple exam rooms full of anxious patients. Whether documenting charts or contributing to the team’s camaraderie, I approach my role with the same mentality that has been ingrained in me throughout my lifetime of baseball. Before each shift, I take a few moments to gather my thoughts and prepare myself for any "curveballs" that might be thrown my way over the next 10 - 12 hours.

Twenty years have passed since I was that four-year-old boy, idolizing his older brother on the baseball field. My experiences as a student-athlete still apply now as I tie up my medical scrubs rather than lacing up my metal spikes. The lessons learned that helped me overcome adversity, make sacrifices, and persevere will stick with me throughout my life. My years of dedication to baseball have prepared me to invest that same commitment to my medical education. I look forward to applying the lessons I have learned on the field, in the classroom, and in the medical setting to gain each patient's trust, partnering up and “coaching” them to achieve their healthcare goals. I am excited about my decision to pursue a career in medicine, and I look forward to the experiences, challenges, and emotions that lie ahead.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: A lifetime of baseball has enabled me to develop the skills and confidence to work with any team while understanding the importance of placing the needs of others before my own. The collectivist, ‚ÄúWin as a team and Lose as a team‚Äù mentality has shown me the importance of a strong and unified community, and how necessary it is to foster goodwill, teamwork, and cooperation for the sake of that community‚Äôs health. Going to college as a student-athlete in South Central Los Angeles provided me the opportunity to appreciate an extremely diverse culture and city. On my various teams, I developed a natural ability to connect with fellow players from many different backgrounds, where we consistently worked hard, embraced our differences, and persevered to achieve our greatest potential. It has been a pleasure to learn and grow from the stories and experiences of others, allowing me to broaden my horizons to become the culturally competent physician, leader, and individual I yearn to be.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Through the Big Brother Big Sister organization, I was matched to mentor Eddie, a 15-year-old boy with autism from a low-income, Hispanic household. During our visits, Eddie and I play sports, chess, and talk about whatever is going on in his life at the time. Initially, our various activities did not spark his interest until we went to the golf range, to which he had never been. While hitting balls, I was surprised to see Eddie turn to me with a smile on his face asking if we could ‚Äúdo this again?‚Äù That night, I was proud when his mom called thanking me for discovering Eddie‚Äôs newfound interest in golf, an accomplishment Eddie‚Äôs mom did not think was possible. Though Eddie is my mentee, our shared time has taught me the potential every individual possesses if given the opportunity to have a mentor who encourages positive experiences. I have learned more from him than I ever expected about the importance of appreciating the little things, the big things, and everything in between.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
At the onset of the global health emergency in Spring 2020, USC transitioned to virtual education and strongly encouraged students to return to their primary residence. This unprecedented experience of isolated learning allowed me to overcome and embrace the challenges of being quarantined while trying to maintain academic excellence. While the circumstances surrounding COVID-19 were unfortunate, my return home to Las Vegas turned out to be a special blessing in disguise._x000D_
_x000D_
As discussed in my ‚ÄúCaregiver‚Äù most meaningful experience, my mother was diagnosed with triple-positive left breast cancer within one month of my return home. During this time, I had the opportunity to help my family and be a pillar of support for my mother throughout her battle with cancer, while my father, an ED physician, needed to distance himself from my mother while continuing to take care of COVID-19 patients. It brings joy to my heart to say that she lives today, after beating cancer!

Hrdshp_Comments: My father created a comfortable life for my family in Saudi Arabia away from impoverished and war-torn Syria; however, he knew that my brothers and I would lack educational and career opportunities as non-Saudi citizens. When I was three, he sacrificed all he knew to bring us to the US and start a business. Regardless of his efforts, the business was never profitable and failed when I was 6, forcing us into bankruptcy and frugal years. Most crippling was watching my mom regress in her transition to life in the US. She struggled to improve her English and was isolated within the new culture. These obstacles deteriorated her mental health and her relationship with my father manifesting in constant fighting. I had to grow up fast to mediate intense arguments and chose to reside at home during college to assist our family financially and emotionally. Issues climaxed in my sophomore year when my mother was arrested for a domestic violence incident. Unemployed and pending a divorce from my father, I became her caretaker. With help from my brothers, I sought treatment for her which eventually allowed my mom to regain her personal dignities. I’m grateful to know that the worst has passed and that I will always have the support of my family moving forward.
personal_statement:
I was 16 when my cousins and I had just ended a few basketball games at our local gym. From friendly wagers, I had earned enough money to buy comedy tickets I had been saving up for. Or so I thought, until an older man entered the gym and offered “double or nothing” as incentive for us to continue playing. I thought it would be an easy win, but after a couple games, I was quickly humbled, and the man generously returned my winnings to my cousins. He gave me a ride home, and I learned he was a hospitalist named Andrew. We became good friends and would frequently play basketball together after that. After getting to know my interests and personality, he alluded that medicine may be fitting for me and I began exploring the idea with him; he ultimately became a close professional and personal mentor to me. In retrospect, everyone won that day: my cousins kept their money, Andrew got his exercise, and I started my path to medicine.
In my early years of college my family struggled but navigating through these difficulties provided me with valuable life lessons. During sophomore year my mother was arrested after an altercation with my father. She was in a difficult place and her health and well-being became my priority. I coordinated many hearings, appointments, and court orders all requiring a significant amount of time, effort, and attention. Attending every appointment, I mediated interviews hindered by the Arabic language barrier, while collaborating with her psychiatrist to be an effective caretaker at home. This meant organizing and understanding my mother’s medications and creating an environment at home that fostered her healing. In retrospect, my mom was my first patient; through her I learned how to provide care for those with illnesses — seeing how proper care and treatment can improve someone’s life. I learned to be hopeful during tough times and discovered that I value providing service and care to people to alleviate pain like I had for my mom. I knew through this experience that I wanted to provide solutions to mitigate suffering for those with complex medical conditions, encouraging me to continue my journey in medicine.
During these difficult times, I enjoyed working within my neurobiology research group. I found comfort in my ability to find answers and develop conclusions within my work when many other aspects of my life seemed uncertain. I enjoyed learning to fold peptides and perform electrophysiology experiments, while deepening my understanding of the principles of scientific inquiry. I am especially proud of my work investigating the novel alpha10 nicotinic receptor, in search for a molecular probe to elucidate its clinical applications. I learned to utilize the available literature, develop proper protocols, and follow data to appropriate conclusions. Mentored by a physician scientist, I began to understand the responsibility of physicians to advance science and continue as lifelong learners. As I continued in the lab, I also began working as a cardiology tech which allowed me to experience meaningful interactions with patients. I enjoyed educating patients about heart monitors and finding ways to personalize and simplify my explanations. These opportunities were similar to my other roles in teaching and tutoring while directly impacting someone’s health. I am enthusiastic about a future where I may gain knowledge to educate patients as a clinician and to progress science as a researcher.
Looking back, I found that when I wasn’t teaching the patients, they were teaching me. My favorite part of my job was connecting with them and learning their stories, triumphs, and struggles. While stationed at the cancer hospital one day, I entered a patient’s room whose name was of Middle Eastern origin, like myself. His name was “Ali,” and he reminded me of my older brother. While weak, bed bound, and visibly in pain from his cancer, he managed to express liveliness and emotion in our conversation. Although our respective countries were distant and even spoke different languages, he said, “We are neighbors.” With the little Arabic he knew, he called me “habibi,” a term of endearment. I spent quite a bit of time keeping him company in his room that evening. It was difficult to hear his agony but also inspiring to see his optimism. This patient encounter emphasized the important connections I hope to make as a physician
Leaving Ali’s room, I felt some pride in distracting him from his hardships. However, I realized that was all I was able to do—provide a little comfort and a momentary distraction. Regardless of our interaction, he would still wake up the next morning in pain with a bleak diagnosis. I desired to answer his complex medical questions and make decisions to lessen his suffering. After much reflection, I have realized that it is the summation of my life’s events that led me to pursue a career in medicine. Ultimately, I hope to work toward a future where I may provide solutions and treatment plans to create more positive outcomes for patients from a variety of socioeconomic and cultural backgrounds. I’m grateful my mom’s inspiring resolution, and I’m hopeful that as a physician I can provide the compassionate care integral for her recovery to heal other patients.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As a Syrian who traveled to the US at a young age, I share a special experience with younger immigrants in helping my parents assimilate to a new world. While performing an intake with a Hispanic mother at the free clinic, I began speaking to her through her son. I‚Äôd never met the young boy, but I felt connected by our shared interpreter role that symbolizes our responsibility as mediators between cultures. I didn‚Äôt live their culture, but I understood them because I had been in the boy‚Äôs shoes. Residing at a cultural intersection most of my life, I‚Äôve been afforded a perspective that enables me to understand a unique set of people and scenarios. I‚Äôm also reminded of my coworker, a father of two from Rwanda. We‚Äôre mostly dissimilar but have developed a close friendship through discussions of our immigration story. Ultimately, I‚Äôve learned my unique perspectives have allowed me to find similarities with others, and I‚Äôm excited to connect with the diverse population in Chicago.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Volunteering at my local free clinic has been an especially meaningful experience for me as I learned to care for the vulnerable populations in Salt Lake City. Throughout my time I‚Äôve cared for many unique patients and gained insight into the health disparities they face. After a couple years of developing my skills around the clinic, I was excited to join our diabetes team that assisted in the after hours diabetes clinic. Mary was one of the first patients I met who taught me the impact of these efforts. After performing her eye exam and retinal scan I brought her into an exam room to take her vitals and blood sugar. I enjoyed our conversation listening to how much she‚Äôd improved since her last visit. I could hear the genuine excitement in her voice explaining how she was down 20 pounds with blood sugars under 100. As I examined her feet, I felt proud to be part of her battle against diabetes. I hope to find similar opportunities in Chicago, serving the diverse population of patients.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The pandemic has been a difficult time for my family and me. In the initial spring months, my father lost his job and was unemployed for quite some time. My brother and I tried to make up for the lost income; however, my paychecks diminished when research labs on campus prohibited undergraduate access. As bills began piling up, we could no longer keep our home. My parents and brother moved into an apartment while I found an affordable sublet. Simultaneously, I began adapting my research ambitions, scheduled shadows, and volunteer obligations that were canceled. Although I was disappointed, I saw an opportunity to be creative with my time and assist in our global crisis. With the new ability to connect online, I worked to connect high schools with universities, developing an online volunteer tutoring group for struggling students. Making these transitions mid-semester was challenging, but I felt fortunate compared to others and grew through managing the obstacles.

personal_statement:
Trust: From Cradle to Grave 

Trust is the belief that someone is reliable, good, honest, and effective. Trust doesn’t come easily, especially in difficult moments. Particularly in medicine, during moments of need, patients don’t always have a choice for whom they must rely on and trust for their care. I have found trust to be something that must be earned by helping others through some of their most vulnerable moments in life—in infancy, adulthood, and even death. These experiences helped solidify my desire to pursue a career as a physician, a position where trust is foundational. 

When I was a volunteer swim instructor, one of my first students was an eleven-month-old baby. All of the confidence I thought I had flew out the window the moment I realized the responsibility I was being given with such a small human being. What made me qualified to teach someone so young and vulnerable? The child’s mother was willing to blindly put her trust in me, a complete stranger, when she dropped the infant in my arms. I had to think quickly and carefully on my feet to ensure the safety of the infant and maintain the mother’s trust. To do this, I kept the child’s safety my number one priority and involved the mother closely during every lesson. At the end of the six-week course, the infant was happy and made great progress, and the mother felt more secure in her son’s safety. Because they were willing to trust me, I gained confidence in working with young children along with their parents and discovered a new passion for working with kids. 

Another experience that helped me learn the importance of trust was my position at Chrysalis, a support home for individuals with disabilities. One of the clients I worked with was diagnosed with borderline personality disorder, and, as a result, was impulsive and had a hard time expressing her emotions in appropriate ways. The client was insistent on doing things on her own, and she frequently talked about how she didn’t like being constantly supervised. She clearly didn’t believe the program could help her. I knew I needed to approach her behavior plan differently and in a manner that addressed her feelings. If she didn’t trust me, there was no way I could help her improve her behavior. I made it my goal to become her friend and not solely another authority figure. Because of my approach, she became much more receptive to my guidance. After a year of maintaining her trust, I was able to help her enroll in college and finish her first semester. She still calls me her “extra” school success advisor.  

To kickstart my medical career, I obtained my CNA certificate and began working at a Memory Care Unit in an assisted living facility. One night while I was working, my residents had just finished eating their dinners and I set up the movie "The Sound of Music" for them to watch. The 180-gallon fish tank illuminated the room. It was my turn to change the cold packs for a recovering male resident who was restricted to his room because of hip surgery. I was worried about him because he had refused dinner that day and had been running a slight fever. The first thing I did when I entered his room was check his vital signs. His eyes were closed, and his oxygen compressor was making its slight air release noise every few seconds. When I read the thermometer, I stopped in my tracks. 86.0° F. I quickly scanned the thermometer again. A similar reading displayed. His chest was not rising or falling. He had no pulse. 

I quickly notified the Registered Nurse of his passing and began the postmortem process. I asked if any of his family would be coming to say goodbye but was informed that they would not be able to get there for a few hours. He was to stay in his room by himself until they arrived. This made me sad. I had been working with this resident for months, and I knew I had to be there for him. As the end of my shift neared and I completed my other duties, I immediately went to his room to keep him company. The uneasiness I felt earlier turned into a feeling of responsibility. I was his caregiver, the person who his family trusted to be there with him during his most vulnerable moments, even his last. As I sat there, I was overcome with raw emotion. Just a few hours ago, he had been reading the newspaper and cracking jokes to me about my ponytail resembling a horse’s ass. Now, the "Jeopardy" noises from the other room filled the silence as I sat with him. "Jeopardy" was his favorite show. 

Now as I prepare for a career in the medical field, I ask myself: who gave me the right to be present in each of these moments? The answer lies in the reality that I am preparing myself for a career that is built upon unconditional trust. Who is there for others in their most vulnerable moments at all stages of life? A physician. A physician is not just someone who diagnoses and treats individuals who walk through hospital doors. A physician is someone who holds people’s trust during their most mentally and physically challenging moments. I look at being in this position of trust in a humbling manner and as a great honor.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: When I began my position as a service leader, I met with one of the tribal leaders. She explained to me that many of these children were not expected to pursue academics, graduate high school, or attend college. Due to past indigenous strains, these children are expected to help support their families as soon as they are old enough, so it often cuts out time for education. One day at the center I witnessed an 11-year-old child creating a spot for her sleep-deprived younger brother to lay because he hadn‚Äôt been put to bed the night before. In my family, education has always been a top priority, so this was different. Coming from a place of privilege I realize that not every family is able to prioritize things like education. I learned many must prioritize other things for survival‚Äôs sake and I must support that. Instead of just giving academic motivation, the focus at the center became on providing a safe, comfortable place for these children to leave their responsibilities behind.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: In my role as a Direct Support Staff for individuals with disabilities, I observed that many of my clients could not advocate for their own practices of healthy habits‚Äîboth mental and physical. It was my role as their caregiver to provide tools and direction for them to become productive citizens of their community. This included encouraging my clients to choose healthy eating habits, engage in physical activities, practice regulating their emotions, and set goals for their future. When I started working with one specific client, she had strict supervision guidelines. She could not be left alone during any task and had monitored phone calls. I took the time to create connections, establish a trusting relationship, and provide resources for her as her staff. Because of this, she was able to enroll in college, obtain her driver‚Äôs license, and began transitioning into a more independent lifestyle away from the program.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
During the early spring and summer of 2020, I had planned on acquiring another CNA position at my local hospital, although due to COVID-19, the hospital and many other healthcare facilities remained on a hiring freeze for the entirety of this time requiring me to find a caregiving position elsewhere, one that did not hold the position title of "CNA". Instead, I obtained a job at the company Chrysalis to work as a "Direct Support Staff" for individuals with disabilities. This Direct Support Staff position had some similar caregiving and healthcare duties as that of my previous CNA position._x000D_
_x000D_
Also, while I was able to complete some physician job shadowing during this last year, because of COVID-19, I was not able to begin in-person job shadowing until late 2021 and therefore was not able to obtain as many physician job-shadowing hours and experience as I would have preferred.

personal_statement:
I was in elementary school when I recognized my fascination with the human body. I knew that I had an older brother that died because of his “bad heart,” but the night my mother handed me a book about the cardiovascular system, I had an interest to learn more. Of course at this time I did not understand the complex anatomy of the heart, and likely could not even pronounce complicated words like “cardiovascular,” but I remember how I felt holding a book that I believed held the answers to his heart condition. I would trace my fingers along the outline of the animated heart, trying to imagine how strong it must be to propel blood to the tips of my fingers and toes, and I would press my ear against a family member’s chest in an effort to hear the “lub-dub” of a healthy heart. I was fascinated by its complexity, but as any 10-year old, I was unfamiliar with what varied avenues medicine could explore aside from understanding the body’s organs. My initial introduction into medicine was two-fold. I had a fascination with the intricacies in the human body, and I had love for my older brother that further drove this passion. These two aspects of medicine, both the science and humanity features, have continued to show up in my pursuit of medicine from the classroom to the Emergency Department. I have an interest in understanding the human body, and I have a passion for caring for people through my investment in the individual. Through this, I have come to a clear understanding as to why I choose medicine.
 In college, I volunteered at St. Louis Children’s Hospital as a Patient Care Assistant. I would visit patients in their room while holding toys underneath both arms in an effort to surprise kids and their families with fun activities. The kids would often be so absorbed in our silly games, that their parents felt comfortable enough to leave the room to finally get fresh air. I felt proud being able to help patients and their families feel better, even if for only a short amount of time. “Make sure to visit me again!” kids would exclaim, as I left their room. I frequently made an effort to recognize their faces, and the toys they enjoyed most to ensure I would align my tasks to their needs. But because I only worked a few hours every week, our interactions were limited in my role as a volunteer. I imagined myself as a trained physician at Children’s Hospital and how differently the patient care interaction would look compared to my volunteer position. I envisioned how I could create relationships with my patients and their families and watch their condition change over the span of minutes, hours, and days. The end goal would still remain relatively similar, however: To reestablish a sense of normalcy in the patients' and families' lives.
 The connection I experienced as I interacted with patients was something I witnessed as medical providers interacted with each other to find a solution. I would frequently watch in awe as physicians, physician assistants, nurses, and more would “round” and discuss both short-term and long-term care plans for patients with their families. I would get excited to be part of such a team dynamic that had the overall goal of making the patient feel better. I recognized that within my role as a Patient Care Assistant, however, I was part of a similar team. We would enter our shift and interact with fellow volunteers and supervisors to create a plan for the shift: What rooms we needed to visit; whose room is most urgent; what toys do we need to pick up and sanitize; what stationary activities should we set up for within the Patient Care Room; and overall, how can we help the patients and their families feel better and support their medical team in the process?
 I recognized this team goal more as I shadowed in the Emergency Department at Barnes-Jewish Hospital in St. Louis. “Hi, my name is Dr. ___, and this is our medical team. We are here to help you feel better,” was a frequent sentiment given by physicians when introducing themselves to the patient. I recognized compassion from the doctors when anxious patients would express their concerns about being in the Emergency Department, and how the doctors would respond by talking to the patient about their needs, providing extra blankets, and holding hands with the patient as the examination continued. The investment in the patient would continue into the Work Room, where physicians would collaborate on a comprehensive plan for the patient to ensure that they would receive the best care possible. As an undergraduate student that was simply shadowing, I was able to take part in the discussions between the physicians and other medical professionals who all wanted to help the patient return to their sense of normalcy.
 In the future, I look to connect my passion for science and people in a salient combination of community engagement in medicine. I’ve had experiences managing the rigor of both science and advocacy throughout my academic career, and my most recent involvement was the management of studying for the MCAT while ensuring my family member’s health and financial needs were being met during his medical crisis. Medical school will prepare me to heal both the individual patient and the community through my work as a physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
During my time working as a Patient Care Technician at Total Access Urgent Care, I have had exposure to many differing perspectives. One viewpoint in particular, however, was from a patient who was very vocal about his hesitancy surrounding the COVID-19 vaccine. The patient emphasized his reluctance in receiving the vaccine and wanted my input about his decision. In an effort to better understand his perspective, I instead asked more about what led him to his reluctance. After having a greater understanding of the patient‚Äôs decision making process, I then decided to share my own decision making process when discussing my vaccine experience. _x000D_
_x000D_
Although the pandemic has unfortunately become a point of much disagreement for our world, this conversation between a patient and myself ended with a greater understanding of an opposing viewpoint. I learned that to be a physician it requires conversation, context, and patience in order to effectively treat and care for an individual. _x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
Throughout my personal, academic and professional career, I continue to have a deep investment in the St. Louis community. In an effort to reduce health disparities in my community, for example, I founded the College Admissions and Networking program (CAN) through partnerships with local school districts and the Urban League of St. Louis during a summer in college. CAN was a program for local highschool students who were interested in attending college, and looking to learn more about the application process. CAN provided students with mentors, professional networking connections, a financial stipend, resume and personal statement workshops, and more. Through CAN, students became more confident not only with their college application, but also with their professional and personal journey._x000D_
_x000D_
I am committed to helping my community through healthcare, whether that entails reducing health disparities by increasing access to educational opportunities, mentorship, or medical education._x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact:
The COVID-19 pandemic has made me more aware of the immense privilege it is to care for someone and their health. As a result of the pandemic, and the decreased number of medical professionals able to care for the community, I decided to take an Emergency Medical Technician (EMT) class. And because of this class, I decided to work as a Patient Care Technician (PCT) at Total Access Urgent Care as I await my EMT licensure exam. _x000D_
_x000D_
Throughout my experience of working in healthcare thus far, I recognize the immense privilege I have to care for such individuals. I am able to care for people who visit the clinic when they are feeling their worst, and they enter through the clinic doors trusting our medical team._x000D_
_x000D_
Working as a PCT is actively preparing me for medical school and beyond. I am not only learning the scientific method that medicine employs, but I am also learning how to interact with patients and their families through conversations about their health.

Inst_Action_Desc:
1/16/2020 - My roommate and I were fined $5.00 for a residence hall violation for stacking boxes near our window area when they were not supposed to be there. During the weekly inspection of all dorm rooms, our resident hall director determined that the floor of our room was not clear of personal belongings. Specifically, on the fine, he noted that he "noticed a large pile of boxes and belongings in the back of the room by the window."

2/24/2021 - My roommate and I were fined $5.00 for a residence hall violation. We had left our room for class and failed to clear our textbooks off of the floor. During the weekly inspection of all dorm rooms, our resident hall director determined that the floor of our room was not clean. Specifically, on the fine, he noted that our room "did not meet the outlined expectations for room checks."

My roommate and I failed to work together to ensure that our room met residence hall standards on two separate occasions. I learned that when things are not up to standard, it is the responsibility of all team members, not just an individual, to directly correct or mitigate issues. My roommate and I should have functioned as a team, and we were met with consequences when we did not do so. I have realized that this lesson is highly applicable to healthcare as well as everyday life.
personal_statement:
“Cedarville Medic 13 respond mutual aid for Silvercreek Township to assist Medic 42, confirmed cardiac arrest, CPR in progress.” My heart pounded as the transmission came over the radio. The neighboring fire department needed our help: my first code. As I buckled myself into my seat, palms sweating, a sense of calm rushed over me with the click of the other seatbelts. We were a team, and we had prepared for this. When my crew arrived on the scene, I watched as one of my crew members took over chest compressions while another pushed multiple doses of atropine and epinephrine. As I charged the defibrillator to deliver a shock and quickly prepared additional doses of medication, I felt a sense of purpose. I was part of a team working to save someone’s life. Through the haze of activity, our cardiac monitor detected a weak pulse. I helped secure the patient to a backboard and carry him to the ambulance. As we neared the doors of the emergency department, we lost his pulse. I lingered as the ED staff took over his care, pacing nervously, watching as the pulse came back onto the monitor. We had done it, as a team. Through my work as an EMT and firefighter, I have had the privilege to continually witness firsthand the seamless teamwork and collaboration that is required in healthcare today. These experiences have inspired me to become a physician, someone who not only makes diagnoses and institutes proper interventions, but also supports his team and works with them to give the best possible care to his patients.

While the successes were initially what drew me to medicine, I have since learned that I can make a significant impact even when things do not go as planned. A week into my junior year of college, I responded to a call for an elderly patient who was unresponsive with suspected COVID-19. As we sped to the address, I suited up in my gown, strapped on my N-95 mask, and prepared my equipment for a full code. When we entered the patient’s house, it was clear that she had passed away hours before. After I helped cover her with a sheet, I glanced at the coffee table and saw photos of her with little children, presumably her grandchildren. Suddenly, the body underneath the sheet became much more than a casualty of COVID-19 or a patient for whom we came too late. As we stood outside waiting for the coroner to arrive, her husband told us how much he loved her and how grateful he was for the time they had spent together. I realized that there is so much more to medicine than simply saving a patient. Healthcare professionals are constantly privy to some of the most vulnerable movements of their patients’ lives. Compassion and support are just as important as providing quality clinical care to patients. The interactions with patients and their families became a focal point for me in my clinical duties. Even after many tiring, stressful nights in the back of the ambulance, these conversations are what inspire me to continue working. My desire to be a physician is motivated by the opportunity this will give me to make a difference in the lives of my patients and their families on a daily basis.

Through my clinical experiences, I have seen the extent to which medical conditions can affect patients’ lives and how much more there is to discover in the field of medicine. This is what drew me to research. As an EMT, I often helped a patient with epilepsy who had frequent grand mal seizures. While there were things that we could do in the moment to stop the seizures, the fact she had them so frequently added an element of unpredictability to her life that constantly hung over her. I wanted to delve further into the underlying etiology of epilepsy and what could be done to improve these patients’ lives. I joined a lab my junior year where I researched mutations of a neurodevelopmental protein that, when mutated, could lead to epilepsy in infancy. We found that the mutated proteins had a low affinity for neural cadherin, thus leading to seizures. Uncovering what causes this form of epilepsy is integral in designing new therapies for millions of people. While patient care is my passion, I have become excited about the ways research can change what is possible in the treatment of patients.

I want to be a physician so that I can play a pivotal role in improving the human condition by way of administering quality, compassionate care to all of my patients. I have come to view treating patients as not only a responsibility, but as a privilege. Physicians have the ability to be a healing, restorative force in valuable human lives, and what drives me to get out of bed each day is the opportunity to positively impact someone’s life, especially through their health. I have realized that equally as important as being an effective diagnostician is being present in my daily interactions with others, whether they be my colleagues, my patients, or their families. I firmly believe that all people deserve the best health care possible, and I am excited to bring my passion for helping others to my medical studies and for the future interactions that will shape who I become as a clinician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I had the privilege to serve on a medical service trip to a small village in Guatemala. None of our patients spoke English, and they came from a culture vastly different from ours. The best way to understand those different from you is to listen. We could only communicate through local translators, but I learned more about their culture than I probably would have from any other way. We talked about the food they ate, the traditions they held, and how their medical conditions affected how their society viewed them. I learned a clinician‚Äôs approach must be tailored to each patient and that it must be a priority to honor a patient‚Äôs medical decisions in an ethical manner. Medicine is a bridge that has the power to reach across cultural, social, gender, religious, ethnic, and socioeconomic boundaries. All people need and deserve quality care, and it is our duty to learn more about our patients to ensure that we are always sensitive, respectful, and kind in our approach to caring for them.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I‚Äôve assisted many students who attempted to end their life or struggled with suicidal ideation throughout my time serving as an EMT with Cedarville University Emergency Medical Services (CU-EMS). One call, in particular, was very impactful; my crew was dispatched for a patient who was going to drive his car into a nearby ravine but was stopped by his roommate, who dialed 911. When I began my assessment, the patient sobbed and began to open up about very difficult things happening in his life. In our conversation, I showed him that I genuinely cared for him and wanted the best for him. I stressed to him that he had immense value that wasn‚Äôt based on his current circumstances. Toward the end of the call, he thanked my crew for not treating him only ‚Äúlike a patient‚Äù but as a human being. After the call, I developed and implemented a framework and subsequent training that CU-EMS currently utilizes for compassionately assisting patients with mental health emergencies on our campus.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The COVID-19 pandemic shined a bright light on the healthcare disparities and inequalities rampant in today‚Äôs society. The pandemic did not adversely affect my application, but it heavily influenced my preparation and reinforced my motivation to become a physician. As an EMT, I treated countless COVID patients. These patients dialed 911 because they were in respiratory distress; however, around half of these patients were afraid to go to the hospital because they didn‚Äôt know how they were going to afford their treatment. This isn‚Äôt an uncommon concern today, but it was especially troubling because my patients‚Äô lives were in direct jeopardy. Patients should not have to struggle to express their concerns about affordable healthcare in between what could potentially be their dying breaths. Every person on this earth deserves quality healthcare. Eradicating the healthcare disparities in our society will require much advocacy and a genuine desire to make a difference in each patient‚Äôs life.

personal_statement:
From my earliest days, music has been at my very core. My parents often talk about the way I would sit as a toddler, mesmerized by the music playing on the CD player next to me, quickly becoming exasperated at the slightest interruption. My attachment only grew when I was able to create music myself. The first time I made a sound on my flute overwhelmed me; I couldn’t believe that my own breath had created the frequencies reaching my ears. I have studied piano, flute, and saxophone for the majority of my life. Music has always brought me immense joy and fulfillment. It is where I am most at peace.
With perspective, I now see that my early days of studying music were, in essence, for myself. Playing my instruments gave me a sense of accomplishment. In time, I learned that the gift of music was in fact a way to give something of myself for the benefit of others. In coming to this understanding, my relationship with music fundamentally changed. It was this awakened perspective that has also quite surprisingly been the catalyst for my pursuit of a career as a physician.
In my freshman year of college, I joined Tufts Public Harmony, a student group that performs music at retirement homes, shelters, and cancer centers. No longer was I just performing for family, friends, or ticket-holding audiences. At every concert, I was struck by music’s simple yet profound impact. As my group performed, audience members seemed to escape their struggles as the joy of the music reached them. I felt a deep sense of purpose in bringing this comfort to listeners. Public Harmony gave me the opportunity to use music as a vehicle for service, which cultivated my motivation to dedicate my life to healing. It is this same feeling that fuels my aspiration to be a doctor. In medicine as in music, I hope to provide relief to others. I embrace a sense of service in treating others with compassion, respect, and empathy.
I experienced this same call to service in my role with the Care Navigation team at East Boston Neighborhood Health Center. The patient population, primarily comprised of immigrants to the United States living below the poverty line, has been disproportionately impacted by COVID-19. The community needs were great and the resources scarce. My position, which involved connecting patients to aid such as food, clothing, and rental assistance, raised my awareness to their overwhelming needs and to the impact I could have, even on a small scale. My role grew more meaningful as I understood the value in the human connection that I could provide. Every phone call with patients was an opportunity to ease their burden just a little bit, even if that meant simply listening to their concerns. Contributing to this side of patient care strengthened my draw to medicine. As with the impact that I found in sharing my music, there is profound importance in being present for people in need.
Today, I am working as the clinical research assistant in the Center for Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center. This role has allowed me to further take what I have learned about service, healing, and connection and combine it with my love of medical science. While I have always been fascinated by biology, so much of my identity growing up revolved around being a musician that I had not considered pursuing the medical field. This position has helped me solidify my passion for science through the lens of patient care. I get the privilege of experiencing the convergence of medical science and human connection on a daily basis by supporting patients through the process of receiving new treatment in clinical studies.
While I have been inspired by successful patient outcomes, I have also witnessed the frustrations of managing chronic disease. Working with the IBD physicians has raised my awareness about the disappointments inherent in practicing medicine. Sometimes treatments are not effective, leaving limited options. My biggest takeaway from these discouraging situations is the importance of validating the patients’ concerns while instilling confidence in the continued path of their care. I have developed great reverence for the role of clinicians as they navigate the highs and lows of caring for the vulnerable, and I deeply value the moments in my day when I am able to contribute to this care. Now in a clinical setting, just as I found with sharing my music, I am most fulfilled by being a source of trust and relief for others.
What draws me to medicine is the opportunity to serve at the intersection of science and human connection. The experiences that have guided me along my journey have revealed to me that I am most fulfilled when I am sharing my gifts for the sake of improving the lives of others. Music will always be one of my most cherished outlets; it brings me solace and keeps me balanced. However, it is through understanding the impact that music has when shared that I find purpose in providing comfort. While I have found different ways of fulfilling this purpose, my clinical work has confirmed to me that practicing medicine is where I would best be able to serve others. As I pursue medicine, I intend to dedicate myself to healing, service, and being present for those in need.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: My experiences studying abroad in two different countries broadened my understanding of other cultures while also allowing me to empathize with its inherent discomforts. While studying in Spain, I lived with a host family. Adjusting to the environment of a new culture and trying to navigate an unfamiliar family dynamic all while only speaking Spanish was overwhelming at first. But despite the cultural differences, I ended up forming a beautiful and close relationship with the family. In Vienna, Austria, I studied privately under a professional Austrian flutist. Being mentored by someone from a different culture was a valuable learning experience for me. My teacher had philosophies, standards, and ways of giving feedback that were different from those of any of my American instructors. As a foreigner, I felt it was imperative for me to respect and learn from her customs. I got the most out of both experiences once I allowed myself to lean into the discomfort of the unfamiliar and adapt.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: After attending high-risk obstetrics rounds at East Boston Neighborhood Health Center, I became more aware of the lack of informational resources available to new and expecting mothers in this underserved patient population. I researched classes that were offered in the area, but none of them were taught in Spanish and few were geared toward a low-income audience. With the support of a grant, I designed a free series of workshops in Spanish for new and expecting mothers. While this was a small endeavor in the face of massive health disparities, the workshops made an impact on mothers in the community because they offered a space that was designed specifically for them to learn and connect with each other. The workshops enforced autonomy in healthcare and parenting, because access to the proper information allows for decision-making with confidence. At Rush, I hope to continue to use my resources to make an impact in the community by promoting patient empowerment and autonomy.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I consider myself to be extremely lucky in the limited ways that the pandemic has impacted my plans and goals. The biggest challenge I faced was the shift in modality of most of my experiences from in-person to virtual. All of my classes were virtual from March of 2020 until I graduated in May of 2021, making it more difficult to access help from faculty or collaborate with classmates. Attending lab sessions online posed its own challenges; I had to learn how to grasp the concepts of the procedures without the opportunity to perform them myself. Additionally, my internship with the care navigation team at East Boston Neighborhood Health Center was switched to remote in the spring of 2020. Instead of meeting with patients for consults at the resource center like I had been doing, I was only able to make phone calls. Being remote made it more challenging to connect with patients and gain a complete understanding of their needs, especially since we were communicating in Spanish.

Inst_Action_Desc:
In preparation for the Cell Biology midterm my sophomore year, I created an extensive study guide that covered all class materials in great detail. During group study sessions leading up to the exam, my classmates and I discussed important concepts using my study guide as an outline. When taking the open-book, online exam, I utilized my study guide the best I could. However, this study guide was shared to the classmates I worked with, and I was naive to use the same study material on an exam that did not permit group-work. On two questions that asked about a specific concept that we had covered during the study sessions, my classmates and I had written an answer that was nearly identical to what was on my study guide. 

Ultimately, I was responsible for sharing my study guide with my classmates. Studying as a group is a valuable learning method, but it is a different story when that led to a gateway of cheating in an exam that strictly prohibited collaboration. I should have been aware that as an open-book exam, sharing a study guide was a risk factor for both myself and my fellow classmates. I pushed my boundaries to an extent I now realize I should not have, and it was an experience that fundamentally changed my mindset regarding the need to be more cognizant of my own behavior and those around me.
personal_statement:
I walked towards my fourth patient room in the intensive care unit at Barnes Jewish hospital, clutching my clipboard and iPad. As an undergraduate research assistant, my task was to visit patients undergoing cardiac surgery requiring cardiopulmonary bypass to assess potential symptoms postoperative delirium. Tightening the nose bridge of my K-94 mask and waving hello to the nurses by the monitoring desk, I took a deep breath and knocked. 

Rose was an 86-year-old woman suffering from severe heart problems and the side effects of an invasive surgery; she was exhausted and in pain. She refused an examination when I visited her earlier, sobbing and motioning for me to leave. Still anxious but feeling more prepared, I greeted Rose and approached her with a warm smile, releasing a breath of relief when she smiled back. I conducted the assessment slower than usual, frequently glancing up to check in on Rose’s condition. As soon as I wrapped up the questionnaire, Rose grasped my arm and said, “I’m so sorry about yesterday, dear.” Even though she was the patient helplessly in pain, Rose repeatedly apologized, explaining how her sickness debilitated her. While I was at a loss for words, her sister, Mary, handed me a jeweled keychain shaped like an angel that she had made throughout the weeks of Rose’s hospitalization and thanked me for my patience with Rose. My throat tightened under my smile as I walked out of the room, almost instinctively attaching the keychain to my lanyard. Their gestures of gratitude unveiled a new side of the patient experience in a setting of poor health and distress, leaving me dumbfounded.

Perhaps I was so unnerved by Mary’s kindness because of my experiences with my father’s illness. My father suffered a sudden brain hemorrhage and was in a coma for three months, gaining consciousness only to find complete paralysis of the right side of his body. Despite over twenty years of physical therapy, his footsteps are easy to distinguish because he now limps, his handwriting nearly illegible as he now writes with his left hand. But the most difficult thing for me and my family was his anger and violence whenever he was in pain. My mother would always remind us to consider the source of his rage, however irrational and frustrating, in order to communicate with him. Between each wince of pain he let out and the exasperated outburst that followed, I could see and finally begin to understand his reality as a chronic patient. My relationship with my father is a complicated one, but I am grateful for the challenging (albeit enlightening) times I spent witnessing his side of the patient experience.

While I have been prepared to address the realistic barriers to physical and mental health with patience and empathy, working at Total Access Urgent Care shaped me to be equally as sensitive and perceptive of a patient’s myriad of identities as I would be of their symptoms. During the peak of COVID-19, our team accommodated outrageous patient volumes despite the overwhelming lack of information regarding the pandemic while being short staffed. Every day, I took patients’ vital signs and asked the entry questions written on my clipboard, carrying on routine conversations. That is, until I met Brian.

“Have you had a fever in the last three days?” I habitually inquired. A seemingly simple question I have asked countless times, yet it already assumed so much. “I’m so sorry,” Brian said with uneasy laughter. His eyes darted towards the linoleum floor as he continued, “I can’t afford a thermometer, so I have no idea.” As I prescribed acetaminophen and injected IV fluids to Brian, who indeed had a high fever, I began to reevaluate the position I held in the clinic and what more I could do to provide relief to low-income patients like Brian.

With my own identity as a Korean American raised in Seoul, the strong education in the humanities I received, and experience aiding patients like Brian, the significance of the intersecting factors of identity carries a heavy weight on my back. My exposure to diverse patient populations in St. Louis communities reinforced the subtle implications of identity in medicine, especially its role in the social, physical, and biological determinants of health. As an aspiring physician, I can use my experiences to approach medicine through an intersectional lens, prioritizing foremost the patient’s reality and identity. I will approach each patient holistically and empathetically listen to their stories in order to serve them best.

The path to becoming a physician is a long one, but I can say with confidence that I am ready to begin the journey of a lifelong learner and a committed healer. The resilience and kindness I have seen in patients like Rose drive me towards becoming a physician worthy of their appreciation, and my father’s illness has ingrained in me a habit of learning and accommodating. I am ready to be challenged by difficult and unforeseen situations in the clinic — like Brian’s — because it is through these circumstances that I will learn and grow. I am ready to be a physician who not only has expertise in the medical field, but one who examines all personal identities and perceives the complexity of intersectionality when diagnosing and treating a patient.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As a Korean American raised in Seoul who attended a rigorous boarding school in Concord, Massachusetts from the age of 14, I firmly believe that my racial, cultural, and academic background set the solid foundation of who I am today. Attending a strict boarding school helped me accept criticism as constructive feedback and act accordingly to better my performance. I learned how to approach novel situations with patience, discover alternative solutions with independence, and embraced life-long habits of organization and efficiency. Adapting to an environment that accommodated a different culture, language, and behavioral standard shaped me to be flexible in every situation I find myself in. My interests in medicine began long before attending boarding school, but my experiences in cultural assimilation in New England and aiding diverse patient populations in St. Louis solidified my interests in global health, especially in recognizing and addressing impediments to inclusive healthcare.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
During my undergraduate years, I found comfort in the small, close-knit campus environment that was referred to as ‚Äúthe bubble.‚Äù While the bubble felt reassuring, it troubled me that I knew so little about the community around me. To interact with the neighborhoods and populations of St. Louis, I decided to take initiative by participating in community service groups. _x000D_
 _x000D_
I began volunteering at Project Downtown St. Louis every weekend, where I helped prepare fresh, nutritious meals for the unhoused population in St. Louis. On one particular winter morning, as I was heating up chicken noodle soup, I realized that I could provide more warmth than one bowl of soup. As the student coordinator, I set up donation boxes throughout campus and dormitories to collect winter garments and blankets. As the president of my university‚Äôs chapter of Doctors Without Borders, I recruited volunteers to join me in donation rounds where we provided winter clothing along with the meal we prepared.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
In March of 2020, the intricate cogs that were working together to build my student life and career path were jammed to a stop. The time I spent at the Cerebral Palsy Rehabilitation Program came to a halt, as did every community service group I worked with. My onboarding process to begin research was paused and then canceled entirely until the next academic year. Finding myself with ample time, I pushed forward my start date to work at Total Access Urgent Care._x000D_
 _x000D_
Despite the difficulties of navigating through a global pandemic, I realized that I was fortunate in many ways. As masks became available, I prepared warm meals for the unhoused population in St. Louis. As I became accustomed to a remote work environment, I volunteered as a text line counselor to provide relief to texters. After the tumultuous summer of 2020, I began research studying postoperative delirium. Most importantly, I had the opportunity to work as an essential healthcare worker during a time when my help was vital.

personal_statement:
"Casey, Sam’s not going to make it.” These words from my father, a neurosurgeon at Meritus Health in Maryland, brought me to my knees. Sam was not only a longtime family friend, he had been my guide and mentor throughout my Nonproliferation and Terrorism graduate studies. Years spent as a CIA analyst had made him exceptionally wary of “government corruption” and skeptical of recommendations for vaccination against COVID-19. A few hours later, my mentor would become another pandemic victim. 

Since I was a child administering basic care, including vaccinations and assisting with deliveries, on my family's alpaca farm in Hagerstown Maryland, I have always had an interest in medicine. Enrolling at the University of Richmond, I started pursuing a pre-medical degree but following the Russian annexation of Crimea in 2014, I became equally interested in global cultures and politics. The addition of my Russian Studies joint degree led to additional coursework, including a class where I designed a project on the Russian anti-plague surveillance system, which would eventually provide the seed for their biological weapons program. This burgeoning interest in how other peoples organize themselves in response to public health threats led me to study the intersection of science and national security in the Middlebury Institute of International Studies and the Moscow State Institute of International Relations dual degree program. Following graduation, I landed what I thought at the time was my dream job as a biological weapons counterproliferation analyst at a national laboratory. 

Early in my career, I believed intelligence to be the ideal way to utilize my joint passion for science and understanding people in service of my countrymen. However, over time I developed some moral misgivings about the nature of my work, feeling that I was not in a position to contribute directly to my community. As the pandemic raged outside the guarded walls of our compound, and while many of my pre-medical friends from school were on the front lines in various capacities, I was behind a gate chasing boogeymen. My work had exposed me to tropical and infectious disease research and emergency medicine preparedness, rekindling my love for hard science and leading me to reconsider my earlier decision to not pursue medical school.

The next step meant wholly letting go of who I was to become who I always wanted to be. I left my prized clearance role and accepted a position as a clinical research fellow at Cumberland Valley Retina Consultants (CVR). In my role, I assist with preparing patients for interocular treatment and coordinate two clinical research trials focusing on management of age related degenerative and diabetic eye conditions. It lacked the pay and pomp of my prior work, but I immediately loved the multitude of moments for human connection it afforded me. Be that redirecting an agitated dementia patient or calming a child before a surgical procedure, I became completely enamored with medicine’s vast capacity for good. 

My professional background also led to a volunteer position with the Red Cross Disaster Action Team as an on call responder for local disaster victims. Over the past year, I have been called to assist numerous victims of house and tent encampment fires, working to provide immediate financial relief, housing and other services. Victims like Sue, who’s ex-husband battled mental illness and in a fit of rage, set fire to her home, leaving her and her five year old son homeless. Sitting beside Sue to go through the options I could provide for food and shelter, she began to sob. Setting down the brochures I had put together for her, I placed my arm around her shoulder, reassuring her that we were going take care of her and her son and that they were not alone. “Thank you, I really needed to hear that,” she whispered as her sobs slowed. Sometimes, our best service comes in simply being present.

My years of study, research, and work in national security and counterterrorism honed my adaptability to new and challenging environments, often requiring me to master material in which I had little or no academic background. In these roles, I was consistently able to quickly rise and take on more responsibility than I was initially given. Skills including weighing competing hypotheses to analyze and determine relevance to the problem at hand, have translated well in my current clinical role. I also developed strong intercultural communication skills as a graduate student both here and in Russia presenting highly technical content to individuals from a multitude of backgrounds. Yet it has been my interactions with my patients at CVR and those like Sue, that continue to reaffirm my decision to return to my aspirations to become a physician. While the technical and scientific attributes embodied by a healthcare career will always pique my intellectual curiosity, it is the ability to provide comfort and compassion to others during what may be one of the worst days of their life that drives me. It is my hope to one day provide guidance to individuals like Sam, my mentor, to gain the trust needed to guide their healthcare decision process and to partner with those in need as part of the next generation of 21st century physicians.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: ‚ÄúYour eyes are green like mine!‚Äù Not the first words I expected from my new roommate, I soon learned that green eyes were rare in Anel's native Kazakhstan. Our backgrounds could not have been more different‚Äîwhere the Appalachians had towered over my childhood, Almaty's skyscrapers had hers. By pointing out our similarities, she was looking for a connection. Very different in our cultural upbringings, we frequently disagreed, particularly on topics relating to gender norms. However, her unabashed enthusiasm and non-judgmental attitude, coupled with her ability to discuss viewpoints from a genuine place of interest on both sides, blossomed into a deep friendship in that tiny Moscow flat. Anel taught me that looking for any tiny similarity, even green eyes, can connect us to those unlike ourselves. I still keep her grandmother‚Äôs chak chak recipe, scrawled on the back of a receipt, as a reminder of the time we shared and of my promise to visit her one day._x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Richmond Virginia's complicated racial past left lasting scars on its contemporary civil life. One of the most insidious issues I learned about from the schoolchildren I tutored was that of de facto school segregation. A desire to help further led me to Kristen Larson, former school board member running for city council on a platform of providing equal access to quality education. Using a work study scholarship, I joined her campaign as an unpaid intern. A core team of two, we canvassed hundreds of houses and engaged with the local community at events. In the end, we managed to unseat the establishment candidate on election day. Kristen taught me the basics of grassroots organization, how to maximize impact with limited resources, and that one highly motivated person can make a difference. Since her election, Kristen has helped establish a city Ethics Commission, secured additional funding for public schools, and protected public parks ‚Äî key centers of community ‚Äî from development.

personal_statement:
