“Is your fridge running? Then you better go catch it!” Making this prank call is typical behavior for a 14-year-old. Yet for 14-year-old “Cam” at Covenant House Florida (CHF), an under-21 homeless shelter where I spent two summers as a volunteer intern, the consequences were different. Because this harmless prank was against CHF rules, Cam was removed from one of his last housing options and separated from his brother, friends, and support network at CHF. 

I will never forget when I learned that Cam would be expelled. His absence raced through my mind the entire day, and when I checked out, I gave him a hug and assured him that he would be okay. Getting in my car to head home, I broke down in tears. I had studied poverty in my classes as a poverty studies minor, but its unfairness and inequity were not made tangible to me until that moment. The sadness and frustration of seeing Cam removed from CHF has lasted with me far beyond that day in July 2019, as the experience sparked a fire within me to fight for the vulnerable and work for justice in every interaction. My time at CHF was immensely important to my commitment to enter the medical field. I learned how to effectively communicate with the youth at CHF, a population who (not unlike those sick at a hospital) had undergone trauma and were skeptical of my ability or willingness to help them. My experiences there shaped in me an attitude of and ability to practice compassion. I gained confidence in meeting people at their most vulnerable state and working to alleviate their suffering, whether that be with the youth at CHF or the patients I hope to treat one day. I look forward to gaining even more experience working with vulnerable populations during my year of service beginning in August 2022, as a Social Work Assistant at Mercy Medical Center in Baltimore, MD. 

Catholic theologian James Keenan wrote that “Mercy is the willingness to enter into the chaos of another.” If this is the case, then perhaps no other vocation involves more mercy than being a physician. Entering the chaos of others is certainly an accurate way to describe some nights on duty as a Resident Assistant (RA). One particularly chaotic night stands out, where in a span of 30 minutes, a resident fell down the stairs and broke his tailbone, three parties had to be shut down, and a resident tearfully shared with me his struggles back home and in adjusting to college. Strangely, during the chaos of that night, I found a deep sense of fulfillment. I was entirely focused on the moments at hand, working to help the community I care so much about and doing what I could to ease the suffering of my residents. My time as an RA taught me what leadership and mercy truly is – sharing life with others and walking with them in both their joys and sorrows. My role gave me the unique privilege of being a friend, mentor, and resource to my residents, and made me a better leader. In walking with my residents throughout the year by mourning their losses, celebrating their successes, and helping them thrive in the dorm, I made a real impact in their lives. Being an RA has given me a small taste of the responsibility each physician has in engaging their patients at their most distressed times and serving as a trusted resource. 

Gaining a patient’s trust is perhaps the most important role of a physician. Trust was something I fully gave and received as a counselor at Camp Sweeney, a summer camp for children with Type 1 diabetes, in 2021. The campers there trusted me from the start to take care of their Type 1 diabetes and administer the proper corrections for their blood sugar. Yet they also trusted me to be their friend, an older brother, and a positive example in their life who will instill confidence in them to take on a disease as daunting as Type 1 diabetes, or any other challenge life throws at them. I realized this trust in “Adam”, a high school senior at the camp. Late one night, he told me that he could not believe how hard I worked to care for him. He said despite meeting me only a week ago, he viewed me as just as much of a positive role model as his father. It humbled me to think that the compassion I showed Adam in such a short time could lead to such a trusting relationship between us. Yet for the campers to trust me like Adam did, I had to trust my fellow counselors. Our days were long and packed with activities from 7am – midnight. After the campers went to bed, we cleaned the cabins, entered medical data, made lesson plans, and communicated with campers’ parents. We were sleep deprived and had to rely on each other in every way, and we were a team that functioned because we trusted each other. I will forever be grateful to the campers who taught me how to trust others and be trusted, and to the counselors who taught me how to work as a team under even the most difficult of circumstances.
            
In reflecting on my experiences over the past few years, I see that I have grown to love being present to help others in the chaos and suffering of their lives. At the heart of the patient-physician relationship is trust and compassion, and I hope that I can build off my experiences to continue to walk with others through their illness.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
I knew the experiences of the youth at Covenant House Florida (CHF) would contrast mine, but I did not know how different we might appear to be. They were almost all Black or Latino; I was White and Asian. They often had a different primary language from English, ate different foods than me, and had cultural traditions and perspectives separate from my own. They had undergone trauma I could not imagine, and I had immense privileges that they had never experienced. _x000D_
_x000D_
Yet we were also remarkably similar. We were teenagers who grew up in South Florida and dealt with the same challenges of finding your place as an adolescent. In both the similarities and differences I found with the youth, I formed deep connections and learned that trusting relationships can be forged across cultural and socioeconomic differences through genuine care and a desire to better understand another. It is through this same care and desire to understand that I hope to connect with my patients._x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
In Summer 2020, the worsening pandemic and the murder of George Floyd and its ensuing protests highlighted the deep systemic racism in our nation, and its effects ranging from health disparities to police brutality. _x000D_
_x000D_
During this difficult summer, seeking to make a positive impact in my community, I returned to CHF. I could not provide an answer to the youth about the injustice present in our world, but I could provide hope in small ways. I disinfected surfaces, led guitar classes, and started conversations that allowed the youth and I to process, together, the events of the summer. _x000D_
_x000D_
That summer, I realized that it is often small, everyday actions that are most impactful. As a physician, I will not be able single-handedly eliminate disparities in health or ensure access to quality care for everyone in the world, or even the US. However, I can do my part to show compassion and understanding to my patients, and to be attuned to their unique needs and circumstances. _x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact:
Though I struggled to adjust to online learning and the lack of in-person clinical opportunities, the pandemic also affected my view of medicine and my potential role in it. It brought to light the need for education and equity within the medical field and throughout society. There was and still is a constant stream of misinformation regarding COVID-19, ranging from its origins to the safety and efficacy of vaccines. Our world needs physicians who will steadfastly communicate the truth and earn the public‚Äôs trust, and I hope to be in a position to do that. _x000D_
_x000D_
COVID-19 also exacerbated already vast disparities in health. Those who were already poor and marginalized suffered the brunt of the health and economic consequences of the pandemic. Hospitals in the inner city and rural areas were overwhelmed, and patients and medical professionals alike suffered as a result. COVID-19 further strengthened my commitment to practice in areas with the greatest need and fight health disparities.

Hrdshp_Comments: As a first-generation student of blue-collar immigrant parents who would later become citizens, I struggled with navigating my way through school. Throughout much of my adolescence, my father struggled with alcoholism and left me responsible for taking care of my younger sister every afternoon. At the time, my mother worked the swing shift, and I recall the conversations we'd share over the phone regarding my father's status and where he had been most of the night. I remember the feelings of defeat and embarrassment in the classroom the following day after failing to turn in my homework. I never prioritized school simply because I had other priorities at home. It wasn't until I had a child of my own that my father managed his addiction and stopped for good. By then, I managed to graduate high school even when half of my class did not. I entered college with zero guidance. However, I made an effort to transform myself into the scholar I am today. These circumstances that I endured have taught me the value of a stable household and the impact that social and family dynamics can have on one's health. Having my own family taught me time-management skills and the importance of leading by example, and this is what I will continue to do for others who require guidance.
personal_statement:
She was writhing in distress in her hospital gown; I suppose anything to feel an ounce of relief. The epidural had yet to take effect, and intensity filled the room. I tried to comfort my partner in any way possible, from physical touch to distraction, as she birthed our first child. After the first invasive attempt at an epidural, the anesthesiologist advised that she wait for the effects to “kick in”. However, only half of her lower body was numb. The physician returned, performed the procedure a second time and within moments, her pain and suffering was instantly alleviated. Her anxiety had subsided, and the screams were replaced by the cries of our newborn baby boy. It amazed me how the physician was able to manipulate the physiology of the human body beyond the cognitive aspect with the use of medicine to allow for such a beautiful moment to surface. This ultimately led to my transition from envisioning myself counseling in an office, to one day counseling patients at the bedside. 

Initially, I gravitated towards the field of counseling, specifically regarding addiction and substance use. In my youth, I was convinced that alcohol use in the home was the norm. Growing up, I recognized that my father fulfilled the characteristics of a high-functioning alcoholic. I vividly remember playing in the rocks outside of my father’s AA meetings and standing at his bedside when doctors explained that he was nearing liver failure. I often wonder what would have become of my father if he had not sought addiction treatment. Witnessing this disease take its toll on my father, as well as the patients that I frequently encountered in the various mental health facilities around town, allowed me to recognize that treating addiction lies beyond the behavioral aspect. 

As a Latino student, in addition to school, I navigated my way through construction sites to provide for my family while juggling the demands of fatherhood. I quickly realized that a strong work ethic doesn’t always translate well into academic success. As a first-generation, I struggled to maintain the balance between these various roles, and my grades suffered as a result. I realized that in order to achieve my goals in medicine, education needed to take priority, a decision that ultimately resulted in my growth. I began to shape my day around school, rather than shape my day around work; I began dedicating specific time to spend with my kids, forcing me to be productive during my allocated study time. I applied myself and as a result, I fostered academic success through critical thinking and self-discipline. 

During this time, I also immersed myself in healthcare as a mobile phlebotomist. I found myself surrounded by hundreds of experiences and anecdotes that were not my own. Over the years of working with the incarcerated, low-income, psychiatric, homeless, disabled, and Latinx communities throughout Southern Nevada, I made it a habit to form personable connections with patients. I recall a time with a Hispanic patient named “Angel” whose labs I routinely drew. Angel was suffering from cancer and a terminal diagnosis; he expressed how isolated and lonely he felt, partly due to a lack of communication. Anticipating his mortality and fearing mechanical conventions would replace his physiological functions, I was able to provide him with familiarity in a foreign environment through our shared native language. I sought to provide him with comfort and intimacy as he spent his remaining days in a single-room hospital bed. 

When my mother suffered a debilitating back injury from a car wreck, she expressed similar feelings of isolation during her lengthy hospital stay. This event, along with my clinical experiences, also illuminated the health disparities that exist in medicine, particularly in regard to linguistic and cultural differences. I felt privileged to share in some of the most intimate moments of people’s lives, as I had done with Angel, even if I was only there to fulfill a laboratory task. I took advantage of my role to form relationships with patients, sharing laughs with the patients and their families and creating a more human experience. This furthered my desire to provide a personal approach to healthcare with my future patients and to improve their quality of life. 

Ultimately, my experiences within the Las Vegas community allowed me to recognize that genetic, environmental, and physiological contributing factors all complicate the treatment of chronic diseases. In my clinical experiences, I have had the opportunity to improve communication by mitigating language barriers in healthcare. I recognize that limiting myself to cognitive treatment in counseling would leave me unfulfilled, as I seek to treat the entire person, as I witnessed physicians do during the birth of our first child. I aim to deepen my understanding of the disease processes as a diverse physician, serving the vulnerable communities that surround me. My passion for counseling plays a significant role in my bedside manner, and I truly believe that the opportunity of a medical education would give me the platform to fulfill my ambitions as a physician, especially in the many intersections of care within medicine.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I met my mentor during my undergraduate education, who invited me to join her research lab. I was immersed with people of varying backgrounds and identities in an academic setting. Until then, I had only drawn blood from a diverse population and worked with other Hispanics in construction. I was provided the opportunity to engage and learn about the increasing hardships other minority groups faced. During a meeting, the leader asked us a question about the results of our study. I voiced my opinion only to discover that others did not agree with me and that I may have been wrong in my assumptions. Although my answer was based on my experiences, I never considered how their diverse experiences may have been different. I know now that when diverse individuals are allowed to collaborate, we are also given the opportunity to challenge assumptions and biases. I gathered a multicultural awareness from this group and learned to compromise when others provided a perspective different from mine.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: My experiences in the Las Vegas community have shown me the importance of compassionate care and increasing representation in healthcare. There have been plenty of instances where I was the only Spanish-speaking person in the hospital. I am reminded of the opportunities I have had to translate and interpret for those in my community, including my parents. As a phlebotomist, medical scribe, and Spanish interpreter, I have communicated the needs of those with limited English proficiency while breaking down the barriers that would otherwise result in poorer health outcomes. As a representative of the Latinx community, I recognize that I am uniquely positioned to educate and advocate for individuals within the Latinx and immigrant populations with whom I can relate on a cultural and socioeconomic level. I hope to showcase my experiences gained in Southern Nevada early on at Rush Medical College, specifically caring for those experiencing inequities in healthcare on the West Side of Chicago
7_-_COVID_Impact: As a healthcare worker prior to the pandemic, I recall feeling a sense of guilt while drawing a patient's blood as they physically declined. Meanwhile, their family was forced to stand outside the window, attempting to communicate with them. Having only met the patient for a few minutes, I became their liaison with the outside world. Even while mouthing words through the glass, I felt I was stealing precious moments away from their family members as they took their last few breaths. The protocols during the pandemic made for difficult times within the healthcare realm, but I found meaning in my service to these patients. My guilt had transformed into feelings of gratitude. Outside the hospital, childcare opportunities dwindled for long stretches due to COVID-19, and the research opportunities and undergraduate courses I was involved in had transitioned into a remote setting. Thankfully, with the help of community programs, we continue to manage through this hardship.

personal_statement:
At the age of 11, I thought entering middle school would be the most joyous time of my life, it never occurred to me how fast plans can change. I remember one day, sitting in the waiting room of an unfamiliar doctor’s office. We were waiting on my sister, who was having a minor surgery. It seemed to last an eternity. When the surgeon emerged calling for us, everything moved so quickly as the next thing we knew, we were told that my sister has an advanced form of Non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma and needs to be admitted to the hospital immediately for treatment. I recall the brief moment I was able to see her, still unsure about what was happening. 

All through this calamity, I was able to see the dedication and diligence of the doctors who tirelessly worked to save her life. I was filled with hope and determination as the medical team devoted themselves to her care, while also uplifting my mother, father, and us siblings. Through them, we were able to steal as many precious moments as we could to be by her side. As she improved, they celebrated with us – every encouraging test result was as much of a joy for them as it was for us. For that time, her doctors were a part of our family. Seeing all they did for her, and the relationships they built with my family helped me realize my calling. The day we received the news that she was in remission was the day I decided that I wanted to become a doctor. 

As much of a driving force this motivator was, I soon learned that the real challenges and hard work that I would have to persevere through in pursuing this profession were ahead of me. I have been fortunate to have a bit of medicine in my family as my uncle, a cardiothoracic surgeon, has been a great help. His guidance led to volunteer opportunities and shadowing experiences early on in my journey. In 7th grade I thought I may want to go into cardiothoracic surgery; so, we set up some time over a break for me to come to shadow him. Despite being only 13, the entire staff treated me as if I were a serious medical student. I followed him throughout his day, standing by his side as he performed surgeries. Being so close to the operations was thrilling, but also shocking. During the first surgery, I had to step aside and sit down, as the smell and the warm climate were making me nauseous. A nurse brought me water, and for a moment, I contemplated leaving. I knew I was getting a great opportunity, so, despite this minor hindrance, I returned to my post and watched attentively the rest of the surgery and those that followed. I never had to step away for the rest of the day. While I made it through, the thought of leaving and going back to comfort was tempting. I know that medicine presents many challenges, but I learned I can face and overcome them by setting aside discomfort to learn. Not wanting to go home empty-handed, my uncle and I collected some research on the heart and its function that I later presented to my family. While I did not receive a grade for my un-assigned project, it still hangs on the wall of my bedroom as one of the proudest moments of my childhood.

For much of my time in high school, I volunteered in the cancer ward at my local hospital. Today, my sister is as strong as ever, and the opportunity to help other families has been a motivator for my volunteer work. In the beginning, I worked a general role, providing support for staff and families. I gathered lunch or coffee or whatever was needed for the families whose blank expressions mirrored those of my family as we waited on my sister. I knew small things such as a magazine or someone to listen with a smile could break the monotonous daily lives of the families in such moments of hardship. Most days I stayed much longer than what I was scheduled for, as comforting others doesn’t stop at the end of a shift. My commitment was noted as families often spoke to my supervisor about my dedication to their aid. While I have pursued other opportunities since my time there, I still visit the ward on my school breaks to aid in any way I can. I often come to help train new volunteers in the unit. Learning to lead a synchronized team, ensure the utmost commitment from the volunteers through accountability, and continue to help emotionally provide for families has helped me build my leadership skills and further develop empathy. The unit I volunteered at was awarded the hospital’s Excellence award, which still leaves me smiling today.

With this experience, I’ve also learned that not all stories have a happy ending and that my family’s experience was very fortunate. My contribution was meaningful, but also difficult. I have had to wrap my arms around weeping mothers, who were forced to say goodbye to a life’s worth of hopes and dreams. I have seen patients with positive outlooks take a devastating turn for the worse. With this, I have learned that in this life, nothing is certain, things can change in an instant, for better and for worse. It is the families that have the strength to push on, and the caring medical staff that inspire me to contribute in any way I can to advance change in the right direction. To make these great, meaningful changes, I must become a physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: My time volunteering and the Halim Clinic has broadened my world views. Its mission is to provide effective, quality care to those unable to afford treatment by focusing on a patient-centered, outcome-based, and cost-effective approach to medicine. The clinic is a Muslim initiative and many of the patients are Arabic-speaking. This has presented me with a great opportunity to learn and care for people unlike myself, as I am not Muslim and do not speak Arabic. In this setting, I learned to care for people while respecting their culture, making sure they are comfortable and that a respectful relationship is maintained. I also learned how to effectively communicate despite the language barrier. Here, I used creative means to ensure a mutual understanding between the patient and myself. Understanding that each patient interaction is unique, this taught me the importance of varying approaches to patient care to best fit each patient‚Äôs cultural, emotional, and physical needs.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: During COVID, I worked as a caregiver in an assisted living facility. Our community was on lockdown which restricted residents to their rooms, limiting face-to-face interactions. While this was done for their safety, it made for a lonely environment. The only interactions residents had were with us caregivers who helped them throughout the day. I made sure to spend as much time as I could interacting with each resident, but with over 100 residents, my time was short with each. I had an idea to connect the residents together to emulate life before COVID. Each room had an iPad for the residents, so for those interested, I installed Zoom and connected them together. Many who were hesitant would join later when they heard laughter and joy from the rooms next door. I was able to make this uncertain time a little more comfortable by connecting the residents, making all the difference for the morale of the community.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The COVID pandemic has impacted and changed the way I approach my education. With the switch to remote learning, I learned to become more independent in my education by having to do outside research on topics that challenged me. Prior to this, I could ask a question in class or directly speak to my peers, but with online classes, I was without these immediate resources. At first, this was challenging, as it is easy to get lost in the vast amount of information online. After some time, however, I became efficient in finding and applying the information to continue to do well in my exams and classes. This quick adaptation helped me in my medical school preparation by allowing me to truly learn the material in my undergraduate classes that are the foundation of what is needed to succeed in medical school. I also became better at independent learning, which in conjunction with collaboration, has helped me maximize my learning.

personal_statement:
My drive to become a physician stems from wanting to follow in my father’s footsteps. As someone who has dedicated his life to others, he has become my biggest inspiration. From a young age, I have been exposed to the various roles of a physician. The first role is as a healer. My father is a pediatrician, and seeing him return a child in a better state than they arrived at the hospital taught me the most pivotal role a physician has. The second role is as an educator. Watching my father sit down and talk to his patients, the patient’s families, and even our own extended family revealed to me the collective role a physician has in their community. The third role, and not the last, is as an empathizer. I have seen how important it is for my father to sit down with patients, make a connection with them, answer their questions and learn about their ailments, diagnose them, and eventually see them through their treatment. All in all, the pursuit of a profession that serves simultaneously as a healer, an educator, and an empathizer in a community has driven me to dedicate my life to the betterment of others.

My father served as a spark in pursuing a career in healthcare; this initial spark has only been reaffirmed through my various clinical experiences in the healthcare setting. In particular, in high school, while volunteering at a local hospital, I remember a patient named “Delilah”. She had cancer, and she was visibly sick and frail. However, for some reason, she had a smile on her face and was dancing to the song “Happy” by Will Pharrel. With my careful ear, I was able to hear that she was on track to start a new cancer treatment. I was later able to sit down bedside next to her. She told me about previous treatments that were unsuccessful, and that her biggest motivation to continue persevering was to make it to her daughter’s wedding in the coming summer. In medical school, I am eager to learn the foundations of the body, how and why things go wrong, and the various treatments patients depend on. 

A few weeks later, I ran into Delilah again. This time, she was hysterically crying. The latest round of her treatments had prevented her cancer from metastasizing. She was crying tears of joy. Seeing her patient experience, and the diligence of her surrounding healthcare team, taught me the personal side of medicine. Physicians are leaders in the hospital setting, and have an enormous impact on patients' lives and their families. I cannot wait to be a part of that.

	In college, I continued my clinical experience as a medical assistant at a pediatric clinic and as a health scholar at a couple hospitals. What I took from these experiences was that there are inequalities in access to healthcare, and there are disparities in how people trust healthcare and those that practice medicine. Many are reluctant to go to the hospital due to costs and the inability to understand their treatment. Additionally, many have many reasons why they delay treatment, which may lead to chronic disease. As a physician, I am eager to break down some of the many barriers in accessibility to healthcare. I strive to take care of patients who know I care, trust my recommendations, and leave my care with a positive regard as it pertains to the healthcare system. 

It will be a great privilege to practice medicine. Having been inspired by my dad, and reaffirming those aspirations through clinical volunteering and employment, I have come to learn the importance a physician has in the clinic. I hope to heal, educate, and empathize with those in need, and advocate for the marginalized as to mitigating the indirect inequities that have resulted in the practice of medicine. I hope to be a resource to those who do not fully understand their treatments, and allow them to live happy, safe, and healthy lives. Medical school will be just another step in my journey to take care of, inform, and provide others with a sense of security, just as my father has with his patients.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
As a second-generation Egyptian immigrant, I have always been regarded as unique. I also practice a faith unfamiliar to many others, and my family comes from a Muslim country. I am Middle Eastern, and those around me are as different as I am. In healthcare, these differences manifest themselves in many ways, and I can draw on my life experiences to contribute to a medical community that seeks to cater to the many needs of those it aims to provide care for._x000D_
_x000D_
Throughout my clinical, research, and volunteering experiences, as well as my undergraduate education, l have always worked with people different from myself to achieve goals. I have also always gone out of my way to learn about those around me. At Rush, I will contribute to the culture of collaboration in the community because I have learned to appreciate people different from myself.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
Working at a food bank has exposed me to the inequities faced in the community and the need to provide the underserved with proper resources, including health care. Barriers in access to affordable food, transportation, and health care services make it difficult for underserved communities to live a healthy life. Working as a medical assistant in Palmdale, a medically underserved area, also brought my attention to the necessity of health services for everyone. I am thankful for the opportunity to reach these communities and do what I can to lessen their difficulties. However, there is still much more to be done. As a medical student and future physician I will be able to do more to improve the health of underserved communities._x000D_
_x000D_
I am committed to working alongside my peers, and eventually taking care of patients, no matter who they are, where they live, or what they look like. I will strive to better understand and lessen socioeconomic disparities caused by racial and ethnic inequities

personal_statement:
As I took Sam to the fishing hole, I saw a flicker of sorrow pass her typically jovial face as she watched her cabin mates head down to the docks for sunrise boating. This visible vulnerability took me by surprise, and although her disappointment struck me deeply, I was at a loss for how to console her. Should I cater to her jesting nature and distract her with jokes? Or was this a time where she simply needed a hug? As she looked woefully up at me, I knew that although I was not able to change her situation, my presence and companionship would help ease her disappointment.

Sam was too old and too smart to be easily redirected from her sorrow. Softly, I broached the subject. With tears in her eyes, Sam told me about how much she wanted to be like the other kids, just for once. She was embarrassed that even at a camp for sick kids she was still too ill to be with the rest of the pack. There was nothing that I could say to reverse her sorrow, but I did my best to help her through the gloom, acknowledging her sorrow, validating her feelings, and expressing my friendship. By the end of the morning, we had caught 12 fish, including the biggest sunfish Sam had ever seen. Sam did not need a fleet of boats to make her morning bright, she needed to be heard, understood, and celebrated for who she was. As we walked back to the cabin after a vibrant, slimy morning, Sam held my hand tightly, and smiled quietly.

Throughout that summer, I was not only challenged to care for many campers' physical needs, but also to comfort those who resented and feared their conditions and encourage them in their abilities. Before working at The Painted Turtle, I considered myself a supportive, caring, and empathetic person. However, after spending a summer of tough conversations, hospital visits, and midnight bathroom fiascos, I found that my natural empathy needed to be molded and honed into something more powerful--compassion in action. As I began to stretch and flex my empathy into compassion it became more and more natural for me to relate to campers, to anticipate their needs, and most importantly to create a space that allowed them to communicate what they needed to say.

I did not always have the perfect line to reverse despair, but I left camp at the end of the summer proud of the ways that I had challenged myself to grow as a caregiver. The Painted Turtle changed my understanding of what it meant to be an excellent physician, but shadowing Dr. Raju in Gastroenterology provided witness to this in a new way.

Prior to shadowing Dr. Raju, my exposure to clinical settings strictly encompassed either pediatric or geriatric patients, so this experience gave further insight into life as a physician. As I followed Dr. Raju from one appointment to the next, I found that unlike at camp or even in Family Practice shadowing, Dr. Raju saw adult patients ranging from people who were completely comfortable getting routine procedures to people who had wasted their organs with drinking and smoking to people who were even aggressive and rude during their visits. I was impressed to see that Dr. Raju went above and beyond for his patients regardless of their past interactions.

One patient in particular came in for a routine colonoscopy. Unlike most other patients, this patient was exceptionally rude, repeatedly insulting Dr. Raju in front of the other team members. Rather than let this individual’s actions affect him, Dr. Raju continued to treat this patient the same way as his other patients--speaking with them and addressing them in a respectful manner while maintaining professionalism by being assertive when necessary. While this impressed me, I was truly humbled when I saw Dr. Raju continue to take the extra time and care with this patient necessary to check and double check every wall of the colon. Dr. Raju showed me that true compassion in medicine goes beyond simply doing what you can for a doe-eyed child, it can be tedious--repeating a procedure for the thousandth time. It can be trying--working with patients who manifest their fears through aggression. And it can be frustrating--watching as patients disregard medical advice.

Although I am not yet a physician, I see a similar parallel in my tutoring interactions. Many students can be apathetic, cynical, and even verbally abusive. In my three years of tutoring and mentoring, I have seen how differently people react to challenges and uncertainty. I have learned to adapt to these situations, and I have discovered how to help students find the tools to express themselves. By connecting what I learned in my camp and shadowing experiences to my past three years of tutoring, I have honed the skills necessary to become someone worthy of wearing the medical badge. I hope to continue building on this foundation of compassion through a medical education that makes me both more knowledgeable and more human.
In the past four years, my understanding of what it means to be an excellent physician has evolved. Without the ability to turn empathy into compassion and compassion into communication, prescriptions and instructions fall flat. At a time when public faith in science is being put to the test, I want to be a physician that restores hope, communicates genuinely, and earns patient trust.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
From going to Polka festivals to speaking Croatian with my grandma, I have always enjoyed embracing my culture and learning about people‚Äôs cultures; however, it was not until working at The Painted Turtle, a summer camp for children and teens with serious illnesses, that I saw how medical conditions could create a culture of their own. _x000D_
As summer began, the week for campers with skeletal dysplasia was my first real introduction to how blind I was to what life with a serious medical condition included. As I got to know the girls in my cabin, I saw their extensive and vibrant community. I had always thought of culture as mostly driven by ethnic traditions, but these middle schoolers from all over the United States were united by their medical condition. This experience showed me that the role of a physician involves more than knowing how to treat an illness: it is knowing how to treat the patient-- recognizing that their experiences make them who they are.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: When I began tutoring at Waco High School, I found that many of the students were in need of not only tutoring, but also of attention, motivation, and most importantly, praise for what they could do. Many of the students were impressed with my status as a college student, and as their tutor, I worked hard to connect with my students and demonstrate that I was once in their very shoes struggling with the exact same concepts. As the weeks went by, it was extremely satisfying to see the transformations that ensued. While these students may not remember me or even what I taught, I believe that giving them a positive interaction with learning has helped to improve their perception of themselves and their abilities. As I prepare to spend my gap year teaching middle school science, I hope I will be able to continue helping my students learn course material while gaining confidence in themselves and appreciation for their abilities.
7_-_COVID_Impact: As an undergraduate student, I had planned on joining Dr. Law‚Äôs research lab which looks into the mechanisms of cardiac dysfunction in cancer cachexia. I would have joined Dr. Law‚Äôs lab at the start of the spring semester in 2021; however due to COVID-19 and other restrictions, Dr. Law was unable to open her lab at the planned time. Although I graduated before I could work in the lab, I attended monthly meetings with Dr. Law to discuss existing literature regarding cachexia, and I completed courses and received certificates of training in animal worker OHSP, bloodborne pathogens, scalpel and needle, formaldehyde, compressed gas, autoclave, fire, radiation, cryogen, hazardous waste, and physical, chemical, and biological hazards safety.

Hrdshp_Comments:
My path to college was filled with barriers from financial hardship to parents that never attended college. I attended a high poverty high school with 48.5% of students classified as socioeconomically disadvantaged and minority enrollment of 84%. I qualified for the free lunch program since my family’s income was below 130% of the federal poverty guideline and eligible for food stamps when I applied. I never had money to hire a tutor or buy test prep courses. Not deterred, I worked harder.

When applying for college, I was creative. I researched and emailed admissions for fee waivers and sat down with the scholarship book and applied to every one I thought applicable. In total, I received 11 scholarships. I negotiated with one college on tuition price and had my aid increased by 50%. I commuted 3 hours daily to downtown LA since I could not afford to live and eat on campus. While classmates paid thousands on tutors, I self-studied for classes and had a job to pay for books.

I’ve had barriers to my success, but I am continually determined to not let them hinder my ambitions. I credit my resilience and success, as a first-generation Mexican woman with a graduate degree from a top college, to my solid support system and the assistance I have received from teachers, advisors, family, friends, and strangers.
Fee_Assistance_Program: Y - Invalid for Application Submission information
personal_statement:
My introduction to the world of medicine was abrupt. Waving goodbye to my father as he left home, my ears were pierced minutes later by a deafening bang followed by a chilling silence. Sprinting outside, my eyes were met by the sight of mangled metal. Leaving the neighborhood, his car had been hit by a truck that ran the red light. Minutes later, police, ambulances, and fire trucks arrived. In the chaos, I was helpless. Dazed, I watched the EMTs treat my dad. Inspired, I enrolled in an EMT course the next summer. I never wanted to feel as helpless as I did that day. Soon enough I was practicing emergency medicine in my college community. Each patient represented a complex puzzle that required swift problem-solving and recall of scientific knowledge.

The transition to college and commuting was difficult as reflected in my grades. My dad was prematurely forced into early retirement my freshman year from his warehouse job due to the liability of him having chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, peripheral artery disease, and deep vein thrombosis. During the 6 months it took to receive his pension, our family had no income. I looked for a stable job, earned money on the side for gas from tutoring, and attended classes. I experienced the lowest grades of my academic career. It seemed easier to give up, but I persisted. I wanted to prove to myself that I could come back from disappointment and learn more about subjects that fascinated me. It was only a small part of making me stronger, but it begged the most obvious question, why study the human body and medicine?

The answer came unexpectedly and more abruptly than my initial introduction to medicine. In my final year of graduate school, my father suffered a stroke, an occlusion of the left internal carotid artery, leaving him paralyzed and unable to care for himself. Hearing the neurologist explain over the phone what brain regions were affected, I recalled the anatomical regions I studied while brain tracing MRI data in my research. There were so many variables to consider, and they couldn’t say for sure if his speech or motor movements would improve. Only that they recommended a nursing home. That was unacceptable to me. It was the height of the COVID-19 pandemic. There was no vaccine and constant reports of disturbingly high nursing home fatality rates and severe staff shortages. There was no assurance of when or if I would ever see him again with a no visitor policy. He wouldn’t be able to call or text in his state. It was then my family made a decision. Upon his discharge, I took on the role of caregiver and advocate. This role has become my greatest challenge.

Returning home, help was limited and costly. I navigated performing rehabilitation with him each day, monitoring alcohol and nicotine detoxification and withdrawal symptoms. I assisted in daily activities such as bathing or putting on a shirt. Knowledge from my courses in motor control helped me to work with him to rehabilitate gross and fine motor skills from being able to sit up to forming a fist grip. What I didn’t know, I scoured journals, queried my professors who were physicians during office hours, and sought support from people that had taken the caregiver role.

Working in emergency medicine, I had only fleeting contact with my patients. I’d stop a bleed or administer naloxone, but then release them home or to a hospital. I wasn’t responsible beyond a narrow scope in time for mainly physical issues with tangible solutions. My clinical work didn’t prepare me for the complex emotional and mental problems of a rather grumpy and at times unmotivated patient that was my father. Medications and physical therapy did not address the emotional and mental anguish. He represented a complex medical puzzle requiring a solution that skillfully intertwined the physical, psychological, and spiritual. I discovered how integrative medicine does amazing things, and it was exciting for me to discover the right mix. Each day was exhausting but rewarding with its small victories. By transitioning to the online environment due to the pandemic, I was able to balance being a student, daughter, and caregiver. I had a 4.0 GPA in my final semester despite the many roles I played.

Medicine took on a new meaning and depth. It became more than my class lectures or applying a tourniquet. It’s multidimensional, requiring an all-encompassing solution relying on constant curiosity, problem-solving, and teamwork. It was empowering and rewarding to experience the impact my care had on my father. He has not only begun walking again but is now sober, experienced a weight loss from 258 to 192 pounds, and more connected to our family than ever. Looking back, it would have been so easy to put him in a nursing home. But that’s not who I am. It would have been a waste of my knowledge and skills.

Through this all, my greatest challenge has become my greatest achievement. As my world shifted under my feet, I matured, grew stronger, and became an advocate. Beyond the unique challenge that comes with solving a patient’s unique medical dilemma, my life experiences have solidified my desire to practice medicine to experience the true reward of its effects on a patient, their life, their families, and their caregivers.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Advocacy at the intersection of health and social care I believe is of the utmost importance and caring for a disabled father, I have learned to effectively advocate on someone else‚Äôs behalf. From navigating, submitting and receiving Disability Benefits for my father and a neighbor with severe Asperger‚Äôs syndrome, I have fought an HOA board for accessible parking and common areas and advocated for the rights of an abused disabled friend. These experiences provided me with the tools to be a compassionate and effective advocate._x000D_
_x000D_
Spending hours researching disability rights and laws, I am mindful of how much more I have to learn from and about the disabled community. I am committed to understanding and showing empathy for communities outside my own and will strive to continue this practice in my future as a physician. I am committed to adapting to new and differing points of view and lifestyles. I am confident that with my diverse experiences, I will bring my valuable perspective to RMC.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Never will I forget the first time I was faced with the reality of existing inequalities working in medicine. Receiving the dispatch, I was thrilled but nervous to finally put my EMT training and textbook knowledge to practical use. The dispatch was for fainting, a syncopal episode. By the time my partner and I arrived, the man regained consciousness. After assessing his stability, I probed him for information pertaining to his past medical history. Apprehensive, the man explained that he did not have access to routine medical care and could not afford the medication he was supposed to take. This was my first real lesson about the complex dilemma of inadequate healthcare access within my community and the critical health equity gap. As a volunteer EMT in Los Angeles, I was able to give back to my community and improve community health from stopping bleeds to blood pressure screenings. I deeply desire to continue to impact my community directly as a physician in my future career.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
As a Global Medicine master‚Äôs student, I was unable to travel and obtain clinical experience abroad during COVID-19. The immersive nature of the program was pivotal in influencing my decision to apply during my junior year of my undergraduate education._x000D_
 _x000D_
Additionally, I ultimately made the difficult decision to take leave from my job as a first responder after weighing the risk to my household members that were diagnosed with respiratory issues. It was a difficult personal decision to balance my sense of duty to my family and my duty as a healthcare provider. The lack of health-related resources available during the crisis allowed me to problem solve for my father when he became physically disabled in the middle of the pandemic. Caring for him along with assisting other family members such as my grandmother and helping my nieces with their online coursework truly broadened my awareness of the variety of challenges brought on by the pandemic and I felt a duty to help where I was able.

personal_statement:
When I knocked on John’s door, I was expecting nothing more than a routine conversation encouraging him to vote for Abdul El-Sayed in Michigan’s upcoming gubernatorial primary election. As soon as I mentioned Abdul’s name, however, his eyes lit up. He quickly interjected to ask about Abdul’s healthcare policies, noting his persistent issues with Crohn’s disease. Within just a few minutes, I discovered that John was living paycheck to paycheck, and in many cases he had to choose between paying for his next meal or receiving care for his chronic illness. 

My appreciation for the gravity of healthcare was solidified during my time volunteering for Abdul’s campaign in the summer of 2018. Speaking with voters throughout Metro Detroit, I learned about the prominence of healthcare access as an issue for many Americans. As I traveled from neighborhood to neighborhood, I found that John’s struggles were not an exception to the rule – they defined it. During my time on the campaign, I faced a harsh truth: of the voters I spoke to, the ones who expressed the most significant reliance on the healthcare system were also those who faced systemic disparities affecting their care. Whether due to prohibitively costly medication or poor medical literacy, there is a cyclical nature to the cause of these health problems and the inability to properly address them, which eventually leads to even further health decline. 

Empowered by my time with Abdul’s campaign, I joined Opportunities to Educate Children, a student-organization dedicated to tutoring underprivileged children in Washtenaw County. As a tutor, I had the chance to form long-term relationships and play a role in the growth of others. In particular, my experience with Gavin, an eighth grader I tutored in algebra, opened my eyes to the impact of serving others. While seeing his increased understanding of algebraic concepts was rewarding, I found the most satisfaction in the connection I was able to form with him as his tutor. Whether I was demonstrating how to graph slope-intercept functions or advising him on his March Madness bracket, I always felt fulfillment in strengthening the bond I had with him and in turn becoming a better mentor. 

Throughout these varied experiences, it became clear to me that I could best serve my community by merging my desire for interpersonal connection with my deep interest in advancing health access and equity as a physician. I decided to pursue an opportunity as a medical scribe to further my clinical exposure, while attempting to grasp the true lifestyle of a physician first-hand. While scribing in an outpatient urology clinic, I witnessed the long-term relationships physicians create with their patients as well as the larger impact medicine can have. This was exemplified by the relationship between a patient, “Alex Smith”, and his urologist Dr. Kernen. Following Alex’s diagnosis with prostate cancer, he was heartbroken that he would not be able to complete his upcoming goal of running a marathon. Dr. Kernen, also a runner, was determined to help Alex recover and accomplish his goal. Following several months of treatment, he was finally able to train for a marathon and eventually completed this marathon side-by-side with Dr. Kernen himself. 

In observing cases like Alex’s, my desire to pursue medicine was further reaffirmed. While the impact of treating and relieving patients of their physical ailments cannot be understated, I believe the bonds formed through service are equally powerful. Similar to my experience with Gavin, Dr. Kernen’s impact on Alex went beyond their time in the clinic and the operating room. Stories like Gavin’s and Alex’s are not merely coincidental; they are linked by a common theme of service, which enables the growth and sustainability of these relationships.

My desire to become a doctor did not occur as a lightbulb moment; rather, it took place through a myriad of experiences, each one of which strengthened the previous. While my curiosity for science and service drove me to seek these opportunities, it was my involvement with individuals like John and Gavin which constantly brought me back to medicine. Through medicine, I have found an avenue to explore the intersection between my scientific interest in healthcare and forming the interpersonal connections that drive personal and communal growth. Whether through my experiences in the clinic or in my community, I feel assured that medicine is the most sacred and fulfilling form of providing service. It would be a privilege to become a physician, and I look forward to a lifetime of serving my community, one patient at a time.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Throughout my time working in urban communities I have gained an appreciation for the necessity of providing primary care. As a research assistant in Emergency Medicine throughout various Detroit hospitals, I have observed the issues associated with a lack of access to a primary care physician. In many cases, these patients end up in the emergency department after episodes of acute problems that could have been avoided if their health needs had been previously addressed. As a result, they develop chronic issues that otherwise could have been avoided. While in the emergency department patients can receive treatment for any imminent threats to their health, but this may only paper over the cracks of much more complex issues. For this reason, many patients are forced to frequently visit the emergency room out of necessity as health problems continue to arise.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
Ann Arbor has given me a home to live in and a community full of support throughout my undergraduate years. When the COVID-19 pandemic began, I was desperate to find a way to give back to my community during such trying times. When I found Opportunities to Educate Children (OEC), an organization where I could virtually tutor children in Washtenaw County, I jumped on the opportunity. For many children, their educational access was hampered by the pandemic, one of many detrimental effects faced by underprivileged communities. _x000D_
_x000D_
I found spending my time helping others ignited my interest in a career in service. While I faced many inconveniences due to the pandemic, I am aware that for many the implications of the pandemic were much more life-altering. Implicit in the role of a doctor is putting the needs of others in front of yours, no matter the background of a patient, and our responsibility of giving back to others less fortunate is only amplified during such an unprecedented time.

personal_statement:
“Your job is just to keep your patient alive and get them to a grown-up.” I knitted my brow at this statement by my instructor during my Wilderness EMT course. By a “grown-up,” she meant transferring patient care over to a doctor. Of course, I understood exactly what she meant. A patient with an urgent medical condition deserves the attention of a medical professional with far more training than I currently have. But as I scribbled that quote in my notes amid diagrams of pneumothoraces, I knew that I would not be satisfied as an EMT-Basic. I had enjoyed my time away from school, but I was ready to become a “grown-up” myself.

The past several years of my life have been filled with many medical and outdoor experiences. As a break from the pre-med college life, I spent my summers leading groups of Boy Scouts on rugged canoeing expeditions in the Boundary Waters of northern Minnesota. The work was tough, as some of these teenagers had never traveled a waterway more complex than your average lazy river. But after a few initial days of patiently coaching paddle technique and praying that the boats stayed upright, I was always pleased to see my Scouts catch on and shoot across lakes with a vengeance. By the end of the trip, I would be tired, smelly, and absolutely brimming with pride. I found a similar experience with my other outdoor education roles, as I helped youths overcome initial hesitations to later have fantastic and affirming experiences rock climbing or ocean kayaking. I’ve learned plenty from my outdoor jobs, from fire-building to astronomy navigation, but the most important lesson has been that of servant leadership. 

I have always carried this broad life goal of wanting to bring about positive change in the world, and as an outdoor guide I realized the impact that I can make by arming another person with the tools for their own success. In other words, I desire to empower people to lead even better versions of their lives. Healthcare certainly provides the means to do this, but there are many careers within the field that help people achieve their health and life goals. As I worked on my biology degree, I considered a veritable alphabet soup of career paths, from RN to PT to EMT, before landing firmly on the goal of becoming a physician. Yet again, I found that clarity in the woods. 

In January of 2021, I spent ten days tucked in a snowy North Carolina mountain “holler” with 20 other students training as Wilderness First Responders, or “woofers” as the abbreviation WFR is verbalized. Similar to a shortened EMT course, our curriculum included classroom learning about health issues that may come up in a backcountry setting, as well as outdoor sessions where students would take turns acting as patients with various ailments. I learned two important lessons from the patient simulations: I have no future in acting, but I really want to be a physician.

In one pivotal scenario, my pretend patient presented with respiratory distress and a recent history of unexplained pain in one leg. I worked through my assessment until I remembered seeing similar symptoms in a real patient while shadowing at a hospital. After the scenario, I confidently shared with the class that I had diagnosed the patient with a pulmonary embolism. Yes, the instructor told me, but that’s not the point. As a woofer, he explained, my job was not to deliver a diagnosis but gather enough information to determine whether that patient needed to “stay, go, or go fast.” Deflated, I was not satisfied with only those three options. I wanted to learn everything about the patient, gather all signs and symptoms, break it all down and build them back up into a diagnosis. Furthermore, I didn’t want to stop at the diagnosis but develop a proper treatment plan and help put it into action. After explaining all of this to my WFR instructor, he smiled and said, “You’re going to need more than a ten-day course for that, kid. Sounds like you need to head to medical school.” 

Now, sitting in my Wyoming EMT course a year later and across the country, I found myself having the same affirming feeling: it was time to take the big step forward in my medical journey. I appreciate all the skills I’ve learned from my wilderness medicine courses and have needed to use many of them while working as a trip leader or for a ski patrol. However, each experience left me wanting to know more and be able to do more for my patients. While I have learned so much in the lecture halls and research labs of UGA, the great outdoors presented me with my most important life lessons. On the lakes of Minnesota, I found myself called to a life of servant leadership and enabling my future patients to be the best, healthiest versions of themselves. In the mountains of North Carolina and plains of Wyoming, I confirmed the career path that would allow me to serve patients while satisfying my own need for intellectual challenge. I understand that the academic road ahead of me is arduous, but I face it with conviction, as no organic chemistry course or Minnesota wind storm has been able to stop me yet. I look forward to finally becoming that “grown-up” medical provider I’ve heard so much about and using those skills to assist others, whether in a hospital or out in the woods.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I shadowed a gynecologist in Georgia as he performed thirty pap smears in one day. For most American women, the practice is a quick routine with stirrups and paper gowns. In a different hemisphere, I assisted a gynecologist at a temporary clinic in a small Peruvian village. There the women wore traditional garb- long sleeves and skirts of thick, colorful fabric- that reflected their conservative social norms. Most were aghast when asked to assume the position for a pap smear. The doctor spent most of each visit explaining the importance of the test and taking measures to ensure as much modesty for the patient as possible, such as having me stand guard at the door. Instead of a quick routine, the Peruvian doctor spent much time addressing cultural concerns while still working in the patient‚Äôs best interest. With similar understanding and patience, I hope to learn about my patients‚Äô unique backgrounds so that I can tailor my educational and treatment plans to best benefit them.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: One of the best choices I made in college was to join the international organization MEDLIFE, short for ‚ÄúMedicine, Education, and Development for Low-Income Families Everywhere.‚Äù I was attracted to the group‚Äôs holistic approach to service. With my school‚Äôs chapter, I participated in many local service projects and eventually took a position on the executive board to help plan and lead these events. For one event, we partnered with a local food bank during the fall of 2020. The food bank was having trouble safely distributing food at their facility, so we organized a drive-through food pick-up for families in need. I saw an opportunity to address another one of our organization‚Äôs pillars as well, so I distributed educational materials on COVID-19 and nutrition to every car at the event. The drive-through food distribution was a resounding success, and we proceeded to host two more similar events. I am proud that our chapter was able to safely address an urgent need in our community.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The pandemic began in the spring semester of my junior year of college. I had begun volunteering weekly at Piedmont Athens Regional hospital in the fall semester and had to take a break from it for most of spring 2020. Additionally, I had plans to work as a backpacking instructor at Philmont Scout Ranch in New Mexico that summer of 2020, but the program was canceled for that season. However, I was able to return as a canoe guide at Northern Tier in Minnesota where the program could be run socially distanced. Finally, I had plans for another medical service trip through the international organization MEDLIFE over the spring break of 2021, but unfortunately, that was not possible. Despite these interruptions to my planned clinical volunteering and employment, I do not believe that my academics were significantly impacted.

personal_statement:
It always seems to be the day that you wear white shorts that it happens. I was sitting in my middle school geography class, with my hand raised to answer a question about Sri Lanka's location on the map when I got a sinking feeling in my stomach. I rushed to the bathroom, leaving my answer up in the air where my hand used to be, hoping I'd make it before it left a mark. A fruitless attempt on yet another day where my period had bled through my menstrual products and ruined my pants.

Through middle school and high school, this became the norm for me and many other young students - getting excused from school due to a period mishap. We would be sent home to "fix the problem," only to return to a bigger issue: an education interrupted by something that was out of our control, a part of our biology. I was tired of putting my education on hold because I had to go home and change on a monthly basis. The shame and embarrassment of these incidents stay fresh in my mind, and every now and then I still catch myself hiding a tampon in my jacket sleeve on the way to the bathroom, feeling like a vulnerable middle-schooler all over again.

Once I went to college, I was able to begin making decisions about my own health in a way I was not able to in the past. In the Latinx community, there is a social stigma behind young girls going to the gynecologist, let alone going on any form of birth control. This stigma pervaded into my own home so that there was nothing I could do to ease my heavy monthly cycles. People in the community conflate women's health with sexual promiscuity, and therefore many young women and girls miss the opportunity to get a head start on their health with preventative screens or the early HPV vaccine. I found myself dealing with unmanageable pain and heavy bleeding caused by my periods, but I was unable to ask for birth control to alleviate my symptoms due to these negative beliefs. This stigma behind women's health persists through every stage of life, and I have seen it manifest throughout my college experience and beyond. I have had close friends confide in me about health concerns related to UTIs, yeast infections, STIs, and pregnancy while still being hesitant to see a doctor. A lack of trust in physicians is widespread in many communities of color, and the intersection of women and other marginalized identities can compound this fear further.

This thought lingered in my head when I was shadowing Dr. Baker, a pediatrician, during one particularly poignant patient interaction. The patient was a young girl who came in with her mother and was showing potential symptoms of pregnancy. Her eyes were as wide as saucers while sitting in the examination room, and I could feel the tension between the patient and her mother. The patient explained her lack of knowledge surrounding her period, pregnancy, and sex. She was able to calm down once her mother left the room, and I witnessed how a positive physician-patient relationship led to her getting the information and care she needed. A pregnancy test and STI screen were ordered, and her confidentiality was protected. She made me think about myself as a teenager, and how I wished I had a physician with whom I felt comfortable disclosing personal information.

I know I am not alone in the struggle with the silent shame tied to reproductive health: the inability to make informed decisions due to negative social stigma is a reality faced by too many women. As an adult, I continue to recognize, and become more informed of, the systemic and societal barriers preventing women from receiving adequate care. When shadowing Dr. Chahroudi in the HIV outpatient clinic, there was a young mother who had just given birth to her first child. She told us how she was unaware of her HIV status, which could lead to negative health outcomes for her child, until her first prenatal appointment. The stigma behind HIV is another example of what could deter patients from getting tested or receiving preventative medications. I was fortunate to witness this child's prognosis, which due to thorough care from Dr. Chahroudi, seemed to lean towards a negative HIV diagnosis.

These two experiences, along with my personal experiences with women's health, unveiled to me how a kind, open, and well-trained physician can make a difference in women's lives from childhood to motherhood. The safety and understanding in both Dr. Baker's and Dr. Chahroudi's offices are qualities that I hope to emulate for my future patients.

I strive to become a better advocate for women's health. I hope to be a physician who can provide a sense of comfort to those coming into my office; someone whose patients feel they can speak with openly and free of judgement. While so much remains to be done on a societal level regarding women's healthcare, I know that as a physician I can ensure at least one more doctor's office is providing thoughtful, inclusive education and care to patients. As a part of the medical community, I will seek to expand my outreach to the physicians I work alongside, and I hope to one day take on an educational role to pass down my expertise to the next generation of physicians. I will be an adept and supportive provider, always endeavoring to do the best for my patients.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
I volunteer at the Clarkston Community Health Center, which serves a large immigrant population. There, I met a Telegu-speaking family from India. The daughter explained her mother‚Äôs medical history by gesturing to her throat. She grew concerned when the translator did not understand, so I asked if it was a thyroid issue. The woman heard me say ‚Äúthyroid‚Äù and was overjoyed that I understood what she was communicating.  _x000D_
_x000D_
This experience made me reflect on when I was a caregiver for my grandmother. I recall how nervous I was when reciting past medical complications at her appointments. I felt, just as the woman in the clinic, how stressful it can be to put a loved one‚Äôs health into a stranger‚Äôs hands. Even though our backgrounds are different, I understood her. I learned that no matter where you come from, anxiety around healthcare is universal. Patients and caregivers are vulnerable, and being a calm, attentive physician goes a long way in making people feel comfortable.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
On the Executive Board of the Latinx Student Organization, I connected with my own Latinx community and opened my eyes to the many issues we faced within the university and beyond. Statistics show Hispanic populations have worse health outcomes compared to white, non-Hispanic people, which I witnessed firsthand when the COVID-19 pandemic exacerbated health disparities. I heard stories from Latinx students ranging from limited healthcare access due to financial struggles to language barriers. I saw this call for help from my community and organized fundraising events to address the financial need of our wider Atlanta Latinx community._x000D_
_x000D_
I became more adept at serving underrepresented populations and became a voice of advocacy. I was faced with raw, difficult conversations about socioeconomic status and race, but I have learned how these topics can impact health on a wider scale. LSO has motivated me to continue being a Latinx leader and working in social justice as a future physician.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
Before the onset of the pandemic, I was living on campus, with a paid lab position, and taking all my courses in person. Suddenly, I was given notice to vacate my university apartment immediately. My university's decision to transition fully to remote also meant that the remainder of my paid research lab position was terminated, along with potential clinical roles. The pandemic protocols limited my ability to access the lab in person, but I stayed involved with my research lab remotely. I adapted to a new college life within my childhood home, sharing one desk and limited Wi-Fi between four people. _x000D_
_x000D_
During this time, I cared for my grandmother who was diagnosed with Alzheimer's during the pandemic. Taking on a caregiver role while managing my online courses was not how I foresaw the end of my college career, but I learned a lot about how to be adaptable. I am grateful that I could support my family, and my appreciation for the demanding work involved in hospice care grew tremendously.

Under_School: State University of New York at Binghamton
personal_statement:
The deafening screech of sirens stunned my senses. Blinded by the flashing lights of the ambulance and police cars around me, I paused to collect my thoughts. My ambulance crew was dispatched to the scene of a motor vehicle accident. As I approached the wreckage, I saw a middle-aged man lying motionless in his seat through the broken window. I reached through the window and felt his cold, damp hand and waning pulse. Next to his foot lay an empty syringe. I fought back turbulent emotions as I calmly told my crew chief about my patient's diminishing pulse and breathing. My patient's family watched me earnestly, trusting me to treat their loved one. I felt a sense of immense responsibility that I'd never felt before. His condition indicated overdose, and after administration of Narcan, his vitals improved. I was overwhelmed with gratitude that my patient survived, and I marveled at the power of medicine and the human body's complexities. 

The human body has always fascinated me. I spent every year of elementary school anticipating the next lesson on biology and watching youtube science videos with fervor after school. This curiosity only grew over time. I began my undergraduate studies almost sure that I'd pursue a Ph.D. in biology researching human disease models or genetics. I started my first-year research class with zeal; I was ready to apply everything I had learned in my science classes. I thoroughly enjoyed my courses and loved research, but as the semester progressed, I began to feel deprived of a certain fulfillment. I concluded that the stress and isolation of my first semester in college were getting to me, and I needed a break from the routine.

I actively pursued extracurriculars hoping for some sense of direction. I met and spoke with a diverse group of people between volunteering and working and discovered that their stories and lives interested me. It quickly became clear that the lack of fulfillment I was feeling in my science and research classes was due to a lack of human connection. This realization drove me to pursue experiences where the two worlds of science and human connection could intersect. I decided that I wanted to study biology in a clinical setting, so I could still make some human contact while also furthering my knowledge in the subject I loved. I enrolled in an EMT course that semester, excited for the opportunities this certification would grant me. It was during this course that my interest in medicine solidified. 

Soon after receiving my certification, I was a trainee on my first shift at my collegiate volunteer ambulance agency, and I had to take a blood glucose reading. I stared at the patient's shoes as I meekly explained that she would feel a quick poke from the lancet. I heard her chuckle and looked up to see an exhausted yet smiling face. She blithely exclaimed that I looked more scared than she was. I appreciated her kind humor as she gave me her hand without hesitation. She was hypoglycemic, but her energy returned a couple of juice boxes later. As I drove back, I realized that I loved every bit of that experience despite the anxiety. Above all, seeing her get better during the thirty minutes I spent with her felt inexplicably rewarding. I later wondered how she was doing, disappointed that I would likely never meet her again. Such experiences furthered my desire to become a doctor, where I can form long-term relationships with my patients while playing an active role in their healing. 

I decided to shadow a general surgeon working in a low-income community to learn more about the medical field. On my first day, I met a female patient scheduled for a cholecystectomy. She lay in the bed uncomfortably as the surgeon walked in to speak with her. She frustratedly asked questions about the procedure. I smiled as the doctor answered her questions patiently, asking her if he was making sense to her from time to time. As he turned to leave, he stopped to ask her if she was cold in the drafty room. She nodded, and he brought over a heated blanket, gingerly tucking her in and assuring her that he would do his best for her. She replied smiling, "I know, doc, I trust you." Her speech conveyed solace, in stark contrast to her original state. I was baffled at the doctor's ability to calm down a stressed patient simply by prompting a conversation and answering questions with grace and patience. I learned through this simple interaction the importance of the emotional well-being of the patient and building trust.

In retrospect, I realized how much I wanted to practice medicine when my overdose patient took his first breath of a new life. When his family thanked my crew through tears, I understood the importance of being emotionally present for the patient and their family. This call was one of my first as a cleared provider, and I will forever remember it. I often think about the patients and the families I have met and wonder how they are now. I have realized how much I value building relationships founded on trust. There is something magical about a doctor and their intimate connection to the patient's life for which they are responsible. This connection is one I aspire to establish in the future.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Although born and raised in a small town in upstate New York, I moved to Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, in 2012 for two years. Not knowing the Arabic language and being alienated from my American culture, I initially experienced culture shock in the metropolitan Arab city. But as time progressed, I began to embrace the immense diversity around me. At my international school, I befriended people like princes and princesses of royal families and refugees from war-torn countries. I learned the importance of having an open mind as I heard the stories of my friends from across the globe. I became accustomed to working with people of different backgrounds and built long-lasting relationships. I learned the importance of being a leader and inspiring leadership in others who struggled to find their place in a new culture. Reflecting on this experience through the healthcare lens, I realize how much I would enjoy a connection to a diverse patient population, further enhancing my cultural competence.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
As a Wellness Advocate in my collegiate ambulance agency, I presented to agency members to educate them on various topics. One especially memorable presentation was that of the five social determinants of health.
