My peers and I emphasized the importance of keeping these determinants in mind when treating patients and being diligent in keeping personal biases at bay. Members approached me after the presentation, and we discussed in depth how these determinants influence our practice in the ambulance, especially when responding to specific patient demographics. _x000D_
_x000D_
As a Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion Committee member, I noticed discrepancies in our patient demographic. While speaking to various students of color on campus, I realized how some students distrust EMS and are unwilling to call for help even during dire situations. As a result, I advocated for my agency to reach out to cultural organizations on campus to educate students on our roles as EMS workers and their patient rights.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Aside from the challenges I faced due to the acute transition to online learning and the cancellation of clinical opportunities, I was thankfully able to adapt my approach to gaining valuable experiences. As a Crisis Text Line Texter, I spoke to individuals who faced severely deleterious effects of the pandemic. As I responded to these individuals, I was greatly humbled. I saw firsthand how socioeconomic barriers prevented some of these individuals' access to healthcare and emotional support systems. While volunteering as an EMT in an underserved community, I became attuned to the lack of resources and education for community members at large. I gained a perspective on the work that healthcare workers must do in underserved areas to prevent the spread of misinformation. Although I faced adversity during the pandemic, it opened my eyes to many facets of our healthcare system that were not apparent to me before, and for that, I am grateful.

Hrdshp_Comments:
I was born in Venezuela and raised in a small village in south Lebanon by my mother and grandparents. While my father relocated to the United States to build his flooring business, my grandpa served as my role model and father figure. I consider myself a disadvantaged applicant because poverty created distinct challenges for me and my family, including my father’s separation to try and make ends meet; our constant moving (including back and forth to the USA); assimilating to America while being bullied for my accent and limited English skills; and dependence on federal assistance throughout high school and college – though I am blessed to benefit from federal aid.
 
In her efforts to support five children, my mother worked twice as hard to feed our family. Upon permanently relocating to the USA, I began working at my dad’s flooring shop to alleviate her burden. I also delivered food as a DoorDash driver and built a small e-commerce business for additional income. In college, I depended on Pell Grants and my two jobs to cover tuition, and relied on my more experienced predecessors – including peers, faculty, and advisors – to navigate my pre-medical path. Ultimately, I am grateful for my struggle, which has equipped me with the resilience, grit, and commitment required to excel as a medical student.
personal_statement:
“Time of Death: 1:52 am.” The physician’s words pierced me as the sheets were pulled over my eldest brother’s face. My legs numbed from the utter shock and heartbreak as his stretcher rolled away to carry off my dearest friend. I was left in existential paralysis as my mind raced between the fond memories of his precious life and the horrific scenes of its end. I lacked the language for it as a fifteen-year-old; but the word I needed to best understand the experience was trauma: his fatal motorcycle accident; my terror as I awoke my parents at sunrise with quivering lips to break the news; or the mourning of his loved ones. The trauma was all-encompassing, driving me into depression, and pulling me away from school. The numbness I felt was finally shattered when I was awoken by the blow of the letter “F” that covered my midterm coversheet – my first ever failure. I vividly remember questioning myself: Will I be okay with an “F”? Does “F” define me? Would he be okay with my “F”? From that point on, I transformed this “F” into the fuel I needed to begin healing from trauma and become a healing force for others. Before long, I realized it was no coincidence that this awakening led me right back to the trauma-filled environment of urgent care, where my passion for medicine – and goal to serve as a future physician – was cemented.  

As a child in the village of Aanqoun in southern Lebanon, delivering acute care in the form of treating patients with high grade burns was part of our family’s daily routine. Low socioeconomic status and health care resources kept patients away from the crippling and exorbitant hospital costs. Instead, they turned to a then-retired firefighter – my grandfather – who committed the remainder of his life to treat them free of charge. Patients showed up at our doorsteps indiscriminate of time or day, and I would reflexively run to fetch my grandfather’s heavy brown leather burn kit. As I grew older, that bag became lighter; and likewise, assisting my grandfather in treating burns became seamless. Less obvious at the time, witnessing his selfless act of kindness and impact on patients’ lives was a catalyst for a lifelong commitment to service. 

It was a commitment that I cherished dearly even after we immigrated to the United States of America. At first, with the site of neglected and malnourished children not as prevalent in my new American community, it was difficult to relate. Nevertheless, motivated by my previous experiences treating burn-patients, and empowered by Gandhi’s saying: “the best way to find yourself is to lose yourself in the service of others,” I enrolled in the Henry Ford Wyandotte Hospital (HFWH) Health Occupations courses. There, I was exposed to crucial elements of health care such as bedside manners, patient advocacy, collaborative care, and patient-centered medicine. Assisting patients and interacting with physicians, nurses, physician assistants, pharmacists, and physiotherapists offered foundational insight into the American health care system and grounded my interest in medicine. I also had a humbling glimpse at the unique challenges faced by patients at HFWH including cultural barriers to medicine, uninsured medical expenses, and mental health; all of which put my privilege in prespective.  

With hopes of broadening my exposure, I joined the Atlantis premed shadowing program in Spain. I was fortunate to scrub in over twenty procedures and shadow numerous specialties such as pediatrics, cardiology, urology, general surgery, trauma, and orthopedics. I closely followed one patient with a severe penetration injury through the abdomen and thorax. Witnessing the continuity of care from his emergency presentation; urgent extraction of foreign body and irrigation and debridement; admission to intensive care; and treatment of multiorgan failure in the context of post-operative sepsis, was both exhilarating and heartwarming. To be there for patients in the thin line between breath and air, is a feeling I can best express not with words, but rather my unwavering determination to fulfill a career in medicine. 

Further, I was fortunate to volunteer at the Life Medical Center urgent care in Dearborn, MI – where I became a medical assistant (MA). Under the mentorship of Dr. Eldirani, I was introduced to evidence-based medicine and its impact on patient outcomes. It was exciting to learn how wet lab and clinical research studies are translated to the bedside. With time, I began exploring how my research under the supervision of Dr. Belanger at Detroit Mercy could be applicable to health care. We investigated the effects of Atrazine, a nationally used herbicide, on development and behavior of crayfish. I relished in discovering that crayfish are used as model organisms to study olfaction in higher vertebrae. I aim to continue expanding my research skillset to improve patient care and empower my future patients.

Ultimately, I approached each of these experiences with a dedicated and inquisitive mind to explore and unite the values of healing, advocacy, and empowerment. As an MD candidate, these are the values I will champion and carry forth; for I have learned that regardless of my path as a physician, I can always find myself, by being lost in service to others.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Working as a medical assistant, and helping my grandfather treat burn patients were two of my most pivital moments in my premed journey. With each experience, I united healing and advocacy with a dedication to diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI)‚Äì values I will champion at Rush Medical College. Through it all, I was endowed with a critical lesson: never underestimate a seemingly small act. I learned how a kind act could develop a cherished bond with a patient all while ameliorating their healing journey. For example, if one speaks a foreign language, they may require a translator. However, making small efforts such as using Google translate is better than silence, and fosters a sense of inclusion. _x000D_
 _x000D_
Finally, as a Lebanese migrant, I have developed a global view committed to building bridges of understanding. I can‚Äôt forget being bullied for my thick accent; and yet, I am grateful for the empathy, cross-cultural understanding, and commitment to DEI that my own experiences afford me.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Lebanon faced the worst humanitarian and economic crisis in its history. Realizing their needs, I reached out to my friends and initiated a fundraiser to raise money by placing donation boxes at local supermarkets and gas stations. As the organization began to grow, we reached out to other people, organizations, influencers, and businesses, and we have now raised over $10,000 for Lebanon. Since everyone is a unique individual able to bring something new to the table, I realized the value of teamwork and learning from others. Having the experience of working with different personalities and communicating skillfully in a crisis context has broadened my perspective on leadership styles, humanism, and social justice. My involvement with the Lebanon Relief project and other non-profit organizations have led me to the MD program at Rush Medical College, which fosters similar outreach programs in underserved areas.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
The COVID-19 pandemic was filled with challenges ‚Äì the most devastating being losing my beloved grandfather. Overcoming his loss proved to be an eye-opening experience as I learned to never take life for granted and began connecting more with friends and family. _x000D_
 _x000D_
During the pandemic, I felt burdened by the new virtual learning environment and the lack of support. It affected me not only academically but also mentally. To resolve my frustration, I learned to ask for help more often than I was accustomed to and comfortable with ‚Äì which was both humbling and important for my self-growth. I also learned how to meditate and find my inner peace to create a more sustainable lifestyle and mental environment as we transitioned into a ‚Äúnew normal‚Äù of remote learning. _x000D_
_x000D_
By buying groceries for relatives and neighbors, I realized that exercising my agency in the little ways could add up to meaningful contributions of service and self-growth ‚Äì values which have prepared me for the MD career path.

Hrdshp_Comments: My transition to college meant taking on full coursework, adapting to new academic expectations, and maneuvering spaces that were unfamiliar to a first-generation, low-income student like myself. This transition was challenged by familial and work responsibilities that I did not have the privilege of dismissing, solely because I was a freshman in college. Both my parents have worked labor intensive jobs that at full-time barely allow for some financial relief. I took on a job at sixteen to aid financially and improve internet access at home, increase access to nutritious foods, and have the means of supporting my transportation. My upbringing has led me to constantly adapt and take on a non-traditional leadership role in my family to provide stability. While in college although my familial responsibilities decreased, I still contribute financially and provided support. In combination with work, commuting to school, and extracurriculars, it’s been critical to have proper time management to carry out my day to day. Like many first-generation students, I rely on academic spaces that help uplift underrepresented students. But as a Latinx and Queer identifying person, finding a space that feels safe and supportive is hard to come by especially while navigating social and cultural expectations.
Major_Long_Desc: Molecular & Cell Biology; Nutritional Sciences - Toxicology
personal_statement:
My curiosity for innovation and community derived solutions, led me to consider a career where I would actively engage with communities to understand relevant barriers and disadvantages that may impede optimal health. As I considered careers, I wanted a role that would grant me the opportunity to lead outreach and advocacy efforts, serve as an educator, and have the possibility of working with marginalized communities. It was not until an unforeseen event impacted my family, that I was exposed to the possibility of becoming a physician and be able to carry out those functions in society. In December of 2017, my mom was in a terrible collision, and she had to be rushed to the hospital. As I tried to process my own worry and fear, I was hindered by thoughts of figuring out healthcare coverage and providing support to my family. From a young age I began taking an active role in my family to alleviate stress, which for me meant managing payments, translations, and advocating for my parents. My voice was especially impactful in predominantly English-speaking spaces, like health care settings where I served as the medium between my parents and their providers. I didn’t know if my mom would be receiving adequate care due to linguistic and cultural barriers, further adding to my concern for her. Fortunately, we had an engaged healthcare team that prioritized my mom’s symptoms, making sure no information was lost during the translation process. Members of the healthcare team relayed educational information to my family on how to best support my mom during her recovery. It was the first time a physician had demonstrated investment in my family’s health. Witnessing the interaction the provider had with my family and their role within the healthcare team, prompted my motivations to pursue a career in medicine. I realized the physician’s role encompassed the efforts in which I was interested in engaging. 

As I entered college I chose to major in biology and nutritional sciences. This allowed me to obtain a solid foundation in science while also obtaining public health application of the molecular basis of disease. Considering that as a physician I will have to consider disease of a patient with social determinants of health that may hinder recovery or management of disease, the exposure to public health and biology further catalyzed my pursuit of medicine. While being a research assistant, under the guidance of Dr. Susana Matias, I have seen the application of these principles amongst Latinx farmworkers by assessing factors during the COVID-19 pandemic that have exacerbated workplace risks, housing, and healthcare access for this population. Helping in the data cleaning and analysis process, I used Spanish, to understand responses and assign responses to specific categories. The prevalence of chronic disease and occupational risks is high in this population, yet little research or advocacy is done on this vulnerable community. I decided to participate in this research to continue to bring awareness and support to this community, to help build relationships amongst this group and help ensure advocacy efforts continue in creating equitable access to health care. I realized research plays an integral role in advancements within medicine and helps bring awareness to issues that may otherwise remain neglected. As a physician I hope to continue the expansion of research amongst marginalized populations.

As I continued my exploration of medicine, I became a medical assistant in an internal medicine and gastrointestinal clinic. I made it my personal mission to vegetate supportive and inclusive environments that allowed patients to disclose their concerns. By reading up on previous encounters, engaging in conversation, and relieving pressure from the clinic visit - which most times is surrounded with fear and worry - patients are able to confide in me and relay their specific needs. As I witness how our providers interact with their South Asian community, it is visible that removing cultural and linguistic barriers leads to better health outcomes, patient retention, and providing accessibility in understanding medicine. Patients were more willing to join efforts with the provider since they had information explained to them in a language and ways they understand. As a physician I hope to continue to dismantle barriers for Spanish speaking and other marginalized communities. 

I hope to emulate the physicians on our team to similarly educate, mentor and lead with compassion, cultural competency, and patience. These efforts will be integral in my practice as I hope to foster an environment that is supportive for patients and the healthcare team. My initial motivation to explore medicine came from a life changing event my mom experienced and my experience in clinical settings has further cemented this career path. I believe that as a physician, I am able to continue engaging in aspects of biology and public health, such as diagnosing, educating, and continuing research and advocacy, which will allow me to work directly with patients from various backgrounds in alleviating distress and healthcare barriers.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As a medical assistant, stationed at a primary care clinic and an urgent care, I witness the contrast between patients that have access to a PCP versus those who do not and resort to urgent cares to manage their conditions. Like many low-income patients, I am ensured through Medi-Cal. I have access to a PCP and can advocate for my parents‚Äô health during their visits. Unfortunately, documentation status is factored into eligibility of Medi-Cal. Uninsured populations at the urgent care struggles to navigate predominantly English-speaking spaces and face barriers in finding affordable healthcare insurance. These barriers lead them to urgent cares when conditions are exacerbated but require long term attention to ensure there are improvements. Without further outreach, neglecting linguistic challenges and barriers to obtaining insurance discourages non-English speaking patients from seeking care ultimately exacerbating disease burden amongst underrepresented populations.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As a Health Advocate for Alameda Health System, I helped serve low-income, marginalized communities. In my role I listened, lead with compassion, and advocated for patient needs. I facilitated the connection between patients and community organizations that addressed legal aid, food insecurity and financial resources. The work I was conducting was like my role at home, since I helped many Spanish speaking patients navigate predominately English-speaking spaces. Additionally, as a Digital Health Navigator, I surveyed patients on telehealth options. Through the telehealth survey, I assessed any barriers patients faced in taking advantage of telehealth services like digital literacy, devices, and internet access to subsequently connect them with community resources that can aid their circumstance and screen them for free devices funded by Roots Community Health Center. _x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact: During the pandemic, my work hours increased to 30-35 hours per week, to provide financial support when my father‚Äôs work was reduced. To manage my larger work commitment, I had to compromise and take Pass/No Pass grading options for a few of my courses to allow me to continue to participate in leadership positions and club organizations. Juggling work, academic and extracurricular activities became challenging when the transition to in-person learning began because I had to factor in a 40-minute commute to my schedule since I lived at home with my parents. Through learning how to adapt my schedule to fit my personal, financial, and academic needs, I believe that the time management and adaptability skills I have obtained will assist me in my pursuit of a medical education.

personal_statement:
Lights flashing and sirens wailing, we arrived at the scene of a two-vehicle collision where a young man sat against his car, head in his hands. I was assigned to care for this man and document his injuries. As I began the triage, he barely looked me in the eye and mumbled, “I’m alright.” I quickly saw that while this man may not have had any glaring injuries that I could physically attend to, he was hurting and required care. My heart immediately went out to him, and I stopped asking my checklist of questions and put a hand on his shoulder. I reassuringly stated “Hey, you're not alone, I am here for you. You let me know whatever you need, ok?” as I stayed by his side, conversing, until the scene was cleared. While he did not require bandages or an arm splint, he needed someone to stand with him and help navigate through the shock of the accident. I left the scene that day knowing I had helped this man accomplish a meaningful victory over the initial grief and fear that loom when processing a tragic moment such as this. This experience among many others as a volunteer firefighter have helped shape my understanding of what true care is. While it requires using fact-based knowledge to solve the visible issues, it also necessitates employing empathetic and tactful service to bring the oft hidden realities of the situation to the surface.
 Interning in the UC Davis Medical Center Surgical ICU provided a close connection to healthcare and inspired my passion to be a medical doctor. In the unit there was an elderly man, “Bill”, too frail to eat on his own and each shift I made a point to feed him his breakfast tray. While I quartered his grapes and mixed granola into his oatmeal, Bill and I chatted about life and formed a genuine connection which often centered around our shared love for basketball. Our interactions taught me patience while allowing me to hear his beautiful story and understand Bill as a person, not just the patient in bed 14. Feeding patients was not one of my designated tasks, but was something the nurses greatly appreciated me assisting in.  As I reflected on why I went out of my way to do this, I was reminded of my goal to be a person of service. I joined this internship to contribute to the healthcare team in any way possible and feeding patients was a contribution. Our conversations about Bill’s college years and my questions about his grandkids put him at ease and allowed him to forget about his pain for a time. My small contribution to Bill’s wellness allowed him to feel welcome in a place that was far from home. The impact I had on Bill helped inspire me to pursue a career as a medical doctor where I will have an even greater capacity to connect with patients on an emotional level while taking a lead in making medical decisions for their physical betterment. No matter if I am the doctor determining a care plan or just the intern serving eggs, each patient deserves the utmost attention to detail and steadfast care. 
As a silent observer of thousands of patient-provider interactions, scribing in the emergency department (ED) has provided me with an excellent view of the diversity, depth of knowledge and responsibility involved in medicine. Hundreds of people come through the ED in a day, and many seem to have similar complaints or come from the same background, but I have learned that each patient is unique. Allowing the toxic culture of preconceived notions to creep in quickly crowds out the ability to provide empathetic service. Providing this level of service requires compassion which motivates the most detailed analysis. As a scribe, doctors often call out exam findings or critical labs, and I must document them in a meaningful way. Instead of simply waiting for the provider, I developed a habit of reviewing results, so I could anticipate what the physician wanted me to record. This practice has developed my interest in each diagnosis because every case presents an opportunity to learn and expand my inquiry in medicine, while also exposing me to the responsibility involved as a leader in patient care. In the face of this commitment, each physicians’ unwavering resolve to care for patients individually has inspired me to develop an even greater attention to detail and a vision for equitable care as I seek to be a medical doctor. 
My interactions during roadside emergencies, while bedside in the ICU and at the emergency department have been vital along my journey to medical school. I have learned to patiently connect with people in my care, execute my role on the team with excellence and provide each patient with empathetic service. As a doctor, I do not want to approach patient care with just a “see problem, fix problem” mindset, instead I will resolve to know I am treating real people who may be going through something I could never comprehend. I aspire to approach each case with humility and a mind ready to listen, not any presumptions of who the person is, where they come from or what they may have been through. I want to commit my life to being a leader in the service of others. Practicing medicine as a physician provides a perfect opportunity to discover the unique realities of those around me and use those insights to provide them with the most compassionate care possible.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: With three other students, I led a public health campaign to aid "Help Me Grow Yolo County'' (HMGYC) with their community outreach through event planning and social media advertisements. HMGYC is an organization that provides free developmental screening and community resources to children of underserved populations. When interviewing families of diverse backgrounds, who had used HMGYC‚Äôs resources, I gained a greater understanding of the financial hardships and difficulty accessing healthcare they face. Collaborating with the project manager and families, we developed a survey for parents in English and Spanish, allowing the community members to provide feedback to HMGYC. This experience opened my eyes to the difficulty underserved populations have obtaining needed healthcare support and the many ways I can help. Working with HMGYC inspired me to advance health equity by supporting organizations that provide essential resources to underserved communities.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I have impacted my rural hometown community through my work as a volunteer firefighter for the West Plainfield Fire Department. Every day, I carried a radio with me which alerted me when our department was dispatched on a call. Whether I was asleep at 2am, swimming in the pool, or driving to the store, I dropped what I was doing and went to the fire station to respond to the call with the firefighting team. One time we arrived on scene to a large grass fire, spreading rapidly through a dry brush field toward a family‚Äôs home. We acted quickly to protect their house and barn and put out the blazing fire. Our quick response and efficient work saved this family‚Äôs farm. We also aided various elderly individuals who had fallen, treated people in vehicle accidents, and cleared roadways after big storms and floods. I am excited to transfer my skills and experience from the fire service to Chicago‚Äôs west side neighborhoods while attending Rush Medical College.

personal_statement:
I awoke to my tongue twisting and my body violently convulsing, but all I could do was stare at the ceiling and hope for it to end. Fade to black. I’d wake again, this time to my mother crying over me hysterically. This odd morning routine became my new norm when I was diagnosed with a pediatric epileptic condition. I frequented the hospital and received nothing short of excellent care. Unusually enough, I became enthusiastic about these visits and admired the providers for their unwavering kindness and patience. I developed aspirations to help children who face similar challenges and to replicate this standard of care.
After outgrowing my seizures, life was uneventful until high school. Within a month, I was devastated by the abrupt passing of my grandmother on my birthday, my father suffering a heart attack requiring surgery and my grandfather’s diagnosis of Parkinson’s disease. This was then followed by my mother’s and eventually my cousin’s battles with cancer. I learned to view the hospital with a more solemn understanding and deeper empathize with those facing illness. I do not desire to dwell on hardships, but to exemplify a medical reality where not every patient can be saved and many individuals are indirectly affected as a result. This underscored the importance of treating the whole patient, which means taking their loved ones into account as well. These experiences demonstrated that physicians must carry themselves with relentless optimism, kindness and resilience. 
I developed an interest in science with a strong preference for biology, which later became my major during my undergraduate studies. My collegiate interest in biology matured to a passion for biomedicine after my cousin fell ill. I coped by clasping on to a future in which I could delay death and found myself seeking knowledge about these conditions. Inspired by my family’s challenges, I narrowed in on attending medical school.
After graduation, I became a certified medical assistant at a Dermatology practice. I developed a close relationship with four physicians and intently studied their interactions with patients. The doctors that I worked with were unique, but all demonstrated defining traits that I came to recognize in myself. They exuded extraordinary compassion and attention to detail while providing indiscriminate care. Each physician, and most impressively the pediatric dermatologist, always remained patient and calm. Perhaps what I admired most was the genuine relationships that they developed with their patients. I truly appreciated this aspect of medicine and aimed to develop similar relationships with patients.
I treated each patient as an opportunity to learn and tried my best to incorporate these impressive qualities into my interactions. This experience provided unforeseen growth in my ability to perform medical tasks, interact with patients and thrive as a member of a team. I eventually was promoted to lead medical assistant and became responsible for more complex tasks and training other M.A.’s. My employers applauded my progress in this role and expressed their confidence in my potential as a medical student. I continued this experience with an eagerness to learn and improve myself as a medical professional.
My life shifted when my roommate moved out to care for his father who developed COVID-induced Guillain-Barre syndrome. This led me back to San Diego, where I navigated the MCAT while shadowing, volunteering and assisting in care for my disabled mother, niece and autistic nephew. My nephew, who requires constant supervision, is also non-verbal which helped me improve my ability to communicate beyond speech. My experiences with him sparked a newfound compassion and interest in providing care for complex patients, including those with special needs. This period helped me learn to efficiently manage several obligations, as well as, reaffirmed the value of family and the patience that you must carry as a physician.
I went on to expand my experiences by working as a M.A. at an Orthopedic Surgeon’s office and engaging in clinical research. In contrast to dermatology, orthopedic patients often arrived in agony. I was moved by each providers’ empathy and relentless efforts to help those in severe pain. Despite a patient’s tears and frustrations, the providers always remained collected, supportive and treated symptoms as pieces of a puzzle. They used physical manipulations, advanced imaging and data from procedures such as nerve conduction studies to identify the sources of their pain. I was fascinated by their abilities, and after watching several successful procedures in the operating room – inspired. 
My experiences have provided a unique lens into what it means to work in healthcare and continue to drive my pursuit of attending medical school. Each challenge has reinforced my compassion, enthusiasm to learn and my desire to help others. By choosing to become a physician, I intend to treat complex patients and build lasting relationships while upholding a high-standard of care. I’m aware that the health-related hardships I've faced are universal, and I can only imagine a future in which I’m a part of the solution – I seek a greater purpose in which I can contribute to someone living a healthy, fulfilled life.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
In urban San Diego, Scripps Hospital treats a diverse population of disadvantaged and underserved individuals. I am fortunate to volunteer as a Patient Safety Rounder, where I round on every hospital unit to check in with patients and aid in their care. This position has enabled me to assist numerous patients characterized as minorities, homeless, impoverished, or with mental illnesses. _x000D_
_x000D_
Although my upbringing differs from the background of many patients, I have connected with them by understanding their unique circumstances. Actively listening to patients and taking an interest in their cultures and experiences has helped me relate to them. Connecting with these patients helped me understand that all people, regardless of race, ethnicity, and status, share a fundamental unity ‚Äì a capacity for love and community. I deeply empathize with underserved communities and am compelled to serve them as a physician by providing care and improving the social determinants of health and education.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As a volunteer with Step-Up, I have directly impacted struggling students from underprivileged communities. For several months, I have provided tutoring and mentorship to a non-native English speaker who has had difficulties adjusting to school in America. My ability to speak Spanish has helped me initiate conversations and connect with him, though it has elicited laughter a few times. Although he and I are unalike, by taking an interest in his hobbies and culture, we have formed a close bond. Through this connection, his academic performance has improved, and I intend to continue contributing to his life. I have also helped my disabled mother care for my autistic, non-verbal nephew. Through great effort, he is potty-trained, able to function more independently, and can now say a few words. Helping these children is one of my most significant accomplishments and has inspired me to use my teaching background to develop health-education programs that benefit disadvantaged individuals.
7_-_COVID_Impact: My roommate‚Äôs father fell ill with COVID-induced Guillain-Barre Syndrome, ending our lease early in Seattle. So I moved in with my parents in San Diego and assumed the responsibility of helping care for my disabled mother and my niece and nephew, now aged 13 and 9, respectively. Being their full-time caretaker became difficult for my mother amid the pandemic due to daily online zoom classes and homework. My nephew, non-verbal, diagnosed with autism, as well as sensory integration disorder, requires constant supervision and hands-on assistance with daily activities. Often while trying to study, I‚Äôd have to stop to assist my family, which undoubtedly made this journey challenging. Once it came to scheduling my exam, COVID-19 restrictions resulted in minimal availability in San Diego. I had to travel for over two hours alone and stay at a hotel in an unfamiliar city the night before my exam. While COVID posed challenges, overcoming these difficulties made me a stronger student and person.

Hrdshp_Comments: Shortage of doctors, clinics, and other medical professionals in my hometown and surrounding areas which significantly impact the underserved/impoverished communities. My hometown has the highest amount of concentrated poverty in the nation.
personal_statement:
My hometown, Fresno, CA, has the highest concentrated poverty in America, with food insecurity an everyday reality. All my life I witnessed this but didn’t realize the severity until I volunteered during high school at the Poverelo House, a non-profit that provides meals and services to the homeless community. One day after serving meals, I joined a table and listened to their conversations. I was amazed to hear how much of a commodity food was to them. The next few days at school, I noticed students throwing wrapped, uneaten hamburgers and burritos into the garbage and couldn’t believe my eyes: yesterday I’d heard that food was nearly gold to one group of people while a few miles down the street students were throwing it away. I knew I had to do something. After racking my brain for weeks, I finally came up with the Food Recovery Program to collect, repurpose, and distribute the wrapped and untouched “waste” from student lunches and deliver it to the needy people in our community. For the next several months, I talked out the details with the school district’s staff and officials, the director of the local food bank, and my team of volunteers. Seeing my program give hope to thousands of people in my hometown inspired me to devote my life to serving my community and improving poverty—I just had to figure out the best way to do it. 

During a 2018 visit to Masten Towers, one of the low-income housing facilities where we delivered food for the Food Recovery Program, I saw firsthand how food insecurity can affect health outcomes. Masten Towers was in the middle of a “food desert,” which meant residents had to resort to fast food or other unhealthy choices that contributed to ailments such as diabetes. During my visit, I met Jose, who appeared malnourished and confided to me that he had a difficult time affording healthy food, housing, and medical care. When I visited two years later, I reencountered Jose and he told me he was glad that there were people like me who cared. Throughout his life, he’d felt abandoned, but now things seemed different. He said he was both happier and healthier due to the nutritious food choices. Seeing my advocacy create better health outcomes showed me I could best serve my community by becoming a physician who directly works with patients to educate them on healthier living. 

To learn more, I started shadowing doctors both at UCLA and in Fresno. The contrast between these two made me realize the differences in resources, training, and technology between a major metropolitan area hospital and community hospitals like those in my hometown. I experienced this disparity firsthand when a family friend, Maria, was told by a local doctor in 2021 that her prognosis for her condition was poor. When she told me the terrible news, I comforted and reassured her. Then, I researched treatment options with Maria and ultimately helped her find the care in San Francisco. Others, however, aren’t as fortunate. When my father’s friend, Harold, was diagnosed with prostate cancer, he elected to have a “routine” prostatectomy at Fresno Community Hospital, but died due to complications during the surgery. Harold had wanted to go Los Angeles for his procedure, but couldn’t make the trip due to financial restraints. These experiences showed how factors like finances, accessibility, and doctor experience and training can affect the care patients receive and their overall health outcomes. Moreover, helping Maria find the care she needed made me more confident in my decision to pursue medicine and make better medical care more equitable and accessible to these underserved.

Seeing these two opposite health outcomes also motivated me to become an undergraduate researcher under Dr. Leonard Marks at UCLA to study new treatment modalities and give doctors everywhere more knowledge and confidence. My current research aims to make prostate cancer diagnosis and treatment more humane. With focal therapy, a non-invasive technique for ablating tumors in the prostate, I saw an operation performed in the clinic and within two hours the patient was walking out of the room cancer-free. I was astonished that someone could go from having cancer to being cancer-free in one morning, whereas radiation can take many months and have debilitating side effects. Seeing the direct effect we are having on people’s lives has inspired me to use medicine and research to provide high-quality care to underserved communities and beyond.  

My journey toward healthcare began after noticing the wastefulness and food insecurity in my hometown. Though I am immensely proud of my Food Recovery Program, it also exposed me to the healthcare disparities that poverty, food insecurity, and poor access to quality healthcare can cause. My subsequent research experience as well as my interactions with Maria and Harold have inspired me to become a physician to address these issues. Working to find creative solutions through research and learning how to deliver quality medical care is my driving force. I am now physically and mentally ready and prepared to devote myself to improving my community through medicine.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
I grew up in Fresno, home to a large diverse and underserved population. As a teenager, I saw the disparities in healthcare that many faced and created a program that collects the uneaten food from local primary and secondary schools and delivers it to the needy population. As the program‚Äôs founder/leader, I collaborated with many people of different backgrounds, listened to them, and made a plan to meet the needs of the people. These experiences helped me in March when I volunteered with my Swipe Out Hunger club at a homeless shelter in LA. I used the skills I learned in my previous experiences to form relationships with the diverse population we were serving, many of whom were immigrants. _x000D_
_x000D_
I believe that I‚Äôm well-prepared to communicate and interact with diverse peers and patients at Rush Medical College. I hope to practice inclusive excellent during medical school and beyond by developing free clinics in underserved regions in Chicago to provide reliable and no-cost medical care.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As a third generation Armenian-American, I‚Äôve been active in the Armenian Church, youth group, and at the California Armenian Home (a skilled nursing facility). Growing up, I often heard and learned about the poverty in Armenia, but never had the opportunity to see it in person. Finally, in 2018, after spending two summers of fundraising at the Saturday Farmers Market at my high school, I made enough to go to Darbnik, an impoverished village, to hand out clothes and school supplies. There, I noticed the aged and beaten clothing the children had; some were even shoeless! We proceeded to hand out a wide selection of shirts, shorts, socks, shoes, and educational books and items. I‚Äôll always remember how the children‚Äôs eyes lit up when they finally received their new clothes and school materials. Being able to personally change the lives of all the children in this village strengthened my resolve to become a physician for the underserved.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
The pandemic made it difficult for me to get research positions or internships since everything was closed. Like everybody else‚Äôs, my campus was immediately shut down and didn‚Äôt fully open for 18 months. Prior to March 2020, I had internships and positions lined up, but I wasn‚Äôt able to pursue them during the pandemic. One of the positions that I was looking forward to the most was my Sports Medicine internship with UCLA athletics. I would have been working with the athletes, tending to their needs alongside doctors and trainers. Above all, I would have learned a lot about sports medicine and how to handle athletic injuries and rehab. _x000D_
_x000D_
I also had a research position lined up was also affected by the pandemic, since the PI moved to be closer to their family and left UCLA Hospital. Once these opportunities were gone, I had a difficult time finding other positions since I was at home and many facilities were either temporarily shut down or only reserved for graduate students.

personal_statement:
Along with drugs and sex, conversations about menstruation were taboo in my South Asian household. Therefore, as I sat in my middle school health class watching a vague video about puberty from 1999, getting my period became my biggest fear. It wasn't the start of my period that haunted me, but rather the inevitable, and seemingly forbidden, conversation I would have to have with my mom. Due to cultural expectations and language barriers, my family never talked about menstruation, and sometimes I wondered if my older sister and mom even had periods. When the inevitable did occur, I mustered up all of my courage to tell my mom about the new development. Unsurprisingly, instead of educating me on what was happening in my body, my mom bombarded me with rules and restrictions I had to follow. Instead of teaching me proper hygiene techniques, I was taught to hide my pads and tampons in brown paper bags. I wasn’t allowed to wear certain clothes, I couldn’t go to religious places, and I could only use a certain bathroom in the house because I was “dirty.” Throughout the conversation, my mom didn’t use the words period or menstruation once. Instead, she used phrases such as “that time of the month” and “when you don’t feel well”.
Menstruation felt like a curse. I felt disconnected from my body due to the mysteries of why I was bleeding, what was causing the bleeding, and how my body was changing in other ways. The taboo around menstruation and other health issues in my family fueled my desire to seek out information about the human body and medicine. 
Studying human physiology at my university answered my many questions about the human body and its mechanisms in times of success and failure. Inevitably, my growing knowledge about medicine was paired with an increasing awareness of the lack of communication about and access to health information. It was a pattern that was frustratingly evident in every patient encounter I had. As an EMT, I noticed the patients’ confusion about blood pressure cuffs and stethoscopes. As a clinical research assistant at the VA, every conversation about Parkinson’s disease with the patients was filled with shoulder shrugs and uncertainty. The gaps in their knowledge about the medical devices and their diseases often led to their noncompliance with health care interventions. So when taking blood pressures, I would explain to patients how I was inflating the cuff to stop the flow of blood, similar to stopping water flowing in a pipe, and then I was listening for the flow to begin again. When showing Parkinson's patients specific exercises to improve their symptoms, I explained the role of exercise in improving their balance and strength to prevent falls.
After satisfying my urge to understand the human body, these new experiences inspired me to minimize misconceptions and increase health literacy through education. Determined to combine my fascination with the human body and my passion for communicating with individuals about their care, I decided to pursue a Master's in Public Health during my gap year. My goal was to gain skills for effective communication and promotion through cultural competency and analytical thinking.
My decision to pursue an MPH degree, and eventually an MD degree, was reinforced through scribing for Dr. C at the Brigham and Women’s Dermatology department. Dr. C, who has both an MPH and MD degree, showed me the ability to both treat the ailment and prevent future disease through education with each patient encounter. 
On my third day as a scribe, we were running behind the schedule as I followed Dr. C into the last appointment of the day. From the moment we walked into the room, I felt the patients’ apprehension and unease engulf the room like a storm cloud. Dr. C radiated compassion and empathy as she absorbed the patient's endless list of concerns. Instead of dismissing each lesion as benign, she used colloquial language to patiently talk about each mole and explain how seborrheic keratoses arise. She described each treatment, detailed the mechanism of the prescribed medications, and helped the patient practice identifying lesions on her own skin using a handheld mirror. The patient's anxiety was replaced by trust and confidence in both Dr. C and her own ability to care for her skin. As I stood in the corner of the stark white exam room scrambling to document the details of the appointment, I couldn't help but be enchanted by Dr. C’s magical ability to empower and educate her patients and dream about being in Dr. C’s position in the future. Being a physician had been my dream due to its intricate relationship with understanding and rectifying the functions of the human body. Now the same dream is fueled by my desire to empower individuals by providing necessary knowledge about their bodies and the relevant medicine, enabling them to participate in their own care. 
The once 11-year-old girl who feared menstruation and was hindered by the uncertainty of her body would be proud that she decided to complete her MPH degree and pursue an MD degree. Through these two degrees, I will educate others through compassion and empathy about their bodies to empower autonomy and confidence in their abilities to make beneficial health decisions.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Because I was raised to prioritize education above all else, I was surprised to see the 5th-grade girls I mentored think school was ‚Äú a waste of time‚Äù. My initial reaction was to label them as ‚Äúlazy and ungrateful‚Äù. However, as I took a step back and attempted to understand my mentees‚Äô backgrounds, I recognized that their families didn't view dedication as a necessity._x000D_
In this situation, instead of judging the girls, I patiently discuss their perspectives on education and its benefits with them. They explained why they felt studying was useless and I respectfully responded with why I thought knowledge was valuable because it can help solve intricate problems and help them enter their dream careers._x000D_
Through this experience, I learned that along with one‚Äôs culture and ethnicity, their upbringing has a major impact on their beliefs and values. As a future physician, I will evaluate all patient interactions from multiple perspectives to provide tailored care to each patient.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
As an EMT in Boston, I encountered patients from a wide range of socioeconomic classes. With each patient interaction, I noticed a blaring difference in their knowledge of the health system and their medical treatments._x000D_
One trip with a 40-year woman showed me the power of knowledge in medical care. When the ride began, the patient avoided eye contact and shied away when I tried to take her blood pressure and HR. Instead of telling her ‚Äúit's protocol‚Äù, I explained how blood flows through our vessels like water in pipes and used a similar analogy to explain the importance of pressure. I felt her anxiety melt away as she told me that this is the first time in 15 years that she understood the purpose of all the ‚Äúpoking and prodding‚Äù._x000D_
Through this experience, I recognized that lack of healthcare education is a major contributor to health disparities. At Rush, I hope to use my public health knowledge to create accessible health information resources for the surrounding Chicago communities.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
After receiving the dreaded ‚Äúcampus is closing‚Äù email, it felt as if time froze still. I had left friends without goodbyes, my belongings were left in my dorm, and my clinical activities were paused. Although I was grateful to have a stable home to quarantine in, I noticed my overall motivation falter. I slowly disconnected from society because I found it difficult to engage in conversations and social media due to the constant devastating news of overflowing ERs, children losing parents, and citizens disobeying precautions. _x000D_
Aware that ignoring the tragedies wasn‚Äôt the solution, I become a safe care assistant at BWH to aid in the pandemic-relief efforts in any way I could. There, I handed out clean masks to all visitors and checked symptom attestation badges to help keep healthcare workers safe. _x000D_
Living through this public health crisis drew my attention to the gaps in education and accessibility of health care and increased my desire to study public health and medicine.

Hrdshp_Comments: I grew up in an underserved healthcare area in Nigeria. The closest hospital was quite far and I only visited for emergencies as we were expected to give part payment before treatment though they did not have enough providers. This led to self-medication. Whenever I was sick, my mother usually diagnosed malaria or typhoid - it was always either of the two. She was not a healthcare professional but It was the best she could do as there were no alternatives. She usually gets medication from medicine stores or from the market. I recall an adverse reaction of rashes and skin peeling I once had after self-medicating on an adulterated drug for malaria. Additionally, there was no running water and constant electricity, I used candles and kerosene lamps for homework and chores which contributed to my poor eyesight. On some occasions, I had to wake up early to fetch water before going to school. Although life was hard, it was beautiful because I was surrounded by my extended family. Amenities became significantly better when I migrated to the US in 2015. Though I had two part-time jobs to make ends meet all through college, I excelled in my classes because I had experienced a tough past and had learned to balance my time. My struggles have made me stronger and enabled me to learn valuable life skills.
personal_statement:
Growing up in Nigeria, health access was not readily available, and regular checkups were luxuries to most people. When people had a medical emergency, there were no ambulances to take them to the hospital. One such incident occurred when I was 11 years old. Our neighbor, Mama Chinaza, went into labor at 11 PM. Unfortunately, it was one of those nights when we had a power failure in the neighborhood. The closest hospital was 90 minutes away and my Uncle Alex was the only one who had a car in the apartment complex. En route to the hospital, I did everything to pacify Mama Chinaza. I offered her water and practiced everything I had seen in the movies with her.  Luckily, she successfully gave birth to a girl.  Soon, Uncle Alex’s car became the “ambulance” in our apartment, and I was his assistant. We had to frequently take our diabetic neighbor to the hospital because he lacked insulin and had an inappropriately high carbohydrate diet. Ultimately, it was my experiences with Uncle Alex that made me develop a passion for patient care.

To learn more about medicine, the closest thing I had was a copy of a brown-paged, dusty, old “Where There Is No Doctor,” an encyclopedia of ailments and their treatments. I went through this book like a dictionary and as I flipped through each page with more hunger for knowledge, my mind could not comprehend why I needed to tie a cloth to stop a bleed or give salt water to a diarrheic person.  I marveled at each descriptive scenario while also being hopeful that I would know what to do for the sick or injured when there was no help around. As a young child in Nigeria, I wanted to be a doctor and be part of a team that does their best in ensuring health access for everyone.

I moved to the U.S. 6 years ago for better opportunities, and with my immigration, I had better access to healthcare. To learn more about medicine in this new country, I became a Certified Nursing Assistant (CNA) and worked with a care team to develop care plans for patients. I looked at my patients holistically, rather than thinking of them as sick or injured. One memorable patient I had was a middle-aged woman, who was admitted for kidney failure. Overwhelmed with emotions of all the things going on in her life, she burst into tears. I empathized with her and for the rest of her stay in the hospital, I visited and chatted with her while making sure that she was comfortable. This experience furthered my desire to continue to educate myself so that I could help people like her directly.

As a CNA, I take value in the little experiences I have with patients in being able to express empathy; things like helping an elderly lady speak with her family members or making sure a patient with dementia listen to their favorite music every day. Every patient has their own burden to bear, and because of this, I made it a priority to create an atmosphere where they can focus on their comfort and health. While I love the personal interactions I get with my patients as a CNA, I wish to have a more active role by becoming a physician to help lead patients to make changes in their lifestyles. My experience working with patients has taught me about the quality of patience and compassion because some may not get better, but the kindness shown is rarely forgotten.

I understood the value of patience in helping others when I started tutoring students. I not only wanted to fulfill my mission in life through medicine but through education as well. As a student, I learned that a lot of people cannot advocate for themselves because of limited knowledge. With this in mind, I became a literacy tutor to help illiterate adults in English and Math hone their skills in hopes of increasing their health literacy. As I gained more insight into my students, I noticed I helped them gain more confidence in learning as they achieved academic success. In turn, I felt elated in helping them reach their goals. This experience inspired me to become a physician who empowers her patients through health literacy, education, and patient care, especially in underserved communities.

My goal is to cater to underserved communities as I have an understanding of what it is like living and growing up in one. Fortunately, my diabetic neighbor is doing okay now and the last time I visited Nigeria, I bought him a glucometer and taught him how to use it to help him better manage his diabetes. While I could not help with his food insecurity problems, I gave him tips on foods to eat and avoid. As a student and as a nursing assistant, I have learned to recognize that there are other factors that affect one’s health.

The brown, old book is still collecting more dust somewhere in our apartment in Nigeria and has served its purpose in my life by fueling my desire in medicine. Thanks to my science classes, I now understand the purpose of a tourniquet and an electrolyte solution! I may never understand everything in that book, but I do know that my experiences have instilled in me a desire to help and educate others, values that will prepare me for a career in medicine.  Whether it is working as a volunteer doctor in my home country, or working as a physician in the U.S., I aim to treat, while also empowering patients to play active roles in preserving their health
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: It was at the memory care unit of an assisted living community that I was exposed to the different cognitive health problems facing the senior residents. For ‚ÄúSunny‚Äù, I had to remind him to pull his pants down before he urinated, and for ‚ÄúMary'', I had to remind her that her room was the first door on the left. I learned how to uniquely care for people with different physical and mental capabilities and patiently instruct them to complete a small task. My job has developed my bedside manner, and I saw the value of small interactions in a patient‚Äôs experience: light and temperature changes can make their room a little more similar to home. These small factors are important when addressing a patient‚Äôs care beyond their presenting symptoms and in improving a patient‚Äôs overall outcomes. As a physician, I will have these experiences in mind to provide quality patient care and address social factors that affect health, especially in service to underserved and vulnerable populations.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I decided to be a volunteer tutor at Charles County‚Äôs literacy program because of research that I did which highlighted the impact of literacy on healthcare outcomes. I meet with my student biweekly and teach basic math skills while also developing a genuine relationship with her. Her goal is to be proficient at subtraction so that she can get a job that involves financial management. I learned to adapt my teaching skills to her learning style, become an effective communicator and leader, and most importantly, strategize to help her reach her goals. Watching her improve and gain confidence in her math skills has been a humbling experience for me. Increasing the levels of education in my community will advance social and economic equity, and improving health among other social issues affecting people. As a future physician, I will have this experience in mind and use the knowledge that I gained to communicate with my patients while continuing to promote literacy and, in turn, health.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
The pandemic resulted in the cancellation of my summer internship. Consequently, I conducted a virtual internship in the form of a thought experiment ‚Äîusing nanographene for the targeted drug delivery of an anti-cancer drug SN38. I had weekly presentations and assignments from the PI and other researchers. I presented my findings on my weekly research and answered questions from the audience, which strengthened my critical thinking and communication skills._x000D_
There was an abrupt change in the environment and mentality surrounding my job as a CNA. The pandemic forced me to pick up more shifts at the hospital as we were constantly understaffed, in addition to being a student. Initially, my coworkers and I grappled with the uncertainty surrounding the pandemic and our lack of protective clothes and gloves. Amidst our fear, we quickly came up with alternative PPE solutions and how to give care to COVID-19 patients while ensuring our own safety simultaneously which strengthened our teamwork.

Hrdshp_Comments: Although I grew up in an area that had abundant resources, my family experienced many financial difficulties that prevented our access to these resources. My parents are both first-generation immigrants from Vietnam, who came to the United States to provide better opportunities for their children. My father immigrated first to establish residency and acquire citizenship, before bringing my mother and I in 2002. After their arrival, my parents began to work as nail technicians. Since I was a child, my parents have worked 8-hour shifts every day, with the exception of Sundays. Even with their hard work, we received assistance via food stamps and were on Medicaid. Additionally, I qualified for the free lunch program. Although we were on Medicaid, there would often be times when we could not adequately receive the healthcare that we needed. When I was in high school, my sister was diagnosed with Turner's Syndrome and required lab work, imaging, and growth hormone treatments. Some of these services were not entirely covered by insurance, resulting in an additional financial burden on my parents. Through this experience, I have become aware of the inaccessibility of healthcare for low SES individuals. I hope that as a physician, I can work towards making healthcare more equitable for my patients.
personal_statement:
“In the field, you see patients on one of the worst days of their life. Not everyone sees it that way. It’s your responsibility to advocate for them at the hospital,” said the paramedic to me during my first ride-a-long. As I reflect on the experiences that brought me to medicine’s doorstep, I recognize how these words informed my philosophy of medicine. Through schooling, we acquire the academic prowess necessary to diagnose and the clinical technique to carry out treatments. On the other hand, no textbook teaches you the interpersonal skills that lay the groundwork for a patient encounter. You develop these through your experiences with others, and for me, I learned about patient advocacy in the unorthodox environment of a first-generation immigrant home. 

With English not being their first language, my parents relied on me as an interpreter to navigate their daily lives. Whether that be at the bank, a parent-teacher conference, or a doctor’s appointment, I was mediating all their essential conversations. One specific memory that comes to mind is when my sister was diagnosed with Turner’s Syndrome during my senior year of high school. As the doctor discussed the findings of the karyotype and her labs, my parents’ faces were contorted with worry and confusion. The doctor recognized this, so she spoke in basic terms, then allowed brief pauses so that I could relay it to my parents. Despite the uncertainty that accompanied the next several hospital visits, that initial interaction was a defining moment for me. From this, I learned the first tenet of patient advocacy was to ensure that patients are, and have a right to be, informed throughout the entire process. Although my amateur translating seemed trivial, I realized that it was a necessary role so that my parents would be included in the conversation. 

The following year, I attended college and was confronted with the big decision of figuring out my career path. To explore the pre-medical pathway, I applied to Tulane EMS, albeit with some hesitation and anxiety. Being an EMT was something I could have never imagined myself doing. I assumed there was no place for a small, quiet girl who was lacking the physical strength and tough attitude that was a prerequisite for emergency medicine. Yet, on one of my first calls, I became aware of the role my emotional strengths could play. We arrived on scene to a patient with a depressed skull fracture. As I held her head for manual stabilization, I could see the fear in her eyes. Her shock was evident as she watched us apply a cervical collar, put her on a spine board, and moved her into the ambulance. During the transport, she began to cry, asking about what was going to happen to her now. I consoled her and patiently explained the circumstances. I held her hand while my partner took vitals, in hopes it would quell a little bit of the fear. By the time we arrived on the ramp, she was smiling and laughing with us. It became clear to me what the value of compassion in medicine was.

After many more experiences in EMS, I declared my major in neuroscience to jumpstart my journey. During the first semester of my junior year, I was given the opportunity to be a Supplemental Instructor for a Cellular Neuroscience class. Although a foundational class, I knew that the content could be daunting. My dedication to their learning was exemplified by the time I spent creating study resources, providing recorded lectures, and holding office hours. I still remember how fulfilled I felt when a student personally messaged me to say that attending my review sessions and using my resources had brought her grade up significantly. Just as a student needs an encouraging environment to succeed, a patient requires a support network during their treatment regimen. I hope to apply the same diligence in a clinical setting, so that my patients feel empowered throughout their healing process. 

Consequently, I had the privilege of seeing this healing process when I was an Emergency Department Technician at Ochsner Medical Center. I was not only able to observe doctors conduct primary assessments and derive their differential diagnoses, but I was assisting them in doing so. This experience also stressed to me the importance of quality medicine in patient populations rife with comorbidity. It was sobering to see patients in critical condition due to poor lifestyle choices or financial constraints, thus emphasizing to me the practicality of preventative healthcare. I was also inspired in my work with psychiatric patients to speak up for those whose conditions are stigmatized. We owe all our patients the same respect and dignity, regardless of their social location or circumstances outside their control.

Deciding to pursue medicine was not a simple revelation for me. Instead, it was a progression of experiences that I was fortunate enough to have. Through my interactions with patients in clinical settings, I have become keener to the realities of the human existence and the responsibilities that doctors hold. Everyone deserves to have a provider in the room who respects their best interests. I look forward to receiving a medical education that enables me to advocate for underserved populations, while remaining kind and empathetic throughout.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As a volunteer EMT and an ED technician, I encountered patients who could not access preventative care due to financial barriers, low health literacy, or medical mistrust. Furthermore, these patients belonged to marginalized groups, whose identities intersected across lines of race, gender, and sexuality. The effects of this would be reflected in their medical history, often riddled with comorbidities that were poorly managed. Without access to basic primary care, these patients would only present to the emergency room when their conditions became acute. This experience elucidated the disparities that afflict disadvantaged communities and the role that healthcare providers play in resolving these issues. Physicians are leaders within their field, experts in their medical studies, and patient educators, but most importantly, they can be advocates for change. Thus, I aim to be a physician who employs an intersectional perspective when providing equitable, quality care.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: During the summer of 2020, I remember watching as the nation experienced a turning point. The George Floyd protests emphasized the inequities that Black, indigenous, and people of color (BIPOC) face daily, and I recognized these same inequities were reflected in my EMS organization. Over the years, many BIPOC members raised an issue with the organization‚Äôs protocols, but with limited success. As a result, there was a high attrition rate for these members, both unfair to them and our diverse patient population. To address this, I gathered BIPOC members within my cohort and drafted a proposal to present to our executive board. The proposal detailed changes to the protocols, such as a zero-tolerance discrimination policy, mandatory cultural workshops, and revision of our selection process. Following the protocol reform, there was a positive shift within the organization, and our patient community benefited from our more inclusive practices.
7_-_COVID_Impact: When the COVID-19 pandemic reached New Orleans, I was asked to move out of my dorm. Right before this occurred, I had begun a job at the Tulane Financial Aid office and a volunteer position at Children‚Äôs Hospital New Orleans. However, I had to put these commitments on hold and was not able to return due to COVID restrictions. Once I returned home, I was responsible for attending online classes while providing full-time care for my younger sister, since my parents continued to work. After returning to school in the fall, I began a research position but unfortunately could not continue since it was unpaid. I had to pay rent for off-campus housing, so I sought out a different job that could better address my financial needs. I began working as a supplemental instructor for a semester and after, I was an ED technician. Additionally, I continued volunteering for Tulane EMS, providing emergency care and also transporting COVID-positive students to quarantine facilities.

Under_School: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
personal_statement:
It was a Friday morning – I woke up, got dressed, and hopped into the car with my parents to go to the hospital one city over for an endoscopy. I was hopeful, but cautious. I had been in and out of doctor’s offices for years and had a previous endoscopy four years earlier that was inconclusive. I had a chronic gastrointestinal disorder that doctors couldn’t seem to solve. After my endoscopy, my parents took me to get food while I yearned to be at the soccer game that I missed that day. Throughout my childhood, my gastrointestinal illness repeatedly separated me from my first love, sports. Whether it was due to feeling sick or having a doctor’s appointments, I missed countless basketball and soccer games or practices, all while aching to be on the court or field with my friends. 

The doctors concluded from my endoscopy that I had IBS. Over the course of the following year, I adjusted my diet and lifestyle, with the help of my gastroenterologist, so that I could manage my IBS and enjoy sports again. My experiences with IBS provided my first exposure to the medical field and revealed a desire in me to help others with chronic conditions so that they also could return to the lifestyles they once treasured. However, I was not sure in what capacity I would be able to do so. 

As I entered college, I was able to pursue my love for sports through an Exercise and Sports Science major and managing the UNC Men’s JV basketball team, convinced that I wanted to be an athletic trainer or physical therapist. My classes instilled in me the value of exercise on the well-being of an individual and showed me that there are many factors affecting one’s health. My experience as a manager allowed me to work in a fast-paced environment, learn how to problem solve in a variety of circumstances, and become a flexible and reliable teammate to other managers. With nightly practices and games each Saturday, I gained time management skills by efficiently balancing my full-time school and work schedules. During my sophomore year, I was able to strengthen my communication skills, acting as head manager for a group of over twenty JV managers, delegating tasks and coordinating between coaches, referees, and the UNC JV team.  

It wasn’t until my junior year of college that I began to consider medicine as a future career. During that fall semester, I volunteered at a local non-profit, A Helping Hand, providing home healthcare for older adults under the poverty line. As I formed connections with each of my clients, I witnessed how they were treated in a society that primarily caters to younger generations and learned of the biases they face from medical professionals. One of my clients, Mrs. R, faced a mobility impairment and was unable to drive, so I was her only access to leaving her senior-living apartment each week and her only assistance with in-house chores. I recall her apartment, with smoke stains soaked into the carpet and walls, dirty dishes piled in the sink, magazines, food, and various trash cluttering the floor, and the odor of weeks-old food and cat litter. All of this was due to her immobility, not due to her lack of care for the apartment. One day, she expressed how she missed being physically active and felt that her doctors believed that she didn’t care enough to improve her condition since she often missed doctor’s appointments due to her immobility. She made me aware of my own biases, and I realized how much her handicap inadvertently negatively impacted her already poor health. Being able to go directly into the homes of my clients enabled me to see how medical status, living conditions, socioeconomic class, and race are interrelated in the overall health of an individual. After this internship, I desired to make a change in the healthcare provided to older adults or disadvantaged populations, and I wanted to be the provider my clients deserved. 

Since my junior year of college, I have participated in various health-related environments, like COVID testing sites on campus and most recently, working as a medical assistant at a dermatology office. Teenagers with acne, older adults with skin cancers, babies with eczema, men and women struggling with hair loss, and people of all ages with obscure rashes are just a glimpse of patients I get to meet daily. Every day, I am excited and gripped by the various patient cases. Most importantly, I’m able to witness the joy, relief, and gratitude of the patients as they are treated for their chronic cystic acne, skin cancers, lifelong eczema or psoriasis, alopecia, and even something as rare as a dermatitis herpetiformis rash. Being a physician means improving the quality of life and being a difference maker in the lives of all patients, and I want to be a part of that. 

My passions for health, service, learning, hard work and interpersonal relationships drive my desire to make an impact as a physician, both in and out of the clinic. Whether my career involves assisting athletes’ in recovering from sports injuries, providing primary care to geriatric populations, aiding disadvantaged communities, or delivering dermatological care, I will seek to leverage my career to provide the greatest care, compassion, and service offerable, thus fulfilling my true calling as a doctor.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: He was just another patient that I pulled back on a busy Tuesday afternoon. I brought Mr. W to his patient room and asked about his concerns for his dermatology visit. While walking out of the room after obtaining his information, I complimented the necklace Mr. W was wearing. As he thanked me, I noticed he got choked up. ‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù he said, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just my partner gave me this necklace, and he just passed away two months ago.‚Äù I immediately extended my apologies and stayed in the room as he confessed his difficulties in coping with grief. When giving Dr. L the chief complaint for Mr. W after leaving the room, I informed her of Mr. W‚Äôs loss. During the visit, Dr. L also empathized with Mr. W and allowed him to express his emotions. Even though Dr. L didn‚Äôt share a similar experience, Dr. L offered emotional support and got to know Mr. W on a level more than just a physical illness. This showed me the criticality of compassionate care, and I aim to treat my patients similarly in the future.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Through an internship, I provided home care to older adults below the poverty line. Caring for my two clients, Ms. R and Ms. S, allowed me to improve their quality of life in unique ways. Each Wednesday, I was responsible for assisting Ms. R in running errands such as attending doctor‚Äôs appointments, going to the bank, grocery shopping, or even cleaning her apartment, as her lack of mobility limited all aspects of her life. By helping her with these seemingly ordinary tasks, I reduced the stress Ms. R experienced and contributed to Ms. R feeling more in control of her life.
