On the other hand, Ms. S exposed me to the difficulties older adults face in forming genuine relationships with those around them, especially if they live in younger cities or have no family nearby. Ms. S often confided in me how lonely she felt, and by spending time with her each week, I was able to provide the companionship that she desired and a listening ear. As a result, Ms. S felt more seen and valued.
7_-_COVID_Impact: COVID-19 dramatically changed my education during my junior year of college; within weeks, my classes adopted a virtual format and I moved to my hometown. At this time, I faced the challenges of developing relationships with professors and classmates while adjusting to life at home for the first time in three years. Once I returned to campus my senior year, I was eager to become involved on campus again. Although opportunities were limited, I volunteered in a virtual balance class for older adults and during my second semester, I volunteered at testing sites on campus. COVID-19 created many changes, but it also allowed me to respond with resilience and reflect on why I want to be a doctor, which has better prepared me for medical school.

personal_statement:
From the garden on Halfmoon Lake to the Jungles of Guyana, following my interest in promoting healthier lifestyles steered me to pursue medicine. My foray into public health began during my undergraduate studies. Despite working full-time, I reserved time to pursue my interest. One of which was grassroots development, leading me to join Clear Vision Eau Claire. The organization focused on using democracy to address a community-identified issue. My life-long hobby of gardening inspired me to join the healthy lifestyle group. Our goal was simple. To expand community gardens in low-income neighborhoods to increase access to fresh produce. After a year of planning and advocacy, our efforts paid off. The new garden on Halfmoon Lake produced some of the sweetest melons I had ever tasted. Hungry for more, I became a research assistant for a project studying fruit and vegetable consumption in children. Our team studied the effects of health promotion and token-economy incentives. Our interventions led to healthier food choices. I wanted to continue exploring careers that would allow me to use the scientific method to improve health at the population level.  

After graduating, I joined the Peace Corps to begin my career in public health and community development. My job as a Community Health Promoter took me to Develdt, a small village of about 300 Arawak people deep in the hinterlands of Guyana. There I worked with the only healthcare provider, a Midwife named Leah. The river serves as the only road in the community. Leah and I would paddle a dugout canoe in the hot equatorial sun to our patients’ homes. During one trip, we visited an antenatal patient, “Mia,” in her second trimester. We noticed her blood pressure had increased by 40 mmHg since our last visit. She was diagnosed with preeclampsia. Mia’s midwife immediately referred her to the nearest hospital. Despite our daily pleas for her to seek a higher level of care, Mia’s next trip to the hospital would end at the morgue. Comfort cares and prayers were the only interventions we could provide on the long boat ride to the hospital. Witnessing her preventable death profoundly impacted me, and I still struggle to identify all the emotions associated with that day. However, I realized the privilege of being trusted to provide care and support for Mia and her family. For the first time, I began considering a clinical career rather than focusing solely on public health.

Shortly after Mia’s death, I had to leave Develdt due to a security concern. I had two options: return to the United States or continue my service at a new site. I was devastated to leave Develdt but knew I had to finish my commitment. My second assignment took me to the Venezuela-Guyana border. The Mabaruma Regional Hospital was a small 28-bed facility with four physicians and eight nurses. I developed close friendships with my colleagues while living in the hospital compound. We would lime and gaff (hang out) every night until the mosquitoes became unbearable. These friendships instilled me with the confidence to pursue medicine. In the hospital, it was clear that the physician’s expertise improved patient outcomes. With their knowledge, they could navigate the challenging, low-resource environment better. I would wonder what would have happened to Mia if a physician had been stationed less than a four-hour boat ride away. My experience in Mabaruma fortified my decision to pursue medicine. When I joined the Peace Corps, I promised to serve where needed most, and I fully intend to continue this promise and aspire to address the need for rural physicians in America. 

Following my successful Peace Corps experience, I continued my commitment to service at the Department of Veteran Affairs. To better understand American hospitals, I became a ward clerk. The physicians I worked with in the traumatic brain injury ward supported my desire to further my education. They were always enthusiastic about explaining patients’ imaging and how their lesions presented. During my time on the wards, I was inspired by the physicians’ role of not only clinically managing patients but also the expectations of their loved ones. Their knowledge allowed them to provide both realistic hope and ample comfort. Seeing the humanistic art of medicine in America would further my resolve to study medicine.   

After three years of clinical experience abroad and stateside, I was eager to begin my post-baccalaureate studies. I excelled academically and professionally while working full-time. While studying, I was able to earn three promotions during my four-year tenure. Going back to school and pursuing medicine in my late twenties was not a decision I made lightly. My experience caring for patients helped me further understand and develop the incredible emotional resiliency required of me as a physician. My Peace Corps service taught me despite hardship, quality education is enduring. This knowledge propelled me on my journey of obtaining the most extensive clinical education possible. I look forward to continuing as a lifelong learner. I want to continue using my experiences in public health, civic engagement, and capacity building to improve health for the individual and the community.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
For 27 months, I lived and worked with two Amerindian (indigenous) tribes of South America while serving as a Peace Corps Volunteer. During this time, I lived with an Amerindian host family, which further increased my understanding of the Amerindian community._x000D_
_x000D_
I worked hard to always conduct myself with respect to the culture and took the time to learn about the tribe's history and culture. I immersed myself in my community to make friends and was rarely alone. I spent every night and day playing volleyball, football, or chatting with my neighbors. Much to their glee, I learned many traditional crafts, including making bread and wine from cassava, weaving tibisiri into hammocks, and carving the pits of fruits into jewelry. I learned that I had the maturity to adapt to new situations and maintained a professional demeanor in a new culture during even challenging circumstances. I also learned to be more open-minded to other cultures.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As a Peace Corps Volunteer working in Guyana, South America, I had many projects related to improving the capacity of healthcare delivery by integrating technology for development. However, one of my favorite projects was focused on improving the educational outcomes of students at the Mabaruma Secondary School. There was a shortage of qualified mathematics teachers living in the remote community, and students at the secondary school struggled to pass their national examination to enter competitive studies at the university. I partnered with local business and the foundation for learning inequality to setup an offline server that made Khan Academy accessible for any student with a smart phone (a resource almost every student had). Students to this day are still utilizing the Khan Academy server and have reported greater pass rates on the national university entrance exam.

personal_statement:
As I sit planning my first weeklong 50-mile hike with my scouting group to climb Utah’s highest point, King’s Peak, I am both thrilled and fearful. I have already packed my tent, food, and clothes, but I still need to make sure I have space for hand sanitizer, soap, twice as much clean water as everyone else, and a hefty supply of urinary catheters to last a week. These types of concerns, however odd, have dominated how I think for years. I was born with bladder exstrophy requiring several surgeries starting at birth and continuing over the next few years of my life. Those surgeries included forming an augmented bladder with my small intestine, closing my urethra, and re-implanting my ureters to decrease reflux. Even with these surgeries I had to learn how to use catheters from an early age to be independent at home, school, and elsewhere.

From the start of elementary school, I worried about fitting in. I didn’t want others to know I had anything wrong with me, so I kept my medical problems from my classmates. To do this, I had to plan my days around going to the bathroom frequently to prevent infections. I needed to know where bathrooms were located and how I would use a communal sink and stalls without my fellow classmates finding out about my condition. Such planning from a young age was difficult and at times stressful.

Aside from these difficulties, I also wondered if I would be able to do all the things everyone else did around me. These concerns were washed away as my doctors not only provided me ways to succeed physically, but also mentally. They encouraged me and assured me that I was indeed capable of living a normal life, and they explained how I could do so. I still plan out my days, flush out my bladder frequently, and fight occasional UTIs, but because of the care provided by my physicians I was able to conquer many challenges like going on my weeklong 50-mile hiking trip. Thanks to the help of my physicians, I was able to run track, play tennis and baseball, and live a very fulfilling, active life, despite my urologic challenges. My physicians inspired me to want to heal others both physically and mentally to enable them to live the healthiest and most fulfilling lives possible.

My desire to pursue medicine and serve others propelled me to get hands on experience serving people in a hospital setting. This led me to a job as a patient care technician in the mother-baby unit. As the only male in an all-female team taking care of newborns and new mothers, I quickly learned how to put patients at ease and overcome some of their initial discomfort in working with a male caregiver. This unit of the hospital, like others, was accompanied by a variety of emotions. From the joy of birth to the sadness in loss, or anxiety from health complications. At times a child was separated from their mother to attend to a birth complication or medical need; this was always very trying for the mother. In these nerve-racking moments real healing was more about receiving peace of mind than any kind of medication for sleep or pain. I learned the critical role that clear communication and knowledge had in giving peace of mind. When a mother knew in real time what treatment her child was receiving and how it would help, her stress was reduced. Only then could she relax enough to begin healing herself. Assisting in this process strengthened my previous resolve to help provide physical and emotional healing to others.

After learning about the powerful effect that knowledge can have on a patient, I developed and carried out an education project with Central Utah Early Intervention. This project addressed an alarming increase in the number of children with severe delays in communication and social interaction skills as they entered preschool. I visited over 20 physician offices in underserved areas of rural Utah to spread awareness of this growing issue and to provide education for physicians. This included how to access support services like early intervention programs, and a speech milestone handout for parents to track their child’s progress. As I provided this education, I was surprised by the relief expressed by physicians who saw these developmental delays on a daily basis but were unsure how to access support in their area. My desire to provide healthcare equity as a physician grew as I saw the sincere love that physicians felt for their patients in these small communities.

My personal experiences with medicine have allowed me to lead an active and fulfilling life. Those experiences integrated with my time working in the hospital have fortified my inclination to attend to the physical, mental, and emotional needs of others. Additional growth has come to me by participating in several extracurricular activities including the work I carried out with those in rural areas of Utah suffering from speech delays, illuminating research at the Mayo Clinic to improve future care of patients with heart failure, providing interpretation for Spanish speaking patients at a free clinic, and more. I am eager for the opportunities to help those in need that would come to me as a physician, and am confident, based on my life experiences so far, that I will be able to overcome any challenges that would come my way.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I served for two years as a missionary for my church in Boston, MA. I was assigned to Spanish speaking communities which necessitated learning a new language. I helped with their physical needs, assisting them to find housing and employment as many were immigrants from the Caribbean and Central America. I learned to appreciate their stories, diversity, and courage in overcoming so many obstacles to obtain a better life for their family. To continue using Spanish to help others I interpreted at a clinic that gave free medical care to those who were under 150% of federal poverty level. I learned about their health, financial, and cultural challenges. I found that each patient had a distinct story to tell and wanted their voice to be heard. By listening to and relaying their unique circumstances to physicians many obtained the care they needed. I have learned to love and value diverse cultures. I also learned that simply listening can often be the most impactful way to help someone.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I completed an outreach project in coordination with Central Utah Early Intervention for rural central Utah when I learned about severe communication and interaction delays for children entering school; delays so severe they were being qualified for special education. I visited over 20 clinics to provide access to early intervention programs, including home visits, as well as speech milestones for parents. During this time, I spoke with several physicians about the difficulties they faced in terms of support, and the necessity of treating a variety of things because they are the only resource for their patients. I was impressed with the love they had for their communities helping as many as they can to experience healthcare equity. This population health project has provided a meaningful resource for physicians to share with families to receive in home treatment at little to no cost. I hope this project will turn the tide for speech delays and prevent such severity in the future.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Due to the pandemic, patient interactions, physician shadowing, and research opportunities were limited. Though I was able to work as a patient care technician in a mother/baby unit, I wanted to participate in several varied experiences. I learned that to get these experiences I had to be more flexible in what I was looking for and participating in. I also had to be much more persistent and creative to find and participate in opportunities with ever changing COVID restrictions. Even after an experience was set, requirements of the facility or practitioner would change. With creativity, persistence, and flexibility I was still able to experience a wide variety of opportunities including: becoming a COVID screener at the emergency room entrance and at the Red Cross, creating and implementing a speech and language delay awareness drive, shadowing several physicians, participating in research at two institutions, and presenting research at the ACSM conference in San Diego.

Hrdshp_Comments: I was born and raised on the South Side of Chicago. My father grew up in Chicago, earning his GED there after dropping out of high school. My mother is from rural Minnesota and earned an associate degree. Our financial standing has always been strained, as my father did not contribute to our household. Moreover, the appearance of my parent’s income on paper meant that we were not able to apply for government assistance programs. Our means have been even further stressed since the advent of my father’s illness, thus limiting my access to educational, personal, and professional opportunities. Although my parents prioritized education, the lack of institutional investment in public schools in our neighborhood meant I had more barriers to receive what others had innately. Thus I have had a lifetime of traveling further, fighting for scholarships, and maintaining employment to keep up with my peers. While I have been successful in my pursuit of higher education, I have also experienced isolation, exclusion, and microaggressions in these spaces due to differences in my racial and socioeconomic statuses. Even though there have been obstacles, I am proud to be a low-income, first-generation college graduate and appreciate how my background has shaped the population I want to serve as a future physician.
personal_statement:
I have grown up hearing my father say, “you can be anything you want to be if you put your mind to it.” Despite this, my parents never fathomed that I would seek to become a doctor. In hindsight however, they laid the perfect foundation to lead me to this career, by demonstrating in their lives how fulfilling a life of service can be. 
I first began to think about medicine as my life of service, when my father became chronically ill as I left high school. In the free time that my father gained due to his sarcoidosis, he reflected deeply on his life and realized that he wanted to build stronger relationships with his children. Medicine has indeed served my father by sustaining his physical being; however, this is just a proxy. At the heart of it, medicine has given my father a second chance at cultivating the parts of his life that he has deemed meaningful to him. I believe that medicine is the ultimate act of service to society because by transforming an individual’s health, they may now have the potential to transform so much more in their life. I am driven to practice medicine because of its power to create stronger communities filled with individuals who are able to focus on things meaningful to them. 
My father’s illness led me to the pre-med classes that developed my deep curiosity for science, but it was in my psychology research experiences where I began to uncover the values I want to uphold as a doctor. Working on a research study where participants shared their different beliefs and habits about sexual health, I found myself thinking about how if I was their doctor, I would need to tailor conversations to best encourage safe sex practices. Inspired by this experience, I desire to become a doctor because in this career I will have the privilege of building personalized partnerships with my patients, through learning about their individual lifestyles, needs, and beliefs. However, I believe these partnerships are more than a privilege; they are a necessity to provide high quality healthcare. As a physician, I will champion individualized medicine guided by partnerships with my patients not only because it leads to more effective treatment, but because patients deserve to feel empowered. 
While I believe that contributing to research is an act of dedication to the human community at large, in an effort to support individuals’ health more directly, I joined Health Bridges. This organization is dedicated to improving health equity in Pomona, California by enrolling uninsured individuals for temporary insurance in their native language. Towards the end of my time with this program, I assisted a man who was being treated for a broken arm. As I began to speak to him, he told me quite hastily in Spanish that he did not care about whatever I was trying to sell him. As I learned to become more resilient throughout my time in this program, I introduced myself and expressed my concern for his injury. Once he became more receptive, I engaged in a discussion with him about the program. I patiently helped him to understand what the program entailed, ultimately leading to him expressing a desire to enroll. For this patient and all others, this work truly resonated with me, especially as the reality is that my father, who is unable to work, could have been one of the patients I enrolled, if not for being married. I intend to provide high-quality healthcare to underserved communities as a physician, always actively promoting access to healthcare across socioeconomic and language barriers. 
In my current role as a liaison between the physicians and patients at Generation Next Fertility (GNF), I have built on the clinical skills first fostered by Health Bridges. My second time on-call I was presented with a critical issue - a woman in an IVF cycle who needed to take her trigger shots in thirty minutes did not have one of them at home. Immediately, my mind began whirling - Should the dosage of the medication be changed? What was her nearest fertility pharmacy? How would taking it late affect her egg retrieval? After contacting the on-call physician, I evaluated and determined the best action, making sure to keep the patient informed and calm. Everyday I witness the physicians at GNF similarly use critical thinking skills in patient care. I have long known medicine requires an adeptness towards analyzing symptoms to determine a diagnosis and exhibiting strong judgment towards the most appropriate treatment. My time at GNF has taught me that while being excellent in this regard is a fundamental need, good medicine transcends this and requires strong listening skills, a commitment to continuous learning, and a curious and innovative mindset. 
These experiences have led me to understand that as a physician, my goal will be to work in partnerships with patients, delivering high-quality healthcare that is defined by empathy, creativity and persistence. Seeking to build stronger communities, I will prioritize delivering healthcare to underserved populations, while also conducting research that improves the health of future communities. Above all, as I go through this journey, what I hope to “put my mind to” the most, as my father would say, is always continuously learning and improving, in service to my future patients.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: At Generation Next Fertility, I have seen one particular patient complete egg retrievals for months, but not be successful in having forming embryos. With this context, her physician has inquired about whether the patient was open to egg donation, which would give her a much higher chance at pregnancy. However, the patient informed us of the taboos that surround egg donation in her culture and that specifically her mother had expressed extreme displeasure with her daughter pursuing this. This was hard for me to hear because it would be the choice I would make if I was the patient. However, it was easier to understand after she confided in me that her relationship with her mother and her culture were the most important things in her life and she would never want to jeopardize that. This patient helped me to understand that if an individual‚Äôs values or choices do not align with mine, it is important that I trust that they are making the most beneficial decision for their own life.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: In college, I led a partnership with a Tongan Community group to provide events focused on COVID and vaccine empowerment. This occurred around the time that vaccines were being rolled out and the community that we were working with expressed hesitancy over receiving them. While it brought me immense satisfaction to apply my scientific knowledge to present the technicalities of the vaccines, I found that the conversations we had after the presentation were just as important. Here, we discussed specific fears community members had and shared our personal stories why we believed it was important to become vaccinated. I also believe that the time we spent building a relationship with the community over the course of the semester played a major role in building up their community‚Äôs trust. Ultimately, I am proud to not just have played a part in increasing the vaccination rate in this community, but making sure that these community members felt secure in their health choices.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The pandemic first impacted my path to medical school through having my time studying abroad in Greece cut short, which meant I spent less time shadowing in a neurosurgery unit and I was not able to start volunteering with a refugee organization as intended. When school resumed, I also lost out on several extracurriculars, but an especially important one to me was my research mentor closing her Health Psychology lab after it became obvious that the pandemic was not ending. It was also harder to perform well in school. As my family did not have internet access at home, we had to rely on checking out often unreliable hotspots from the library. Moreover, the immuno-compromised state of my father‚Äôs health often made it hard for me to concentrate.

personal_statement:
Drowning myself in a tub of Neapolitan ice cream, I was unaware of the capacity a single moment had to change one’s entire future. In the spring of 2009, my best friend, Alexa, got into a biking accident that left her in a four-month coma. Peeking over the Blue Bell tub, I attempted to decipher my parents’ medical jargon, but only felt more powerless. For the next few months, I visited Alexa every other day. I can still smell the sterile PICU and see the maze of cords connected to her little body. I was so visibly distraught on one such visit that I attracted the attention of Alexa’s doctor. Crouching down so she was at eye level with me, she explained that while she was treating Alexa’s brain, I had the important task of treating her soul by being with her. At the time, I had no idea what that meant; however, the understanding that I could help Alexa get better by keeping her company cheered me up considerably. After 4 months, she woke with partial paralysis. Alexa and I became inseparable to the point that I attended her weekly speech and physical therapy sessions with her for over a year. It wasn’t until I was about to move away for college that Alexa’s mother spoke life-altering words: “Alexa is alive because of you. I know doctors treated her after the accident, but if you were not with her through her recovery, I don’t think she would have had a reason to improve.” This experience was my proverbial call to action–both sparking my interest in the biological sciences and inspiring me to pursue a career in medicine. 

Years later while shadowing Dr. Barnett, a neurosurgeon, I noticed his disposition was reflective of mine with Alexa. Without speaking a word, the palpable helplessness of each patient faded with Dr. Barnett’s infectious tranquility. He taught me that the understanding between a doctor and their patient is not only to fix them physically but to be their ally through their entire health journey. Doctors require not only empathy and compassion but a stillness that resonates with others. Contrary to my previous beliefs, healing one’s body and soul don’t have to be separate endeavors and in fact, the best doctors are ones who couple these processes. Using my experiences with Alexa and Dr. Barnett, my presence as a physician will be more than treating patients’ health conditions but making sure they don’t lose themselves in the process.

While I primarily feel grateful for Alexa’s awakening, I also remain perplexed by her body’s recovery. To address my curiosity about the human body, I joined Dr. Li’s lab, which explores the microbiome’s impact on diseases. I quickly grasped how much the human condition remains unexplored, igniting a new appreciation for the sciences. Working under Dr. Li and collaborating with other labs in similar fields, I worked to computationally analyze bacterial DNA fragments collected by the lab’s undergraduate and graduate students. Our different backgrounds allowed us to approach our research question from various angles to more comprehensively interpret our data. This taught me that the effort of an individual doesn’t compare to a collective of diverse researchers. This lab’s unity primed me for the collaboration between physicians of independent specialties: individually as an element and together as a solution.

To explore my artistic passions, I joined the Fashion and Student Trends club with the intention of being a stylist. It became apparent that the closest I would get to directly working with clothes was through modeling, which entailed a task I was entirely unfamiliar with and apprehensive about: a runway show in front of a thousand people. I knew I would regret abandoning my interests for fear of failure, so I learned how to walk a runway. The six months of practicing and preparing for the show required my development and dependability, as I needed to receive, understand, and execute critiques. Furthermore, one model’s absence would interfere with the show’s execution. When I was given the role of opening the show, my returning fear quickly subsided with confirmation of my significant progress. Through collaborating with the designers and adjusting to their last-minute changes, I had the honor of giving life to lines with unique cultural references and stylistic techniques. My designers counted on my resilience, reliability, and willingness to grow, all of which are traits that patients count on their doctors to possess. 

After witnessing Alexa’s recovery, I realized that the complexity of humans goes beyond our physicality and involves an elaborate network of feelings, conflicts, and overcomings. Unlike cars, people cannot go into a shop broken and come out repaired. We do not come with manuals, because, as the central lesson of medicine, simplicity is not a part of our nature. It’s a doctor's job to use patients’ unique backgrounds, experiences, and communication methods not only to make diagnoses but also in approaching patient interactions. It’s a doctor’s job to constantly broaden their knowledge bank. It’s a doctor’s job to treat their patient and not just their condition. To those entrusted with this responsibility, I want to say thank you, and I hope to someday provide another 8-year-old with the courage to treat their friend’s soul.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: This summer, I studied abroad in Spain where I met a local, Cami, who soon became a close friend. Cami embodied the vibrant and warm culture in Spain. On our way back from a waterfall hike, we lost the path in the darkness, so I attempted to find my way back. Once I realized Cami wasn‚Äôt following me, I walked over to see her laying on the ground looking at the stars. ‚ÄúCami, we need to find out way back before it gets too late,‚Äù I explain to her. Cami replied, ‚ÄúThe path isn‚Äôt going to get up and walk away. Besides, it‚Äôs already dark, so what‚Äôre 15 minutes to find all the constellations.‚Äù Laying down for nearly an hour, we identified all the major constellations and even named a few of our own. At that moment, I didn‚Äôt understand how nonchalant she was about losing our way, but now I realize that, for her, being lost was an adventure, not a setback. This mindset has even become a part of my current mentality in dealing with small inconveniences, as it sets a more positive light on life._x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation: During a shift as a Care Extender volunteer at Ronald Reagan, I was transferring Mr. Torres, a patient, while he divulged the stories of his youth and the inspiration behind his poetry. He had an undiagnosed illness yet was unphased in spite of it, showing no fear and incredible resilience. He said, ‚ÄúElla, if I can pass on just one grain of my mistakes and lessons to you, then I‚Äôll be satisfied with my outcome.‚Äù ‚ÄúBut then they wouldn‚Äôt be my lessons to learn,‚Äù I told him. Mr. Torres laughed and said, ‚ÄúI wish I could have heard that earlier, and maybe I wouldn‚Äôt have made so many mistakes with my children.‚Äù I told him that there was no time like the present, and soon after, Mr. Torres contacted his children who he had previously not wanted to bother. On my next shift, I met his daughter and was given a signed copy of his poetry book. Although I may have helped motivate Mr. Torres to repair some of his relationships, he reminded me that my mistakes are a necessary part of my own journey.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I quarantined with my cousin, Faven, who only left her room at night to ensure that I was still breathing. The isolation quickly dismantled her mental condition which had been restored for 15 years since her parents were killed during the Ethiopian Civil war. Her theories about the threats to our lives could not be eliminated by logic. To her, I needed protection from anyone else that entered the house, including my parents. Every day, I watched my free-spirited cousin get replaced with someone consumed with fear and anxiety. During our one-sided conversations, I attempted to pull every thread that reminded her of our safety, but I was always left with unraveled string. This experience entirely altered the way that I viewed the triggers of the human psyche, and it gave me another array of mysteries that I craved to solve through the pursuit of medicine.  It taught me that sometimes people don‚Äôt want you to help them fight their silent battle but simply understand that there is one.

personal_statement:
The plan was simple. Early that morning my mom would take my older brother to her office for a brain MRI. My father drove separately so he could take him back to school after the scan. He never attended class that day. My aunt pulled me out of school and explained on our drive to Mott Children’s Hospital that my brother had a brain tumor that needed to be removed. So vividly, I remember the first time I laid eyes on him. Surrounded by loud equipment, he had on a hospital gown and what seemed like one hundred tubes protruding from his body. My older brother, the one that was always able to best me in everything, was defenseless. What troubled me further was seeing my parents, two doctors who seemed to always know what to do, so helpless and vulnerable. I ran out of his room terrified, refusing to go back no matter how much my parents begged. I remained this way until one of the nurses approached me. Smiling confidently, she sat next to me and held out her hand, to which I stared for a while before taking hold. For what felt like an eternity, I sat crying as she wiped away each successive round of tears and mucous from my cheeks. That simple display of compassion by that nurse gave me the courage to rejoin my family and support my brother. Over his two-year battle with cancer, it was the countless incredible experiences like this from the staff at Mott that ultimately convinced me becoming a doctor was what I should spend the rest of my life working towards. 

Getting great grades is important, but a doctor is so much more than a book-smart individual. Recognizing this, I made the commitment to dedicate my free time at college to improving skills beyond excelling academically. I took on a job as a laborer to a group of bricklayers, not really knowing what to expect. I knew the work would be hard, but I never expected the experience to be so meaningful. My crewmates were comprised of mostly immigrants, many of whom lived paycheck to paycheck. Each second I wasted on the job was food off their table. This motivated me to work harder than I knew I was capable of, and the crew quickly took notice. They gave me pay raises and let me work longer hours, but the money was not nearly as valuable as the experience. Many of the workers opened up to me about their struggles. They spoke about the pain they put up with each day due to working this labor-intensive job, and how they refused medical care as they could not afford it. Reflecting on their stories of struggle I often asked myself, “what did I do to deserve the privileges I have grown up with?” The answer is, “not enough.” Therefore, I chose to commit every ounce of my time to becoming a doctor so I can provide care for people like my crewmembers who need it most. So I can make an impact in the lives of those who have less. So I can one day answer this question about my privilege differently. 

The countless hours I dedicated to clinical care opened my eyes to the joy of personally assisting patients in their journey to better health. As a physical therapy technician, I thoroughly enjoyed leading the patients I worked with through their strenuous exercise regimens. It was difficult at times to see their faces of discomfort as I challenged them to push past their comfort zone. What made it absolutely worth it, was having the privilege of witnessing their improvement with each successive day of therapy. I was pleased with how natural I felt in the clinical setting and took pride in the care I administered. Throughout my summers as a technician, I often reflected on the feeling of gratitude I had towards the staff at Mott for all they had done for my family. The thought that the patients I worked with felt a shard of this sentiment towards me overwhelms me with happiness and motivates me to continue my journey to becoming a doctor. 

The goal of contributing to the discovery of information that has the potential to improve millions of lives has motivated me to do research at the Henke Cardiovascular Laboratory. Much like building a house, research is no one-person job. I appreciate the collaborative nature of research, never wasting an opportunity to pick the brains of the many knowledgeable doctors and staff on my lab team. My favorite part of research is not running a successful experiment, but rather figuring out why an experiment failed. Those exciting aha moments where I catch my mistakes make up many of the valuable lessons I have learned throughout my time at the Henke Lab. 

These past four years I have taken on many roles beyond student. Through my commitment to research, patient care, and labor amongst other things, I have developed the skills necessary to overcome the many challenges the future holds. There is not a day that goes by in which I fail to recognize the pivotal role my support networks have played in building who I am today. I am so thankful for the experiences I have had, and the relationships I have formed. In my professional career, I strongly desire to make an impact in the lives of others, just as so many have done for me. I desire to know on my last day that I spent my life doing something meaningful. I am certain this desire will best be fulfilled by becoming a doctor and will do everything in my power to achieve it.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Working alongside many union workers in downtown Detroit during my time at Metros Masonry broadened my worldview. Diverse in age, ethnicity, and socioeconomic status, I had the privilege of growing close to people whose lives were radically different than mine. Hearing their stories of struggle made me feel out of place, as my biggest problems paled in comparison to their challenges. I told this to one worker whom I had grown especially close, for which he shared a perspective that I often reflect on. He said, "Antonio, for everyone in this world, their biggest problem is their biggest problem". He was explaining that though we all grow up differently, with struggles unique to each individual, the emotion that accompanies those struggles are the same. Sadness, excitement, and fear are emotions we all feel, though they may be elicited through different means. This is what makes us human and why regardless of who we are or where we come from, we are certainly more alike than different.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Through my role as a physical therapist technician, I have helped restore movement to hundreds of patients. This role is very hands-on, requiring my full attention throughout the entirety of the workday. At all times I am carefully monitoring the patients I work with, looking for ways I can improve their understanding of what they are doing. I have found that through trying to develop personal connections, I am best able to earn my patient's trust, which in turn gives them confidence that their strenuous recovery regiments have a purpose. Through my efforts to administer the best care possible as a technician, I have been rewarded by witnessing those I help achieve their recovery goals. In my opinion, there is no better feeling in the world than being told: ‚Äúthank you‚Äù.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Because of Covid-19, my plan to work as a therapy technician during the summer of 2020 had fallen through as only the therapists were allowed to return to the office; however, I did not allow this to discourage me. Immediately I began scouring the internet for volunteer opportunities in my area which was a struggle as most volunteer positions were shut down. However, through many internet searches, I eventually discovered Maybury Farm, an educational working farm. The farm work was all outside where I could safely distance myself from others. It was so rewarding to use my talents in woodworking and mechanics to ensure the animals at Maybury Farm were cared for. Additionally, I reached out to my former employer for volunteer work at Associated Orthopedists of Detroit, where I screened patients for Covid-19 prior to visiting with their doctor. I even found a way to contribute to my research lab from home by using online software to do data analysis and histology.

Hrdshp_Comments: There were points in my life when my family and I were faced with an unstable income; this made medical expenses very difficult. Therefore, we utilized Medicaid multiple times to supplement the costs.
personal_statement:
A small bomb exploded blocks away from where my family and I were staying in Cairo, Egypt. The devastation is engrained in my mind, with people begging for help. Wanting to be more proactive in the aftermath, I asked my aunt, a nurse at the local hospital, if I could volunteer. Stomach churning, my aunt stopped me at the entrance to Abbassia Fever Hospital. “This may be a lot to handle. Are you sure you want to do this?” I nodded.
The hospital’s sanitation made it challenging to work. The halls were dusted with sand, multiple patients were crowded into single rooms, and cats roamed the wards. In this resource-strapped environment, even I - as a volunteer - had a hand in patient care. One older woman had a severe case of bronchitis. She would have intense coughing fits that occasionally caused her to vomit, which I would clean up. But despite her ailments, she told me stories about her grandchildren and jewelry-making. We bonded over the meaning of different stones as I gave her medication and fed her meals. She was not only a patient but a businesswoman and a caregiver, and I wanted her to get back to the things she loved. When she was discharged, her excitement to return to her life was something that inspired me to keep going through those turbulent times. Through this experience, I found an outlet that allowed me to contribute to my community in a way I found gratifying - I can provide care to individuals through medicine and watch them slowly regain their health over time.
My drive to help others amidst adversity continued at home. Growing up Arab in a mostly White, conservative area an hour away from where 9/11 happened, I sometimes felt like I was living in a hostile environment. However, I received only a fraction of the discrimination that my grandparents faced, with their thick accents and limited assimilation with American culture. As a result, I became their liaison in this environment.
When my grandpa discovered he needed a pacemaker, he was reluctant to get the procedure. He had experiences with other professionals who dismissed his concerns as he struggled to articulate his thoughts in English. He feared this would happen with the doctor, but he reluctantly agreed to see a cardiologist, so long as I went with him. Sensing that my grandpa was apprehensive during the visit, the cardiologist kept a level-headed view and respected his concerns. The doctor carefully explained the procedure and allowed me to talk to my grandpa in Arabic to confirm his understanding. This professionalism and respect for someone initially hesitant about her practice showed how physicians must not only convey information but must also be willing to meet patients where they are. My grandpa’s decision to get the pacemaker was not based only on medical necessity but also on his concerns about discrimination that needed to be addressed for him to be comfortable receiving treatment. To this end, the cardiologist exhibited cultural sensitivity and served as a role model to me as my interest in a medical career grew. 
In college, I have continued to find ways to serve and advocate for others. I assisted students as a teaching assistant, became an active listener to guide people with mental health issues, and tutored children who were falling behind. These experiences taught me that success is rarely clear-cut or immediate. As much as I wanted a student to receive an A on their next exam or have a client come out of a session feeling perfectly good about their mental health, focusing on gradual improvement and setting long-term goals was more effective. With this in mind, success in these endeavors was not defined by a complete fix but by my ability to help people acquire skills to cope with and progress on their challenges. As I continue to expose myself to medicine through shadowing, I realize how similar lessons apply to the practice of medicine and how my service experiences prepare me for what it means to be a medical provider. Shadowing in the trauma operating room, I watched surgeons amputate a man’s leg. Shocked, I asked if something could be done to prevent this. Due to vascular injury, the doctors could not save his leg, but the focus was to try and amputate it below the knee, which would give him the best functional outcome given the circumstances. The patient would then need to start the long journey of recovery, rehabilitation, and training to live a full life as an amputee. I began seeing what it means to advocate for individuals in the face of medical complexity, where success is not based on cures or fixes but on guiding patients to make the most of their options.
My varied service experiences abroad, at home, and at school have taught me about empathy, especially toward those facing adversity. I hope to channel this perspective in medicine, in which I aim to help patients endure difficult situations and guide them forward. My background has prepared me to work with others, teaching me what it means to align on shared goals, even if they fall short of a cure. I find gratification in the process of healing others, as I experienced while volunteering in Egypt and advocating for my grandfather, and I am motivated to persevere in my endeavors today and in my future as a physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: "What? It was normal. It's still normal," my grandmother said in response to my shock when she told me she had undergone female genital mutilation (FGM). I grew to believe that it was a harmful procedure and wanted to continue studying its negative impacts, from obstetric fistula to PTSD. However, when I began working with a professor, initially expecting to do the same work, she helped me step outside Western thought and explore FGM and its meaning to those who perform the practice. She detailed her work with women in the Democratic Republic of Congo, explaining that she realized some practices are more nuanced than they first seem. I have since shifted my perspective on the practice, now studying it with an understanding of its value to others, seeing how it was a rite of passage for women like my grandmother tried to explain to me. Through this experience, I learned that though a particular practice or ideal isn't normal to me, it is vital to recognize its significance to others.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: My mother scoffed at the rainbow bracelet my brother was showing her and tersely told him to put it away. The excitement drained from his face. He had hoped to explore his femininity this year, but my mom's religiosity was at odds with this. Wanting to help him but knowing I could not change my mother's ideals overnight, I tried to shed light on other issues. I identified her recent episodes of short temper with my brother's mishaps. Bringing this to her attention helped her realize that she needed to be kinder. This led to her having more productive conversations with him instead of allowing anger to overpower her. Eventually, she began to see my brother's struggles from his side. Soon after, on a trip to the mall, she allowed him to purchase a pink shirt she had previously rejected. I learned that making small steps towards a greater goal makes achievements more manageable which parallels how many physicians work with colleagues and patients when treating illnesses.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
As my school transitioned to online learning, I first struggled to find the motivation to continue studying in this format. However, understanding how my classes might apply outside the classroom or after college, I still maintained the same work ethic as in-person by creating two separate spaces in my room - for work and rest. This maintained some normalcy. _x000D_
_x000D_
With my father unemployed and my mother on temporary leave, I had to assist my family financially. I worked more hours with my research position, became a physics tutor, and sold many of our belongings. With so much responsibility, I needed to find an outlet to allow myself to relax. I found cooking to be a great form of meditation._x000D_
_x000D_
Finally, with in-person clinical experiences unaccessible, I utilized WebShadowers, a virtual shadowing website. I learned about various specialties through an examination of case studies. Hearing from a wide range of physicians allowed early exposure to fields I otherwise wouldn‚Äôt have considered.

personal_statement:
While I sat on the far too familiar exam table looking down at my swollen ankle, I reflected on the feelings of heartache and relief that I experienced in that room over the past 10 years. I injured both the medial and lateral ligamentous structures of my ankle—the words themselves did not mean much to me, but Dr. P’s tone conveyed what was at stake. Immediately undergoing surgical repair would have unceremoniously closed the book on my gymnastics career, but the orthopedics team recognized my passion and used their expertise to guide me through successful nonoperative management and an exciting year full of taping and bracing. I was impressed by the specialists’ knowledge and admired their ability to create a treatment plan that brought my goals to fruition. This experience ignited a personal interest in the field of medicine. I was curious to learn about a career in which I could play the role my doctors played for me—ensuring a patient can preserve their way of life even after calamity strikes.
In search of experiences that would cultivate this interest, one which occurred during my sophomore year of college gave me insight into the gravity of the doctor-patient relationship. As an intern in an orthopedics clinic, I met Ms. LD. After rooming her, I listened to her conversation with Dr. V. I watched her expressions ebb and flow with his body language. When he explained the diagnosis and potential surgical treatment, she heard his words, but listened to his delivery and reacted accordingly. After Dr. V explained the high likelihood of a successful outcome, I saw relief quickly shift to disappointment as she explained her hesitancy to opt for the operation. There was no way she could take a leave of absence from work for post-op recovery. Reflecting on my decision to continue competing despite my injuries, I could relate to this feeling of frustration. Perhaps the phrase that stuck with me most was, “It is ultimately up to you whether we operate, but if it were my mother in your position, I would encourage her to get surgery.” I was amazed by this statement because it revealed the constant interplay between physician and patient autonomy, and also how to maintain professionalism within the confines of the intimacy of the doctor-patient relationship. I noticed how Ms. LD was committed to following through with the nonoperative treatment plan because Dr. V adapted it to consider her concerns. Observing the results of this and many other patient-centered approaches to healthcare galvanized my desire to be a physician.
Following my exposure to medicine in the clinic, I was eager to align my academic preparation to fit my medical interests by studying kinesiology. My personal experiences as a gymnast and as a clinical intern placed the classroom content in vivid context. Learning about ankle injuries, I applied this new knowledge to examine my own rehabilitation journey. After the doctors in the clinic taught me about certain muscles, I could finally identify them on a cadaver. Exploring this intellectual interest reminded me of how my doctor explained the science of my situation. As a patient, it reinforced my trust in his ability and enabled me to make a more informed decision. I desire to be a physician who works diligently to help patients understand why a particular treatment is recommended or how their ailment occurred.
Outside of direct encounters with patients, I engaged with programs that gave me confidence in my feelings about my path to medicine. As a woman of color, it was transformative to be exposed to leaders in medicine who shared my demographic through the Daniel Hale Williams (DHW) Pre-Health Honor Society. One particular night after putting in grueling hours of organic chemistry homework, I went to a workshop where the medical students introduced patient interview and physical exam techniques. I felt at home on the clinician’s side of the patient encounter. As I walked back to my apartment that night, I had a renewed ambition to master pre-med classes, so that I would be well prepared for medical school. I was grateful this organization existed to provide such an experience to me, where I could discover my passion for medicine. More importantly, I was eager to lead the DHW community and develop content that exposed other students of color to the possibilities in healthcare careers. Realizing the influence I can have on future generations sparked an aspiration to use my platform to improve the landscape of race and gender in medicine, paving the way for others to follow.
Seeing encounters with patients like Ms. LD in the clinic highlighted the physician’s multifaceted roles of healer and advocate, as well as displayed the importance of the very same empathy that I felt during my bout with musculoskeletal issues. Meanwhile, through my studies and various DHW events, I saw yet another layer of the physician’s role in society at large as an educator and sponsor for change. I feel ready to take on the challenge of learning the science of medicine and translating that knowledge into skills that will allow me to take on these roles of a physician. Most of all, I am excited to exercise my expertise to provide hope to my future patients and stand alongside them in their journey to restoration.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
I anticipated much of the conflict that living in Charlottesville after 2017 would bring. As an African American and Filipino American woman, I have always recognized the need to empathize with those unlike me because I always had to. I had no idea how transformative it would be to meet leaders in medicine who looked like me and who were also navigating majority culture spaces. _x000D_
_x000D_
I am grateful for the Daniel Hale Williams Pre-Health Honor Society (DHW) because it offered guidance and encouragement so that a woman of color could further explore her passion for medicine. I came to realize I too could inspire younger students in our community, whether a medical student or an attending physician. It revealed to me the overwhelming need for representation and cultural competence, and that an essential role of a physician is to be a sponsor for change. Therefore, I will use my platform at Rush and beyond to improve the landscape of race and gender in medicine.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
DHW exposed me to the ways that medicine is improving and needs to continue to improve for minority populations. Serving my community has always been at the core of my values, from providing meals to the homeless with my church family to mentoring children in a project neighborhood. However, leading DHW was an opportunity to serve in a different way. Since the opportunities in DHW impacted me in so many ways, I was eager to develop content that would expose other students of color to the possibilities in healthcare careers._x000D_
_x000D_
Even more important than the guest speakers and programs, our team fostered a supportive and influential community. I saw this through the success of a big sibling program, and especially as I personally mentored underclassmen. Whether we met regularly or I answered a few questions about studying habits, I loved being able to pass along advice and encouragement. My hope is that I can inspire the next generation just as much as the previous one has done for me.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
There were two challenges that impacted my journey to medical school during the pandemic. While I am grateful that spending one summer as an intern was enough to galvanize my desire to become a physician, the experience was cut short. I hoped to continue this work the following two years, but the positions were not available due to the pandemic. Nevertheless, I took advantage of opportunities to enroll in summer classes and study for the MCAT._x000D_
_x000D_
On a more personal note, in 2020 I was diagnosed with an autoimmune disease. This positioned me on the patient side of the exam table, especially as I coped with the frustration of taking an immunosuppressant medication in the middle of a pandemic. However, I gained a new perspective when reconciling the difficult reality of the situation. It helped me realize another layer of the physician‚Äôs role that I am eager to take on‚Äîto stand alongside patients, whether knowledgeable and excited or vulnerable and defeated, in their journey to restoration.

personal_statement:
As we walked into the room of the joyful 76-year-old patient, I was nervous about the life-changing conversation the physician was about to have. Dr. Adamson offered her sincere condolences for the news and explained how the CT Abdomen showed multiple localized tumors on the liver. As I saw the tears roll down the patient's wife's face, I became heartbroken and could not bear to imagine what it was like to hear that news. Dr. Adamson proceeded to say, "I know this must be difficult for both of you to hear." I recognized that she allowed the patient time to digest the tragic news and gave him space to express his fear, frustration, and concerns. Through positive affirmations, she validated the patient's feelings through reiteration while addressing every concern. She explained the possible treatment options with detailed descriptions for each plan, allowing for informed autonomy. With both Dr. Adamson and I being aware of the waiting room filling up, she proceeded to stay with the patient to enable him and his wife room to express their thoughts for another 20 minutes. I was amazed to see someone handle a situation so well, holding the patient's well-being above all. It was the first time I realized that being a physician is not only about understanding human physiology but is also equally about the communication and care you give to your patients. The conversation was transformative as I understood the value of being a patient advocate and defined why I wanted to go into medicine. As we left the room, I even saw the patient smile. 

This experience has inspired me to pursue advocating for those that need support. I elected to volunteer at the Health Resource Center and worked as a stand-in social worker, offering resources to the discharged patients and providing support through their toughest battles. Working in the clinic allowed me to step into the role of the "explainer," which I loved. I directed and informed patients regarding available resources for their specific socioeconomic needs, such as applying for insurance to contacting food banks. As I sat with these individuals of differing socioeconomic backgrounds and learned about their stories, I recognized the disparities these patients face in medicine. It is to patients like these that physicians must ensure to help guide them from a place of suffering to receiving the right resources that benefit their well-being. When providing information and answering questions, I began to understand the difficulties that many health care professionals face with language barriers. The most memorable conversations I've had were with the children that had foreign parents who could not speak about their conditions and problems fluently in English. I often had flashbacks to my childhood when I questioned why my mother could not go alone to her primary care appointments. After talking indirectly to numerous patients through their children, I realized that my mom needed me then, recalling times when I had to explain the physician's emphasis on obtaining Pap smears or HPV screenings. These experiences have inspired me to strive to become a physician that can understand these challenges and be a strong patient advocate by providing clear medical communication to individuals like my mother. 

I am still developing my skills as an "explainer." While tutoring elementary students in science and reading comprehension, the step-by-step process has helped me develop my communication skills by learning to explain concepts patiently. I cannot compare the satisfaction of taking a struggling student to the "aha, I got it" moment. Although on a smaller scale, I believe this is why I am drawn to children who are full of life and enjoy seeing their journey to becoming independent adults. Further on, my experiences with a pediatric ENT have affirmed my passion for pursuing pediatrics through seeing the fun interactions the physician has with the patients during the physical examination. I recognized the importance of creating a relaxed environment for the patient by watching the physician's ability to take a tempered toddler into a calm, giggling patient by talking about "looking at their boogers" with an otoscope. I saw first-hand how the physician prioritized educating both the parents and the children, helping explain the plan of care that is understandable for all. I recognized the physicians' teaching role with patients, medical students, residents, and colleagues in the medical field. I aspire to become a resource for children with whom they can come to have difficult conversations, ask questions they are too afraid to ask their parents, and create a positive and safe environment.

I want to become a physician to provide effective care to my patients through developing these meaningful connections and caring for their mental, social, and physical health. Being a doctor means being an advocate, a communicator, and going the extra mile to ensure that patients are cared for and have their questions answered. To take the time to explain a confusing or difficult diagnosis. To be a physician that listens to their patients' needs. To be a person that understands that medicine is a conversation.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
While working at Saint Louis University's Health Resource Center, I helped provide various resources to patients from differing socioeconomic backgrounds at the free healthcare clinic. I was an individual who could actively listen to their problems resulting from disparities such as financial issues and food scarcity._x000D_
 _x000D_
This experience was the first time I played a part in assisting someone's well-being in a medical environment. I have seen countless patients who constantly say that they would not have sought care if the free clinic was not available. It unsettles me about the individuals with treatable conditions that cannot receive the proper care. _x000D_
_x000D_
I recognized my love for creating meaningful patient interactions and the importance of preventative medicine by advocating for the patient's social circumstances and health. I understand the importance of primary care in underserved communities, as these workers help support individuals facing problematic health disparities.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
After the free health clinic, we ask patients to complete a survey. The form has 12 questions asking for information such as the need for insurance or financial aid. When I discuss with the patient at discharge, I always ask the questions again to ensure they did not accidentally mark "no" for a question that I was able to provide resources for. I asked about her housing situation, as she circled, "no." She explained that she must have misread the question as she currently has an unstable housing situation due to her financial problems. _x000D_
 _x000D_
I looked through the database of available resources and found an organization that provides rent assistance and individual case management. I explained to her how to best contact the organization and with a prepared list of questions to best discuss her situation. She thanked me for the help and explained that she had limited access to the internet to be able to find these resources. I was proud of the support the clinic provides for the community.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
The COVID-19 pandemic created difficulties for me to shadow physicians in the hospital throughout the first two years of my college career. Many hospitals near Saint Louis University (SLU) did not allow undergraduate students to shadow; overall, limiting my desire to understand the different specialties in the beginning years of university. With SLU hospital re-opening to undergraduate students in Fall 2021, I visited nine different specialties for a combined 106 hours throughout my junior year of college._x000D_
_x000D_
Additionally, the pandemic created challenges in developing strong relationships with all my professors. With SLU transitioning to a mixture of in-person/online courses, it was hard to form professional connections. However, even with this disruption, I still made efforts to attend office hours and stay after class on Zoom to interact with my professors by asking questions and further opportunities to apply myself.

personal_statement:
I tossed the ball into the air like I had many times before. I arced my racket high into the sky and struck the tennis ball hard over the net, serving the ball to my opponent, who quickly launched the ball back at me. I positioned myself for another swing. As I pushed off my left foot, I experienced immediate shooting pain in my left knee. I was diagnosed with a meniscus tear. Sports were how I connected with my friends in high school, and I was devastated. After the surgical repair of my meniscus, I underwent six grueling months of rehabilitation, and my physician's comforting presence played an enormous factor in my healing. The simple, genuine humaneness in his eye contact, smile, and explanations regarding my care cemented my trust in him. His quiet confidence alleviated my fears, and I felt euphoric on the day I laced up my shoes and walked back onto the tennis court. My physician's positive impact on my journey to recovery left me inspired. I became enthralled with the idea of becoming a doctor to similarly heal and comfort future patients with whom I come into contact.
My desire to become a physician was further reinforced during high school. After a cow eyeball dissection, I became interested in anatomy. I recall dissecting the eyeball, astonished at the intricacy of the eye. I was amazed at the layering of the structures in the eye that allows us to see. I was further inspired when I collected 500 used eyeglasses from local optical shops to donate to Aravind Eye Hospital in Coimbatore, India. I witnessed the joy that patients experienced when the glasses helped them see the letters during their vision exam. Seeing used eyeglasses impact patients, I was further motivated by the notion of improving patient quality of life as a future physician.  
My journey and fascination with medicine continued during my undergraduate education. I started working as an ophthalmic technician and scribe at a retina clinic. After I shared my interest in becoming a physician, one of the retina specialists in the clinic allowed me to examine his eye. I secured the headgear, and he adjusted the lens to his eye. Suddenly, his bright orange retina flashed in my field of view. I was astonished to see the anatomy of the eye in such detail. My desire to continue on this path was strengthened after observing his live retina. I also learned about the role of physicians as investigators and the importance of medical documentation. I was fascinated that every piece of health information that I gathered could be used by the physician in arriving at the diagnosis and treatment. 
In my role as an ophthalmic technician, I had a distinct encounter with a mother and her premature baby that impacted the way I hope to interact with future patients. When the mother walked into the office, she greeted me with a smile, but I could sense that she was nervous. I was worried as well but knew I had to remain confident. As I lifted the baby's eyelid to instill the eye drops, the baby began to cry. The mother yelled, "Be gentle." Her admonishment startled me, and I retreated my hands. I quickly apologized and handed her a glove, asking if she would like to hold the baby's eyelid. She finally made eye contact with me, and I could tell that involving her in the process caused her to relax. Initially, our interaction was uncomfortable. However, as I modeled the compassion and comfort my orthopedic surgeon showed me when I was a patient, we began to build a rapport. Often, patients are in vulnerable states due to a myriad of reasons. Therefore, I must be prepared to modify my approach and techniques to comfort my future patients. I aspire to always think of my patients and their needs first as I help them navigate their medical journey.
As my interest in medicine grew, I joined two research projects analyzing fundus photos for hemorrhages or yellow pigments in the retina. We were looking to determine if these signs were a side effect of patients taking anticoagulants or medications for interstitial cystitis. I was drawn to this project because I have permanent tinnitus as a side effect of an over-the-counter medication. Through both experiences, I further learned about the connectedness of the body's systems. Medications used to treat one part of the body could negatively affect another part of the body. One of my goals in medicine is to continue the work physicians have achieved in informed decision-making. I want to emphasize education on the benefits and consequences of treatments to give patients the knowledge to make decisions about their health. 
Ultimately, being a patient with a knee injury revealed my desire to become a physician. As I explored my curiosities for medicine, it confirmed my purpose. The physician who healed me became the model that I want to exemplify. As I pursue a life as a physician, I will do my best to comfort patients through compassion and confidence to build rapport. My goal is to build trust in these interactions to earn the privilege of helping them. I am determined to endure the rigors to gain the skills and knowledge to positively impact my future patients. I am prepared to commit myself to evolve into a provider who treats patients holistically and puts the patients' needs first.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: My interactions with the native Spanish speakers while volunteering for Mission Cataract were the most eye-opening. I took Spanish classes in 2015, but I was not confident in my communication skills. I could guide these patients in the clinic, but those adept at Spanish communicated with them. Thus, I was motivated to continue learning Spanish. Since 2017, I could have basic conversations, and I witnessed how conversing in their native language made them appear more comfortable. From my experiences at the clinic, I witnessed how language barriers in health care can directly impact patient comfort and affect their willingness to discuss their conditions with the medical staff. Thus, I desire to be a future physician who can connect with patients and staff. Furthermore, I want to foster an environment where cultural differences do not affect health outcomes. To promote health equity in a nation as diverse as ours, I must understand the needs of the diverse patients I will encounter. _x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation: During the pandemic, I witnessed the potential of community outreach. I helped with a vaccination drive, made 200 masks, and performed temperature checks. I worked with the priests and other volunteers to ensure county guidelines were followed to reduce the spread of COVID. Furthermore, when spreading awareness of the vaccination drive, we learned about the fears regarding the vaccine. Some members expressed they felt more comfortable receiving a vaccine in a familiar setting and where the workers spoke their native language. As a result, they urged their friends and family to follow suit. In the process, I realized how powerful community partnerships could be in promoting public health. These comprehensive healthcare partnerships can be tailored to the communities' health, social, and cultural needs, leading to better health outcomes. I see myself as a physician using my knowledge from these experiences to develop joint partnerships to alleviate disparities in healthcare. _x000D_

Hrdshp_Comments: My family's income was commonly at or around the poverty line and we received medical for many years.
personal_statement:
The first thing I said when someone asked what I wanted to be when I grew up was an ambulance girl. When one of my siblings would crash their bike, I would be so excited—because I got to clean their wounds and put band aids on for them. After "ambulance girl" I had a dozen different ideas about who I could become—rockstar, pilot, teacher (and I do still love teaching)—but what I knew at a young age was that I never wanted to be my brother. Retrospectively, that’s pretty unfair. Chris was kind, he was patient with his much younger siblings, and he helped the people around him. But in adolescence, he also became addicted to drugs. As an adult, rather than a 7 year old, I now know addiction is not a choice. Chris was struggling, in ways that many young people struggle. With neurodivergence, with mental health, with just trying to fit in.

Much of my work and volunteer experience has been centered around helping children and adolescents. I’ve worked at several preschools, helping to guide children through some of their most formative years, and at first it was overwhelming. Conflict and injury prevention is preferable, but not always attainable when juggling so many different kids. In one instance, I was across the room when I saw Zachy punch his sister Vanessa. It’d be easy to walk over and say, “Hitting is bad, Zachy, you can’t play with the blocks anymore.” What took more time and patience, but in the end was much more effective, was to communicate that what Zachy did was wrong in a way that he understood, so hopefully he wouldn’t do it again. It was an opportunity for me to teach empathy and accountability to both kids, and to further their social and emotional development. Moreover, my communication skills later translated to my work as a tutor, learning assistant, and TA, when teaching biology and anatomy, and improved my ability to gauge my students’ understanding.

On UC Davis Medical Center’s pediatric floor I was also involved in helping children process emotions, and hopefully distract them from everything they were going through. I would spend my time there ensuring the cleanliness and safety of the playroom and communicating with Child Life staff and the nursing team about how I could best assist them. Some of my favorite moments, though, were going bedside with kids. My most rewarding experience here was going bedside with a middle school girl, whom I spent around an hour chatting with while her dad was out. She told me all about her taekwondo classes, her diagnosis, and her crush, then she wanted to hear some of my embarrassing stories. Several weeks later, I was sitting in the playroom doing art therapy with a little girl, when the same middle schooler spotted me from the hallway. Her face lit up and she waved. Not 5 minutes later, she walked into the playroom, her mom in tow, saying she wanted to introduce us. I’d already been volunteering at UCDMC for 2 quarters at this point, but when I reflect on my time there, it was that moment when I knew my presence was truly making a difference. I chose to embark on this internship so I could experience how a pediatric floor was run, and also so I could determine how well I was able to handle working with sick and injured kids. While it was difficult knowing that not every patient that I interacted with was going to recover, that middle school girl reaffirmed that pediatrics was a path that I could undoubtedly pursue.

My course work in human rights helped me as a CNA as I worked with the elderly in a skilled nursing and post-acute facility, specifically relating to the rights of the elderly and the ethics of care. Young people and the elderly both crave independence, but also require patience and, honestly, the ability to disguise feelings of exasperation. There were patients with dementia who had to be told the same information every 5 minutes. Others experienced sundowning, and could get very aggravated, or even aggressive in the afternoons. If a patient like that was upset and swearing at staff, I had to be able to not take it personally. It’s not that I did something wrong necessarily, but that they were tired, confused, and frustrated. It was still my job to help them to the best of my ability, which was much easier when I remained calm and friendly.
