I found that, similar to kids, patients suffering from dementia were very discerning when it came to tone and facial expressions. As one of my patients remarked, I had a “calming presence,” that I learned to utilize to help defuse potentially volatile situations.

At the core of every extracurricular experience I had, I realized that most people just want someone to listen and to care about what they are going through, which is possible to do while still getting every other task done. Whether they’re 3 years old or 93 years old, allowing people to talk about their struggles free of judgment, to just be someone who cares and wants to ease their suffering, can make all the difference. This, combined with my interest in disease, my fascination with anatomy, and my passion for teaching, have led me to believe that medicine is the route through which I can heal and alleviate pain. I can utilize the patience and compassion my brother showed others to help young people struggling like he did.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: During May of 2020, near the onset of the pandemic, I helped found a nonprofit to advocate for social justice and ethnic studies at a time when communities of color were protesting ongoing violence and vitriol. Inspired by learning about and meeting activists of the Civil Rights Movement, the goal of Reform Revolution Project was to be a social media based resource amplifying the voices of POC. My work with RRP was a means of supporting the BIPOC and LGBTQ+ friends that I had made, while also educating myself and others on critical topics. I did extensive reading on ethnic studies and racial justice in order to further understand the circumstances this country was (and still is) facing, to spread accurate and thorough information, and to better advise my mentees. I grew up poor, but in other ways I am very privileged. I believe that I have the obligation to use my privilege to destroy systems of oppression. The better informed I am, the better I am able to connect with my patients.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: When working as a CNA, there were several patients that I assisted who had dementia. Two of these residents in particular could be challenging at times. The first experienced sundowning, and could become extremely aggravated, or even aggressive, in the afternoons. The second patient had early onset dementia, but because she was still relatively young, she easily became restless and bored. Oftentimes she would forget to press her call light, and just begin yelling for assistance. It was easy to become annoyed on certain days, for myself and the other staff, but I always worked to conceal it from these residents, as they may sense it and become agitated as well. I gave my patients- and coworkers- grace; if they were overwhelmed I would step in to assist the patient instead. It gave other CNAs a chance to regroup and patients the space to calm down. Treating the residents, and my coworkers as well, with patience and kindness created a less stressful, happier environment for everyone.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, many of my plans post college have been delayed, if not put on indefinite hold. Travel plans changed, but more importantly, the experiences I had in the medical field were altered. I was unable to finish my last shift as a Child Life Volunteer in March of 2020. Additionally, my plans to enroll in another Global Medical Training expedition could no longer happen.  However, I was also given the opportunity for other experiences that I otherwise would have been unable to achieve. I started a social justice non-profit, took CNA courses, and was active in the medical field during a pandemic. I try to make the best of whatever situation I find myself in, so even though I am applying a year after I had originally intended, I am glad for the new and unique experiences I was able to have.

personal_statement:
As the paramedics tore off my hockey skates, revealing the sharp cut of a blade across my ankle, panicked gasps flooded the arena. I dipped in and out of consciousness in the ambulance, jolting awake at the occasional bump until I was left gazing at the white ceiling of a hospital room, feeling alone. At ten years old, I was overwhelmed by the unfamiliar medical jargon that filled the room as providers entered. Confusion and fear eclipsed any physical pain from the gaping wound. Then, a physician held my small hands. When I looked into her eyes, I felt her genuine concern and compassion. As someone who prefers understanding, I finally let out a sigh of relief when she explained how she would numb and stitch my ankle, and that I would be perfectly fine. Although I will never forget the distress and uncertainty, I will always hold onto the feeling of solace the physician provided. I knew then that I wanted to pursue a career in medicine, offering this sense of comfort to others. Specifically, I wanted to emulate this physician's practice of applying expertise to provide individual-centered guidance and care.
It was this desire that led me to volunteer with Pipeline, an organization that provides mentorship and support to West Philadelphia high school students. One day, in an effort to promote the COVID-19 vaccine, I explained how it functioned to my five students. To my dismay, I was met with blank faces on my Zoom screen. I asked the class if they planned on getting vaccinated, in hopes of increasing engagement. 
“No.”
Surprised, I blurted, “What? Why?” Given the statistics that showed how the pandemic had disproportionately ravaged West Philadelphia, I struggled to understand their hesitance. With a shrug, one student replied, “I dunno. I guess I don’t wanna be a guinea pig.”
I was confronted by the reality that communities, perhaps including these very students, have vastly different relationships with physicians and medicine as an institution. For many, the healthcare system does not represent the beacon of hope that it has been for me. All the facts about mRNA couldn’t change that.
To address this difference, I asked my students to share their concerns about the vaccine with me privately, if they felt comfortable. With a better understanding of their fears, I presented facts and statistics, emphasizing the ones that directly addressed these doubts. After my final slide, I again asked if they planned on getting vaccinated. Bright yellow emoticons popped up on my screen. Four of my students “raised” their hands.
This experience reaffirmed my desire to be a physician. Connecting with my students, clarifying any uncertainty or misinformation that led to distrust, and supporting them as they took ownership of their health was incredibly fulfilling. It was also motivating; having built a more nuanced understanding of the inequalities marginalized communities face through the heartfelt experiences shared by my students, I wanted to play a larger role in addressing this disparity.
I soon found an opportunity by volunteering with SHOP, a community health outreach program. To make myself a familiar face, I began conducting blood pressure screenings for underserved residents at a homeless shelter.
Weeks flew by, and I soon recognized and regularly interacted with some of the residents. One chilly night, an overdressed man shuffled in. He was one of the regulars who typically avoided having his blood pressure taken. However, this time, he slowed down as he walked by the table.
“Would you like a blood pressure test?”
Hesitantly, he nodded. I proceeded to take his blood pressure. 140/105. “That’s bad right?” he mumbled. As I removed the cuff from his trembling arm, I saw him anxiously staring at the monitor. He continued, “I know it’s bad. I don’t know why. What do I do?”
I first commended him for taking such a significant step. By bravely allowing me to take his blood pressure, he established a baseline for a partnership where we could clarify his confusion and navigate his fears. Then, I calmly explained the difference between the two numbers. I described how each heartbeat pumps blood throughout the body, exerting pressure on the vessels, and how if this pressure is too high, the vessels can become damaged. He nodded along, occasionally interjecting, until he exhausted all of his questions. Through this experience, I felt how invigorating it was to guide someone who was lost, to help them directly address their angst. Yet, I was unsatisfied with my inability to answer all of his questions or to offer a path of actionable steps forward. Momentary comfort wasn’t enough; I wished to treat him through his whole journey in managing his condition.
As a physician, I will strive to be a source of comfort and knowledge for my patients. In the past few years, I have recognized that a key component to achieving my goal is connecting with the community I hope to serve and understanding their unique concerns. Throughout college, I have seized as many opportunities as possible to learn how to address social disparities in medicine and build skills to provide compassionate care. Studying medicine will allow me to take the next step in joining a community of providers dedicated to enacting long-standing change and solutions.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
To avoid COVID, I quit my job at McDonald‚Äôs. However, this luxury was not an option for others like my co-worker Alma. She had to keep working to support her two children and had unknowingly contracted COVID. Unable to get a PCR test due to time and accessibility restraints, COVID had spread throughout her family._x000D_
_x000D_
Upon hearing this, I asked Alma if she planned on seeing a physician. She declined, citing her fear of being judged._x000D_
_x000D_
Her statement demonstrated a recurring issue within our society: negative assumptions. Since I knew about her family and financial situation, I understood her inability to isolate herself during the pandemic. However, someone unfamiliar with the case would instantly frown upon hearing that she didn‚Äôt adhere to the initial quarantine. This experience showed me the importance of remaining unbiased, especially when it came to strangers. Without an open mind, one wouldn‚Äôt be able to connect with a patient to the level critical for providing well-rounded care.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
One day, while volunteering at a homeless shelter, an older man came over to get a blood pressure screening. As I prepared the machine, I noticed him intently reading a pamphlet. Immediately, I recognized the brochure as one I had made as part of SHOP‚Äôs Education Committee. These pamphlets typically focused on raising health awareness and healthy lifestyles in the community._x000D_
_x000D_
‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the pamphlet about?‚Äù I asked nonchalantly. He responded that it was about getting a replacement for a COVID vaccination card. A friend had lost hers, and he wanted to help her get a new one._x000D_
_x000D_
Later that year, I talked with the shelter‚Äôs director when she mentioned that the residents genuinely appreciated the brochures. It was inspiring to see how something seemingly insignificant, like a leaflet, could profoundly affect people‚Äôs lives. This experience showed me that every action I make can benefit the community I serve, and I plan to carry this insight with me as a student at Rush and later as a physician.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
Living in the virtual world because of COVID felt defeating at first. Stuck in Illinois, I found it difficult to focus during online lectures. In addition, the educational resources I used to rely upon quickly vanished._x000D_
_x000D_
My extracurriculars were also affected. I had just joined a research lab before COVID. Unfortunately, I wouldn‚Äôt be able to enter the lab again for a year._x000D_
_x000D_
Although acclimating to the pandemic was difficult, my efforts to adapt presented me with a new perspective on impacting society. The Alumni Reunion that I had spent the past year planning with Penn Traditions had also been canceled. However, determined to not take away the momentous reunions for Penn Alumni, I felt inspired to design a virtual event. Teaming up with other class chairs, we developed a unique yet memorable online celebration._x000D_
_x000D_
This experience showed me that with effort, one can always impact the community. I hope to carry this insight as I strive to continue actively engaging in community service.

personal_statement:
For my first high school volunteer experience, I worked as a “greeter” at a small hospital in the West Side of Chicago. Every Saturday I stood at the doors of the entrance of the hospital– a dull and mundane routine. I repeated the same information to every incomer: “up the stairs and to the left” for the cafeteria and “down the hall and two right turns” for the emergency room. One morning, during a Chicago snowstorm, I noticed a woman, Magdalena, shivering in the blizzard as she neared the front steps. Visibly frostbitten, I approached her and asked if I could escort her to the emergency room. She whispered, “I’m okay, thank you” in a thick Polish accent I immediately recognized. Appearing distrustful of hospitals, I spoke to her in our shared mother language, explaining that I wasn’t a doctor, but I could help her receive medical care, and I assured her the staff would take good care of her. The wrinkles in her smile framed her frightened blue eyes as she whispered, “Dziekuje” (thank you); I wrapped my coat around her to bring her inside. I went home feeling grateful I could intimately connect with and comfort a patient with the Polish-speaking skills I rarely found useful in my predominantly English-speaking hometown.

With a Polish mother and a Haitian father, I’m the epitome of the culture blending of American immigrant families. As I began college, I was enthralled with the opportunity to apply my appreciation towards diverse communities and cultures. Chicago, like the rest of the U.S., encompasses a beautiful mixture of races, languages, and cultures, but it’s easy to lose sight of the importance of these differences when delivering personalized care to such communities. Thus, I began assisting Chicago’s minority Polish communities – specifically elderly immigrants with little American assimilation – by providing translation and medical interpreting services for these patients before eventually acquiring bilingual proficiency in Polish medical terminology. I strived to play a role in giving underserved communities access to healthcare by breaking the language barrier between patients and physicians. By doing so, I recognized its importance in delivering personalized care in medicine. Beyond the ability to translate Polish medical terms, I endeavored to discern the different cultures I interacted with by also improving my Spanish and becoming conversational in Russian.The multicultural environment I offered to patients made it easier for them to address personal circumstances that would have otherwise been difficult to interpret and openly talk about. I appreciated how establishing meaningful social connections with patients and their cultures could mean the difference between making potentially life-saving decisions.

Building on my clinical experience and strong communal ties, I applied my scientific knowledge from the classroom to my medical pursuits. As a neuroscience major, I wanted to develop a more comprehensive understanding of the health determinants of cerebrovascular disease, as such factors were exacerbated in the underserved communities I had been interacting with. Alongside my mentor, neurologist Dr. James Brorson, I combined my interests in neuroscience, statistics, and health disparities into developing a clinical predictive model to identify patients at risk for a secondary attack after an initial stroke; our goal was to develop a prevention monitoring strategy for clinicians and patients. I immersed myself in the study design aspects of research and published my first successful manuscript. Beyond data analysis, this research exposed me to precision health medicine. The ability to analyze individual patient data, and then apply statistics into medicine to produce a predictive model, was appealing to me given the broader aims of our research. I was fascinated we could swiftly calculate one’s risk for a clinical outcome based on individual baseline factors using our model. I saw myself at the forefront of precision medicine, wanting to further this by applying what I had learned into disease prevention, early diagnosis, and closing the gap in health disparities in ways I had imagined when translating to my fellow immigrant Polish community. With such goals, I will foster this passion in the Masters of Science in Precision Health at the University of Chicago this fall.

Through my experiences, I have begun to understand the complexity of what it takes to become a physician, and I will channel this into delivering personalized medicine with outsized impacts on patient healthcare to a wider population. Beyond healing, physicians must integrate the aspects of applying interpersonal skills, which includes making social change by community outreach to bridge health disparities, and by constantly evolving the field of medicine through focused prevention and care. I seek to empower underserved communities and expand my skills as an advocate, leader, scientist, and multilingual doctor. With a combination of these attributes, I hope to heal others who are unable to advocate for themselves, implement my future research into precision medicine, and be at the forefront of bridging health disparities. This way, the next time I cross a patient like Magdalena, I will be the one saving her life.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As a former US Rhythmic Gymnastics National Team member, I‚Äôve developed an appreciation for the diverse peoples that embody our world. At my first World Championships, I encountered an Angolan athlete, noticing a serious injury. Because her team lacked medical staff, I called over our team‚Äôs doctor to assist her‚Äì she welled up with tears at the aid we gave her, because her country could barely afford even attending the competition. The next day, she brought us a container of Muamba de Galinha, a traditional Angolan dish. We shared this meal, reflecting on the similarities and differences with my Haitian background and hers. Though we came to the competition under different circumstances, I realized that no matter what country, race, or socioeconomic status we belong to, we are all united under the necessity for medical care. I hope to foster such meaningful interactions in every patient I encounter as a student at Rush, catering to patients of all walks of life.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: With a Polish mother and Haitian father, I have always been fond of the cultural diversity of Chicago. Part of my excitement with starting college was the opportunity to apply my appreciation for such communities surrounding my school, especially in the South Side of Chicago. Like the rest of the US, Chicago has a beautiful mixture of races, languages, and cultures, but it‚Äôs easy for these differences to be unacknowledged in personalized care. I connected with minority communities by providing translation services for Polish elderly immigrants‚Äì I wanted to mediate interactions between patients and physicians with a language barrier. I felt I advocated for these patients‚Äô needs better, as a common language made addressing personal circumstances easier. My contribution was minor, but I valued being a part of change for the quality of care for those of my heritage. By learning more languages like Russian and Spanish, I hope to be able to offer this to even more patients in Chicago.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Adjusting to COVID-19 proved to be challenging from the start. I felt overwhelmed with my Organic Chemistry course while moving remotely. Working in healthcare became a burden on my parents during my final exams; after catching the virus, I didn‚Äôt complete the course to the best of my abilities. However, I made up for my lack of Organic Chemistry knowledge, earning high marks in Biochemistry. After struggling, I wanted to strengthen remote learning at UChicago, so I became a part of the Exploratory Teaching Group. Here, I worked for a project with professors from my premedical courses to alleviate obstacles in learning throughout the pandemic. Analyzing data from surveys I created, I led focus groups to guide direct feedback for professors. Mentoring enabled me to advocate for students‚Äô honest criticism in regard to their courses‚Äì I was able to turn something I struggled with into a positive experience for my peers.

personal_statement:
Behind my resume lies a unique upbringing that has provided me with the compassion and sensitivity needed to become a champion for advocacy. I have two moms and a twin sister who are all LGBTQ-identifying. Living in an extremely traditional community, I was very much aware that our family was different. In elementary and middle school, my sister and I were the only students with same-sex parents, creating a sense of openness to those around me. My sister's struggle with ADHD and anxiety throughout her life has also added to my sensitivity, both emotionally and situationally. My scientific mind goes to a place where I dive deeper into genetics as I have watched her experience many setbacks; my calm, reflective demeanor and laser focus could not be more opposite, yet we share similar DNA. Luckily, my parents were able to provide my sister with the resources needed to thrive, and that has made all the difference. When I watch other students struggle, I often volunteer my time to help, understanding how anxiety and loss of confidence can derail a person. My parents have also been great role models in the areas of service, hard work, and humor. It was through the lens of a healthcare administrator and an educator that I gained an appreciation for giving back and practicing kindness every day.

Before I knew what resume building was, I had been consistently following a path of service, mentoring, and healthcare. One experience that was instrumental in my decision to pursue a career as a physician was my work as an EMT at 16 years old. Being exposed in real-time to the fragility of life added to my compassion and curiosity. After extensive training and practice, my skills were not enough to save one of my patients. Why did the CPR not work?  Why did the science behind my treatment fail? I went down the rabbit hole; researching what went wrong, asking what I could have done differently. Thankfully, I had a mentor who helped me work through this and assured me that I could not have done anything differently. Overcoming this reality would take time, but I refused to quit, continuing to hone my skills and gain experience.

Another example that reflects both my sensitivity and ability to problem solve under pressure involves a marble and an elementary school student. Unable to contact the parents, the school nurse asked that he be taken by the ambulance to the ER for an X-ray. Comforting the sobbing kindergarten student came very naturally as I told him about the time when I had snacked on Legos and had to have pictures taken of my stomach as well. Ironically, I treated this situation with the same level of focus and passion that I did when administering CPR to my dying patient a few weeks before. Being able to access my toolbox of skills across different situations has built my confidence as a clinician. I would continue to refine these skills in my clinical work as a scribe and MA at CityMD Urgent Care, during the height of COVID.

The pandemic looming, I closely followed the research in creating the vaccine but had minimal lab experience at the time. The opportunities presented to me at Tufts would change that, allowing me to take my curiosity, initiative, and leadership to another level. Forming JEZA Genomics with two classmates, we designed a treatment to combat cancers associated with BRCA1 mutations. This was my first stepping stone in synthesizing and practicing translational science in medicine. Similarly, my summer work at Hibercell exposed me to lab research used in clinical trials and the process of bringing cancer treatment to market. Having been an advocate for patients as a first responder and then working behind the scenes in the lab, I was able to participate in and appreciate the full circle of care.

Reflecting on all of the experiences and people who have led me here today, I am reminded of where I started. The roots, support, and opportunities created in my home gave me the foundation and confidence to question and explore the world around me. By taking advantage of these opportunities, I was able to follow a path that serves both myself and others very well. When I think about what kind of physician I will be or why I should be given the chance to attend medical school, I leave you with the following: I have progressed from a curious student to a clinician and researcher. My dedication to this journey can be seen in every class that I have taken, every patient that I have treated, and every situation where I have pushed myself to be the best person that I can be. My compassion, work ethic, flexibility, and pure joy that I find in my work are what sets me apart. My only regret during this process has been my performance on the MCAT, which I unknowingly took while battling COVID. This score did not reflect my practice test performance scores and I kindly request that you take this into consideration when assessing my application. I guarantee that taking a chance on me will not be a gamble and that the physician that I will become will reflect positively on the school that I represent.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Growing up in an all-female household with same-sex parents has instilled in me an openness to the world from a young age. I grew up learning never to make assumptions or pass judgments on others. This is a gift that I have carried throughout my life and have applied in many different environments. As a Tufts FOCUS Leader, I guided Tufts first-years in urban community work throughout Boston. I was charged with creating a safe environment for my team, but also for those we served. In providing tutoring, environmental cleanup, and mentoring efforts, not only did my diverse perspective contribute to the success of our work but also allowed me to connect with my peers from diverse backgrounds. This sensitivity to the needs of others that I have acquired through both my home life, years of global service work, and position as an EMT has been instrumental in my personal growth. As a future physician, relying on this open-mindedness will help me serve my patients more compassionately.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Working on the front lines during COVID as a first responder and scribe at CityMD proved to be my most challenging work in health care. It is here where I feel that I made the most impact on the surrounding community, as we served as a safe place for everyone. I have never been part of an organization that worked so tirelessly and selflessly as my colleagues at CityMD. The teamwork and unity that we modeled for the panic-stricken patients of underserved communities were calming and reassuring to many families. Kindness, kindness, and more kindness were our daily motto as we strove to get through 14-hour shifts while serving over 200 patients per day. This was one of my proudest moments in giving back to my community and one that I hope to continue as a student at Rush, as becoming a primary care physician in an urban setting is my goal.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I am very proud of the application that I have put together for Rush. I take much pride in the work that has gone into my academic, professional, volunteer, and research successes. From my training as a clinician to my many roles as a mentor on campus, I bring unparalleled energy, commitment, and care to my work. The only discrepancy on my application would be my MCAT score. Unknowingly taking the exam while having COVID, my performance reflected my health at the time. I can only say that my practice test scores - 510 and 511 - which I am happy to submit, are more in line with my capabilities and your standards. My confidence in my future as a medical school student remains unwavering, yet to an admissions committee, I understand the concerns. I would greatly appreciate you taking the above information into serious consideration when deciding on my candidacy. I guarantee that I will continue to be an exceptional student and contributing member of the Rush community.

personal_statement:
I tore down the track, baton in hand, with the yellow finish line growing ever closer. The crowd’s cheers were muffled by my rhythmic breathing and the sound of my metal spikes piercing the rubber surface below me. As I crossed the finish line, I burst into tears— not of happiness, but of sorrow. That was the last race I would run before enduring a year of pain and physical therapy. My orthopedic surgeon had assured me that running the rest of the season would not further damage my bilateral labral tears. Yet the pain of pushing through my injury was insignificant compared to the heartache of stepping away from my sport and from my team. Nevertheless, I underwent successive labral repair surgeries that summer, abruptly switching from an active life on the track to what seemed like an eternity on the couch. 

The next year, I worked tirelessly to regain my strength and the ability to run. Through hours of physical therapy and countless doctor appointments, I began to rethink my relationship with track and field. A year earlier, running had been my passion, something I felt I could never live without. However, after interacting with the medical system as a patient, I gained a deeper appreciation for the privilege that comes with being able-bodied. With this humbled perspective, I have a new appreciation not only for athletics, but also the medical professionals who guard our physical abilities.

My personal introduction to medicine fueled my fascination with the human body and its capacity to heal. When my orthopedist walked through the clinic door during my last appointment, he was already grinning ear to ear, awaiting the in-depth questions I brought to each visit. This same boundless curiosity enveloped me at track practice where I stood on the sideline querying my coach, who was also my physics teacher, about the most effective quadriceps-calf angles to maximize power. Once I returned to running, it was no longer simply a mode of competition, but rather a means of exercising my curiosity. 

When I started college at UVA, I rushed to the library to scour the literature on orthopedics. I enrolled in Kinesiology and became a participant in several research studies in the physical therapy department. My second year at UVA, I reached out to Dr. Abhijit Dighe, the Research Coordinator in the Cui Lab of Orthopedics. Dr. Dighe became my mentor, encouraging me to harness my curiosity through cell culture, animal handling, and surgical procedures. Other researchers trusted me with difficult dissections and provided me with opportunities to grow as an undergraduate researcher. As a member of the Cui Lab, I was grateful to be able to contribute to a growing body of research while channeling my curiosity.

I learned so much from my patient and research experiences in orthopedics, but ultimately felt something was missing. Eager to gain a different perspective in medicine, I applied to the Scribe program in the UVA Emergency Department. I immediately fell in love with the intersection of my orthopedic interests and other evidence-based practices. I also wanted to gain exposure to the multitude of disciplines within the medical field. It was through these daily encounters with patients with varied maladies that I became steadfast in my determination to practice clinical medicine. After just a few shifts, I petitioned the administration to allow me to work above the 20-hour per week limit, eager to return to the ED soon after leaving each shift. 

I can still recall the first trauma I encountered in the ED. My ears buzzed with voices surrounding the workroom as medical personnel swarmed the hallway, echoing “MVC with rollover, extremity amputation.” Glued to the corner of the bay, writing frivolously with a notepad in hand, my mouth hung open behind my mask. The orthopedic team strode into the bay with a commanding presence, toting the severed extremity in an Igloo cooler. They orchestrated the entire encounter with a sense of composed urgency, reassuring the patient that she was in good hands. At that moment, I realized that surgeons have the rare ability to reassure people during their worst circumstances by providing them with concrete solutions. I yearned to one day be in that position, able to assuage someone’s fears with the confidence that I have the skills to truly care for them.

As a scribe, I feel honored to contribute to the patient care team and to have taken part in each patient’s medical narrative. Now when I return home from a long shift in the ED, I set down my scrubs and pick up my running shoes. But while I may be able to lace up and enjoy the rest of a sunny day after coming home from the Emergency Department, most of the patients I see cannot. These afternoon runs have become a sacred space for reflection in my life. Not only do I express gratitude for my own recovery from injury, but I also think of those I helped care for in the ED. Looking back, my injury opened the door to my interest in medicine and allowed me to balance pain and resilience. With each of these runs, I condition both my body and my mind, and feel more prepared for a future as a compassionate physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Throughout my life I have worked with individuals of different beliefs, cultures, and languages. Growing up outside of Chicago, many of my peers and friends came from different backgrounds. I have spent much of my lifetime studying Spanish and Latinx culture, and continue to develop my language and cultural awareness skills in the Emergency Department. While I am always learning from new interactions, I feel that much of my ability to understand diverse perspectives comes from my upbringing. Growing up with an identical twin sister who could not have been more dissimilar from me, we struggled to reconcile our differences. However, constantly lumped together despite opposing personalities, I gained an understanding for perspectives that are not my own. My experience being a twin taught me compassion and understanding for diverse perspectives. I will continue to develop these interpersonal skills through the challenges I face in the future, and look forward to using them at Rush.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: At the outset of the pandemic, COVID-19 cases were disproportionately affecting low-income and minority individuals, people whose social determinants of health already put them at risk for many other diseases. Inspired by another organization spear-headed by Columbia University students, I co-founded the COVID-19 Student Service Corps at UVA, a service organization aimed at addressing the pandemic‚Äôs disproportionate effects. Within our first few months, we fundraised over $25,000 for local homeless shelters, provided over 300 face masks to UVA Health and low-income nursing homes, and supplied thank-you gifts to healthcare professionals. Born from a feeling of helplessness, CSSC gave me a voice in the community and allowed me to support local programs when they were struggling. While I wished I could have aided in patient care as a physician during the pandemic, I feel grateful that I was able to contribute through reducing disparities within my own community.
7_-_COVID_Impact: During much of Spring/Fall 2020, undergraduate students were not allowed in class, in research labs, and in volunteering facilities. I conducted research in the Cui Lab of Orthopedics and contributed to a research project that we were trying to publish, but ultimately could not continue when the laboratory shut down in March 2020. I learned valuable research skills including cell culture, surgical procedures, animal handling, and data analysis which I will use in my future endeavors. In an effort to continue research during this time, I applied to work as a Clinical Research Assistant with the NIH Prevent COVID-U study. I worked in the UVA division of the study recruiting participants, recording data, and handling phlebotomy specimens. I feel privileged to have learned clinical research skills while contributing to the vaccination effort and will continue to improve the fields of medicine and public health in my future career.

personal_statement:
Growing up, I had a tendency to ask questions. In fact, I often found myself bombarding my family with questions whenever I encountered something unfamiliar or confusing. This trend, along with the fluency with which I spoke English at an early age, earned me the nickname Professor “Kasa Brofo”, courtesy of my grandfather. This phrase literally means “professor speaks English” in Twi, a Ghanaian language. Based on this, I have always known that I would like to pursue a career in a field that encourages an inquisitive nature. However, I did not develop an interest in becoming a physician until a trip back to my home country, Ghana, in the summer of 2015.
After a fun-filled start to my vacation, I spent the remainder of this trip bedridden. What had started as a sharp pain in my stomach was overshadowed by constant chills and feelings of nausea. No one in my family knew what to do except my grandma, a retired nurse. Upon seeing the state I was in, she sprung into action. She inquired about the onset of my illness and my symptoms. She then hypothesized what my illness was, received confirmation from a clinic doctor, and cared for me until I recovered. When I felt helpless, she listened to my frustrations and reassured me that everything would be okay.
Soon after I recovered, we returned to the United States. I would often reflect on the fearful thoughts I had while I was sick. At the same time, I grew increasingly appreciative of my grandma’s actions. I became curious about the impact of diseases and conditions on those they affect and how healthcare professionals work to address the issues their patients face. As a result, in true Professor Kasa Brofo fashion, I sought out opportunities that would grant me insight into these dynamics.
The following summer I began volunteering at a local hospital. During one shift, I heard a grunt coming from a patient awaiting surgery. They were unable to speak due to a thoat-related condition and were pointing to a nearby whiteboard. Once I handed them the whiteboard, they wrote that they needed to use the bathroom. Though I was unable to aid the patient myself due to my limits as a volunteer, I informed nearby nurses about the patient's request and they provided assistance. Not long after, this patient was transported to the operating room. As they exited, I heard echoes of physicians discussing their approach to operating on the patient’s larynx, and it delighted me to know that this patient would receive help. Freedoms often taken for granted, such as one's ability to speak, can be stripped away by diseases or conditions. Consequently, I became interested in becoming a physician as physicians, more so than other healthcare professionals, possess unique knowledge and skills to improve the quality of life of the afflicted.
After having this encounter, I began to wonder how physicians approach diseases and conditions that are not well understood or have no clear treatment. In college, I engaged in research on addictions and neurodegenerative diseases, and these projects were often led by physicians who used their clinical knowledge to infer the physiological implications of their findings. From this, I developed an appreciation for the research side of medicine and its role in improving our knowledge of pathologies and developing and improving treatments.
Furthermore, the COVID-19 pandemic made the importance of public health initiatives more evident, and I pursued a public health minor to become more informed on these matters. Through my minor, I was exposed to systematic measures to promote the health of entire communities. A common motif in my public health courses was how these measures often fail to address the uncontrollable circumstances one faces. Social determinants of health, such as socioeconomic status or nationality at birth, are correlated with differences in susceptibility to certain conditions and illnesses. However, change is possible. From discussions with my family, I learned of how my grandfather, a parasitologist, played a role in eliminating Guinea worm, a neglected tropical disease that plagued Ghana for decades. As a physician, I hope to spearhead public health efforts and conduct clinical research aimed at improving the health of others locally and globally. Such efforts would include organizing educational campaigns, performing pro bono work in underserved communities, and studying diseases to develop and improve diagnostic and treatment methods.
These revelations into the complexities of the role of a physician and the significance of their work ultimately inspired me to become one. Those with impaired health can be facing one of the lowest points in their lives, and I have a desire to play a role in preventing people from suffering. Thus, for me, the meaning of Professor Kasa Brofo has morphed to mean someone with an inquisitive nature who employs their knowledge to care for others. As a physician, I aspire to investigate health issues and what is lacking in current approaches to address them. I aim to address those gaps while positively influencing the health of those in my community and all over the globe. Therefore, as I take this next step, I strive to become a physician who fully embodies what it means to be Professor Kasa Brofo.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: In 2007, my family immigrated to the United States from our home country Ghana. I initially viewed this relocation as nothing more than a change in scenery, but I was gladly mistaken. Suddenly becoming the only Ghanaian in my classroom was quite a culture shock. However, my time in the United States has taught me valuable lessons. For instance, many of my peers have different ethnic and cultural backgrounds than my own. As my peers and I bonded through our shared interests, challenges, and experiences, I better understood that despite our more apparent differences, we have similarities worth appreciating. Furthermore, my peers and I have exposed each other to different cuisines, customs, and festivities. These exposures deepened my respect for other cultures, and I endeavor to share aspects of my culture with others when possible. As a student at Rush Medical College, I will aspire to continue this cultural exchange and promote an inclusive atmosphere for my peers and me to thrive.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
Due to COVID-19, many families experienced difficulties, and these challenges perpetuated health disparities due to the societal and structural determinants of health._x000D_
In hopes of playing a role in reducing the pandemic's impact on my community, I volunteered at Table to Table, a local food distribution program. As I conversed with the families we assisted, many thanked my peers and me for our efforts, and some even mentioned they planned to distribute the food to family and friends who could not attend the food drive. Through these conversations, I better understood that the significance of our work went beyond the families we saw._x000D_
However, as the COVID-19-related restrictions reduced, the number of families we assisted gradually decreased from thousands to hundreds. Rather than lamenting, I recognized this indicated we were successful in helping our community during a difficult time. Consequently, I became even more grateful for having the opportunity to impact my community.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
When the quarantine period began, I returned home from campus and attended my classes remotely for three semesters. This transition was difficult due to the sudden loss of routine and having to deal with the challenges of remote learning and quarantine-induced social isolation. However, with time, I adapted to the situation._x000D_
I also had to withdraw from my research position at the Jamaica Plains VA Medical Center. Due to my role, I could not work remotely, and since I live in New Jersey, I could not routinely travel to Boston to fulfill my duties. Despite this, I remained determined to gain more research experience, and eventually, I obtained my current research assistant position. Furthermore, social distancing policies affected my ability to shadow physicians and volunteer in hospitals. In response, I found other ways to pursue my interest in medicine and impact my community. I participated in remote shadowing programs and volunteered with various organizations to help my community.

personal_statement:
Growing up, I earned the title of “Gabby Gavy” from most of my teachers. Parent-teacher conferences always yielded the same dreaded feedback: too talkative and too inquisitive. My chatty nature and spirited personality were reprimanded throughout my education. Such constant negative reinforcement shattered my self-confidence. It would take years to learn my talkative personality was not a character flaw but rather one of my greatest assets. Learning to appreciate my authentic self has been a journey filled with hard work, conscious reflection, and unexpected life lessons, but within it, my passion for patient care was catalyzed.  

My wavering confidence was tested with the arrival of my brother. When he was born, the same tropes that plagued me through parent-teacher conferences reared their ugly heads. With my mom in school and my dad battling his health, I was entrusted with raising my brother and became his closest companion. His personality was the complete opposite of mine: non-verbal, hypersensitive, and withdrawn. He failed to meet traditional child milestones and at age three, he had yet to utter a single word. After visiting several specialists, he was diagnosed with apraxia and autism. 

For my brother, my outgoing and talkative personality was of little use. It wasn’t an immediate realization but rather the culmination of many interactions. I was forced to develop an alternative to the communication style I depended on. At the time, I didn't realize it, but years of caring for my brother forced me to develop a new asset: adaptability. I soon recognized that, while my communication style wasn't negative, it wasn't always the answer. I soon adopted other means of communicating, working diligently to be the big sister my brother deserved. We learned basic sign language, communicated via visual aids, and developed our own language of symbols and gestures. 

Amid these pursuits to capture my identity, I grew accustomed to the reverberation of my father’s cries of immense pain. These bouts of pain were due to a series of chronic physical ailments stemming from an accident in his youth. His anguish peaked in 2016, as he awaited jaw replacement surgery. Just months after getting my driver's license, he entrusted my inexperience to rush him to the emergency room. Sitting by his side, I saw a broken spirit struggle to articulate his medical history. Feeling helpless, I found myself using the voice that I had grown ashamed of to advocate on his behalf. Rattled with nerves as two physicians stood over me, I was driven by a deep passion to share his story. As the doctors formulated a plan, I felt a wave of relief because my efforts were helping to ease my dad’s pain. What was once my biggest flaw had become my saving grace. 

While I listened intently to the physicians develop a detailed approach, something else happened: I came to the realization that these physicians talked just like me. They had a familiar, vibrant enthusiasm. I witnessed empathy delicately piece my father’s fractured optimism together. Quickly, I realized that even with an effective treatment regimen, comfort and empathy made the ultimate difference for my dad. In a strange way, my voice had helped me on the biggest stage.  

I continued to embrace internal reflection through my patient-care ventures. On my first day as a patient attendant, I approached a room of security guards. I was immediately cautioned that my patient had dementia and was incredibly violent. After hours of watching security struggle to calm him down, I began asking him about his life. He mentioned being a history professor and told me about his prior research endeavors. He shared amazing stories, ranging from investigations during the Vietnam war to working on journals as head historian. While unrelated to his condition, it was an integral part of his life. I immediately understood the power of lending one’s ear. Once again, Gabby Gavy fortified a relationship and eased stress through discourse, proving the power of my formerly burdensome voice. 

My dad’s cries, my brother’s struggles, and the nuances of my patients yielded a striking commonality: these tales slowly enveloped my life. Medicine provides an opportunity to amplify the patient story. In becoming a physician, I will leverage the opportunity to hear one’s story fostering an environment of holistic care that emphasizes communication as a tool that can save lives. My childhood experiences have instilled a special understanding that every patient requires a tailored form of communication. As a practitioner, I will strive to weave my empathy and medical knowledge to revolutionize the course of one’s medical journey.

Gabby Gavy, once my biggest insecurity, presented itself as a lifeline for those struggling most. Whether at home or in the hospital, I’ve seen the power of absorbing the patient story, as it grants the ability to connect with people beyond a superficial level. I see no alternative to medicine, my experiences have positioned me to use a former vulnerability to positively impact individuals. I believe that Gabby Gavy, with the complementary skills gained in medical school, will create special connections that will better patients’ lives.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: My Michigan undergraduate experience brought me one unexpected gift: Chicago. With my partner there, I became a regular Chicago visitor and grew passionate about decreasing disparities in healthcare access throughout Chicago‚Äôs 77 neighborhoods. In 2019, I exited the familiarity of the midwest and flew to Peru on a service project to promote public health by building stoves in rural communities. My trip took a daunting turn as differing culinary practices resulted in a week‚Äôs stay in a hospital. Immersion in a new culture helped me challenge my thinking of common ethnocentrism and biases. Cultural competence and respect became my primary goal whether a rural villager, a doctor or a nurse. I saw substantial growth in my ability to empathize with and support those of different origins. Each hand-built stove brought a smile, a feeling that can‚Äôt be replicated within one‚Äôs own people. The value of each interaction was palpable, demonstrating the worth of diversity in stark practice.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
My younger self was my brother‚Äôs keeper. With my mom working full time and my dad struggling with chronic disabilities, his growth was woven with mine. My brother faced significant developmental delays, forcing me to learn quickly how to empathize with someone fundamentally different than me. His success was directly linked to the care and support he received during his most formative years. Whether developing unique means of communication or advocating on his behalf, I became his biggest supporter. _x000D_
	_x000D_
The impact I had on my brother was a local, isolated example. My influence grew when I shifted my advocacy to a community 6000 miles away. As COVID spread, I was tasked with contriving innovative solutions to ensure disabled Israelis had access to key resources like groceries, therapy, and entertainment amidst lockdowns. Both at home and abroad I developed a passion for disability-aware care and advocacy, ensuring that as a physician, I will foster positive change beyond my community._x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact:
Before COVID struck, employment was a key feature of my daily life. COVID brought an unexpected halt to my Aphasia tDCS research. With strict regulations in place, I lost a source of income and was forced to stop my work-study research program. Similarly, I had committed to visiting Israel in the summer of 2020 for a clinical research internship but instead, it was modified to a less interactive virtual program._x000D_
_x000D_
I also had to depart from my student housing and move home with my family which entailed a stressful living environment. I was unable to work to support myself because there were immunocompromised individuals in my household. Due to the new remote format, it was difficult to personally acquaint myself with professors. Many of my professors used pre-recorded lectures and asynchronous office hours in which students preemptively sent questions. Whether financial, familial, or educational, the obstacles I faced during the pandemic had a profound impact on my college experience.

personal_statement:
During my first internship at a pain clinic, I’m sitting in the office eagerly awaiting the next appointment while taking a small break from wheeling patients into the Arizona summer heat. The faint sound of the hardwood floors creaking grows louder as the next patient passes the office for the nearby procedure room. I get up to help prep them and meet, “Anne,” a small woman confined to her wheelchair. As I help her onto the operating table, the discomfort she’s experiencing is clear. Tears flow down her face as she screams in agony at every inch moved. After the treatment, I help clean her and get her back into the wheelchair. I gather her personal belongings and notice the tears still running down her face, this time tears of relief. “I can move!” she screams to me. “I feel so much better!” While I wheel her towards the exit, she cries while telling the doctor how valuable his treatment was. This interaction epitomizes the reason I wish to pursue medicine: I am passionate about inspiring others through meaningful relationships and quality care. 
	My passion for healthcare developed when my brother was still young. The six and eight year age gap between my siblings and me meant I often took on the caretaker role as our parents worked. Slowly, I grew excited at the opportunity to not only take care of them, but to also be a potential role model and to tackle all the responsibilities that came with being a big brother. When my youngest brother, Gabe, was eight, he developed a bone tumor. Thankfully, it was benign, but the word “tumor” was still a significant cause of uncertainty and worry. The memory of helping carry my brother, still groggy from anesthesia, from the car to the couch will always be ingrained in my mind. His recovery was two weeks, and, in that time, I did my best to make him comfortable. While helping clean his 4-5 inch incision made me nervous the first time, the nerves soon gave way to fulfillment that I was playing a small part in his path to recovery. 
	From his diagnosis to checkups, I observed the reassuring and comforting effect that amazing doctors had not only on my brother, but also my family and me. The healthcare team was a light in a time of distress as they maintained the highest degree of compassion. Thereafter, I knew that I wanted to pursue a career in medicine. I experienced true joy in helping my brother recover and seeing him progress. The feeling was distinct from nervousness or excitement, it was a sense of euphoria that I had never felt before–it came from aiding in improving one’s well-being. I also fell in love with the idea of potentially being a bright light and positively impacting others the way my brother’s physicians had uplifted my family and I. 
	As I grew up, I found myself drawn to sports because of the cohesive feeling that comes with being part of a strong team. Few things are more rewarding than being part of a group of people contributing to achieving a common goal. Being a part of a team can connect people and form bonds like nothing else can, and I strongly desire a career that emphasizes teamwork while aligning with my personal values. When thinking of a strong team, I always think about my observation of a surgeon performing his first procedure at a new clinic. “Needle driver?” he asks before taking an X-ray. “We don’t have one, doc,” replies the team as they help him find an alternative. Later in the procedure, the TV projecting the X-ray develops problems and they switch to counting vertebrae by hand while viewing the small screen on the C-arm. The doctor counts aloud and the team helps corroborate the correct procedure site. Despite the wavering environment, I witnessed the physician collaborate with his team to successfully execute the surgery.
	My lifelong passion for science spurred me to seek out research opportunities in college, and those experiences have also pushed me in the direction of medicine. Though I explored interesting research topics and gained incredible learning experiences, I was quickly unsatisfied with the idea of performing research full time. My work in the lab lacked the patient-facing interaction that I had found so fulfilling during my clinical experiences. The type of relationships I have formed through research are completely different from the patient-physician ones I have seen. The ability to build bonds and form true, personal relationships with people from a variety of backgrounds while helping improve people’s quality of life is something unique that I have found only in patient care. 
	Time and time again I’ve been told that healthcare is a calling. Like most calls, we can decide to answer or ignore it. Being on the receiving end of care with my brother Gabe, observing the spine surgery, and experiencing research all furthered my passion to build meaningful relationships while inspiring patients and helping them regain a sense of regularity. Seeing the difference doctors can make in the lives of people like Anne solidified my decision to answer the call of healthcare in my own life. Hopefully one day I myself will influence someone else to answer their own call to medicine as I contribute to improving my patients’ quality of life.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Getting assigned random roommates my freshman year of college was an exciting opportunity for me to meet new people from various backgrounds. I was paired with someone who moved from China to attend college. Though we lived different lifestyles, It was important to me that I learn about his values out of respect and to build a healthy relationship. _x000D_
	_x000D_
I asked questions about his views on different topics and we had discussions about cultural differences. I even attended the ASU Mid-Autumn festival with him, a traditional Chinese celebration, in order to really learn more about his culture. I played traditional games, partook in celebratory traditions, and enjoyed authentic food. Taking initiative when learning about his culture was important to me in order to help him feel more comfortable in a new environment. From this experience, I took away the value in being open-minded and how it promotes respect and brings to light similarities between people of different backgrounds._x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
In the height of the pandemic, I was only able to volunteer at the hospital‚Äôs front desk. With many regulations, we were put into situations that required strong social skills to best help visitors._x000D_
_x000D_
Denying visitation to the ICU was a testing situation. I think of when a young lady came in begging to see her dying father. With the maximum number of guests reached, we had to initially stop her from seeing him. Unable to verbally say much, I actively listened as I urgently tried to find a way to let her in. _x000D_
_x000D_
I learned the importance of nonverbal communication and consideration towards individual circumstances. Trying to understand the feelings of another was a necessary part of my role. It was common for guests to express frustration, but it was important to understand that it was not rooted in hostility, rather worry for a patient. It was fulfilling to play a part in connecting visitors with their loved ones and to try and lighten a guest‚Äôs day during an undesirable situation._x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact:
COVID-19 forced me to move back home and my grades suffered due to difficulty adjusting to an online format. Communication with peers and teachers decreased due to different time zones and slower response times, making it harder to ask questions. Physically doing things in person is important to my learning style and I missed that opportunity._x000D_
	_x000D_
Preparing for the MCAT is difficult enough. I did my best to stay healthy, but it is impossible to eliminate risks with roommates. One of them tested positive the week before my first exam and I needed to quickly leave before I was exposed. Staying at a friend's place added lots of additional stress._x000D_
	_x000D_
The pandemic also inspired me to tenaciously pursue various experiences to make up for what was lost. I grew even more motivated to connect with people I look up to. Looking back, I am thankful for the lessons I learned and the time I got to spend with my family. I learned how to be unafraid in the face of adversity and go after what I want.

Hrdshp_Comments: I was raised in Vallejo, California, a predominately Black and Brown community. The public schools I attended were underfunded and when the city declared bankruptcy, this further exacerbated the low quality of education provided to students in the district. In high school, I started to notice the impact of the lack of resources and insufficient staff and teachers. My high school’s graduation rate was well below the state average. While the school offered AP classes, most were poor quality and did not prepare students for the AP exam or college-level courses. When I took AP Chemistry, not a single student in my class passed the AP test. Moreover, Vallejo is a city where crime is rampant and I lost many peers to gun violence and the incarceration system. Interacting with my peers in class one day and the next day they were gone was traumatic. When my older brother passed away in a car crash during my junior year of high school, I struggled to find a new normal. So many young lives have been taken from my community which has taught me to be grateful for my life and opportunities. As a future physician, I hope to serve communities like mine while also being a source of inspiration to young people by showing them all that they can accomplish in this world.
personal_statement:
I grew up in Vallejo, CA – a predominately Black and Brown city rich with ethnic diversity. Family and community are the foundation of my life and upbringing. I view my parents as role models, successful in their careers and life. From a young age, my brothers and I were involved in church and other organizations that uplift the Black community. These activities shaped my values such as giving back to those in need and striving for excellence. Community involvement brought me out of my shell from a shy girl to a confident and outgoing woman who loves to engage with others. My work in the community contributed to my growth, and provided me encouragement and support to pursue my dreams of becoming a physician.
My seventh-grade frog dissection planted the seed for a career in medicine. During class, I noticed the intricacies of the frog’s body, and I thought about the intricacies of the human body and how doctors work to heal people. From then on, I was intrigued by the idea of becoming a doctor. However, despite the culturally rich environment of Vallejo, it is one of three cities in California to declare bankruptcy; its public schools were severely underfunded, which negatively impacted my academic foundation. My high school lacked adequate resources, teachers, and access to AP classes. Although I excelled academically, this was not indicative of the preparation I needed to transition to college. To help me navigate the college admissions process, I relied on organizations such as the Willie B. Adkins Scholars Program (WBA), a free college preparatory program for Black students that provided support and resources to matriculate to college. WBA also connected me to my first clinical experience at Kaiser Permanente. In my senior year of high school, I interned at Kaiser and observed an emergency C-section. I was fascinated by the procedure and admired the quick and calm thinking of the providers. I left the operating room feeling that I could be one of those physicians in the future, further cultivating my desire to explore a career in medicine.
After high school, I matriculated at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA). I initially struggled to perform well in my science coursework and realized my high school education had not adequately prepared me for the rigor of college. To improve academically, I utilized campus resources, attended tutoring sessions, and developed better study strategies. Although these strategies helped my overall performance, I was not balanced, and I sacrificed personal care, which eventually led to burnout. In my determination to continue progressing, I spent my last year learning to balance academic and personal responsibilities, and my grades improved.  
After graduating from UCLA, I continued to explore my interest in medicine. I accepted an AmeriCorps fellowship at a Federally Qualified Health Center in Richmond, CA that serves a predominantly Black and Latinx population, similar to my community. I provided colon cancer health education, recruited patients for pregnancy and mental health support groups, and assisted with the Covid-19 vaccine efforts. As part of our outreach during the pandemic, I contacted patients with information about program resources, including our new group therapy sessions. One day, a woman answered the phone with an upbeat voice. She was excited to learn about and join our group therapy. She explained that as a teacher, she struggled to connect with her students through Zoom, in addition to having personal difficulties. I listened as she confided in me, and at that moment, I was glad to be a confidant to someone who needed to be heard. I learned the value of connections with patients and providing them with the space to express themselves. My engagement with patients strengthened my desire to become a physician who creates safe spaces and develops meaningful relationships with patients so they feel heard and seen. 
After finishing my AmeriCorps fellowship, I continued building my academic portfolio by completing the UCSF Post Baccalaureate Program. While in the program, I developed better study habits and established a stronger foundation in the sciences. I also gained confidence in my academic abilities and excelled in my upper division science courses while participating in research and graduate-level health disparities seminars. I attended and led a biweekly journal club on current health care topics impacting underserved populations. Our discussions and my engagement with like-minded peers further drives my passion for becoming a physician. I want to be a part of the effort to increase equitable access to health care for all. 
I believe everyone deserves a caring and compassionate physician who listens, especially patients from underserved and disenfranchised communities. I want to guide patients to live a healthy life no matter their socioeconomic status. My community instilled in me the value of giving back, and I want to serve my community and other vulnerable populations by providing excellent medical care. As a Black woman and future physician-advocate from an underserved community, I hope to inspire the youth who share my identities to never give up on achieving their dreams, despite the barriers they may face.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I completed my AmeriCorps Fellowship in Richmond, California, at a clinic where 60% of the patient population spoke Spanish. I was worried that I would not be able to communicate effectively with many of the patients. My Spanish was limited and although we had access to interpreters, I felt obligated to speak in their language as much as possible to make them feel comfortable. Every day during my drive to work, I used a program to learn and practice conversational Spanish, and my comprehension improved. However, as I learned more about language barriers between patients and providers and the negative impact on patient care and outcomes, I set the goal to continue learning. I saw how knowing even a little bit of my patients‚Äô language made a difference. As a physician, I am committed to providing culturally-sensitive care. I want my patients to feel comfortable regardless of their ethnicity or language.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As an AmeriCorps Fellow, I helped combat food insecurity in the city of Richmond, CA, an urban underserved community in a food desert. I partnered with a local food bank to distribute free vegetables and groceries to about 60 members of the community every week. One day I spoke to a woman who had seen our flier and requested a food box delivered to her home as she could not make it to the clinic for our outreach. I assured her I could arrange for her to receive a weekly food delivery. Every time I brought the food box to her home, she thanked me for my service, and I was grateful to have the privilege of connecting with this woman while addressing her food insecurity. As a physician, I want to build meaningful relationships with my patients and engage with them to address social determinants of health in their community.
7_-_COVID_Impact: In my senior year, COVID-19 emerged, ending my college experience prematurely. I moved back home and finished my last quarter virtually. I adapted my learning style to accommodate Zoom lectures. After graduating from college, I was an AmeriCorp fellow at a federally qualified health center, working with patients from underserved communities. To continue pursuing my desire to become a physician, I participated in the UCSF Post Baccalaureate Program. The program was mostly virtual because of the pandemic. I used the same study methods I learned in my last quarter of college to excel in my science coursework. I again built connections with my professors by actively participating in Zoom lectures to increase the quality of my academic experience. I also engaged in a continuous quality improvement project to improve health outcomes for NICU patients, which had to be conducted remotely. Ultimately, the pandemic challenged me to grow as a student and a future health care worker.

Hrdshp_Comments: I am a first generation American. Growing up, I was ridiculed for my skin color or Ghanaian culture. Yet, I am still proud of my heritage and grateful to live in the U.S. When my parents separated in 2010, my mother became the only financial support. My mother worked two jobs to support my sister, me, and my grandparents in Ghana. I was motivated to perform well in school to do better for my family. Despite going to an under resourced school, I sought out every opportunity to take challenging courses and participate in extracurriculars. When my older sister went to college, my mom and sister took out large loans. I knew my college tuition would fall all on me. I tutored myself for SAT. When I was admitted into Duke with a full scholarship, I was proud. However, I was not prepared for the rigor of the STEM classes. After struggling academically, I became adept at seeking resources. I took rigorous courses and improved my GPA. Outside of academics, I’ve done fascinating research and mentored younger students. Since graduating and moving back home, I’ve struggled with MCAT and applications costs. Although my father doesn’t support me financially, because he is living, I didn’t qualify for the fee assistance program. My experiences have been difficult, but they have shaped me to become solution oriented.
personal_statement:
No breeze blew in the church. A sweltering heat baked all of us researchers and participants inside. That day, I oversaw the station to measure the participants’ height and weight. I kindly asked the next participant to come forward. A look of intrigue passed her face. I suspected like the others she was interested in how I looked like her yet spoke with such a weird accent. Afterwards, I escorted her to the next station for blood and urine collection.  I was a researcher for my university and Millennium Promise to address health effects of small-scale gold mining and mercury exposure in rural Amansie West, Ghana. I chose to be a part of this research because I wanted an opportunity to serve my Ghanaian community, specifically a medically underserved population. Although I am Ghanaian, the participants were of different economic class, educational background, and spoke Twi fluently. Learning how to communicate effectively and navigate cultural differences would prepare me for future patient interaction. 

Before starting the research, we talked to the residents about gold mining and mercury exposure. They observed that since the town had started mining more, people were getting sicker and dying younger. We, the researchers, were supposed to fill that gap. Even with our different areas of expertise, extensive research, and collaborative efforts, that gap was still monstrously vast. Not only did the gold mining cause occupational injuries, damage to organ systems, but the mass deforestation caused greater malaria outbreaks and food insecurity. Addressing and observing the intersections of global and environmental health I cared deeply about was more complex and challenging than I expected. 

My interest in medicine started young because of my mom. Growing up, I often heard, “no candy, no soda, desserts only once in a while, put the juice down and drink some water”. I believe my mom emphasized healthy eating choices not only because she was a Certified Nurse Assistant (CNA) but because as a Ghanaian, she had a holistic view of health. Ghanaians have a rich culture relying on diet, lifestyle changes, and herbal remedies. While I’ve had the privilege of over-the-counter medications, I also have the privilege of drinking ginger tea to soothe a cough. This perspective helped me to understand what health meant to the research participants. Their environmental and economic factors created such dire health inequities and a reliance on holistic medicine. Although I was not able to give medical advice, I observed how the local health professionals catered their medical advice to the participants’ views of medicine. I want to be a physician to culminate that holistic knowledge with medical treatment to improve the well-being of my patients.

This research informed my senior thesis on how heavy metals biomagnify in riparian systems. After working with the community residents, I never thought I’d be trudging through muddy ponds collecting algae and spiders to see effects of heavy metal exposure at an ecological level. Just as I had looked at the relationship between human health and the environment, I was able to be attentive and search for patterns among these pond organisms. However, the data was muddled and unclear. I read more papers, analyzed my limitations, and created different graphs and figures. I was able to form conclusions and identify future directions. Similar to a doctor, sometimes the results and diagnostics do not align with the original hypothesis. Often for patients, there is not always a clear diagnosis. Despite that, being a part of that scientific process has taught me how to synthesize knowledge to form new strategies to address a problem.

Post-graduation, I became a dialysis technician so that I could provide patient care for an underserved community. Most people at risk for kidney failure and subsequently need dialysis are low income and/or Black and Latino. Entering the world of dialysis, gave me exposure to what it’s like for patients to live with chronic disease. Before each treatment, I asked the patients how they felt and any health or life updates. In between the interesting stories of their misbehaved puppy or their adorable grandbaby, they would mention medically pertinent information. Often, the patients would disclose more information than I would expect. This established trust allowed me to effectively advocate for them. If a patient felt nauseous, I would recommend pulling less fluids. This was a preventative measure so that their blood pressure didn’t drop. Overall, treatment measures were determined by the physician orders. I was more interested in the procedures and designing of the treatment plans that the physicians did. Working with the patients made me eager for the future where I would have greater initiative over patients’ health.

My experiences have come full circle to confirm how intersectional health is. Medicine isn’t practiced in isolation. My life has culminated in me being competent to understand how to serve diverse patients and their needs. My upbringing, research, and clinical experience have given me a taste of healthcare. I want to practice medicine where I conduct the medical treatments and improve the health trajectory of my patients.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
On the surface, I was the same as the study participants. We were all Ghanaians. Despite a shared culture, I couldn‚Äôt have been more different from the participants. In 2019, I conducted global health research in Ghana. When I arrived in Amansie West, it sharply contrasted with my family‚Äôs experiences. The people in Amansie West were rural farmers or miners, and most couldn‚Äôt read or write. I was astonished and ignorant._x000D_
_x000D_
The first day of field research had severe communication barriers. It was difficult for the participants and me to understand each other. Frustrated with the communication difficulties, I began studying again. After every day of fieldwork, I watched videos for learning Twi and took notes late into the night. Over the weeks, my Twi improved. I was able to help the sampling team work more smoothly. I am still currently trying to learn Twi. Reflecting on this experience taught me how to be more culturally competent and forego any assumptions about people.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: In 2021, I joined Kramerica Gives as a mentor for high school students. Most of the students are low-income. Each mentor is assigned a mentee; I was assigned a senior student, JG. At the beginning of the school year, JG struggled academically. I focused on the goal of her graduating on time. As for JG‚Äôs academics, I helped her establish better study habits. In order to graduate, JG had to make up all the classes she failed in online courses. I introduced JG to the study method of scheduling study and break time and repeating. I told her to set goals for completing her coursework by specific dates.
