Each time she completed a course, I congratulated her, so she knew I believed in her abilities. Months later, I was able to cheer when JG walked across the stage for her graduation. Throughout the school year, I also supported JG in exploring her interests. She discovered her passion for healthcare and will enroll in a phlebotomy course. I am grateful that I could lead JG to academic success.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
The news of COVID-19 broke my junior year and I was sent home. I was upset that I would not be able to volunteer at the Duke Hospital after spring break. When I returned home, I struggled to study with a poor internet connection and a lack of a quiet study space. However, the most concerning situation was when my mother contracted COVID-19 from her CNA job. I had to care for my mother; thus, I fell behind. Fortunately, my mom recovered from COVID-19, and I was able to improve my grades. _x000D_
_x000D_
Over the summer and senior year, I was restricted from my community or Duke Hospital volunteering or shadowing. I participated in virtual tutoring, mentorship, and shadowing experiences. I also had to create a new thesis. For every removed opportunity, I was persistent in finding an alternative. I realized I wanted more clinical experience. Post graduation, I became a dialysis technician. While I worked, I learned how to provide patient care and collaborate with other healthcare professionals.

personal_statement:
I was six years old when my father took me on my first trip to the Cleveland hospital. My dad and I hopped into our car early in the morning for a full day of driving. On the way to the hospital, my father introduced me to his favorite bands—the Beatles, Green Day, Wilco—and explained to me what the different parts of a song were. Reflecting on the nature of this trip now, my father was likely making an effort to distract me from the reason for our whole trip. All that I knew was that some doctor wanted me on a medication that my parents knew I would have to take every day for the rest of my life. Because a lifetime prescription was not ideal for their son, my parents sought a second opinion in Cleveland. I also knew that this hospital trip had something to do with my heart, but I did not understand what an “enlarged aortic root” meant. When we finally arrived at Cleveland, my dad and I checked into our hotel, where we stayed the night until we visited the hospital the following morning. 
	At the hospital, my dad and I spoke with several doctors, who then decided to perform an echocardiogram. Despite my fear of the foreign procedure, seeing the inward workings of my heart and watching it rhythmically beat was one of the most fascinating, entrancing scenes I had ever witnessed. I could not take my eyes off of the screen as the doctor named and described each of the valves of my heart. Watching the physician use such an intriguing machine to measure my heart valves in such a non-invasive procedure was something I did not know was possible. After this first hospital experience, I started asking all sorts of questions about the various tests the doctors ran, trying to understand each of them. In turn, the staff at Cleveland patiently explained them to me to make certain that I was comfortable. The compassionate hospital staff made a lasting impression on me. They somehow ensured that a terrified, confused six-year-old child felt at home and safe in an environment that was otherwise entirely new and unknown. Ultimately, my time in Cleveland ignited within me the desire to learn about the human body and medicine and how to use such knowledge to care for the people around me, as my first doctors did for me. 
This longing to learn and understand has only grown throughout my life since. Any time I would meet a medical professional, I would ask them how some test or piece of machinery functioned. Moreover, my experiences as a hospital patient led me to an interest in biology and human anatomy. I signed up for an elective anatomy and physiology class in high school, and eventually chose to major in biology at my undergraduate school, Dordt University. The countless questions that I had begun asking as a child continued to be answered in college, as I acquired an in-depth knowledge of biology through courses in histology, genetics, microbiology, and, of course, human anatomy and physiology. My time at Dordt, furthermore, allowed me to use this understanding to assist fellow students through my positions as a tutor and teaching assistant in the chemistry and biology laboratories. I had the valuable opportunity to help my peers grow by adapting information to their unique learning styles. 
My aspiration to care for others came to fruition in my college years in opportunities outside of school as well. Toward the end of my freshman year, I earned my EMT certification. During the following school year, I served as a volunteer for the local ambulance squad, a position in which I participated in emergency and inter-hospital transfer calls. Throughout this experience, I practiced treatment and patient relations in each call that I took. After my junior year, I spent the summer as an EMT for Superior Air-Ground Ambulance Services, near my home in Indiana. While serving there, I worked alongside a paramedic for interhospital transfers with critical patients as well as led basic life support cases. I found great fulfillment in caring for my local community through this position. I appreciated the opportunity to hear and learn from the individual stories of my diverse patients and to exist as a positive example of a healthcare provider. In this role, I met people at their most vulnerable points and did all that I could to assist them, both physically and emotionally. Not only did this pre-hospital setting magnify my desire to help and care for others in the medical field; it further encouraged me to continue my education so that I could improve my ability to do so.
	Overall, I believe that my unique, personal experiences both inside and outside of the hospital have given me invaluable, empathetic insight into what is like to be both a patient and a care provider. Knowing the indispensable difference that a positive, compassionate care team can make on an individual, I feel called to the work of a doctor. I can think of no greater privilege—to serve and provide care for those who need it most and to make what I hope is a positive impact on my community.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: When I was studying at Dordt University, I took several Spanish classes which gave me the opportunity to practice speaking Spanish with native speakers. These tutors came from various countries in South and Central America. Our one-on-one sessions consisted of us talking about our lives and how were were raised. While I gained a greater appreciation for the language, I was given a first hand account of what life was like in countries such as Paraguay and Guatemala. They gave me a wonderful view of their cultures, from the food all the way to family life. It was eye-opening to understand their experiences in their native language. It taught me just how different all of us can be. It challenged my thinking of what I understood as universal experiences. Overall, it showed me just how important it is to talk to others to hear their stories so that we may truly understand them.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I would say that one of my most meaningful positions was as a tutor at Dordt University. In this role, I interacted with all types of students for many different classes. By my senior year, I was tutoring around 10 hours a week for groups as large as 10. The most challenging part of this position was adapting the information to each student's learning style. As I assisted these students in their learning, I was able to promote good study habits and positive attitudes. The most obvious change I could see were the students who had tutoring with me over various years. At first, I do think they needed a bit of guidance. But, after the first year I think they came to my sessions just out of familiarity.  When I graduated, they told me "I'm not sure what we will do without you next year". I just told them that I wasn't necessary for me to stick around, they had become great students. Overall I not only gave my students knowledge, but confidence in themselves.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I do believe that COVID-19 did impact my application and preparation for medical school when it comes to my shadowing hours. The pandemic affected all healthcare systems and prevented most shadowing opportunities that I had. Also, my mother was diagnosed with cancer at this time and I did not want to risk exposing her to the virus as her chemotherapy weakened her immune system. Since I lived at home, I couldn't in good conscious go out and risk her health. Also, though I was away from home for my undergraduate education, I was not able to start shadowing due to my coursework and various positions until my senior year.

Hrdshp_Comments: As Muslim-Iranians, my family and I have been directly affected by the racial and socio-economic barriers that surround our healthcare system. Compassionate health care that is culturally-sensitive is a fundamental human right that we cannot afford and do not have access to. Specifically, racism and racial bias have created a lack of Muslim-Middle Eastern physicians in the Denver area, which creates a disparity for Muslim and minority patients. By becoming a physician, I will actively address this disparity within my medical practice. I will support all disadvantaged patients and address health care disparities within my community. Furthermore, due to my parents limited income, maintaining a livelihood has been a struggle, and at certain times we have relied on welfare programs to survive. Also from an early age, I have worked full-time to financially support the needs of my family. Despite these challenges within my life, I know that I can overcome adversity through hard work, dedication, and intellect. I have also learned the value of sublimation: instead of being discouraged due to these circumstances, I transform the negative experiences within my life into a positive power for good that will help others.
personal_statement:
When I was 11 years old, my family was hit with horrible news: my mother was diagnosed with breast cancer. To make matters worse, we did not have the proper health insurance or finances to cover her treatment. Access to and the cost of doctor visits, surgeries, and additional treatments became a barrier in the path to curing my mother’s cancer. Only through the help of welfare and Medicaid, was my mother able to receive the treatment that she needed. My mother battled breast cancer for two years straight and underwent a mastectomy, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy to become cancer-free.
Despite the barriers in the path to curing my mother’s disease, we were truly fortunate to overcome this adversity. However, this is not the reality for most poor and marginalized patients. Proper treatment and personalized health care are fundamental rights that they will never access or afford. As such, providing treatment to disadvantaged patients is my personal motive for studying medicine and becoming a physician. Specifically, I aim to provide free health care to poor and uninsured patients by partnering with non-profit organizations.
The Jesuit tradition is rooted in providing service to the poor and marginalized, and pursuing justice on behalf of all people. By studying at Regis University, I actively pursued these Jesuit values alongside my science education. Personally, I integrated community service into my education by volunteering at the university chapel. During my free time, I worked at the chapel and provided service to the homeless population of Denver. Making meals, fundraising money, and donating clothes were some of the ways that I helped. I also pursued justice for disadvantaged people through my knowledge of biochemistry and mathematics. By working as an undergraduate research assistant, I investigated the therapeutic use of a cancer therapy drug, lumazine. This research project addressed complications and barriers to cancer treatment. Specifically, I optimized the irradiation time and dosage concentration of lumazine in such a manner that would reduce damage to healthy cells and the cost of treatment. This research project and volunteer work greatly transformed my science education by providing a foundation of service rooted in helping those who are less fortunate.
By using my Jesuit education and research experience, I served my community during the COVID-19 pandemic. I volunteered as a laboratory assistant at the Regis University COVID Testing Center and provided free RT-PCR and ELISA testing. Within poor-minority communities, such as my own, underlying disparities were further exacerbated such that people were getting sick and dying from the virus at disproportionally higher rates. This disparity was partially caused by barriers in the path to proper testing. By providing free and easy-to-access testing, I took a crucial first step in overcoming health care disparities and effectively combatting COVID. I also assisted Student Health Services with patient sample collection, contact tracing, and a vaccination drive that provided free flu shots. Through this volunteer experience, I learned that health is much more than the absence of disease. While COVID cases have decreased recently, the disparity in COVID’s impact is still present. Declined mental health and increased substance abuse are some of the long-lasting consequences that we must deal with. As such, it is my ongoing duty to address these problems within my community.
Currently, I work as a professional research assistant (PRA) within the laboratory of Dr. Ramon Lorca at the University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus. I really enjoy this research position because of the innovative approach that we are taking to solve gaps in patient treatment. Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) is an adverse condition during pregnancy which increases neonatal mortality, and there are no treatments for the condition. Our research will overcome this gap in treatment by developing a novel mouse model of IUGR using optogenetics. The validation of this model will allow for the future development of treatments and preventative therapies. Furthermore, the translational nature of this research has shown me the link between the bench and the bedside. I have learned that the most effective physicians incorporate research and investigation into their medical practice. By working as a PRA, I have gained crucial research skills that will hopefully build the foundation for me to become a successful physician-scientist.
Reflecting upon my mother’s disease and the impact that it has had on my life, I remembered a fond childhood memory of doing math problems with her. I remember the countless hours sitting at the kitchen table with my mom while we worked through my geometry homework. Now, I look back at those childhood tutoring sessions with deep admiration. Despite her struggles, my mom always found the time to help me and sacrificed so much to always be there for me. As a Jesuit student, research scientist, and future physician, I hope to have this same effect on the lives of my patients. No matter the struggles that I may face, I will always be there to uplift and serve others.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
By attending Regis University, I had the opportunity to pursue a Jesuit education that sought to build a more just and compassionate world. As a Jesuit student, I stood in solidarity with others and embodied the spirit of providing service to the poor and marginalized. Through this experience, I was seeking to answer the question, ‚ÄúHow ought we to live?‚Äù._x000D_
After extensive reflection on this question and my experiences, I understand and recognize that Muslim, Iranian, and Middle Eastern individuals are underrepresented within medicine. This represents a disadvantage for all Middle Eastern patients as they are not receiving medical care that is conscious of their personal needs. Furthermore, I understand and recognize that there is an overall lack of diversity among physicians and healthcare professionals. As such, I want to build a diverse and inclusive environment within healthcare that both supports Muslim-Middle Eastern individuals and all healthcare professionals and patients.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
As a minority who comes from a low-income household, I am no stranger to the opportunity gap that exists in higher education. Specifically, individuals from minority communities are hindered from attending college and achieving academic success. To address and correct this disparity, I volunteered with Colorado ‚ÄúI Have A Dream‚Äù and provided assistance to disadvantaged students within my community. _x000D_
By volunteering as a mathematics tutor, I provided personalized tutoring sessions and a holistic learning experience for my student ‚ÄúDestiny‚Äù. Through the consideration of Destiny as a whole person and not solely focusing on her academic achievement, I exercised mental, physical, and spiritual growth. I believe that these efforts have been impactful as Destiny improved her math grade, aced her final exam, and developed a passion for mathematics. Furthermore, my volunteer work is ongoing as I hope to further educate, inspire, and remove barriers to higher education for disadvantaged students.

Hrdshp_Comments:
My financial and social circumstances throughout childhood contribute to who I am today. My dad was unemployed twice for long stretches, and during each, we did not have access to insurance. My mother developed a painful gynecological health condition during the second unemployment and could not afford to get help until his new job during my junior year. This position was across the country and I took on several responsibilities in the household on top of school—driving my brothers to commitments, taking care of errands, working part-time, and keeping the house running when my mom was not able to. 

I also learned how being a woman of color impacts how others see me from a young age, and in school, I dealt with racism and discrimination for my religious identity. I had to fight to show I belonged in advanced classes, clubs, and honor societies, and struggled with stress and anxiety from belittlement from both students and adults.

As a result of these experiences, I matured quickly and grew stronger. I became resourceful and driven, and worked to overcome the long-lasting effects of what I went through by exploring my passions and discovering a strength for advocacy. I have grown immensely as an individual, and in retrospect, I believe the way I responded to my struggles is my greatest strength.
personal_statement:
It has been a handful of weeks since I earned my learner’s permit. The highway is still terrifying to my seventeen-year-old self. The Garden State Parkway is not meant for weak hearts, especially not my white knuckles as I grip the steering wheel, seat pulled up so close that I am inches away from the horn. This car doesn’t have air conditioning either–the ’97 Camry is not built for a fifty-mile trip, but the minivan is off for service.

I have to take the wheel, metaphorically and literally. My mother is in no shape to drive, and my father is across the country, working at a new job after a long unemployment. My mother has endured a litany of reproductive health issues. She has been suffering from severe, prolonged uterine bleeding, and as of today, it has reached the point where I am washing her clothes every other day.

“Do you have any family history of medical conditions?”

This is the longest part of triage during every trip to a new medical professional. Usually, I hear the answer from my mother, expecting her to rattle off generations of conditions. For the first time, it is my turn to run through the list for someone else.

While I had visited family members in the hospital after procedures, I could always lean on my parents to step in when it felt too overwhelming. This was different. My biggest support system was the person that was dealing with an illness. I felt drawn to the way my mother’s doctors used their voices. I saw how they worked with her, taking the time to hear her pain and offer advice, comfort, and validation all at once. My experiences with my family and community taught me the discomforts experienced by immigrants in hospital settings, and I wanted to be an advocate for them, particularly women that went through the hardships my mother did.

After two semesters of bouncing between majors, wanting more from my degree beyond science prerequisites, I tied pre-med with my interests in multicultural politics and advocacy with a major in international studies.

Student Government was the first organization I joined in college. It introduced me to the impact of advocacy on a college campus and forced me to confront my fear of public speaking. Speeches, presentations, and meetings with administrators were no longer barriers–they were pathways I leveraged to advocate for my peers. My first meeting with a university official was with a member of the Wellness Center, as was the last. This “full-circle” moment may have ended in the same meeting room, but the person that walked in during my last meeting had accomplished several initiatives, left action plans for many more, and grew through each of the leadership positions held in the organization. The Senator that fumbled through notes on a proposal for resources to support a smoke-free campus was now Chief Health and Wellness Officer, presenting the organization’s vision for embedded wellness as part of the university’s Strategic Plan. The work I had done to advocate for student needs, especially through the last year and half of COVID, had inspired me to envision a future where I tackled the task of improving public health outcomes through daily interactions with patients.

While Student Government taught me to think creatively to tackle student health on campus, it was my clinical experience that allowed me to witness the immense vulnerability felt by patients in clinical settings. As a volunteer at Swedish Hospital and Rush Copley, I was able to assist a diverse population of patients. Whether it be providing blankets, delivering flowers, or wheeling patients to appointments, I valued the connections I formed and the chance to ease their anxieties, even if for just a minute.

“Linda” was an elderly woman I met while volunteering in the PCU. She was recovering from surgery after a fall. This procedure may have been common, but it was Linda’s story that served as a reminder of how completely medicine can transform lives. Linda was an avid athlete. She played tennis, badminton, rowed, and ran for charity, despite her age. Her fall had put an end to an active lifestyle, and she explained that what began as hopelessness transformed into determination to work towards healing upon the encouragement of her physicians. I enjoyed the ability to sit with her and listen, aiding in simple tasks, and helping her read the note cards attached to her flowers.

When I reflect on why I want to be a doctor, I think about the heart disease that has affected my family over the past several generations. I think about the funerals I could not attend during the pandemic, caused by COVID entering a household of vulnerable elders. I think about the food pantry housed in one of the predominantly South Asian areas of Chicago, guiding community members through the process with accented Urdu. I think about the refugee girls I mentored and tutored, finding sisterhood and providing any support I could while they lived in defiance of the conflict they’d escaped. I think about the ways I have learned to love to make a difference, no matter how small, in the relationships I have built with others. My passions lay within a mix of human interaction, medical curiosity, and outreach, and as a physician, I strive to combine them to bring the best care to my patients.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
‚ÄúAnna‚Äù was a first-generation student I tutored in writing. I supported her in transforming her frustration into a love for authoring autobiographical stories. Her writing was vivid and meaningful, painting a picture of her wistfulness over the vibrant country she had left behind. Through this all, she tackled her family‚Äôs financial issues, taking time off studying to work. Her status as a recent immigrant made her the target of microaggressions, and she dealt with this stress on top of the burden of maintaining her household. Anna was a role model for me in the way she honored her culture and family in what she did, but she was also an example of how disparities impact every sector of life._x000D_
_x000D_
In working with students like Anna, I have learned about the richness that comes when people have access to the resources to achieve. My own work with people from a variety of backgrounds has broadened my perspective of the human experience and makes me passionate about sharing these reflections.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
In the times I helped locate healthcare and food in an already under-resourced area, I felt frustration with a system that had caused so much stress for the immigrant and refugee girls at GirlForward. I noticed the way their trauma manifested‚Äìissues in school, stress from helping manage their houses, and physical ailments caused by constant tension. I sought to create a mentorship curriculum and ESL program that tackled these conversations while also providing relief and fun, developing activities that strengthened community-wide sisterhood._x000D_
_x000D_
These girls were just a few years younger than me and had endured displacement, fled persecution, and traveled to a country that was completely unfamiliar. We found common ground through topics that were universal experiences for teenage girls‚Äìschool, friendships, and television‚Äìand some that weren‚Äôt, like war. I valued every single moment I spent volunteering, trying to create a safe space for them to temporarily exist as just teenagers.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
Due to COVID, I was unable to continue two clinical experiences I earned. I was hesitant to pursue a clinical job since my parents were both considered high-risk for infection. In addition, my family experienced losses abroad‚Äîfamily and friends that passed just days after contracting COVID. I also experienced financial constraints due to a loss of hours at work._x000D_
_x000D_
I found other ways to engage with my community that wouldn‚Äôt put my family in harm‚Äôs way‚Äîtutoring immigrant students, volunteering at a food pantry, supporting student-athletes remotely, and running errands to decrease my parents‚Äô exposure. I also worked with my university‚Äôs Wellness Center to tackle the adjustment online by leading initiatives that promoted mental, physical, financial, and social wellness in such an isolating time._x000D_
_x000D_
My experiences during the pandemic inform the type of career I want to have: a physician that delivers equitable and inclusive care while working to address the policies that cause injustice.

personal_statement:
What does baking bread have to do with my interest in medicine? This was not a realization I thought I would ever make, but it's significant to the type of physician I aspire to be. On March 30, 2020, I received the following email from my university: "Dear students, effective immediately, everyone is not to return to campus for the rest of the semester. The university will transition to remote learning as the campus will be effectively closed. In addition, Trinity athletics will be canceled." While the full 600-word campus update was more informative, this was how my brain first processed the information. From my point of view, everything was being stripped away from me. I could no longer have in-person classes/labs, shadow physicians, play soccer, or even see my friends. 

Logically, I understood that this transition was made to protect the health and wellbeing of our communities. However, this understanding did not make it any easier emotionally. One day, after logging off from my chemistry lab zoom class, I got ready for soccer practice only to remember I didn't have practice for the foreseeable future. While I was sad, this was my new normal. I had to make the best of it. Since the pandemic was emotionally draining for everyone, I wanted to make something to lighten up my family's mood and do something challenging that got my science brain thinking. That's when my journey of becoming a makeshift baker began. Over the next six months, I went into bread baking boot camp. And let me tell you, it wasn't easy. My first month was a combination of utter failures and setbacks. From my yeast farm never actually being strong enough to raise dough to French baguettes that tasted like fermentation (and not in a good way). 

Eventually, after some trial and error testing various water/flour/yeast ratios and long nights of YouTubing, "How the heck do you make dough rise?", I finally produced my first bread loaf. It was small and weirdly formed, but I made it, and it tasted good. Seeing my family's faces light up when I shared my bread with them amplified my happiness. At that moment, I knew all my hard work was worth it. For the next few months, I learned how to make almost every variation of bread and pastry, experimenting with different flavors, toppings, and techniques until I had an arsenal of bread recipes at my disposal. 

I discovered that the emotional and fundamental aspects of bread-making are the root of my interest in medicine and why I decided to major in neuroscience. The heart of making bread is understanding the fundamentals of how flour, water, and yeast interact. This knowledge boils down to the core basics of math, biology, physics, and chemistry. While you can expand on this knowledge by adding additional ingredients and using different techniques, the core foundation is still the same. This foundation can make over 100 different types of bread. The medical field is similarly situated. Physicians must first master those exact four basic sciences before they are integrated and expanded upon in our preclinical years of medical school. This foundation can then be applied to over 135 specialties and subspecialties, each with its own skill sets and techniques. 

As for the emotion, making bread was fun and challenging, but the happiness I felt sharing my bread with my family made it that much more worthwhile. The basic sciences and sociology courses I took as an undergrad were engaging and challenging. However, I observed the integration of basic sciences and sociology, watching Dr. Garrett perform colonoscopies and other surgeries. In addition, witnessing the emotional satisfaction Dr. Garrett and her team demonstrated when successfully changing patients' lives was amazing. I also observed how healthcare changed the lives of children and gave them a second chance at a quality life with their families and friends through my participation with The Children's Hospital of San Antonio and TigerThon. 

I noticed that the emotional and mental aspect of medical care is crucial for the patient and the physician. Medical care is as much physical as it is mental healing. I learned this from witnessing the medical journey of others but also from my medical journey. I have had injuries to my ankle, knee, and back playing soccer. My dad, who did a dual residency in internal medicine and psychiatry, always explained my injuries from a physical and mental perspective. He explained that it is essential to consider both when caring for patients. I saw this duality firsthand with the physicians who helped me and in the ones I shadowed-seeing this dual nature of patient care and the love these physicians have for what they do. 

Baking bread is a microcosm of the medical field because physicians must first understand the fundamentals before applying this knowledge to help patients overcome obstacles and live their lives to the fullest. In addition, no physician acts alone. Like no single yeast can raise a whole loaf of bread, it takes an entire team of physicians and healthcare providers to give patients the necessary tools to heal. I have seen it again and again, both in my medical journey and witnessing the medical journey of others.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
For three weeks, I was able to experience Spain‚Äôs wonderful culture firsthand learning how to dance traditional flamenco and how to prepare many culinary dishes. This was my first time out of the country without my family, so it was a unique chance for me to get out of my comfort zone and immerse myself in a culture that is completely different from my own. This experience opened my eyes to the considerations I want to make as a physician, especially when treating patients from different cultures. For example, there may be treatments in traditional American medicine that are considered not acceptable for some patients due to the traditions of their culture. I believe it is my job as their physician to recognize these differences and help them around these barriers to create a safe space for all my patients to receive quality and personalized care._x000D_
_x000D_
_x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Makayla was a bright second grader I met a couple of years ago who loved to play outside and wear pink bows in her hair. I remember the first time I met her she was so shy that she hid behind her homeroom teacher. Her teacher expressed to me that she was worried because Makayla was two years behind her classmates in reading and math as her parents worked multiple jobs and were not able to help her at home. In our first session, Makayla could barely get through a kindergarten-level book or add numbers without my help. Over the year, I worked with Makayla twice a week after school. Watching her grow to be able to read Frog and Toad by herself brought tears to my eyes. Education is the greatest gift we can give someone. I not only taught Makayla to read and count. I fostered in her a love of learning which she will take with her for the rest of her life.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Being a hands-on visual learner, the pandemic was academically and socially challenging for me. Since everything was switched to virtual, I had to quickly shift from the normal way I was accustomed to learning. My extracurricular activities such as soccer and community service getting shut down made it even more challenging. I was supposed to volunteer at the children‚Äôs hospital and with vulnerable populations, but we had to switch to virtual volunteering because of the pandemic. While I am grateful that I was still able to do a little volunteering, the pandemic limited the amount of patient interaction I would have liked. Fortunately, I was able to go back to in-person volunteering this past spring and I am actively planning future volunteer opportunities at the children‚Äôs hospital for myself and other students at Trinity.

personal_statement:
“Get me a clean white sheet, a pillow, a cup of tea, and let me die.” These were my grandma’s words while in a hospital in Poland, just after she was found nearly dead. The man who rescued her was a doctor; he saw her lying lifeless on the ground and brought her to safety. The Nazis had taken everything from her: her family, her youth, her hair, and now almost her life. For three months, she lay in a hospital bed on the brink of death, and the doctor visited her every day. She experienced the ultimate injustice and lived to tell the story, wishing me only one thing: to help those suffering. 
Grandma instilled in me the duty to aid others–tzedakah, in Jewish terms–but I didn’t realize that my path to achieving this would be through medicine until late into undergrad. Entering college, I wanted to learn about everything. I had always been an avid reader and writer, yet I was similarly engrossed in math and science. I could envision myself as a novelist as much as a mathematician. I often felt pressured to choose a specific path, to focus on one discipline that I could call my own. As time went on, everyone found their niche, but I couldn’t choose. I spent my first two years taking classes exploring poetry, music, math, gender, and philosophy. In my first chemistry class, however, I realized science was my true love.
In organic chemistry, I became infatuated with reaction mechanisms. Each synthesis problem felt like a puzzle, and I loved challenging myself to find the best solution. I was amazed that by combining chemicals, we could synthesize compounds and that the information we learned was being applied to create life-saving drugs. Biochemistry combined my passion for mechanisms and my interest in the human body. I was awestruck by the intricacy of essential processes like glycolysis and thermoregulation. As I learned more, I began to see how everything was intertwined; the muscles I learned about in physiology behaved like the springs in physics, and the math I learned about in physical chemistry was applied to the kinetics in biochemistry. The big picture was striking, and I was eager to learn more.
Suddenly, my path became obvious. My love for science and my desire to help others formed a perfect intersection in medicine. I had never felt like I was destined for something before, but after realizing I wanted to be a doctor, I couldn’t imagine myself doing anything else. The idea that I could use science to help people was intoxicating, and I knew that I would devote my life to doing so. 
Once I began to imagine a career in medicine, Grandma’s words felt like a prophecy. I wanted to be like the healer that saved her life–the one that made mine possible. Shadowing physicians at Lenox Hill Hospital made it clear that I made the right choice. While observing a cardiologist visit her patients, I realized how many different people doctors encounter every day. Patients varied in age, race, size, ability, and gender, yet the cardiologist treated everyone with the utmost respect and kindness. Although each patient had their own background, their stories converged on the white table of the exam room. Most of them were scared–sick with or at risk for heart disease–and looking to their doctor for guidance. I was in awe of the cardiologist’s candor and confidence as she spoke to her patients clearly and carefully, and I wanted to one day do the same.
The clinical research that I participated in reaffirmed this commitment. Interacting with patients was incredibly eye-opening and enhanced my love of medicine. Since the participants had been diagnosed with Coronary Artery Disease and had at least two uncontrolled risk factors, they were understandably worried about the future of their health. Through the study, I had the chance to teach patients about various ways that they could implement lifestyle changes to control their risk factors. I was inspired by the hopefulness that arose in the patients once given the knowledge that they could drastically improve their health by changing aspects of their daily routine. Upon seeing their renewed confidence, my drive to aid others through medicine was further ignited. 
Through my clinical experiences and advocacy work, I developed an interest in providing care to women. I would love to utilize my knowledge of trauma-sensitive care in combination with my scientific studies to create a safer space for women. It would be a privilege to continue to do research and ultimately design a standard of care that is catered specifically to the treatment of women and other marginalized groups of people. I want to help people who have suffered trauma and show them that their bodies and minds are resilient, as the doctor did for my grandma. 
My road to pursuing a career in medicine was anything but straightforward. I was not born knowing I would one day become a doctor. However through exploring my many interests, science and medicine called to me. Although I felt frustrated at times because I didn’t have a clear path, I now realize that my time exploring various disciplines was a blessing. I can confidently say that becoming a physician is what I am meant to do, and I know that Grandma would be proud.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: ‚ÄúShe won‚Äôt believe that I made them,‚Äù she said, gazing down at the earrings. Doreen‚Äôs eyes were sparkling, wet from emotion. I was leading a crafting workshop at a senior center when I guided Doreen through making a pair of earrings for her daughter. I was surprised; I hadn‚Äôt expected her to become emotional about accomplishing something that had seemed simple to my nimble hands. For Doreen, however, this was no menial task but an extraordinary feat. This was the first time I realized my privilege being able-bodied; I took for granted my ability to complete physical tasks like using my hands and walking upstairs. Working at the senior center changed my perspective and opened my eyes to the challenges that many older adults and people with disabilities continually face. For the rest of my time at the center, I ensured that all events were accessible and committed to learning more about disability justice; I hope to incorporate anti-ableist practices into my clinical care at Rush.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: In May 2020, I was informed that my college's administration was writing a new Title IX policy without input from students or professionals trained to work with survivors of sexual violence. Upon hearing this information, I was extremely worried about the well-being of students who would be subjected to this policy in the future. A group of advocates and I banded together and convinced the administration to let us review the policy and present revisions to the board. Many challenges came with this, including the fact that everything had to be done remotely. I took on the responsibilities of organizing virtual meetings and ensuring that the other advocates remained motivated and committed to the cause. After months of back-and-forth with the administration and legal team, almost all of our revisions were accepted into the final policy. Although the process was frustrating at times, it is rewarding to know that we made a lasting difference that will protect survivors for years to come.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Being sent home in March 2020 due to the pandemic meant traveling across the country from my college in California to my childhood home in New York. Living with an immunocompromised and extremely high-risk family member while at the epicenter of the pandemic meant taking every possible precaution to keep our family safe. The fear of what might happen if COVID entered the house was daunting; yet, I knew I was incredibly fortunate. There were people in the same position as me who didn‚Äôt have access to the resources I did. Thus, I decided to figure out how to serve my community without putting my family member at risk. By utilizing Zoom and social media, I was able to lead virtual initiatives to support those who are underserved. I held mask-making workshops via Zoom and started a mutual aid fund for low-income students at my school. By utilizing these contactless forms of service, I was able to contribute to my community while ensuring that I didn‚Äôt endanger my family.

personal_statement:
The lyrics swim through my cerebral cortex like a wakeful dream. Music is my genesis, it is the spark that ignited my passion for medicine. From the age of two, I have been enchanted by the melodies of Carnatic music, an ancient style of Indian classical music. What began as a toddler’s imitation of her mother’s lullabies evolved into an intensive study of music vital to the formation of my character. The 4 AM vocal exercises instilled discipline; the improvisational style of Carnatic music fostered creativity; the drive to continually grow as a singer blossomed into a love for lifelong learning. 

For the past four years, I have had the privilege of imparting the rich tapestry of classical music to children with disabilities – an experience that has arguably taught me more than my students. My first student was Karuna, a 16 year old girl with perfect pitch and moderate autism spectrum disorder. “Sa Ri Ga Ma Pa Da Ni Sa,” I sang the notes of the first scale taught in Carnatic music, asking Karuna to repeat after me. Silence filled the air as her dark brown eyes remained focused on the floor, her face blank. Undeterred, I gently encouraged her to participate by playing icebreaker games to slowly coax her out of her shell. While she eventually echoed individual notes with remarkable accuracy, she was unable to string them together. My unspoken frustration with the failure of traditional training exercises was dwarfed by my unwavering belief in her potential, spurring me to research and incorporate techniques utilized in music therapy. Following our third class, Karuna’s mom tearfully confided in me that her teachers had deemed Karuna incapable of learning to read. As I held her hand and offered what solace I could, my resolve to nurture my students’ wellbeing solidified. 

“Bhavani, Bhavani! Look at this!” Karuna exclaimed after class. Eyebrows furrowed with concentration, she slowly enunciated the words of her first book. Several months of creatively adapting music therapy techniques into the rigorous curriculum of Carnatic music yielded incredible success. Karuna’s verbal communication, fine motor control, and confidence dramatically improved to the point where her healthcare team asked what treatment was responsible. Her ailing grandmother even thanked me for the gift of seeing her oft nonverbal and unresponsive granddaughter come alive after music lessons. Witnessing the powerful impact I had on the health and lives of my students was truly humbling. 

While I had been set on a career in scientific research, I realized that I craved this direct human impact as well. Through teaching music, I discovered my passion for understanding people’s stories and uplifting underserved communities. I was left with the feeling of wanting something more than expanding the boundaries of knowledge from my future career. However, I did not make the connection to medicine until the spring of my sophomore year, when I was diagnosed with ovarian cancer. 

My time as a patient was marked by the rhythmic beeping of a heart rate monitor, the harsh glare of overhead lamps, and the coppery tang of fear. While I had been symptomatic for the past year, receiving my diagnosis was both a blessing and a curse. Having an answer for the paralyzing fatigue ravaging my body and brain was initially a relief, but only precipitated more terrifying questions. Hours upon hours of scouring PubMed helped ground me in the endless sea of uncertainty. Science was the beloved, well-worn blanket to which I clung. Delving into the hormonal interactions of the menstrual cycle in the classroom and performing ovariectomies on mice subjects in the lab were now imbued with real application, coming alive in a way they never had before. But it was spending time with my doctors that changed my life. The delicate humor Dr. Wilson blended into her explanations of the progression of disease, the attentive gaze of Dr. Park as he actively listened to my concerns about side effects, and the compassion with which Dr. Shah dried my tears meant the world to me. I desperately longed to support patients at their most vulnerable, scared, and exposed, as my healthcare team had done for me. Every aspect of being a physician – serving as an advocate, healer, scientist, mentor, leader and educator — resonated deeply with me and my heart sang with purpose. The only future I could envision for myself was on the other side of the hospital bed as a doctor. 

My lifelong love of music brought me to my career in medicine. Teaching children with disabilities kindled my fiery dedication to improve equity in healthcare, but it was my experiences as a patient that cultivated my appreciation for the transformative power of medicine. Upon my full recovery, I pursued my dream of being a physician through researching the mechanisms of uterine fibroid growth, creating reproductive healthcare workshops for women in rural India, and developing a therapy chatbot app to make mental health treatment more accessible. I hope to further explore my passions for narrative medicine, global health, and applications of technology to healthcare in medical school. I embark upon this lifelong journey with the goal of making a meaningful difference in the lives of patients like Karuna and myself.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Braving a barrage of discordant chants, I reached the car entering the Planned Parenthood clinic in Nashville. As I accompanied the young woman inside through the clinic, I learned that Imani was desperately hoping for access to reliable health information as she had received no sex education at school. Imani hailed from the Black community in North Nashville and attended an underfunded school with a dismal graduation rate, worlds away from my hometown in a suburban immigrant enclave with excellent public schools. I left my shift that day determined to share the knowledge I had with those that had not received the same opportunities. For Imani and others like her, I am passionate about improving access to reproductive healthcare education for vulnerable communities. To pursue this mission, I developed a series of sexual and reproductive health educational workshops for women in rural India. I hope to learn to employ education to ameliorate reproductive health disparities at Rush.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Araavani. This Tamil term for gender and sexual minorities is embedded in the colorful mosaic of my existence. Bridging my identities as a queer brown woman has shaped my awareness of how systems of inequality intersect. It was this understanding I called upon when Claire, my classmate who recently came out as trans to her Korean parents, confided in me that she had nowhere to go home for the summer. Accounting for her undocumented immigration status, I was able to find transitional housing for her through a nonprofit that did not require identification for services. It was with individuals like Claire in mind that I founded Queer & Asian, an affinity group at Vanderbilt that cultivated intersectional dialogue on campus. I continue to contribute to my community by volunteering with LGBTQ+ teens experiencing homelessness in Chicago. I hope to apply my perspective to equitably serve patients of all backgrounds with an understanding of how structural barriers affect their health.
7_-_COVID_Impact: When COVID-19 swept the world in 2020, I was taking a medical leave of absence from college to recover physically and emotionally from the toll of ovarian cancer. I had been volunteering as an EMT and participating in a survivorship rehabilitation program, both of which were abruptly halted due to the pandemic. I adapted to these unprecedented challenges by shifting to a successful self-directed recovery plan and delving deeply into independent projects that could be pursued remotely. One such endeavor was developing educational workshops about sexual and reproductive health for women in rural India with limited access to resources in this area. The pandemic shaped my views on the vital importance of public health education as a critical part of patient understanding and confidence when interacting with health systems. As an aspiring physician, I am committed to employing health education to rectify the health inequities exacerbated by COVID-19.

personal_statement:
As I walked by the line of hundreds of residents of Choluteca, Honduras – some of whom walked miles in the sweltering heat – I did not know what to expect. With my packet of Spanish medical phrases in hand, I smiled at the first family as they walked into the classroom-turned-temporary triage center. The mother smiled back as she tried to get her bickering children to settle down; a scene reminiscent of my own mother trying to manage my siblings and me. As my anxiety started to dissipate, I began to wonder what more I had in common with the residents of Choluteca.
What brought me to Choluteca – and has led me to many novel experiences – was a sense of curiosity present since my childhood. Growing up, I would constantly ask my parents “why,” quickly followed by “how.” I still strive to understand how the world around me works at both the macro- and micro-level, leading me to pursue biology and psychology. The more I tried to answer my questions, the more new ones arose, and the further enthralled I became. My passion for human connection has always been salient as well, causing me to explore new spaces at an early age, from volunteering at an inner-city elementary school throughout middle and high school, to going on my first service trip to Tobatí, Paraguay, at age fifteen with a school organization. On the trip, a student suffered from heat stroke and was immediately seen by the organization's paramedics. Fortunately, he made a quick recovery, but I wondered what the locals would do during medical emergencies in the remote areas of Tobatí without on-site paramedics or a hospital nearby.
My volunteer experience in Paraguay opened my eyes to the differences in healthcare access around the world, leading me to seek out more opportunities to learn about and help mend this gap. My answer was found in college through Global Medical Brigades, which landed me in Honduras. After a bumpy two-hour bus ride from the capital city, we had arrived in Choluteca, a rural town where healthcare is not easily accessible. I worked diligently in the clinic to assist both patients and local doctors. In my free time, I would play with the children who gathered in the schoolyard. We played pattycake and tag, or “lanza,” as the children called it, using a mixture of Spanish, English, and gestures to overcome the language barrier. However, we did not convene at the elementary school to play games – that was just a bonus. We were there because we shared a common value: equal access to healthcare.
Back at home, I was still drawn to community engagement in medicine, and I began volunteering at Rainbow Babies & Children’s Hospital in Cleveland. While I was unable to assist doctors in a hands-on way as I did in Honduras, I was able to provide a different resource important to medicine: comfort. Volunteering at the hospital taught me that it is sometimes the little things, such as offering an extra toy car, keeping a patient company at bedside while watching a movie together, or offering a tired parent a coffee break, that truly leave an impact on the patient and their family’s stay. I discovered that there is more to patient care than just treating physical ailments, and seeing the patients smile as their attention moved away from their pain and onto the games we were playing assured me that I am on the correct path.
While my time at the hospital has been incredibly fulfilling, this did not mean that healthcare disparities reminiscent of those I witnessed abroad were not present. One memorable instance was a volunteer experience with a Spanish-speaking mother and daughter. Recalling the Spanish I learned from school as well as from my trips to Honduras and Paraguay, I was able to converse with the family. Despite my broken Spanish, the mother was relieved to have someone to talk to, and her initially shy daughter eventually became comfortable enough to engage in play when she realized that she could enjoy herself without the burden of language confusion. However, she clutched onto her mother when the doctor returned and began delivering important recovery details in English. At the end of the instructions, the doctor and mother exchanged an “Okay,” and the doctor quickly left. Knowing her language abilities, I asked in Spanish if she understood, to which she replied “No.” I translated the doctor's message, but was left unsatisfied as my childhood curiosity prompted me with a myriad of questions. Why was the message delivered in English to a known Spanish-speaker? Why wasn’t the hospital’s translation system used? How have instances like this affected patients’ health outcomes thus far? This experience was a rude awakening to the ways in which marginalized groups are often overlooked in healthcare.
However, rather than harboring negative feelings towards the healthcare system, this experience further invigorated me to pursue a career in medicine. Many minorities and underrepresented groups unfairly have poorer health outcomes due to unequal care, and, as I have seen through my travels, everyone deserves the opportunity of good health – including families like the one I met in Choluteca. Now I have a newfound sense of determination, as my goal is not only to help others, but to use medicine as a gateway for change and equality.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: In Design For America (DFA), a student organization that aims to ameliorate community-identified issues, my team worked with our county‚Äôs board of developmental disabilities to create an inclusive events calendar tailored for use by individuals with developmental disabilities (DDs). As DFA champions human-centered design, my team connected with individuals in the DD community through surveys, interviews, and prototype testing. In doing so, we listened to their stories, learned about accessibility challenges, observed their experiences with the product, and integrated their feedback and critiques to improve design. As I modified the initial prototype to prioritize the needs and preferences of individuals in the DD community, I gained insight into how different experiences affect the way we interact with our environments. Empathy, flexibility, and willingness to simply listen to those being served is crucial in providing optimal and equitable outcomes in diverse populations.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: While in college, I was a leader in Horizons, a mentorship program that inspires Cleveland high school students, predominantly from minority and low income communities, to explore their medical aspirations. As President, I helped design and facilitate sessions for students to explore medicine, from learning about organ systems through real cadaver organs, to a career fair for healthcare providers to lead hands-on activities in their fields. Other sessions involved seminar-style team-based learning, such as discussing medical case studies. It was rewarding to witness the program triple in size throughout my four years as a member, and to see Horizons instill a passion to pursue future careers in medicine in an increasing number of students. As a person of color, providing equitable care includes combating barriers of entry to increase representation within healthcare, and I was honored to provide high school students in my community with exposure, experience, and support as a mentor.

personal_statement:
In October 2005, I sat in a hotel room in Houston, Texas, and I scrolled through various news channels that flashed images of the devastation and flooding resulting from Hurricane Katrina. At that time, for my family, the state of our home in New Orleans, Louisiana, was the least of our concerns. "He's running out of insulin and needs dialysis," was what I overheard my grandmother whisper to my Mom in the bathroom. At the age of 6, I was not sure what insulin or dialysis was, but by the look on my Mom's face, I knew my grandfather was in trouble. Over the years, I had helped my grandfather, a type II diabetic, take his medications every morning, prep his insulin shots, and rode in the car as my grandmother brought him to dialysis. However, that morning he had only one pill left, his insulin syringe was only halfway filled, and we didn't go on our morning trip to dialysis. Displaced by the hurricane with limited access to consistent healthcare or medications, his blood sugar levels rose, and his kidney function declined. 
When my family moved back to New Orleans, it was difficult for my grandfather to find a doctor where he could reestablish care. Additionally, resources such as insulin and other medications were scarce. Without adequate care, my grandfather's health worsened. Within months, he lost his eyesight, had both legs amputated, and eventually had triple bypass heart surgery. Internalizing the impact diabetes and the inconsistent access to healthcare had on my grandfather kickstarted my interest in medicine. 
    Years later, I learned that my grandfather's experiences with difficulty accessing medications, dialysis, and healthcare providers were not unique. New Orleans has a predominantly black population, and most of this population suffers from diabetes. Hurricane Katrina exposed the insufficiency of healthcare resource allocation and disproportionately impacted this vulnerable population. This reality inspired me to take an interest in treating these vulnerable populations in hopes of improving the care for our country's underserved communities. 
     Learning about the healthcare barriers in a low socioeconomic city of New Orleans, I developed an interest in exploring the effect of decreased health literacy and access to healthcare on patients' experience with the healthcare system. Exploring this new interest, I started to work as a medical scribe in a medically underserved area. While working in the urgent care one morning, I grabbed my laptop and followed Dr. David as the nurse called from room 3, "Dr. David, come quickly." We entered the room where Ms. Ruth had an abscess to her buttocks. She was tachycardic and tachypneic, had a weak pulse, cold, clammy skin, and her blood sugar was 452. "Call 911. She's in septic shock". My role in the clinic, when needed, was more than just a scribe. I dropped my computer and helped the nurse gather IV bags, get the EKG machine, and other materials to help prep for the arrival of the ambulance. Dr. David explained that since she had diabetes, she was more inclined to develop an abscess and that the bacteria from the abscess had most likely entered her bloodstream. We followed up on her hospital report later and discovered that Ms. Ruth had passed away in the hospital. I wondered if she had come in sooner, could the spread of the infection have been prevented. Would she still be alive if she had known that she was more predisposed to abscesses? This experience deepened my motivation to understand the role that public health and health education play in the outcome of patients. 
      A few months later, while volunteering at Harbor Grace Hospice, I was responsible for caring for Mr. Clyde, who had stage 4 colon cancer. During our visits, we watched movies, and I assisted him within the scope of my ability. Our relationship grew over the next few weeks of me fluffing his pillow or changing his sheets. Mr. Clyde began to open up to me and share details of his life. He talked about missing his deceased wife, who used to care for him, and his spiritual feelings and struggle with accepting his next phase in life. I listened with an open mind, and we developed a deep connection through our conversations and time together. Our visits were when he could ease his mind and process his thoughts and emotions. Through conversing, he became visibly more at ease with each interaction. This experience solidified my decision to pursue medicine as I saw the importance of empathetic and supportive care and acknowledging patient concerns. As a physician, I will strive to build communication and trust with my patients to make them feel seen and heard.  
     The culmination of my personal and healthcare experiences shaped my decision to be a physician. My journey, beginning with my grandfather, has constantly reminded me of my goal: to minimize healthcare disparities in marginalized and minority groups. I hope to provide care to all regardless of race, culture, or health literacy and lessen the socioeconomic barriers to equitable health. I used to live in fear as diabetes slowly took over my grandfather's life. As a physician, I hope to advocate, heal, and educate my patients through culturally competent care, so they never have to experience that fear.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
In college, I took an audiology class in which I learned the alphabet and a few basic phrases in American Sign Language._x000D_
 One week, multiple deaf speakers attended lecture to share their experiences. I spoke with one speaker, Amy, who had a cochlear implant, and I thanked her for being able to share her story. As I said "share," she motioned to the chair beside us. I realized she was lipreading to understand me, and saying "share" looked like "chair." I then fingerspelled "share" to help her. This interaction allowed me to explore a new form of communication and, therefore, better appreciate and understand the unique circumstances of others. I learned how meeting people different from myself is crucial for encountering new cultures and perspectives. _x000D_
	My experience learning about the deaf community has taught me to collaborate with and support diverse groups, a perspective I will share with my classmates at Rush University.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
During my senior year, I started "Groundskeepers," which aimed to promote and educate about social justice on my team and within the Charlottesville community. A week before I moved into my freshman dorm, racially motivated violence took over the grounds of UVA and Charlottesville. "Groundskeepers" worked to establish that those events were not representative of Charlottesville and were not tolerated in the community. I helped to organize walks across the city and campus to remember Heather Heyer, who was killed during the violence, and bring awareness to UVA's history of slavery. I led discussions with my team about racial inequality. I also advocated for lacrosse clinics for lower socioeconomic groups in Charlottesville to increase access to lacrosse in these groups and hopefully increase the representation of minority groups in lacrosse. _x000D_
I hope to use my experience leading change in the Charlottesville and lacrosse communities to improve the health of the Chicago residents.
7_-_COVID_Impact: During the summer of 2020, I planned to work as a medical scribe and participate in research with my biochemistry professor. Unfortunately, both opportunities were canceled due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Since I would not be scribing or doing research, I contacted volunteer organizations looking for ways to get involved, and I began volunteering at Partners for Home in June 2020. On my first day, I grabbed a box of meals and set out to distribute food to homeless individuals in my territory. From there, I developed our COVID-19 education and vaccination program, which helps the homeless population stay up-to-date on variants and the spread of COVID-19 and provides access to the vaccines. I became passionate about providing necessary resources and vaccines and educating these homeless individuals on methods to keep them safe. Most importantly, this opportunity inspired me to one day weave community outreach and health education into my future as a physician.

personal_statement:
With my legs shifting nervously on top of the crinkly table paper, I waited for Dr. Sanders to enter the examination room. The doorknob creaked and her eyes met mine, fraught with concern. My mother trailed behind her and laid a reassuring hand on my shoulder. “Your heart is not doing well,” Dr. Sanders explained gently. “Your body is breaking down the muscle to get the energy it needs.” As if on cue, my heart began to race as I realized that my unassuming GI visit had become an intervention.

In a hospital bed just hours later, I stewed in unease. The diagnosis on my chart felt like a warrant for my arrest, evoking suspicious looks from hospital staff as I ate or used the restroom. I initially resisted treatment, viewing my clinicians as my adversaries. Yet during weekly visits to the eating disorder program, Dr. Sanders treated me with the same genuine respect and compassion she provided adult patients. Her comforting “How are you feeling?” opening each visit was not a pleasantry, but an invitation to unpack the complex emotions I felt. She worked with me to build a meal plan suited to my interests after learning about my distaste for the hospital’s quiche. She inquired about my siblings and my dreams for the future. These subtleties revealed that to her I was more than my case history; first and foremost, I was a human being. With humility, she forged a trusting relationship that encouraged me to commit to recovery and adopt lifelong coping skills. Over a decade after overcoming this challenge, I maintain contact with Dr. Sanders and she is my role model and the type of physician I aspire to be. She treated me with humanity at a time in my life when stigma threatened to define me.

My mind often returns to this moment, especially when I think of my brother. Not everyone is as lucky as I was to have a strong relationship with a provider or attain recovery. Though physicians can work to combat their own internal biases, they cannot always protect patients from stigma outside the bubble of their office. In and out of treatment for substance abuse since early adolescence, my brother bore the burden of stigma around addiction. Relatives questioned the cause of his deviant behavior and sought to punish him for a perceived lack of discipline. Yet ultimately what I saw before me was a child seeking to relieve his burgeoning anxiety. It stung to see others strip him of his humanity the second they labeled him as an addict instead of a person struggling with addiction.

Seeing the vitriol directed at my brother ignited a fire in me to prevent others from experiencing the same injustice. As a mentor for Cayuga Heights Elementary school students, I practiced the skills of listening, and more importantly, cultural humility. Though I could not fully understand the life experiences of the third-grader whose family dealt with poverty and housing instability, I could listen to her story, appreciate her incredible resilience, and learn from her curiosity. As we drew pictures or learned about Earth Day, I recognized that my official role as a mentor was far less important than my implicit role as a trusted adult companion. At Cayuga Medical Center, though I could not relate to the challenges of incarceration, I could treat the young men from the local youth detention facility with respect when they arrived for weekly COVID testing. Each week spent conversing and commiserating about the blistery Ithaca weather taught me that each of them, like my brother, is a human being with a rich background and wisdom to impart. 

I will carry my passion for exploring the intersection of medicine, stigma, and substance use with me into my future clinical research and practice. At Cornell, I work with Dr. Ezell to interview and understand the lived experiences of racial and ethnic minorities who use opioids in rural New York. As a physician, I will continue to advocate for people experiencing addiction and treat them with the dignity they deserve at the bedside. My drive to diminish barriers to care among racial and ethnic minorities also stems from my background–my mother is Puerto Rican, and the distrust of medicine often shared in her culture frequently prevents her from seeking medical care. Through my upbringing and research, I have gained empathy for those who distrust Western medicine. With mutual communication and honesty, I will provide all patients with the excellent care they deserve.
Combining my passions for health equity, addiction recovery advocacy, and pediatric care, I want to go to medical school to build a strong foundation in patient-centered healthcare upon which I can forge relationships with patients as Dr. Sanders did with me. Leveraging my social capital as a physician, I will help all patients, especially those from vulnerable and underserved populations, enjoy better health. Stigma prevents many people from receiving quality healthcare and young patients from having honest communication with their healthcare team. With the knowledge of the human body and the privilege of leadership I will have as a physician, I can better advocate for patients and work alongside them to navigate their health concerns.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Raised by a Puerto Rican mother with a commitment to familismo, familial interdependence, I am sensitive to cultural differences that impact healthcare access. My grandmother, valuing time with her children over what she viewed as an impersonal healthcare environment, spent her final months with leukemia at home instead of receiving care. Similarly, my mother often delays medical care to care for her children and prefers to make collective medical decisions. My experiences have revealed that unilateral healthcare decision-making can often cause undue suffering. Understanding the complexity of values surrounding healthcare, particularly among minorities, affords me a unique perspective that allows me to practice shared decision-making to honor patients‚Äô values. Today, driven to reduce health disparities, I conduct research about opioid use among racial/ethnic minorities in rural NY, gaining an invaluable population health perspective that contextualizes my clinical interactions.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
At the start of the pandemic, I was unsettled by the inequitable access to COVID-19 testing. Living in Ithaca, where nearly 40 percent of residents live below the poverty line and many are unhoused, I was especially troubled by this disparity, recognizing the increased chance of community spread in Ithaca‚Äôs unhoused encampments. I began working at Cayuga Medical Center‚Äôs site to provide city-subsidized testing to everyone regardless of insurance status._x000D_
_x000D_
Though the testing site was a drive-through location, many patients arrived by foot. Thus, my coworkers and I devised a workflow that allowed one of us to serve these patients while others continued to assist patients in vehicles. Without adjusting our care delivery, testing would have been limited to those who could afford a vehicle or taxi service. I have learned that small adjustments, accomplished through self-reflection and humility, can significantly improve the inclusivity of healthcare.

personal_statement:
"One, two, three … six more to go." I surveyed the big parking lot, searching for my targets. I was doing my usual volunteer task at the Cleveland Clinic: collecting wheelchairs that patients left when discharged from the hospital. Yet that day, I noticed an elderly woman standing by herself, in the corner of the parking lot, holding onto an IV pole, and she seemed lost. When I asked if she needed any help, she tried to speak, but words didn't come out; instead her plaintive voice turned into a low mumble. Suddenly, grabbing my arm tightly, she looked me in the eye. At that moment, I knew that, bewildered and distressed, she required immediate attention. Holding my arm up to support the woman, I called my supervisor, who quickly arrived with the EMS crew to escort the woman to the ER. Later, telling me that the woman had experienced acute chest pain when she had left the hospital, my supervisor commended my timely discovery and reaction, so that the woman did not have any significant aftereffects. Thanks to those words of praise, though only a volunteer who carried out a minor duty, I viewed myself as an essential part of a team that responded to and relieved the pain and suffering of a helpless patient with care, promptness, and efficacy.
My volunteering experiences motivated me to seek a better understanding of patient care and encouraged me to become more involved in the medical field. As I shadowed Dr. Chiang in the Sleep Medicine Clinic of the University Hospital, I discovered that being a physician entails far more than prescribing drugs and providing treatment. One day, we saw a follow-up visiting patient for sleep apnea and sleepiness during the day. The patient explained that the prescribed CPAP machine was not working and requested Provigil, a drug to treat excessive sleepiness but with serious side effects. The data from the CPAP machine, however, showed that the patient's sleep apnea was well under control. Dr. Chiang asked if I understood this confusing situation; and when I considered it from the patient's perspective, suddenly everything became clear to me. For a truck driver, sleepiness during the day would hurt his performance and result in decreased safety, which might cause the patient to lose his job, and thus the patient wanted Provigil to remove his sleepiness quickly. Dr. Chiang explained to the patient that Provigil could lead to sleep insomnia, which would worsen his sleeping, and reassured him that the CPAP machine treated his sleep apnea effectively so that he would feel much more energetic and would not lose his job. The patient expressed gratitude both for the medical care that he had received and for the empathetic concern with which it had been delivered. Witnessing Dr. Chiang's impact on the patient, I realized the importance of building connections with patients through an understanding of and regard for their individual thoughts, worries, and circumstances.
My effort to comprehend the methods and conditions that make for effective patient care not only involves direct interaction with patients but also sparks my interest in translational research. Dr. Monnier's research on drug development for age-related cataract caught my attention. My grandmother suffers from this infirmity, but the only treatment has been surgery, which is too risky for someone her age. I joined Dr. Monnier's lab to develop drugs to cure age-related cataract in elderly patients like my grandmother. I started by learning everything from scratch and working on the research project with no postdocs to follow, because Dr. Monnier hoped I could think as a researcher instead of blindly following him. From reading papers, designing experiments, communicating with lab colleagues, and presenting results in lab meetings, I discovered how to behave as a professional researcher. I would spend days reading papers to create the most promising research sets and nights in the lab removing lenses from the eyes of mice and culturing them. Then I would devote an equal amount of time and scrutiny to revise and restructure the experiments when they failed. Yet it was these repetitive procedures that led to discoveries and progress in the project. The iterative process that characterizes rigorous and effective research, I learned, is essential to advancements in the treatment of disease and improved patient care.
As I have continued on my path toward medicine, I have often reminded myself of the people I saw, served, and helped – the lonely woman in the parking lot, the truck driver fearful of losing his job, and the elderly patients plagued by age-related cataract. Like most patients, they were ordinary people who encountered a health crisis and thus required attention, an understating of their circumstances, and skilled care. Solicitude for individual patients in need is what motivates me to pursue medicine. I want to connect with, tend to, and advocate for people like them as a future physician.
