1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I participated in the TRIO program where I shared my road to college and advised on building a college application for Cleveland local high school students. During the Q&A session, I noticed that some students were more interested in tuition and financial aid, while I focused on professional development when I was applying. One of them shared that she had brothers and sisters to take care of. Thus, she preferred a college nearby with abundant work-study programs. Another disclosed that since his family did not support him attend college, tuition and financial aids would determine whether he could pay for college himself. Listening to their stories, I realized I had given suggestions from my perspectives. I was grateful that the students entrusted me with their private matters and help me understand their backgrounds. Now, I could offer advice to meet their actual needs. From the experience, I learned to think in other‚Äôs shoes, listen to their needs before I offer advice and help.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
As an Orientation Leader, I once led a group activity to decide whether statements associated with sexual violence and misconduct were a myth or fact. One statement said that if someone dressed provocatively or walked alone, they were responsible for unwanted sexual advances. One group member claimed that because someone chose to perform risky behaviors, they were responsible for the consequences._x000D_
I stood up to address the issue. I explained to the group that victim-blaming attitudes encourage rape culture and sexual violence. By blaming the victim, we alienated the victims and normalized sexual misconduct and abusers‚Äô actions. I encouraged the group to take action when facing discrimination like this. _x000D_
After the event, I reached out to the group member privately. He admitted that he overlooked the issue and came to understand the importance of combating victim-blaming. I‚Äôm glad that I changed his thought and promoted inclusiveness among the group._x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact: All the hospitals nearby closed their volunteer programs during the pandemic. I lost the chance to gain more experience and was unable to support the patients and my fellow healthcare workers during this difficult time. Yet I was grateful to continue my education with support from my family. Thus, I determined to find other ways to support those who were more affected. I joined the Physical Resource Center, a store created to offer free essentials to our hard-hit neighbors in the pandemic. I became the co-personnel manager to solve the issue of shortage in volunteers. In addition, I reached out to our faculty advisor to initiate connections with local organizations to increase our visibility and offer our resources to more people who were in need. We delivered essentials, including food, sanitation supplies, clothes, and furniture to the greater Cleveland community. The experience strived me more to ensuring accessibility and equality of resources for the vulnerable population.

Under_School: The Ohio State University Main Campus
personal_statement:
At the age of 10, I vividly recall bawling my eyes out when my parents told me we were moving again. Before settling in San Antonio, Texas, we lived in New York, Michigan, Colorado, Minnesota, and Canada. I never fully understood that every move was necessary for my father to further his medical career. Being a foreign medical graduate, he was required to repeat a decade of medical training to be able to practice in the US. Every year throughout elementary and middle school, I found myself at a new school in a new state, always managing to make new friends within a few days. While some may attribute our numerous moves as a lack of stability, I embraced them as lessons on flexibility. I learned to connect with people quickly and adjust to new environments. My parents recognized this adaptability, making them feel comfortable with my decision to graduate high school early and move out for college at 16. Alone, I moved from Texas to Ohio, where I spent a year earning my associate degree before transferring to The Ohio State University.

 Being born and raised in America while living in a Muslim Egyptian household, I lived in what felt like two completely different worlds.  From my parents, I learned what it's like to grow up in an impoverished village in Egypt. From my peers, I’d learned about Christmas, and Halloween- festivities I wasn’t able to partake in because it wasn’t a part of my culture. I felt conflicted between my household eastern values and the western values I absorbed from the world around me. It wasn’t until high school that I started to understand my identity as a first generation American, that I have the privilege of benefitting from the richness of various cultures.

My high school class consisted of around 100 students with unique, diverse backgrounds, including Asians, Europeans, Latinos, and others. Socializing with such a heterogeneous group encouraged me to embrace my roots and come to terms with my Egyptian-American identity. It was through my friends that I was able to learn about many different cultures and traditions. This exposure broadened my perspective, helping me better connect and relate with people less familiar with American culture throughout college.

 Our capacity to understand one another's point of view is crucial in our ability to connect with each other. I have seen loved ones suffer from addiction, as well as mental and physical health issues. I have witnessed how people can struggle within unfortunate circumstances, and I acknowledge that these are universal human problems. Being close to these issues helps me truly understand and empathize with other people’s hardships. The study of medicine is the study of these struggles. Physicians study the human body and mind in order to ease the struggles of our fellow humans, and I can’t think of a field more deserving of my resources.

Throughout much of grade school, whenever I saw one of my classmates struggling with a concept that I mastered, I’d jump at the opportunity to explain it to them using an alternative method. Seeing a wave of clarity wash across a friend’s face as I explained a concept to them was fulfilling, which is why volunteering as a tutor was one of the most rewarding experiences I've done. I was seventeen years old in my second year of college, working with a community center for refugees, teaching high school students, not much younger than me, science and math. Whenever I helped a student think in a different way in order to better comprehend a problem or concept, I was always reminded of the fulfillment that came along with watching the gears turn in their head. I was proud of myself for helping someone overcome their struggle, and of the student for caring enough to learn.

Growing up, I lived at my father’s fertility clinic. I observed and performed back-office operations necessary for quality patient care. It was inspiring to see a newfound ease sweep across a patient’s face when my father simplified the complex science behind their medical issues. While medical students did rotations with him, I'd join their discussions to learn alongside them. The natural comfort and curiosity I felt in these discussions reassured me that I'd be interested in the content I will be studying in medical school and beyond.

Regardless of what city we were jumping into, I’ve been surrounded by medicine from an early age. However, it wasn’t until my last year of college that I realized I was on this path for the wrong reasons. Although I enjoyed the medical related content in my classes, ultimately I planned on being a doctor because it was what I’ve been pushed toward. When I came face to face with this realization, it made me contemplate my choices. The lessons we internalize from our life experiences are what shape who we are. After reflecting on my past, and pondering the future, it registered that my desire to be a physician doesn’t stem from others' expectations of me, but rather it is rooted in my core values. I feel an electric excitement at the prospect of knowing the inner workings of the human body, and being able to utilize this knowledge to positively impact those around me, whether that impact is treating patients, teaching others, or inspiring someone to be better.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
_x000D_
I was visiting Texas one summer, and I had a long uber drive with a friendly, talkative driver. He was an older white man in his 60‚Äôs, without much formal education. After getting to know each other better, he brought up some conspiracy theories he believed in. I initially thought he was just a crazy old man, but I inquired about his beliefs and heard him out, realizing that his ill-informed beliefs stemmed from a lack of education. He was suspicious of the COVID pandemic because if you look at lysol from decades ago, it would mention coronavirus on the packaging. I realized that he didn‚Äôt know that coronavirus is a family, not a specific disease. My background in medicine and biology made this fact obvious to me, but how could someone without the proper scientific knowledge have known? This encounter encouraged me to reflect on how my privileged background affects my perspective, and stay conscious of how other‚Äôs unique life experiences result in their point of view. _x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I was 17 years old during my second year at Ohio State University when I joined the Students for Refugees club, where I was able to connect with a local community center and started tutoring highschool students. This center provided tutoring services for students of all ages, who were mostly children of African immigrants. Being not much older than them, and also the son of muslim immigrants, I was able to relate to many of them closely, making them feel more comfortable and willing to listen and work with me. Through this experience, I realized that the best way to teach material is to understand how a student thinks, and then deliver the content in a way that is compatible with the student‚Äôs thought process. In order to effectively teach my students, I had to understand them. Whenever I was successfully able to teach a student how to think meta-cognitively about their studies, I would see them become more self-confident in their ability to learn.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Adjusting to COVID was a rough transition, as staying home daily hindered opportunity to connect with my peers and professors. Many students fell behind due to virtual learning, and while I did not feel I was obtaining the same quality education and experience, I was stayed consistent by keeping myself on an organized schedule so I wouldn‚Äôt fall behind my classes.  During this time, I kept my social life from wavering by connecting with old friends and new classmates via group chat apps and gaming. COVID also made my tutoring program switch to virtual sessions, which felt less personal, and more difficult to teach and connect with our students. It was also difficult to know where to find safe, impactful opportunities, especially when COVID initially struck and there was little known about its severity and infectivity.. During this time, I started to practice yoga and meditation by watching videos and reading online, and I found that this greatly helped my mental and physical health

Hrdshp_Comments: Growing up in a single-parent household with my mom and younger sisters, it was often difficult to manage our finances and bills. I began to work in high school to help out, and my work obligations took up much of my time which led to my grades slipping. Although my education was very important to me, I found it difficult to balance my responsibilities to help out financially, with my academic work. While applying to college, I knew that many of the opportunities and experiences would not be available to me if I had to continue working as much to fund my education. As a result, I applied to as many scholarships as I could find, and was fortunate to receive enough funding to cover my costs. While I no longer had to work, I had to still help out my mom with picking up/dropping off and babysitting my younger sister while I did my coursework. I had to dedicate a lot of time to this, but I was able to use my previous experiences with my job to work on my time management. My experience with funding my education and seeking out these opportunities to continue my growth as a student, as well as look after my youngest sister, is a testament to my perseverance and self-motivation, and I am very happy to be working towards completing my degree in Neuroscience.
personal_statement:
“Please, don’t worry” 

Looking my tia in her eyes, I gently squeeze her hand, as the once silent room erupts in agonized protest. 

My tia was born with a congenital heart defect that required her to undergo multiple open-heart surgeries. Every time she had to go to the hospital, our worry about her health was compounded by the reality that she did not have healthcare. The irony of my sick tia asking us not to worry about her health was overshadowed by the reality that we did have to worry, since we were limited in finding her the best care because of her lack of healthcare coverage. 

My experience with my tia drove me to work with other underprivileged Latino individuals, so I joined Consejo. As part of the Consejo team, I worked intimately with individuals suffering from Substance-Use Disorders and Mental Health illnesses. I met “Jane” who was a young, single mother struggling with addiction. As I formed a deeper connection with Jane, she told me about her lack of healthcare coverage, which greatly affected her chemical dependency treatment program options. She shared with me how this led to difficulty for her to find accessible jobs in her own city, so that she could begin to regain custody of her children. Realizing this lack of resource for our clients to re-integrate after court-ordered treatment programs, I created the official youth resources brochure for our organization that outlines opportunities to get involved in the community. Working closely with Jane led me to realize my passion for having a more direct role in patient care, and work closely with patients. 

Interested in continuing my work with individuals from my own community and other underserved populations, I shadowed at the newly formed Latinx Diabetes Institute to gain a further understanding of the role and responsibilities of a doctor. While shadowing Dr. Alarcon-Casas Wright, I witnessed many Latinx diabetes patients who required further education on their condition. One particular Latina patient mentioned that while her diabetes education classes were informative, much of the advice was impractical for her. Interested, I asked her to elaborate on what that meant. She pointed out to me that she couldn’t afford to buy many of the foods she was advised to eat, and had only heard about certain foods for the first time at a nutrition class.  

After meeting with the patient, Dr. Alarcon-Casas Wright further informed me about the prevalence of diabetes in the Latinx population, and pointed me towards papers and articles that I read to further my understanding. This experience made me realize the importance of culturally informed physicians and treatment plans, and inspired me to continue my work with these more marginalized populations that did not have access to as many medical resources due to their cultural and socioeconomic background. While shadowing Dr. Alarcon-Casas Wright and reading further about diabetes advances, my appreciation for medical research began to grow. 

Since my tia had many health issues associated with her congenital heart disease, I spent many hours with her,  pouring over scientific articles detailing the future of medical advances in cardiology and constantly letting her know about anything new I had read. My interest in these scientific advances in medical treatments grew as I spent more time researching my tia’s own medical issues. With a passion for research, and advancing our knowledge of diseases and treatment, I joined a research lab studying debilitating retinal degenerative diseases such as Age-Related Macular Degeneration, which is present in my family. While working in the lab, I developed my perseverance and tenacity as I analyzed papers and extracted critical information, constantly looking for more to learn, and growing as an independent and critical thinker. Based on the papers I read, I independently designed a project aimed at further characterizing the complement system in retinal pigment epithelium cells (RPE). From my results, I continued to develop and expand my project, and received fellowships that funded my work. Working on my research project allowed me to recognize and appreciate the ever-evolving nature of medicine. 

In my career, I aspire to continue working to advance the field of medicine, contributing to novel treatments, and providing culturally informed care directly to patients. Becoming a physician allows me to combine my passions perfectly: to be an instrument of change through advocacy, research, and direct care. My passion for medicine stems from a desire to work closely with underserved populations, and provide essential healthcare services. While healthcare coverage was something my family had to worry about, I am driven to become a physician that provides care to all, regardless of gender, socioeconomic, or cultural identification, and serve as a change-maker to ensure everyone has access to the best quality care.

My journey has prepared me and solidified my passion for a career in medicine, and given me the opportunity to have unique experiences that inform my role as a compassionate carer. Therefore, I strive to become a physician practicing with complete dedication, providing the best care possible as a scientist, leader, and caretaker.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: At Consejo, I work closely with youth clients that have a substance-use disorder that come from very diverse backgrounds. One client I worked with was a young Native American female who was a single-parent. As I did not share a similar background, I found it more difficult to give her specific information about opportunities. As a result, I asked for permission to sit-in on a treatment session to gain a better insight into her interests and struggles. This led to me gaining a greater understanding of her background and experiences, and I was able to help connect her with resources. This experience enhanced my ability to understand those from different backgrounds by emphasizing the importance of a growth mindset. I learned that to empathize with the client, I had to actively listen and acknowledge her journey and perspective. I also learned about the importance of thorough care for each individual, in the context of their background and experiences.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As a volunteer with the youth program in Consejo, I met a young adult who struggled heavily with substance-use disorders, who shared with me his identification with the LGBTQ community. Indicating that he was unable to share this part of his identity with his family, this frustration often manifested in behavioral issues, and increased substance use. Although I personally lacked the training to help this client most efficiently, and our organization did not have resources for LGBTQ, I set out to contact organizations in the area that worked with LGBTQ youth, serving as an advocate for this client. Working closely with him, I helped him navigate the resources and find a support system that fit all his needs. To prevent such a challenge in the future while helping LGBTQ clients, I reached out to local organizations and streamlined our services so we would work collaboratively. In my role as an advocate for one individual, I was able to better our resources for a community.

Hrdshp_Comments: Both of my parents have severe health problems, which required me to take on more responsibilities at home. My mother could not work for long periods of time because of her health conditions, namely lupus, and had to stay at home. She also had open-heart surgery about a year ago. During her recovery period, I cared for my sister, helped with her homework, and drove her to and from school because my dad’s hours were cut during the pandemic, and could not afford to take extra time off work to perform these duties. Furthermore, my father was recently diagnosed with heart problems and an eye condition that weakened his vision and required him to get frequent eye shots, which prevented him from driving. Due to this, I had to leave campus regularly throughout the school year in order to take him to and from his doctor’s appointments.
personal_statement:
“Only 5 hours left,” I thought to myself as I waited alone in front of my mom’s operation room. 

Over the past few years, my mom could not complete daily tasks without constantly feeling bouts of pain. A week earlier, she went in for a routine biannual angiogram, due to her lupus, but instead was admitted into the hospital for a triple bypass surgery. As the oldest child, I had to suppress my fear of losing my mom to stay levelheaded enough to console my 12-year-old sister and be someone my dad can rely on.

I was thankful to join my mom despite the hospital’s COVID visitor policy because it would have pained me to see her go through such a daunting experience alone as others, including my grandpa, did. I felt a sense of purpose and joy in seeing that simple gestures, like carrying her belongings or listening to her worries, comforted her.

The nurse took my mom to a cold, empty pre-operative room. I sat on a chair by my mom’s bed and held her hands, comforting her with my presence. She made me promise that if anything happened to her, I would make sure that my dad and sister both live well. The weight of that statement was heavy, but I assured her that I would do my best and smiled.

After five long hours, I got a call saying that my mom was out of surgery. A sense of relief washed over me, and I rushed to see her. She looked pale and exhausted and had tubes lodged in her throat and up her nose. None of that mattered because my mom was still alive. Witnessing the pain she felt before surgery and recognizing the loss that my family would have experienced if she had not received medical attention, I decided to become a doctor to ensure that others also have access to care.

Although my mom’s surgery influenced my decision to become a doctor, my appreciation for medicine existed for as long as I can remember. I became in charge of my parents' medications at a young age. I would organize their pills by color and size and toss them into their mouths, not knowing why or how they worked, nor understanding the responsibility I had at the time. All I knew was that they made my parents feel better. 

When I was six, my mom had a miscarriage. After sitting in on most of her appointments, I was devastated to hear that my unborn sister “had gone to a better place.” This experience made me abhor the idea of sickness and determined to fight it. Despite this, my mom’s doctor made us feel cared for. She held my mom’s hand and cried while delivering the news as if my sister was her own. I sensed the care and dedication this doctor put into her work and admired her for it. 

Shortly after, my mom got pregnant again. Thankfully, she was seen by a medical team that utilized the latest technology to help my mom give birth to my sister. I realized how fortunate we were to have access to care but also recognized that many others do not.

The moment I got the chance, I started volunteering at hospitals in the heart of Los Angeles to both learn more about medicine and give back. I got the opportunity to witness medical care during the pandemic. I saw illnesses that tormented patients and claimed people’s lives, especially during COVID. While completing simple tasks, like distributing water, joining rounds, or voicing patients’ concerns, I also saw how the medical team tirelessly collaborates to aid patients.

I was later selected to be an intern at a hospital. I remember calling a Spanish-speaking patient to confirm her appointment and realizing that nobody at the clinic knew enough Spanish to relay the message to her. I reached for a pen and paper and quickly wrote a script. Later, one of the nurses taped my script to the computer, so other staff members could utilize it in the future. Through this, I learned the importance of tailoring medical services to individual needs in order to make care accessible to people from different backgrounds, including non-English speakers of my own community.

This encounter emphasized that medicine is a profession built upon service. I realized that this patient, like many others, does not have access to basic resources, like medical care being readily available in the language she is most comfortable with. This motivated me to seek out ways to work with underserved communities to minimize the effects of existing language barriers. I became a peer-learning facilitator, providing academic support to students from underserved communities. I also mentored and provided free college-prep services to underprivileged Coptic students through the Coptic Education Foundation. These experiences not only allowed me to serve but to learn. I met a variety of people, who persisted through circumstances much more challenging than my own, inspiring me to remain resilient and optimistic unconditionally.

Although my initial perception of medicine as a child was naive, the experiences I have had, both circumstantially and voluntarily, have reinforced my passion for medicine. I want to serve people and improve their lives despite the odds stacked against them. I do not have the solution to every problem, but I am confident that with sincerity, determination, and compassion, one can provide quality care to others, regardless of who they are, and leave an impact on their lives.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
As an EMT, I transported an elderly hospice patient who wanted to spend his last days at home. Upon arrival at his home, I saw that about ten people shared the space and that our patient‚Äôs bedroom barely fit the gurney. As my partner and I were leaving, our patient‚Äôs wife asked me to read the instructions on his medicine bottles because she never learned how to read. I explained to her the instructions and waved goodbye as we walked out._x000D_
_x000D_
The fact that so many people shared the same space with our patient and that his wife did not know how to read demonstrates that there are societal issues, including health literacy, inadequate housing, and socioeconomic disparities, to be addressed in order to truly improve the quality of life of people from vulnerable backgrounds. Although I did not experience some of these circumstances, I empathized with our patient and became committed to addressing the educational and financial disparities that affect many members of our society since then.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
Pursuing higher education is a challenge for immigrants and students from low-income backgrounds. As the oldest child of immigrant parents, I felt lost navigating the admissions process, like many others. Due to my experiences and passion for increasing the representation of disadvantaged and minority students in higher education, I became a mentor with the Coptic Education Foundation. _x000D_
_x000D_
As a mentor, I direct students to tutoring services, counsel them, publicize scholarships opportunities, organize community service events, guide them through the college application process, and hold workshops tailored to their needs. We recently helped an orphaned teenager who immigrated with his disabled brother from Dubai alone get admitted into college. Through this experience, I learned the importance of dedicating services to specifically address the needs of disadvantaged communities to ensure that our community is equipped with resources to help its members realize their goals.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
During the pandemic, my parents experienced major health issues and my grandpa passed away.  causing me to take on more responsibilities at home, while balancing my academics, extracurriculars, and studying for the MCAT. When transitioning to in-person learning, my dad was diagnosed with an eye condition that required eye injections. I would regularly leave campus to drive him to his doctor‚Äôs appointments since he could not drive. This took time that I could have spent studying otherwise, which affected my academic performance. _x000D_
_x000D_
Also, the hospitals paused volunteer work, keeping me from dedicating as much time as I would have liked towards helping there. _x000D_
_x000D_
However, I believe that living through the pandemic had a silver lining because it challenged me to manage my time better and prepare for the unexpected. I also learned to establish boundaries between myself and others. I have learned to manage my stress and time better, and my grades are also exhibiting an upward trend currently.

personal_statement:
Mama, Phupu, Dada—my mother, aunt, and grandmother. These are the maternal figures who strengthened my ties to womanhood, the core of my earliest exposures to healthcare. Through their journeys, I experienced the fluctuating nature of medicine, whether it be relief in hearing my brother’s beating heart during Mama’s ultrasound, fear of a suspicious mass found in Phupu’s mammogram, or helplessness while watching Dada struggle to explain her arthritis pain in broken English. Although I was too young in these moments to resolve my mothers’ anxieties, the physicians managing their conditions could. They supported our family during times of grief and joy. Inspired by their comprehensive approach to address all aspects of my mothers’ medical concerns, I realized I also wanted to be a physician, providing holistic and personalized care to my patients and leveraging my own experiences as a woman to address any barriers they may face in accessing healthcare.

In college, I worked with an NGO, Paani, to distribute clean water to families in Pakistan. Although Paani’s focus was ensuring access to clean water in these villages, I was captivated by the struggles of their young women. A community of physicians were behind my mothers, but in Sindh, the lack of healthcare systems compounded with cultural and physical barriers compromised women’s health. I remember viscerally reacting as Uzma, a first-time mother, described using a damp cloth as a pad. Old biology lectures consumed me as I became fearful of her increased risk for vaginal infections. Uzma’s location impeded her access to alternative products and the social stigmas against menstruation also restricted Sindhi women like herself to more archaic practices. Even though Uzma and I were born in fundamentally different environments, the same South Asian stigmas governed me as well, prohibiting me from using tampons to preserve my hymen’s integrity. I realized I wanted to serve women in these Sindhi communities, not only because of our shared identity but a shared understanding of our struggle.

I quickly pushed Paani to expand their efforts to include women’s health, spearheading an initiative that paired each built well with feminine hygiene product distributions and an educational workshop detailing how to properly use those products. I remember calling into our first class and suddenly seeing my screen filled with women of all ages, eager to understand their own role in their health. This moment opened my eyes to the gap that existed in women’s health across the world, whether in the rural communities of Sindh or within the American healthcare system. I understood how vital it was for patients to be in control of their health and have someone understand their personal or religious choices when providing healthcare.

However, the more I worked to implement women-specific initiatives for Paani, the more I learned that the preventative measures I was creating were imperfect. No matter how many hygiene kits were provided, women were not immune to becoming sick. I met Asma, a young girl from Sindh, in pain and at risk for sepsis due to her untreated UTI. Unable to help, I realized that I didn’t want my aspirations in healthcare to stop at preventative measures—I desired the medical knowledge of a physician to provide care when those resources fell short.

With the struggle of patients like Asma ingrained in me, I sought out physicians who could guide me to become the doctor that I intended to be. Under the mentorship of Dr. Tasneem Bader, I watched her apply her medical expertise and foster strong relationships with all of her patients, a facet I hope to also implement when guiding treatment in my own practice. It was when a new patient, Hajra, came in for a routine physical, that I got to see how medicine involved not only the science of diseases but also the trauma underlying them. Hajra’s pap smear indicated mild dysplasia, not cancerous, but with the potential to be. In the weeks I spent finding her an OBGYN, I tried to place myself in her shoes, unable to imagine her fear of not being able to start a family. Fortunately, her pathology report did not indicate cancer, but as a woman with similar life goals, my heart ached for those who may not have been as lucky as she was.

It was through observing experiences beyond those of my family, whether Hajra’s or the women in Sindh, that I garnered a deep appreciation and respect for women’s health. To me, women’s health encompasses not only the physiology of women’s bodies, but also the emotional support I can provide to patients both in times of difficulties and joy. As a doctor, I want to improve patient outcomes in my community, a need that cannot be fulfilled solely through preventative resources. As I continue learning about social and biological aspects of medicine, I want to provide compassionate and personalized care to my patients, using my unique position as a physician to lessen the impact of systemic inequities that they may experience. The foundation of every family is rooted in the strength of their women. I hope that through my care I can nurture these roots and, in turn, advance the health of my community.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Ted had been under Dr. Omarali‚Äôs care for 15 years, always recounting stories of his youth whenever he visited. On this day, Ted was extremely upset: a pharmacist at CVS offered him an additional booster against COVID-19. Ted voiced his firm opposition against vaccines to me, convinced that the first ‚Äújab‚Äù he received was the cause of his current condition._x000D_
_x000D_
While I consider vaccinations to be important, in this instance I set aside my own beliefs and continued taking Ted‚Äôs vitals as normal. I sympathized with his frustrations and encouraged him to speak with Dr. Omarali about his concerns. Ted ultimately chose not to, but the experience taught me the importance of respecting patient autonomy. As a physician, I can better educate my patients, but I must also develop a personalized care plan that is sensitive to their sociocultural circumstances and individual choices. Irrespective of Ted‚Äôs beliefs, it was my responsibility to treat him with compassion and kindness while providing care.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: When I first joined the nonprofit Paani, I learned of Haru, a young boy who died from diarrhea, a treatable illness that turned fatal due to a lack of healthcare access. Haru‚Äôs story was common, as more than half of his rural district of Sindh, Pakistan walked 2 miles every day to reach a contaminated water supply. Inspired by Haru, I ran a bake sale on campus, where I sold cupcakes to fundraise for a water well and raise awareness for health disparities that continued to affect Haru‚Äôs village. Not only did I get to see the culmination of small acts of service, but I was also able to educate my peers about the community needs of underserved villages, inspiring them to get involved in Paani. Today, Haru‚Äôs village has a deep water well, with a plaque in his name. The legacy of Haru motivated me to expand my efforts within Paani. So far, our team has built over 4500 water systems to alleviate water scarcity and increase access to clean water in Pakistan, a number we continue to grow daily
7_-_COVID_Impact:
Imminent travel bans and our abrupt transition to a virtual semester caused me to abandon my Ann Arbor apartment overnight and move back to California. My privilege allowed me to stay at home safely with my family, and even though traditional opportunities like my research position at Stanford were canceled, I found little ways to help my local community in such turbulent times._x000D_
_x000D_
In the Bay Area, the lack of available PPE supplies prompted my family and I to found the Himmati Foundation, a nonprofit that distributed masks and sanitation items to local shelters and hospitals. We comforted mothers like Jess, who lost her daughter to coronavirus. In these moments I leaned on the power of community support to provide relief, recognizing that behind every statistic was a home grieving from the socio-economic and health consequences of the virus. COVID-19 has pushed me to view medicine with compassion and in becoming a future physician, I hope to continue serving these communities in need.

personal_statement:
Puzzles, riddles, and brainteasers; I have always been drawn to anything that has challenged my mind  to solve problems in the most systematic way possible.  As I have grown older, my problem-solving abilities have developed and refined, providing me the insight to see there is often more than one  path to arrive at a given solution. As I began to ask more questions, I came to understand that some problems needed to be solved through trial-and-error rather than the stepwise processes I had previously relied on. 
Early on, pursuing a career in medicine made sense based on my interests in STEM as well as my desire to ask questions, find answers, and solve problems; but I never truly understood why I was drawn to the field. It was not until I began working full-time as a scribe in a busy emergency room that I began to discover the answer to this question. Through medical decision making, I observed how physicians systematically ruled out possible diagnoses, while using the fundamentals of science.  I saw science “come to life” as it was applied to improve the wellbeing of those in need.
However, it was through human connection with patients that I saw a new side of medicine, one in which scientific reasoning was not as useful.  Each day showed me how a simple conversation and taking the time to become acquainted with the patient was a central puzzle piece to finding a diagnosis.  Many of the patients who frequented our ER were from the severely underserved area south of Chicago and faced unmet healthcare needs and systemic disadvantage. For many patients, the ER was their only access to healthcare, so physicians trained in emergency medicine were tasked with treating both acute and traumatic issues. Despite a full waiting room most days, these dedicated physicians showed up to the ER and provided each patient with a high level of care and compassion.
As a scribe, I was exposed to a wide variety of cases and patients ranging from as young as a few days old to over 100 years old. While some people received relieving news, others’ lives change in an instant due to bad outcomes and unforeseen diagnoses.  Immersed in daily learning experiences, I noticed how quickly physicians had to think on their feet and evaluate what needed to be done to help the patient. While every procedure was fascinating, my biggest take away was how the physician’s duty to provide support and compassion was as important as their duty to treat the illness. 
The first case of my very first day as a scribe was a pediatric sexual assault, also known as a Code R.  I had recently passed floor training and was nervous to chart on my own. Prior to that day, I had never experienced a Code R chart. Luckily, I had trained with Dr. Azam a couple times, so I was familiar with his charting preferences. Due to the sensitivity of the case, I was unsure if I should even accompany Dr. Azam into the patient’s room, but he eased my uncertainty by getting the patient’s permission. He instructed me to leave my laptop outside the room and focus on remembering the pertinent details for the chart to help the examination room feel “warmer.”  Like many days, the ER was packed so there was little time to spare. However, when Dr. Azam walked into that room, there was no indication that we were pressed for time. Dr. Azam decided to take his white coat and stethoscope off and grabbed an extra chair for himself and for the patient’s mother. 
As I stood in the corner of the room, I was impressed with Dr. Azam’s personable manner.  Through the heartbreaking details of the case, he navigated the conversation with tact and composure. Dr. Azam ensured that the patient and her mother understood every medical option available, but he did not stop there. The compassion Dr. Azam displayed to this young girl, during arguably one of her hardest days, was aspirational. After leaving the room, Dr. Azam suggested that we take a walk to decompress after the heavy conversation. As we were walking, he said that Code R cases would never get easier and that sometimes bad days would outweigh the days that “being a doctor feels like being a superhero.” He then proceeded to say, “there will always be time for the medicine. Don’t overlook the patient sitting in front of you because you got lost in the medicine.” 
In the grand scheme of things, it is probably unlikely that Dr. Azam will remember the details of that case. However, for the patient, for her mother, and for me, that day will never be forgotten. They will most likely remember how the physician listened and sympathized with them during one of their hardest moments.  For me, however, I will never forget Dr. Azam’s advice. He made me see what it means to treat the person, rather than the patient or the illness.  Medically, this was not the most “interesting” case or even a case for which I was prepared. However, this case demonstrated that patient care is far more than medicine and “cracking the code.” While my initial interest in solving problems drew me to medicine, it is the people and their stories that are the reason I want to become a physician. My hope is that I can be an advocate and a person of support during a moment in my patients' lives.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Working as an RA during college, I had the opportunity to learn from students with whom I did not share a similar background. Through interactions with my residents, I found out more about each of them, as well as more about myself. For example, I had an international student who was dealing with homesickness as this was their first time away from their family. Although I could not relate directly to the international student experience, I was able to find common ground as we discussed our families, some of our traditions, and the ways that we try to keep in touch when we are far away from our loved ones. My time as an RA also provided me with a lot of lessons on how to be sensitive to differences in culture, especially when dealing with roommate/hallmate conflicts. Ultimately, I found that simply listening to my residents was always the best approach, and entering each interaction without any preconceived notions resulted in the best outcomes and learning opportunities.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Working as a Learning Assistant (LA) for Introductory Biology and Biochemistry during the pandemic was foundational as it provided me with opportunities to create community during an unprecedented time and foster a culture of support. I created a safe space for my students to collaborate, synthesize information, and think critically. Unlike a TA, I was not responsible for assessing students‚Äô performance, so I related to their struggles, advocated on their behalf, and provided them with an example of resilience in STEM. For example, I shared my experience of having to retake Intro Biology after an unsatisfactory course grade and withdrawing from Biochemistry due to the switch to asynchronous classes, but despite that, I was still recommended by professors to serve as an LA because of my tenacity. Furthermore, my identity as a Black Woman inspired other students and continued to challenge an existing narrative that excludes certain identities from thriving in science or as leaders.
7_-_COVID_Impact: During my junior year of undergrad, I made the critical decision to take a gap year following my upcoming graduation.  Following the disruptions caused by the COVID pandemic, I felt that I would not be the strongest candidate had I chosen to apply with my limited shadowing, volunteering, and clinical experience. I also chose to take additional, focused time studying for the MCAT to strengthen my application. While COVID-19 changed the way that I lived and learned during the remainder of my undergraduate experience, it also gave me time to mature as a student and person during truly unprecedented times. As I continued to prepare for medical school, I developed a better understanding of systemic disparity and inequality as I saw my community disproportionately impacted by a deadly pandemic, and this confirmed my desires to make a difference in underserved communities.

personal_statement:
“How can I make my life meaningful?” is the question that I have struggled to answer since I was a child. As early as middle school, my peers seemed to know exactly what they wanted to pursue. My sister also committed to becoming a doctor when she was only in high school. At first, I thought I was lacking the passion or fire inside myself that would make me so committed to any goal. I felt this way throughout high school and college. I wish I could say I’ve known my whole life that I was destined for this path, but that would be a lie. It is only after years of consideration and thoughtful analysis that I realized that becoming a doctor was what I truly wanted to do. Exploring different fields throughout this journey is what helped me discover my destined path. My current resolve to become a physician stems from the collection of my past experiences, some related to healthcare and some not. Unfortunately, there isn’t enough space here to delve deep into each of these, so I chose some key experiences to highlight.
 
At age 11, my visit with my grandparents in Punjab, India reshaped my world. My grandmother is a physician who established medical care in impoverished villages that had no toilets or electricity. That trip, a team of doctors, interns, and I, under makeshift tents, served lines of villagers who traveled miles for medical care. Although I didn’t realize it at the time, the compassion I had for these people, and the feelings of euphoria through serving, was something I would chase for years in my experiences at home.
 
From ages 3 to 17, I danced at a professional company. I noticed a high turnover of students who couldn’t afford classes. This led me to become the sole proprietor of “Dance Away” at age 14. The purpose of my company was to give low-income children the same opportunities I had, by providing classes, 3 times a week, at $3 an hour, sometimes for free. Soon I had 30 clients, and by age 15, I was running a full business. I enrolled at UC Berkeley so I could stay local and continue these classes.
 
Balancing schoolwork, dancing, and Dance Away proved challenging and rewarding, though not the same euphoria I felt in India. I volunteered at a pregnancy clinic in an impoverished area of SF. I witnessed women come in physically and mentally defeated, but leave empowered. Witnessing this change was an incredible, first clinical experience that solidified my desire to help people.
 
At Berkeley, I co-founded “Invention Corps,” which used design thinking to tackle economic, social, environmental and health issues, locally and abroad. I headed our first project, Hygiene Heroes, which focused on improving sanitary conditions in Tamil Nadu, India, where over 37,000 schools are located. Open defecation was a major cause of disease because of unusable, unsanitary toilets. We built a website for students to identify restrooms that met minimum sanitary conditions. Schools that didn’t meet minimum standards were pressured to enforce repairing of their toilets. I also oversaw another project, called Visualize Ghana. Women in Ghana were dying of cervical cancer because few hospitals could afford the device used to detect the disease. We created an inexpensive digital prototype of a device that is still used in Ghanaian hospitals today. Serving people globally was so fulfilling.
 
Until then, I only planned on receiving a degree in Public Health, so I spent less time on academics, and more time at Dance Away and other settings. I worked retail as a beauty advisor. It was when I worked as an ER scribe that I finally found the euphoria I’d been chasing since India. I loved serving people through medicine. This is where my love for medicine began. Many doctors strongly encouraged me to apply to medical school, but I wanted to explore more before fully committing. I worked for a medical device company that sold surgical devices for the foot. I trained podiatrists and observed surgeries. I shadowed a physician in a rural city to experience a more relaxed work environment than the ER. I realized the impact I could potentially make as a physician, with my background in Public Health. I could combine research in communities, with the sciences, to create immediate and future changes, locally and abroad. I decided to pursue a medical degree and enrolled in a post-baccalaureate program. Then when the COVID-19 pandemic hit and the worldwide lockdown began, I helped to create a response team and worked on 2 projects: Resource19 and Shared Distance, which can be found in more detail in my application.
 
Passion doesn’t always have to be ignited at a young age and consistently present throughout your whole life. Sometimes, passion is cultivated and grown. During undergad, I was unsure of my career path and was therefore focused more on experiences to help me decide. Once I decided, I was focused and determined. This is why my college GPA is low, and my post-bac GPA and MCAT scores are high.
I finally found the answer to how I can make my life meaningful.  I have been mentored by amazing doctors and nurses who have taught me to serve with a compassionate, service-minded attitude. My love for science and my commitment to learning, fused with my passion for serving others will make me a successful doctor.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: One experience that enhanced my understanding of inclusion was when I co-founded UC Berkeley‚Äôs Invention Corps. Diversity was a major factor in our consideration of candidates. We created an interdisciplinary community of designers; we accepted 25 students of different ethnicities, sexual orientations, and socioeconomic status. In retrospect, this was fundamental to the functioning and thriving of our organization. Being able to interact and communicate with people of different backgrounds was difficult for some. I remained open-minded, willing to learn, communicative, and respectful of each person. Inclusion of all people facilitated open discussions, leading to more effective solutions. My projects taught me that working with people of different backgrounds and expertise helped engineer solutions through collaboration and open-mindedness. I hope to continue fostering diversity and inclusion in an environment that encourages it, such as at Rush Medical College.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Rush focuses on serving areas impacted by societal and structural determinants of health, which has been an objective of mine since age 11, when I visited India. My grandmother is a physician who established medical care in disadvantaged areas of north India, and being a part of serving in this capacity, inspired me to serve areas that need the most help. I later volunteered at a pregnancy clinic that helped women facing unplanned pregnancy, and who were struggling mentally and financially. I created a club at UC Berkeley, where I worked on two projects that served impoverished areas in India and Ghana. I shadowed a physician in rural Grass Valley, California, so that I could understand the needs of patients living in rural areas. My passion lies with the people in these regions, and the location of Rush provides an opportunity for me to impact residents living in areas that are disproportionately impacted by the social determinants of health.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
The transition to online learning due to COVID-19 affected my studies. Professors were less accessible, peer collaboration was hard, and online lab simulations were not nearly the same as in-person labs._x000D_
 _x000D_
During COVID-19, my older and immunocompromised grandparents caught the disease. This was during my post-baccalaureate studies. Much of my consequent time was spent caring for them and making sure they were comfortable, while trying not to get sick myself. Juggling this care of my grandparents, which lasted about 1.5 months, with my studies was difficult, but it gave me valuable bonding time with them, and taught me how to manage my time effectively._x000D_
 _x000D_
Positive developments that resulted from the COVID-19 pandemic include my involvement in 2 projects: Resource 19 and Shared Distance, which can be found in more detail in my application. Because the pandemic was so unprecedented, it allowed me and my team opportunities to impact the community in creative ways.

personal_statement:
I was sitting alone in my childhood bedroom when I first discovered it: a lump in my breast. Although the mass occupied only a few millimeters physically, it consumed me with uncertainty and fear mentally. It was a week before my high school graduation, a time meant to be filled with hope and promise, but instead spent shuttling in and out of doctor’s visits. The medical world was so foreign to me, but by the end of the month, the smell of ultrasound gel had a newfound familiarity. The ability for my doctors to decode intricate scans from complex imaging equipment fascinated me. As an incoming engineering student, I was driven by the transformative power of technology to bring real life solutions to people, like the ultrasound machines in front of me. My doctors’ most powerful tool, however, was their empathy. They held my hand during difficult conversations, gave me their personal phone numbers, and even counseled my parents who were facing their own fears. As I waited for my biopsy results, I reflected on how I could drive innovation in medical devices while upholding that same level of human connection that had proven to be so valuable to me.

I joined Project MESA as an engineering student, a team focused on building portable gynecological exam tables to donate to mobile clinics in rural Nicaragua. I understood the value of healthcare screening through my own health journey and was motivated to improve access for patients worldwide. Our work felt impactful; our tables had served over 45 Nicaraguan communities and hosted over 1000 cervical cancer screenings. But through my research in obstetrics, I learned inaccessibility to healthcare is not a foreign concept, but rather a harsh reality in our own backyards. I explored how social determinants of health impact the receipt of prenatal care services in the US. I uncovered that these inequities were associated with lower visit utilization, higher preterm births, and higher incidence of postpartum depression. There were even drastic differences in accessibility to simple and routine visits like ultrasounds or nonstress tests. I was troubled to see that patients under the care of the same physician at the same hospital were subject to vastly different pregnancy outcomes due to these social factors. Perhaps more perplexing was that my background in engineering seemed to prioritize ineffectively. My work in optimizing care thus far involved streamlining the healthcare system, but not improving access to it. The uniqueness of this research showed me the importance of combining process improvement and implementation alongside patient advocacy. Otherwise, our most vulnerable patients would never benefit from all the bells and whistles of a sophisticated system.

The following Fall, an internship offer from GE Healthcare allowed me to work on diagnostic technology that had been so pivotal to my own health journey a few years prior. But when the pandemic hit, I was relocated to Madison Wisconsin, home to the ventilator production plant, where production had surged by 1500%. I had been deemed as an “essential worker” contributing to the frontlines of the global pandemic. I wore a mask, safety goggles, and steel toed shoes and spent my days on the production line, streamlining the process to improve output and on-time deliveries all around the world. I was galvanized by the energy and dedication of those around me, countless of whom had come out of retirement to lend a helping hand. But truthfully, I was frustrated. I felt a disconnect between my work and patients on the other end. As I saw Dutch manuals attached to orders to the Netherlands and Korean power cords attached to machines headed East, I couldn’t help but visualize who this ventilator would touch next. Furthermore, I knew there were several systemic barriers preventing deserving patients from reaching these machines. My work was important to patients downstream, but I realized how much I valued their interaction. I knew what it was like to go through a health crisis, and I remembered the crucial impact of my physician’s empathy. Those that were on the other end of the machines I manufactured were going through the same terrifying experience and although these ventilators would help keep them alive, direct human compassion would keep them uplifted.

Although many do not view it as such, I see medicine and engineering as being remarkably similar. In both fields, you enable others with the tools to succeed. In engineering, this tends to happen macroscopically, improving processes and machines large-scale. In medicine, interacting with patients at the individual level and identifying personal needs scopes work at a more microscopic, direct level. My experience in the hospital showed me that despite the intricacies of my ultrasound machine, the most significant aspect of my care was building relationships with my doctors. It was their empathy and kindness that helped me persevere during my own most vulnerable time. I want to be there for patients during theirs.

Ultimately, my biopsy revealed a benign fibroadenoma. The mass would likely be a part of me for the rest of my life, but so would my commitment to advocacy and to improving precision of healthcare delivery to patients who need it most.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
After a dementia and heart disease diagnosis, my grandmother came to live with us full-time. Given her struggles with English, my grandmother required my help in communicating with her doctors. I noticed her vulnerability in the healthcare system as a non-native speaker and watched as she struggled to weigh treatment options._x000D_
 _x000D_
Thinking about cultural contexts and their relation to disease progression came to mind when I started volunteering at Brookdale Senior Living. What my grandmother struggled to convey because of a language barrier, Ron struggled to convey because of his military background. He tended to underrate his pain levels to appear ‚Äústrong‚Äù in the face of his condition._x000D_
 _x000D_
I‚Äôm committed to helping develop responses tailored to the specific needs of people like Ron and my grandmother. I see the importance of providing culturally sensitive and comprehensive care, understanding a patient‚Äôs personal considerations and the social determinants that bear on their health.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
As a female engineer, I have been nervous to speak up if not 100% confident in my answer. I was afraid of reinforcing negative stereotypes among my male colleagues._x000D_
 _x000D_
In a college leadership workshop, my performance displayed a willingness to let others speak over me. My mentor encouraged me to speak first in three conversations that week. Once I did, I started to shine: I was picked as a top leader amongst my intern cohort._x000D_
 _x000D_
I later managed an intern who expressed having imposter syndrome. I set up one-on-one meetings, intent on instilling confidence and reassuring her that how she felt was familiar to me. I encouraged her to trust her training. ‚ÄúYour perspective is valuable, especially when those around you are unlike you,‚Äù I reminded her._x000D_
 _x000D_
I know how to spot someone feeling othered, having gone through it myself, and how to empower them to use their voice. I hope to bring this skillset to my interactions with my classmates and patients at Rush University.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I had been working with Dr. Peahl on implementing telemedicine to increase access to prenatal visits for about six months when the pandemic hit. It had kickstarted the need for virtual medicine, so I enthusiastically led a team working to calculate the staffing needs for a new online visit schedule. We pulled together a team of clinicians and operations experts to verify and validate data, having to make quick and thoughtful considerations as we translated our findings into real clinic practice less than 48 hours later. I saw that telemedicine had its own limitations. There were folks without broadband internet who couldn‚Äôt utilize digital appointments and others who suffered without face-to-face interaction with their doctors. My work taught me to consider the ways that I want to combine my interest in more accessible medicine with my background in engineering. I‚Äôve also come to see the importance of patient-centered care and tailoring medicine to the modalities and needs of patients.

personal_statement:
As dawn approached, I walked across the untamed grass on a Philippine military camp, swatting away any bloodthirsty mosquitoes in my wake. I had almost forgotten how humid it was in my birth country, having immigrated to the U.S. several years ago. On that day, however, I was no longer the Filipino teenager I left behind. Instead, I was an American soldier on a mission, one of the multiple healthcare professionals who were sent to various regions in the archipelago to heal, teach, and rebuild. Specifically, my mission was to establish contact with the 95th Infantry Battalion and instruct them in combat casualty care.

I arrived at the makeshift classroom, with only two ceiling fans to keep the air flowing across the room during the summer. Not long after my preparations were complete, three Philippine officers approached me. I knew one captain beforehand; the other two had heard about my course and requested that I teach their units as well. One captain said with despondence, “We need to know how to save ourselves.” 

What drove the message home was the fact that in just a few weeks, these soldiers would be deployed to fight the communist New People’s Army in the aftermath of a five-month siege of a city, also known as the Marawi rebellion. I was faced with the responsibility of teaching soldiers not just to pass a class, but to use what they learned in real combat. It was then that I realized I was their only source of training in military medicine. Accepting would mean teaching a class that was originally intended for 35 soldiers to over 130 participants. I wondered what I was getting myself into for a moment, but this has never stopped me before.

I agreed.

To accommodate the increase in participants and overcome my lack of resources, I overhauled the format and reached out to the Philippine Army nurses for additional medical supplies. Each morning, I would walk into a class with soldiers seated on plastic chairs, eyes glued to me with pens ready to write on paper. We worked through the hellish heat of the equator, crawling on the ground to simulate the application of lifesaving interventions while under fire. I went through the motions of tactical field care, showing soldiers how to deal with injured comrades after a firefight and how to perform medical evacuation until it was muscle memory.

My instruction came to an inevitable end. I shook the hand of every soldier I taught. I took a bittersweet photo with the commanders and nurses. I departed the country soon after my American colleagues finished their missions. It was emotional for me because I felt inadequate as their instructor.

I started to think that if I had training as a physician, I could have done more to prepare them for more complex medical scenarios. I believed we had the time; I just lacked the training. I recall sitting in my car one December evening several months later, the night before I needed to sign my reenlistment contract. I had spent days mulling over each option they offered me, but thoughts about my last mission kept gnawing away at my mind. I kept going over what I could have done better, but I recognized that was in the past. I needed to do something to improve who I am for the future.

I realized that having a limited scope of practice held back my desire to learn and do more to help others. I remember having military binders stuffed with flowcharts sitting on our desks whenever I came into the clinic. Every algorithm inside was punctuated by referring to a physician at the earliest sign of complexity. Whenever they were called in, I was in awe of how they navigated the nuances of every case to come up with a final solution. I recognized the deeper considerations behind each medical decision, yet they made it simple for the patient to understand. Witnessing the amount of trust the patient had in them showed me their immense responsibility. The best physicians used each case as a teaching moment, allowing us to learn from their expertise.

Each day I spent as a medic following a binder’s orders, I felt unable to truly think for myself. I was empty and unmotivated, like a drought that sorely needed a deluge. The downpour I needed could only arrive in the form of being a physician, who seemed to know exactly what to do when nobody else did.

Finally, I decided not to reenlist to pursue medicine. I transferred to Emory University soon after my honorable discharge. My first year back in school was notably difficult, but I was able to move past the culture shock of my transition. I found success in my education as an anthropologist studying the intersection between biology and culture. I relished all my courses in humanities, which I feel are understudied assets in medicine. Each course in human tradition, evolution, and religion provided another lens to view patient care.

I keep in mind all of the soldiers I taught, foreign or not, throughout all of this. I was a force multiplier, augmenting every soldier's abilities to keep each other alive. I view physicians as even stronger multipliers, having the capability to educate other members of the healthcare team and improve the standard of care for every patient they come across. I look forward to the opportunity to step into those shoes, no matter how difficult it may be.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
After becoming a medic, my first assignment was to South Korea. Seeing as I had only been in the U.S. for less than a year after enlisting, I jumped from one foreign country to the next and took the 18-hour flight to its capital, Seoul. On the ride to my first unit, I distinctly recall staring at the signs all around me. I couldn‚Äôt read them, so I pulled out my phone and started learning right away. I used this knowledge to bridge the gap with my new friends, the Korean Augmentation to the United States Army (KATUSA) soldiers ‚Äì South Korean conscripts spending their military service with us. We exchanged cultural knowledge every day that we could._x000D_
_x000D_
As a future physician, I believe I will be able to capitalize on my ability to integrate with any culture. Coupled with my training in anthropology and religion, I expect to be able to keep an open mind during any patient interaction in order to make them feel heard, comfortable, and secure with the treatment my colleagues and I will render.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: In one of my missions, I deployed to the Philippines to teach military medicine to foreign soldiers and medical professionals. Within the same set of objectives, I also trained civilians living in remote areas in cardiopulmonary resuscitation. Having grown up in very similar conditions as a former citizen of the country, I resonated with the members of the community more easily than others. It took no time at all to be able to understand what they needed to help them improve their health outcomes. With the help of my team and the medical supplies we brought, we were able to offer not just momentary relief, but also a system that continues to provide essential training to the community. When we encountered issues we were not equipped to handle, such as dental and chronic conditions, we consulted with specialists assigned to the metropolitan areas. Their assistance helped us recognize our limitations, which paved the way for future missions between the Philippines and the United States.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
As a person that places a premium on hands-on experiences to solidify concepts learned within the classroom, the pandemic affected my ability to be successful in the sciences due to the transition to a purely online curriculum. While I appreciate the hard work and effort made by our university‚Äôs faculty in a novel environment, I still wish I was able to take advantage of the state-of-the-art facilities our departments boasted._x000D_
_x000D_
In terms of research, my plans to participate in the biological anthropology labs provided by my university were also discontinued. This resulted in our cohort taking an important course for my major that was ultimately deprived of essential experiences, such as examining skulls of our ancestors in person. However, I used this opportunity to take on several overloaded semesters in order to fully invest myself in my newfound field of study - anthropology. This allowed me to explore as many interests as I could before diving into the formal study of medicine.

personal_statement:
Although I joked about the “sun-kissed tan” on my legs, my betadine-stained skin revealed the true story. I laid on the stretcher in the UCSF pediatric ED, shaky and numb, contemplating how my hip reconstruction surgery had led to an infection in my back at the epidural site. After countless opioids, MRIs and now the infection, I quickly realized how far I was from a point of recovery; returning to school and my “normal life” seemed impossible. While 2017 was enveloped in pain and isolation, I began to realize how these experiences shaped my passion for human connection and curiosity in the human condition. What was once a source of anxiety and tumult became the impetus behind my journey to become a doctor. 
   Intrigued by mechanical maladies similar to my own, I spent my summer shadowing Dr. Atkin and his third-year medical students. Dr. Atkin’s clinic was in San Francisco’s Mission district, a historically Hispanic, low-income neighborhood, now subjected to bouts of gentrification. As the only cost-free private orthopedic surgeon in SF, a diverse patient cohort hailed from across the Bay Area in the early morning to seek treatment before work. Our first patient, Maria, conveyed tenderness in her shoulder and pain when she tried to lift her daughter. Although exhausted, Maria was grateful for our physical examination, amidst the guarded winces. Within a small office, we inspect Maria’s MRI and corroborate observations with pertinent positives and negatives from the earlier examination. I manipulate the life-sized skeleton in the corner of the office to visualize my theories. As the medical students and I knit together pieces of the puzzle, acromion impingement arises as the diagnosis. We reenter the exam room to share the news. Maria feels relief for her diagnosis, yet I see the heaviness that becomes her as she learns of treatment: surgery. The uncertainty and instability that comes with recovery poses questions of who will care for her kids and how she will work. Dr. Atkin saw the distress following diagnosis and lent support towards Maria, with comforting words, comprehensive, yet digestible explanations of what treatment and recovery would entail and lastly, a hand to hold. The lengths Dr. Atkin went to for his community, the free-of-charge appointments, the primary use of Spanish and accommodations of odd hours, inspired me to bring forth that same dedication to those around me. While my notepads became filled with poorly drawn sketches of shoulders, notes of cruciate ligaments in the knee and mantras of Dr. Atkin, the weight of responsibility for someone’s livelihood became a prominent thought in my head. As I pondered how as a future physician, I could change the course for my patients subjected to systemic barriers like Maria, I engaged with each patient and allowed them to be vulnerable and scared, even if it meant just holding their hand. If I was able to aid their experience in such a small way as a college student, I reveled in the possibilities I might have as a doctor. 
   Tightly grasping the knowledge I gained by working with Dr. Atkin, I traveled across the country to Boston. Unbeknownst to me, working as an EMT through the height of the pandemic would not only reinforce the lessons previously learned while shadowing Dr. Atkin, but also expand my medical knowledge and perspective on healthcare as I attended to patients in the back of an ambulance. The rundown, lonely nursing homes where COVID ran ramped and the government-funded housing where COPD flares were ignored, due to the high cost of ambulances and medications, ravaged these communities. As the first face of help, I saw a myriad of emotions in the patients I served. Escalating respiratory failure was met with adequate supplementary oxygen and frequent vitals, but also emotional support, even if it just meant holding their hand. I explained the purpose of the SPO2 monitor to my patients when I clipped it on their finger, as I noticed the number of hospitalizations listed on their charts. I wondered how this list would differ if they did not have to worry about paying for their next oxygen tank or obtaining access to their albuterol. I wanted to provide comprehensive explanations of their condition and treatment, so they could make informed decisions about their health, as I had experienced with Dr. Atkin and my own doctors, yet I was limited by my scope of practice and knowledge. While I savored the triumphs of healthcare, specifically in emergency medicine, the tribulations were burned into my memory. In turn, I saw the many ways I hope to alleviate the burden for my patients as a doctor and offer meaningful explanations regarding their health.
   Although the surgical scars on my back and hip remind me of a difficult crossroads I faced a few years prior, I am now met with years of experiences shaped by connections with my patients and my communities in SF and Boston. I think of the years of knowledge that are gradually fulfilling my curiosity not only about the human body and all its wonders, but also all the ways it can fail. As I continue my journey, I hope to utilize my ever-growing knowledge and personal experiences to provide meaningful care to all individuals.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: For years, I felt like an imposter. On the outside, I had no visible scars or deformities caused by my congenital hip dysplasia and corrective surgery. Despite this, I am reminded of my condition through my concealed scars, screws in my hip and residual pain. I have recognized that my path to diagnosis and treatment is not the same for all. My experience living with an invisible disability has inspired me to serve as an advocate for those who face barriers, such as systemic inequalities and disabilities. Invigorated to provide meaningful care to underserved communities, I pursued my journey in healthcare. I would frequently encounter patients deteriorating due to a lack of understanding of their condition or inability to afford medications. My experiences, as a patient and healthcare worker, not only revealed my desire to become a doctor that is cognizant of the challenges my patients face, but also knowledgeable on sociocultural factors and values that define their community.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As a technology tutor at Rosie‚Äôs Place, I have the opportunity to teach women, who are experiencing homelessness and poverty, how to use a mouse and type. While it is challenging to comprehensively explain what a mouse is, and how you use it, I have realized how my word choice may be perceived differently by someone who did not grow up with English or with a computer. I observe how small adjustments to my explanations are far more beneficial than others. Moreover, my understanding of technology and teaching has completely shifted. I grew up with a tool that allowed me to readily shape my perspective through news articles, social media and infinite information; however, once the women at Rosie's Place step away from the computer at the end of our session, they don't see it again for days or weeks. Their access to information and freedom to learn from the internet is inherently limited and with each session, I learn to accommodate these differences as best I can.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, my pursuit of research opportunities was disrupted. As a result, I chose to delve into clinical experiences. Working through the pandemic was met with strict protocols and scared patients. These novel situations pushed me to better utilize my limited resources and strengthen my clinical skills within the unknown territory COVID had created. The rise of omicron and staff shortages at the end of 2021 proved to be a significant challenge. After eventually getting COVID in January due to a full COVID patient caseload, it took me a month to recover. Consequently, I was forced to push back my MCAT. While I am proud of my recovery, it was difficult to see my MCAT score as an accurate reflection of my capabilities. This experience reaffirmed that growth is not always linear, and there are times where external circumstances can heavily influence a journey. I have learned to approach challenges in life, school and healthcare with a desire to learn and grow.

personal_statement:
Cries of frustration sounded throughout the downstairs living room as I desperately tried to communicate with “Jake,” a child with autism I worked with as a behavioral health technician. Jake’s frustration soon led to self-harming behaviors as he anxiously began to bite his hands. Seeking to help, I encouraged Jake to bite his sensory chewie and practice his breathing exercises. However, this did not calm him, and I felt helpless as Jake began to bleed from the freshly opened scars on his hands.
