In this challenging moment, I sought guidance from my supervisor on how I could better help Jake in his efforts to communicate and effectively cope with stressful circumstances. I was instructed to meet Jake’s psychological needs by consistently providing him with sensory input. I readily applied my supervisor’s direction by providing sensory pressure to Jake’s hands and arms. This relieved Jake’s stress, and he was happier and more attentive as he participated in his learning programs. This experience introduced me to the psychological aspect of effective patient care. I recognized that in addition to his prescribed medications and learning programs, Jake had psychological needs that, when met, could improve his overall health and well-being. Understanding this, Jake and I were able to work together and overcome barriers to his wellness.

In addition to understanding the psychological aspect of patient care, a unique experience I had interacting with “Ryan” has prepared me to address the social aspects of health. Ryan was the concerned and supportive uncle of a child that presented to the Children’s Justice Center following a potential case of sexual abuse. After I completed my duties of helping the child feel safe and comfortable for his forensic medical exam and interview, I had the opportunity to speak with Ryan. Ryan began by expressing concern about his nephew but then opened up about his current challenges as a member of the LGTBQ+ community. Many of his challenges resulted from living in an area that often harbors negative attitudes towards that community due to prevailing social norms. My research experience investigating the impact of social factors on health and well-being put me in a better position to listen compassionately to Ryan, understand his needs, and offer words of support. As we spoke, his concerns began to give way to feelings of hope and belonging. I am grateful I was present at this moment to help Ryan and experience firsthand the importance of social understanding in delivering quality care to patients and their loved ones. Ryan received the support he needed and was, in turn, better prepared to care for his nephew. This experience also encouraged me to continue participating in research that focuses on the social determinants of health. Such research has helped me better understand individual patients and the social factors that disproportionately affect health outcomes in specific communities.  

Lastly, in working as a medical scribe at a neurosurgery clinic, I began to understand the biological aspect of patient care. I recognized that the providers’ understanding of human anatomy and biomedical technology enabled them to convey medical knowledge to patients. This gave patients a greater understanding of their health and empowered them to make decisions regarding their treatment plan. As I diligently sought to become more familiar with the biomedical technology employed at the clinic, I was also able to participate in the biological aspect of patient care. On one occasion, as I collected a new patient’s past medical history, she expressed that she was anxious about her appointment because she assumed that a neurosurgery consultation guaranteed invasive spinal surgery. Using my recently acquired knowledge of the clinic’s medical interventions, I informed the patient that the neurosurgeon offered alternative treatment options to invasive spinal surgery. I then encouraged her to feel comfortable discussing these options and any concerns she had with the neurosurgeon. Our conversation helped ease the patient’s worries and gave her a greater sense of autonomy in making treatment decisions.   
    
I believe I am ready to begin the journey of a physician. I am prepared to meet challenges through collaborating with others, such as in my experience seeking my supervisor’s help to recognize and care for psychological needs. I am committed to increasing my knowledge of the social determinants of health and combatting social inequality so that no patient or their loved ones feel marginalized or unsupported. Additionally, I am dedicated to understanding biomedical technology to effectively guide patients in making treatment decisions. I want to become a physician, so I can draw upon my experiences to meet the psychological, social, and biological requirements of patient care. I am prepared to use my experiences and acquire essential skills in medical school to best serve patients and their loved ones with this holistic approach to healing.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I served as a volunteer representative for two years in Manila, Philippines. In this role, I worked with many Filipino associates in conducting weekly community service projects among the local population. To effectively coordinate with my Filipino associates and meet the needs of the local people, I had to become proficient in the native language, Tagalog, and gain a sufficient understanding of Filipino culture. I started by critiquing my own biases and acknowledging what I did not know about Filipino culture. I then frequently sought guidance from my Filipino associates. In learning from them, I gained a deeper appreciation of the Filipino language and traditions and was able to develop meaningful relationships within the community. Through this experience, I recognized that cultural humility is essential to understanding those unlike myself. I will continue to evaluate my own beliefs and biases and seek to learn from the diverse populations I serve as a physician.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
In my medical sociology course, I completed an original analysis of data examining access to healthcare among US children exposed to adverse childhood experiences. These children need quality care to mitigate the long-term negative impacts of such experiences on well-being. However, my data analysis showed that children exposed to adverse experiences have less access to care than children not exposed to such experiences. This disparity may be linked to social factors such as stress, lack of social support, and increased economic uncertainty in marginalized neighborhoods. _x000D_
_x000D_
To help this community of children, I have participated in organizations that ensure children exposed to traumatic experiences receive the care they need. I volunteered as a peer mentor at the Utah State Hospital to befriend and meet the needs of a pediatric patient exposed to abuse. Currently, I am volunteering at the Children's Justice Center to assist and support children that have been victims of sexual abuse.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I volunteered as a peer mentor for a pediatric mental health patient at the Utah State Hospital. I was very excited about this position because I enjoy empowering children and adolescents to pursue their goals by helping them overcome barriers to their health and wellness. I hoped to volunteer as a peer mentor for a year. However, the hospital closed the mentoring program after three months due to COVID-19. COVID-19 also interrupted my ability to shadow and observe physicians in person. While hospitals were closed to student observation, I registered for an online shadowing program to better understand a physician's role and daily schedule. This program offered weekly presentations from physicians in a variety of specialties. I completed about 25 hours of online shadowing, which provided me with key insights into the life of a physician. This experience supplemented the in-person shadowing I completed after hospital restrictions eased.

personal_statement:
Growing up my dad nicknamed me Dr. Amal. I never took the nickname seriously because most immigrant parents aspire to give their children the opportunity to pursue professional careers such as medicine. His aspiration for me slowly morphed into my desire as I became more exposed to the medical field and intrigued by its biological underpinnings. Biology sparked my curiosity and I became quickly absorbed by the subject in school. My teachers quickly took note of my enthusiasm and found ways to foster it through extracurricular activities such as dissection labs and book recommendations. By the time I started at St. Thomas there was no question I wanted to major in biology. As I dove deeper into my coursework, I also sought out hands-on research experiences such as working in an environmental toxicology lab where I gained countless new skills and knowledge difficult to transfer in a classroom setting. I became deeply entrenched in my passion for biology and inspired to pursue a career where I could apply the knowledge I was gaining to help care for people in their most vulnerable moments.  
My interest in being a physician was also confirmed by volunteering and shadowing experiences at Fairview Southdale Hospital. The volunteer program strengthened my desire to work with people because I enjoy connecting with diverse patient populations and trying to make a positive impact on their care journeys. While volunteering, I jumped at opportunities to help hospital staff and engage in conversations regarding what inspired them to choose their career paths. Through these conversations I gained insightful advice and the belief that with perseverance I could walk through those same halls in the future as a physician.  
Volunteering also opened the door for me to shadow in the operating room and be mentored by an anesthesiologist at Fairview. This life changing mentorship opportunity affirmed my passion for medicine as I observed Dr. Pershing perform procedures that seemed beyond the bounds of reality. Most strikingly I was inspired by Dr. Pershing’s calm leadership and authority over the operating room during an emergent case. His expertise combined with his immense sense of responsibility for each patient shone through as he and everyone in the OR did everything possible to save the life on the table. Watching the orchestra of people and equipment shuffle in and out of the OR was awe-inspiring; my life was forever changed in that moment knowing I wanted to be on the other side helping.
Soon after this experience, I began working as a pharmacy technician to widen my breadth of knowledge about the healthcare system outside of a hospital setting. Working in the pharmacy during the COVID-19 pandemic uncovered my eagerness to be on the frontlines helping despite the risk. I felt a responsibility to use my abilities in order to ensure people had access to their medications and were able to receive a vaccination once available. Working in the pharmacy confirmed my interest in medicine and made me realize I find the most joy in the clinical aspects of healthcare. I greatly value my time as a pharmacy technician, but I want to be on the other side of the prescription pad practicing as a physician and dedicating my time to caring for patients and using my knowledge to enrich patients’ health and ultimately their lives.  
Although my education, volunteering, shadowing, and work experience greatly influenced my decision to pursue medicine, my background and upbringing also played a pivotal role. As a second generation immigrant I am more aware of the current gaps in representation in our healthcare system, and I want to be part of the solution to making our doctors more representative of the populations they serve. Additionally, as the daughter of a Middle-Eastern immigrant I am highly appreciative of the opportunity to further my education because not all women in my culture are afforded the same chance. My parents have been outspoken advocates for my education and proud supporters of my medical school aspirations even when it went against cultural norms. 
I want to use my diverse background to relate to patients on a level only possible due to shared experience. I was able to attend St. Thomas on a full tuition scholarship awarded based on academic excellence and my commitment to diversity, equity, and inclusion efforts. Through the events and workshops associated with my scholarship program, I learned to embrace my diversity as a strength rather than a disadvantage. Being able to connect and empathize with people from all different backgrounds is a quality that would make me an outstanding physician. My lived experience as a second generation immigrant and as someone who has struggled to embrace their identity make me especially cognizant of the struggles faced by other minority populations who are often overlooked. 
Becoming Dr. Amal would not only fulfill a personal dream, but also represent a victory for all who support me and saw my potential even before I did. I never thought medical school was something attainable for me because of cultural barriers, financial worries, and self-doubt. Although challenging, these struggles were also the things that drove me to fight harder for my dream that I hope to make a reality.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Volunteering in a hospital and as a tutor in an urban middle school, I took opportunities to connect with patients and students from varying backgrounds, socio-economic statuses, and differing urban and rural upbringings. I gained new perspective and deepened my understanding and empathy for the unique challenges diverse populations face. _x000D_
As a pharmacy technician I interact with various patient populations and enjoy relating to and learning about individuals‚Äô cultural backgrounds, religious beliefs, gender identities, and native languages. I foster inclusive environments by making an effort to learn common phrases in other languages or refer to patients using their preferred pronouns. _x000D_
Furthermore, the mission of my college scholarship was to promote diversity, equity, and inclusion. Through this program, I shared my own background and learned about others through workshops, involvement in campus events, and participation in a peer mentorship program for underrepresented students. _x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As our state went into full lockdown during the COVID-19 pandemic, I continued to work at the pharmacy ensuring people received their medications. One of my close friend‚Äôs family was hit especially hard by the news of the pandemic because both her and her mom have autoimmune diseases that would make catching COVID-19 particularly devastating. Their family took Minnesota‚Äôs stay-at-home orders very seriously and limited their physical contact with everyone. Since the pharmacy I work at is located in a grocery store, I would pick up groceries for their family and drop them on the doorstep after my shifts. This small gesture meant more to them than I could‚Äôve imagined. For me it was something I could easily do to help ease their anxiety during this time when everyone was struggling. This experience showed me that simple acts of kindness can have positive impacts that are disproportionately greater than you‚Äôd expect.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
The pandemic presented innumerable challenges as we struggled to adjust to a world that was crumbling around us. Half of my undergraduate experience was remote learning; this made it difficult to achieve goals I set to conduct undergraduate research. Despite the sparse research opportunities, I still managed to participate in two research positions._x000D_
Many extracurricular activities I normally participated in were also put on hold. This included forced breaks from the Fairview Southdale Hospital volunteer program and the volunteering I did through St. Thomas. _x000D_
I continued to work at the pharmacy during this time despite my serious concerns about living at home and potentially passing on illness to my family members with pre-existing conditions. This fear also held me back from applying to jobs in a hospital or clinic setting. I couldn‚Äôt justify risking my family‚Äôs health any more than I already was to increase my clinical experience.

personal_statement:
“911, what’s your emergency?” “Please help! My son … he’s … he’s unresponsive and his eyes are rolling!” My mother’s frightful, pleading words filled my ears as my infant brother stiffened and twitched. Within minutes, EMS had arrived to transport him to the hospital. While the ER team worked deftly, the chaos and uncertainty surrounding my brother’s health weighed heavily on me as a six-year-old. Among the fear and commotion, a doctor knelt before me, looked into my tearing eyes, and reassured me with words I will never forget: “Don’t lose hope. We’ll bring him back.” I was awed by the team’s dedication to meeting my brother’s medical needs and understanding our cultural values of our recent immigration from India as they delivered compassionate care to him and our family. My brother thankfully regained consciousness after nearly 40 minutes of experiencing a febrile seizure. That moment ignited my dedication to becoming a physician. Since then, I have worked diligently to obtain the education, experience, and skills necessary to become a physician who provides the same compassionate, culturally aware, and personalized care to my future patients. 

Many years later, I returned to the hospital, not as a visitor but as a patient transport volunteer. Through many discharges, I witnessed immigrant patients facing the burdens of healthcare, including health illiteracy, ineligible health coverage, and fear. One such patient, “Luis,” was a recent migrant from Mexico and a victim of prolonged hospitalization due to liver cirrhosis. While in the hospital, he struggled to communicate with health care professionals, had rare visits from friends, and was despondent for the entirety of his stay. Upon speaking with health care providers and integrating my own exploration, I gained valuable insight into Luis’s liver cirrhosis and how it was affecting his overall physical and mental health. Seeing his despair, I approached him and said, “¡Hola! ¿Como está usted?” His smile told me that he appreciated my effort to connect with him through his native language. I consoled Luis through sharing my personal experiences of confronting cultural and medical challenges in an immigrant family. In Spanish, I encouraged him to progress in his recovery and used every break I had during my shift as an opportunity to continue our conversation, empathizing with the struggles and obstacles he had faced as an immigrant. Building a relationship through language and motivating patients in their recoveries reinforced my ability to combine language with clinical discovery to create individualized, transformative patient care. 

My desire to be a compassionate physician who connects with patients and places their needs first was further shaped by my experience working in a primary care clinic serving disadvantaged patients in my community. One patient, “Rose,” was a 64-year-old African American woman who had quadriplegia and expressive aphasia from a car accident in her youth. Because she consistently arrived alone on a motorized wheelchair, the health care team assumed she lacked a support system to assist her. The first few visits were unfruitful as many of us struggled to comprehend her fragmented speech. I gained knowledge of Rose’s aphasia after receiving advice from speech therapists. On a subsequent visit, I had the opportunity to speak and work with her directly. To help us communicate, I wrote down common words and had her pronounce them to better understand Rose’s speech patterns. Over the next several weeks, our conversations grew deeper. I sat eye level with her as we bonded over growing up with cultural differences, including pastimes and holidays. As I spent more time with Rose and our connection deepened, I learned she lived in an assisted living center where her needs were not being met. Unfortunately, she was afraid to voice her concerns over fear of being mistreated. Concerned for Rose’s welfare, I shared the insights I gained from my conversations with her to the rest of the team to help get her transferred to a new assisted living center, where I directly communicated her needs to the caretakers there. Working with patients like Rose further developed my compassion and sensitivity, and I will continue to advocate for future patients to help exceed their needs. 

Long gone is that young boy who feared losing his brother. My experiences in health care have motivated me to continue exploring medicine through empowering patients and advocating for their needs. I see myself as a physician who will be a beacon of reassurance and hope to patients and families, especially during times of distress. I desire to carry my calling into medicine by opening a free clinic that aids struggling patients in navigating healthcare. Dedicated to connecting and engaging meaningfully with all my patients, I will mold a standard of care that is culturally aware, individualized to each patient, and open to all clinical discoveries.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: My unique knowledge of being a puppy raiser for Leader Dogs for the Blind can enhance the diversity of Rush Medical College through my ability to see different perspectives. Raising puppies has allowed me to understand the daily challenges of those without sight, thereby helping them gain mobility, confidence, and independence with the assistance of a guide dog. Through advocating for those with vision problems by training my puppies in various environments, such as stores and schools, I help spread awareness of visual impairments and promote the inclusion of those less fortunate. During training, I attempt to understand the world from a puppy‚Äôs point of view, which enables me to set them up for success by positively reinforcing acceptable behaviors and redirecting inappropriate ones. Strengthening my perspective-taking will allow me to better understand the viewpoints of future peers and colleagues in our collaborative efforts and have a higher level of empathy toward future patients.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: The most impactful experience has been my role as a geriatric health care assistant, where I help deliver medical care and support to home-bound senior patients. This experience has been incredibly impactful to me as I have been exposed to many obstacles, such as health illiteracy, language barriers, and cultural differences, that elderly face in acquiring equitable health care. Having been exposed to these facets of medicine early has enabled me to be innovative in discovering ways to help patients and families alleviate struggles. From discovering patients‚Äô lifestyles through communicating in Spanish to explaining treatment plans to giving ideas for relaxing music, I am gratified to improve the health of the elderly community. My role as a geriatric health care assistant has inspired me to open a clinic that delivers compassionate, personalized care to older adults to meet their medical needs, overcome barriers to health care, and reduce the effects of social determinants of health.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Similar to other students experiencing virtual college courses, limited clinical experiences, and paused research endeavors, I transitioned into college amid the pandemic. Though I sought out direct patient contact experiences and research, healthcare settings were not allowing students to work directly with patients and university labs were shut down. Despite the challenges I encountered, I became involved in puppy raising for Leader Dogs for the Blind, volunteered in a mass vaccination center, and founded the organization Grizzlies Give at Oakland University. In my ventures, I learned ways to serve and impact those who have been more greatly affected by the pandemic. From these experiences, I discovered an aspect of creativity in acquiring unique experiences, especially during times of crises. As a future physician and leader, I aspire to serve patients to help them overcome challenges and will continue to engage in diverse experiences while supporting various patient populations.

personal_statement:
The ear-splitting scream of my twin sister flooded my senses with a jolt of pure, unadulterated panic. I dashed from my room to find her scrambling up from the floor, blood pouring from her nose as she stared up at me from the landing she’d just fallen from. Despite my terror, my protective sister instincts kicked in, and I flew down the stairs to her side. My arms remained tightly wrapped around her the entire drive to the hospital. After an hour spent nervously fidgeting in the ER waiting area, a doctor emerged, approaching my mother and I to deliver the update. Thankfully, my sister’s injuries were fairly minor. She had suffered a laceration to her columella, but after a few stitches to close the wound, she was recovering well. 

Listening to the physician, I felt my suffocating fear and anxiety dissipate. The doctor was calm and kind, and when she left to tend to my sister once again, I felt markedly better. For the first time, I came to understand that a physician doesn’t just help the person on the exam table––they also have the power to positively affect the patient’s loved ones. I saw first-hand the ripple effect of medicine: help one person and you can improve the lives of countless others. Even at the age of twelve, I was captivated by this idea, and a determination to touch people’s lives in the same way that my sister’s doctor had settled in my mind. 

As I grew older, exposure to anatomy and biochemistry created a personal fascination with the human body. As I delved into studying science, I developed an appreciation of the importance of education, which I recognized as another avenue to touch people’s lives. My experience founding a nonprofit, focused on bringing free SAT tutoring to students in my hometown, was a uniquely fulfilling application of this realization. Yet, I missed science, and my desire to heal people medically still felt incomplete. In my time as a scribe, I saw my passion for education fit seamlessly with that desire.

Walking into the exam room, I smiled at the patient, a kind-hearted older gentleman named Greg. Greg was no stranger to the office; the doctor I worked under had seen him three times in the last month due to a melanoma on his back. Looking over his surgical path report with a pleased expression, the doctor said, “It looks like we got it all, the margins are free and there is no further work needed.” At the news, Greg’s face split into a grin. He listened intently as the doctor reminded him to remain vigilant about sun protection, and the specific features of a lesion that make it suspicious. Struck by the way the doctor acted as a teacher for the patient, I was once again reminded of the ripple effect of medicine. This time, I saw how physicians offer knowledge to each patient they treat: information that is then transmitted to the patient's peer circle, allowing its impact to continue to grow. I saw my thoughts reflected in real life when Greg’s sister came into the office the next week for a full body skin check. Fascinated by this discovery, I’d feel a surge of fulfillment each time I reassured a patient about the benefits of a procedure. However, watching a patient's psoriasis flare because they couldn’t afford medication and seeing lupus patients suffer through joint pain because of pricey copays, I grasped the unfair expense of achieving good health. I felt drawn to help provide healthcare to those who often cannot access it, which led me to act as a medical volunteer at a clinic for people experiencing homelessness in downtown Los Angeles.

Sweating in my blue scrubs, I flipped the exam room for the next patient, a middle-aged woman named Krysta. As the nurse brought her into the room, she immediately doubled over, hacking intensely. A twinge in the sound of her voice made me hand her a bucket, and I bit back a gasp as Krysta vomited blood. The nurse signaled me to notify the physician, and after I explained her condition to the doctor, he asked me to assist the next patient while he went to see Krysta. I hesitated, but kept moving. At the end of the day, I asked the doctor for an update on Krysta’s condition. I was hit with a wave of grief, confusion, and guilt after learning she’d been sent to the emergency room and had passed away there. Struck by an understanding of how quickly a patient's condition can become critical and the tragedy of a lost human life, I felt a small part of the burden that physicians carry. I thought of the ripple effect once more––this time picturing the responsibility implicit in the opportunity. Working in the clinic the next day, I felt changed. Krysta’s memory offered important context to each patient interaction, and witnessing loss cemented my desire to work tirelessly to improve people's physical and emotional health. 

The waiting room chair where I sat awaiting news about my sister comes to mind often these days, and as I reflect on my passion to become a doctor, I marvel at how my perspective on the ripple effect of medicine, the one that captured my attention so long ago, has shifted, grown, and matured just as I have. I understand now that the profession of healing people, and thus touching the lives of so many others, is a privilege, burden, and magnificent opportunity that I cannot imagine my future without.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: While working at a needle exchange site, a place where people can obtain sterile needles in order to decrease the spread of bloodborne diseases, I was asked to speak to protestors outside the clinic. I heard the somewhat misinformed argument that I expected, that needle-exchanges result in more drugs. However, I also heard a mother speak about her son who contracted Hepatitis B because of a discarded needle. Hearing the pain in her voice made my plan to support my argument with figures seem callous. I realized that I could not ask this woman to listen to statistics while she believed our clinic made light of her son‚Äôs suffering. As I sympathized with her and offered our clinic‚Äôs free treatment services, her anger lessened. Only after this interaction did I attempt to communicate the positive impact of our clinic. Interacting with protestors, I grasped that understanding the beliefs held by others must begin with taking time to recognize the experiences that inform their beliefs._x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Answering the phone with a tentative hello, I felt surprised as a counselor from the largest public school in Dayton introduced himself. He asked me about Test Prep for Success, the nonprofit I had run for two years at this point, and said he had a student that was exceptional, but needed an amount of attention he couldn't offer. I hesitated, as the upcoming session was full, but hearing the desperation in his voice, I agreed. The student, Trey, was quick to distraction and uninterested at first. As I got to know Trey and he bonded with our team of tutors, he blossomed. By the end of the session, he was scoring in the 90th percentile and on his official ACT, he scored 12 points above his first practice test. Trey called me when he got into college and told me about the promise he made to his grandmother to be the first in his family to attend college. As he thanked me for allowing him to make his promise a reality, I assured him that it was only his hard work that brought him there.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, I took Physics I & II P/F, as I needed to move home to Ohio to be the primary caretaker for my grandmother and thus did not have access to the correct lab materials. My undergraduate institution has agreed to unmask the P/F grades, and I will send over the updated transcripts with letter grades for my Physics classes as soon as I receive them. I am also planning to retake the Physics this coming fall.

Hrdshp_Comments: In 1999, at seven years old, a neuropsychological test diagnosed me with ADHD and dyslexia. I was placed in the resource room to help raise my reading level and was given an individualized education program (IEP) with accommodations from 2nd to 12th grade that followed me through college. My public school retested me every three years in 2003, 2006, and 2009 to reevaluate my diagnoses and accommodations. In college, I received accommodations for extended testing time. My most recent neuropsychological test was in Nov. 2017 and was consistent with my diagnoses and previously recommended accommodations. Being a student with ADHD and dyslexia can be challenging. Often, my peers read faster and outpace me, but I have come to recognize and accept my strengths and weaknesses. I may not be a fast reader, but instead, I can offer creative perspectives on problem-solving because of how I take in information differently. I had learned the importance of neurodiversity and representation. I discovered through group discussions that the best outcomes are achieved when each group member offers a unique perspective. My ADHD and dyslexia have made education more challenging, but it has also allowed me to relate to others and empower those who think less of themselves because of their differences.
Fee_Assistance_Program: Y - Invalid for Application Submission information
personal_statement:
As I was evacuating from Peru during the Pandemic, I reflected on the eight months of volunteer work I did in an impoverished community and how I ended up where I am today. My mind was flooded with memories of the challenges I overcame and those who encouraged me along the way as I flew back to the more familiar landscape of Michigan. 

My interest in medicine began in high school. I became a certified nursing assistant in 2012. During this time, I got feedback from the nurses who said, “Derek, you soak up knowledge like a sponge.” I was constantly curious about the underlying physiology behind the treatments we were administering, following nurses around and asking what they were doing and, most importantly, why. I spent two years in this role. Reflecting on its significance, I feel it’s where my passion for serving humanity began. But I wanted more, and I felt I had reached a barrier that could only be overcome through education, so I reenrolled at my community college. 

During my first semester, I took a microbiology course with Dr. Matt Badtke, a young professor passionate about encouraging students. I shared with my dad how fascinating the class was, and how I liked learning about the microscopic organisms that live in and around us.  Excitedly, my dad told me he had kept my great-grandfather’s microscope and tissue slides from his years in medical school in the 1920s. I was so excited to show this antique to Dr. Badtke, so I took the microscope and slides to his office. As we examined the tissue samples, I felt like I was transported through time, looking through the microscope like my great-grandfather as a medical student. Dr. Badtke later nominated me for a student excellence award in microbiology and encouraged me to apply for the Community College Summer Fellowship Program at the University of Michigan.

I completed the summer research program, and a semester later, in 2015, transferred to the University of Michigan. At that time, I was questioning if studying science was the right path for me. I started taking Spanish classes, which led to a study abroad in Barcelona, Spain, in 2017. In Spain, I realized that the history of art was a field of study that combined my interests in culture, psychology, languages, and the arts. I discovered the intersection of art and medicine while working on an independent research project about the artwork produced by institutionalized psychiatric patients. I had a revelation about the similarities between the artist and the patient. They both need their culture, history, and unique story understood, not just the surface-level details of an illness or a brush stroke, but instead the path they took. I saw that individuals are shaped by their experiences which shape their health and well-being. This rekindled my interest in medicine.

During the months I spent in Peru, I initially struggled with my Spanish, but as I became a part of the community I served, I became more fluent and learned the vocabulary of the region. This allowed me to experience things I would not have otherwise. My students taught me a traditional Peruvian dance. We danced around the classroom together as their parents clapped along. My students ranged from 5 to 18 years old, but one student in particular, 10-year-old Henry, challenged me the most in the classroom. I could always count on Henry to interrupt the other students' answers or ask off-topic questions. He couldn’t help it. He was so eager to learn. I told him I liked his enthusiasm but reminded him we had to take turns speaking in class. That redirection only lasted 15 minutes until he couldn’t handle waiting anymore. But rather than let this bother me, I invited him to talk with me about his interests after class, and this became our regular thing. Henry taught me that sometimes the most challenging people are ultimately the most rewarding. 

As a teacher during the pandemic, I saw how limited my support was in Peru. It was evident that the community I served no longer needed a teacher; instead, they needed a doctor to support them. I saw the community’s medical system failing. They had run out of oxygen, COVID tests, and personal protective equipment. I felt helpless that I was unable to do more for them. Poverty made the community extremely vulnerable to unforeseen circumstances. I saw the full effect of social determinants on health and the inequities in their healthcare that weren’t initially visible until the need for emergency medical care caused doctors to make difficult decisions as they triaged patients. 

Leaving Peru was difficult; plans to be there for three months turned into eight, and potentially longer, but COVID truncated my plans.  My flight went from Lima, Peru to Miami to Detroit, and shortly thereafter, I arrived at my childhood home, where my mother greeted me. Life oddly felt full circle as I moved back into my old bedroom. I shared the stories of what I learned on my journey. I related the struggles of a community where half of the students do not reach the basic standards in reading, science, and mathematics. I tried to convey the barrier of poverty that dictates their lives, education, and health. I told my mom that, given my need to serve humanity, I was ready to pursue the study of medicine.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: My first time abroad was in Barcelona, Spain. I spent eight weeks as a study abroad student over the summer of 2017. I joined my host mom to celebrate the culture of Catalonia and participated in traditional dances and food preparation; I surpassed anything I could ever learn through a book alone. From this trip, I realized the value of learning through lived experiences, which developed my abundance of openness to embracing the lives of others. I believe that everyone can teach us something new when we put aside our beliefs and assumptions to listen to their stories and lived experiences through the lens of their identities. My first time aboard changed how I experienced life, and I continued to build off what I learned in Spain during my time as a volunteer in Per√∫ from September 2019 to April 2020.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: While teaching with Superlearner in Per√∫, I worked to address the inequities in their education system. I was challenged to be resourceful. This challenge was not easy; I had to be creative with my materials yet effective in my work to empower my students. So, I met with the families and their children to better understand their needs. I wanted to create a curriculum that excited my students, met their interests, and improved the areas of their education that were underdeveloped. I deliberately worked to understand everyone‚Äôs ideas and suggestions because I knew I did not know what was best for them. I put the community at the center of my work because I knew that is how I would meet their needs and make lasting improvements in their community. I shared what I had learned from the community with the other volunteers and the President of Superlearner, and we collaborated to successfully meet their educational needs.
7_-_COVID_Impact: While I was in Peru during the onset of the pandemic, the effects the social and political determinants of health had on the community I served became so apparent. The disproportionate effects the pandemic has had on marginalized communities emphasized their lack of access to preventive healthcare, which increased the risk of complications due to untreated conditions such as heart disease or diabetes. These healthcare disparities have motivated me to become a physician, so I can create change through social justice to improve health equity. Being abroad during such an unprecedented time tested my adaptability and resilience to the evolving health crisis and lockdown rules. I quickly realized that nothing had challenged my language skills more than needing to know with 100% accuracy what the Ministry of Health and the President of Peru said during their daily briefings.

personal_statement:
A 14-year-old female with no past medical history presents to the ED with marked edema of the right orbit. This 14-year-old female was my younger sister, Zoe, and after ruling out any dangerous pathology, the cause was deemed: idiopathic. Idiopathic is a  word: "idio" referring to self, and pathic referring to a disease; together, they mean a condition of its own and further meaning a disease of unknown cause. Hours earlier that night, I heard a shrill cry coming from my sister’s room. I ran to her and found her right eyelid had swollen to the size of a golf ball, completely obstructing her vision. We were home alone that night, so I grabbed her hand, helped her into the car, and drove her straight to the ER. 
 
I remember meditating on the possibility of a disease of unknown origin, naïve to the limitations of known medicine. It was this mystery and the vastness of the unknown that provoked me to search for an answer accepting the risk that I may never find one. Despite this quandary, I observed how much the subsequent ophthalmologists, dermatologists, and allergists cared about Zoe’s well-being. Their commitment to finding a solution deeply resonated with me. They were all professional and empathetic, using their knowledge to provide thoughtful and considerate care. They served as educators, explaining to me the anatomy and physiology behind the symptoms Zoe suffered from.

I felt powerless. I couldn’t fix this problem like her big brother always had. I decided to pour myself into the medical literature, looking for answers. I saw myself as a detective of sorts, piecing together the clues and creating theories to explain this illness. I took this case on “pro bono”, as I would joke with her, knowing I had the capacity to make a difference, and thus began my path to medicine.
 
Soon, I became a medical assistant at a dermatology clinic, and I loved working in this environment. I especially enjoyed making the patients and staff laugh, forming close relationships. Over a two-week span, we strangely saw three separate cases of purple toes. The physicians and I were stumped by these skin manifestations due to the patients’ histories and ages. The patients were frustrated with their mysterious symptoms, and I understood their predicament. I shared their frustration and empathized with their fear. So, I donned my sleuth cap and hit the books. I found a possible connection to new findings from COVID-positive patients in Europe. Fortunately, the providers confirmed this discovery, enabling us to give the patients a much-needed explanation. I was ecstatic to help solve our patients’ cases and awed by the power a team working in harmony can have on our patients' lives. I knew that medicine was my passion and understood that I would be the physician that put a smile on every patient’s face.
 
This same passion led me to choose to major in Molecular and Cellular Biology to understand the mechanisms and building blocks of the human body more thoroughly. Just as a detective must understand the mind of the criminal, I chose to explore the mind of physiology and disease. Hungry for more, I pursued a position at a microbiological research lab, where I received a mountain of new cases. Pioneering novel biological systems and mechanisms in Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a pathogen that plagues Cystic Fibrosis patients, was an opportunity that allowed me to delve deeper into the science that intrigued me.

As I pushed the boundaries of discovery, failure and I quickly became best friends. I designed a project to create a new mutant strain devoid of any nutrient transporters to investigate the mechanism of the pathogen’s survival. After a rigorous 2-week process, my initial mutagenesis came back as a failure. This was unfortunately followed by two months of repeated failures. Informative meetings with my professor yielded several potential remedies to my situation. Nevertheless, the solution remained unknown, and I had a new case to solve.

Although the unknown was the source of my struggle, the unknown also became the source of my resolve. The slightest possibility of my research contributing to new medical discoveries or pharmaceutical breakthroughs against Cystic Fibrosis drove me to solve this mystery. Eventually, I discovered the source of my anguish was a batch of contaminated primers; as such, my failure was guaranteed from the start. I recognized the unfaltering plight of research physicians and my own resilience in the face of adversity, understanding I shared their commitment to finding answers with only a glimmer of hope.

Medicine provides the perfect opportunity for me to battle against mysteries that have a human impact. I am infatuated with learning how different diseases occur and how I can use that knowledge to help others through challenging moments in their lives. Moreover, I hope to become the type of physician that will advocate for patients like my sister who suffer without answers. I admire the opportunity to sleuth as a part of a team, as no great detective operates alone. I look forward to serving my community with curiosity, confidence, and kindness and aim to reassure my patients that there is an answer, or we will not stop until one is found.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I have lived in and around Chicago my entire life, which has enabled me to understand how powerful the diversity of my city is. Encountering various cultures throughout my life has made me appreciative of the multitude of backgrounds that make Chicago feel like home. Many of my friends have roots from all over the world, and I have been privileged to experience their traditions. My best friend, Amir, is Palestinian and a practicing Muslim. In 2019, he invited me to attend a Palestinian wedding. Having only attended Greek weddings in the past, I did not know what to expect. I was astounded by the unique beauty of the wedding, from the ceremony to the traditional attire. I met many wonderful people and engaged in conversations with attendees who hailed from all over the world. Through this experience, I learned the importance of connecting with individuals who may not share my beliefs, and to embrace and celebrate the differences that make us stand out.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
My Greek Orthodox background has given me a unique perspective on life. I have always been involved with the church, and my life is irreversibly rooted in Greek culture. Although being Greek means belonging to a tight-knit group, I was always taught to love and respect everybody for their individuality. _x000D_
_x000D_
Through my church, I discovered Habitat for Humanity. In this organization, I traveled to underserved areas of the Chicagoland area and participated in something larger than myself. My favorite aspect of building these homes was the opportunity to meet the families we were helping. I enjoyed talking with them and hearing their stories and was proud to give something back to individuals in need. My involvement in building these homes may have been a small contribution to an otherwise large project, but each nail and brushstroke was more than material to me. I look forward to continuing to serve my friends, family, and community in Chicago as a Rush medical student and future physician.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
I initially struggled with online classes due to the lack of face-to-face interaction with instructors. However, this format forced me to become more independent, as I had to teach myself how to approach and understand complex topics. Additionally, research labs were not accepting students, which limited my ability to satisfy my curiosity in the areas of microbiology and biochemistry. I adapted to the circumstances and remained motivated to make a difference, leading me to find a volunteer position at a dermatology clinic. There, I screened patients for COVID symptoms and took their vital signs. Soon after, I was offered a position as a medical assistant._x000D_
_x000D_
After struggling with two COVID-19 infections myself, I harbor a greater appreciation for my health and that of my loved ones. I now educate my parents and relatives on vaccinations and preventive care. Overall, the pandemic has made me more compassionate, efficient, creative, and further appreciative of teamwork in healthcare.

personal_statement:
Since I was young, I have wanted to work in medicine. At the dinner table, my father would often describe medical cases he saw in his clinic that day. These discussions inspired my initial interest in medicine. When I was fourteen, my freshman biology instructor, Mrs. Jackman nominated me to attend a summer hospital observership. This experience at Summit Hospital in Oakland exposed me to medical care in an urban setting. During the program, I had the opportunity to spend time with pathologists in the hospital morgue. I found the various techniques for identifying the cause of death fascinating. They showed me the distinctive cardiac tissue scarring of a man who died from a heart attack, the darkly stained lung tissue from a chronic smoker, and the large nodules covering a cirrhotic liver. In college, while shadowing a general surgeon at Johns Hopkins, I witnessed a seriously ill woman who had developed necrotizing fasciitis of her abdominal cavity. The surgery team kept her alive by removing the affected tissue and providing antibiotics. It is that confluence of scientific knowledge and the practical application of medical therapies that has always interested me. I want to be capable of a deep understanding of human anatomy and physiology to improve patient care.
In high school, as a TA for the computer lab, I realized I had a strong interest in computer science. After graduating from Cornell University, I joined the electronic medical record company, Epic Systems. As a technical analyst, I instruct nurses, physicians, and clinic managers on how to effectively use Epic’s software. I fly to outpatient clinics across the country to help them roll out their new system. The electronic medical record makes the practice of medicine safer and more efficient. We can automatically notify providers about drug allergies, unsafe medication interactions, and allow physicians to review medical records entered by their colleagues from across the country. This reduces the need for duplicate lab testing and imaging, which reduces unnecessary costs. Additionally, I have worked with physician IT champions and chief medical information officers whose understanding of both clinical care and technology allows them to improve the electronic tools providers use. 
The Covid pandemic has obviously presented many challenges for everyone. It began during my senior year at Cornell. At that time Cornell focused on ensuring lectures and tests could continue online but the university eliminated personal time with faculty. I reached out to other students in my courses and arranged study sessions. Working together greatly reduced isolation and helped all of us better understand the coursework. While working at Epic, I have been promoted to train newly hired employees. I enjoy sharing what I’ve learned with them so that they can provide support to other medical facilities. 
My father is one of two fluent Spanish speaking primary care physicians in a large medical center in Contra Costa County, California. Nearly 20% of the population in Contra Costa are native Spanish speakers. Patients who speak only Spanish frequently rely on friends or family to translate their medical history and care instructions. During my hospital shadowing experience, I saw firsthand tremendous improvements in patient understanding and treatment compliance when care instructions were given in the patient’s primary language. I hope to be able to provide medical care to the large Spanish speaking population with language fluency and cultural understanding. 
I developed an interest in medicine at a young age. I have followed an educational and occupational path that has prepared me for medical training. I believe it is possible to further improve both the quality of patient care and its accessibility. This will require future medical providers to utilize compassion, scientific understanding, and technology to optimize healthcare. I hope that I can help to make this happen.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I am Puerto Rican. My grandparents were born in Puerto Rico and my father was the first person in his family to attend college. I feel very strongly that ethnic and cultural diversity is important in medicine. Chicago has a large African American population. As someone who is also a member of a minority group, I know what it means to be underrepresented in medicine. I am sensitive to patients preferring providers that represent their culture. A lack of ethnic and cultural representation leads to an environment where patients feel that they are outsiders within the hospital environment. I grew up in a neighboring city to Oakland, California which has a large African American community. I did a hospital observership in Oakland where I interacted with many African American patients, many of whom did not have health insurance. Unaffordable health insurance is an enormous inequity in our health system that needs to be addressed more effectively in our society.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: My personal experience of moving to Wisconsin after college was challenging. I did so during the peak of the Covid pandemic, and I spent a great deal of time isolated. This was in part due to moving to a new state, and more critically, the Covid virus. Coupled with the extreme winters in Wisconsin, I spent far too much time isolated in my apartment. At Epic, I serve as a mentor to new hires. Most newly hired employees to the company are recent collegiate graduates, like I was. After my experience, I take care to encourage that the people I mentor develop professionally while also building a strong social support network in and outside the company. The training and work at Epic can be very demanding. Helping the newly hired employees develop strong social bonds in the area helps them build resilience.
7_-_COVID_Impact: I have not experienced any abrupt disruptions during my application for medical school due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The pandemic did not begin until I was near graduation from Cornell. At Epic I was able to train and work remotely.

Hrdshp_Comments: I came out as transgender when I was fourteen. In Kentucky there are very few therapists and even fewer speech language pathologists who provide care to transgender patients, and only one support group for LGBT youth (with low transgender attendance). I struggled to find a voice coach for trans adolescents in my area–the only available group coaching was an hour and a half away and didn’t have any members under the age of forty. Finding a SLP, therapist, endocrinologist, and surgeon was difficult as an adolescent, years of documented care was required to be treated. When I went through surgery I was one of the youngest patients and found receiving patient education from staff very  difficult to comprehend as a teenager whose world was in upheaval. Through all of this I as a teenager had to discover where to find care, how to become who I truly am, and attempt school and extracurriculars. Physicians and nurses see people at their most vulnerable, I know first hand how terrifying it is to be a transgender patient. With a medically educated dad and his economic support it was still a constant struggle to find providers and navigate the requirements for treatment. This was a very isolating experience, and I am thankful that I had my parents’ support.
personal_statement:
On March 17, 2020, I volunteered to work as a nurse in the first COVID ICU in Boston. I did not know what to expect but knew that I wanted to be on the frontlines. My first COVID patient was “Ana,” an older Hispanic woman who told me all about her life, family, and favorite recipes. I shared my own stories and held her hand for hours while we watched music videos on YouTube, talked about what makes the best tortilla, and our go-to Christmas cookies. As she struggled to breathe, I helped her lay prone. I knelt on the floor, and we prayed together. She was terrified from lack of oxygen; I was scared because we did not yet know how COVID spread. I stayed with her because, despite the danger, there was nowhere else I would rather have been than holding her hand.

The next night, Ana was trying desperately to breathe and could not speak. I sat with her all night. As my shift ended, she coded. At home, I was unable to sleep. Some experiences in medicine break down every wall we can build, yet these struggles are where I find my greatest passion for medicine. When I returned, she was intubated and peaceful. I called her family to update them, but her condition quickly deteriorated, and for a time she was the sickest patient in the unit. Three weeks later, I was there when she woke up — the first face she saw.

We all overcame huge hurdles to provide care during the pandemic, but the physicians caught my attention. They spent rounds doing their best to brighten the staff’s lives and to prevail over COVID. Physicians spent every moment researching COVID, trying to find ways to increase survival. Their investigative drive and agency to save lives helped solidify my desire to go back to school to become a physician. I needed the ability to do more for the patients beyond what my nursing license allows, to digest and implement new studies, be the team leader, and let my mind work.

I first became interested in a clinical career when I spent days under my radiologist dad’s desk, listening to him dictate in what seemed like another language. However, during my adolescence, my focus was derailed from academics to a journey of self-discovery. During my junior year of high school, I finally managed to come out as transgender to my family. In the years that followed, as I became a woman, I finally became myself. At first, there was joy, and then quiet acceptance. After a time, the “transgender” label lost its power, and I became simply — Charlotte. I had found out who I was, but I had to discover what being myself meant. My first two years of college were a time of discovery of who Charlotte is to me. By my third year of college, I felt settled and finally turned my attention back to academics. My grades skyrocketed.

As a nurse, I loved being the face of the team for the patients, the advocate that was on their side first. I’m motivated to become a physician to bring that advocates role with me to the head of the team. I kept seeking “to know.” During COVID, specifically I wanted to know the science behind proning a patient, to understand why patients were clotting, to anticipate what ailment might come next. For instance, I recall a patient I’ll call “Dory.” Her blood pressure was in the 200s and she was confused and hallucinating. For two shifts, I worked to get her blood pressure down, along with my dayshift counterpart. When I left my second shift, her pressure was finally down, but, when I came back, I noticed something was wrong. Dory had not urinated since my last shift, so I started by scanning her bladder for fluid. I could not find any. I noticed that the change coincided with the decrease in blood pressure, and I worried if she was in a quasi-hypotensive state. If it was affecting her kidneys, I wondered what else might be affected, so I reached out to the physician. I outlined my concerns, my reasonings, and what I thought might be wrong. It took Dr. P less than ten seconds to mention “renal artery stenosis.” From our efforts, Dory got the help she needed, and it reinforced that there was more for me to do, more for me to know. Caring for Dory, titrating drips, giving chemo, I had tasted the science of medicine and proved again and again to myself that I need the fuller breadth of knowledge that comes with being a physician like Dr. P.

As a future physician, my goal is to continue to serve my patients as a knowledgeable advocate. My own journey of self-discovery has highlighted that every person wants to be seen, heard, and treated like the person they are. In hospitals, patients feel sick and vulnerable; often, they are lying down, their beds nearly on the floor, as the team hovers over them. In caring for patients, I sit with them at their side, on their level. With Ana, I fought to keep her off a ventilator, staying beside her to titrate her oxygen, despite the dangers of the unknown pandemic. In caring for Dory, I had an intuition and advocated for her, and realized that I had a hunger for the knowledge that Dr. P so effortlessly displayed. I have cared for many patients as a nurse; now I'm ready to become a physician so that I can not only serve as a partner and an advocate for my patients but also have the knowledge to guide the team in finding and implementing the best treatment for my patients.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
I have loved learning about cultures different from my own, caring for others. In my public health clinical course as an undergraduate nursing student my professor taught us something that I took with me into my practice. Dr. O‚ÄôConnor was a pillar within nursing and cared primarily for homeless populations and those in areas around Boston Medical Center. She taught me the power of a bed bath as a metaphor. The moral was to always see your patient as they wish to be seen, as a person with life experience and the ability for kindness._x000D_
 _x000D_
I have seen first-hand patients scared to receive care because of the cost, patients that do not fully understand their diagnosis or care plan, and fear over laws passed that will directly impact patients. As a transgender woman I look towards the courts with trepidation, as a future physician I look forward to providing care to my patients in an affirming and compassionate manner. _x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
Singing bowls, scented oils, chanting, and ceremonial clothing are not what most people think of when they think of May 2020. Less so when people think of a nurse during the COVID pandemic. A nurse is first a patient advocate, even after that patient has passed away. Before my Buddhist patient was intubated, she asked that if she were to not wake up, would we help her priest uphold her traditions? I heard her request, and she died not long after she was intubated. I had her priest‚Äôs number and called him; I navigated a ritual for a culture I was unfamiliar with over zoom. _x000D_
 _x000D_
I was able to organize for the priest‚Äôs son to bring me a box of oils and clothing. The priest, the patient‚Äôs family, and her friends all joined the zoom call. I had never been introduced to a ritual like this and am honored to have taken part. While it was far from the perfect postmortem care she would have received outside the hospital were this not COVID, I did my best to advocate for her wishes. _x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact: The COVID-19 pandemic took the world by storm. I distinctly remember volunteering in early March 2020 for the first COVID ICU in Boston at my hospital of Massachusetts General. While this time was difficult for myself, my coworkers, my patients, and their families, I am eternally grateful to have been a nurse during this time. I still harbor many memories filled with grief from holding the hands of those who were dying without their families. Calling their loved ones and trying to set up zoom calls immediately before intubation, the last time many families might see their loved one alive and I was the only person present. It was during this time that I decided to pursue medicine. My physician colleagues worked tirelessly during COVID to help their patients, to help staff members, and to look for anything that might heal. I was inspired by this dedication and am on the path to medicine with this medical school application. I am grateful to have been a nurse during the pandemic.

Major_Long_Desc: Physiology and Developmental Biology; Spanish Studies
personal_statement:
It was mid-July and despite wearing two down jackets and a hat, Alvin shivered uncontrollably. As we played games, he told jokes and shared stories about his children and grandchildren. When I inquired, Alvin explained that his chills were a side effect of his treatments for Hodgkin’s Lymphoma. To temper the chills, Alvin microwaved a sock filled with rice and tucked it under his shirt. I loved this solution. As his health declined, I learned more about his cancer and continual suffering. My relationship with Alvin helped me identify my passion for helping those who endure chronic illness. This desire has continued to grow as I have seen individuals with ongoing pain suffer through activities of daily living. I want to be a physician so I can serve and advocate for those with chronic disease. 

After seeing Alvin’s rice remedy, I learned to sew rice bags. I started sewing during Sunday Night Football and by the end of the game, I had 25 bags to deliver to a local oncology clinic. My project has grown over the years. I have taught hundreds of people to make rice bags and have coordinated with pharmaceutical companies and oncology clinics across four states to distribute thousands of bags. Often on deliveries, I would visit with patients as they received infusions. I loved being in the clinical setting and watching physicians create treatment plans to address nausea, infections, and other side effects. Next to such dedicated physicians, I started to question if my efforts were making a difference. Around this time, I received a note from a patient who wrote, “Your thoughtful gift warmed my hands and my heart. Thank you. You will never understand its worth to me.” This note left me with a renewed sense of purpose. As I spent time in oncology clinics, I felt a need to serve patients with chronic conditions whose symptoms continually change and whose diseases may have no cure. 

While continuing to lead the rice bag project, I sought opportunities to work with others who suffer from long-term illness. As I shadowed physicians in different specialties, I saw that chronic disease is not always easy to treat. Like these physicians, I want to focus my training and efforts to work toward better solutions for patients who face limited treatment options for their recurring pain. My interest in chronic disease led me to volunteer with the Arthritis Foundation. As a project coordinator for the Arthritis Foundation, I helped organize the annual Jingle Bell Run. The event was a success by many metrics, but for me, the success came in meeting a six-year-old boy with juvenile idiopathic arthritis. I noticed he sat alone in “Santa’s Workshop” watching others color and paint rocks. When I offered to color with him, he said that he LOVES to color and that he CAN color, but he could not hold onto a skinny crayon due to a recent flare in his hands. This young boy’s pain was debilitating, but invisible to others. I used an elastic to put four red crayons together which created a thicker hold for him. Then, he and I colored together. The realization that this boy’s flare would pass, but his arthritis would not, cemented my resolve to work for those with long-term disease to mitigate temporary and long-term disability. 

I became aware of the invisible suffering of those in the Latino community when I started working as a medical interpreter. I saw that language barriers and other systemic issues often lead to persistent adversity. Such was the case with Luz. The physician looked at Luz and said, “Stage five kidney failure.” Understanding his tone, but not yet his words, Luz waited for me to interpret. Tears flowed down her face as the magnitude of her diagnosis hit—she knew her life would never be the same. Sitting close and listening to her fears about the life-long implications of her condition, I reached out and held her hand. My heart broke for Luz, knowing she had many challenges ahead. I could see that her condition was directly related to lack of insurance and her personal distrust of an unknown medical system. Language barriers, access to care, and other societal roadblocks make life especially difficult for Latino patients and can affect receiving a timely diagnosis. I have tried to help those in Latino communities by translating medical literature for local clinics and canvassing neighborhoods to raise awareness of public health initiatives. I want to help advocate for better access to healthcare in Latino communities as I work with patients like Luz who require ongoing care. 

The image of Alvin shivering in 90-degree heat left a lasting impression on me. Cancer took Alvin’s life last Fall, but our time playing games anchored my desire to help patients like him attain a better quality of life. My experiences with Alvin served as a catalyst for working to ease chronic suffering through the rice bag project, the Jingle Bell Run, and interpreting. As I have seen the constant struggles of those with chronic disease, I have felt a greater pull to work as a physician to help make their lives better. I am eager to begin this path to become a devoted physician to both treat and advocate for those who suffer from chronic illness.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
In Lima, I worked as a triage assistant for 200+ volunteers originating from various countries. When I accompanied 19-year-old Juan to the hospital, he bounced his leg and seemed overly nervous for a simple broken wrist. Having grown up in a village near the Amazon, this was his first time in a hospital. The physician arrived and asked Juan if he wanted him to consult a ‚Äúhuesero,‚Äù a traditional healer. Juan was relieved and grateful. This physician had a keen understanding of his patient‚Äôs needs and was able to combine the practices of modern and traditional medicine to help him._x000D_
 _x000D_
Closer to home, my interpreting showed me that every physician treats diverse populations. Lack of insurance and a distrust of our healthcare system affect many in the Latino community. While one person cannot become an expert on every cultural norm, being sensitive to them can help provide better care. I am dedicated to the diverse student body and patient base associated with Rush Medical College._x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
Making and sharing burritos with the most vulnerable population in Salt Lake City opened my eyes to the effects of societal and structural determinants of health. When I started passing out burritos along Rio Grande Street, I saw many addictions and obvious mental health concerns people faced. In this setting, I wondered if a burrito helped anyone at all._x000D_
One year into the Burrito Project, a project volunteer was touring a social services facility aimed at helping women who are homeless. On the tour, our volunteer told of her involvement sharing burritos in homeless encampments. When she left, Aly, the receptionist stopped her. Six months earlier, Aly was given a burrito. When she took the burrito, something in her changed. In her words, ‚ÄúI decided then that I could do better. I realized I was worth something. It was hard work, but now I have a job.‚Äù This story far exceeded any hopes of the Burrito Project, but it proves that even small services can have great impact on others.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
While preparing for medical school, COVID affected both my clinical exposure and service opportunities. Thinking restrictions would be short lived, I started working as a remote researcher for UCSF and studying to become a licensed medical interpreter. As restrictions continued, I had to be flexible and adapt. I started video-interpreting which exposed me to many specialties and opened my eyes to many disparities in our current healthcare system. _x000D_
_x000D_
Prior to COVID, I served as the director for the Brighter Horizons service program. When it shut down, I looked for new ways to help others. This is when I started the Burrito Project. Working with the housing insecure for the last two years has helped me understand how this population has multiple comorbidities and faces multiple barriers to healthcare. As I sought new clinical and service opportunities during the prolonged uncertainty of the pandemic, these experiences compelled me to serve as an advocate for the medically underserved.

personal_statement:
Nurses hastily cleared the halls, placed plastic from ceiling to floor, and unspooled tape that read “DO NOT CROSS.” They created a direct quarantined path from the emergency department (ED) doors to a negative pressured exam room. It was March 2020, when rumors spread about a novel virus that is so familiar to us today. As a medical scribe at Emory University Hospital Midtown’s ED, I was working on patient charts, sitting behind the charge nurse when she received a call from EMS en route transporting a patient in respiratory distress directly from the airport. We anticipated potentially the first patient infected with COVID on the east coast. Nursing staff and physicians donned personal protective equipment, holding an uncanny resemblance to astronauts exploring a new world, and carefully entered the patient’s room to administer care. Witnessing these moments of courage, at a time when little was known about COVID and no vaccinations existed, have profoundly inspired me to become a physician. Doctors are one of many types of front line workers fighting against medical threats to humanity in new and ever changing atmospheres. Watching these doctors brave the unknown, to take care of patients when nobody else could, was my call to action to become a doctor.
 
I believe that health equity and health literacy are crucial for patient care and for the public. At the hospital, we take care of a notable amount of patients who are minorities, and unfortunately, some experiencing homelessness. These patients frequently presented to the ED unvaccinated, with COVID-like symptoms, and were skeptical about the safety and efficacy of the COVID vaccines. If they had the proper resources about the vaccine, their visits to the ED might have been avoided altogether. I have had the honor of working closely with Dr. John Lewis on two major projects that focus on health equity, literacy, and education. Coincidentally, only months before the pandemic began, one of these projects focused on spreading the word of health disparities through a layperson's health literacy startup called Emergency Medicine Remix. This began as a podcast centered on the social determinants of health and how they affect care in emergency departments and later, we created episodes with vaccination facts. At that time, I had not realized how important this work would become. 
 
As a founding member of Health Spoken, our second project, I worked closely with Dr. Lewis and a team of resident doctors to create an educational platform on health topics unfamiliar to the general population. Health is a hybrid language that changes constantly over the course of time and is often misunderstood. The complexity has been exacerbated by misinterpreted medical jargon, social disparities, and inequitable access to healthcare. Our mission seeks to break down the complexity of health into something digestible and understandable, to provide a better understanding of this universal language to patients and providers alike. This project has helped me realize how multifaceted healthcare is, especially for the patient. Each patient comes from different backgrounds and levels of understanding of health. As a future physician, I want to apply what I learned from this experience by adjusting my care to each patient and providing them with appropriate resources.
 
As a volunteer, I built houses with Habitat for Humanity at the Medlock 7 site for the Ervin family. The couple and their young child were eager to move into their home, slated to be completed at the end of the summer. The main cohort of volunteers I worked with were retired men with a passion to build. The house started with a slab of concrete in a field of dirt, and as the house was built into a two story structure, so did the camaraderie among us volunteers. This community service opportunity was a beautiful parallel to the physician profession. The wealth of knowledge I gained from my team was similar to how education in the medical field is passed on; from attending to resident and from doctor to patient. The volunteers, uniting to build the house, was similar to how doctors work with their patients to provide a plan of care. This experience helped me realize my passion in helping others, as I saw the joy of the family once the house was completed, and to know that they still utilize what I helped build. As I was hammering nails and painting walls for the welfare and benefit of the Ervin family, I imagined this is how it feels to practice medicine: to help others with all of the might, empathy, and conviction within me. I strive to continue to help people by going to medical school so that I can provide care to patients and enhance my tools from hammer and paintbrush to stethoscope and white coat.
 
The culmination of my experiences have given me a mission to pursue a career in medicine to serve people in their time of need. I have learned that care begins with treating the person before the disease, doing so with an open dialogue about health equity, education, and public health. My experiences allowed me to realize how essential it is for providers to exhibit empathy, tact, and patience to effectuate care that not only heals patients, but builds their trust in the medical profession.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: When I began my undergraduate career, I was looking for a community where I could feel included. In terms of Asian representation on campus, the Vietnamese Student Association was the only organization available at the time. Though I was proud to be a part of an organization that celebrated my own culture, a group of friends highlighted how there is a lack of other Asian cultures represented as well. I had the opportunity to charter Pi Delta Psi Fraternity, Inc., the first Asian interest fraternity on my university‚Äôs campus. Our goal was to bring a voice to all Asian cultures on campus by hosting events to increase cultural awareness and establishing an Asian American office on campus. My role as vice president of the chapter was to communicate with other organizations in the Multicultural Greek Council, assisting me in learning about other cultures I was not familiar with.
