Overall, this experience helped me grow my respect in my own culture and cultures from around the world.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I believe that my personal goals align with the strategies to improve, especially with the focus on public health and providing health care at the highest level. I have worked closely with my mentor, Dr. John Lewis, and a group of resident doctors to create a health educational platform called Health Spoken. Our aim is to break down the complexity of the language of health into digestible information for patients and providers alike. We realized that this complexity is exacerbated by medical jargon and hard-to-access medical research and literature. We are striving to create mutual health literacy, work hard to provide health equity, and build the people‚Äôs trust in the medical profession for all communities. My goal is to uphold our mission to pursue health equity by expanding this project, and if admitted, to include important conversations with fellow students and educate through the platform and reach more communities.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
When COVID initially hit in 2020, the grading system remained the same scaled GPA system and exams were held online using a proctored webcam system. Classes in my Master of Science program have resumed in-person, with recommendations to wear masks._x000D_
_x000D_
Professionally, I was able to hold my job as an emergency department medical scribe and was promoted to Chief Scribe shortly after the pandemic began. I learned how to deal with unique adversities such as managing a large team during a pandemic and working closely with the medical directors to ensure the job was still safe for the team. Additionally, I learned administrative skills such as scheduling 50+ scribes across two sites during my task of combining two scribe teams into one cohesive team. It was more difficult to find volunteering opportunities, but I was able to find outdoor volunteering opportunities, such as Habitat for Humanity. This allowed me to help with building homes for families in need during the pandemic.

personal_statement:
Compassion, as I've seen it in medical practice, holds beauty not just in its implications of drive and empowerment, but also in the gentle, strong emotional assets that define relationships between caregivers and patients. Early on, the journey into medicine defines compassion as something exclusively fierce and exciting. We’re drawn to role models within the field that are introduced to us by the gravity of their accomplishments. In our tangential exposure to compassion as we may see it in exciting situations, the experience of medicine becomes something measured by intensity. 
This was my impression when I began to complete my ride-along hours in Downtown Fargo to earn my EMT license. While I had always known that I wanted to work in medicine, I sought to establish an early relationship with the field in the most patient care-heavy manner that I could think of by involving myself in emergency medical response. Fargo, though far from a metropolis, functioned as an urban system with a steady flow of calls. After enough time, I acclimated to the rigor of dispatch, assessment, and report. Each emergency followed the same fast-paced appraisals, and every care handoff was precise, tailored, and organized. Enthralled with the balance of efficiency and adventure, I was eager to practice in the coming years. 
I carried my experience with me when I returned to college in Ripon, a town of roughly 7,000--stark in contrast to the environment that I had been both raised and educated in. Fargo’s service was fueled by urban emergencies, but with eight nursing homes and an economy driven by blue-collar work, Ripon aimed to serve a population that not only lived together, but also grew, aged, and suffered together. Ripon’s staff knew their patients and often, their stories. Witnessing these deep interactions ushered me into a new context of emergency care. I was captivated by the love that my coworkers expressed not just for the field, but to the community that had been their home for decades. I began to piece together the side of medicine that had escaped my attention; while urgency was present, there was an overtone of gentle patience just as strong as the fiery drive that I had previously known compassion to be. 
I found this mindset applicable to my life as a college student, too. I stepped into a new administrative role as an assistant residence hall director, tasked with overseeing the community-building activities and resource management offered to first-year students. This position combined the confrontation of sensitive situations and the responsibility of mentoring others in positions of authority. To my dismay, I found that Title IX violations were far from uncommon and needed an urgent response paired with an unconditionally safe space for a student to process aftermath–a philosophy that I encouraged in my direct management of these ordeals and in the guidance I offered to my staff of resident assistants. Balance between immediate intervention and warmth was critical, but mentally heavy on supporting resources. Learning to advocate for the students overcoming this challenge and the resident assistants that they turned to required the same empathy that I had seen in ambulance work, as the concept mirrored the culture that I so admired from the surrounding town. These actions served as a medium for cohesiveness and trust that made an unthinkable trauma one that my community could conquer. 
Despite my student status, I found myself as immersed in the town as I was in the college. At this point, I responded to a rare situation: a patient who had spent her entire life in the community had called 911 for the first time. When I arrived, I met Mary who, at the age of 96, was a completely independent member of her community. Unfortunately, she had fallen and needed help. After 30 minutes of lifting, I was able to offer her comfort in the form of a smile and a promise that we would be there again if she ever needed it. She gave my hand a squeeze and spoke a proud thank-you. Mary took me up on the offer, and as we grew familiar, I watched Mary’s health deteriorate, knowing that kindness was all that I could truly offer her. Finally, I received a call that Mary was febrile and incoherent. As we moved her onto the cot, she refused to let go of my hand. Dropping her grip as she shifted to the hospital bed, She mustered a familiar thank-you. I would find out from her obituary that she died twelve hours later, undergoing palliative care. 
The facet of compassion which inspired me to continue working in emergency response has persisted, but is enhanced with the patience that Ripon’s lessons have instilled in me. While caring for Mary, her constitution and grace humbled me as I discovered that I was powerless against her aging. I began my career as someone who fixed, and I am growing into someone learning how to heal. Inspired by Ripon’s sincerity, I am committed to creating an environment that is both familial and efficient. Ripon’s vulnerability is a key factor in creating a patient-caregiver rapport built on unconditional empathy. Such wisdom has taught me how integral multifaceted compassion is to establishing patient relationships, and reflects how much there is to learn on the path to becoming a physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: While I come from an urban area, Fargo is a far cry from a metropolis. I took a job offer to work from Bell Ambulance in Milwaukee after I received my undergraduate degree and was met with a patient population that I had never encountered. I had experience in both urban and rural EMS prior to the start of my position, but I found myself quickly needing to acclimate to an altogether different population. Unlike the geographical isolation that I had seen in rural communities, those I serve in Milwaukee more often struggle with exposure to violence, addiction, and financial limitations with a deeply-rooted distrust in first responders and large medical systems. Learning how to communicate advice that promotes wellness without stifling a patient's experiences is a balance crucial to my patient-caregiver relationships and something I hope to continue developing as I work with a wider range of diverse patients.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: COVID-19 posed unique challenges to rural Wisconsin healthcare which Ripon's ambulance service struggled to overcome in the midst of the pandemic. Ripon is situated a minimum of 30 minutes away from the nearest specialty care hospital and has a high concentration of geriatric high-risk patients that rely on its limited resources. Furthermore, many doubted the severity of the illness and the efficacy of the vaccine, resulting in vast influxes of incredibly sick patients. ICU beds filled up so quickly that soon, the nearest open rooms were in Chicago. Because our service is volunteer-based, many of my coworkers and I held other roles in the community and as public health resources, we corrected misinformation with our firsthand experience. Slowly, we began to see a higher effort in seeking testing or vaccination, and more caution of social distance. As those around us grew more conscious of their friends and neighbors, we worked through the pandemic as a community.

personal_statement:
The receiver made the catch and it was my tackle to make. When I stepped toward the ball carrier, I felt my knee collapse underneath me. I knew immediately this was my last time on the football field. Up to this point, I already had an interest in science and medicine which convinced me to sign up for a health sciences class my senior year of high school. The second half of this class required us to shadow a medical professional for two months. As the first in my family to graduate college, I had nobody in my family to shadow, nor did I know anybody in medicine. My only option was to ask the surgeon who operated on my knee and hope for the best. At the end of my last post-op follow up appointment, I mustered up the courage to ask this doctor I barely knew if he would allow me into his world for eight weeks. Little did I know at the time that the timidly asked, “would you mind if I shadow you?” would change my whole life course. One wrong step in football practice ended up being the first step in my path to medicine.

Shadowing a pediatric orthopedic surgeon introduced me to the importance of patient relationships which, in turn, lead to better outcomes. I distinctly remember a young talented dancer, “Mary,” who came into the clinic with her mother to review her MRI and develop a treatment plan. Upon hearing the news that she was going to need surgery, both Mary and her mother became very anxious. They were both equally concerned about the operation itself, and the subsequent effect on the daughter’s dancing performance. The surgeon noticed their concern and alleviated their anxiety by answering all of their questions. He even drew out the procedure on the exam table so they knew exactly what was going on. The fear of the unknown is common when undergoing surgery and how the surgeon was able to ease the patient and her mother’s nerves through a simple explanation still resonates with me. A rough drawing was able to gain the patient’s confidence and lead to a treatment plan that everybody was on board with. This experience directly influenced my work as an EMT. I envision myself in the physician’s position, hoping to one day be able to lay out a treatment plan in an easy-to-understand manner that gives the patient confidence.

	As an EMT, I rarely get the opportunity to explain a disease process or sickness to a patient because that role is usually reserved for a physician. However, when I get the opportunity, I strive to emulate the surgeon’s approach to applying education in the treatment process. In a memorable patient encounter in which we were treating a diabetic with high blood glucose, the provider had left the room. Alone with the patient, she asked me why we were giving her fluids when she had been drinking Gatorade all day. I took this chance to use an analogy to clarify our treatment to the patient. I explained in this instance, that her blood is like a cup of Kool-Aid powder. The reason why it is important to drink a lot of water and why we were giving her IV fluids was to “dilute” her sugar and make it less concentrated. Similar to when you pour more and more water into the cup of Kool-Aid powder, the Kool-Aid becomes less sugary. At this time, I saw the “a-ha” moment click in the patient’s head. The patient thanked me for the explanation, saying people have always told her to drink water, but now she understands why and she will make more of an effort to stay hydrated. I hope one simple explanation changed her daily habits to avoid this problem in the future. I desire to be a physician equipped with the highest education and understanding of medicine to not only physically treat, but also to educate patients to get them involved in their treatment and live a healthier life.

On the day of Mary’s operation, I discovered comfort in the familiarity of manual work with instruments in the operating room. I also got to witness Mary come in with a ruptured ligament and walk out of the hospital the same day which still amazes me. Observing the surgeon replace the ligament reminded me of my personal experiences. For generations, all of the men in my family have been construction workers, so growing up I always worked with my hands. The tools used in the operation were very similar to those which I have used all of my life. That day in the operating room, I saw myself in the surgeon’s shoes. I realized that pairing my passion for medicine with the dexterous work I enjoy with my father is a real possibility.

I strive to be a physician who is able to help educate and work alongside his patients while performing the treatment at the highest level. I find fulfillment when I can pass on what I have been studying to a patient to promote their participation in treatment, give them a better understanding of what is happening in their bodies, and help them learn what they can do to live their best life. On the flip side, I love the technical aspects of being a physician that would allow me to marry my deep interest in physiology with my passion for working with my hands. I hope to be a doctor who is not only able to mend patients in the acute phase, but also to equip them with the power to take control of their long-term health through education.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I took a Contemporary African American Social Movements class in college which opened my eyes to the experiences of others in my community and the importance of discussing complex topics to understand those unlike myself. I took this class during the height of the civil unrest following the killings of George Floyd and Jacob Blake. The course took a turn to incorporate discussion on the current events resulting from the dangers Fred Hampton warned about in the sixties. These discussions bred powerful testimonies from my professor and classmates on the type of injustices they face today. I am thankful for my classmates' vulnerability in telling their stories to better understand the fear and uncertainty African Americans are forced to live in daily. I have learned that I will never fully understand what my fellow peers have to go through; however, I can choose to be an advocate for them and welcome spaces for discourse to lift the voices that deserve to be heard.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Working as an EMT has exposed me to the health disparities across socioeconomic lines in our current healthcare system. For example, I had an elderly patient who was extremely underweight, his catheter was filled with blood, and he had a large, untreated skin infection. His wife only spoke Spanish and explained to me that she and her husband were immigrants and had no health insurance or money for medical expenses. The patient was clearly in the condition he was in because of a lack of care due to finances. The usual procedure at my job is to collect a health insurance card or bill the patient as self-pay; however, I knew billing this family would devastate them, so we were able to make some calls and treat our patient for free. This situation made me wonder how many people are battling preventable illnesses due to financial troubles. I now strive to advocate for the disadvantaged and promote equitable healthcare for all who need and deserve it most.
7_-_COVID_Impact: During my freshman year, we had to leave campus and continue school online with one month of school left. My sophomore year was more challenging, the whole year was online, and some courses became more self-guided. I had to retool my learning strategies to guide myself through some of the most challenging classes I have taken. I am grateful for this experience, as it has made me a better student. I was able to help my school during this time by COVID testing students and faculty for monitoring and making campus policy changes. My EMT job began at the height of the pandemic, which opened my eyes to the effects COVID had on my city. Most people we treated at the time were COVID patients, and it seemed like a never-ending fight. I am grateful to everybody I work with for persevering and pushing ourselves and our patients through the thick of the pandemic. COVID has motivated me to push through difficult times and has strengthened my desire to apply for medical school.

personal_statement:
“I feel so broken.” 

That was my journal entry the day I was sexually assaulted as a teenager. Now, I am fully recovered, and I choose to focus solely on using my experience to help others. The symbolism of the crocus flower helped me to heal. It is the first flower to bloom in the spring following dark winters--a reminder that brighter days lie ahead. It gave me hope that I too could bloom. During my recovery, I became passionate about helping others feel similar healing which became the foundation of my interest in medicine.

This desire to help people heal became more concrete while I was volunteering for my church in France. I encountered countless cultures and met people from over 100 countries, many of whom were in desperate need of care. 

A particular experience with Abdul, a refugee from Sierra Leone, deeply impacted my interest in medicine. The 19-year-old had witnessed unspeakable horrors. The Ebola virus killed his mother when he was 12 years old. A gunshot to his left shoulder rendered his arm unusable as he fled his country to escape gang violence. As a political refugee in a foreign country, he often suffered discrimination. Abdul felt emotionally, mentally, and physically broken.
 
One day, we were together when Abdul was racially profiled and kicked off a bus. He became very emotional, and I took his hands in mine and cried with him. After some time, I noticed that his fingernails were long, cracked, and dirty--completely understandable for a physically disabled person living in a refugee camp. I found clippers and cut his fingernails. After finishing, Abdul looked at me and tearfully uttered, “this I needed, this I needed.” I valued this opportunity to comfort my friend, but I wanted to do more. I wanted to heal his dangling arm. I wanted to stop diseases like Ebola from killing more of his family members. This further fueled my desire to become a physician with the training to expertly heal people like Abdul.

Driven by my desire to engage in the broader battle against sexual assault, I work with a sexual assault research team that confronts the issue from an academic and legislative level. I am learning how to become an advocate for this vulnerable population. I helped uncover a faulty prosecution method where officers informally called legal officials one-on-one to decide if a charged suspect should be prosecuted. This was leading to many cases going unprosecuted. I was proud to be part of the team that exposed and abolished this faulty method and helped implement a system where far more parties were involved in the decision to prosecute. The small part I played in implementing these positive changes taught me that protecting vulnerable populations is a team effort, and there are many ways to assist. 

Seeing these changes in my local community gave me the desire to assist at the state level as well. During a legislative session, I lobbied legislators on several bills relating to sexual violence and health policy. I was thrilled to play a minor role in the passing of a bill providing broader contraceptive medication access to prison inmates. 
 
Although research and activism are essential in protecting and advocating for vulnerable people, their need for individual, face-to-face care haunted me. Thus, I became certified as a sexual assault survivor advocate. I was trained to support survivors in the emergency department alongside forensic nurses and physicians. One night, I was called in for a 15-year-old girl who was violently raped by her father. The chilling memory of that young girl’s betrayed, shocked face is etched in my mind, along with her clear need for one-on-one care and empathy. I watched as the skilled healers attended to her and even made her laugh. She said that thanks to them, she had hope. My interest in medicine solidified as I witnessed the invaluable nature of individual care.

Further entrenching myself on the front lines of treatment, I became a scribe in the emergency department. I had the privilege of witnessing compassionate individual care delivered to vulnerable populations. One night, an Indigenous American family wept over the body of their mother, who had succumbed to COVID-19, while a transgender patient battled mental illness in another room. On another occasion, a dejected Hispanic teenager brought in her own father, who had attempted suicide. Seeing others experience such pain and vulnerability makes me grateful for the essential researchers, legislators, and advocates who aim to alleviate such struggles. But in these patients’ moments of anguish and darkness, no study, law, or movement can replace the individual care of an empathetic, skilled physician. 

Like the symbolism of the crocus flower did for me, I want to help people heal and bloom. Though there are many vital ways to accomplish this, my broad desire to help others heal has narrowed to my goal of becoming a physician. Caring for vulnerable people on a personal level is my passion. Physicians are uniquely positioned to provide irreplaceable individual care and compassion, and I desire to cultivate the expertise necessary to help people heal and bloom in this personal manner.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Two years of living in cities with diverse populations like Paris and Brussels taught me how to adjust to urban life and prepared me for Chicago. But more importantly, while volunteering in these metropolises, I met people from over 100 countries and befriended individuals from all corners of the earth. _x000D_
_x000D_
An experience with my friend Manjula from Sri Lanka was particularly eye-opening. One day Manjula and I were almost hit by a truck driver who ran a red light. Without thinking, I expressed how reckless of a person the driver must be. Manjula looked at me and said, "In my country, we do not think like this. We think maybe the driver's child was in the hospital." This experience taught me the pitfalls of always attributing behavior to personality traits and the importance of considering situational factors. The lesson has been especially pertinent while serving marginalized communities. I aspire to care for patients with this balanced perspective.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: While living in Paris, I became close friends with Yassia, a man from Burkina Faso. One of the most intense experiences of my life was when Yassia told me he was considering suicide. He faced extreme rejection from his family after revealing he was gay because In the culture he was raised in, homosexuality is strictly taboo. The situation was daunting partly because we grew up speaking different languages and were raised on separate continents. However, I was determined to help my friend and we had a heartfelt conversation. I tried to convey as much love and compassion as possible. Fortunately, Yassia decided to seek professional help, and he was eventually able to overcome his suicidal thoughts. Though he is doing much better, there are still challenging moments, and we often FaceTime to help him process his emotions. I am grateful to have impacted Yassia by playing a small role in helping him forgo suicide and remaining part of his support system.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
An experience stands out from my time working as an ED scribe during the COVID-19 pandemic. One night, after battling the coronavirus, an Indigenous American woman took her last breath with her family beside her. I wanted to comfort the women's distressed children so badly, but before I could do anything, one of them pulled me into a tight hug. This embrace was impactful because, to me, it symbolizes the need for connection during difficult times._x000D_
_x000D_
Striving for this connection on a global level, during the pandemic I volunteered for The Mali Wellness Foundation, a humanitarian group serving the Malian community. I wanted to positively impact these West African people during the pandemic. Thus, at group meetings, I advocated for bringing COVID-19 vaccines to Mali. Gaining approval was difficult but we willed our way to permission to bring the vaccines. The approval process exposed me to barriers in global healthcare but also showed me the possibilities of global collaboration.

personal_statement:
Through an internship at college, I had the opportunity to work closely with a urologist and neurologist to collect data on urologic symptoms and urodynamic results on young patients diagnosed with Spinal Muscular Atrophy. It was humbling to learn about the many sacrifices these children and their families had to make to find comfort in a lifestyle they were constantly adapting to.  While shadowing at the neurology clinic, I met a teen who belonged to this cohort. When asked how she felt her urinary management was going, she shrugged her shoulders and claimed to be indifferent. Her solemn expression and avoidance of eye contact indicated otherwise. From her body language, she might have been emotionally suffering but didn’t feel like she was in a safe and comfortable space to express it. After all, here she was in front of a physician, parent, and a stranger close to her own age, being asked to describe what is normally a private matter. After a moment of silence, the teen bravely opened up about her struggle with functional incontinence and the immense stress and embarrassment it brought her in social situations. A few weeks later, I had the opportunity to meet this patient again in the urology clinic, and my heart felt full to see her so excited to learn about catheter options that would give her a part of her life back. This moment made me realize that communication between patients and physicians goes beyond words, and that what is not verbally shared by the patient can be just as important as what is. I learned the importance of a physician being able to provide a supportive, non-judgemental space so that patients may feel more comfortable to share the uncomfortable. 
I am intrigued by the complex physiological mechanisms that underlie health conditions, and I am also excited by the opportunity to translate this information in a meaningful way to patients. As part of the molecular muscle physiology lab, I had the opportunity to discuss scientific literature through weekly group meetings and one-on-one discussions with the principal investigator of our lab. We would take this time to evaluate researchers’ experimental design, data analysis, and purpose of the research. I had the opportunity to hear from a variety of perspectives–including other undergraduates, master's students and postdoctoral scholars. Understanding that I had limited background knowledge, the more experienced lab members would eagerly explain unfamiliar concepts in terms that aligned with what we had already learned in classes. Through their explanations, and by openly encouraging us to share our own thoughts, the more experienced team members made me feel valued as a team member. This experience exemplified the value of meeting someone where they are at. Just as I had felt valued in the lab, I want a patient to feel like their contributions to our discussions about health are worthwhile.
My research experiences have also driven my desire to provide evidence-based care. In lab, I had the opportunity to observe the life cycle that research undergoes, that starts from an idea that questions the efficacy of standard protocol and that might end in an alteration in the way a physician approaches their care. We focused largely on cancer-associated muscle and adipose tissue wasting. In addition to understanding the pathophysiology of this disease, we also considered how the timing and severity of this wasting across different genders and body compositions affects patients’ survival outcomes and ability to complete everyday tasks. It was in discussing these findings that I discovered my favorite part of the research process, asking “How are the findings clinically relevant? Can they make a meaningful improvement in a patient’s ability to live their life?”. This passion to understand how these questions are addressed has led me to pursue a certificate in Clinical and Translational Sciences.
Watching the doctors interact with the teen patient, I learned how a physician combines compassion, keen observation, and active listening to empower patients to share their experiences. In the lab, I learned how effective teamwork involves personalized teaching so that patients develop confidence to ask questions about their health and that they feel in control of their health decisions. From both research experiences, I gained an appreciation for the research process and learned how to critically analyze scientific literature. These experiences exemplified skills that I am motivated to continue developing as an aspiring medical student and physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As I screened patients for COVID, many African American males had voluntarily mentioned that they had not and were not planning to receive the vaccine. I will admit that upon first hearing this I was frustrated. I began to research the topic of vaccine hesitancy and came upon the Tuskegee experiment. I am appalled that such a study was conducted on these men, that broke every principle of bioethics- the harmful intent in withholding treatment for syphilis, lack of disclosure to patients about their condition, and the fact that was a particular attack on African Americans. Many of these patients‚Äô parents and grandparents would have been alive to witness this atrocity. Reading about this topic opened my eyes to a part of medicine that I was not yet familiar with. I must evaluate my own shortcomings and educate myself first so that I can be effective in educating others and be proactive in fighting systemic racism as a future physician. In doing this, I can lead by example.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I was a marching band section leader in my senior year of high school. I bonded with each student and built trust, so that they felt comfortable asking me questions and reaching out for help. In the end, I was just another teammate with some advice to share. I held many one-on-one practices when official band practice was over. The night before competitions, I would call my bandmates to ease their nerves and hype them up. I worked with a freshman who was struggling mentally; she confided in me that she had autism and we worked on a plan to improve her confidence and capitalize on her abilities. At the end of the season, she wrote me a beautiful letter with an amazing drawing of her in uniform thanking me for supporting and believing in her, and described how she felt she had grown personally; I‚Äôve brought it with me to college to remind myself that my words do reach others, if I ever begin to doubt myself. I recently found out that she too became section leader in her senior year!
7_-_COVID_Impact: At the onset of COVID, all students were sent home to finish the remainder of classes. Many of the lectures were recorded, which has been very helpful for my education because I often need to listen to explanations of concepts multiple times in order to fully integrate the information into my schema. However, it has also been isolating, as there has been a lack of discussion sections since the beginning of online learning, and it's been difficult to collaborate and get to know other students outside of class as most students have taken courses remotely. Without the in-person learning and discussion sections, I feel that our professors have only gotten to know us through office hour meetings, but they have not seen how we interact with others or actively participate in class. At the same time, I have had the opportunity to work at a dental clinic, do research, and lead my student organization, so I was still able to develop educationally, professionally, and personally.

personal_statement:
One Friday afternoon during my sophomore year of college, I stood in shock, knees shaking, as my mother fought through tears to let me know my grandfather had suddenly passed away from a heart attack. On the three-hour trip home that day, I flashed back through all of the memories I shared with my grandfather. One that stood out to me was the first time I saw the long pink scar that ran down his chest while swimming at the lake. The scar, served as a constant reminder of all he had been through, while simultaneously representing the life-saving treatment. I realized my grandfather's surgery had changed my life just as it had changed his. I began to realize that all the times we stood side by side casting our fishing lines into the water would have been impossible without that surgery. On that drive home, my desire to become a physician was sparked as I knew I wanted to heal patients just as the doctors had done for my grandfather.
As I began exploring my interest, my first shift volunteering at a free clinic was later that year. I nervously called “T” back from the lobby to obtain her vitals and collect her history. Entering the bare room and sighing in distress, she informed me of her long-standing history of hypertension and a recent struggle with excruciating headaches. Slowly releasing the air from the cuff, I documented her blood pressure. T begins telling me how she is a single mother, battling depression since her teenage son passed away in a car accident. Teary-eyed and smiling, T told me how much I reminded her of her son because of my demeanor. I could tell most of her stress was dissipating as her posture straightened. Once the doctor rechecked her blood pressure it was near the normal range. I knew that even though she was in pain thinking of her son during our conversation, T was glad someone was there to listen. I could only assume that through our conversation, she was able to better process her son's death. As overjoyed as I was that I could make an impact as a clinic volunteer, I wanted to be able to do more to help T’s physical and mental conditions. I knew as a physician, I would be able to diagnose patients like T and provide the care that they deserve.
On a beautiful day during the following summer, I was setting up a glucose monitoring booth at a community health event in rural eastern North Carolina. “Joe” was approaching our booth and I could tell he was curious yet hesitant. As Joe was reading the sign, he mentioned never checking his blood sugar and never visiting the doctor. To encourage him to establish care, I gave him a pamphlet that had several phone numbers of local doctors’ offices. To ease his nerves, I demonstrated how the test was done on my finger. With a small smile on his face, Joe sat down and extended his hand allowing me to prick his finger. He let out a huge sigh of relief as I showed his blood sugar was within the normal range. Walking away, Joe and his wife were discussing which office they would call while flipping through the pages of the pamphlet. From this experience, I realized the importance of taking the time to make a connection and establish trust with a patient. As a physician, I aspire to continue to improve the health of patients in underserved areas while also educating and comforting them on their path to improving their health.
In my last year of college, I started Railcare’s first mobile clinic in my area. I squeezed and pricked “Pedro’s” finger, collecting enough blood to place into the Hepatitis-C testing vial. Through conversation, Pedro mentioned he was not established with a physician because he was unemployed. When I saw the line indicating the test was positive, my stomach sank. Although it was my first time delivering news like this, I knew that I could get him the help he needed. I could see Pedro’s fear melt away as I explained I would connect him with free treatment. Later that week, the center updated me that Pedro was receiving antiviral treatment. While I was thrilled to assist Pedro with getting the treatment he needed, I aspired to be the physician that provided that care. This further intensified my passion to become a physician because I desire to lead and oversee the long-term care of patients facing diseases like Pedro. 
I am continuously humbled throughout every patient encounter, and eternally grateful to be a part of the team providing them care. Thus far, my experiences have shown me that I can positively impact people's lives in a wide variety of roles. However, I constantly find myself longing to have the ability to do more for their care. I believe that, in addition to my constant involvement in the community, becoming a physician will expand my capacity and reach to make an impact through practicing medicine. The intersection of combining true human connection with the ability to practice medicine is where I aspire to place my influence. In the future, I hope to build upon my current skills to heal patients like my grandfather, diagnose and treat patients like T, educate and comfort patients like Joe, and provide long-term care for patients like Pedro.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Over my two and a half years at the Greenville Community Shelter Clinic, I have met many patients from diverse backgrounds. I felt the vulnerability in ‚ÄúGreg‚Äôs‚Äù tone and saw the fear on his face as he told me he had gone without access to healthcare or healthy meals for several years. Realizing it was not his own choices, but rather the circumstances that led him to develop diabetes. I knew at that moment that the only difference between Greg and myself was the series of things that were out of our control. I couldn‚Äôt help but think that I could have easily been in Greg‚Äôs situation with a simple flip of fate. I also found myself thinking that if Greg was insured, his diabetes could have been prevented or managed better earlier on. This signified that no one chooses to become ill, homeless, or poverty-stricken and everyone like Greg should have access to healthcare. My experiences like this one have furthered my passion to care for the underserved.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: One experience that was very meaningful to me since my graduation was organizing the free mobile clinic that provided HIV/Hep-C testing and the connection to free treatment to the community. This mobile clinic led me to meet and provide testing to patients like ‚ÄúDawn‚Äù. I was relieved and excited to tell Dawn she was negative for both HIV and Hep-C. However, I think equally important was being able to give pamphlets with information on how to prevent these diseases in the future and discuss this with her. Many patients, including Dawn, were surprised to learn of the ways to prevent HIV and Hep-C. Providing this kind of screening and educational prevention, I was confident in its benefit to the community as it spreads the goal of safe practices throughout. I desire to bring this type of involvement to Rush Medical College and the community of Chicago‚Äôs west side and create a lasting change for patients in the community.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
As I left for spring break I was excited to continue shadowing Dr. Guo when I returned. However, during our spring break at East Carolina University, the COVID-19 restrictions took place. I chose to pursue virtual shadowing opportunities, and I was able to gain insight into interesting specialties that I didn't know existed, such as culinary medicine. It was extremely inspiring to learn how Dr. Neison took the extra step by teaching her patients how to cook healthy meals at her primary care practice._x000D_
Before COVID-19, I also had completed training and planned to become a research assistant in a neuroscience lab at East Carolina University. Dr. Issa‚Äôs lab was using zebrafish as a model for studying aggression and I was looking forward to participating in this research. Although, due to the pandemic restrictions, I was unable to. However, I love the neuroscience lab I am in now at the Brody School of Medicine with Dr. Murashov, using drosophila (fruit flies) to research epigenetics.

Hrdshp_Comments:
We were living in Cicero, a predominantly Hispanic town outside of Chicago, until one day, shots rang outside our front door and a man ran through our yard to evade the police. My parents feared that the environment was not one that would support the life and opportunities they wanted us to have. This experience empowered them to make the decision to move. 

My family then moved to the suburbs, where we now faced a new array of challenges. Due to the higher cost of living, my parents worked multiple laborious jobs. I was eight when I helped my mom fill out her paper application to a local retail store. In high school, I started working to ease the financial burden on my parents. I had aspirations to attend college but I was worried about how to get there. I navigated the college process on my own as the educational system did not provide adequate resources for students with diverse backgrounds. I sought out and applied for free college test preparation and received a generous scholarship that provided me the opportunity to attend college. 

During college, I worked multiple jobs both during busy semesters and the summer to support myself financially. I am extremely grateful for the sacrifices my parents have made that allowed me to pursue medical education as these experiences have made me resilient.
Inst_Action_Desc: In my first week of college during my first freshman semester, I received a dorm conduct violation for writing on my friend's door decorations in the residence hall. I took full responsibility for my actions and reported myself to the resident assistant. I subsequently wrote apology letters and redid all door decorations for the residents. After the incident, I reflected on my character and did not want these actions to represent who I am. I worked diligently to earn a leadership position in the campus dorms. I learned the importance of integrity and that our immature decisions have consequences. I greatly regret my mistake but am fortunate to have been able to redeem my character, learn from my mistakes, and I did not receive any other disciplinary actions throughout college.
personal_statement:
I still struggle with trying to imagine a child being held responsible for understanding the complexities of summarizing doctors' visits for their parents. However, this was the reality for me growing up in a Hispanic family where English was not our first language. During this time, my mother was anxiously aiming to promote her new cleaning service by handing out flyers and my father was working paycheck-to-paycheck. My childhood encompassed many responsibilities including translating impossible doctor visits to my parents. Looking back, becoming a physician seemed like a wild dream. 

As years passed, my responsibility and the difficulties with understanding medicine for my parents grew. The most difficult was the moment my father came to me and handed me the papers that solidified his cancer diagnosis. The emotions are hard to encompass; even though I was not his doctor, I had to be the one to read what was written for his diagnosis. As my father was being treated, he shared a room with a man, “Mr. R”. I slowly introduced myself, and throughout time I came to understand that this man was afraid, alone, and confused. Just like my parents, he was an immigrant from Mexico with little family in the U.S. and hardly spoke English. Although the hospital offered online translation services, it seemed as though the interpersonal relationships with the medical team were missing which propagated the isolation that he was feeling. I felt a connection to him and reflected on all that I have been through with my own parents, including the physical, mental, and emotional struggles of being a first-generation child of Mexican immigrants in America. My interest in serving my community is personal and my passion for wanting to connect with patients like my parents and Mr. R encouraged me down the path to becoming a physician

Looking to advocate for my community and to bridge the language barrier between patients and physicians, I decided to volunteer as a Spanish-English Interpreter at a clinic for underserved and uninsured patients. Here, I met “Jon”, a middle-aged Hispanic man who had come in for a routine check-up. Having the privilege to interpret the conversation between Jon and the physician it became clear that he was struggling with untreated mental illness due to cultural stereotypes and a lack of resources in his community. For Latinos, “machismo” is a form of traditional gender roles where men are held responsible for the financial stability of the family, not showing emotion, and mental illness is seen as a weakness. The interaction taught me that while there are fundamental economic issues that prevented him from finding care, there were also other social, environmental, and cultural barriers that impacted his health. It was through interpreting appointments for patients like Jon, that it became evident to me that health is a complex combination of an individual's experience and identity. The experience I shared with Jon made me think of my own parents and how they struggled with the cultural barriers within their healthcare. The interactions I witnessed exemplified the need for physicians that display cultural sensitivity to connect with patients from different backgrounds, and I hope to use my experiences to improve healthcare for underserved populations.

My Latino Studies course also became an influential component of my desire to become a physician. I remember being frustrated when learning about the marginalization of Latina women that perpetuated mistrust between the community and physicians during the time of mass sterilization in the 1970s. This helped me develop a passion for women’s health and the role of social determinants of health (SDOH) in medicine. Working in the College of Medicine at the University of Illinois Medical Center (UIH), I established my own research project to explore a variety of factors that influence the composition of gut microbiota and blood-glucose levels in expectant mothers from Chicago, as well as lead a first-author publication. Analyzing the relationships between blood glucose levels, food deserts, education, and economic stability, I saw the impact these SDOH had on perpetuating health inequity in lower-income communities. It became apparent that lack of preventative care access further contributed to healthcare disparities with patients taking an hour bus ride to receive basic obstetrics care at UIH. I believe research in areas of SDOH is a crucial aspect to address and understand the long-standing healthcare disparities and improve health equity for all patients. I aspire to not only use medicine as a gateway to connect with underserved communities but also to improve healthcare outcomes for patients with health equity research. 

My own personal experiences with my family, interpreting at a health clinic, and health equity research has contributed to my desire to become a physician. I hope to use my background to diminish the impact of language barriers on the patient-physician relationship. I have grown to understand how SDOH contributes to patient outcomes and want to establish trusting relationships with marginalized patient populations to promote equity and inclusion in healthcare.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Working in Chicago meant that I was sure to work with a diverse patient population. I remember, ‚ÄúTina‚Äù, Tina was from the South side of Chicago and came in for a women‚Äôs health exam. She said that she had not been to a doctor‚Äôs office in years due to inability to locate a close office, having been uninsured, and lack of time as she worked multiple jobs. Speaking with Tina, I realized there is never just one challenge that can prevent an individual from receiving care, but it is their collective situation and many social determinants of health (SDOH)._x000D_
_x000D_
Working with patients like Tina exposed me to the difficulties and disparities marginalized patient populations face. I realized there is a need to improve health equity, especially in providing resources for uninsured patients. My aspiration is to foster trusting relationships with underserved populations by considering all the SDOH that factor into their health and improve health equity._x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
I interacted with a patient, ‚ÄúJess‚Äù, who came in with her child and only spoke Spanish. I felt connected to Jess, as I saw my parents' struggle in her. Understandin the burden that interpreting medical appointments can have on a child as I too had to interpret my parent‚Äôs appointments, I made sure to stay alongside her for her appointment. _x000D_
_x000D_
Jess was uninsured and inquired about lumps in her breast. I assured her that I would work with her to locate a free mammogram. I was able to find a location not too far from her that offered free women's healthcare services. After this instance, I worked to compile free or low-cost resources for future patients or even those that call to inquire about pricing. Through this experience, I have become more aware of the importance of advocacy for underserved communities, especially those patients who need help finding their voice in their healthcare plans. I aspire to continue to be an advocate for the Latino community as a physician.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
At the start of the pandemic, my dad began cancer treatment, and my family struggled financially. I worked more to pay for school and other expenses. Also, my experiences shadowing, Dr. Patel, and volunteering as a Spanish interpreter for uninsured patients was cut short. Therefore, I looked for work as a medical assistant._x000D_
_x000D_
During the COVID surge, we saw over 600 patients a day for testing. As the only Spanish-speaking worker, I spent a lot of time working with my community, the Latino population, to help translate COVID-19 test and vaccine education. I worked closely with physicians to create informational Spanish documents for primary care services. I realized that  physician mistrust in underserved communities continues to be an important issue in healthcare. It is important as physicians that we acknowledge the bias and the historic systemic racism that exists in medicine in order to help rebuild the trust with underserved patient populations.

personal_statement:
David tilted his head and narrowed his eyes as he tried to write down the words that were almost as long as the chalkboard itself. He ran his hands through his hair, let out a big sigh, and put his pencil down. 
As the Instructional Assistant, I was reviewing the different types of HIV drugs with my undergraduates in UCSD’s AIDS Science and Society class. After handing out the weekly activity, I sat next to David who I noticed had begun doodling comics. I sensed that David was overwhelmed so I quickly thought of a way to re-engage him in the material. We began to draw the life cycle of HIV as a comic. As he drew, I asked him to explain how each drug could interrupt the disease progression, suggesting that we forget about the technical terms and simply focus on the treatments.

David drew and I listened; as he spoke, I could almost hear the gears in his head clicking into place. I was excited when David found the confidence to stand up in front of the class and explain the drug functions to his fellow students by replicating his drawings on the board. Devising creative methods to facilitate understanding in my students parallels the pedagogical aspect of medicine that I am so drawn to.  

My passion for medicine grew as I saw how the drugs that my students had to memorize became life-changing medications for many of our patients in the infectious disease clinic. I remember the day that Ana came to the clinic for the first time. As the medical assistant, scribe, and Spanish interpreter, I noticed her right away when she asked if she could fill out the forms in Spanish. She spoke with a cracking voice, avoiding eye contact in hopes that I could not see the tears on her face. She sat with her head down as if she did not quite belong.

Ana seemed about my age. Her accent and fear of judgment reminded me of when I first moved from Mexico to the US. I am no stranger to speaking in broken English. I, too, stared blankly at others as they talked, and wondered when I was going to feel like I belonged in a place I was supposed to call my home. It was precisely these familiar feelings that led me to become a medical interpreter—I wanted to make patients feel like they belonged.
As Dr. Haddad explained that Ana's HIV lab results were positive, I carefully interpreted every word into Spanish. When Dr. Haddad asked if she had any questions, she simply shook her head. I encouraged Ana to ask anything that was on her mind. She slowly raised her eyes and began to ask about the effects of the virus on her body and the side effects of her medications. When the consultation was finished, she thanked me and told me that she never thought that she would be able to see a doctor whom she actually understood—let alone one who made her feel seen and heard.

The four walls of Dr. Haddad’s clinic were the best classroom. Ana, along with many other patients, taught me that being an interpreter goes beyond exchanging one word for another. Interpreters must be patients' advocates and foster an environment where patients feel deserving of quality healthcare. Within those four walls, while the patients learned about their conditions and treatment options, I learned that being a physician means much more than diagnosing rare infections. It means calming an anxious mind, restoring dignity in a body that has given up, and spending time to care for someone who feels like they are alone in the world.

Perhaps the best place where I’ve learned to appreciate the intricacies that surround a diagnosis is the Eben-Ezra church on the rural outskirts of Tijuana, Mexico. Once a month, a group of 20 volunteers and I transformed the church into a free community clinic. The pews became the waiting area, the kitchen the triage station, and the office an exam room. Sonia was one of the regulars. She never missed a clinic as it was the only time she had access to medical care and medications. One month, she was unusually anxious; she had been losing weight and experiencing night sweats. As the clinic director, I stayed after everyone left to coordinate all the studies ordered by the volunteer providers. Sonia needed bloodwork and a CT scan to rule out cancer.

Seemingly simple tasks for patients with access to labs, imaging centers, and transportation were like solving a complex puzzle for those like Sonia who did not have access to medical resources. I worked alongside the community health worker to help Sonia get the necessary tests done. A sense of accomplishment washed over me when I called Sonia to share the results: they were negative. Serving as the clinic director for the non-profit International Health Collective sparked my interest in the social factors that contribute to patients’ health. 
I want to be a physician as the profession truly encompasses the matters that I aim to commit my life to: teaching, advocating, and addressing the needs of communities facing barriers to health. I aspire to tailor my approach to teaching my future patients in a way that best fits their needs, just as I did with David. I will strive to make them feel seen and heard, the way Ana felt when she walked out of the clinic, and I am devoted to working with underserved communities in hopes that one day, patients like Sonia will receive the care they deserve.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
In family dinner conversations, every sentence contains a mix of different languages. Most of the sentence is usually in Spanish, with words in Hebrew, Yiddish and English sprinkled in between._x000D_
_x000D_
After being raised in a tight-knit Latin Jewish community for 18 years, I craved interaction with individuals from cultures and backgrounds different from my own. Therefore, during my undergraduate career, I sought experiences that could offer me this opportunity._x000D_
_x000D_
As an orientation leader, I worked alongside 17 staff members in helping incoming students transition into college. The staff was as diverse as the incoming class; we all had different nationalities, socioeconomic statuses, sexual orientations, and religions. This experience taught me that willingness to learn and being open-minded is vital to working with individuals from different backgrounds. At Rush Medical College, I am committed to practicing cultural humility recognizing that I am always in the process of learning and growing.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
As a medical assistant at the Haddad Clinic, I noticed that although many of our patients had limited English proficiency (LEP), trained medical interpreters were not provided during their visits. Therefore, I sought to establish measures that ensured that our LEP patients received the same quality of care as their English-speaking counterparts. _x000D_
_x000D_
I collaborated with insurance companies to learn about the language interpreting services they offered. Using this information, I ensured every patient had access to a medical interpreter during each consultation. Additionally, I coordinated the translation of our patient intake forms and educational materials into our patients‚Äô native languages. It was rewarding to see how these changes improved our patients‚Äô level of satisfaction and comfort._x000D_
_x000D_
As a future physician, I am committed to providing quality care to diverse communities, taking into account their unique social and cultural context to ensure that none of my patients are left behind.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
I crossed the US-Mexico border, not knowing that it would be the last time that I would be able to cross in months. In the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic, I became the clinic director for the International Health Collective's free clinic in Tijuana, Mexico. _x000D_
_x000D_
The rapid increase in COVID-19 cases, along with the closure of the border, made it challenging to continue running our monthly clinics in person. Although the communities we worked with had limited access to technology, I had to find a way to transform the clinic into a virtual format. I worked closely with Gina, the community health worker in Tijuana, to devise a sustainable way to run the clinic virtually. While Gina worked with the local community to take vital signs and distribute medications, I recruited medical providers and interpreters to run the virtual consults. _x000D_
_x000D_
Leading a binational free clinic during the pandemic was one of the most difficult projects that I have embarked on, but it was also the most rewarding.

personal_statement:
The palpable silence beckoned thought and reflection. Only minutes ago, I, and two of my friends, had carried another friend of ours into a humble hospital in the middle of rural Michigan. After a day at the beach, she became extremely dehydrated. Combined with a migraine, her condition worsened until it became obvious that immediate medical attention was required. As I sat in the parking lot, waiting for her parents to finish the ninety minute drive to the hospital, I realized that this day, and the role I played in it, seemed like a culmination of why I have chosen to pursue a career as a physician. 
Months afterwards, my friends would comment on the unwavering calm I unknowingly radiated as I sent one person running to get some sort of anti-nausea drug and then embarking on our journey to the nearest hospital, all within minutes of our friend's condition turning for the worse. This sense of calm has originated from years of standing in the middle of a Randori circle, a Hapkido drill in which multiple attackers circle a person and attack randomly. It had served me well before. A day entrenched in my mind is an afternoon at the Genesee County Free Medical Clinic when a beloved member of the clinic community arrived with a 178/82 blood pressure. As medication was quickly given, I was responsible for continually monitoring his blood pressure. I had taken blood pressures hundreds of times, but I fully realized that the stakes were now raised. Even so, I observed his blood pressure gradually decline back to normal as the entire clinic breathed a sigh of relief. As a pre-med student, these situations give me the confidence that I can roll with the punches brought on by medical emergencies, just as I learned to do on the Hapkido mat. 
As I continued to play the day back in my mind, I remembered the phone call I made to my friend's mother as I drove to the hospital. I asked if she would be okay with calling an ambulance. I heard the pain in her voice as she explained that her husband had just lost his job and that an ambulance would irreparably set them back financially. Before I handed the phone to her daughter in the back seat, still hunched over the plastic trash bag I had given her, the mother told me with a broken voice that I should continue to drive to the hospital. I recognized the tone in her voice. It was the same voice of the woman who limped into the free clinic with a broken leg, knowing that we couldn't fix it, but also being aware that she could not walk into the hospital and receive treatment if she wanted to eat for the next week. It was the same as the man struggling with alcoholism and depression who dragged himself into the clinic looking for any help at all, as he could not afford either medication or therapy. All of these individuals awoke in me the innate desire to do everything in my power to help improve their lives and provide high quality care when they often did not expect it. As the memories flowed through my mind, it was cemented in me that being a physician would allow me to serve a cause greater than myself and employ the calm and focus that comes naturally in tense situations. It would ensure that I could provide the care that those with the broken voices and worried tones needed and deserved for themselves and their loved ones. 
While I sat in the still silent car, a feeling of discontentment gnawed away inside. I had done everything I could, yet I still felt uneasy. Again, I recognized the feeling. A year ago, while I was home for the weekend, my mother called me downstairs and told me that it felt like her heart was racing and she felt uneasy. After I dug my stethoscope and blood pressure cuff out of my car, I found that her blood pressure was slightly elevated. Strange, but nothing incredibly concerning. But as I felt her radial artery pulse against my fingers, I could tell something was wrong. When only 45 seconds had gone by, I had counted 150. A few months later, she experienced an episode of stroke-like symptoms which she later described as feeling like lightning coursing through her body constantly. Countless trips to the emergency room later with no answers, my family was referred to Cleveland Clinic, where physicians were able to diagnose hyperadrenergic POTS. Simply being able to put a name to the symptoms she was experiencing felt like a breath of fresh air, but I was then able to witness these physicians work tirelessly to provide treatment and support. Most importantly, they were able to provide hope that life may just get back to normal someday. The calming presence, insatiable work ethic, and desire to do everything possible for their patients inspired me to further improve my own clinical skills. It fueled the desire in me to work harder so that future patients could have hope for tomorrow. They demonstrated to me that with growth and continued learning, I myself could be capable of being a good physician. The thought continually raced through my mind "This is where I am meant to be."
While I recognized that feeling of discontent of not being able to do more to alleviate my friend's condition, it reminded me of all the reasons I am a pre-med student and look forward to the day when I am able to fully provide treatment, calm, and hope to future patients.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Rounding the corner of the hallway for the first time that shift, I noticed the blinking call light of a patient‚Äôs room. As I knocked and entered the room, I was met by a bedridden elderly woman. Before I could ask what she needed, I was met by the exclamation of ‚ÄúNo man, no man, please.‚Äù I saw the fear and apprehension in her eyes as I quickly left the room and asked a female nurse assistant to assist the patient. A nurse familiar with the patient later told me that according to the patient‚Äôs culture, as a man, I was not to provide care. The nurse said that the patient appreciated my swiftness to get someone else to provide care in order to respect her beliefs. I will always remember the fear of the patient when I first walked into the room. It demonstrated that, even though she needed care, she was ultimately concerned with following her beliefs. It showed me that care must go hand in hand with thoughtfulness of a patient‚Äôs cultural and religious beliefs._x000D_
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Working at a free clinic in Flint, Michigan, I have witnessed firsthand the health disparities that plague the patient population. The effects of the Flint water crisis still grip a community in which a large percentage already live below the poverty line. Hypertension, diabetes, and depression are prevalent and many do not have insurance and are unable to find employment. In one instance, I took a new patient to a room, took his vitals, and asked him his reason for visiting the clinic. Staring at the floor, he told me of his severe depressive symptoms and the anger issues that came with them. He felt his life was spiraling. He could not afford therapy and was desperate for help. He spoke for twenty minutes as I sat, listening in the chair beside him. Weeks later, this man thanked me for putting him at ease in a place in which he normally feels uncomfortable. Thankfully, we were able to secure a free appointment with a therapist, assisting this man on his journey to a healthier life._x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact:
I feel extraordinarily fortunate that I was able to begin at a free clinic on the first day that they reopened to see patients in-person in 2020. I volunteered to distribute countless COVID tests during that summer, proud that I was able to directly help a community at the peak of the pandemic. _x000D_
Soon after, COVID truly hit home. My mother experienced an episode of stroke-like symptoms that rendered her bedridden for weeks. She then experienced symptoms characterized by her blood pressure spiking and her heart rate rising to over 200 beats per minute. She was referred to Cleveland Clinic. She was diagnosed with hyperadrenergic POTS as a result of COVID. At this point, I was back at school, endlessly grateful that I was able to learn in-person, but wishing I was home with my family to help. Late night phone calls from emergency rooms, and long drives home after being tested for COVID characterized my school year, adding to the pressure of an already rigorous school and research schedule.

personal_statement:
“There is nothing I can do for you.” Hearing these eight words once is enough to crush a soul but imagine hearing them repeatedly in a monotonous cycle of disappointment. You are in a foreign place, the lights are blinding, everyone is in a rush, and the halls are filled with subdued crying. You pause and ask yourself, “Do I really need to be here? Will they even try and help me this time?” The vulnerability associated with admitting you have a problem can be crippling, especially when you have been told time and time again that “nothing can be done for you.”
     If asked ten years ago why I wanted to be a doctor, I simply would have said because they fix people. Both my grandmother and mother are registered nurses, and I vividly remember sitting around the dining room table listening in awe as they shared stories from their day. They spoke about performing CPR and administering many different medications, being sure to stop and explain to me what each drug did and why it was needed. I looked forward to these conversations because I was comforted in knowing my mother and grandmother were making a difference. In retrospect, my younger self was infatuated with the notion that being a doctor meant you got to fix people and help those around you. 
     It was not until I was a scribe in Dr. Gregory Kechejian’s office at Beth Israel Deaconess Hospital Milton that I realized being a doctor is more than simply helping others. This realization came when I was in the clinic. We saw a patient who presented with Mondor’s disease, which is incredibly rare and predominantly affects women; however, in this case, the patient was a 25-year-old male who was utterly defeated. He had exhausted all options and was looking for help anywhere he could find it. While I watched the physician-patient interaction unfold in real-time, everything began to make sense. While it is true that doctors “fix” and “help those around them,” these phrases just barely scratch the surface of what being a doctor is. It is more than just treating the disease; it is about treating the patient, the person behind the disease. The patient is the priority. Dr. K knew this, and I was learning. I was learning what it meant to be a doctor and how to have the impact on others my mother and grandmother had on me. 
     When I applied to West Point, my grandfather sat me down and told me, “West Point teaches individuals to lead the world.” Initially, I struggled to understand this saying’s meaning; however, as time progressed, its meaning and relatedness to medicine became clearer. To be a good leader, you need to understand people. The academic, military, and physical rigors of West Point afford individuals like me the ability to reach our full potential as leaders by immersing us in an environment that prioritizes what matters – the people.
     While at West Point, I have had the unique opportunity to fulfill the position of Peer Support Person, responsible for supporting the mental health of 112 people through a network of behavioral health services. Focusing on the individual is imperative because the person looking for help is more important than the depression, anxiety, or stress they may be suffering from. I have hosted events and held many trainings aimed at improving individual mental health because no one should struggle in silence. This position has allowed me to actualize the lessons I learned as a scribe and become a better leader by providing the opportunity to know individuals not as conditions but as people. 
     Military leaders, including the former Command Sergeant Major of West Point, Ken Killingsworth, live by the saying that “the Army is a people’s organization, where the people are the strongest asset.” This same ideology explains why I want to be a physician, specifically a military physician - the people. Interpersonal interactions are a crucial aspect of medicine. Yes, there is a lot of schooling associated with being a physician. Yes, embarking on a career in medicine is a big commitment. However, the true commitment of someone entering the medical field is recognizing the importance of seeing their future patients as people. The Army’s central focus on people as their strongest asset epitomizes this mindset and is ultimately why I want to be a military physician. Putting people first and making sure those eight soul-crushing words never leave my mouth is how I will commit myself to being the best physician I can be. I recognize that I will not be able to fix everything, but I will strive to be there for my patients by providing support and quality care as Dr. K did with his patients. 
     Had I never met that 25-year-old man desperate for guidance in any form he could find, I may not have realized the true meaning of being a physician. I want to be a doctor who sits down with his patients like my mother and grandmother did with me, a doctor who listens to his patients like Dr. K did with the patient who had Mondor’s disease, and a doctor who prioritizes patient interactions because that is how I can “fix people,” how I will “help those around me,” and how I will prolong my infatuation with the medical field.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As a minority at West Point, I am fortunate to interact with people from Rwanda to Thailand, exposing me to various cultures. Living and learning with such a diverse group of people has taught me the importance of interpersonal relationships. I am aware that I will continue to learn throughout medical school because I will have classmates with different cultures and experiences than mine. Instead of inciting reticence, this excites me because I will grow as an individual. Every interaction has a lesson, and my worldview will broaden as a student. Immersion in organizations such as Beth Israel Deaconess Hospital-Milton has taught me that judgments based on physical appearance have no place in medicine. I have learned that biases must be addressed for communication and teamwork to flourish. My experiences as a minority in a diverse environment do not define who I am. Still, they are significant, and I hope to develop a community where differences do not impact perceptions of capability.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Historically, cadets at West Point struggle with their mental health during the winter. It is cold, the sky is gray, the buildings are gray, and coursework is challenging, deeming it the ‚Äúgray period.‚Äù While a peer support person, I attempted to get ahead of the impending mental health crisis and hosted a ‚ÄúBeat the Gray Event.‚Äù I wanted to foster positive thinking and bring joy to an otherwise depressing environment. I reserved West Point‚Äôs game room, ordered food, set out cookie decorating, and created a playlist conducive to socializing. I wanted to ensure that those in my company knew they had a community to rely upon. During the event, countless individuals thanked me because they were struggling and did not know how to ask for help. The last thing I expected was to be thanked, but I was relieved to see that I had impacted my community and helped those in need. I learned that the smallest actions have the biggest impact because, as people, we need to look out for one another.
7_-_COVID_Impact: During the pandemic, my mother, a registered nurse, worked what seemed to be endless hours in the intensive care unit. When she did come home, with the N-95 imprint still bruised on her face, I observed firsthand the toll COVID-19 took on healthcare workers; however, instead of diminishing, my desire to pursue a career in medicine greatly increased. I wanted to be on the front lines, as dangerous as it was, helping in any way I could. I despised staying home and watching the pandemic unfold while I knew people were out risking their lives. I am hesitant to say I benefitted from COVID-19 because of the magnitude of hardships it caused worldwide, but I am aware that COVID-19 aided in shaping me into the person I am today. The pandemic solidified my desire to be a physician and ignited an appreciation for the selfless work of medical professionals. Once guidelines were lifted, I quickly began working as a scribe where I could focus on what mattered - helping those affected by COVID-19.

Hrdshp_Comments: Growing up in Peru, I recall my young parents taking me to rolling clinics, which were trailers with minimal staff that would park by underdeveloped areas of Lima. My dad was still a college student when I was born, and my mom moved to the U.S when I was 2 years old, so accessing healthcare was not particularly easy. When I move to the U.S at age 14, my mom was working at JC Penney and my sister was 5 years old. My mom received SNAP benefits on and off throughout my adolescence, and although the access to healthcare was reachable, the limits of my Medicaid insurance only allowed me to receive basic care. Eye and dental care were a luxury, and I vividly recall the day my mom saved money so I could get contact lenses. Having to save up to pay for the visit and for the contacts made me realize that something as basic as seeing, was considered a privilege. However, I don't consider these obstacles a disadvantage, because these experiences fueled my passion for healthcare equity and accessibility.
Under_School: State University of New York at Stony Brook
personal_statement:
The smell of Vicks Vapor-Rub had always reminded me of the cold nights in Lima, Peru in which my grandma would sit next to me and rub my chest with the ointment whenever I felt the mild symptoms of a cold. Today, the smell of Vicks has a completely different meaning for me. At the height of the second COVID-19 wave, I was working as an EMT-B on a standby in Brentwood, LI, NY, when a call came out for a Charlie severity Difficulty Breathing. The dispatcher indicated this patient was COVID positive, so as the leading technician, I instructed my crew to gear up and wear our personal protective equipment. When we arrived on scene, a police officer was running out of the house, in his eyes I could see both a sense of urgency and relief as he put both of his arms together and signaled to me the CPR motion. Fear struck and adrenaline began to pump, I had been taught the chain of alarm for cardiac arrest for years, but I had never put it to use, neither did I think today was the day I would. I turned around and asked my crew member to pass me the AED. As I ran out of the ambulance I instructed the rest of the crew to pull out the stretcher and to call ALS, which is the Advanced Life Support crew. It all felt painfully long, time had completely stopped and every second felt like an hour. The sense of urgency increased, and as I walked in following the police officer a wave of menthol hit my face, my eyes drifted to the opened container of Vicks on the nightstand and then to the body on the floor.
