He was around 55 years old, I could hear his daughter scream in my native language from the backyard, which is all I remember. The Vicks, the yellow towel, the screams and him. 
    I felt dragged back into reality, and set up the AED immediately. My crew followed moments later into the scene, I could see panic setting in their faces which pushed me to keep my composure. I began by giving clear instructions to the police officers and my team: “Grab his arms, you grab his legs, and we will grab his waist while you hold onto the stretcher” I could hear myself speaking, but all I was thinking was about how this man looked so familiar. He looked like my uncles, like my granddad, like my own dad. He was so young, how did this happen, what even happened. Then it hit me, he was alone, went into respiratory arrest because of COVID and fell into cardiac arrest minutes after. In the face of a lack of ALS, we were forced to perform manual CPR on this man all throughout transport, alternating accordingly, anticipating the magic words “Shock advised, charging…” but they never came.
    The tragedy of it all hit me immediately after we passed off care. We had been on scene for 4 minutes, and transported him in 8, while it all felt like millions of hours passing by, in reality we were moving fast. Muscle memory took over my body, allowing me to perform what I had been taught with exact precision and outstanding timing, but it was not enough. 
    I always knew I wanted to help people, which is what mostly every sympathetic person has to say. It was the how that really troubled me, how could I help this man by becoming a doctor if he was already dead by the time he made it through the emergency doors. How could this have been prevented, I would wonder and ponder the same question over and over again. What could I have done differently, did I even do a good job. I had never truly grasped nor understood the importance of preventative medicine. The importance of managing and treating underlying illnesses, from the way a physician addresses the patient, to the physical care provided. The emphasis on preventing and treating illnesses before they make a patient a high risk for COVID mortality, was never a solution I had considered. In EMS, we care for people once an emergency has occurred, I no longer felt like EMS was the perfect way to help people as I once did. I now know how I want to help people, by preventing and reducing death and illness through treatment, trust and care, by helping them take care of their own health. Just like my grandma used to put Vicks on my chest, to treat my cold before it got worse, which always worked for me.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: At the beginning of my EMT career I took care of a patient with severe foot ulcers, and after the call was over I felt the urge to research the reasoning behind letting a condition develop untreated for so long. I soon began to feel ashamed, for I had failed to realize the complex reality of healthcare accessibility. I decided to reach higher and expand my experience in different areas of Long Island. Soon, I felt my reality shatter as I saw what limited access to healthcare can do to a community, where treatable and chronic conditions were death sentences in the lack of proper treatment. After that interaction I decided to pursue a Masters of Public Health during my gap year, to learn more about issues impacting populations and communities to better myself as a healthcare provider. Learning about issues rooted in systemic oppression and how they impact the health of individuals was truly both devastating and illuminating. Assisting in that fight represents who I want to be and more.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I strongly believe in the impact physicians can have in communities by providing adequate, accessible and equitable healthcare. I have seen the power of fighting the social determinants of health alongside a community and individuals. As an HIV/AIDs peer educator I have seen the negative impacts of stigma, prejudice, homophobia and racism on a patient‚Äôs health. Many college aged individuals do not understand the need of getting tested for HIV/AIDS as they believe it‚Äôs a disease that does not affect them. This gap in education perpetuates cycles of oppression, in which a patient may not want to get tested due to fear of others judging them or due to mere ignorance. It is by educating others and spreading awareness that we can positively contribute to a patient‚Äôs health outcome. As a physician, I truly hope to leverage this by forming relationships with patients founded in trust, vulnerability and humanism.
7_-_COVID_Impact: During the peak of COVID-19, it felt almost instinctual to seek ways to help relieve the burden healthcare workers were experiencing. I began to invest myself in pandemic relief, working towards preventing the spread by testing healthcare workers in facilities where patients were of high risk as well as transporting patients with COVID. At the same time I began to feel detached from schoolwork, and during the summer of 2020 I received a C- for a genetics class. Although I had previously faced struggles in classes, I had never received such a low grade and the feeling of failure pulled me back to a reality I had no longer registered. I began to question my goals and passions as well as my path, as the helpless feeling all medical staff shared intensified. I decided to pursue a masters in Public Health during my gap year. Doing so allowed me to re-encounter the reasons why I decided to pursue medicine to begin with, and fueled my desire to keep improving my academics.

personal_statement:
I learned what it means to care for others from my Pakistani grandfather, who devoted his life to improving the health of his home country. As the country’s Director General of Health, now known as the Surgeon General, my grandfather established universities and created medical camps in remote areas around Pakistan. Every winter my family would visit him in Karachi, and I traveled to the camps to watch him provide care to communities in need. I had the privilege of seeing the love with which he provided medical services to people, the trust they put in their doctor, and their gratitude. Through the years, I saw children my age with far less access to healthcare than I had. It was something I had taken for granted, but never would again. It was in those Pakistani camps that my passion for providing healthcare and addressing health disparities blossomed. 
My experience in the medical camps shaped my thoughts on health equity. Even with access to the camps, the villagers lacked access to hospitals and routine medical care. I quickly learned that providing meaningful communal care meant addressing healthcare shortages. If I hoped to promote healthcare equality as a physician one day, I needed to understand the foundation for equitable resource allocation. Pursuing an economics degree has given me the intellectual tools to understand societal issues and how they relate to provisions of medical care. I hope to apply this knowledge in the medical field by working with patient’s insurance policies to find affordable and personal care options. 
Like my grandfather, I saw the value in providing care to underserved populations in my community. During my sophomore year of college, I interned at the Emerging Pathogen Institute in Gainesville, Florida. There, I assisted the program coordinator with implementing the FluMist Immunization Program. For the program, I went to all public schools in the county to teach about influenza and immunization. I assisted with vaccination clinics for hundreds of students who could not afford it, ensuring no cost by working with insurances and the Alachua County Health Department. Limiting disease spread at no or minimum cost is an essential part of communal health and providing such care is a challenge I look forward to tackling in my career as a physician. 
In addition to my work with the FluMist program, I had the opportunity to work in an established clinic in my hometown, Orlando. After COVID-19 left a local Gastroenterology clinic short-staffed, I stepped in as an administrative assistant. In performing clerical tasks, like scheduling appointments and shadowing, I grew to appreciate the nuance of patient-doctor interactions. I will never forget the time an older man walked out of his appointment, overwhelmed with tearful joy. He told me that the doctor’s life-saving diagnosis meant he would have more time with his granddaughter. Although this clinic was different than the camps in Pakistan, certain aspects remained constant. In both places, doctors worked diligently to diagnose patients; the responsibility, empathy and problem-solving that this kind of care requires is what I aspire to in my future.
What solidified my plan for a future in medicine was my work in translational research. In the summer following my sophomore year, I had the opportunity to acquire many useful skills by working in the Surgery Department Chair, Dr. Hasan B. Alam’s laboratory at Northwestern University in Chicago. Alongside some of the world’s most esteemed surgeons and resident physicians, I worked on a Department of Defense project studying the effects of valproic acid on traumatic brain injury. I learned hands-on surgical techniques and became certified to perform tissue cauterization, collect arterial blood gas and necropsy on large swine as a model for humans. My love for research followed me back to college where I joined Dr. Michael S. Kilberg’s laboratory. There, I worked to determine the potential cause of a relatively new inborn error of metabolism, asparagine synthetase deficiency, by investigating cultured cells. These experiences gave me the skills and ability to secure funding for my own independent research project. As a Research Scholar for the University of Florida Health Cancer Center this coming year, I will lead research on brain tumor therapeutics using the ketogenic diet. My experiences in translational research and passion to learn drives me to seek opportunities to improve patient care in meaningful and innovative ways. 
Seeing the impact of medical care around the world has inspired me to be a physician who works to provide personalized care and serve communities in need. Although my grandfather is no longer with us, I am determined to carry on his legacy of care for everybody regardless of circumstance. From my earliest memories in the medical camps until now, my goals have only become more clear: to provide care as a physician and promote communal health with empathy. My experiences in economics, clinics, and research have given me a well-rounded foundation for higher-level learning in the medical field. I am confident I have the skills and scholarly curiosity to succeed as both a medical student and physician who values healthcare equality.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Throughout childhood, I wrestled with living in my Pakistani culture at home yet wanting to fit into a predominantly white culture at school. Even so, my parents always made a point to ensure that our heritage remains prominent in my life. Over the years, my circumstances have made me courageous and have pushed me to learn from others unlike myself. As a result, I could empathize with patients of various ethnicities and socioeconomic statuses as an administrative assistant._x000D_
Today, I am the only woman and the only person of color in my college research laboratory. In my minority position, I have advocated for others. While studying an inborn metabolism error, I have suggested analyzing genetic variation across ethnicities to find potential variables. By addressing inclusivity in research, I hope to mitigate health disparities that arise due to a lack of representation. These are only a few examples of how I have used my circumstance to connect with others and advance the medical field.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
I can contribute to these strategies by combining social and medical sciences. My coursework in economics has made me aware of social determinants of health and how they impact communities. Understanding the intersection of the economy and healthcare is vital to reducing health disparities. As such, I have taken coursework on insurance policies. With this knowledge, I will strive to provide optimal patient care based on unique plans. I am confident that my perspective on the economy‚Äôs role in provisions of care can reduce healthcare shortages in Chicago‚Äôs communities._x000D_
I have experience impacting my community through the Emerging Pathogens Institute. As an intern, I created promotional strategies to increase vaccination rates and promote health across Alachua County. I organized influenza vaccination clinics in schools and verified insurance claims so each child could receive an immunization at no cost. Advancing communal health is a goal of mine - one I aspire to execute in my career.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
Since I could not secure many shadowing opportunities due to the pandemic‚Äôs limitations, I adapted to find experiences where possible. I was fortunate to take an online course exploring various medical specialties. Throughout the course, I met many doctors in different medical fields and learned about their practices, work-life balance, and patient interactions. This experience effectively increased my exposure to the medical field while preserving my community‚Äôs health and safety. _x000D_
Additionally, I became familiar with clinical medicine by working in a gastroenterologist‚Äôs office. As an administrative assistant, I managed day-to-day operations, created a remote check-in system to ensure patient safety, and streamlined the transition to telehealth services by consolidating demographic information for the doctor. Although I will continue to seek safe patient interactions, I feel these were valuable learning experiences given the circumstances.

personal_statement:
As a little girl, my favorite game was “who can stand on dad’s shoulders the longest”.  The rules were simple. While swimming at the YMCA, my siblings and I would take turns standing on top of our dad’s shoulders to see who could stay up longest.  It was just a game in a community pool, but it taught me a foundational life lesson: on the shoulders of giants we see the farthest. This lesson has inspired me to pursue a career in medicine.  Having stood on the shoulders of so many around me, I’ve developed a passion to be the shoulders on which others might stand, and I am convinced beyond doubt that the manner in which I can best do so is as a physician practicing compassionate advocacy.

Standing on the shoulders of my grandmother, I learned the fundamental importance of patient advocacy. My grandmother was an immigrant to the United States. A single mother, with six kids, little education, and no English, she worked as a seamstress to provide for her family. When a medical team prescribed too much anesthesia to her son, and ultimately killed him, my grandmother had no one to advocate for her.  She was left without reparations, without an apology, and without her son. My grandmother’s experience speaks to the obstacles that communities of color face in healthcare and the importance of patient advocacy in medicine. My grandmother’s experience taught me the value of physicians as advocates.  I hope, as a physician, to work with underserved populations and advocate for marginalized communities through cultural and social awareness in order to create equity in healthcare.

I stood on more shoulders as a biology student working as a scribe with patients on the east side of Detroit. In the classroom, I learned about the biological and sociological etiology of disease. In the emergency department where I worked, I saw how these etiologies collided within an unjust and inequitable social structure.  One day, a team of EMS workers entered the hospital with an older African American woman on a stretcher. Between a colostomy bag, COPD, and congestive heart failure, her arduous circumstances were quite evident. I was shocked when my coworker said, “They do it to themselves.”   This sparked a conversation in which I shared with her how unjust social structures biologically affect the underserved population of Detroit.  This interaction with my coworker inspired me to mediate access to health by delivering patient care more intentionally. I began to empathetically listen to patients' fears in the emergency department, and provide stickers and coloring books for children who had been waiting for a bed. I strove to create an environment in which the underserved population in the emergency department felt more than a check off the list; but rather, that they equally belonged, they were equally cared for, and they were equally heard. 

I stood on yet more shoulders as a researcher in Koshe, a garbage dump in Addis Ababa, home to a large population living in poverty. As part of a nongovernmental organization service trip to Koshe, I was moved by the need for compassionate advocacy for the women we served.  The women in Koshe have no choice but to work early mornings and late evenings in the garbage dump when they are left unprotected by government officials.  As a result, they are often victims of sexual violence.  This unsettled me so deeply that I initiated a research proposal to the NGO. The proposal was approved, and I designed and conducted interviews and questions for sexual assault victims that would allow for data collection. I then analyzed transcripts of interviews with 24 women about their experiences with sexual assault. From this research, I created an advocating analysis that offered holistic and institutional solutions to nonprofits.  While the research is pending publication, this process was transformative. It taught me how research and communication can generate creative solutions that help communities of color. 

On the shoulders of these giants – my grandmother, my patients, and the women of Koshe – I passionately desire to go to medical school.  Standing on their shoulders taught me life lessons that will allow me to deliver the most creative compassionate care for communities of color and other marginalized populations.  Standing on their shoulders has also reshaped my perception of what it means to be a doctor, to be a foothold for the community you serve. As a physician, I aim to support my patient population by creating and offering holistic solutions to assist in them reaching their fullest potential.  Medical school will allow me the opportunity to give to others what has so generously been given to me: shoulders on which to stand, and the support to reach their highest potential.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
How to hug a lepper is not something they teach you at university. Nor are there any classes on how to be comfortable with ‚Äúgursha,‚Äù an Ethiopian tradition in which one feeds a friend by placing the food directly into the mouth of another. Such practices were not taught to me, but I knew that I needed to learn them in order to honor the community I was in._x000D_
_x000D_
In my first trips to Kore, Ethiopia I traveled with a nongovernmental organization to teach English. In working with people who collected garbage dump items for a living and lived in 10 feet by 10 feet homes, my vision of community was immediately broadened. I learned how to be comfortable with leppers and gursha. By learning to adapt to the community around me, I could also understand the importance of women‚Äôs safety when I heard women‚Äôs experiences collecting in a dangerous terrain. Like the practice of gursha, by identifying a cultural difference and humbly adapting to it, I learned to meet the needs of those around us.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
In Kore, Ethiopia, women leave their homes at 4:00 AM to collect garbage in the community dump. They work in the early hours, not by choice, but because it increases their chance of collecting the dump‚Äôs most valuable items. However, it is the same early hours that increase their chance of experiencing gender-based violence._x000D_
_x000D_
These are the women included in my research study‚Äì the findings of which revealed disturbing accounts of harassment and intimate partner violence. Because of the socioeconomic position these women are in, few of them are able to find a job outside of collecting garbage. Without government support, it was incredibly difficult to offer tangible support to a community of women that had experienced so much hurt. However, my research was able to provide the empirical evidence that motivated an NGO to invest in the safety of women at the dump. Today, thirty girls from the community have learned taekwondo self-defense classes three days a week for the past year.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
COVID-19 regulations made traditional training opportunities virtually non-existent for months, but last fall, I was finally able to begin scribing. Serving the populations of both the east side of Detroit and Grosse Pointe, I learned that even a universal virus would have tragically different consequences in communities still facing structural violence.  For patients from lower socioeconomic statuses, their experiences as front-line workers and their long history of not being able to trust medicine revealed how strongly underlying social determinants of health created disparate results.  _x000D_
_x000D_
Although I did not get the opportunity to volunteer as much as I had hoped for during my college experience,  the health-inequity-related tragedies I saw throughout COVID-19 gave me inspiration for the impact I hope to have on underserved communities as a future physician.

personal_statement:
As the opioid epidemic rages in San Francisco, I continue to battle it as a first responder, one dose of Narcan at a time. Running calls in the Tenderloin neighborhood involves heartbreak and violence. It is not uncommon for my patients to threaten, scream at, and spit on me. During a recent shift, I reversed an overdose (OD) and caught a jet of vomit in my lap. After swapping into a clean uniform, I resuscitated another OD. As the patient was thrust into painful withdrawal, he struck me in the chest. These experiences test my resolve, but they do not deter me. I am passionate about working with marginalized patients and serving the Tenderloin remains immensely gratifying. Small wins, however, including the lives I save, are overshadowed by the countless impoverished San Franciscans requiring medical care that I do not yet have the capacity to assist. 

To change the Tenderloin, and innumerable under-resourced communities like it, I need more than Narcan. My experiences in emergency medical services, local hospitals, and clinical research have underscored the demand for physicians who are invested in their community and the people who live there. Motivated by the individuals I have treated in prehospital contexts as well as the providers who have shaped my growth, I am eager to take on a greater responsibility for patients’ well-being as a physician. 

As a first responder, my interactions with patients in single room occupancy housing and temporary shelters have sharpened my awareness of social determinants of health. Digging out an unresponsive man buried under a foot of empty plastic wine bottles in a fifth-floor room evidenced the ways in which living conditions can reflect the severity of underlying disease and vitally inform treatment. Surprisingly, at the ER, nothing about this patient’s presentation suggested alcohol use other than my description of his room. Providers often want to see a photo of a car crash to visualize the force of the collision when determining patient treatment. However, ambulance crews are rarely asked to document the inside of low-income housing. The supplementary information I relayed enabled the emergency physician to identify a non-obvious factor and perform appropriate treatments more quickly. As the interconnected role of biosocial factors becomes increasingly understood, I am eager to deploy my nuanced training to assess and respond to the root causes of patients’ ailments. 

Additionally, serving patients in prehospital contexts has taught me that open-mindedness and empathy are essential for building trust with vulnerable patients and communities. This was especially apparent when I assisted an elderly patient, “Georgia,” who had been marooned for days on her soiled bed amidst heaps of refuse and without working lights. Georgia’s past experiences with the healthcare system had led her to avoid calling 911 despite debilitating abdominal pain. As I listened to her express her apprehensions and affirmed her decision to seek help, I realized the importance of positioning myself as an ally in patients’ health and treatment plans. Once at the hospital, I detailed Georgia’s concerns to the emergency physician, who not only ordered tests to understand her gastrointestinal pains but also mobilized non-acute, community-oriented support to facilitate a successful recovery. The personalized care I intend to offer as a future physician will center patients’ individual needs while also promoting health beyond clinical sites by attending to local context and concerns. 

In addition to lessons learned rendering care as an EMT, I gained new insight into the power physicians have to leverage medicine as a tool to reduce disparities during the height of the Covid-19 pandemic. Seeking to control the spread of a virus that further exacerbated health inequities in structurally disadvantaged communities, I conducted clinical research with physician leadership at one of California’s largest mass vaccination sites. By studying adverse vaccine reactions and measuring the efficacy of preventative action, we strived to improve confidence in the vaccine and encourage patients to return for future doses. Increasing access to vaccines and generating a quantitative understanding of severity and frequency of adverse events helped operationalize an effective local vaccination campaign and led to administration of over three hundred thousand doses in our clinic. As a physician, I look forward to participating in research that identifies and promotes actions designed to combat the unequal distribution of disease.

I have known the Tenderloin neighborhood since I was a high-school volunteer coordinating needle exchange and supplying free food and toiletries. I have a clear understanding of the patient population I want to serve and the motivation required to affect change. Medical education will build upon my ability to connect with patients and equip me with the skillset I need to make a deeper impact by targeting upstream health determinants. After balancing long and grueling ambulance shifts with self-directed study for the past three years, I am excited and prepared to advance toward my future career as a physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: My professional life has facilitated a breadth of experience with a variety of people and cultures. As a result, I have a strong appreciation for wide-ranging perspectives. In China, I learned how to communicate and work effectively with my local colleagues. I also refined my cultural humility as I became familiar with linguistic and behavioral norms. As a salesperson in the U.S., I practiced active listening and empathy to build rapport with business owners across the country. In prehospital and emergency department settings, I have the amazing opportunity to serve individuals who speak different languages, require different care, and expect different outcomes from their healthcare experience. Despite the differences that exist between cultures, I believe there is an underlying humanity that we all share. My life experiences have cultivated my ability to uncover commonalities to build relationships and I look forward to further developing my ability to connect with patients.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: After the murder of George Floyd, I had a conversation with a college friend about our former fraternity. We discussed the organization‚Äôs history and symbology, the physical space it occupied, and its contribution to institutional racism. We began a campaign to re-educate alumni and formalize support for the current students to disband the fraternity on campus and to give the space back to the school. Several months of networking, petitions, and phone and Zoom calls culminated in the resignation of hundreds of Davidson alumni from the organization and a house vote in which the current members tendered a formal revocation of the campus charter to the national fraternity.
7_-_COVID_Impact: As an EMT, I experienced the rollercoaster of frontline healthcare work during the pandemic. At first, ambulance traffic plummeted, and I relied on unemployment benefits to pay for rent and groceries. At other points, I needed to recycle PPE, wear the same N95 for weeks at a time, and use mechanic‚Äôs gloves. When I was called on to assist with emergency tasks that surpassed my typical responsibilities, I learned the importance of flexibility in healthcare. I pivoted to administer vaccine doses at my county‚Äôs mass vaccination clinic and performed deceased testing. These tests required the utmost professionalism and sensitivity as I entered homes to take nasal swabs in the presence of grieving family members. Frontline work through the pandemic taught me resourcefulness and determination, and I am excited to contribute these characteristics to the learning community at Rush.

personal_statement:
As the son of an Army physician, my family moved frequently due to military assignments. Despite these difficult disruptions, I developed the skill of making friends and learned to establish roots in each of our new homes. I took comfort in the consistency in our family’s values, including service to others in the community and a love for knowledge of scientific wonders, especially those of the human body. 
I learned through example. My mother donated a kidney to a stranger in need she became aware of at a work function. She did not feel particularly heroic, and insisted it was the transplant surgeons who deserved the praise, as they were the ones who developed the skills to make such a miraculous thing possible. To my mother, it was just another way to serve others. Both of my parents’ examples influenced me as I developed a desire to pursue medicine as a career.
Another event that reinforced the value of service in my life was when I interrupted my education to be a service missionary in Tucson, Arizona. I served and taught the Spanish speaking communities living in and around Tucson. I visited children being held in border control facilities to offer toiletries or just share in a game of soccer. I learned to speak Spanish and found it thoroughly rewarding. I was motivated by my desire to genuinely connect with and learn of the different cultures of the people I was serving. I found that no matter what differences in customs may exist, all people benefit and thrive from real connections derived from honest and heartfelt communication. I learned patience and humility from frequent rejection and long hours of physical labor helping to improve the living conditions of those with very little material wealth. I even broke one of my front teeth while I was serving others by cleaning up a field. 
When I returned, I decided I wanted to continue positively impacting people’s lives. Obtaining my EMT certification began to fulfill this goal. The day I interviewed for a position with BYU Emergency Medical Service I had an experience that solidified my pursuance of a career in medicine. I went to my grandma’s house for the night to catch an early-morning flight home to Pennsylvania. While I was speaking to her, she mentioned that one of her biggest fears was having a stroke. I agreed that her fears were not unfounded given their unpredictable onset. A few moments later, my grandma suffered from a neurological deficit right before my eyes. Luckily, I recognized the signs of stroke from my training and called the paramedics immediately. They came and examined her and decided not to take her to the hospital that night. I trusted their decision but, subsequently and unfortunately, she had a massive stroke that would lead to her eventual death. 
My thoughts frequently return to that eventful night in Salt Lake City. I realized that in a crisis situation, people seldom rise to the occasion. They are more likely to sink to the level of their training. Luckily, my training was recent and I was able to recognize what was going on with my grandma. The episode helped me realize that physicians can do incredible things with their training to the benefit of others. The shared medical knowledge can enable someone to perform miracles due to the study and practice of the latest medical approaches.
Although health deficits due to age are inevitable, I believe there is value in striving against entropy. I feel that an important aspect of medicine is providing order to a system that wants nothing but to be chaotic. I learned from my experience recognizing my grandma’s stroke that, although death is inevitable, even to those we love, it is important and valuable to make a positive difference through compassionate care, especially in moments of fear and vulnerability. 
I have continued as an EMT with BYU since 2021 and worked hard to keep up with my training and protocols and have even obtained my Advanced EMT certification. It has been incredibly rewarding to help people in their most vulnerable moments. The trust given to a healthcare provider is something I never want to break. The lessons I have learned as an EMT so far have helped me to remember that each patient is an individual with a life story and needs, and not a lifeless practice mannequin.
I furthered my scientific pursuits by participating in research at BYU with Dr. Brad Berges. I investigated horizontal gene transfer in MRSA biofilm colonies. This research interested me given the emergence of ultra-resistant bacterial strains. I found it rewarding to dive into the existing literature to figure out ways to set up our own experiments. I learned quite a few lessons in patience and humility as I worked tirelessly to get my bacteria samples to grow properly. I also learned the importance of peer review as I met frequently with Dr. Berges and the other members of the lab.
My heart swells with compassion to serve and my mind thirsts to acquire knowledge. Every step on my path has led me to more experiences that have prepared me to launch onto the next great learning environment. I have no doubt that my calling in life is to become a physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: My time as a missionary in Tucson, Arizona, helped me to understand the value and importance of diversity in team-driven efforts. The world we live in is incredibly diverse. Even the most homogenous communities can vary greatly in their beliefs and upbringing. As a missionary, I had the opportunity to work with other volunteers from many different places throughout the United States and even Mexico. Each of the missionaries with whom I worked had different life experiences which helped us to better serve the communities we were assigned to work in. I sincerely loved working with people who were not like me. This happened through finding common ground and developing real friendships with them. Inclusive excellence is the greatest way to work, and I am excited to be part of an institution that recognizes the value of diversity in the student body. I am capable of developing a rapport with anyone in spite of whatever superficial differences may exist between us.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: A friend at BYU really enjoyed starting debates with me about LGBTQ people and their right to marry. He asserted society should only accept heterosexual marriages. I didn‚Äôt agree. Neither of us were ever swayed by the other, but we remained friends. We both served missions for our church and reconnected the semester we returned. While waiting in the car line for a COVID-19 test, this same friend with whom I had many heated arguments about LGBTQ marriage equality came out to me. He related to me that he had reflected about himself and his struggles with his own identity. In retrospect, I recognize that my own courage in speaking out on these issues and making others aware I am an ally allowed my friend to know that he was safe sharing this important information with me. This experience reassured me that, although I may experience some pushback from my religious peers on my stances about LGBTQ rights, it is worth it if I can help make others who are afraid or uncertain find comfort.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Although the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic were global in scale, I felt them most during my undergraduate studies. The first weeks adjusting to online lectures and socially distanced work areas were surreal. Most of my cherished experiences from my first year of college came from meeting new people from different backgrounds in my classrooms. Now it felt like it had been taken away and that the responsibility of hearing different perspectives rested upon me. Wearing a mask and sitting away from others made it easy to self-isolate. Life began to feel lonely since I often felt that it wasn‚Äôt safe to make new friends. I had to give up some of my hobbies like singing in choirs, but I redirected that energy toward service as a vaccinator and EMT. Reaching out and serving others was the remedy to the adverse effects of social distancing.

Hrdshp_Comments: Towards the end of high school, I started to develop IBS. Foods that I was once able to eat with no problem caused my stomach to make obnoxiously loud noises, though this also occurred on an empty stomach. I told myself that the noises only seemed loud to me because I was producing them, but that was quickly disproven when a student turned to stare at me after the noise went off during my first university exam. The anxiety I had regarding my stomach made it difficult for me to perform during exams which in turn affected my grades since they could count for up to 90% of my final grade. I felt helpless because it felt like I had no control over my body, but I also knew that nothing would change if I didn’t take action. It took me about two years of trial and error before I was able to understand my body.  I now know what foods to avoid, what brand of probiotics work the best, and what steps to incorporate into my morning routine. The thought of taking the MCAT used to terrify me because I had no idea how I would keep my stomach under control in a silent room for 7 hours. The fact that I was able to sit through it without any issue is a testament to how far I’ve come. My experience with IBS was a difficult process, but I am grateful that it allowed me to develop the fortitude to overcome future adversities.
personal_statement:
I spent quite a lot of my childhood in and out of hospitals. My brother has sickle cell anemia which meant that he had to visit the hospital twice a month: once for a blood draw and another a few days later for a blood transfusion. As the little sister who insisted on doing everything with my brother, I accompanied him to almost every visit. At the time, I didn’t have a deep understanding of what it meant to have sickle cell. I just knew that hospital visits meant that I could play games with my brother for a couple of hours and later go into the toy closet with him to pick out something to take home. It wasn’t until my 21-year-old cousin Junior passed away from the same condition that the reality of the situation finally hit me.

From then on, starting at the age of 9, I began to view the hospital visits more pessimistically. I considered the transfusions to be the only thing that prevented my brother from sharing the same fate as Junior. My worries must have manifested in my behavior because it caught the attention of my brother’s hematologist. I remember one day walking through the hospital corridor to get a snack from the vending machine when, upon crossing paths with my brother’s hematologist, he stopped me and said, “You’ve been a lot quieter recently. Is there anything you want to talk about?”

I’ve always admired doctors; after all, the doctors at the hospital were always heavily involved in my brother’s care and made my entire family feel at ease despite the circumstances. That moment, however, completely redefined my outlook on the profession as a whole. The hematologist took the time to listen to my concerns, reassuring me that my brother’s condition was on the lower end of the severity scale and that the care he was receiving was keeping him perfectly healthy. When I considered his status as a physician and the trust that he had built up with me throughout the years, I couldn’t help but truly believe in his words. That moment helped me come to the realization that doctors do more than just treat the physical needs of their patients; they attend to the general well-being of those around them, using compassion to change lives for the better. This revelation set the course for the future that I’ve been working towards: to be someone like that hematologist who uses their position to make a lasting impact on others during the moments where they'd benefit from the support of a helping hand.

The first time I was able to put this aspiration into practice was when I mentored my former high school’s Mock Trial team. My experience with Mock Trial pushed me to build up the courage to find my voice and it is thanks to the club that I was able to become the person that I am today. I recognized how the club could act as a catalyst for personal growth, so I found it important to give back to help others achieve that growth. Club members would send me a message through GroupMe whenever they had questions, wanted feedback on their script, or if they wanted to have a quick call so that I could listen as they ran through their parts. At times it was difficult to balance my role as a mentor and as a student, but watching my mentees develop a greater sense of confidence in both their abilities and in themselves as people made that experience especially rewarding.

A year later I found myself working at World Vision International, a humanitarian organization whose mission of helping vulnerable children across the globe was something I deeply resonated with. I communicate regularly with project implementation leads to get a sense of how each project is designed to fit the health needs of the beneficiaries and synthesize this information into factsheets which are then distributed to external partners. Working in an international organization means getting comfortable with early mornings and late nights, but this is hardly an issue when I remind myself that these meetings work towards securing children's futures. My time at World Vision has allowed me to support global health services, but it has also expanded my understanding of the health challenges that stem from non-biological factors. In addition to my main tasks, I conduct digital health research where I spend hours delving into the health disparities of different countries such as the lack of a proper health information system in Ethiopia or cultural norms that discourage care-seeking in Uganda. It is up to the service provider to understand and navigate these challenges which I hope to be able to do in order to provide comprehensive care as a physician.

My desire to pursue a career in medicine has matured substantially since that encounter with my brother’s hematologist and with each new experience, my conviction grows as well. When I shadowed at a children’s hospital, I watched as the pediatrician interacted with the patients and their families, a natural balance between casual banter and medical expertise. It reminded me of the way that the physicians interacted with my family during our time in the hematology unit. Knowing just how much of an impact that interaction can have on a person, I hope to one day be in the position where I’m able to give others hope for the future in a way that sticks with them for over a decade, just as I had experienced.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: At World Vision, I create reporting products to showcase the impact of the organization‚Äôs digital health deployments. We collect information by collecting data or having conversations with the implementation teams. Both methods, along with the digital health research I‚Äôve done, have given me an avenue to better understand the unique health challenges that occur in different parts of the world. The only way to become knowledgeable about these health challenges is to either experience them or to learn about them through external means. Through global health, I‚Äôve been able to realize that my own perspective of healthcare was limited to my own life experience. Understanding the social determinants of health that disproportionately affect medically underserved populations is the first step to addressing the barriers that affect their access to health services. After all, it is easy to misunderstand another individual‚Äôs illness experience if you only consider it from only one perspective.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Briana, one of my mentees, struggled with negative feedback; she'd roll her eyes or talk back whenever she received it due to her pride. Though not intrinsically negative, too much pride can get you into more trouble than it‚Äôs worth. It's difficult to recognize how damaging this mindset can be when it is prevalent amongst your peers in the school. The way people approach life is heavily dependent on where they live, so it is important to be cognizant of that to understand why other people act the way that they do. Whenever I had my one-on-one discussions with Briana, I would always nudge her into taking feedback more objectively. One day, I asked Briana to promise me that she‚Äôd listen to the coach‚Äôs feedback without retorting back to which she agreed. A few months later, I was at a reunion lunch with my former team and asked the coach about her. I was happy to hear that Briana stopped talking back and made more of an effort to incorporate the coach's feedback into her performance.
7_-_COVID_Impact: In my first year of university, I quickly learned just how expensive school could be. In anticipation of future costs, I decided to continue working the following summer and planned to dedicate my last two summer breaks to medical experiences. That plan swiftly fell apart once the pandemic hit during my second year of university and I refused to risk being exposed to COVID because it would compromise the health of my high-risk family members. Instead, I searched for alternative ways of gaining clinical experience. I decided to explore virtual shadowing as it was a great way for me to safely observe real patient encounters, and it gave me the opportunity for me to examine cases from a physician‚Äôs perspective. With the improvements in case levels and as a new graduate, I‚Äôm now able to venture into clinical employment. I will be working as a scribe and clinical assistant for the next year. I‚Äôm looking forward to supplementing my virtual experiences with firsthand, in-person experiences.

personal_statement:
Although my scoliosis diagnosis at age eight remains a hazy memory, the feeling of the cold hands of the exclusively male orthopedic surgeons as they examined my developing body is permanently etched into my mind. I was observed like a hawk by medical students who saw me as a case study, rather than a child, while a back brace was roughly tightened around my tiny torso. Although the experience was difficult, I found myself deeply interested in the human body. While walking out of the exam room after an appointment, a resident who had observed the visit told me that he was impressed with the depth of questions I had asked. “You should go into orthopedics,” he told me with a smile. With this encouragement, I began to dream of one day becoming a doctor. 

My interest in becoming a physician grew after I became the leader of the New Jersey chapter of the Curvy Girls Scoliosis Foundation. I armed myself with information, determined to no longer be the invisible patient, but to become an active participant in my own health. I encouraged other girls to do the same: to speak up for themselves, to gain a working knowledge of the human body and become informed patients. When I traded my plastic torso for a titanium spine at the age of 16, the Curvy Girls rallied around me. I enjoyed paying it forward by visiting others in the hospital and encouraging younger girls through the process of bracing. We empowered one another, true, but in supporting a wide variety of girls, I witnessed tragic healthcare inequities: while wealthier girls could schedule their surgeries around school breaks and their parents could be confident that their child was receiving the best possible care, the girls from families from under-resourced communities were waitlisted at charity hospitals. As much as I enjoyed providing support to these girls, I felt as though I had not done enough for them. That same year, I took an anatomy course and fell in love with medicine.I felt a deep satisfaction when I correctly diagnosed the”‘patient” during mock rounds, dreaming about the day I could help someone the way my surgeon helped me. I realized that as a doctor, I would be in the unique position to advocate for the needs of patients and would be able to directly heal others--no other profession would bring me the same satisfaction.	
While volunteering at the Veterans Affairs Hospital, I discovered the immense power of empathy. In the ED, the veterans often arrived alone, with no one to help them process their pain and fear. At times I felt powerless, as I could only offer a cup of water or a friendly face and could not truly ease the pain of the country’s heroes. “Mr. Jones” was one such patient. He was screaming in pain and was unable to speak as I transported him to his scan. Thankfully, by the time I retrieved him from the scan, the morphine he had been given kicked in. “I’m sorry I was yelling before,” he told me. I assured him that it was no problem at all and we spent the trip back to the ED talking about our dogs. I covered him with a warm blanket, wishing that there was more I could do to help ease his suffering. Although my abilities were limited, I found that patients needed the friendly conversation just as much as they needed their medication. I now look forward to the day when I can provide not only comfort and truly heal the patients in my care. 	
When I worked as a medical scribe, my conviction to one day practice medicine grew stronger. I was inspired by the doctors who worked through the pandemic with an unwavering devotion to patient care. While I found my job rewarding, there were days when medicine seemed quite bleak as I listened to the physical and emotional pain of the patients. I often cried as I typed up SOAP notes. The world seemed so broken and grim at times, such as when 4-year-old “Lily”, a lupus patient, was infected with COVID-19. The rheumatologist, Dr. L., had advised her parents to vaccinate themselves to protect their high-risk child, yet her parents refused. When the parents were eventually infected, they cleared the virus easily, yet Lily was not so lucky: she was admitted to the PICU and after weeks of fighting, she succumbed to the disease. I was angered and heartbroken that a child died a preventable death, yet inspired by Dr. L’s response: he candidly but compassionately told each parent about Lily’s tragic death. Her story was a powerful motivator for other parents, many of whom softened their hearts and shifted their views on vaccination. While this was a horrible tragedy, I also witnessed Dr. L save many lives through compassionate scientific communication. I will carry Lily's story with me to fuel my devotion to patient education and preventative care. 	
Although I once naively thought that wearing a white coat would give me the superpowers to heal the world, my dedication to becoming a physician has not changed with learning the reality of the job. I cannot reverse time and change the surgical outcomes of my under-resourced friends, take away the pain from the patients at the VA, or revive those who died needlessly from COVID-19, but I can and will use these experiences to fuel a passion for patient care that is centered around compassion, dialogic communication, and education.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
Growing up in the same home as my Deaf uncle introduced me to American Sign Language (ASL) and Deaf culture at a young age. While my mother, an ASL teacher, taught me and my hard-of-hearing brother ASL to bridge the two cultures in our home, the outside world was not accommodating: my brother refused to wear his hearing aids to school for fear of being teased, and his grades suffered as a result; I was often reprimanded by other hearing people for my ‚ÄúDeaf manners‚Äù--speaking loudly, tapping tables to get the attention of others, and my blunt descriptions. These actions are considered normal to the Deaf, but rude to the hearing. _x000D_
Although awareness about ASL and the Deaf community is growing, my uncle and brother frequently face systemic barriers. Navigating between the hearing and Deaf worlds has instilled in me a mindset of cultural relativism and a thirst for cultural competence, which has shaped my interactions and broadened my worldview.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: In 2016, I nervously answered the phone to speak with the first member of my tenure as NJ leader of the Curvy Girls Scoliosis Foundation. "June" and her daughter "Grace" were distraught over Grace's recent scoliosis diagnosis, which required bracing. My nerves faded away as I realized that they did not need perfect advice, they needed to know that someone was going through the same thing. At the time, I was still wearing a back brace and was scheduled for spinal fusion. I hosted support group meetings, planned fundraisers, and visited members in the hospital. When I went to college, I stepped down from leadership, but kept in contact with the other members. Last May, Grace told me she needed surgery. I sent a care package with her favorite snacks and some toiletries, hoping it would bring comfort. A month after her surgery, I received a kind card from Grace and June, thanking me for my support over the years. I smiled, as my hopes were affirmed: my actions had helped a child in need.
7_-_COVID_Impact: In January of 2020, I was thrilled to learn that I had been offered an internship at Mount Sinai. The internship consisted of shadowing an orthopedic surgeon, assisting in the hospital wet lab, and volunteering in the outpatient office. In March, these plans came crashing down. I was bitterly disappointed, but I knew that staying home was the safest option. I took a job as a virtual medical scribe, for which I wrote SOAP notes for patients all over the country. I noticed that patients from underserved areas (such as rural Pennsylvania and Alabama) presented more often with severe COVID cases, and I began considering how poverty, education gaps, food deserts, and COVID-19 overlap, and realized that I would need to make equitable healthcare a goal of my future practice. The pandemic illuminated inequities that have always existed, and my experience working as a scribe during the pandemic inspired me to expand my mission to include advocating for systemic reforms to improve patient care.

personal_statement:
I have a fundamental belief that medicine is a calling and that it requires a deep level of passion and commitment towards yourself, your coworkers, and most importantly, your patients. Growing up with two parents as physicians, I have observed this throughout my childhood whether it was working on Christmas, performing surgery on the weekends, or getting woken up in the middle of the night to care for a patient. Being a physician is a 24/7 duty. In the past six years, I have begun to experience this more personally, transitioning from the child of a physician to participating in the care of others. I would like to share my journey and why I am so enthusiastic about becoming a medical student.

While in high school, I worked during summers as a physical therapy tech for a local orthopedic practice. It was my first experience involving patient interaction and care. I enjoyed getting to know the patients and watching as they progressed from struggling to step on a small pad to climbing large steps. I felt that I was actually making a difference in someone's life. From here on, I knew that medicine was going to always be a part of my life and I wanted nothing different. During COVID, I spent time in my local hospital’s lab as a tech, which gave me the opportunity to see patient care from a different perspective. The lab was a fast-paced environment, and I realized how every person played a critical role in patient care. While these last two roles took place directly in a hospital or clinic, I wanted to explore medicine in other capacities as well. During my last three years of college, I have been working for Notre Dame Sports Medicine as a student athletic trainer. In this role, I have been exposed to healthcare for the elite athlete from both an injury prevention and recovery standpoint. I love the idea of applying my training to offer patients guidance on how to prevent injuries from occurring.

While these experiences provided a cradle for personal growth and helped me develop important skills, such as communication and dependability, I want to have a larger role in patient care. While working in those aforementioned capacities, I found myself constantly wanting to know more about the patient and why they were experiencing their difficulties or why a specific treatment was chosen, often showering the medical staff with questions. I want to be with the patient from the start of their health journey and work with the patient to diagnose and then find solutions to their health issues.

Last summer, while shadowing an interventional cardiologist, I felt even more drawn to the physician’s role in medicine. There were multiple instances where the physician insisted I go home because I did not want to leave the cath lab. I found it fascinating to see the procedures being done and did not want to miss anything. To know that a person’s life was saved by placing a stent where there was a large blockage was incredible. The technology and skills required to save that person’s life are awe-inspiring. From this shadowing experience, not only did I learn from the cath lab but also from the office side of the practice. One of the most memorable clinic visits involved a couple and their vaccination status. Even though COVID vaccines had been available for months, they had just then decided to become vaccinated. The cardiologist spent some of the visit addressing their vaccine-related concerns and explaining the vaccine’s benefits. Though he did not have to, the physician did this because he wanted his patients to be fully informed in order to make the best health decisions for themselves. I want to have the training and knowledge to do the same and most importantly have a trusting relationship so patients can believe what I am saying.

I have enjoyed the insight and inspirations that I have gained as an athletic trainer, physical therapy tech, lab tech, and observer. These roles have provided the bedrock for the medical education and experiences I hope to gain throughout medical school and residency. The aggregate of these experiences and the intellectual challenges of the training fuels my desire to be a physician. Looking back upon my life so far, I cannot offer an incredible moment or an earth-shattering revelation about the desire to pursue medical school; the desire to be a physician has been with me since childhood. While my parents have certainly inspired me by what they do and encouraged me to chase my dreams, they are not the reason I am drawn to medical school. There are both advantages and disadvantages to being a physician; it is not for the faint of heart and requires a true passion to be successful. I have only continued to be inspired by my experiences, which have provided invaluable insight and opportunities to develop early skills, such as communication, compassion, and leadership, all crucial to providing excellent and effective care. I strive to become a physician because of the wide-ranging impact they can have from being a leader in the community to possibly being the only person a patient can turn to when they are ill, in pain, or simply forgotten. While I realize many talented candidates seek admission, I appreciate your consideration of my application for enrollment at your medical school.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Through my volunteer experience at the Women‚Äôs Care Center, where women can receive free prenatal care and counseling, I interact with families from different backgrounds. Most clients are from impoverished areas and seek guidance there as they have limited resources and nowhere else to turn. This past summer I assisted in teaching a parenting class. At first, I was nervous to participate since there is a bit of a language barrier with some parents and I cannot relate to them as I am not yet a parent. However, I reminded myself that despite having different backgrounds, we can all relate in feeling the same emotions, such as grief and happiness. By understanding this, we can connect with and make a difference in the life of any person we encounter. Once I recognized this, I focused on listening to the parents and finding opportunities to use what life experience I do have to discuss solutions with them.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: When I was a senior in high school, the track team‚Äôs throwing coach quit. This was hard because he was a great coach and knew the techniques so well. His replacement had never coached the field events before, lacking confidence and knowledge of the sport. In my senior year, I had a legitimate chance of placing high at competitions. However, I was no longer confident that I would get there without an experienced coach. As captain, I decided to step up for myself and my team. I watched videos of the technique and worked long after practice was over. Additionally, I tried my best to teach inexperienced teammates how to throw and helped the new coach gain an understanding of the sport. I showed my teammates how to do the drills and assisted them in perfecting their form. Though I did not do as well as I hoped at Regionals, I still did well considering my competition and circumstances. Additionally, the unfortunate circumstances were a good test of my commitment and leadership skills.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
In December of 2020, I lost my uncle to COVID-19 quickly and unexpectedly. He was the family comedian and the life of any party, so the following holidays and other family events were incredibly tough. Additionally, the following semester was more difficult as my uncle was one of my biggest cheerleaders. He was a larger-than-life person who had a definite presence in everyone‚Äôs life, leaving a hole in the hearts of all of us. It was a difficult loss._x000D_
_x000D_
Another challenge I faced due to COVID was finding a research lab to work in on campus. Most labs I contacted were at capacity and could not accept new students due to COVID restrictions. The few labs that did have space were ones in which I was unable to commit the desired amount of hours each week. My full-time job as a student athletic trainer combined with my full class load did not allow the extra time for the few available research positions.

personal_statement:
In 1970, my grandfather courageously said goodbye to his wife, two children, and home in Mexico to chase the “American Dream.” He was faced with the choice to either follow the safe path and live in a country where there are few opportunities for people with little formal education, or to blindly dive into a new country which offered the hope of opportunity that matched his willingness to work hard. Taking the risk to make a better life for his family, my grandfather embarked on a solo journey into the U.S., where he worked a variety of blue-collar jobs until he eventually was able to afford to move his family to begin a new “American” life together — a life that promised not simply prosperity, but rather the opportunity to achieve prosperity with hard work. In turn, his efforts provided me with the American Dream. If it were not for his selflessness and courage to take the risk to immigrate, I would not have the opportunities I have today. His altruistic actions instilled in me a moral standard to put others before myself, to work hard, and to act with courage. I intend to uphold these morals through whole-heartedly devoting myself to becoming a physician with a focus on family medicine.

After immigrating, before my grandparents stood a great challenge: assimilating into American life. They faced overwhelming cultural barriers and some prejudices. To a degree, I was shielded from these prejudices because my mother is of Irish descent. It was not until I was older that the blended cultures in which I was raised allowed me to realize the prejudices that exist. Often, when people would find out that I’m half-Mexican they would say condescendingly, “You’re Mexican?” or “Are you legal?”, as if I do not belong in our primarily white neighborhood. Conversely, when we go to family events on my father’s side, family often joke that I am too tall and white to be Mexican. I learned to become thick-skinned to any of these comments, but it left me with a sense of isolation. I felt as if I didn’t perfectly fit in either category. I was neither Mexican nor American. Now, however, my heritage is something I am grateful for. My experience growing up in blended cultures has rooted in me the importance of inclusivity and diversity. I have been made aware what it feels like to be both in the in-group and out-group. This has made me more self-aware of inclusivity and I now strive to make everyone of all backgrounds feel welcomed and heard. I am fortunate to be able to provide insight from being part of a combination of cultural ideas and aim to use my experience to support diversity and acceptance in my personal and professional life. 

My awareness of, and desire to increase, inclusivity combined with the work ethic, courage, and selfless mindset that my grandfather instilled in me, feed my passion to practice medicine. I have always been fascinated with biology and the complex interworking of the human body. Entering college, I was intrigued by the cellular, research level of medicine and it wasn’t until I began working in a hospital that I became more drawn to the personal level of practicing medicine. My sophomore year, I began working for the University of Kentucky hospital as a patient transporter and observed first-hand the difference that not only physicians make, but the entire healthcare team makes for the well-being of patients. I witnessed discharged patients graciously thank their nurses and physicians. I heard patients’ stories about how wonderful the healthcare team treated them through every step of their recovery. This led me to take a more active role in the healthcare team by obtaining my C.N.A., license and volunteering at the Refuge Clinic, a free clinic for people with little or no insurance. There I had the pleasure of observing patients from various backgrounds, many of which, like my grandfather, were immigrants who spoke only Spanish.

At the Refuge Clinic, I was impacted by one physician in particular, Dr. Perez. As a Spanish-speaker, he made the patients feel comfortable, treated each one with respect, and spent time to get to know them personally. Many of these patients have not seen a doctor in years due to cultural barriers and lack of insurance. Dr. Perez offered a welcoming hand to these patients, who long felt isolated and neglected by the American healthcare system. I was inspired by Dr. Perez who volunteered his time to treat these patients. I aim to become a physician focused on family medicine to help people from all backgrounds. Like the examples before me, I will strive to create personal connections to foster a high standard of care for my patients. I want to help patients like my grandfather once was, with little insurance and a non-native English speaker. 

I am beyond thankful that my grandfather laid the foundations for our family to be able to have opportunities that he could only dream of. His actions and examples have given me the courage to achieve my dream to be a physician. Like my grandfather, I plan to make the most of my opportunities and pursue my passions with determination to better the lives of those I care for, whether they be family or patients. I am committed to upholding my family’s drive for the “American Dream” in my journey to becoming a physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: My father is Mexican, and my mother is German-Irish, so I was raised in blended cultures. This fostered a unique environment in which I was never completely ‚Äúwhite‚Äù nor Mexican. This made it difficult to fit in amongst my friends and family as I was seen as different by both, sometimes being the butt of jokes like my white friends telling me that I would be a great landscaper or my Mexican family telling me that I am too tall to be Mexican. However, these experiences gave me a deeper awareness of diversity and inclusivity. I learned that environments may be diverse but not necessarily inclusive, thus negating any benefits of diversity. With an understanding of the dominant and minority cultures in the U.S., I can contribute to the diversity of the learning environment at Rush because my culturally diverse upbringing allows me to relate to more people. I can use that to enrich the learning environment by presenting and advocating for diverse perspectives and promoting greater inclusion.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I volunteer at the Refuge Clinic which provides health care for the uninsured, many of which are immigrants and people of diverse backgrounds. It is disheartening to see countless patients stuck in a brutal cycle of not having enough money to afford health care, but their only source of income includes working conditions that worsen their condition. I aim to serve these populations that otherwise would be neglected in the health care system and to change the health care disparity in our communities. As a nursing assistant, I help my community by providing patient interaction and hands-on care. On the grand scale of the world, my impact may be small, but every patient we see is one patient who otherwise would‚Äôve likely never seen a physician. I intend to continue donating my time and efforts towards treating patients from underserved communities. Growing up in the Chicago area, I have a deep tie to its community which increases my drive to help Chicago residents achieve better health.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The COVID-19 pandemic presented many unforeseen challenges. Personally, it interfered with my education as it switched to an online format. Although, I am grateful that I was able to continue classes, I believe it impacted the depth at which content was able to be presented. It also eliminated in-class connections with peers and professors. Additionally, opportunities to expand my studies were limited, such as having shadowing opportunities postponed. At work in the hospital, we were overwhelmed with COVID patients and the fear that we would bring the virus home to our families and friends. Despite the fears, isolation, and drastic changes to daily life that the pandemic brought, it did allow me to spend more time with family. More importantly, it also proved to me that I am resilient and adaptive. I was able to successfully continue my education and continue working in a health care environment. I believe that this resiliency and adaptiveness will help me succeed in medical school.

personal_statement:
It was late June, and the Family Health La Clínica team was working at a migrant camp in a remote area of southern Wisconsin. I was seated in the Mobile Health Clinic, finalizing patient lab results, when I heard a slight knock and the door of the clinic swung open. I looked over and saw a young Hispanic man enter sheepishly. I greeted him in Spanish, asking him how I might be of service for him today.  “Mi esposa ('My wife’),” he explained, “wants me to see a doctor. I told her it wasn’t necessary, but she is insisting.” I nodded and showed him towards registration.

His appointment went quickly. The physician finished the routine examination without concern, and the patient was directed to me for blood work. I performed an A1C to monitor for diabetes, a pervasive disease in the Hispanic community. We chatted until I heard the A1C machine beep. I glanced over and my breath caught in my throat. The screen displayed a number I had never seen: 14.0%. The glucose level in this man’s blood had maxed out the machine, indicating wildly out of control undiagnosed diabetes. 

For the next hour, the patient sat tearfully in the clinic as the physician explained the life-threatening consequences that this test result carried, his new array of medications, a string of nutritional advice, and seemingly endless recommendations for lifestyle changes. I listened silently, mind racing. An hour ago, this visit was casual, and only occurred because his wife had insisted. Now, however, it balanced life and death.  

It was in this moment that years of believing that I wanted a career in medicine changed to undoubtedly knowing that I must have a career in medicine. It was a humbling experience to be a member of a team that quite possibly saved this man’s life. Most impactful of all was the handshake the patient gave me before leaving. As he clasped his hands over mine, I could feel his gratitude, so much deeper than words could describe. “Gracias (‘Thank you’),” he told me, as I smiled with reassurance. I was left invigorated to learn, grow, and pursue my childhood dream like never before.

My initial exposure to the field of medicine began years earlier with my grandfather’s pancreatic cancer diagnosis. For me, the idea of death was a foreign one that affected other families, but never mine. This view was promptly shattered as I watched my grandfather quite literally wither away. I watched his mind cloud as he forgot his daughter, his grandkids, and his wife. I watched him lose control of his most basic bodily functions. To this day I can still hear him retching as the chemotherapy side effects plagued him. I can still hear my mother’s sobs when she found her father in his hospice bed in the living room, dead.

This experience planted the seed that would sprout into a dedication for a career as a physician. Despite the darkness that accompanied these long months, so too did light shine. I grew enamored with the flow of the hospital, and was especially drawn toward the compassion, confidence, and leadership displayed by my grandfather’s doctors. My family member was the grateful patient, so it was clear to me just how impactful the role of a physician is. They were the steady, unwavering hand guiding us through uncertain times. I knew that whatever it took, providing meaningful care to patients during their darkest times is what I need to do.

Inspired, I sought opportunities to explore medicine. I secured a shadowing opportunity with an orthopedic surgeon and was also invited to shadow with a renowned neurosurgeon. I remember walking into an operating room for the first time, seeing the seemingly endless racks of shining tools waiting to be used in a full knee replacement. I watched in awe as the surgeon and his team worked flawlessly together, eliminating the excruciating pain the patient had described in clinic not too long before. Despite my small role, I felt alive in the operating room and proud of the skills I was developing during clinical hours. The gratification of the patients that initially drew me towards medicine was omnipresent, and for the first time in my life, I felt that I was helping to create a positive impact on the members of my community. 

My desire to provide compassionate care led me to Family Health La Clínica (FHLC), where I worked as a bilingual Mobile Health Aide specializing in phlebotomy. My team and I traveled Wisconsin to provide free healthcare to underserved, Spanish-speaking migrant workers. With every one of the thousands of patients I served, I knew that my interest in becoming a physician was converting into a calling. My time with FHLC also challenged me with the rigor of healthcare. Despite the stress of caring for others during shifts that often lasted longer than fifteen hours, the experience did anything but turn me away from medicine. I was invigorated by the work, and learned what service truly meant: putting the needs of others above all else.

These experiences have fueled my need to become a physician, and every time I’m working in the hospital, I discover new motivation. I have watched countless physicians selflessly strive to improve the human condition with their leadership, and I know that there is nothing else that I would rather do with my life.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: In 2021, I served migrant Mexican patients who were hit hard by the COVID-19 pandemic. Their working conditions when COVID-19 began were horribly inadequate; their companies provided no masks, no social distancing rules, and no quarantine measures to protect them. They slept in barracks stacked like sardines with the infected dying around them. I was astonished to learn that the medical needs of this underserved group were being ignored, and that innocent people were paying with their lives. These patients opened my eyes to the inequalities faced in my own state of Wisconsin, broke my notion of equality in medicine, and cemented my need to pursue medicine after experiencing their healthcare needs firsthand. At this job, I learned so much about the Hispanic culture, improved my Spanish, and most importantly I improved my own cultural competency. I learned the need to learn about a patient‚Äôs culture to adequately understand who they are, what they‚Äôve gone through, and how to treat them.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Starting my junior year in college, I participated in an organization known as Allied Fresh which focuses on eliminating food insecurity in Madison, Wisconsin. Every week, Allied Fresh ships in personal hygiene products and healthy foods such as fruits, vegetables, grains, and meat to package and distribute to low-income members of our community free of charge. Volunteers like myself are responsible for delivering the supplies to the homes of clients, and I often provided Spanish translation for my group as well. Proper nutrition is a vital prerequisite for people to obtain before they can lead healthy lives and is a key building block in public health; growth, education, employment, and life grind to a halt without it. That is how I and this organization have impacted our community. Underserved community members who couldn‚Äôt afford to feed their families found new hope to grow and prosper, and perhaps one day leave poverty with the help of Allied Fresh.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
