As I was about to begin research, volunteering, and joining clubs COVID-19 forced me to leave campus, causing many of my activities to lack longevity on my application. So, I had to search for creative manners to serve, and found remote work assisting my fellow Badgers. I began volunteering as an organic chemistry tutor and a peer diversity mentor working with struggling and incoming students. _x000D_
_x000D_
Unable to do campus research, I started as a lab assistant in a public health role at the State Laboratory of Hygiene. There I learned laboratory skills, public health, and microbiology. I recently earned my own research project and am beginning molecular biology work. _x000D_
_x000D_
More than anything I wanted to spend time at UW-Health. The pandemic prevented this for over 2 years, but when it began to improve, I secured a position as a volunteer intern in the PICU where I was able to shadow physicians, learn from rounds, and participate in a project to help ensure effective care for the patients.

personal_statement:
At the age of 12, I attended the memorial service for my friend, Anahi. My physical and mental health plummeted to the point where I fainted in the middle of class. In the emergency room, I avoided conversating until the physician asked me what I looked forward to most once discharged. Overcome with emotion, I expressed my grief and conviction that life must be meaningless if a friend can die while simply on their way to school. He listened to me patiently and after talking, his advice helped me remember parts of life I still cherished like my grandma, whom I called Nanay (a Tagalog honorific). She was my roommate who held me when I cried, the hero that protected me when my mother got violent, and the peacemaker that taught my family to forgive. That brief interaction restored my appreciation for life and I found purpose in pursuing medicine to give others hope at times of defeat.

When I moved to college, I used this inspiration to get involved in the community and dedicated my time volunteering at both a local outreach clinic and the hospital. One day I was observing an infusion nurse put an IV on a man with colon cancer. He opened up to me about how he went from taking trips on his motorcycle and surfing to spending his days at the hospital recovering from bowel obstruction surgery. For the following weeks, I signed up to work every day to be there while he recovered. After a while, he was walking on his own, and by the time I arrived for my shift he’d light up and say “There she is!”. He spoke about how painful it was not seeing his son who was serving time with only 5 years left of his sentence and the patient feared he’d die before his son's release. He told me that he failed as a father and as a form of repentance, he let his health deteriorate, undergoing the procedures on his own to not be a burden to his family. With permission, I held his hands, wiped his tears, and expressed with volition that he was not a burden to me. On my last day at the department, I made him a card filled with drawings of the things he would be able to do once out of the hospital like surfing and meeting his son. While our goodbye was mutually emotional, the time we shared gave me confidence in my ability to understand the life of my patient beyond their treatment and acknowledge how their background may influence their health decisions.

Initially, I believed my clinical experience would be postponed due to the pandemic, but shortly after reuniting with Nanay, she was diagnosed with ovarian cancer. With cancer absent from both sides of the family, it was challenging for me to accept this reality. The early days of her diagnosis continued as normal with her happily cooking Filipino dishes and me joining her on walks. But, after her hysterectomy, she became too weak to do activities on her own. Sundays I dressed her in formal church attire and took her to the living room where our priest held service for her. At night, I laid awake for hours comforting her until she could fall asleep. The following months were progressively harder for her with chemotherapy, weekly paracentesis, and the limitation of one visitor each day at the hospital as COVID cases surged. 

I remembered the physician from my youth and used every opportunity to make her laugh, recall our memories in the Philippines, and reassure her that I was happy to be a caregiver. Although I had served patients in the past, taking care of someone that raised me and loved me was both immensely rewarding and painful. As I fed and bathed her, she praised my abilities and how proud she was of my clinical training. But when seasons changed and her treatments continued to fail, I found my skills to be insufficient and took time to educate myself on her condition by shadowing an oncologist. This opportunity gave me both insight into the disease and reassurance from cancer survivors. I remained optimistic and reminisced on my positive experience with the man at the hospital. Sadly this time, I wasn’t able to share a goodbye. 

When Nanay passed, it felt like I was 12 again, quietly standing alone over a casket as I filtered out the sounds of empty condolences. Buried in the same cemetery as Anahi, I sought solace by talking to them, but the silence just had me question my existentialism. Yet, once I returned as a volunteer at the hospital, I regained awareness of my long-term goal. Despite my loss, the chance to give a patient a reason to smile and to keep fighting gave me salvation. I accepted that even as a physician, my ultimate responsibility is not to save someone but to provide them with the best quality of life for the time they are with me. Every encounter is a chance for me to remind others of the value of their existence and that needing help doesn’t discredit who they are and their accomplishments. In return, I am entrusted with their stories and carrying their legacy through continuing acts of service. 

Even during difficult situations, life is not meaningless. I will be a doctor that treats others of all backgrounds and helps them remember the aspects of life they keep close to their heart. Whether it’s the exhilarating feeling of riding a motorcycle or coming home to a loved one, these motivate us to move forward and share positivity with those around us.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: While working at the International Center on campus I led my own class under the English Conversation Program. This class gave international students a place to practice conversational English with the help of English speaking facilitators. Through icebreaker activities I learned about the different cultures and backgrounds of my students which allowed me to see life through their perspective. By considering the environment they grew up in and the beliefs they value, I gained patience and understanding, handling situations respectfully. When a student was offended by unfamiliar slang from another student, I calmly explained the terminology and meaning behind the phrase. By allowing the students to talk it out, they actually became close friends. Students also partook in presentations where they taught the class about their language, music, and holidays. I learned that by giving others the platform to share, they can fully express who they are and gain confidence in themselves.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: At my local outreach clinic I help not only individuals, but their families as well. We have a kitchen where we offer cooking classes and supply patients with the ingredients and equipment to follow along with us. By providing a welcoming space for others, we converse about culture, food and life. The most gratifying aspect of the classes is that those who attend can bring the food they make home to their families alongside ingredients to make the meal at home. The nutritious meals we make are easy to follow and we also incorporate lessons to talk about diseases such as hyperlipidemia and diabetes. Cooking a meal with someone can give a person the motivation and a hands on experience to improve their health. Those who attended our classes were even able to share what they learned with others. I will continue to advocate for more universal healthcare, targeting areas that are the most neglected and providing resources that are culturally sensitive and relevant for patients.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The pandemic was exceptionally difficult for my family as my grandma was diagnosed with ovarian cancer at the same time. With the majority of extended family overseas, we were the only ones who could be there for her. Unfortunately, due to hospital restrictions on guests, we weren't able to visit her as readily when she was admitted. Since I was taking care of my grandma on top of adjusting to online school, I revised my plans for medical school and decided to delay taking the MCAT and take a gap year. This would additionally give me more time to save money for medical school so that my parents could fully finance my grandma's treatment. Once school became hybrid with online and in-person classes, I returned to university and periodically traveled to care for my grandma. When she passed, her burial was delayed a month after her death due to the many COVID deaths which made mourning very stressful. My last quarter of college, I balanced final exams and putting my grandma to rest.

personal_statement:
My father screamed at the top of his lungs from the back seat as my hands tightly gripped the steering wheel and I raced down the road towards the emergency room. It had only been a few days since his gastric bypass procedure, and hours of diagnostic testing at the medical center finally revealed the problem: a leak at the incision site. Though I could comprehend the post-operative discomfort that we were warned about, I was shocked at the magnitude of pain that could result from an error as minor as a loose stitch. 

I have been helping my father all my life, as obesity limited his speed and range of motion. In this situation, however, I felt utterly powerless. The surgery we anticipated with excitement, one that could change his life for the better, brought him the worst pain I have ever seen him suffer through--and I could do nothing about it. The potential to relieve people of pain and stop it from ever reaching this level is why I find value in the medical field, and why I want to be a physician one day.

Pain is a sensation universally experienced by humans that is wide in its scope. Aside from physical pain, one can endure the pain of uncertainty, the pain of being unable to progress, or the pain of failing when they have done all that they could. Pain in all its forms is what I believe robs people of their joy the most; it kills motivation, breeds anxiety and chaos, and makes us feel alone. I consciously avoided these experiences as an adolescent, which resulted in my refusal to pursue anything outside of my comfort zone and intentionally distancing myself from conflict of any kind.

Years later, sitting in the driver's seat of that car, I realized the futility in trying to avoid something that was integrated in human nature. Pain could inflict itself upon even the strongest individuals, the way I perceived my father to be. I now live in pursuit of a solution, rather than running from the problem. I volunteered in the most critical departments of the Orlando Regional Medical Center so that I could to broaden my perception of how pain can affect and present itself in different people. I developed an interest in research, recognizing its potential to optimize patientcare and overcome the plateaus that impede progress. The Interventional Robotics Laboratory was the perfect setting for this, since technology is becoming a powerful tool that can either drastically improve the lives of patients or increase the pain it was intended to prevent.

I have learned that the universality of this struggle represents an opportunity to reach so many people when they are at their lowest. This realization encouraged me to live every day trying to relieve others of pain in the capacity I was able, and leaving people even slightly better than the way I found them was a great success in my eyes. Physicians represent a population with one of the greatest access to people in pain. They have the versatility of technical experience required to prevent it, and work in an environment of confidentiality and trustworthiness that allows them to do so. Every doctor, in one way or another, is a pain specialist.

This vision gave me a purpose in pursuing medicine that was worthy of the struggles that accompanied it. Because of my ambition in high school, the timeline to complete my undergraduate studies was shortened to just over two years, already making it a demanding task to gain valuable experience. In addition, the COVID pandemic had interfered with my entire first year of university, making it difficult to gain involvement in direct patient care and interact with my peers and professors. Yet my determination to realize this future helped me overcome these challenges. I conducted research with the Interventional Robotics Laboratory and secured a teaching assistant position while in a virtual setting. I engaged in telehealth medicine to experience the interactions between a patient and provider during a time when physical exchanges were not possible. I knew the value of these experiences in my personal and professional development and their importance in achieving my ultimate goals, so I adapted to the circumstances in order to carry them out.

My father stayed that night in the hospital and underwent a follow-up procedure the next day. For a second time I saw the familiar wires and tubes protrude from him, hoping to one day understand the purpose of each. Though his unconscious state made him seem at peace for the moment, I was now fully aware of the struggle that would follow. At that point, however, there was nothing I could do except take my father home and hope he would recover quickly. One day, I want to be able to do more than just hope. 

The role of a physician goes beyond fixing bodies; they are ambassadors of mental, physical, and emotional wellness. I want to devote my life to preventing pain in all its forms from plaguing the lives of others, whether through the direct administration of treatment, the proper execution of medical procedures, or the discovery of more effective therapies. As one version of the Hippocratic Oath writes: "I will prevent diseases whenever I can, for prevention is preferable to cure."
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Every year, I serve with the Middle Eastern Christian Ministry in a project to distribute gifts to children who were admitted to the hospital during Christmas day. I prepare the packages with volunteers from various countries who speak many dialects of Arabic, and learned that having a common goal gives us motivation to overcome any individual differences that may stand in our way. When visiting each child‚Äôs room, I was met with a wide demographic of families which had different boundaries and perspectives that I accounted for when serving them. I acted as an interpreter for some of the volunteer members who did not speak English, and was often needed to communicate in Spanish with the patient‚Äôs families directly to explain our mission, allowing me to exercise all the languages with which I was familiar in a clinical setting. I learned that people may react to a situation based on their personal worldview, which must be considered to serve them effectively in their time of need.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Just before high school, my childhood best friend experienced a hostile divorce between his parents that disproportionately affected his well-being. The tension led to a decline in his mental health, and he was diagnosed shortly afterwards with bipolar disorder. Though I was unfamiliar with the condition, I was not prepared to let it destroy his future and quality of life. I made myself available to him whenever he needed, often waking up in the middle of the night to comfort him and alleviate his anxiety. His condition caused his performance in school to diminish, but my sense of responsibility drove me to support him through classes, tutor him in SAT mathematics, and ultimately help him apply for the college which he now attends. I saw that a relatively small contribution on my part could lead to a profound impact in another person‚Äôs life. Through this journey I learned that the individual must take action to create the change they desire to see in the lives of others and the world.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
The entire first year of my undergraduate education took place during the COVID-19 pandemic, which greatly reduced my opportunity to gain further clinical experience. I intended to pursue clinical opportunities from my first semester in university to accommodate the shortened timeframe of my undergraduate studies. However, I was turned away by every clinic, hospital, and physician that I reached out to due to the circumstances._x000D_
_x000D_
Despite this challenge, I found a solution through telehealth medicine and worked diligently to gain clinical experience in more demanding semesters when these opportunities became available. I am proud of my ability to maintain my academic performance while gaining valuable experience in the field, but I suspect that my clinical experience would have been more extensive had the circumstances been different.

Under_School: California Northstate University College of Health Sciences
personal_statement:
Forming a nonprofit organization from the ground up to deliver cards to lonely patients and essential workers who may suffer from burnout; listening to the history of troubled youth and helping them navigate crises; catering to the different needs and learning styles of my students as a peer-assisted learner (PAL) - these various roles may not seem like they have anything in common, but they all represent a key tenet in my aspirations to practice medicine. In each situation, I have reveled in the challenge of synthesizing different pieces of information to solve puzzles and find personalized solutions for the struggles of others.      

This core value stems back to my upbringing, as I watched my radiologist father analyze anatomical structures through CAT scans, MRIs, and other diagnostic imaging. It fascinated me that he could determine a diagnosis from blurs, creases, and blotches. As I learned from observing my father, being a doctor requires the utmost attention to even the most minor details. Routine diagnostic exams can often reveal significant pathology upon thorough review. For example, when a seemingly healthy middle-aged person came in for a pre-operation chest x-ray, my father discovered enlarged lymph nodes hiding behind the pulmonary hilum. Although this was completely unexpected, my father still picked up on an abnormality that altered the patient’s prognosis. It was as if he were solving a puzzle with no picture to guide him. In many ways, this is the story of my life, always seeking the picture on the puzzle box with 1000 pieces scattered before me. Watching my father throughout my childhood stoked my interest in medicine, as I saw the complexity of individual cases and the variety of factors that needed to be considered to diagnose patients accurately. I want to become a physician who constantly gains new knowledge and makes sense of each patient’s puzzle to improve their quality of life. 

In high school, I wanted to diversify my medical experiences, so I sought a reputable mission group that focused on healthcare instead of voluntourism. I joined MEDLIFE on a medical mission trip to Peru, which opened my eyes to the issues of access and equity. In Peru, I saw slums sprawling as far as the eye can see. The notion of brushing teeth, let alone using toothpaste, was nonexistent. At one particular clinic site, I set up a dental station where I taught children how to brush their teeth and gave out supplies. After demonstrating with a dental model, the children eagerly followed my lead and practiced, smiling ear to ear with their new knowledge and supplies. I noticed, however, that one child looked rather dejected. When I asked him what was wrong, he said that he was having trouble using the toothbrush and needed help. Without a second thought, I knelt down next to him and brushed his teeth for him while giving pointers in Spanish. By the time I was done, he was elated and gave me a big high five. Teaching him how to take care of himself felt rewarding and, more importantly, like it was my calling. I showed him how to help himself using nothing but information and empathy. I realized that as a physician, I could empower patients by teaching them healthy habits and practicing preventative medicine. Understanding the importance of continuity in helping patients achieve better outcomes, I revitalized our mission efforts in college through virtual learning opportunities that continue to fundraise for these same Peruvian populations during the pandemic.

While shadowing Dr. Levin, an anesthesiologist at a surgical outpatient center, I noticed one patient in the recovery area. The first thing that he requested was his trusted Miami Heat hat. Observing his body language and seeing that he was anxious and uncomfortable, I handed it to him, saying enthusiastically, “The Heat look good this year!” to which he replied with an instant ear-to-ear smile, “I know right! Jimmy Butler is a legend.” Before I could say another word, he exclaimed, “I think we can win the championship this year!” Dr. Levin walked in to check on the patient, who had a history of reacting to anesthesia with nausea and had been reluctant to use it again. With great confidence, Dr. Levin proudly patted him, declaring, “I told you that you would not have nausea this time.” Although this interaction is one of many that Dr. Levin undergoes on a consistent basis, I recognized Dr. Levin’s attentiveness to his patients, reassuring them that their trust was well placed. Seeing such connections inspired me to keep on the path of medicine so I can one day earn my patients’ trust.

More than any other career, a physician pieces together symptoms and demystifies something complex for patients, giving them more clarity and control over their lives. I envision my future self practicing preventative medicine in underserved communities. My experiences of service as a crisis counselor with the Trevor Project, mentoring students as a PAL, and founding and leading my very own nonprofit have ingrained the value of cultural humility and emotional intelligence into myself and I will carry that to my future practice.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
One day in 2017, I walked in on a very close family member attempting to cut themself. I immediately intervened and attempted to console them. I was heartbroken and confused; this family member had always seemed so happy. With education, I was able to support my family member effectively. Witnessing the transformation that their support system helped make possible, I realized that I wanted to help those without access to similar supports._x000D_
_x000D_
Seeing that the pandemic cut off in-person support for LGBTQIA+ youth led me to sign up for the Trevor Project to become a crisis counselor.  With every conversation, I had the same feeling of wanting to help my family member. However, now I had effective tools to help people to the best of my ability. I aim to be a physician that patients feel comfortable with even if we are from different backgrounds. As such, I commit myself to clear and kind communication in addition to learning as much as I can to demonstrate my willingness to help and listen.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
When I began college in Fall 2020, my desire to support others led me to EGIL (Educate, Growth, Inspire, Learn), where I act as a mentor and workshop coordinator. This nonprofit provides services for children of underserved communities: some are refugees, some are first-generation immigrants, some are orphans, and some are unhoused. Experiencing their resilience firsthand is mind-opening to the things that I take for granted. _x000D_
_x000D_
This has reinforced my passion for working with underserved communities. It is a powerful way to enhance cultural humility that will also benefit future patient interactions and create bonds with amazing people with unique backgrounds and stories. As such, as a medical student, I will commit myself to clear and kind communication in addition to learning as much as I can to demonstrate my willingness to help and listen. Additionally, I commit to fighting health inequities faced by BIPOC in Chicago‚Äôs west side neighborhoods.
7_-_COVID_Impact: Due to COVID-19, my volunteer position at Boca Raton Regional Hospital was prematurely cut short; despite my best efforts, I also had difficulty finding physician shadowing opportunities after moving to the Greater Sacramento area.

personal_statement:
I remember hearing my mother’s shaky voice, feigning calm. Frozen in place, I digested news that my father was undergoing treatment for an ischemic stroke. Will my father have a permanent disability? How will my uninsured parents afford his care? What will happen to the family business? Four weeks away from graduating with a bachelor’s degree, I contemplated my future. My interests in biology and research initially steered me toward a career in biotechnology, but as my father regained function throughout the rehabilitation process my fascination with patient care and medicine grew. The empathy and technical skill displayed by his healthcare team inspired me to explore the medical field and define the role most congruent with my budding desire to treat and heal.

Clarity arrived during my first job in healthcare as a medical scribe, observing hospitalists manage cases ranging from acute kidney injury to gastrointestinal bleeds. One morning, Dr. Mahendra rounded on an elderly patient with end-stage congestive heart failure. I felt the tension in the room climb as she explained to the patient’s daughter that her unresponsive mother’s eerily regular cardiac rhythm was solely supported by the pacemaker firing in her chest. As Dr. Mahendra navigated this sensitive interaction with poise and compassion, I realized that this aspect of medicine – equipping patients and their loved ones with the resources and support to make dignified decisions in moments of vulnerability – was equally as important as formulating definitive treatment plans. This interaction, among others, fueled my desire to lead patient care as a physician.

While scribing provided me with a strong introduction to inpatient medicine, my position as a clinical research coordinator for oncology trials expanded my perspective of the patient-physician dynamic. I appreciated the additional responsibilities oncologists shoulder as Principal Investigators and the tenacity with which they strive to improve patient outcomes through novel treatments. Cancer patients who elect to participate in clinical trials have exhausted frontline treatments, and they place immense trust in their oncologists. 

One of my first research subjects, Mr. B, had metastatic laryngeal squamous cell carcinoma and lost the ability to speak after a prior laryngectomy. Two months into Mr. B’s trial enrollment, his visit attendance became erratic, raising concerns about the irregularity of treatments affecting the therapy’s effectiveness. I visited Mr. B during one of his infusions, broaching the topic of his attendance to better understand his situation. Mr. B’s brow furrowed as he etched on his whiteboard, “can’t afford parking and gas.” Although his treatment was covered by the trial sponsor, Mr. B’s lower socioeconomic status made transportation costs a financial constraint to participation. I worked with my PI and the sponsor to amend this study protocol to include travel and parking reimbursement for all research subjects. This encounter with Mr. B taught me how mindful communication and consideration for a patient’s circumstances promotes patient advocacy while improving treatment outcomes.

My experiences as an ophthalmic technician and scribe brought other aspects of medicine into focus. As the only Spanish-speaking employee at the clinic, it was gratifying to see the timid demeanors of Hispanic immigrant patients shift after greeting them in Spanish. One such patient, Mrs. G, arrived at the clinic complaining of a sudden loss of vision in her left eye. I learned that she had a history of poorly controlled diabetes and hadn’t visited her primary care doctor for two years, citing financial hardship and no health insurance. Clearly in distress, I eased her nerves by guiding her through our assessments and retinal imaging scans. Acting as her translator, I relayed directions while Dr. Taglia performed a dilated fundus exam to gauge the extent of her acute retinal detachment and diabetic retinopathy. After educating Mrs. G on the urgency of her condition and referring her to a nearby Retina Specialist, Dr. Taglia waived Mrs. G’s visit fee, which he often did for uninsured patients. Having lost an uncle to complications from poorly controlled diabetes, this interaction left me feeling hopeful for Mrs. G’s prognosis. Though I played an active role in Mrs. G’s care that afternoon, I longed to be in Dr. Taglia’s shoes. 

As an immature undergraduate lacking a clear vision for the future, I did not perform to the full extent of my academic ability. My experiences in the medical field motivated me to reflect on my past missteps and make the personal changes necessary to reach my academic potential. When I returned to college to improve my academic standing, I worked as a teaching assistant and supplemental instructor for two semesters. These experiences helped solidify my understanding of Anatomy and Physiology concepts, and I also found it gratifying to help other students master those subjects. I look forward to combining my interests in medicine, research and education as a medical student and future physician. It is my goal to expand the reach of translational medicine to vulnerable, marginalized populations and mentor the next generation of medical professionals.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: In spring of 2021, I took on a weekend position as a vehicle transporter for a company called Vehi-ship in Glenwood, IL. This augmented my income while taking courses at IU Northwest. Most of the employees were Black and full of life and humor. They shared stories of the struggles of growing up in broken homes and dangerous neighborhoods, poverty, and lack of opportunity. Some had criminal records for which they served time behind bars, so Vehi-ship‚Äôs low entry requirements gave them an opportunity to support themselves and family. Many also had chronic metabolic diseases such as diabetes and heart disease. This really put into perspective how fortunate I was to have grown up in a stable environment, with opportunities to advance in life because my basic needs were met by my parents and environment. It also opened me up to the charm of a diverse community; our different experiences better informed me of the disparities that afflict minority and underserved communities in my vicinity.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: During the fall and spring semesters of 2021 and 2022, I worked as a supplemental instructor and teaching assistant for Anatomy and Physiology I & II at IU Northwest. Entering this role, I realized that my greatest challenge would be figuring out how to make my SI sessions interactive and engaging for students who had difficulty adjusting to in-person instruction or were unaccustomed to leveraging academic support systems in the past. After consulting the professor, I employed a flipped classroom along with group quizzes, Kahoot exercises, and chalkboard activities to promote interaction and reinforce concepts. This implementation taught me how to guide students‚Äô thought processes so that they may work themselves through any gaps in understanding. It was gratifying to watch students‚Äô performances improve as they became more proactive. This experience taught me how to approach, support, and encourage the academic goals of students from diverse backgrounds and learning style preferences.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
I worked in oncology clinical research at Rush University Cancer Center during the height of the pandemic, and I saw how the novel coronavirus strained the resources and human capital of a large academic medical center. The spread of the virus and shortage of healthcare personnel most affected lower socioeconomic, minority communities._x000D_
_x000D_
After leaving Rush to pursue post-bacc courses I worked as an ophthalmic technician/scribe at LTF Eye Clinics. There, I worked with patients whose socioeconomic status hindered their ability to afford treatment, whose immigrant status presented an additional barrier to accessing care, and whose disability status posed logistical challenges to preventative care. By speaking with patients, I learned how the pandemic affected the lives and livelihoods of patients and loved ones. Each patient interaction brought a new opportunity to learn about the complex interplay of personal and environmental circumstances that shape each patient‚Äôs health status.

personal_statement:
Diagnosed with type 2 diabetes roughly at the same time as each other, I watched my parents struggle everyday from pricking their fingers, to skipping meals in an attempt to manage their blood sugars. Being immigrants from India, a language barrier would sometimes prevent them from understanding educational materials given by the doctor, or how to use the glucometer. When my parents needed to check their blood sugars, I used to pretend I was the doctor, and they were my patients. I pricked their fingers, tested the blood, and then reported the results. Over time, I started understanding how their blood sugars changed based on exercise, their eating habits, and their medication schedule.

However, there was a connection that I didn’t see as a child. Being immigrants added another strain to my parents' healthcare experience: lack of quality health insurance. Doctor’s appointments were expensive, meaning that their diagnoses came too late. Seeing the burden chronic disease placed on my parents spurned a passion for helping the underserved communities around me gain better access to healthcare.

I have had the opportunity to create change in underserved communities on a personal level by volunteering as an EMT at the Urban Ministries Open Door Clinic and at the Mariam Clinic. Both clinics help serve uninsured patients with no other access to healthcare, including many immigrant communities. I am able to help people, who, much like my own parents, are navigating a new country and a new healthcare system. I meet with many patients who have chronic diseases, and can see the impact that healthcare, along with education and treatment, have on various diseases. I have seen a patient go from having a prediabetic A1C to a normal A1C over the course of several months. I have also seen a patient, with no knowledge of even having diabetes, finally receive treatment and be able to see their blood sugar levels decrease. The routine of seeing patients was one that also became like second nature to me, and seeing the results from treatments made me feel like I was truly making a change. Walking down the hallways on my shifts, I would sometimes see patients I had helped in the past, and we’d stop to chat, and I’d give a high-five to their kids in passing. I saw how I had become a part of my patients' lives, as someone they trusted. I began to see the role a physician takes on in a person’s life, and strive to be that person, in the same way that physicians were to my parents.

However, I failed to recognize one thing: what could be done when lifestyle changes, education, and medication weren’t enough? During one of my shifts at the Mariam Clinic, a patient of mine had come in to see the psychiatrist, something she told me while I took her vitals. When the psychiatrist came in, she explained that the death of her mother and being cut off from loved ones due to the pandemic had triggered feelings of hopelessness and isolation. In the past, I had always spoken to patients casually about their lives, but I never had a patient bare such a serious side to themselves. After we listened to her, I watched as the healthcare provider discussed treatment options with her. However, there were no educational materials she could take home about lifestyle or diet changes, and no tests or monitors she could use to measure her condition. There was no feeling of satisfaction that went home with me either, while I was driving back and processing the interaction in my mind. Nothing could be cured overnight, but the important part was that her treatment had begun, and the access to healthcare that the clinic had given her could begin its process. After all, this is why I wanted to become a physician - to give people such as her the ability to have a fighting chance.

One month passed, and it was time for her follow up. I finished taking her vitals, and could see that physically, there was nothing wrong with her. When the psychiatrist came in, she spoke to us about how she continued to miss her mother, and that the effects were interfering with day-to-day tasks. Medication had only helped to an extent, but there was not much else that could be done for her. We spent the rest of the meeting encouraging her and reminding her of the support she had here in the clinic, as well as in her family.

Several months into her treatment, my patient continued to feel down and depressed, and the medication seemed to prove mostly ineffective. However, she told us she still wanted to try to get better. The encouragement and hope we imparted on her at every meeting had given her the strength to want to continue treatment. The space we had given her to talk about her problems had made her feel as though she was not alone. I was uplifted that I had had such an impact on her. Before, I used to spend time after our meetings questioning whether I had let her down as one of her healthcare providers, when I didn’t stop to think about what I had already done for her. As a physician, there will be days that will not always hold successes. However, a physician must never forget about the things that are within their power. Together, my patient and I will take it one day at a time, as I plan to do with all my future patients.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Growing up with a twin sister, I routinely grew tired of the constant comparisons, and people assuming that appearing similar on the outside meant we were similar on the inside. As a result, I began to develop a desire for people to see me as an individual, and not simply under the label of ‚Äútwin‚Äù. As I got older, I began to see more and more how labels began to shape our world, and even our healthcare system. While volunteering with patients at the Urban Ministries Clinic and the Mariam Clinic, I realized the various labels and connotations placed on patients unknowingly. For example, non-English speaking patients were seen as more ‚Äúdifficult‚Äù, and male patients tended to downplay their pain to seem more masculine. However, my own desire to be seen beyond a label had come to influence my clinical experiences, and I found myself getting to know each of my patients beyond a set of numbers and a diagnosis, and have realized what it means to view a patient holistically.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: Currently, many health insurance companies use guidelines which entail that an individual must be a current smoker, or have quit smoking within the past 15 years, to decide whether to cover the cost of lung cancer screenings. However, environmental pollutants can also play a role in the development of lung cancer. As victims of environmental racism, many people of color in NC live in areas with poorer air quality. Due to this, they are disproportionately subjected to having a higher risk of developing lung cancer, but can be ineligible for lung cancer screenings, or to have these procedures covered by their health insurance. As a member of the American Lung Cancer Screening Initiative, with other members, I was able to speak to the offices of two U.S. Congressmen about the passage of H.R. 3749 through the U.S. House of Representatives, a bill that will certify that smoking history is not the only basis for screening, and ensure that health insurance companies cover these screenings.
7_-_COVID_Impact: With the pandemic throwing a wrench into my ability to expand my experiences in the healthcare field, I knew I lacked clarity. The all-important question of ‚Äúwhy do you wish to be a physician?‚Äù could only be answered half-heartedly by me. A research internship that I had originally been accepted to for the summer of 2020 at the Wake Forest School of Medicine had been postponed to the following year. Calling medical offices for the opportunity to shadow doctors at the facility had understandably resulted in many rejections. However, when quarantine and pandemic restrictions began to ease, my ability to gain critical healthcare-related experiences eased along with it. My research internship at Wake Forest resumed for the summer of 2021, and I also found two new opportunities to volunteer with patients at free clinics. Upon graduation, my work still continues in all these areas, and of course, the all-important question of ‚Äúwhy do you wish to be a physician?‚Äù finally has an answer.

personal_statement:
The crowd roared in the largest stadium in the nation: the University of  Michigan’s Big House. As Jax and I prepared for our first stunt of the season, my face stretched into a grinning mask to cover my fear. I trust Jax to get me on his shoulders. He trusts me to keep steady until the kickoff signal.

My fear was from the transition from gymnastics -  a solitary sport - to cheerleading, a cohesive team sport. When I started cheerleading, I only trusted myself: my skills and strength. But, to win in cheerleading, I have to trust my base. Practice and communication together create a rhythm, and no one has the exact same rhythm. My base is my buffer between air and ground. With practice also comes mistakes: my foot slipped, and now the ground accelerated to my face. But Jax stopped the collision in time. Together, Jax and I work with others and build a stunt pyramid. Finally, our team works as a unit and builds the trust for success. 

Out on the field, part of the team faces the crowd and waits for the signal to thrust our signs in the air and shout “GO!” At the other end of the field, the rest of the team does the same with “BLUE!” The crowd follows our direction and chants “GO BLUE!” We then run off the field to allow the players the space they need to restart the play.

Last summer, I took part in a new team and led patients to recovery instead of crowds in cheer. I was a patient attendant at the University of Michigan Medical Center. Once, in the Cardiovascular Care Unit, I sat with an elderly man after his heart surgery. His healthcare team worked together like it was a rehearsed routine. I cleared chairs. Nurses cleared wires. The surgeon readied to shock the patient's heart out of atrial fibrillation. “This isn’t exactly what it looks like in the movies,” the surgeon said to me, “it’s scarier in real life.” He readied the AED paddles, and as he began to say ‘clear,’ the patient’s heart returned to a regular rhythm. “He must’ve heard us and jumped started his own heart. That happens sometimes,” the surgeon commented. To him this may have been a small observation, this moment confirmed that the hospital was my home.

I always knew I wanted to be a doctor. Every time Mom came home from work she burst through the door, her white coat in the breeze behind her, I ran to smell her. It's bizarre, but the antibacterial soaps used at hospitals were pleasant to me. It was a doctor’s smell, a smell I wanted and trusted. I was unsure how important the smell was until I entered the environment of the hospital. Especially in the elderly man’s ICU room. The energy resembled football sidelines and the pressure of the game with my team.

I often asked Mom questions about her work: when my sister had knee pain, I probed her about the diagnosis. “Patellofemoral pain syndrome,” Mom says. When asked what those words mean, she returned:

“Where is the patella?”
“In the knee,” I say.  
“What does ‘-femor-’ sound like?”
“Femur.”

This was her way of dissection, active recall, and listening skill practice. In her elusive way, she was trying to get me to put it together on my own. “It’s the name for the pain in her knee cap?”

“Yes!”

Our discussions were critical for my education, conversations, and experiences. This includes how people speak to me as a Black woman and my interpretation of novels or articles. In 2020, I learned that Black women die from poor maternity care the way Black men die from police encounters. The CDC found Black women's childbirth mortality rates were higher than white and Hispanic women's at 55.3 deaths per 100,000 live births. Black women are 2.9 times more likely to face death at childbirth. Physicians at times diminish Black people’s pain because “we can handle it,” and diminish women’s pain because “we’re dramatic.” Combined, this leads to significant disparities in Black women's mortality rate during childbirth. 

How can the Black community trust healthcare institutions? What role can I play to change that statistic? Initially, orthopedics interested me because of gymnastics and cheer. I often saw musculoskeletal injuries and wanted to add myself to the list of 100 Black female orthopedic surgeons.  Plus, studies show Black patient health outcomes improve with Black physicians. These Black patient care statistics inspired other possible specialties and increased my commitment. I will be on the winning team for the Black community and restore positive healthcare interactions with people who look like me.

When I was a Peer Facilitator for a Research Health Sciences seminar, I shared this statistical information to my students. My students were 1st and 2nd-year undergrads of variable race and gender. I wanted my students to understand other identity perspectives. So I taught about the role of race in research ethics, imposter syndrome, and inclusivity. They seemed as startled as I was. My goal as a teacher was to expose students to how identities affect health care disparities.

I believe patients' trust in physicians and the healthcare institution is central to medical care success. Success requires teamwork and trust. These days I still trust Jax to hold my legs on his shoulders. There, I look across the Big House stadium into my future in medicine leading patients to recovery.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc:
My study abroad experience was integral to my cultural experiences. After growing up near the Austin area, I drove down Division to get to Lake Michigan. I would drive through Humbolt Park and look at the language changes. I‚Äôm glad I understood most of the content on buildings. I grew up with Spanish and knew that I wanted that skill for the rest of my life. I even want to practice medicine in Spanish. Studying abroad is perfect to plunge into Spanish culture. _x000D_
_x000D_
In Spain, I took courses with European graduate students and other American students. The curriculum focused on collaboration with other students in the class. I presented research proposals to everyone. I also lived with University of Salamanca students. I loved the lingo and fashion of the European students. I experienced different Spanish habits: smoking, mealtimes, and walking. These habits are both positive and negative health effects. If countries integrate habits and education, certain nations could improve their health.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
In Spain, I explained why someone who used he/him pronouns referred to themselves as ‚Äúone of the girlies". My friend grew up in a less diverse area than me, and comments like that were rare. He was unsure if my friend was actually transgender. This led to the conversation of ‚Äúhow do you understand gay people?‚Äù Questions all from a cis-heterosexual white man._x000D_
_x000D_
I wondered what my friend saw that made him feel comfortable asking me these questions. Since I was so bewildered, I took my time and listened to the way he grew up. There were few open people in the LGBTQ+ community. His white, Christian neighborhood. _x000D_
_x000D_
I had to stop and think about how to respond to this. He assumes that I‚Äôm Christian and straight because 'all' Black Americans are Christian. I took the time and shared why he should open his perspective. Our conversation ended with ‚Äúthank you for this conversation with me, I appreciated it.‚Äù I realized that he appreciated our conversation and understood more than a reprimand.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
COVID-19 altered my journey to medical school. During freshman year I dealt with school, athletic, and social obligations. I learned how to focus in school and loved my routine. But at home, the racial climate, and pandemic knocked me completely off my axis. School felt impossible to complete. Life became difficult, and for the first time as a Black woman, I had racial slurs hurled at me. I was anxious, lost a lot of social responsibilities, and isolated myself. This continued to my sophomore year. Back in Ann Arbor, I struggled with online school. I needed in-person classes because I learned from other people. _x000D_
_x000D_
The effect that the pandemic had on POC communities built a deeper purpose on why I needed to continue in healthcare. During my junior year, I decided to apply._x000D_
_x000D_
I sacrificed a lot but still had fun. I traveled with football and basketball, celebrated many birthdays, and cherished our 3rd Championship win! I yielded some of my life to COVID, but I‚Äôve managed to return better.

personal_statement:
I lay on the cold, hard medical table immobilized by the doctor’s words: “You have a grade 2 strain in your adductor longus and will be out the remainder of the season.” Alone and uncertain about my future aspirations, I felt lost and powerless. A few weeks later, I received a second opinion. Dr. Weiss Kelly, a sports medicine specialist who works with the Cleveland Browns, sat down with me, leaned in, and asked me what my goals were. I expressed to her that I wanted to play in Notre Dame stadium. Without hesitation, she locked eyes with me and said, “We will make that happen.” Two years later, I made the opening tackle against the 5th ranked Fighting Irish in their home stadium in South Bend.

If you were to ask me six years ago if my childhood dream of playing Division I Football would be realized I would have answered with a resounding no. However, having a doctor champion for my present and future self, galvanized my spirit and allowed my childhood dream to crystalize. Ultimately, Dr. Weiss Kelly’s care and affirmation of my dreams displayed to me that the magnitude of the impact of a physician extends beyond the walls of the clinic or hospital. 

Committing to the welfare of others ignites my passion for service. During my work mentoring with The Afterschool Program (TAP), I developed numerous significant relationships with my mentees while helping them envision a different future. “Will” was one of my first mentees and at 13 years old his passion for basketball was unwavering. Whenever he walked, he would dribble an imaginary ball practicing his crossover and behind-the-back moves. As I spent more time with him, he informed me of his family dynamic. The eldest child in his family, he was responsible for taking care of both his diabetic grandmother and little sister while his mom worked. Consequently, this hindered him from trying out for the middle school basketball team. Thinking about how I could empower Will through this time in his life, I organized a surprise guest appearance for him and the other kids. The disbelief on Will’s face as he hung from the rim after being hoisted up by the 6 '10'’ Vanderbilt starting Center is still vividly ingrained in my mind. 

Despite the positive emotions that I associate with surprising Will, it is challenging for me to ignore the underlying issues of health inequity he and his family encounter. Hearing about the strain Will and his family were under made me hypervigilant about understanding the impact of the social determinants of health. This has since prompted my academic and career endeavors in this arena.  

When I transitioned to the post-baccalaureate program at Washington University in St. Louis, I grew as both a student and an individual. Not only have I been able to take accountability for my prior academic performance, but I have also been able to delve deeply into my passion for healthcare delivery and advocacy. Volunteering with IFM community medicine has directly exposed me to some of the issues that interfere with effective medical care.

One day in the clinic, a man timidly walked back to the exam room. His breathing was unsteady, and he was shaking uncontrollably. His distress reminded me of how I felt when I was sitting alone on the medical exam table in Dr. Weiss Kelly’s office. Slowly getting up, I asked if I could sit next to him. As I comforted him, he confided in me. He explained to me that the doctor’s office always triggered distress for him, and he avoided seeking medical help unless it was necessary due to his prior experiences with the healthcare system. Leaving the clinic that day, I became resolute in my mission to pursue medicine to induce positive medical change for all.

My understanding of how positive medical change could be achieved was furthered by my time shadowing Dr. Coney, a retina specialist for the Cleveland Clinic. Towards the end of his clinic, Dr. Coney received a call from a patient who was running late. Instead of turning the patient away, he told them that he would stay around until they arrived. Walking into the clinic, the patient exclaimed, “I always know you will be there for me, and I greatly appreciate that.” The gratitude of this patient alongside my experience in the IFM clinic has informed my belief about garnering positive medical change for all. I believe that to do so generational trust must be established through the continuity of care.

Reliving my experiences with Dr. Weiss Kelly, Will, and Dr. Coney while also considering my time currently as a volunteer with IFM community medicine, I now understand that access to good healthcare lays a foundation for a legacy of good health. This legacy of good health can then promote agency and choice to do something or to be something better. Being able to pave this foundation for others through establishing communities of trust within the hospital walls and outside of them has been a motivating priority of my service, advocacy, and ultimate reasoning for looking towards the horizons of the noble profession of medicine.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: As an African-American (AA) male growing up in a suburban community with few minorities, I often found myself in places and spaces that my external appearance and speech created unanticipated challenges. This led me to become adept at ‚Äúcode- switching‚Äù ‚Äì alternating my behavior and speech to that of the crowd I was with so that I could blend in. I would endeavor to be ‚Äúcool‚Äù with my AA friends and later strive to be accepted as ‚Äúone of them‚Äù with my Caucasian friends. All the while losing a sense of identity but most importantly losing a sense of belonging. In high school, I began to embrace my authentic self and develop my identity.This not only allowed me to accept my uniqueness in background, but to embrace the uniqueness of others. My identity transitioned from a source of isolation to a secure platform of strength and belonging in diverse settings. It is from this secure platform of strength that I seek to serve and embrace my future patients and colleagues at Rush Medical College
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I often find myself reminiscing fondly upon the time I spent volunteering at The Afterschool Program (TAP) in Nashville.  Over my three years as a volunteer, I mentored many kids each with their own unique talents and gifts. ‚ÄúDavid,‚Äù a 5th grader when I initially began volunteering, was barely reading at the 2nd grade level. As his mentor, I began encouraging him to read his favorite books with me. With each ensuing month, progress in David‚Äôs reading ability was perceptible and his confidence grew. Instead of relying on me to reassure him that he was pronouncing challenging words correctly, he would diligently sound out the word until he had the correct pronunciation. At the end of my time volunteering with TAP, David was a 7th grader reading at a 9th grade level. His maturation into an avid reader is something that I was honored to facilitate. It demonstrated to me the empowering role of positive mentorship and guidance.

Hrdshp_Comments:
While privileged in many ways, my social and financial background has placed me at a disadvantage as a medical school applicant. From age 13, I was raised in a single parent household, limiting our financial resources. When my mother was then diagnosed with cancer, I had to take on a caregiver role for my mother and sister at a young age. I have been working since I was 16, often full time in addition to classes, to help support myself and my education. I have needed to prioritize my income over academics or potential clinical opportunities, allowing me to empathize with how one’s capacity can be diluted by context. Putting myself through my Master’s program and now pursuing medical school has been a journey driven by passion but with limited guidance. Coming from a family of artists, I do not have inherent connections or financial support that could make this a seamless process. I have therefore worked extremely hard to earn everything that I have achieved and highly value each of my successes.
My type 1 diabetes has also been a significant hurdle. While I refuse to let it limit me, it has taken significant time, energy, and money away from my chosen pursuits. Understanding the additional, global demands of a chronic illness is a unique perspective that I would like to bring into the field of medicine.
personal_statement:
There are countless ways to approach a puzzle. Of course, there are some tried-and-true methods, like sorting by color or using the box as a guide, but, after the edges are assembled and several hundred pieces remain, approaches can vary. This is when I am sucked in by the intricacies of a jigsaw, excited to find the best mix of strategies to employ. The more complex, the more I am drawn in. I see practicing medicine as a beautiful blend of puzzles and humanity. In a sense, the medical practitioner and the puzzler are one in the same, both benefit from discovering different perspectives and adapting their strategies to their contexts.

Assured by my personal, professional, and academic experiences, I believe that my strengths in a multi-perspective, problem-solving approach make medicine a context that I can thrive in. In my nontraditional progression towards medicine, I have embraced the compassionate side of healthcare while building a realistic view of the system itself. I have also developed the skills and experiences needed to broaden the viewpoints at my disposal while piecing together where I will fit in this field.

My interest in medicine began in high school when my mom was diagnosed with cancer. Her doctors made a traumatic moment for our family feel surmountable. Their individualized and sensitive care humanized the field of medicine for me. I later found myself leaning into a similar caregiver role, changing my mom’s dressings and monitoring her symptoms. From this, I crafted a vision of a future working within the borders of science, strategy, and helping others.

Later, I unfortunately had the opposite experience while pursuing treatment for my own chronic health condition. I was given standardized treatment plans without discussion. There were moments when I considered not seeking further care as it felt like my voice had been stifled and there were pieces swept under the rug. Feeling reduced to just my diagnosis made the cost of underrepresentation of differently-abled people in medicine clear. As a result, I learned the importance of a patient-centered approach and strong communication skills for practitioners. This experience and the confidence in relating to my patients that I’ve gained thereafter has highlighted an unmet need in the medical field that I feel empowered to fill.

My medical aspirations became deeper rooted within my clinical research position on the MGH pediatric epilepsy team. Putting the pieces together to help a child progress from hundreds of seizures per week to seizure freedom has been one of the most rewarding experiences. I will always remember the joy and pride in my sweetest patient’s face when she first pointed at the blood pressure cuff, excitedly repeating “Hug!”. Something like learning the function of a tool or remembering what I had taught her months prior would have been impossible for her before the trial. Moments like this and the close connections developed with my patients and their families fuel my passion for medicine.

Taking an active role on a care team has also illuminated the many administrative, logistical, and industry demands associated with providing care. Diligently, I have worked through the nuances of treatment options, adherence, and obstacles that go into navigating someone’s health puzzle. Doing so within the regulations of a clinical trial has taught me how to balance competing demands and how to prioritize a holistic approach. Throughout my experiences, I have been able to ground myself in the personal and operational competencies needed to excel as a physician.

Through my Master of Public Health, I have also explored the broader community and institutional contexts of health that impact patients and their care. During a major public health crisis, I was able to learn first-hand how disparities develop and carry throughout our healthcare system, particularly in the context of reproductive and child health. My MPH underscored the importance of making space for a diverse scope of identities and of consciously evaluating my own privileges and their interplay. With a more evolved perspective on what public health truly is, I am now able to apply a greater range of lenses in order to provide culturally-competent and respectful care.

I have been told that I have an almost savant-like knack for puzzling. Personally, I think it has less to do with good visual-spatial skills and more to do with my tenacity and aptitude for problem solving. Each time that I place a piece, I take away new strategies for the next. I now carry the approach of both the puzzler and the practitioner forward, consciously gathering as many perspectives as possible into my dynamic, puzzle-solving toolkit. Although I am prepared for whatever the future holds, there are few absolute certainties in life. Mine include that I have my mom’s unconditional support, that I will someday adopt a Corgi named Waffles, and that I can thrive as a physician. This confidence in my future comes from my nontraditional path, through which I have substantiated my interest in medicine with concrete skills and experiences. Now sure that I have the disposition, drive, and ability to become an excellent physician, I am poised to evolve from puzzle-master to physician.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: When starting my clinical research role, I never expected to learn so much about communication from my nonverbal patients. Until working with them, I had no idea how much I relied on words. When I saw how deeply intune my nonverbal patients and their families were, I thought about how much could be conveyed nonverbally. I decided that I was going to shift my focus from what I was saying to how I was saying it and how the patient was responding. I grew more sensitive to tone of voice, facial expressions, and body language, both for myself and others, and became better able to pick up subtle shifts and their messages. While I continue to speak to all of my patients directly, regardless of whether they can understand me or speak, I know that we can still have ‚Äòconversations‚Äô and build connections in our own nonverbal ways. Having strong nonverbal communication skills will be an asset as a physician, allowing me to create connections and trust with patients who cannot understand my words.
2_-_Challenging_Situation:
In 2017, I began mentoring teens with epilepsy through a weekly dog training program. I was told that Maddie* was enthusiastic but was there for socialization as she wasn‚Äôt developmentally capable of training a dog. Her dog, Poochie, came with a similar disclaimer. Nonetheless, Maddie, Poochie, and I instantly bonded as a team._x000D_
_x000D_
At times, Maddie became upset when Poochie wouldn‚Äôt listen but I helped her learn to refocus her emotions and energy. We celebrated the little victories along the way. Maddie was persistent with training and grew in confidence. With my support, Maddie did the end of year dog show on her own, proudly taking Poochie through all of the same tricks as the group. I know that with persistence and a little support, people can rise to a challenge. As a member of the chronic illness community, it meant a lot to me to be that support for Maddie. As a physician, I won‚Äôt underestimate my patients and will instead give them the same support that I gave Maddie.
7_-_COVID_Impact:
When the COVID-19 pandemic began, my clinical research responsibilities increased substantially and I was considered an in person, essential worker. Overall, I appreciated the additional trust and responsibility given to me to act so independently as well as the opportunity to learn about telemedicine. However, these COVID-19 modifications did add significant strain to my role and took time and energy away from previously intended publication projects, volunteer efforts, and shadowing experiences. _x000D_
_x000D_
COVID-19 restrictions also delayed the completion of my Master of Public Health program from May to September 2021. As I was still working full time, this in turn delayed when I could begin my MCAT prep and medical school applications. While I do think studying epidemiology during a global pandemic is a valuable and enriching learning context, I think the resulting timeline works to the detriment of my medical school application.

personal_statement:
We had discussed the idea for several months before the day finally came. I tried my best to hide my excitement, fearing that it may show how insecure and self-conscious I had been for so many years. In typical preadolescent fashion, I was determined to never let anyone know how embarrassed I was about my exceptionally short stature. Retrospectively, I feel I did a pretty good job of this. I rarely showed negative emotions when others poked fun at me and I did my best to crack a smile or fake a laugh, but it hurt. By the time I was twelve, I was officially shorter than ninety-nine percent of the population for my age and sex. At this point, I was aware of the impact this would have on my future. I knew I would have to work harder than anyone else to succeed in baseball and I knew I would likely face lifelong ridicule about my height. When I finally received my first supply of somatropin, a human growth hormone treatment given to children who fail to grow, I was ecstatic. For the next five years of my life, I injected myself every single night with somatropin, often hiding in the bathroom so my friends would not see during sleep-overs and baseball trips; I did not want anyone to know my secret. For these reasons, I am incredibly thankful for my modest five-foot-seven-inch height, but far more importantly, I am thankful for the lessons my experience taught me on the importance of both medicine and consideration for others. 

While this experience represents a relatively short-lived time period of my life, I owe my initial desire to pursue medicine to it. It was this experience that showed me firsthand how impactful medicine can be both physically and mentally, and I knew it was something I had to share with others. Since that point, my dream of one day becoming a physician has remained as my guiding star - leading me to colleagues, environments, and experiences I would never have expected, and that I will never forget.

My time working as a phlebotomist was enlightening to me for a variety of reasons. For one, I was working in a Level 1 Trauma Center during the deadliest pandemic in American history. Secondly, I was working hands-on with patients for the first time in my life. Thirdly, I was performing a procedure on these patients that sometimes causes pain, and for some, intense anxiety. At this point in my life, I did not have much experience in situations where I was providing support to people whom I did not know, and who may be several decades older than me. Because of this, each and every day was a learning experience in patient care, compassion, and empathy. As the months went by, I met and drew blood from individuals of all ages and all situations; from children as young as 12 years old to near-centenarians, as well as from newly postpartum mothers to patients with life-threatening diseases and terminal illnesses. Through meeting these several hundred individuals, I began to understand what it really means to be a healthcare provider. One experience that stood out to me as a phlebotomist was meeting a particular woman and her daughter. The first time I drew this patient's blood, it became apparent to me that she was not a fan of needles. She pleaded with me to use the smallest needle and to make it as fast as possible, to which I obliged. As I was cleaning up my supplies and preparing her samples to be sent to the lab, I had a short conversation with this woman and her daughter; they mentioned that they were originally from Kansas City. We discussed how we were all from Kansas City for several minutes before I said my goodbyes and wished them a good rest of their day. Several days passed before I was once again sent to draw this woman’s blood. I approached her room, prepared my supplies with the smallest needle possible, and began to walk into her room when a physician swiftly entered the room just before me. I quietly pushed my phlebotomy cart into the room to wait in the corner while the physician chatted with the patient and her daughter. The physician calmly and quickly explained to the woman that she had been diagnosed with Stage 3 colon cancer and that they were currently deciding on a treatment plan. After a brief few minutes of conversation, he briskly exited the room. As tears began to fill the eyes in the room, I thought about my family, my friends, and my loved ones. How would I want them to be treated in this situation? I gently approached these two women, extended my support and empathy, and joined them in prayer. Knowing the gravity of the situation, my sincere hope was that I could provide these women with some amount of encouragement and compassion before leaving the room. 

Since that day, my desire to help patients continues to grow. Through working as an EMT, volunteering as a crisis counselor, advising freshman students, and working with special needs individuals, I have been fortunate to learn from the experiences shared with a wide variety of societal groups. These experiences have all led me to this point; applying to medical school and pursuing my greatest dream. I am incredibly eager to embark on the rigorous and fulfilling journey ahead!
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Serving as a volunteer crisis counselor to many LGBTQ+ individuals through the Crisis Text Line was one experience I had that allowed me to work with individuals unlike myself. Because this work involves such intimate conversation with these individuals, it presented an excellent opportunity for me to truly understand them and learn more about their experiences and culture. This has been a tremendous learning experience for me, allowing me to become more professional, more culturally aware and sensitive, and more understanding in general. As a medical professional, it will be imperative that I take into consideration the culture, background, and lifestyle of each patient in addition to their thoughts and feelings. We know that many minority populations in the United States have significantly worse health outcomes than majority population groups, and it is my hope that my work with diverse populations throughout my life will allow me to avoid these health disparities in my practice.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: As a volunteer for the Central Missouri Foster Care & Adoption Association, my work involved examining foster care and adoption policies and programs around the nation to understand the causes behind disparities we see between foster children and non-foster children. As I delved deeper into these issues, it appeared to me that these disparities were not due to a difference in the innate characteristics of individuals but were rather due to a systemic failure to provide the necessary resources and support to help foster children succeed. In other words, the system in place is not addressing the core issues such as childhood trauma, and the effects of this lack of action are leading to massive disparities in outcomes for foster children versus non-foster children. Using this information, I researched programs used by other organizations around the nation which aim to combat this issue and drafted a 12-page program for the CMFCAA that I believe may help to address these problems.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The primary impact COVID-19 had on my academic life was the movement to online courses for three of my first four semesters of college. While this was an unfortunate way to spend half of my undergraduate years, the main impact this had on my journey to medicine was impairing my ability to volunteer and conduct research. As I was actively seeking out opportunities in these two areas, I was told many times that volunteer opportunities and labs were either no longer in operation, or were in the process of downsizing due to COVID-19 restrictions. For these reasons, I chose to instead pursue healthcare employment opportunities, which were ubiquitous, as well as virtual volunteer opportunities such as Crisis Text Line counseling. While I do believe it would have been advantageous to have conducted research during college, I believe the multitude of healthcare experiences I substituted have prepared me well for life in medical school, and I am hopeful to engage in research during this time.

personal_statement:
Growing up, the physiological and psychological toll of neurodegenerative diseases has plagued my family. Since I was 7, I first-handedly have experienced how Alzheimer's Disease and Lou Gehrig's Disease have affected my grandmother and uncle, and the effect it had on my parents, who acted as their primary caretakers. My personal experiences with these diseases have inspired me to seek a career in medicine, with the goal of pursuing a career in neurology, and being able to assist patients in the same way that physicians have taken care of my family members. From volunteering at University Hospitals in high-school to now volunteering at Northwestern Memorial Hospital (NMH), this passion has been sustained through patient interactions, along with those with my family. Even as I lack the training to alleviate their symptoms or cure them of their disease, these patient interactions have allowed me to connect with their backstories, understand their hopes in receiving care, and ease the burden of receiving care on them and their families as they face the same diseases that affect my family alike. 

My role as a clinical volunteer at NMH has exposed me to many patients with cognitive diseases and highlighted the socioeconomic discrepancies in receiving medical care. One interaction involved a 74-year old patient with dementia who was in need of assistance to get to a supposed appointment with Social Services. It turned out that the patient had mixed this up with an appointment with their neuropsychologist, who indicated upon arrival that this was a common instance due to their disease. This confusion led the patient and I on a hour-long expedition, during which they voiced how difficult it was for them to stay on top of and travel to their hour-away appointments without someone to guide and support them. This discussion helped open my eyes to the socioeconomic discrepancies that patients face in receiving treatment, and how especially important strong social networks are for maximizing neurological healthcare outcomes, as these patients are all the more vulnerable. This patient had been on their own to schedule, remember, and travel to their appointments, with Medicare coverage limiting which doctors they could even see – which is why they had to travel so far. Simply due to their insurance coverage and lack of a strong social support, their normally routine appointment became significantly harder to attend, and their disease harder to manage. With my own family, my grandmother's remembrance of and transportation to her appointments had never been daunting, because she always had my parents and myself to remind and support her through them. Even with insurance issues limiting her treatment options, our familial support and willingness to travel with her proved enough to help her face the inconceivable battle of a disease with no cure. Ultimately, enriching experiences like this one have sustained my desire to become a physician, and to work alongside social workers to assure patients have all the social support possible in receiving treatment. And as a medical student and physician, I hope to provide free assessments and care to enhance treatment availability, so patients like the one above do not have to go to extreme measures for routine appointments. 

While my clinical experiences have strengthened my desire to practice in a clinical setting, my research and teaching experiences drive me to conduct research and teach as a physician. With my research experiences, I have been able to expand upon my interest in combating neurodegenerative diseases in an exploratory setting. Clinical experiences have awarded me meaningful interactions with patients, but by working in labs I have directly applied my knowledge to combat the biological basis for these diseases, and participated in discoveries that may soon be applied in the clinic. Working in the Vassar Lab has additionally allowed me to work and research alongside physicians, like Dr. Cahan who I shadowed, and see how the research they conduct is directly inspired by and applied to the patients they see everyday. These experiences have highlighted that as a future physician, I will be trained to treat patients with known successful methods, but hopefully contribute to discovering groundbreaking techniques in order to treat patients far into the future. But this can only be done with an appreciation for and drive to learn that must extend beyond my medical school years.
