With my extensive experiences as a teaching assistant and tutor, I hope to continue on my pursuit of acting as an educator, but just as importantly learn from the experiences of other physicians, especially as I seek the best ways to treat my future patients. This is something I plan to continue into medical school as my classmates and I embark on the journey that we have envisioned for years – to be great physicians, and to service those who need it most. And with the continuation of these practices from my undergrad into my medical career, I hope to be a physician that assists my patients’ and their families through hardships and one that will be remembered the same way I remember those that have helped my own family.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: Working in the Indian American Medical Association‚Äôs Free Clinic granted me knowledge of how immigrants often lack healthcare insurance, and how that limits treatment and medication options. With this, chronic illnesses such as diabetes are overrepresented amongst this community, and contribute to the onset of other symptoms. My knowledge from working with underserved populations inspired me to advocate for them amongst my undergraduate peers, and to push them to volunteer in the clinic to keep it afloat. This advocacy has involved informing my peers of the disparities amongst the Indian immigrant population in order to push the importance of volunteering at the clinic. This involvement is something I hope to continue at Rush as a medical student and as a future physician. Specifically, I desire to volunteer at the RCSIP Clinic at the Chicago City Church, and to actually play a role in treating patients who cannot afford it otherwise, rather than just learn about their struggles.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: My experiences at predominantly white universities allowed me to understand how the integration into college campuses is more difficult for students of color, as many lack the mentorship necessary to navigate their universities. With the receiving of mentorship from other Black students, I have been inspired to continue this with incoming ones through Black student groups, and to similarly make their integration into university easier. From helping formulate MCAT schedules to helping first-years pick their classes, I reciprocated the help I received. With this, I hope to foster their academic success necessary to stimulate more racial representation in their field of choice. Through this recognition of the importance of mentorship, at Rush I hope to work with the Interprofessional Medical Student Association, where I believe I can help increase diversity in medicine by working to create a mentoring system for Rush‚Äôs incoming Black medical students.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The pandemic cut my patient-care experiences short, yet allowed me to act as a primary caretaker for my grandmother with Alzheimer‚Äôs. Specifically, my grandfather's pre-existing conditions led my parents and I to act as her primary caretakers, as we feared potential COVID complications. With my fully remote courses during 2020-2021, my continual travels home limited my extracurricular involvement, but allowed me to understand the difficulties of caretaking. As non-patient care experiences began to open, I focused my time on research, which allowed me to realize my enthusiasm for neurodegenerative scientific discovery. Additionally, I invested my time in acting as a peer guided study group and an in-class facilitator for organic chemistry. This experience allowed me to directly pursue my interest in providing free academic resources to my peers, and taught me how to structure courses, which is something I hope to continue alongside research and patient-care as a physician.

personal_statement:
Empathy is the ability to take one’s soul into your soul and one’s will into your will. From a young age, empathy has been fostered in my upbringing and engraved in my heart and mind. Growing up, my parents shaped my outlook on life and instilled the concept of placing myself in another’s shoes. As a young girl, my dad was my greatest model, and I was tied to his every move. This included fifteen year old me going to work with my dad. I woke up at 6:00 am and was ready by 6:15. Rushing my very punctual father to make it to the car in time, we drove to meet my dad’s client, Justin. Leading into my first day at work, I was filled with a constant sensation of complete and utter excitement. This excitement latched onto me the whole drive to Justin’s home. As I rang the doorbell, I heard what sounded like heavy thumping down the stairs. Justin was running towards me with open arms, beautiful almond shaped eyes, and a gleaming smile. In an effort to match his excitement, I attempted to wrap my arms around him, hugging him just as tightly. The day at work with my father seemed almost as if it were a play date due to how pleasurable every part of it was. Justin braided my hair, I braided his. The world had deemed Justin disabled, but to me, he proved to be capable and full of potential. 

When the “play date” came to an end, my dad finally convinced me it was time to leave Justin and return home. On the drive home, I told my dad that his job was “easy” and that one day I would come to work here. Only the latter half of that statement was true. To expand and apply this service in my life, I started working with people like Justin. Serving people with disabilities placed me in one of the richest classrooms a human can experience. 

Little did I know how emotionally tolling this job would be. My first client was Summer. Coming from an abusive household, Summer spent most of her life homeless. Upon one of my first meetings with Summer, we discussed her goals and aspirations including her desire to get a job and change her name to escape her past. After hearing her story and speaking with her, I took her on as my first client, with mixed emotions of both excitement but also a feeling of insufficiency. I feared that nothing within my capabilities would be sufficient to help Summer as much as my heart desired. Upon leaving Summer, I went to my car, shut the door, and felt a rush of tears overwhelm me. I was crying. I thought about having my first client ever since meeting Justin and I had waited for this exact moment, a moment that brought me to unstoppable tears. It was a combination of the sight of the living conditions of someone so pure like Summer and the thought of the disparity between how much I wanted to help her and others, but what little I could actually do. I was afraid. Summer’s one request was to heal from a heavy past, and I questioned my ability to provide a solution. 

I quickly realized that empathy alone was not enough. I learned that persistence, humility, and competence must be added to empathy to adequately care for another person. I believe that medical school is the missing puzzle piece that will add these virtues to my empathy to allow me to holistically tend to the people around me. 	
			
I am further motivated in my pursuit of medicine through my clinical experience at St. Mary & St. Mina nonprofit clinic. The main demographic of this clinic included patients from marginalized and underserved communities, which revealed the outcome of disparities in healthcare diversity. Maggie came into the clinic post-op. While waiting for the physician to come in, Maggie spoke with me about her experiences visiting the local hospital. She expressed that her concerns were being disregarded and categorized as simple everyday complaints, and how intimidatingly uncomfortable the hospital was for her. With the disparities of healthcare, a topic dear to my heart, I made sure to sit with Maggie and hear her story. I collected the information and handed it to the medical team. I empathized with Maggie and realized that as a physician, my commitment and empathy will transmit to patients yielding multifaceted healing in the physical, emotional, and spiritual domains. I realized that as a physician, it is important to learn the nuances of each patient to provide for their individual needs.

Medicine encompasses more than the tangible. I believe that going to medical school will allow me to use my knowledge, time, and gifts to lend a helping hand to those in need. Although several career fields are centered towards this common goal, medicine is not simply the best career path out of many. Medicine is the only career path that appeals to, both, my desire to manifest my empathy in actions while also incorporating my infatuation and passion for biomedical science. Medicine has always been my plan A as well as my plan B and C, and so on. I believe that with the superfluous amount of people in the world in need of medical assistance, my experiences have solidified my passion to bring marginalized communities compassionate and representative care. My obsession has framed my life experiences, putting pieces of a puzzle together where the only missing piece is medical school.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I started a tutoring program inspired by children in my community who struggled academically. A lot of them faced language barriers and the new online learning exacerbated their struggles. As the service grew, it rapidly developed to include racial, ethnic, and gender diversity. This is very dear to my heart as an African American female of Arab descent. Growing up, I rarely saw people who ‚Äúlooked like me‚Äù doing things I wanted to do. As a child, if you do not see something represented in society, you assume it is not possible. As I incorporated volunteers from various backgrounds, the service provided hope and inspiration for kids. They saw someone like them excel through middle school geometry for instance. This experience for me highlighted the power of embracing culture as a means of uplifting others and bringing people together. I witnessed the value in immersing myself in a learning environment filled with diverse people, inspired to apply this in my personal endeavors.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: At Pinellas Professional Home Care Inc. I am a living coach for persons with disability. What this entails is focusing on helping clients who wish to improve their health and well-being and work towards their personal goals and enjoying each day to the fullest. Whether its helping my clients buy groceries to make dinner for their family or prepare for their first job interview, the act of helping another person reach their goals was worthwhile. Moreover, I believe my service went beyond checking accomplishments off a list. I have had the amazing opportunity to help people gain confidence and a sense of self-efficacy by supporting and encouraging them. Along with guiding clients to maximize their full potential, I am also a friend. Simply developing strong relationships built on love and trust has been the most influential. I believe this aspect of my work, building long lasting relationships, allowed me to impact another person.
7_-_COVID_Impact: The pandemic limited my opportunity to embark on mission trips and local medical and non-medical service opportunities. While the pandemic prevented experiences in health care settings, I resorted to virtual opportunities like virtual shadowing and plan to take part in the experiences the pandemic has halted both in the medical setting and beyond.

Inst_Action_Desc:
While living in the dorms during the fall semester of freshman year in 2018, I was the recipient of a low-level alcohol infraction. One night I received a message from a friend to join them and other people in a dorm to play a couple of card games that included alcohol. I accepted, and a few minutes after I arrived the resident assistants appeared and we were written up.

Before joining the room, I was unaware the card games included alcohol. Still, I made the illogical decision to stay in that environment. This was a short-sighted act and I take full responsibility for my actions. It was the last of any type of misconduct. I met with the conduct board and explained that I was only in the presence of alcohol. Afterward, I wrote a letter detailing the harms of drinking alcohol. The situation was resolved and I am currently in good standing with the university. I deeply regret this incident as it is detrimental to my reputation as a good student. 

This incident taught me that it is important which type of people I associate with. I needed to find a group of people that shared my interests in science and medicine. This incident has allowed me to mature and find a network of other students, such as Biology Club and Black Student Union, who share the same academic goals as me.
personal_statement:
The blinds were closed shut. The illumination from her bathroom with the door slightly ajar dimly lit her room. This was her preference. Her daily options were between staring into space while her immune system worsened or going to sleep to ignore her growing staph infection. She rarely spoke to me when I bathed her or dropped off a food tray. When she did speak, it was a whisper. Those whispers left me sitting in the chair next to her bed- fully dressed in patient protective equipment- listening to her talk about the loneliness, pain, and regrets she felt at the end of life. I too had a compromised immune system due to my premature birth, so I have experienced my share of hospital melancholy. It took everything in me not to cry in front of this woman who I saw grow devoid of light. This woman never touched her food, never pressed her call light, and never complained about the nursing assistant service. What stuck with me most is when she said I reminded her of her son, who she described as the most caring soul. Her son sadly never visited the nursing home. Each consecutive day her health deteriorated, leaving her dejected. Before the woman moved to quarantined hospice care, she helped me understand that my love for acts of service and medicine are intertwined because both require problem-solving and are rewarded by gratification. Everything I did for her was in hope that her spirits would rise. Her occasional smile when I told her a joke was enough to break the gloom in the air for a few moments, but her demeanor quickly became woeful again. These breaks of gloom gave me a chance to see who she was without the grief of disease. This poignant example of my patient made me realize why I wanted to be a doctor: to rekindle the sense of life stolen from those with illnesses. 

   Working in a nursing home left me with more questions pertaining to the MRSA bacterium. My curiosity led me to conduct my senior thesis on its pathogenicity and what it means from a public health standpoint. My rising interests in infectious diseases and public health drove me toward researching vaccine-derived poliovirus at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. I scoured many articles on the efficacy of different polio vaccines for those most at risk. This research resonated with me because it was focused on helping disadvantaged communities. 

   My father, a physician from Nigeria, showed me the nature of the medical field when I was growing up. As an immigrant with an accent, he encountered significant challenges to becoming a successful clinician, but he still persevered. He planted the seeds of altruism and self-worth into me at a young age. He also taught me that a person’s background is a major contributor to ones health status. As a child, my father took me to his practice after school each day. During his office phone calls he approached each patient case like an organic chemistry reaction: examining each possible route to get to the product with different reactions. He showed me the meticulous manner in which physicians performed acts of service. This is when I knew I wanted to be a physician.

   Marginalized communities like ours do not get many chances at a wholesome life, but I take pride in my heritage. When I was informed that I was going to be the first black male to graduate from my Health Science program at my school, I realized that I needed to lead by example and show others who are like me that excelling in the medical field is possible. This spurred me during undergrad to volunteer at the Indiana Math and Science Academy, a school for marginalized students with learning disabilities. 

   I have seen first-hand the relevance of socioeconomic determinants of health among minorities during my time volunteering at Nashville General Hospital. Those with low literacy living in low-income areas with food deserts are disproportionately affected by chronic conditions. On the individual level, I love to volunteer in any area where my help is needed. Hence while I was interning at the CDC, I spent time helping set up and run an HIV testing clinic. I was able to talk with many people while surveying their health choices and direct them to testing booths. Being able to positively affect an individual’s health and see the change firsthand is truly a feeling second to none. Where I heavily felt this same pull was at the CDC. I talked to many Epidemic Intelligence Service officers about their experiences. A few were doctors who described how they responded to infectious disease outbreaks and how they collected data all while treating individuals in the area. With the exposure to the nursing home, my past science classes, and my CDC experience, I want to be an infectious disease physician. This profession would fulfill all three of my passions: infectious disease, individual patient treatment, and serving as a public health advocate for underserved communities. But to get this part of my career, I need a deep and formal understanding of the human mind and body along with the clinical experience. This is why I want to go to medical school.
1_-_Personal_Attributes_/_Life_Experienc: I was the first black male to graduate from my Health Science program. At first, I was intimidated and afraid of the possibility that my teachers and peers might profile me. It took me a few semesters to understand that, although my race can be a social barrier, the main obstacle in my path to academic success was myself. I learned to be proactive in my education and social life. I learned not to be afraid to ask for help and to be an advocate for myself and those in marginalized positions like mine. This experience in undergraduate gave me a different outlook on my journey to success. It taught me to value those who came before me and paved the path that I am on. This is where my value of community stemmed from. I was initially guarded in my interactions with my peers because they were all from different backgrounds than me, but many of them became good friends. I had to cast away the thought of superficiality- that is, embrace others with open arms regardless of their background.
2_-_Challenging_Situation: I spent the summer months in rural Tennessee helping the locals with any issues they were concerned with, including house repairs, yard work, building sheds or wheelchair ramps, and even running a day camp for their children. The city was Altamont, an area where literacy was low and chronic diseases ran rampant. Many did not have healthcare coverage, and many of the homes were single income with multiple children. I was able to speak with many of them. They detailed their violent and sorrowful upbringing and how there are not many options for them regarding lifestyle because of the environment they were born in. This experience gave me the opportunity to witness the effect of poor health literacy with poor public health and its consequences. I learned to listen and empathize with their concerns. They needed resources from external organizations that also aligned with their values as well. This experience afforded me the opportunity to understand intersectionality when helping others. _x000D_
7_-_COVID_Impact: The beginning of the pandemic proved to be burdensome academically. Many of my classes moved online and most of the social events were canceled. The pandemic consequently put a strain on my plans to take a Certified Nursing Assistant course during that summer. They postponed it for a few months, and I was able to take it during the winter. My original plan was to take the CNA course during the 2020 summer, get my certification, and then study the MCAT material during the late fall and winter so I can take the test early the following 2021 year. Due to COVID-19, I had to now take the CNA course in the 2020 winter, which allowed me to start working at the nursing home the following 2021 summer. That summer I realized I needed more time to study for the MCAT because the long CNA shifts were strenuous on my schedule, so I had to postpone my test until April 2022. With the results from the April MCAT, I plan to retake the test in January 2023.
